That is what happened at the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge on Tuesday to a surprisingly self-possessed osprey, a once-threatened bird of prey whose comeback since the 1970s has made it a symbol of ecological recovery.

headline: In Pursuit of Mayor Bloomberg, the Reluctant Endorser
text: They court him over coffee and drop by when they are in town. They dangle invitations for golf and enlist friends to put in a good word.

headline: Owner of Lane Bryant Sold to Rival for $890 Million
text: 7:59 a.m. | Updated  with announcement of the deal

headline: Board Is Met With Jeers as It Recommends an Increase in Rents
text: A panel voted on Tuesday to recommend raising rents on rent-stabilized apartments in New York City by amounts comparable to those approved last year.

headline: Harper Is Washington’s Newest Attraction
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Romney Foreign Policy Spokesman Quits
text: Richard Grenell, an openly gay and longtime Republican foreign policy spokesman hired last month by Mitt Romney’s campaign, abruptly resigned on Tuesday after antigay elements in the party criticized his appointment and some Republican advisers said Mr. Grenell had been sidelined by the campaign during a busy foreign policy week.

headline: Out of Sorts
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s something very meta about a crossword puzzle where the entry that reveals the theme to you is the answer [CROSS]WORDS. And yet, that’s exactly what happened to me during this very enjoyable solve.

headline: Libertine on the Loose
text: PARIS

headline: Tomás Borge Martínez, Sandinista Rebel and Nicaragua Interior Minister, Dies at 81
text: Tomás Borge Martínez, the last surviving founder of the Sandinista rebel group that toppled Nicaragua’s dictatorship in 1979 and a former feared interior minister in the revolutionary government, died on Monday in Managua. He was 81.

headline: Corrections: May 2
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Playing Without Rose, Bulls Lose to 76ers and Series Is Tied
text: CHICAGO — Derrick Rose limped to center court to deliver the game ball before Game 2 between the Chicago Bulls and the Philadelphia 76ers on Tuesday night. Rose, the N.B.A.’s reigning most valuable player, forced a smile, waved to the crowd, and then retired to a suite where he watched the 76ers’ 109-92 win that evened the Eastern Conference first-round series at 1-1.

headline: Tanks, Jets or Scholarships?
text: Amman, Jordan

headline: Debate Over Who Should Be Allowed to Administer Anesthesia Moves to Courts
text: DENVER — A long-running dispute over whether nurses should be allowed to administer anesthesia without doctor supervision has been playing out here and around the country in recent months, with some states insisting that such a move is needed to address the shortage of physicians in rural areas.

headline: With Report, a Tabloid Editor Is Again Part of the Story
text: As a newspaper editor who has commanded troops on both sides of New York’s pungent tabloid wars, Colin Myler has always shown a thirst for the eye-popping story and a willingness to take the heat to run something that will sell, sell, sell.

headline: Obama Approach to Diplomacy Faces Test in China
text: WASHINGTON — When Hillary Rodham Clinton made her first trip to China in 2009, barely a month into her tenure as secretary of state, she said that American concerns about human rights should not interfere with other pressing global issues on which the United States and China could find common ground. Human rights advocates were appalled, and under orders from the White House, Mrs. Clinton softened her remarks the next day.

headline: Fate of Postal Service Awaits Action in House
text: WASHINGTON — Despite Senate approval of a bill to help the debt-ridden Postal Service, thousands of post offices across the country still face closings beginning in two weeks if the House has not completed work on its version of the legislation.

headline: Complacency and Concern as St. Louis Faces Vulnerability to Deadly Storms
text: ST. LOUIS — The music blared and beer flowed as dozens of people milled around outside a downtown bar last week, celebrating another victory by their beloved baseball champions, the Cardinals. Dark, thunderous skies and rain did not stop the fun.

headline: Interim Police Chief Named for Agency in Martin Case
text: An interim chief has been hired to lead the police department in Sanford, Fla., where the chief stepped aside amid criticism over his handling of the Trayvon Martin case.

headline: Norman Fruman, a Scholar of Coleridge, Dies at 88
text: Norman Fruman, a scholar who roiled literary waters in the 1970s with a biography of  Samuel Taylor Coleridge that accused the poet of stealing ideas and disingenuously aggrandizing his own creative history, died on April 19 at his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 88.

headline: It’s a New Month but a Similar Struggle for Hughes
text: The most revealing evidence of how bad this season has been for Phil Hughes came to light on a night when he was armed with his best stuff, facing a pitcher who had not won since last June and working against a team the Yankees usually beat with impunity.

headline: At May Day Demonstrations, Traffic Jams and Arrests
text: Thousands of protesters converged on Lower Manhattan on Tuesday afternoon in the culmination of May Day demonstrations organized by the Occupy Wall Street movement, resulting in occasionally bloody clashes and the arrests of more than 30 demonstrators.

headline: Bullying Flyers, Devils Grab Win and Momentum
text: PHILADELPHIA — His arms extended and legs dangling in the air, David Clarkson lay atop the dislodged net like a hockey-playing Superman, which, to his Devils teammates at that instant, he very well was. He had just scored the decisive goal in Game 2 of their Eastern Conference semifinal Tuesday night against the Flyers, and at the other end of the ice Devils goalie Martin Brodeur figured Clarkson was milking the moment, posing for photographs. Zach Parise knew otherwise. He skated a few strides and told his pal, “Get off the net so we can celebrate.”

headline: Boasting About Bin Laden
text: Savvy politicians know that it’s usually a good sign when a political advertisement provokes cries of outrage from the opposition. The picture gets murkier, though, when that same advertisement prompts high-minded expressions of disappointment from the politician’s own supporters. Sometimes that’s a signal that the ad in question has overreached and risks a backlash. But sometimes it’s just a sign that those high-minded supporters don’t recognize the weakness that the ad is trying to exploit, or just don’t have the stomach for a necessary fight.

headline: How to Fund the Arts in America
text: How can public and private organizations work together to stabilize arts funding?

headline: Early Blunders Put Niese on Bench a Long Time
text: HOUSTON — Jon Niese made a couple of blunders early in his start Tuesday night, and as a punishment, he was forced to sit and watch in the dugout as his teammates were unable to bail him out.

headline: Libya: Hague Court Is Asked to Stand Down
text: Libya has asked the International Criminal Court in The Hague to withdraw its claims to try Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi and Libya’s former intelligence chief, Abdulla al-Senussi, so that they can be tried in Tripoli. The request, released by the court on Tuesday, was the latest step in the dispute over who will try Mr. Qaddafi, a son of the former Libyan ruler Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and Mr. Senussi on charges of crimes committed during Libya’s uprising last year. The court has issued arrest warrants for the men and ordered Libya to turn them over, but Libya has insisted that it will try them, even though it is still rebuilding its justice system. The request said Libyan authorities were making progress in investigating the cases and preparing for trials that will meet international standards. In Mr. Qaddafi’s case, witnesses have been interviewed and evidence of his “direct involvement in killings” has emerged, the document said. But the case against the intelligence chief, arrested in Mauritania in March, has been delayed, it said, because his liver disease has prevented his transfer to Libya.

headline: Somalia: Suicide Bomber Kills 4, Including Legislators
text: At least four people were killed, including members of the transitional parliament, and at least a dozen were wounded after a suicide bomber blew himself up on Tuesday at a cafeteria in the central Somali town of Dhusamareb. Analysts blamed the Shabab, an insurgent group that has claimed responsibility for several previous suicide bombings.

headline: Cézanne Artwork, Out of Sight for Years, Sells at Christie’s
text: New collectors and old poured into Christie’s Rockefeller Center sales room on Tuesday night for the start of the big spring auctions. They may have come hoping for fireworks but instead sat through an anemic sale devoid of the kind of suspense and sky’s-the-limit bidding that can give these big-money evenings their excitement.

headline: Jets Sign a Kicker
text: The Jets spiced up their kicking competition, signing the veteran Josh Brown to challenge the incumbent Nick Folk in training camp. The team has not announced the signing, but the move was confirmed by a football executive with knowledge of the deal.

headline: Mixing Weight Training and Aerobics
text: Is it wise to practice weight training and aerobic exercise on the same day?

headline: Word of the Day | bureaucracy
text: bureaucracy •\byu̇-ˈrä-krə-se, byə-, byər-ˈä-\• noun

headline: Suicide Attack Follow Obama’s Afghanistan Visit
text: Updated, 1:13 p.m. The Taliban said that they were sending a message to President Obama with a suicide bombing at a protected compound in Kabul, Afghanistan, used by United Nations workers and other foreigners, just hours after Mr. Obama left the country. The attacks followed Mr. Obama’s visit with troops and signing of a strategic partnership agreement with Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai.

headline: Made in America, Lost in Tsunami, Found in Canada
text: HONG KONG — It has been 14 months since the earthquake and tsunami struck Japan’s northeastern coast, killing 20,000 people and smashing apart houses, schools, seaports, entire villages. The cleanup is ongoing, of course, and Japanese officials estimate that 1.5 million tons of debris was sucked out to sea by the recoil of the waves.

headline: In Crown Heights, Getting Past Stereotypes Through Learning
text: Four high school students from the Caribbean arrived this year at a high school in the heart of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, with zero knowledge of the history of tension between the black and Lubavitch Jewish communities. A reporting workshop led them on a journey through stereotypes and misinformation to conversation and discovery.

headline: Talk About the Kentucky Derby With The Times’s Joe Drape
text: Before you finish your handicapping and while you’re preparing your simple syrup for mint juleps, please join us for a Google Plus video hangout this Thursday, May 3, at 3 p.m. EDT, to discuss this year’s Kentucky Derby and the horse racing industry. Joe Drape and Jay Schreiber of The Times will be hanging out, and we would like to invite you to participate in the conversation, whether it be about picks for the big race or Drape’s series on how the economics of the sport have made it more dangerous for the animals and humans. If you are available for 40 minutes beginning a little before 3 p.m. and would like to hang out with us, use the comment area below to tell us how you came to be a horse racing fan and what questions you have about the Derby or about racing over all or sign up directly on our Google Plus page. If you comment below to R.S.V.P., please also include a link to your Google Plus profile page.

headline: News Quiz | May 2, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Airlines in Middle East Take Up Slack in Aviation
text: “Everybody makes money in the airline business, except the airlines,” Joyce Johnson-Miller, a senior managing director at Relativity Capital in New York, told a conference of airline finance executives in March, Christine Negroni writes in The New York Times.

headline: Hours After Obama’s Visit, Suicide Attackers Kill at Least 8 in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Less than two hours after President Obama left Afghanistan, powerful explosions shook Kabul on Wednesday when a team of suicide attackers struck a private residential compound used by hundreds of foreigners in the east of the city, breaching the outer perimeter and leaving at least eight dead — seven Afghans and a guard — and about 17 wounded, officials said.

headline: Myanmar’s Opposition Leader Takes Her Seat in Parliament
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Dressed in flowing purple silk, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi climbed the stone steps of Parliament here Wednesday, delicate and serene in the face of a mob of photographers as she prepared to create a milestone for her country.

headline: UBS Earnings Sink, Following a Trend in Europe
text: 8:41 p.m. | Updated

headline: May 2, 1863 | Stonewall Jackson Shot by His Own Men at Chancellorsville
text: On May 2, 1863, Confederate Gen. Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson was accidentally wounded by his own men at the Battle of Chancellorsville in Virginia. The Confederate forces won the battle, but the loss of Gen. Jackson greatly damaged their war efforts.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 2, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “2-Year College, Squeezed, Sets 2-Tier Tuition.”

headline: Chinese Dissident Is Released From Embassy, Causing Turmoil for U.S.
text: BEIJING — In a series of dramatically conflicting developments on Wednesday, the Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng left American custody under disputed circumstances, and what briefly looked like a deft diplomatic achievement for Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton turned into a potential debacle.

headline: A Vaporous Reason for Doubting Climate Change
text: WHO believes that clouds may counteract climate change?WHO is the most prominent member of this group?

headline: Ben Lowy: Virtually Unfiltered
text: Who is Ben Lowy?

headline: Who Was at Obama’s $35,800 Dinner?
text: In the May 6 issue of the magazine, Nicholas Confessore writes about the difficulties the Obama campaign has had recruiting Wall Street donors this year. Which would help explain why the president’s March 1 fund-raiser at ABC Kitchen didn’t have as many financiers as his people originally hoped. Below, an almost-comprehensive guest list.

headline: Obama’s Not-So-Hot Date With Wall Street
text: In late January, Brad Thompson, the Obama campaign’s chief liaison to major donors in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, called some of his contacts in the area, most of them Wall Street executives. The president’s next trip to town would be in early March. Would they be interested in helping to host a small dinner?

headline: How Important Is Keeping Your Cool?
text: Life is filled with pressure, which squeezes us from an endless variety of sources. Does the manner in which we react to this stress show the world anything about us, and if so, what?

headline: O’Brien Blazing His Own Path in Denmark
text: With the Danish Superliga season heading into the final stretch, Long Island’s Conor O’Brien is enjoying a breakout season in which he has his club, Sonderjyske, within reach of a Europa League berth.

headline: Broadcaster Distances Itself From News Corp.
text: LONDON —Britain’s biggest satellite broadcaster, in which the Murdoch family is the biggest shareholder, reported a big surge in profits on Wednesday, a day after a parliamentary panel castigated the media titan Rupert Murdoch as unfit to run a major international company.

headline: China Demands Apology from U.S.
text: HONG KONG — The news broke simultaneously from both the Chinese and the Americans on Wednesday afternoon, with U.S. officials speaking to reporters on background just as Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency, was issuing its own brief bulletin: Chen Guangcheng had left the U.S. Embassy in Beijing of his own accord and was getting medical treatment at a hospital in the city.

headline: Counselor’s Calendar | May Checklist for Juniors
text: In March, The Choice introduced an occasional series called Counselor’s Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track as they go through the admissions process.

headline: The Safety Net and Layoffs
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Dubai You Don’t Know
text: LONDON — In the summer of 2009, a Jordanian banker invited me to dinner at his house in Amman. He was tired. He had had a big day. He had just put the younger of his two daughters on a plane for Dubai, where she was going to work for an accounting firm. His older daughter, who ran a regional nonprofit organization, was also considering a move to Dubai, he said. Apparently, the two young women, who had both studied at American universities, viewed Amman, where they had grown up, as a backwater compared to Dubai, which was a cosmopolitan place of opportunity.

headline: The Early Word: Winding Down
text: Today’s Times

headline: Harbaugh and Mangini on Spying and Telling
text: Ravens Coach John Harbaugh in a radio interview Tuesday morning on the Saints’ bounty system and cheating:

headline: Seoul Says North Korea Tries to Disrupt Air Navigation
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Government officials here accused North Korea on Wednesday of sending out jamming signals apparently in an attempt to disrupt civilian and military air and ground traffic in South Korea, forcing 252 commercial flights to switch off their global positioning devices.

headline: A Conversation With: Freida Pinto and Michael Winterbottom
text: The movie “Trishna” starring the Indian actress Freida Pinto of “Slumdog Millionaire” fame opened at the Tribeca Film Festival in lower Manhattan last Friday. The film is directed by Britain’s Michael Winterbottom, who is known for his eclectic work, including the documentary “The Road to Guantánamo” about three British Muslim Guantánamo prisoners.

headline: Nadal Is No Fan of the New Blue Clay Courts in Madrid
text: The clay will be blue at the Madrid Open this year, and that has Rafael Nadal seeing red.

headline: Tip of the Week: Making Mobile Screen Shots
text: Capturing an image of whatever is on your iPhone or Android phone display can be helpful for sharing or saving things on screen. How you take your mobile screen shot depends on what phone you have and what version of the operating system it is running.

headline: What Would You Pay to Buy This Business?
text: What’s more fun than a barrel of monkeys? How about owning an upbeat, high-margin online retailer with more than $3 million in annual sales? This cheeky e-commerce business offers an eclectic mix of merchandise, including gummy-bear lamps and flowers in a can and lots of other items, whimsical and practical.

headline: Digital Notes: Spotify’s iPad App Arrives, at Last
text: It is not the first streaming iPad music app, having been beaten to that punch by Rhapsody, Slacker, Pandora and iHeartRadio. And by Rdio, and Mog. And TuneIn. And Sirius XM Radio. O.K., by pretty much everybody.

headline: Stone Links: A Physicist’s Flap
text: In a recent interview with the Atlantic about his book “A Universe From Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather than Nothing,” Lawrence Krauss, a theoretical physicist at the University of Arizona, was notably dismissive of philosophy’s intellectual value. After hearing from his friend, the distinguished philosopher Daniel Dennett, he’s decided to clarify his comments. Though he acknowledges that philosophers can improve our understanding of ethics and the various sciences of the mind (neuroscience, cognitive and evolutionary psychology, etc.), he thinks no similar gains are on the cards when it comes to physics. In particular, he thinks the reflections of physicists themselves on their methods and results have been much more productive and insightful than those of philosophers. (See Rationally Speaking for a pro-philosophy reply.)

headline: Armed With Data, Fighting More Than Crime
text: Government accountability systems don’t usually become global superstars, but CompStat did.  The ideas in CompStat were first developed by Jack Maple, when he was a lieutenant in the New York City Transit Police, as a way to track subway crime and more intelligently deploy transit cops.  In 1994, when William Bratton, the chief of the transit police, became chief of the New York City Police Department, he brought Maple with him as a deputy. They then applied CompStat principles throughout the city’s entire crime fighting operation.

headline: A Taxonomic Error, Reversed Decades Too Late
text: A surprising discovery has emerged from dusty museum closets. Closer inspection of around 800 long-dead reptiles reveals that the Caribbean has a whopping 39 species of skink — zippy little lizards — rather than six. Not since the 1800s have so many unique reptiles been added to a list of species in a single go, researchers say.

headline: Romney Confronts Power of the Presidency
text: Mitt Romney is witnessing the power of the presidency.

headline: Jobless Rate Reaches New High in Euro Zone
text: FRANKFURT — Unemployment in the euro zone rose to a new high in March, according to figures released on Wednesday. The data came a few days before crucial elections in France and Greece, and it is likely to prompt more intense calls for an easing of Europe’s austerity drive.

headline: Daily Report: New York City Sets Social Media Rules for Teachers
text: New York City public-school teachers may not contact students through personal pages on Web sites like Facebook and Twitter, but can communicate through pages set up for classroom use, report David W. Chen and Patrick McGeehan in Wednesday’s New York Times, according to new rules by the city’s Education Department. The rules are the department’s first list of guidelines governing the use of social media by employees.

headline: Ashton Kutcher Shows Many Faces in Popchips Ad Campaign
text: On CBS, Ashton Kutcher is a star of “Two and a Half Men.” In a new campaign for Popchips snacks, he will play four men.

headline: Giants, Jets and a Few Final Words on the Draft
text: Final thoughts from Matt Waldman of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio. For his observations on the offensive skill player selections for all 32 teams, you can go to Part I and Part II  at his blog.

headline: Seat of Power
text: “The Passage of Power,” the fourth installment of Robert Caro’s brilliant series on Lyndon Johnson, spans roughly five years, beginning shortly before the 1960 presidential contest, including the Bay of Pigs, the Cuban missile crisis and other seminal events of the Kennedy years, and ending a few months after the awful afternoon in Dallas that elevated L.B.J. to the presidency.

headline: ‘Facebooks’ for Companies Beef Up
text: The market for corporate social software must be getting big: the purveyors are following each others’ strategies, and talking each other down.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Once an Ambitious Law Firm, Reduced to Grim Dispatches  |  On Monday, about 50 former Dewey partners opened their in-boxes to find a poignant note. A fellow former partner said he was starting an assistance fund for Dewey staff members and junior lawyers who might find themselves unemployed. The same day, Dewey’s remaining partners received a grim dispatch from the firm’s leadership. Given Dewey’s state, management encouraged them to look for new jobs.

headline: Princeton Review Charged With Falsifying Billing for Tutors
text: The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan announced the indictment of one of the largest and most well known private tutoring companies, Princeton Review, for falsifying records and accepting millions of dollars in reimbursements for testing services it never provided to New York City schoolchildren.

headline: Opinion Report: The Pay-Gap Provision
text: From the editorial page

headline: Fierce Clashes Erupt in Egypt Ahead of Presidential Vote
text: CAIRO — As least 11 people were killed after assailants attacked protesters staging a sit-in near Egypt’s Ministry of Defense early on Wednesday, setting off hours of clashes that threw the coming presidential election into disarray as at least five candidates announced the suspension of their campaigns to protest the deaths.

headline: Rich Guy Says We Should Be Grateful For His Wealth
text: So a former partner of Romney’s at Bain says, in a new book, what Romney probably believes: we should be really grateful to the rich for all the rich things they do. Because, you see, they don’t spend all their wealth building homes as big as the Taj Mahal; some of it they invest in innovation.

headline: Austerity Alternatives
text: Ryan Avent writes what I’ve been meaning to write about the backlash against the austerity backlash. It’s all about attacking a straw man. Nobody — certainly not me — believes that, say, Spain or even France can simply go back to Keynesian policies unilaterally. Instead, the point is that if European leaders want the euro to survive, they have to recognize that the austerity thing isn’t working, and offer Europe-wide alternatives. Avent:

headline: Former Edwards Aides Tell of Affair’s Impact on Wife and Campaign
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — As John Edwards sat motionless, his eyes cast downward at his federal trial here on Wednesday, a former campaign aide described the devastating effect a tabloid newspaper article about his extramarital affair had had on Mr. Edwards’s wife, Elizabeth.

headline: Inside ‘Prometheus’
text: Images from Ridley Scott’s film starring Noomi Rapace, Michael Fassbender and Charlize Theron.

headline: You Say Messianic, I Say Messianic
text: JERUSALEM — As I was driving to Jerusalem on Monday morning, the regular lineup of morning radio shows was suddenly interrupted. It was 7:57 am, but the anchor couldn’t wait three minutes for the daily 8 am round-up to deliver this news: Benzion Netanyahu, the father of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, had died at 102. He was a well-known historian, intellectual and Zionist. He was also an outspoken alarmist, who warned Israelis of Iran’s apocalyptic intentions.

headline: Eurofile | Terroir Parisien
text: As far as the three-star chef Yannick Alleno is concerned, nothing tastes better than Paris. Which is why the kitchen at his new Latin Quarter bistro, Terroir Parisien, attempts to use as much produce from Paris (honey from urban hives, for example) and the surrounding Ile de France region as possible. “It’s a real challenge to find local produce,” he says. “So many of the farms that fed Paris for centuries have been urbanized, and many of the indigenous breeds of vegetables, fruits, poultry and other produce have nearly disappeared.”

headline: He’s Not Done With Exploring the Universe
text: IT is the year 2089 when Elizabeth Shaw, an archaeologist with a spiritual bent, chips through a wall in a cave in the bleak mountains of Scotland and finds out that the human race is not alone in the universe. Illuminated by her torchlight is a 35,000-year-old painting of people worshiping a giant, who is pointing to a small cluster of stars.

headline: Morning Buzz: A Dancer’s Life Is Saved Onstage
text: Good morning. It is likely to rain today, with highs in the upper 50s.

headline: European Regulators May Reopen Street View Inquiries
text: BERLIN — European privacy regulators said Wednesday that they were considering reopening their inquiries into Google’s collection of personal e-mails and Web searches for its Street View service. The move came after revelations that the activity had not been a lone programmer’s error, and that others at the company had been told about it.

headline: Meeting Art Garfunkel
text: Update, May 8 | See what Art Garfunkel says about this story.

headline: Deconstructing Parliament’s Loquacious Condemnation of News Corporation
text: The British are notoriously fastidious writers, but known more for theprolixity than concision. The 121-page report from the House ofCommons Culture Media and Sport Committee on the phone hackingscandal mentioned that they felt “misled” 38 times. We thought it would be helpful to annotate key passages with an eye toward brevity. Think of it as an American translation.

headline: It Is Not Cricket! (It’s Politics)
text: As the cricket player Sachin Ramesh Tendulkar joins the Rajya Sabha, the upper house of Parliament, we’ve been wondering over here at India Ink “What, exactly, are the similarities between cricket and politics?”

headline: Afghan Agreement Treads Familiar Ground
text: The president was negotiating a landmark strategic agreement outlining a long-term relationship with a country after years of war. But three senators objected to the president signing such an agreement without seeking approval from the Senate.

headline: ‘Dystopian Future’ Draws Problem Solvers to Mumbai
text: One recent weekend, a group of economists, university professors and tourism executives gathered in the conference room of a think tank near Nariman Point to ponder the question, “Is Mumbai truly global?”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Unfit’ to Be Tied and Network Television Looks Up
text: News Corporation was prepared for severe criticism in the parliamentary report released Tuesday in Great Britain but Rupert Murdoch was taken aback by the personal nature of the committee’s findings, which labeled him “unfit” to lead a major corporation. “Rupert is still in denial about how quickly his influence and prestige in the U.K. has gone down the drain,” said one person close to the company and Mr. Murdoch who could not publicly comment on private discussions.

headline: Hovering Above the Skyline, Armed With a Camera
text: On Monday, the Empire State Building became the second tallest building in New York. So if you’re not safe from being looked down upon even if your rooftop is 1,250 feet in the sky, what hope do the rest of us have?

headline: Harvard and M.I.T. Team Up to Offer Free Online Courses
text: In what is shaping up as an academic Battle of the Titans — one that offers vast new learning opportunities for students around the world — Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Wednesday announced a new nonprofit partnership, known as edX, to offer free online courses from both universities.

headline: Retirement, Slipping Farther and Farther Away
text: Over the last decade and a half, Americans’ expected retirement age has slowly risen to 67 from 60, according to a new Gallup survey.

headline: Getting Refunds if the Price Drops
text: YOU thought you scored a great deal when you found that $200 rate for your $300-a-night hotel. But then you compared notes with other guests and learned that some paid even less. It happens to even the best bargain hunters — whether it is a hotel deal or airfare — and it’s not a good feeling.

headline: Clashes Erupt in Egypt Ahead of Vote
text: The violence threw the presidential race into disarray as several candidates, some blaming the military for the deaths, said they were halting their campaigns.

headline: Pettitte Backs Off Clemens Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — Despite its embarrassing error at Roger Clemens’s perjury trial last summer, which quickly led to a mistrial, the federal government has pushed forward, hoping for a victory the second time around.

headline: Garden States
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Low-Level Radiation Puzzle
text: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists is casting new light – or maybe just heat — on the murky field of sizing up the health effects of small radiation doses.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The San Francisco Chronicle: “I want Inglenook to be what it was,” said Francis Ford Coppola (right) of his new property, which he hopes to restore to its former glory. “It was Napa Valley’s premier cru.” Jon Bonné reports on the film director’s history in the wine business and his plans for the future. — Eric Asimov

headline: Liverpool to Star in TV Series
text: This fall, soccer fans will get a rare look inside a Premier League team.

headline: Carlyle Lowers I.P.O. Range on Eve of Pricing
text: The Carlyle Group has lowered the range for its initial public offering to $22 to $23 a unit, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, as the private equity firm and its advisers prepare to price the stock sale later in the day.

headline: After Defeating Duke, Denver Heads to E.C.A.C. Tournament
text: DENVER — In its biggest win of the season, the No. 16 Pioneers defeated highly ranked Duke on Friday night as part of the Whitman’s Sampler Mile High Classic at Sports Authority Field, posting a 15-9 upset in front of a crowd of 12,282 to end the regular season.

headline: Suffering Preeclampsia — After Giving Birth
text: Sarah Hughes woke up on Halloween last year and knew something was wrong.

headline: Jawbone’s Jambox, Now With More Jam
text: Sometimes products are so compelling they deserve a big brother. Jawbone introduced the first Jambox in 2010 to some fanfare – it was a small, nicely-designed wireless speaker that filled a room or event with sound using Bluetooth. Its newest sibling, the Big Jambox, is twice as big as the original model and it weighs just two pounds more (2.7 pounds over all). It has all of its little brother’s DNA but with a bigger, richer sound and a larger battery.

headline: Men’s Colorful Kilties Return
text: Once an inescapable facet of 1950s country clubs, a kiltie is a long fringed tongue of leather that attaches to a golf shoe’s inside tongue and folds over the laces.

headline: New Barriers Planned on Road Where 7 Died
text: The State Transportation Department will immediately begin installing new concrete barriers on three viaducts along the Bronx River Parkway, following a catastrophic accident that claimed the lives of seven relatives last weekend, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Business Day Live | May 2, 2012
text: With BlackBerry 10, Research in Motion hopes for a comeback; why complacency is a problem for Google; and China's vanishing trade imbalance.

headline: From Fairway to Runway
text: IN some fashion quarters, enthusiasm for old-school heritage style is fading like embers. But elsewhere, it is raging out of control, with evermore vivid hues and ornate detail. One need only glance down, at the recent spate of colorized bucks and saddle shoes. Or take a gander at the even more surprising reappearance of an over-the-vamp, over-the-top shoe detail one might have thought was gone forever: the kiltie.

headline: Spring Board Book Roundup
text: The best of the season’s board books, featuring dinosaurs, bees, trains and more.

headline: NBC Blankets Churchill Downs
text: Looking forward to watching your favorite horse step onto the track for the 138th running of the Kentucky Derby or the R&B star Mary J. Blige belt out the national anthem? NBC appears to have it covered. After broadcasting the major prep races ahead of Saturday’s run for the roses, the network is extending its commitment to horse racing with 14½ hours of planned Derby coverage.

headline: An Army Apart
text: DELHI — In the fall of 2007, shortly after retiring as chief of the Indian army, J.J. Singh became president of the Delhi Gymkhana Club, one of those venerable social institutions where, sipping gin at the bar, it is difficult to imagine that the British ever left India. Pervez Musharraf was the president of Pakistan at the time, and the joke of the day was: See what distinguishes the two countries? While one army chief moves on to head a nation, the other moves on to head a social club.

headline: Big Mo
text: So, in case you’re wondering, the reason I’m suddenly everywhere is the reality of the book trade, which is that to have a best-seller you must be a best-seller: “momentum”, getting on to those lists, is crucial, so a burst of sales in the first few weeks is all-important.

headline: Spring Board Book Roundup
text: SIMMS TABACK’S DINOSAURSWritten and illustrated by Simms Taback.20 pp. Blue Apple Books. $12.99. (Board book; ages 2 to 4)

headline: Coming Soon | Rubber Soles
text: Time to start brushing up on your Gene Kelly puddle kick, gentlemen. The galosh, that protective and effective rubber overshoe, made a comeback during the fall 2012 runway shows with many designers turning the seasonal necessity into a certifiable fashion statement. At Prada, shoes featuring rubberlike sidewalls were followed by proper galoshes in navy blue and black over shiny lace-up oxfords beneath. Emporio Armani’s flocked black versions so closely resembled pairs of dressy evening slip-ons that one could easily mistake the two. Collaborating with Swims, the Oslo-based company best known for making weather-ready footwear, Armani introduced the Armani by Swims overshoe, to be sold alongside four different shoe styles starting in July. Swims, which originally manufactured brightly colored rubber galoshes, now incorporates Japanese nylon and Scotchguard into a complete line that includes desert boots, dressy brogues and Chelsea boots. Its new Classic Royal overshoe, with a velvety looking finish, is perfect for a rainy night at the opera.

headline: Obama’s Ex-Girlfriend Details Their Relationship
text: An early girlfriend of President Obama’s chronicled a relationship of more than a year in which she struggled to pierce his now famous reserve, which she termed “a bit of a wall — the veil,” according to journals reproduced in a new biography.

headline: The 91 Percent Solution
text: Update: Whoops. Reasonable conservatives are so rare that I shouldn’t get them confused, but anyway now I have the right name.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Fiji for the Rest of Us
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Morning Walkabout – 5/2: Middle East Jet Spree, Plane Headaches and More
text: Where the Big Birds Fly Airlines in the Middle East and in Asia are buying Airbus and Boeing jets at a quick pace, making up for a dip in purchases by Western carriers. (The New York Times)

headline: Letters to the Travel Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Are Travel Agents Back?” (April 22): As a veteran agent with over 30 years in the industry, I feel that the article should be entitled “Young Travel Agents Rescuing an Endangered Profession.” Do older agents have no place in this trend? The article failed to address an important question. Do these young agents have the depth of knowledge that veteran agents with decades of experience can offer? Part of travel “navigation” is the sharing of deep destination knowledge. Also, as an aging baby boomer, I do speak the same “language” and understand the stage-of-life issues facing my generation right now. Not everyone needs the creation of a sound track for their in-flight distraction.Nancy Pole WilhitePortland, Ore.

headline: Taking On the Little Guy, but Missing the Bigger Ones
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission seems to think that it has done a much better job of investigating financial crisis wrongdoing than the Justice Department. And it’s true.

headline: LinkedIn Finally Adds an iPad App
text: After reworking their iPhone and Android platforms, LinkedIn now offers users the chance to make connections on the iPad.

headline: Tenor and Violinist Receive Martin E. Segal Awards
text: A tenor and a violinist have been selected as the winners of the 2012 Martin E. Segal Awards, which recognize emerging artists associated with Lincoln Center. The tenor, Paul Appleby, and the violinist, Augustin Hadelich, each received $7,500 to be used for career advancement and future study. The recipients, chosen by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, were honored at a lunch on Wednesday in the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center.

headline: Italy’s Own Lost Cause
text: In the same eventful spring of 1861 that marked the outbreak of the American Civil War, Italy declared its existence as a united kingdom. In fact, just as the bombardment of an island fortress in Charleston, S.C., riveted the attention of a nation plunging into civil war, the kingdom of southern Italy made a last-ditch stand against northern Italian bombardment of a waterfront fortress midway between Rome and Naples. The two sieges, of Fort Sumter and of Gaeta, came only weeks apart.

headline: Army Will Reshape Training, With Lessons From Special Forces
text: WASHINGTON — The Army is reshaping the way many soldiers are trained and deployed, with some conventional units to be placed officially under Special Operations commanders and others assigned to regions of the world viewed as emerging security risks, like Africa.

headline: Diesel-Powered Chevy Cruze May Be a Tough Sell
text: Chevrolet is scheduled to introduce a diesel-powered version of its Cruze sedan in the United States next year. Last week, the automaker said in a media release that it expected the vehicle to latch onto an upward swing in the popularity of diesel cars, citing market research from Baum & Associates that projected diesel sales to double by mid-decade.

headline: Warren Says She’s Proud of Being American Indian
text: 6:05 p.m. | Updated Elizabeth Warren on Wednesday defended her decision to identify herself as a minority in a directory of law professors in the 1980s and ’90s, saying that she hoped it would help her “meet more people who had grown up like I had grown up.”

headline: Taking On Home Projects to Save Money
text: Let them hammer nails?

headline: Reef Sharks and Humans Don’t Mix
text: Sharks may have more reason to fear people than ever. In reefs surrounding Pacific islands inhabited by people, there are 90 to 97 percent fewer sharks than in similar areas without people, according to a study in the journal Conservation Biology.

headline: Is Obama More Popular Than He Should Be?
text: It’s well known that presidential approval ratings are a powerful predictor of election outcomes. President Obama’s current 47 percent approval rating would be among the lowest approval ratings of any incumbent president who went on to be  re-elected.

headline: Comcast Reports Progress at NBC, but Declines in Cable Subscriptions
text: One year after taking control of NBCUniversal, Comcast posted a quarterly profit on Wednesday that exceeded analyst expectations and signaled progress at the struggling NBC broadcast network.

headline: Spring Staples | Bouquet Blitz
text: Seasons change and so must accessories.We’re only two days into May and already April’s showers have give way to — what else? — flowers. If ever there was a time to brush up on your blooms, now is it. Here, the actress Jessica Biel, with her engagement ring on-hand, stocks up at the farmers’ market in Los Angeles; the model Kate Moss softens all black with pale pink tulips; and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, pairs a more formal arrangement of roses and ranunculuses to go with her cornflower blue dress.

headline: Walking Away From Merger Deals
text: Pep Boys disclosed on Tuesday that the Gores Group, a private equity firm, was considering whether a recent earnings announcement and a possible deterioration in Pep Boys’ operations constituted a material adverse change, or MAC. If so, it would give Gores a basis to escape its $1 billion deal to acquire the auto parts and repair company.

headline: With People Aplenty, Twitter Aims to Cut Through the Noise
text: Twitter is one busy beehive of chatter these days. People on the service now post more than a billion Twitter messages every three days, and the company is adding  more than a million users each week.

headline: State Officials Throw Out Another Pearson Test Question
text: For the fourth time in a month, state education officials found errors by Pearson, the test-maker, which made a problem virtually impossible for students to solve.

headline: Exploring How Communication Can Smooth the Human Journey
text: I’ve been giving a lecture in recent months in which I explain the upside of humanity’s fast-evolving and expanding menu of ways to share and shape ideas — what I call the “Knowosphere.” Here’s a particularly good recording, made at Santa Monica College:

headline: Dealmaker Leaves Fingerprints on Another Scandal
text: The first e-mail was sent to New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton on Sept. 3 from the federal prison system’s minimum-security camp in Florence, Colo. It promised $5,000 for Saints players who delivered hard hits on Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers in the N.F.L.’s season-opening game a few days later.

headline: Irish Cardinal Rejects New Accusations on Pedophile Priest
text: DUBLIN — The leader of the Catholic Church in Ireland, Cardinal Sean Brady, said on Wednesday that he would not resign despite new accusations that he failed 35 years ago to alert the parents of victims of a serial pedophile priest, allowing the abuse to continue for at least another decade.

headline: N.F.L. Suspends Vilma and Three Other Players for Bounty Scheme
text: Jonathan Vilma, the New Orleans Saints’ defensive captain, was suspended by the N.F.L. without pay for the 2012 season Wednesday. The league said he helped the former defensive coordinator Gregg Williams in “establishing and funding” the team’s bounty program, which rocked the Saints this off-season and also led to the suspension of Coach Sean Payton.

headline: Hit TV Shows and Movies Help Time Warner Offset Losses
text: Hit sitcoms like “2 Broke Girls” and “Big Bang Theory” helped offset losses at Time Warner’s magazine division and costs related to early cancellation of the pricey horse-racing drama “Luck” on HBO.

headline: U.S. Lags in Global Measure of Premature Births
text: Fifteen million babies are born prematurely each year, and the United States fared badly in the first country-by-country global comparison of premature births, which was released Wednesday by the World Health Organization and other agencies.

headline: TimesCast | May 2, 2012
text: The Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng leaves the United States Embassy in Beijing | Soccer gains popularity in Cuba, where baseball is king.

headline: Image of the Day: May 2
text: A Coppersmith Barbet peeps from its nest.

headline: After Exile, Career Reset
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Beginnings of a Succession Plan
text: Last week, I wrote about holding a succession-planning meeting with my family. While I am not planning to retire any time soon, I recognize that bad things do happen — unexpected bad things like sickness, disability, and of course the ultimate bad thing, death.

headline: Seven or so Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Bon Appétit
text: When I upgrade from my typical home-prepared dinners of hummus or breakfast cereal to something actually created using multiple ingredients and heat, it is to cook my “chickpea stew,” a sophisticated blend of canned chickpeas and jarred tomato sauce.

headline: Officer Stabbed in Brain Exits Hospital to Cheers
text: Just 15 days after being stabbed through the brain on an East Harlem street, a New York police officer was released from Mount Sinai Hospital on Wednesday to a hero’s ovation from his colleagues.

headline: A Change in Police Policy Has Immigrants Hoping for More
text: LOS ANGELES — The weekend checkpoints set up along intersections here were always meant to catch those who had had too much to drink. In an operation intended to be equal parts deterrent and enforcement, the police would stop every car, testing drivers suspected of being under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

headline: The Country and the City
text: David Brooks: Gail, you are just back from Turkey investigating the international situation and the clash of civilizations. I am just back from southern Indiana where I investigated the clash of civilizations of a different sort, namely which serves better burgers: White Castle or Steak ‘n Shake.

headline: Steve Coll Talks About the Power of Exxon Mobil
text: In his new book, “Private Empire,” Steve Coll offers an expansive portrait of Exxon Mobil: its leaders, operations, global entanglements, environmental impact and relationship to the United States government. In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Coll discussed the company’s access to various presidents, the future of energy consumption and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Business Day Live: The BlackBerry 10 Prototype
text: With BlackBerry 10, Research in Motion hopes for a comeback; why complacency is a problem for Google; and China’s vanishing trade imbalance.

headline: These Ghosts Are Singing With a Southern Twang
text: ATLANTA — At the bloody heart of “Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,” the Southern gothic musical by Stephen King and John Mellencamp, is a tense sibling rivalry between a novelist with a dark streak and a blue-jeans-wearing crooner. Frank (Lucas Kavner) and Drake McCandless (Justin Guarini) are surely meant to evoke younger versions of the famous team that created them.

headline: A New Addition to Samsung’s Family of Players
text: As the functions and versatility of smartphones increase, there seems to be little point in having a handheld media device anymore. But that doesn’t stop electronics companies from pumping out new versions of the “phone without a phone.”

headline: Shopping Snapshots: May 3
text: Nicholas Kirkwood to open store in the meatpacking district; South Beach-inspired spring wear; and French Art Nouveau carved-horn jewelry.

headline: Summer Essentials | Tony Melillo Tees and Tanks
text: Trust Tony Melillo, the editor turned designer who’s been responsible for more than one cult clothing line in his time, to create the holy grail of summer fashion: the perfect T-shirt. Made from cloud-soft Peruvian cotton, his ATM tees and tanks for men and women have obsessive little details like shirttail hems and shoulder pleating, all in complexion-flattering colors. “Making only one thing keeps you incredibly focused, so if you are a perfectionist — and I am — you are bound to come up with a great product,” he says. The women’s tank (a poolside staple) and men’s henley (a weekend must) do for a hot summer day what wool does for winter. You’ll wonder how you ever went without.

headline: A ‘Huge Win’ for Homophobia
text: On Tuesday Richard Grenell, an openly gay spokesman for the Romney campaign, resigned — or, more accurately, was hounded out of town by social conservatives. And the religious right isn’t taking this victory sitting down. Bryan Fischer of the American Family Association, who previously said that hiring Mr. Grenell was like telling the “pro-family community” to “drop dead,” gleefully relayed the news on his radio broadcast Tuesday.

headline: ‘New Girl’ on Fox Is Latest Victim of a Disappearing TV Audience
text: What is happening to “New Girl?” The hot comedy of the fall is the cause of yet another head-scratching development for network television.

headline: Live from New York, Eli Manning Talks About the Saints’ Bounty Program
text: Most of Wednesday’s conference call involving Giants quarterback Eli Manning and Lorne Michaels, the executive producer of “Saturday Night Live,” focused on Manning’s appearance this weekend as host of the late-night comedy show. In between discussing his rehearsal schedule and his favorite all-time skit, however, Manning did take time to address the suspensions handed down by N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell, who disciplined four players for their involvement in the New Orleans Saints’ bounty program.

headline: Occupy Wall Street: From the Streets to the Archives
text: Earlier this week a Times article looked at social scientists who are trying to study Occupy Wall Street in real time. But a group of archivists are also hitting the streets, and the Internet, in an effort to preserve the movement’s traces for scholars of the future.

headline: Is Roy Hodgson Not Sexy Enough for England?
text: As Roy Hodgson faced the news media on Tuesday for the first time as England manager, a common theme of questioning became apparent: “Why are you not Harry Redknapp?”

headline: TimesCast | Soccer Scores in Cuba
text: Soccer has been gaining popularity in Cuba, where baseball is king.

headline: Tom Edden in ‘One Man, Two Guvnors’
text: Tom Edden plays Alfie, an octogenarian waiter, in the Broadway comedy at the Music Box Theater.

headline: Scores Cuffed or Cited by End of Day of Demonstrations
text: Tuesday’s May Day protests continued into the wee hours of Wednesday, with about 2,000 marchers gathering at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Plaza on Water Street after dark and several hundred returning to Zuccotti Park, Occupy Wall Street’s former home base, after midnight.

headline: Whack! | Matt Singer’s Space Dog Piñatas
text: In 1957, the Soviet Union eked out a lead in the space race by launching a Moscow street mutt named Laika into orbit on the Sputnik 2. In the years since, Laika’s last hurrah — she survived only the first few hours of the journey — has inspired many longer-lived cultural artifacts: a statue in Moscow, a neo-futurist play, an oil painting in California, a Finnish surf rock band, a graphic novel and now a piñata. In honor of Cinco de Mayo, the Manhattan-based designer Matt Singer has rendered Laika (shown here), along with successor space dogs Belka and Strelka — who went up together in the Sputnik 5 and survived — in papier-mâché.

headline: An Artist Keeps Her Cool
text: PERCHED on a stool at her studio in Williamsburg recently, Rita Ackermann was a picture of cool anonymity. She wore a battered fatigue jacket and frayed jeans, hanks of her corn-colored hair all but obscuring her features.

headline: Prosecutors Focus on Pimps and Clients, Instead of Prostitutes
text: It was not exactly a run-of-the-mill prostitution case: the men accused as ringleaders were a father and his son, a pimp team coercing women to push their trade like traveling sex saleswomen, handing out business cards at hotels and strip clubs.

headline: Jack White Scores His First No. 1 Album
text: Jack White has never had a No. 1 album with any of his various bands: the White Stripes, the Raconteurs, the Dead Weather. But with the release of his first solo record, he now does, bumping Lionel Richie from the top of the Billboard chart.

headline: N.F.L. Statement on Bounty Punishments for 4 Players
text: The league’s official statement, which was quickly rejected by the union and is sure to be appealed by the four players, is below. According to a teammate of the Saints’ Jonathan Vilma, Vilma learned of the news that he was suspended for the season by seeing it on “SportsCenter” (via ProFootball Talk.com):

headline: Allergies as a Blessing in Disguise
text: Are allergies making you miserable? They may be a blessing in disguise, according to the work of Margie Profet, an evolutionary biologist who is profiled in the latest issue of Psychology Today. In the late 1980s and early ’90s, Ms. Profet became one of the first scientists to argue that allergies evolved as a way to expel carcinogens and other toxins from the body, a theory that helped win her a MacArthur Foundation “genius grant” in 1993.

headline: Smiles for a Summer Movies Cover
text: Back in March we asked readers to choose a favorite from among 10 illustrations submitted by students at the Savannah College of Art and Design as a potential cover of the annual Summer Movies issue of Arts & Leisure. Now the readers — close to 29,000 of you — have spoken, and above are the top three vote getters. The first two, which drew far more votes than the others, share a sense of playfulness and humor, while the third seems more in line with our ultimate choice: Heather Carter’s enchanting illustration of fireflies on a summer evening.

headline: TimesCast | Dissident Exits U.S. Embassy
text: May 2, 2012 — After intensive negotiations, American officials said the Chinese government promised that Chen Guangcheng and his family would remain safe and could relocate to Tianjin.

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
text: Shearman & Sterling announced on Wednesday that Creighton O’M. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, has been elected senior partner of the New York law firm.

headline: Daughters of the Revolution
text: Last week, Tyler Cowen tweeted that the second episode of HBO’s endlessly-discussed new show “Girls” is “very … Douthatian. If you are a Straussian, that is.” By “Douthatian” I’m assuming that he meant implicitly socially conservative, and now that I’ve caught up with the show, I think if anything its critique of contemporary (New York, upper middle class, white) sexual mores is explicit rather than esoteric. Indeed, before the conversation about “Girls” descended into a pointless argument about whether racial minorities are adequately represented on a program that’s clearly supposed to be portraying a narrow and privileged slice of American life, the critical reaction to the show, both positive and negative, grasped pretty directly what Lena Dunham’s show is doing. It’s offering a fairly dystopian take on twentysomething social life, in which the comedy is dark, the sex is gross, the romance is disappointing, and the mix of nudity, jadedness and bawdy talk doesn’t carry any of the aspirational frisson that was always associated with the post-sexual revolution single life on a show like “Sex and the City.”

headline: A Chinese Dissident’s Smuggled Video Messages
text: Updated, 8:14 p.m. As my colleague Jane Perlez reports, Chen Guangcheng, the blind Chinese dissident who fled house arrest last week in a dramatic escape from security forces, left the American Embassy in Beijing on Wednesday and is now in a nearby hospital.

headline: Criminal Charges for 13 in Florida A&M Hazing Death
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Thirteen people were criminally charged on Wednesday with hazing in the death of a Florida A&M University marching band member who was beaten after a football game last fall.

headline: Impassive Stoudemire Describes His Accident
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — To Amar’e Stoudemire it was all an accident, a momentary swipe of his left hand in the frustrating wake of a dispiriting defeat. In his words, he meant to “make some noise,” not summon paramedics and several days of censure.

headline: Business Day Live | RIM's Comeback Hopes
text: May 2, 2012 - With BlackBerry 10, Research in Motion hopes for a comeback.

headline: Paralyzed Player Signed by His Former Coach
text: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers made a notable and poignant free-agent signing Wednesday when they added one of Coach Greg Schiano’s former Rutgers players: defensive tackle Eric LeGrand, who was paralyzed after injuring his spinal cord in a game in 2010.

headline: Updates on the French Presidential Debate
text: The Lede followed the first and only debate between the two candidates in the second round of the French presidential election. The incumbent, Nicolas Sarkozy, has been trailing in the polls against his Socialist rival, François Hollande. The debate lasted nearly three hours with no breaks.

headline: Trapped in the Middle Seat
text: WHILE continuing economic uncertainty around the world has rattled business confidence, it has not stopped companies — from the smallest widget-maker to the largest financial institution — from sending their battle-tested travelers back on the road this year.

headline: A Promising Skeleton in the Quarry
text: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

headline: News Corp.’s Board Says It Has ‘Full Confidence’ in Murdoch
text: 3:59 p.m. | Updated A British parliamentary panel concluded on Tuesday that Rupert Murdoch was “not a fit person” to run a huge international company. But ultimately the News Corporation board, not British lawmakers, will decide whether Rupert Murdoch is “fit” to run a major corporation.

headline: Junior Seau Found Dead
text: The former Charger Junior Seau, one of the best linebackers in N.F.L. history, was found dead in his home in Oceanside, Calif., on Wednesday, apparently from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said. He was 43.

headline: Britain Remains a Dissenter as Europeans Try to Set Capital Reserves for Banks
text: BRUSSELS — A meeting of European Union finance ministers turned a little unruly late Wednesday when George Osborne, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, accused his counterparts of making him look like an “idiot” because he pushed for approval of stricter banking laws.

headline: Scouting Report
text: HITTING THE RACKS

headline: Video of Obama's Speech in Afghanistan
text: President Obama, speaking to an American television audience from an air base in Kabul, said he had traveled there to herald a new era in the relationship between the United States and Afghanistan.

headline: Helsinki City Board Votes Against a Guggenheim Helsinki
text: The city board of Helsinki, Finland, has shot down a proposal to build a $185 million Guggenheim Museum along the city’s waterfront, Reuters reported on Wednesday.

headline: Injuries Change Playoff Lineups
text: The playoffs march on, and the list of injured N.B.A. players — including some stars who are key components of their teams — continues to grow too.

headline: Dwyane Wade Dominates Through Subtlety
text: When LeBron James takes over a playoff series, he takes it by the throat. His dominance is often so obvious and blunt that his contributions become impossible to ignore. James stands at the center of it all, bathed in spotlight, and wrapped in our collective awe.

headline: Backyard Science: Tallying Local Species to Learn About Diversity
text: Overview | How many different species live in your neighborhood? How do researchers assess species diversity and why is diversity important to humans? In this lesson, students conduct species tallies, document their findings with photographs and video and construct maps and photo galleries that summarize the results.

headline: Silver Lake Takes Stake in William Morris Endeavor
text: The private equity firm Silver Lake has acquired a minority stake in the William Morris Endeavor Entertainment talent agency, the two announced on Wednesday, in a move to expand their presence in new media.

headline: How Robots Inspect the Oklahoma Sky
text: We were in the middle of Oklahoma, with cows lowing in the distance and nearby fields of immature winter wheat soaking up a bright February sun. Yet, incongruously, a robot army seemed to be marching across yon hill.

headline: Chesapeake’s Chief Executive Addresses Disclosures
text: HOUSTON — Chesapeake Energy’s chief executive, Aubrey K. McClendon, broke his silence on Wednesday after two weeks of media revelations about his byzantine financial dealings, but he expressed no remorse for anything except the distraction caused by the publicity. Shares of the natural gas drilling company closed down 14.6 percent.

headline: The Declining Role of Start-Ups
text: Business leaders and politicians often laud the United States for its entrepreneurial culture, but the pace of start-up activity has been declining since the 1980s, a decline that – not surprisingly – accelerated during the most recent recession and its aftermath.

headline: Junior Seau, Famed N.F.L. Linebacker, Dies at 43; Suicide Is Suspected
text: OCEANSIDE, Calif. — Behind the police tape, a white coroner’s van sat in front of a garage on the 600 block of South the Strand. It waited to collect the body of Junior Seau, a linebacker among the most feared in N.F.L. history, father to three teenagers, son to the mother who wailed long and loud on Wednesday.

headline: In-Between Days
text: “Are you still here?” It was early January in New York, the first week of my daughter’s pre-kindergarten. Waiting for the elevator in the disorienting silence of post-drop off, I found myself staring at a gargoyle on the side of the Riverside Church, where she goes to school.

headline: Another Big Name Exits Reverse-Mortgage Lending
text: Yet another household name has given up making reverse mortgages — loans that let borrowers age 62 and older tap the equity in their houses without having to make monthly payments. The lenders get their money back once the borrowers move or die (and their relatives sell the house).

headline: Lundqvist Is a Finalist for Lindsay Award
text: WASHINGTON — Henrik Lundqvist was named a finalist for the Ted Lindsay Award, given to the most outstanding player as voted by other N.H.L. players.

headline: When Insolvency Cases Are Global
text: 12:37 p.m. | Updated The UNCITRAL Insolvency Working Group is meeting all week. (I’m participating as an observer, although of course this column represents only my own views.)

headline: At Milken, Feelings of Malaise
text: LOS ANGELES — If a single word captured the mood of the Wall Street contingent at this year’s Milken Institute Global Conference, “uncertain” would fit the bill.

headline: It’s Daffodil Day. Where Are All the Dads?
text: This morning I took a couple of hours away from my desk, and went to “Daffodil Day” at my two youngest children’s preschool. It was not an inspiring day for the school’s annual flower-picking outing; clouds hovered, it was 45 degrees and the ground was wet from yesterday’s rains. But this is New England, and we said we would pick daffodils, and the weather for the rain date looked, if anything, worse. So daffodils were picked, in the company of some 40 small children, assorted teachers and about 15 parents who’d volunteered to provide transport and flower-wrapping-in-wet-paper-towel services.

headline: Jonas Kaufmann Withdraws From the Metropolitan Opera’s ‘Die Walküre’
text: The tenor Jonas Kaufmann has again withdrawn from the role of Siegmund in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Die Walküre” by Richard Wagner. Stuart Skelton will take over in Monday’s performance, the Met said on Wednesday, because Mr. Kaufmann is ill. Frank van Aken replaced Mr. Kaufmann on Saturday, placing him on stage opposite his real-life wife, Eva-Maria Westbroek, who is singing Sieglinde.

headline: Call It Victor’s Secret
text: ARE men really ready to shop for underwear the way women do?

headline: New Song to Benefit Amnesty International
text: One of the last musical projects Levon Helm participated in at his rustic studio in Woodstock, N.Y., was “Toast to Freedom,” a heart-warming single that will go on sale Wednesday to raise money for Amnesty International on its 50th anniversary.

headline: Back to School for Derby Contenders
text: The 20 horses being prepared for this Saturday’s Kentucky Derby have completed their final workouts. There is not much more to do at this point from a fitness standpoint. The horses will gallop each morning to keep ticking over. A few might do a short work just to sharpen up a couple of days before the race. Essentially the horse is as fit as it will be — that won’t change. The goal of the trainer is to have the horse fit, sound and happy on Saturday. Being relaxed is also helpful.

headline: Gingrich Quits Race and Says He Prefers Romney to Obama
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — More than half a dozen news cameras lined the back of a small ballroom packed with journalists, campaign staff members and a few supporters on Wednesday for Newt Gingrich to repeat what he’s been saying for more than a week: He’s out.

headline: In Iris Love’s Wide Circle of Friends
text: SOME dog lovers live for their dogs and hardly give people the time of day. Others are more social. And then there is Iris Love, the New York socialite whose Pekingese won the Best in Show award this year at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: Contradictions Temper Optimism in Deal on Chinese Lawyer
text: Did Chen Guangcheng, the blind self-taught lawyer who spent the past six days holed up in the American Embassy in Beijing, make China’s leaders blink? Or will American diplomats come to regret the agreement they helped negotiate on his behalf?

headline: Italo Train: Ferrari of the Railyard Has Automotive Pedigree
text: Americans wary of interminable waits in highway traffic and at the T.S.A. security checkpoint have dreamed for years of high speed trains like France’s TGV or Germany’s so-called ICE train. But as reported in Sunday’s Times, from Italy comes news that two high-speed rail lines are competing on features like design, quality of cuisine and the feel of the luxury-brand leather on their seats.

headline: Art and Leisure
text: WHAT’S a high-powered art fair without parties? New York City rolls out a red carpet for Frieze.

headline: Considering Life’s End and What Comes After
text: Unless you are a poet or an undertaker, the notion of spending roughly two hours musing over death might not be high on your list of preferred ways to spend a Tuesday evening. Yet somehow the intense, insightful German baritone Matthias Goerne and the brilliant Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes made the prospect of morbid soul searching not only inviting, but also deeply stimulating.

headline: The Angels in the Heavens Sing for Themselves
text: Truth be told, the “Representation of Chaos” that opens Haydn’s 1798 oratorio “Die Schöpfung” (“The Creation”), sounds oddly decorous to modern ears. Granted, it begins with a short burst of brassy dissonance, and altered versions of that gesture return during the slow, dark-hued overture that pours forth before the angel Raphael’s serene narration of the familiar scene from Genesis: the formlessness of the earth, the darkness on the face of the waters. And when a second angel, Uriel, announces the creation of light, Haydn provides a magnificent explosion of C major orchestral timbre.

headline: An Island Villa in a Gated Compound
text: A three-bedroom beachfront villa in the northeastern part of the Dominican Republic is on the market for $1.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... the Dominican Republic
text: A BEACHFRONT VILLA IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

headline: The Frieze Art Fair Brings Its Art and Entertainment to New York
text: On Friday the London-based Frieze Art Fair flings open its tent to the public and brings its distinctive brand of arts entertainment to the city.

headline: Themes From the Netherlands That Feel Familiar
text: In its 40 years the Dutch company Introdans has amassed a polyglot body of work typical of contemporary repertory companies, including dances by the usual suspects Twyla Tharp, Nacho Duato and Jiri Kylian. Its dancers are generally sleek, handsome movers, able to traverse this particular swath of modern and ballet styles efficiently.

headline: Where ‘Just Looking’ Is Just Fine
text: THE kook on the bus had a Starbucks cup filled with ice on his head. He was crooning a soulful version of “Fly Me to the Moon.” The guy was not a performance artist, and yet his serenade seemed aptly artful since the M35 bus was headed for the next big cultural destination, a rock in the East River that, as far as many New Yorkers are concerned, might as well be in space.

headline: Steina's 'Orbital Obsessions'
text: An excerpt from “Orbital Obsessions” (1977) by the Icelandic video artist Steina. The work is on view at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo, N.Y. (Video courtesy of the artist.)

headline: Artist, Draw Thyself (and Your Mother and Therapist)
text: For 25 years, from 1983 to 2008, Alison Bechdel wrote a buoyant comic strip that you could find only in America’s alternative weekly newspapers. Its title was “Dykes to Watch Out For,” and its combination of politics, college-town neuroses and heavy petting could make you blush. It was “Doonesbury” with all-girl sex scenes.

headline: Paul Sharits's 'Dream Displacement'
text: Excerpt of Paul Sharits’s film installation (original installation 1976), Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo, N.Y. (Courtesy Estate of Paul Sharits, Anthology Film Archives and Greene Naftali Gallery)

headline: European Politics Dims Ukraine’s Chance to Shine
text: MOSCOW — This was supposed to be a moment of triumph for Ukraine. In just over a month, it is to become the first former Soviet republic to host the European soccer championships, an achievement its leaders hoped would showcase its emergence from an authoritarian past and its embrace of Western values.

headline: Zeroing In on Cellulite
text: SELINA, 53, did not want to worry about her lumpy thighs before her wedding in June. So when she heard a host on “The Doctors,” a syndicated TV show, say that a new treatment called Cellulaze can “banish cellulite,” she paid $6,500 for it. “The fact that it’s supposed to be a permanent solution was definitely what sold me,” said Selina, who got a hefty discount because she agreed to be Exhibit A for a doctor-training session.

headline: Renaissance in an Industrial Shadow
text: BUFFALO

headline: CNN Ratings Decline Stirs Worries
text: “Maybe CNN is just like an emergency room.”

headline: Blogging a Path Through Illness
text: Documentaries about people dealing with debilitating medical conditions don’t get any more wrenching than “65_RedRoses,” a film about one woman’s race against the unforgiving cystic fibrosis clock.

headline: Lights Out for Research Satellites?
text: Earth-observing systems operated by the United States have entered a steep decline, imperiling the nation’s monitoring of weather, natural disasters and climate change, a report from the National Research Council warned on Wednesday.

headline: Business Day Live | Google Complacency
text: Nick Bilton and Quentin Hardy discuss how the success of companies like Google makes it harder for them to understand what people are looking for in the next generation of products.

headline: Paul Krugman’s Reddit Chat: Europe, Partisanship and Self-Flushing Toilets
text: Yesterday, Paul Krugman took part in the first official New York Times chat to be hosted on Reddit. The “IamA,” which touched on issues from his article about Ben Bernanke in the April 29 issue of the magazine, generated more than 4,100 comments and questions and was at the top of Reddit’s “Hot” list for most of the afternoon and evening, outdoing even the “Venus to Appear in Once-in-a-Lifetime Event” thread.

headline: Acrobat Sets Date to Cross Niagara Falls on Tightrope
text: Fans of funambulists can finally mark their calendars.

headline: Hello, Stranger
text: THE “Missed Connections” section of Craigslist, where people post wistful and often lyrical missives to potential love objects they glimpsed on the street, is one of the site’s most popular. And it has given rise to other sites that try to make up for the common human inability to act immediately on romantic impulses.

headline: Exuberance Is Just One of His Skills
text: Don Was, the Grammy Award-winning producer, has a clear recollection of his first encounter with Blue Note Records. He was a teenager, listening to the car radio in his hometown, Detroit, when he heard the title track of a 1966 album by Joe Henderson. “I heard this saxophone playing, and it was riveting,” he said recently. “I didn’t know anything about jazz. But this thing jumped out and grabbed me. It was ‘Mode for Joe.’ ”

headline: Brooklyn’s Musical Matrix
text: About two years ago, when Bryce and Aaron Dessner began considering which acts to book for Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, the music festival they put together for the Brooklyn Academy of Music, they knew they wanted to represent the local scene. The Dessners, twin musicians who are part of the indie band the National, also realized that this was an impossible undertaking.

headline: Novartis to Buy Fougera Pharmaceuticals for $1.5 Billion
text: Novartis International agreed on Wednesday to buy Fougera Pharmaceuticals, a maker of generic skin care medicine, for $1.525 billion in cash. The move would make the company the biggest manufacturer in the field.

headline: Tender Trap
text: WILLIAMSBURG’S indie spirit has been challenged by rampant development (Bedford Avenue is even blighted by a Duane Reade now), but not every newcomer kowtows to the condo dwellers. Tender Trap, an unassuming bar that opened in February, is practically a premillennial throwback: dirt-cheap drinks, good music and a goofy, artsy side that makes it feel like a neighborhood fixture.

headline: Celebrity Perfumes Get Competition
text: WANT to smell like Cosmic Radiance? (According to Britney Spears, the perfume is a musky mix of citrus fruits and white flowers.) Or you, too, can feel as Lovely as Sarah Jessica Parker, play Truth or Dare like Madonna or ooze the official scent of Jennifer Aniston through your pores.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘How Kentucky Became Southern’
text: An excerpt from Maryjean Wall’s book, “How Kentucky Became Southern: A Tale of Outlaws, Horse Thieves, Gamblers, and Breeders.”

headline: Man Accused of Pushing Officer to His Death in Brooklyn Is Convicted
text: A man accused of pushing a police officer to his death from the stoop of a Brooklyn brownstone last year was convicted of manslaughter but acquitted of the more serious charge of murder on Wednesday.

headline: Wiretaps Remain Crucial Evidence
text: Wiretaps are often the smoking gun that prosecutors like to use because a defendant’s own words can sway the jury in a criminal case.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, India, Afghanistan and Syria.

headline: A Satirist Goes for None-Too-Subtle Shading
text: IT took Andrew Shaffer 10 days to write “Fifty Shames of Earl Grey,” his parody of the best-selling erotic novel “Fifty Shades of Grey.” Little did he know it would land him a lucrative book deal in about as much time.

headline: In Seoul, Two Hanoks Make a Modern Home
text: An art professor and preservationist combined history and modernity in two traditional wooden structures.

headline: Connecting the Centuries
text: Seoul, South Korea

headline: Back Spinning, After the World Stopped
text: Four months ago Jonathan Toubin woke up in a hospital bed barely alive. Mr. Toubin, a 40-year-old D.J. and rising figure in the Brooklyn music scene, had been lying in bed in a hotel room in Portland, Ore., resting up for a show, when a taxi crashed through the wall and pinned him under its wheels.

headline: A Hospital in Bloom
text: To commemorate the closing of the Massachusetts Mental Health Center’s old building in 2003, the artist Anna Schuleit was asked to create a work of art on the abandoned site. Some 28,000 pots of flowers were used for the “Bloom” installation.

headline: Video: R.I.M. Rests Hopes on BlackBerry 10
text: Brian X. Chen and Peter Lattman discuss Research In Motion’s hopes for a comeback with BlackBerry 10. While people have been pessimistic about the company’s chances to regain its footing in the smartphone market, the response to its new operating system was generally positive.

headline: Balanchine’s Gift for Joining What Nature Has Sundered
text: The ballets of George Balanchine make the peculiar natural. You and I do not turn out our legs to 180 degrees; you and I do not dance on point.
