In the stage worlds of his ballets, however, these things become the premise through which music and drama become keener and more intense. Watching, we find our senses changed. The fusion of music and womanhood and academicism is heady stuff.

headline: Pelfrey’s Fill-In Falters for 2nd Straight Time
text: HOUSTON — Mike Pelfrey had the ability to drive Mets fans mad with his inconsistency. Some of them may be missing him now.

headline: Video: Complacency at Google and Facebook
text: Nick Bilton and Quentin Hardy discuss how the success of companies like Google and Facebook makes it harder for them to understand what people are looking for in the next generation of products.

headline: The Business of Going Broke
text: Inside Republic Textile Equipment’s 60,000-square-foot warehouse, industrial-scale knitting equipment stands beside fabric-testing paraphernalia, which is next to printing machines and countless bins of spare parts. All of it, the remnants of factories and businesses gone bust, belongs to Mike Diamond, who has spent the last 50 years making a living in an industry that, for lack of a gentler term, might be called the going-broke business.

headline: Seeking Redress When Air Travel Goes Awry
text: IN his 12 years as a semi-frequent traveler, David Shashoua never got bumped off a flight twice in one day.

headline: Massage Spas, New Oases for the Harried Flier
text: ABOUT five years ago, Richard Laermer, a public relations executive, found himself with time to kill during a layover at Logan Airport in Boston.

headline: After the Plane Gets You to the Airport, an App Comes in Handy
text: As many times as I’ve seen an airport vendor selling a tired-looking sandwich for $10, I’m still dumbstruck. I’ll often circle the terminal for 20 minutes, starved and incredulous, before ending up with that miserable sandwich because it’s the least worst option.

headline: The Business of Dealing With Kidnapping Abroad
text: WHEN the kidnappers shackled his feet and cuffed his hands, Edo de Ronde managed to restrain his fears. The Dutch marketing consultant, who was abducted last year in South Africa, kept calm in captivity, he recalled, until a gun was put to his head. Mr. de Ronde then asked himself, “What will they say at my funeral?”

headline: Talking Business in Flight? Be Careful
text: PETER COCHRANE, a technology consultant, entrepreneur and blogger, usually unwinds on the train between his home in Ipswich, England, and London with coffee, cookies and a newspaper.

headline: World Mind Sports Games Quarterfinals
text: At the trial to select the United States open team for the World Mind Sports Games in August, the 120-board quarterfinals were played on Tuesday and Wednesday. At the halfway stage these were the scores by captains’ names: Warren Spector 153 international match points, Nick Nickell 95; John Diamond 128, George Jacobs, 112; Roger Lee 121, Martin Fleisher 101; and Reese Milner 99, Jim Mahaffey 90. The final results can be found at usbf.org. Play in the semifinals (Thursday and Friday) and final (Saturday and Sunday) can be watched live at bridgebase.com starting at 11 a.m. Eastern Time.

headline: How to Muddy Your Tracks on the Internet
text: Legal and technology researchers estimate that it would take about a month for Internet users to read the privacy policies of all the Web sites they visit in a year. So in the interest of time, here is the deal: You know that dream where you suddenly realize you’re stark naked? You’re living it whenever you open your browser.

headline: Apps That Do Everything but Pack Your Bags
text: YOUR corporate travel department is not a bad thing. It can negotiate preferred rates with hotels and car rental agencies. It can get a person on the phone when large travel companies keep you on hold until midnight.

headline: V.I.P. Treatment Eases the Way Through Security
text: BIG spenders get special treatment — the world was ever thus. And those who spend the most money also receive increasingly preferential treatment at airport security.

headline: Commission Rules for Bloomberg TV in Dial Dispute With Comcast
text: The Federal Communications Commission ruled in favor of Bloomberg TV on Wednesday, saying Comcast must program the less-watched cable channel in the same “neighborhood” on the cable dial as competitors like Fox Business and CNBC and more general news channels like CNN and MSNBC.

headline: Hotels Close to the Runway, but Far From Stress
text: HOTELS at airports used to be lonely places where blackout curtains and soundproof walls were the biggest selling points. But creating ever more deluxe, relaxing retreats close to or even in the middle of airports is a growing trend.

headline: The Quince, Coast to Coast
text: Quince trees, once de rigueur in America’s Colonial gardens, fell out of favor over the years. But some growers are still very attached to them.

headline: In Praise of the Misunderstood Quince
text: AFTER half a century in public life, the most famous quince trees in New York are looking — let’s say mature. Or how about distinguished?

headline: For Health, Drink Water (but Don’t Drink the Water)
text: EXPERTS agree that the best thing business travelers can do to reduce their chances of getting sick is to maximize their use of soap, water and hand sanitizer and minimize the number of times they touch their face. Other tips include:

headline: The State of Mobile: Less Talking, Fewer Texts, More Data
text: People generally talk less on the phone and send fewer text messages now because there are so many ways to communicate over an Internet connection. Though this may seem obvious to anyone who owns a smartphone, a new study confirms the trend.

headline: Your Road Buddies: Zillions of Germs
text: FOR Dr. Philip M. Tierno, business travel means combat. The enemy is heartless and relentless, stealthy and ubiquitous. It is poised to attack every second of the day, even when he’s asleep. It exploits his rare moments of weakness and turns everyone and everything around him into agents who thoughtlessly do its bidding.

headline: Is New Sex-Education Course Too Much or Just Enough?
text: In an article in The East Sider, her student newspaper, an 11th grader at East Side Community High School writes that the city's new mandatory sex education course, which began in January, “is nothing like the old one where it was all about abstinence and different sexually transmitted diseases.’’ She asks: Is it too much, or just enough?

headline: Entrepreneuring Charity
text: Carol Roth, business analyst, evaluates an investor pitch from a small business.

headline: Long Island Principal 'Horrified' by Quality of State Exams
text: Sharon Emick Fougner, principal of Elizabeth Mellick Baker Elementary School in Great Neck, Long Island, urged the state education commissioner to conduct a review of the math exams that were given to fourth to eighth graders last month, saying she was "quite honestly horrified by the content, format, language and presentation of this year's exams."

headline: Homes for $890,000
text: Properties in Missouri, Maine and Washington.

headline: What You Get for $890,000
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: What to Read on Your Way to Heaven
text: Maud Newton writes about her experience growing up among Christian fundamentalists in her Riff in the April 29 issue of the magazine on Todd Burpo’s best seller, “Heaven Is for Real.” In the book, Burpo recounts his 3-year-old son’s near-death experience and resulting supernatural visions. Below is a selection of books included in Amazon’s “Customers Who Bought This Item Also Bought” list for “Heaven Is for Real.”

headline: Prescriptions for Opioid Painkillers Climb in City
text: The number of opioid painkiller prescriptions filled for New York City residents rose 22 percent in two years, to more than two million in 2010, according to data released Wednesday by a city panel.

headline: Sales at Jonathan Adler and Others
text: Bedding, pillows and table linens from John Robshaw are as much as 75 percent off, through May 4 (the Indigo Dip decorative pillow, regularly $100, is $40); 245 West 29th Street (Seventh Avenue), (212) 594-6006.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. My bedroom has worn carpet. Should I replace it with a hardwood flooring before trying to sell my home?

headline: A Classic Collaboration
text: Olivia Putman has been busy since taking over as head of Studio Andrée Putman, her well-known mother’s Paris-based business, five years ago. Ms. Putman, 47, has designed furniture for Fermob, Emeco and Serralunga as well as the Le Rivage hotel in Hong Kong. And last week, she was in town to introduce a line of lighting created in collaboration with Lalique.

headline: A Revival for a Modern Collection
text: The furniture manufacturer Herman Miller is reviving a concept it first developed in 1948: a selective portfolio of furniture for modern living that it believes will stand the test of time, known as the Herman Miller Collection.

headline: Piecing Together an Interesting Tray
text: Designing a tray seems like it would be a relative no-brainer. But for Bruce and Stephanie Tharp of Materious, the Chicago-based design studio, it posed a challenge: “how to bring something interesting to what is fundamentally just a flat surface,” as Mr. Tharp put it.

headline: Woods Is Back on the Course, but Saying Little
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Tiger Woods’s first drive Wednesday in his pro-am round for the Wells Fargo Championship split the fairway, giving credence to his assertion earlier in the week that he fixed the bad posture that led to his bad ball-striking at the Masters, his last competitive event.

headline: A Country’s Attic, on Display
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Inspiration Behind an Open Door
text: EVERY year, spring brings with it the promise of new planting, home improvement projects and renovations. Those in search of inspiration can find it in the houses and gardens open to the public across the country. Most tours are self-guided, unless otherwise noted.

headline: An Artful Tower of Flowers
text: Several years ago, Royal Tichelaar Makkum, a Dutch ceramics company founded in the 16th century, restored two identical 17th-century flower pyramids for the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam. At the time, the company also made a replica of one of the pyramids, which each consisted of 11 stacked vases. That replica, left, was a jumping-off point for four designers — Hella Jongerius, Studio Makkink & Bey, Studio Job and Alexander van Slobbe — to reinterpret the 17th-century pyramid. The first exhibition devoted solely to those designs, “Pyramids of Makkum,” opens May 10 at Gallery Libby Sellers in London.

headline: Evan Roth, an Award-Winning Man of Many Tags
text: In street-culture circles, Evan Roth is already a boldface name, with a résumé that includes collaborating with Jay-Z on a music video and creating a computerized analysis of graffiti motion.

headline: The Ultimate House Tour
text: A look inside the rooms at the White House that are open to the public.

headline: A House Tour: Yes, That House
text: WASHINGTON

headline: In Fairfield County, a Homeless Concours Seeks Shelter for 2013 and Beyond
text: A consulting group formed by the directors of the Fairfield County Concours d’Élégance, the collector-car weekend in southern Connecticut that traditionally marks the end of the concours season in the Northeast, announced this week that the event would not take place this year.

headline: The Once and Future Mayor
text: London

headline: A Hidden Nest Atop Barneys to Make Deals
text: GOLDEN birds are painted onto the thick columns of Fred’s at Barneys New York, the coolly elegant ninth-floor dining room of the department store. They perch stiffly, arch their necks and hold their beaks high; their plumes are perfectly groomed, their bodies remarkably thin. There is no question they inhabit the higher branches of their kingdom, much like the diners chirping beside them.

headline: The Joy of Drawing on Glass
text: Much of the iPad’s magic — and its success — comes from the directness of the touch screen. For decades, you dragged a mouse on one surface to make the cursor move on another. And now, suddenly, you can tap or draw right on the screen.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: ‘Open Data’ and Turntable.fm
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: Bodleian Announces Crowd-Sourced Victorian Music Project
text: The Bodleian Library at Oxford is inviting “citizen librarians” to help describe and catalog its collection of 4,000 pieces of mid-Victorian music, the library announced.

headline: Newt Gingrich Formally Suspends Campaign
text: Newt Gingrich formally suspended his campaign in a speech on Tuesday in Arlington, Va.

headline: Boy Outsmarts Experts on Byzantine Empire
text: Benjamin Lerman Coady took one close look and knew it: the map on the wall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was wrong.

headline: Bodemeister Morning-Line Favorite for Derby
text: Bodemeister, coming off an impressive win in the Arkansas Derby, was installed as the 4-1 morning-line favorite for Saturday’s $2 million Kentucky Derby after post positions were drawn Wednesday. Trained by Bob Baffert, Bodemeister will break from Post 6 for the mile-and-a-quarter race.

headline: George Zimmerman’s Disparaging Remarks About Mexicans on MySpace
text: As George Zimmerman’s legal team began a new social media presence for him this week, one of its first challenges on the new Facebook page has been responding to questions about an old MySpace account, where he made disparaging remarks about Mexicans.

headline: Airport Hotels Get an Upgrade
text: Airports and adjacent hotels are being renovated with an eye toward creating a more pleasing environment for the traveler.

headline: In Brooklyn Brownstone, Future President Found a Home on the Top Floor
text: There is no plaque on the brownstone half a block from Prospect Park that says, “Barack Obama slept here.” Not yet, anyway.

headline: Wireless Carriers Who Aid Police Are Asked for Data
text: WASHINGTON — A leading House Democrat is demanding information from the country’s biggest cellphone companies about their role in helping local police departments conduct surveillance and tracking of suspects and others in criminal investigations.

headline: Chess Leader Visits Syria Under Cloud of Ambiguity
text: MOSCOW — The president of the World Chess Federation, an eccentric Russian millionaire who last year tried to negotiate a settlement in Libya’s civil war, has again shown up for talks with a faltering dictator.

headline: Signs of Decision on Accused Philadelphia Priests
text: SPRINGFIELD, Pa. — Several hundred Roman Catholic priests from the Archdiocese of Philadelphia gathered Wednesday for a closed-door meeting with Archbishop Charles J. Chaput days before he has said he hopes to announce the results of an investigation into claims of sexual abuse against 27 priests.

headline: Breakfast, but No Play
text: To the Editor:

headline: Target, Unhappy With Being an Amazon Showroom, Will Stop Selling Kindles
text: Target, signaling its growing irritation with its rival Amazon, announced on Wednesday that it would stop selling the online retailer’s Kindle e-readers.

headline: ‘The Scream’ Sells at Sotheby’s for $120 Million, a Record
text: A version of Edvard Munch’s “The Scream,” one of the most recognizable images in art history, sold at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night for just under $120 million, the most ever paid for an artwork at auction. Five bidders competed for the work, which sold to a telephone bidder.

headline: Green Mountain’s Rocky Slide
text: Green Mountain Coffee Roasters reported disappointing financial results on Wednesday evening, adding weight to the criticisms of skeptical investors who are betting against the company’s shares.

headline: Devils’ Rookie Defenseman Regains His Edge
text: NEWARK — Adam Larsson, the Devils’ 19-year-old rookie defenseman, had grown a playoff beard, just in case he would actually get into a playoff game. His blond whiskers are thick and spiky, practically like a veteran’s.

headline: Death of a Salesman’s Dreams
text: ARTHUR MILLER’s “Death of a Salesman,” now on Broadway in a Tony-nominated revival — and starring a heart-shattering Philip Seymour Hoffman as a Willy Loman for the ages — is the most devastating portrait of punctured middle-class dreams in our national literature. Yet as I sat through a recent performance, I wondered why the play was revived at all.

headline: A Delicate New Balance on National Security
text: WASHINGTON — One moment he boasts about taking out America’s No. 1 enemy, and the next he vows to bring home troops from an unpopular war. For President Obama, the days leading up to his re-election kickoff have been spent straddling the precarious line between hawk and dove, and possibly redefining his party for years to come.

headline: China Curbs on Currency Still an Issue
text: WASHINGTON — The pace of appreciation of the Chinese currency against the dollar has slowed in the last year, ensuring that China’s manipulation of its exchange rate remains a central topic as Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner arrives in Beijing for the annual dialogue between the nations.

headline: Israel Military Clears Soldiers in Deaths of Gaza Civilians
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military announced Wednesday that it had closed its investigation into the 2009 deaths of at least 21 members of an extended Palestinian family who were huddled in a house that was struck by Israeli shells or missiles during the Gaza war, and that no legal steps would be taken against any soldiers involved.

headline: Methodists Vote Against Ending Investments Tied to Israel
text: The United Methodist Church, the nation’s largest mainline Protestant denomination, voted against two proposals on Wednesday to divest from companies that provide equipment used by Israel to enforce its control in the occupied territories.

headline: Police Warrant Squads Were Used to Monitor Wall Street Protesters, Suspects Say
text: On Monday, the New York Police Department sent its warrant squads after an unusual set of suspects: people who had old warrants for the lowliest of violations, misconduct too minor, usually, to draw the attention of those squads.

headline: Progress Is Seen in Advancing a Final Volcker Rule
text: A major new rule that has drawn the ire of Wall Street is on track for completion sooner than some bankers had expected, dashing the hopes of financial industry lobbyists, who have pressed for a delay.

headline: Carlyle Prices I.P.O. at $22, Below Expected Level
text: For years, the Carlyle Group had sought to follow its private equity rivals in stepping out as a publicly traded firm, a status that once promised wealth and prestige.

headline: For Law Students, Dewey & LeBoeuf Internships Evaporate
text: Well, this is awkward.

headline: Things That Really Matter
text: Another week of presidential politics, another outbreak of faux outrage and media manipulation.

headline: Fox Mocks ‘The Voice’ With a New Dating Show, ‘The Choice’
text: How much does the Fox network disdain the challenge that “The Voice” on NBC has posed to its dominant singing competition, “American Idol”?

headline: With a Merger Unlikely, Dewey’s Options Shrink
text: The crisis confronting Dewey & LeBoeuf deepened on Wednesday as the law firm’s chances of finding a merger partner dwindled.

headline: The Lower Floor
text: I found last week’s Supreme Court argument in the Arizona immigration case utterly depressing, and I’ve spent the intervening week puzzling over my reaction. It’s not simply that the federal government seems poised to lose: unlike the appeals court, the justices appear likely to find the heart of Arizona’s mean-spirited “attrition through enforcement” statute, S.B. 1070, permissible under federal law.

headline: After Primary Losses, Legacies of Debt and Strained Reputations
text: When the Republican primary season began last year, some of the candidates seemed like such long shots that they could have been running simply to enhance their résumés. After all, the exposure through nationally televised debates could increase name recognition, pave the way to lucrative speaking fees and book advances or help with a re-election bid.

headline: Greg Jackson Dies at 60; Ran a Haven in Brooklyn
text: Greg Jackson, a former professional basketball player who turned a Brooklyn recreation center into a hive of productive activity in one of New York’s most troubled neighborhoods, died on Tuesday in Brooklyn. He was 60.

headline: YouTube and Kin Woo Marketers, Seeking to Siphon Dollars From TV
text: THE people behind the Tribeca Film Festival are getting a channel, but unlike the channel from the people behind the Sundance Film Festival, don’t look for it on television.

headline: Changing the Subject
text: Let’s talk about the Senate races. It’s a matter of mental health. We cannot spend the next six months fixating on Romney versus Obama. Before you know it, we’ll be so bored that we’ll start arguing about whether it’s seemly for the president to brag about killing Osama bin Laden.

headline: Earl Rose, Coroner When Kennedy Was Shot, Dies at 85
text: Earl Rose, who as the Dallas County medical examiner when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated insisted that he should do the autopsy, only to be overruled in a confrontation with presidential aides, died on Tuesday in Iowa City. He was 85.

headline: California Man’s ‘Drug Holiday’ Becomes Four-Day Nightmare in Holding Cell
text: LOS ANGELES — By his own admission, Daniel Chong planned to spend April 20 like so many other college students: smoking marijuana with friends to celebrate an unofficial holiday devoted to the drug.

headline: Short-Term Fixes
text: Federally subsidized student loan rates were bound to become an election-year fight, since Congress provided only enough money for five years of low-interest rates in 2007. Now that the rates are about to double, both Democrats and Republicans are failing to do the right thing again.

headline: Kentucky Derby Favorite? Oddsmaker Shrugs
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When the post positions for the Kentucky Derby are drawn and the morning-line odds announced, there is the expectation that some order has been installed on a riot of a horse race. Twenty 3-year-olds, mere adolescents, will go a marathon distance of a mile and a quarter for the first time, before more than 100,000 people, many teary-eyed from either the singing of “My Old Kentucky Home” or mint juleps.

headline: When Flying 720 Miles Takes 12 Hours
text: It took Josh Hunter three separate planes, two connections and a two-hour drive to get from Mobile, Ala., to Cincinnati at Easter. When he added it all up, his 720-mile trip had lasted 12 hours — about the same it would have taken him to drive.

headline: Public Fury and Penalties for Saints’ Bounties
text: As we examined a few weeks ago, the harsh punishments handed down for the Saints’ bounty system are partly a result of public relations. The N.F.L. could have easily decided the  suspensions when it originally announced the findings in its Saints bounties investigation, but instead it waited several weeks. Commissioner Roger Goodell had time to gauge the public’s reaction to the news — there was no precedent for him to go by.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 8
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s Leap of Faith
text: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s long resistance to Myanmar’s brutal dictatorship gave her people — and the world — hope that her country would someday be free. Her swearing in this week as a member of Myanmar’s Parliament is an important step forward, but the struggle to establish a real democracy is not over.

headline: Dolan and Bishops Urge Albany to Raise Minimum Wage
text: ALBANY — Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan and New York State’s bishops are calling on the Legislature to increase the minimum wage, adding an influential source of support to a proposal that has divided lawmakers along party lines.

headline: Subverting the Miranda Rule
text: When the Supreme Court ruled in the landmark Miranda case that criminal suspects in custody must be told of their right to have a lawyer and to remain silent, the purpose was to ensure that the police and prosecutors did not obtain a confession through improper means. But the office of the Queens district attorney, Richard Brown, has concocted a way around this basic principle with a “central booking interview program” in which prosecutors interrogate suspects before they are arraigned or have counsel assigned to them. Fortunately, a state trial judge has found the program misleading, deceptive and unethical, and will not allow the district attorney’s office to use statements from this type of interview at trial.

headline: Romney Camp Stirred Storm Over Gay Aide
text: It was the biggest moment yet for Mitt Romney’s foreign policy team: a conference call last Thursday, dialed into by dozens of news outlets from around the globe, to dissect and denounce President Obama’s record on national security.

headline: Britain’s Biggest Satellite Broadcaster Distances Itself From Murdoch
text: LONDON — Britain’s biggest satellite broadcaster, British Sky Broadcasting, or BSkyB, distanced itself on Wednesday from its largest shareholder, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, in a sign of the difficulties Mr. Murdoch faces here following a scathing parliamentary report that declared him not fit to run a global media empire.

headline: A New View of the Aqueous Globe
text: “There is a river in the ocean” are the first words in Matthew Fontaine Maury’s pioneering work, “The Physical Geography of the Sea,” first published in 1855. Sailors have always been aware of ocean rivers — currents, that is — but Maury was the first to produce a scientific chart of the major currents. It was based on thousands of observations recorded by seamen and was, in a sense, an expanded version of the Gulf Stream chart printed in 1769 by Benjamin Franklin after consulting a Nantucket skipper.

headline: France Approaches the End of a Presidential Campaign With a Bitter Debate
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and his Socialist challenger, François Hollande, clashed bitterly on Wednesday night in their only televised debate before Sunday’s election, with accusations of lying, calumny and arrogance marking a detailed discussion of French economic and social policy.

headline: Lottery Numbers
At Espada Trial, Jurors’ Notes Hint at Clash in Deliberations
text: A federal jury considering whether former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. is guilty of embezzling hundreds of thousands of dollars from a nonprofit health care network to support his lavish lifestyle is showing signs of discord after three days of deliberations without a verdict.

headline: Back Home for His First Start
text: David Phelps is making his first big league start Thursday, but he will be doing so in familiar territory. A St. Louis native, Phelps will have plenty of family and friends on hand when he takes the mound for the Yankees against the Royals in Kansas City.

headline: A Car Chase, Secret Talks and Second Thoughts
text: BEIJING — Injuries suffered in the course of a daring nighttime escape. A covert appeal from underground activists to top State Department officials for humanitarian protection. A car chase through the streets of Beijing to spirit a dissident to safety inside the fortified American Embassy.

headline: Court Urged to Order Decision on Nuclear Waste Site
text: WASHINGTON — Two states with large amounts of military and civilian nuclear waste told a federal court panel on Wednesday that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was flouting the law by declining to decide whether the Nevada desert is a suitable burial spot — even if the Obama administration says the storage plan is dead.

headline: Zoning Slows Mayor’s Plan to Remake Willets Point
text: The Bloomberg administration has spent more than $130 million in recent years trying to speed up the redevelopment of a pockmarked, 13-block stretch of auto repair shops near Citi Field in Queens.

headline: You Put the Spell on Me
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This is one of those days that I have been looking forward to for quite a long time. Today I get to introduce you to a very talented young man who is making his debut today, but whom I’ve had the pleasure of getting to know over the past couple of years.

headline: How Chemicals Affect Us
text: Scientists are observing with increasing alarm that some very common hormone-mimicking chemicals can have grotesque effects.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders in City Seek Candidate for Mayor
text: Saying that the likely Democratic candidates for mayor are too liberal for the average New York voter, the city’s five Republican county chairmen said Wednesday that they wanted to identify by the fall a candidate to run on the Republican line.

headline: ‘The Scream’ Is Auctioned for a Record $119.9 Million
text: It took 12 nail-biting minutes and five eager bidders for Edvard Munch’s famed 1895 pastel of “The Scream” to sell for $119.9 million, becoming the world’s most expensive work of art ever to sell at auction.

headline: Old Owner of Dodgers Not a Popular Topic With New Owners
text: The new owners of the Los Angeles Dodgers had nearly escaped their first news conference on Wednesday without discussing their predecessor, Frank McCourt, when questions were asked about his continued role with the team: he still owns half the land surrounding Dodger Stadium, including the parking lots.

headline: California: Faculty Agrees to Campus Strike in the Fall
text: Faculty members in the California State University system said Wednesday that they had approved plans for a two-day rolling strike at campuses all over the state. The California Faculty Association, which represents professors, lecturers and librarians at the system’s 23 universities, has been negotiating with administrators for new contract for nearly two years. Union officials said that the strike was endorsed by 95 percent of the 12,500 members who voted last month. The rolling strike, which would not take place until the fall, would be the largest faculty strike in the state’s history and would take place over two days at each campus, ultimately affecting more than 400,000 students. The state has cut roughly $970 million from the California State University system since 2008, and university officials have responded by lowering the number of students admitted and raising tuition 23 percent. The union has asked for a 1 percent raise and says that administrators have asked to freeze faculty salaries, which have not increased since 2008.

headline: Virtual Kentucky Derby
text: A virtual simulation of the latest Derby champions racing against each other.

headline: A Slower Rise for the Renminbi
text: The Chinese government kept its currency from appreciating during the financial crisis but allowed it to rise in 2010.

headline: Are We Headed for a Cold War With China?
text: Do recent human rights cases and the standoff in the South China Sea point to a larger conflict on the horizon?

headline: Fallout of Bin Laden Raid: Aid Groups in Pakistan Are Suspect
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — In the shadows of the American operation that killed Osama bin Laden, the fate of a small-town Pakistani doctor recruited by the C.I.A. to help track the Qaeda leader still looms between the two countries, a sore spot neither can leave untouched.

headline: Report Points to Decline in Ability to Monitor the Earth
text: Earth-observing systems operated by the United States have entered a steep decline, imperiling the nation’s monitoring of weather, natural disasters and climate change, a report from the National Research Council warned Wednesday. Long-running and new missions are frequently delayed, lost or canceled because of budget cuts, launching failures, disorganization and changes in mission design and scope, the report said. “It’s likely our capabilities will decline fairly precipitously at just the time they’re most needed,” said Dennis Hartmann, a professor of atmospheric sciences at the University of Washington and the chairman of the committee that produced the report. He mentioned the continuing federal budget crisis, the aging of equipment, a severe shortage of medium-size satellite launchers, and some initiatives that cost billions of dollars without producing results.

headline: Orioles No Pushover for Yankees This Year
text: For years, the Yankees had been able to rely on their series against Baltimore to improve their record and pad their statistics. But the Orioles are leaving Yankee Stadium this week with two victories in three games and some momentum in the American League East.

headline: A Brooklyn Constellation
text: A sampling of the connections among Aaron and Bryce Dessner, curators of the Crossing Brooklyn Ferry festival, and some of the artists performing in it.

headline: Outfield Still in Flux
text: The Yankees’ outfield will remain in flux for at least a little longer. Brett Gardner is expected to travel to Kansas City with the team, but he will not be activated off the disabled list for at least the first two of the team’s four games against the Royals.

headline: Corrections: May 3
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: He’s a Heavyweight, and Willing to Say So
text: Jonathan Broxton is not the first pitcher to weigh 300 pounds; he is the first to admit it.

headline: The Long Way Home
text: With airlines cutting back direct service to small and midsize airports, passengers trying to save money are left with longer and more complicated flights.

headline: Foul Play Ruled Likely in Case of Spy Found Dead in Bag
text: LONDON — Deepening the mystery surrounding the death of a reclusive MI6 agent found doubled up inside a padlocked duffel bag in his London flat, a coroner said on Wednesday that it was unlikely that the case would ever be solved, but that the “balance of probabilities” suggested that he had been unlawfully killed. Scotland Yard reacted immediately by saying it would continue its efforts to hunt down the killer.

headline: Imprisoned Ethiopian Journalist Is Honored With PEN Award
text: As many of his colleagues fled Ethiopia’s crackdown on the news media, Eskinder Nega stayed to write.

headline: Sitting Around, Having a Drink, Joking About Sex. On Iraqi TV.
text: BAGHDAD — The concept of the television program was subversive by Iraqi standards: a comedy daring enough to joke about sex and relationships.

headline: State Officials Looking at Long Island Fire as Arson
text: Less than a month after a sprawling fire on Long Island damaged at least 10 homes and forced many residents to evacuate, officials have characterized the blaze as arson, a spokeswoman for the state’s Department of Environmental Conservation said.

headline: Corruption Case Hits Hard in a Tough Time for Greece
text: ATHENS — When the authorities detained a former defense minister here last month pending trial, many Greeks found it cause for celebration, a rare case of a “big fish” meeting justice in a political culture widely seen as rife with corruption.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: More Than Meets the Eye
text: The Challenge: Can you solve the mystery of a 56-year-old woman who goes for a routine eye exam but ends up with a diagnosis of a disease she had never heard of and never suspected?

headline: Word of the Day | strut
text: strut •\ˈstrət\• verb and noun

headline: Microsoft Taps Yahoo Scientists for New York Research Lab
text: Microsoft is opening a research lab in New York City, and the back story is a further sign of the brisk market for computing brains these days.

headline: South Korea: North Accused of Sending Jamming Signals to Disrupt GPS
text: South Korean government officials accused North Korea on Wednesday of sending out jamming signals in an apparent attempt to disrupt civilian and military air and ground traffic in the South, forcing 252 commercial flights to switch off their GPS devices. The North has tried to sabotage South Korea’s use of GPS, widely employed in air, sea and ground navigation, at least three times since 2010, the Korea Communications Commission said. The commission said the latest jamming began Saturday, after North Korea’s recent warnings of “special actions” to attack the government of President Lee Myung-bak in South Korea and the South’s conservative news media, which the North accuses of insulting its leadership.

headline: U.N. Resolution Threatens Sanctions Against Sudan and South Sudan
text: The United Nations Security Council approved a resolution on Wednesday threatening Sudan and South Sudan with sanctions if they failed to halt escalating cross-border fighting that was called a “serious threat to international peace.” The resolution demanded the nations resume negotiations on fraught issues like oil sharing to try to stop the violence. Russia and China, which have resisted voting against Sudan in the past, joined in the unanimous passage of the resolution. The resolution also called for both nations to remove their forces from Abyei, arguably the most iconic of numerous contested regions along the border. Last month, hostilities heated up when South Sudan captured the oil-rich region of Heglig from Sudan. It later withdrew, after Sudanese airstrikes and pressure from the international community, but clashes between the two nations continue along the border, as well as inside South Sudan’s territory.

headline: Chinese Media Decry Western Interference in Chen Case
text: HONG KONG — The dramatic departure of the human rights lawyer Chen Guangcheng from his safe harbor at the U.S. Embassy became ever more confused on Thursday, as he seemed to be wavering in his resolve to remain in China.

headline: Honduras: Neglect Cited in Prison Fire
text: The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights said Wednesday that the conditions that led to the Feb. 14 fire that killed 361 people at the Comayagua national prison were the result of decades of neglect of Honduras’s prisons and iron-fisted anticrime policies. A commission delegation that visited the prison and two others late last month concluded that the “most worrisome” problem in Honduras’s prisons was that the authorities had effectively ceded control to the prisoners themselves, in part because guards were not properly trained.  This “has led to high levels of violence and corruption, in a context of absolute impunity,” the commission said. The delegation also found severe overcrowding, as well as unsafe housing and inadequate food, water and medical care.

headline: Ad With Ashton Kutcher As ‘Raj’ Yanked After Outcry
text: An advertising campaign for potato chips that featured the actor Ashton Kutcher playing an “Indian” character named “Raj” in brown makeup with a sing-song accent appears to have been pulled after drawing heavy criticism from Indian-Americans the day it started.

headline: Midnight Lightning Strikes for Gaborik and the Rangers
text: WASHINGTON — Marian Gaborik stood outside the Rangers’ dressing room, exhausted but happy and, most of all, redeemed.

headline: Farewell to a Friendly Figure From the Knicks’ Past
text: Few people who have ever worked at Madison Square Garden were as warm and generous as Fuzzy Levane, but it was the pro basketball team occupying the arena to which Levane actually provided his most lasting gift.

headline: Why First-Time Parents Overspend on Baby
text: “What’s the silliest thing you bought for your first baby?”

headline: Rangers-Capitals Replay: Game 3
text: Marian Gaborik scored the winning goal in the third overtime as the Rangers took a two-games-to-one lead in the Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Capitals.

headline: An Army Apart
text: “In the fall of 2007, shortly after retiring as chief of the Indian army, J.J. Singh became president of the Delhi Gymkhana Club, one of those venerable social institutions where, sipping gin at the bar, it is difficult to imagine that the British ever left India,” Hartosh Singh Bal writes in Latitude blog of The New York Times. Pervez Musharraf was the president of Pakistan at the time, and the joke of the day was: “See what distinguishes the two countries? While one army chief moves on to head a nation, the other moves on to head a social club,” Mr. Bal writes.

headline: News Quiz | May 3, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Britons Vote in Bellwether Midterm Ballot
text: At a time of deepening austerity, social cutbacks and political fallout from the long-running phone hacking scandal, Britons went to the polls on Thursday in bellwether mayoral and local council votes seen as likely to offer a midterm judgment — and most likely a rebuke — to the country’s first coalition government since World War II.

headline: Societe Generale Profit Drops 20% in First Quarter
text: 4:57 a.m. | Updated

headline: May 3, 1971 | Mayday Tribe Holds Antiwar Demonstration
text: On May 3, 1971, police clashed with antiwar protesters who called themselves “the Mayday Tribe,” and staged three days of demonstrations in Washington aimed at shutting down the nation’s capital.

text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, “At Binghamton University, Halt to Pledging Amid Hazing Concerns.”

headline: From China, Activist Pleads for Help in Call to U.S. Hearing
text: BEIJING — Chen Guangcheng, the blind dissident lawyer at the heart of a diplomatic crisis between China and the United States, telephoned in to a Congressional hearing on Thursday to plead for help in leaving his country.

headline: Jozy Altidore: Blogs and Kisses
text: I’m back.

headline: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan’s Budget
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: It’s Usually Woeful to Be the King
text: Maybe you want to be a king in New York. Who wouldn’t? Think of the power, the perks, the crown, the parties in the Hamptons, where even bush-league royals make the gossip columns. If you’re a king in New York and you ask some peasant how to get to Carnegie Hall, you think he’s going to crack wise and answer “practice”?

headline: Do You Prefer Your Tacos ‘Authentic’ or ‘Appropriated’?
text: America is a melting pot, a massive mash-up of culinary traditions that often combine in unprecedented ways. What is your favorite ethnic food? Has it been embraced by the American mainstream?

headline: The House That Sabri Built
text: BEIT IJZA, West Bank — One of the first statements under oath that I took for Al Haq, a human rights organization I helped establish, was from Sabri Garaib, a farmer from Beit Ijza, a Palestinian village ten miles northwest of Jerusalem. I remember sitting on the porch of his house overlooking the garden and the low, undulating hills planted with wheat and barley that spread out on all sides. All 112 acres, I was told, were in danger of being expropriated by the new Jewish settlement of Givon Hahadasha.

headline: Koovagam’s Non-Stop Party Comes With Chaos
text: Religious festivals in India are typically explosive affairs, but few pack the surreal punch of Koovagam. The tiny village of Koovagam, burrowed in between hazy green fields, and approachable only by a single stretch of winding dirt road, is isolated enough to form what amounts to a 24 hour party fortress: You can come to the village to celebrate, but save for the select groups who commission a bus – you’re very simply trapped there until morning.

headline: Does India Deserve the Government it Has?
text: Once upon a time in France there was a poor man named Valjean who stole because his family was starving. He was caught and put in prison. After his escape and many tribulations, he became a successful businessman – and more importantly, a very good man. Later, he even became the much-respected mayor of his town. However, there was a police inspector, Javert, who never forgot or forgave him and continued to hunt him down for a large part of both their lives.

headline: The Ethicist Contest Winner: Give Thanks for Meat
text: A few weeks ago, we invited readers to make an argument for the ethics of eating meat. Thousands of readers submitted essays, and thousands more voted on the finalists that we posted online. Our panel of judges — Mark Bittman, Jonathan Safran Foer, Andrew Light, Michael Pollan and Peter Singer — chose the essay below as the winner. It will be published in the May 6 issue of the magazine.

headline: The Soft-Shell Hard Sell
text: Although fish come and go according to the season, seafood has become, like many other foods, a global commodity that can be had at any time. The soft-shell crab remains an exception. Starting in May and throughout the summer, the blue crab abandons its shell and starts to form a new one, making its sweet, briny, delicious meat — usually incredibly tough to get at — immediately accessible. When the crab is molting, in fact, practically the whole thing is edible, and the new shell is among the best parts. The combination of tenderness and crunch makes it one of the great delights of eating. (If you’re squeamish about this, I suggest you get over it, or swear off animal products altogether.)

headline: Honey, I Got a Year’s Worth of Tuna Fish
text: Forty-five minutes before midnight on a wintry Tuesday evening, Cathy Yoder and Monica Knight, a pair of 30-something Boise women who run a popular coupon blog called Fabulessly Frugal, strode with purpose through the parking lot of their local Albertsons supermarket. It was the third and final night of “doubles” at Albertsons. This biweekly happening, during which the store issues coupons that double the value of manufacturers’ coupons, is to dedicated coupon clippers what the full moon was to Druids. Yoder and Knight, who are Mormon and have nine children between them (Yoder: seven; Knight: two) had spent the day working on their blog and then taught a three-hour couponing class — all without a drop of forbidden caffeine. Yet with the supermarket in sight, they grew visibly jazzed, like Vegas high rollers entering a casino. “We’ll have it all to ourselves, and we’ll know all the cashiers,” Knight said.

headline: The Meat You Eat
text: Is it ethical to eat meat? That short question, posed in these pages a few weeks ago, inspired a debate heated enough to roast a fatted calf (or a really enormous zucchini, depending on your dietary orientation).

text: Tom Gauld, who illustrates our weekly Riff column, has just released “Goliath” — “the story of David and Goliath from the giant’s point of view,” according to his Web site. The graphic novel was published by the Montreal bookshop and small press Drawn and Quarterly, and a sampling of its pages, below, demonstrates how Gauld can use simple, clever visuals to explore the larger, more complicated issues of war and heroism.

headline: Daily Report: Europeans Rethink Their Google Inquiries
text: European privacy regulators said Wednesday that they were considering reopening their inquiries into Google’s collection of personal e-mails and Web searches for its Street View service, reports Kevin J. O’Brien in Thursday’s New York Times. The move came after revelations that collecting the Internet data had not been a lone programmer’s error, and that others at the company had been told about it.

headline: A Weight Hobbling G.M.
text: DETROIT — General Motors posted its ninth consecutive profitable quarter on Thursday. But almost three years after its taxpayer bailout and bankruptcy, the nation’s biggest automaker still can’t shed the stigma of being “Government Motors.”

headline: Boho Brooklyn, 1940s Edition
text: “NO opera plot can be sensible,” W. H. Auden wrote, “for people do not sing when they are feeling sensible.” More than any major poet of his era, Auden, who died in 1973, dabbled in serious forms of musical drama. Opera’s wildness and implausibility took him places where poems, or intellect alone, couldn’t go. He longed, on occasion, to break into song.

headline: Superheroes, Super Battles, Super Egos
text: Scientists estimate that we reached Peak Superhero in the summer of 2008, when “The Dark Knight” sucked the attention of every critic, pundit and sentient moviegoer into its inky nexus. It is not as if the number of movies featuring troubled guys wearing costumes and fighting evil has diminished since then. Quite the contrary. But the genre, though it is still in a period of commercial ascendancy, has also entered a phase of imaginative decadence. (Do you really want to have an argument about this? If so, put on your best oversize metal suit and wait for me at the top of the New York Times building. I’ll be there as soon as I finish beta-testing my death ray. Apologies in advance to any commuters crushed by flying debris.) The latest evidence — though it is unlikely to be the last, with a new “Spider-Man” and another “Dark Knight” looming on the horizon — is “Marvel’s The Avengers.”

headline: Any Given Sunday
text: For Matt Abramcyk, a co-owner of TriBeCa hot spots like Tiny’s and the recently opened Super Linda, and a former owner of the Beatrice Inn, it’s hard not to bring work home. When he hosts a brunch party with his wife, Nadine Ferber (she’s a co-founder of the nail salon Tenoverten and runs the West Village shop Mick Margo), Abramcyk is in charge of the drinks, music and lighting. The flowers, food and table are all Ferber’s territory — most of the time, anyway. She recalls a potluck with a “pretty odd mix of moderately tasty dishes,” and lots of alcohol. “Before we knew it, we had the ’80s station blasting and a full-on dance party in our living room.” More…

headline: The Big Top | Frieze New York’s Super Structure
text: Today is the official opening of the first Frieze Art Fair in New York, which boasts 182 exhibitors from 30 countries. While the fair’s original location in Regent’s Park, London, is a well-known destination, for New York the fair’s organizers chose a spot that may seem obscure even to locals: Randalls Island, a barely one-square-mile island in the East River. Frieze has a history of working with renowned architects, like David Adjaye and Carmody Groake, to design a new tent each year. This time, the commission went to the Brooklyn architecture firm SO-IL, whose partners, Florian Idenburg and Jing Liu, cut their teeth on projects like the Derek Lam headquarters in SoHo, the summer 2010 courtyard installation at MoMA/PS1 and the New Museum (where Idenburg was the project architect for SANAA). The Moment caught up with Liu to find out more about the Frieze project, the challenges of its location and how the first tent they ever designed turned out to be a colossal one.

headline: European Central Bank Opposes Higher Taxes
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Ahead of crucial elections this weekend in France and Greece, Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, warned governments on Thursday against the “easier road” of raising taxes to fill public coffers, saying it would not solve Europe’s economic problems.

The men were sheepishly drawn to a football hero and reverently requested an autograph or fumbled with their phones and digital cameras for a moment with Bradshaw. Women were attracted to his big, open smile and larger-than-life personality.

headline: Russian General Makes Threat on Missile-Defense Sites

headline: Mitch McConnell Praises Citizens United
text: Long before he became the Republican leader, Senator Mitch McConnell had built a career out of opposing limits to political fundraising and spending, supposedly in the name of free speech. By helping reduce barriers to the purchase of influence in Washington, he became one of his party’s most adept money raisers.

headline: My Mom Was My Roommate
text: The last time I slept alone, it was in a crib. Ever since then, I shared a bed with my mother. And this was in Washington Heights, a Manhattan neighborhood known for its relatively affordable and spacious apartments.

headline: Color Me My Way
text: Next month, pop culture’s court painter, LeRoy Neiman, turns 91, an occasion he’ll celebrate by publishing an often amusing autobiography, “All Told” (Lyons Press, $30). “Plenty of others have had their say about me and my art, for better or worse,” Neiman said in an e-mail interview, perhaps alluding to critics who have dismissed as commercial his crazy-colored renderings of athletes, presidents and Playboy Bunnies. “But until now, I’ve never told my own story.”

headline: Jazz Fest, but With Food on the Big Stage
text: NEW ORLEANS — Gourmands at the jazz fest here have been known to buy sacks of cracklings to eat as they approach the cochon de lait po’boy stand, then add them as a crunchy topper to the sandwiches of suckling pig on French bread slathered with mayonnaise and coleslaw. The 43-year-old festival, which ends this weekend, is as much about the food as it is about the music. Maybe more.

headline: This Sunday: A Video Introduction to The Money Issue
text: In the magazine’s Money Issue, Adam Davidson writes about a former partner of Mitt Romney’s at Bain Capital who thinks that income inequality isn’t the problem with the U.S. economy; it’s part of the solution. The issue also includes Nicholas Confessore on Barack Obama’s courtship of Wall Street, Amanda Fortini on coupon-clipping as the key to economic growth, Keith O’Brien on how McDonald’s came back from the bring of a public relations nightmare (going online tomorrow) and Pietra Rivoli on the business of going broke.

headline: Nimble Clown Playing Old in Rough-and-Tumble Role
text: TAKE a floppy-haired Muppet. Dress it as a waiter. Rearrange its face until its features slope to one side. Throw it across the room. Repeatedly. If that puppet came to life it might look something like the actor Tom Edden in the British comedy “One Man, Two Guvnors,” now on Broadway at the Music Box Theater.

headline: The Samurai Shopper | Pepper Sprays
text: The Samurai Shopper considers shopping a sprightly exercise in privilege and discretion: acquiring this, admiring that, refining one’s taste or accommodating swings in shape or weight. Occasionally, the acquisition trail swarms with bargain-hungry hordes out to spoil the genteel pleasures of getting and spending. At a blowout sale recently, one agitated shopper wielded pepper spray to temporarily blind a competitor in a stream of red hot chili juice.

headline: Breaking Down the Rangers’ Marathon Game
text: On Wednesday night and into Thursday morning the Rangers and the Capitals played the longest game so far in these N.H.L. playoffs, a three-overtime, 114-minute masterpiece of frantic saves, bloodied jerseys, blocked shots, hard checks and hit posts.

headline: More Teenagers Use ‘Highly Effective Contraception’
text: Teen pregnancy rates are at a 30-year-low (and births to teenage mothers are down as well, to 34.3 births per 1,000 girls 15 to 19 years old in 2010, the lowest rate since the government began keeping track in 1940). Today, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released numbers offering one possible reason for those positive trends: more sexually experienced teenagers reported current use of highly effective contraceptive methods (intrauterine device, implant, pill, patch, ring or injectable contraceptive).

headline: Ghost Story ‘Rebecca,’ Halted by Mortal Problems, Sets New Broadway Dates
text: It may not yet have its lead actors, but the long-awaited, long-delayed Broadway production of “Rebecca” has an opening date of Nov. 18 at the Broadhurst Theater, its press representatives said on Thursday. “Rebecca,” a musical version of the Daphne du Maurier novel (which was also adapted into the Alfred Hitchcock film) had been scheduled to start performances at the Broadhurst on March 27 and open on April 22. It would have starred Tam Mutu as the well-to-do Maxim de Winter and Sierra Boggess as his new wife (known in the musical only as “I”), who joins him at the estate that may be haunted by the ghost of his first spouse.

headline: Dewey Deal Lawyer Decamps to White & Case
text: Morton A. Pierce, a powerful vice chairman at Dewey & LeBoeuf, is departing the troubled law firm.

headline: Many Colleges Are Still Taking Applications for the Fall

headline: Netrebko Withdraws From ‘Don Giovanni’ in Berlin, Citing Another Role: Mother
text: The soprano Anna Netrebko has dropped out of a sold-out high-profile run of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” at the Staatsoper in Berlin – and ticket-buyers will receive compensation. Ms. Netrebko, in a press release on Thursday on the opera house’s Web site, apologized but said she had had a “very busy year” and needed to spend time with her 3-year-old son, Tiago. The company said Maria Bengtsson would take over for Ms. Netrebko, who was to have sung the role of Donna Anna. Five performances are planned from June 24 to July 6.

headline: Readers Respond on How a Web Site Builds Trust
text: I recently wrote here about Ridejoy, an online service that matches riders who need a ride with drivers who have space in their cars. The post looked at the company’s Web site and highlighted two crucial challenges: one, how to make the site seem inviting and simple enough that first-time visitors will get the idea and start using it and, two, how to overcome natural concerns about putting two strangers in the same car.

headline: Flowers in the Hospital
text: Flowers were one of the first things my immigrant mother noticed about American hospitals when she gave birth to me, her first child. Some of her fellow patients had so many plants and bouquets that their rooms felt like greenhouses; others had only a single bloom on their nightstands. But each of those flowers, my mother would later say whenever she insisted on floral offerings for hospitalized friend and relatives, meant “there is someone out there who cares.”

headline: Why Fouls Are a Major Factor in Heat-Knicks Series
text: Through the first two games of the playoffs, there has been much consternation about Miami’s notable free throw advantage over the Knicks, with the Heat having twice as many foul shots (60) as New York (30). The deficit,  including a 33-11 free-throw differential in Game 1, was reflected a 48-34 disparity  in personal fouls.

headline: Calls Grow for Cardinal in Ireland to Resign
text: DUBLIN — Pressure is building on the leader of the Catholic Church in Ireland, Cardinal Sean Brady, to resign in the wake of damaging accusations made against him in a BBC television documentary about his role in a secret inquiry into clerical sexual abuse.

headline: Neil Gaiman: By the Book
text: What book is on your night stand now?

headline: More on the Science of Clouds and Climate
text: In a recent article, I mentioned that scientists are trying to use historical records and data sets to get a better handle on how clouds might respond to the warming of the planet.

headline: An Old-School Move for an Innovative Group
text: The business of photojournalism was entering a period of profound change in 2001 when seven noted photojournalists got together to form the VII Photo Agency.

headline: Bobby Cannavale to Return to Broadway in Clifford Odets’s ‘Big Knife’
text: The Tony Award-nominated actor Bobby Cannavale (“The ____________ With the Hat”) is coming back to Broadway next year in the Roundabout Theater Company revival of the Clifford Odets play “The Big Knife,” the theater announced on Thursday. Directed by Doug Hughes, the play, set in the 1940s, stars Mr. Cannavale as Charlie Castle, a successful Hollywood actor who holds a secret that threatens to end his career.

text: “I studied MAD the way some kids studied the Talmud,” Art Spiegelman wrote in one of his graphic novels.

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Sequel ‘Catching Fire’ Finds Its Director
text: If the director Francis Lawrence can make us believe in Robert Pattinson and Reese Witherspoon as Depression-era strivers who fall in love against the backdrop of a traveling circus, as he did in “Water for Elephants,” then presumably he can do anything. For his next moviemaking trick Mr. Lawrence, whose films also include “I Am Legend,” will take the reins of the “Hunger Games” franchise and direct its second installment, “Catching Fire,” the studio Lionsgate said on Thursday.

text: To the Editor:

text: Brooks Atkinson’s original 1946 review of Eugene O’Neill’s play.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Iceman Cometh'
text: Nathan Lane and Brian Dennehy in a scene from the Eugene O’Neill play, directed by Robert Falls at the Goodman Theater in Chicago.

headline: Is Yucca Mountain Still Dead?
text: As I reported in this article, two states with big volumes of military and civilian nuclear wastes are suing the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to try to force it to adhere to the terms of the Nuclear Waste Policy Act, which called for the development of a waste repository at Yucca Mountain, near Las Vegas.

headline: Samsung Unveils New Version of Its Biggest Phone Hit
text: Samsung, the world’s largest phone maker, released details on Thursday of a new smartphone, the Galaxy S III. It’s the third version of the manufacturer’s most successful smartphone.

headline: The Drama King
text: William C. Rhoden says LeBron James is a hard-working stage performer on the basketball court, playing to the crowd and often overacting.

headline: A Hiker’s Guide to Healing
text: WHEN I was packing to leave college in the spring of my freshman year, shoving jeans and T-shirts and mittens into my suitcase and crying, I spoke with my parents on the phone. I told them I was unimpressed by school. I told them I was cold in Colorado, even in April. But I’d already told them what really made me decide to leave: I had been raped.

headline: A Wonderfully Exciting Game That Just Happens to Kill Its Own Stars
text: Could concussions hurt football as badly as steroids did baseball?

headline: U.S. Study Cites Worries on Readiness for Cyberattacks
text: WASHINGTON — A study commissioned by President Obama to assess the nation’s ability to respond to terrorist attacks and man-made and natural disasters has found that state and local officials have the most confidence in their public health and medical services but are the most concerned about whether agencies can respond to cyberattacks.

headline: The Racket Is Optional
text: Venus Williams, 31, has won 43 Women’s Tennis Association tour titles, including 7 singles Grand Slams. Ms. Williams grew up in Compton, Calif., and lives in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., where she recently reintroduced her tennis apparel line, EleVen. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: Selling the Xbox as if It Were a Cellphone
text: Usually people have to plunk down two or three hundred bucks to buy a new video game console. Microsoft is about to see what happens when it tries to sell its Xbox game system more the way it would a cellphone, giving customers a break on the cost of the device as long as they commit to pay a monthly service bill.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Moves Past NBC’s ‘The Voice’
text: Just a day after announcing that it would pattern a new dating show called “The Choice” after NBC’s singing competition “The Voice,”the Fox network on Thursday was greeted by news that with this week’s ratings results, “American Idol” has regained its spot as the top-rated show on television – surpassing, yes, “The Voice.”

headline: State Attorney General Sues Foundation for Retired Racehorses
text: The New York attorney general Thursday sued the directors of the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, one of the largest nonprofit organizations devoted to retired racehorses, saying they had driven the foundation into insolvency and failed to provide money for the basic care of the more than 1,100 horses in their control.

headline: For Florida’s Gabi Wiegand, a Risk Pays Off
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — Gabi Wiegand is feeling pretty good about becoming a Gator.

headline: A Son in the Morning and a Game at Night
text: Forty minutes before Thursday night’s playoff game between the Knicks and the Miami Heat, Chris Bosh’s No. 1 Heat jersey hung in an otherwise empty locker inside the visiting locker room at Madison Square Garden. Bosh’s absence was understandable. About 16 hours earlier, his wife, Adrienne, had given birth in Miami to the couple’s first child, a son, Jackson.

headline: Young People Are Watching Less TV, Though Still 100 Hours a Month
text: The rate of television viewership among young people continued to decline through the end of last year, according to ratings data released by the Nielsen Company on Thursday.

headline: Leonard Cohen to Kick Off Tour on Halloween
text: Leonard Cohen will play Madison Square Garden in Manhattan and Barclays Center in Brooklyn in December at the end of a tour to promote his new album, “Old Ideas,” Rolling Stone reported. The tour will start in Austin, Tex., on Oct. 31 and end with the shows in New York on Dec. 18 and 20.

headline: Wheelies: The Lapine Memoriam Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Q.& A. With Misty May-Treanor
text: Misty May-Treanor is a two-time Olympic gold medalist in beach volleyball who has won more tournaments than any other female player. May-Treanor and her longtime teammate, Kerri Walsh, are teaming up again for the London Games this summer in pursuit of what would be their third gold medal. May-Treanor, who is on the international beach volleyball circuit and wrapping up her master’s degree in coaching and athletic administration at Concordia University, said she has never been to London, except for the airport, even as a tourist.

headline: Many Parents Are Financially Supporting Adult Children After College, Study Finds
text: Some news that might be of interest to parents: Most baby boomers have allowed their adult children to move back home after college graduation, rent free, according to a new study.

headline: Former Player’s Suicide Won’t End His Widow’s Fight
text: RICHMOND, Va. — For Mary Ann Easterling, the prudent and less painful options, it might seem, are to move away and move on.

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., Facebook Sets Price Range at $28 to $35
text: 3:43 p.m. | Updated After shying away from the public markets for years, Facebook is ready for its debut.

headline: Discovery Buys Revision3, Producer of Web Video Series
text: Discovery Communications said Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Revision3, a leading producer of Web video series.

headline: Politico Makes the Call: New Obama Biography ‘Dangerous’
text: Politico on Thursday morning led its site with a photo of a concerned President Obama under the headline “The Dangerous New Obama Book,” over an article about the new biography from The Washington Post writer David Maraniss. Instead of offering any specifics of what dangers Mr. Obama faces – after all, the book itself hasn’t come out yet, though a few excerpts have appeared — it purports to reflect a low-grade anxiety among Obama advisers.

headline: Island’s Genetic Quirk: Dark Skin, Blond Hair
text: In the Solomon Islands, about 10 percent of the dark-skinned indigenous people have strikingly blond hair. Some islanders theorize that the coloring could be a result of excess sun exposure, or a diet rich in fish. Another explanation is that the blondness was inherited from distant ancestors — European traders and explorers who came to the islands.

headline: Forces Storm University in Syria During Protest, Killing at Least 4, Activists Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A violent clampdown by Syrian security forces against a student demonstration at Aleppo University ended with at least four students killed, including one heaved out a fifth-floor window, and scores arrested, activists and opposition organizations said Thursday.

headline: Tortured Logic
text: The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals has issued a disappointing ruling that may complicate any future effort to hold Bush administration officials responsible for their immoral and unconstitutional treatment of prisoners after Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Palestinians Go Hungry to Make Their Voices Heard
text: KHARAS, West Bank — The newest heroes of the Palestinian cause are not burly young men hurling stones or wielding automatic weapons. They are gaunt adults, wrists in chains, starving themselves inside Israeli prisons.

headline: Secretary of Defense on Climate, Foresight and the National Interest
text: It’s worth noting Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta’s remarks on energy, climate and security last night at an Environmental Defense Fund event honoring the Defense Department for its work on the intersection of these issues. Here’s an excerpt:

headline: Bin Laden’s End, From the Beginning
text: When members of the Navy’s elite SEAL Team 6 stormed Osama bin Laden’s compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, a year ago and took out the leader of Al Qaeda with two precision shots, they ended an unprecedented decade-long manhunt for the terrorist.

headline: Graphic Language: Reviewing and Creating From the Work of Christoph Niemann
text: Overview | How do illustrators translate information, concepts, narratives and emotions into images? How can these images communicate differently than words? In this lesson, students apply questions like these to a close analysis of the work of Christoph Niemann, as shown in his Abstract Sunday blog. They then make illustrations in small groups and on their own that are a response to, or inspired by, Mr. Niemann’s work.

headline: The Business of Going Broke
text: May 3, 2012 - Catherine Rampell talks to Georgetown University finance and International business professor Pietra Rivoli about the boom time for the business of going broke.

headline: Discussing the Kentucky Derby via Google Plus Hangout
text: Joe Drape, Jay Schreiber and Jim Luttrell of The Times talked with readers in a live Google Plus video hangout to handicap Saturday’s Kentucky Derby and discuss the state of horse racing. Watch a recorded playback above.

headline: Earl Sweatshirt Returns
text: The rapper, a key member of the Odd Future hip-hop collective, has returned to Los Angeles from a stint in Samoa to resume his career as an emerging star.

headline: ‘Julia’ Becomes Vehicle for Obama’s Messaging
text: Nearly 20 years ago, a multimillion-dollar ad campaign created a fictional couple — “Harry and Louise” — to dramatize the dangers of President Bill Clinton’s health care reforms.

headline: TimesCast | Chinese Dissident Seeks Exit
text: May 3, 2012 — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner continued economic talks with China, but they were overshadowed by the Chen Guangcheng case.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Husband Spits Out the Pits!
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: A Hidden Nest for a Power Lunch
text: From the street outside Barneys on Madison Avenue, one would never guess at the power lunches that are taking place above at Fred’s. Diners spotted there include Hillary Rodham Clinton, Christine C. Quinn and Jonathan Tisch.

headline: Romney Assails Obama on Handling of Chen Case
text: PORTSMOUTH, Va. — Mitt Romney criticized the Obama administration on Thursday for its handling of the case of Chen Guangcheng, the blind Chinese dissident lawyer, calling reports coming out of China “a dark day for freedom.”

headline: The Prius V and Its Entune System
text: When our 12-year-old minivan finally gave up the ghost, it was time to go car shopping.

headline: The Evolving Teenage Brain
text: Why do teenagers “behave with such vexing inconsistency: beguiling at breakfast, disgusting at dinner; masterful on Monday, sleepwalking on Saturday?” David Dobbs has compiled the available scientific answers to that question masterfully in “Teenage Brains” for the National Geographic. Teenage brains, he says, are effectively bringing a new operating system online.

headline: The Well Quiz: Are You a Morning Person?
text: How hungry are you when you wake up? Are you dependent on your alarm clock? Find out whether you’re really a lark, a night owl or somewhere in between.

headline: Loeb Accuses Yahoo Officials of Résumé Padding
text: 3:38 p.m. | Updated  with a statement from Yahoo

headline: A Ticket to Barcelona’s Show
text: Culinary wizardry, architectural marvels and more await in the Catalan city by the sea.

headline: Mike Birbiglia’s ‘Sleepwalk With Me’ to Start BAMcinemaFest
text: Twenty New York premieres are among the lineup of 22 films announced Thursday for the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s fourth annual BAMcinemaFest, the selection of new films and special events that runs from June 20 through July 1.

headline: 36 Hours in Barcelona, Spain
text: BARCELONA is always gravitating toward what’s next, what’s new. Sure, the Catalan capital in northeastern Spain is rich with historic sites and classic tourist activities — browsing the centuries-old Boqueria market, studying the works of Picasso and Miró, posing with Gaudí’s frosted fairytale houses in Parc Güell — but the city’s current dynamism is rooted elsewhere. To discover what’s fueling Barcelona right now, look to new contemporary art museums and small galleries. Look to the bold tapas bars and buzzing night life rejuvenating outlying neighborhoods. Look to the new, but make time for old favorites too.

headline: Out-of-State Donations Fueling Kerrey’s Run
text: Perhaps presaging the provenance of his future election pocketbook, former Senator Bob Kerrey, who is seeking to regain his Senate seat in Nebraska, raked in $30,000 over the last few days, all of it from people or groups outside Nebraska.

headline: Report Finds Improvement in Credit Scores
text: 5/4/12 | Updated to correct a figure.

headline: TimesCast | Author Robert Caro
text: May 3, 2012 - In the latest installation of his biography of President Lyndon Johnson, Robert Caro explores the power of the presidency.

headline: The Complaint
text: The complaint outlines how the foundation took formal responsibility for more horses than it could afford, despite repeated warnings of financial distress from its own officers.

headline: Hot Italian Sausage
text: Time: About 10 minutes

headline: Farro Pasta With Nettles and Sausage
text: 3 tablespoons olive oil

headline: When Nettlesome Becomes Nice
text: AT the market the other day (a rather chilly spring day), a vendor had gorgeous bunches of wild stinging nettles in addition to a farm-grown bok choy, mustard, pea shoots, dandelion and young chard. Because I adore the flavor of nettles, the choice was easy. And somehow I knew immediately that what I wanted to make for dinner was a bowl of earthy farro pasta with nettles.

headline: Up Front
text: When Julia Glass’s first novel, “Three Junes,” was the surprise winner of the National Book Award for fiction in 2002, the stunned author’s initial words, upon reaching the podium, were wonderfully telling: “I think I felt emotions this intense only two other times in my life, and that’s when my newborn baby sons were put in my arms. Only a whole lot fewer people were watching.”

headline: No Charges for Officer in Killing of Man, 68
text: A grand jury voted not to indict a White Plains police officer who shot and killed a 68-year-old former correction officer and former Marine in his apartment last November, the Westchester County district attorney said Thursday.

headline: Out There | Factory Fresh
