headline: A Student’s Conversation With Michael Mann on Climate Science and Climate Wars
text: Casey Doyle, a student at Warren Wilson College who writes for the Swannanoa Journal, the publication of the school’s Environmental Leadership Center, had the opportunity to speak with the climate scientist Michael Mann when he visited the campus to speak about his book, “The Hockey Stick and the Climate Wars.”

headline: Together Until the End
text: When a Pennsylvania man who’d spent six years caring for his wife with Alzheimer’s somehow decided in March to kill her and then shoot himself, and their family declared that he’d done so “out of deep devotion and profound love,” I read the news articles with mingled horror and compassion. I’m sure many here shuddered.

headline: International Center of Photography Names New Executive Director
text: The International Center of Photography in midtown Manhattan announced on Thursday that it had appointed a new executive director, Mark Robbins, Dean of the School of Architecture at Syracuse University.

headline: Bronx Man Stopped at Airport After Knife Found on Walker
text: Traveling. You know how it is. You’re late for a flight, you throw your stuff in the car — and you forget to remove the table knife with the four-inch blade that you keep holstered to your walker.

headline: Wall Street Wants More From the JOBS Act
text: The JOBS Act appears to give a generous gift to Wall Street. But Wall Street is now seeking clarification — and further exemptions.

headline: Bank of America Goes With WPP as It Changes Ad Agency Lineup
text: Bank of America, seeking ways to resolve persistent image problems with customers, said on Thursday that it was making a major change to its lineup of advertising agencies.

headline: Manhole Lid Theft Is On the Rise
text: Some residents of the South Richmond Hill neighborhood in Queens were a little suspicious a couple of Sundays ago of the man in the yellow vest using an automotive jack to lift a cast-iron manhole cover out of the street by himself.

headline: TimesCast | Record Price for Artwork
text: May 3, 2012 — On Wednesday night, Edvard Munch’s 1895 pastel, “The Scream” sold for a record price of just under $120 million at Sotheby’s auction house in New York.

headline: Dmitri Young Wants to Help Brother Delmon, and at-Risk Kids
text: Dmitri Young looks at his younger brother, Detroit Tigers outfielder Delmon Young, and knows what he is going through. Delmon is serving a weeklong suspension by Major League Baseball for an incident in Manhattan in which he is accused of directing  anti-Semitic slurs at a panhandler and scuffling with tourists while under the influence of alcohol in the early hours of April 27.

headline: At Rhinebeck Car Show, a Vintage Fiat That’s No Expatriate
text: Rhinebeck, N.Y., a Hudson Valley village founded by Dutch settlers, has a fitting fascination with vintage mechanical things. The Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome houses one of the finest collections of flyable antique aircraft in the United States. And this weekend, the Hudson River Valley Antique Auto Association unofficially kicks off the New York metropolitan area’s collector-car season with its annual Rhinebeck car show and swap meet, held at the nearby Duchess County Fairgrounds.

headline: New Doubts Over Reform as Jordan Shifts Cabinet
text: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II of Jordan swore in a new cabinet this week assigned to make progress on laws allowing for more government posts to be filled by elections, but political activists and analysts here said on Thursday that the quick succession of governments over the past year and a half did not bode well for the prospect of genuine reform.

headline: Bachmann Backs Romney Months After Leaving Race
text: PORTSMOUTH, Va. — Since running against Mitt Romney for the Republican nomination, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota has slowly been changing her tune about the man who has become their party’s presumptive nominee. And at a rally here on Thursday with Gov. Bob McDonnell, Mrs. Bachmann officially threw her support behind Mr. Romney, calling the choice in November between him and President Obama “very easy.”

headline: I.S.S. Endorses Ackman in Fight for Canadian Pacific Railway
text: OTTAWA — Institutional Shareholder Services, the proxy advisory firm, strongly endorsed the activist investor William A. Ackman’s alternative slate of directors for the Canadian Pacific Railway on Thursday as well as his call for a new chief executive.

headline: That Anguished Scottish Family: Toil, Trouble and Maybe Junior
text: And baby made three? In the opening moments of this “Macbeth,” directed by Ron Russell, a home video plays, showing a mother, father and infant. There’s also a photo nearby of those parents, the Macbeths it turns out, gently kissing their baby’s head. A painted version of that image forms a backdrop above the stage.

headline: Koch Gives $35 Million to Smithsonian Natural History Museum
text: The billionaire industrialist and philanthropist David H. Koch has donated a whopping $35 million to the Smithsonian’s National Museum of Natural History in Washington for a complete overhaul of the museum’s dinosaur hall. Mr. Koch, the executive vice president of Koch Industries in Wichita, Kan., has previously showered the history museum on the National Mall as well as the American Museum of Natural History in New York with his largesse.

headline: Infinite Possibilities
text: The Russian-born French designer Maria Pergay created a gleaming ‘‘T’’ out of stainless steel and topped it with a diamond. ‘‘I tried to do it justice,’’ says the 81-year-old artist, who is known for her avant-garde metal furniture. Pergay got her start as a window dresser and says she has a ‘‘big appetite’’ for materials like wood, silver and, especially, stainless steel: ‘‘It is incorruptible, perfectly strong and feminine.’’ In addition to her recent retrospective in Paris, Pergay, who was inducted into the Legion of Honor in February, will celebrate her 55-year career with an exhibition of new and old work at Design Miami/Basel in June.

headline: What’s Good for Gun Manufacturers…
text: If President Obama wins re-election, the 2nd Amendment is dead! Gun owners will be rounded up and herded into Marxist re-education camps! If guns are outlawed, only deer, elk, geese and quail will own guns!

headline: Fish Skipping Olympics to Play in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — At a news conference overlooking the White House at the W Hotel last Tuesday in Washington, the annual A.T.P. tournament held in the city announced that it was changing its name to the Citi Open and that it intended to add a new grandstand court to its grounds.

headline: In Double Reversal, Councilman Re-fires Aide He Had Rehired
text: 7:19 p.m. | Updated In a single whiplash-inducing week, a spokesman for a City Council member was fired, rehired and, on Thursday, fired again, a bizarre turn of events following the revelation that the aide once served a federal prison term for an antiwar arson attack on an Army recruiting center.

headline: MoMA Plans a ‘Garage Sale’ for Its Atrium
text: Often the most popular installations in the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium are the most unusual. There was the time when the performance artist Marina Abramovic sat stock-still for 700 hours, staring at the hundreds of worshipful visitors who came to gaze into her soul. And the time when the artist pair Allora & Calzadilla presented “Stop, Repair, Prepare: Variations on ‘Ode to Joy’ for a Prepared Piano.” The two cut a hole in the case of Bechstein baby grand and set it on casters, then hired musicians to play Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy” from inside the hole while maneuvering the piano slowly through the space. There was also the Danish-Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson’s rotating metal fan, which swung from a cable just above head height.

headline: Oh Nettle, Where Is Thy Sting?
text: What with the current craze for foraged wild foods (or should I say resurgence of interest, since people have been collecting wild edibles since the dawn of history), now is a good time to hunt for stinging nettles. This week’s City Kitchen column has a recipe employing them, paired with nutty-tasting whole grain farro pasta and hot Italian sausage. You can forage for the sausage at a good butcher, but I also give an easy recipe for homemade sausage.

headline: Making a Case to Remember Burr
text: Brian D. Hardison, a lawyer and judge on the outskirts of Atlanta, has built a persuasive case in defense of Aaron Burr. Since the 1990s he has been acquiring mounds of paperwork showing this politician’s sympathetic sides.

headline: Inflation and Joblessness: The Tipping Point
text: Another day, another clue in the quest to understand why the Fed isn’t trying harder to reduce the rate of unemployment:

headline: Kick Up Those Heels
text: IT’S only May, but I’ve already begun thinking about Nov. 4, when I’m scheduled to run the New York City Marathon. I ran it successfully — if less than spectacularly — in 2007, but I went over my five-hour goal by 15 minutes. I knew I would try again, and I know I’ll need help staying motivated. Thankfully, for those seeking the support of a more social running experience, New York has many options.

headline: Months After Stroke, Senator Kirk Leaves Rehab Center
text: CHICAGO — Senator Mark Steven Kirk of Illinois, who suffered a stroke more than three months ago, was released Thursday from a rehabilitation center here, according to a statement from his family.

headline: Back to a Favored Finnish Composer
text: New-music groups often seem to storm through stacks of new scores as if they were airport novels, rarely giving them a second look once they’ve appeared on a program. That may be liberating in the sense that every program creates fresh challenges, but given the amount of work it takes to prepare a performance, it must be frustrating as well.

headline: Loyola Defeats Denver in E.C.A.C. Tournament
text: DENVER–Despite arguably their best fourth-quarter performance of the season, the University of Denver men’s lacrosse team lost, 14-13, in overtime to No. 1 seed Loyola in the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference tournament semifinals Wednesday in Denver. With the loss, the Pioneers lost their chance at an automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: A Piggy Bank Pal?
text: An old friend sent a group message asking if we wanted to go to a Madonna concert. I replied with a resounding yes. She bought the tickets and asked everyone to pay her by a certain date. I asked for an extension (thanks to my rent) and called several times to give her payment updates, but she never called back. Finally, she sent a text message, telling me she had sold my ticket. She thought it was rude that I hadn’t paid on time. I find her behavior shocking and classless. Am I right or wrong?Alexis, Manhattan

headline: A Special, Private Midtown Gallery for Student Artwork
text: A student art show of over 100 pieces is lining the walls of an investment banking firm. The artists are from  40 middle schools and high schools throughout the city. One student said after seeing his photo framed and on display, "I didn't think this would go so far."

headline: A Lot of History for Just One House
text: THE 40-foot-wide house at 163 East 63rd Street is layered with New York history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Syria, Afghanistan and China.

headline: What Is Being Done to Improve Parent Involvement?
text: A parent coordinator writes: These days there is a lot of emphasis on school accountability and teacher accountability. But who is paying attention to parent accountability and finding ways to help parents become more involved? "Someone is always talking, measuring, criticizing -- but not solving," she writes.

headline: Black and White and Red All Over
text: WAS the 1875 Tribune Building a pioneering skyscraper masterpiece, foully demolished in 1966 before the Landmarks Preservation Commission had a chance to save it? Or was it no better than a “sugar refinery,” a “liquor palace” torn down in the 1960s to the near-silence of preservationists?

headline: When Good Movies Are Bad News
text: Here’s Grantland’s Zach Baron on Josh Whedon’s superhero-fest “The Avengers,” which in addition to setting box office records around the world is apparently pretty entertaining:

headline: For Republicans, Clear Approach to Medicare Has Many Sides
text: Among the Republican fiscal hawks, the 2012 election is supposed to be a stark choice between a Republican Party willing to make the tough spending decisions necessary to get the deficit under control and a profligate Democratic Party still relying on “Mediscare” tactics to avoid responsibility.

headline: For Chinese, a Man in the News Is Much Discussed, if Not by Name
text: BEIJING — Those outside of China know him as Chen Guangcheng, the self-trained lawyer whose crusade for individual rights has led him to confinement, escape and, now, an international diplomatic incident. Ordinary people inside China refer to him online in a different, coded way.

headline: The Do-Nothing Caucus
text: Karl Smith gets shrill about Raghu Rajan’s latest (pdf), which he calls “nonsense on stilts.” He’s right — and it’s deeply depressing that stuff like this passes for wisdom.

headline: Behavior Pattern | The Psychology Behind Fashion’s Latest Favorite
text: Few things in fashion are as polarizing as prints. As the designer Lela Rose, who has a history of working with bold prints — for her fall collection, she created a series of grid prints based on the work of the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava — says, “People’s reaction to them is not, ‘Hmm, maybe I’ll wear this and see how it goes.’ You don’t buy a print thinking you’ll learn to like it. It’s love or hate.”

headline: 10+ Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Vogue

headline: My Head Talks Again
text: Lawrence O’Donnell tonight, near the end of the hour, from Princeton.

headline: Enter the Contentment Factor
text: AT first, Blake and Robin Kelly were in no rush to relocate. They had six months remaining on their lease of a three-bedroom house near Daytona Beach, Fla., when Mr. Kelly, who had been studying and working at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, landed a job in New York.

headline: Digital Notes: Singer Raises $450,000 on Kickstarter for Her Album
text: As my colleague Jenna Wortham pointed out on Monday, a smart wristwatch has become the biggest-grossing project on the crowdfunding site Kickstarter, with $8.3 million pledged (and 15 days left to raise money). A new record has also been set in the music category by Amanda Palmer, a singer, keyboardist and occasional ukulele player. She began raising money on Monday to support the marketing of her new album, asking for $100,000. She raised that amount in the first seven hours, and by Thursday afternoon, she had raised more than $450,000, with 28 more days for her fans to contribute. “This is the future of music,” Ms. Palmer declared in a video for her project.

headline: AMC Orders Two New Drama Pilots
text: AMC, home of “Mad Men,” “Breaking Bad” and “The Walking Dead,” has moved deliberately in assembling its celebrated stable of prime-time dramas. So it represented a positive flurry of activity when the cable channel announced Thursday that it had ordered pilots for two new dramas at the same time.

headline: Theater Listings for May 4-10
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spherical Symbol of Resilience Is Going Away, but It’s Unclear Where
text: For the last 10 years, Fritz Koenig’s 25-foot-high “Sphere for Plaza Fountain,” which survived the collapse of the World Trade Center buildings all around it, has been among the most public of memorials to 9/11. Hundreds of people see it daily in its prominent location at Battery Park, meaning that hundreds of thousands have taken the time to study its fissures and dents and scratches and bruises. It is an eloquent emblem of the city’s hours in the crucible and a symbol of its endurance.

headline: A Ride Cloaked in Secrecy
text: Doug Mills was photographing a young equestrian in Middleburg, Va., on Sunday afternoon, when he got a call he couldn’t refuse:

headline: Video Shows Cairo Protesters Were Attacked by Armed Assailants
text: As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh report, Egypt’s military rulers denied on Thursday that they had any role in the attacks on protesters in the Cairo neighborhood of Abbaseya this week that left at least 11 people dead.

headline: Seven Tickets to India, Please, and Reservations for an Adventure
text: “The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel” belongs to the “Enchanted April” school of agreeable grown-up entertainment, in which transplanted Britons shake off the North Atlantic chill on a life-altering trip to warmer climes. Instead of Italy in the 1920s, the place of renewal is Jaipur, India, and the time is now.

headline: Pension Plan Sues Wal-Mart Officials Over Failures
text: One of the nation’s largest pension plans filed a lawsuit Thursday accusing Wal-Mart’s leadership of breaching its fiduciary duty in connection with a bribery scandal at the retailer’s Mexican subsidiary.

headline: When to Refinance Again
text: THOSE who refinanced their mortgages a year or so ago, when interest rates averaged just below 5 percent for a 30-year fixed-rate loan, may be wondering whether it’s time to refinance yet again, now that rates are at least a full percentage point lower.

headline: From the Desk of Osama bin Laden
text: Our colleagues Peter Baker (@peterbakernyt) and Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) write on some juicy reading out today from the Combating Terrorism Center at the United States Military Academy at West Point: a report on a cache of 17 previously classified letters and other documents recovered from Osama bin Laden’s compound in Pakistan.

headline: Movie Listings for May 4-10

headline: Black Journalists Association’s Award for Beyoncé Draws Criticism
text: Beyoncé has sold millions of records and collected a shelf of Grammys, but she is about to add an unexpected award to the list: The New York Association of Black Journalists plans to honor her with a writing award at its annual banquet this month, the group announced on Wednesday.

headline: If I Had the Cash, I Wouldn’t Buy That
text: My first live encounter with “The Scream,” by Edvard Munch, was during a December stay in Oslo several decades ago. After a week of experiencing the sun-starved Norwegian midwinter, all dawn, dusk and oppressive darkness, I felt I knew where Munch’s image of released hysteria was coming from.

headline: Building Blocks of Meaning, Retranslated
text: In a drawing from 1966, “Heaps of Language,” Robert Smithson assembled a pyramid of words about words: “Language” at the apex, supported by “phraseology speech,” “tongue lingo vernacular,” and on down through a base of synonyms. The playful exhibition “Ecstatic Alphabets/Heaps of Language,” opening on Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, borrows Smithson’s title and runs wild with his vision of words as materials.

headline: Q & A
text: Fixing a Hole in the Ceiling

headline: Tracking Ballet’s Pull on Youth Worldwide
text: The tears are often held tremulously back and the many hurts smiled away in “First Position,” an appealing, largely upbeat documentary about young ballet dancers duking it out, sometimes on point and in tulle, for top honors at the Youth America Grand Prix.

headline: Slashes, Scribbles and Delirium
text: Photographs of the peripatetic Italian Modernist Lucio Fontana (1899-1968) often show a neat, slightly imperious man who resembles a successful banker relaxing after work in his starched white shirt, black vest and dark tie. He is outfitted thus in a series of images taken by the Italian photographer Ugo Mulas in 1964. Showing the artist in his studio calmly cutting one of his long signature slashes in a pristine canvas, they give a restrained, dignified start to the extraordinary exhibition of Fontana’s work at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. But look out.

headline: Correspondent Involved in Misleading ‘Today’ Segment Leaves NBC News
text: 7:04 p.m. | Updated Lilia Luciano, a correspondent who was involved in a misleading news report about Trayvon Martin and George Zimmerman in March, is no longer employed by NBC News, the network confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Lessons From the Dean of the School of Improv
text: I recently spoke with the 83-year-old improvising pianist Cecil Taylor for about five hours over two days. One day was at his three-story home in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, where he has lived since 1983. Two female friends worked as his assistants, lighting his cigarettes and bringing him Champagne as he held forth volcanically behind a semicircular desk in his study. The other was at his favorite neighborhood restaurant, where he walked in, looked at the bartender, reacted as if stunned by her beauty for the first time, and kissed her hand. She seemed used to it.

headline: Sparano Can Hardly Wait to Coach Jets’ Offense
text: As the new offensive coordinator Tony Sparano sidestepped questions about Tim Tebow’s role in the Jets’ offense Thursday afternoon,

text: In recent years Karole Armitage’s dances have gone one of two ways: deep, resilient works that validate her keen grasp of technique and craft with an otherworldly, ineffable underpinning, or those that attach themselves to the surface of trend, supported by little more than the veneer of slick bodies.

headline: Bloomberg Budget Calls for More Teachers This Fall, Not Less
text: After losing roughly 5,300 public school teachers to budget cuts over the last several years and watching class sizes rise, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday that he plans to reverse course by providing money to hire more teachers.

headline: Project Space
text: “I used to be really scared of this area,” says the artist Francis Upritchard of London’s Hackney district, where she and the furniture designer Martino Gamper share a charmingly quirky three-story apartment in a public housing project — what the British call a council flat. “When I went with the estate agent, there were eight students living there and it was filthy,” she recalls of the flat, which she bought six years ago. “The living room was two different rooms.”

text: HYDE PARK, N.Y. — If you want to get some sense of how the American presidency has evolved over the last century, take the Roosevelt Ride. It started running here this week near the estate where Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt lived and where the modern presidency began to take shape.

headline: Comic Guerrilla Tries Sticking With the Script
text: Fans and detractors alike will bring the same set of questions to the new Sacha Baron Cohen movie, “The Dictator,” in which he plays Admiral General Aladeen, the tyrannical, extravagantly bearded leader of the fictional Republic of Wadiya. What fresh outrage have we now from this British comic guerrilla who has managed to annoy the Anti-Defamation League, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation and the government of Kazakhstan, to name just a few unamused parties? Who exactly is the joke on this time, and will they get it? And what happens when the most aggressive and confrontational satirist in contemporary comedy has to make do without real-life foils and stooges?

headline: When There Really Is Not a Drop to Drink
text: Jay Famiglietti, one of a handful of expert witnesses in Jessica Yu’s “Last Call at the Oasis,” is a thoughtful scientist with an engaging manner who specializes in water. In particular, he studies — and tries to raise public awareness about — the rapid depletion of water supplies caused by agricultural overuse, rampant development and global climate change. His analyses are thorough and clear, and he presents them, at public meetings and straight to Ms. Yu’s camera, with good-natured patience. For the most part, that is. At one point, contemplating a future of unchecked consumption and political paralysis, he sums it all up in blunt layman’s terms: “We’re screwed.”

headline: Sacha Baron Cohen Won’t Talk but the Supreme Leader of Wadiya Has a Lot to Say
text: Like Borat and Brüno before him, Admiral General Aladeen is not just a character but a months-long, transmedia immersion on the part of its creator, Sacha Baron Cohen. Blurring the lines between performance artist and hype artist, the British comic is promoting his new movie, “The Dictator,” only in full tinpot-tyrant drag. For an article on the film, Mr. Baron Cohen would not comment but he agreed to channel the Supreme Leader of the fictional republic of Wadiya for an in-character interview. Here is the text of the interview, minus a few expletives.

headline: Models for Government
text: To the Editor:

headline: Free Events at Littlefield, and a PEN Reading in Carroll Gardens
text: Around the turn of this century, the Miser knew a saxophonist in Brooklyn who would walk to rehearsals in Park Slope from his home in Carroll Gardens. He would head warily down Union Street, past dead, silent factories and the rusting remains of another era. On the Union Street Bridge he’d pause to hear, carried on the chemically compromised air wafting up from the Gowanus Canal underfoot, the high, lonesome singing of the stray dogs that roamed the neighborhood.

headline: Touring the City With Fresh Eyes
text: JANE STREET in the West Village is just a few blocks from where the author and urban critic Jane Jacobs lived, but it’s named for the farmer who grew tobacco around there more than two centuries ago. Though Jacobs deserves her own namesake street, she will be getting the next best thing this weekend when the Municipal Art Society hosts nearly 70 free walking tours conducted by neighborhood residents in all five boroughs.

headline: Mere Society Paintings? Look Again
text: If, by some fluke of metaphysics, the last four decades of Édouard Vuillard’s long, prolific and rewarding career were erased from collective memory, he still would not be forgotten. Before the age of 30 he made some of the most beguiling paintings of fin de siècle Paris: intimate, compact, brushy pictures of his mother and sister in the apartment he shared with them and the dressmaking shop they worked in. Painting with special attention to wallpaper and fabric patterns, he made people almost dissolve into atomized, flattened surfaces, anticipating a century that would pulverize into air everything once taken for solid.

headline: ‘Ome,’ the Sound of the Scientific Universe Expanding
text: The age of “omes” is here. It began with the genome, continued with the proteome, branched out with the memome and reached full flowering with the notion of the omome.

headline: Dancing on Her Own Grave With a Spring in Her Step
text: There’s so much that’s wrong with “A Little Bit of Heaven,” including its misleading title (think further south and then head toward the ninth circle), that it’s hard to know where to begin. For starters, when did cancer become funny? Not that it’s ever hilarious, even in laugh-lined movies like “Funny People” and “50/50,” to name two comedy-drama amalgams that combine cancer and chuckles in one improbable package. Certainly it isn’t funny in “A Little Bit of Heaven,” a cringe-inducing romantic comedy turned cancer tragedy turned inspirational hosanna about living in the moment, embracing your bliss and other clichés.

headline: Duke Farms
text: A 2,740-acre estate in Hillsborough, N.J., has had a $45 million face-lift.

headline: Treasury Department Sees New Path to Ending Bailout
text: The Obama administration has a new approach for shedding its stake in bailed-out banks: Make it the private sector’s problem.

headline: Lowered Expectations on the Jobs Report
text: What a difference one bad month – and one bad report – can make in expectations.

headline: For International Students, a College Admissions Checklist for May
text: In March, The Choice introduced Counselor’s Calendar, an occasional series intended to keep students on track throughout the college admissions process.

headline: Oh, for a Rug to Sweep Secrets Under
text: “You’re living in sin,” declares Eileen Cleary (Kathleen Turner), a devout Roman Catholic mother, to her lesbian daughter, Shannon (Emily Deschanel), in “The Perfect Family.”

headline: The Roosevelt Ride
text: A new National Park Service shuttle runs near the estate where Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt lived.

headline: Bearing Arms and Cranking Up the Controversy
text: HIDALGO — If controversy could be rolled up and smoked, Ted Nugent would be on oxygen by now.

headline: For Craftsmen, Fragile Lifeline From Craigslist
text: With few places to turn, construction workers have colonized Craigslist as the cyberspace equivalent of the street corner or the Home Depot parking lot.

headline: Japan’s Leaders, Pressed by Public, Fret as Nuclear Shutdown Nears
text: OSAKA, Japan — Barring an unexpected turnaround, Japan this weekend will become a nuclear-free nation for the first time in more than four decades, at least temporarily.

headline: Awkward Love Triangle, With Nanny at Center
text: I worry about “You Hurt My Feelings,” a film you want to wrap your arms around and shelter from a ruthless marketplace. Like something that David Gordon Green might have made before being seduced by more generously financed projects, this fragile sophomore feature, written and directed by Steve Collins, reminds us that watching movies matters much more than listening to them.

headline: Rivera Injured Shagging Flies in Batting Practice
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Mariano Rivera, his face contorted in pain as he lay on the ground next to the center-field wall, was carted off the field Thursday after an apparent injury sustained during batting practice.

headline: Midlife Crisis Solved by Reconnecting With Craft
text: For most people, a midlife crisis is solved by changing careers, partners or therapists. But for the filmmaker Amos Kollek, the depression and artistic stasis that followed the failure of his 2003 film, “Happy End” (also called “Nowhere to Go but Up”), was best countered by once again picking up a camera. This time, however, he turned it on himself.

headline: A Race That’s About Crunching the Numbers
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Warren Campaign Spends Another $800,000 on Ads
text: The Senate campaign in Massachusetts continues at a hectic pace, even though the election is six months away.

headline: Two Legislators Strive to Out-Conservative Each Other for a State Senate Seat
text: Three years ago, State Representatives Todd Smith and Kelly Hancock, both Republicans, were on opposite sides of a fight over how to dig the Dallas-Fort Worth area out of gridlock.

headline: A Malevolent Matriarch and Her Evil Brood
text: Playing an older, more tight-lipped version of the psychotic nanny she embodied in “The Hand That Rocks the Cradle” (1992), Rebecca De Mornay still knows how to twist maternal instincts into grotesque shapes. As the malevolent matriarch in “Mother’s Day” — an unnecessary remake of an unremarkable 1980 shocker — she soothes and sneers with commendable conviction. Unfortunately her cinematic offspring never come close to keeping up.

headline: Woods Struggles but Stays Within Reach
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Webb Simpson said he was nervous playing in Tiger Woods’s group Thursday, but it was Woods who had the shaky game in the first round of the Wells Fargo Championship at Quail Hollow.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Facebook’s $10 Billion Sales Pitch
text: Starting Monday, Facebook executives will travel the country to field questions from prospective investors and  convince them that the social network is worth $86 billion and perhaps a lot more.

headline: Pipe Dreams and Scythe Dreams: Begging Drinks in Hell’s Anteroom
text: CHICAGO — In the muddy darkness that blankets the stage in the opening minutes of “The Iceman Cometh” at the Goodman Theater here, human forms seem to be slumped on battered chairs and tables in the back room of a dingy saloon. Curled or contorted into lifeless poses, they resemble slumbering animals, some starved to the bone, others bloated and sluggish.

headline: Bosnia Still Needs Fixing
text: IN the Bosnian city of Mostar, a beautiful Ottoman-era limestone bridge called the Stari Most arched over the Neretva River for 427 years, surviving earthquakes and two world wars. After a barrage of shelling in 1993, during the Bosnian civil war, the bridge collapsed. Citizens were stranded on opposite sides of the riverbank. Ethnic strain wasn’t the cause. It was the effect. Across the country, the war itself was dividing citizens into three ethno-nationalist clusters: Bosnian Serbs, Bosnian Croats and Bosnian Muslims (Bosniaks). Twenty years after the war began, and 17 years after the Dayton accords brought the fighting to an end, the bridge stands again, and a shallow peace prevails.

headline: Talking to a Child Who Is Overweight, but Unaware
text: Last week, a father asked how he should approach his daughter, who, at 12, he described as both “overweight” and “young for her age.” His hope? To “start a conversation with her without making her feel like there is a problem with her appearance in the world around her.”

headline: How to Get Business to Pay Its Share
text: JAMES MADISON never played with an iPhone, but he might have had something to say about the news last weekend about Apple. Over the last few years, the company has avoided paying billions of dollars in state and federal taxes by routing profits through subsidiaries based in tax havens from Reno, Nev., to the Caribbean.

headline: Map’s Hidden Marks Illuminate and Deepen Mystery of Lost Colony
text: For centuries, the Tidewater coast of North Carolina has held one of early America’s oldest secrets: the fate of more than 100 English colonists who vanished from their island outpost in the late 1500s.

headline: Fuzzy Levane, Fixture of New York City Basketball, Dies at 92
text: Fuzzy Levane, who as a high school and college star and as a coach and scout for the Knicks was a fixture of New York City basketball for a half-century, died on Monday in Irmo, S.C. He was 92.

headline: Poll Shows Competitive Presidential Contest in Virginia
text: Barack Obama won Virginia four years ago, the first time a Democrat had won the state in more than 40 years. This year, it looks like Mr. Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, may have a competitive contest for the state’s 13 electoral votes.

headline: U.S. Chose Better Path to Recovery
text: Last summer, things looked bad on both sides of the Atlantic. There were fears of double-dip recessions, and stubbornly high unemployment rates. Stock markets swooned.

headline: Marshal Tito in Queens
text: I’M a 31-year-old physical therapist living in Astoria, Queens, an American citizen more into “Seinfeld” reruns than bloodthirsty revenge. And yet, 20 years after the start of the Bosnian war that exiled my Muslim family, I still hesitated to buy my lamb prsuta from my neighborhood’s Serbian butcher, until I learned he had been here 30 years. So he couldn’t have been the soldier with the AK-47 who took my father and brother to the concentration camp.

headline: A Vintage Fiat That’s No Expatriate
text: RHINEBECK, N.Y., a Hudson Valley village founded by Dutch settlers, has a fitting fascination with vintage mechanical things. The Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome houses one of the finest collections of flyable antique aircraft in the United States. And this weekend, the Hudson River Valley Antique Auto Association unofficially starts the region’s collector-car season with the annual Rhinebeck car show and swap meet at the nearby Dutchess County Fairgrounds.

headline: Rivera Hurts Knee; Career May Be Over
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — If there has been one constant with the Yankees during the most recent edition of their dynasty, it has been the unparalleled success and durability of their closer, Mariano Rivera.

headline: Brazil Sending More Troops to Guard Amazon Borders
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil is deploying more than 8,500 troops to the far reaches of the Amazon rain forest this month in an operation aimed at cracking down on drug smuggling, gold mining and illegal deforestation, officials said.

headline: 2 Brothers Accused in Huge Theft of Prescription Drugs
text: The largest theft of prescription drugs in United States history, as described by the authorities, was intricately orchestrated and meticulously executed.

headline: A Real Girl, 14, Takes a Stand Against the Flawless Faces in Magazines
text: In Julia Bluhm’s ballet class, girls arrived and often declared that they were having a fat day. Or that their skin was pimply or blemished. Or that they looked disgusting. When she hears complaints in her middle school, where she is in the eighth grade, Julia said, she has one answer: “Are you crazy?”

headline: Nature’s Call Draws Views for a Texan’s Political Ad
text: HOUSTON — Texas politics has never been for the fainthearted. A new Internet ad by an underdog Republican running for a seat on a powerful state commission proves it may not be for the tactful, either.

headline: Even on an Off Day, McIlroy Can Still Shine
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The seventh fairway at Quail Hollow calls to mind the nearby Sugar Mountain ski resort, with so many buds in the air it looks as if it were snowing feathers. It seemed better suited for the snowboarding champion Shaun White than for his new friend Rory McIlroy, who came to the hole Thursday struggling mightily with his swing.

headline: State Bonds in Jeopardy as Tobacco Cash Fades
text: Steady declines in smoking, a big win for public health, are creating problems for municipal bond investors.

headline: Settlement Money Patched Nassau County Budget Gaps
text: The hundreds of millions of dollars in tobacco bonds issued by Nassau County, N.Y., illustrate both the perils in forecasting tobacco cash flows over decades and a reluctance to use the money for its original intent.

headline: Do Nothings and Know Nothings
text: If you worked at a place where barely one in 10 people approved of what you did, if you took a six-figure salary for a job that let you go on “recess” for about 29 weeks of the year, and if you were addressed as “honorable” for said employment, you might suffer an occasional bout of shame.

headline: Small Investors May Get to Own a Bit of Facebook
text: Facebook, which plans to make a market debut this month that could value it at $86 billion, is the stock that everyone seems to want.

headline: Once Remote, Goldman Sachs Puts on a Friendly Public Face
text: After a steady stream of criticism since the financial crisis, Goldman Sachs is trying to burnish its image.

headline: Tired of ‘Tainted’ Image, Lobbyists Try Makeover
text: WASHINGTON — Howard Marlowe was speaking a few weeks ago to a government relations class at the University of California, Berkeley, about his work as a federal lobbyist when several students voiced their deep mistrust of his profession and their misgivings about ever considering it themselves.

headline: At Dewey & LeBoeuf, Notable Departures Continue
text: Dewey & LeBoeuf continued to face high-level departures and other potential indications of a shutdown on Thursday, even as the law firm’s leadership denied reports that it planned to close.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Will Kelly Run for Mayor? One Candidate Tires of Talk
text: In New York City political circles, it is the question that will not go away: Will Raymond W. Kelly, the popular police commissioner, throw his blue cap into the ring and run for mayor?

headline: New Bribery Charges Filed Against Ex-Senate Leader
text: Joseph L. Bruno, a former majority leader of the State Senate, was charged on Thursday with taking bribes and kickbacks in a fraud scheme during his long tenure in office, setting up another battle with federal prosecutors who won a conviction against him in 2009.

headline: ‘Beyond Debate’
text: Jose Padilla, the American citizen detained as an enemy combatant after he was arrested by the Bush administration in May 2002, was denied contact with his lawyer, his family or anyone else outside the military brig for almost two years and kept in detention for almost four. His jailers made death threats, shackled him for hours, forced him into painful stress positions, subjected him to noxious fumes that hurt his eyes and nose and deafening noises at all hours, denied him care for serious illness and more.

headline: The Risk From Chemical Plants
text: More than a decade after 9/11, thousands of facilities that produce, store or use highly toxic chemicals remain vulnerable to a terrorist attack or accident that could kill or injure hundreds of thousands of people living downwind of an explosion. A Congressional Research Service report identifies 483 facilities in 43 states where a chemical disaster would put 100,000 or more people at risk.

headline: Almost at the Gate: Joe Drape’s Derby Picks
text: There is a full field of 20 horses for Saturday’s Kentucky Derby. The Churchill Downs oddsmaker, Mike Battaglia, set the morning line. Joe Drape, who picked last year’s Derby winner at odds of 21-1, has listed the horses in order of preference.

headline: Inequality, Debt and the Financial Crisis
text: Recent research by economists from the International Monetary Fund and academia offers some new insights about income inequality, with important implications.

headline: Tampa’s Plea for a Bit of Disarmament? Rejected
text: Mayor Bob Buckhorn of Tampa, Fla., proudly packs a .38-caliber revolver as one of the 900,000 Floridians holding concealed-weapon permits these days. But even Mayor Buckhorn thinks it is a bad idea to allow the people who will be thronging outside the Republican National Convention in the city this August to carry concealed weapons.

headline: What’s in a Name? (Part 3)
text: This is the third in a three-part series.

headline: Results of French and Greek Elections Could Signal Shift on Economic Crisis
text: PARIS — France and Greece vote Sunday in elections that will be closely watched for the future of the European Union and the euro. The votes will once again highlight the emerging crux of the euro crisis: Will democratic politics offer a solution to the economic crisis or just make it worse?

headline: Mixing Marketing With Social Games and Extreme Sports
text: DEGREE MEN, the deodorant by Unilever, is starting a video marketing campaign that aims to increase the brand’s interaction with its core consumers by offering content tailored to social gaming sites.

headline: Players Could Test Goodell’s Authority
text: The four players suspended by the N.F.L. for their roles in the New Orleans Saints bounty program prepared Thursday for what could be a lengthy attempt to overturn their suspensions.

headline: Plutocracy, Paralysis, Perplexity
text: Before the Great Recession, I would sometimes give public lectures in which I would talk about rising inequality, making the point that the concentration of income at the top had reached levels not seen since 1929. Often, someone in the audience would ask whether this meant that another depression was imminent.

headline: A Derby Pick, Made in the Rain at Saratoga
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: In a Time of Change and Investment at Cablevision, Its Net Income Plunges
text: Cablevision, a cable company based in New York that is in the midst of an aggressive investment phase, on Thursday posted a 45 percent drop in net income for the first quarter of the year.

headline: 4 Years Later, Race Is Still Issue for Some Voters
text: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio — This is the land of die-hard Democrats — mill workers, coal miners and union members. They have voted party line for generations, forming a reliable constituency for just about any Democrat who decides to run for office.

headline: The Campus Tsunami
text: Online education is not new. The University of Phoenix started its online degree program in 1989. Four million college students took at least one online class during the fall of 2007.

headline: A Community Recalls a Star Who Never Left
text: OCEANSIDE, Calif. — Last Sunday, three days before Junior Seau was found dead in his oceanfront home, he spoke at the memorial service for his mailman. The theme of his speech, according to those in attendance: to celebrate life.

headline: Mexico Drops Big Fine in Settlement With Wireless Carrier
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s antitrust commission said on Thursday that it was dropping a fine of nearly $1 billion against the local unit of the wireless carrier América Móvil in return for a promise by the company to change its pricing practices.

headline: How Romney Can Win the Swing Votes
text: What can the candidate do to win over women, Hispanics and Republicans who are moderates on gay issues?

headline: Emergency Extractor
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I loved this one. A real workout (maybe just for me, because I am admittedly not a sports follower, and the northwest had me stymied for a while until SIXERS’ GAME obediently fell into place), but what fun entries!

headline: Dissident’s Plea for Protection From China Deepens Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — The Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng’s abrupt reversal and plea for protection from the United States has deepened a diplomatic crisis and exposed the Obama administration to withering criticism that its diplomats miscalculated when they negotiated his departure from the American Embassy in Beijing.

headline: Some Rest for the Weary: An Iron Man in Game 3 Earns a Day Off
text: WASHINGTON — There was no practice for the Rangers or the Capitals on Thursday. They were still recovering from Wednesday’s Game 3, which took 4 hours 34 minutes and three overtimes to finish.

headline: Settlement in Payroll Scandal Gives Mayor’s Budget a Lift
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday that an infusion of almost half a billion dollars from the settlement over the CityTime payroll scandal would enable New York to fill more than 2,500 teaching positions that were to be eliminated in the budget for the coming fiscal year, while avoiding tax increases or layoffs of police officers or firefighters.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,943 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Brutalist Building, Damaged, Gets Reprieve
text: A controversial government building designed by the celebrated Modernist architect Paul Rudolph in Goshen, N.Y., has been rescued from the bulldozers — at least temporarily.

headline: Wastewater Becomes Issue in Debate on Gas Drilling
text: Vexed by declining revenue, officials of the Niagara Falls water utility seized on a new moneymaking idea last year: treat toxic waste from natural-gas drilling at its sewage-treatment plant once hydrofracking gets under way in New York State.

headline: Knicks Are Off and Almost Out
text: The bodies kept falling away, his support system stripped, until Carmelo Anthony stood as the Knicks’ last bulwark between postseason relevance and extinction. So he kept dribbling and shooting and powering through traffic, until he had run out of room and run out of time.

headline: Florida: Eight in Hazing Case Turn Themselves In to the Police
text: Eight of the 13 people facing criminal charges in the hazing death of a Florida A&M University marching band member have voluntarily turned themselves in to the police, state officials said Thursday. On Wednesday, the state filed charges against band members who are accused of fatally beating a fellow student, Robert Champion, 26, in a hazing ritual after a football game in November. State authorities have arrested all of the suspects who turned themselves in, and they are working with lawyers and family members to find the other suspects. Also Thursday, Mr. Champion’s parents called on the university to disband its marching band, which has been temporarily suspended since the fall. His mother, Pam Champion, said she was disappointed that those responsible had been charged with hazing, not with murder.

headline: A Show of Solidarity for Hunger Strikers
text: Scores of Palestinian prisoners have joined a hunger strike that officials say now counts more than 1,500 participants.

headline: Tired Legs
text: Five Rangers players skated more than any Capitals player in Wednesday’s playoff hockey game.

headline: Evidence in Clemens’s Trial Includes Syringes and Vials
text: WASHINGTON — Jurors in Roger Clemens’s perjury trial on Thursday had an up-close view of what prosecutors say is an important pile of trash: a partly crushed beer can, yellowed cotton balls, used syringes and empty vials — all items the government will later contend connect Clemens to performance-enhancing drug use.

headline: Floyd D. Hall, Head of Eastern Airlines, Dies at 96
text: Floyd D. Hall, a former airline pilot who rose to chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines in the mid-1960s but who was unable to stem the financial difficulties that eventually led to the company’s demise, died on April 26 at a nursing home in Woodstock, Vt. He was 96.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: No More Country on ‘Idol,’ but a Soul Powerhouse Emerges
text: Skylar Laine, the ebullient young country singer from Mississippi, was voted off Fox’s “American Idol” on Thursday night, leaving a field of four singers as the talent show enters its home stretch.

headline: Charles Higham, Celebrity Biographer, Dies at 81
text: Charles Higham, a prolific celebrity biographer whose books drew vast attention for their memorably vast claims (Errol Flynn was a Nazi spy, Howard Hughes played a central role in Watergate), died on April 21 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Ryan McDonagh: A Lot of Ice Time
text: In Wednesday’s triple-overtime win over the Capitals, Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh skated more than 53 minutes, the most of any player.

headline: Lead Slips Devils’ Grasp Twice, but They Grab It for Good in Overtime
text: NEWARK — When Ilya Kovalchuk stepped on the ice before Game 3 against the Philadelphia Flyers on Thursday night, he was bathed in a spotlight and the crowd at Prudential Center thundered its approval, creating an even bigger din later when he scored a goal.

headline: Despite Chaos Above Ground, Cairo’s Metro System Runs Smoothly
text: The Cairo subway continues to offer residents consistent, efficient service, while most others suffer in the year since the revolution.

headline: Underground, Everything That Life Above Is Not
text: CAIRO — By the dusty factories at the end of the subway line, two day laborers emerged from the cars, dreading their return to life above ground.

headline: Leaving the Presidency in Russia, Medvedev Fights for Relevance
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev spent last Friday trying to persuade the grandees of United Russia that he is a conservative who can lead the party to victory. But many looked at him and saw Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin’s liberal sidekick, who emboldened the opposition and supported the West in Libya.

headline: David Bowman, Satirical Novelist, Dies at 54
text: David Bowman, a novelist and cultural critic whose first two books, “Let the Dog Drive” and “Bunny Modern,” received wide praise in the 1990s for their satirical voice, died in Manhattan on Feb. 27. He was 54.

headline: Three Photographers Found Dead in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — The bodies of three photojournalists were found dismembered on Thursday in the eastern state of Veracruz, days after a crime reporter for a national magazine was killed in her house there.

headline: U.S. Stresses Concessions From China
text: WASHINGTON — American officials said early Friday that their annual summit meeting on strategic and economic issues with China had resulted in tangible economic concessions, despite the unprecedented diplomatic furor over a Chinese human-rights advocate seeking aid from American officials.

text: Since last April, the economies and markets in the United States and the euro zone have radically diverged.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Birther Moment
text: If you are 1/32 Cherokee and your grandfather has high cheekbones, does that make you Native American? It depends. Last Friday, Republicans in Massachusetts questioned the racial ancestry of Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic Senate candidate. Her opponent, Senator Scott Brown, has accused her of using minority status as an American Indian to advance her career as a law professor at Harvard, the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Texas. The Brown campaign calls her ties to the Cherokee and Delaware nations a “hypocritical sham.”

headline: James Ends Foul Night With Flourish
text: LeBron James played the role of D.J. in the Heat’s locker room before taking the court for Game 3 at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. The first song he selected was by the rap duo Outkast, “Da Art of Storytellin’ (Part 1).”

headline: Thunder Rout Mavericks for Commanding Series Lead
text: DALLAS — Kevin Durant slowed the tempo as he dribbled toward a deflated Dallas Mavericks defense. Given such a rare open 3-point shot, Durant instinctively swished the jumper — a basket that came with five minutes still to play yet symbolized how the Oklahoma City Thunder have imposed its will on the reigning N.B.A. champions.

headline: Knicks-Heat Replay: Game 3
text: Action from Madison Square Garden, as Miami defeated New York, 87-70, to take a 3-0 lead in their first-round series.

headline: Freakish Accidents Haunt the Yankees
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Mariano Rivera’s torn knee ligament, which almost certainly ended his season and perhaps his career, was the latest of three progressively worse freak accidents that have occurred to Yankees pitchers so far this year.

headline: News Quiz | May 4, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Britain: Ex-Officials in Murdoch Empire to Face Questions in Hacking Inquiry
text: Two former executives at Rupert Murdoch’s British tabloid newspapers, Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson, pivotal figures in the phone hacking scandal with strong links to Prime Minister David Cameron, will give evidence to a public inquiry next week, according to schedules released Thursday. Mr. Coulson, who resigned as the editor of the tabloid The News of the World, which was at the center of the scandal in 2007, became a senior adviser to Mr. Cameron before being forced to step down last year. He has been arrested on suspicion of conspiracy in the hacking case and of corruption in approving payments from journalists to public officials. Ms. Brooks, who was chief executive of Mr. Murdoch’s British newspaper company News International, also has close ties to Mr. Cameron. She has been arrested on the same grounds as Mr. Coulson and on suspicion of obstructing justice. The appearances are likely to deepen scrutiny of the links — described by critics as improperly cozy — between Mr. Murdoch’s media empire and Mr. Cameron’s government. Separately, a former Scotland Yard special operations officer was arrested “on suspicion of misconduct in a public office” as part of Operation Elveden, the investigation into the payments to public officials, the police said. The arrest was made, the police said, as a result of information provided by Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation.

headline: Russia: Ukraine Rejects a Putin Offer
text: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday said the Ukrainian opposition figure Yulia V. Tymoshenko was welcome to receive medical treatment in Russia — a dig at Ukraine’s president, who imprisoned her in a case widely condemned as politically motivated. Mr. Putin told reporters that “it will be our pleasure” to host Ms. Tymoshenko, Ukraine’s former prime minister, who is serving a seven-year sentence for overstepping her authority while in office. German officials have made a similar offer. Ukrainian officials immediately rejected Mr. Putin’s proposal. Mr. Putin, however, said complaints about the Tymoshenko case should not have any bearing on the Euro 2012 soccer tournament. Several Western European countries are planning to boycott the games. “In absolutely every case, you can’t mix politics, business and other issues with sport,” Mr. Putin said. “Sport is outside politics.”

headline: London’s Mayor Aside, Conservatives Fare Poorly in British Races
text: LONDON — Boris Johnson, the towheaded, nimble-tongued mayor of London, provided a modest lift for the British Conservative Party on Friday after winning re-election amid a deluge of defeats for the party in local races around the country.

headline: BNP Paribas Profit Rises 10% in First Quarter
text: PARIS — BNP Paribas, the biggest French bank, reported on Friday that its first-quarter net income rose nearly 10 percent, helped by the sale of a real estate business, and said it was on track to reach its capital strength targets.

headline: Nascent Deal Would Let Dissident From China Study in U.S.
text: BEIJING — China and the United States reached a deal Friday that calls for the dissident Chen Guangcheng to travel to the United States with his family, in what appeared to be a resolution to an eight-day diplomatic crisis that had threatened to strain the relationship between the two countries and left the Obama administration open to attacks from human rights activists and political opponents at home.

headline: Double Blast in Volatile Russian Region Kills 13
text: MOSCOW — At least 13 people were killed and more than 100 were wounded in a double bombing at a police station in Russia’s tumultuous North Caucasus region late Thursday night, officials said, a stark reminder of the challenges facing Vladimir V. Putin in the region as he prepares to take over the presidency next week.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Records Strong First-Quarter Results
text: LONDON — Royal Bank of Scotland, whose principal owner is the British government after a bailout, said on Friday that earnings in the first three months of this year improved and that it was close to repaying all its government-backed emergency loans.

headline: May 4, 1970 | National Guard Opens Fire at Kent State
text: On May 4, 1970, the Ohio National Guard opened fire on antiwar protesters at Kent State University, killing four students and wounding nine others.

text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Ahead of the Curve, Yet Again.”

headline: India’s ‘Telecom Revolution’ Turns Ugly
text: Facing new regulation and retroactive taxation, telecommunication companies in India are revolting – foreign companies are pulling out of the country, local executives who were once cozy with government are publicly condemning official policies, and several operators are suing or threatening to sue the Indian government.

headline: What’s Cluttering Up Your Life?
text: Clutter, which this Times article defines as almost anything that takes up too much physical or mental space, has a way of creeping into our lives and impeding them. With each new acquisition we lose a bit more space, a bit more breathing room, and a bit more freedom. What clutters up your life, and what can you do to lessen its impact?

headline: Cisse’s Goal Was Soccer Made in Germany
text: Papiss Cisse’s goal against Chelsea Wednesday night was many things; a beautiful first touch, a wonderful turn and an emphatic volley in to the top-right corner of Petr Cech’s net. But it signified a change in the make up of the game.

text: Sometimes, an admissions officer’s job is more than sifting through enormous stacks of applications. Sometimes, an admissions officer has to take a stand.

headline: Structural Unemployment and Good Jobs
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

headline: BMW Sounds, Beyond Door Chimes and Exhaust Notes, at the Frieze Art Fair
text: Befitting the expansive grounds of Randall’s Island in the East River, the first New York edition of the Frieze Art Fair, which began in London, includes large-scale sculptures and a tent filled with paintings and mixed-media pieces. Three works, however, are scheduled to have their premieres inside automobiles.

headline: For Eden Gardens’ Fans, Ganguly Trumps All
text: A scene from seven years ago: a crowd of 60,000 cheer South Africa and boo Indian players, who crash to a 10-wicket defeat in a 50-over cricket match. Nothing unusual in it, except that the match was played not in South Africa, but right here in India, at Eden Gardens, the iconic cricket stadium in Kolkata.

headline: Suicide Bomber Attacks Market in Pakistan, Killing at Least 26
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Dozens of people, including two senior security officers, were killed and scores were wounded in a suicide attack on a government checkpoint in a tribal district along the Afghan border, hospital and government officials said.

headline: A Down Week, Worsened by a Weak Jobs Report
text: Stocks sank on Friday, with the broader market posting its biggest weekly decline this year after a disappointing report on jobs in the United States.

headline: The Jokes Are on South Africans
text: JOHANNESBURG — On Tuesday evening, as I walked into Metro, a trendy restaurant-cum-comedy club in a northern suburb of Johannesburg, my heart skipped a beat. I noticed that our table was close to the stage.  As an obsessive stand-up-comedy fan, I know that these actors love to pick on the front row. And South African comics are particularly cruel.

headline: 20 Kentucky Derby Champions Face Off, Virtually
text: A Web site that specializes in horse racing games has produced a 3D video simulation of the Kentucky Derby with the 20 most recent winners including Smarty Jones, Silver Charm, Barbaro, Real Quiet, Big Brown and others. All of the contenders are depicted with the true racing attributes of their 3-year-old careers, developed with technology from Horse Racing Simulation L.L.C.

headline: A Stunning, New Social Media Tactic: Handwritten Notes
text: Recently, I gave a Marketing 101 talk to a group of small-business owners in Austin, Tex., mostly principals at professional service companies like law firms. I’m a big fan of handwritten notes as an effective, inexpensive but surprisingly powerful tool and highlighted them in my presentation.

headline: How McDonald’s Came Back Bigger Than Ever
text: It was a simple plan. McDonald’s would pay to appear at the top of the trends list on Twitter’s home page, using the social-media site to drive people to its new commercials highlighting some of the real-life farmers and ranchers who supply McDonald’s with its ingredients. Executives at the fast-food company loved the commercials; the word in-house was “authenticity.”

headline: Putting Names to Faces From the 1960 Democratic National Convention
text: Two weeks ago, we asked for your help identifying the people in Garry Winogrand’s photographs from the 1960 Democratic National Convention. You delivered: 96 comments produced dozens of leads for us to pursue. Thanks to your help, some of those extras — the bow-tie-clad gentleman to Robert Kennedy’s right in one picture, the photographer to Adlai Stevenson’s left in another, the man behind the candelabra in a third — are now fleshed-out humans with names, affiliations and even a few stories.

headline: Immigrants Say ‘Non’ to Sarkozy
text: MARSEILLE — In a grimy corner cafe on a street above Marseille’s Vieux Port, the only concession the owners have made to a strict nationwide smoking ban is to have removed the ashtrays. France’s Mediterranean metropolis likes to follow its own rules.

headline: British Government Seeks Special Status at Hacking Inquiry
text: LONDON — Days before two former executives at Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid newspapers here are to testify at a judicial inquiry into Britain’s phone hacking scandal, the government of Prime Minister David Cameron was granted special status that yields advance access to witness statements and the ability to question testimony.

headline: Finding a One-of-a-Kind Hat for a First Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — I’m embarrassed to admit this: I cover horse racing, and I have never been to a Kentucky Derby. I have been to five Preakness Stakes, five Belmont Stakes, two Blue Grass Stakes and one Ohio Derby. But never have I strolled across the hallowed grounds beneath the Twin Spires at Churchill Downs. Never have I sipped a mint julep so sweet I could only be in the Bluegrass State. On Friday, on Kentucky Oaks Day, that will change.

headline: In Assam Ferry Accident, Death Toll in Dispute
text: Rescue teams continue to monitor both banks of the Brahmaputra River for survivors after a ferry carrying over 300 passengers capsized Monday evening in the Dhubri district of Assam. Assam officials say 37 people have died in the state, but other estimates are nearly three times as high. The number of missing is also in dispute.

headline: Wastewater Jitters in New York
text: As I report in Friday’s Times, disposing of the waste produced by natural gas drilling will become a larger and more contentious issue if New York State gives the go-ahead to horizontal hydraulic fracturing, which uses millions of gallons of fluids per well to release gas from the Marcellus Shale.

headline: For Rivera, Maestro of Ninth, Injury Is Not Final Symphony
text: For almost 17 years, Mariano Rivera has starred for the Yankees with humility and grace. His dignified demeanor, as much as his famous cut fastball, has defined him in the public mind.

headline: Seau Family Will Donate Brain for Study
text: Sam Farmer of The Los Angeles Times is reporting that Junior Seau’s family will allow his brain to be studied for possible damage that could have led him to suicide. The article quotes the Chargers’ chaplain as saying: “The family was considering this almost from the beginning, but they didn’t want to make any emotional decisions. And when they came to a joint decision that absolutely this was the best thing, it was a natural occurrence for the Seau family to go forward.” The family wanted “to help other individuals down the road.”

headline: Remembering Junior Seau, the Football Player
text: Few players brought more passion and intensity to the football field than Junior Seau. On Thursday, Seau’s death was officially ruled a suicide. He was 43 years old. A few thoughts about Seau the football player:

headline: A Kaleidoscope of Charms
text: ISTANBUL — “We are all diminished by the success of our friends” is a saying that lies at the bedrock of the politics of envy. If true, it means that I, along with fellow squad members of my high school junior-varsity basketball team, have every reason to feel just a few centimeters high. Only one of us, Orhan Pamuk, has gone on to win a Nobel Prize.

headline: Daily Report: Small Investors May Get a Piece of Facebook
text: Typically, shares of hot initial public offerings like Facebook go almost entirely to the biggest clients of the Wall Street banks that oversee the stock sale. But as Susanne Craig and Evelyn M. Rusli report in Friday’s New York Times, Facebook’s executives and underwriters have discussed raising the number of shares that will go to small investors, according to people briefed on the matter who were not authorized to speak on the record.

headline: Reaction to April Jobs Report, in Tweets
text: What would a jobs report be without sharp opinions about what it all means? The American economy added 115,000 jobs in April, the government said Friday, while the unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent. What do these employment numbers say to you about the pace of the economic recovery, or about what economic policies should now be considered? Let us know what you think in the comments below, or send us a message on Twitter, to @nytimesbusiness. We’re collecting a variety of ideas and thoughts, all of them available after the jump.

headline: Settlement of CityTime Scandal Will Pay for Teachers
text: The annual city budget tug-of-war has begun. headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Touch-Ups at Teen Magazines, and Goldman’s Friendly Face
text: Julia Bluhm, a 14-year-old from Maine, disturbed by the photographs of “perfect” girls in magazines, started an online petition asking Seventeen magazine to “commit to printing one unaltered — real — photo spread per month.” The petition now has nearly 50,000 signatures, and Jim Dwyer was there when Julia this week attended a protest at the magazine’s offices, and later met with the editor in chief of Seventeen, Ann Shoket.
