headline: Mood Swing
text: The designer Lindsey Adelman is embracing her dark side. Who knew she even had one? Since opening her New York studio in 2006, she’s become known primarily for her Bubble Series chandelier, an industrially-inspired brass armature blooming with charmingly lumpy blown glass globes. It consistently tops the shopping lists of architects and designers like Peter Marino and Kelly Wearstler; a sheik in Kuwait has one, and Ivanka Trump has two in her new Park Avenue apartment. “It’s almost like hanging a tree branch from your ceiling,” Adelman says, who, as a design student at the Rhode Island School of Design, also dabbled in sculpture.

headline: Ignoring the Real Money in the Bank of America Lawsuits
text: 12:07 p.m. | Updated With a ruling from the Delaware Chancery Court

headline: How to Raise a Financial Wizard
text: Though only a third of 2012 has passed, Zac Bissonnette is already a strong contender for the cheekiest author of the year award.

headline: In-Laws Sentenced in Afghan Girl’s Torture Case
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan court has delivered a 10-year prison sentence to three in-laws of a 15-year-old girl who was imprisoned and tortured for five months for refusing to become a prostitute, the girl’s lawyer and government and humanitarian officials said late on Thursday.

headline: Getting Better, Slowly
text: The second-consecutive disappointing monthly jobs report put a damper over markets Friday morning. But there are some positive signs.

headline: Translators Get a Slam of Their Own at PEN Festival
text: Pity the poor translator. He (or more often she) works in the same solitary fashion as the novelist, poet, playwright or essayist, but must be content only with reflected glory: at best, his or her name in small print on the cover of a book, or, just as likely, relegated in smaller print to an interior page. Which is why an event like the “Translation Slam” Thursday night, part of this year’s PEN World Voices literary festival, must be a translator’s delight, a rare opportunity to stand in the spotlight — in this case literally.

headline: Video: This Week’s Movies, May 4
text: In today’s edition of “This Week’s Movies,” we hear our critics’ thoughts on three releases. A. O. Scott has some not-so-super words about “The Avengers,” Manohla Dargis looks at the ballet documentary “First Position” and Mr. Scott offers his take on “Last Call at the Oasis,” a documentary that offers unnerving predictions of water shortages. Let us know your thoughts on this week’s movies in the comments area below.

headline: Protesters Rally Against Proposed Cuts in After-School Care
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released his executive budget on Thursday, it confirmed the worst fears of many parents and advocates for after-school programs.

headline: Inside the Ropes, Then Behind Bars
text: LAS VEGAS — Inside the Mayweather Boxing Club, where the assembled included a lawyer, a famous rapper, a celebrity chef, a girlfriend, an ex-girlfriend, a dozen boxers, a few dozen spectators and, naturally, three representatives from Habitat for Humanity, the boxing equivalent of a Batman signal flashed.

headline: Hong Kong, Beijing, Shanghai
text: Dine in the clouds, visit one of the most surveilled spots in the world and have some tea in this tour of China’s gateways.

headline: Easy China, 3 Ways
text: FOR the first-time visitor to China, planning a trip to the most populous country on earth can be an exercise in trying to tame the infinite. Where to begin? Since most people will be flying into Beijing, Hong Kong or Shanghai, we suggest basing yourself in one of these three cities, each in its own state of frenzied transformation. As two Times correspondents, David Barboza in Shanghai and Keith Bradsher in Hong Kong, and Dan Levin, a regular contributor from Beijing point out, each city is a study in contrasts. Dazzling, ultramodern skylines conceal hidden corners of traditional China: historic neighborhoods crisscrossed by alleyways in Beijing; teahouses in Shanghai; and centuries-old temples in Hong Kong. Which isn’t to say that these metropolises, with their up-to-the-minute shops, galleries, restaurants and bars don’t possess their own magic. They do. Below, essential tips on what to see and do for a week in China’s gateway cities.

headline: Al Qaeda on the Media
text: Everyone’s a critic. Presidents and congressmen, press secretaries and campaign managers, everyone seems to have a view of the news media these days, and usually not a positive one. Add to the list Osama bin Laden and his circle.

headline: Victor Hugo’s Guernsey
text: See where the writer lived and worked during the most productive period of his life.

headline: Where Victor Hugo Found Freedom
text: IN October 1855 Victor Hugo arrived on rainy, wind-swept Guernsey seeking refuge. A fierce opponent of the Second Empire of Napoleon III, he had been banished first from his native France, and then Belgium and the island of Jersey. By the time he landed on this small neighboring island in the English Channel, the exiled writer was in desperate need of asylum.

headline: Fast Company
text: Casual fans of the Kentucky Derby, mint juleps in hand, can’t be expected to extend their curiosity much beyond the woozy singing of “My Old Kentucky Home” and the chaotic two minutes of racing that follow, unless a Triple Crown winner seems a serious possibility. One is unlikely to hear any mention of another, equally famous Derby (pronounced “Darby”) taking place a month later at Epsom Downs in England. Unlike its Kentucky counterpart, the Epsom Derby, the subject of an intricately plotted and stylistically burnished crime caper by the English writer D. J. Taylor, is run on turf, over uneven terrain. While these differences may seem slight, the cultural gulf separating the two derbies might as well divide baseball from cricket.

headline: Grieving Lessons
text: Over five decades of exuberant shape-shifting across the fictional landscape, Anne Tyler has cut the steady swath of a literary stalwart, writing novel after novel whose most memorable characters inhabit a cosmos all their own, a contemporary meta-­Baltimore populated by ordinary if idiosyncratic citizens, middle-class homebodies cocooned yet smothered by their families. What makes each story distinctive is the particular way its characters rebel against hereditary confines, cope with fateful crises or forge relationships with new acquaintances who rock their world.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE NEWLYWEDS,  by Nell Freudenberger. (Knopf, $25.95.) The story of a Bangladeshi woman, her new American husband and their previous romantic entanglements is told with empathy, an effective writing style and an international sensibility.

headline: The Spy Who Came in From the Couch
text: Strolling through Vienna in “lemony sunshine” on a mild August day in 1913, Lysander Rief, a “young, almost conventionally handsome man” with “brown, breeze-blown hair” and a “sportsman’s build,” stops dead, compelled by a luscious but disturbing advertisement for an opera. In the poster, he beholds a distraught goddess, naked but for the merest scrap of filmy gauze, who recoils from a glowering serpent, “cowering, hands pressed to her sizable breasts, cupping them protectively.” She is “young, beautiful, vulnerable,” he thinks as he stares at the poster, “confronted by some squamous, no doubt phallic monster about to ravish her.”

headline: The Unkindest Cut
text: When she learned she had advanced ovarian cancer, the feminist scholar Susan Gubar felt a “sense of liberation” that was almost euphoric. Caring for her elderly, increasingly demented mother had given Gubar a good look at the realities of old age, while her father’s suicide years earlier had deeply injured their family. Here, she thought, was a path between a life cut short and one painfully prolonged — a death (for late-stage ovarian cancer is almost invariably fatal) in her 60s, when her daughters were grown and she was happy in her second marriage and her work.

headline: An Empire of Her Own
text: Everyone in Second Empire Paris knows the name of Zola’s celebrated courtesan, Nana, “with all the lilting vivacity of its two syllables.” Not so her sister under the skin, the fallen heroine of Carole DeSanti’s provocative historical novel, “The Unruly Passions of Eugénie R.” Forced to labor in the same vineyards as her flamboyant contemporary, Eugénie does so in obscurity. She’s no celebrated “grande horizontale,” even though she shares the name of France’s empress — and even though one of her lovers makes her famous with a painting that wins a prize in the Salon of 1861. His picture’s title: “An Unknown Girl.”

headline: Dawn of Creation
text: For a decade now, new­-media Cassandras have been warning about the Death of Journalism as We Know It, and it may yet come to pass. Certainly, attention spans seem shorter these days, and the line between actual thinking and mere aggregation grows ever blurrier. Yet when I look at journals like The Point and n+1 and Triple Canopy; at The Believer and Granta and The New Yorker; at the Kindle Singles and longreads.com and even at what gets passed around on Twitter, I see a robust demand for, and supply of, long-form “magazine writing.” And in just the last few years, a cohort of younger writers including Elif Batuman, Wells Tower, Sam Anderson and John Jeremiah Sullivan has emerged to put its distinctive stamp on the genre. I’m tempted to call the result — with apologies to Tom Wolfe, Robert Boynton and anti-­taxonomists everywhere — the New New New Journalism.

headline: And Then There Were 39
text: “A singular disadvantage of the sea,” Stephen Crane wrote in his 1897 story “The Open Boat,” based on his experiences on a lifeboat off the coast of Florida, “lies in the fact that after successfully surmounting one wave you discover that there is another behind it just as important.” The unrelenting sea and its vast indifference to the shipwrecked is a subject that has always attracted both writers and readers. We are fascinated, and appalled, by how quickly men and women are brought to a childlike state, curled in tight on themselves and unable to call on their own free will, sanity or morality. Most riveting of all, perhaps, is the tension that emerges between extreme emotional and physical reduction and an expanded, even predatory, desire to survive.

headline: Unleashing the Power
text: It’s anyone’s guess whether our digital world ends with a bang, a whimper or a singularity. One thing’s for sure: It began with a double entendre.

headline: Inside the List
text: I FEEL GOOD ABOUT MY NECK: The former New York Times Op-Ed columnist Anna Quindlen has been a steady presence on the best-seller lists since she quit newspapers for novel-writing in 1995, and this week her new book about graceful aging, “Lots of Candles, Plenty of Cake,” storms the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 2. To judge from an interview she gave last year, Quindlen — unlike Nora Ephron — isn’t one to feel bad about her neck as she stares down her 60s. “After a number of years working on it very, very hard with my trainer, I now can stand on my head,” she told Kathy Patrick, a Texas hairstylist who owns a combination bookstore and beauty shop (a literary salon!) called Beauty and the Book. “And I’m pretty proud of that,” Quindlen continued. “The fact that I couldn’t stand on my head when I was 22, and I can now that I’m 58, is something that I take a lot of pride in. . . . I think when you’re over 50, you get less and less and less fearful of things, because you understand that, you know, what’s the worst that can happen if you try and fail? So my experience is that most of the women I know over 50 really don’t give a rip what anybody thinks anymore. And it means that they wind up taking chances they might not have taken when they were 25, and doing things they might not have tried. And I think that’s one reason why I feel really good about where I am right now.”

headline: Who Was That Masked Man?
text: Since the discovery of his richly furnished tomb in 1922, Tutankhamen has ascended to an afterlife no pharaoh in ancient Egypt’s 3,000-year civilization could have imagined. His reign was brief, circa 1336-1327 B.C. Historians had previously known so little about him that they were not sure if he had died young or come to the throne as an old man. But the sight of his golden death mask provoked a media frenzy, and the wild conjecture has continued down to our time of high-tech studies of the Tut mummy.

headline: Black Sheep
text: When I was a girl, my father often warned me of the dangers of the wayward life. One could take a wrong turn, go down the wrong path. “And,” he always ended his admonitions, “end up like your cousin, Barney.” My father warned me about Barney the way fathers in fairy tales warn their children about paths that lead to the edge of a cliff or wolves that might wish to befriend us. Barney, born Barnet Lee Rosset Jr., was, in my father’s eyes, the black sheep of the family. The renegade, the ne’er-do-well, the ungrateful son. He’d purchased a failing publishing company called Grove Press. He was squandering his father’s fortune. He was a Communist and a pornographer.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE ANATOMY OF INFLUENCE: Literature as a Way of Life,  by Harold Bloom. (Yale University, $20.) Now in his 80s, the distinguished literary scholar offers a kind of summing-up of ideas, born of his urge “to say in one place most of what I have learned to think about how influence works in imaginative literature.” Between exegeses of Shakespeare, Whitman and others, Bloom reminisces on his rise from bleak poverty and on his first years at Yale in the 1950s.

headline: On Their Stomachs
text: Calories were made to be counted, but they have generally been counted for two very different reasons. We associate calories with excess, but for most of its history this little unit of energy was linked to shortage. The years since World War II have been a time of cheap and plentiful food, and of obese and sick citizens. Since our own daily struggle is fought against fat, we fail to see that many of the conflicts of the past were wars against hunger. Just as obesity leads to diabetes and human blindness, so plentiful food leads to decadent forms of history and social blindness. We are fortunate to have a bracing book like “The Taste of War,” which does much to correct understanding of the causes of armed conflict and mass murder.

headline: Business Day Live | May 4, 2012
text: Frenzied interest in Facebook's pending market debut; Dean Maki of Barclays looks at employment numbers; and James B. Stewart on the decline and fall of Dewey & LeBoeuf.

headline: A Tourist in My Son’s New Home
text: I THOUGHT it was hard when my sons went away to college. That fearfully empty nest. Everyone else can go right ahead and be chipper about all the newfound free time. About how nice it is not to have to wake up at 2 in the morning to see if high school curfews have been met. Frankly, that was a piece of cake compared with the difficulty of knowing what one’s children were doing in college and when they were doing it. Little did I know that college was only the first step in the painful process of parental separation. Why do we talk about the children’s need to separate? It’s the parents who come unglued.

headline: Seattle, 50 Years After the Fair
text: ON a recent morning, as wind and spitting rain lashed the Space Needle’s observation deck, the Seattle writer Knute Berger described the World’s Fair that opened far below, in Seattle Center, 50 years ago last month.

headline: NoPa, San Francisco
text: Here, you can learn to stretch your own cheese while sporting a t-shirt from a shop called San Franpsycho.

headline: Hotel Review: The Shelborne South Beach
text: UPSHOT

headline: Taking a Trip to Lend a Hand
text: IN 2006, after impulsively signing up for the Hurricane Katrina relief effort, Ken Budd was struck by one important question: How much good could he, a 40-year-old magazine editor, actually do there?

headline: I Found My Biological Parents, and Wish I Hadn’t
text: I was young, maybe 4, when I learned where babies came from. I was sitting on a leopard-print couch in my mom’s bachelorette apartment, and her friend decided on a whim to read to me that seminal ’70s book on the nitty-gritty of conception, “Where Did I Come From?” I remember experiencing a gag reflex and wanting to plug my ears and sing lalalalalalala.

headline: Who Made That Frisbee?
text: Walter Fredrick Morrison and his girlfriend, Lucile Nay, discovered that flying discs were marketable when a stranger asked to buy the metal cake pan they were flipping through the air on a Santa Monica beach. By 1938, the couple were selling the 5-cent pans for a quarter a piece. Morrison used the proceeds to buy Nay a $35 diamond engagement ring. After a stint as an Army Air Corps pilot during World War II, Morrison tried his hand at developing “a flying disk far superior to that of a flying cake pan.” Together with a butane supplier named Warren Franscioni, they created the Flyin-Saucer, but it didn’t go very far until Morrison created a new version in 1955, dubbed the Pluto Platter. The disc had a bump that evoked an alien cockpit on top and the names of the planets around its rim. Wham-O, the visionary toy company known for its slingshots and, soon, its Hula-Hoops, bought the rights in 1957. Wham-O renamed the flying disc Frisbee, which Morrison didn’t like one bit. “Had I been consulted, I’d have vehemently objected,” he wrote in his account of the Frisbee business (written with Phil Kennedy),“Flat Flip Flies Straight!” Wham-O went on to nix the alien cockpit and planetary names, opting instead for a new, sportier disc with a stripe in the center and the words “Official Pro Model” on top. By the mid-1960s, “there was one of everybody’s roof,” says Robert Rauch, president of the World Flying Disc Federation. The Frisbee was, quite simply, “cool,” says Tim Walsh, author of a book on Wham-O. “This thing rose on the wind.”

headline: The Realest Reality Show in the World
text: A ribbon unfurls in the colors of the Venezuelan flag, while a drum roll announces the show’s title sequence and a trumpet tootles. Block-letter words pop up on the screen: “humanity,” “struggle,” “socialism.” It looks for all the world like a “Daily Show” parody. And then comes a close-up of the show’s host and star, Hugo Chávez, president of Venezuela, usually dressed in all red or a military jacket, sometimes crowned with a Che-style beret, standing on the road among his supporters or before a live audience at Miraflores Palace in Caracas. The show is entirely unscripted. Chávez usually begins by stating the date and saying, “Aló Presidente!” then grinning and giving himself a round of applause. “Aló Presidente!” he repeats and you can’t tell if he’s introducing the program by its title or simply greeting and congratulating himself.

headline: The 4.22.12 Issue
text: POST-PROZAC NATION

headline: How Elaine Wynn Survived 45 Years in Sin City
text: In 2011 you were included on a list of self-made female billionaires. There were only 19 of them. A cynic might question how divorcing the casino magnate Steve Wynn two years earlier and taking half his business make your fortune self-made.  For every person who says that, you can find another person who will say, “Elaine was a major contributor to the success of that company.” Did I create an environment that allowed him to thrive? Did I create an anchoring to the personality that made us have good equilibrium? That’s what I’d say I hope my contribution is. Is that worth a billion dollars? I have no idea how to quantify that.

headline: Legends of the Ball
text: Voguing is back in vogue.

headline: On Our Radar: Birds and Wind Turbines
text: Using Google Earth as a platform, the American Bird Conservancy creates an interactive Web-based map that highlights more than 2,000 places in the United States where birds are likely to be particularly vulnerable to impacts from wind energy development. [American Bird Conservancy]

headline: The Surprising Shortcut to Better Health
text: For more than a decade, Gretchen Reynolds has been writing about the science of health and fitness. Her weekly column, Phys Ed, is one of this paper’s most popular features, regularly appearing on top of the “Most E-mailed” list. Now Ms. Reynolds has distilled the knowledge gained from years of fitness reporting into a new book, “The First 20 Minutes: Surprising Science Reveals How We Can Exercise Better, Train Smarter, Live Longer,’’ published last month.

headline: From Britain, a Court Ruling on Improper Child-Seat Use
text: A legal case in Britain raises questions about whether a parent might be charged with negligence for incorrect use of a child seat.

headline: The Screen Can’t Hear When You Yell ‘Bravo’
text: IF you visit the Web site of Piedmont Opera in Winston-Salem, N.C., and hover your cursor over the heading “On Stage,” a menu drops down. “MetHD,” a link to information about the local transmission of the Metropolitan Opera’s “Live in HD” movie theater broadcasts, leads the list of the company’s offerings, including two live Winston-Salem productions: Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” and Robert Ward’s “Crucible.”

headline: Investing in a Racehorse Without Breaking the Bank
text: I SPENT a day this week at Belmont Park, site of the final leg of the Triple Crown. I was with George Bolton, an investment adviser who once owned part of Curlin, winner of the 2007 Preakness Stakes and the current record holder for the most money won by a thoroughbred horse.

headline: Group Planning Protest at Party Convention Rankles Some With Name Change
text: What’s in a name? The biggest group planning to demonstrate in September at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C., has decided to change its name from the Coalition to Protest at the DNC to the Coalition to March on Wall Street South — Building People’s Power During the DNC. The change has spurred debate within the protest movement.

headline: Look of The Moment | Balmain Beauties
text: The Look: Gold Standard. Five fashion superstars heavily embellished and rock-steady head to toe — slouchy pantsuit! glittery mini! — are something to tweet home about (#FF @Balmain).

headline: Your Best Tip for Raising a Moneywise Child
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I took a look at Zac Bissonnette’s new book “How to Be Richer, Smarter and Better-Looking Than Your Parents,” and wondered who could have raised a 23-year-old capable of writing a personal finance guidebook. (This is his second book, by the way; the first was about paying for college.)

headline: A Good Line On the Résumé For an Orchestra
text: IF anyone can tell the Edmonton Symphony Orchestra or the Alabama Symphony Orchestra what blessings may flow from a Carnegie Hall debut, it is the Nashville Symphony. Having rented the hall on its own initiative and paid its own freight, Nashville made its Carnegie debut in 2000, conducted by the music director who had elevated its stature, Kenneth Schermerhorn, five years before his death.

headline: New Proposal on Fracking Gives Ground to Industry
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday issued a proposed rule governing hydraulic fracturing for oil and gas on public lands that will for the first time require disclosure of the chemicals used in the process.

headline: Morning Walkabout – 5/4: Estate Opens as Park, and Plans for the National Mall
text: Duke Estate to Open Up The 2,740-acre estate in Hillsborough, N.J., that had been owned by the heiress Doris Duke has gotten a $45 million touch-up and will open to the public as a park on May 19. (The New York Times)

headline: Two Heads Work Together for Multiple Feet
text: THE choreographer Benjamin Millepied, 34, and the composer Nico Muhly, 30, have created four pieces together since 2007. The most recent, “Two Hearts,” will have its premiere at the New York City Ballet’s spring gala on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater. In recent conversations with Roslyn Sulcas, in New York and on the phone, they talked about their newest work and the nature of their collaboration. These are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: She’d Rather Be Swinging on a Trapeze
text: IN 2002 a teenage Natalia Tena snarled her way onto movie screens in “About a Boy” as Ellie, a London tough who takes an awkward schoolboy under her wing. In the decade since, Ms. Tena’s combination of ferocity and sweetness — with her swooping brows and penchant for salty language, she seems the kind of woman who would just as soon kick as hug you — has landed her supporting roles as Nymphadora Tonks in the Harry Potter franchise and, more recently, as Osha in HBO’s “Game of Thrones.”

headline: A Change of Scenery a Short Hop From Asia’s Cities
text: In Seoul or Beijing, craving some mountain air? Do you want to get out on the waterways of Hong Kong? Three of our correspondents in Asia have some suggestions. Choe Sang-Hun takes the Bukaksan Fortress Walk; Didi Kirsten Tatlow explores temple ruins at Silver Mountain and Joyce Hor-Chung Lau takes the Star Ferry.

headline: Vocation or Exploration? Pondering the Purpose of College
text: OUR oldest son is finishing up his junior year in high school, and we’re already overwhelmed by what I’ve been calling the college challenge — trying to figure out what college he can get into and what we can afford.

headline: May 6 — 12
text: THE first  MONTCLAIR FILM FESTIVAL in New Jersey concludes on Sunday with a lineup that includes a King and a Boss.

headline: 5 Things You’ll Learn in the Money Issue
text: This Sunday, we bring you The Money Issue. Check out our video introduction to what you’ll find in the magazine. And if you want to continue taking the easy way out, here are five things you’ll learn if you read the whole thing:

headline: Scriptless in Seattle: A Filmmaker’s Map
text: SEATTLE

headline: A Center for Those Seeking Help Is Now Struggling
text: A long line of older people with shopping carts lined the rain-slicked sidewalk on Henry Street in the Lower East Side this week. One by one, they entered an old brick building, trudged down a short flight of creaky stairs, and picked up their weekly lifeline from a food pantry. Next door, in a church-basement English class, a group of Asian women sang “God Bless America,” before the teacher peppered them with questions.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: A sausage stand opens at noon Friday at Vandaag, 103 Second Avenue (East Sixth Street), a Northern European-inspired restaurant in the East Village. The chef Humberto Guallpa will be offering three types of sausages, including a pickled beef frank and a minced pork and beef fried sausage. The seasonal “Wurstelstand” will open from noon to midnight Sunday through Thursday and until 2 a.m. on Friday and Saturday. The stand is located on East Sixth Street, close to Second Avenue.

headline: Digging Deeper Into Green Mountain’s Profits
text: It’s time to question the financials of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters.

headline: Conrad Black Is Freed
text: Conrad M. Black, the fallen newspaper baron, was released from a federal prison in Miami on Friday, according to news reports.

headline: Now Collaborating | Marni and Brian Rea
text: “We see the line as an opportunity to experiment with art and products,” says the designer Consuelo Castiglioni about Marni’s Edition collaborations. For what is now the third attempt — past projects included a series of watercolor sketches by Kim Gordon and painted plastic bags by the artist Claude Caillol — Castiglioni tapped the New York Times contributing illustrator Brian Rea, whose whimsical line drawings accompany the Styles section’s “Modern Love” column. “When I came across Brian Rea’s work, I was captured by his vision,” she says.

headline: Off the Charts: Shrinking Government
text: The government sector of the economy shrank during the first three years of the Obama administration, but the private sector grew more rapidly than it did during the first three years of either of George W. Bush’s terms in office. The charts show the growth in gross domestic product from the first quarter of the year in which each president was inaugurated through the first quarter of the subsequent election year. All figures are adjusted for inflation.

headline: Santorum Has a Private Meeting With Romney
text: PITTSBURGH — Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum met Friday morning in Pittsburgh before Mr. Romney’s campaign event here, their first private meeting since Mr. Santorum dropped out of the Republican primary last month.

headline: Does Helicopter Parenting Drive Dads to Cheat?
text: From the department of impulsive yet compelling conclusions drawn from dubious data comes this one: the adultery-enabling Web site Ashley Madison says that Park Slope, Brooklyn, is home to more cheating spouses than any other neighborhood in New York City.

headline: Iranians Vote in a Runoff for Parliament
text: TEHRAN — Conservative factions that already dominate Parliament here seemed to be cruising to victory on Friday in a second round of elections to the 290-member assembly.

text: Stories from the world of the Olympics, from around the Web.

headline: A Little Trouble in Big China
text: Half a world away from the battlefields of Virginia, a small community of American traders and missionaries in the international port of Shanghai watched the Civil War play out as a distant and grinding agony. News from the United States took at least two months to reach them – and when it did, the anxiety many felt to leap onto the next California-bound steamer generally faded when they thought through how long it would actually take before they could get back home, enlist and put on a uniform.

headline: Breakthrough Performances
text: Dennis Lim looks at some of the noteworthy performances of the summer movies season.

headline: Unemployment, Beyond the Rate
text: The unemployment rate is a measuring stick with many problems, one of which is that it tends to shift our focus from a human tragedy to the measuring stick itself, as if we were discussing the level of water in a reservoir.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Eye Exam Solved!
text: On Thursday I challenged Well readers to figure out a medical mystery involving a middle-aged woman who learned she had an unusual disease after visiting an ophthalmologist. The case was surprising because the woman didn’t feel sick, yet the doctor made the diagnosis just by looking at her and asking her a few simple questions that confirmed his diagnostic suspicions.

headline: Government Getting Smaller in the U.S.
text: FOR the first time in 40 years, the government sector of the American economy has shrunk during the first three years of a presidential administration.

headline: Chapeaux, Chapeaux
text: Philip Treacy, the milliner responsible to so many trembling heads, including some royal ones, was giving a hat-making demonstration when Suzy Menkes and I walked in. Ms. Menkes and I had just wrapped up a 90-minute dish with journalism students at the Academy of Art University in San Francisco. The school held its fashion graduation show on Thursday, and Ms. Menkes and I, along with Mr. Treacy, Sarah Burton of Alexander McQueen, and Princess Reema Bandar Al-Saud, a prominent retailer, were there to there to meet students and talk about our jobs.

headline: Why Mario Chalmers Is So Effective
text: Now down 3-0 in their first-round playoff series against the Miami Heat, the Knicks have struggled to contain LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh.

headline: Kids Draw the News | Pharaoh Bloomberg
text: Our second Kids Draw the News assignment, “The Pharaoh Bloomberg Incident,” has brought 15 submissions and still counting — from as far off as Burundi in central Africa!

headline: Romney May Come to Regret Comment on Job Creation
text: Every president makes statements as a candidate that he later comes to regret once he is in the White House. He finds himself held to a standard that sounded good on the campaign trail, but may not be realistic in office.

headline: A Final Hunt for Fossils in Nazaria
text: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

headline: Don’t Be Shocked by More Big Acquisitions, Facebook Says
text: If you thought the $1 billion Instagram buy was big, don’t be surprised by more big buys: Facebook will continue to invest in things that rev up its presence on mobile phones.

headline: New York Times Co. Lays Off 50 in Non-Newsroom Jobs
text: The New York Times Company cut about 50 positions this week from human resources, legal, finance and other corporate departments, the company confirmed on Friday.

headline: On a Roll, Maryland Prepares for the N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: It’s becoming more and more apparent–the Maryland women’s lacrosse team is as strong as it’s ever been. After winning three straight games to win the A.C.C. tournament title and then routing No. 15 Georgetown even while on their last legs, the Terrapins will be impossible for the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee to overlook on Sunday.

headline: Remembering the Dead: New Names for a Wall That Keeps Growing
text: Early this Saturday morning in the Florida Panhandle, in keeping with a schedule set in motion decades ago, a crowd will gather around a memorial for a solemn roll call – the names of a specialized group of American service members, 289 in all, who have died in the line of duty since 1942.

headline: Business Day Live: Owning a Bit of Facebook
text: Frenzied interest in Facebook’s pending market debut; Dean Maki of Barclays looks at employment numbers; and James B. Stewart on the decline and fall of Dewey & LeBoeuf.

headline: Mayor Offers Few Details on Romney’s New York Visit
text: The candidate was pleasant. He acknowledged that New York was amazing. And, if he walked down the street, the mayor would greet him, and by his first name, no less.

headline: Finding Ways to Protect an Investment in Horses
text: Paul Sullivan has been writing the last couple of weeks about investing from the heart — choosing investments that reflect a passion. Last week, he wrote about filmmaking as an alternative investment. This week, in a nod to the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, he wrote about investing in racehorses.

headline: Therapy of a Different Sort
text: The six women who gathered in Wendy Wilson’s living room in Massapequa, on Long Island, on a Saturday morning — five in person, one on speakerphone from Florida — were talking about dependence and independence, big issues for people ages 75 to 88.

headline: Muslim Woman Bridges Faiths to Advance Progressive Goals
text: Faiza N. Ali paced across the plaza outside City Hall in Lower Manhattan, consulting a to-do list and juggling the messages on two BlackBerries. How was the turnout? Were the speakers prepped? One minister had already alerted Ms. Ali that he was running late. Another of her colleagues had gone to Borough Hall in Brooklyn by mistake.

headline: The Investor Next Door
text: FOR as long as there have been condominiums, there have been investors hoping to make an easy profit off an apartment here or there.

headline: Invasion of the Phillies Fans
text: Nationals Chief Operating Officer Andrew Feffer did not like what he saw, or heard, when his team hosted the Philadelphia Phillies last August. Attendance totals may have been the highest of the season, but it was hardly a home crowd.

headline: U.S. to Restart Tribunal, Aiming to Show It’s Fair
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba  — As the United States restarts its effort to prosecute — and ultimately execute — five detainees accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks, it has fallen to Brig. Gen. Mark S. Martins both to prove them guilty and to show the world that the tribunal system is now legitimate.

headline: TimesCast | May 5, 2012
text: The United States added 115,000 jobs in April | The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof discusses the case of Chen Guangcheng | A knee injury may end Mariano Rivera’s career.

headline: Well-Rested D’Angelo to Give First U.S. Performance in 10 Years
text: It has been more than a decade since D’Angelo, the reclusive R&B singer from Virginia, had a hit song or gave a concert. His last album, “Voodoo,” came out in 2000, went platinum and won two Grammy Awards, including one for best R&B album. But since then he has stayed away from the music scene and has been in the news only for his occasional run-ins with the law.

headline: Royal Entrances for Budding Stars
text: Léa Seydoux, ‘Farewell, My Queen’

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Robert Caro discusses the new volume in his series about Lyndon Johnson; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Charlotte Rogan talks about her debut novel, “The Lifeboat”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Moment
text: An advertisement from President Obama's 2008 campaign for president.

headline: Third Point Demands Yahoo C.E.O. Be Fired by Monday
text: It appears that Third Point’s Daniel S. Loeb senses a lot of blood in the water after his latest attack on Yahoo.

headline: No Maverick
text: An advertisement from President Obama's 2008 campaign for president.

headline: Fundamentals
text: An advertisement from President Obama's 2008 campaign for president.

headline: Justice Delayed, Torture Classified
text: After an unconscionably long delay of nearly a decade, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks will be arraigned Saturday in a military commission at Guantanamo Bay.

headline: Outsourcing
text: An advertisement from Barbara Boxer's 2010 campaign for Senate.

headline: Philharmonic Shifts Central Park Dates to Give the Grass a Break
text: The New York Philharmonic said on Friday that it was moving the dates of its two Central Park concerts this summer closer together so the stage would not have to be set up twice, saving wear and tear on the Great Lawn. The concerts will take place July 13 and 16, instead of July 12 and 17.

headline: Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Psychology Today
text: When I was assigned Psychology Today for this miniseries in which editors here are reading every last word of another magazine and reporting “what they learned,” I wondered briefly about the pairing of publication and reader, but tried not to read too much into it. I’m interested in human behavior, so, why not? Then I picked up the current issue. The cover story: “Difficult People. How to Handle Whiners, Manipulators, Bullies & More.” The story profiles difficult “types” (the Hostile, the Egotist, the Neurotic) and how best to deal with them — especially, I feel compelled to point out, in work situations.

headline: Clashes Erupt Again as Egypt Nears End of Transition
text: CAIRO — For the third time in a week, deadly clashes erupted near Egypt’s Defense Ministry when military policemen fired tear gas and water cannons and threw rocks to disperse tens of thousands of protesters, in a sign of growing tensions as the country nears the end of a turbulent 15-month political transition.

headline: Book Review Podcast: L.B.J. in the White House
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Bill Clinton reviews “The Passage of Power,” the latest volume in Robert Caro’s epic series about Lyndon Johnson. The book includes a portrait of Mr. Johnson during his time as vice president, when the power he had wielded as a legislator was sorely missed. Mr. Clinton writes:

headline: Marine Ecosystem Pledges Unmet, Data Shows
text: Countries have made little progress in meeting their obligations to protect fragile marine ecosystems under the international Convention on Biological Diversity, new United Nations data shows.

headline: Family of Seau Decides to Give Brain for Study
text: The family of the former N.F.L. linebacker Junior Seau will allow his brain to be examined by researchers who study head trauma, according to a chaplain for the San Diego Chargers.

headline: North Carolina’s Ban on Gay Marriage Appears Likely to Pass
text: On Tuesday, North Carolina will vote on a state constitutional amendment that declares, “Marriage between one man and one woman is the only domestic legal union that shall be valid or recognized,” thereby banning recognition of same-sex marriage, civil unions and domestic partnerships of any kind.

headline: Florida Library Removes ‘Fifty Shades of Grey,’ Erotic Trilogy, From Shelves
text: 2:51 p.m. | Updated The “Fifty Shades of Grey” trilogy has swept bestseller lists across the country for weeks, revitalized stale marriages and captivated scores of women drawn to its erotic fiction. But in the eyes of some librarians, it’s nothing but pornography.

headline: Pearson Defends Use of Pineapple Story on State Test
text: Pearson, the testing company, says it stands behind the math and reading tests the company developed for New York State this year and, in a letter to the state Education Department, defended its decision to include a now-notorious passage about a pineapple and a hare on the eighth grade English language-arts exam.

headline: For Olczyk, the Lure of Hockey and Horses
text: Eddie Olczyk is well known in hockey circles. He played 16 seasons as a center in the N.H.L., winning the Stanley Cup with the Rangers in 1994, and coached the Pittsburgh Penguins from 2003 to 2005. Now a game analyst  for NBC Sports Group, currently covering the Rangers-Washington Capitals playoff series, he is also a Chicago Blackhawks broadcaster. What many don’t know is that Olczyk, 45, is a horseplayer and has owned horses. He joined us in making our Derby picks this year.

headline: Precisely
text: An advertisement from Barbara Boxer's 2010 campaign for Senate.

headline: Workers
text: An advertisement from Barbara Boxer's 2010 campaign for Senate.

headline: Mitt vs. Mitt
text: An advertisement from President Obama's 2012 campaign for president.

headline: Swiss Bank Account
text: An advertisement From President Obama's 2012 campaign.

headline: J_dimps Tweets
text: A Staten Island grandmother amasses a large following on Twitter.

headline: A Recycling Czar for New York City
text: In a sign that New York City is getting serious about improving its poor recycling record, the city’s Department of Sanitation is appointing a recycling industry innovator as its new “deputy commissioner for recycling and sustainability.”

headline: Miami Heat | The Webster for Target
text: When Laure Heriard Dubreuil, the owner of the Miami boutique the Webster, was growing up in France’s Cognac region and Paris in the 1980s and ’90s she and her sisters would dress identically, and even her brothers wore corresponding outfits. Those days may be over for Heriard Dubreuil et famille, but her new collection for Target offers summer dresses in the same kind of “joyful, vibrant” prints and silhouettes. Baby sis can wear a smocked version of her older sibling’s A-line look in a flamingo print. And there’s a palm-leaf motif (inspired by the wallpaper at the the Webster) in a maxi-dress for toddlers and tweens alike. Actually, Heriard Dubreuil has done the same piece for mom, as well as “to die for” color-blocked cardigans for both mother and daughter and scarves that “women are going to steal from their teenagers.” All proof that matchy-matchy can be a good thing.

headline: Scientist Sentenced in French Terror Case
text: PARIS — A Paris court on Friday sentenced a French-Algerian particle physicist to five years in prison, one of them suspended, on the charge of “criminal association with the intent to prepare terrorist acts,” ruling that the man’s online correspondence in 2009 with a presumed member of Al Qaeda constituted a criminal act.

headline: Stoudemire Wants to Play on Sunday
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – If the Knicks are going to get swept by the Miami Heat, it will apparently come with Amar’e Stoudemire on the court, in a jersey and shorts, not on the bench, with his arm in a sling.

headline: At Campaign Stop, Romney Tries to Capitalize on Weak Jobs Report
text: O’HARA, Pa. — Following a television appearance Friday morning, Mitt Romney used a campaign stop here to again capitalize on the disappointing job growth in April and criticize President Obama for what he called “a sad time in America.”

headline: Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys Dies
text: 9:38 p.m. | Updated  An obituary for Adam Yauch, by The Times’s Jon Pareles, is available here.

headline: Hundreds Mourn 7 Family Members Who Died in a Bronx Car Crash
text: On Friday morning, the day before Jazlyn Gonzalez was supposed to receive her first holy communion, she arrived at the Church of St. Raymond in the Bronx for the last time, in a shiny white coffin.

headline: Teenage Magazines and Airbrushed, Unattainable Beauty
text: Julia Bluhm’s Change.org petition hit my Facebook page and my Twitter feed on Thursday, and maybe yours as well.

headline: Steven Blier and James S. Russell
text: AS the artistic director of the New York Festival of Song, Steven Blier can conjure up a ballad, madrigal or lied appropriate to any romantic situation.

headline: Harden and Davis Are Added to U.S. Basketball Roster
text: The Olympic roster for the U.S. men’s basketball team – currently in something of an infant state – has already been plagued by injury. Star center Dwight Howard had surgery to address a herniated disk in his back, and will be unavailable for the summer games. Just days ago, we saw Derrick Rose’s gold medal aspirations mirror his crumpled form on the hardwood floor – downed and folded due to a torn A.C.L. Roster hopefuls LaMarcus Aldridge (labral tear) and Chauncey Billups (torn Achilles) also underwent surgery to deal with their respective ailments, cutting Team U.S.A.’s 20-man roster down to just 16 available players.

headline: TNT’s Renews Police Drama ‘Southland’
text: Good news for fans of realistic — by television standards, anyway — police dramas: TNT announced on Friday that it had ordered a fifth season of the critically praised but anemically rated “Southland.” Ten new episodes will be produced, with the premiere scheduled for February.

headline: Before Camaro ZL1’s Quarter-Mile Run, a Strength-Training Regimen
text: On Friday, Chevrolet noted in a news release that its engineers had run a showroom-stock 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1, fitted with a 6-speed automatic transmission, through the quarter mile in 11.93 seconds at 116 miles per hour. A ZL1 with a 6-speed manual was clocked in 11.96 seconds at 117 m.p.h.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Beautiful Way to Get the Weather
text: Aside from games, perhaps no other category of apps is as cluttered as the weather category.

headline: Sarkozy Supporters Attack French Journalists
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy appears to have soured on the news media in France, lashing out on Friday at what he described as “intolerance and bias.”

headline: Living In | Cutchogue, L.I.
text: In the Town of Southold, a hamlet popular with second-home buyers; properties range from raised ranches to hilltop estates.

headline: A Summer Place, Magnetic Year-Round
text: LOUISA HARGRAVE came to Cutchogue in 1973 because she and her husband at the time, Alex, discovered that as the sunniest place in New York State, it is ideal for growing grapes to make wine. They founded Hargrave Vineyard and helped start an industry that has transformed the North Fork of Long Island, which is home today to nearly 50 vineyards and wineries.

headline: The Munchkins Are a Problem: The Wonderful Land of Oz
text: On the day of the fifth grade musical, Helene Stapinski is picking  up balloons, putting final touches on the set, opening windows -- and running around the building trying to find her mother-in-law a pillow to cushion her healing hip. But soon the curtain opens, and ....  Find out what happens in this final installment of "The Munchkins Are a Problem: One Mom’s Struggle to Direct the Fifth-Grade School Play."

headline: In the Netherlands, 100 Gardens and More, in a Once-a-Decade ‘Theater of Nature’
text: For flower lovers traveling to the Netherlands, this is a special year: The Floriade horticultural expo, which only comes around every decade, runs until Oct. 7 in Venlo, in the southeastern part of the country.

headline: For the Knicks, the Point Guard Problem Gets Worse
text: Three games into their best of seven series, the Miami Heat have dominated the Knicks. Although some of the games have been close at times, Miami has pulled out victories by margins of 33, 10 and 17 points. That the Heat have not allowed the Knicks within 10 points of victory by the final buzzer speaks to their authority in this engagement. Although most pundits expected the Knicks to put up a stronger fight, the reason for the poor showing from the New York crew is the lack of a good point guard.

headline: How Florida Got Better
text: Kitty Cullen has more help this year. The junior attacker and Tewaaraton Award finalist is not putting up the same gaudy statistics she did in 2011, but her team is stronger.

headline: Barn Raising
text: Like a lot of people who are not originally from New York City, Tiina Laakkonen had a hard time thinking of the Hamptons as “the country.” Laakkonen, a former model and now a fashion stylist who has worked for The Times, grew up in Imatra, a small town in Finland, and likes to joke that she comes from “peasant stock” and doesn’t understand “fancy things like swimming pools.” Her husband, Jon Rosen, who owns the digital post-production company Nucleus Imaging, spent his childhood summers in Amagansett, N.Y., and has an almost Proustian attachment to the area. So when it came to finding a house there, Laakkonen insisted that it be a true country house. Or as she puts it, “I’m not a horsy person, but I like the idea of it.”

headline: ‘Neighborhood Watch’ Becomes ‘The Watch’ to Distance Itself From Martin Shooting
text: LOS ANGELES — “Neighborhood Watch,” the movie, is now just “The Watch.”

headline: TimesCast | Mediocre Jobs Report
text: The United States added 115,000 jobs in April, lower than expected and far below the number needed to keep up with population growth. The report provides some momentum for Mitt Romney.

headline: Liaison Says Heiress Rued Edwards Donations
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Rachel Mellon counted Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis among her dearest friends. She amassed millions through her family’s success with Listerine and her husband’s banking fortune.

headline: TimesCast: Mediocre Jobs Report
text: The United States added 115,000 jobs in April, lower than expected and far below the number needed to keep up with population growth. The report provides some momentum for Mitt Romney. Richard W. Stevenson reports.

headline: In New Ad Campaign, Orbitz Comes Out as Pro-Vacation
text: Orbitz wants to plant a flag, literally and figuratively, as an advocate for leisure travel and taking vacations.

headline: Nicholas D. Kristof on Chen Guangcheng
text: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on whether the Obama administration mishandled the case of the Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng.

headline: A Band of Contrarians, Bullish on Greece
text: LONDON — As Greece girds for an election on Sunday that top politicians warn could ultimately force the country to leave the euro zone, some risk-happy investors have adopted an improbable rallying cry: buy Greek bonds now.

headline: The Get | Understated Summer Sandals

headline: TimesCast | Yankees' Closer Injures Knee
text: May 4, 2012 — The New York Yankees’ 42-year-old star closer, Mariano Rivera, injured his knee while chasing fly balls during batting practice in Kansas City. His storied career may be over.

headline: A 'Mean' Message From the P.S. 176 Chorus
text: Students in the chorus and orchestra at P.S. 176 in Brooklyn included an antibullying song in their spring repertoire: "Mean" by Taylor Swift. In an interview with WNYC's Beth Fertig, the students say the song resonated.

headline: Splayed Roast Chicken With Ramps
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates a different way to roast a chicken.

headline: Going Green, Incognito
text: Ford hopes to ease the transition to electric vehicles with the 2012 Focus Electric, a model that is nearly indistinguishable from the gas-powered version ... in looks, at least.

headline: Splayed Roast Chicken With Caramelized Ramps, Garlic and Capers
text: Time: 1 hour 35 minutes

headline: A New Breed of Roast Chicken, Cast-Iron Seared
text: DOES anyone really need another recipe for roast chicken?

headline: 80-Year-Old Widow Is the Rage on Twitter
text: Life became listless for Josephine Lamberti, 80, after her husband died several years back, so she turned to a grandson, Donny Brandefine, who she knew made those video “thingies’’ for the Internet.

headline: New Application Is Submitted for Keystone Pipeline
text: TransCanada, the company behind the disputed Keystone XL pipeline, submitted a new application for the project to the State Department on Friday, as expected. The company will route the pipeline around the environmentally sensitive Sand Hills region of Nebraska, and the revised proposal starts a fresh clock on the environmental review process.

headline: Mattingly Hopes Rivera Keeps Pitching
text: CHICAGO – Don Mattingly’s final season was Mariano Rivera’s first. Mattingly retired from the Yankees after an excruciating playoff loss in 1995. He said he hopes Rivera does not retire after Thursday’s knee injury in Kansas City.

headline: Cherishing Sun-Baked Cinema
text: ‘Lifeguard’ (1976)

headline: Of the Many Ways to Roast a Chicken, What’s Your Favorite?
text: There are so many techniques for roasting a whole chicken.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $31,500,000
text: A full-floor apartment at 1030 Fifth Avenue that sold for $31.5 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: What Corporate Governance Experts Are Saying About Yahoo’s Chief
text: What should one make of the latest imbroglio ensnaring Yahoo, namely the revelation that its chief executive, Scott Thompson, had inflated his academic credentials?

headline: Duran Duran Sails Back to ‘Rio’
text: Exactly 30 years ago, Duran Duran, dressed in fluorescent suits, perched themselves at the bow of a fabulously elegant ketch named Eilean to make the music video for “Rio.” That video remains iconic, but its 70-foot star spent much of the past three decades in a sad state of disrepair — even sinking briefly, and then becoming fodder for termites. It took the chief executive of the fine watch company Panerai to restore the Eilean to its ’80s-pop glory. And late last month, the boat was finally reunited with the Duran Duran members Simon Le Bon, Nick Rhodes and Roger Taylor during the Antigua Classic Yacht Regatta, a gentlemanly racing event that brings together classic yachts from around the world.

headline: Heartland Pulls Billboard on Global Warming
text: Drivers moving along Chicago’s inbound Eisenhower Expressway on Friday may have been surprised to see Ted Kaczynski, the so-called Unabomber, staring at them from a massive billboard. “I still believe in global warming. Do you?” the billboard read in large maroon letters. Just below was the Web address www.heartland.org.

headline: Recharging Retro While Pondering the Ambitions and Choices of Today
text: Deep misgivings lurk in the lean, confident, sleekly retro pop songs of Electric Guest, a Los Angeles band that performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night. “I know I, I won’t make it/don’t know what to do,” Asa Taccone sang over the tootling major chords and snappy, handclapping beat of “Waves” from the group’s debut album, “Mondo” (Downtown/Across the Universe).

headline: Adding Mussel to Your Meal
text: Mussels are a delicious and sustainable way to get your heart-healthy omega-3 fatty acids, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: McDonagh’s Minutes: Even More Impressive
text: Ryan McDonagh’s 53 minutes 17 seconds of ice time during the Rangers’ three-overtime Game 3 victory at Washington that stretched from Wednesday evening to Thursday morning was  remarkable for many reasons — and now a new statistical fillip makes it even more remarkable still.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: The Stock Everyone Wants
text: Although most of the shares in Facebook’s multibillion-dollar offering will go to large investors, a slice will be reserved for “the people.” And a once-ambitious law firm has been reduced to grim dispatches. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Adding a Little Flicker to Those Lights
text: “YOU look so ... glamorous,” says a fellow mom at my son’s Sunday morning soccer game. “Thank you!” I reply, slightly puzzled, as I’m wearing no makeup, yoga pants, a puffy jacket and a “Dog Is My Co-Pilot” T-shirt.

headline: Through the Lens of His Camera, a Different Perspective
text: Everyone comes to horse racing by a different route. Mine was through my father. He taught me how to read The Daily Racing Form, and exposed me to the great horses during the Triple Crown seasons in the late 1970s as I lay on the family room floor watching Seattle Slew and Affirmed become Triple Crown champions.

headline: Wheelies: The Meet the New Boss Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Sifting Through Evil in a Hunt for Buried Gold
text: It has Eddie Izzard, and it has fishnets, but no, Mr. Izzard is not doing his cross-dressing thing again. He’s having what appears to be a pretty good seafaring time clomping around on one-and-a-half legs in “Treasure Island,” a new, four-hour version of Robert Louis Stevenson’s find-the-gold story being broadcast Saturday on Syfy.

headline: Pointing the Way to Where E.V. Drivers Can Plug In
text: IN the effort to establish standards that will encourage the acceptance of electric vehicles, there has been much wrangling over the development of a universal design for the plugs that connect battery chargers to cars.

headline: The Battery-Driven Car Just Got a Lot More Normal
text: BERKELEY, Calif.

headline: Importing Japan’s Forbidden Models
text: LIKE many young men whose passion is cars, Chris Collins learned early on where to find driving excitement. The tuner-division specials, the spirited models with high-revving engines and extrasensory suspensions — those were the machines he craved.

headline: Fairfield Concours Is Canceled
text: THE consulting group formed by the directors of the Fairfield County Concours d’Élégance, the collector-car weekend in Connecticut that traditionally ends the concours season in the Northeast, announced last week that the event would not take place this year.

headline: Argentina Tweaks Britain With Olympic Ad Shot Secretly in Falklands
text: Britain’s defense minister demanded an apology from the Argentine government on Friday for a “provocative” television commercial tied to the London Olympics that restates Argentina’s claim to the Falkland Islands.

headline: The Anatomy of a Power Couple
text: CHRIS HUGHES, 28, publisher and editor in chief

headline: Elite Colleges and Wall Street’s Recruiting Machine
text: Despite Wall Street’s reported recruiting problems, which made headlines after the resignation of Greg Smith, a Goldman Sachs executive, the nation’s financial firms are still drawing top graduates with six-figure incomes that can relieve the financial burden of student loans, a recent college graduate writes.

headline: Rulebook Has a Few Exceptions
text: BRINGING a car into the United States that was not originally engineered to meet federal regulations can be a monumental task. Emissions equipment and safety gear may need to be installed, and crash testing may be required.

headline: AT&T Chief Regrets Offering Unlimited Data for iPhone
text: When Randall Stephenson, AT&T’s chief executive, spoke about the state of the wireless industry at a conference this week, he shared some surprisingly frank comments about the iPhone. In particular, he said that he wished the company had never offered an unlimited data plan for the device and that he loses sleep over free texting services like Apple’s iMessage.

headline: A Powerful Combination
text: “Are you twelve?”

headline: Armed With the Classics, and Reaching for More
text: Evgeny Kissin has built a stellar career as an interpreter of the standard Romantic canon, with Chopin and the Russian masters at its heart, and he has become an increasingly thoughtful Brahms and Beethoven pianist as well.

headline: My Head Talks Nonstop
text: I’m on Chris Matthews, starting at the top of the hour at 5, then repeated at 7 I think.

headline: Last Year, Champions. This Year, in Trouble
text: The first two games between the Mavericks and Thunder were emotional, very close affairs. The Thunder won both on home court, but the Mavericks still felt strong hope because the series was shifting to Dallas.

headline: Dish Network Says It Will Drop AMC in Summer
text: Amid a deepening feud with AMC Networks, the Dish Network is starting to inform its customers that it will drop AMC and several other cable channels sometime this summer.

headline: What Cornelius Vanderbilt and J. Paul Getty Have in Common With at Least One Former Bain Partner
text: In this week’s issue of the magazine, Adam Davidson writes about Edward Conard, a friend and former partner of Mitt Romney’s at Bain Capital — and someone willing to speak out on behalf of the proposition that income inequality benefits most Americans. To say so publicly may seem out of step with the times, when you have billionaires famous for driving beat-up pick-up trucks (Warren Buffett) or wearing hoodies (Mark Zuckerberg), but Conard is by no means the first wealthy American to offer a pointed defense of his wealth.

headline: Authentic Japanese
text: Owners of Japanese domestic market cars go to great lengths, and often considerable expense, to find and maintain models configured just as they would be in a Tokyo showroom.

headline: Seventh Grader Sets Met Museum Straight
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acknowledged an error that was pointed out by a seventh-grade boy from West Hartford, Conn., in a 6th-century map of the Byzantine Empire. “In reproducing a map we had done in 2000, we didn’t get it done perfectly,” Helen Evans, the Met’s curator for Byzantine art, said. “He brought it to our attention.”

headline: Composer’s Parting Gift Is One to Remember
text: The Finnish composer Magnus Lindberg is also a skilled pianist. So he is not one of those composers who write demanding piano works without really understanding the degree of difficulty. Mr. Lindberg absolutely knew that his Piano Concerto No. 2 would present awesome technical challenges for the soloist.

headline: Panetta Warns Military Over Afghanistan Misconduct
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned on Friday that the spate of high-profile episodes of misconduct by some troops in Afghanistan not only discredited the entire armed forces, but also damaged America’s chances for battlefield success.

headline: Sit Down, Cool Off and Fire Up a DVD
text: ‘Barbarella’ (1968)

headline: Honoring a Giant of Jazz With an Enduring Voice
text: Louis Armstrong, Sophie Tucker and Ethel Waters: modern popular and jazz singing sprang from this trinity, Michael Feinstein declared on Wednesday evening at the Allen Room, where he presented the Jazz at Lincoln Center program, “Ethel Waters: Blues, Broadway and Jazz.”

headline: Gifts for Enjoying a Touch of Green, Indoors or Out
text: NOT every bride or bridegroom has a green thumb, the desire to maintain a garden or even the luxury of outdoor space. But a touch of green is within everyone’s reach.

headline: On the Market in New York City

headline: If the Ring Finger Isn’t a Green Thumb
text: NOT every bride or bridegroom has a green thumb, the desire to maintain a garden or even the luxury of outdoor space. But a touch of green is within everyone’s reach. Low-maintenance terrariums or indoor cactus gardens make cheerful, lasting gifts. And cooks who enjoy fresh ingredients can grow herbs or harvest a crop of mushrooms just an arm’s length away in their own kitchen.

headline: Performers to Fulfill a Doodler’s Dream
text: “Ambient Cowboy,” a new work by Ivy Baldwin Dance that opened at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, begins with Ms. Baldwin and Lawrence Cassella on a bare stage. Bright lines emerge out of nowhere on the wall behind them, lengthening in free curves that spill over, surprisingly, onto the plane of the floor. Only when the lines are suddenly switched off does it become clear that they are made of light.

headline: 2 New Grandchildren for Romney, With Help of Surrogate
text: Mitt Romney’s oldest son, Tagg, on Friday announced the birth of twin sons with the help of a surrogate. The newest members of the Romney clan, David Mitt and William Ryder, make Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, grandparents of 18.

headline: Heat’s Bosh Returns to Miami to Visit Newborn
text: Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra said Friday that Chris Bosh returned to Miami again on Thursday night after the Heat beat the Knicks to be with his newborn son, Jackson. Bosh will return to New York in time for Game 4 on Sunday afternoon, although Spoelstra said the travel details were still being worked through.

headline: I Promise That if Elected, Everyone Will Win the Lottery
text: Henry IV of France guaranteed a chicken in every pot in the 16th Century. So did the Republicans in 1928. Neither party succeeded, but the potted-chicken notion seems positively modest by the standards of today’s political promises.

headline: Tortorella Praises Callahan, the Quiet Captain
text: WASHINGTON–Rangers Coach John Tortorella has said many times and in many different ways how much he admires and relies on the team’s captain, Ryan Callahan. In the Rangers’ three-overtime 2-1 victory in Game 3, Callahan showed his worth again.

headline: How Many People Believe A.D.H.D. Is Caused by Poor Parenting?
text: Trust even the most casual survey to spit back numbers that reflect what parents of children with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (A.D.H.D.) already know: a good chunk of their peers think children with A.D.H.D. struggle more with poor parenting than with a definable, treatable medical condition.

headline: 5 Philadelphia Priests Are Barred From Ministry
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Roman Catholic archbishop of Philadelphia announced Friday that five priests under investigation for sexual abuse would be permanently removed from ministry, while three other priests had been exonerated. The 8 were among 26 priests who were suspended in early 2011 because of past accusations of sexual abuse or improper sexual behavior.

headline: Chekhov, Rendered Tongue Trippingly
text: Hey, guys, what say we have a Chekhov slumber party? We’ll put on our pajamas, open a few bottles of vodka and sit around and talk about how hopeless our lives are — maybe with Russian accents. Come on, it’ll be fun.

headline: Bain Capital Wants Distance From Retired Partner Who Argues for Inequality
text: Bain Capital, the private equity firm founded by Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, would like to clear something up.

headline: Dewey Leadership Acknowledges the Firm Could Close
text: Dewey & LeBoeuf told employees Friday that the law firm might close and that they could lose their jobs, the first acknowledgment from management of a possible dissolution.

headline: Yankees’ Rivera Vows to Overcome Knee Injury
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Mariano Rivera sat and chatted amiably with Derek Jeter at Jeter’s locker Friday afternoon, an enormous smile somehow creasing his face despite the season-ending injury he had sustained the night before.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 4
text: Subjects include the arrival of the space shuttle Enterprise, Occupy Wall Street protests and 1 World Trade Center, now the tallest building in New York.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: Anyone who has ever renovated a house knows that construction invariably takes longer than expected. You make your decisions about floors and walls, and then weeks become months become, in some instances, years. And you realize that even when taste is a given, patience is a virtue. In this issue we feature homes that are a testament to the consistency and tenacity of their owners. For Francis Upritchard and Martino Gamper, as we learn in Marina Cashdan’s profile, it was a matter of rethinking a curious apartment with no real features (and in a London housing project, no less) over time, when their artistic careers permitted, and with the help of resourceful, clever compatriots. Then there are Jason Schmidt and Bill Mullen’s majestic portraits of New York style setters who dress like their sofas. Finally, in the case of Jon Rosen and Tiina Laakkonen, it was the decision to build from scratch a Scandinavian-inspired compound in Amagansett, N.Y., that was, soup to nuts, of their imagining. And did it drag on? Well, a bit.

headline: ROFLCon: The Internet Goes Offline to Talk Web Culture
text: What makes something a meme? Or perhaps more importantly, what causes a meme, like the Occupy Cop or Disaster Girl, to go viral or even mainstream?

headline: Thoughts From a Week in the Ford Focus Electric
text: Driving the 2012 Ford Focus Electric for a week gave me an opportunity to mull some questions about how a purely electric vehicle ought to behave and look. In this case, my E.V. looked nearly identical to its gas-burning equivalent. It lacked an internal-combustion engine, but from behind the wheel and from outside the car it was, quite simply, normal.

headline: "Forward"
text: An advertisement from Barack Obama's 2012 campaign.

headline: Court Reverses $2 Billion Ruling Against Ford and Orders a New Trial
text: DETROIT — The Ohio Court of Appeals has overturned a judge’s ruling last year that the Ford Motor Company must pay $2 billion to commercial truck dealers who claim they were overcharged by the company for more than a decade, Ford said Friday.

text: An excerpt from a Metropolitan Opera production of Engelbert Humperdinck’s opera.

headline: CBS Threatens ABC Over ‘Glass House,’ a ‘Big Brother’-Like TV Show
text: Lawsuits over blatant copycatting in reality television have gone nowhere in the past, but ABC may be pushing that record with its plans for a summer show called “Glass House.”

headline: Holmes and Watson, Back to Bantering
text: Crime hasn’t disappeared from England as a result of Sherlock Holmes’s 21st-century efforts; it has merely become irrelevant.

headline: Lugar Behind in Indiana Senate Race, Poll Shows
text: Richard G. Lugar, one of the longest-serving members of the United States Senate, is trailing his challenger among likely voters in Indiana’s Republican primary, a poll released Friday said.

headline: HBO Challenged Over Horse Treatment
text: HBO has come under renewed scrutiny for the treatment of horses on “Luck,” its recently canceled dramatic series set in the world of gambling and horse racing, as documents obtained by an advocacy group once again questioned the handling of animals used in the series and the qualifications of professionals charged with looking after them.

headline: State Department Revises Foreign Student Job Program After Abuse Complaints
text: The State Department, responding to a wave of complaints from foreign students about abuses under a summer cultural exchange program, issued new rules on Friday significantly revising the types of jobs the students can do, prohibiting them from most warehouse, construction, manufacturing and food-processing work.

headline: Finding the Humor in Giving Out Comedy Awards
text: We need irreverent comedians more than ever these days, because without them, how could we possibly sit through all those tedious award shows?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Wiretapping the Web, and the App Lottery
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: Discrepancies on Medical Bills Can Leave a Credit Stain
text: When Ray White’s son was about 9 years old, he struck a tree branch while riding his bike. Within minutes, an ambulance whisked him off to the emergency room. The boy recovered, but many months and phone calls later, Mr. White’s insurance company still had not paid the $200 ambulance bill, even though the insurer had assured him it was covered. He finally decided it was easier to pay it himself.

headline: How Much Should Parents Help With School Work?
text: “We have a seventh grader,” A. writes, “and a question. How much should we be helping him with his homework?”

headline: From Israel, a United Nations of Jazz
text: The proposition that jazz is a global language, spanning continents and cultures, has been a reliable diplomatic device for so many years that it now has the ring of a banality.

headline: Students Compete for a Shot at the Golden Pi
text: Hundreds of middle school students will take part in a city-wide math competition on Saturday. They're competing for math glory, a golden Pi trophy and the chance to break open a six-foot tall Pi piñata.

headline: Harvard and M.I.T. Take Their Classes Online
text: Digital classrooms are a growing field, thanks in no small part to success stories like the Khan Academy, so it’s no surprise that traditional brick-and-mortar universities are increasingly looking to add an online element to their learning platforms.

headline: State Testing Is Over. Let's Review.
text: As the state tests began, SchoolBook asked parents and teachers: “How are your children holding up during standardized testing?” One teacher responded: "I remember feeling maybe 1/4 of this stress and panic when I had to take the SAT when I was 17. These kids are 7 and feel the weight of the rest of their lives on their shoulders while they take these tests." Here's a roundup of other responses.

headline: It’s No Tomato, but a Stalk Gets Some Respect
text: WINSLOW TOWNSHIP, N.J.

headline: Rooftop Cuisine, Reincarnated
text: WITH spring temperatures regularly hitting the 70s, one of the best places to eat in downtown New Haven is the roof deck at 266 College Street. Until this year, that would have been Bespoke, a contemporary Mediterranean restaurant. But this spring, you’ll be eating mezze at its new incarnation, Gilt Moroccan Steakhouse and Lounge.

headline: Video of the Security Crackdown in Cairo
text: As my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Liam Stack reported from Cairo, security forces fired tear gas, shot water cannons and threw rocks at tens of thousands of demonstrators who converged on Friday at the headquarters of Egypt’s defense ministry.

headline: Frustrating Day May End With Trip Home for Woods
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Tiger Woods knew even before he walked off the course Friday that he would not be back this weekend at the Wells Fargo Championship.

headline: Bollywood Characters Pursuing Weapons While Fleeing the Deadliest One, the Past
text: Like many Hindi movies, “Jannat 2” doesn’t like to keep you guessing about its characters’ motivations. Why is that cop (Randeep Hooda) swigging whiskey and preparing to dangle a suspect off a bridge? Because, his partner soon explains, he has lost his wife and vowed revenge against the gun smugglers who killed her.

headline: Classic Dishes on an Eclectic Menu
text: KUDOS to chefs with big ideas, both in food and in bricks and mortar. These visionaries have repurposed all manner of neglected buildings, turning river piers, churches, warehouses and factories into handsome dining spots. In Westchester County, one of the most recent and brilliant of these renovations is Club Car, carved into the handsome 19th-century Mamaroneck train station. The careful renewal of this jewel is the work of Brian MacMenamin, the executive chef, and the resulting restaurant is a beauty.

headline: Judge Halts Martin Marietta Bid for Vulcan Materials
text: A Delaware judge on Friday blocked Martin Marietta Materials for four months from pursuing its proxy fight and hostile bid for Vulcan Materials.

headline: Spring’s Plays Offer Peek at New Home
text: THIS spring’s play readings by the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater of South Orange, to take place May 16 and 23, will look slightly different from the way they usually do. In addition to hearing two new plays read by company members, audience members will have a chance to preview the nonprofit theater’s future home: the Oakes Center in Summit.

headline: Revisiting a Thriller, Revised as a Farce
text: A handsome man accused of murder is running for his life on the roof of a speeding train at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. Actually, he is pretend-running across some luggage lying on a mostly bare stage, but the audience buys the illusion with a smile.

headline: An Undefeated Boxer’s Next Challenge: Prison
text: As Floyd Mayweather Jr. prepares to face up to 87 days in jail for domestic violence and harassment charges, he remains focused on the ring.

headline: Pearson Says Its Tests Are 'Valid and Reliable'
text: Pearson, which has a $32 million contract to develop tests for New York State, defended a controversial question involving a talking pineapple on one of its reading tests.

headline: U.S. Final for World Mind Sports Games
text: The final of the trial to select the United States open team for the World Mind Sports Games looked, on Friday afternoon, as though it would be a battle between the top seed, Nick Nickell-Ralph Katz, Bob Hamman-Zia Mahmood and Jeff Meckstroth-Eric Rodwell; and the second seed, John Diamond-Brian Platnick, Fred Gitelman-Brad Moss and Eric Greco-Geoff Hampson.

headline: On Keeping Medical Bills From Hurting Your Credit Score
text: Paying your medical bills is becoming more complicated, particularly as more patients become responsible for a greater share of their medical costs. And often, hospitals and other providers are turning over bills more quickly to collection agencies.

text: HUNTINGTON, N.Y.

headline: Warren Continues to Face Questions About American Indian Status
text: LAWRENCE, Mass. — Elizabeth Warren received an enthusiastic welcome at a lively labor breakfast here on Friday – the first in a string of campaign stops for the day – but she continued to face questions over whether she unfairly claimed status as an American Indian to advance her academic career.

headline: A Sneak Peek at Thomas Demand’s Storm-Tossed Imagination
text: Three years ago, the German conceptual artist Thomas Demand saw a startling video on YouTube that captured the chaotic scene inside a cruise ship being tossed about by a storm in the South Pacific. Everything not bolted down — chairs, tables, bottles, cartons, people — could be seen sliding back and forth across the floor as the ship rocked violently. But where most viewers might have forwarded the link to their friends, Demand decided to recreate the scene, minus the people, entirely out of paper and cardboard, then film it.

headline: Examining Wyeth Anew
text: Blown against a gray granite rock face by a winter’s worth of wind, the brown-and-beige mound of tangled leaves, twigs and dry pine needles seemed to be lying by the road waiting for a painter to happen by. Especially a painter enamored of muted color, desiccated texture and minute detail.
