headline: At the Boathouse Seeking Love
text: Ah, if only the path to true love really were a waltz! That is what Matt Friedman, the gentle but determined hero of Lanford Wilson’s Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning “Talley’s Folly,” wants to believe. Shortly after he makes that assertion, though, he learns that there can be many a wounding stumble on that dance floor. And it’s hard to imagine a more vigorous metaphor for those missteps than a 42-year-old accountant in a three-piece suit trying to balance himself on ice skates on the wooden floor of a broken-down Victorian boathouse.

headline: Living in the New Metropolis
text: About half of humanity lives in a city, and by 2050, it’s likely that 70 percent of the world’s population will be in urban areas, according to United Nations predictions.

headline: Treasury to Sell More Shares in A.I.G. as Stock Recovers
text: The government is loosening its grip on the American International Group, the insurer bailed out by taxpayers during the financial crisis.

headline: A Familiar Location, but New Ambitions
text: THE owners, the chef and the menu are new at the Americana Kitchen and Bar in Syosset, which opened in March, and a banner outside reads, “Grand Opening.” The name, though, is little changed from that of the previous restaurant at this location, which was called 516 American Kitchen and Bar.  Adding to the confusion is the logo of the new place, which consists of an interstate highway sign with the numbers 516.

headline: On an Island, Worker Bees Fill a Long White Hive
text: Randalls Island is a green piece of Manhattan real estate separating the East and Harlem Rivers. In the century after the city acquired the land in 1835, it was the site of a poorhouse; a reformatory for juvenile delinquents; and a hospital for “Idiots and Children.”

headline: Frieze New York
text: Frieze, the contemporary art fair that originated in London nine years ago, introduces a New York franchise.

headline: Introducing Opinionated Video Hangouts
text: Over the past several months, The Times has been experimenting with Google+ Hangouts, an innovative feature of Google+ that has allowed us to host live video conversations between our journalists and our readers and broadcast them publicly. Here in the Opinion department, we are excited to announce a special series of Hangouts that we’ll debut over the coming months.

headline: Dallas Prepares for a Last Stand
text: DALLAS — Derek Fisher sat courtside Friday at American Airlines Center and soaked in the spectrum of perspective this particular piece of hardwood has come to represent in the past year.

headline: Has Obama’s Magic Jobs Number Changed?
text: Earlier this year, just before the government’s January employment report came out, I wrote that creating 150,000 jobs per month seemed to be a rough breakeven number for President Obama. If payroll growth came in above that number, he looked to be a favorite for re-election and an underdog otherwise.

headline: Dewey’s Fall Underscores Law Firms’ New Reality
text: When I graduated from law school in the 1970s, Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood rolled off the tongue in the same company as Sullivan & Cromwell, Davis Polk & Wardwell, and Cravath, Swaine & Moore, venerable New York firms whose place at the pinnacle of the law profession seemed unassailable. For a young lawyer, a job at any of them was the first step to the golden ring of partnership and, with it, lifetime tenure, prestige and affluence.

headline: Turning Virginia Blue
text: In 2008, Barack Obama became the first Democrat to win Virginia in more than 40 years, in part because of inroads he made in the Richmond area and growing suburbs in the southern part of the state.

headline: Attention, Riders: A Word From Two Rail Chiefs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tell Us About the MCA You Knew
text: Adam Yauch was a New Yorker of countless locations — from the halls of Brooklyn Friends School and Murrow High School to the streets of the East Village to seemingly every single loft, club and venue where noise could be made and shows bum-rushed. Perhaps in his travels across the city, you met Mr. Yauch, before he was a Beastie Boy, when he was touring, or when he went by MCA or Nathanial Hornblower. Tell us about it.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Tops
text: Fascinators were the highlight last week of the 30th Frederick Law Olmsted luncheon of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy.

headline: Serbs Losing Fervor for European Union Accession
text: PETROVAC NA MLAVI, Serbia — Looking eerily like the Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic, a stout and stern-faced Ivica Dacic roused supporters crowded in a sports arena here this past week, promising to protect Serbs from the ravages of capitalism and warning that violence against Serbs in Kosovo was tantamount to an assault on Belgrade.

headline: The Short Hot Life of Heartland’s Hateful Climate Billboard
text: The online spin cycle on global warming has become so fast and toxic that an electronic billboard in Chicago can flash an ultra-offensive message designed to draw attention to a conference of climate contrarians, then generate a global burst of Web traffic and then be withdrawn 24 hours later as “a necessary price to make an emotional appeal to people who otherwise aren’t following the climate change debate” (the statement this afternoon from the Heartland Institute, the group that paid for the messages).

headline: An Indie Impresario, Who Made His Mark Fast and Memorably
text: Adam Yauch, who died Friday of cancer at 47, was one of the best things to happen to American independent cinema in years. In February 2008, when Mr. Yauch announced the arrival of his distribution company, Oscilloscope Pictures, which he founded with David Fenkel, it sent a jolt through the indie world. An offshoot of Mr. Yauch’s Oscilloscope Laboratories, his and Mr. Fenkel’s new film division entered the fray right on the heels of a very strong Sundance Film Festival, when to many of us everything still looked so right in the indie business.

headline: Believe You Can Wins Kentucky Oaks
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Rosie Napravnik was a little heart broken. She wants desperately to win a Kentucky Derby, but saw those dreams delayed earlier this week when the colt she was to ride, Mark Valeski, was not fit enough for his trainer, Larry Jones, and scratched. But that was no reason to leave town; she was riding a filly named Believe You Can in the Grade I $1 million Kentucky Oaks on Friday.

headline: Serbia, at a Crossroads, Prepares for Elections

headline: One Who Came Back
text: The Brewers right-hander Yovani Gallardo tore his right anterior cruciate ligament covering first base on May 1, 2008. In a telephone interview from San Francisco on Friday, Gallardo said he was told he would miss the rest of the season. Yet with Milwaukee pushing for the playoffs, he returned on Sept. 25 and started Game 1 of the division series. He said he did not do extra work beyond the regular rehab protocol.

headline: Two Invitations, One Official, One Political, With the Same Guest List
text: There is a complex set of rules that governs how much of a president’s re-election campaign is run out of the White House. But as President Obama gears up for the 2012 election, those lines can be blurred.

headline: Head of Drill Sergeant School Reinstated
text: The Army on Friday reinstated Command Sgt. Maj. Teresa L. King as commandant of its drill sergeant school at Fort Jackson, S.C., six months after suspending her under a cloud.

headline: Parodies of Power Proliferate
text: WE know that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg dabbles in broken Spanish. We suspect that Sheldon Silver, the State Assembly speaker, doles out the occasional Yiddish barb. And we allow for the possibility that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo might, in fact, have felt “FABULOUS” after the passage of same-sex marriage legislation last year.

headline: Don’t Believe China’s Promises

text: GROWING up on a farm in South Carolina, John Henry Byas had only an outhouse and a chamber pot when nature called.

text: RICHMOND, Va. — With President Obama due here on Saturday, Aida Pacheco and Providencia Santiago were musing on the life expectancy of their Obama campaign signs in their solidly Republican, mostly white neighborhoods just outside this city.

headline: For This Kind of Money, a Used iPad Proves to Be a Steal
text: The e-mail landed in Ryan’s in-box 41 minutes after midnight on Feb. 23. It read:

headline: Case of Man Killed by Police to Get Civil Rights Review
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan will begin a review of whether civil rights laws were violated in the case of a 68-year-old man who was shot to death last year by a police officer in his apartment in White Plains, N.Y., a spokeswoman for the United States attorney in Manhattan said on Friday.

headline: Long Shot’s All-Out Style May Set Pace at the Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — No one begrudged Shivananda Parbhoo his ear-to-ear smile on Friday morning. It was the day before the Kentucky Derby, and he had a horse named Trinniberg with a date in the starting gate. He had picked the colt out himself at a sale in Florida for a bargain price of $21,000.

headline: Slowed Physically, Rangel Promises to Go Full Speed in Primary Fight
text: He moved slowly and relied on a walker, but Representative Charles B. Rangel vowed on Friday to wage an energetic primary fight against an aggressive Democratic challenger.

headline: Obama’s Wonderful Town
text: Today, the story of the bare-chested crossword-puzzle solver.

headline: More Long Island Rail Road Retirees Are to Face Fraud Charges
text: A prosecutor said on Friday that about 10 more people would be charged in what the government has called a huge fraud scheme involving hundreds of Long Island Rail Road workers, some of whom collected extra benefits each year after falsely claiming to have disabling injuries while retiring to lives of vigorous activity, including golf, tennis, aerobics and biking.

headline: Now Online | T Design and Living
text: For the summer Design and Living issue of T, we really get into people’s personal space. It starts with the cover story, Tiina Laakkonen’s farmhouse on Long Island, which the fashion stylist and former model has filled with furniture and objects from her native Finland. Then there is the London council flat shared by the artist Francis Upritchard and the furniture designer Martino Gamper, a quirky space the creative couple transformed with their own two hands. We also meet three style setters whose interiors are so in sync with their exteriors that they practically blend in with the furniture (in a good way, of course!). Thomas Beller writes about his life divided between two cities he loves: New York and New Orleans. And Susan Morgan takes a tour of the tiny house that the visionary architect Anne Griswold Tyng designed for herself. It contains all of her biggest ideas writ small. Take a peek!

headline: Monserrate Pleads Guilty to the Misuse of City Funds
text: Hiram Monserrate, a former city councilman and state senator, pleaded guilty on Friday to improperly using Council money to finance a failed political campaign.

headline: Mr. Chen, Welcome to America
text: Arcadia, Calif.

headline: Hedge Fund Intensifies Attack on Yahoo Amid Storm Over Padded Résumés
text: Third Point has intensified its assault against Yahoo.

headline: Radicals, Baseball and Broadway
text: HOWEVER you define power — influence, control, effectiveness — the subjects of three new books can stake their claim to it.

headline: Week in Pictures for May 4
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the arrival of the space shuttle Enterprise, Occupy Wall Street protests and 1 World Trade Center, now the tallest building in New York.

headline: The Gospel of Prosperity
text: The largest Christian television network faces allegations of ethics violations from an unlikely source.

headline: In Elections, Greeks Are Expected to Make Old Guard Pay for Turmoil
text: ATHENS — In the two years since Greece asked for a foreign bailout, its leaders have had trouble governing even with a clear majority. Now, as the country heads to elections on Sunday in which no single party is expected to secure enough votes to form a stable government, they may have to try governing with political chaos.

headline: Job Numbers Become Instant Campaign Fodder
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney responded to Friday’s weaker-than-expected job numbers with a sweeping denunciation, declaring it a “terrible and very disappointing report” — evidence of an economy that is “slowing down, not speeding up.”

headline: Union Files Grievance Over Bounty Suspensions
text: In the first move of what figures to be a contentious fight, the N.F.L. players union launched its defense of four New Orleans Saints players suspended for their roles in the team’s bounty program with a three-pronged attack on Commissioner Roger Goodell’s authority.

headline: Rules Tightened on Municipal Bond Deals
text: Federal regulators trying to prevent more debt disasters like the one in Jefferson County, Ala., tightened a rule on Friday for the brokerage firms that help cities and states raise billions of dollars every year.

headline: Rising Early, With a New Sentence in Mind
text: Robert A. Caro, 76, has spent half his life exploring the vicissitudes of power, in his Pulitzer Prize-winning 1974 biography of Robert Moses, “The Power Broker,” and in his monumental biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, now up to its fourth volume, “The Passage of Power,” which was published this month. Mr. Caro lives on Central Park West with his wife, Ina, whose most recent book is “Paris to the Past: Traveling Through French History by Train.” He typically spends Sunday working.

headline: For China, a Dissident in Exile Is One Less Headache Back Home
text: After more than a week of high-level diplomacy over the fate of the blind activist Chen Guangcheng, the Chinese government was widely seen as making a major concession on Friday by agreeing to allow Mr. Chen to apply to leave for the United States.

headline: Rapper Conquered Music World in ’80s With Beastie Boys
text: Adam Yauch, a rapper and founder of the pioneering and multimillion-selling hip-hop group the Beastie Boys, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 47.

headline: Ethics Panel Fines Espada $80,000
text: ALBANY — Former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. was ordered to pay $80,000 on Friday by the New York State Legislative Ethics Commission, which said he had violated state law by hiring his uncle.

headline: Report Lists Many Flaws in Handling of 911 Calls
text: New York City’s 911 emergency dispatch system sometimes sends firefighters or police officers to the wrong address. Operators sometimes waste precious seconds and sow confusion by failing to follow a standard script when taking information from callers. And, sometimes, an emergency operator can ask eight questions about a caller’s location and other details, then patch in another operator who asks six more questions, before getting to the most important one: “What is the emergency?”

headline: In Instant, Rivera’s Understudy Becomes Successor
text: Until now, Dave Robertson was a rising deputy, an increasingly valuable piece of the Yankees bullpen.

headline: Remember, Remember, the Fifth of May
text: Most Americans would be hard pressed to recount the events surrounding Cinco de Mayo, a holiday better associated with margaritas and lime-necked Coronas than any historical event. Some wrongly believe that May 5th is Mexican Independence Day (that’s actually Sept. 16th); others believe it marks the glorious founding of the country’s alcohol industry.

headline: Exit Ramps Lead Right Back Here
text: Nine years ago, when I was introduced to my future husband by a mutual friend, he was working in Nashville, and living 885 miles away, in a town house apartment in Brooklyn. To afford this unusual arrangement, he spent the three or four nights a week that he was in Tennessee at a Motel 6 — not the Motel 6 closest to his place of employment, but a cheaper branch farther away from the interstate where the sheets, forgetting discussions of thread count, possessed the feel of something made at Union Carbide.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In a Season Filled With Streaks, Goalie Stays on an Unsteady Course
text: Ilya Bryzgalov signed a nine-year, $51 million contract with the Philadelphia Flyers in the off-season to help stifle the goaltending despair that has hounded the team since the departure of Ron Hextall in the late 1990s. But Bryzgalov’s first season on Broad Street has been inconsistent from opening night to the postseason.

headline: A Clear Warning From the Jobs Numbers
text: This week’s economic news was mixed, but the employment report on Friday was unmistakably weak. The economy added only 115,000 jobs in April, versus 154,000 in March and 200,000-plus in each of the three months before that. Even taking into account that unusually warm winter weather probably distorted the recent results, the underlying trend shows an economy that has been creating about 175,000 jobs a month — enough to keep the recovery crawling along, but too weak to appreciably raise hiring or wages.

headline: In Sudan, Give War a Chance
text: Addis Ababa, Ethiopia

headline: City Bookkeeper Charged With Stealing $2.6 Million From Estates
text: A bookkeeper in the office of the Brooklyn public administrator stole more than $2.6 million from the estates of people who died without wills over a period of three years, prosecutors charged on Friday.

headline: Chen Guangcheng’s Uncertain Future
text: There is fresh hope in the harrowing odyssey of Chen Guangcheng. Nothing is guaranteed, but after days of frantic diplomacy by American diplomats — and bluster and threats from China’s government — the dissident and self-taught lawyer may be allowed to travel to the United States on a student visa, and bring his wife and children with him.

headline: New York’s Children Shouldn’t Pay the Price
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg this week put out his revised proposal for the next city budget — a $68.7 billion plan that spares teachers, police and firefighters but slashes vital programs for needy children. That is not the way to balance a budget.

headline: Building in Harlem Caves In
text: A brownstone in Harlem fell in on itself Friday in what a Fire Department official called a “pancake collapse.” No injuries were reported. The building, on West 123rd Street near Lenox Avenue, was being renovated, a Buildings Department spokesman said, but it did not appear that the work was an immediate cause.

headline: Fault Line
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow, this one was a thorny grid for me to navigate. Quite a mental workout, some Stuff I Just Didn’t Know, and a few misdirects (like filling in NOM de guerre instead of CRI), but ultimately doable. And yet, despite having to walk away and come back and few times, it felt very satisfying when I finished. Maybe I’m just becoming a real Saturday solver.

headline: A Day Off Recharges the Weary Rangers
text: WASHINGTON — After a day off to see a movie, walk around town or tour Arlington National Cemetery, the Rangers were fresh and loose at practice Friday. It was their first time on the ice since they won Game 3 in the wee hours of Thursday morning, after 114 minutes 41 seconds of sweat-drenched, bone-rattling, muscle-burning hockey.

headline: ‘The Scream’ on the Block
text: Looking at Edvard Munch’s 1895 pastel “The Scream,” it’s hard not to see it as a commentary on the price it brought at Sotheby’s in New York this week — $119,922,500, the highest auction price ever paid for a work of art. In a pose treasured by winners of beauty pageants (as well as trick-or-treaters and many others), Munch’s figure on a bridge seems to be shrieking with — you decide.

headline: Our 2012 Kentucky Derby Picks
text: The Rail’s contributors welcome this year’s Kentucky Derby guest picker, Eddie Olczyk, an NBC Sports hockey analyst who played 16 seasons as a center in the N.H.L. before coaching the Pittsburgh Penguins from 2003 to 2005.

headline: Aleppo Clash Poses Risk of Widening Syrian Revolt
text: Syria’s government risked stoking a new source of rebellion on Friday when its forces fired on a mass demonstration in Aleppo, the country’s largest city, where activist groups said thousands of people had massed to demonstrate against the violent closing of the main university there the day before. At least four demonstrators were said to be killed.

headline: Corrections: May 5
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Repository for Eagles Finds Itself in Demand
text: Miles from downtown Denver, in a small warehouse on the city’s edge, Bernadette Atencio watched as two men methodically bundled piles of dead eagles into boxes, careful to include enough frozen gel packs so the remains would not thaw.

headline: Teaching Me About Teaching
text: Next week is National Teacher Appreciation Week, and, as far as I’m concerned, they don’t get nearly enough.

headline: Uncommon Injury for Pitchers; Positive Signs for Rivera
text: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera declared Friday that his career was not over, and according to medical experts and peers who have come back from a similar knee injury, there is no reason to believe he will not be able to return.

headline: An Entrepreneur at the Vanguard of Pottery
text: CHOLULA, Mexico

headline: Friday Night Music: Panem Edition
text: So I’m tracking online book sales, and it turns out that there are three major categories: 50 Shades of Grey, Hunger Games, and everything else. I don’t know if there’s any 50 Shades of Grey music, and I doubt that I want to know. They did, however, commission songs from some of my favorite musicians for the Hunger Games CD; here are two of them.

headline: Mantle’s Knee Injury Was Just the Start
text: There had been no real competition for most famous knee injury in Yankees history. That would have been Mickey Mantle’s, in Game 2 of the 1951 World Series, on the game’s biggest stage, in front of 66,018 at Yankee Stadium. Then came the one Thursday night to closer Mariano Rivera, while he shagged fly balls in batting practice in a mostly empty stadium in Kansas City, Mo., one of the game’s smallest stages.

headline: Family Battle Offers Look Inside Lavish TV Ministry
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — For 39 years, the Trinity Broadcasting Network has urged viewers to give generously and reap the Lord’s bounty in return.

headline: Trinity Broadcasting Network: A Nonprofit Corporation’s Balance Sheet
text: This is the 2010 tax form filed by the Trinity Broadcasting Network, which is legally registered as the Trinity Christian Center of Santa Ana, Inc. Nonprofit corporations are required to report their sources of income, expenditures, executive salaries and other information on the 990 form. This filing, the latest that is publicly available, shows that TBN received $93 million in tax-free grants and donations in 2010.

headline: The Weekend Word: Strategies
text: Today’s Times

headline: Solid Start, Some Timely Hits, Then the Bullpen Was Called
text: An unforgiving script was replayed on Friday night for the Mets. A strong starting pitching performance, backed by solid run support, gave way to a relief corps incapable of holding the lead in a 5-4 loss to the Diamondbacks at Citi Field. It was the Mets’ fourth straight defeat.

headline: Jeter’s Homer Helps Yankees Upend Royals
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — If the injured Mariano Rivera needed any convincing that age need not be a deterrent in his return from a serious knee injury, Derek Jeter provided it on Friday night.

headline: Recognizing the Limitations of Meloball
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: Woods Fails to Make Wells Fargo Cut
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Wandering drives and errant putts undermined Tiger Woods on Friday at the Wells Fargo Championship, as he missed the cut for the eighth time in 267 P.G.A. events and for the second time in a row at this tournament.

headline: Phoebe Jacobs, Publicist for Jazz Greats, Dies at 93
text: Among the many jazz stories that Phoebe Jacobs delighted in telling, one always stood out as characteristic of her tenacious and resourceful service to the music. It was the wee hours of an April morning in the 1950s, and Ella Fitzgerald had finished her last set at Basin Street East in Midtown. Ms. Jacobs, a publicist and general assistant for the club at the time, was walking her to the door when Fitzgerald, glancing at her wristwatch, casually remarked that it was her birthday.

headline: After Giving Youngster a Try, the Mets Turn to a Veteran
text: When Mike Pelfrey sustained an arm injury at the end of last month, an opportunity opened for a young Chris Schwinden to hop into the Mets’ rotation, as he had done at the end of last season.

headline: Defining the ‘It’ Horse in the Derby
text: For serious handicappers, horses rise to the top of the Triple Crown contender list based primarily on their performances on the racetrack.  It’s a fairly straightforward premise: the horse either wins, or at least performs very well, or it doesn’t.  The assumption is that the more a horse wins or at least acquits itself well in challenging stakes-level company, the greater the likelihood it will continue to do so.  At least that’s the theory.  It’s basic quantitative analysis.  But take away the numeric data and few handicappers – and probably even fewer $2 bettors – likely could spot a true “quality” horse at first glance without clutching their quantitative performance data as an essential guidepost.

headline: Zvi Zeitlin, Violinist Who Championed Modernist Composers, Dies at 90
text: Zvi Zeitlin, an internationally renowned violinist known for interpreting the work of contemporary composers, died on Wednesday in Rochester. He was 90.

headline: Batsman Offers New Dimension to Twenty20 Matches
text: “Twenty20, the newest and shortest of cricket’s three formats, favors the game’s sluggers,” Huw Richards writes in The New York Times.

headline: A Religious TV Empire
text: Paul and Janice Crouch, who built the world’s largest Christian television operation, have been criticized for secrecy about their use of public donations and are now facing lawsuits by a granddaughter.

headline: Armenia: Rally Balloons Explode
text: Scores of people were hurt in Yerevan, the capital, on Friday when gas-filled balloons exploded in a huge ball of flames at a campaign rally for Armenia’s Republican Party ahead of parliamentary elections on Sunday. More than 60 people, including children, were hospitalized after the explosion, and photographs showed bystanders fleeing as flames shot up in a crowded square. The Emergencies Ministry said 144 people had been injured; some were burned and others were hurt during the panic after the explosion. No deaths were reported. Nikolai Grigoryan, the deputy director of Armenia’s rescue service, told the Novosti Armenia news agency that the balloons had been filled with helium and were ignited by a bystander’s cigarette. However, helium is an inert gas that does not burn.

headline: Russia: Gay Rights Activist Fined
text: A court in St. Petersburg on Friday fined a gay rights campaigner about $170 in the first application of a new municipal law against distributing what the law calls “gay propaganda.” The charge stemmed from a rally held last month, where the campaigner, Nikolai Alekseyev, carried a poster that said: “Homosexuality is not a perversion. What is a perversion is field hockey and ice dancing.” The St. Petersburg law is the model for a bill that has been submitted to the lower house of Parliament, which could be applied nationwide if approved. Mr. Alekseyev said he would appeal the verdict.

headline: The Powers of New York
text: Influence in New York is now wielded by a larger and more diverse array of people. Here’s a look at who is at the top and who may be on the way, as identified by the reporters of The New York Times.

headline: Rivera’s Not Ready to Close the Book
text: A look at some highs and lows of Mariano Rivera’s 18 years with the Yankees.

headline: Israel: Brother of Rabin’s Killer Is Freed After Serving His Sentence
text: Hagai Amir, 43, the brother of the killer of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, was released from prison on Friday after serving 16 years for helping to plan the 1995 assassination. Mr. Amir emerged from the prison in central Israel raising his fingers in a V sign. He told reporters that he had no regrets, adding, “I am proud of what I did.” For some Israelis, the release opened old wounds of one of the most traumatic events in recent Israeli history. Dozens of leftists waiting outside the prison shouted “Disgrace!” as Mr. Amir was driven away in a van. The killer, Yigal Amir, a right-wing Jewish extremist, is serving a life sentence for shooting Mr. Rabin after a peace rally in Tel Aviv.

headline: Equality and Fraternity Through the Eyes of an American in Paris
text: The French television channel, France 3, invited a half dozen international correspondents to examine an issue playing out in the French presidential campaign through their personal lens. Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, chose the state of France’s Arab and African minorities.

headline: How Mariano Rivera Compares to Baseball’s Best Closers
text: Considered the best closer in baseball history, Mariano Rivera has more saves than any other pitcher.

headline: Science and Truth: We’re All in It Together
text: THE greatest bird news of our lifetime occurred at the height of the George W. Bush administration. In April 2005, amid a pageant of flags and cabinet ministers in Washington, John Fitzpatrick, the director of the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, announced that an ivory-billed woodpecker had been spotted for the first time in more than half a century in an Arkansas swamp.

headline: Mexico: 23 Bodies Discovered
text: Twenty-three bodies, nine of them hanging from a bridge and the rest decapitated and found in a van, were discovered Friday in Nuevo Laredo, across the border from Laredo, Tex., the Mexican authorities said. The heads of the decapitated victims were later found in three coolers near a municipal building. The gruesome discovery, believed to be related to battles among criminal gangs, comes less than a month after the dismembered remains of 14 men were found in the city’s downtown. Nuevo Laredo is in Tamaulipas State, one of the country’s most violent.

headline: Guilty Plea in Conspiracy Case Linked to Colombian Guerrillas
text: A former member of the Syrian military pleaded guilty on Friday in federal court in Manhattan to conspiracy to provide material support to a Colombian terrorist organization. The case stemmed from an international sting operation run by the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. An indictment charged that the defendant, Jamal Yousef, agreed to provide military-grade weapons to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, for hundreds of kilograms of cocaine. The supposed FARC representative he was dealing with was actually an informant for the D.E.A., the authorities have said. In return for his plea, prosecutors agreed to drop a narcoterrorism conspiracy charge against Mr. Yousef, 54, who faces a maximum of 15 years in prison when he is sentenced in August.

headline: Indian State Carrier Fined $80,000 by American Authorities
text: The U.S. Department of Transportation has fined the state-run Indian carrier, Air India, $80,000 for noncompliance with regulations. The airline failed to post “customer service and tarmac delay contingency plans on its website” and “adequately inform passengers about its optional fees” by the required date, a news release issued by the department said.

headline: Classic Ad: Toyota Corolla GT-S
text: The popularity of Japanese performance models from the mid-1980s among collectors, customizers and wannabe street-racers is no secret, especially since the release of the “Fast and Furious” films. But in this ad for the 1985 Corolla GT-S, Toyota seems to have anticipated the phenomenon, or at least have seen an opportunity to play against the brand’s puttering econocar reputation.

headline: Giants, Ravens and Umenyiora: Is There a Deal There?
text: Terrell Suggs of the Ravens may be out for the season with an injury. Osi Umenyiora of the Giants also has an injury, a bruised ego; he’s unhappy with his contract again. Clark Judge of CBSSports.com puts on the old thinking cap:

headline: An Opulent Lifestyle
text: Paul and Janice Crouch, who built the world’s largest Christian television operation, have been criticized for secrecy about their use of public donations.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: In southern Kashmir’s Shopian district, two terrorism suspects disarmed police officers guarding a village with a majority Hindu population, Hindustan Times reported. This is one of the few villages in the Valley where Hindus have continued to live even after the migration of thousands of Hindu families from the Muslim-dominated state at the peak of militancy in 1990, the newspaper said.

headline: Living in the New Metropolis
text: “About half of humanity lives in a city, and by 2050, it’s likely that 70 percent of the world’s population will be in urban areas, according to United Nations predictions,” Martin Roemers writes in the Sunday Review of The New York Times.

headline: Buffett Talks Succession and Taxes at Berkshire Annual Meeting
text: OMAHA — Tens of thousands of shareholders gathered at the CenturyLink Center here to take in Warren E. Buffett’s pronouncements on his massive conglomerate, the global economy and whatever else tickles his or investors’ fancy. DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin was one of the reporters on stage to ask questions as well.

headline: M.B.A.s Playing at Prime Minister
text: What would the prime minister do?

headline: The Incredulity Problem
text: Link fixed

headline: Weather Keeps Horses From Training
text: The Churchill Downs racetrack was closed Saturday morning, which prevented horses from training. With lightning in the area, training was deemed potentially dangerous, especially after a lot of rain fell Friday night.

headline: A Cause — and Questions — in Cambodia
text: A little more than a week ago, the Cambodian forest activist Chut Wutty died under circumstances for which officials have already provided three different accounts.

headline: Six Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Surfer Magazine
text: 1) There are five guys on the masthead who have the title “Surfer Photographer,” a designation apart from the magazine’s “Senior Photographers” and “Contributing Photographers.” I like my job plenty, but I’m guessing that Chris Burkard, Jason Childs, Todd Glaser, Morgan Maassen and Zak Noyle like theirs more.

headline: Across Angry Europe, Voting for ‘The Other Lot’
text: MARSEILLE — My late friend and one-time employer, Louis Chaponneau, a French provincial grocer, used to tell me back in the early 1960s that he much admired the British political system in which the Labour and Conservative parties took turns to run the country.

headline: James Cameron on Chinese Filmmakers, Censorship and Potential Co-Productions
text: BEIJING – James Cameron, director of “Titanic” and “Avatar,” among other well-known movies, visited Beijing in mid-April for the Beijing International Film Festival. The festival was screening the 3-D version of “Titanic,” which had recently opened in theaters here. More important, Mr. Cameron was here to meet with people in the Chinese film industry to talk about doing joint productions and getting greater distribution for his 3-D films, which use technology developed by Cameron Pace Group, or C.P.G.

headline: Le Petit Prince of L’Oréal
text: PARIS

headline: Six-City App Giveaways For Travelers by Fodor’s
text: Fodor’s is doing its part to help travelers cut costs by giving away apps for six cities via iTunes.

headline: At a Hearing, 9/11 Detainees Show Defiance
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Khalid Shaikh Mohammed fingered his long, henna-dyed beard and stared down in silence on Saturday, pointedly ignoring a military commissions judge asking in vain whether the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks understood what was being said and whether he was willing to be represented by his defense lawyers.

headline: Economic Tribalism
text: Hmm. This seems to be meta Saturday, with reactions to how people think – or, all too often, don’t think — about economics taking center stage.

headline: Surprise! A President Runs for Re-Election
text: As President Obama heads to Ohio and Virginia on Saturday to “kick off” his re-election campaign, it seems a curiosity to remember that it has been 20 years since an incumbent president formally “announced” his intent to run for a second term.

headline: Mammoth Trees, Champs of the Ecosystem
text: It’s important to respect your elders, children are reminded. It seems that this goes for trees, too.

headline: A Gateway to a Career Through Volunteering
text: Q. You are a new college graduate without a job or concrete career plans. You might be interested in doing public service work for a year or two. Could that help you find your way to a career?

headline: Playing for Tees, and $5
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A boy with a used set of left-handed women’s clubs would spend all day playing at a par-3 course in San Diego for roughly the price of a child’s movie ticket. He met another boy who became his first rival. This is how Phil Mickelson punched his ticket to the World Golf Hall of Fame, through a lifetime of identifying targets and taking aim at them as if they were flags on the practice range.

headline: Burnett Records a Dubious Achievement
text: When Jered Weaver of the Los Angeles Angels threw a no-hitter last Wednesday, it was not the most unusual pitching line in the majors that day. In the last 30 years, 55 pitchers have thrown a no-hitter. But only five in that stretch have done what A. J. Burnett did Wednesday in St. Louis.

headline: Guidry Can Relate to Allure of Outfield
text: Ron Guidry understood perfectly. He knew why Mariano Rivera loved shagging fly balls during batting practice and why Rivera’s dream has been to play center field before his certain first-ballot Hall of Fame career was over.

headline: Faltering German Party, a Coalition Partner to Merkel, Faces an Electoral Test
text: COLOGNE, Germany — It is campaign season here along the Rhine River, and the main street in the gentrifying neighborhood of Deutz could be viewed as something of a microcosm of German politics.

headline: Last Reactor of 50 in Japan Is Shut Down
text: TOKYO — Japan’s last operating reactor was taken offline Saturday, as public distrust created by last year’s nuclear disaster forced the nation to at least temporarily do without atomic power for the first time in 42 years.

headline: Dance Lessons in Life
text: I COME from a family that loves dancing. When I was in high school my mother decided I should learn to dance, so she bought me ballroom dance lessons as a graduation gift. She believed people should be comfortable walking onto a dance floor with a partner. For a while, I was obsessive about dancing. One summer I painted a dance studio in exchange for more lessons.

headline: Variety: A Gem of an Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — What a fascinating book this quote comes from.

headline: Outgoing Owner and Quiet Trainer Lend Color to a Nearly White Colt
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Dr. Kendall Hansen is a man of many words. Mike Maker, the trainer of Hansen’s namesake colt, is just the opposite.

headline: The Continuing Problem of Bank Instability
text: To the Editor:

headline: Manchester City Facing a Stern Test in Newcastle
text: Two obstacles stand in the way of Manchester City and its first top-level title in England since 1967-68: Pappis Cissé and Newcastle United. Then there is next Sunday’s game against the relegation-challenged Queens Park Rangers to end the Premier League season.

headline: Coining Terminology for Life on the Web
text: WHEN a friend recently asked for advice about using social media, I excitedly embarked on a description of my daily routine — checking in on Foursquare to share my whereabouts with friends, posting tweets to Twitter, sharing screenshots from the latest “Mad Men” episode on Tumblr, and skimming through the stylized images on Instagram.

headline: When Hillary Meets ‘Didi’
text: On Monday in Kolkata, the U.S. secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is scheduled to meet with the chief minister of West Bengal, Mamata Banerjee,(nickname “Didi” or Big Sister) a woman whose power over Indian central government decisions has been virtually unchecked but whose increasingly erratic actions are raising concern  even in her own party.

headline: Damming the Amazon
text: Brazil is planning to build at least 20 hydroelectric dams in the Amazon region by 2020, but indigenous residents say they are threatened and so is the rain forest.

headline: Amid Brazil’s Rush to Develop, Workers Resist
text: As the country moves to tap one of the world’s last great reserves of hydroelectric power, the Amazon basin, strikes and worker uprisings at the biggest projects are producing delays and cost overruns.

headline: For Hard of Hearing, Clarity Out of the Din
text: DIGITAL hearing aids can do wonders for faded hearing. But other devices can help, too, as audio technology adds new options to help people converse at a noisy restaurant, or talk quietly with a pharmacist at a crowded drugstore counter.

headline: Amid Brazil’s Rush to Develop, Workers Resist
text: JACI PARANÁ, Brazil — The revolt here on the banks of the Madeira River, the Amazon’s largest tributary, flared after sunset. At the simmering end of a 26-day strike by 17,000 workers last month, a faction of laborers who were furious over wages and living conditions began setting fire to the construction site at the Jirau Dam.

headline: On the Eve of the Derby
text: In what is now an annual pilgrimage, I journey to Louisville to see the finest 3-year-old horses compete on the first Saturday of May. My first Kentucky Derby — in 2009, when Mine That Bird upset the field — was overwhelming, exhilarating and a deluge of sensory stimulation (perhaps hovering on overload). Famous jockeys, world-renowned trainers, media personalities I have seen on television, and some of the best-looking horses I have ever seen. It was incredible. It was fabulous. It was everything I could have wished for and more! And when I won a significant amount of money betting on a long shot to win, I hustled to the gift store to purchase a commemorative piece of jewelry to remind myself of that glorious moment.

headline: Skowron Had a Knack for Making Memories
text: Of all the people, on all the days, to appear in the Yankees clubhouse. Bill Skowron was sitting on a couch in the visitors’ clubhouse at U.S. Cellular Field in Chicago. He was an employee of the White Sox, a continual presence in community relations, and yet he looked every bit as much a part of the Yankees, as comfortable and as accepted, as he had been when he played for them. Moose, as Skowron was known to generations of Yankees and their fans, could do that.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor;

headline: A Rising Tide Against Class-Action Suits
text: IN 2007, Matthew Wolf returned his Nissan Infiniti about a year into his 39-month lease. For most people, that would mean a hit to the wallet, including the loss of the few hundred dollars he paid in advance to lower his monthly payment.

headline: Long History of Drug Use in the Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — By all accounts, the 90th Kentucky Derby in 1964 was the first to include a competitor running on the drug furosemide, then known as Lasix. The initial dose was given surreptitiously by Alex Harthill, known as the Derby Doc, to the winner, Northern Dancer.

headline: A Pullback in May? Maybe Not This Time
text: IT’S understandable if the month of May fills investors with trepidation.

headline: Mickelson Does Not Plan to Rest on His Laurels
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Phil Mickelson is not ready to sit in a rocking chair on the veranda and reflect on his golfing career over a tall glass of iced tea with lemonade. Mickelson, who turns 42 next month, believes some of his best results are ahead of him, which lends an awkwardness to his induction Monday into the World Golf Hall of Fame.

headline: Former Royal Aikens Tells His Story
text: For 14 years, Willie Mays Aikens had longed for this weekend to arrive. Convicted in 1994 on four counts of crack cocaine distribution and one count of using of a firearm during drug trafficking, Aikens, a World Series star for the Kansas City Royals, said May 5, 2012, was once his release date from federal prison.

headline: Queens Man Is Shot by Off-Duty Officer in the Bronx
text: An off-duty police officer shot a 19-year-old man who had fired into a Bronx park and then shot at the officer and another officer as they pursued him, the police said Saturday.

headline: Never Mind Europe. Worry About India.
text: THE economic slowdown in India is one of the world’s biggest economic stories, but it is commanding only a modicum of attention in the United States.

headline: An Economic Lifeline of Barley and Hops
text: BEND, Ore. — When the economic analysts write the final memo on how this Cascadian playground got its buzz back, they might not title it “How Beer Saved Bend.”

headline: Never Swerve When Driving the Bus
text: This interview with  Carl Bass, president and chief executive of Autodesk Inc. , a maker of 3-D design, engineering and entertainment software, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant .

headline: At Tight End, an Accountant
text: MIAMI — The last time Les Brown caught a touchdown pass, he was a lanky all-state wide receiver in Salt Lake City.

headline: Mortgage Unit Troubles Ally Financial
text: WHEN General Motors was bailed out, the government sank $17 billion of taxpayers’ money into G.M.’s troubled finance arm, GMAC.

headline: In French Race, the Tortoise Sets His Own Pace
text: PARIS — François Hollande, the 57-year-old favored to be elected narrowly on Sunday as France’s president, is no revolutionary. He likes to talk of “harmony” and “pragmatism” and often quotes the poet and politician Aimé Césaire about “lucid hope.”

headline: Many G.O.P. Freshmen Who Stormed the House Find It Harder to Stay Seated
text: MOLINE, Ill. — Representative Bobby Schilling’s face was twisted with tension. Another official event, another group of Democrats who craved to see him wiped from the Congressional map. Plus, he would have to smile.

headline: A Leader From the Start
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — In February 2011, in one of his first acts after taking over the 108th-ranked defense in the Football Bowl Subdivision, Arkansas State’s defensive coordinator, Dave Wommack, asked each of his players to fill out an eight-page questionnaire. One answer, written by a redshirt junior named Demario Davis, struck Wommack as particularly memorable: Davis vowed that the Red Wolves’ defense would finish among the top 25.

headline: A Blessing for Those Who Brave City Streets on Two Wheels
text: There were, to be sure, lighthearted, even silly moments at the Blessing of the Bikes at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Saturday, but some cyclists had gone there for very profound reasons.

headline: Jobs Few, Grads Flock to Unpaid Internships
text: Confronting the worst job market in decades, many college graduates who expected to land paid jobs are turning to unpaid internships to try to get a foot in an employer’s door.

headline: The Jobless Young Find Their Voice
text: WASHINGTON

headline: In the Spotlight of Power, Putin Keeps His Private Life Veiled in Shadows
text: MOSCOW — It was a rare public sighting of Russia’s premier political couple, but in the end it only fueled the rampant questions about whether they are much of a couple at all anymore.

headline: At California State, Protesters Start a Fast
text: NORTHRIDGE, Calif. — Angry about tuition increases and cuts in courses and enrollment, a dozen students at California State University have taken their protest beyond marches — their usual tactic — and declared a hunger strike.

headline: Whistling His Own Tune
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — When Joey Crawford began his career as an N.B.A. referee in 1977, there were two officials on the court for each game, no 3-point line and just 22 teams in the league, including franchises in Buffalo and in Kansas City, Mo. “It was a different era,” he said.

headline: Mitt Romney Promises to Create Eleventeen Million Jobs
text: OK, not exactly. But he did say that we should be creating 500,000 jobs a month — which almost never happens — and that we should have 4 percent unemployment, which is way below almost anyone’s estimate of the lowest rate we can have without accelerating inflation.

headline: Current TV
text: My head talks to Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Prison Passion Play
text: Inmates, many of them serving life sentences, put on “The Life of Jesus Christ,” a passion play chronicling the biblical story, on the grounds of the Louisiana State Prison at Angola.

headline: A High School Senior Is Also a Keen Student of College Recruiting
text: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J. — Alex Kline could be described as an under-the-radar prospect who surpassed his competitors to receive a high-major offer. That, of course, is recruiting jargon, a language Kline expertly speaks.

headline: Inmates Make Debut as Actors in Passion Play
text: “The Life of Jesus Christ,” a three-and-a-half-hour play with a cast of 70, made its debut this weekend in a three-day run at the Louisiana State Penitentiary.

headline: In Prison, Play With Trial at Its Heart Resonates
text: ANGOLA, La. — On a December night in 1991, the man who would later play Jesus committed a string of armed robberies in New Orleans. Ten years later, the woman who would play the Virgin Mary robbed a Mexican restaurant across town. A month after that, a teenager killed his girlfriend and infant daughter. He would go on to play Joseph.

headline: Obama Formally Kicks Off Campaign in Ohio and Virginia
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — President Obama sought to rekindle the passion of his 2008 victory on Saturday with a pair of huge rallies in battleground states that signaled a new, more politically aggressive phase of the campaign and a sharpened critique of Mitt Romney.

headline: What Would Improve Job Prospects for Young Workers?
text: As Hannah Seligson reports in Sunday Business, joblessness among the young remains at crisis levels. In April, the unemployment rate for workers under age 25 was 16.4 percent, compared with 8.1 percent over all.

headline: Bonding in the Midst of Barbaro’s Ordeal
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Barbaro’s racing life is associated with as much sadness as triumph. But it also produced quite a love story.

headline: A Late Goal Gives the Capitals a Win and a Tie
text: WASHINGTON — Through the fog of questionable calls and Alex Ovechkin’s hit to defenseman Dan Girardi, a larger truth emerged from the Rangers’ 3-2 loss to the Washington Capitals on Saturday.

headline: Saudi Ambassador Returns to Egypt
text: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia’s ambassador returned to Egypt on Saturday, a week after the Saudi government closed its embassy in response to protests there in the worst diplomatic rift in years between the two countries.

headline: Jack Whitaker Was Always Camera Ready
text: From the 1960s through the ’90s, Jack Whitaker specialized in reports and essays that brought elegance to CBS’s and ABC’s coverage of golf, horse racing and the Olympics. Among the few other similarly evocative commentators were two of his colleagues, Jim McKay and Heywood Hale Broun.

headline: China, in Old Tradition, Races to Airbrush Fallen Leader Out of Public Life
text: CHONGQING, China — Until recently, visitors who arrived at the urban planning exhibition hall here were greeted with a high-tech shrine to Bo Xilai, who served as the municipality’s charismatic Communist Party chief. A video recounting Mr. Bo’s “smash black” crackdown on organized crime featured mug shots of gangsters emblazoned on tombstones. Maoist revolutionary songs blared from speakers in the “red culture” wing. Lasers zipped across the “honest government” gallery.

headline: Trying to Mold a Post-Assad Syria From Abroad
text: ISTANBUL — Emad ad-Din al-Rashid, a former assistant dean at the Islamic law college of Damascus University, opened his MacBook Air laptop and flipped through spreadsheets detailing the unmet needs of seemingly every besieged neighborhood across Syria.

headline: Global Warming Ad Quickly Dropped
text: A new ad campaign comparing people who believe in global warming to murderers has foundered, with its conservative sponsor pulling a digital billboard down less than 24 hours after it went up in Chicago.

headline: Jean-Baptiste Michel
text: Jean-Baptiste Michel is a French-Mauritian mathematician, engineer and researcher with appointments at Harvard and Google. He uses a quantitative approach to study trends in human disease, language and culture based on linguistic and grammatical patterns in vast libraries of digitized texts.

headline: In the Middle of a Food Fight
text: COUNT on The New York Times to take a basic topic and vault it into the stratosphere of esoteric, philosophic discussion. Food, for instance.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Studying the Humanities
text: Readers discuss what kind of college education is most valuable.

headline: Lesson in Timelessness by a Fly-Fishing Master
text: FREEPORT, Me. — Several miles from the nearest striped bass, smallmouth bass or brook trout, a short man with a floppy hat unfurled a bright yellow fly line through the air in tight loops, its flight illuminated by an unseasonably warm March sun. One passer-by stopped, then another and another as the line sailed across a lawn turned makeshift casting area, over a rope marking a sidewalk, and finally into the street beyond.

headline: Rangers-Capitals Replay: Game 4
text: The Capitals beat the Rangers, 3-2, in Game 4 of the teams’ Eastern Conference semifinal series at Washington.

headline: These Islands Aren’t Just a Shelter From Taxes
I.Q. Points for Sale, Cheap
text: A STRIKING trend in today’s culture is the pursuit of rapid cognitive enhancement. The idea behind many popular video and online “brain-training” games is that practicing tasks that strengthen memory, attention and other mental processes will make you a smarter person.

headline: The Name and Speed to Revive the Steal
text: A shortstop in Bakersfield, Calif., might personify baseball’s next generation while carrying a name from the old days. He is Billy Hamilton, and although he is not yet the best base stealer to ever hold the name, he might be the fastest player in baseball today.

headline: Chen’s Final Escape?
text: Hong Kong

headline: Nanotechnology Shock Waves
text: “I SING the body electric,”Walt Whitman wrote in 1855, inspired by the novelty of useful electricity, which he would live to see power streetlights and telephones, locomotives and dynamos. In “Leaves of Grass,” his ecstatic epic poem of American life, he depicted himself as a live wire, a relay station for all the voices of the earth, natural or invented, human or mineral. “I have instant conductors all over me,” he wrote. “They seize every object and lead it harmlessly through me… My flesh and blood playing out lightning to strike what is hardly different from myself.”

headline: Are Oral Arguments Worth Arguing About?
text: Washington

headline: Back When The Knicks Won One
text: The last time the Knicks won a playoff game, Iman Shumpert was 10.

headline: New York Neighborhoods Pay Tribute to a Beastie Boy
text: While Adam Yauch, a founder of the hip-hop group the Beastie Boys, was born in Brooklyn and rapped about the borough, it was the Lower East Side and the East Village, along with its more rough-and-tumble elements, that seemed to most inspire him.

headline: Back to ‘Graceland’ After 25 Years
text: The documentary “Under African Skies,” which opens this week in New York and Los Angeles, will remind many people of what they love about “Graceland,” the Paul Simon album whose 25th anniversary the film celebrates. Seeing it will also be a jolt for those who have forgotten the world of bitterness into which it was born.

headline: Black Women and Fat
text: FOUR out of five black women are seriously overweight. One out of four middle-aged black women has diabetes. With $174 billion a year spent on diabetes-related illness in America and obesity quickly overtaking smoking as a cause of cancer deaths, it is past time to try something new.

headline: Future TED Talks
text: Giving “the talk of your life” in 18 minutes or less — as the people from the fields of Technology, Entertainment and Design who are invited to speak at the TED lecture series are encouraged to do — has never been more popular. Indeed, the talks’ future is all too bright.

headline: North Korea’s Performance Anxiety
text: “IT’S a boy,” Edward Teller exulted after the world’s first hydrogen bomb exploded in 1952 with a force 1,000 times more powerful than the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima.

headline: Curling in Summertime
text: Consider curling, the Olympic sport so strange that you need to mix metaphors to explain it. You could call it frozen shuffleboard or bocce on ice, but that’s not enough. There’s a rink, two bull’s-eye targets and smooth stones to slide. But there are also brooms and a lot of yelling, and strategy. It’s Flintstones winter bowling. It’s track-and-field plus ballroom dancing, done by crazy housekeepers.

headline: The End of Clean Energy Subsidies?
text: The federal government has given generously to the clean energy industry over the last few years, funneling billions of dollars in grants, loans and tax breaks to renewable power sources like wind and solar, biofuels and electric vehicles. “Clean tech” has been good in return.

headline: Murdoch’s Pride Is America’s Poison
text: ROGER AILES is (a) the genius who midwifed the astoundingly successful Fox News; (b) the sharpest thorn in the side of Barack Obama; and (c) the most important surviving officer in Rupert Murdoch’s global media army.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 6
text: The Sunday shows have a lot of ground to cover on domestic and foreign policy fronts, after a week that included an unannounced presidential trip to Afghanistan, the exit of a Republican presidential candidate from the race and a disappointing jobs report.

headline: The Outsourced Life
text: IN the sprawling outskirts of San Jose, Calif., I find myself at the apartment door of Katherine Ziegler, a psychologist and wantologist. Could it be, I wonder, that there is such a thing as a wantologist, someone we can hire to figure out what we want? Have I arrived at some final telling moment in my research on outsourcing intimate parts of our lives, or at the absurdist edge of the market frontier?

headline: An Idea Worth Saving
text: Public financing of presidential elections, the greatest reform to come out of the post-Watergate era, died this year after a long illness. It was 36 years old, and was drowned by big money and starved by the disdain of politicians who should have known better.

text: WHITECLAY, Neb.

headline: The Party of Julia
text: A WEEK ago the Obama re-election campaign unveiled a slogan for the fall campaign — its answer to Ronald Reagan’s “Morning in America,” Bill Clinton’s “bridge to the 21st century,” and other successful re-election pitches. There were reports that the slogan-writing process had been a struggle for the White House, and the final product bore those rumors out. “Forward,” the Obama campaign will be declaiming to Americans, which feels like a none-too-subtle admission that a look backward at the Obama economic record might be bad news for the president’s re-election prospects.

text: DES MOINES

headline: Predators Try to Cope With Two Stars on the Bench
text: The unpredictable nature of this season’s Stanley Cup playoffs asserted itself yet again last week when the Nashville Predators, who were trailing Phoenix by two games to none and being solidly outplayed, suspended their top two scorers for Game 3 of their second-round series, and were better off for it.

text: Updated odds as of 5:41 p.m., according to KentuckyDerby.com.

headline: Police Officers Rescue 5 People From Queens Blaze
text: Police officers who had gone to a Queens housing project on a search warrant ended up rescuing five people trapped in an apartment by a fire that was raging in the kitchen, the authorities said on Saturday.

headline: Early Success Is No Guarantee of a Career Among the Elite
text: Vaibhav Suri became India’s newest grandmaster last Sunday when he won the Luc Open in Lille, France. At 15 years, 2 months and 21 days old, he is the 27th youngest grandmaster in history.

headline: Frank H. Pearl, Publisher With a Zeal for the Serious, Dies at 68
text: Frank H. Pearl, a lawyer and investor in Washington who entered the book business on a quest to publish the serious, quality literature that he felt large corporate publishing houses had neglected, died on Friday in Baltimore. He was 68.

headline: Plan for the Tangled Baby Hawk Is to Wait and See, for Now
text: Update, May 8 The hawk has gotten free of the bag. Read the post.

headline: Live Analysis: I’ll Have Another Wins Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — I’ll Have Another overtook Bodemeister in deep stretch to win by one and a half lengths, pulling off the upset in the 138th running of the Kentucky Derby in front of a record crowd of 165,307 at Churchill Downs on Saturday.

headline: A-V Club
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — A somewhat mundane grid for me, mostly because I was hoping for more of the sparkling wordplay I’ve come to expect on a Sunday. This is Alex Vratsanos’s first Sunday New York Times puzzle, and while I liked his two other puzzles, this one left me wanting … I don’t know, more entertainment for my work, maybe?

headline: From Misfit With Blog to Author With Deal
text: When blogging first exploded in the early 2000s, the great promise was that it would level the literary playing field. Unknown writers would suddenly have the reach of John Grisham or Janet Evanovich. Agents and publishers would be surfing the Web instead of sifting through the slush pile to find new talent.

headline: Bill Granger, Journalist Turned Author of Fiction, Dies at 70
text: Bill Granger, a newspaperman turned novelist whose fiction alternated between international spy thrillers and police procedurals set on the gritty streets of Chicago — and occasionally blended both — died on April 22 at a veterans home in Manteno, Ill. He was 70.

headline: Chelsea Wins Cup but Not Job Security for Manager
text: LONDON — Chelsea, the team that rebelled in midseason and got rid of its coach by failing to perform for him, won the English F.A. Cup at Wembley Stadium on Saturday. And it now stands two weeks away from the Champions League final in Munich.

headline: The Height of Corporate Irresponsibility — Anheuser Busch
text: My Sunday column looks at a particularly egregious example of a company putting greed above conscience. I’m speaking of Anheuser Busch selling hundreds of thousands of gallons of alcohol on the edge of Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, knowing that almost all of it will go to illicit drinking on the reservation and feed a devastating alcohol problem there. Incidentally, if you want to learn more about the issue, you can read this Times article or watch the documentary “Battle for Whiteclay.” (The Times reporter and photographer were roughed up in Whiteclay during their reporting, but I ran into no problems.)

headline: 9 Swing States, Critical to Presidential Race, Are Mixed Lot
text: Since the housing bubble burst, Nevada has been plagued with record foreclosures, the nation’s steepest drop in home values and its highest unemployment rate.

headline: Lessons of Iraq Help U.S. Fight a Drug War in Honduras
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE MOCORON, Honduras — The United States military has brought lessons from the past decade of conflict to the drug war being fought in the wilderness of Miskito Indian country, constructing this remote base camp with little public notice but with the support of the Honduran government.

headline: Honduras Becomes the Focal Point in America’s Drug War
text: The United States military has brought lessons from the past decade of conflict to the drug war, constructing remote base camps with little public notice but with the support of the Honduran government.

headline: In Love and Loss
text: Michael French has frontotemporal dementia, for which there is no treatment. As his condition deteriorated, his wife, Ruth, had to move him to a nursing home, where she spends most days.

headline: When Illness Makes a Spouse a Stranger
text: He threw away tax documents, got a ticket for trying to pass an ambulance and bought stock in companies that were obviously in trouble. Once a good cook, he burned every pot in the house. He became withdrawn and silent, and no longer spoke to his wife over dinner. That same failure to communicate got him fired from his job at a consulting firm.

headline: Studies Tie Abnormal Protein Buildup to Dementia
text: “If there’s something to be done, I want to be in on the ground floor,” said Elizabeth, 67, a woman participating in studies of frontotemporal degeneration at the University of California, San Francisco.

text: MOJAVE, Calif. — The sign into town, slightly weathered, says “Gateway to Space!”

headline: Via Video Feed, Families Watch 9/11 Case and Seethe

headline: A Yankee’s Unfortunate Pregame Debut

headline: I’ll Have Another Beats Bodemeister for Derby Win
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Something stunning was about to happen as the two colts bounded into the deep stretch, the one in front hitting the ground with a wobble, the one giving chase gathering strength with every stride. Either Bodemeister was going to give the trainer Bob Baffert, fresh off a heart attack, his fourth Kentucky Derby victory, or I’ll Have Another was going to give an anonymous jockey, Mario Gutierrez, one of the most unlikely victories in the 138 runnings of America’s greatest horse race.

headline: Immigration Policy at Issue in Democratic Primary for Sheriff in Travis County
text: In Travis County, which many consider the liberal hub of Texas, a controversial immigration-enforcement policy is at the forefront of the sheriff’s race.

headline: Tax-Subsidy Rules Bode Ill for Affordable Housing in Low-Income Areas
text: In many ways, the planned site for a huge, affordable apartment complex in South Dallas seemed perfect.

headline: End Is Likely for Knicks; Stoudemire Is a Maybe
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It might have been the Knicks’ final practice in a jam-packed season of lengthy winning streaks, lengthy losing streaks, the rise of a global phenomenon, the ousting of a coach and a series of devastating injuries. Yet it felt more like a run-of-the-mill afternoon in March than a playoff-worthy day in May.

headline: Elias Steadies the Devils in Postseason’s Tumult
text: NEWARK — Still crafty, versatile and irrepressible at 36, Devils center Patrik Elias played in his 148th Stanley Cup playoff game Thursday. Elias has won it all twice, so he has developed a good sense of timing. And this, he decided, was not quite the right moment to shoot the puck.

headline: Putting Injuries in His Past, Defenseman Moves Forward With the Winning Goal
text: WASHINGTON — For Washington Capitals defenseman Mike Green, this season had been one of missed chances and time on the sideline.

headline: With Paul in Lead, Clippers Regain Edge
text: LOS ANGELES — Lob City, despite everything, is still here.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Alone in Lead, Simpson Glances Over His Shoulder
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Although he’s not in the lead, Rory McIlroy might be in the best position heading into Sunday’s final round of the Wells Fargo Championship. After shooting a six-under-par 66 in the third round Saturday at the Quail Hollow Club, McIlroy, the reigning United States Open champion and the No. 2-ranked player in the world, is two strokes behind the local favorite and leader Webb Simpson and a stroke behind two other players.

headline: Mavericks Are Swept Off Their Throne by Thunder
text: DALLAS — Sweep complete, Oklahoma City players muted any celebration, respectfully exchanging handshakes and hugs with the Dallas Mavericks. The Thunder ended the reign of the N.B.A. champions with such stunning swiftness and efficiency Saturday night that there was little reason to gloat amid what amounted to an inevitable passing of the torch.

headline: Bats Go Quiet as Yankees Lose Again
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Minutes after the Yankees’ 5-1 loss to the Kansas City Royals on Saturday, Alex Rodriguez sat in front of a laptop in the clubhouse examining video of his at-bats in the game, none of which were productive.

headline: From Jazz Heirlooms to Doom Metal

headline: The Vampire Who Came Out in the Afternoon
text: IT was “Satan’s favorite TV show,” according to a religious tract of the time. Tim Burton, 8 years old when the Gothic daytime soap opera “Dark Shadows” came into the world and not quite 13 when it breathed its last, was clearly untroubled that his viewing preferences were similar to those of the Prince of Darkness.

headline: For Di Matteo, Win Does Not Mean Job Security
text: Chelsea’s 2-1 win over Liverpool in the F.A. Cup final on Saturday raised more questions about the job security of the teams’ managers than it answered, Rob Hughes writes from London. Has Chelsea’s interim manager, Roberto Di Matteo, done enough to keep the job? Has Kenny Dalglish done enough to merit keeping his?

headline: Daniel Fischer, Stephan Mandresh

Block, at the Ocean Club, a hotel on Paradise Island.

headline: Mayweather’s Win Is Unanimous but Not Easy

headline: A Killing Reverberates From a Cambodian Forest
text: HONG KONG — In another time, in a less connected era, if a lone protester had been murdered in a remote forest somewhere in Asia, it would have gone largely unnoticed and unremarked. A small voice is quieted, and the larger world moves on.

headline: From Bark to Bottle – a Cork Story
text: For the second year, I’ve co-taught a documentary production course at Pace University in which a team of graduate and undergraduate communication students travels on spring break not to lounge on a beach, but to shoot a short film with an environmental theme. Last year’s film focused on an American woman working for decades in Belize to farm shrimp with limited environmental impacts.

headline: Round-Trip Tickets for Chen Could Upgrade U.S.-China Relations
text: HONG KONG — The status of the Chinese human rights lawyer Chen Guangcheng remains somewhat fluid, as Beijing and Washington try to negotiate an elegant exit from some rather inelegant diplomatic wrangling over the past two weeks.

headline: Denouement in France
text: French voters went to the polls on Sunday in what was being characterized as perhaps the most dramatic and consequential election in the postwar era, with the Socialist candidate, François Hollande, widely expected to defeat the incumbent, President Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: Hollande Ousts Sarkozy in French Presidential Election
text: PARIS — François Hollande defeated President Nicolas Sarkozy on Sunday, becoming the first Socialist elected president of France since François Mitterrand. Mr. Hollande campaigned on a gentler and more inclusive France, but his victory will also be seen as a challenge to the German-dominated vision of economic austerity as a way out of the euro crisis.

headline: Greek Voters Punish 2 Main Parties for Collapse
text: ATHENS — Greece was plunged into political uncertainty on Sunday after voters bolstered the far left and neo-Nazi right in a wave of protest that saw the crushing defeat of the dominant political parties they blame for Greece’s economic collapse.

headline: Artist’s Family Says Gallery Ignored Warning of Fakes

His wife, Phyllis; his daughter, Gretchen; and an art scholar went to see two gouache drawings that the gallery had recently acquired and that it hoped to sell as works from Diebenkorn’s celebrated Ocean Park series.

headline: From Coward and Porter, a Night of Songs Witty, Wistful and Wise
text: “An avalanche of words” is how Mark Waldrop, the host of the Lyrics & Lyricists program “Mad Dogs and Educated Fleas: Nöel and Cole, a Battle of Wits” described the program at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening. By the end of the two-and-a-half-hour show, the Kaufmann Concert Hall was half-buried in drifts of refined light verse invented eons before “whatever,” “no problem,” “awesome” and “dude” dominated everyday language. This was the first time Mr. Waldrop, a frequent behind-the-scenes director of many Lyrics & Lyricists shows, stepped to the fore; he appeared stiff and flustered.

headline: Hollande Squeaks It Out, Paris Erupts, Sarkozy Concedes
text: François Hollande has been elected France’s second Socialist president. Nicolas Sarkozy, in his concession speech, called for unity and respect for the Republic. The vote was closer than many expected and, like the 2000 election in the U.S., suggests a deeply divided country.  Read more »

headline: Derby Start Made for a Sprint, a Finish Made for Closing
text: Much anticipation for this year’s Kentucky Derby surrounded the likely set-up of the pace for the race. Bodemeister, the favorite at post time, was predicted to be close to a fast early pace. The instructions from trainer (Bob Baffert) to jockey (Mike Smith) were to let the horse run, if that is what he wanted to do.

headline: Sailor Fighting the Undertow of Repression
text: It is hard to believe that John Dexter’s production of Britten’s “Billy Budd,” which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night after a 15-year absence, was introduced back in 1978. Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, talks about how essential it is to modernize the theatrical elements of opera. But few recent Met productions are bolder or fresher than Dexter’s staging of this great Britten work.

headline: Markets to Give France a Grace Period, Analysts Say

headline: Special Chairs and Lots of Time: Marina Abramovic Plans Her New Center
text: On Monday, the globe-trotting performance artist Marina Abramovic is to unveil the design of the new art and education center she plans to build in Hudson, N.Y. Called the Marina Abramovic Institute for the Preservation of Performance Art, it will be designed by the architects Shohei Shigematsu and Rem Koolhaas of the firm OMA and housed in a former theater that is now an indoor tennis court.  Built in 1929, with 20,000 square feet of space, it is among the largest buildings in the town, two hours north of New York City.

headline: Young Dancers, Poised in the Classic and the Contemporary
text: The Studio Company of American Ballet Theater has undergone various changes over the years, but in 2011 the group officially became a part of the ballet theater’s Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School. On Friday night that connection was apparent as injuries led to some prominent cast changes; dancers, plucked from the school as well as Ballet Theater, were called in to fill the gaps.

headline: A Woman Abandoned in a Story Often Told
text: The mythical Arab sorceress Armida has been a character in an epic poem; the subject of operas by composers like Lully, Rossini, Haydn and Dvorak; an archetypal abandoned woman and a metaphor for the dangerously alluring East; even, in a 2005 opera by Judith Weir, a television reporter on location in Iraq. But it is safe to say that she was never an assistant at a tailor’s shop.
