headline: Convening a Salon for Gertrude Stein and Friends
text: For more than 30 years now Symphony Space has set aside a day to focus at length on a specific composer, artist, era or theme: Wall to Wall, the enduring marathon concept that started with a daylong Bach concert in 1978. In most of these events it can seem as if Symphony Space were attempting to cram an entire voluminous world into 12 hours on a single stage, to varying if nearly always edifying effect.

headline: Romantics Heated Up and Served
text: Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it, the philosopher George Santayana wrote in a piquant turn of phrase often misappropriated or mangled. Confronted with a program of works by the young German composer Jörg Widmann, like the one presented at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening as part of Carnegie Hall’s Making Music series, you could elaborate on the concept: Those who can remember the past are welcome to make merry with it.

headline: Tough on Batters; Harder on Himself
text: Mets starter R. A. Dickey hurled the rosin bag at the mound, disgusted with himself despite emphatic applause from the 29,107 fans at Citi Field. Dickey was three outs from a shutout, but he had to settle for his fourth victory of the season when Manager Terry Collins removed him after he allowed a run-scoring double in the ninth.

headline: A Young Soldier Pauses on Dallas Cowboys Turf
text: The players are at the Texas Stadium outside Dallas. They are larger than life, immortalized on the Jumbotron, bathed in glory. Pompom-waving cheerleaders celebrate their triumphs. Spectators thrill to the sight of their heroics on the field. Strangers want a piece of them, but access is limited. Still, Billy Lynn, the favorite, finds himself getting “passed around like everybody’s favorite bong.”

headline: Original Review: ‘The Caretaker’
text: Howard Taubman’s original 1961 review of Harold Pinter’s play.

headline: Disruptions: Indiscreet Photos, Glimpsed Then Gone
text: People once took photographs so they could capture a moment for themselves and keep it forever. Then digital cameras and cellphones turned photos into something more ephemeral and more easily shared. But as the case of Anthony Weiner demonstrated, photos that are shared but are not meant to last, sometimes stick around.

headline: Militant Tied to Ship Bombing Is Said to Be Killed
text: WASHINGTON — A senior Qaeda militant in Yemen linked to the deadly bombing of an American warship there in 2000 was killed in an airstrike on Sunday, the Yemeni government said, in the latest sign of an escalating American campaign to counter the terrorist threat there.

headline: One Week’s Journey Through a Whole Century in Ballet
text: One way to look at ballet is to concentrate on the choreography; and in this respect New York City Ballet has unmatched wealth in terms of both quantity and quality. Its spring season, which began on Tuesday, brought 12 ballets into repertory by Saturday night, going all the way back to 1934 (George Balanchine’s ”Serenade”), and up to 2006 (Christopher Wheeldon’s “DGV: Danse à Grande Vitesse”). Next week’s additions include two world premieres. This abundance, phenomenal elsewhere, is ordinary at City Ballet.

headline: Hughes and Offense Allow Yankees to Exit Kansas City on an Up Note
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — After a particularly dispiriting loss Saturday night, Alex Rodriguez set out the core expectations that he and his teammates in the middle of the batting order hold sacred: damage, production, wins.

headline: CBS Threatens ABC Over Reality Show
text: Lawsuits over copycatting in reality television have gone nowhere in the past, but CBS has suggested to ABC that it may consider one over a summer show called “Glass House.” The format is similar to CBS’s long-running summer series “Big Brother,” and ABC has hired many former production members from that show. On Friday CBS sent a sternly worded letter to ABC about it. The letter implies, without directly saying so, that CBS will sue ABC over copyright infringement. The letter said that CBS was “putting ABC on notice that its continued development and production of ‘Glass House’ exposes ABC to liability.” The letter said the elements of the new show are “substantially and strikingly” similar to “Big Brother.” In “Glass House,” which has its debut on June 18, 14 people are chosen to live in a house all summer with cameras on them in pursuit of a cash prize — the essence of “Big Brother” competition. In the past copyright cases have proved nearly impossible for reality-show plaintiffs to win because, in simple terms, everybody’s reality is inherently different. The total number of former staff members on “Glass House” is at least 18, according to the CBS letter, all of whom signed nondisclosure agreements when they worked for “Big Brother.” The CBS letter argued that it would be impossible for anyone who signed such a letter to help produce a similar show without breaching the agreement. ABC had yet to respond to the CBS letter or requests for comment by Sunday afternoon.

headline: Attacker in an Afghan Uniform Kills a NATO Soldier

It was possibly the latest in a recent string of so-called green-on-blue assaults on coalition soldiers by their Afghan partners this year.

text: FRANCE is glad to be rid of Nicolas Sarkozy, who lost the country’s presidency in a runoff election this weekend to the Socialist candidate, François Hollande. He was ineffective in office, and prone to gaffes in public.

headline: To Keep Viewers Watching, New Ads Come With Varied Endings

Now, along come different versions of the same commercial — but this time each version is aimed at the same audience.

headline: More Thoughts on Willie Mays Aikens
text: Certain characters in baseball have always intrigued me, and one is Willie Mays Aikens. I grew up outside Philadelphia, with my baseball awakening coming just after the 1980 World Series. The Phillies had beaten the Royals, but the better way to say it is that they somehow withstood Aikens. He hit two homers in Game 1, drove in the winning run in Game 3, belted two more homers in Game 4 and hit .400 over all – even better than the Series most valuable player, Mike Schmidt.

headline: In World of Turmoil, a Rare Moment of Joy
text: For all the baggage inherited and hauled around, all the mishaps endured or missteps taken, the Knicks deserved one. If for no other reason that they showed up battered and bandaged, they merited an endgame buzzer that put a bounce in their steps and teeth in their smiles.  They earned the streamers that fell from the Madison Square Garden rafters, a spontaneous celebration of sheer — and mere — survival.

headline: Independent Senate Run in Maine Puts Parties in a Pinch
text: BRUNSWICK, Me. — Former Gov. Angus King of Maine has a warning for the national political parties that may flood his state with negative ads to derail his independent candidacy for the Senate: “I will take note of how I am treated in this campaign.”

headline: Stock Trading Volume Has Declined
text: United States equity market volumes have generally declined over the past three years, since reaching a monthly peak in March 2009.

headline: Stock Trading Is Still Falling After ’08 Crisis
text: Even though American stocks have doubled in price in the last three years, investors and traders large and small keep giving the market the cold shoulder.

headline: No Longer Just ‘Adult-Onset’
text: A study of diabetes in overweight and obese youngsters bears an ominous warning about future health care trends in this country. It found that Type 2 diabetes, a new scourge among young people, progresses faster and is harder to treat in youngsters than in adults. The toll on their health as they grow older could be devastating.

headline: In Rise and Fall of China’s Bo Xilai, an Arc of Ruthlessness
text: BEIJING — “News 1+1” is a sort of Chinese “60 Minutes,” a newsmagazine on state-run China Central Television that explores — as much as the censors permit — the more contentious corners of Chinese society. In December 2009, the program took aim at a much-publicized anticorruption campaign in the metropolis of Chongqing, a crusade that had grabbed national attention for its sweep, but raised deep concerns about its brutality and disregard for the law.

headline: Out to Shake Up Music, Often With Sharp Words
text: Like any big music company, the offices of TuneCore, a digital distributor in Brooklyn, are lined with official-looking plaques certifying blockbuster record sales.

headline: David Weiss, Artist on Team Celebrating the Banal, Dies at 65
text: David Weiss, one half of Peter Fischli/David Weiss, or Fischli/Weiss, a Swiss art duo known for sculptures, photographs and videos that enumerate, celebrate and ever-so-gently skewer the banalities of everyday life, and for “The Way Things Go,” one of the most acclaimed art films of the late 20th century, died on April 27 in Zurich. He was 65.

headline: Study Says Broker Rebates Cost Investors Billions
text: The rules governing Wall Street generally force stockbrokers to seek out the best prices for clients who pay them to buy and sell shares.

headline: George Lindsey, TV’s Goober Pyle, Dies at 83
text: George Lindsey, the Alabama-born actor and comedian best known for playing the good-natured if none-too-bright gas station attendant Goober on three television series, died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 83.

headline: Many Competing Paths on the Road to the Phone Wallet
text: The idea of using a smartphone as a wallet has been slow to catch on in the United States. A big part of the problem has been that most stores do not have the proper physical equipment to allow customers to pay by tapping their phone.

headline: A Rival for Owens, and Questions of What If
text: A new PBS documentary details the life of Jesse Owens before and after his historic performance at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. Laurens Grant’s film hits many familiar themes and surprises with others, but one of its gems is Owens’s compelling rivalry with Eulace Peacock, one of the few contemporary sprinters who, during a stretch in 1935, had Owens’s number.

headline: More Time for Justice
text: Hawaii significantly strengthened its protections against child sexual abuse last month when Gov. Neil Abercrombie signed a measure extending the statute of limitations for civil lawsuits filed by child victims. At least as important, it opens a one-time two-year window to allow victims to file suits against their abusers even if the time limit had expired under the old law.

headline: Hip-Hop Copyright Case Had Little Explanation
text: Over Thanksgiving weekend 2010, a popular hip-hop blog, Dajaz1.com, was shut down as part of a sweep by federal authorities of dozens of Web sites suspected of copyright infringement and selling counterfeit goods. A year later, the government dropped its case against Dajaz1 and returned the site to its owner. But why?

headline: Pinteresque Hospitality
text: “What am I going to do?” cries the scruffy old fellow in a stricken voice, his imploring eyes fixed on the back of the younger man before him. “What shall I do? Where am I going to go?”

headline: The Cautionary Tale of Dewey & LeBoeuf
text: The law firm of Dewey & LeBoeuf was created in 2007 in the largest merger of law firms in history. Last week it encouraged all of its partners “to seek out alternative opportunities.” The firm is falling apart because of financial problems after overpaying star partners, gross mismanagement and other factors. But its troubles are only an extreme version of those facing many other firms.

headline: Cuomo Seeking New Agency to Police Care of Disabled
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, seeking to strengthen the state’s chronically weak response to abuse of disabled people who live in publicly financed homes, plans this week to propose creating an agency dedicated to investigating problems with the care of nearly one million vulnerable New Yorkers.

headline: ‘Condom Policing’ in New York
text: New York City has used two common-sense initiatives to drive down H.I.V. infection rates over the last 20 years. It has encouraged needle exchange programs for intravenous drug users and it has flooded the city with condoms, passing out more than 37 million last year alone.

headline: Mayor’s Feud With Press Is Escalating in Toronto
text: OTTAWA — Relations between Rob Ford, Toronto’s mayor, and The Toronto Star, the highest circulation newspaper in Canada, have never been cordial.

headline: After War Room, Heading Ivy League Classroom
text: NEW HAVEN — On a recent evening in a classroom at Yale, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal held forth for two animated hours on the conflicts in Northern Ireland and South Africa, with bits of his own history as the former top commander in Afghanistan thrown in. In earlier classes he covered the Bay of Pigs and Vietnam and, as his students tell it, recounted in mesmerizing detail the events in “The Runaway General,” the Rolling Stone article that cost him his job.

headline: Boy, 12, Killed by Rising Parking Lot Gate in Brooklyn
text: Her son’s interests were like those of many 12-year-olds, Doris Chase said: sports and clothing. He had never played on the roll-up parking lot gate in his Brownsville, Brooklyn, neighborhood. “He’d always be out playing ball,” said Ms. Chase, 33. “He liked to dress and look nice.”

headline: TNT and TBS Think Big for a Rolling Stone Issue
text: There’s one thing that the publisher of Rolling Stone magazine and its advertiser partners want readers to remember about a coming special issue — that it’s big, with a capital B.

headline: Devils Don’t Let Up, Pushing Flyers to Edge of Elimination
text: NEWARK — The Philadelphia Flyers’ steely playoff resolve, held in check for the last three games by an unrelenting Devils’ attack, finally melted with four seconds left in the second period Sunday, when Claude Giroux thrust his right shoulder into Dainius Zubrus’s head.

headline: Got a Computer? Get a Degree.
text: Harvard and M.I.T. are going to offer free courses online, but not for credit. Why not?

headline: ‘Once’ and ‘Sons of the Prophet’ Win Smaller-Show Honors
text: Recent Off Broadway productions of the musical “Once” and the play “Sons of the Prophet” won top honors on Sunday night at the presentation of the 27th annual Lucille Lortel Awards, which recognize excellence at medium-size and small New York theaters. “Once,” about a friendship that turns to love between a Dublin guitarist and a Czech pianist, won for outstanding musical, choreography (Steven Hoggett), and lighting design (Natasha Katz, who tied in the category with David Weiner for “Through A Glass Darkly”).

headline: After Suspenseful Plays, Game Ends With a Clang
text: Dwyane Wade gave the Miami Heat the lead four times in the fourth quarter Sunday and, with the Heat down by 2 points with precious seconds ticking off the clock, he could have made it five, the fate of the Knicks’ season hinging on his final shot.

headline: France’s President-Elect Has Fans Aplenty at Home
text: TULLE, France — François Hollande learned how to be a politician in this small city in the rural south-central region of France known as Corrèze.

headline: Knicks-Heat Replay: Game 4
text: The Knicks’ 89-87 victory ended a drought of 11 years without a playoff win, and prevented a sweep by the Heat.

headline: Socialist Wins in France
text: François Hollande defeated President Nicolas Sarkozy on Sunday, becoming the first Socialist elected president of France since François Mitterrand.

headline: Infinite Itch: Learning to Live With Hives
text: Bill Brancaccio inherited a sharp mind and a brawny physique from his Long Island family, and something more: a susceptibility to hives, itchy, red welts that can last for minutes or for days, sometimes recurring for weeks, months or even years.

headline: Arab Spring Spurs Palestinian Journalists to Test Free Speech Limits
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Yousef Shayeb, 37, a Palestinian journalist from Ramallah, published an article in a Jordanian newspaper this year charging officials at the Palestinian diplomatic mission in Paris with corruption and espionage. In an interview here last week, he said that he had imagined people might thank him for his exposé. Instead, he spent eight days in a Palestinian Authority jail.

headline: Markets Are Calm After Political Shake-Up in Europe
text: Election results in Europe injected new uncertainty into financial markets on Monday, but stocks on Wall Street generally rode out the political developments with little change.

headline: In the Chen Case, Collateral Damage
text: HONG KONG — The last time this happened, the last time he was grabbed by the Chinese authorities, he was “disappeared” for 60 days. Beatings, shouts, shackles, blindfolds, no sunlight. He said he was banged on the head so severely — typically with plastic bottles filled with water — that his memory began to slip. He couldn’t remember his Skype password or how the furniture was arranged in his bedroom back home.

headline: Juve and Jozy, Ajax and Anderlecht: a Roundup of the European Races

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Tears and Broken Glass as India’s Largest Transgender Festival Closes
text: Human beings often seek spiritual healing out of a sense of psychological pain. In the case of India’s hijra population, a group with a tradition that spans back until at least the Kama Sutra period, their sources of pain are sociologically complex, poorly documented, but difficult to deny: According to outreach groups like the Mumbai-based gay rights organization Humsafar Trust, India’s hijra population has a staggering rate of H.I.V. infection that numbers somewhere between 29 and 49 percent.

headline: May 7, 1945 | Nazi Germany Surrenders in World War II
text: On May 7, 1945, Germany signed an unconditional surrender at Allied headquarters in Reims, France, to take effect the following day, ending the European conflict of World War II.

headline: In Kolkata, Clinton Talks Indian Retail and Iranian Oil
text: The U.S. secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton, told a town hall meeting in Kolkata on Monday that she planned to discuss opening India’s retail sector to foreign investment with Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee and that India should do even more to reduce its dependence on Iranian oil.

headline: Austerity Faces Sharper Debate After European Elections
text: PARIS — Hours after voters in France and Greece delivered sharp rebuttals to advocates of austerity as the antidote to Europe’s financial crisis, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Monday pointedly insisted that neither she nor her government favored a renegotiation of a fiscal pact underpinning the Continent’s belt-tightening.

headline: Cycle of Fear
text: Like many people, I like to set aside a few hours every day, generally between 3 and 6 a.m., to lie quietly thinking about everything that could go horribly wrong with my life and all the ways in which I am negligent and reprehensible. I have spasms of panic over things I shouldn’t have written, or, worse, things I should have; I regret having spent all the money and wonder where more money might ever conceivably come from; I wish I’d kissed girls I didn’t, as long ago as 1985. I’m suddenly convulsed with remorse over mean things I did in middle school (I am sorry, Matthew Reeve); I force myself to choose my least favorite death (drowning).

headline: Life on Both Sides of the Border
text: “Family is complicated,” the photographer Joseph Rodriguez said. “That’s all.”

headline: When Have You Ever Failed at Something? What Happened as a Result?
text: When have you ever failed at something that was important to you, whether in school, at home, with your friends or anywhere else? How did you react to that failure? Did anything positive come out of it? What?

headline: College Bound and Proud to Be Relieved of My Indecision
text: After months of deliberating and changing my mind hundreds of times, I can finally say that I know where I’m going to college. The stress has evaporated and only pure relief remains. The commitment deposit has been filled out, and I even managed to turn it in a day early!

headline: Syrians Vote in Election Dismissed by Foes as a Farce
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government held parliamentary elections on Monday, calling them an important step toward reform, while virtually ignoring public demands for sweeping democratic change that have rocked the country for the past 14 months.

headline: Putin Takes Helm as Police Punish Moscow Dissent
text: MOSCOW — In the lustrous, vaulted throne room of the czars who came before him, Vladimir V. Putin on Monday reclaimed the Russian presidency. A 30-gun salute cracked over the eerie quiet of the city, and Russia’s defense minister returned to Mr. Putin the black suitcase that contains the controls to a vast nuclear arsenal.

headline: Decathlon History Is His in the Making
text: The 2012 Olympic decathlon — Ashton Eaton’s first, if all goes according to form and plan — will not begin until August. But Eaton is experiencing the Olympics far from London with help from his coach, Harry Marra.

headline: Showdown in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — At around 7 p.m. Sunday, Prime Minister Vladimir Putin’s press secretary, Dmitri Peskov, made an on-air comment to the Dozhd television channel. Answering a question about the violence that had broken out in Bolotnaya Square in central Moscow, he said he believed the police were being too soft on the protesters.  At that moment I was sitting at a cafe a two-minute walk from Bolotnaya, gripping my phone, white-knuckled: My 10-year-old daughter, Yael, was in the square where the police were clashing with protesters.

headline: Treasury to Sell A.I.G. Shares at $30.50 Apiece

headline: Doctors Without Borders Pull Back in Kashmir
text: Médecins Sans Frontières shut down its operations in the Kupwara district of Kashmir last month and will significantly reduce its activities in the valley as a whole, cutting a staff of 100 by more than half.

headline: Congress Returns to Full Agenda Awash in Election Year Politics
text: For months, the Obama campaign has plotted to run directly against Republicans in Congress. With Mitt Romney now settled in as the presumptive presidential nominee and leader of his party, Democrats are hoping that some disenchantment with the House Republicans’ legislative agenda – and the frequent intransigence of some of its most conservative members – will help bolster President Obama’s standing, and give some glow to their own House and Senate races.

headline: Appreciating, and Assessing, Teachers

Blow focused his Op-Ed column on a teacher near and dear to his heart: his mother, a teacher of 34 years who then volunteered in a school after she retired, then won a seat on the school board -- proof, he writes, that "teaching is one of those jobs you do with the whole of you."  And Michael Winerip devotes his On Education column to teaching students who are resisting participation in a new Stanford University and Pearson Education study to develop a system to weed out unfit teachers.

headline: Dangers of National Unity

headline: Daily Report: Seeking the Next Instagram
text: When Facebook bought Instagram for $1 billion last month, it raised a lot of eyebrows — and questions about which buzzed-about young start-ups might be on track for similar success, Jenna Wortham and Nicole Perlroth report in Monday’s New York Times. There is certainly no shortage of companies to choose from. The start-up scene is on fire, flooded with apps and services that are attracting users and backing from venture capitalists. But it can be hard to determine which companies are just at the height of their hype cycle, and which are worthy of the kind of attention Instagram was receiving when Facebook came calling.

headline: From ABC News and Univision, an English-Language Channel for Hispanics
text: Catering to the growing number of bilingual Hispanics in the United States who watch English-language television, Univision and the ABC News division of the Walt Disney Company are teaming up to start a cable channel with news and lifestyle programming.

headline: Rushdie Brings PEN Festival to Close
text: The PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature ended Sunday night on a traditional note, with a lecture by the Indian-born novelist Salman Rushdie, the target of an ayatollah’s fatwa in 1989, about the freedom to write. In recent years the festival has experimented with offerings that blur the distinction between literature and other forms of art or entertainment, and this year was no exception: the 37 scheduled events included one on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum in which three writers recited texts over a live musical performance by the Kronos Quartet and another on Saturday night that had five authors giving a thematic reading called “Messiah in Brooklyn” as they stood amid an installation at a gallery called the Invisible Dog Art Center.

text: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, left, returns a traditional gesture from West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee.

headline: Kosher-Food Manufacturer to Pay $577,000 in Settlement

headline: Kitchit, for Chef-Made Meals at Home
text: Waffles and coffee on a breakfast tray for Mom? Instead, how about a dinner party for 8 or 10 at home, cooked by an accomplished (and maybe even famous) chef? Kitchit, a service that started last year in San Francisco and last month in Los Angeles, has just landed in New York. It offers custom-tailored dinners, lunches, brunches, cocktail parties and even picnics and barbecues at home, with chefs doing all the shopping and cooking.

headline: Leading Off: N.B.A.’s Real Season Arrives
text: The first round of the N.B.A. playoffs has not yet wrapped up but the regular season has long been rendered irrelevant. That was about the same time the Lakers were officially old, too Kobe-centric, and doomed. The Celtics were just old. The 76ers were boring and irrelevant. Remember all that?

headline: Offshoot of Tribeca Film Festival Coming to Florence
text: Having recently wrapped up its 11th annual running in New York, the Tribeca Film Festival is preparing to take a Tuscan holiday. On Monday, Tribeca Enterprises, the parent company of the Tribeca Film Festival, said it was working with IMG Artists, the performing arts management company, to create Tribeca Firenze, a series of film programming that will run in Florence, Italy, June 11 to June 18.

headline: Elizabeth Phillips: Teachers Need to Be Supported
text: Elizabeth Phillips, the principal of Public School 321 in Brooklyn, has been an outspoken critic of the state exams for elementary school children and the teacher data reports. Ms. Phillips, who leads a high-performing school of 1,407 children, said good teachers were the essence of good schools. "I feel like almost everything I do has to be geared to how I am supporting the teachers," she says.

headline: Now Playing | The World Premiere of Bonnie Prince Billy’s New Music Video
text: Will Oldham is often described as prolific, and with good reason. The singer-songwriter of many monikers — he has recorded music as the Palace Brothers, Palace Music, Palace Songs and Bonnie Prince Billy, among other names — has seldom gone a year without releasing a record in almost two decades. He has also been known to rerecord his old songs, making instrument-packed renditions of what were spare arrangements and turning dark, slow ballads into light, country-inflected numbers. To coincide with his new book, “Will Oldham on Bonnie ‘Prince’ Billy,” Oldham is again releasing a new batch of his own oldies — a six-song EP called “Now Here’s My Plan,” made up of fresh versions of songs from the Prince Billy catalog. Among the recordings, available on July 24 at Drag City, is an impossibly upbeat rendition of “I See a Darkness,” the beautifully bleak song off his 1999 album of the same name that was later covered by Johnny Cash. To Ben Berman, who directed the music video for the new version, above, the buoyant rendition is not incongruous with the song’s subject matter. “To me the song is about friendship,” Berman says, speaking by phone from Los Angeles. “It’s about a person who is dark and morose and maybe unhappy in his life but who has a friend who makes it all worthwhile.” There wasn’t much of a planned concept for the video, Berman says, but the result was something of a study in contrasts: black-and-white photography in cinematic Glasgow, Scotland, plus goofball dance moves and special effects that make Oldham’s and his band members’ eyes swirl around in opposing directions like stick-on googly eyes. “We share a similar sensibility for what we find bizarrely funny,” Berman says. “He’s the perfect amount of weird.”

headline: The Get | Prada Re-Edition Bag
text: Those gripped by Met Ball mania will be pleased to hear that pieces from the Prada archive can now be had outside of the Costume Institute, too. (Should you have been under a rock in recent weeks, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s latest exhibition, “Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations,” opens on Thursday and runs through Aug. 19.) In honor of the show, Prada is offering a special re-edition collection — nine iconic bags in original and new fall colors — at its New York stores. Among the styles, which span more than a decade (1991-2005), are the bowling bag from spring 2000, the timeless doctor tote from fall of that same year and this canvas and leather clutch covered in a memory-jogging William Morris floral from fall 2003. At just under $2000, it’s a small price to pay for Prada history.

headline: The Uses and Misuses of Unpaid Internships
text: Camille Olson, one of the nation’s leading lawyers in advising employers about internship programs, says internships can be an excellent way for employers to get a good sense of a potential hire — to kick the tires, so to speak — and see, for example, how hard-working or creative someone is. If an intern performs well, it seems natural for the employer to offer a regular, permanent job. But if the intern is not up to snuff, it is much less painful to let the person go after three months than to lay off a recently hired regular employee after three months. That latter course not only hurts the worker, but also helps give the employer a reputation as an undesirable place to work.

Though the recipe dates from 1962, this grisly instruction isn’t an outdated practice, but one followed today in many commercial kitchens.

Wendy Wick Reaves, the gallery’s curator of prints and drawings, will serve as acting director while a search committee, headed by Richard Kurin, the Under Secretary for History, Art, and Culture, looks for a new chief.

headline: Shepard Fairey Paints Neil Young’s New Songs
text: The admiration between Shepard Fairey and Neil Young goes both ways. Mr. Fairey, a longtime fan of the musician, included him in “May Day,” his 2010 show at Deitch Projects portraying cultural heroes of the left. Then Mr. Young, who stages an annual benefit concert for the Bridge School in Northern California, asked Mr. Fairey to create art for an album marking the concert’s 25th anniversary. So the artist wasn’t exactly surprised, he said at the opening of his new show at Pace Prints, when Mr. Young asked him to make a painting representing each song in his new album with Crazy Horse, “Americana.” What Mr. Fairey didn’t expect was the intensity of Mr. Young’s involvement. For all the tracks, the artist submitted several digital mockups inspired by the narrative (none based on an identifiable original source, he emphasized). Then Mr. Young picked his favorites. Mr. Fairey said he was also surprised to learn that “God Save the Queen” is not just a Sex Pistols song but an old British anthem and the source of the melody for “My Country ’Tis of Thee.” His finished painting depicts the Queen and Betsy Ross sewing a combination of British and American flags; its text reads “God save the land of liberty”— a phrase with both a dual origin and a double meaning. “Neil and I talked about that,” Mr. Fairey said. “They left England, and basically made the same mistakes. In some respect it all blends together.”

headline: Drilling Down: Business Travel Tips From a Travel Columnist
text: This week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to a column about United Airlines written by Joe Brancatelli, a travel columnist: “Worst. Airline. Ever. Again.” According to his own Web site — “the homepage for business travelers” — Mr. Brancatelli “has logged countless miles, spent way too many nights in mediocre hotels, wasted far too many hours in airline clubs and drunk far too much bad coffee. In other words, he’s just your Average Joe Business Traveler.” We went back to him to see what other words of advice he might have for small-business travelers. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: The New New List
text: Fishing is the new farm stay.It’s not enough to go meet your osso buco. Sustainable seafood requires you to spend a week with your fish, too. At Jakes in Jamaica, guests head out with the fisherman Dennis Abrahams (right) to catch kingfish, Spanish mackerel and wahoo for supper back at the hotel. Gansevoort Turks and Caicos sends you deep-sea fishing, then cooks your catch to order. And at the Four Seasons Resort Nevis, the chef is a scuba master who leads divers on a hunt for Caribbean spiny lobster, then barbecues them beachside.

text: ALBANY – Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday that he was excited that President Obama’s trip to Albany this week could bring attention to the state’s economic development efforts.

headline: Accessories Watch | The Season’s Must-Have Scarves
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Tortorella: Capitals Series Has Been ‘Harder’ Than Senators Series
text: Ranger Coach John Tortorella was asked Monday morning why the Rangers-Capitals series had so far lacked the bite of Rangers-Senators in the first round. He didn’t really answer that particular question, but did say, “To me, this series has been an even harder series to play than the Ottawa series.”

headline: After Hayabusa Heart Transplants, Smart Cars That Pump Fire
text: Americans tend to think of the Smart Fortwo as a fuel-frugal, docile ride, but a few mechanically inclined enthusiasts are tinkering with, if not wholly upending that image.

headline: After Spending Freely, Liberal Town Faces Fight on Frugality
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Here, “where the suburb meets the city,” as banners downtown proclaim, there is a Williams-Sonoma but also New Jersey’s first licensed medical marijuana dispensary. President Obama captured 83 percent of the vote. Residents support two libraries and two independent bookstores, and driving the six-mile stretch of town, you are never more than 10 minutes from your pick of two Whole Foods.

headline: Giants’ Mota Suspended for 100 Games
text: Guillermo Mota, a relief pitcher for the San Francisco Giants, was given a 100-game suspension Monday after testing positive for clenbuterol, a performance-enhancing substance banned by Major League Baseball.

headline: Flood of Donations to Fight AIDS Appears Not to Detract From Other Health Issues
text: Pouring donor money into fighting AIDS in a poor African country does not necessarily detract from addressing other medical problems there, like malaria, malnutrition and infections, a six-year study in Rwanda has found.

headline: Crying Treason
text: Today in Ohio, Mitt Romney said he doesn’t think President Obama should be tried for treason.

headline: Parents’ Depression Linked to Problems in Children
text: Like many other primary care doctors, I sometimes sense the shadow of depression hovering at the edges of the exam room. I am haunted by one mother with severe postnatal depression. Years ago, I took proper care of the baby, but I missed the mother’s distress, as did everyone else.

headline: Executive of Hospital Gets 3 Years for Bribery
text: The former hospital chief executive at the center of a bribery conspiracy that ensnared former State Senator Carl Kruger and others was sentenced on Monday to three years in prison.

headline: Tough Cookie Takes Manhattan
text: Emily Bergl is the very model of a modern gal in too much of a hurry to play by the rules and waste her energy making nice for the sake of good manners. At any time of the day you can see variations of her stage character clacking noisily along Manhattan sidewalks, oblivious to her surroundings, a cellphone glued to her ear. If she’s pushing a stroller, you’d better get out of the way.

headline: Standout Hats at the 2012 Kentucky Derby
text: Like the Easter parade, the Kentucky Derby is where you’ll find the largest concentration of heavily adorned head pieces.

headline: An Unreleased Beastie Boys Clip Is Pulled From YouTube
text: A previously unreleased clip of the Beastie Boys made during the taping of a show on Comedy Central that was posted on YouTube was pulled down on Monday after Viacom Inc. complained that it had been posted without permission, said Jeremy Zweig, a spokesman for the media company.

headline: How ‘Mad Men’ Landed the Beatles: All You Need Is Love (and $250,000)
text: In most cases, “Mad Men” is bound by the history of the era in which it takes place. But on Sunday night, a new episode of that 1960s period drama that concluded with the Beatles song “Tomorrow Never Knows” appears to have made some history of its own, marking a rare instance in which a song written and recorded by that band has been licensed for use on a television series.

headline: In Military Courts, Considering Alternative Punishment for Troubled Service Members
text: Since the first one opened in Buffalo in 2008, veterans treatment courts have spread to more than 80 locations across the country. The special courts give civilian judges discretion to consider a veteran’s service-related drug or mental problems in sentencing, and have been praised by many experts as helping to ensure troubled veterans get needed treatment.

headline: The Slog to the Sea, Accompanied by Speeches of Unlikely Eloquence
text: CHICAGO — The sound of snoring in the audience preceded the drumbeat of footsteps onstage at a recent performance of “The March,” Frank Galati’s studious but lifeless stage adaptation at the Steppenwold Theater here of the E. L. Doctorow novel about Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman’s victorious sweep through Georgia and the Carolinas during the latter days of the Civil War. The unmistakable wheeze of a sleeping patron is not unheard of at the theater, certainly, but never before have I felt envious of the fellow drifting off to dreamland.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, France, Greece and Germany.

headline: Huge Asteroid Is Still the Central Villain in Dinosaurs’ Extinction
text: For some 30 years, scientists have debated what sealed the fate of the dinosaurs. Was an asteroid impact more or less solely responsible for the catastrophic mass extinction at the end of the Cretaceous geological period, 65 million years ago? Or were the dinosaurs already undergoing a long-term decline, and the asteroid was merely the coup de grâce?

headline: Tumbling Creatures
text: Q. I bring home fresh produce from a garden that invariably has little critters embedded, sow bugs and the like. I put them outside on my 19th-floor window ledge, and they crawl or fall away. Do they get hurt?

headline: Colorado Same-Sex Union Bill Gains G.O.P. Supporters
text: DENVER — Supporters of a bill that would allow civil unions for same-sex couples in Colorado were hopeful on Monday that the legislation, buoyed by the support of key Republican lawmakers who broke party ranks, would pass before the legislative session ended this week.

headline: Qaeda Plot to Attack Plane Foiled, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency, working closely with foreign partners, thwarted a plot by the branch of Al Qaeda in Yemen to smuggle an experimental bomb aboard an airliner bound for the United States, intelligence officials said on Monday.

headline: Preserving Marine Life (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Early Thinkers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turning Up the Heat on Lettuce: Lettuce and Green Garlic Soup
text: Every once in a while I put out a message on the Recipes for Health Facebook page asking readers to tell me what they’re getting in their C.S.A. produce baskets, what they need recipes for. The most recent responses reflected an overabundance of lettuce. One reader replied: “Lettuce. So much lettuce. Lettuce to the point where I get a nervous tic just thinking about eating another salad.”

headline: Help for the Pregnant (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ulysses Goes to College, in a Lively Monteverdi
text: NEW HAVEN — For many years Ellen Rosand, a professor of music at Yale and a noted scholar of Baroque opera, has been turning undergraduates at the college into opera buffs through a popular introductory course. But recently Yale students who like to sing and prefer learning by doing have had a more tantalizing option: They can try out for the course Analyzing, Directing and Performing Early Opera, in which the class assignment each semester is to put on a fully staged production of a selected Baroque work.

headline: Emergency Painkillers (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tale of the Met’s 45-Ton Diva
text: “Wagner’s Dream”: a loaded title if ever there was one. Implicit almost throughout Susan Froemke’s documentary film of that name — when it is not explicit — is the notion that Wagner, frustrated with limited 19th-century staging techniques, could have only dreamed of something like the high-tech machine that Robert Lepage has used to stage the “Ring of the Nibelungen” at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: The Science Times Podcast
text: An H.I.V. success story; a Soviet medical mystery; and a hard look at the U.S. health care system.

headline: New Albums From ‘Off!’ and Here We Go Magic
text: OFF!

headline: The Madness That Is Part of Every Life
text: PARIS — Not long into “1980 — A Piece by Pina Bausch” a woman begins to skip around the stage, waving a white handkerchief. “I am tir-ed, I am tir-ed,” she chants in a sing-song, childlike rhythm. Round and round she goes until her chant is interrupted by gasps for breath, her steps falter, and her arm shakes with the effort of holding the fabric aloft.

headline: CBGB Is Dead. Long Live CBGB.
text: For the last six years the name CBGB has been little more than a logo on T-shirts for young people in the East Village. Now a group of investors has bought the assets of that famous punk-rock club, which closed in 2006, and plans to establish an ambitious music festival this summer, with an eye toward reopening the club at a new downtown location.

headline: Few Seize on a U.S. Bond Program Backing Green Energy
text: With the country reeling in 2008 from the financial crisis, Congress created a special program to help struggling local governments finance clean energy projects. Under the initiative, cities and counties could sell bonds to pay for a new wind farm or energy efficient windows at City Hall, and the federal government would help pick up the tab.

headline: That Endless Search for Self-Identity
text: Pavel Zustiak, born in what was then Czechoslovakia, has reason to focus on notions of identity and home. In a way his “Painted Bird” trilogy, which takes its point of departure from the Jerzy Kosinski 1965 novel of that title, reveals Mr. Zustiak’s quest to find his place in the world — mirroring the wandering young male protagonist in the book.

headline: Preliminary Deal for Sale of Coyotes
text: Commissioner Gary Bettman announced Monday night that a preliminary deal had been reached to sell the Phoenix Coyotes.

headline: An Elite College Education, Online?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making Railroads Safer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Intersection: Where Culture Meets Style
text: In this first installment, we spot Brit Cato, a fashion stylist, hoofing it across DeKalb and Carlton Avenues in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on a recent afternoon.

headline: Still a Chill in Spy vs. Spy
text: Which part of the cold war is over?

headline: Privatizing Learning
text: To the Editor:

headline: Homes of ‘The Scream’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Baby Boomers and the Shrinking Work Force
text: Among the lowlights of the jobs report for April was the news that the share of adults who are either working or looking for work fell. For men, this measure — called the labor force participation rate — was at its lowest level since 1948, when the government first began keeping track.

headline: Live-Tweeting the James Beard Awards
text: Melissa Clark, a columnist for the Dining section, is tweeting from Monday night’s James Beard Foundation Awards ceremony in New York, which honors chefs and restaurants from across the country. Follow her at @goodappetite, and look for the hashtag #jbfa. The event is getting under way now.

headline: iTunes in Luxembourg
text: To the Editor:

headline: Teases of a Streisand Return to Brooklyn
text: Barbra Streisand is coming home to sing in Brooklyn! Maybe!

headline: Mets Place Tejada on Disabled List
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets placed shortstop Ruben Tejada on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right quadriceps Monday and recalled Jordany Valdespin from Class AAA Buffalo.

headline: State Assembly Will Not Legalize Mixed Martial Arts, Speaker Says
text: ALBANY — Mixed martial arts will not become legal in New York this year after the State Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said on Monday that a bill to allow it would not come to the floor for a vote.

headline: It’s Not So Lonely at the Top: Ecosystems Thrive High in the Sky
text: Looming over the northern edge of the Amazon rain forest are some of the most remarkable mountains on earth. Known as tepuis, or tabletop mountains, they are typically ringed by sheer cliffs that rise thousands of feet from the surrounding lowland jungles. Instead of peaks, tepuis have enormous flat expanses at their tops. To reach the tops of many tepuis, the only choices are scaling the cliffs or flying in a helicopter.

headline: Zombie-Ant Fungus Has Its Own Killer Fungus
text: Like something out of a horror movie, the zombie-ant fungus attacks and invades the brains of carpenter ants. Possessed ants march to their death, and the fungus lives inside the exoskeleton.

headline: A Crocodile Too Huge to Fit on the Family Tree
text: Giant crocodiles, far larger than any known to date, lived in Kenya two million to four million years ago among our human ancestors, according to a new report.

headline: Liberals Steer Outside Money to Grass-Roots Organizing
text: After months on the sidelines, major liberal donors including the financier George Soros are preparing to inject up to $100 million into independent groups to aid Democrats’ chances this fall. But instead of going head to head with the conservative “super PACs” and outside groups that have flooded the presidential and Congressional campaigns with negative advertising, the donors are focusing on grass-roots organizing, voter registration and Democratic turnout.

headline: Women, Weight and Wellness
text: What should be more important to women: A positive body image or a fit physique that is less at risk for diabetes and other health issues?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Grid Batteries and Buffett on Yahoo
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. See more here.

headline: Unable to Say ‘I Do’
text: Just two days after his inimitably voluble vice president kind of, sort of, probably came out in favor of same-sex marriage, and just a day after his education secretary expressed more succinct, unambiguous support for it, Barack Obama is scheduled to visit New York and cross paths with the governor who is arguably the Democratic standard-bearer for marriage equality, Andrew Cuomo.

headline: Once an Urban Landfill, Now a Rowing Paradise
text: LEONIA, N.J. — Near the junction of the New Jersey Turnpike and Interstate 80, not far from the conga line of traffic grinding toward New York City, lies a body of water that was once a garbage dump.

headline: Pitting Child Safety Against the Family Farm
text: Durham, N.H.

headline: Ex-Vice Chairman at Dewey Is Said to Claim That He Is Owed $61 Million
text: A former vice chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf has told the law firm that it owes him $61 million, an amount underscoring the vast sums at stake as the firm teeters.

headline: Rhode Island: State Told to Hand Over Murder Suspect
text: The state must deliver a man accused of murder to federal authorities, a federal appeals court in Boston ruled Monday. Gov. Lincoln Chafee refused to surrender the inmate, Jason W. Pleau, in June 2011, when prosecutors wanted to try him in federal court. Mr. Chafee argued that doing so could expose Mr. Pleau to the death penalty, which Rhode Island does not have. Mr. Pleau is accused of robbing and killing a gas-station manager in 2010. Mr. Chafee has not said whether he will appeal the ruling.

headline: Facing Popular Competitors, Twitpic Releases Free iPhone App
text: TwitPic, the photo sharing service for people who use Twitter, announced Monday that it had released its first application for the iPhone.

headline: Citibank Pays to Put Name on Shared Bikes
text: It will still be months before they are available for rent, and a few days before their precise locations will be revealed. But the 10,000 bicycles in New York’s much anticipated bike-sharing program have a name: Citi Bike.

headline: French Center-Right Assesses Two Unpalatable Paths
text: PARIS — The victory of François Hollande in presidential elections, the first by a Socialist in 17 years, has thrown the French right into turmoil and opened fresh opportunities for a Socialist triumph in legislative elections in June, with all the potential for a continued redrawing of France’s political landscape.

headline: The Dog Ate My Birth Certificate
text: Austin, Tex.At the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner last month, President Obama playfully referenced a passage in his memoir in which he told of eating dog meat as a child in Indonesia. Riffing on Sarah Palin’s line — and responding to Republican criticism — he said, “What’s the difference between a hockey mom and a pit bull? A pit bull is delicious.” (Of course, Republicans have had their own canine issues, given Mitt Romney’s predilection for fastening his Irish setter to the top of the family car in the 1980s.)

headline: Questioning Safety of Heavy Passengers on Planes
text: More than six decades ago, when the federal standards on the strength of airplane seats and seat belts were written, government regulations specified that seats be designed for a passenger weight of 170 pounds. But now the average American man weighs nearly 194 pounds and the average woman 165.

headline: Chinese Exporters’ Weakness at Fair Points to Broader Economic Anxiety
text: GUANGZHOU, China — The green, blue and brown picnic backpacks displayed by the Xiamen Tawa Enterprise at the Canton Fair here in recent days are ingeniously designed, with special pockets for vacuum bottles, silverware and matching cloth napkins.

headline: Pinched Aspirations of Iran’s Young Multitudes
text: TEHRAN — About two months ago, when many Iranian families were stocking up on rice and meat to prepare for seemingly inevitable military conflict with the West over Iran’s nuclear program, Ali Mesgaran, 35, decided to open a sandwich shop.

headline: On the Eve of Voting, a Senator Fights On
text: In the final, frenzied days of campaigning, Richard G. Lugar, who has won six previous elections to the United States Senate, has not exactly soft-pedaled the size of his challenge in the Indiana Republican primary on Tuesday.

headline: For Knicks, the Odds Are Long and the Bench Is Short
text: There was a time, not long ago, when all things seemed possible in the Knicks’ world, when odds were defied, conventional thought was crushed and the unexpected became routine.

headline: Yahoo’s Chief Apologizes to Staff
text: Yahoo’s embattled chief executive, Scott Thompson, sent an e-mail to employees on Monday apologizing for how the issue of his misstated academic credentials has drawn criticism toward the Internet company.

headline: No Room for Dissent in a Police Department Consumed by the Numbers
text: Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly is the cop from central casting, possessed of a square jaw, swagger and charm, and a flinty willingness to challenge any critic. Of late, party and business leaders have tried to lure him into carrying the Republican banner in the 2013 mayoral derby.

headline: Bending Company Policy on Business Travel
text: PSST. Want to buy an airplane seat with a tiny bit more legroom so your knees don’t knock your chin on that four-hour flight? How about a hotel that’s part of a chain where you have a ton of loyalty points and they treat you like family, rather than one across town that your company wants you to use?

headline: Google Tries Again With Google TV
text: Google, once again, is making a push into the living room.

headline: Tales of Tattoos and Turbulence
text: I HAVE a green card and a lot of tattoos. For many years, that combination meant I spent a lot of time in a lot of holding rooms.

headline: 2 Bills and Comments by Officials Stir Debate Over Same-Sex Unions
text: WASHINGTON — A day after his vice president’s expansive comments all but endorsing same-sex marriage, President Obama faced renewed pressure on Monday to complete his “evolving” on the issue and to take a clear stand despite the unpredictable consequences for his re-election bid.

headline: Challenger to Rangel Lands a Prominent Endorsement
text: State Senator Adriano Espaillat, intensifying his outreach to Latino voters in his campaign to defeat Representative Charles B. Rangel, was endorsed on Monday by one of the city’s most prominent Hispanic leaders, Fernando Ferrer.

headline: The Structural Revolution
text: The country is divided when different people take different sides in a debate. The country is really divided when different people are having entirely different debates. That’s what’s happening on economic policy.

headline: Staging the Self: ‘The Hunger Games’
text: A couple of weeks ago my daughter visited from California. She brought with her the first volume of Suzanne Collins’s “The Hunger Games.” She read it in short order and drove to the local Barnes & Noble to get the other two. She finished them in a day, and then passed all three on to me. I devoured them and passed them on to my wife, who also read them in record time.

headline: China Expels Al Jazeera Channel
text: BEIJING — Al Jazeera, the satellite broadcasting network, was forced by the Chinese authorities to close its China news operations of its English-language channel on Monday, the first such action in almost 14 years and the strongest sign yet of fraying relations between the ruling Communist Party and the overseas journalists who cover it.

headline: Just the Facts
text: Many people seem to regard a nonfiction writer’s obligation to stick to the facts as a roadblock to creativity. Perhaps that’s why so many artists attempt nonfiction projects, then end up embellishing their narratives with invented elements.

headline: A Taste of Italian, Served Up in a Big Bus
text: THE food truck is gaining a reputation in the United States as a destination for those craving fine cuisine.

headline: Patron’s Contributions and Their Intent Are Focus at Edwards Trial
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Defense lawyers for former Senator John Edwards spent much of the morning trying to show that money from the heiress Rachel Mellon used to cover up Mr. Edwards’s affair was not intended to influence the election but was just a gift from a friend.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Queens Parents’ Arrest Calls Attention to Under-Age Drinking
text: A raucous, alcohol-fueled party in the private, Rockaway Peninsula enclave of Breezy Point ended Saturday night with the parents of a lacrosse player at the prestigious Poly Prep Country Day School hauled away in handcuffs and charged with 43 counts of unlawfully dealing with children, a misdemeanor that can include serving alcohol to minors, the police said on Monday.

headline: Judge Bans Key Portion of Interview With Clemens
text: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors in the Roger Clemens perjury trial started their week on a down note Monday when the judge presiding over the case ruled against their request to play a clip of Clemens’s 2008 interview with “60 Minutes” that the government had hoped would bolster its case.

headline: Obama Hands Congress Economic ‘To Do’ List
text: WASHINGTON — With a polarized Congress already on the defensive, President Obama on Tuesday will outline a five-point “to do” list for lawmakers that packages job creation and mortgage relief ideas he has proposed before, administration officials say.

headline: Israeli Court Rejects the Release of Hunger Strikers
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Supreme Court on Monday rejected appeals for the release of two Palestinian prisoners who have been on a hunger strike for 69 days to protest their incarceration without formal charges, sharpening concern for their lives and raising the specter of widespread unrest in the event of a death.

headline: Arm Troubles for a Yankees Prospect
text: Less than a week after Michael Pineda had surgery to repair a torn labrum in his right shoulder, Jose Campos, the other pitcher the Yankees received from the Seattle Mariners in the Jesus Montero deal, went on the disabled list for Class A Charleston.

headline: Reflecting on Buffett, Business and Politics
text: OMAHA — “When Charlie and I took this job, we did not agree to put our citizenship in a blind trust.”

headline: This Story Isn’t Over Yet
text: As a young man, Robert A. Caro was a newspaper reporter.

headline: Signs of Support as Cuomo Outlines Plan on Disabled Abuse
text: ALBANY — With just seven weeks to go in the legislative session, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday that he was determined to win passage of legislation overhauling the state’s response to the abuse and neglect of vulnerable residents.

headline: Dead Dolphins and Birds Are Causing Alarm in Peru
text: Late last year, fishermen began finding dead dolphins, hundreds of them, washed up on Peru’s northern coast. Now, seabirds have begun dying, too, and the government has yet to conclusively pinpoint a cause.

headline: Brooklyn Neighborhood Gets an ‘I Know You!’ Moment
text: Bedford Avenue, the main artery of Northside Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is lined with artisanal restaurants, crowded bars and, on any given Saturday night, a multitude of drunken people. While it is unarguably a destination for revelry, it is not typically known as a celebrity refuge.

headline: F.D.A. Staff Raises Concerns About Arthritis Drug
text: Federal regulators said Monday that an experimental pill being developed by Pfizer to treat rheumatoid arthritis raised “serious safety concerns” and was linked to a higher risk for lymphoma, a form of cancer, and serious infections.

headline: Eleven Madison Park Chef Leads Beard Award Winners
text: Daniel Humm, the chef and an owner of Eleven Madison Park and NoMad, was named Outstanding Chef for 2012 on Monday night by the James Beard Foundation at its annual awards ceremony. The title, and its accompanying medal, were handed to him after chefs, restaurateurs and others trooped onstage at Avery Fisher Hall for hours to receive their laurels at the ritual — which is sort of like the Oscars without the dance numbers.

headline: Getting Lessons on Water by Designing a Playground
text: The sixth graders at Stephen A. Halsey Junior High School 157 in Queens have a tough assignment before them: design a new playground that will transform a sea of black asphalt at their school into a recreational oasis — and, while they are at it, help clean up New York City’s waterways.

headline: Bidders Compete to Run Trade Center Observatory, 1,200 Feet Up
text: Seven companies submitted bids Monday afternoon to operate what will be New York City’s highest and largest observatory, at 1 World Trade Center, according to real estate executives.

headline: As Car Owners Downsize, the Market Is Strong for Their Used S.U.V.’s
text: Car dealerships have many customers like David King, who traded in his 2007 Chevrolet Tahoe in late April because filling its 26-gallon tank with $4 gasoline had become so expensive. He now drives a Chevrolet Volt 25 miles each way to work, where he can charge the plug-in hybrid so it rarely uses any gas.

headline: A Match Oh So Perfectly Mismatched
text: Ah, spring, when even a misanthrope’s fancy turns to thoughts of love, or at least the vicarious experience of it. Seriously, don’t you feel in the mood for a romantic comedy right about now — one that isn’t too sappy on the one hand, or too snarky on the other?

headline: Neato
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Is it a sign of the upcoming apocalypse if the co-Queen of Mondays (the other being Andrea Carla Michaels) is published on a Tuesday?

headline: Rays’ Joe Maddon: The King of Shifts
text: Yankees outfielder Nick Swisher likes to call Tampa Bay Rays Manager Joe Maddon “the mad scientist,” and with good reason. When the two teams met, in St. Petersburg, Fla., on the opening weekend of the regular season, the Rays’ fielders moved to the left and to the right and straight into the Yankees’ heads.

headline: Mr. Biden’s Moment of Truth
text: Every so often, candidates running for high office say what they really think about an important issue. It’s virtually always a problem, especially if that candidate is a vice president and what he thinks differs from his president.

headline: Exit Nicolas Sarkozy
text: There are several reasons Nicolas Sarkozy, the president of France, will soon be vacating the Élysée Palace. His colorful lifestyle cost him votes on the right, and his pandering to the immigrant bashers cost him votes on the left. But the overwhelming reason for his loss in Sunday’s election was voters’ resentment at the painful, counterproductive austerity policies crafted by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and warmly endorsed by Mr. Sarkozy as the antidote to Europe’s financial crises.

headline: Monitoring Care for the Disabled
text: The stories of abuse, suffering and unexplained deaths among those sent to homes for the disabled in New York State are horrifying. A worker sits on an autistic boy and crushes him to death. Another worker sexually abuses a 54-year-old disabled woman. A quadriplegic drowns as an aide leaves him in a tub of water.

headline: Bank of America Starts Mortgage Reduction Effort
text: Bank of America has started sending letters to thousands of homeowners in the United States, offering to forgive a portion of the principal balance on their mortgages by an average of $150,000 each.

headline: What Is Wrong at Florida A&M?
text: Criminal charges have finally been filed against 13 people allegedly involved in the beating death of a Florida A&M band member. Even if those who caused Robert Champion’s death are sent to jail for six years — the maximum under Florida’s felony hazing law — schools, law enforcement and civic organizations will all have to work to change the brutal culture of hazing that is ingrained in marching bands at some historically black colleges.

headline: No Clear Winner in Greece
text: New elections will be called in Greece if no party can form a coalition.

headline: After Elections, Europe Focuses on Growth
text: BERLIN — In the volatile aftermath of raucous elections, which nearly destroyed the political establishment in Greece and ended 17 years of conservative reign in France, the emphasis across Europe, even in the austerity heartland of Germany, has shifted to the very real problem of growth for the stagnant Continent.

headline: An Old Texas Tale Retold: the Farmer vs. the Oil Company
text: SUMNER, Tex. — When the TransCanada men first came, Julia Trigg Crawford said, they were polite. They offered money. Seven thousand dollars to let the Keystone XL pipeline cross her family’s 600-acre farm on its way from the Alberta tar sands to the refineries on the Gulf Coast.

headline: For a Blunt Biden, an Uneasy Supporting Role
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama reviewed the comedy routine he was to deliver at the recent White House Correspondents’ Association dinner, one joke struck him as too hot. It suggested he might dump Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. from the ticket.

headline: Bob Stewart, Inventor of Game Shows, Is Dead at 91
text: Bob Stewart, a television producer with a penchant for transforming the seemingly mundane into blockbuster game shows like “The Price Is Right” and “To Tell the Truth,” died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Steering Murdoch in Scandal, Klein Put School Goals Aside
text: Last week, after a British parliamentary report declared that Rupert Murdoch was “not a fit person” to lead a major corporation, several senior News Corporation executives huddled in tense discussion on the eighth floor of the company’s New York headquarters.

headline: Supping and Sipping, the Memories Before the Race
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. – While I’ll Have Another’s connections reveled into early Sunday morning, others had their fill during the week at dozens of pre-Derby parties.

headline: A Met’s First Career Hit Is a Big One in the Ninth
text: PHILADELPHIA — Jordany Valdespin stood by his locker in the visitors’ clubhouse at Citizens Bank Park, cleaning shaving cream out of his ear and soaking in the beer that his teammates sprayed on him in celebration.

headline: Carl Bernadotte, Prince Whose First Loyalty Was Love, Dies at 95
text: He brought a bouquet of violets to meet her ship. She gave him a kiss.

headline: House Bill Offers Aid Cuts to Save Military Spending
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican-led House this week will lay bare the choice between social programs and Pentagon spending in an age of austerity when it takes up legislation to slice $261 billion from food stamps, Medicaid, social services and other programs for struggling Americans over the next decade to stave off more than $50 billion in military spending cuts scheduled to take effect next year.

headline: Candidate Crush Confidential
text: I have to confess I have spent the last nine months having a series of crushes on absolutely the wrong people — hypocrites, philanderers, zealots. The more inappropriate their behavior, the more I would swoon. Sure, it felt funny to say “you go, girl” when Michele Bachmann announced that she’d heard that the anti-HPV vaccination causes mental retardation. I tried to explain to my friends that Newt’s colony on the moon would make our country great again, bring down gas prices, or cure unemployment (surely a few of those nine-year-old janitors could get hired up there someday). As each candidate dropped by the wayside, I would flit capriciously to the next, hoping that this would be “the one,” a relationship that could flourish on its own terms and not be turned into roadkill by the Romney money machine.

headline: Change in Paris May Better Fit U.S. Economic Positions

headline: AMC Said to Be Talking to Chinese Buyer

headline: Leader of Israel Centrist Party Kadima Agrees to Join Netanyahu’s Coalition

headline: Rangers Stun Capitals With a Scramble and a Slap Shot

headline: Phillies’ Hamels Is Suspended for Five Games

Major League Baseball responded to Hamels’s actions — and perhaps his candid remarks, too — with a five-game suspension and an undisclosed fine Monday.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Chaos Among Closers
text: Every year, we see a 40-to-50-percent turnover rate among opening-day closers, this year that rate seems even higher. Let’s take a look around the majors at a few of these. Except where noted, all information is through Sunday.

headline: Coming to a Corner Near You
text: There’s no dearth of street style content on the Web these days. But what you don’t see much of is street fashion that captures many varied parts of New York City and the people who live here. Today we’re introducing a new video series called “Intersection: Where Culture Meets Style.” Every other Tuesday, we’ll show you the individual style of a New Yorker who we have scouted on a corner in one of the five boroughs (yes, all five). New Yorkers’ style is as diverse at the neighborhood they come from, and we want to record it.

headline: Stocks Fall on Greek Turmoil

headline: Putting the Guilt Back in Killing: Game Features Zombies With a Little Soul
text: Zombies are the new Nazis, at least when it comes to video games. The handoff couldn’t have been more straightforward. In World at War, the 2008 iteration of the wildly popular Call of Duty series, the game designers, perhaps sensing that players were tiring of the pleasures of killing the soldiers of the Third Reich, introduced a new mode: Nazi zombies. Shooting already dead members of Hitler’s army proved even more satisfying than doing the same to (digitally) living but historical Germans. Out with World War II, in with World War Z.

headline: Tale of a Spring Chicken
text: A week or so before Easter, I stopped into the Housing Works on 23rd Street to make a donation. While filling out all the forms involved, I fell in love with a slightly silly-looking papier-mâché chicken that must have been a window display in its former life. “How much is that?” I asked the cashier. “Oh,” he said, “you can’t buy that chicken. It just came in and hasn’t been priced yet.”

headline: The Nuns and the God Within
text: Along with the death of Charles Colson, the other significant religion story to break during the time I took off for book promotion was the controversy over the Vatican’s investigation into the theological drift of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious, a group that includes the leadership of the majority of America’s orders of nuns. The controversy has mostly been framed in the press as the latest round in a debate running back to the Second Vatican Council – yet another clash between “Spirit of Vatican II” American Catholics and a more conservative hierarchy in Rome, with familiar flashpoints, a familiar cast of characters, and the same basic political and theological issues at stake. And it is that, in part: If you read the Vatican “doctrinal assessment” of the LCWR, you’ll find echoes of the debates that have divided American Catholicism since the 1960s — women’s ordination, human sexuality, how great a stress to place on Catholic social teaching versus the dogmatic aspects of the faith, and the broader question of where authority ultimately resides within the church.

headline: When the Wind Whispers, Whose Name Does it Call?
text: Acciona, a big renewable energy company based in Spain, says it is naming its new 132-megawatt wind farm in Oklahoma “Big Smile.” The name is an oblique reference to an Acciona employee who died last year, the company says.

headline: On E-Books and Stephen Colbert: A Few Words With Maurice Sendak
text: In a 1993 article in The Times, Maurice Sendak, who died Tuesday morning at the age of 83, told Sarah Lyall: “Grown-ups desperately need to feel safe, and then they project onto the kids. But what none of us seem to realize is how smart kids are. They don’t like what we write for them, what we dish up for them, because it’s vapid, so they’ll go for the hard words, they’ll go for the hard concepts, they’ll go for the stuff where they can learn something, not didactic things, but passionate things.”

headline: Table Talk | Pabu in Baltimore
text: For Michael Mina, picking the partner in his first restaurant collaboration was easy. “I have been going to Hana Restaurant for many years,” says the Michelin-star chef and restaurateur. “And I have always dreamed of working with Ken Tominaga.” (Tominaga is Hana’s owner and chef.) Their first restaurant together, Pabu, opens for dinner tonight in the Four Seasons Hotel Baltimore.

text: Carol Giacomo, who covers defense policy for the editorial board, is in Afghanistan this week on a trip for journalists organized by NATO. Here’s a dispatch from her visit to the Afghan National Police Training Center.

headline: Leading Off: Hanging on a Minute
text: It is at once the beauty of sports and its agony, the tiny slivers of time that change a game, a series, a season. The Rangers have been on the agony side plenty enough, their last championship coming a full generation ago, and what they did to the Capitals Monday night in Game 5 of their second-round playoff series had been done to them only a few years back, when the Sabres snatched a lead away in the waning seconds, won in overtime and squelched a mesmerizing season.

headline: From 1926, Hakoah Vienna’s Message to the U.S.
text: For several years, top European teams have traveled to the United States for lucrative summer tours, planting the flag of soccer while also extending their “brand.” It is easy to forget, however, that it was not always so. In the 1920s soccer was a novelty to most Americans and the sight of a team completely composed of all Jewish players was more than a novelty — it was unheard of.

headline: Fashion Forward in Comfort at the Met Gala
text: After working the cocktail room at the Met gala last night, I dropped into the Temple of Dendur to see if dinner guests were comfortable in their $20,000 seats, or whatever one costs these days. I ran into Julie Gilhart, the former Barneys fashion director, who had a manicurist apply the letters AMAZON.COM to her nails. Amazon wants to play with the high-fashion people. Then Alber Elbaz of Lanvin came over and introduced his date, Emma Stone. Her red minidress looked like the rippled surface of a flowered bathing cap.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/8: Endangered Wild Horses and Upscale Camping

headline: Why, Ronald, You Haven’t Aged at All!
text: If you’re McDonald’s, one way to counter public-relations nightmares is by using some of your $2-billion-plus advertising budget to “present a greener, more healthful McDonald’s.” But all that reinvention has left at least one figure behind, suggests an article a friend showed me a few months ago: Ronald McDonald himself. Just check out the clown as he appeared in the ’60s, ’70s and ’80s. (One of the pleasures to come from reading Keith O’Brien’s article about the company in last weekend’s magazine was the inspiration to start looking up old McDonald’s commercials on YouTube.) The first one below, by the way, is Willard Scott, the first Ronald McDonald, wearing a value meal on his head in a weirdly meta 1963 ad.

headline: From a Young Fan, a Reminder of Racing’s Charms
text: At the risk of incriminating myself, I will admit that I was nearly guilty of a Kentucky sacrilege. While I typically find that there is no better place and time than the Bluegrass during Derby week, I had arrived at the precipice of becoming completely numb to the joys of America’s greatest horse race.

headline: Jungle Gym
text: In the Costa Rican jungle near the village of Cabuya — past a bridge, through a series of wooden gates and up an unmarked trail — sits a new yoga retreat, the Sanctuary at Two Rivers. Founded by the actress Perrey Reeves, who played the very yoga-fit Mrs. Ari Gold on HBO’s “Entourage,” and Jeff Gossett, a restaurateur, the solar-powered resort was built completely by hand: no bulldozers, only shovels. “When you cook with a lot of love, you taste it; when you build with a lot of love, you can feel it,” Gossett says of their decade-long project. (And when you plant with a lot of love, evidently, you can smell it: the orchids blooming right outside the showers are no accident, he adds.) Visitors can either sign up for one of the Sanctuary’s regularly scheduled packages, like the weeklong Full-Moon Retreat, or rent out the entire 40-acre property for a private yogi gathering. The “accessible, eco-conscious and peaceful” country of Costa Rica, Reeves says, was the only place where the pair considered breaking ground. “Plus, there are monkeys!”

headline: Bans on School Junk Food Pay Off in California

headline: General Hancock’s Hour
text: By early May 1862, Union general George B. McClellan finally had his heaviest siege guns aimed at the Confederate lines at Yorktown. For a month, his attempt to take Richmond, Va., the rebel capital, by way of the Virginia Peninsula had been stalled — both by his overestimation of Confederate troop strength and by the South’s extensive fortifications. At long last, however, McClellan seemed ready to blast away at the rebels.

headline: Sharks, Butterflies and Controversy: Damien Hirst at the Tate Modern
text: Few artists have stimulated more controversy in recent years than Damien Hirst. From his first exhibitions in London in the late ’80s and early ’90s, featuring, among other works, “The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living,” in which he suspended a shark in formaldehyde, and “Mother and Child Divided,” a four-part sculpture of a bisected cow and calf, he has aroused both extreme distaste and great admiration among critics and the public.

headline: The Structural Signature
text: How do you assess stories about what’s going on in the economy? You can go with your prejudices, of course. You can turn to detailed econometric evidence — although my experience is that essentially nobody, including the econometricians, is convinced by that sort of thing. But the way I usually try to do it is to ask whether the available facts fit the “signature” the story seems to imply — that is, do we see the general pattern that the argument would suggest we’d see?

headline: Mike Bibby’s Strong Suit: Experience
text: For good or ill, the Knicks’ playoff prospects are now in the hands of the 15-year veteran Mike Bibby. Playing in his 10th playoffs, Bibby, 33, who was signed to the veteran’s minimum on Dec. 11, is more than familiar with the opponent at hand. Last season, Bibby put up the worst numbers of his career for the Miami Heat, a disappointing season culminating in a 3.6 Player Efficiency Rating (PER) during last year’s run to the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Participate in a Live G+ Hangout With Ambassador Rice and Me
text: Join me in a conversation at the intersection of social media and news. I’m going to interview Susan Rice, the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, in a live Google+ Hangout on Air on May 17 at 2:30 p.m. Eastern Time. Help me put her on the spot and challenge both of us with your questions.

This recipe calls for romaine, but you can try it with whatever you have on hand, as long as it’s sturdy enough to stand up to some heat. In China, where lettuce symbolizes prosperity and wealth, a simpler dish made with the lettuce only is served at New Year’s.
