headline: Jacques Pépin: A Force in America’s Food Revolution
text: I CAME to America at the end of 1959 and started working at Le Pavillon two days later. That is where I met Craig, who came to write an article on Le Pavillon and Pierre Franey, who was the executive chef. Craig introduced me to Helen McCully, food editor of House Beautiful, and through her I met James Beard. A few months later, through Helen again, I met Julia Child, who was finishing the manuscript for “Mastering the Art of French Cooking,” and I had the opportunity to look at it.

headline: When He Dined, the Stars Came Out
text: ON May 18, 1962, readers of The New York Times woke up to learn that of all the Chinese restaurants in the city, “there is probably none with a finer kitchen” than Tien Tsin, in Harlem. The same article praised four other places to eat, including Gaston, on East 49th Street, which “may qualify as having one of the most inspired French kitchens in town,” and Marchi’s, on East 31st Street, “one of New York’s most unusual North Italian restaurants.”

headline: At East Side Community, a Stand Against Racial Profiling
text: SchoolBook holds its first teach-in Tuesday about "How to Bring Tough Conversations Into the Classroom." Meanwhile, East Side Community School on the Lower East Side figured out a way to handle an event that walked from the front page into many classrooms: the shooting death of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin in Florida. Students organized a Hoodie Day, and as one wrote for the school newspaper, The East Sider, "It was especially important for us to bring this to the students’ attention because most of us at East Side look like Trayvon.''

headline: TNT Orders Series Based on Novel by Dr. Gupta of CNN
text: The cable channel TNT said on Tuesday that it had ordered a medical drama series inspired by a corporate colleague, CNN’s chief medical correspondent, Dr. Sanjay Gupta.

headline: Bryan Miller: Accepting a Seat at an Exclusive Table of Friends
text: I CANNOT claim to have been an intimate friend of Craig Claiborne — that fraternity could fit in a roomy banquette — although over two decades of friendship I was the beneficiary of many quiet acts of kindness by this shy and complicated man. When I was a green freelance writer for The New York Times, for example, suddenly I became a candidate for a staff position. And I got it, only later to learn that Craig had pulled the strings. Astonishingly, after only nine months at the paper, I was offered the job of restaurant critic. Again, it was Craig working behind the scenes. And there were many more examples.

text: As voters across Europe call for fewer government cutbacks and more spending on public programs, investors are asking a simple question: How would it be paid for?

text: Green mole is one of the best destinations I can think of for the tough outer leaves from a head of romaine or leaf lettuce. If you don’t eat meat, you can make the mole with vegetable broth and enjoy it over rice and vegetables.

headline: Teaching a Deaf Child Her Mother’s Tongue
text: Most babies are born into the culture and community of their families. If the family is Latino or Tatar or Han Chinese, so is the baby. The baby learns the family’s language — “the mother tongue.” Culture and language are passed down from parents to child.

text: Education officials say they will not make personnel decisions at 24 schools scheduled to be closed and reopened this summer, until a court hearing next week. Unions representing the city's teachers and principals claim that the city's plan to replace staff members at the schools violates their contracts, and they are seeking a restraining order so an arbitrator can have time to rule on their complaints.

headline: Romaine and Radish Salad With Buttermilk Lemon Dressing
text: Those of you who are getting loads of lettuce in your C.S.A. boxes may be tiring of salads, but this simple combination will never get old for me. Radishes look and taste beautiful against a romaine backdrop, and the creamy dressing is especially complementary. Radishes are rich in folic acid, vitamin C and anthocyanins, phytonutrients that are believed to have antioxidant properties.

headline: Stone Links: Dissecting the Dismal Science
text: “What To Do About the Rich,” a post at the Philosopher’s Beard, offers a unique approach to the problem of the 1 percent. Capitalism is salvageable, the author argues, as long as we’re willing to consider a modest proposal: getting rid of the rich. Asserting that, because their extreme economic independence from the rest of society leads to a de facto ethical independence, “the rich don’t have the same political interests as the rest of us”, the author concludes that “no-one can be both a member of our democratic society and rich.” The solution? Once an individual reaches a certain threshold of democratically “problematic” wealth, they have a choice: give it back, for example to the charity or social program of their choice, and rejoin the rest of the broad middle class, or, leave the country, which the author points out shouldn’t be much of an issue for the extremely wealthy, who have the ability to, and often do, maintain multiple residences across the globe.

headline: F.T.C. Charges Myspace With Breaking U.S. Law in Sharing Users’ Personal Information
text: WASHINGTON — Continuing its crackdown on Internet privacy violations, the Federal Trade Commission charged Myspace on Tuesday with violating federal law by breaching its promise not to share users’ personal information, including their Web browsing habits, with advertising companies.

headline: The Continuing Reign of Wilbur Ross

text: I’m late in coming to this, but I’d be remiss not to mention a speech that John Brennan, the Obama administration’s top counterterrorism adviser, delivered on April 30 about a government program to kill suspected terrorists—including American citizens—with remote-control drones.

headline: Cartoonist Courts Ire of Kentucky Fans
text: To Joel Pett, the longtime editorial cartoonist at The Lexington Herald-Leader, the tempest currently roiling among Kentucky fans over his cartoon lampooning Coach John Calipari’s trophy case, is both expected and slightly depressing.

headline: Just a Second: Timing of Rangers’ Goal Is Revisited
text: Brad Richards’s tying goal in the final seconds of regulation against the Capitals on Monday may go down as one of the great goals in Rangers’ playoff history. But Tuesday, the history was revised — by a second.

headline: A Warm Exchange Between Obama and Cuomo
text: They shared a hug, a couple actually. And then each offered effusive praise of the other. That was the scene on Tuesday when President Obama and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo shared a stage in Albany, where they visited a new science and engineering center at the University at Albany. Mr. Obama, who doesn’t really need to campaign in New York State since he’s virtually guaranteed of winning the state in November, hailed Mr. Cuomo for his achievements. Mr. Cuomo, who has been the subject of nonstop speculation about his own presidential ambitions in 2016, praised Mr. Obama for steering the country through a financial storm. Then came more hugs. Read more on the Caucus blog.

headline: A Peek Into The Times’s Archive
text: A recent video report offered a rare glimpse into The Times’s archive of newspaper clippings and photographs. Jessica Bennett of Tumblr, working in partnership with WNYC, produced the video and an article about the trove, housed deep beneath street level in a cellar adjacent to The Times building.

headline: Upstarts Continue to Hijack Votes in Germany
text: KIEL, GERMANY — When the results in Germany’s most recent state election came down, the Pirate Party cued up what could be their new theme song: “We are the Champions” by the rock group Queen blared from the speakers as exit polls showed the young party entering the third regional legislature in three elections.

headline: Digital Notes: Royalty Service Responds to Suit by Sirius XM
text: SoundExchange, which distributes royalties for digital music, has asked a federal judge to dismiss an antitrust lawsuit filed against it by Sirius XM Radio.

headline: Baked Fish, Fez Style
text: At lunchtime by the pool at La Mamounia, the lavish hotel in Marrakesh, the buffet is global. The grilled lobsters were tempting to be sure, but a highlight was fish boldly baked Moroccan-style, with spices, herbs, tomatoes and olives. I left Morocco a few weeks ago with the recipe in my notebook and thought of it for our Greek reds. Though the wines could accept a broad range of dishes, one might detect a Greek accent in the fish dish, with its garlic, lemon, parsley, peppers, tomatoes, olives and olive oil. It’s an easy all-in-one recipe that can be served at room temperature. Double or triple it and you have the anchor for a summer party menu, even on a buffet that is less copious than the one in Marrakesh. Cool some Greek reds to pour alongside.

headline: Adventures in New Greek Reds
text: MAVROTRAGANO and mandelaria; limnio and vlahiko; and of course, agiorgtiko and xinomavro. I know: it’s all Greek. That’s what is so exciting.

headline: Visiting the Frugal Promised Land: Business Class

headline: Is Obama More Popular Than He Should Be, Revisited
text: In an earlier post, I noted that President Obama’s approval rating was higher than a model of presidential approval predicted — something that seemed to set him apart from previous presidents. In response, commenters here on FiveThirtyEight and The Monkey Cage (see also Jay Cost) noticed that, for most presidents from Dwight D. Eisenhower until Mr. Obama, the model’s predicted approval rating was consistently lower than the actual approval rating. In this post, I want to do four things:

text: Chase is the latest bank joining the hunt for lower-income customers and plans to introduce a re-loadable debit card nationwide this summer.

headline: In Stitches | Golden Hook’s Knitting Grannies
text: Nothing compares to a cold-weather accessory made by a grandmother’s loving hands, even if that grandmother isn’t yours. Such was the thinking behind Golden Hook, a boutique in Paris with a shop online that employs grannies all over the world who knit custom-made hats and scarves. The idea came to the company founder Jérémy Emsellem, 26, four years ago while he was studying semiotics at the École Supérieur de Publicité. To make some extra money, he’d been crocheting beanies for his friends when “it all got to be too much,” he says. “I asked my great-aunt for help. She said no but volunteered her friends. And that’s where it all began.” Today Emsellem and his 27-year-old business partner and brand stylist, Maia Krzisch, call on the help of nearly 40 grandmothers/nanas/nans, ages 60 to 83, to keep their business booming.

headline: The Road to Rapture, Paved With Rock

headline: Concussion Puts Thole on D.L. at Least a Week
text: PHILADELPHIA — Since he arrived in the majors with the Mets in 2002, Ty Wigginton has maintained a career as a lumbering utility man. At 230 pounds, he can also generate some steam rumbling down the base paths.

headline: At Garden’s Visitor Center, a Welcome Transparency
text: In its 102 years, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden has amassed quite a collection. There’s the rose garden, with its 1,000 varieties; the Shakespeare garden, with 80 plants mentioned in his works; and the Japanese Hill-and-Pond Garden, the oldest in any American public setting, with its pines and quince and great schools of overstuffed koi skimming the water’s surface. And of course there are the flowering cherry trees, more than 200 of them in long promenades, Brooklyn’s answer to the annual spectacle in Washington. The cherry blossoms can bring as many as 37,000 visitors to the garden on a weekend day in early spring.

headline: At Wireless Conference, Different Takes on Demand for Spectrum
text: At the CTIA Wireless conference in New Orleans on Tuesday, the president of the wireless trade group CTIA couldn’t stop talking about his industry’s need for more spectrum, the government-rationed radio waves that carry voice calls and wireless data.

headline: Canada Is Slow to Act on Emissions, Audit Warns
text: Canada will probably not meet its already-diminished greenhouse gas reduction targets, the country’s environment commissioner warned on Tuesday in a report to Parliament. The commissioner, Scott Vaughan, blamed a lack of government oversight, particularly for the oil and natural gas industry, which is Canada’s fastest growing source of greenhouse gas related emissions.

headline: Republicans Seek Independent Investigation of MF Global
text: A growing number of Republican lawmakers are pressing Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to appoint an independent counsel to investigate the collapse of MF Global and the firm’s misuse of customer money.

headline: A Writer Who Defied Categorization
text: A handful of writers — Shakespeare, Dickens, Kafka — have had the posthumous good fortune to become adjectives. W. G. Sebald, the German-born author of “The Emigrants,” “Austerlitz” and “The Rings of Saturn,” who died in a car accident in 2001 at 57, had a sensibility sufficiently distinctive to warrant such immortality. The only problem — or, rather, the characteristic paradox — is that “Sebaldian” would have to mean something like “systematically resistant to classification.” Was he a novelist? A memoirist? A historian? A travel writer?

headline: RIM Looks to Sony and LightSquared for Talent
text: The Canadian smartphone maker Research In Motion has again reached out to two troubled companies to find executive talent as it prepares to introduce a new series of phones that it hopes will reverse its rapidly declining market share.

headline: Dreading Visits From Friendly Neighbors
text: You can see how “Protected” would work well at the New York International Fringe Festival, where it had its start. There’s this comically nervous guy, afraid of his own shadow (for good reason — he is brand-new in the witness protection program), dealing with his next-to-worst nightmare: a series of odd characters turning up, in rapid succession, at his front door. And he hasn’t even finished installing the new locks.

headline: Oracle’s Fight for the Future
text: The continuing lawsuit between Oracle and Google has raised a lot of thorny questions about patent violations, copyright violations and what constitutes a fair use of software. One other large question is not in the lawsuit itself: Why did Oracle bring this lawsuit in the first place?

headline: Original Review: ‘Gentlemen Prefer Blondes’
text: Brooks Atkinson’s original 1949 review of the Broadway musical.

headline: An Actor’s Best Friend: A Gem of a Role (or 2)
text: The pressure of expectations and performers past loom large as Megan Hilty, a star of NBC’s Broadway-themed series “Smash,” tries out a breezy comic line on the City Center stage during a recent rehearsal for “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,” the final show in this year’s Encores! series of musical revivals.

headline: Obama, Biden and Same-Sex Marriage

headline: Five Things I Learned from Reading Every Last Word of House Beautiful
text: Before diving into the May issue of House Beautiful to learn some things, I learned some things about House Beautiful. It’s 116 years old! (It’s twins with The New York Times Magazine, which also started in 1896.) That makes it the oldest shelter magazine currently being published in the U.S. Originally it was for “the young practical homemaker,” but its audience seems to have changed since then. Presumably it’s doing well, since there are a whole lot of ads and editorial content before the Editor’s Note appears on Page 73.

headline: Alcohol and the Reservation: Anheuser-Busch’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Compatriots in Geekery Recover From the Past
text: There are many games in “You Are in an Open Field” at the Here Arts Center: 1980s-style video games; role-playing games; and “nerdcore” hip-hop, almost resembling a rhyming game. Ostensibly a comic narrative about transcending childhood trauma, this stew, from the New York Neo-Futurists troupe, is really about nostalgia — for Dungeons & Dragons, for innocent rap, for Space Invaders.

headline: Black Women’s Weight
text: To the Editor:

headline: Green Mountain Replaces Chairman After Margin Call
text: Margin calls can be merciless, as the founder of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters has now found out.

headline: Catalog of Brooklyn Heroes, Helping Some to Freedom
text: “Color Between the Lines” strives to document many of the forgotten abolitionist heroes of Brooklyn, with an emphasis on “many.”

headline: Mitt Romney Bails on the Truth
text: Mitt Romney’s claim that his ideas contributed to the revival of the auto industry is preposterous and easy enough to knock down. It’s exhausting, however, to refute each and every laughable distortion or outright untruth that he and his campaign issue virtually every day.

headline: As Elite Universities Embrace Online Learning
text: To the Editor:

headline: Confronting Evil: 3 Generations Gripped by the Holocaust
text: In “Eavesdropping on Dreams,” a premiere by the Barefoot Theater Company at the Cherry Lane Theater, three generations of women — an Auschwitz survivor named Rosa; her daughter, Renee; and granddaughter, Shaina — alternately deny and confront their horrifying past. The backdrop of most of their memories and nightmares is the Lodz ghetto, which outlasted all of Poland’s other Jewish ghettos by becoming an industrial complex for the Nazi army. Mordechai Chaim Rumkowski, the Nazi-appointed, dictatorial Jewish leader of the ghetto, plays a prominent role in the family history as well.

headline: The Masters of Bons Mots Are Alive and Thriving on Broadway
text: Americans expect politicians to be scripted on that great, unbounded stage that is public life. (The dangers of not being so have been confirmed in recent months by Mitt Romney’s occasional moments of spontaneity.) But wouldn’t life be more entertaining — not to mention more euphonious — if someone like Gore Vidal were writing their dialogue?

headline: CornellNYC Chooses Its Architect
text: After a competition that included some of the world’s most prominent architects, Thom Mayne of the firm Morphosis has been selected to design the first academic building for Cornell University’s high-tech graduate school campus on Roosevelt Island in New York City.

headline: Fire Dept. Doubles Minority and Female Applicants
text: For the past two years, Fire Department recruiters have complied aggressively with a court-mandated effort to diversify the department by increasing the number of minority applicants.

headline: ‘How to Succeed’ Revival to Close
text: The suits at the World Wide Wicket Company are closing up shop. The Broadway revival of Frank Loesser’s 1961 musical “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” will close after its performance on Sunday, May 20, the show’s producers announced on Tuesday. It will have played 30 previews and 473 regular performances at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

headline: Beastie Boys Face New Suit Over Sampling
text: Since Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys died on Friday, a great deal of attention has been paid to the group’s innovative use of sampling, as well as to the legal issues that have surrounded sampling for decades.

headline: 606 R&D
text: 606 Vanderbilt Avenue (between St. Marks Avenue and Prospect Place), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; (718) 230-0125; 606vanderbiltbklyn.com.

headline: The Dispute Over a Persian Gulf Island

headline: Slide Show: 606 R&D
text: When Ilene Rosen was in charge of the savory food at City Bakery, her roasted cauliflower, vegetarian banh mi and grilled tofu with chili sauce were persuasive arguments for a vegan diet. Little did I know that she had dark pleasures up her sleeve, like a sandwich of thick Benton’s bacon, drained Gold’s horseradish and buttered sourdough toast. At her new place, 606 R&D, the small kitchen includes both a rotisserie (for exemplary roast chicken) and a Donut Robot, financed through Kickstarter, that churns out fresh cake doughnuts throughout the day. And although she wasn’t in charge of pastry at City Bakery, she must have picked up a tip or two from the master baker Maury Rubin over 15 years: the pie crusts at the new place are extraordinary.

headline: Just Put In the Work
text: The problem with having goals is that they can zap your motivation as easily as they can feed it.

headline: N.F.L. Players Live Longer Than Other Men, Study Says
text: The N.F.L. is making some of its former players aware of a study that found that they are likely to live longer than men in the general population. The study was commissioned by the players union and was sent by the league Tuesday to men who played in the N.F.L. before 1993.

headline: Wikipedia Kills Page Linking Obama Slogan to Socialist Movement
text: The effort to get Wikipedia to include articles on the socialist roots of the Obama-Biden campaign’s slogan, “Forward,” ended in failure on Tuesday.

text: 7:50 p.m. | Updated  Richard G. Lugar, a six-term Republican senator from Indiana, lost his bid to stay in office after his Tea Party-backed rival questioned his conservative credentials and accused Mr. Lugar of losing touch with Indiana and its voters.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,947 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: The Methods of Margolis
text: Jim Margolis and his team at GMMB – one of the lead media firms for the Obama campaign – has helped craft, hone and sell President Obama’s message since 2007. But Mr. Margolis’s touch and style can be found on many other campaigns, dating back to Bill Clinton’s 1992 presidential bid.

text: WASHINGTON — Forget hope and change.

text: Jeremy Peters Reports

text: Mr. Kleinberg, 55, is the president and a partner of the design firm MKDA, along with his brother, Jeffrey, and his father, Milo, who founded the firm in 1959.

headline: Should U.S. Troops Fight the War on Drugs?
text: Should the military be involved in the war on drugs and does military involvement in poor  countries with weak governments destablize them?

headline: The Twitter Hack Attack That Wasn’t
text: Hackers claiming to be part of the Anonymous group released what at first glance appeared to be usernames and passwords for 55,000 hacked Twitter accounts on Pastebin on Tuesday. But a closer look revealed that nearly half those accounts were duplicates and that the vast majority belonged to accounts that had been suspended by Twitter in the past.

headline: Senate Inquiry Into Painkiller Makers’ Ties
text: Two senior senators said on Tuesday that they had opened an investigation into financial ties between producers of prescription painkillers and pain experts, patient advocacy groups and organizations that set guidelines on how doctors use the drugs.

headline: Baltimore Police Scandal Spotlights Leader’s Fight to Root Out Corruption
text: BALTIMORE — Tucked behind a liquor store, opposite a flooring company, Majestic Body Shop was an unremarkable sight amid a blur of commercial properties just east of the city limits. But the police cars that always seemed to be parked at the repair shop caught the eyes of passing drivers. The F.B.I. noticed as well — agents were videotaping Majestic and tapping its phone.

headline: Accuracy of Appraisals Is Spotty, Study Says
text: In the recent economic crisis, commercial landlords and lenders discovered myriad ways to find themselves on the brink of financial disaster. Excessive purchase prices — many based on faulty property appraisals — were a major factor, specialists say.

headline: Indians Host Clinton While Also Wooing Iran
text: NEW DELHI — Admittedly, the timing was awkward. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in New Delhi this week after declaring that India should reduce imports of Iranian oil and comply with Western sanctions. Yet across town, India and Iran were trying to figure out ways to do business together.

headline: Understanding Children, Yet Wanting Them to Grow Up a Bit
text: The cliché about children’s book writers is that they’re sensitive, mewling types — wearers of cardigans, dispensing uplift as if it were Purell hand sanitizer.

headline: From Beijing With Love
text: Washington

headline: Liberal Donors’ Plan Worries Top Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Senior leaders of the Democratic Party expressed alarm on Tuesday that a $100 million plan by liberal donors to increase voter turnout would duplicate a similar effort by President Obama’s campaign and squander a chance to fend off an advertising onslaught from Republican groups.

headline: Keeping the Internet Neutral
text: Imagine a network of private highways that reserved a special lane for Fords to zip through, unencumbered by all the other brands of cars trundling along the clogged, shared lanes. Think of the prices Ford could charge. Think of what would happen to innovation when building the best car mattered less than cutting a deal with the highway’s owners.

headline: A Blossom That Mom Can Sip
text: Lillet, the elegant wine-based aperitif made in southwest France for the last 140 years, is best known in its original pale version: white wine flavored with citrus and a touch of quinine. Lillet Blanc was joined by red Lillet Rouge in 1962. This spring the drink has blossomed in pink. Lillet Rosé is essentially the blanc with some added red fruit liqueurs and a little of the Rouge for color — a medley that is refreshing, a little fruity and excellent for a Mother’s Day toast. But it is also so easy on the palate that the label should warn that, at 34 proof, it not be mistaken for rosé wine. Serving it on ice dilutes the alcohol.

headline: For Connecticut Governor, a Less-Willing Legislature
text: HARTFORD — In the second hectic and contentious year of Dannel P. Malloy’s tenure as governor, Connecticut lawmakers will race the clock on Wednesday to conclude a legislative session characterized by efforts to bridge an unexpected budget deficit, pass Democratic social legislation and address the nation’s largest achievement gap between schools in rich and poor neighborhoods.

text: Opening

headline: Cheese With a Brooklyn Point of View
text: Washed-rind cheeses (basted with brine, spirits or other liquid as they mature) are a fairly recent addition to the repertories of artisanal cheesemakers in the United States. These cheeses tend to be funkier and stinkier than other types, and are often high on the lists of connoisseurs.

headline: Scars From Knee Surgery Fade, but There’s Pain in Every Step
text: Greenburgh, N.Y.

headline: Head of Asia Society Is Moving On
text: After 22 years with the Asia Society, Vishakha N. Desai, 63, will step down as president and chief executive in September, the society is to announce on Wednesday. Ms. Desai will join the Guggenheim Foundation as a senior adviser for global policy and programs, a new consulting position. She is also talking with several universities to develop an initiative focusing on the intersection of culture and international relations. “The time is right,” Ms. Desai said in an interview, adding that she had overseen the development of two new multimillion-dollar buildings, one in Hong Kong and another in Houston. During her tenure the Asia Society also expanded its New York headquarters and established new offices in India and South Korea. “It’s more about changing the direction of my life,” Ms. Desai said.

headline: Head of Asia Society Will Step Down After 22 Years
text: After 22 years with  the Asia Society, Vishakha N. Desai will step down as president and chief executive in September, the society is to announce Wednesday. Ms. Desai will join the Guggenheim Foundation as a senior adviser for global policy and programs, a new consulting position. She is also talking with several universities to develop an initiative focusing on the intersection of culture and international relations.

headline: Young Obama’s Poetic Politics
text: FEW people expect to see their undergraduate musings about modern poetry splashed across the pages of Vanity Fair for millions to read. But then, few people emerge from their college years to become president of the United States. So President Obama couldn’t have been too surprised to see the new issue of that magazine carrying an excerpt from the journalist David Maraniss’s forthcoming biography, “Barack Obama: The Story,” which featured a letter that Mr. Obama wrote to his college girlfriend in the 1980s, discussing the worldview of T. S. Eliot’s poetry and prose.

headline: Clear Hair Products Enter a Cluttered Market
text: WHITE RAIN. Halo. Breck. Drene. Prell. Agree. Hälsa. Lustre-Creme. Gee, Your Hair Smells Terrific. Vidal Sassoon. Flex. There are enough discontinued, forgotten, moribund or also-ran hair-care brands to make marketers want to, well, pull out their hair.

headline: The Ecotopiast Who Glimpsed the Future
text: Ernest Callenbach died a few weeks ago, and I felt a tinge of sadness. I first read his semi-utopian novel “Ecotopia” just after it appeared in 1975, when I was living in Somerville, Mass., and working as a cab driver and “editor” of an erratically appearing newspaper. The early- to mid- ’70s, as frivolous and lush as they might appear in hindsight — what with “free love,” cool drugs, cheap living and all — were in some ways not much different from now. We had a pragmatic president

headline: Is Plant Liberation on the Menu?
text: I would like to thank the many readers who took the time to respond to my previous post for The Stone, “If Peas Can Talk, Should We Eat Them?” Among the approximately 350 comments were several who opposed or misread the argument underlying the piece: that plants have a more complex existence than most people believe, and that that fact should move us to reconsider our ethical approach to eating them. I’d like to address some of those misreadings and objections.

headline: Many Pursuits, but Bipartisanship Isn’t One of Them
text: The man who deposed the Republican foreign policy conscience of the Senate is a 60-year-old homebody and former geologist who loves riding motorcycles, running marathons and thumbing through history books in bed. He is best known in political circles for trying — unsuccessfully — to block the auto bailout that saved thousands of jobs in Indiana, the state he seeks to represent in Congress.

headline: Yahoo Tries to Address Error on Chief’s Degree
text: Yahoo sought to contain the turmoil surrounding its chief executive’s embellished academic record on Tuesday, as the director who led the search for the executive said that she would not stand for re-election to the board.

headline: Jobs@Arabia.com
text: Amman, Jordan

headline: Reversing Years of Neglect on a Hill Above Nashville
text: NASHVILLE —  On a bluff overlooking the Cumberland River, the odd collection of trolley barns and old hospital buildings here known as Rolling Mill Hill has been in some stage of redevelopment for the last 14 years.

headline: A Hill With a View of Nashville
text: A 34-acre site overlooking the Cumberland River and Nashville has been in redevelopment for more than a decade. Now its revival is starting to make real progress.

headline: Campaigning Beyond Inspiration
text: President Obama could not single-handedly transform American politics. Many of his young 2008 supporters learned that to their disillusionment, and as he begins his re-election campaign, the president himself seems a more somber candidate who learned by trial the limits to inspirational change. In his first formal campaign speech, delivered on Saturday, Mr. Obama’s view of what might happen with a robust use of government power was intertwined with the shadow of a Republican Party that has fought every attempt to use that power.

headline: What Passed in Hartford
text: Notable measures taken up or approved during Connecticut’s legislative session, which is to end on Wednesday.

headline: Delaying Justice at Guantánamo
text: Military commission hearings began last week against five men held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for conspiring in the 9/11 attacks. Other detainees, however, are held without charges and their legal right to challenge their detention remains blocked.

headline: How Much for That Coffee?
text: Imagine that you have exhausted your checking account at the mall when you swing by the coffee shop for some reviving caffeine. Would you prefer the bank to: a) decline the purchase on your debit card so that you can pay cash, or b) pay for that coffee and then slam you with a $35 overdraft penalty. We know what we would answer.

headline: Losing the Middle
text: The majority of senators retiring or facing tough re-elections this year were ranked in the middle of the Senate’s ideological spectrum in 2011.

headline: Get Your Motor Running
text: In Rwanda, where horses are few and motorcycles are abundant, a variation of polo known as moto-polo has sprung up, becoming a popular sport to watch and play among locals and foreigners.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Is Backing a Rangel Challenger
text: State Senator Adriano Espaillat’s campaign to unseat Representative Charles B. Rangel received a boost on Tuesday from an unexpected quarter, when a “super PAC” based in Texas announced that it planned to support Mr. Espaillat against Mr. Rangel.

headline: Public Advocate to Call for Audit of Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
text: As the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practice draws increasing criticism from black and Latino New Yorkers, the city’s public advocate, Bill de Blasio, said he would call on the mayor to force a reduction of the controversial practice.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Library for the Future
text: For over a century, New York’s majestic central library on Fifth Avenue has drawn grateful scholars and dazzled tourists. Faced with financial uncertainties and a pressing need to modernize, the president of the New York Public Library system, Anthony Marx, has put forward a $300 million proposal to renovate the flagship building. The plans, which are still evolving, sound both necessary and forward-thinking in this digital era. But the library’s overseers have to take care that they preserve the essence of this cultural landmark.

headline: A Lot Like Polo, Only Faster and With Beer
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — Game day. Sam Dargan, 29, a four-year veteran of the nascent sport known as moto-polo, awoke early — or relatively early, for a Saturday in East Africa — and began the traditional routine.

headline: After Guilty Plea, Pimp Fires His Lawyer at Sentencing
text: Jason Itzler arrived in court on Tuesday to be formally sentenced to prison, a solemn reckoning for most criminal defendants. But for the self-proclaimed King of All Pimps, the day played out like one more act in a never-ending immorality play.

headline: Désamour and Amour
text: PARIS

headline: Graphic: Silicon Valley’s Banker
text: Michael Grimes of Morgan Stanley has helped lead 28 technology initial public offerings over the last year, including some of the hottest new Internet companies. Now, he is readying for his biggest debut yet: Facebook.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Grimes Is Where Money and Tech Meet
text: Silicon Valley doesn’t have much love for Wall Street, perceiving buttoned-up financiers as fee-obsessed number crunchers who don’t really understand technology.

headline: Frantic Finish
text: Brad Richards’s goal with 7.6 seconds left in regulation of Monday’s Game 5 win over the Washington Capitals was the latest score to tie a playoff game in Rangers history.

headline: Gay on TV: It’s All in the Family
text: On “Glee” this spring, a transgender character named Unique is competing in a sing-off. On “Grey’s Anatomy,” Arizona and Callie are adjusting to married life, having been pronounced “wife and wife” last year.

headline: Woods Facing Criticism and Tough Course at the Players
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Tiger Woods’s past two trips to the Players Championship ended with him withdrawing from the PGA Tour’s signature tournament because of injuries.

headline: Moderate Republicans Fall Away in the Senate
text: I wrote earlier about the electoral implications of the defeat of longtime Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana in the Republican primary on Tuesday. It should make the seat much more competitive and will increase Democrats’ odds of retaining the Senate, although the nominee that Republicans chose instead, Richard E. Mourdock, the state treasurer, is perhaps a very slight favorite over the Democratic nominee Joe Donnelly.

headline: Board Rejects Sheik Seeking Two of Heiress’s Homes
text: Three rambling apartments at 907 Fifth Avenue were put up for sale this year by the estate of Huguette Clark, a copper heiress known for her reclusiveness and her multimillion-dollar doll collection. Just two of these apartments take up the entire eighth floor of the building, with more than 20 rooms, a 100-foot expanse overlooking Central Park and a combined asking price of $31 million.

headline: An Effort to Bury a Throwaway Culture One Repair at a Time
text: AMSTERDAM — An unemployed man, a retired pharmacist and an upholsterer took their stations, behind tables covered in red gingham. Screwdrivers and sewing machines stood at the ready. Coffee, tea and cookies circulated. Hilij Held, a neighbor, wheeled in a zebra-striped suitcase and extracted a well-used iron. “It doesn’t work anymore,” she said. “No steam.”

headline: Puzzle Three From the Brown University Puzzle Tournament
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — We’ve been through the first two puzzles from the Brown University Puzzle Club’s tournament, and today we get to try our writing implements at number three, by Eshan Mitra.

headline: Law School Plans to Offer Web Courses for Master’s
text: The law school of Washington University announced Tuesday that it would offer, entirely online, a master’s degree in United States law intended for lawyers practicing overseas, in partnership with 2tor, an education technology company.

headline: $2 Million Penalty for Sexually Harassing West Side Tenants
text: Three men who operated Upper West Side apartment buildings, one of them a building superintendent who was also a convicted sex offender, have agreed to pay more than $2 million in fines to tenants who were sexually harassed by the superintendent, the United States attorney’s office said Tuesday.

headline: A More Expensive Internet
text: High prices can be a major obstacle for low-income Americans who want to access the Internet.

headline: Psychiatry Manual Drafters Back Down on Diagnoses
text: In a rare step, doctors on a panel revising psychiatry’s influential diagnostic manual have backed away from two controversial proposals that would have expanded the number of people identified as having psychotic or depressive disorders.

headline: An Aging Savior Isn’t What the Yanks Need
text: For Brian Cashman, the call that changed the season came last Thursday while he was eating dinner with his children at a Chipotle restaurant in Darien, Conn. The Yankees’ media relations director, Jason Zillo, told Cashman that Mariano Rivera had just been carted off the field at Kansas City.

headline: E.P.A. Chemist Who Warned of Ground Zero Dust Is Reinstated
text: A senior Environmental Protection Agency chemist who argued that she was removed from her job in retaliation for accusing the agency of underestimating the toxicity of dust at ground zero has been reinstated with back pay by an administrative board.

headline: Seeing Source of Electricity in Water Pipes
text: The water that comes out of taps in New York City runs downhill 125 miles from the Catskill Mountains, every last drop the product of 19th-century genius and scheming that made the modern metropolis possible.

headline: Four Homers and 18 Total Bases, Again
text: Four home runs, a double and 18 total bases? While a remarkable game for Josh Hamilton, it has been done before, and even bettered.

headline: Knicks, Trailing by 3-1, Focus on What Is, Not What Might Have Been
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Their faith restored, their lineup (mostly) intact, the Knicks boarded a flight bound for South Florida on Tuesday, to face down LeBron James and confront a haunting montage of memories:

headline: Regulator Predicts U.S. Will Soon Take Part in Chinese Inspections of Auditors
text: The chairman of the United States regulator that inspects audit firms — an agency that has been frustrated by its inability to review audits of Chinese companies that turned out to be frauds — said Tuesday that he expected that his staff would soon be able to sit in on Chinese inspections of auditors.

headline: Elite Kentucky Recruit Attracts N.C.A.A. Inquiry
text: EVERETT, Mass. — The N.C.A.A. sent two members of its enforcement staff to Massachusetts this week to inquire about Nerlens Noel, who is the country’s top basketball recruit and has committed to play at Kentucky.

headline: Avoiding a ‘Prescribed Version’ of China
text: When the photographer Rian Dundon went to China, he was intent on making photographs that avoided the usual visual tropes and clichés. The color red, for example. Huge crowds. Grinding poverty set against a backdrop of soaring office towers.

headline: German Patience With Greece on the Euro Wears Thin
text: BERLIN — Just weeks ago, the idea that Greece would leave the euro zone was almost unthinkable. Now, with Greece’s newly empowered political parties refusing to abide by the terms of the country’s international loan agreement and Europe’s leaders talking tough, that outcome is looking increasingly likely.

headline: Devils Rally to Eliminate Flyers
text: PHILADELPHIA — Two lines formed on the ice for handshakes at 10:06 p.m. Tuesday, and the Devils and the Philadelphia Flyers wished each other well. A five-game series seemed like a smart prediction before it began — but there had been a stunning twist. The Devils won.

headline: Digby Wolfe, ‘Laugh-In’ Writer, Dies at 82
text: Digby Wolfe, a writer and actor whose acerbic wit, absurdist sensibility and political edge helped shape “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In,” the zany collage of televised comedy that captured the tumultuousness of the 1960s, died on May 2 in Albuquerque. He was 82.

headline: Roman Totenberg, Violinist and Teacher, Dies at 101
text: Roman Totenberg, a Polish-born violin prodigy who came of age in the era of expressive players like Fritz Kreisler and Jascha Heifetz, shared their virtuosity and influenced generations of musicians as a teacher, died on Tuesday at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 101.

headline: Montclair Rejects Candidate Seeking to Reduce Spending
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Voters in this historically liberal town rejected on Tuesday a mayoral candidate who had campaigned on a platform of reducing spending and debt and freezing taxes.

headline: Record Sales for a Rothko and Other Art at Christie’s
text: A dreamy canvas of three colors — Mark Rothko’s “Orange, Red, Yellow,” from 1961 — shattered all auction records for contemporary art at Christie’s on Tuesday evening, selling for nearly $87 million. It was a stunning moment in an auction that itself brought in the highest total ever in the postwar and contemporary category.

headline: Heir to Rivera Hangs on to Pass His First Test
text: For more than a decade, the fiery guitar licks and pounding drums of Metallica’s “Enter Sandman” were synonymous with winning in the ears of Yankees fans. But on Tuesday night, that heavy metal anthem was replaced in the ninth inning by the Southern finger pickings of “Sweet Home Alabama,” the Lynyrd Skynyrd classic that signified a changing of the guard, for at least this year.

headline: Obama’s Marriage Maneuvers
text: 5:47 p.m. | Update Visit my blog for an update to this column written after President Obama’s statements about same-sex marriage today.

headline: ‘The Voice’ Crowns a Winner: Jermaine Paul
text: Score one for Team Blake. After Monday night’s round of live performances and (brief) set-tos, “The Voice” wound up its second season on Tuesday with a new champion: Jermaine Paul, from the team coached by Blake Shelton. Take a look at one of the performances that put Mr. Paul, a former backup singer for Alicia Keys and Mary J. Blige, over the top:

headline: A Perfect Game and Now a 4-Homer Game
text: We have not even finished the second week of May, and already this is a baseball season like no other. For the first time in history, the most precious achievements for a pitcher and a hitter have occurred in the same season.

headline: Mets Turn Tables and Take Advantage of the Phillies’ Beleaguered Bullpen
text: PHILADELPHIA — The flags in center field at Citizens Bank Park note that the Phillies are the five-time defending National League East champions, with a set of starting arms unequaled in baseball, on display in a ballpark that has sold out 216 consecutive games.

headline: Celebrate Brooklyn Announces Its Summer Lineup
text: Celebrate Brooklyn!, the Prospect Park summer festival featuring an international roster of artists, will begin on June 5 with a concert by Jimmy Cliff and end on Aug. 11 with a concert with Lyle Lovett and Aoife O’Donovan, the producer BRIC Arts Media Brooklyn announced on Wednesday. Twenty-five of the 32 shows, all at the Prospect Park Bandshell, are free, with a suggested $3 contribution at the gate.

headline: Where Manufacturing Is Gaining
text: After hemorrhaging jobs during the recession – and over the last decade, for that matter – manufacturing has been one of the few bright spots of the recovery, restoring 489,000 jobs since the beginning of 2010.

headline: How Working the Muscles May Boost Brainpower
text: Upending the cliché of muscleheads, scientists at the Laboratory of Neuroscience at the National Institute on Aging recently set out to examine whether changes in muscles prompted by exercise might subsequently affect and improve the brain’s ability to think.

headline: Word of the Day | runic
text: runic •\ˈrü-nik\• adjective

headline: Would-Be Devil Has Become a Pivotal Ranger
text: Brad Richards’s last-gasp goal in regulation, Marc Staal’s overtime slap shot, Henrik Lundqvist’s third-period save on a breakaway that tipped the crossbar. Those were the indelible images from one of the most thrilling victories in Rangers history, a 3-2 triumph over the Washington Capitals in Game 5 on Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Slow Pace of Clemens Case Is Boring Jurors, Judge Says
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge presiding over the Roger Clemens perjury trial gave prosecutors and defense lawyers a stern talking-to on Tuesday because the proceedings — now in their fourth week — are plodding along so slowly that the jurors are losing interest.

headline: Ukraine: Boycott Derails Meeting
text: The Foreign Ministry announced Tuesday that it would postpone a summit meeting of Central and Eastern European countries because many leaders planned to boycott it to protest the treatment of Yulia V. Tymoshenko, an opposition leader who has been imprisoned since October. The countries planning to stay away include Germany, Italy, Austria, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, Bulgaria and the Czech Republic. Ms. Tymoshenko, a rival of President Viktor F. Yanukovich, was sentenced to seven years on charges of harming Ukraine’s interests during gas negotiations with Russia. Moscow and the West have said the prosecution was politically motivated and are pressing Mr. Yanukovich to free her. Some countries are also boycotting the Euro 2012 soccer championship, for which Ukraine is scheduled to serve as a co-host next month.

headline: China: Court to Hear Artist’s Lawsuit
text: Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist, said Tuesday that a court in Beijing had agreed to hear his lawsuit against the city’s tax authorities. Mr. Ai is suing the officials for bringing a tax case against him. Tax officials have said Mr. Ai’s company, Beijing Fake Cultural Development, owes the equivalent of $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai said he did not owe that amount and has argued that his wife, Lu Qing, is formally in charge of the company. Mr. Ai was detained for 81 days last year and has continued to mock the Chinese government and the Communist Party since his release.

headline: Indians Host Clinton While Also Wooing Iran
text: “Admittedly, the timing was awkward,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times. “Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in New Delhi this week after declaring that India should reduce imports of Iranian oil and comply with Western sanctions.” Yet across town, “India and Iran were trying to figure out ways to do business together,” Mr. Yardley writes.

headline: Short-Handed Bulls Rely on Their Defense to Stay Alive
text: CHICAGO — The Bulls may be missing their All-Star star point guard and starting center, but depleted did not mean eliminated Tuesday at the United Center.

headline: Nationals’ General Manager Disciplined for Hamels Remarks
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge presiding over the Roger Clemens perjury trial gave prosecutors and defense lawyers a stern talking to on Tuesday because the proceedings — in their fourth week now — were plodding along so slowly that the jurors were losing interest.

headline: News Quiz | May 9, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Corrections: May 9
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: China’s Expulsion of Journalist Has Parallels in Thailand
text: HONG KONG — China’s expulsion of the correspondent for Al Jazeera — a move seen as reprehensible by supporters of press freedoms and the right of dissent — has parallels in other parts of Asia.

headline: India, a Nation United….by Noodles?
text: Six nights a week after a hard day’s work, Michelle Sebastian, 29, single and a luxury hotel executive in Bangalore, returns home to a hot shower and a large bowl of noodles. She changes the vegetables each night, she switches the sauces and she varies the masala, the blend of Indian spices. But her dinnertime staple stays the same: instant noodles.

headline: Behind Twists of Diplomacy in the Case of a Chinese Dissident
text: WASHINGTON — Over two days of meetings with China’s leaders in Beijing last week, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had not uttered a word about Chen Guangcheng as her aides arranged to transfer the blind Chinese dissident from the United States Embassy to a hospital, only to have the plan unexpectedly blow up. Then, last Friday, she finally broached the subject with China’s senior foreign policy official, Dai Bingguo.

headline: Mood Upbeat on Iranian Trade Tour of India
text: It was hard not to be amused by the odd diplomatic spectacle in New Delhi this week, which saw Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton in town trying to convince India to stop importing oil from Iran – even as an Iranian trade delegation was here trying to drum up more business.

headline: Ferrari Stunt in China: Gone Awry in 60 Seconds
text: HONG KONG — Luxury cars are viewed with a special disdain in China, and a certain amount of envy, too, of course, as tangible symbols of the country’s widening gap between the rich and the not. Audi A6 sedans (in black) are known to be the choice of party and government officials, for example. Bentleys and Ferraris are also very much in vogue among China’s privileged 1 percenters.

headline: May 9, 1994 | Nelson Mandela Chosen South Africa’s First Black President
text: On May 9, 1994, South Africa’s newly elected Parliament chose Nelson Mandela to be the first president of the post-apartheid era.

headline: Time for Greece and the Euro to Part Ways?
text: For months, we have been asking the same questions: should Greece and the euro go their separate ways? Are there just too many hurt feelings? Was the relationship based on too many lies from the start? Despite everyone doing their best to work through the issues, are there irreconcilable differences?

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 9, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the Well blog post “Heavy Backpacks Can Spell Chronic Back Pain for Children.”

headline: A Teenager Stands Up to Doctored Fashion Magazine Photos
text: WHAT bothered Julia Bluhm about Seventeen Magazine?WHAT did she do to draw attention to the issue?

headline: ‘We Jump Over Camels’
text: After more than a year covering the Arab Spring — struggling with intransigent bureaucracies, governments hostile to journalists and people who didn’t want to be photographed — Ed Ou was relieved to encounter a subject where images came easily.

headline: In Libya, the Captors Have Become the Captive
text: One night last September, a prisoner named Naji Najjar was brought, blindfolded and handcuffed, to an abandoned military base on the outskirts of Tripoli. A group of young men in camouflage pushed him into a dimly lit interrogation room and forced him to his knees. The commander of the militia, a big man with disheveled hair and sleepy eyes, stood behind Najjar. “What do you want?” the commander said, clutching a length of industrial pipe.

headline: Do You Prefer Your Children’s Book Characters Obedient or Contrary?
text: Maurice Sendak, one of the most important children’s book artists and writers of the 20th century, died on Tuesday. Did you ever read his most famous story, “Where the Wild Things Are”? His characters were not the sanitized, moralistic personalities of much children’s writing, but were “headstrong, bossy, even obnoxious.”

headline: When Memory Sings Harmony
text: What amazing songs. That’s the lingering impression from Tuesday night’s Beacon Theater concert by the reunited Beach Boys, who until this year had not performed with Brian Wilson since 1996.

headline: Tearful Underdog Triumphs in ‘The Voice’ Finale
text: At the outset of the second season of “The Voice” Jermaine Paul was all about business. In his initial blind audition, he sang Avril Lavigne’s bratty “Complicated” with muscle and imagination, if not total grace. Two of the show’s four coaches turned their chairs to face him: Cee Lo Green, a whimsical eccentric who’s attracted to idiosyncratic vocal powerhouses, and Blake Shelton, a gentle soul who often appears to be guided by emotion and gut more than talent.

headline: ‘Even Though It Took Me All Year, I Wouldn’t Change a Thing’
text: The last week in April was a stressful one for many of us seniors. For me, it came down to a Thursday night, just a few days before May 1. My certainty in my decision had been building for a couple weeks, and as I filled out the online forms to submit a deposit and commit to my final choice, I had no doubts.

headline: Oh, Pipe Down
text: May 9 is the 43rd day of Major League Baseball’s current regular season. (Or the 36th day, if you disregard the annoying two-game set in Tokyo between the Mariners and the Athletics during spring training.) Each team has played as many as 32 games, enough to establish a few pleasant surprises in the standings (the Orioles, the Nationals) and a few striking disappointments (the Red Sox, the Brewers).

headline: The Early Word: New Day
text: In Today’s Times:• Richard G. Lugar, one of the Senate’s longest-serving members and a moderate who personified a gentler political era, was turned out of office Tuesday by Richard E. Mourdock, the Indiana state treasurer, Monica Davey reports. Mr. Mourdock’s campaign was fueled by millions of dollars from Tea Party groups that deemed Mr. Lugar too willing to compromise.

headline: Food Stamps and Unemployment Insurance
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Long View: India’s Very First Corruption Scandal
text: The political media exposé, of the sort that invariably earns the suffix “-gate” in the United States, can come in a surprising variety of shapes and sizes. The coverage of Watergate, sustained in The Washington Post over more than 300 stories, sank a presidency. In 1987, India’s own Watergate broke in The Hindu, which printed hundreds of documents in facsimile form to expose the Bofors corruption scandal, involving kickbacks received by politicians in exchange for a defense contract. On the other hand, independent India’s first momentous political scam broke in 1957 with what seems, in comparison, to be a pebble hurled at the side of an ocean liner – and yet it forced the swift resignation of a finance minister, T. T. Krishnamachari.

headline: For Union Rags, It Was Over Before It Began
text: They say a picture is worth a thousand words; these pictures tell a story of how Union Rags started poorly in this year’s Kentucky Derby.

headline: Toyota Projects Profit to Double in Fiscal Year
text: TOKYO — Toyota Motor reported another step in its uneven road to recovery Wednesday, saying that income for the fiscal year that ended in March had tumbled, but that it expected profit for the current year to more than double to ¥760 billion, helped by new models and a pickup in the global economy.

headline: Tip of the Week: Finding Facebook Photo Comments
text: Uploading albums of photos on Facebook is a convenient way to share multiple pictures of an event with friends. If the page for the photos is set to Album view, comments from friends on the entire album appear below the thumbnails, but you must click on each image to see the specific comments for that picture.

headline: Shopping for a Better World
text: To be successful in business today, a company must do more than just sell a good product.  According to a recent study (pdf), 80 percent of Americans are likely to switch brands, if comparable in price and quality, to one that supports a social cause.

headline: The Top 10 Rookie Mistakes for Entrepreneurs
text: Many people who start businesses, including me, have little or no experience and just jump in. Over the years, I have compared notes with many fellow entrepreneurs, and I have seen them make the same mistakes over and over again — I recognize them because I have made them all, too. Here is my list of the biggest rookie mistakes:

headline: A Brief Patriotic Interlude
text: How good are The Civil Wars? Watch and listen:

headline: Occupational Hazards
text: More on the structural unemployment thing. As Mike Konczal points out, there’s something clearly obsessive about the desire to tell a structural story. It’s not just that people keep coming up with new arguments after each successive argument is shot down by the data; it’s the fact that it’s the same people who keep coming up with new arguments, strongly suggesting that they really want to believe it’s structural, and won’t take no for an answer.

headline: A Structural Blast From the Past
text: Fun with structural unemployment:

headline: Glaxo to Make Hostile Bid for Human Genome Sciences
text: GlaxoSmithKline plans to take its $2.59 billion bid for Human Genome Sciences directly to shareholders this week, after being rejected by the biotechnology company last month.

headline: ‘Sissies’ and Bounties, and Kurt Warner Addresses Critics
text: LaVar Arrington, the former Redskin linebacker, continued the discussion about the potential dangers of youth football on Tuesday. Perhaps he did not elevate the discussion, but he continued it.

headline: Hong Kong Regulator Seeks Penalties for I.P.O. Fraud
text: HONG KONG — Bankers in Hong Kong, the world’s biggest market for initial public offerings, could face as much as two years in prison and fines of more than $100,000 if false or misleading information is included in the listing documents filed by companies they bring to market, according to a proposal by a Hong Kong regulator.

headline: A Conversation With: Mohamed Nasheed, Former President of the Maldives
text: Mohamed Nasheed, who was elected president of the Maldives in the country’s first democratic elections, in 2008, but who was ousted in February, visited India recently to meet with Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and other officials to express his concerns about the direction his country is taking, and to urge that India press for an early election there.

headline: Foreign Language Math Tests Had Problems, Too
text: The discredited questions just keep mounting: The Daily News reports on Wednesday that foreign language versions of the state math exams that were administered at the end of April had translation errors, and the state has said they will not grade 20 questions.

headline: Former Dresdner Bankers Win Court Battle Over Unpaid Bonuses
text: LONDON — In the battle over banker bonuses, score one for the bankers.

headline: Coalition of the Willing
text: JERUSALEM — Monday morning I was on the phone with Doron Avital, a smart if quirky Knesset back-bencher from the Kadima Party. The announcement that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud Party was forming a grand coalition with Kadima was still a day away.

headline: Opinion Report: Overdraft Fees
text: From the editorial page

headline: Daily Report: The Go-To Banker for Silicon Valley
text: Michael Grimes of Morgan Stanley, a gadget enthusiast with a computer science background, has become Silicon Valley’s go-to banker for the technology world’s initial public offerings, reports Evelyn M. Rusli in Wednesday’s New York Times. He has shepherded the initial public offerings of LinkedIn, Zynga, Groupon and Yandex. But now he is getting ready for the big one: Facebook. It is on track to be the largest Internet offering since Google’s in 2004.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Morgan Stanley, Where Money and Tech Meet  |  Silicon Valley does not have much love for Wall Street, perceiving buttoned-up financiers as fee-obsessed number crunchers who do not really understand technology.

headline: On Our Radar: A Dry Year So Far
text: A map prepared by NOAA indicates that much of the nation has gotten off to a dry start this year. [NOAA Climate Services]

headline: Strategies for Growth, Even in Down Times
text: IN the middle of 2010, Tom Sesti decided he needed to do something about the cost pressures that had been plaguing his business, Bandals. Based in Rochester, Mich., the company had introduced a product, women’s sandals with interchangeable decorative tops, soon after the economic crisis hit in 2008. Almost immediately, the five-employee company was hit with cost increases of 15 to 30 percent for manufacturing and raw materials.

headline: How to Save on Extra Cruise Fees
text: CRUISES have long been promoted as all-inclusive vacations with accommodations, meals, entertainment and transportation all rolled into one price. But the number of extra amenities passengers must pay for has been proliferating as cruise lines go beyond the usual extras (like shore excursions, cocktails and Internet access) and add increasingly elaborate offerings.

headline: Styled to a T | Julie Delpy
text: The Director

headline: Wednesday Reading: The Frugal Traveler Flies Business Class
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Continuing Leadership Deadlock in Greece as Its Lenders Watch and Wait
text: ATHENS — Greece’s political leaders failed again on Wednesday to form a government, as increasingly anxious and irritated European leaders urged the country to keep its commitments to creditors and decide whether it wanted to stay with the euro.

headline: Morning Buzz: A Call for Tougher Rape Laws
text: Good morning. Expect a day of rain, and a high of 72 degrees.

headline: Hey, Buddy. What Do You Want?
text: Dear Diary:I had a few minutes before an interview, so I sat by the steps of the library at Bryant Park. I went to make a note on my résumé pad, but had to search for a pen in my bag first.

headline: Peltz Takes a Big Stake in Ingersoll-Rand
text: Nelson Peltz, the activist investor, is going after Ingersoll-Rand.

headline: After a Record-Breaking Weekend, ‘Avengers’ Director Joss Whedon Reflects
text: When, after a film and television career of ups and downs, you go on to direct the movie that breaks the record for highest-grossing opening weekend what do you do next? If you’re Joss Whedon, the director and screenwriter whose superhero blockbuster “The Avengers” made $207.4 million in its first weekend in North America (and has so far grossed $702.1 million worldwide, according to boxofficemojo.com), you lay low for a few days, maybe catch up on some comics and then give an idiosyncratic interview-slash-self-analysis to the Web site Whedonesque.com.

headline: Image of the Day: May 9
text: Snake awareness show organized in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh.

headline: New Russian Aircraft Crashes During a Promotional Flight in Indonesia
text: MOSCOW — The wreckage of a demonstration airplane for a Russian-made passenger jet that vanished on Wednesday during a 50-minute flight over Indonesia was found there on Thursday on the side of a mountain volcano shrouded in mist.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Gay Characters Draw Little Outrage; Obama’s Mad Man
text: When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. talked about the effect “Will and Grace” had on the national debate on gay rights, he was harkening back to a time when gay, lesbian and transgender characters on network television became weapons in the culture wars. That’s no longer true, argues Brian Stelter, pointing out that gay characters and themes on shows like “Modern Family” and “Glee” don’t attract the outrage and boycott threats that were once aimed at “Will and Grace” and “Ellen.”

headline: Bed Bath & Beyond to Buy Cost Plus
text: Bed Bath & Beyond is going shopping.

headline: Prime-Time Stern
text: IF anyone has a right to feel on top of the world, it’s Howard Stern — especially inside his elegant, cumulus-high apartment on the West Side of Manhattan, dominated by a solariumlike living room with views on one side extending far up the Hudson and the other encompassing the entire bucolic breadth of Central Park.

headline: Lebanon Lens
text: In just five years, the 38-year-old Nadine Labaki has become the director laureate of her tiny, politically fragile country of Lebanon. She first came to prominence in 2007 with her debut, “Caramel,” a sleepily beguiling film about the private lives and longings of four women working in a beauty shop in Beirut, which Labaki, in the starring role, lovingly portrayed as a warmly gossipy city full of battered, Old World charm. The film refused to so much as nod at the 15-year civil war that tore the city apart. “You say Beirut and people think bombs and women crying in the street, but I wanted to show a sweet, everyday Lebanon, on a sunny day,” she says.

headline: The TSA: What Will They Think Up Next?
text: News reports on the covert agent who infiltrated Al Qaeda and foiled a plot to destroy a US-bound airliner have stressed that he recovered an “innovative” bomb, a “sophisticated,” “experimental” device with “no metal parts … and a different kind of detonator, designed to escape detection at airport security.” If recent history is any indication, that means the Transportation Security Administration is scrambling, as I type, to come up with some sort of patch.

headline: Indian Government and Vodafone Group Talk Tough
text: The British telecommunications company Vodafone Group owes the Indian government 200 billion rupees ($3.7 billion) in taxes and late fees related to its 2007 acquisition of Hutchison Essar, R.S. Gujral, India’s finance secretary, said Wednesday during an interview with NDTV. “There is no question of the government negotiating.”

headline: Protecting Killer Frogs From Killer Humans
text: Some names turn heads. Ivan the Terrible or his acolytes may have seen the need for a name that evoked shock and awe in the 16th century. Now, the Rana (Spanish for frog) Terribilis Amphibian Reserve has opened for business in Colombia, thanks to the good offices of several biodiversity organizations.

headline: AT&T and Sprint Chiefs Display a Difference in Moods
text: Differences between the chief executives of AT&T Mobility and Sprint became clear with remarks they made at the CTIA Wireless conference in New Orleans this week. One seemed to be a techno-Pollyanna, while the other was a downer in comparison.

headline: The Dream Team’s Very Bad Day
text: The video, nearly 20 years old, shows the Dream Team doing something they never did at the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona: losing. They faced a group of top college players that included Grant Hill, Bobby Hurley, Penny Hardaway and Chris Webber, who vowed: “I’m not going to be intimidated.”

headline: As Soldiers Strut and Tanks Roll, Putin Calls for Respect
text: MOSCOW — Speaking at Russia’s giant yearly parade of high-stepping cadets and heavy weaponry through Red Square, the newly inaugurated president, Vladimir V. Putin, said on Wednesday that the country had “a great moral right” to the respect of other nations, particularly on matters of global security.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Advocate: Noting that a sizable chunk of the cast of Bravo’s new food-competition show is gay and out, The Advocate stops to ask: What does it mean to be a gay chef in today’s food world? — Julia MoskinDecanter: A movie version of “The Billionaire’s Vinegar,” the 2008 book about expensive bottles of wine fraudulently said to have been owned by Jefferson, is under way, starring Brad Pitt, and produced by Will Smith. — Eric Asimov

headline: Streisand to Sing in Brooklyn
text: It’s official, after days of near-confirmations: Barbra Streisand is coming home to Brooklyn to perform at the new Barclays Center arena at Atlantic Yards in October. Barclays Center announced Wednesday morning that Ms. Streisand, 70, will take the stage on Oct. 11.

headline: A Broadway Debut in Works for Tom Hanks
text: Tom Hanks is in negotiations to make his Broadway debut next year playing the Daily News columnist Mike McAlary in a new bio-drama by Nora Ephron, Mr. Hanks’s spokeswoman confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Mort Lindsey, TV Bandleader and Accompanist to Stars, Dies at 89
text: Mort Lindsey, who led Merv Griffin’s television orchestra, accompanied Barbra Streisand on the piano in Central Park and played with Judy Garland in her celebrated comeback concert at Carnegie Hall, died on May 4 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Japan to Nationalize Fukushima Utility
text: TOKYO — Japan is ready to nationalize Tokyo Electric Power, the operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, under a 1 trillion yen ($12.5 billion) bailout plan that was approved on Wednesday.

headline: Before Primary Win, Mourdock Sought to Block Chrysler’s Bailout
text: Richard Mourdock set the political world abuzz late on Tuesday when he defeated the incumbent Senator Richard G. Lugar in Indiana’s Republican primary, reflecting the power of his conservative and Tea Party backers by ousting a fixture of the Senate.

headline: Bookshelf
text: Delightfully illustrated by the Indian artist Ram Singh Urveti, “I Saw a Peacock With a Fiery Tail” (Tara Books, $18) dusts off a 17th-century English nursery rhyme written in trick verse; this version has die-cuts on each page to reveal the poem’s hidden meanings. The formalist games continue with “Sound” (Faber & Faber, $18), by the hip-hop fanatic and Yale Law School grad T. M. Wolf, who also has degrees in intellectual history and urban planning. His dizzying interests somehow coalesce in this first novel, with the prose arranged here and there on horizontal lines, like musical notation. In “Swimming Studies” (Blue Rider Press, $30), the artist, writer and ex-competitive swimmer Leanne Shapton wades through a lifetime of aquatic souvenirs. And “Ancestral Modern” (Yale University Press, $50) is a dazzling survey of contemporary Australian artists working in the 50,000-year-old Aboriginal tradition. (The book is tied to a Seattle Art Museum exhibit that begins on May 31.)

headline: Wheelies: The Limited Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Business Day Live | May 9, 2012
text: A shake-up at Green Mountain Coffee; Toyota on the road to recovery; and how being gay on TV became uncontroversial.

headline: Step by Step
text: In Hans Christian Andersen’s classic tale, an ugly duckling transforms into a beautiful swan. But in “Ballerina Swan,” a new picture book written by the former New York City Ballet star Allegra Kent and illustrated by Emily Arnold McCully, the swan is the ugly duckling.

headline: Postal Service Holds Back on Closings
text: WASHINGTON — The United States Postal Service said Wednesday that it would keep hundreds of small post offices open by reducing business hours or offering stamps and packaging in grocery stores, whittling down its ambitious plan to streamline its services and balance its books by closing thousands of post offices.

headline: Prepared Statement of Senator Richard G. Lugar on the Concluded Indiana Senate Primary
text: The following is the text of Richard Lugar’s statement distributed shortly after his concession speech Tuesday night.

headline: Pacers Rebuild a Winner, Quietly
text: While the basketball world focuses on the plight of the injury-riddled Chicago Bulls, or the excitement of the Lakers-Nuggets series, there is another team that is advancing in the playoffs with exactly no fanfare.

headline: Koss Wi-Fi Headphones: Sound Idea, Fuzzy Execution
text: The Koss Striva Pro headphones are a great idea, but it will take some work to make them a great product.

headline: The Confusing Gay Landscape
text: A day of dissonance: on the front page of The Times today, there’s a story that asserts—with the utmost accuracy, based on my own television viewing—that networks are presenting more and more shows with prominent gay characters and prominent gay themes, to a noteworthy absence of outrage and protest. (I discussed one of these shows, ABC’s “Happy Endings,” in a blog post not long ago.)

headline: Third Point Calls for Interim C.E.O. at Yahoo
text: Daniel S. Loeb does not seem particularly moved by Yahoo’s latest efforts to contain the controversy surrounding the embellished academic record of its chief executive.

headline: Morning Walkabout – 5/9: Berlin Airport Delay and American Airlines’s Frequent, Frequent Fliers
text: Berlin Airport Delayed, Again Berlin’s new airport, originally set to open next month, is now opening in August. The delay poses a problem for Air Berlin and Lufthansa, which will have to reroute flights to two other airports that had been due to close the day before the new one was to open. (Jaunted)

headline: Kraft Tries Again With a Ritz Snack, Aiming Younger
text: Kraft Foods is reintroducing a snack product that it brought to market three years ago and calls successful. Why? Because with more “oomph” added to the marketing mix, like a social game on Facebook, it could be more popular, executives said.

headline: Swing Fever
text: Rangers slugger Josh Hamilton has collected experiences over the past year like a rolling ball of tape collects everything in its path. There was the horrifying moment last July when he tossed a ball to a fan, who fell to his death over a too-short railing trying to catch it. The World Series then delivered a crushing competitive blow as the Rangers blew an all-but-certain victory in Game 6. The offseason brought an ugly relapse into alcoholism. All of which makes Hamilton’s four-homer game on Tuesday night that much more mesmerizing because Hamilton is a living, breathing poster for the full range of human emotion. If he weren’t real, you get the feeling Maurice Sendak might have made him up. He is definitely a wild thing.

headline: Etsy Raises $40 Million for International Expansion
text: Etsy, the online marketplace for handmade and vintage goods, is getting a very non-D.I.Y. present.

headline: At Sawgrass, the 17th Hole Is on the Spot
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The island green, par-3 17th hole at T.P.C. Sawgrass might be the most recognizable hole in golf and is the face of the PGA Tour’s showcase tournament, this week’s Players Championship.

headline: A Fuel Cell for Young Engineers
text: The Salt Water Fuel Cell Monster Truck ($26, owirobots.com) is a labor-intensive snap-together model truck with an innovative DIY battery — a tiny fuel cell, the same technology that some automakers like Honda hope will provide the green future of personal transportation.

headline: Call for Legislature to Revive Colorado’s Civil Union Bill
text: DENVER — A call for a special legislative session by Gov. John W. Hickenlooper could revive a bill that would have allowed civil unions for same-sex couples in Colorado. The bill died late Tuesday night after lawmakers reached an impasse over whether it would be heard on the floor of the House of Representatives before the legislative session concluded on Wednesday.

headline: Becoming My Mom
text: Growing up, we could count on Mother’s Day to broadcast whose mother was dead or alive. As we stepped into church in our scuffed Mary Janes, we’d be greeted by ushers with an urgent whisper: “Is your mother living?” If we piped up “Yes!” we were awarded a bright pink carnation to wear all day. If we mumbled “no,” we were pinned with a white one to honor a lost mom. I used to watch the children and adults wearing those ghostly corsages and pray that day would never come for me.

headline: Dewey’s Jeffrey Kessler Heading to Winston & Strawn
text: 7:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: Nicholas Katzenbach, 90, Dies; Policy Maker at ’60s Turning Points
text: Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, who helped shape the political history of the 1960s, facing down segregationists, riding herd on historic civil rights legislation and helping to map Vietnam War strategy as a central player in both the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, died Tuesday night at his home in Skillman, N.J. He was 90.

headline: Tiny Ancient Animal Club Gains a Member: Mini-Mammoth
text: There’s a new addition to the “tiny ancient animals I’d like to have as a pet” list: a mini-mammoth that stood about three feet high. It joins Sifrhippus, the first horse, which shrank to the size of a cat as the climate warmed about 56 million years ago.

headline: For Hope Solo, a Chance to Change Direction
text: If Hope Solo has one regret about last year’s World Cup – other than not winning the final match – it was her decision to defend the penalty kicks the way she did.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Afghan Refugee Children Perish in Harsh Winter
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After a harsh winter killed children in refugee camps around the Afghan capital and brought attention to poor conditions there, a new study by a French aid agency said the disaster was more extensive than originally thought, with at least 100 young children claimed by the cold.

headline: Playing Tag With Dolphins
text: Tara Thean, a biology major at Princeton University, writes from Sarasota Bay in Florida, where she is studying signature whistle development in wild bottlenose dolphins.

headline: A Trifecta of Intolerance
text: Tuesday was pretty great for the forces of intolerance. North Carolina voters approved an amendment that makes discrimination an official part of their state constitution.
