Colorado Republicans stonewalled a vote on permitting same-sex civil unions because it looked like the measure would pass. And Indiana’s Republican primary voters tossed out the venerable Senator Richard Lugar and replaced him with a man who thinks our problem is that we have too much bipartisanship.

headline: Spring Staples | Hoop Dreams
text: Seasons change and so must accessories.

headline: Q&A: Toward a Greener Tour and a Green Guitar
text: On Tuesday, a House Natural Resources subcommittee held a hearing on two bills that would repeal portions of the Lacey Act. While the law is a century old, the bills mainly challenge amendments passed in 2008 that made it illegal to import wood into the United States that was unlawfully exported under another country’s statutes.

headline: Live Nation Joins the Dance Party, Buying Promoter of Creamfields
text: In a deal that demonstrates how important electronic dance music has become to the concert industry, Live Nation Entertainment has bought Cream Holdings, the British promoter behind Creamfields and one of the biggest names in European dance festivals.

headline: Brown Releases First TV Ad
text: Senator Scott P. Brown on Wednesday released the first television ad of his re-election campaign in Massachusetts. It is a positive spot that highlights his central campaign themes of independence and bipartisanship.

headline: Fannie Mae Posts Profit; Seeks No Aid
text: WASHINGTON —  Fannie Mae, the government-backed mortgage financier, said on Wednesday that it made a profit in the first quarter and that it did not need additional bailout money — a first since the federal government took it over in fall 2008.

headline: New Estimate Sees Rise in Medical Costs in Retirement
text: Medical costs continue to loom large over retirement, a report from Fidelity Investments says.

headline: Keeping Scully in Booth Is Dodgers’ Easiest Call
text: Vin Scully’s memories of sales of the Dodgers date to 1950, when the team was still in Brooklyn, and now include the recently completed $2.15 billion acquisition by a group that includes Magic Johnson.

headline: Podolski Makes His Move to Arsenal
text: Things took a turn for the worst in last weekend’s climatic end to the Bundesliga, when the Rhein Energie Stadion descended into anarchy upon the defeat of Cologne by Bayern Munich, condemning the team to relegation from the top flight of German soccer.

headline: Technology Industry Seen Growing Fastest in New York
text: New York City’s budding technology industry is growing rapidly by attracting investors and engineering talent despite spotty access to a reliable broadband network, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: ‘The Voice’ Finale Jumps in the Ratings
text: NBC’s most potent programming weapon, “The Voice,” ended its season with a flourish Tuesday night, improving by about 16 percent over last year’s finale, which aired against much weaker competition.

headline: A Shiny New Web Site for the S.E.C.
text: We at DealBook are suckers for major Web site redesigns. (Last year, for example, we covered that of Goldman Sachs.)

headline: Asked About Gay Marriage, Romney Doesn’t Answer
text: FORT LUPTON, Colo. — At an event at an oil-and-gas production company here Wednesday morning, Mitt Romney refused to answer questions on same-sex marriage, a topic about which President Obama is expected to speak this afternoon, in an interview with Robin Roberts of ABC.

headline: College Dot Com
text: Editors’ Note: The conversation that follows took place before President Obama told an interviewer from ABC News that he thinks same-sex couples should be able to get married.

headline: Now Reading | ‘America’s Other Audubon’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Cuomo Says Obama Must Make Own Decision on Same-Sex Marriage
text: ALBANY – This time last year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo began crisscrossing New York State urging voters to support the legalization of same-sex marriage. But this week, when President Obama visited the capital region and the governor had a few minutes alone with him, Mr. Cuomo did not reprise his pitch.

headline: Apple Updates iOS 5.1
text: After releasing iOS 5.1 back in March, Apple has released a minor software update for the iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch.

headline: TimesCast | May 9, 2012
text: With gay marriage the hot-button topic, the president sits for a TV interview | A double agent’s role in thwarting a terrorist bomb plot | Steve Coll on the near-sovereign power of Exxon Mobil.

headline: Obama Expected to Address Gay Marriage
text: President Obama publicly endorsed same-sex marriage during a television interview, taking a definitive stand on one of the most contentious and politically charged social issues of the day.

headline: Hedge Fund Inflows Slowing, a Report Indicates
text: Hedge funds are facing an uphill battle to lure in investors and shake off weak performances.

headline: Lin Says of Knee: ‘It Didn’t Feel Right’
text: MIAMI — Jeremy Lin realized two days ago that his hopes of making a first-round playoff appearance were growing dim.

headline: What We Learned From Reading Every Last Word of 14 Magazines
text: Hugo Lindgren discovered the cost of a Maserati in Tehran in The Economist.

headline: Sun Rises, and There Will Be a ‘Law & Order’ on NBC
text: NBC ended the suspense early about the future of the last “Law & Order” series standing. The long-running “S.V.U.” edition will be back for a 14th season, the network announced Wednesday.

headline: Cheap and Colorful, an Overseas Home Beckons
text: THEY might have to contend with a monsoon season. Their electricity may go out on a regular basis. And they probably won’t have the choices they once had at the grocery store. But some people are trading the conveniences of American living for retirement in another country.

headline: Living Abroad in Retirement
text: A look at the most attractive and affordable options for more American retirees abroad.

headline: In Iran and China, Mishaps and Challenges Censoring the Web
text: When a fatwa met a filter in Iran this week, the filter apparently won.

headline: World Trade Center’s Symbolic 1,776-Foot Height Is at Stake in a Redesign
text: Seventeen-seventy-six will never lose its place in the history books, but its claim to the record books may have been undermined by a decision not to build a sculptural cladding for the mast atop 1 World Trade Center.

headline: With Primary Over, a New Battle for Indiana Senate Seat Begins
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The morning after Senator Richard G. Lugar, in his 36th year in office, was overwhelmingly defeated in a Republican primary election, this state awoke on Wednesday to another surprise: A new battle, now likely to be far fiercer and costlier than once expected, was already brewing over the seat he leaves behind.

headline: Who Will Light the Caldron in London?
text: The centerpiece of every Olympic opening ceremony is the arrival of the torch and the lighting of the caldron.

headline: Skin Deep
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Bombproof Case for Your iPad
text: You probably aren’t expecting your iPad to be hit by an improvised explosive device, but if you are, you might want to secure it in a Pelican case.

headline: Single Mom in Need? Not the Look
text: ON the way to Family Court in Manhattan last week, Linda Evangelista may have schemed to project the image of a woman wronged. If so, she missed the mark.

headline: In Spain, a Debt Crisis Built on Corporate Borrowing
text: LONDON — In a country with one of the highest levels of company debt in the world, few businesses in Spain shoulder as big a burden as Grupo A.C.S., the global construction giant whose debt woes have become a mirror image of Spain’s own increasingly severe financial struggle.

headline: Bank of America Investors Complain, but Approve Chief’s Pay
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Despite noisy protests inside and outside Bank of America’s annual meeting here Wednesday, shareholders signed off on the $7 million 2011 pay package for the chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan.

headline: Student Crossword | The Periodic Table
text: “Copper Chloride,” from The Periodic Table of Videos, a video series about each element of the periodic table.

headline: Ahead of Spanish Grand Prix, McLaren Moves Closer to ‘Ugly’ Step-Nose Design
text: In March, when the McLaren Mercedes driver Jenson Button won the Australian Grand Prix, it reaffirmed beauty’s place in Formula One racecar design. The victory lap, however, may be shorter than anticipated.

headline: Europe May Need More Power to Deal With Bank Crisis
text: LONDON — After several failed efforts to restore confidence in their sickly banks, European governments face growing pressure to change course and give the European Union more power to shore up the region’s shakier lenders.

headline: Greek Journalists Dodge Threats and Yogurt to Cover Rise of Far-Right Party
text: As reporters from around the world remain in Greece, covering the post-election political turmoil, Greek journalists continue to face intimidation for reporting on the rise of a xenophobic party from the far-right.

headline: Two Are Cleared in ’97 Killing of an Officer but Convicted of Plotting Mob Murders
text: A federal jury on Wednesday acquitted a man accused of being a boss of the Colombo crime family and another defendant of six gangland killings, including the shooting of a New York City police officer, but convicted the men on racketeering charges, including conspiracy to commit murder.

headline: A Real Post About the Fake Walt Frazier
text: If you flavor your basketball analysis with rhymes, as Walt Frazier does, you leave yourself open to parody. Dan Brill knows that and gleefully exploits Frazier’s boundin’ and astoundin’ rhyme-schemin’ on his Twitter account, (Not) Walt Frazier.

headline: For Woods, the Hall Can Wait
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — By the time he was 30 years old, Tiger Woods had enjoyed a Hall of Fame career, or more like two of them as he piled up 46 wins and 10 major championships.

headline: F.T.C. and White House Push for Online Privacy Laws
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration and the nation’s chief privacy regulator pressed Congress on Wednesday to enact online privacy legislation, saying new laws would level the playing field between companies that already had privacy policies and those that lacked them, and thus escape regulatory oversight.

headline: AMC Renews ‘Talking Dead’ and ‘Comic Book Men’
text: It’s not every AMC series that needs a Beatles song on its soundtrack to achieve creative success. On Wednesday, that cable TV home to 1960s drama “Mad Men” said it had given second-season orders to two unscripted programs that don’t require costly pop-rock gems to establish time, place and mood: “Talking Dead,” a talk show centered around AMC’s hit horror series “The Walking Dead,” has been renewed for 16 episodes, as has “Comic Book Men,” a reality series set in Jay and Silent Bob’s Secret Stash, the Red Bank, N.J., comic-book store owned by the filmmaker Kevin Smith.

headline: Pregame Chatter: Rangers Are Loose Before Game 6
text: WASHINGTON — There wasn’t much to say beyond the obvious before Game 6 Wednesday, with the Rangers seeking to close out the Capitals and reach the Eastern Conference finals for the first time since 1997.

headline: ING Direct Adds Remote Check Deposit App
text: ING Direct — the online bank that is now officially part of Capital One — is offering mobile check deposit, joining a growing list of banks offering the service.

headline: Edwards Jury Is Told How Wife Was Torn
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Elizabeth Edwards put herself through emotional and mental gymnastics to find a way to believe that her husband, former Senator John Edwards, had not conceived a child with a campaign videographer, one of Mrs. Edwards’s closest friends told a federal jury here on Wednesday.

headline: Benjamin Millepied’s New Company Coming to Peak Performances in the Fall
text: Benjamin Millepied’s company, L.A. Dance Project, will make its first appearance on the East Coast with October performances at Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series, it was announced on Wednesday. Also on the bill are a new chamber opera about the African-American artist Clementine Hunter, created in part by Robert Wilson; a new and so-far untitled work by Laurie Anderson and the Kronos Quartet; performances by South Africa’s Via Katlehong dance group, the Richard Alston Dance Company and the Jasmin Vardimon Company; and the first presentation of “Dog Days,” a mix of “opera, musical theater and rock-infused concert music” set in an imaginary “war-torn United States,” Peak Performances said. “Dog Days” is the work of David T. Little, Royce Vavrek, Robert Woodruff, Judy Budnitz and Alan Pierson.

headline: Obama Says Same-Sex Marriage Should Be Legal
text: WASHINGTON — Before President Obama left the White House on Tuesday morning to fly to an event in Albany, several aides intercepted him in the Oval Office. Within minutes it was decided: the president would endorse same-sex marriage on Wednesday, completing a wrenching personal transformation on the issue.

headline: Flipboard Finally Reaches Android Users
text: Previously exclusive to iOS, the popular social-news app Flipboard is now available to Android users.

headline: Parents of P.O.W. Reveal U.S. Talks on Taliban Swap
text: HAILEY, Idaho — The parents of the only American soldier held captive by Afghan insurgents have broken a yearlong silence about the status of their son, abruptly making public that he is a focus of secret negotiations between the Obama administration and the Taliban over a proposed prisoner exchange.

headline: A New Turn on the Road of Life
text: For decades, toymakers have sought for ways to translate their physical board games into digital versions, first as arcade games, then as handheld and console games, and now as apps. While apps work well as one-person games, they are not as much fun to play with four people huddled over a smartphone or tablet on family game night.

headline: PBS Will Move Series of Films to Monday Night
text: 4:43 p.m. | Updated Just weeks after hundreds of independent filmmakers protested a scheduling change for two award-winning independent film series on PBS, the broadcaster said Wednesday that it would move both series, “Independent Lens” and “POV,” to a Monday night slot and begin promotional efforts to recover viewers who were lost this season.

headline: A Suit Over a Showman
text: LaMarvon Jackson was about as anonymous a college basketball player as he could be. Hailing from Alabama, he averaged about eight minutes and one point a game in two seasons for the University of Arkansas at Little Rock. A 6-foot-5 forward, he did not march on stage at the N.B.A. draft, and he may never play in Madison Square Garden.

headline: Polanski’s Next Movie Is of a Man Persecuted, a k a the Dreyfus Affair
text: LOS ANGELES — In France, the pursuit of Roman Polanski by American authorities who remain intent on bringing him to trial for a decades-old sex offense has raised comparisons to the Dreyfus Affair. And those comparisons will surely be revived by Mr. Polanski’s next film project: A political thriller to be called “D,” based on the story of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus.

headline: A Benefits Statement You Can Read
text: Belle Likover, a 92-year-old seniors advocate in Shaker Heights, Ohio, led the Ohio Department of Aging’s advisory council last year, and she is not easily deterred by government mumbo jumbo. Still, she struggled to understand the summary of payments she recently received from Medicare after a five-day hospital stay.

headline: Whither Europe
text: FLORENCE — The State of the (European) Union was the subject of a high-level conference in Florence on Wednesday and most participants agreed that it is dire.

headline: Espada Jurors Cite Impasse, but Judge Says to Keep Working
text: The jury in the embezzlement trial of former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. indicated on Wednesday, the eighth day of deliberations, that it was at an impasse.

headline: Is That Onions You Smell? Or Battery Juice?
text: Gills Onions, a food processing company based in Oxnard, Calif., needs copious amounts of electricity for refrigeration, lighting and other jobs, and it sets an example by making its own, using onion waste. But it recently became a little greener — and more economical — by adding an enormous battery.

headline: No Matter Their Impact, Historic Words
text: It will be a few hours still before we learn all that President Obama said to ABC News this afternoon, before we can fully parse the words and analyze their effects, as we surely will. That’s our job. That’s our obsession.

headline: How My Child Skipped the State Tests
text: A parent describes the experience of having his third-grade son "opt out'' of the state exams.

headline: Defendant’s Lawyer Reacts to the Verdict
text: The defense lawyer for Thomas Gioeli reacts to the jury’s decision to acquit his client in the 1997 murder of an off-duty police officer, but convict him of other charges.

headline: Protesters in Moscow Alter Approach to Avoid Arrests
text: MOSCOW — On an empty plaza in a Moscow park, a man unfurled a yoga mat and sat down. Soon enough, two uniformed policemen arrived to confront him.

headline: Beastie Boys Return to the Top 20
text: On the music charts this week, Carrie Underwood has a hit new album, the Beastie Boys return to the Top 20 and Gotye hits No. 1 on multiple singles charts.

headline: The President Speaks Out (Finally) on Marriage
text: It was a long time coming: President Obama spoke out today in favor of marriage equality. “I’ve just concluded that for me personally it is important for me to go ahead and affirm that I think same sex couples should be able to get married,” he said in an interview with ABC News.

headline: Invisibility, All in Good Taste
text: LOOK, there’s nothing wrong with a uniform. It sets a tone. It saves time. It’s legible from a distance. Getting dressed well isn’t about addition, it’s about subtraction. I can name that style in four pieces. No, three. Make that two.

headline: House Votes to Extend Charter of Export-Import Bank
text: WASHINGTON – The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly voted to extend the life of the Export-Import Bank, siding with business groups over conservative activists who wanted Republicans to let the bank’s charter lapse at the end of this month.

headline: Trading the Elliptical for Video
text: At a DVD release party last week at the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan, middle-aged women confessed to feeling like schoolgirls as they ate hummus and snapped up copies of a new series, “Lord of the Abs,” $70 for 5 discs. The lord in question was one Gilad Janklowicz, 57, an Israeli fitness instructor known for jaunty seaside aerobics (set in Hawaii), a deep tan and stomach muscles like Atlas.

headline: Demanding, and Losing, Some Pounds of Flesh
text: Too much artificial sweetener has been stirred into “Fat Camp,” a new musical at the American Theater of Actors about teenagers singing their way to slimmer waistlines. This sentimental cartoon hopscotches through the usual teen-angst territory in its depiction of a camp full of misfits confronting familiar anxieties — the dawning and crushing of crushes, the miseries inflicted by the popular kids — as they try to avoid temptations their slimmer peers don’t have to worry about, like candy bars.

headline: Cisco Income Rises in Line With Forecasts
text: John T. Chambers, chief executive of Cisco Systems, on Wednesday gave a dark outlook for the world economy. It looks like investors in the company, which makes network equipment, agreed and started selling Cisco shares.

headline: Just Dinner With Friends
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Fed Approves I.C.B.C.’s Takeover of Bank of East Asia
text: The Federal Reserve opened the door for China’s biggest bank to establish a presence in the United States on Wednesday, allowing the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China to take a majority stake in an American institution.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Contribution to President’s ‘Evolution’
text: Before Barack Obama became the first president to support gay marriage, he was the first president to be so thoroughly surrounded by people who support gay marriage. Many of his donors are gay, and so are quite a few of his staff members, including his social secretary and the aides who made this moving video about their lifelong quests to accept themselves and to be accepted.

headline: Welcome to Our Backyard
text: What’s the most surprising species close to home? Readers responded with a variety of wild organisms, large and small.

headline: Educators Debate Boundary Between School and Life
text: Using everyday experiences and current events helps students master classroom material, especially if they feel emotionally connected to the issue, educators said at Tuesday's SchoolBook co-sponsored event at WNYC's Greene Space. Here are other take-aways, as well as links to valuable resources, to help teachers incorporate real life into their lessons.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage and Black Voters
text: The president’s announcement on same-sex marriage will definitely not play well with one crucial constituency: African-Americans, many of whom are conservative when it comes to gay rights, despite their own support for the civil rights movement of the 1960s.

headline: Theories of Evolution
text: Why did President Obama declare his support for same-sex marriage now?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Addiction and Mainstream Memes
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: Could Obama Have Affected North Carolina?
text: In March, the Obama administration weighed in on the proposed North Carolina amendment to ban same-sex unions, with a statement that the president did not support what he saw as “divisive and discriminatory efforts to deny rights and benefits to same-sex couples.”

headline: Support for Gay Marriage Outweighs Opposition in Polls
text: President Obama’s decision to endorse same-sex marriage undoubtedly entails some political risk, but recent polls suggest that public opinion is increasingly on his side.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Not Supported in Most Swing States
text: Seven of nine states expected to be close in the presidential election have laws or constitutional provisions that prohibit same-sex marriage.

headline: Ban College Football? Breaking Down a Debate
text: Two prominent writers argued for banning college football on Tuesday night at New York University’s Skirball Center as part of the Intelligence Squared U.S. Debates series. Their opponents were two journalists, who also happened to be former players. Buzz Bissinger (the author of the high school football book “Friday Night Lights”) and Malcolm Gladwell (the best-selling author and New Yorker staff writer who compared football to dogfighting) want to get rid of football on campus. Tim Green (a former N.F.L. defensive end) and Jason Whitlock (a Fox Sports correspondent who played football in college) want it to stay.

headline: Sexuality and Other Multitudes
text: Look closely at the provocative image on the cover of John Irving’s new novel, “In One Person.” It depicts a slender, nearly bare-backed person either hooking or unhooking a bra. Context suggests that the photographer’s model is a woman, but the hands may be a little large. The shoulder blades are widely spaced, the left hip slender. This seemingly straightforward photo turns out to be completely ambiguous about gender and sexual identity.

headline: What Romney Has Said About Same-Sex Marriage
text: In endorsing same-sex marriage on Wednesday, President Obama has offered voters the sharpest possible contrast with his presumptive Republican opponent, Mitt Romney, on a social issue that polls show still evenly divides the country.

headline: Rivera Says He Was Leaning Toward a Return Anyway
text: During spring training, the injured Yankees pitcher Mariano Rivera, who is in the final year of his contract, said that he knew whether he would return for another season next year and that nothing would change his mind.

headline: Volcker Defends a Rule Bearing His Name
text: The Volcker Rule, loathed by many bankers, still has the support of an influential Wall Street critic: Paul A. Volcker.

headline: Jewelry With a Glimmer of Rock Star
text: MUMBAI

headline: TimesCast Politics | May 9, 2012
text: President Obama declares support for same-sex marriage in an interview with ABC.

headline: Cultural Heavyweights Let Public Library Know They Don’t Like Planned Revamp
text: More than 700 scholars, writers, publishers, artists and others sent a letter to the New York Public Library on Wednesday protesting the $300 million restructuring of the 42nd Street flagship building and calling for a public discussion of the plan.

headline: At Hedge Fund Conference, Spotlight on Falcone
text: LAS VEGAS — It was strange watching Philip A. Falcone, the embattled chief of Harbinger Capital Partners, sitting onstage at the 2012 SALT Conference, a hedge fund gathering taking place over the next three days here at the opulent Bellagio hotel.

headline: The Voodoo Behind the Voice
text: The Internet hit pop music hard. Without the Net, we’d still be buying songs from record stores. Apple would still be just a computer company. And Justin Bieber would probably be working in a Burger King in Ontario.

headline: A Penthouse in the Heart of Malmo
text: A two-bedroom penthouse with a roomy terrace in Malmo’s city center is for sale for $1,040,856.

headline: House Hunting in ... Sweden
text: A TWO-BEDROOM PENTHOUSE WITH A TERRACE IN MALMO

headline: Following in the Footsteps of Gwen Verdon and Ann Miller
text: There are few choreographers who influenced American theatrical dance more than Jack Cole, and yet he has been largely forgotten. “Heat Wave: The Jack Cole Project,” a new revue impressively produced at Queens Theater in the Park, wants to change that.

headline: Grand Central Honored for Its Engineering
text: The Erie Canal, the Hoover Dam and now Grand Central Terminal: The Beaux-Arts railroad station is joining the first two on the list of National Historic Civil Engineering Landmarks, according to the American Society of Civil Engineers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, Kashmir, Gaza and Germany.

headline: Vain Glorious | The Clean Slate
text: Who: Persons of Interest Barbershop in Brooklyn.

headline: A Shostakovich Satire and a Colorful Program
text: Touring orchestras usually bring their best game to New York, but the weeklong Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall has upped the ante. The series, which opened its second season on Monday evening, requires ensembles to offer creatively assembled programs and to demonstrate in the application process that these are their norm.

headline: Let’s Show Some Respect for Songs From the ’70s
text: While watching the singer Nicole Henry go through her paces at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening, I had the sense of being in the presence of a pop-soul superwoman whose every gesture and inflection conveyed confidence and mastery.

headline: Remembering Vidal Sassoon
text: The hair pioneer, who died at the age of 84, helped women change the way they thought about their tresses.

headline: Arthritis Pill From Pfizer Wins Support of U.S. Panel
text: A federal advisory panel recommended approval on Wednesday of a rheumatoid arthritis pill that could offer patients an alternative to the injectable medicines already on the market, but several members expressed concern about safety and urged the Food and Drug Administration to require rigorous follow-up studies.

headline: The Success of the Gay Marriage Movement
text: In my Campaign Stops column this week, which came out just before President Obama’s official reversal on gay marriage, I made the following point about why his position was becoming so untenable:

headline: Digital Notes: Samsung Buys a Start-Up That Streams to Mobile Devices
text: Samsung Electronics has bought mSpot, a technology start-up that streams music and video to mobile devices. The companies announced the deal on Wednesday, and did not disclose financial terms, but a South Korean news report over the weekend about the companies’ negotiations estimated mSpot’s price at $8.8 million.

headline: Works That Are Longer on Style Than on Choreography
text: The dancers of Alonzo King Lines Ballet are easy on the eye: handsome, sleek, accomplished, individual. They luxuriate in their own motion; there’s a lotus-eating quality to their style. And style rather than choreography is the overriding impression left by the company’s current program at the Joyce Theater.

headline: Companies May Accept Sturdier Android Tablets
text: The word tablet is practically synonymous with iPad. Most companies using tablets are favoring Apple’s devices, and there is no serious contender. But among labor-intensive businesses,  those with factories and workers out out on job sites or in the fields,   there is strong interest in Android tablets because of the greater ability to customize them.

headline: President Obama on Gay Marriage
text: ABC News Interview

headline: What You Get for ... $700,000
text: VOLCANO, HAWAII

headline: It’s Lonely at the Top (Cold, Too) Up on Mount Washington
text: “The Observers,” an experimental film by Jacqueline Goss, looks in on the weather observatory atop Mount Washington in New Hampshire, but don’t expect to learn much about the work that goes on there. This is no documentary. It feels like a meditation about solitude and the extremes of nature, and perhaps a lament of sorts.

headline: Homes for $700,000
text: Properties in Hawaii, Connecticut and Los Angeles.

headline: Romney Draws Contrast, but Does Not Hammer Obama on Gay Marriage
text: Mitt Romney responded to President Obama’s endorsement of same-sex marriage by drawing a contrast with his own oft-repeated view that “marriage is a relationship between a man and a woman.”

headline: News Corp. Profits Increase Despite Scandal
text: In a signal to Wall Street that the continuing phone-hacking scandal in Britain has not had a significant impact on its bottom line, News Corporation on Wednesday reported a 47 percent increase in profit and said it would buy back an additional $5 billion worth of stock.

headline: So How Do We Talk About This?
text: PARENTS have learned to expect, and often dread, two sex talks with their children: the early lesson about the “birds and the bees” and the more delicate discussion of how to navigate a healthy sexual life as a young adult.

headline: City Instructs Schools to Expand Common Core Introduction
text: In an effort to expand the introduction of a new set of learning standards into the city's public schools, officials are asking science and social studies teachers to introduce more reading and writing into students' classwork. This school year, English and math teachers have already begun to adapt their lessons to the new requirements.

headline: Why ‘Faith’ Never Had a Prayer
text: Broadway has always been a gambler’s business, and the biggest crapshoot of the season was the new musical “Leap of Faith,” whose producers hurried it into New York this spring rather than lose a prized theater that had suddenly become available. This week the bet soured, as the producers announced a closing date of Sunday, with losses exceeding $14 million, making “Leap of Faith” the biggest flop of the season as well as the latest case study in how shows fail.

headline: What’s Hatching in Dance Incubator
text: What would be the biggest wish of a choreographer about to start a company? There’s something even more valuable than a blank check: the support of Mikhail Baryshnikov. And this month two choreographers are lucky enough to have it.

headline: Terrain Opens in Connecticut
text: Promising to do for gardening what Urban Outfitters did for street style, Terrain is opening its second garden and home store on Friday in Westport, Conn.

headline: How to Not Look Too Silly on a Skateboard
text: THE BOARD

headline: In China, Volkswagen Outsources Product Plan to the People
text: When an automaker decides to crowdsource ideas for its product line, it could do worse than canvassing the biggest crowd in the world.

headline: Skateboarding Past a Midlife Crisis
text: A GRINDING sound, somewhere between a rattle and a rumble, erupted over the suburban New Jersey hill. The figures, clad in motorcycle leathers and helmets, started to appear, one, two, three, until there were almost 20, crouched on skateboards, like a squadron of roller-villains.

headline: Obama’s Evolution on Same-Sex Marriage
text: A look back at some statements by the president since his 2004 bid for United States Senate shows his gradual “evolution” toward an endorsement of gay marriage.

headline: New Cautions About Long-Term Use of Bone Drugs
text: In an unusual move that may prompt millions of women to rethink their use of popular bone-building drugs, the Food and Drug Administration published an analysis that suggested caution about long-term use of the drugs, but fell short of issuing specific recommendations.

headline: Stage Scenes: Audra McDonald
text: A look at some of the actress’s past stage performances.

headline: From Earth to Mars, at the Armory
text: IF you wanted to find a good place in Manhattan from which to plan a manned mission to Mars, the studio of the artist Tom Sachs might not be the first place you would look.

headline: Solar Installers Offer Deals, Gaining Converts
text: HOLMDEL, N.J. — Jay Nuzzi, a New Jersey state trooper, had put off installing solar panels on his home here for years, deterred by the $70,000 it could cost. Then on a trip to Home Depot, he stumbled across a booth for Roof Diagnostics, which offered him a solar system at a price he couldn’t refuse: free.

headline: The Mars Project
text: The artist Tom Sachs is preparing for liftoff at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: U.S. Team Set for World Mind Sports Games
text: The United States open team at the World Mind Sports Games in Lille, France, in August will be Nick Nickell-Ralph Katz, Bob Hamman-Zia Mahmood and Jeff Meckstroth-Eric Rodwell.

headline: Assessing Whether Solar Panels Make Sense for You
text: As I report in The Times, legions of companies will offer to install a system at no upfront cost and promise customers cheaper, cleaner electricity over the course of 20 years. Some are small and local, while others, including SolarCity, Sunrun, Sungevity and SunEdison, are larger, with national or even international reach. Some large manufacturers, like SolarWorld, even offer financing plans for home installations.

headline: Your Reactions to Obama’s Same-Sex Marriage Stand
text: Tell us how much of an impact President Obama’s endorsement of same-sex marriage will have on your vote in the 2012 election.

headline: A Landmark Day for Gay Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Indiana Voter Mourns the Defeat of Senator Lugar
text: To the Editor:

headline: Put Your Rage Into a Cartoon and Exit Laughing
text: When you get angry, you can lash out or seethe inside.

headline: Sex Trafficking Victims
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Modernist Dream House in Los Angeles
text: A three-story glass box anchored on a steep slope, designed by the architect Allyn Morris, becomes home to an octogenarian admirer.

headline: A Reward for Decades of Waiting
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Choosing Safe Food Containers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Magic That Is Apt Alongside a Pint, or the Pint-Size
text: My only bartending stint involved mixing boring drinks for rich people who were waiting to sit for dinner, so I never learned the sorts of bar tricks that might entertain a less transient clientele.

headline: Sales at Artemide, Sferra and Others
text: Lighting fixtures and LED lights by Michele De Lucchi, Karim Rashid and others will be up to 70 percent off at Artemide May 11 and 12 (the Tolomeo classic table lamp, pictured, originally $405, will be $243); 46 Greene Street (Broome Street), (212) 925-1588, artemide.net.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Our apartment has an old, awkward kitchen, but we don’t have the budget to renovate before selling. Should we get plans drawn up, so buyers can see what’s possible?

headline: Shrinking Violets They Aren’t
text: THE difference between a vacant lot and a community garden comes down to a single thing: a sunflower.

headline: Charles Pollock on Coming Back to Furniture Design After a 30-Year Hiatus
text: The Pollock Executive Chair, introduced in 1963, was one of the most popular office chairs of its time. To this day, it’s a mainstay of the Knoll Collection. But what of its designer, Charles Pollock?

headline: A Palette of Gray Areas
text: WHEN Bryan Huffman, a North Carolina decorator, took the stand in the John Edwards trial to describe his part in funneling money from his friend Rachel Mellon to the former senator during his failed presidential bid, many in the decorating profession groaned in irritation.

headline: A New Web Site for Doug and Gene Meyer
text: Doug and Gene Meyer aren’t afraid of color — in fact, it’s a trademark of their designs, both in fashion and home. The brothers, who started their design studio in 2004, have collaborated on a range of home décor items, from fabrics and rugs to tableware, but for years their products were available only through showrooms or specialty shops.

headline: Kips Bay Show House Moves to the Upper West Side
text: For the first time in its 40-year history, the Kips Bay Decorator Show House will be held on the Upper West Side, and in a glassy new high rise to boot. With one notable exception — in 2008, when Manhattan House, the modernist white elephant on East 66th Street, hosted the show — the organizers have typically secured an Upper East Side town house for the nearly 30-odd decorators who volunteer to gussy up rooms to benefit the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club. But this year, there were no empty town houses to be had.

headline: So an Architect Walked Into a Bar
text: For his first attempt at a bar stool, David Khouri wanted to work with metal and wood, but in a way that “wasn’t Woodsy Owl,” he said. Mr. Khouri, an architect who is a partner in the New York firm Khouri Guzman Bunce Limited, was going for “more of a hybrid aesthetic of handmade and glamorous,” as he put it.

headline: It’s Not Easy Making Do With a Measly Million
text: WHO’S rich?

headline: Making Sure Money’s Still There When It’s Needed
text: IN years past, retirement was guided by simple arithmetic. You knew exactly how much Social Security, savings and your defined-benefit pension would pay you, then cut back any unaffordable expenses when you hit 65.

headline: A Few of the Paths to a Calmer Life
text: Jerry Seinfeld and Oprah Winfrey are among the most enthusiastic endorsers of the value of meditation, but doing it — actually learning how to clear your mind — may be a little more difficult than simply turning off a TV. Indeed, simply defining meditation can be a bit of a challenge.

headline: Country Comfort Wanted, and a Nearby Safety Net
text: SCENIC vistas and room to roam provide the serenity that retirees like Jim and Ava Higgins thrive on. The view from their one-acre property overlooks the town of Libby, Mont., with the craggy peaks of the Cabinet Mountains in the background.

headline: Working Late, by Choice or Not
text: REPORT after report has made abundantly clear that job growth is weak, but there’s one wide swath of the population where employment growth is going gangbusters: older Americans.

headline: Fight Financial Fraud With Tricks of Your Own
text: DO retirees have GPS devices that tell con artists where they live? It often seems so.

headline: Help for Pro Athletes When the Cheers Stop
text: DURING the New England Patriots’ 1982 training camp, several of Keith L. Lee’s teammates urged the second-string defensive back to push for a promotion. Mr. Lee, then a free agent pickup in his third year with the team, cornered his coach one day to lobby for the starter’s job. But his dream was dashed.

headline: Talk to Me, Not to My Daughter
text: THE first time Corky Alkin remembers being a nonperson was 20 years ago, at a shoe store in the San Fernando Valley suburbs of Los Angeles. Although Mrs. Alkin was the one shopping, the salesman spoke only to her grown daughter, Jodie Reff.

headline: In Sitting Still, a Bench Press for the Brain
text: IN 1969, Katherine Splain, then a student at the College of New Rochelle, saw the dark side of drug use among her peers. So she sought a different — and legal — path on her inward journey.

headline: Learning a New Language on Location
text: AMERICANS are not known for their facility with foreign languages, and learning gets more difficult as people age. But that has not stopped 60-, 70- and 80-somethings from heading to senior-friendly language immersion classes to tackle verb conjugations and the nuances of idioms — in places like the Tuscan hills and beach towns of Costa Rica.

headline: Fitness Regimens, Well Beyond Shuffleboard
text: GROWING old these days is no longer fading away gracefully, but “doing something active like playing golf, coming back and dropping dead,” says Colin Milner, who directs a group promoting active aging. “It’s not years of decline.”

headline: Federal Prisoner Fares Well in West Virginia’s Democratic Primary
text: This year, West Virginia’s Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin and its Senator Joe Manchin, both Democrats, would not say whether they would vote for President Obama, laying bare the fact that the president faces an uphill climb even among members of his own party.

headline: Readers of All Ages, Just Wild About Sendak
text: To the Editor:

headline: Can Your Child Find Porn on Your Phone?
text: Whether a six-year-old is tapping on Grover in “The Monster at the End of This Book” on an iPad, or a teen is blowing through “The Hunger Games” on a Kindle Fire, some parents don’t realize that many devices, marketed for reading, music listening or gaming, also provide Internet access — and sometimes a back-door to unwanted content.

headline: A Streisand Encore, 5 Decades Overdue
text: They may not be the luckiest people in the world, but Brooklyn people who want to see Barbra Streisand struck a jackpot of sorts Wednesday: the singer confirmed that she is returning to her home turf, to perform for the first time since she graduated from Erasmus Hall High School as a fiercely ambitious teenager and became, well, Barbra Streisand.

headline: Rivera Is Treated For Clot In Calf
text: When Mariano Rivera tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee last Thursday, he was carted off the field, taken to a hospital in Kansas City, placed in a magnetic resonance imaging tube, and told to stay off his feet as much as possible for several days.

headline: Shopping for Decorative Boxes
text: David Scott, an interior designer and the author of “Outside the Box,” shopped for boxes that were both utilitarian and decorative.

headline: Decorative Boxes
text: TO say that David Scott is box-obsessed might be an understatement.

headline: Facebook Says, Lower Your Expectations About Mobile
text: Here an ad, there an ad, everywhere an ad ad. Except on Facebook’s mobile app, that is.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,952 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Mets Have Faced Parade of Lefties
text: PHILADELPHIA — The sample size is small, but the Mets have faced 15 left-handed starters in 31 games this season. Are teams trying to manipulate their pitching rotations to have lefties face the Mets’ left-handed-heavy lineup?

headline: 2 Men Stole Iron Grates in Midtown, Police Say
text: For at least the second time in two months, the police pulled over two men transporting heavy metal taken from public places. This time, though, the cargo was not manhole covers from the Bronx, but iron grates that had been protecting trees in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Despite Appearances, Goalies Say They Practice Those Routine Plays
text: WASHINGTON — Philadelphia goalie Ilya Bryzgalov’s lethal giveaway in the Flyers’ loss to the Devils on Tuesday night raised the question of whether goalies practice routine relay passes and dump-offs enough.

headline: Putin to Skip Group of 8 Session, Delaying Postelection Meeting With Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Russia’s newly inaugurated president, Vladimir V. Putin, will not attend a summit meeting of world leaders in Maryland next week, the White House said on Wednesday, postponing until June the much-anticipated first meeting of President Obama and Mr. Putin as the leaders of their respective countries.

headline: Game Over for the Climate
text: GLOBAL warming isn’t a prediction. It is happening. That is why I was so troubled to read a recent interview with President Obama in Rolling Stone in which he said that Canada would exploit the oil in its vast tar sands reserves “regardless of what we do.”

headline: PGA Tour Keeps Exception for Masters
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The PGA Tour does not allow courses with a discriminatory membership policy to host its tournaments, but Commissioner Tim Finchem said it would continue to make an exception with Augusta National, which does not permit women as members.

headline: Teixeira Receives Good News About Cough
text: Mark Teixeira had a battery of tests performed Wednesday to determine the nature of his violent and persistent cough, and he received good news. Teixeira, who has been wracked by the cough for about a month, said he was found to have nothing more serious than severe congestion in his bronchial passageways.

headline: Much Ado About Double or Nothing
text: THE interest rate on the popular Stafford federal student loan program is set to double in July, after the Senate could not reach agreement on Tuesday on a way to keep the rate at 3.4 percent. President Obama has blamed Republican obstruction for the looming rate increase; Mitt Romney says the lower rate should be extended but hasn’t specified how to pay for it.

headline: In Ciudad Juárez, a New Emotion
text: Signs that Ciudad Juárez is on the road to recovery after years of an onslaught by drug-trafficking cartels include the young people who have joined art collectives in lieu of gangs and the recently reopened nightclubs that are drawing crowds out after dark.

headline: Slivers of Hope Amid the Melancholy in a Mexican Border Town
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — The crowd toasted with beers as first-time models strutted the makeshift catwalk in princess wedding dresses and Tarahumara Indian-inspired flower-print jumpers, all produced by local fashion designers bent on showing the world that their troubled border city is as much about hemlines as homicides.

headline: A Faux Walt Frazier, in All His Rhyming Glory
text: If you flavor your basketball analysis with rhymes, as Walt Frazier does, you leave yourself open to parody. Dan Brill knows that and gleefully exploits Frazier’s boundin’ and astoundin’ rhyme-schemin’ on his Twitter account, (Not) Walt Frazier.

headline: Romney Reaffirms Opposition to Marriage, or Unions, for Gay Couples
text: Like many conservative Republicans, Mitt Romney is opposed not only to same-sex marriage, but also to the civil unions that many states have adopted as an alternative to full marital rights for gay couples.

headline: Your Vote: Man vs. Morel
text: Our question for today is: How do you feel about the defeat of Senator Richard Lugar in the Indiana Republican primary?

headline: Office of Congressional Ethics Report on Rep. Vern Buchanan
text: The investigation into charges of violations by Rep. Vern Buchanan.

headline: S.E.C. Is Investigating Accounting of Chinese Client of Deloitte in Shanghai
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed Wednesday that it was investigating another Chinese client of the Shanghai affiliate of Deloitte, the large accounting group, on suspicion of accounting fraud. It did not identify the company, but an official said the investigation, which began in 2010, was continuing.

headline: Report Casts Harsh Light on Lawmaker’s Fund-Raising
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional ethics investigators concluded in a report released Wednesday that Representative Vern Buchanan, a Florida lawmaker who leads House Republican fund-raising operations nationwide, appeared to have tried to illegally influence the testimony of an ex-business partner regarding allegations of campaign finance violations in his own race.

headline: Teenage Rider May Reset the Bar
text: MIDDLEBURG, Va. — At 13, an age when many young riders are still cantering fat ponies over low picket gates, Reed Kessler was urged to think about the London Olympics by her coach, the international show jumper Katie Monahan-Prudent.

headline: Poverty’s Poster Child
text: PINE RIDGE, S.D.

headline: After a Rebellion That Shook Albany, Three Falls From Grace
text: ALBANY — Not so long ago, the Four Amigos were the kings of Albany.

headline: Looking Back on a Distinguished Career
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Gary Player has done it all and seen it all in the game of golf.

headline: A Circle of Tech: Collect Payout, Do a Start-Up
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Matt Cohler was employee No. 7 at Facebook. Adam D’Angelo joined his high school friend Mark Zuckerberg’s quirky little start-up in 2004 — and became its chief technology officer. Ruchi Sanghvi was the first woman on its engineering team.

headline: Vidal Sassoon, Hairdresser and Trendsetter, Dies at 84
text: Vidal Sassoon, whose mother had a premonition that he would become a hairdresser and steered him to an apprenticeship in a London shop when he was 14, setting him on the path that led to his changing the way women wore and cared for their hair, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ex-Officer Sentenced for Robbing Drug Dealers
text: A former New York City police officer was sentenced on Wednesday to 25 years in prison for robbing drug dealers with a gang.

headline: Combating Olympic-Class Odors
text: OLYMPIC advertisers tend to highlight the grit and determination of athletes, but a Procter & Gamble brand is taking the unusual approach of pointing out that a team stinks.

headline: Obama’s New Courting of Hollywood Pays Off
text: LOS ANGELES — For years, President Obama has largely been absent in Hollywood, a point of unhappiness with a community accustomed to the constant doting of Bill Clinton. But over the last few months, Mr. Obama and his representatives have held a series of meetings and telephone calls with some of the region’s most influential donors and fund-raisers, reflecting Hollywood’s new importance in the president’s re-election campaign.

headline: After Questions on Tactics, Accretive Cuts Forecast
text: Despite a surge in revenue in the first quarter, Accretive Health on Wednesday lowered its earnings estimate for 2012 because of the loss of an important contract amid accusations that the medical debt-collection company had used overly aggressive tactics.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 9
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: President Obama’s Moment
text: It has always taken strong national leadership to expand equal rights in this country, and it has long been obvious that marriage rights are no exception. President Obama offered some of that leadership on Wednesday. “I think same-sex couples should be able to get married,” Mr. Obama said in an interview with ABC News that the White House arranged for the purpose of giving Mr. Obama a forum to say just that.

headline: Liberty and Justice for All
text: It is done.

headline: House Votes Overwhelmingly to Extend Export-Import Bank
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly voted to extend the life of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, siding with business groups over conservative activists who wanted Republicans to let the bank’s charter lapse at the end of May.

headline: For Elliott Management’s Singer, Success Lies in Humility
text: LAS VEGAS — It should come as no surprise that Paul Singer, the founder of the $20 billion hedge fund Elliott Management, is critical of the current administration.

headline: Thompson Quits Authority to Focus on Bid for Mayor
text: In the latest example of his increasing focus on his next mayoral campaign, William C. Thompson Jr. informed the Cuomo administration on Wednesday that he was stepping down as chairman of the Battery Park City Authority.

headline: Long-Running Antiterrorism Work With Saudis Led to Airline Plot’s Failure
text: WASHINGTON — In the video, Yemeni militants can be seen forcing their prisoner to his knees in the bright sunlight. The gunmen read out a death sentence declaring the man to be a Saudi spy who hoped to infiltrate Al Qaeda, and then, as the screen goes blank, a rifle shot rings out, followed by cries of “God is great!”

headline: Some Hospitals Will Curb Samples of Baby Formula
text: It is part of the modern maternity experience: the pink or blue knit caps, the identity bracelet, the impossibly tiny jumpers, and not least, the goody bag filled with infant formula.

headline: Obama Endorses Same-Sex Marriage
text: President Obama endorsed same-sex marriage in a television interview on Wednesday, taking a definitive stand on one of the most contentious and politically charged social issues of the day.

headline: Mere Tinkering With a Bad Program
text: The Obama administration announced last month plans to repair Secure Communities, the program that compels state and local police to join its wide and expanding hunt for illegal immigrants. From now on, when illegal immigrants are stopped for traffic violations by local police, Immigration and Customs Enforcement will consider detaining and deporting them only after they have been convicted, not before.

headline: Atop the Leader Board in Fun and Nonconformity, Too
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.

headline: Rhode Island’s Principled Stance
text: Jason Wayne Pleau, a Rhode Island prisoner, has said he would accept a life sentence without parole, the state’s severest punishment, for robbing and murdering a gas-station manager. The Justice Department, however, wants to prosecute him for those crimes under federal law with the option of seeking the death penalty. The crimes are generally handled by states, so the department’s insistence on making this a federal case is hard to fathom. Justice would be well served if the department let the state deal with Mr. Pleau.

headline: Making Room for the Locals
text: The wholesale produce market at Hunts Point in the South Bronx features fruits and vegetables from around the nation and the world. Yet the 105-acre distribution hub provides very little space for smaller, local farmers to sell their produce to schools, restaurants and other retailers. Only about 4 percent of the $2.3 billion in annual sales there comes from food grown in New York State; another 8 percent comes from New Jersey.

headline: Don’t Look Down
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Things have gotten so creative with the New York Times puzzles that I feel like it has become part of my job to reassure you that you are not, in fact, having an aneurysm when a grid doesn’t, at least on the surface, make sense.

headline: A Watershed Move, Both Risky and Inevitable
text: President Obama’s endorsement of gay marriage on Wednesday was by any measure a watershed. A sitting United States president took sides in what many people consider the last civil rights movement, providing the most powerful evidence to date of how rapidly views are moving on an issue that was politically toxic just five years ago.

headline: New Rules May Curtail Some Fees in Mortgage
text: WASHINGTON — The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said it planned to propose tighter mortgage lending regulations that would limit the ability of banks and mortgage brokers to charge certain transaction fees, possibly ending one of the most abusive costs levied on consumers when they buy a house.

headline: 2 Opinions on Stop-and-Frisk Report
text: In 2003, the second year of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s first term, police officers confiscated 604 guns through 160,851 stop-and-frisk encounters: a success rate of one gun for every 266 stops.

headline: Still Working, Well Into the Retirement Years
text: By choice or necessity, many Americans work well into their seventies and beyond.

headline: Clemens’s Mail Latest Flash Point in Trial
text: WASHINGTON — The perjury trial of Roger Clemens still awaits the appearance of Brian McNamee, Clemens’s chief accuser and former trainer. McNamee is expected to testify that he injected Clemens with steroids and human growth hormone — rebutting Clemens’s version that he only received injections of vitamin B12 and the painkiller lidocaine.

headline: G.O.P. Senator Who Backed Gay Unions Won’t Run
text: James S. Alesi, one of four Republican state senators in New York who voted in favor of same-sex marriage last year, said Wednesday night that he would not seek re-election because he did not want to go through a difficult primary campaign and put Republican control of the State Senate at risk in November.

headline: Reporting Molestation in the Orthodox Community
text: Documents related to ultra-Orthodox child sex abuse allegations show the difficult road victims and their families must tread as they seek justice through the secular court system, even as some parts of their community begin to loosen restrictions on reporting abuse.

headline: Breaking the Silence on Child Sex Abuse
text: Ultra-Orthodox Jewish victims of molestation and their families tread a difficult road as they seek justice through the secular court system, even as some communities begin to loosen restrictions on reporting abuse.

headline: Ultra-Orthodox Shun Their Own for Reporting Child Sexual Abuse
text: The first shock came when Mordechai Jungreis learned that his mentally disabled teenage son was being molested in a Jewish ritual bathhouse in Brooklyn. The second came after Mr. Jungreis complained, and the man accused of the abuse was arrested.

headline: An Attempt to Clear Up Mortgage Application Confusion
text: Correction: An earlier version of this post said that the newly required plain-vanilla loan would have no upfront fees. It can have flat upfront fees but can’t have any points.

headline: The Roller Coaster Stops
text: MIAMI — The unraveling of the Knicks’ illusory coalition of stars began with Amar’e Stoudemire’s lonely walk to the bench. He took off his goggles, slapped hands with Tyson Chandler and plopped into his seat, a sense of finality descending over them all.

headline: Battier Still Going All Out for a Title
text: MIAMI — It has been more than a decade since Heat forward Shane Battier tasted a championship, and that was with Duke in 2001.

headline: An Expensive Defeat
text: Richard G. Lugar outspent Richard E. Mourdock nearly 3-to-1 in Indiana’s Republican Senate primary race, but outside groups poured millions of dollars into the campaign.

headline: A Father's Gifts
text: The columnist William C. Rhoden talks about the important things he received from his recently deceased father.

headline: California and Quebec Near an Agreement for Trading of Carbon Permits
text: SAN FRANCISCO — California and Quebec moved to knit together their fledgling carbon markets on Wednesday as California proposed a new regulation allowing cross-border trading of the permits that industries must acquire to cover their emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: For 24 Schools Getting New Start, 24 New Names
text: Two dozen public schools are being renamed as part of New York City’s strategy to qualify for nearly $60 million in federal grants to help the so-called struggling schools get fresh starts.

headline: Should Churches Get Tax Breaks?
text: Should religious organizations be subject to the same rules and taxes as secular ones?

headline: Mets Make Themselves at Home in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — David Wright tried to remember the last time the Mets swept the Philadelphia Phillies at Citizens Bank Park. This is Wright’s ninth season in New York, and he has seen the National League East transform from a division in which the Mets were behemoths to one dominated by the Phillies.

headline: A Death Rattles a Palestinian City
text: The death of the governor of the Jenin region has alarmed Palestinians worried about the return of violence to a city widely regarded as a model for the West Bank.

headline: Rangers and Capitals Will Play Game 7 at the Garden
text: WASHINGTON — The Rangers stepped onto the ice at the Verizon Center on Wednesday night with a chance to close out the Washington Capitals and advance to the Eastern Conference finals against the Devils.

headline: Model West Bank City Loses a Crime Fighter
text: JENIN, West Bank — Relaxing in their rooftop salon one recent night, Amal Qadoura headed to fetch ice cream for herself and her husband when the shooting began. First, she recalled, two bullets were fired at one side of the glass-enclosed porch, followed by a barrage from a hilltop on the other side.

headline: Memo to Would-Be Members of the 1%: Move to the Northeast or Mid-Atlantic
text: Reaching for the American dream? Your best chances are probably in New York, New Jersey or Maryland.

headline: Robertson Fails in Second Test as Closer, Giving Up 4 Runs
text: One challenging aspect of being a closer is the ability to rebound from failure. Even the unparalleled success of Mariano Rivera, who saved a record 608 games before being injured last week, was built on his ability to shed a bad loss and pitch well the next time out.

headline: Egypt Court Suspends Vote, but Ruling Is Disputed
text: CAIRO — An administrative court on Wednesday suspended Egypt’s presidential election, scheduled to start on May 23, but legal experts said the ruling was expected to have little effect, and the candidates continued their campaigns, including preparations for the first televised debate Thursday night.

headline: Though Disparate, Syria Rebels Tenacious Against Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than a year into the Syrian uprising, protesters and fighters say, disparate opposition cells inside the country still scramble on their own for money and weapons, creating a risk that different factions will form conflicting loyalties to whoever ends up financing or arming them.

headline: $44.8 Million, Going Twice at Sotheby’s
text: A blond bombshell and a twisted male figure — classic images by Roy Lichtenstein and Francis Bacon — tied for top price at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night, bringing $44.8 million each.

headline: Group Sees Sign of Iran Cleanup at Nuclear Site
text: New commercial satellite imagery of an Iranian military site that has remained off limits to international nuclear inspectors shows recent activity that suggests the Iranians have tried to clean up a suspected explosives testing chamber there, a group that tracks nuclear proliferation said Wednesday.

headline: Washington’s Rookie Goalie Has All the Answers
text: WASHINGTON — Once again the rookie goalie Braden Holtby refused to lose when so much was on the line for the Washington Capitals.

headline: El Salvador: Court Denies Spain Request for Extradition of Suspects in Killings
text: The Supreme Court has rejected an extradition request from Spain for 13 former military officers accused of planning and ordering the killings of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter during the country’s civil war.  The Salvadoran court ruled late Tuesday that the former officers could not be sent abroad because the country’s Constitution at the time of the killings prohibited the extradition of Salvadoran citizens. Five of the six Jesuits were born in Spain, where judges have used the doctrine of universal jurisdiction to prosecute crimes committed outside of the country, as they did against the former Chilean dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Posting Your Cancer on Facebook
text: In the world of social media, we are our own self-portraitists. Our digital identity is doctored to show the best version of our lives. (Maybe a more apt name for Facebook would have been “Best Face” book.) It’s not a new observation to point out the disparities between our online identities and our real selves, but for me, as a cancer patient, that gap has never felt larger.

headline: Hollywood to Back Effort to Aid Veterans’ Return to Civilian Life
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood is putting its megaphone behind efforts to assist returning Iraq and Afghanistan veterans in the transition to civilian life.

headline: Dynamo Ends 16-Year Search for a Home
text: The former Houston Oilers quarterback and NFL Europe executive Oliver Luck sat pondering his role as president of Major League Soccer’s latest franchise. Its first game was three months away yet there were no front-office employees, no headquarters and no stadium lease.

headline: Word of the Day | skulduggery
text: skulduggery/skullduggery •\ˌskəl-ˈdə-g(ə-)re, ˈskəl-ˌ\• noun

headline: Corrections: May 10
text: SPORTS

headline: Rangers’ Replay: Game 6
text: The Eastern Conference finals were within the Rangers’ grasp Wednesday night, but they fell behind 1 minute 28 seconds into the game on a power-play goal from the Capitals’ Alex Ovechkin and went on to lose.

headline: Stray-Cat Barbecue, Dirty Tap Water, Celebrity Hijinks, No Chen — the Usual
text: HONG KONG — It sounds quite preposterous, of course, this idea that 1.3 billion people could be kept wholly in the dark about a news event in their own country, an event that was simultaneously making headlines in the rest of the world.

headline: Data Signals Economic Trouble in China
text: HONG KONG — As China’s leaders have been preoccupied with a political struggle leading up to a once-in-a-decade leadership change this autumn, there are increasing signs that the Chinese economy may be running into trouble.

headline: Knicks’ Replay: Game 5
text: Despite a momentary slip three days earlier, the Heat, led by LeBron James’s 29 points, left no doubt about their superiority in clinching the first-round series over the Knicks, four games to one.

headline: Russian Hackers Attack Live Streaming Video Sites
text: Hackers shut down a United States online video company on Wednesday that was being used by Russian activists to stream live video of protests in Moscow, prompting the company’s leaders to launch a Russian-language version of the site.

headline: Jewelry With a Glimmer of Rock Star

headline: News Quiz | May 10, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Wreckage of Russian Aircraft Found in Indonesia
text: MOSCOW — Rescuers who hiked Thursday to the remote slope of a dormant Indonesian volcano where a new-model Russian passenger jet crashed found no signs that any of the 50 people aboard had survived, according to local news media and the Russian Foreign Ministry.

headline: Cameron Seems Unscathed After Ex-Aide’s Testimony
text: LONDON — It had been billed as a day when Prime Minister David Cameron might face a serious political threat to his tenure if the evidence went badly against him at the judicial inquiry into the scandal involving phone hacking and payoffs to public officials that has enveloped Rupert Murdoch’s media empire in Britain.

headline: May 10, 1869 | First Transcontinental Railroad Is Completed

headline: When Should You Feel Guilty for Killing Zombies?
text: Zombies, along with Nazis and aliens, may be the easiest of all video game entities to slaughter without a second thought. Have you ever played a game in which you felt conflicted about the virtual violence you were inflicting — or do you lay waste to your pixelated enemies without a second thought? Is there anything that makes you hesitate before pulling the virtual trigger?

headline: Joe Weisenthal vs. the 24-Hour News Cycle
text: Joe Weisenthal wakes up around 4 a.m. most weekdays, afraid that in the five or six hours he has been sleeping, something happened that could move financial markets. His alarm is his cellphone, and after he silences it so that his wife can sleep, he rolls from bed and starts to type, still in his pajamas, in the darkness of his apartment at the edge of the Financial District. And the first thing he types, the first of about 150 daily messages he posts on Twitter, is almost always this: “What’d I miss?”

headline: Clashing Realities in a ‘City of Champions’
text: There are two realities depicted in the photographs on the side of the Messiah Baptist Church in Brockton, Mass. One is of an old white man entering a backyard pool party for the Martel family on the Fourth of July (Slide 1). The other is of a young black woman wearing a bandanna on her head, midriff exposed, cigars tucked into her pants (Slide 7).

headline: Breaking Up Four Big Banks
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

text: I received two consecutive rejections from the only private colleges I applied to (Wesleyan and Vassar). Surprisingly, I wasn’t very disappointed. In fact, I was relieved that my choices were significantly narrowed down.

text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Twin suicide car bombs that targeted a notorious military intelligence compound shook the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Thursday, killing and wounding hundreds of people and raising the likelihood of extremist elements propelling the conflict to a more treacherous phase.

headline: Seau Tribute Expected to Draw Huge Crowd Friday
text: Junior Seau is being honored as if he were royalty, which he essentially was in Southern California, particularly in the San Diego area.

headline: Twelve Uncomplicated Summer Cocktails
text: Mixing a good drink requires a bit of care, but anyone can do it.

headline: It’s 5 O’Clock Somewhere
text: Those bottles of premade mixes that line the beverage aisles of supermarkets are the Hamburger Helpers of the cocktail industry: you don’t need ’em. Mixing a good drink requires a bit of care, but anyone can do it. Most real cocktails contain little more than fresh citrus and a few other accompaniments like bitters or simple syrup (boil equal parts water and sugar, just until the sugar melts; store in the fridge, forever).

headline: Greetings From Afghanistan!
text: If you can put aside fear of being shot, blown up or kidnapped – in other words, basically pretend that Afghanistan is not in the grip of a brutal and seemingly interminable war – the country boasts some truly breathtaking tourist attractions.

headline: I Have Seen the Future of Manufacturing
text: So I spent a week in Germany, touring a factory that makes conference tables and office chairs. I have been working with this company, which I’ll call Company G, for almost a year now. The head of its North American operations called me last June, out of the blue, to ask whether we might be interested in doing custom work and some short run production for them. He had found me the way most of our clients do, by searching the Internet.

headline: Greek Socialist Leader Says Agreement On a Coalition Government Is Possible
text: ATHENS — With Greece still rudderless after inconclusive elections, the leader of the Socialist Party indicated on Thursday that he might be able to establish common ground with the leader of the moderate Democratic Left Party and try to form a government that would extricate the country from a deepening political crisis that has angered its foreign creditors and roiled global markets.

headline: Central Bank In Britain Stays Course On 2 Fronts
text: LONDON — The Bank of England decided to keep its bond-purchasing program unchanged Thursday because of concerns about inflation even after the British economy fell back into a recession in the first quarter of this year.

headline: HSBC in Talks to Sell Latin American Units
text: LONDON – HSBC said on Thursday that it was in talks over the potential sale of its operations in several Latin American countries, the latest effort by the European bank to focus on a small number of core markets.

headline: Disappointment as Gay Marriage Is Left Out of Queen’s Speech
text: LONDON — Call it bad timing. On the very day President Barack Obama gave his endorsement to same-sex marriage, the British government appeared to defer a promise to legalize it.

headline: For Horse and Rider, a Perfect Pairing
text: Jesus Castanon has ridden in the United States for a little over 22 years. He is originally from Mexico, where he rode for three to four months before moving his tack to California. Castanon has ridden more than 2,000 winners; his win aboard Shackleford in the 2011 Preakness Stakes was his first Grade I stakes victory. Shackleford and Castanon did not duck a race for the entire 2011 campaign, with strong efforts in the Grade I Haskell Stakes (second) and the Grade I Breeders’ Cup Dirt Mile (second). However, it was a little over 50 weeks before they returned to the winner’s circle, in the Grade II Churchill Downs Stakes on Saturday.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Despite Industry’s Woes, Hedge Fund Titans Appear Calm at Conference  |  The hedge fund industry may be facing a storm of regulatory concerns, weak performance and government inquiries. But the industry’s titans appeared relatively relaxed at the Bellagio hotel in Las Vegas, the scene of the 2012 SALT Conference.

headline: A Vampire Thirsty and Bewildered
text: Of all the morbid beauties in Tim Burton’s work, the spooky goth girls and deathly pale boys, none wear their ghoulishness as lightly or winningly as Johnny Depp. And what a bewitching corpse he makes in “Dark Shadows,” Mr. Burton’s most pleasurable film in years. As Barnabas Collins, the scion of a wealthy family turned unwilling vampire, Mr. Depp has a face as white as chalk and long-fingered hands that skim the air like skittering spiders. After 200 years of entombment, Barnabas awakes in 1972 and, like a latter-day Rip van Winkle, only thirstier, drinks in a world populated by monsters, living and dead, and lovingly adorned with Mr. Burton’s signature kinks.

headline: A Return Home to Family and Stage
text: AUDRA McDONALD is glowing. She has just spied a pair of men’s Adidas sneakers by the front door of her New York State country home, and with a delighted laugh slips them on to take her two rowdy dogs out for a walk. “They’re Will’s shoes,” she says of her fiancé of five months, the theater actor Will Swenson.

headline: On Our Radar: Lugar, the G.O.P. and Climate Change
text: Richard G. Lugar, the longtime Indiana senator defeated in a primary by a candidate who dismisses global warming as “junk science,” says that most of his fellow Republicans “cannot admit to any nuance in policy on climate change.” [The Hill]

headline: Spain Is Likely to Take Steps to Strengthen Its Banking System
text: MADRID — Spain is expected to announce on Friday measures to strengthen the banking sector, just two days after seizing control of Bankia, the country’s largest real estate lender.

headline: Coty Raises Bid for Avon to $10.7 Billion
text: Coty has raised its bid for Avon Products to $10.7 billion, hoping to persuade the beleaguered cosmetics company to come to the negotiating table.
