headline: Pearson Tells State: We'll Do Better
text: Once again the state math and English tests created by Pearson are in the news, with a report that the educational company is feeling the pressure stemming from test errors that have caused 29 questions to be struck from the exams so far. Meanwhile, state Board of Regents Chancellor Merryl H. Tisch on Wednesday said Pearson's mistakes were "really disturbing."

headline: Kids Draw the News: The Case of the Missing Manholes
text: Our colleagues at The Times’s City Room blog have a new feature called Kids Draw the News, where they assign the 12-and-unders in the audience a current article about New York City to illustrate, and post the results in a slide show. The first two assignments — a brawl at an elite athletic club and an episode in which a heckler called New York’s mayor Michael R. Bloomberg “Pharaoh Bloomberg” — drew responses from as far off as Africa.

headline: Shows You See Again, for the First Time
text: OFTEN it really is better the second time around. Occasionally the thrill is gone. And then there are those instances — and they are the rarest — when it all seems exactly the same.

headline: Thursday Reading: What to Do When Children See Porn
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: They Sure Weren’t Singing My Song
text: DOES it say something about the state of the American musical theater that the animating incident in the most accomplished new Broadway show of the season is the repairing of a vacuum cleaner? It almost makes you nostalgic for those dark days when the talk of the Rialto was the spectacle of a chandelier plummeting toward the stage, or a helicopter landing on it.

headline: Tussle in Brussels
text: I’m in Belgium for the afternoon — and yes, I mean the afternoon. One of those things. So, not much blogging today! Here are the slides for my talk (pdf).

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Spawns Circle of Young Tycoons
text: With lucrative shares and a web of valuable industry contacts, some early Facebook employees have left the company to either create their own start-ups or bankroll their friends, Somini Sengupta reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: On Graduation Day, Commencement or Brunch?
text: Dear Diary:When my daughter graduated from New York University five years ago, commencement took place in Washington Square Park. (Now it’s at Yankee Stadium.)

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Obama Stops ‘Evolving’ on Same-Sex Marriage
text: President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage on Wednesday in a hastily scheduled interview with Robin Roberts of ABC News. The timing was driven by Vice President Joseph L. Biden Jr.’s comments that aired on Sunday on “Meet the Press,” Jackie Calmes and Peter Baker reported, but also by the drumbeat of reporters’ questions at the news briefing of the president’s spokesman, Jay Carney. While the thinking of the president’s advisers this week was that he would make the announcement next Monday on the ABC morning talk show “The View,” even the delay of a few days became untenable.

headline: Time Travel
text: Snippets from the summer’s most evocative fiction.

headline: Car Bombings Kill at Least 55 People in Damascus
text: Two explosions at an intelligence building in the capital on Thursday struck at the peak time for employees to arrive.

headline: His Own Network of Tortured Souls
text: HE will be swinging between tall buildings wearing Lycra this summer, but right now Andrew Garfield is a wreck. Wrapped up tight against the crisp afternoon in a hoodie and pea coat, he sipped camomile tea with honey during a recent interview in Chelsea, punctuated by coughing fits.

headline: Georgia Under Construction
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Driving from the Black Sea in the west to the rolling wine country in the east, one might be forgiven for thinking the entire nation of Georgia is currently under construction.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Esquire: The box-office success of “The Avengers” seems to be making America mad for shawarma. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: DirecTV to Produce Original Series, ‘Rogue,’ Starring Thandie Newton
text: Having developed the brand of its Audience Network around shows like “Damages” and “Friday Night Lights,” which it has shared with or inherited from other broadcasters, the satellite television provider DirecTV said on Thursday that it had ordered its first original scripted series, one that rests on the slender shoulders of the actress Thandie Newton.

headline: Collaborating With the Cast and Playwright
text: IT may be only fitting that “Clybourne Park,” a play about two generations of real-estate squabbles, had to fight to land a Midtown address. Now ensconced at the Walter Kerr Theater and boasting four Tony nominations, including one for best play, Bruce Norris’s bleak, funny spinoff of Lorraine Hansberry’s “Raisin the Sun” took a circuitous route to Broadway after its well-received start at Playwrights Horizons in 2010.

headline: Dispute Between China and Philippines Over Island Becomes More Heated
text: BEIJING — China escalated its quarrel with the Philippines over an island in the South China Sea on Thursday, halting Philippine bananas at customs for longer inspections and starting an official media campaign that suggested that any claims on the island represented an infringement of Chinese sovereignty.

headline: The Treaty That Could Decide the Vodafone India Tax Case
text: As the British telecommunications company Vodafone Group and India’s finance ministry edge ever closer to a full-blown confrontation over taxes related to Vodafone’s $11.1 billion acquisition in India, a key issue may be the India-Netherlands Bilateral Investment Treaty, signed between the two governments in 1995.

headline: Still Recognizable Without Pigtails
text: A DECADE ago Spencer Kayden stole New Yorkers’ black, black hearts as Little Sally in the dystopian musical “Urinetown.” But shortly after making her big Broadway splash she disappeared from the East Coast altogether. Now Ms. Kayden is back in New York, and more important, back on Broadway.

headline: Biden Got Out ‘Over His Skis,’ Says Obama
text: President Obama gently chided his vice president for forcing his hand on the issue of gay marriage, but said he would have gotten around to declaring his own change of mind anyway before going to the Democratic National Convention in North Carolina.

headline: Leading Off: An Ovechkin Sighting
text: For almost the entire season, it has been tempting to request Alex Ovechkin’s picture be placed on the side of a milk carton. Sure, someone was skating around wearing a No. 8 Capitals jersey. He would score occasionally, celebrate wildly and flash that gap-toothed smile, but this was not the Ovechkin anyone knew. That Ovechkin was a force of nature, would score 38 goals (his 78-game total) in a dream, would take 303 shots (more than 200 fewer than in his best season) before the trade deadline, would rack up 26 penalty minutes (also a career low) in a month.

headline: UniCredit Profit Rises on Debt Buyback
text: LONDON – UniCredit reported strong profit for the first quarter on Thursday, with net income rising 12 percent, to 914 million euros ($1.2 billion). Investors welcomed the gains, sending shares of the Italian bank up 7.8 percent in late afternoon trading.

headline: CUNY to Open Institute Devoted to Mexican Studies
text: For many New Yorkers, the growth of the Mexican immigrant population has been not unlike the experience of falling asleep at the start of a winter storm and waking up to find the city covered in a foot of snow.

headline: Goldman Moves to Comply With Volcker Rule
text: Goldman Sachs, moving to comply with a new rule aimed at reducing the riskiness of the country’s big banks, recently sold some of its investments in hedge funds.

headline: Business Day Live | May 10, 2012
text: James B. Stewart on what Europe's structural problems mean for the United States; Facebook's network of tech tycoons; and Cisco as a proxy for the world's economy.

headline: More Families Report Having No Savings at All
text: New research from the University of Michigan finds that while the average savings rate has grown since 2008, the proportion of families who say they have no savings also has grown over the last two years.

headline: Alison Bechdel Talks About Drawing, Writing, Family and Shame
text: Alison Bechdel’s graphic-novel memoir “Fun Home” (2006) was an acclaimed look at the life of her gay father, who she believes committed suicide by stepping in front of a truck soon after Ms. Bechdel told her parents she was a lesbian. Her new book, “Are You My Mother?,” tells the story of her efforts, through therapy and reading, to understand her relationship to her mother. In The New York Times Book Review, Katie Roiphe called it “as complicated, brainy, inventive and satisfying as the finest prose memoirs.” The Times’s Dwight Garner was less enthused. He found the book’s tone “therapized and flat,” and said that Ms. Bechdel’s mother was “a kinder, less complex, less riveting figure” than her father. In a recent interview via e-mail, Ms. Bechdel discussed the art of drawing psychoanalysis, the “mild virus” of shame, her influences and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Romney Apologizes After Reports of Bullying Emerge
text: An in-depth examination of Mitt Romney’s teenage years at a prestigious private prep school describes an episode in which he bullied a fellow student and portrays Mr. Romney as a prankster who pushed boundaries. After the report came out, Mr. Romney on Thursday apologized for behavior that might have hurt anyone.

headline: Knicks’ Subplots Remain Unsettled
text: Watching the Knicks play the Miami Heat five times over 12 days was competitively akin to the famous sword fight in “Monty Python and the Holy Grail,” when King Arthur hacks off the left arm of the Black Knight and says, “Now stand aside, worthy adversary.”

headline: Amazon Program Offers ‘Harry Potter’ Series to Kindle Owners

text: Images from Tim Burton’s comedy starring Johnny Depp.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/10: Biased Bias at Gatwick, and Using Your Online Friends for Travel
text: Air Travel Still Robust A trade group is predicting that air travel this summer will match last year’s level: 206.2 million passengers in the June to August peak flying season. The number would be a slight decline from the record high, set in 2007. (Wall Street Journal)

headline: Watch Out for a Falling ‘Spider-Man’! ‘Forbidden Broadway’ Is Returning
text: “Forbidden Broadway,” the long-running satirical revue of the artistic highs and overacting lows of New York theater, ended in March 2009 with more than 9,750 performances to its credit, after creator Gerard Alessandrini decided that “Shrek the Musical,” “Guys and Dolls” and other Broadway fare at the time weren’t worth spoofing. But with critically derided shows like “Ghost the Musical” and “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” now on the boards, Mr. Alessandrini couldn’t resist a comeback.

headline: For Huskies and Their Fans, a Different Picture for Next Season
text: When Connecticut announced this week that its women’s basketball broadcast rights would move to SportsNet NY (SNY) from its longtime home on Connecticut Public Broadcasting, the moved seemed logical enough in that the Huskies covet more attention in the New York market. But the broadcaster it left behind, which has been showing Huskies women’s games for 18 years and started long before they became a dynasty in their sport, was saddened by the move.

headline: An Online Tool For Gauging the Relative Value of Efficient Cars
text: Regular readers know I’m a big fan of university courses in which students not only learn by doing, but also contribute to sustainable human advancement through their learning. I’ve seen great examples at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Duke University, Pace University (of course!) and now the University of California, Santa Barbara.

headline: Doubling of Stafford Interest Rates May Cost Only $6 More a Month
text: The Senate may have failed to act on a bill that would have prevented the doubling of interest rates for some student loans, but the inaction may not matter much. According to two experts on financial aid, if the interest rate on Stafford loans doubles to 6.8 percent this summer, as scheduled, students would pay only about $6 more a month for one year of loans.

headline: Concussions May Be More Severe in Girls and Young Athletes
text: During a soccer game two years ago, Megan Wirtz, a goalie for her high school team, was bending down to pick up a ball when an opposing player mistakenly kicked her in the face.

headline: Conan O’Brien to Appear on Letterman Show
text: Two late-night hosts with something in common — they both lost the “Tonight” show to Jay Leno — will meet for a conversation on the air next week when Conan O’Brien visits David Letterman’s show.

headline: For Red Bulls, It’s All About the Result
text: HARRISON, N.J. — What do you call an M.L.S. team that has played the past few games without its two highly paid designated players and has won three straight by identical 1-0 scores?

headline: ‘Chaplin’ Musical Tramps Its Way to Broadway
text: The silence has been broken: “Chaplin,” a new musical about the life of the comic performer and cinema pioneer Charlie Chaplin, has found a Broadway home. The production, which features music and lyrics by Christopher Curtis and a book by Mr. Curtis and Thomas Meehan (“Annie,” “The Producers” and “Hairspray”), will be presented at the Barrymore Theater, where it will begin previews on Aug. 21 and have its opening night on Sept. 10, its press representatives said on Thursday. “Chaplin” will be directed and choreographed by Warren Carlyle, who had those duties on “Hugh Jackman, Back on Broadway” and also choreographed the recent Broadway revival of “Follies.”

headline: Prince of Wales, Weatherman of Scotland
text: Most of the world may know him as Charles, Prince of Wales, but the heir to the British throne is also known, in the land north of Hadrian’s Wall, as the Duke of Rothesay, Earl of Carrick, Baron of Renfrew, Lord of the Isles and Prince and Great Steward of Scotland.
