text: Nothing influences presidential elections more than the direction of the economy in the months before Election Day.

headline: Drink and Thrive
text: Everyone has an “if only I could go back and tell my younger self…” moment. Some would undo regrettable career, romance, even fashion choices. I would teach my younger self how to make a decent drink.

headline: Motorcyclist Hopes Fans Follow Him to Nascar
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Travis Pastrana crawled through the window of his No. 99 Toyota, kissed his wife and flashed his magnetic smile. Even though he had placed 22nd in his Nascar Nationwide Series debut last month, he was pleased that he had not wrecked his car or anyone else’s.

headline: Partisanship Is Not a Bipartisan Problem
text: In my post yesterday on Tuesday’s voting, I mentioned that Richard Lugar lost the Indiana Senate primary to Richard Mourdock, a radical right-winger. I didn’t have time to write at length about his thoughtful farewell letter, but it’s worth revisiting as a sort of treatise on the state of politics.

headline: Kings Headed to Unlikely Western Conference Final
text: Forgive hockey fans in Los Angeles if they seem a little confused right now. It’s been nearly 20 years since the Kings have done this well in the playoffs and shown this much promise. The eighth-seeded Kings are in the Western Conference finals, thanks to impressive wins over Vancouver Canucks in five games and a sweep of the St. Louis Blues. Up next is the equally surprising Phoenix Coyotes, the West’s third seed.

headline: Video: Cisco as a Bellwether
text: Quentin Hardy discusses the latest earnings report from Cisco Systems, and what it says about the health of the technology industry.

headline: Regulator Approves New Exchange Rules, but Delays Others
text: Some of the nation’s largest exchanges face stricter oversight under a plan approved on Thursday, a move that came even as federal regulators agreed to delay bolder plans to scrutinize the $700 trillion derivatives market.

headline: Mary Higgins Clark: By the Book
text: What book is on your night stand now?

headline: Obama’s Stance Is Significant, if Not Bold Leadership
text: When they look back 50 years from now, historians may well describe President Obama’s declaration on same-sex marriage as righteous or inspiring or, as my colleague Adam Nagourney put it this morning, a watershed moment. What they probably won’t call it is a case of bold political leadership.

headline: Gibbs and Rove Debate Gay Marriage Announcement
text: Robert Gibbs, a top adviser to President Obama, said on Thursday that it was unclear how the president’s endorsement of same-sex marriage would play out in the election, calling it a “a 50-50 issue at best.”

headline: Relatives of Dissident Said to Face Harassment
text: BEIJING — Family members and lawyers representing Chen Guangcheng are facing increased harassment despite an international deal brokered to help Mr. Chen, a legal activist who escaped house arrest last month and sought refuge in the American Embassy here.

headline: Photo Replay: May 10
text: The day in sports included the European women’s artistic gymnastics championships in Brussels and the men’s ice hockey world championships in Helsinki.

headline: Have You Seen This Naked Woman Before?
text: These pictures by Terry O’Neill, from a current exhibit at the Morrison Hotel Gallery in the SoHo section of Manhattan, celebrates 50 years of photography of the Rolling Stones. The photos caught our eye recently, and also raised some questions.

headline: An Endless Quest for Weight-Loss Pills
text: Right after residency, I took a summer job in a family practice in a beach town on Long Island, covering Fridays and weekends for the regular doctors. The setting was quite different from my training in an urban hospital. It was a bit of a culture shock to go from a world of critically ill hospitalized patients to an outpatient suburban setting where most weekend appointments were for sore throats, rashes and sprained ankles. But I quickly became a pro at Lyme disease identification.

headline: Hot Spot | The Scotch
text: Located in St. James, London’s newest and coolest night spot, the Scotch has already hosted the likes of Kate Moss, Jay Jopling, Stella McCartney and Scarlett Johansson. Not surprisingly, the club has a tough door policy. I was given a password on my recent visit: “punchy,” which I mistakenly morphed into “jumpy.” The doorman was not amused.

headline: Using Terror Charges to Stifle Independent Reporting
text: Friday 10:02 a.m. | Updated Prosecutors in the eastern African nation of Burundi are seeking a life sentence for 23 journalists, including one working for Radio France International, who have been charged with “participating in acts of terrorism,” according to Reporters Without Borders and local journalists.

headline: A Revamping of Bing in the Battle for Search Engine Supremacy
text: BELLEVUE, Wash. — When Facebook goes public in the coming weeks, there will be a lot of winners. Among them is one of the stalwarts of the tech industry, Microsoft, which has a small stake in the company.

headline: Afghan Police In Spotlight After Foiling Taliban Strike
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An attack by six Taliban infiltrators in the eastern province of Paktika on Thursday killed three police officers but was put down before it reached the government offices that were its target, Afghan officials said.

headline: Live Updates on Egypt’s Presidential Debate
text: Two of the leading candidates to be Egypt’s next president squared off in a televised debate on Thursday night in Cairo, and The Lede reported on the clash between Abdel Moneim Aboul Fotouh, a former leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, and Amr Moussa, a former diplomat under Hosni Mubarak, as it unfolded. The live video of the event has now ended, but readers can still dip into the stream of updates from Times reporters in Cairo below, and scroll through highlights of the discussion on Twitter in the widget to the right of this post.

headline: With Creative Work Still to Be Done, ‘Flashdance’ Now Eyeing Broadway in 2013
text: The Broadway-bound, $12 million musical adaptation of “Flashdance,” based on the 1983 film about a working-class welder who dreams of becoming a dancer, is now aiming to open in spring 2013 instead of fall 2012, one of the lead producers said on Thursday. The producer, Marc Routh, cited a lack of available Broadway theaters in the fall, though he also noted that more creative work needed to be done on “Flashdance.”

headline: Tour Rookie Gets Unusual, and Delayed, Entry into Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. – As the first alternate at this week’s Players Championship, the golfer Brian Harman spent Thursday morning at T.P.C. Sawgrass hoping for a phone call that never came — until it was too late.

headline: Obama Campaign Pushes the Issue of Gay Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. apologized to President Obama for hastening him into an endorsement of same-sex marriage, several people briefed on the exchange said Thursday, even as the White House sought to capitalize in the campaign on Mr. Obama’s long-awaited expression of support.

headline: How Compatible Are Rival E-Readers?
text: 3:04 p.m. | Updated Adding information about a Calibre plug-in.

headline: Hypermiling Taylors Set Fuel-Economy Record in Volkswagen Passat TDI
text: John and Helen Taylor, the Australian hypermilers who made news in the United States in 2009 by averaging 67.9 miles per gallon in a tour of the 48 contiguous states, recently added another record to their considerable tally. The couple drove 1,626.1 miles in a 2012 Volkswagen Passat TDI SE from Houston to Sterling, Va., breaking the Guinness record for the longest drive in a passenger car on a single tank of diesel fuel.

headline: City’s Hispanic Makeup Shifts as Dominicans Leave and Mexicans Arrive
text: Reversing a trend that had held for decades, more Dominicans left New York City than arrived since 2000, a new census analysis found. And a surge of Mexican immigrants nearly bumped them ahead of South Americans into third place among Hispanic groups.

headline: ‘Cougar Town’ Moving to TBS
text: After three seasons on ABC “Cougar Town” is shifting to TBS, the comedy-centric cable channel that has been trying to promote a slate of original sitcoms.

headline: Lawsuit Says Sheriff Discriminated Against Latinos
text: PHOENIX — A federal lawsuit asserting a “pattern of unlawful discrimination” by law enforcement officials here claims that Latinos at the county jail were often referred to as “stupid” or addressed with a coarse ethnic slur. It also says that an e-mail circulated among jail officers contained a photograph of a Chihuahua in a swimsuit, over the words, “A rare photo of a Mexican Navy Seal.”

headline: Finding Beauty in Old Things
text: Writing in Wednesday’s Times about the Repair Cafe in Amsterdam, where broken things find a new life, reminded me of a 2010 magazine story I did about Christiane Högner, a German designer based in Brussels.

headline: Board Room
text: At the New York Surf Film Festival last fall, as he took in the world’s latest surf movies amid the urban canyons of Lower Manhattan, the San Diego-based filmmaker and longtime surfer Pierce Michael Kavanagh could not shake a question: With its rich surf culture and history, why did San Diego not have a surf film festival of its own?

headline: Yemeni Camel Jumpers
text: As western Yemen rests of the brink of revolution, poor villagers hold on to an enduring custom.

headline: Tea Party Group to Endorse Brunner in Missouri Senate Primary
text: Of all the vulnerable Democratic incumbents in the Senate, none might be more endangered than Missouri’s Claire McCaskill, but the one bright spot in her uphill climb toward re-election has been the disarray on the Republican side, where three Senate hopefuls have battled for advantage for months.

headline: WIC Works, But Enrollment Is Down
text: Economic hardship means families have to make tough choices among basic needs. Rent, mortgage, food, heat, health care — when what’s coming in is far less than what needs to go out, parents are inevitably stressed. Both the economic needs and the impact on parents are associated with health problems for children — economic struggles, in particular, increase the risk that young children will suffer from delayed development and nutritional deficiencies, and living with a depressed caregiver additionally undermines their well-being.

headline: For Atlético Madrid, a Winning Approach
text: Atlético Madrid beat Athletic Bilbao, 3-0, on Wednesday in an all-Spanish final to win the Europa League. For Rob Hughes, the game was not only a battle of tactics but also one of philosophies in building a team: a team full of Basque players against one filled with imports from the world transfer market. Read his article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Lorelei Is Back, Head Over Carats
text: Does gold digging qualify as an official Olympic sport this year? (Hey, since synchronized swimming, you never know.) If it does, there’s no question as to who will be bringing home the gold medals this summer. Yes, folks, the legendary Lorelei Lee has re-entered the ring, and she’s got her mojo back. Anyone who would stand between her and the crown — er, tiara — should prepare to fall.

headline: TimesCast | Large Explosions in Syria
text: Two powerful car bombs exploded outside a key military intelligence compound in Damascus on Thursday, the largest such attack since the uprising began 14 months ago.

headline: Homeless Youths See Dreams on a Broadway Stage
text: Shortly after Wednesday night’s performance of “Newsies the Musical” at the Nederlander Theater, Capathia Jenkins made a rather unusual curtain call, returning to the stage to bring together two audiences for whom she plays a similar role.

headline: The Caucus Click: Lauper and Pelosi
text: Representative Nancy Pelosi, second from right, met with the singer Cyndi Lauper, second from left, and others on Thursday in Washington, to discuss gay rights advocacy and same-sex marriage.

headline: Bank to Pay $202 Million To Settle Suit On Mortgages
text: Deutsche Bank agreed on Thursday to pay the federal government more than $200 million to settle accusations that it knowingly misled the Department of Housing and Urban Development about the quality of mortgages that later defaulted.

headline: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Backs Preventive Use of H.I.V. Drug
text: SILVER SPRING, Md. — A drug already used to treat H.I.V. infection should also be approved to prevent it, an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday. The recommendation is the first time that government advisers have advocated giving antiviral medicine to healthy people who might be exposed through sexual activity to the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Marriage Postscript
text: On the morning (well, the day) after President Obama’s announcement of support for same-sex marriage, many people are asking: so how will that change things? Is this the dawn of, or precursor to, the ability for gay and lesbian couples to marry anywhere in the United States?

headline: Mitt Romney, Reformed Bully?
text: Mitt Romney apologized, sort of, after The Washington Post reported that while he was in high school, he bullied a “soft-spoken” student “perpetually teased for his nonconformity and presumed homosexuality” with “bleached-blond hair that draped over one eye.”

headline: In 2 Sudans, Familiarity With Path to War
text: MAYOM WEL, South Sudan — On a recent blistering afternoon, this village danced in an open field. Women sashayed, hoisting chairs over their heads. Barefoot children scampered. Old men, with skin as dry and cracked as the bark of a savanna tree, jabbed rifles toward the burning sky.

headline: Why They Bully
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Mother’s Day, Social Media Allows a More Personalized Ad Pitch
text: Mothers have long taught their children to be sociable. For marketers seeking to cash in on Mother’s Day 2012, the focus is on social, as in social media.

headline: A Clay Vessel
text: To the Editor:

headline: White’s Web
text: To the Editor:

headline: Private Equity Explained, in a Cartoon Video
text: The 1980s are officially over, as far as private equity is concerned.

headline: Loeb Says Yahoo Quietly Set Record Date for Annual Meeting
text: Third Point said on Thursday that Yahoo had told banks, brokers and other institutions that the record date of its meeting had been set for May 17, giving shareholders until Monday to buy shares and settle their trades.

headline: TimesCast Politics | May 10, 2012
text: Republicans respond to President Obama’s support for gay marriage | African-Americans in North Carolina | New economic data offer insight into electoral outcomes.

headline: Early Sendak Print Is Uncovered in a 1947 Yearbook
text: The late Maurice Sendak’s first professional illustrations, according to The New York Times and others, were for a physics textbook called “Atomics for the Millions” that came out in 1947.

headline: Last-Minute Mother’s Day | In Defense of Scented Candles
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Theater Talkback: Live and Laughing
text: I have to admit I approached the Music Box Theater, where the buzzed-about London import “One Man, Two Guvnors” opened on Broadway recently, with some trepidation, an anxious sense that the giddy delights of this updated version of an Italian comedy would leave me stone cold, as farces often do.

headline: Obama Girls Influence the President — Again
text: In describing his personal “evolution” on same-sex marriage, President Obama cited the importance of private, dinner-table conversations with his daughters — the latest example of him mentioning his children in public.

headline: When Disaster Strikes the Nursing Home
text: As hailstones the size of golf balls beat thunderously on the roof of the nursing home, an urgent announcement rang out from the loudspeakers.

headline: Street Bookseller's Stock Confiscated
text: The vendor had much of his inventory removed after selling at Columbus Avenue near 68th Street for nearly a dozen years.

headline: The Capitals Have Found a Way Not to Go Away
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — In previous postseasons, the Washington Capitals have often played the patsy.

headline: Once Shorting Subprime, Bass Now Bullish on Mortgage Bonds
text: LAS VEGAS — Kyle Bass, a Texas hedge fund investor who profited from shorting the mortgage market amid the financial crisis, has had a change of heart.

headline: United States vs. Joseph M. Arpaio
text: In a 32-page civil rights lawsuit, the Justice Department contended that Mr. Arpaio’s campaign against illegal immigration had resulted in a “pattern or practice of unlawful discrimination” aimed at Latinos.

headline: Hip, or About to Break a Hip?
text: Is a 45 year-old pursuing a dangerous sport like skateboarding embarrassing and risky or inspiring and life-affirming?

headline: Painted Maya Walls Reveal Calendar Writing
text: Hacking through jungle growth and clearing away rubble, archaeologists made their way to excavate a house buried at the edge of ruins of a large Maya city in the remote Petén lowlands of northeastern Guatemala. It turned out to have been the studio for royal scribes with a taste for art and a devotion to the heavens as the source of calculations for the ancient culture’s elaborate calendars.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Numbers Slide
text: While the ratings for Fox’s “American Idol” have held steady in recent weeks as almost every other network program declined, that was not the case on Wednesday night as the singing competition hit some of its lowest numbers of the season for a performance episode. According to Nielsen data the two-hour show averaged 16.1 million total viewers, which tied a season low, and slid to a season low in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

headline: Bell Chooses Health Over More Football
text: A month ago, the free agent offensive lineman Jacob Bell signed a one-year deal to continue his eight-year N.F.L. career with the Cincinnati Bengals. But even though he feels healthy, the rising concern about head injuries coupled with the recent suicide of the venerated linebacker Junior Seau prompted Bell to reconsider, and this week he announced his retirement.

headline: Is That Credit Score a FICO, or a FICO 8?
text: It’s difficult enough already to grasp the nuances of consumer credit scoring. So it doesn’t help when industry players are fuzzy about just which score they’re talking about.

headline: Would a Special Counsel Help or Hurt the MF Global Inquiry?
text: Representative Michael G. Grimm has drafted a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., asking for the appointment of a new prosecutor to investigate the collapse of MF Global and $1.6 billion in customer money that went missing in its final days.

headline: Facebook's Network of Tech Tycoons
text: May 10, 2012 — One of Facebook’s lasting legacies may just be the diaspora of Internet and technology entrepreneurs it has created.

headline: Slavic History in Art  Hangs in Prague
text: The “Slav Epic,” a 20-painting cycle depicting the history of the Slavic people by the Art Nouveau master Alfons Mucha, is settling in for a two-year run at Prague’s Trade Fair Palace. Following a bitter legal dispute over custody of these historic canvases, “Slav Epic: Myth, History and Vision” finally opened on Thursday.

headline: It Beats Having a Space Alien’s Child
text: One of the bummers about having children, Anne Enright declares in “Making Babies,” her excellent memoir, is that it “can interfere with your drinking for up to 15 years; first because you don’t want to drop them, and subsequently because you don’t want to make them cry.”

headline: The 20-Minute Workout
text: Gretchen Reynolds, the Phys Ed columnist, on the science of high-intensity interval training, or H.I.I.T., which scientists are finding can be as effective as longer endurance training.

headline: Quietly, Lazard’s Ex-C.E.O. Returns to the Firm
text: It was a little over a decade ago that William R. Loomis Jr. stepped down as the chief executive of Lazard, having served in that role for only a year.

headline: U.S. v. Arpaio
text: The Justice Department is finally suing Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., accusing him of civil-rights violations, discriminatory policing and abuse of power. The government’s complaint against the man who calls himself “America’s Toughest Sheriff” reads like an indictment of a Southern sheriff in the time of Jim Crow, only in this time and place the racism and violence are directed at Latino immigrants and citizens.

headline: The 20-Minute Workout Video
text: Instead of asking how much exercise we need, some scientists are looking into how little we can do and still get maximal health and fitness benefits.

headline: D.I.Y. Biology, on the Wings of the Mockingjay
text: Genetically modified organisms are not wildly popular these days, except one: a fictional bird that is central to the hugely popular movie and book trilogy “The Hunger Games.” That’s the mockingjay, a cross between a mockingbird and a genetically engineered spy bird called a jabberjay.

headline: UBS Hires Global Co-Head of Real Estate
text: UBS said on Thursday that it has hired Peter Baccile as a joint global head of real estate, leisure and lodging investment banking. Mr. Baccile, who was most recently at JPMorgan Chase, will lead the UBS real estate group with Jackson Hsieh and will report to Matthew Grounds and Simon Warshaw.

headline: A Long Trip for Iona Water Polo
text: After winning its second straight M.A.A.C. title, Iona College (24-11) is headed back to the N.C.A.A. women’s water polo championship.

headline: Greeks Revel in Torch Lighting. Again.
text: Perhaps the real talent the Greeks have for the Olympic torch lighting is making every one seem like an unforgettable, sacred, once-in-a-lifetime event featuring high priestesses instead of something they stage every two years. With actresses.

headline: After Fiery Speech, Voting Rights Amendment Is Pulled
text: Sometimes during lengthy floor debates on bills, interesting things happen in the witching hours.

headline: Hyderabad, India
text: Where the colors make your eyes dance and the food makes your tongue sweat.

headline: 36 Hours in Hyderabad, India
text: SITUATED in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, Hyderabad is a juxtaposition of old and new unlike any other city in India. While Microsoft, Google and other technology giants have offices in the glass and steel structures in the district known as Cyberabad, the history of this more than 400-year-old city is just as alluring as destinations like Jaipur and Agra, with sites like the 13th-century Golconda Fort, once home to the famous Kohinoor diamond, and the iconic Charminar monument in Hyderabad’s teeming Old City. In the past, Hyderabad was often overlooked as a tourism destination. But in recent years, sleek hotels, restaurants and night spots that cater to the 20- and 30-somethings working in the information technology industry have been attracting jet-setters from around the world who come to discover the past and experience the rapidly evolving present.

headline: House Approves $310 Billion in Cuts, but Passage in the Senate Is Very Unlikely
text: WASHINGTON — The House approved sweeping legislation on Thursday to cut $310 billion from the deficit over the next decade — much of it from programs for the poor — and shift some of that savings to the Pentagon to stave off automatic military spending cuts scheduled for next year.

headline: A McDonald’s Big Enough for Olympus
text: Tom Spiel acquired his first McDonald’s franchise in 1966: store No. 855, in Riverside, Calif. Since his wife, Candace, pushed to remodel it a couple years ago, their restaurant has become, as Keith O’Brien wrote in last weekend’s magazine, the epitome of how McDonald’s has been rebuilding its image — by making customers feel better about eating at McDonald’s. Hence, solar panels on the carport, eco-friendly L.E.D. lights in the ceiling panels, totally new décor. A company executive for the Southern California region put it this way: “You want to be seen in an environment that replicates the personality you want.”

headline: Keeping Schiap Small
text: Once Elsa Schiaparelli got going, she didn’t quit. She was enormously innovative from the start of her career, in 1927, as visitors to the new Schiaparelli-Prada exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will readily see. She created severely chic suits as well as witty party clothes and accessories for at least two generations of irreverent women.

headline: Poulter Makes Himself at Home in Florida
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. – Ian Poulter is from England, but he looked at home Thursday at T.P.C. Sawgrass, shooting a seven-under-par 65 to take the early lead in the first round of the Players Championship.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Risky Business’ Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Artifacts | Women’s Work
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Bear Grylls’s Adventure Tales
text: BEAR GRYLLS knew it had been a bad idea when he took a step and his foot sank out of sight. Everyone had told him how dangerous the harbor near his childhood home on the Isle of Wight could be. At low tide the “quick mud” could suck a person down. He tried to free himself, but the struggle only took him farther down. By the time the mud reached his neck, he could hear it make a sucking sound. Then, almost instinctively, he found a solution.

headline: A Painter Stripped Bare
text: According to many critics, Lucian Freud started making great paintings only after he let go of drawing: abandoning flat, crisply outlined figures for massively fleshy nudes nourished by a full brush. The quietly ravishing “Lucian Freud Drawings,” at Acquavella Galleries, gives Freud’s works on paper a chance to speak for themselves, beginning with his childhood sketches and ending with the last etching plate he touched.

headline: Clip: ‘The Color Wheel’
text: A scene from "The Color Wheel," directed and co-written by Alex Ross Perry.

headline: Clip: ‘Elena’
text: A scene from the drama “Elena,” directed by Andrei Zvyagintsev.

headline: Germany Signals It Will Permit Small Steps to Promote Growth in Europe
text: BERLIN — The outlines of a potential compromise in Europe’s battle between deficit-cutting austerity and policies to promote growth have begun to take shape. The question is whether the kind of cautious measures palatable to Germany, austerity’s champion, will do enough to combat the Continent’s imbalances and do it soon enough to put its weaker countries on more solid economic footing.

headline: ‘Lucian Freud Drawings’
text: An ambitious and revealing show of Lucian Freud’s drawings at Acquavella Galleries spans eight decades of his life.

headline: Christie Vetoes Health Insurance Exchange
text: In a swipe at President Obama’s signature health care legislation, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey vetoed on Thursday an online marketplace that the Legislature created to help residents and small businesses buy health insurance.

headline: For Devils’ Finances, the Playoffs Are a Definite Plus
text: The Devils may be on shaky ice financially, but they are getting a lift from their deep playoff run.

headline: Fifty Shades of Red
text: My daughter is engaged to a wonderful young man. We just met his parents. In a candid moment, his mother shared tremendous excitement over the “Fifty Shades of Grey” trilogy. As a feminist, I find the books’ focus on submissive women in sadomasochistic situations offensive. But I’d like to build a good relationship with my daughter’s future mother-in-law. She’s been asking what I think of the books. Can I share my views without condemning hers?

headline: Revis Is Reserved on His Contract, and Candid About Belichick
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Amidst speculation that he might hold out for the second time in three years, Jets Pro Bowl cornerback Darrell Revis stayed away from talking too much about his contract.

headline: Daughter and Mother, Chasing Adulthood
text: On one wall of her bedroom Ansiedad (Cierra Ramirez), the teenage heroine of Patricia Riggen’s “Girl in Progress,” has an outline of the stages of her planned coming of age. Derived from a longish montage’s worth of research, the chart is also a knowing encyclopedia of teen-movie clichés. Ansiedad is a bright Seattle high school student who looks young for her age even though she is in some ways wise beyond her years. (Ms. Ramirez turned 17 this year.) She is determined to grow up fast, and to get away from her mother, Grace (Eva Mendes), who also may have some growing up to do.

headline: In Europe, Entry Closes on Start-Ups With Their Foot in the Door
text: FRANKFURT — When Next Alternative, a Canadian start-up, wanted to raise money a few years ago, it opted for a listing on a new offshoot of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. As part of the bourse’s so-called First Quotation Board, the six-month-old start-up could tap investors for capital without the higher costs, stricter disclosure requirements and other regulatory hurdles of an offering on the main exchange.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Brain Surgery Tweets, and Fiorina to Zuckerberg
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. See more here.

headline: Never Mom Enough
text: Time magazine asks “Are You Mom Enough?” But any mother knows that’s never been a yes or no question.

headline: Before Whitney’s Move, a Koons Retrospective
text: The Whitney Museum of American Art has no intention of leaving quietly. Before heading to its new, considerably larger home in the meatpacking district of Manhattan in 2015, its final exhibition will be as much a first as it is a last. The museum is planning to present a Jeff Koons retrospective that will fill all of its Madison Avenue home, with the exception of the fifth-floor permanent exhibition galleries.

headline: Nadal Loses on Madrid’s Blue Clay After Complaining About It
text: MADRID — Rafael Nadal remains the king of clay, but not of blue clay.

headline: Mere Society Paintings? Look Again
text: If, by some fluke of metaphysics, the last four decades of Édouard Vuillard’s long, prolific and rewarding career were erased from collective memory, he still would not be forgotten. Before the age of 30 he made some of the most beguiling paintings of fin de siècle Paris: intimate, compact, brushy pictures of his mother and sister in the apartment he shared with them and the dressmaking shop they worked in. Painting with special attention to wallpaper and fabric patterns, he made people almost dissolve into atomized, flattened surfaces, anticipating a century that would pulverize into air everything once taken for solid.

headline: ’30 Rock’ Will Return, but Only for 13 Episodes, NBC Says
text: There will be more of the Emmy-winning comedy “30 Rock,” but not a whole lot more.

headline: Video: Facebook’s Diaspora
text: Somini Sengupta and Peter Lattman discuss the generation of Internet and technology entrepreneurs that Facebook has created, and how that might end up being one of the company’s lasting legacies.

headline: Speaking of Fashion
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art won’t have to stay open till midnight to accommodate crowds for “Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations,” this year’s Costume Institute extravaganza, mainly because the show isn’t all that extravagant, certainly not on the order of the Alexander McQueen exhibition last year.

headline: Justin Timberlake’s Latest Project? Pillows
text: These days, fame has a tendency to metastasize, producing strange outgrowths that are often called “collaborations.” Is it a surprise, then, that Justin Timberlake — who has already ventured into fashion and Memphis-style barbecue — would follow in Lenny Kravitz’s footsteps and design a home collection? Probably not. But it is refreshing that the entertainer’s enthusiasm for home décor appears to be rather genuine. “I do love a stripe,” he confessed to The Moment on Wednesday, while showing off the first parts of his HomeMint collection: a series of rather anodyne throw pillows.

headline: Saratoga Season for New York City Ballet May Shrink
text: Financial pressures may force New York City Ballet to reduce its Saratoga season to one week instead of two, which would be the second downsizing in five years, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Shopping for Loans Online
text: SHOPPING for a mortgage online can save borrowers a lot of time, and possibly money if they find the right deal. But working with these so-called online marketplaces can also be overwhelming for some people, especially as the various lender offers start pouring in.

headline: ‘Every Exit Is an Entrance: 30 Years of Exit Art’: ‘30 Years of Exit Art’
text: Exit Art

headline: Anne Arnold: ‘Sculpture From Four Decades’
text: Alexandre Gallery

headline: A Fading Flower Gets Pruned, but Not Her Dialogue
text: A well-bred but heavily indebted young lady makes for a lovely social accessory, and an even lovelier extramarital scapegoat.

headline: On the Trail, Romney Not Eager to Engage on Gay Marriage Issue
text: OMAHA – Mitt Romney rarely passes on an opportunity to respond to President Obama or the actions of the White House. But that is precisely what he did here on Thursday.

headline: Rotimi Fani-Kayode: ‘Nothing to Lose’
text: The Walther Collection Project Space

headline: AOA Tribal Art Fair
text: Fletcher-Sinclair Mansion

headline: Paralysis of the Heart
text: I WAS driving my 11-year-old son, Joe, to school. It had been one of those mornings. He was singing opera and doing hip-hop moves when I needed him to put on his shoes.

headline: They Use Guns for Anger Management
text: “We’ve become a nation of slogan-saying, bile-spewing hatemongers! We’ve lost our kindness! We’ve lost our soul!” shouts Frank (Joel Murray), an aggrieved middle-aged everyman with plenty of reasons to be mad as hell.

headline: Sidewalk Bookseller Returns to Find Shop Gone
text: 7:02 p.m. | Updated Charles Mysak has become a fixture on the Upper West Side, selling his used books for nearly a dozen years on the sidewalk of Columbus Avenue near 68th Street.

headline: New Costumes at City Ballet
text: Tonight, Lincoln Center will once again be filled with stars and socialites dressed to the hilt as the New York City Ballet opens its spring season. But true fashion lovers should look not to the plaza but to the stage for the most exciting designs. In an usually fashion-focused gala, the Rodarte sisters have created the costumes for Benjamin Millepied’s new premiere and Gilles Mendel has supplied the designs for Peter Martins’s latest work. And in perhaps the most significant move, the classic costumes for Balanchine’s “Symphony in C” have been revamped with crystals by Swarovski.

headline: Ivy League Rejects Idea for Conference Basketball Tournament
text: The athletic directors of the Ivy League have turned down a proposal by its coaches for a postseason conference tournament in men’s and women’s basketball, the league said Thursday.

headline: Ceramist’s Students Keep Studio and Spirit Alive
‘Cloud City’ at the Met
text: A multipolygonal habitat of reflective stainless steel and acrylic, a new installation by Tomás Saraceno, is being assembled on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Intimacy’s Many Facets
text: The form of dance theater that the choreographer John Jasperse develops in “Fort Blossom revisited (2000/12)” is often astonishing. Watching Wednesday’s premiere, I was several times left with the sensation of having traveled to unknown terrain. The piece is an expanded 70-minute reworking of his “Fort Blossom” (2000). (We should not spend time figuring out what the title might mean.)

headline: The Books We Lie About
text: Earlier this week, an English Web site published a list of the “top books that Brits lie about reading.” It inspired us to come forward with our own list of books we’ve been less than truthful about having read. Here are some voices from our staff (names have been redacted to protect the guilty):

headline: Summoning the Spirit (and Bands) of Nightclubs Past
text: The Undead Music Festival exists to provide a collage of impressions collected on the fly. It claims no organizing principle other than the vitality of the music, most of which scans broadly as jazz: combo stuff, high-contrast and alert, shot through with forceful improvising. With shows in different pockets of the city each night, it’s not about a specific locale or scene, or isn’t supposed to be.

headline: The Fun Starts Here
text: GROWING up in the 1970s in Bloomington, Ind., Eric Zimmerman enjoyed what he described as “an amazing childhood of play.” He and friends raced around in such pursuits as Ghost in the Graveyard and Kick the Can. He recalls epic games of dodgeball. But his most vivid memories center on the games that he played with his father — the brainteasers, the wrestling matches, the pinball games at arcades. “He was a very playful person,” Mr. Zimmerman, now 42, said of his father, who died when he was 5.

headline: Hitchcock and ‘Mildred Pierce’ at Museum of Moving Image
text: If you’re like the Miser, you consider a $13 Midtown multiplex ticket a luxury. And that’s before you’ve had the privilege of overpaying for a pile of popcorn and a soda as big as your head. Double that if you’re on a date, and triple it, at least, if you want to treat your family. Factor in dinner somewhere before or after. A night in with takeout Thai and Netflix starts looking pretty sweet.

headline: Condo or Rental, It’s New in Dumbo
text: THE housing market in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn is having a busy spring, with a major condominium building opening in the 200 block of Water Street, a rental building on the same block preparing for an influx of new residents, another rental tower beginning a conversion to condos, and work starting on Two Trees Management’s latest residential project, at 30 Washington Street.

headline: Futuristic Aerie With a Park View
text: IN Tomás Saraceno’s imagination his constellation of 16 joined modules under construction on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will take off in a heavy puff of wind and float over Central Park. “The whole thing will go into orbit,” Mr. Saraceno, the Argentine artist who made it, said on a recent foggy morning.

headline: When Walkers Were Weird and Runners Few
text: ALMOST everyone calls the dirt path undulating around the Central Park reservoir the “runners’ track.” But ever since the ugly chain-link fence from the 1920s was replaced with a reproduction of the original in 2003, the path has often been crowded with walkers, dog owners and even cyclists jockeying for position. Runners resent the new arrivals on their course — but is it theirs?

headline: A Convergence of Blood, Sweat, Tears and Tchaikovsky
text: On Wednesday evening, during a particularly poignant passage of the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto, blood began pouring out of the mouth of the young violinist Hahn-Bin.

headline: Rethinking the 55-Plus Market
text: SOME would-be buyers who visit Villagio, a 55-plus housing development in South Brunswick, think they’ve arrived at the wrong place.

headline: Welcome-Home Houses
text: THEY met eight years ago at a Marine Corps combat center: Michael Roushion, 25, of Oakland, Calif., had served one tour of duty and was re-enlisting; Nicole Burnett, 18, newly graduated from Lincoln High School in Yonkers, was fulfilling her childhood dream of becoming a Marine.

headline: Pop Goes the Rhapsodist
text: “I’ve got the outfit for the party,” Rufus Wainwright sang as stage lights flashed on to reveal him and his band at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night. All were in black, wearing sunglasses, except for Mr. Wainwright, with his gold-lamé pants and shiny red shoes.

headline: Fill In the Blanks
text: BEFORE Michael Kenduck’s listing for a 10-year-old three-bedroom stucco colonial in Franklin Square officially went on the market, more than 40 potential buyers had already “walked” through. Their previews were embellished by virtual staging of their choice — by means of an interactive tour in which each visitor “painted” and “decorated” some rooms in the house (which is actually empty).

headline: Q & A
text: Tourists Flock to My Building

headline: Festivals Are the Newest Thing for New Music
text: It is springtime in New York, and festivalitis has struck again.

headline: Office Detectives
text: At my office, we were feeling a nagging concern about a candidate we were strongly considering for a position. So we decided to call someone at a company the person had listed on the résumé but had not provided a reference for. Wow, did we get earful on the person (not in a good way)! But then we weren’t sure if it was ethical to use this information in assessing the person. Of course, it was awfully hard to forget. We ultimately didn’t hire the person. NAME WITHHELD, OAKLAND

headline: Can’t Get That Place Off My Mind
text: AFTER growing up in Far Rockaway, Queens, Bruce David Martin headed for Greenwich Village. His first apartment there, in 1973, was a shared two-bedroom on the Avenue of the Americas and Bleecker Street; the rent was $185 a month. Back then he didn’t mind the noisy street.

headline: So Whose ‘Swan Lake’ Is It?
text: In ballet “classic” and “19th century” are almost synonymous. Core essences of ballet — academic virtuosity, big-theater projection, formal grace, boy-hunts-girl romantic drama and spectacular ceremony — were forged in the era of 19th-century Romanticism in ways that audiences continue to respect. A good “Giselle” or “Swan Lake” can still take us to the heart of the genre.

headline: A Portrait of the Artist as an Old Man in Love
text: Life was sweet for Picasso during his 10 years of romance and cohabitation with Françoise Gilot, from 1943 to 1953. Or so it would seem, judging by “Picasso and Françoise Gilot: Paris-Vallauris, 1943-1953,” a wonderful exhibition at Gagosian Gallery. The Picasso of these years — he was in his 60s and early 70s — seems to revel in the joys of family and domesticity. Gone are the moonstruck years with Marie-Thérèse Walter and the violently conflicted ones with Dora Maar. The crazy-old-man last act is yet to come. Looking at pictures here of his young children Claude and Paloma at play, you can imagine yourself seeing through the eyes of a loving, benevolent father — who just happens to be the most inventive artist of the 20th century.

headline: Stonewall in the Valley
text: As far as Civil War engagements go, the Battle of McDowell, which took place on May 8, 1862, in Virginia’s Shenandoah Valley, was relatively small — a few hundred casualties on both sides, out of just under 13,000 combatants. But the Confederate victory marked the beginning of one of the war’s most important chapters: the Shenandoah Valley campaign, led by Maj. Gen. Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson.

headline: In Beverly Hills, Preservation Gains a Toehold
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Lies, Damned Lies and Literature
text: The thud of a volume of Proust hitting the ground is among one of the first hints that the talented Chilean director Cristián Jiménez might be up to something far more narratively ambitious than it may initially seem in “Bonsái.” A low-key, misleadingly desultory story about love, art and memory, this movie even cites the opening lines from “Swann’s Way,” the first volume of “In Search of Lost Time.” Sometimes on waking, the narrator explains, while realizing that he’s been dreaming about what he had been reading before falling asleep, his thoughts “run into a channel of their own, until I myself seemed actually to have become the subject of my book.”

headline: These Crime Solvers May Yet Kill Each Other
text: The USA Network’s motto is “Characters Welcome.” Apparently they’re especially welcome if they resemble Oscar Madison and Felix Unger. Already stocked with “Odd Couple” knockoffs in “Psych” and “White Collar,” USA on Friday adds to its inventory “Common Law,” another comic crime-fighting show about mismatched partners.

headline: Movie Listings for may 11-17
text: Movies

headline: Theater Listings for May 11-17
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Detours on the Road to a Family Reunion
text: The Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda — best known for “Nobody Knows,” about four young brothers and sisters forced to survive on their own after their mother abandons them — has such an extraordinarily delicate manner with children that his approach can feel like a code of ethics, a declaration of honesty toward these often badly used and exploited performers. The gentleness of his approach, his stylistic unobtrusiveness and the way that children open up in front of his camera are among the subtle pleasures in his latest film, “I Wish,” a quiet, seemingly rambling story about two exceptionally capable brothers who have been separated by their parents’ bad marriage.

headline: Pop/Rock for May 11-17
text: Pop

headline: Under the Spell of a Bombshell
text: David Rousseau (Jean-Paul Rouve), the amateur gumshoe who traipses through the snow in Gérald Hustache-Mathieu’s sardonic neo-noir, “Nobody Else but You,” is a successful detective novelist drawn to a tiny French town near the Swiss border. As he navigates the icy roads of a place nicknamed Little Siberia, José Feliciano’s version of “California Dreamin’ ” plays on the car radio. And in a way this French film is a Southern California dream of the sort concocted by James Ellroy in “L.A. Confidential” but removed to Europe and put in a deep freeze.

headline: Cashman Testifies About McNamee at Clemens Trial
text: WASHINGTON — Roger Clemens must have felt a little love come his way Thursday at his federal perjury trial when Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, unabashedly praised his work habits, his leadership skills and his competitiveness.

headline: Jazz Listings for May 11-17
text: Jazz

headline: Inside ‘Tonight You’re Mine’
text: In Anatomy of a Scene, David Mackenzie narrates a scene from his film, which was shot at a Scotland music festival.

headline: Did the News Media Drive the Gay Marriage Debate?
text: On the Fox News Channel on Wednesday afternoon, the anchor Shepard Smith played a clip of President Obama expressing his support for gay marriage, then delivered this stinging assessment: “The President of the United States, now in the 21st century.”

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for May 11-17
text: Classical

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, Nepal, Indonesia and Israel.

headline: Diet Drug Wins Panel’s Approval
text: Government advisers recommended approval on Thursday of a weight-loss drug developed by Arena Pharmaceuticals, making it likely that a new obesity treatment will reach the market this year.

headline: Dance Listings for May 11-17
text: Dance

headline: CBS Sues ABC Over Show It Says Copies ‘Big Brother’
text: 6:58 p.m. | Updated CBS followed up on its threat against ABC with a lawsuit asking the court to block a proposed ABC series called “Glass House” because of its similarities to the long-running CBS summer series “Big Brother.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for May 11-17
text: Art

headline: Observations of an Asteroid Provide Hints of How the Earth Came Together
text: Confirmed: Vesta, the second largest of the asteroids, is a runt planet.

headline: Iraq’s Wounds
text: Although America has declared an end to its war in Iraq, the suffering continues for thousands of the allies it left behind.

headline: Spare Times for May 11-17
text: Around Town

headline: Spare Times — For Children for May 11-17
text: ‘UP TO YOU’

headline: Fallout From the Gay-Marriage Decision
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bachmann Withdraws Swiss Citizenship
text: Alas, the Tea Party movement won’t be setting up shop in Zurich anytime soon.

headline: Going Social, but Not Creepy, in the New Bing
text: Microsoft rolled out a new version of its Bing search engine with new features aimed at weaving together the experience of Internet search and social networking. There is, however, one eyebrow-raising new Bing feature Microsoft was testing that it decided not to release to the public.

headline: Family Way
text: Just as everyone was getting ready to throw out the Baby Bjorns and start practicing detachment parenting à la française comes a new book, from the esteemed philosopher Elisabeth Badinter, warning that French motherhood isn’t all it’s cracked up to be.

headline: Chemical Plant Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: First Handcuffs Lock Them Together, Then Love
text: Pop music has a way of dressing up familiar themes and emotions in new beats and sonic textures, and “Tonight You’re Mine,” David Mackenzie’s new film, does something similar. In outline it is an absolutely standard meet-cute romantic comedy, with the usual obstacles on the way to the central couple’s triumphant kiss, which takes place against a backdrop of fireworks and cheering crowds. There are inconvenient rivals who must be gotten out of the way, and comical sidekicks to lighten the mood. But the look, the rhythm and the scruffy, on-the-fly ambience of the film make it feel unusually fresh and lively. It may be the same old song, but it’s also a catchy remix.

headline: Without Mentioning It, Obama Gets Applause for Gay Marriage Stand
text: SEATTLE – All it took was President Obama’s quick, vague phrase – “no matter who you love” – and about 2,000 supporters at a Democratic fund-raiser here on Thursday erupted in applause and cheers, seeming to guess he was alluding to his newly announced support for same-sex marriage.

headline: Trailer: 'Grand Illusion'
text: A trailer for Jean Renoir's "Grand Illusion," which makes a return to the big screen at Film Forum.

headline: Jean Renoir’s Timely Lessons for Europe
text: “GRAND ILLUSION” had its premiere at the Venice Film Festival in 1937, and it has been around ever since, by enduring consensus one of the greatest films ever made. It is true that Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda chief and cultural arbiter, was not a fan, but Mussolini, patron of the festival and Europe’s leading fascist cinephile, kept a print in his personal collection. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared that “all the democracies in the world must see this film,” which is still sound advice. The nations that fall within that rubric may have grown in number since those days, but none of those democracies, old or new, is so secure as to be immune to the lessons of Jean Renoir’s great and piercing antiwar comedy.

headline: Yankees Express Confidence in Robertson
text: The Yankees have shown support for Dave Robertson after he struggled during save opportunities in two consecutive nights, his first two since taking over the closer’s role from the injured Mariano Rivera.

headline: U.S. Drug War in Honduras
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Album About Healing, Made in a Wounded Land
text: Music, politics and race: To what degree does a style belong to the people who developed it? At what point, if any, does musical fusion become musical theft? Is the greater good served by a noble project if it involves the flouting of solemn rules? And once the rules have changed, and the noise has died down, how much do these debates really matter?

headline: Neighborhood Joint | The Brooklyn Art Library
text: The library holds more than 12,000 sketchbooks made by people from all over the world.

headline: Midwives to a Peace Process, Where Church and Mosque Coexist
text: The Lebanese director Nadine Labaki’s blunt, satirical fable, “Where Do We Go Now?,” takes place in a rural Middle Eastern village where Christians and Muslims coexist in an uneasy peace. The village is ringed with land mines, and its cemetery is filled with the bodies of young men who have died in sectarian warfare.

headline: For International Students, a Guide to U.S. Community Colleges
text: As we’ve recently mentioned on The Choice, it is not too late to apply to a college or university in the United States for the fall semester. At least 375 colleges and universities reported that they still have space next fall for freshmen and transfer applicants, according to the 2012 Space Availability Survey from the National Association for College Admission Counseling.

headline: Movement on Social Issues
text: Support for same-sex marriage in the United States has increased faster over the past 15 years than public opinion on other social issues.

headline: University of Pennsylvania Described Warren as a Minority Faculty Member
text: BOSTON — Elizabeth Warren, a Senate candidate here who has been under fire for claiming minority status in a legal directory in the 1980s and ’90s, was also described at one point by the University of Pennsylvania, where she had been on the faculty, as a minority.

headline: A Home for Sketchbooks of the World
text: SHE remembers crashing into the chicken coop and seeing feathers flying, one of her adventures growing up on the island of Cebu in the Philippines. There, she built lonely castles of sand, played hide-and-seek through cornfields and slept in a hammock hung by her grandfather.

headline: Students Make Gains in Testing on Science
text: American eighth graders have made modest gains in national science testing, with Hispanic and black students narrowing the gap between them and their white and Asian peers, the federal government reported Thursday.

headline: A Dewey Bond Offering Made No Mention of Partner Guarantees
text: A bond offering by Dewey & LeBoeuf did not disclose the extensive guarantees that it gave to partners, an omission that could subject the law firm’s partners to litigation, securities lawyers say.

headline: Yahoo’s Chief Said to Tell Executives He Did Not Submit a Résumé
text: Yahoo‘s embattled chief executive, Scott Thompson, told the company’s senior management on Thursday that he never submitted a résumé or falsified his academic credentials, a person briefed on the matter said.

headline: Crawling Backward in Time Into Haunted Real Estate
text: The dead are unquiet and the living are terrified in “The Road,” a powerfully atmospheric blend of ghostly encounters, horrific situations and missing-persons mysteries from the Philippine director Yam Laranas.

headline: Fox Networks and Survival Sunday
text: No, Survival Sunday is not some nefarious scheme to help you endure the rigors of Mother’s Day in the United States.

headline: Conflict in Sudan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pro Bono for New Lawyers?
text: To the Editor:

headline: How New York City Measures Schools’ Performance
text: To the Editor:

headline: If It’s Made of Metal, Thieves Aren’t Picky
text: The high price of oil is not the only effect of commodity inflation hitting the streets of New York. A surge in the value of copper, iron and other metals has fueled a wave of thefts from sidewalks, roadways and rail yards in the last few months.

headline: Two Los Angeles Slackers at Responsibility’s Door
text: “A Bag of Hammers,” Brian Crano’s low-budget dramedy and first feature, is certainly sure of itself. Any film tossing comic interludes among its closing credits has to be convinced of their hilarity and of the good will the movie has earned with viewers by then. Perhaps the film’s naked traffic in sentiment up to that point made Mr. Crano so bold. Whatever; his confidence was unwarranted.

headline: The Case for Global Accounting
text: For more than a decade, politicians and regulators around the world have claimed to want a common set of high-quality accounting standards that applied globally. The extent to which that rhetoric will become reality may soon become apparent.

headline: Young Girl With a Gun Goes to Vegas
text: When Luli (Chloë Grace Moretz), the 13-year-old heroine of “Hick,” a botched coming-of-age story, decides to leave her Nebraska home for a glamorous life in Las Vegas, she takes off down the road, skipping. That’s after she’s practiced her Clint Eastwood moves in the mirror with her gun (a birthday present): “You feel lucky, punk?” Well, uh, do you?

headline: Husband Seeks Affair With His Wife as She Was
text: The romantic comedy “Nesting” takes an old idea and tosses in a few today-sounding phrases in hopes of coming up with a fresh-feeling movie. But that isn’t enough.

headline: Pregnant Technophile in Transit
text: The best thing about “Small, Beautifully Moving Parts” is its admission that a positive pregnancy test is not always cause for giddy celebration; the worst thing is that, even at a lean 73 minutes, this flimsy road movie feels at least 43 minutes too long.

headline: The Multidimensional Fate of a 1912 Schiele Portrait
text: A key chapter in the post-Nazi history of 20th-century art ownership gets an indignant retelling in Andrew Shea’s polished talking-head documentary “Portrait of Wally.” The book and film “The Rape of Europa” laid out the scope of the Third Reich’s thefts and their aftermath, but “Portrait of Wally” spotlights the well-witnessed fate of Egon Schiele’s 1912 oil painting depicting his flame-haired mistress, Walburga Neuzil, known as Wally.

headline: Head of Abortion Rights Group Will Step Down
text: The president of Naral Pro-Choice America will step down at the end of the year, the advocacy group announced Thursday.

headline: Maddening Mind Game With a Methodical Archivist
text: Cloaked in the low-rent aesthetic of a public television program washed up from the 1950s, Daniel Cockburn’s episodic experiment “You Are Here” is as challenging to write about as to decipher. An unsettling visual inquiry into, among other things, the nature of consciousness and the building blocks of identity, this audacious debut feature resists categorization.

headline: Others in the Spotlight After JPMorgan’s Big Trading Loss
text: 8:01 a.m. | Updated

headline: French Thriller’s Potpourri of Crooked Cops, Gangsters, Drugs and a Hostage
text: As the film critic Anthony Lane once observed, there’s nothing so exhausting as being goaded into a state of constant excitement. He wasn’t talking about “Sleepless Night,” but the shoe fits. Hectic and harebrained, this galloping French thriller tosses a potpourri of plot points — crooked cops, sleazy gangsters, stolen drugs and an underage hostage — into a packed-to-the-gills nightclub, and stirs. Repeatedly.

headline: Not Quite Closing Time
text: Doug Glanville returns with an occasional column on baseball and other sports.

headline: Maternity Ward Swag
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Sixers Finish Off an Upset of the Battered Bulls
text: PHILADELPHIA — Title contenders when healthy, the battered Chicago Bulls were looking to stay alive Thursday night in their first-round series with the 76ers. The adage “defense wins championships” had been downgraded to “defense postpones vacation reservations.”

headline: China’s Growth Slows, and Its Political Model Shows Limits
text: CHONGQING, China — After the economies of Western nations imploded in late 2008, Chinese leaders began boasting of their nation’s supremacy. Talk spread, not only in China but also across the West, of the advantages of the so-called China model — a vaguely defined combination of authoritarian politics and state-driven capitalism — that was to be the guiding light for this century.

headline: Woods Settles Closer to Cut Line Than Lead
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — At the Medalist Golf Club, some 200 miles south of here on Interstate 95, Rickie Fowler and Tiger Woods occasionally practice together. Paired in competition for the first time Thursday at the Players Championship, Fowler said it was not that different from their games at home.

headline: Parents: Hands Off the Homework
text: A. has a seventh grader, and a question: how much is the right amount to help him with his homework? Not, she wrote, the daily stuff, but the projects — the kind of thing an adult would (should) start in advance, and an adolescent boy with a few other things on his mind might well leave until the last minute. “How much,” she asked, should we be “making sure he gets done what he’s supposed to get done?”

headline: Egyptian Candidates Clash in TV Debate, an Arab First
text: CAIRO — Two of the leading candidates to become Egypt’s next president clashed Thursday night in the Arab world’s first televised presidential debate, trading barbs about their political histories and arguments about the role of religion in public life.

headline: The Choice That Wasn’t
text: FORTY-FIVE years ago, on April 21, 1967, a right-wing group of colonels seized power in Greece. Tanks rolled into the center of Athens; politicians, artists and journalists were arrested; and the ensuing military dictatorship lasted for seven years.

headline: 30 Seconds With Bernard King
text: Bernard King started making jump shots at Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn and never stopped until he became a star in the N.B.A., playing with the Knicks, the Nets, the Utah Jazz, the Golden State Warriors and the Washington Bullets.

headline: In Reversal, Espada Jurors Indicate a Verdict Is Near
text: As jurors in the federal embezzlement trial of former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. indicated Thursday that they might be close to a verdict after nine days of deliberations, Mr. Espada said he believed that an unusual force was at work: “evil spiritual powers.”

headline: How Pakistan Lets Terrorism Fester
text: ON the anniversary of Osama bin Laden’s death last week, Pakistan was the only Muslim country in which hundreds of demonstrators gathered to show solidarity with the dead terrorist figurehead.

headline: Subsidies Aid Rebirth in U.S. Manufacturing
text: ROME, N.Y. — Walking through his high-ceilinged factory here, explaining the production of sheets of copper, M. Brian O’Shaughnessy comes across as a staunch advocate of manufacturing in America. But he invariably adds: “There is nothing made in the United States that has to be made here — that can’t be shipped in from some other country.”

headline: Pentagon Stresses Efforts to Recover U.S. Soldier Being Held in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — The United States government is doing everything possible to locate Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who is being held captive by insurgents after being seized in Afghanistan in 2009, the Pentagon’s top civilian and military leaders said Thursday.

headline: Can Physics and Philosophy Get Along?
text: Physicists have been giving philosophers a hard time lately. Stephen Hawking claimed in a speech last year that philosophy is “dead” because philosophers haven’t kept up with science. More recently, Lawrence Krauss, in his book, “A Universe From Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather Than Nothing,” has insisted that “philosophy and theology are incapable of addressing by themselves the truly fundamental questions that perplex us about our existence.” David Albert, a distinguished philosopher of science, dismissively reviewed Krauss’s book: “all there is to say about this [Krauss’s claim that the universe may have come from nothing], as far as I can see, is that Krauss is dead wrong and his religious and philosophical critics are absolutely right.” Krauss — ignoring Albert’s Ph.D. in theoretical physics — retorted in an interview that Albert is a “moronic philosopher.” (Krauss somewhat moderates his views in a recent Scientific American article.)

headline: The Last Mother’s Day
text: I started making wine a couple of years ago with a bunch of guys who know far more about the ways of the grape than I do. Between the crushing, racking, barrel-tasting and bottling we talked about wine and sports, women and sports, politics and sports, and maybe some other things that I can’t remember, and sports.

headline: Digital Notes: Dogged by Lawsuits, MP3Tunes Files for Bankruptcy
text: For years, digital music start-ups have faced two persistent, and frequently intertwined, dangers: record company lawsuits and bankruptcy.

headline: Prosecution Rests After Presenting Video of Edwards’s Lies About His Affair
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Prosecutors rested their case against former Senator John Edwards on Thursday, offering as their last piece of evidence a national television interview he did in 2008 in which he denied much about the affair that ultimately brought him to the federal courtroom here.

headline: After Decades, Directory Shifts to the Web
text: The greening of New York’s Green Book is complete.

headline: Playing Favorites
text: Reporter David Carr asks a multigenerational musical family about their song writing.

headline: In Middle of Chaos, a Calming Force
text: LOS ANGELES — As the Los Angeles Kings began their Western Conference semifinal series against the St. Louis Blues, goalie Jonathan Quick demonstrated his value abruptly and dramatically.

headline: Mixing Ads and Comedy Shorts Online for TBS
text: IT may not be a bad idea to begin this article the way a comedian might: A funny thing happened to TBS on the way to the upfront.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Easy Useless Economics
text: A few days ago, I read an authoritative-sounding paper in The American Economic Review, one of the leading journals in the field, arguing at length that the nation’s high unemployment rate had deep structural roots and wasn’t amenable to any quick solution. The author’s diagnosis was that the U.S. economy just wasn’t flexible enough to cope with rapid technological change. The paper was especially critical of programs like unemployment insurance, which it argued actually hurt workers because they reduced the incentive to adjust.

headline: The Human Cost of Ideology
text: For more than a year, House Republicans have energetically worked to demolish vital social programs that have made this country both stronger and fairer over the last half-century. At the same time, they have insisted on preserving bloated military spending and unjustifiably low tax rates for the rich. That effort reached a nadir on Thursday when the House voted to prevent $55 billion in automatic cuts imposed on the Pentagon as part of last year’s debt-ceiling deal, choosing instead to make all those cuts, and much more, from domestic programs.

headline: Why Would the Feds Investigate the Facebook-Instagram Deal?
text: The Financial Times on Thursday reported that the Federal Trade Commission was investigating Facebook’s acquisition of Instagram, a move that, if true, could add a new wrinkle to Silicon Valley’s biggest and most anticipated public offering.

headline: Ex-Official’s Drive in China Leads to Torture Inquiry
text: CHONGQING, China — Police officers here are being investigated over whether they used torture and other questionable methods to obtain evidence during a so-called anticrime campaign overseen by Bo Xilai, the deposed Chinese leader who for four years ran the party machinery in this fog-shrouded western metropolis.

headline: A Shock From JPMorgan Is New Fodder for Reformers
text: It didn’t take long for bank reformers to say we told you so.

headline: Ovechkin Making More Out of Less
text: In the first round of the playoffs, Alex Ovechkin, Washington’s $10-million-a-year superstar, was not happy when Coach Dale Hunter reduced his customarily substantial ice time.

headline: To Make Fracturing Safer
text: There is little doubt that natural gas, which is plentiful and cleaner than coal, could help with the country’s energy and climate problems. But as Interior Secretary Ken Salazar once warned, the drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing could be natural gas’s Achilles’ heel unless the public can be sure it will not pollute water supplies or the air.

headline: Fatal Shooting in Hotel Lobby, Then a Suicide
text: Two men were killed on Thursday in what the authorities described as a murder-suicide in the lobby of a Queens hotel.

headline: Duck Is Mauled in Central Park, Apparently by a Loose Dog
text: In the sculptured wilderness that is Central Park, nature’s rawer edge is not often apparent. But on Wednesday, a park ranger discovered a female mallard that had been mauled by an animal, apparently a dog. A local animal hospital euthanized the duck, which had lost most of its tongue and half its bill.

headline: Capitol Hill, Slower Than Snail Mail
text: For all its historic reputation at persevering, the United States Postal Service is just not making it as a business. It is running deficits of $36 million a day. It will go bankrupt this year and annual losses could rise to $21 billion a year by 2016 unless the House and Senate can agree on a sensible reform plan — one that protects consumers but also recognizes the financial realities imposed on the Postal Service by the Internet age.

headline: As Greenpoint Gentrifies, Sunday Rituals Clash: Outdoor Cafes vs. Churchgoers
text: Brunch at an outdoor cafe during the warmer months has become as much a Sunday morning ritual in some of the trendier New York neighborhoods as going to church.

headline: Louis Pollak, a ‘Powerful Heart’
text: Judge Louis Pollak, who died this week in Philadelphia at 89, carried on a grand liberal tradition in the law. His father, Walter Pollak, persuaded the Supreme Court that the Scottsboro boys convicted of rape in Alabama did not get a fair trial. And soon after clerking for a justice, he helped write the N.A.A.C.P. brief that did much to persuade the Supreme Court to outlaw segregation in Brown v. Board of Education.

headline: European Countries Seek Easing of Provision Included in Iranian Oil Embargo
text: Britain said Thursday that it was in talks with other European Union members about possibly easing a provision of their Iran oil embargo, set to begin in less than two months, that could cause harmful and unintended side effects because it bans Europe-based insurers from covering any ships that carry Iranian oil anywhere in the world.

headline: Bullying Story Spurs Apology From Romney

headline: For Ultra-Orthodox in Abuse Cases, Prosecutor Has Different Rules

Hynes, with a message: his ultra-Orthodox advocacy group was instructing adherent Jews that they could report allegations of child sexual abuse to district attorneys or the police only if a rabbi first determined that the suspicions were credible.

headline: Cleared, but Will the Next Person Be So Lucky?

They were waiting to take his picture.

headline: Playoff Puzzle of the Brown University Puzzle Tournament

headline: C. David Heymann, Biographer of the Rich and Famous, Dies at 67

headline: What’s the Matter With Kansas? … What’s the Matter With Wall St.?
text: Democrats often ask, “What’s the Matter with Kansas,” referring to the notion, captured by Thomas Frank in his 2004 book of that title, that the Republican establishment has cunningly persuaded the lower-middle class to vote against its economic self-interest by catering to its cultural preferences. The deal, these Democrats say, is low taxes on the rich, in exchange for support of the socially conservative values of the lower middle class. We saw that dynamic at play in the Republican primaries, in which the candidate who most excited the working and middle class base, Rick Santorum, was the one who offered the most aggressively conservative cultural platform.

headline: Family Ties, Knotted Up in the Lyrics
text: WHEN most families fight, as most families do, you might hear about it over the back fence or see a stray post on Facebook. When the Wainwrights get into it, the spat often shows up in a full-blown song, which begets other songs. That kind of thing will happen when one of America’s most bracing folk writers, Loudon Wainwright III, marries another folk luminary, Kate McGarrigle of the McGarrigle Sisters, and they have two musically gifted children, Rufus and Martha. Factor in a serious relationship, which has long ended, with another member of the folk pantheon — with Suzzy Roche of the Roches, that produced yet another musical offspring, Lucy Wainwright Roche — and cue decades of songs, many of them about a complicated life in a family of musical royalty. Some of those songs have titles that don’t scan well in a family newspaper, including Loudon’s ditty about a fight for position at the breast of Rufus’s mother and Martha’s profane rocket aimed at her father’s shortcomings. Back and forth it goes, with Rufus’s “Dinner at Eight” revealing that supper at the Wainwrights was sometimes more dark indie movie than sitcom.

headline: Who Made That Clothespin?
text: The survival of the spring-hinged clothespin into the modern era is an unlikely story of Darwinian selection. From 1852 to 1887, the U.S. patent office issued 146 separate patents for clothespins. The first design that resembles the modern clothespin was patented in 1853 by David M. Smith, a prolific Vermont inventor. Smith also invented a combination lock, a “lathe dog” (a machine part for shaping metal) and a lifting spring for matchboxes. His “spring-clamp for clothes-lines” offered an elegant model of “two levers” hinged so that “the two longer legs may be moved toward each other and at the same time move the shorter ones apart.” Smith’s design was later improved by the 1887 patent of another Vermont inventor, Solon E. Moore, whose great contribution was the “coiled fulcrum,” made from a single wire, which joined the two grooved pieces of wood at the center of the clothespin. Moore’s version had the advantage of being both sturdy — it kept clothes securely on the line — and easy to manufacture.

headline: Can You Call a 9-Year-Old a Psychopath?
text: One day last summer, Anne and her husband, Miguel, took their 9-year-old son, Michael, to a Florida elementary school for the first day of what the family chose to call “summer camp.” For years, Anne and Miguel have struggled to understand their eldest son, an elegant boy with high-planed cheeks, wide eyes and curly light brown hair, whose periodic rages alternate with moments of chilly detachment. Michael’s eight-week program was, in reality, a highly structured psychological study — less summer camp than camp of last resort.
