headline: This Week’s Movies, May 11
text: In today’s edition of this week’s movies, the critics offer their thoughts on three new films. Manohla Dargis has positive things to say about “Dark Shadows,” the eighth collaboration between the director Tim Burton and the actor Johnny Depp, calling it “Mr. Burton’s most pleasurable film in years.” A. O. Scott looks at the romantic comedy “Tonight You’re Mine,” which was shot over several days at a music festival in Scotland. And Mr. Scott also reviews the teenager-coming-of-age tale “Girl in Progress,” with Eva Mendes. Watch the above video, then find our critics’ complete reviews here.

headline: Let’s Go, Mess!
text: Somewhere along the line in turning from an ordinary sports day into a 10-ego pileup, Thursday produced a fascinating competition for hottest mess of the day. Our apologies for overlooking any comparable sporting calamities — and no apologies for omitting Tiger Woods after his opening-round 74 at the Players Championship because it’s only news these days when Woods isn’t a mess — but please allow the Lakers, the Red Sox and Rafael Nadal to duke it out for the title.

headline: Bookshelf: Sleep Tight
text: Picture books about bedtime.

headline: After JPMorgan Trading Debacle, a Chorus of Criticism
text: The news of JPMorgan Chase’s estimated $2 billion loss stemming from a misguided hedging strategy in the bank’s chief investment office has set off a spring-loaded schadenfreude cannon among the industry’s critics.

headline: Bookshelf: Sleep Tight
text: NIGHT KNIGHT  Written and illustrated by Owen Davey.  32 pp. Templar/Candlewick Press. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: From ‘Incredible India’ to the ‘Incredible Tiffin’
text: Lamb cooked seven different ways, crispy papdi laden with tamarind chutney and yogurt, cottage cheese with raw mangoes in silken tomato gravy —these were just some of the 37 dishes at the “Incredible Tiffin” dinner Wednesday evening in New Delhi, sponsored by the Cuisine India Society to promote India’s vast variety of cuisines.

headline: Online, Exploring a Manhattan Dotted With Farms
text: Few notions are more alien to Manhattanites than the fact they are living on what was once farmland.

headline: Bookshelf: Mommy
text: Picture books that are odes to the maternal.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/11: Hungry in Helsinki and a Toddler on the No-Fly List
text: Hungry in Helsinki The writer Monique Truong, on a visiting-writer stay in Helsinki, finds her way around the city’s food markets. (T Magazine)

headline: Demi Monde: Rarefied Cocktails and Tastings
text: A hostess will greet you at the little entryway in the financial district and announce your arrival at Demi Monde, a below-ground cocktail lounge and restaurant that will begin to unveil its food and drink on a limited basis this weekend.

headline: Bookshelf: Mommy
text: MEET ME AT THE MOON  Written and illustrated by Gianna Marino.  40 pp. Viking. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6)

headline: Literary Influences, Personal Pathologies
text: AT 27 the New York filmmaker Alex Ross Perry already has two features to his name, both notable for their eccentric ambition and estrangement from the larger landscape of American indie cinema — or perhaps their opposition to it. In a field where so many others are conditioned to produce work that is eager to please, Mr. Perry’s films — the oddball war movie “Impolex” (released last year) and the brother-sister psychodrama-comedy “The Color Wheel” (opening at BAMcinématek on Friday) — are determinedly individual and abrasive, even downright unassimilable.

headline: What’s Going on in Afghanistan?
text: Carol Giacomo, who covers defense policy for the editorial board, is in Afghanistan this week on a trip for journalists organized by NATO. Here’s a dispatch from her visit to Camp Holland.

headline: ‘Ring’ Heads
text: The Wagner Society of New York holds a meet and greet for an international group of “Ring” cycle fans attending the new production at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: So How Much Credit Should Obama Get?
text: Ever since the president voiced his support for gay marriage, there has been a big, old blog debate centering on the question of just how much courage it took. On the one side, Andrew Sullivan gushed. On the other, John Cook snarled. We advocate reading both, but we really recommend this measured and intelligent response from our very own Matt Bai over at The Caucus.

headline: Look of The Moment | Jessica Alba
text: The Look:  Dressing Outside the Lines. A wild graffiti print can’t be contained, not even by proper satin pumps and slick hair.

headline: Habitat for Humanity Tries Big-Scale Approach to Housing in Oregon
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — John D. Gray, 92, got wind about three years ago, near the bottom of the Great Recession, that Habitat for Humanity was doing something pretty interesting here in Oregon’s largest city. In a depressed real estate market, Habitat, the nonprofit housing group, was betting big: trying to buy vacant land on the cheap, shopping from banks in repossession and foreclosure sales to squirrel away for housing projects years in the future.

headline: Q. and A. With Times Reporters About Abuse in Ultra-Orthodox Jewish Communities
text: Ultra-Orthodox Jews in the New York region have been grappling with how to address child-sex abuse in the community. On Thursday, The Times published an article describing how ultra-Orthodox Jews who come forward with allegations of abuse often encounter intense intimidation from their neighbors and from rabbinical authorities, aimed at pressuring them to drop their cases. On Friday, a second article examined the record of the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, in prosecuting these cases. Mr. Hynes has adopted a policy of not publicizing accusations of child-sex abuse involving the ultra-Orthodox in Brooklyn.

headline: Business Day Live | May 11, 2012
text: JPMorgan Chase's $2 billion loss; the education of Mark Zuckerberg, Chief Executive; James B. Stewart on why same-sex marriage is good for business; and graduating into debt.

headline: Lettuce Eat!
text: Most of us eat lettuce cold, as a salad or a crispy fresh topping on a sandwich or burger. But in this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman turns up the heat on lettuce, putting the crispy greens in a stir-fry, a hot soup, a warm sauce and a cooked bean dish. And for traditionalists, she’s also offered a cold salad.

headline: How Much Punch Does a Wine Pack?
text: PARIS — In my column this week on the Wachau region of Austria, I look at the issue of rising alcohol levels in wine. The whites of the Wachau have sometimes been criticized for their heft, with alcohol levels that have crept above 15 percent in certain cases.

headline: Hype Rules at N.F.L. Rookie Camps
text: There is no such thing as bad news at an N.F.L. rookie camp.

headline: Long-Running Recalls of Ford Windstar Minivan Are Expanded to Virginia
text: Ford has expanded two previous recalls of its troubled Windstar minivan, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration this week.

headline: Why “Julia” Is Dangerous For Obama
text: While the commentariat debates whether this week’s gay marriage shift will be good news or bad news for the president’s re-election chances, I see that Jonathan Chait has risen to the defense of last week’s White House gambit — the “Julia” slideshow, featuring a cartoon everywoman whose path through life is smoothed by the beneficence of Barack Obama, which was the subject of my Sunday column (among many other withering conservative critiques). To the suggestion that the slideshow’s view of American life feels at paternalistic and government-centric, Chait responds:

headline: Girls Keeping It Real, and Not So
text: The pop duo Karmin became famous by assaulting the songs of others, performing glib and highly stylized YouTube covers that inadvertently doubled as sketch comedy. Those that attracted the most attention were the hip-hop songs: seeing the duo’s cheery white singer, Amy Heidemann, gnash her way through complex rhymes and keep up was a spectacle, no doubt, if an awkward one.

headline: I’d Like to Thank . . .
text: Several Tony Award nominees talk about the acceptance speeches they practiced years ago.

headline: Conditioning and Winning, Lasix-Free
text: Horses evolved as social grazers of the plains, group survivalists moving and grazing together most all of the time. During their 60-million-year evolution, horses came to require near-constant forage, friends and locomotion to maintain health and vigor of wind and limb.

headline: Giving Chase to Young Love on the Run
text: RECOUNTING the genesis of his new feature, “Moonrise Kingdom,” Wes Anderson sounded like he could be talking about any of his other movies. “The desire for fantasy to be real is part of the inspiration,” he said. From his 1996 debut, the shaggy-dog caper “Bottle Rocket,” to the animated Roald Dahl adaptation “Fantastic Mr. Fox” (2009), loss and longing have been the cornerstones of his films, which almost invariably concern the melancholic plight of dreamers and depressives, yearning for past glories, vanished innocence, a world that matches the one in their heads.

headline: Image of the Day: May 11
text: An old man waits for an artificial limb to be fitted during a free medical camp in Jammu.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: Avoid a Rift With Your Mother-in-Law, at All Costs

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Judith Newman discusses Anne Enright’s memoir “Making Babies”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Pamela Paul talks about children’s books; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: A French Riviera Gastrocrawl
text: For years, there have been so many Michelin-starred restaurants along the Côte d’Azur, the glamorous seaside strip known to Anglophones as the French Riviera, that the company’s guidebook includes an inset map of the region to display them legibly. Today, though, it’s not fancy dining rooms with tuxedo-wearing waiters and vertiginous tariffs that are the stars, but small, casual homey places with chefs who showcase the region’s superb produce as part of brief and regularly changing menus — and at reasonable prices.

headline: The Consequences of Motherhood
text: No subject offers a greater opportunity for terrible writing than motherhood. Men, of course, have their painful sportswriters, fellows who don’t just document the mildew and peeling paint on a boxing gym’s walls but go on to liken it to the weeping of fetid tears over the tragedies they’ve seen. But women? Just as the sports guys mythologize the athlete, mommy writers mythologize the child, the bond, the late nights and the little toothless grin breaking out like sunshine from behind a thundercloud of tears. (I actually read that in a book. A book someone published. No, I’m not naming names.)

headline: Behind the Masks
text: “We are formed by what we desire,” says Billy Dean, the fatherless narrator and chief hero of John Irving’s 13th novel, “In One Person.”

headline: Paradise Lost: A Mother-Daughter Spring Break
text: ONE of the good things about divorce is that you get to see less of your children.

headline: 5 Tips for Traveling With Your Mother
text: 1. Sleep will undoubtedly cause some friction. You see it as a necessary and restorative 12 to 14 hours; your mother sees it as a freak biological mutation standing in the way of a nonstop bonding session with her only child. The best time to address this issue is during the brief overlap in awake time the two of you will enjoy between the hours of 3 and 8 p.m.

headline: Dragon Bait
text: “Hold out baits to entice the enemy. Feign disorder, and crush him.”

headline: Boggle the Mind
text: Have you ever wondered how Nike came by its famous slogan “Just Do It”? Neither have I, but it’s an interesting story. Dan Wieden was searching for a tag line to unify a series of ads his agency was making for Nike. Late one night he suddenly thought about the convicted murderer Gary Gil­more, whose last words before his execution were “Let’s do it.” Sitting at his desk Wieden turned that phrase over in his mind until it became “Just do it.” Accolades ensued.

headline: A Tiger in Love
text: A compulsive and infectious narrative restlessness marks Rajesh Parameswaran’s first collection of short fiction, “I Am an Executioner.” Although tagged by the generic subtitle “Love Stories,” Parameswaran’s work demonstrates about the same relationship to traditional literary debuts as the insects in his strange and beautiful story “On the Banks of Table River (Planet Lucina, Andromeda Galaxy, AD 2319)” do to the earthlings who have colonized their planet.

headline: The Original Colonists
text: This is not a humble book. Edward O. Wilson wants to answer the questions Paul Gauguin used as the title of one of his most famous paintings: “Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?” At the start, Wilson notes that religion is no help at all — “mythmaking could never discover the origin and meaning of humanity” — and contemporary philosophy is also irrelevant, having “long ago abandoned the foundational questions about human existence.” The proper approach to answering these deep questions is the application of the methods of science, including archaeology, neuroscience and evolutionary biology. Also, we should study insects.

headline: Worshiping in Vietnam
text: Inside an ornate temple where the Cao Dai faithful gather.

headline: Process of Extermination
text: In “Homage to Catalonia,” his memoir of the Spanish Civil War, George Orwell remarks that Francisco Franco’s military uprising against Spain’s elected government “was an attempt not so much to impose fascism as to restore feudalism.” Paul Preston’s magisterial account of the bloodshed of that era bears this out. Fascism may belong to the 20th century, but Franco’s grab for power evokes earlier times: the parading soldiers who flourished enemy ears and noses on their bayonets, the mass public executions carried out in bullrings or with band music and onlookers dancing in the victims’ blood. One of Franco’s top aides talked of democratically chosen politicians as “cloven-hoofed beasts,” and anything that smacked of modernity — Rotary Clubs, Montessori schools — seemed to draw the regime’s violent wrath. Echoing the Inquisition, Franco ordered particularly despised foes put to death with the garrote, in which the executioner tightens an iron collar around a person’s neck.

headline: Should the Knicks Keep Steve Novak? Can They?
text: With so much salary owed to Carmelo Anthony, Amar’e Stoudemire and Tyson Chandler, the Knicks will be working with limited resources when they fill out their roster in the off-season.

headline: Back Stories
text: In his “Lives of the Poets,” Samuel Johnson saw no necessary alignment between a writer’s life and work. A finicky Cambridge don like Thomas Gray, who indulged in the “fantastic foppery” that he could write only “at certain times, or at happy moments,” could sit down at a happy moment and compose his sad elegy on the plight of the rural poor, who lived and died “far from the madding crowd.” Despite his dislike of Gray, Dr. Johnson wrote of the poem, “I rejoice to concur with the common reader.”

headline: Chilled to the Bone
text: Joseph Olshan has stepped up and written one for the home team. CLOUDLAND (Minotaur, $24.99) is set in the bleak Upper Connecticut River Valley that forms the border of Vermont and New Hampshire, a place where spring doesn’t arrive until it’s summer. Catherine Winslow, whose intimate narrative voice keeps directing our eyes to the beauty of this stark landscape, is taking a walk when she comes upon the half-frozen body of a woman in a pink parka, strangled and stabbed and left beneath an apple tree to spend the past winter under a blanket of snow.

headline: The Lighter Side of Terrorism
text: In the 1974 Italian comedy “Bread and Chocolate,” Nino Manfredi played an Italian guest worker in Switzerland who’s stripped of his papers after he’s caught urinating in public.

headline: The Writer in the Family
text: So there I stood at the front of my granddaughter Jessica’s fourth-grade classroom, still as a glazed dog, while Jessie introduced me to her classmates, to whom I was about to speak. “This is my grandfather, Boppo,” she said, invoking my grandpaternal nickname. “He lives in the basement and does nothing.”

headline: Up Front
text: Judith Warner — the author of the best-selling “Perfect Madness: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety,” and a former contributing columnist for The New York Times — is one of our most eloquent and candid commentators on hot-button issues affecting parents and children. On our cover this week she considers two books that take forceful stands on the topics of motherhood and family policy: “The Conflict,” Elisabeth Badinter’s report on the state of French motherhood, and “The New Feminist Agenda,” Madeleine M. Kunin’s critical survey of how American women and their families are faring some 40 years after the women’s movement.

headline: Food on the French Riviera
text: See dishes from four restaurants serving spirited cuisine.

headline: Inside the List
text: DON’T PANIC: When Douglas Adams, the author of “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy,” died of a heart attack 11 years ago this month, a group of fans organized an impromptu “Towel Day” celebration in his memory. Why Towel Day? Because a towel, as readers of Adams’s delirious novel will remember, “is about the most massively useful thing an interstellar hitchhiker can have.” (Suggested uses: beach-lounging on Santraginus V, sailing a miniraft down the River Moth, hiding from the Ravenous Bugblatter Beast of Traal and, “if it still seems to be clean enough,” drying yourself off.) The tribute caught on, and this year people in at least 15 countries will observe May 25 by carrying towels to readings, movie screenings and other events related to “The Hitchhiker’s Guide,” which spent a cumulative 11 weeks on our paper­back list. In 1981, when the first American edition was released, Gerald Jonas praised it in the Book Review. “Humorous science-fiction novels have notoriously limited audiences,” he wrote. “They tend to be full of ‘in’ jokes understandable only to those who read everything from Jules Verne to Harlan Ellison. The ‘Hitchhiker’s Guide’ is a delightful exception.” And yes, he mentioned the towels.

headline: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Enters Bankruptcy Process
text: 2:48 p.m. | Updated Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, the educational and trade publisher in Boston, has agreed with most of its creditors to eliminate $3.1 billion of debt and enter a prearranged Chapter 11 bankruptcy process, the company said on Friday.

headline: A Rustic Retreat in Uruguay
text: Tiny Pueblo Garzón features boutiques, a noteworthy winery, a hotel with a plunge pool and more.

headline: Where the Faithful Worship Among the Tourists
text: JUST before midnight, the monks were still arriving. Dressed in long, flowing white robes, they resembled fireflies as they rode through the darkness on their motorbikes, descending on the towering temple at the heart of the Cao Dai holy land in southern Vietnam. Many were attending their fourth service of the day.

headline: Into Thin Air, True Believers
text: I STOPPED, again, to catch my breath in the thin Andean air, struggling to ease the dizziness as I inhaled from a portable oxygen tank. I must have been a curious sight to the Peruvians passing by. My friends, Andray and Louise, stood beside me, concerned. Realizing we were blocking pedestrian traffic, I pressed myself into the side of the mountain to let the other pilgrims pass.

headline: By Her Majesty’s Grace
text: Confession: I am such a fan of Kristin Cashore’s first two novels, “Graceling” and “Fire,” that over the past three years, I’ve returned many times to her author Web site to find out when I could get my hands on her latest, “Bitterblue,” which plays sequel and companion to the first two. Finally, I got my copy. And I wasn’t disappointed.

headline: In Philadelphia, Food Trucks Are Rolling
text: FOOD trucks used to be fleeting purveyors of adventurous cuisine, so hard to locate that following the right Twitter feed was the only way to find them. Now, they are a nearly inescapable part of the culinary landscape in many cities, as common as trucker hats once were among their clientele.

headline: Fractured Fairy Tales
text: The business of children’s books can seem, for reader and author alike, a bit like buying a ticket for the lottery: from many similar-seeming scraps of paper, one or two will hit the jackpot, while most will be tossed or remaindered. Baffling enough in the big book world, this disproportion, in which one book gets so much and the others so little, is particularly baffling when it comes to fantasy literature for younger readers. That a lottery seems unpredictable is, of course, what makes it a lottery — still, the difference between, say, the commercially mighty “Eragon” and all the other Tolkien followers seems so minute one doubts anyone could have predicted its peculiar appeal.

headline: A Little Bird Told Me
text: Having once been a child who read plenty of picture books, I’ve learned that owls are wise, pigeons are insistent and nightingales are heartbreakingly sad. Two picture books, “More” and “Little Bird,” without exactly anthropomorphizing the magpie and blackbird within, offer different avian lessons about treasure and treasures.

headline: Gumshoes
text: Members of the criminal underworld, beware the little children. They’ve been on to you for years, and the number of mystery-loving young readers seems only to grow. Now to the ranks of Encyclopedia Brown and Cam Jansen comes the newest crop of budding Hercule Poirots: two are American, one is from Botswana, one gang hails from England, and two are Canadians with twitchy noses. The one thing they have in common is that each provides the seeds to understanding how a perfectly average child (or rabbit) might go about becoming a sleuth when baddies need foiling.

headline: Hotel Review: Dream South Beach
text: UPSHOT

headline: The Caretakers
text: It wasn’t easy to read “Summer of the Gypsy Moths” while living with an 11-year-old whose first literary love was the “Clementine” series, also written by Sara Pennypacker. The third time I retrieved my copy from my daughter’s bedroom — a tween lair crammed with bobblehead turtles, Tootsie Roll-scented lip balms and shells from every beach she’s ever visited — I realized this book was the first of my literary possessions she’s ever truly coveted.

headline: It Takes Two
text: Richard Scarry, that genius at engaging and entertaining children, always insisted on featuring animals as characters. Scarry, who died in 1994, believed children might or might not identify with the way a person looked, but with animals, children could project themselves into the story no matter what. Four new picture books all wisely use an assortment of animal pairs to explore important childhood issues like sharing, overcoming differences and conflict resolution.

headline: From the Killing Fields
text: Arn Chorn-Pond was 11 years old when the Communist Khmer Rouge swept into power in 1975, and his story is a catalog of the brutality of the next four years, when as much as one-fourth of the Cambodian population was executed or died of hunger, overwork and untreated disease. It is a story most young Cambodians have never heard, in a nation where the past has been buried along with the bones of the killing fields, a nation whose holocaust is not so much denied as it is smothered in denial. It is also a story that will very likely be new to most American ­teenagers.

headline: Letters to the Travel Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “My London, and Welcome to It” (April 29): One of my fondest memories of London includes the daring businessmen, carrying their briefcases, dashing out before oncoming traffic comes around the corner at what seems like incredibly high speeds. They usually make it, but I am never willing to follow them. One great tip: fly into and out of Gatwick. It’s easy to navigate, and has a direct connection to Victoria Station.Molly Robertson,Taos, N.M.

headline: Boy Blogs World
text: Is Mad magazine dangerous? As a kid I thought so, reading every issue cover to cover in my local drugstore and then spending a significant portion of my allowance anyway because the owner once yelled at me for attempting a fold-in-and-run. I didn’t mind: those issues were worth the $1.35 (cheap!) to bring home and parse talmudically, seeking to understand, at age 11, the parodies of “Tootsie” and “Aliens”; trying to glean some idea of adulthood from Snappy Answers to Stupid Questions; blissing out to ribald drawings of nearly unclothed ladies. Mad seemed so anarchic that I hid it from teachers who, I assumed, would cry “Potrzebie!” were they ever to discover I was smuggling the Usual Gang of Idiots into my locker.

headline: Feels Like Home
text: Where is home — and why do we yearn for it so? Many celebrated children’s books, directly or indirectly explore these questions, from “The Little House,” by Virginia Lee Burton, to Margaret Wise Brown’s “Little Fur Family” to Laura Ingalls Wilder’s “Little House” series.

headline: The Pilot and the Spy
text: I’m in a bit of a predicament. Oh, it’s not the predicament of a girl pilot who has crash-landed in occupied France during World War II, or of a girl spy who has been captured by the Gestapo, but it’s still problematic. I have to review a book in which even the hint of plot summary could ruin everything.

headline: Handle With Care
text: “A  master mahout becomes one with his elephant,” we are told in this charming novel for middle-grade readers. “He is brother and sister, mother and father, and son and daughter to his elephant. He lives, eats and sleeps with his elephant. He feeds it from his table, and bathes with it in the river. The mahout becomes an elephant, and the elephant becomes a mahout. The two are inseparable. But just as there are all kinds of elephants, so, too, there are all kinds of mahouts.”

headline: Restaurant Report: Tycoons in Duluth, Minn.
text: If you’re going to open a restaurant celebrating millionaires, Duluth, Minn., is a surprisingly appropriate place to do it: at the turn of the 20th century, the city had more of them per capita than any other in the country. For the owners of Tycoons, which made its debut last winter as the national Occupy movement was still in full swing, though, the timing wasn’t ideal.

headline: Broken Family Camp
text: Over the course of one life-­changing summer, Ella Mackenzie, a plucky and preternaturally mature fifth-going-on-sixth grader, is sent to what she calls Broken Family Camp. Ella’s family is broken all right, in all the ways we might expect a plucky and preternaturally mature narrator’s family to be broken, and then some. Sick/absent/dead parent? Check, double check. Her mother has leukemia — Extreme Cancer, Ella calls it — and is about to have a stem cell transplant. Her father, who works as a guide at an outdoor travel adventure company, has literally gone fishing, as he has for most of Ella’s childhood. (Her cellphone’s ring tone for him is “Nowhere Man.”) An only child, she has no memories of her parents together. “When people divorce, the situation is bad but not a complete disaster,” she explains. “The kids eventually get stepparents and maybe half siblings, back-and-forth schedules between houses and divided-up vacations. We had a lot of that in Santa Rosa. But when we Mackenzies do things, we do them all the way. It’s Extreme Divorce, like some kind of reality-TV show.”

headline: Summer at the Shore
text: It’s all too easy for adults who write for adolescent girls to caricature their subjects, whether they’re the snooty prep school girl, as improbably vicious as any “Real Housewives” cast member, or the artsy outsider longing to be understood. But some young adult authors, most notably Judy Blume, respectfully develop nuanced teenage characters who are capable of doing more than furthering a story line.

headline: More Quality Family Time With the Wainwrights and Roches
text: The Scene:The family showed up at Dixon Place, the cozy, pretty performance space on the Lower East Side. Cameras, both still and video, had already been set up and there was a circle of chairs waiting, but they made sure they had all hugged and welcomed each other before taking a seat. There was very little tension and subtext as they settled in, much more of it when the recorder came on, and then none of it once they had finished. The Wainwrights and Roches know how to reveal just enough conflict to make for an interesting interview, but nothing that creates lasting grudges. When the group interview was done, three generations, siblings and half-siblings, grandpa and shy grandchild, all began weighing in on where the gigantic crew might eat. This is a family that likes and loves each other very much, even if they don’t always pretend to get along. Below are some additional edited excerpts from the interview.

headline: Diving for Underwater Offerings
text: Lisa J. Lucero, a professor of anthropology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, is studying ancient Maya underwater offerings in central Belize under the auspices of the Belize Institute of Archaeology, National Institute of Culture and History.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE PASSAGE OF POWER: The Years of Lyndon Johnson,  by Robert A.Caro. (Knopf, $35.) The fourth volume of Caro’s magisterial work spans the five years that end shortly after Kennedy’s assassination, as Johnson prepares to push for a civil rights act.

headline: The Taliban, in Their Own Verse
text: Three-and-a-half years ago, weeks before Barack Obama was elected president and as the United States military was preparing to leave Iraq and dedicate more troops to its bogged-down campaign in Afghanistan, an Afghan writer put his name to “Graveyard,” a 14-stanza poem.

headline: Shoe Thrown at Defendant in Norway Murder Trial
text: A man was escorted out of a courtroom in Oslo on Friday after he stood up and threw a shoe at Anders Behring Breivik, who is on trial for the murder of 77 people in Norway on July 22 last year, Norwegian news reports said.

headline: Style Map | Rhine and Dine
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Weekend Fare: Mother’s Day and More
text: Everything you ever wanted to sip, from classic gin martinis to a new Belvedere lemon tea, will be mixed, shaken and stirred in any number of libations at the Manhattan Cocktail Classic kickoff Friday night at the New York Public Library. Tickets are sold out, but a host of events, from workshops to tastings, will be held in restaurants and bars across the city through Tuesday. Some sessions have sold out, so check the Web site for ticket availability.

headline: The Ballet Stage: To Them, the Job
text: WHEN American Ballet Theater returns to the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, audiences won’t be deprived of the usual array of full-length classics, opulent farewell performances and, of course, those glamorous guest artists, including Denis Matvienko, Polina Semionova and Ivan Vasiliev. But what about the soloists, corps de ballet members and apprentices that make up the heart of the company? For the Met season each dancer — all told around 76 — will clock in roughly 160 hours of stage time, performing everything from leads, like the Firebird in Alexei Ratmansky’s new production, to one of the Wilis in “Giselle.”

headline: When Magical Thinking Wins the Game
text: In a post on our Slap Shot blog, Jay Schreiber of The Times writes about a sandwich that he believes may well be influencing the fate of the Rangers in Game 7 on Saturday night. He is certainly not alone in his magical thinking. Fans everywhere incorporate all kinds of routines into their lives, believing they could very well help steer the hand of fate.

headline: Black Babies and Blackboard Predictions
text: Something very strange, but very telling, took place in the spring of 1862 during Congressional deliberations about a proposed measure to abolish slavery in the District of Columbia: senators debated black birth rates, colonization and the likelihood – the desirability, even – of blacks disappearing as a race. A debate that began as a consideration of the fate of 3,000 men and women in the District of Columbia became a wide-ranging discussion about the demographic future of the nation.

headline: The Corner of Falstaff and Zerbinetta
text: THE gods had Olympus. Baseball has Cooperstown. Broadway has Sardi’s. And the Metropolitan Opera?

headline: Paperback Row
text: ON CHINA,  by Henry Kissinger. (Penguin, $18.) Over four decades Kissinger has strived to help Washington and Beijing prevail over a history of conflict, mutual grievance and fear. His shrewd review of Sino-American relations shows how China’s history has shaped its foreign policy; addresses the central role he played in Nixon’s historic trip to China; and argues that a strategic partnership is “essential to global stability and peace.”

headline: A Higher Price Tag for a Nuclear Project
text: The flagship project of a hoped-for but not-yet-realized “nuclear renaissance,” the Vogtle 3 and 4 reactors under construction near Augusta, Ga., may cost about $900 million more than had been estimated, the Southern Company said in a filing this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Off the Charts: Germany’s Trade Within the Euro Zone Falls
text: Germany’s trade surplus with other members of the euro zone has plummeted since the beginning of 2012, but has risen with countries outside the European Union.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Against Massachusetts, Colgate Will Meet Its Match
text: The Colgate men’s lacrosse team advanced to the N.C.A.A. tournament for the second time in program history on Sunday, when they were selected to play the University of Massachusetts as an at-large bid. The Raiders (13-3) secured the bid with a 13-11 win over A.C.C. powerhouse Maryland the day before. The game was fairly close throughout, but a four-goal run in the final minutes of the third quarter and the opening minutes of the fourth put Colgate up 11-9 from down 9-7.

headline: May 13 — 19
text: IMMIGRATION is an issue everywhere in the country, but Arizona may be the epicenter, and its schools are among the places where the various positions have their most practical effects. “PRECIOUS KNOWLEDGE,” Thursday on PBS’s “Independent Lens” series (check local listings), takes a look at how a Mexican-American studies program in Tucson was affected by state legislation to abolish such initiatives.

headline: In New Ad, Defense of Ann Romney and Motherhood
text: Motherhood, apple pie — and political attacks.

headline: S.E.C. Opens Investigation Into JPMorgan’s $2 Billion Loss
text: Regulators are investigating potential civil violations surrounding the $2 billion loss that JPMorgan Chase disclosed on Thursday, raising further questions about trading activities at the nation’s biggest bank.

headline: Twice-Cooked Duck With Pea Shoots
text: Time: About 20 minutes, plus about 1 hour for initial duck simmering

headline: Duck at 2 Speeds, Capturing the Wok’s Magic
text: I AM a huge fan of Chinese food, but I’ve never had any real training in its preparation. My education, if you could call it that, has been gleaned mostly from travel, cookbooks, advice from friends and eating in restaurants.

headline: Developers Cease to Offer Condo Incentives
text: THREE months ago, when Wei Min Tan, a broker at Rutenberg Realty, negotiated a deal for a new $3 million three-bedroom condominium at the Aldyn on the Upper West Side, he was able to save his buyers $95,000 in transfer taxes and other costs, as well as to finagle a free storage space.

headline: Who Is Who in the British Tabloid Scandal
text: Key individuals involved in the News of the World phone hacking scandal.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Creative Destruction
text: The Times’s David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about creative destruction in contemporary culture.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Maryland Has Momentum
text: The Maryland women’s lacrosse team turned around its season after a stretch of inconsistency, and won three consecutive games in the A.C.C. tournament, two against teams that had beaten them earlier in the season, to remain the class of the always powerful A.C.C.

headline: President of Rock Hall to Step Down
text: The longtime president and chief executive of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum announced on Friday that he will retire at the end of 2013, and the museum’s board of trustees has begun a search for a successor. The official, Terry Stewart, 66, has been in charge of the Cleveland institution since 1999.

headline: Stephanie & Alastair
text: Stephanie and Alastair tell the story of how they met through a mutual friend who suggested they should date after finding photos of Alastair and Stephanie each dressed in Harry Potter costumes.

headline: Chronicling the Pounds, Their Risks and Causes
text: DURING the production of “The Weight of the Nation,” a set of films about obesity that HBO will start showing this week, John Hoffman watched over and over again the commercials for sugary snacks and gut-busting meals that appear in excerpts. He knew exactly which buttons the ads were trying to push and why, yet he still was not immune to them.

headline: City Unveils Locations of Bike-Share Stations
text: The bike-share stations will be pliable, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said — their assembly so simple that, if problems arise, docks can be removed without leaving a trace.

headline: Two Smooth Operators on the Line
text: Pillow Talk

headline: Crossover Realities: The Singers and Styles That Stoke His Sound
text: The Atlanta rapper B.o.B. is known for his crossover collaborations. His debut album, “B.o.B. Presents: The Adventures of Bobby Ray,” which reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart in 2010, included Haley Williams, the singer for the emo rockers Paramore; Rivers Cuomo of Weezer; and a riff from Vampire Weekend, among others. A year earlier, for his first hit, “Nothin’ on You,” he collaborated with the R&B singer Bruno Mars. And “Both of Us,” the current chart-topping single from his second album, “Strange Clouds,” released this month by Grand Hustle Records/Rebel Rob Entertainment/Atlantic Records, features Taylor Swift. Nicki Minaj and Morgan Freeman also make appearances on “Strange Clouds,” along with the strains of B.o.B. himself strumming the guitar.

headline: Dressing Up the Duck
text: In this week’s City Kitchen column, I’m making twice-cooked duck, a sort of Western cook’s variation on a theme. It’s actually an amalgam of a few ideas. Based on the classic Chinese twice-cooked pork and packed with sweet and hot Sichuan flavor, I added cumin seeds. Not typically thought of as a Chinese seasoning, cumin is in fact used throughout northern China, and lately a number of New York restaurants have been featuring it in a dish called Muslim lamb chop, or in various other spicy lamb dishes. I’m a cumin fan, and I think it works well with the duck too, but leave it out if you wish.

headline: Programmers Keep Shows’ Prospects in Focus (Groups)
text: IN the spring of 1989 NBC seemed to have a new hit comedy on its hands. As the network prepared to announce its fall schedule, executives were thrilled to find that test audiences loved “Sister Kate,” a sitcom about a nun who takes in a group of orphans. Meanwhile the test results from another show about a stand-up comic and his quirky friends had also come back and seemed to be equally definitive, but in the opposite direction.

headline: TMX Group’s Quarterly Earnings Decline 10%
text: OTTAWA — The parent company of the Toronto Stock Exchange reported lower first-quarter earnings and revenue on Friday as it continued to wait for regulators to approve its takeover by a consortium of Canadian financial institutions.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: For Denver, a Fast Start Matters
text: After a heartbreaking overtime loss to Loyola in the semifinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament, the University of Denver men’s lacrosse team received an at-large bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: An End to Bad-Hair Days
text: IT was around 1960, during her early days as a model and years before she became an editor at Vogue, that Grace Coddington met the famed hairstylist Vidal Sassoon. Ms. Coddington, born in Wales and not yet 20, was a hit among the hairdressers of London.

headline: Bookshelf: Brothers and Sisters
text: Picture books about siblings.

headline: Going to the Chapel and We’re Not Getting Married
text: When President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage on Wednesday, he mentioned “those soldiers or airmen or Marines or sailors who are out there fighting on my behalf” who are gay but cannot marry in most states.

headline: Dewey’s Bankruptcy Big Wig Joins Proskauer
text: For the past several weeks, Dewey & LeBoeuf’s Martin J. Bienenstock, one of the country’s leading bankruptcy lawyers, has worked on among the most difficult assignments of his career — trying to save his own law firm.

headline: Bookshelf: Brothers and Sisters
text: ONE SPECIAL DAY  By Lola M. Schaefer. Illustrated by Jessica Meserve.  40 pp. Disney-Hyperion Books. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: Investing in Restaurants Can Work, but It’s Not as Easy as Pie
text: RELAXING in a restaurant, satisfied after a good meal and maybe a glass of wine, it’s easy to dream about what it would be like to own the place.

headline: Eike Batista to Invest in Brazilian Music Festival
text: Eike Batista, the Brazilian billionaire who made a fortune in the oil, gas and mining industries, is making a move into the music business.

headline: General Motors Pursues LEED Certification in Brazil
text: As automakers rush to demonstrate leadership on environmental issues, green has become marketing gold. The latest proof came from General Motors, which said Thursday that it expected an engine plant under construction in southern Brazil to receive Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design certification.

headline: Obama to Skip Economic Summit in Russia
text: As the White House pondered the meaning of President Vladimir V. Putin’s abrupt decision to skip next week’s Group of Eight summit meeting at Camp David, the Russians took note of the fact that President Obama was skipping an Asian summit meeting in Russia later this year.

headline: For a Day, Kimmel Beats Leno in Ratings
text: This is news that can only bring a smile to the face of Jimmy Kimmel: Thursday night, he beat probably his most bitter rival, Jay Leno, in the ratings — even though Mr. Leno had a 30-minute head start on him.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: The Case for the ‘Cats
text: Comic-book fans eagerly awaiting the summer release of “The Dark Knight Rises” have been particularly intrigued by the tagline on one of the early posters of the film that reads, “The legend ends.”

headline: Divorcing a Husband, but Not a Grandmother?
text: This week’s quandary is a simple one. “I’m going through a divorce,” a friend posted on my Facebook page. “I now have a soon-to-be ex-mother-in-law who is very much still the grandmother of my kids. I’d love to see some sage advice on how to navigate this tricky relationship.”

headline: Britney Spears Likely to Join Judges of ‘X Factor’
text: Britney Spears is likely to be named a judge on Season 2 of “The X Factor” on Monday as the show’s creator, Simon Cowell, reveals changes to the singing competition.

headline: Reflections on the Third Annual Found Poem Contest
text: It gets harder to choose every year.

headline: So Long, High School … College Awaits!
text: The process for enrolling into college is finally over. It is time for the fun to begin!

headline: A ‘Phantom’ Has Not Vanished Entirely
text: Suddenly, there it is. Everywhere. Almost overnight, it seems, 1 World Trade Center has inserted itself into the skyline, visible from places where the sky had seemed more empty than open since 2001.

headline: Amy Goldman and Cary Fowler
text: IT was a passion for seeds that brought Amy P. Goldman and Cary Fowler together, and although their romance began fairly recently, it had been germinating for some time, invisible in both of their lives, like a kernel in the ground.

headline: Outside Europe, German Trade Surplus Soars
text: GERMANY’S trade surplus with its fellow euro nations has fallen to the lowest level in nearly a decade. But its trade surplus with countries outside Europe is soaring.

headline: Back to Basics, Real Basics
text: TO some, our obsessive bent toward refinement has created humanity’s greatest triumphs: art, architecture, music, Cobb salad. Others wring their hands at more suspect refinements — white flour, white sugar, white chocolate — and see only doom. But do we have a choice?

headline: Cracking the Smart Energy Market
text: American homes are getting smarter, at least when it comes to using energy, a consumer research firm reports. By 2020, some 60 percent of homes in the United States will have some type of smart energy management system, according to estimates from the firm, Parks Associates. Still, adoption has been slower than some companies had hoped.

headline: How to Mother a Mother
text: During pregnancy, many women are pampered and cared for more than at any other time of their lives. Husbands are attentive, family members call to see how the mom-to-be is feeling, and friends host baby showers, lavishing a woman with gifts and attention.

headline: Forty Years Later, a Photographer Finally Gets His Show
text: Recently a photographer friend on Facebook introduced me to the remarkable work of John Myers, who had his first solo exhibition earlier this year at the Ikon Gallery in Birmingham, England. What made this feel like such a discovery is not only quality of the pictures themselves but also the fact that Myers stopped taking photographs altogether in 1988.

headline: A Radio Talent Turned TV Talent Judge
text: Howard Stern, the controversial but popular radio host, will join NBC’s popular summer competition, “America’s Got Talent,” as its latest judge.

headline: Macroeconomic Morality
text: A brief postscript to today’s column: contrary to what some people may think, I don’t regard anyone who disagrees with me as necessarily a mendacious idiot. Economics is hard, and people will disagree. Sometimes people will give advice with the best of intentions that turns out, in hindsight, to have been disastrous; that’s a tragedy but not a sin.

headline: Want to Be at the Garden for Game 7? Wallet, Please
text: There are few experiences in sports like a game seven. One team wins, the other goes home.

headline: Austerity, Safety Nets, and Spending
text: The latest in the attempt to make excuses for the abject failure of austerity is the claim that European countries didn’t really practice austerity after all. This is mainly coming from the usual suspects – the people who, for example, used Census hiring to claim that Obama was presiding over a vast expansion of government employment. (What will it take for pundits to realize that if Veronique de Rugy, for example, cites a number you can pretty much assume that it’s wrong?) But I have to say that the responses I’ve seen have been surprisingly weak – some people who should know better are conceding the point that maybe there haven’t been big spending cuts. Yes, there have.

headline: Crédit Agricole Plans Contingency for Greek Exit
text: PARIS — One of France’s biggest banks, Crédit Agricole, said Friday that it was working on contingency plans in case Greece exits the euro, the latest on a growing list of European financial firms and businesses to signal they were preparing for all possible outcomes as Greece’s financial and political situation deteriorate.

headline: Mitt Romney, Bullying and Long Shadows
text: What you do, what you post, what you say matters — now, and for a long time to come.

headline: In Black and White, a Gritty History of New York Crime
text: Here’s one case where, as far as the city is concerned, crime can pay. Among the 840,000 archival images placed online recently by the city’s Department of Records are 1,326 police evidence photographs mostly taken from 1915 to 1920. The Municipal Archives gallery provides free research online and at a new visitors’ center at 31 Chambers Street behind City Hall, but a digital file or 8-by-10 print will cost $45.

headline: Book Review Podcast: A Novelist’s View of the Absurdities of Motherhood
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Judith Warner considers two new books about the culture and politics of motherhood, and Judith Newman reviews Anne Enright’s memoir “Making Babies.” Ms. Enright is an acclaimed fiction writer who won the Man Booker Prize in 2007 for her novel “The Gathering.” Though Ms. Newman writes that, “No subject offers a greater opportunity for terrible writing than motherhood,” she praises Ms. Enright’s contribution to the genre:

headline: The Digital Lost-Dog Poster
text: “BONNIE is missing” blared the e-mail subject line. A 2-year-old female pit bull weighing 55 pounds, with gray and white markings, she was last seen on the corner of Maple Avenue and Myrtle Street in my community, wearing a chain collar. “I am asking for your help in finding my lost dog,” her owner pleaded.

headline: Puerile
text: I’ve been debating whether to post this, but I guess I probably should just for future reference. Apparently there are a number of people on the political right who have given up actually trying to refute what I say, and have turned to stupid pranks instead. Regular readers may recall that in recent months one guy opened a Google Plus account pretending to be me, making outrageous posts that got picked up by right-wing blogs; then someone opened a fake Twitter account in my name, doing the same thing.

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Sweet Smell of Raúl Esparza
text: Actors go to great, often absurd lengths preparing for roles: Robert De Niro gained more than 60 pounds to better portray Jake LaMotta in “Raging Bull”; Nicole Kidman did Cyrano de Bergerac one better by growing a formidable Virginia Woolf-like nose in “The Hours.” But real method acting is less complicated and literal than that. It’s about making connections to sensory experiences — sights, smells, tastes, sounds — in order to flesh out a character’s character. The consummate Broadway actor Raúl Esparza is very clever in this regard: he picks a cologne/perfume for each role he takes and wears the scent until the the show shutters.

headline: The Risks of Restaurant Investing
text: In the latest installment in his series on investing in a passion, Paul Sullivan, in this week’s Wealth Matters column, takes on investing in restaurants.

headline: Addiction Diagnoses May Rise Under Guideline Changes
text: WASHINGTON — In what could prove to be one of their most far-reaching decisions, psychiatrists and other specialists who are rewriting the manual that serves as the nation’s arbiter of mental illness have agreed to revise the definition of addiction, which could result in millions more people being diagnosed as addicts and pose huge consequences for health insurers and taxpayers.

headline: Australians Come to Visit (Or to Work or to Study)
text: Last year nearly 800,000 Australians traveled to the United States, an 81 percent increase over 2006. At a time when overall tourism to the United States has dipped, travel here has become the fastest growing market for Australians, according to Australia’s Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism.

headline: Times Sells Remaining Stake in Fenway Sports Group
text: The New York Times has sold its remaining stake in the Fenway Sports Group, the company that owns the Boston Red Sox, the latest in a continuing effort to shed assets unrelated to the company’s flagship newspaper.

headline: Checking In on Attendance Figures
text: Preseason expectations have a way of not panning out. Baseball pundits, for instance, expected the Yankees to be in the mix in the American League East and the crosstown Mets to be firmly in last place.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Daughter’s Therapeutic Memoir About Mom
text: Claiming the No. 1 spot on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is “Are You My Mother?: A Comic Drama,” a memoir within a memoir. Written and illustrated by Alison Bechdel, it focuses on her relationship with her mother and processes both creative and therapeutic.

text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Annual Census at Risk in House Budget Bill
text: One casualty of the sweeping budget bill that passed the House on Thursday was an annual survey conducted by the Census Bureau, a rich source of data that social researchers say is critical to modern demography.

headline: How Moore’s Law Affects Wall St. Trading
text: There are plenty of reasons that JPMorgan Chase had a $2 billion trading loss on a hedging strategy gone wrong — poor oversight, mismanaged risk and poorly constructed defenses.

headline: Bank Regulations Gain Fresh Support
text: WASHINGTON — Leading members of Congress on Friday demanded that federal regulators strengthen proposed banking rules and scrutinize trading closely in the wake of JPMorgan Chase’s disclosures of trading losses.

headline: Knicks’ Problem in a Word: Offense
text: The New York Knicks lost in the first round to the Miami Heat because their offense faltered. During the regular season New York averaged 104.4 points per 100 possessions, also called offensive rating, which was 17th best in the N.B.A. In Games 1, 3, and 4 of the playoffs, New York managed deplorable ratings of 81.4, 82.8, and 94.1 respectively on offense.

text: The day in sports included diving in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., ice hockey in Stockholm and beach volleyball in Beijing.

text: Craig Breedlove was practically a household name in the 1960s, when he set speed records of 400, then 500 and finally 600 m.p.h. at the Bonneville Salt Flats.

text: The $2 billion trading loss that JPMorgan Chase disclosed late on Thursday provided ample ammunition for supporters of the Volcker Rule, which would restrict government-backed banks’ ability to conduct proprietary trading.

text: Research in Motion has said the security of its smartphones is superior to that of its competitors’ phones. But companies specializing in security tools for Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android systems may give businesses another reason not to buy a BlackBerry.

headline: Pretty Works That Are New, but Not All That Modern
text: A gala has two particular purposes: to raise money and to assure the donors that their money is assisting a cause that is worth believing in. At New York City Ballet, that cause has always been to make ballet face both past and future: to blend tradition (classical ballet) with modernity.

headline: McIlroy Remains Mystified by TPC Sawgrass

headline: Action-Oriented Sedan With a Predatory Spirit
text: GIVEN an unforeseen economic slump, an overblown unintended-acceleration drama and an unimaginable earthquake in Japan, it’s clear that the recent wounds suffered by Lexus and its parent, Toyota, weren’t all self-inflicted.

headline: Now Standard With a New Lexus: A Greeter and a Genius
text: WITH simple radios, bench seats and AAA road maps fading into history — replaced by Bluetooth audio, 20-way massaging chairs and voice-driven navigation systems — many frustrated owners need a new kind of driver’s ed.

headline: Wheelies: The Third Chances Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Conserving Utah’s Fragile Salt Flats
text: ANY number of racetracks hold claim to colorful back stories, their heritage of championships battled fiercely to the finish. But it is doubtful that any racecourse has a history to match that of the Bonneville Salt Flats.

headline: A Man With an Irresistible Urge to Run Wide Open
text: CRAIG BREEDLOVE was practically a household name in the 1960s, a result of his bringing the unlimited land-speed record back to the United States. In becoming the first to officially push the mark past 400 miles an hour, he dethroned a decades-long dynasty of capable British teams.
