text: More Photographs

headline: Nuggets Making Things Interesting Against Lakers
text: The story line appeared to be written early for the Lakers-Nuggets first-round playoff series. The Lakers went up, 2-0, and it seemed to follow that the Nuggets would be fading away soon at the hands of Kobe Bryant and Co.

headline: Opening Doors That Won’t Budge
text: AUDIS and Dodges that lock out their owners, and Lexus and Toyota hybrids with coolant leaks, are among the mechanical ailments covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Five Centuries in Love: That’s a Lot of Past Lives
text: Forget “till death do us part.” In the Bollywood romance “Dangerous Ishhq” love transcends bodies and conquers time. After a knock on the head and some past-life regression therapy, the long-suffering heroine, Sanjana (Karisma Kapoor), learns just how long she’s been suffering: about 500 years.

headline: Roasted Broccoli Rabe
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to roast leafy broccoli rabe.

headline: A Reprieve for NBC Comedies, Including ‘Community’ and ‘Parks and Recreation’
text: NBC seemed to shake up the Twitter-based fandom of its comedy lineup this week by delaying to the last minute orders to renew shows like “30 Rock,” “Community” and “Parks and Recreation.”

headline: Video: Roasted Broccoli Rabe
text: A recent addition to my roasted vegetable repertory is broccoli rabe. Like regular broccoli, its tamer sister, roasting renders it softer, sweeter and crisp around the edges. And if you happen to have the oven on anyway (say, for making splayed roast chicken), it’s also extremely convenient.

headline: Chic in Review | Kanye West, Fashion Police
From Ramallah, Tales of Danger and Dislocation
text: Last year the globetrotting Yoshiko Chuma and members of her collective, the School of Hard Knocks, traveled to the Palestinian city of Ramallah. There they collaborated with El-Funoun dance troupe on a production called “6 Seconds in Ramallah.” On Wednesday the work arrived in New York for the opening of the La MaMa Moves! festival, but it arrived in pieces.

headline: For Clippers, It’s All About Paul
text: Chris Paul is likely too committed a competitor to be altogether absent from the Los Angeles Clippers’ potential closeout game on Friday night, but as we saw in Game 5 on Wednesday, an ailing Paul nonetheless puts the Clippers at a substantial deficit.

headline: Carroll Shelby, Car Builder Who Added Muscle to American Racing, Dies at 89
text: Carroll Shelby, a Texas chicken farmer turned hot-rodder who went on to build innovative sports cars like the Cobra that challenged Europe’s longtime dominance of road racing as well as high-performance versions of production cars like the Ford Mustang, died on Thursday in Dallas. He was 89.

headline: Blooming Far Beyond Where They’re Planted
text: In essence, the Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall is a “contest in programming,” as Elliott Forrest from WQXR radio put it on Wednesday night in a brief onstage interview with Jacques Lacombe, the music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

headline: First Nuns and Girl Scouts, Next Dora the Explorer
text: The men who run the Catholic Church seem to have a lot of time on their hands.

headline: Germany Sees Increase in Crimes With Political or Racist Motives
text: BERLIN — Politically motivated violent crimes in Germany increased by nearly 18 percent in 2011, a year in which two U.S. airmen were killed by an Islamist extremist and a neo-Nazi cell identified as carrying out a series of previously unsolved murders of immigrants was uncovered.

headline: Can One Economist Replicate the Shenzhen ‘Miracle’?
text: In this week’s magazine, Adam Davidson writes about an economist who has advanced a radical proposal for developing countries: build a city from scratch. Take some uninhabited land, set up an autonomous government and assure investors that this city is safe for business. Paul Romer, the economist who came up with the idea, has persuaded Honduras to give it a shot. His advice was to start with a strip of land that could accommodate 10 million people.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Mother Myth and Big Omaha
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: Whitney Houston’s Family to Appear in a Reality Show
text: Members of Whitney Houston’s family have agreed to allow cameras into their lives for a reality show on the Lifetime cable channel later this year, Lifetime Networks announced on Friday.

headline: Friends. Cruelty. Whatever.
text: There’s something about telling an audience, “Now imagine a montage of things that signify the ’90s” that evokes the decade as much as flannel or Monica Lewinsky jokes.

headline: Senate to Hold Antitrust Hearings on Universal-EMI Deal
text: 6:41 p.m. | Updated A Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust issues will be holding hearings on the Universal Music Group’s proposed $1.9 billion takeover of EMI’s recorded-music division, which puts out work by the Beatles, the Beach Boys, Pink Floyd and many others.

headline: Romney to Avoid Same-Sex Marriage in Commencement Speech, Aides Say
text: Mitt Romney’s commencement address Saturday at Liberty University, the evangelical institution in Virginia founded by Jerry Falwell, comes on the heels of President’s Obama’s announcement Wednesday that he supports same-sex marriage.

headline: Time to Show Your Teacher Some Love
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Trio and Its Many Talented Friends
text: The never-ending jam band project — to mingle everything with everything else, preferably for a dancing crowd — flexed some happy permutations on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Masonic Armory in Fort Greene, where Medeski Martin & Wood and guests performed for the Undead Music Festival of jazz and improvised music. The trio of John Medeski on keyboards, Billy Martin on drums and Chris Wood on bass played three sets: on its own, as a trio swapping out one member for various guests and as the center of an expanded group with another batch of guests.

headline: A Request to Make the Pearson Tests Public
text: A parent writes that he believes there is no good educational reason to keep parents and others from seeing the state exams produced for the state by Pearson, and so has filed a request under the state's Freedom of Information Law for the release of copies of the exam and the answer sheets.

headline: Guilty Verdict in Murder Case That Involved Singer’s Family
text: CHICAGO — The former brother-in-law of Jennifer Hudson, the singer and actress, was convicted on Friday of murdering her mother, her brother and her young nephew.

headline: Majority Say Obama’s Gay Marriage Stance Won’t Change Their Vote
text: In the first poll to emerge after President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage, a majority of Americans say it will make no difference on how they vote in November. According to a Gallup/USA Today poll released Friday, 6 in 10 Americans said his support for same-sex marriage would not make a difference on how they vote, and 51 percent said they approved of his position on the issue.

headline: The Most Likely Route to Same-Sex Marriage: The Courts
text: President Obama threw his support behind same-sex marriage this week. But for the same-sex couples who must spend thousands of dollars on replicating the benefits that opposite-sex married couples automatically receive, his words won’t make much of a difference.

headline: A Prep-School Bullying Report, and Romney’s Reaction
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Queens D.A. Defends His Booking Program
text: To the Editor:

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Activists Look to Law
text: While President Obama’s support for same-sex marriage is symbolic, his words have little power to erase the long list of extra costs and legal hurdles that same-sex couples face. For a more realistic chance at change, gay couples are probably better off looking to the courts.

headline: The Girl Who Objects to Airbrushing Young Models
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Portrait of Segregation in New York City’s Schools
text: In New York, efforts over the years to reduce the segregation of schools have had little effect.

headline: A New Focus for Lawyers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tactical Play at the World Mind Sports Trial
text: Bridge can be an interesting tactical game. There may be no “right” action, only what works at the table.

headline: Romney’s Adversarial View of Russia Stirs Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney’s recent declaration that Russia is America’s top geopolitical adversary drew raised eyebrows and worse from many Democrats, some Republicans and the Russians themselves, all of whom suggested that Mr. Romney was misguidedly stuck in a cold war mind-set.

headline: ‘Why Don’t We Have Any White Kids?’
text: IN seventh-grade English class, sun leaked in through the windows. Horns bleated outside. The assignment was for the arrayed students to identify a turning point in their lives. Was it positive or negative? They hunched over and wrote fervidly.

headline: Cryptic Calendar and the People Who Made It
text: PHILADELPHIA — And it shall come to pass that when the 13th baktun comes to an end, so will the world. Everything, even the entombed red-cinnabar-coated kings, shall be destroyed in an apocalypse. So it has been foretold — and so many believe — by the ancient Maya calendar; even Maya deities like the jade-haired maize god and the goggle-eyed storm god must submit. In Arabic numerals the final date would be represented this way: 13.0.0.0.0.

headline: Iran Presses for Official to Be Next Leader of Shiites
text: NAJAF, Iraq — As the top spiritual leader in the Shiite Muslim world, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani has instructed his followers on what to eat and how to wash, how to marry and to bury their dead. As a temporal guide, he has championed Iraqi democracy, insisting on direct elections from the earliest days of the occupation, and warned against Iranian-style clerical rule.

headline: Friday Night Music: Wye Oak
text: It’s been a while since I posted anything of theirs, and I don’t think I’ve ever actually put up their biggest song so far. Two versions here, acoustic and not; actually, I often find that watching two very different versions of a song makes me appreciate both versions more, because you get a better sense of the “bones” of the thing (and also of just how good the musicians are). For some reason the embed isn’t working on the acoustic version, so here’s the link.

headline: In Germany’s Most Populous State, a Regional Leader Rises to Challenge Merkel
text: COLOGNE, Germany — Social Democrats here in Germany’s most populous state are drawing inspiration from François Hollande’s defeat of incumbent President Nicolas Sarkozy in France and hoping that a victory in this political bellwether will spell the beginning of the end of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s seven-year reign.

headline: A Facebook Founder Renounces His U.S. Citizenship
text: Eduardo Saverin, one of the founders of Facebook, officially defriended the United States in September, giving up his American citizenship for the more tax-friendly residency status of Singapore.

headline: At a Bronx Middle School, a Day of Selling and Learning
text: Like hawkers at a street fair, the students of M.S. 223 in the Bronx worked the crowd at their annual business expo on Friday, trying to sell interest in the companies and products they created. The principal, Ramon Gonzalez, was thrilled with the students' enthusiasm: “They got a chance to sell their ideas, their products, to adults. It’s great.”

headline: The Mother of All Bad TV Moms
text: Sorry to bring this up on a weekend devoted to celebrating mothers, but you know all the things that have been wrong with young people for the past half-century? Mom’s fault.

headline: Traveling on Foot to the 19th Century
text: There are niche companies. And then there is Jody Sperling’s Time Lapse Dance, whose raison d’être is the American stage artist Loïe Fuller (1862-1928), a pioneering figure in modern dance who dazzled Paris and captured the imagination of numerous artists with her spectacular performances fashioned from fabric and light.

headline: Merger Not Ruled Out at American Airlines
text: Facing criticism from its labor groups and pressure from rival airlines, American Airlines said on Friday that it would be willing to consider a merger while it restructured operations in bankruptcy court, even as it stressed that it still intended to emerge from bankruptcy as a stand-alone carrier.

headline: Facebook Shares More About How It Uses Your Data
text: How does Facebook use all the words, pictures and clicks of its 901 million users?A group of European college students first raised that question last year. The Irish Data Protection Office, which regulates all of Facebook’s European data policies, took it up. On Friday, Facebook shared a bit more.

headline: Trayvon Martin’s Mom Makes a Mother’s Day Appeal
text: Sybrina Fulton, the mother of Trayvon Martin, made a Mother’s Day appeal in a video uploaded to YouTube on Friday, asking people across the country to oppose gun laws like the one in Florida that has been cited in her son’s shooting death.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 11
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the unveiling of the bike for New York’s new bike-share program, an arrest connected to a long-unsolved murder and the voting tendencies of the city’s Russian immigrants.

headline: Diagnosing the D.S.M.
text: AT its annual meeting this week, the American Psychiatric Association did two wonderful things: it rejected one reckless proposal that would have exposed nonpsychotic children to unnecessary and dangerous antipsychotic medication and another that would have turned the existential worries and sadness of everyday life into an alleged mental disorder.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fabulosity
text: The fashion world’s 64-year-old party of the year, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute benefit, is now a celebrity gala.

headline: Territory Claimed by China and Philippines Is Mainly Underwater
text: As my colleague Jane Perlez reported on Thursday, China expressed concern for “the safety of Chinese nationals and institutions in the Philippines,” before protests planned for Friday over a small territory in the South China Sea claimed by both nations.

headline: Action Cinema That’s Beaten to Bloody Pulp
text: Ahhhh, the music of action movies: the squeal of car brakes, the staccato report of an assault rifle, the meaty crunch of a roundhouse right. Not everyone’s idea of ear candy, certainly, but for discerning mavens of mayhem, these auditory delights, and their visual accompaniment, are delectable.

headline: TimesCast | Succeeding Ayatollah Sistani
text: Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the supreme religious leader for the world’s Shiite Muslim community, is 81, and because of his age, Iran has offered its own candidate to replace him.

headline: Still Flaunting the Luxe Life
text: Last year, Joseph C. Nunes, a professor of marketing at the University of Southern California, published a paper with two colleagues in the Journal of Consumer Psychology titled “Conspicuous Consumption in a Recession: Toning It Down or Turning It Up?” Examining product lines from Louis Vuitton and Gucci developed right before the financial crisis of 2008 and during the recession, the researchers concluded that despite the predictable musings of the popular press forecasting diminished ostentation, showiness was thriving. Logos were far more prominently displayed on products introduced during the recession than they were on products that went out of circulation, they determined. Prices were raised, and the profits of the companies hardly suffered as a result.

headline: The Anatomy of a Jokester
text: Today, let’s do a favor for Mitt Romney.

headline: Motion to Dismiss Charges Against Edwards Is Denied
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — The fate of former Senator John Edwards will remain in the hands of a federal jury, despite arguments by his lawyers here on Friday that the government has failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that he broke the law and that all charges should be dropped.

headline: Have the BRIC Nations Lost Their Momentum?
text: What happens to the world economy if Brazil, Russia, India and China experience a slowdown?

headline: Algerian Election Results Draw Disbelief
text: ALGIERS — Algeria’s governing party strengthened its rule in parliamentary elections this week, officials announced Friday, dampening hopes that the vote might bolster the standing of opposition voices and eliciting audible gasps of skepticism from many of those who heard the results at a hilltop hotel here.

headline: The Last Empress
text: SHE almost squeaked through unscathed. A product of a generation of patrician Americans who lived by the dictum that a woman’s name ought to appear in print only at birth, marriage and death, Rachel (Bunny) Lambert Mellon, the widow of the banking heir and philanthropist Paul Mellon, made it almost to her centenary little known outside her rarefied sphere.

headline: $12 Million to Help Cuomo Came From Just 20 Donors
text: A new group backing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo raised more than $12 million from just 20 donors last year, helping it rapidly become the largest-spending advocacy organization in Albany politics, according to documents released by the group late Friday.

headline: This Prague Spring Features Music
text: With a rousing program of local and international music acts, Prague Spring kicks off on Saturday, offering a tantalizing prelude to the Czech capital’s packed summer festival season.

headline: Meditation, and Time With the Sticks
text: Dafnis Prieto, a Cuban-born drummer and composer, has spent the past 12 years working with some of jazz’s most demanding bandleaders —  the Latin-jazz pianists Eddie Palmieri and Michel Camilo, the avant-garde saxophonists Henry Threadgill and Steve Coleman —  and forging his own voice as an artist. The recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship last year, Mr. Prieto, 37, is often on tour, and so he savors any Sunday he can get in Washington Heights, where he has lived since he arrived in New York in 1999. He moved to his current apartment in January, and lives there with his girlfriend, Ivet Ros Perez, 43, a nurse in the intensive care unit at Montefiore Medical Center.

headline: Obama Returns to Topic of Economic Recovery
text: RENO, Nev. — After unexpectedly endorsing same-sex marriage and injecting a volatile social issue into the 2012 race, President Obama returned to the topic of the economy Friday, promoting his proposals to allow more Americans to get low-interest mortgage refinancing.

headline: Reviewing the Lexus GS 350
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2013 Lexus GS 350, the midrange luxury sport sedan from Toyota’s luxury subsidiary.

headline: Nuclear Negotiator Seeks ‘Beginnings of the End’ of Iran Dispute
text: The lead negotiator for the six-nation group bargaining with Iran over its contentious uranium enrichment program said Friday that she hoped to achieve “the beginnings of the end” of the dispute at the next meeting, to be held in Baghdad on May 23.

headline: Edward Lear, 200 Years On
text: There are two Lears in English Literature: King and Edward. One veered off into madness.

headline: As Dewey Collapses, Partners and Retirees Face Big Financial Losses
text: For the law partners at Dewey & LeBoeuf, losing their jobs may be the least of their worries.

headline: Harlem Split on Plan to Honor Officer Killed in Mosque in ’72
text: Stirring emotions that date back 40 years to days of violent tension between African-American Muslims and the police, a Harlem community board is weighing whether to name a street after a police officer who was shot in 1972 inside a renowned Harlem mosque. People in the neighborhood wonder whether the gesture will reopen old wounds or help heal them.

headline: Gone Hollywood, With Subtitles
text: “THIS is my exercise,” said Somasundaram Gunasegaram as he scrambled nimbly up an iron ladder to the cramped projection booth in the Jackson Heights Cinema, a tired old movie house on 82nd Street just off Roosevelt Avenue in Queens.

headline: In Heart of Mariners Lineup, a Reminder to the Yankees
text: The man Yankees fans regard as the Burglar of Seattle, better known as Jack Zduriencik, was not wearing a mask or a striped shirt when he arrived at Yankee Stadium, and he was not carrying Jesus Montero around in a white sack over his shoulder. Still, there are many who believe that he robbed the Yankees.

headline: The Bet That Blew Up for JPMorgan Chase
text: When will Wall Street stop springing these types of nasty surprises?

headline: Pyramid Power,  Over Me
text: Dick Clark’s death reminded me of how much a part he was of some of the most fun I ever had in my life. I mean being on “The $25,000 Pyramid.”

headline: With a Typewriter in Tow, a Cyclist Fosters Creativity
text: COLD SPRING, N.Y. — The turquoise typewriter sat on a small white table in the middle of a wide sidewalk on Main Street. Beside it stood a beckoning chalkboard: “Write Yourself Here.”

headline: Afternoon Tea in Old New York
text: Entering the Carlyle from Madison Avenue and 76th Street after, say, a visit to the Whitney or the Frick, is like stepping into a discreet and private cocoon. And to float into the hotel’s Gallery, the two narrow rooms where afternoon tea is served, is to walk onto a film set, or to lose track of time entirely. Suddenly, it could be midnight, though you could only be in New York. The walls are darkly papered and paneled with still lifes of flowers; the lights are softened by pleated shades, and unless there’s music at the adjacent Café Carlyle, the only sound is of civilized conversation. It’s the perfect place to talk. And who better to talk to than your mother?

headline: Businessman Killed at Hotel Had Host of Critics
text: There was no shortage of people who had a problem with Brian J. Weiss.

headline: The Struggle to Vote
text: It was nearly 10 p.m. on Wednesday when Paul Broun, a Republican congressman from Georgia, rose on the House floor to propose that no more money be spent enforcing a section of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

headline: Family Told How to Hide Inheritance, U.S. Claims
text: The meeting of the Seggerman family at the elegant Four Seasons Hotel in New York in August 2001 was like many such gatherings of bereaved families: a patriarch had died and the children had come to discuss their inheritances.

headline: Crossword Puzzle Stirs Controversy in Venezuela
text: LIMA, Peru — Among the answers to a crossword puzzle that ran in a Venezuelan newspaper on Wednesday were A-D-A-N, the first name of President Hugo Chávez’s brother; R-A-F-A-G-A-S, which can refer to a burst of machine-gun fire but also a gust of wind; and A-S-E-S-I-N-E-N, which in Spanish is the plural of the imperative form of the verb to kill.

headline: McIlroy Is Afterthought Again at Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Tiger Woods’s quest to avoid another missed cut and Rory McIlroy’s failure to make the cut were the center of attention Friday at the Players Championship.

headline: No. 1 Florida Wastes No Time in Becoming a Force
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. —  As a high school senior in the fall of 2008, Sam Farrell was courted by many of the elite women’s college lacrosse programs in the country. She had led her high school team to a pair of Maryland state championships, and perennial national title contenders like North Carolina, Maryland and Johns Hopkins wanted her services.

headline: Loss Stains JPMorgan’s Chief, One of Banking’s Top Risk Managers
text: Days before revelations of JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss rocked Wall Street, the company’s always-confident chief executive, Jamie Dimon, was his usual exuberant self.

headline: In North Carolina, Beliefs Clash on Marriage Law
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — North Carolina is as good a place as any and possibly better than most to explore the often contradictory sentiments at the heart of the same-sex marriage debate.

headline: Veterans Against Youth in Celtics-76ers Matchup
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — The playoffs so often take on a Darwinian approach, and the Boston Celtics on Friday certainly felt as if they survived — and not much else — in defeating the Atlanta Hawks in the first round.

headline: A Russian Protest Leader Takes Center Stage
text: MOSCOW

headline: The Push to Make Cab Rides Smarter
text: When it comes to technology, 2007 was the last big year for taxis. That year, New York City began requiring that cabs be fitted with devices so that customers could pay with credit cards and with GPS devices so that they could track their progress on touch screens in the back. (Cabbies went on strike twice before the gadgets were finally installed.) Also that year, Apple introduced the iPhone, although the cab connection was not immediately apparent.

headline: In JPMorgan Chase Trading Bet, Its Confidence Yields to Loss
text: When reports emerged in the first week of April that a JPMorgan Chase trader in London was making bets so big they were distorting a little-known market in credit derivatives, an embedded regulator approached executives.

headline: Egyptian Campaign Focuses on Islam’s Role in Public Life
text: CAIRO — Twelve days before a presidential election, a televised debate that carried on into the early morning hours Friday has put the role of Islam in Egypt’s government at the center of the campaign, with the self-described liberal Islamist in the race coming under fire over whether his agenda is too religious or too secular.

headline: Who Speaks for the Children?
text: For decades, Brooklyn prosecutors pursuing child molesters netted few complaints or convictions in the borough’s cloistered, politically powerful community of ultra-Orthodox Jews. Rabbinical authorities banned relatives of the abused from reporting the crimes to non-Jewish authorities; those few who spoke out were shunned — expelled from synagogues, their children expelled from schools — or pressured into dropping their cases.

headline: When I Root, God Laughs
text: Religion, someone once said, is what goes through your mind as your plane taxis down the runway. It isn’t. What goes through your mind as your plane taxis down the runway is mortality. It’s aeronautics. It’s the space shuttle Columbia.

headline: Memories of a 1994 Classic
text: My wife remarked the other day that I seem to have acquired a second job, one with a lot of late hours. She isn’t wrong, exactly. With the N.H.L. playoffs under way, I have been putting in a lot of time as a hockey fan, watching a game, sometimes two, almost every night, and the experience is so draining that it does sometimes feel like work. When Game 3 of the Rangers-Capitals series went into triple overtime, I didn’t care who won. I just wanted someone to put the puck in the net so I could go to bed and get some sleep before reporting to my day job.

headline: Leftist Party’s Rise Upends Greek Political Order
text: ATHENS — The collapse of Greece’s dominant parties in Sunday’s elections swept a new political force onto the scene here: the Coalition of the Radical Left, or Syriza, a pro-euro yet anti-austerity party that has Greece’s creditors trembling with its calls for the country to reject its current loan agreement and nationalize the banks.

headline: What Seeds Are Often Planted In
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! The Sunday, the Variety puzzle will be a brand-new form that I won’t give away just yet, but I truly hope you will give it a try. It’s incredibly innovative and must have been a bear to construct. For this puzzle, there will be a Notepad that reads: “In each pair of clues, one is for the answer word, the other for an anagram of the answer. Which is which is for you to discover.”

headline: JPMorgan Chase’s $2 Billion Loss
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, can be clear as a bell when he denounces financial reform. But on an emergency conference call with analysts on Thursday to announce the bank’s stunning $2 billion trading loss, his message was frustratingly vague.

headline: In Remission and on a Mission
text: Seun Adebiyi — an Olympic hopeful, Yale Law School graduate and leukemia survivor — is trying to start a public cord-blood bank in Nigeria.

headline: When Will They Learn?
text: “It plays right into the hands of a bunch of pundits out there,” sighed Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, on Thursday.

headline: When Holst Read the Mahabharata
text: It wasn’t easy to compose operas in the wake of Richard Wagner, whose legacy loomed with menacing authority over the end of the 19th century. With his harmonic innovations, the mythical scope of his subjects and his delicate balance of grandeur and intimacy, Wagner was a model both seductive and treacherous.

headline: New York Times Company Sells Final Stake in Fenway Sports
text: The New York Times Company said on Friday that it had sold its remaining stake in the Fenway Sports Group, the company that owns the Boston Red Sox, the latest move in a continuing effort to shed assets unrelated to the company’s flagship newspaper.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: A College Stretch

headline: E-Mails Provide Inside Look at Mayor’s Charter School Battle
text: The city released hundreds of e-mail messages Friday, providing a behind-the-scenes look at one of the major battles of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration, the 2010 campaign to expand charter schools, or, as one dramatic e-mail put it, the “fight of our life.”

headline: Mean Boys
text: Mitt the menace.

headline: Rangers, Through Second-Guessing, Just Want to Play Game 7
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — There is not much to do about playing a Game 7 except play it, Rangers Coach John Tortorella said after practice Friday.

headline: Ibanez’s Homer Assures That Montero’s Blast Doesn’t Haunt Yankees
text: The Yankees entered last off-season with Jesus Montero as the expected designated hitter in 2012. General Manager Brian Cashman rerouted that plan in January when he traded Montero to the Seattle Mariners. That left the Yankees searching for designated hitter options before they helped filled the spot by signing Raul Ibanez in February.

headline: Finding a Match, and a Mission: Helping Blacks Survive Cancer
text: A month after his 2009 graduation from Yale Law School, Seun Adebiyi learned he had not one but two lethal blood cancers and began an odyssey to find a bone-marrow donor. Mr. Adebiyi, 28, who came to this country from Nigeria as a child, made appeals through Yale, on radio stations, in a YouTube video and even on a trip to Nigeria to ask law students to volunteer.

headline: In a Stylish Newcomer, a Promise of Bounty
text: A WELCOME newcomer to northern Central Avenue in White Plains, Grace’s Table occupies a site with an inauspicious past. Only four years ago, Gregory’s was gutted and remodeled into an elegant, extravagant, but oddly named restaurant, BOE@324. It never caught on and in quick succession Ibiza, Gervasi’s and Crave came and went in the same spot.

headline: After Difficult Start, Reyes and the Marlins Show Signs of an Awakening
text: MIAMI — Hours before Jose Reyes prepared to face the Mets for the second time this season, he insisted that he was feeling much more comfortable with his new team. As he smiled and leaned back in a chair in front of his locker, practically overflowing with Marlins gear, it certainly appeared that way.

headline: Scoring Two Against Francisco, Marlins One-Up the Mets’ Comeback
text: MIAMI — The Mets’ surprising early success and the Marlins’ unforeseen foibles have added some texture to the National League East’s story line, which was sketched out differently a few months ago.

headline: F.A.A. Chief Who Quit Is Cleared of Charges
text: A judge in Virginia has cleared the former chief of the Federal Aviation Administration of the drunken driving charges that cost him his job at the agency.

headline: Thousands of Species, Each a Work of Art
text: Joel Sartore has been a conservation photographer for more than 20 years, shooting primarily for National Geographic. About seven years ago, he brought his gear into a makeshift studio and began working with zoo-raised animals, most of which have biologists and handlers tending to their every need.

headline: Despite Opposition, Immigration Agency to Expand Fingerprint Program
text: Obama administration officials have announced that a contentious fingerprinting program to identify illegal immigrants will be extended across Massachusetts and New York next week, expanding federal enforcement efforts despite opposition from the governors and immigrant groups in those states.

headline: Introducing Children to the Sources of Food
text: STONINGTON, Conn.

headline: Yankees Demote Nunez So He Can Focus on Improving at Shortstop
text: Eduardo Nunez has played five positions and committed four errors in 20 games this season, two things that factored into the Yankees’ decision Friday to demote him to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre.

headline: Dimon vs. Volcker, the Television Series
text: Does Jamie Dimon think efforts to restrict banks’ trading have gone too far? Just ask him.

headline: Inside a Storefront, Sushi Under Blue Lights
text: ANY preconceived notions of what a storefront restaurant looks like are shattered by Kashi, a year-old Japanese place in Huntington. It is drop-dead gorgeous.

headline: Bloomberg Among Critics of Prosecutor in Brooklyn
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday sharply criticized the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, over his handling of child sexual abuse cases among the borough’s large ultra-Orthodox Jewish community.

headline: Certifying Good Growers
text: Four East End wine producers have founded a nonprofit education organization that will certify local growers as practitioners of sustainable agriculture.

headline: Lottery Numbers
At JPMorgan Chase, a Complex Strategy That Backfired
text: JP Morgan most likely structured a complicated trade in a way that effectively magnified losses.

headline: Evelyn B. Johnson, Pilot and Instructor, Dies at 102
text: Evelyn Bryan Johnson last flew a plane in 2005. Two years later, she remained eager to get back behind the controls.

headline: Joyce Redman, Actress Who Feasted on Many Roles, Dies at 96
text: Joyce Redman, a distinguished Irish-born actress widely acclaimed for her intelligent stage presence in Shakespearean drama and French comedy, though probably best known to American audiences for her silent improvisation with a lobster, an oyster, a pear and Albert Finney in the exuberantly lascivious eating scene in the 1963 film “Tom Jones,” died on Wednesday in Kent, England. She was 96.

headline: Corrections: May 12
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Mediterranean Fare, With Italian Flair
text: JOE ALBERGO spent most of his career cooking for hire, beginning at 15 in a Brooklyn luncheonette. Along the way — with stops in England, Spain, Jakarta and the restaurant of the Hôtel Plaza Athénée in New York — he quizzed his co-workers about their favorite native dishes. When he was finally ready to open his own place, Mr. Albergo drew on that accumulated lore, as well as on the lessons he had learned at the knee of his Neapolitan grandmother.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Berkshire Hathaway’s annual shareholders meeting, the coming Facebook public offering and a stunning trading loss by JPMorgan Chase were among the week’s top business stories.

headline: JPMorgan Sought Loophole on Risky Trading
text: WASHINGTON — Soon after lawmakers finished work on the nation’s new financial regulatory law, a team of JPMorgan Chase lobbyists descended on Washington. Their goal was to obtain special breaks that would allow banks to make big bets in their portfolios, including some of the types of trading that led to the $2 billion loss now rocking the bank.

headline: Childlike Fancies and Adult Terrors
text: The grotesque old witch who becomes young and beautiful at the end of Act I has arrived in Westport. So have the prince who explains that he was “raised to be charming, not sincere,” the rejected cow Milky White and the baker’s wife who can’t have children because of a salad-related curse.

headline: Alabama: Teenager Charged in Half-Sister’s Death
text: A 14-year-old boy was charged with murder on Friday in the strangling death of his 9-year-old half-sister. When the girl, Katelynn Arnold, was found hanging by a rope from a tree at her house in Ragland on Thursday night, her feet were touching the ground and the police were uncertain about the circumstances of her death. “It’s not an accident,” said Dennis Russell, the St. Clair County coroner. “It’s definitely a homicide.”

headline: Florida: Polo Mogul Is Sentenced to 16 Years
text: The polo tycoon John Goodman was sentenced to 16 years in prison for driving under the influence, manslaughter and vehicular homicide in the death of Scott P. Wilson, 23. The sentence was about half of the maximum faced by Mr. Goodman, 48, the founder of the International Polo Club Palm Beach in Wellington. In 2010, Mr. Goodman ran a stop sign in his Bentley convertible, striking Mr. Wilson’s car, which careered into a canal. Mr. Goodman walked home and waited an hour before calling 911, prosecutors said, and the victim drowned.

headline: Two Volumes on Parenting, From Two Perspectives
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

headline: Finding Comedy in Ailments, Longing and Despair
text: The prelude to the production of “Uncle Vanya” at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall is dramatic in its own way. Audience members travel down the center aisle of the lovely jewel-box theater in East Hampton and climb a stairway to the stage, where they find seating for 55 viewers.

headline: Death Watch, in Two Places
text: OF the roughly 75 items on display at the Suffolk County Historical Society in Riverhead, a menacing-looking object known as the Wickham ax has been especially fascinating to many visitors.

headline: A Frisky ‘Hound’ Frolics on the Moor
text: Sherlock Holmes, Dr. John Watson and Sir Henry Baskerville are discussing a mysterious letter while they swelter in a sauna and — wait, no, that can’t be right; there is no such sweaty encounter in Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s “The Hound of the Baskervilles.”

headline: Cooking on the Range, on the Delaware River
text: THE writer Elizabeth Gilbert is planning a family reunion in Frenchtown, where she lives, to celebrate the reissuing this month of the cookbook “At Home on the Range” (McSweeney’s), by her great-grandmother Margaret Yardley Potter.

headline: Syria: A Suicide Bomber Is Foiled in Aleppo, the State News Agency Says
text: Security forces in Aleppo killed a suicide bomber driving a stolen minibus crammed with five large canisters of explosives before he could detonate them, the state-run Syrian Arab News Agency reported Friday. The agency said the driver had intended to bomb Aleppo’s densely populated Al Shaar neighborhood a day after two suicide bombers killed at least 55 people in Damascus. Syrian officials say the attacks vindicate their contention that President Bashar al-Assad’s foes are foreign-backed terrorists, while opposition figures say the government is trying to scare people. But outside experts see growing evidence that fighters from neighboring countries, possibly sent by Al Qaeda in Iraq, are joining the fight in Syria, further complicating efforts by the United Nations and Arab League to uphold a shaky cease-fire. The number of United Nations truce monitors on the ground in Syria has now reached nearly half the planned total of 300, the chief United Nations spokesman, Martin Nesirky, said Friday. Mr. Nesirky rejected suggestions that the cease-fire was near collapse. “This is a plan that has the full support of the international community,” he said. “No one is saying this is an easy task.”

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Gone Hollywood, Bollywood Theater in Queens Still Struggles
text: “This is my exercise,” said Somasundaram Gunasegaram “as he scrambled nimbly up an iron ladder to the cramped projection booth in the Jackson Heights Cinema, a tired old movie house on 82nd Street just off Roosevelt Avenue in Queens,” Corey Kilgannon writes in The New York Times.

headline: Formula One Comes Home
text: BARCELONA — After running the first four races of the season either on the other side of the world or in the threatening unknown terrain of Bahrain, Formula One has come home to Europe. And boy, did it ever feel like home as the paddock people arrived in Barcelona for Sunday’s Spanish Grand Prix.

headline: Five Centuries in Love: That’s a Lot of Past Lives
text: Forget “till death do us part,” Rachael Saltz writes about the Bollywood romance “Dangerous Ishhq,” which means dangerous love. In the film “love transcends bodies and conquers time,” Ms. Saltz writes.

headline: The Early Word: Pivot
text: Today’s Times

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The illegal sale of 200 acres of land owned by the Defense Ministry in Srinagar to private owners has exposed the role of state government officials who were allegedly bribed to push the deal through. The sale of the land “posed a security threat” to strategic army installations and the airport in the valley, around which this contested piece of land is located, The Indian Express reported.

headline: Highlights From Junior Seau Public Memorial
text: Suggested reading on the public memorial for Junior Seau at Qualcomm Stadium in San Diego on Friday. Among the speakers were Dan Fouts, Bobby Ross, LaDainian Tomlinson and John Lynch. The Broncos’ John Elway, Peyton Manning and John Fox were among those in the crowd. A video highlight of the night can be found at ESPN.  The full speeches can be found at the Chargers’ Web site.

headline: Getting On the Bus by Getting Off the Bus in Suburbia
text: Last week was walk-your-kids-to-school week in the district where I live, and so that’s what my husband and I did. So did many of our friends and neighbors, which made for a sweet, old-fashioned scene at 8:30 each morning, as clusters of families funneled on foot onto the school property — like something out of “Little House on the Prairie,” except, of course, that many of us were clutching our children’s hands lest a rogue Subaru swerve out of control.

headline: JPMorgan and Solyndra
text: I haven’t weighed in on the JPMorgan stuff, because I haven’t had time to figure out the whole thing. I would say that I’ve always wondered why Jamie Dimon had such a reputation for smarts, since nothing I’ve seen seemed to justify the reverence; maybe nothing did.

headline: Europe Slips in World Influence Stakes
text: LONDON — Surprise, surprise! The international standing of European nations has declined in the past year, according to a survey published this week, and Germany is no longer the state most admired by the rest of the world.

headline: Horst Faas: A Last Hurrah
text: We asked Richard Pyle, Horst Faas’s colleague at The Associated Press for many years, who wrote Mr. Faas’s obituary for the A.P. (featured on Lens yesterday), for a personal remembrance of the famed photographer and photo editor.

headline: That Guy Renting Bowling Shoes Is a Beauty
text: Las Vegas has its share of drag shows, but a few cross-dressing entertainers have decided to trade their stilettos for bowling shoes.

headline: Dennis Tueart: Manchester City Forever
text: Dennis Tueart, the man who brought Manchester City its last major trophy — the 1976 League Cup — before the club won the 2011 F.A. Cup, has been making the rounds in England as one of his former clubs nears winning the Premier League title.

headline: Ashima’s Ascent
text: Ashima Shiraishi, an 11-year-old bouldering enthusiast from New York City, has been turning more than a few heads in the climbing world.

headline: Tiny Hand Over Hand
text: HUECO TANKS STATE PARK AND HISTORIC SITE, Tex. — With a concentrated squint, Ashima Shiraishi silently sized up her first rock of the day, a menacing slab of jagged beige boulder 20 feet high, scuffed by white chalk left behind from bigger, older, more experienced climbers.

headline: Spy Balloons Become Part of the Afghanistan Landscape, Stirring Unease
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The traders crouched beneath the walls of an old fort, hunkered down with the sheep and goats as they talked, eyes nervously flitting up from time to time at the blimp that has become their constant overseer.

headline: Romney Tells Evangelicals Their Values Are His, Too
text: LYNCHBURG, Va. — Mitt Romney traveled to Liberty University, the spiritual heart of the conservative movement, on Saturday, seeking to quell concerns about him among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life.

headline: Phil Who? Knicks Will Probably Play It Safe
text: For a decade, the Knicks conducted business like a crazed QVC addict with a stack of limitless credit cards — lunging at every shiny object, no matter the price or the consequences.

headline: Variety: All Mixed Up
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you haven’t done this puzzle yet, prepare to be amazed and astounded. I know I was.

headline: Q. and A. With Ray Lucas
text: Ray Lucas does not blame the N.F.L. for his addiction to prescription painkillers, and he does not blame football. After contemplating suicide, he got help, and he said he wants to throw a lifeline to others. Lucas, a former Rutgers, Jets and Dolphins quarterback, now an SNY football analyst, is working with Reckitt Benckiser Pharmaceuticals to inform the public about treatment options. In his case, he took Suboxone, an opioid that he said managed his withdrawal symptoms and eventually allowed him to subdue his addiction. Lucas, 39, answered questions recently via e-mail.

headline: After Divisive Primary, Shifting to the Center
text: WASHINGTON — Presidential nominees have several options for repositioning after ideologically charged primary campaigns: strategic silence, new proposals, a different tone on the brighter general election stage.

headline: At the 17th Hole at Sawgrass, Awaiting a Big Splash
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The betting window was closing. As the golfers Aaron Baddeley, Harrison Frazar and Justin Leonard walked to the 17th tee box at T.P.C. Sawgrass, the man in the bucket hat, golf shirt and khaki shorts waved a wad of dollar bills and said to the fans seated behind him, “Who do you have?”

headline: Death Sentence Reviews Leave Unsettled Issues in Texas
text: Stanley Schneider was shocked last year when Texas’ highest criminal court sent his death row client an early Christmas gift of sorts, ordering the trial court to re-examine evidence from a psychologist who had decided that John Reyes Matamoros was mentally fit to face execution.

headline: Greek Leader Will Attempt to Broker a Coalition
text: ATHENS — Greece’s president will start negotiations on Sunday to form a coalition government in a last-ditch effort to avoid new elections and further political turmoil.

headline: New District in Texas Promises a Scramble for Congress
text: Want to guarantee a campaign throwdown? Toss 2 major American cities, 2 large minority populations and 15 candidates into one newly drawn Congressional district.

headline: C.E.O. or Not, You Always Need Feedback
text: This interview with  Deborah Farrington, a founder and general partner at StarVest Partners, a venture capital firm in New York, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Factions Are Forming Among Texas Republicans
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Player’s 4-Homer Night Highlights Career
text: Michael Aubrey was home in Shreveport, La., last Tuesday night, studying for final exams, when his brother-in-law — a fan of the Texas Rangers — told him in a text message that Josh Hamilton had just hit his third home run. “I know a guy who did four,” the message said.

headline: Is There a Romney Doctrine?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A Next-Generation Offering From Willie Nelson
text: On April 20, on Willie Nelson Boulevard outside Austin City Limits Live at the Moody Theater in downtown Austin, Willie Nelson witnessed the unveiling of an eight-foot, one-ton bronze rendering of his likeness. Perhaps because he is too humble to ponder his own achievements, Mr. Nelson, 79, simply said with a smile, “I’ll be stoned 1,000 years.”

headline: A Dodgers Fan in Pinstripes in Postwar Japan
text: After they lost to the Brooklyn Dodgers in the 1955 World Series, the Yankees embarked on a six-week barnstorming tour of the Pacific islands.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Statistics Say Cooperstown, and Damon Agrees
text: BOSTON

headline: West Bank Leader Says Security Forces Can’t Get Guns
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said Saturday that his security forces were struggling because Israel had refused to allow them to import a shipment of weapons, and that he was “very, very, very afraid” of what might happen if one of the Palestinian prisoners on a long-term hunger strike died.

headline: Cutbacks Hurt a State’s Response to Whooping Cough
text: MOUNT VERNON, Wash. — Whooping cough, or pertussis, a highly infectious respiratory disease once considered doomed by science, has struck Washington State this spring with a severity that health officials say could surpass the toll of any year since the 1940s, before a vaccine went into wide use.

headline: Western Conference Finals Prediction
text: No. 3 Phoenix vs. No. 8 Los Angeles

headline: The Numbers Are Adding Up for the Thunder
text: Last season the Oklahoma City Thunder became the youngest team in N.B.A. history to reach the conference finals. The Thunder lost to the Dallas Mavericks, 4-1, in that series, but Oklahoma City exacted  revenge by sweeping the defending champions in the first round of this year’s playoffs.

headline: Man Arrested in Shooting in West Bank
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Palestinian Authority officials said Saturday that they had arrested the man they believed was responsible for the May 1 shooting at the house of the governor of Jenin, who died hours later after suffering two heart attacks.

headline: Human Rights, Not So Pure Anymore
text: THE international commotion around the blind Chinese activist Chen Guangcheng aroused memories of earlier dissidents like Andrei D. Sakharov and Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Eastern bloc heroes of another age who first made “international human rights” a rallying cry for activists across the globe and a high-profile item on Western governments’ agendas.

headline: Candidate in Egypt Makes an Insider’s Run for President
text: SHIRBEEN, Egypt — At a recent campaign rally here, Ala’a Zinhom said he had no interest in voting for Amr Moussa, a former Egyptian foreign minister who is campaigning for the job once held by Mr. Moussa’s old boss, President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: A Generation Hobbled by the Soaring Cost of College
text: ADA, Ohio — Kelsey Griffith graduates on Sunday from Ohio Northern University. To start paying off her $120,000 in student debt, she is already working two restaurant jobs and will soon give up her apartment here to live with her parents. Her mother, who co-signed on the loans, is taking out a life insurance policy on her daughter.

headline: Dodgers Are Starting to See Better Days
text: On his first game day as the president of the Los Angeles Dodgers, May 4 in Chicago, Stan Kasten basked in the scenery at Wrigley Field. He might have taken special pride in the flags flapping atop the center-field scoreboard.

headline: A New Amenity May Show Up on Some London Roofs for the Olympics: Missiles
text: LONDON — “It looked like one of those things where you get free pizzas through the post,” Hilal Bozkurt said, describing the innocuous-looking leaflet that came through her mail slot recently. “But this was like, free missiles.”

headline: Drowning in Debt
text: Like thousands of her peers, Kelsey Griffith will graduate from college owing thousands of dollars in student loans. Her university, which told her to pursue her dreams rather than focus on the price, didn’t tell her about the steep monthly payments she would be facing.

headline: Student Debt at Colleges and Universities Across the Nation
text: Interactive charts showing the increasing student debt levels at colleges and universities in the United States.

headline: Coyotes Keep Enduring and Winning
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The Phoenix Coyotes rank last in attendance in the league. They have been operating in bankruptcy for three years. They are so hamstrung financially that they have trouble signing free agents.

headline: Student Portraits: College Loans
text: The Times spoke to current and former students about taking loans to pay tuition.

headline: Syracuse Lacrosse Legend Has Women’s Team at No. 4
text: SYRACUSE — Gary Gait, who helped Syracuse win three consecutive N.C.A.A. lacrosse championships from 1988 to 1990, was recently watching another generation of players practicing the sport and preparing to pursue their own bit of history.

headline: Australia’s Superstar Mare Does It Again
text: On Saturday, Black Caviar did what she has always done: the superstar mare from Australia won another race, her 21st consecutive.

headline: Playoff Run Aside, Coyotes’ Ownership Is Still a Prickly Issue
text: After three seasons of fits and starts and various suitors, the Phoenix Coyotes could be sold in coming weeks to a group headed by Greg Jamison, the former chief executive of the San Jose Sharks.

headline: In Manchester, Supremacy in English Game Is Poised to Move Across Town
text: The Premier League title will be awarded Sunday in Manchester, England; that much is certain. This is not an uncommon occurrence.

headline: Sepia Tones Distort Feats of Distant Past
text: Last month, Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox pitched the 21st perfect game in the major leagues. Last week, Josh Hamilton, the Texas Rangers outfielder, became the 16th major leaguer to hit four home runs in a game.

headline: The Economics of Marginalization and Hopelessness
text: That’s one of the subject headings in this recent survey paper (pdf) on teen births, which are much higher in America than in other advanced countries. The authors find evidence suggesting that inequality and lack of mobility are central, another sign that Wilkinson-type views about the corrosive effects of inequality are going seriously mainstream.

headline: Protests Over Arms Sales to Bahrain
text: One day after the State Department said the United States would resume some arms sales to Bahrain — despite what the United States acknowledges as “unresolved human rights issues” among the country’s leadership — activists on Saturday denounced the measure, as demonstrators descended on the country’s capital city to protest the government’s detention of political prisoners.

headline: Breakout Season for Sacha Kljestan
text: When Anderlecht clinched its 31st Belgian title last Sunday after a 1-1 draw with Club Brugge, it was a career milestone for Sacha Kljestan who has been a consistent presence this season in central midfield for the Brussels-based club.

headline: Doan Keeps Faith in Coyotes
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Shane Doan, the Coyotes’ captain and longest-suffering member, does not often  mention his religion publicly. He  does not have a Tim Tebow-style celebration upon scoring a goal. But he does writes Bible verse on his hockey stick.

headline: E. J. Potter, ‘Michigan Madman’ of Motorcycle Racing, Dies at 71
text: E. J. Potter, a k a the Michigan Madman, a legend of the American drag strip who earned his nickname riding 170 miles per hour on a motorcycle he fitted with a Chevy V-8, and who later went nearly 200 m.p.h. on a three-wheel bike powered by a jet engine, died on April 30 in Ithaca, Mich. He was 71.

headline: What’s Really Scary
text: Update: Aha, Romm credits Michael Tobis at the bottom of the post.

headline: Dieting for Dollars (or Maybe a Movie Ticket)
text: BACK in 1999, Michael Paolini, an inventor at I.B.M. in Austin, Tex., was having lunch at a Ruby Tuesday’s with some fellow engineers when the group decided that too many burgers and fries were translating into thicker waistlines. It was time to lose weight.

headline: Meet Your Neighbors, if Only Online
text: I DON’T know many of my neighbors. I blame genetics: I’m hard-wired for shyness. Or so I thought until I signed up with Nextdoor.com, a neighborhood-based social network. There I have discovered a comfortable place for even a borderline recluse like myself.

headline: Mexican Violence Leaves Behind Trail of Doubts
text: COLIMA, Mexico — After her son Alfredo was killed last year at his auto parts shop, Carmen Plascencia de Carrillo noticed that two half sisters skipped the wake and funeral.

headline: Pregame Chatter: Preparing for Game 7
text: Preparing for a Game 7 can be tricky, as the Rangers’ John Mitchell discussed Saturday morning, hours before the big clash against the Washington Capitals at Madison Square Garden that would decide which team would advance to the Stanley Cup’s final four.

headline: Patents Aren’t Only for Engineers
text: I NEVER considered that I might obtain a patent one day. To me, patents were mostly for engineers, not for actuaries like me.

headline: García Rallies to Stay in Contention
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Sergio García was headed in the wrong direction, with no end in sight. But rather than give in to another frustrating weekend, García overcame some early hiccups and ended the third round of the Players Championship in contention.

headline: Brewers’ Owner Invests in Team That Built Team
text: Mark Attanasio is an investor, and his intuition has served him well in business and as the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers. His asset-management firm is growing, and although his baseball team is not winning — for now — it is stable.

headline: From Forklifts to Photography
text: I GREW up in Brooklyn, on Flatbush Avenue near Prospect Park. One of my earliest memories is of learning to use a hand dolly to move boxes. My father, who was a truck driver, later taught me how to operate a forklift and, when I was old enough, to drive an 18-wheeler.

headline: Fast Starts for Top Players at Three Elite Tournaments
text: The top-ranked players in three elite tournaments — the United States Championship in St. Louis, the Sigeman & Company event in Malmo, Sweden, and the 47th Capablanca Memorial tournament in Cuba — took early leads last week.

headline: Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care
text: THERE are lots of important things to worry about these days: terrorism, the economy, climate change and, for Yankee fans, the loss of Mariano Rivera. But worry is a scarce commodity. Even a mother — Jewish or not — can’t worry about everything. So it is important that we limit our worries to real as opposed to imaginary risks.

headline: Flights to Safety Can’t Hide the Dangers
text: THE pattern has been repeated so many times that it might be comforting if it weren’t so disturbing.

headline: Obama and Biden Honor Officers in Ceremony
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, along with his vice president and the secretary of homeland security, honored 34 law enforcement officers chosen as the year’s Top Cops, 31 of whom joined them on a spectacular Saturday in the Rose Garden; the three absent winners are recovering from gunshot wounds.

headline: Saving the Lives of Moms
text: THIS is a Mother’s Day tribute to a mighty woman and to the doctor who gave her back her life — and also a celebration of a grand new women’s hospital that you as readers helped to build.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Making Taxation Fairer
text: Readers offer ideas for tax reform but doubt it will happen.

headline: Mary Gordon
text: Mary Gordon is a Canadian expert on child development and the founder of Roots of Empathy, a classroom program adopted in 10 countries that has been shown to reduce cruelty and bullying. The program involves periodically taking infants to elementary schools where students become attached to the babies and learn to empathize, ultimately raising their emotional and social consciousness.

headline: When You Text Till You Drop
text: I DON’T know about you, but I’ve always found the debate about what our mobile devices are doing to us — to our behaviors, our manners, our minds — at least as interesting as reports about what we’re doing with these devices.

headline: Rearranged Marriage: A Sequel
text: I KNOW our relationship seems to have run its course, Diane, but before you take any more meetings with that divorce lawyer, I want you to listen to this pitch: a marriage reboot. I’m thinking “When Harry Met Sally” meets “my relationship with my ex-girlfriend Cassie.” With a few tweaks, I’m confident we can breathe new life into this tired franchise.

headline: Muddling Through Mother’s Day
text: I’M pretty certain it was six years ago. I know I was in a restaurant. I know, too, that I was a little tipsy — that’s the only way the impulse could have come to me, the only way I would have acted on it.

headline: For Obama, It’s About the Children
text: In a historic interview last week, President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage. As he discussed his journey toward that position, the president sounded many familiar themes, like the importance of distinguishing between civil and religious marriage and of living up to American ideals of fairness. At the core of his narrative, however, was a relatively novel element — an affirmation of gay couples as parents.

headline: Greek Tragedy
text: AS I follow the modern Greek tragedy unfolding in Europe, I flash back to the 18 years I spent in Athens, walking to school in Plaka (the old part of the city), on the same streets that have recently been filled with protesters and violent clashes.

headline: The Amygdala Made Me Do It
text: WHY are we thinking so much about thinking these days? Near the top of best-seller lists around the country, you’ll find Jonah Lehrer’s “Imagine: How Creativity Works,” followed by Charles Duhigg’s book “The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business,” and somewhere in the middle, where it’s held its ground for several months, Daniel Kahneman’s “Thinking, Fast and Slow.” Recently arrived is “Subliminal: How Your Unconscious Mind Rules Your Behavior,” by Leonard Mlodinow.

headline: Capitalists and Other Psychopaths
text: THERE is an ongoing debate in this country about the rich: who they are, what their social role may be, whether they are good or bad. Well, consider the following. A 2010 study found that 4 percent of a sample of corporate managers met a clinical threshold for being labeled psychopaths, compared with 1 percent for the population at large. (However, the sample was not representative, as the study’s authors have noted.) Another study concluded that the rich are more likely to lie, cheat and break the law.

headline: Thanks, Maurice
text: Artists and designers pay tribute to Maurice Sendak.

headline: Thanks, Maurice
text: Maurice Sendak’s 1963 “Where the Wild Things Are” unlocked a scary, psychologically nuanced, inner world long taboo in mainstream children’s books. Mr. Sendak once told me that King Kong was a great character and had influenced him when he created “Wild Things.”

headline: At JPMorgan, the Ghost of Dinner Parties Past
text: WHAT goes around comes around. Sometimes it happens sooner than you’d think.

headline: With a Hit Here, and Another There, the Mets Defeat the Marlins
text: MIAMI — The Mets’ 9-3 victory over the Miami Marlins on Saturday afternoon was a substantial one, without a doubt, but one that still had to be manufactured, bit by bit, through small contributions from every corner of the team.

headline: Reunion, and Returning as Your Real Self
text: COLLEGE alumni departments market spring reunion weekends like Caribbean cruises with lectures, barbecues, kids’ camps and dancing under the stars. Many people attend them to relive in some fashion their wild, carefree youth. Others go to show their classmates that they’ve made a success of their lives. When I went back for the 25th reunion of my 1982 college class, I was motivated primarily to show up as my authentic self.

headline: The Human Disaster of Unemployment
text: THE American economy is experiencing a crisis in long-term unemployment that has enormous human and economic costs.

headline: Winning the News Cycle, Losing the Race
text: FOR a generation or more, liberals have complained that the Republican Party uses social and cultural debates to distract voters from pocketbook issues. From Howard Dean’s 2003 lament about Southerners voting on “race, guns, God and gays” to Thomas Frank’s musings on what’s supposedly the matter with Kansas, the Republican focus on social issues has been regularly portrayed as a bait-and-switch, designed to bamboozle Americans into voting against their economic interests.

headline: The Wisdom of Slime
text: THE United States interstate highway system is often celebrated as a simple yet highly efficient transportation scheme — one that, starting in the 1950s, transformed the American economy and lifestyle. Its network of roads was designed to maximally span the country with a minimal number of links, while still allowing for enough redundancy to help drivers overcome wrong turns and missed exits.

headline: Harming the Troops
text: Republican lawmakers love to say they are protective of religious freedom and supportive of the military. Last week, Republicans on the House Armed Services Committee passed two measures that undermine both in an effort to deny equal rights to gay men and lesbians.

headline: The Battle for Westchester
text: America has become far more diverse in the 44 years since the Fair Housing Act was passed, and many of the barriers that kept communities separate and unequal have eroded. But the fight against unlawful discrimination has not ended. In affluent Westchester County, just outside New York City, officials continue to resist integrated housing, even as they endure repeated setbacks in federal court.

headline: Haiti’s Cholera Crisis
text: The cholera epidemic in Haiti, which began in late 2010, is bad and getting worse, for reasons that are well understood and that the aid community has done far too little to resolve. A chronic lack of access to clean water and sanitation make Haitians vulnerable to spreading sickness, especially as spring rains bring floods, as they always do. Summer hurricanes are bound to come; more misery and death will follow. The Pan American Health Organization has said the disease could strike 200,000 to 250,000 people this year. It has already killed more than 7,000.

headline: What if It Weren’t Called Pink Slime?
text: The first casualties of the hamburger ingredient contemptuously dubbed “pink slime” will likely not be anyone who eats it but rather the workers who make it. Beef Products Inc. announced last week that it will close three of its four plants and lay off about 650 workers by May 25. It had little choice. While an estimated 70 percent of the ground beef sold in this country in early 2011 contained what the manufacturers call “lean finely textured beef,” orders from supermarkets for ground beef containing the ingredient plummeted this spring after a series of supposed exposés raised consumer concerns.

headline: This Column Is Not Sponsored by Anyone
text: PORING through Harvard philosopher Michael Sandel’s new book, “What Money Can’t Buy: The Moral Limits of Markets,” I found myself over and over again turning pages and saying, “I had no idea.”

headline: Seeking Original Bliss
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Kutcher’s Arrival Helps Revive a Comedy
text: How much did the departure of Charlie Sheen hurt the comedy “Two and a Half Men”?

headline: Mark Zuckerberg, C.E.O.
text: Is Mark Zuckerberg, founder of social media phenomenon Facebook, ready to be the chief executive of an 80 billion dollar company?

headline: Reading Together, Knowing the Ending
text: WHEN my mother was dying of pancreatic cancer, I would often go with her to chemo, and we would usually talk about books. Discussing what we were reading was something we had done all our lives. But it wasn’t until one day during her second month of treatment that we realized that we had created a very peculiar book club: one with only two members.

headline: The Education of Mark Zuckerberg
text: Mark Zuckerberg is ready for his close-up.

headline: Writer’s Cramp: In the E-Reader Era, a Book a Year Is Slacking
text: For years, it was a schedule as predictable as a calendar: novelists who specialized in mysteries, thrillers and romance would write one book a year, output that was considered not only sufficient, but productive.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 13
text: A few days after JPMorgan Chase reported a $2 billion trading loss, the bank’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, will appear on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” Also on the program will be Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who was an author of legislation intended to prevent banks from taking big risks. He will discuss how more government oversight could have prevented JPMorgan Chase’s loss.

headline: Robert Smalls’s Great Escape
text: As elite Charlestonians slept unaware in the lavish mansions of the Confederacy’s spiritual capital, a slave — a mulatto man trusted by both his owners and employers — executed a daring plot that struck at the core of the white Southern imagination.

headline: Those Moms Who Need a Boost on Mothers Day
text: My Mothers Day column is about one of the great scourges of the developing world that arises in the process of childbirth: obstetric fistula. I’ve seen lots of grim things in my reporting, but a fistula in a teenage girl is about the saddest. Conversely, there’s nothing more joyous than a girl who has just had her fistula repaired and now has her life back again.

headline: Louis H. Pollak, Civil Rights Advocate and Federal Judge, Dies at 89
text: Louis H. Pollak, a federal judge and former dean of two prestigious law schools who played a significant role in major civil rights cases before the Supreme Court, including the landmark Brown v. Board of Education desegregation case, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 89.

headline: Indies
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — First, Wordplay wishes a Happy Mother’s Day to all who have given birth, adopted, fostered, or otherwise been important in the life of a child.

headline: Yankee Stadium Welcomes Berra for His 87th Birthday
text: Yogi Berra sat in the passenger seat of a golf cart driven by his close friend and de facto valet Ron Guidry and soaked in the applause of the Yankee Stadium crowd. It was minutes before the Yankees’ game against the Seattle Mariners on Saturday, and the Yankees honored Berra on his 87th birthday.

headline: Shortfall in California’s Budget Swells to $16 Billion
text: LOS ANGELES — The state budget shortfall in California has increased dramatically in the last six months, forcing state officials to assemble a series of new spending cuts that are likely to mean further reductions to schools, health care and other social programs already battered by nearly five years of budget retrenchment, state officials announced on Saturday.

headline: Angelica Garnett, Writer of Frank Memoir of Bloomsbury Childhood, Dies at 93
text: Angelica Garnett, the last direct link to the Bloomsbury set, whose memoir of growing up amid its potent brew of sex, secrets, artistry and renown is notable for offering a child’s-eye view of that darkly charmed circle, died on May 4 in the South of France. She was 93.

headline: Saving a Disappearing Beach
text: Coastal erosion in South Kingstown, R.I., has shrunk parts of the town’s beach to less than a dozen feet during high tide.

headline: Horst Faas, Photographer Who Showed Horrors of War, Dies at 79
text: Horst Faas, a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning war photographer who later was editor of The Associated Press staff in Saigon that produced some of the most haunting photographs of the Vietnam War, died Thursday in Munich. He was 79.

headline: In Rhode Island, Protecting a Shoreline and a Lifeline
text: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I. — Mike Couchie looked up from his Heineken as an opened door ushered an unearthly roar into the Ocean Mist, a seaside bar here.

headline: For Tea Party, Focus Turns to Senate and Shake-Up

headline: Woman Dies in a Brooklyn Fire That Is Deemed Suspicious
text: She was 25 and curvaceous, and she often drew admiring glances in the gritty Brooklyn neighborhood where she was known to invite men for visits to her apartment, her neighbors and the authorities said.

headline: Strong Start by Hughes Carries Yankees
text: Phil Hughes departed the Yankee Stadium mound nearly two weeks ago to lukewarm applause, with fans seemingly unsure whether a mild sign of progress was worthy of their cheers or still merited their disapproval. Hughes had struggled throughout the first month of the season, and Yankees fans were growing restless about his inconsistency.

headline: New York Police Release Data Showing Rise in Number of Stops on Streets
text: Police officers stopped people on New York City’s streets more than 200,000 times during the first three months of 2012, putting the Bloomberg administration on course to shatter a record set last year for the highest annual tally of street stops.

headline: Career in the Minors Is Interrupted by the Devils’ Push for the Stanley Cup

headline: Gunmen in Afghan Police Uniforms Kill 2 NATO Soldiers

headline: For Na, Shaky Swings but a Solid Score

A stiff breeze carried Harris English’s opening drive so far left that his ball conked a marshal in the head. Tiger Woods had to back off a birdie putt at 18 when an ice cream wrapper flitted into his line.

headline: U.S. May Scrap Costly Efforts to Train Iraqi Police

headline: Bloomberg Defends Same-Sex Marriage in State That Rejected It

headline: ‘The Avengers’ Holds Strong at No. 1
text: Tim Burton’s tepidly reviewed “Dark Shadows” wilted under the holdover heat of “Marvel’s The Avengers,” which took in an astounding $103.2 million at North American theaters in its second weekend. That No. 1 total pushed the domestic gross for “The Avengers” (Disney) to about $373.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. “Dark Shadows,” a $150 million horror comedy starring Johnny Depp, was a distant second, with about $28.8 million in ticket sales.

headline: Vermont Towns Have an Image, and They Say Dollar Stores Aren’t Part of It

headline: Putting Is Easy, if You Work at It

headline: Adding Oomph, a New Breed of Fairway Woods

headline: So Many Rebels but a Shortage of Causes
text: What is this, National Outlaw Month? The Discovery Channel seems to think so. It has rolled out two new series about people who are lawless or want to create the impression that they are. If nothing else, the shows reveal the differences between real outlaws and mere poseurs.

headline: On Mother’s Day, Candidates Court Women With Videos
text: President Obama is planning to address Barnard College graduates Monday in a speech that is expected to target the women’s vote. But on Sunday, the campaigns of both the president and Mitt Romney were actively courting that vote through videos tied to Mother’s Day.

headline: City Opera’s Unabashed Underworld

On Saturday night the company presented the first of four performances of Telemann’s “Orpheus” at El Museo del Barrio, the Hispanic cultural center on Fifth Avenue that has an intimate 600-seat theater ideal for Baroque opera.

headline: A Hero’s Welcome for Rex, a Marine’s Best Friend
text: It has become second nature for Rex, a retired sergeant in the Marine Corps, to nose around the perimeter of any space he walks into. Rex, an 11-year-old German shepherd, surely would have done so at Yankee Stadium on Sunday if he were unleashed.

headline: Movement Transforms a Poet’s Elegy
text: “Nox,” by the poet and classicist Anne Carson, is an extraordinary book, and not just because it comes in a box and unfolds like an accordion. It is an elegy for Ms. Carson’s brother and also a translation of an elegy by the Roman poet Catullus. Like all elegies, “Nox” is a massing of words facing a muteness. The dead do not reply. If you wanted to translate the book into a performative medium, it makes some sense to bring in the eloquently mute.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Executive Resigns in Trading Debacle
text: Stung by a huge trading loss, JPMorgan Chase will replace three top traders starting Monday, including one of the top women on Wall Street, in an effort to stem the ire that the bank faces from regulators and investors.

headline: Pettitte Feels at Home, but Shows Some Rust
text: Andy Pettitte’s 573-day hiatus from a major league game ended at 1:02 p.m. Sunday, when he pounded his mitt twice, tugged his cap once and galloped out of the home dugout at Yankee Stadium to start his 17th season of work in the big leagues.

headline: A Melting Pot of Music and Movement
text: Watching a pair of recent dances by John Heginbotham I sometimes got the impression of a bright, enthusiastic child plunked down in front of a home entertainment center: channel surfing, shuffling through music, responding to whatever pops up with bursts of varied movement.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
