headline: Logic and Neutrality
text: Here’s an idea many philosophers and logicians have about the function of logic in our cognitive life, our inquiries and debates. It isn’t a player. Rather, it’s an umpire, a neutral arbitrator between opposing theories, imposing some basic rules on all sides in a dispute. The picture is that logic has no substantive content, for otherwise the correctness of that content could itself be debated, which would impugn the neutrality of logic. One way to develop this idea is by saying that logic supplies no information of its own, because the point of information is to rule out possibilities, whereas logic only rules out inconsistencies, which are not genuine possibilities. On this view, logic in itself is totally uninformative, although it may help us extract and handle non-logical information from other sources.

Last week Mr. Isserlis functioned in a similar dual capacity at the 92nd Street Y in partnership with the fortepianist Robert Levin. After a lecture-recital preview on Wednesday evening, Mr. Isserlis and Mr. Levin performed all of Beethoven’s works for cello and piano on Thursday and Saturday evenings.

headline: ‘Downton’ Heir to Make His Debut on Broadway

headline: Sippy Cups and Other Little-Known Childhood Hazards

headline: Outer Critics Circle Announces Awards
text: The Outer Critics Circle, a group of theater writers outside of New York, said on Sunday that the new Broadway musical “Once” and the new play “One Man, Two Guvnors” received three top awards each in the group’s 62nd annual competition honoring Broadway and Off Broadway productions. “Once” won for best musical, director of a musical (John Tiffany) and book (Enda Walsh); “One Man” won for best play, director of a play (Nicholas Hytner) and actor in a play (James Corden). The drama “Sons of the Prophet” won for Off Broadway play and “Queen of the Mist” won for Off Broadway musical, while this season’s Broadway productions of “Death of a Salesman” and “Follies” won for best play revival and musical revival.

headline: Meltdown in Motherland
text: When Clara, my daughter, turned four months old, my husband Danny and I celebrated the end of the “fourth trimester.” From here, the books had said, things would get easier. I began to look forward to fitting into old clothes, my C-section incision no longer hurting, attending parties, readings and concerts. I’d already gone back to my day job tutoring teenagers eight weeks before (freelance artists don’t get maternity leave), but I missed my real work— writing. Now, the new, post-baby version of my beloved internal life could begin. I’d write and read, while producing milk and cuddling my girl.

text: MOSCOW — “Socrates might be surprised to find out that we have included him in the history of civil disobedience,” says Tamara Eidelman, a 53-year-old history teacher from one of Moscow’s better schools, to the 300 people who have gathered in this park in central Moscow.

headline: Willing to Pay (a Little) More for Clean Energy
text: The perception that the American public is adamantly opposed to higher energy costs is at the root of most political opposition to policies favoring the adoption of renewable energy. But a new study of public opinion finds that people are in fact willing to pay to move to cleaner energy.

headline: Bringing the Colors of Church Into a Paris Museum
text: Monumenta, now in its sixth edition, has become one of the most important annual contemporary art happenings in Paris. This year the event, opened on Thursday, features Excentrique(s), an installation by Daniel Buren that fills the 14,000 square-meter Grand Palais through June 21.

headline: Fox Fall Lineup Makes a Bet on Comedy
text: 9:22 a.m. | Updated The biggest bets of the new fall season are being placed on comedy, and the Fox network will push its own chips onto that genre in the fall when it introduces a full night of comedy on Tuesday nights.

text: Season 5, Episode 8

headline: At Explore Charter School, a World and a System Divided
text: One large segment of New York City remains segregated, and that is in the city's schools. As the latest in a New York Times series, "A System Divided," illustrated on Sunday, black children are often taught in schools that are disproportionately black, by teachers who are likely to be white. The article takes a close-up look at one such school, the Explore Charter School in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, and is accompanied by a graphic presentation of the citywide issue.

headline: Opinion Report: Maker’s Mark
text: From the editorial page

headline: In Post-Primary Period, Campaigns Race to Define Challenger
text: There is no good time for a presidential candidate to face what Mitt Romney faced last week, when The Washington Post reported that he had tormented a fellow student while at prep school in the 1960s.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: JPMorgan Chase Executive to Resign After Trading Loss  |  The huge loss at JPMorgan Chase has claimed three top traders in the bank’s London office, including Ina Drew, one of the most senior women on Wall Street, The New York Times reports.

headline: Leaders in Greece Remain Resistant to Unity Coalition
text: ATHENS — With Greece hurtling toward new elections and a possible exit from the euro zone, President Karolos Papoulias prepared to make a last-ditch appeal on Monday for the country's sharply divided political parties to form a unity government even as his hopes for success all but evaporated over the weekend.

headline: ‘Breathtaking’ Victory for Manchester’s Other Team
text: LONDON — Soccer fans get really mad if you say it’s only a game. For some it’s more like a religion, only more intense.

headline: Too Many Sacred Cows
text: DELHI — On May 11, a furor erupted in India’s Parliament over a black-and-white cartoon from 1949. Reproduced in a textbook for high-school juniors, the drawing depicts B.R. Ambedkar — India’s foremost Dalit leader and the chairman of the committee that drafted India’s 1950 Constitution — whip in hand and astride a snail labeled “the Constitution.” The first Prime Minister of India, Jawaharlal Nehru, stands behind him, also wielding a whip.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: TV Networks Are Ready for Their Close-Up
text: The television industry’s “upfronts” reach full steam this week, with presentations by the networks. These annual productions, which began in the 1960s, are meant to give a clear picture of what the TV schedule is going to look like, but with so much in flux, the upfronts have had to adapt.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s Acquisitions Offer Clues to Its Future
text: When Facebook snapped up two small start-ups just days after buying Instagram, it was business as usual, Jenna Wortham reports in Monday’s New York Times. Facebook buys small companies on a regular basis — almost two dozen over the last two years — to beef up its team of engineers, add to the site’s offerings and sharpen competition with rivals.

headline: Euro Reversibility
text: A brief blast from the past. What I hadn’t realized when I wrote that two years ago was the extent to which eurozone banks could float through a slow-motion bank run by borrowing from the ECB. So the real moment of truth comes if and when the ECB — or more accurately the Bundesbank, which may ultimately be on the hook — decides to pull the plug.

headline: Paradise Lost
text: Thirty-eight years ago, when I was 20 and traveling in Central America recovering from a broken heart, I met a middle-age American couple who invited me to come along with them to Guatemala on an orchid hunt. For the next several weeks we drove and hiked through the highlands in search of rare plants. There was a war going on, in which our country’s involvement remained questionable, and no doubt this had something to do with the fact that on three separate occasions over the course of those days our tires were slashed. One could have thought this might interfere with my affection for the place. It did not.

headline: N.Y. Lottery Brings Back a Favorite Character
text: It seems oxymoronic to say “a lot of little bits,” but that is just what the New York State Lottery will present in its new advertising campaign.

headline: More ‘Brigadoon’ Than ‘Trainspotting': Craig Ferguson Brings ‘Late Late Show’ to Scotland
text: LOS ANGELES — In his seven years as host of “The Late Late Show” on CBS, Craig Ferguson has had many an unusual broadcast, whether it was an episode lighted partially by flashlight when his studio lost power or an evening dedicated to the BBC science-fiction series “Doctor Who.” But until now, Mr. Ferguson had never brought his show to his home country of Scotland.

headline: Palestinians in Jails End Hunger Strike
text: JERUSALEM — Hundreds of Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails ended a hunger strike on Monday that had lasted for weeks, signing an agreement with the Israeli authorities that promised improved conditions, according to officials. headline: An Environmental Crusader’s Newest Goal: Congress
text: In the name of living his New York City life with as little environmental impact as possible, Colin Beavan embarked on a punishing project five years ago. He and his family stopped taking the elevator to their ninth-floor Manhattan apartment; they did their laundry by stomping on it in the tub; for about six months, they even went without electricity at home. Mr. Beavan called the project No Impact Man, scored a book deal and became the subject of a documentary.

headline: The City Game
text: Normally, if you have any opinion on who wins the English Premier League, it demonstrates your world view on sports, whether you have one or prefer not to cross borders set up by ESPN. But considering the way Manchester City won the Premier League title, even ESPN had to give a nod in its highlights, and you need not show your passport when opening a conversation today with: “Two goals in stoppage time to win the league? Did you see that? Holy cow.”

headline: Umbrian Chickpea Soup, Primitive to the Bones
text: MY previously favorite soup, before I started eating the one I’m about to introduce you to, was taught to me in Montalcino, Italy, a hilltop town in Tuscany, by a grandmother named Olga. It uses what might be considered unreasonably large amounts of olive oil, until you consider that the base of the soup is water, that the soup itself is vegan (it’s almost entirely made of fresh vegetables, along with cooked white beans, a little tomato paste, parsley and the oil), and that soup without any fat at all is not only unusual but also often tasteless. This is real cocina povera, the cooking of people so poor that neither meat nor cheese is included.

headline: Head of Time Warner Cable Is Unfamiliar With Apple’s AirPlay
text: AirPlay, a software tool included with Apple’s iPads and iPhones, is widely viewed as being potentially disruptive to the cable industry, because it makes it easy for people to view a broad variety of Internet content on a television. Time Warner Cable’s leader, however, hasn’t heard of it.

But in a city whose twin obsessions seem to be property and luxury brand names, there has never been a “starchitect”-designed residence until now.

headline: On Our Radar: Imagining Many More Gray Whales
text: A study of DNA from whale bones in Washington State suggests that the gray whale population in the eastern Pacific was somewhere between 78,000 and 116,000 before the advent of aggressive whaling there in the 19th century. Previous estimates put the historical population at 15,000 to 35,500. [ScienceDaily]

headline: China’s Obsession With Stability Can Come at the Cost of Laws
text: LINYI, China — The central government says that the activist Chen Guangcheng is a free man, and has promised him an investigation of the harrowing abuses he suffered at the hands of guards here. Mr. Chen’s desperate escape last month from persecution to American protection has embarrassed China’s leaders and cast new shadows on their commitment to the rule of law.

Gordon Gee, the president of Ohio State University, keeps a framed quotation that reads, “If you don’t like change, you’re going to like irrelevance even less.”

headline: Bookshelf | ‘The Brooklyn of Fashion Insiders’
text: After the fashion community embraced her “private and friendly” guides to Paris and Manhattan, Carole Sabas, a reporter in French Vogue’s New York bureau, set her sights on Brooklyn. “A borough that people like Kate Young, Freja Beha and Sophie Theallet all call home can’t be wrong, fashionably speaking, so I had to check it out for myself,” Sabas says of her newest project: “The Brooklyn of Fashion Insiders.” Compiled by Sabas and her collective of stylish tipsters/borough residents — Maria Cornejo, Arizona Muse and T’s online editor, Jane Herman — the portable handbook celebrates and explores Kings County businesses and their cool, laid-back attitudes. “Even the celebrity tattoo artists are friendly,” Sabas says. (The guide’s cover art was created by Marc Jacobs’s inker of choice, Scott Campbell, who works in Williamsburg.) What struck Sabas most, though, is the borough’s wide-spreading reputation for dishing up stylishly straightforward food: “I keep thinking of the words ‘epicurean chic,’ something I previously identified with Europeans in the 1970s,” she says. Among the restaurants that made Sabas’s cut: James in Prospect Heights, Roman’s in Fort Greene, Cafe Colette in Williamsburg and Dressler (which I personally recommended for its gorgeous dining room and elegant cocktails). But it’s more than just a listing of hip eateries. The guide also spotlights Brooklyn’s best yoga studios (Greenhouse Holistic and Shala), florists (Sprout Home and Saipua), vintage boutiques (Bogart & Moore and Erie Basin) and car services (Northside), which are handy when bridge-hopping back to Manhattan, if you must.

headline: Watching TV Linked to Poor Diet in Students
text: A national survey of more than 12,000 students in grades 5 to 10 has found that television viewing is associated not only with unhealthy snacking while watching, but also with unhealthy eating at all times.

headline: College Costs Weighing Down a Generation With Student Debt

headline: John Irving’s Rules of Attraction
text: During his appearance at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday night, John Irving said he thought he was done with the theme of “intolerance of our sexual differences” after “The World According to Garp.” But his new novel, “In One Person,” from which he read two extended scenes, features a bisexual narrator named Billy Dean, and Mr. Irving’s bibliography makes it clear that he has always been drawn to the experience of unconventional sexuality.

headline: Australian Triathlete Hospitalized with Suspected Case of Tuberculosis

headline: The Seasonal Charms of Green Garlic: Green Garlic, Chive and Red Pepper Frittata
text: Green garlic has a window of about a month at farmers markets’ in Los Angeles, where I live, and I cannot resist buying it every time I go. At the beginning of the season the bulbs look more like leeks or spring onions than garlic, as they have not yet set cloves. To prepare them I just cut away the stalks as I would a spring onion, cut them in half and remove any tough stalk that might be running down the middle, remove the papery outer layers and chop like a scallion or leek.

headline: George Martin, Katy Perry and Indie Label Heads on Universal-EMI Deal
text: The Universal Music Group’s proposed $1.9 billion takeover of EMI’s recorded-music business — which releases work by the Beatles, the Beach Boys, Katy Perry and Coldplay — is perhaps the music industry’s most significant deal in the last decade, and one of its most contentious.

headline: Choosing Less

headline: A Potential Fix for iMessage Woes
text: A few weeks ago, I was using Apple’s iMessage messaging service on the iPhone, making plans to see a movie with a group of friends. Suddenly they stopped replying, and about an hour later I saw them check in at the movie theater on Foursquare.

headline: A Once-Unthinkable Choice for Amputees
text: Five years ago, on a muggy August morning in Hicksville, N.Y., Ann Kornhauser was out walking her golden retriever when bones in her left foot suddenly cracked. Ms. Kornhauser, then in her late 50s, soon learned why: doctors discovered a rare tumor in her foot. They amputated half of it.

headline: Pocket: The New Way to Read It Later
text: You know what feature has been missing from Facebook? It’s not that fancy: just a simple way to save “star” or “favorite” posts that you are interested in, but don’t have time to read right now. There is just too much stuff out there. What we need is a way to come back to a folder of starred posts and go through them when there is time.

headline: Pregame Chatter: Rangers’ Rupp, a Former Devil, Plays Down the Rivalry
text: The morning before Game 1 at Madison Square Garden on Monday, Mike Rupp, the only former Devil on the Rangers’ roster, was asked about the rivalry between the teams. He remembered his first experience with it, when he joined the Devils during 2002-3 season.

headline: E.P.A. Appeals Coal Mine Ruling
text: The Obama administration said Monday that it would appeal a federal judge’s ruling that the Environmental Protection Agency illegally vetoed a major coal mining project in West Virginia.

headline: Cocktails for the History Books, Not the Bar
text: A collection of cocktail world figures lined up Saturday at the Manhattan Cocktail Classic, the annual New York drinks convention, to shoot down some sacred cows.

headline: In 1994, Plenty of Tension but No BlackBerrys
text: For Rangers and Devils fans, this does feel like 1994 again — except for the electronics. Back then, before the BlackBerry and the iPhone, before it was taken for granted that you could summon up whatever information you wanted in 10 or 20 seconds, you could sometimes be forced to live by your wits if you were trying to figure out how your team was doing.

headline: Lincoln Center Theater to Open a New Stage
text: At a time when Broadway has grown increasingly costly, Lincoln Center Theater is opening a new stage on Tuesday that will feature work by emerging playwrights, directors and designers, and will charge just $20 for every ticket.

headline: Buying Local Wines: Does the Idea Travel Well?
text: ONE of the pleasures of working in wine retailing is pointing customers toward new and exciting wines, and especially to bottles that mean something to you. The sense of discovery and the sharing of a pleasant experience help to bolster a notion of community that can be fragile in a mobile society.

headline: Drawn to Simplicity | Philippe Weisbecker’s ‘Greenhouse Studies’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: JPMorgan’s Loss: Illegal, or Just Bad Judgment?
text: Senator Everett Dirksen is reputed to have once said, “A billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon you’re talking real money.” JPMorgan Chase disclosed a $2 billion loss on a complex hedging strategy indeed qualifies as an object lesson for that axiom.

headline: Raygunomics
text: Tom Tomorrow explains it all — and I get zapped:

headline: Can Runners Have ‘Too Many Miles on the Tires’?
text: I used to run with a guy who was unhappy with the way his performance had deteriorated over the years. In his early 20s, he said, he had been super-fast. A couple of decades later and about 20 pounds heavier, he had lost that amazing speed.

headline: The Vice President as a Teenager: A Lesson à la ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: A skit from “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Job Creation vs. Profit Creation
text: The Romney campaign often faults the president for concentrating on “distractions” (like whether same-sex couples deserve equal treatment under the law) instead of economic issues. Today the Obama campaign took the bait, releasing a two-minute ad that calls Mitt Romney a “job destroyer.”

headline: Finale of ‘Desperate Housewives’ a Ratings Winner
text: Television viewers tuned in to say goodbye to the residents of Wisteria Lane on Sunday as the series finale of “Desperate Housewives” on ABC was the most-watched program of the night. The two-hour show added more viewers every half hour and finished with an average of 11.1 million and a 19 percent bump in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic compared to last week, according to Nielsen. While far below the 24 million viewer average of the show’s water cooler-fueled first season, the finale was easily the best ratings performance for the series since March 2011.

headline: Street Style: Kitten Heels
text: The best of readers’ street style for the week of May 7.

headline: Offshore Transmission Line Takes a Step Forward
text: A pioneering proposal to build a wind power transmission line  on the ocean floor from southern Virginia to northern New Jersey cleared a hurdle on Monday when the Interior Department opened the way for the project’s sponsors to start work on an environmental impact statement.

headline: The Science Times Podcast
text: Bionic limbs; chimps with table manners; and sperm buyer beware.

headline: Trainer’s Long-Awaited Testimony Details Illegal Drug Use by Clemens
text: WASHINGTON — The details, if familiar, were still powerful: a hotel room in Toronto in 1998, drugs and a syringe laid out in a bathroom and the best pitcher of his generation asking for what no one ever thought he needed: artificial help.

headline: TimesCast | Greece Unity Remains Elusive
text: Greece's president makes last ditch efforts to form a unity government as markets slide on worries of of a default.

headline: In Choosing a Sperm Donor, a Roll of the Genetic Dice
text: Sharine and Brian Kretchmar of Yukon, Okla., tried a number of medical treatments to conceive a second child. After a depressing series of failures, a doctor finally advised them to find a sperm donor.

headline: Chimpanzees’ Table Manners Vary by Group
text: Depending on where a meal is served, a person might tuck in with a fork and knife, with chopsticks or with bare hands. Chimpanzees, it turns out, have a similar kind of cultural variation: Neighboring groups of the animals have unique nut-cracking styles, a new study in the journal Current Biology reports.

headline: Drilling Down: A Teenager Raises $7 Million
text: This week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to a story about Sahil Lavingia, a teenager who recently raised $7 million for his start-up, an online payment platform known as Gumroad. Sahil, the story reports, founded Gumroad after dropping out of the University of Southern California and doing a stint at the recent social media darling Pinterest. We decided to ask Sahil, who is 19, a few questions about how he raised the money (from Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield Byers) and how his life has changed. A condensed version of our e-mail conversation follows. One note: he didn’t actually use the word “poor” to describe his grades.

headline: First Major Paper Review
text: In the FT. Some criticisms, of course, but it says it’s “thoroughly persuasive” and “lively and readable”. I’ll take it.

headline: Baseball Fires Arbitrator Who Overturned 50-Game Suspension
text: Less than three months after Major League Baseball objected to the overturning of Ryan Braun’s 50-game suspension for a positive drug test, Shyam Das, the arbitrator in that case, was fired, according to a person in baseball with direct knowledge of the decision.

headline: After $2 Billion Loss, JPMorgan Reshuffles Trading Group
text: Several days after announcing a $2 billion loss in its chief investment office, JPMorgan Chase is clearing house.

headline: A Sea Creature Puts Its Best Foot Forward
text: Brittle stars are sea creatures with five limbs and no brain. Found on the seafloor across the world, they have no obvious front, unlike humans and most other animals. Now, a new study reports that the brainless creatures are nonetheless able to move in a coordinated way, by designating one limb as the “front-facing” limb, and using two others to propel forward.

headline: Broadway Plays Avoiding Box-Office Doldrums
text: Broadway plays are often limping at the box office in May, filling seats with Tony Award voters (who don’t pay for tickets) before the annual ceremony, on June 10 this year. Several plays close right afterward, because of a lack of awards or because their star actors want to return to Hollywood (or go on vacation). But this month has been notably good for many plays, including some without stars. Last week 10 of the 14 plays on Broadway grossed more than 40 percent of the maximum possible amount – an indication that they broke even or turned a profit.

headline: The Sun’s Unrelenting Rays
text: Q. Do animals suffer from sunburn? If so, is it just the hairless ones, or are domestic animals like dogs and cats also at risk?

headline: Michelle Obama Urges Olympians to Draw Children to Sports
text: DALLAS – First Lady Michelle Obama said she wants Olympians to reach out to beginners in their sports.

headline: Crime Boss’s Tomb Is Exhumed for Clues in Missing Girl’s Case
text: ROME — Since 1983, when 15-year-old Emanuela Orlandi vanished on a street here on her way home from a music lesson, investigators have struggled to solve her disappearance. Various theories have tied the presumed kidnapping to intrigue involving the Italian secret services, organized crime, even the attempt to assassinate John Paul II — or possibly all three.

headline: A Precursor to Playboy: Graphic Images in Rock
text: Researchers have discovered illustrations of female anatomy in a rock shelter in France that date back 37,000 years.

headline: John Updike Society Buys Author’s Boyhood Home for $200,000
text: The John Updike Society has signed an agreement to buy the celebrated author’s childhood home in Shillington, Pa., for $200,000 and preserve it as a historic property.

headline: Specks Ahoy
text: Sicily’s well-worn island circuit of Pantelleria, Panarea and Stromboli is overrun with tourists in the summer and prohibitively expensive year-round. But there are other untrampled isles where in-the-know Italians touch down (or tie up).

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Virtual Robbery, and Tracking Apple Rumors
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. See more here.

headline: Research Supports Limits on Borrowing from Retirement Plans

headline: ‘Peter and the Starcatcher’ to Go on National Tour Next Year
text: The producers of the Broadway play “Peter and the Starcatcher” announced on Monday that they would mount a national tour of the Tony-nominated production starting in Denver in August 2013, a relatively rare business move for a non-musical play – and one aimed squarely at Tony Award voters from around the country who are filling out their ballots this month.

headline: Reaching for Zen With Each Stroke and Lap
text: As far back as I can remember, I have been more at home in water than on land. My father taught me to swim at age 3, and I’ve been an enthusiast ever since.

headline: Mapping a Solution to School Zoning Questions
text: Like many other New Yorkers, Kristi Barlow found herself consumed with the process of finding the right neighborhood and the right school for her child, and when she couldn't find an accurate map showing, block by block, which neighborhoods were zoned for which elementary schools, she made one of her own. Out of that obsession was born a small business.

headline: A Ticket, 3 Taser Jolts and, Perhaps, a Trip to the Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — There have been many hundreds of varied rulings in the lower courts on when the use of Taser stun guns by the police amounts to excessive force, and sooner or later the Supreme Court will have to bring order to this area of the law. Next week, the justices are scheduled to decide whether to hear an appeal from three Seattle police officers who say they are worried about the future of what they call “a useful pain technique.”

headline: In a Global Marketplace, Toyota and Volkswagen Make Room for Niche Vehicles
text: Though the world’s major automakers have optimized their efficiency and profitability by producing global vehicles that can be sold worldwide with minimal changes, specialization still plays a role in the automotive marketplace.

headline: Yahoo’s Former Chief to Leave Without Severance
text: Yahoo‘s departing chief executive, Scott Thompson, will leave without severance pay after being forced out after admitting to an erroneous academic record.

headline: My Son Looks Like a Girl. So What?
text: My 12-year-old son has hair halfway down his back, and the fact that the bottom half of it is currently pink does not seem to be clarifying anything for anybody: everyone, everywhere assumes he’s a girl.

headline: Forever Mistaken for a Captain
text: I’M sure this happens to everyone who lives in New York City, but because I lived in Manhattan for 25 years, I become the city’s de facto ambassador when I’m traveling about. I have to listen to seatmates do imitations of New York accents, hear about the menus of their favorite New York restaurants, talk about the cops, litter, dogs on the street, bagels and even Mayor Bloomberg, whom I know nothing about.

headline: The TSA Pats Down Henry Kissinger
text: For all their hard work confiscating shampoo bottles and commanding passengers to remove their shoes, TSA screeners have yet to catch a terrorist. They have, however, given Henry Kissinger a full pat-down.

headline: A Mathematical Challenge to Obesity
text: Carson C. Chow deploys mathematics to solve the everyday problems of real life. As an investigator at the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, he tries to figure out why 1 in 3 Americans are obese.

headline: Britney Spears to Join the Judges of ‘The X Factor’
text: Pressing the reset button on his reality show, Simon Cowell said Monday that “The X Factor” would have two new judges come this fall, Britney Spears and Demi Lovato.

headline: Hawaii’s Beaches Are in Retreat, and Its Way of Life May Follow
text: Little by little, Hawaii’s iconic beaches are disappearing.

headline: TV Show ‘Girls’ Adds to the Muddle on HPV Testing
text: Hannah, the spunky central character in the edgy new HBO series “Girls,” is a creative and endearingly naïve 24-year-old bumbling fearlessly through postcollege life. She works for years at an unpaid internship that never turns into a job and pretends to be far more sophisticated about sex than she actually is. She’s a loyal friend, but whatever you do, don’t ask her about human papillomavirus, or HPV. She’s clueless.

headline: The Student Who Made Me a Better Teacher
text: Laura Klein, a middle school teacher and blogger, writes: "Perhaps all teachers have one student for whom they are teaching.  Sedina was that student for me.  Even now, when I am no longer her teacher, she’s still the one."

headline: Cleareyed, Full-Hearted, Unflinching Fatherhood
text: Buzz Bissinger’s first book, “Friday Night Lights” (1990), about high school football in Odessa, Tex., was a best seller that’s become an acknowledged classic of American sports writing.

headline: Caesareans Are Cost-Effective in Poor Countries, Study Finds
text: With many countries chronically short of surgeons, should laymen be trained in emergency surgery? It is one of the trickier questions in global health.

headline: A Company Caught in a Crucible of Challenges Rises to the Occasion
text: The real test of a ballet company’s health comes not at opening nights or galas, but when injuries remove beloved dancers, or new productions return, or marvelous ballets are revived with alternative casts. All the above were on view this weekend at New York City Ballet.

headline: Death on the Job
text: Rise in fatality rate in the oil and gas industry.

headline: Drumming With Only Minimal Planning
text: As its name implies, the Look & Listen Festival, now in its 11th season, is built to give audiences something to see, as well as plenty to hear. Concerts are held in galleries, and the audience is encouraged to examine the works on display, which in any case provide a striking frame for the performances.

headline: Add Another Experience to a Young Artist’s Résumé
text: Before singing Heitor Villa-Lobos’s sweeping “Melodia Sentimental” on Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall, the soprano Nadine Sierra announced with mock anxiety, “My birthday is May 14, so I’m getting older.”

headline: Bullets in Slow Motion, Lovingly Aimed
text: As the Champagne flowed amid the giggles, the bodyguard looked out from the rooftop soiree high over São Paulo and stared at the vast slum below. He turned to his partner in arms and mused, “Nothing like the view of extreme poverty to make a penthouse cocktail party really swing.”

headline: Probiotics Can Ease Digestive Upset of Antibiotics
text: Probiotics — live micro-organisms that offer some benefit to their host — significantly reduce the risk for diarrhea caused by taking antibiotics, a review of 82 trials has concluded.

headline: Regimens: IUD May Be Best Emergency Contraception
text: In a review of previous studies, researchers have concluded that the insertion of an intrauterine device after unprotected sex is the most effective and safest method of emergency contraception.

headline: Splashes of Guilt in Waves of Envy
text: Oh, to be a young artist, brimming with confidence, passion and a desire to remake the world by making beautiful things.

headline: Rough Treatment in Shandong
text: Journalists working for The New York Times were accosted by men who followed them after they tried to talk to residents near Dongshigu, the village where Chen Guangcheng’s was held captive.

headline: A Fond Farewell to Ron Paul, Who’s Not Really Leaving
text: Ron Paul announced today that he will no longer spend campaign money to compete in states that have not yet voted, which is probably wise. Mr. Paul has spent around $34 million so far to accumulate 104 delegates. That’s $326,923 and change per delegate.

headline: Test Case Could Help Knicks Keep Free Agents
text: The N.B.A. players union is asking an arbitrator to clarify certain free-agent rights in a case that could immeasurably benefit the Knicks this summer, according to several people involved in the process.

headline: Regrets About College
text: I still get a lot of e-mail from readers asking whether college is really worth it, given the huge debt burden it produces (as my colleagues have been documenting) and the large number of unemployed recent graduates.

headline: Another Brooklyn School Wins Another National Chess Championship
text: A busload of young chess wizards from a Brooklyn school left for Nashville last Wednesday, and returned to their school Monday afternoon with a three-tiered, first-place trophy from the United States Chess Federation's National Elementary Championship.  “We won! I feel so excited that we won first place, especially because we beat a middle school,” said Helen Xue, 11, a fifth grader on the team.

headline: Coming Around to Williamsburg
text: Williamsburg has long been an alternative fashion mecca for those with a predilection for vintage shopping. The Brooklyn neighborhood is a natural destination for haunts like the new What Goes Around Comes Around pop-up shop, the first-ever in the area for the 19-year-old vintage lifestyle brand. The boutique, which may become permanent after its initial three-month run, is nestled in the heart of Williamsburg at 184 Kent Avenue between North Third and North Fourth Streets. It features both vintage pieces and the What Goes Around Comes Around ready-to-wear collection with discounts of up to 90 percent.

headline: St. Louis Conductor Takes New Post in Sydney
text: David Robertson, below, the music director of the St. Louis Symphony, has taken a position on the other side of the world, becoming artistic director and chief conductor of the Sydney Symphony in Australia starting in 2014. Mr. Robertson will succeed Vladimir Ashkenazy as the orchestra’s leader. His contract in Sydney runs through 2018. Mr. Robertson, who first appeared as a guest conductor in Sydney in 2003, assumed his post in St. Louis in 2005, when he also became principal guest conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. The Sydney Symphony seems to have made an attractive offer. In its announcement of the appointment the orchestra said Mr. Robertson would take part in at least two CD recording projects a year; a yearly concert performance of an opera; regular commissioning of new works in collaboration with other orchestras; and annual touring, with a focus on China. Much of the Sydney Symphony’s season takes place during the off months at St. Louis. Mr. Robertson’s contract in St. Louis ends with the 2013-14 season, but a spokesman there said he and the orchestra were in discussions to extend his tenure.

headline: Facebook’s Prospects May Rest on Trove of Data
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief, has managed to amass more information about more people than anyone else in history.

headline: For 2 Decades, Airport Worker Used Murder Victim’s ID, Officials Say
text: On a July morning in 1992, a man named Jerry Thomas was shot to death in front of the Y.M.C.A. on Parsons Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens. According to the Queen’s district attorney’s office, no one was arrested for his murder.

headline: Art, Ancestry, Africa: Letting It All Bleed
text: Alicia Hall Moran is an operatic mezzo-soprano, and Jason Moran is a jazz pianist. They met at the Manhattan School of Music and married in 2003. Since then they’ve made a lot of their work separately. Mr. Moran has toured and recorded for 12 years with his trio, the Bandwagon. Ms. Moran has performed as a singer with Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and is now the understudy to Audra McDonald in the role of Bess in “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” on Broadway. But they have worked together steadily, too, more than many people know.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Case of Former Sailor With Stress Disorder
text: The Supreme Court on Monday rejected the petition of a former Navy corpsman who had received a court-martial in 2010 for striking two superior noncommissioned officers while on duty. The former sailor, Osborn Miranda, had argued that his guilty plea in the case was not valid because he suffered from both post-traumatic stress disorder and bipolar disorder. During the guilty-plea inquiry, a military judge did not delve into the disorders, thereby ignoring a possible defense or a limit of culpability, Mr. Miranda argued.

headline: Variety in a Flying Career, Spiced With Aggravation

headline: Modernist Rigor Rooted in Maya Lore
text: When Melissa Smey became the executive director of the Miller Theater at Columbia University in 2009, she inherited a programming philosophy largely defined by a charismatic, highly visible predecessor: George Steel, now the general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera. No newcomer, Ms. Smey had worked with Mr. Steel at Miller since 2001. Most of what she has presented since taking over has fitted the mold of what she previously helped Mr. Steel to build.

headline: Movements on a Scale That’s Cozy
text: There is something to be said for the excitement of grand stages and sweeping spectacles. But there is a particular, more visceral thrill that comes from being in a tiny space. This thrill is heightened when these dancers are first-rate artists — the anticipation alone of close encounters creates its own buzz.

headline: How to Be a Lifelong Rangers Fan
text: The Knicks have been mercifully eliminated from the N.B.A. playoffs. The Yankees have not yet reached the trading-minor-leaguers-for-Joey-Votto deadline. Football is months away, and Tim Tebow is working out with the Jets’ punting unit.

headline: Tracing the Path of Jewish Medical Pioneers
text: The young man who applied to medical school in the spring of 1933 had graduated from Dartmouth College with good grades, a keen interest in medicine and, according to the university official who interviewed him, a nice sense of humor.

headline: Mets Plan to Keep Francisco as Closer
text: One day after another implosion by the Mets’ bullpen, Manager Terry Collins opted not to make any rash moves. Collins said Monday that he was leaving Frank Francisco in the closer’s role and was hoping that Francisco would fix some mechanical issues, including the possibility that he was tipping his pitches.

headline: President of France to Open New Term by Getting to Know a Neighbor Better
text: PARIS — It is a measure of the importance to France of the relationship with Germany that François Hollande, after taking office on Tuesday, will eat his first dinner as president of France in Berlin, in the company of Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Mr. Robertson, who first appeared as a guest conductor in Sydney in 2003, assumed his post in St. Louis in 2005, when he also became principal guest conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra.

headline: The Case for Overreacting
text: Via Mark Thoma, Simon Wren-Lewis argues that if we’re up against the zero lower bound but are uncertain about the size of the output gap — how far the economy is operating below potential — we should deliberately overreach on fiscal policy. Why? Because monetary policy can correct any excess stimulus, but not an inadequate stimulus.

headline: JPMorgan Loss Puts Spotlight on Possible Ratings Downgrade for Global Banks

headline: For New York Police, There’s No End to the Stops
text: New York City’s public advocate, Bill de Blasio, put forward a modest proposal last week. He wants the Police Department to include the number of street stop-and-frisks, which is in a state of geometric expansion, in its weekly review of precinct crime statistics.

headline: Romney’s Weasel Problem
text: You can wince at the cruelty of adolescence, as many did, after reading the Washington Post account of how a teenage Mitt Romney led a gang of prep school buddies to attack another boy.  “Senseless,” “vicious” and “stupid” were the words used by witnesses quoted by name in the piece.

headline: Beyond the Sandbags and Steel, 12 Lanes to Another Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Behind the black door in downtown Kabul is a place unlike any other in this city, even in the whole country.

headline: Syrians Defy Leaders to Aid Those in Need
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — For 48 hours, the two Damascus residents struggled to reach the besieged city of Homs by car, trying to deliver boxes of blood bags so surgeons there could operate on the wounded. But gunfire made the roads impassable.

headline: New York Council Wants Banks to Describe Efforts in Poor Areas
text: As a huge trading loss at JPMorgan Chase intensifies criticism of the nation’s big banks, the New York City Council plans to vote on Tuesday to require banks to make public their efforts to be socially responsible before the city decides where to deposit the billions of dollars it keeps in banks.

headline: A Landmark Ruling in South Africa
text: For the past decade, South Africa has been the preferred vacation spot, shopping destination and international transit hub for members of the tyrannical and murderous government ruling its northern neighbor, Zimbabwe — a government that has rigged elections, beaten and killed opposition activists and ruined a once thriving economy. All of this could now change because of a landmark legal decision.

headline: Coca-Cola Tests Sweeteners in Battle of Lower Calories
text: Coca-Cola is testing a new blend of sweeteners aimed at lowering the calorie counts in sodas, following on the heels of its rival, PepsiCo, which introduced the 60-calorie Pepsi Next at the end of March.

headline: In Graduation Speech to Women, Obama Leaps Into Gender Gap
text: President Obama, shifting the focus from his recent endorsement of same-sex marriage to what he portrays as a lifelong belief in the essential role of women, told female graduates of Barnard College in New York City on Monday that they should go out and “fight for a seat at the head of the table.”

headline: 1994 Revisited: Q. and A. With Stephane Richer
text: During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. On May 15, 1994, the Rangers and the Devils met at Madison Square Garden in Game 1. After the Devils’ Claude Lemieux tied the score, 3-3, with 43 seconds left in regulation, Stephane Richer scored the winning goal in the second overtime for the Devils. Now 45, Richer spoke by telephone from Montpellier, Quebec, where he owns a golf course.

headline: 23 Syrian Soldiers Reported Killed by Rebels
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Nearly two dozen Syrian government soldiers were killed in intense clashes with the opposition over control of the central, rebel-held city of Rastan, opposition groups said Monday, deepening questions about the viability of a cease-fire engineered under United Nations auspices.

headline: New Cast Atop Yahoo Faces Stubborn Troubles
text: As Yahoo’s latest chief executive and newest board members settle into their roles, they will be confronted with the same problem that has bedeviled their predecessors: how to fix one of Silicon Valley’s most crisis-plagued companies.

headline: Well-Rested Thunder Crush Lakers
text: OKLAHOMA CITY – In the aftermath, as the crowd at Chesapeake Energy Arena continued to rock around them, Andrew Bynum and Pau Gasol remained on the Los Angeles Lakers’ bench for several minutes as they searched for some answer to what the Oklahoma City Thunder had done to them.

headline: Warning Signs of a Failing Tree
text: Six indicators of stress, decay or potential failure used to assess the health of trees.

headline: Comedies Lead the Way for the Next TV Season
text: AS the television upfront week for the 2012-13 season gets under way, the networks announcing their schedules signaled clearly how much they are counting on comedy to improve their fortunes.

headline: At Upfront, Fox Shows Off Some New-Media Tricks
text: During upfront week, it can sometimes seem as if television networks trip over one another to show off their new-media prowess.

headline: Saudi Arabia Seeks Union of Monarchies in Region
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Saudi Arabia pushed ahead Monday with efforts to forge a single federation with its five Persian Gulf neighbors as the conservative monarchy seeks to build a new bulwark against the waves of change sweeping the Middle East.

headline: Bronx Lawmaker Seeks a Sharp Contrast With Disgraced Predecessor
text: Former state senators from one particularly hapless section of the northwest Bronx have something in common on their résumés: one went to jail, another is still in jail and a third now faces jail.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Risk of Greek Euro Exit Rattles Markets, but Hints of More Talks Emerge
text: BERLIN — As gridlock among Greece’s political parties made new elections and another month of uncertainty there all but inevitable, European markets dropped significantly on Monday amid concerns that Greece’s departure from the euro was near, and right behind it a new round of financial instability for Europe and the outside world.

headline: New Twist in a March Senate Election That’s Still Too Close to Call
text: It has been eight weeks since voters in South Brooklyn cast their ballots for a short-term state senator in a short-term district. Eight long weeks of accusations, legal proceedings and ballot counting.

headline: Make Banking Boring
text: Let’s begin by stipulating the obvious: nobody outside of JPMorgan Chase knows for sure what really happened with those trades that have cost it so much money and done such severe damage to its once stellar reputation.

headline: Deadliest Danger Isn’t at the Rig but on the Road
text: After working 17 hours straight at a natural gas well in Ohio, Timothy Roth and three other crew members climbed into their company truck around 10 o’clock one night last July and began their four-hour drive back to their drilling service company’s shop in West Virginia.

headline: The Right’s Righteous Frauds
text: Say what you will about Bristol Palin, she’s a quick study. It didn’t take her long to master the ways of her elders on the censorious right and decide that personal circumstance and past error needn’t prevent someone from claiming righteous leadership. Uncle Rush must be proud.

headline: The ESPN Man
text: Two of the nation’s smartest analysts have just come out with reports on how the presidential election looks six months out. Bill Galston of the Brookings Institution argues that at this point President Obama has a modest advantage over Mitt Romney. The pollster Peter D. Hart says that “this election is no better than a 50-50 proposition for the president.”

headline: Mitt Likes Music, Including This
text: The Gregory Brothers present a musical video mash-up about what Mitt Romney likes — from lakes and trees to music and cars to grits and “Twilight.”

headline: Experts Say Default Would Mean Eviction
text: ATHENS — Could Greece default on its debt and still remain in the euro zone?

headline: How Bank Handles Bad Bet Is Fraught With Peril
text: “If I go there will be trouble, and if I stay it will be double.”

headline: Turning a Phrase
text: This is the fifth in a series of writing lessons by the author, starting with the basics and leading to more advanced techniques.

headline: Documents on the Oil Field Exemptions From Highway Safety Rules, Explored and Annotated by the Times
text: Documents related to the so-called oil field exemptions from highway safety rules that allow truckers to work longer hours than drivers in most other industries.

headline: On Familiar Garden Ice, Brodeur Struggles to an Oft-Heard Refrain
text: Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur had barely finished scuffing the goal crease for better traction before the opening face-off Monday night when a full house at Madison Square Garden began serenading him with the “Marty!” chant he has heard for most of the last two decades.

headline: ‘Mitt Likes Music, Including This’
text: In 2008, Barack Obama whipped voters into a hope-fueled frenzy, audaciously promising a government that would be able to pass laws.  Perhaps President Obama thinks a similarly bold strategy will help him prevail this fall over his Republican rival, Mitt Romney.

headline: Music Notes
text: Below are the lyrics to "Mitt Likes Music, Including This,” an Op-Doc by the Gregory Brothers, and the source for each line.

headline: The ‘Perfect Hedge’ Remains Elusive at JPMorgan
text: At JPMorgan Chase, they called it “the icing” — as in the icing on the cake.

headline: Iran Sees Success in Stalling on Nuclear Issue
text: TEHRAN — As Iran starts a critical round of talks over its nuclear program, its negotiating team may be less interested in reaching a comprehensive settlement than in buying time and establishing the legitimacy of its enrichment program, Iranian officials and analysts said.

headline: Prison Term for Family Friend in Harlem Boy’s Killing
text: Tyshene Mungo lost her son on a warm night in September 2008. A longstanding dispute between two rival gangs — the Lenox Boys and 2 Mafia Family, or 2MF — escalated after one member crossed a median on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard that separated their territories in Harlem.

headline: Drug Trial Starts for Figure Prominent in Rap World
text: Prosecutors say James Rosemond is a drug kingpin, and he went on trial Monday in federal court in Brooklyn on charges that he led a criminal enterprise that sold millions of dollars worth of cocaine, laundered money and tampered with witnesses.

headline: Hollow Victory
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’re like me, the kind of crossword solver who tends to solve from top to bottom, you probably appreciate it when the payoff is near the bottom. There’s nothing quite like wending your way through the grid, slightly puzzled (see what I did there?) as to what might possibly be tying the long entries together, then reaching the entry that will reveal all. If you’re like me, there’s that delicious moment where you stare at the grid, blink a few times, and then allow yourself to give in to that wonderful “Aha!” moment.

headline: In Washington, Mixed Messages Over Tighter Rules for Wall St.
text: Conflicting signs are emerging in Washington over whether JPMorgan Chase’s surprise trading loss will spur tighter regulation on Wall Street.

headline: Rapper Faces Death Threats in Iran Over Song
text: TEHRAN — With lyrics that tread on ultrasensitive topics and an album cover that shows the dome of a mosque in the shape of a woman’s breast, Shahin Najafi is an international rapper who elicits an intense reaction here.

headline: Self-Promotional Pimp Draws 4 Years
text: Jason Itzler, the self-proclaimed King of All Pimps, was sentenced on Monday to four years in prison for promoting prostitution, money laundering and drug charges, but not before he called for the legalization of prostitution.

headline: Red Flags Said to Go Unheeded by Bosses at JPMorgan
text: In the years leading up to JPMorgan Chase’s $2 billion trading loss, risk managers and some senior investment bankers raised concerns that the bank was making increasingly large investments involving complex trades that were hard to understand. But even as the size of the bets climbed steadily, these former employees say, their concerns about the dangers were ignored or dismissed.

headline: Scandal Not Affecting China’s Political Calendar
text: BEIJING — Despite a spectacular political scandal and swirling rumors of high-level infighting, signs are that China’s once-in-a-decade leadership change is still on track for this autumn, according to party insiders and observers.

headline: The Strange Life of the Closer
text: In two years since becoming the closer for the Milwaukee Brewers, John Axford ranks second in the majors in save percentage, trailing only Jose Valverde of Detroit. Last Friday he blew his first save in 50 opportunities, and left the ballpark before reporters could talk to him.

headline: Mongolia: Ex-Leader Granted Bail
text: Former President Nambaryn Enkhbayar was granted bail on Monday and will remain hospitalized after refusing water for 10 days to protest his detention on corruption charges. He ended his hunger strike after bail was granted. The Sukhbaatar District Court’s decision was confirmed by a Mongolia prisons service spokesman, T. Amarsaikhan. Mr. Enkhbayar and his family said his arrest last month, on charges dating as far back as 2000, was an attempt by the government to keep him from taking part in parliamentary elections next month.

headline: Coty Withdraws $10.7 Billion Offer for Avon
text: Coty said on Monday that it was abandoning its pursuit of Avon Products, citing Avon’s “unwillingness to engage in discussions.”

headline: As Mets Hold Breath, Francisco Holds Lead
text: Mets starter Miguel Batista did his job against Milwaukee on Monday night, and so it was time for Manager Terry Collins to do his: delicately handle a fragile bullpen trying to preserve yet another tight ballgame.

headline: End of the Affair?
text: Investors are shunning the stock market, and who can blame them? As serial bubbles have burst, faith in the market has been rewarded with shattered retirements. At the same time, trust has been destroyed by scandals and — as demonstrated by the reckless trading at JPMorgan Chase — the slow, uncertain pace of financial reform.

headline: Not Too Late to Curb the Filibuster
text: Fed up and rueful, Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, made a startling admission on Thursday: he should have reined in the filibuster rule last year, when he had a chance. As Republicans engaged in yet another of their endless filibusters on what should have been a routine matter — reauthorizing the Export-Import Bank — Mr. Reid took to the floor and praised two senators for being right last year when he was wrong.

headline: Confronting Keystone Again
text: The next chapter in the Keystone XL pipeline saga has now begun. In January, President Obama rejected the first proposal from TransCanada, the pipeline company, on grounds that there was not enough time for a thorough environmental review of the project, which would carry crude oil from the Alberta tar sands to the Gulf Coast.

headline: A Steeplechase Death
text: Scenes from the Iroquois Steeplechase in Nashville, where Arcadius, an 8-year-old gelding, collapsed and died soon after leaving the winner’s circle.

headline: A Sidewalk Shed in Perpetuity
text: For all the high-rise beauty of the city’s silhouette, pedestrians down below must step warily beneath mine-shaft-like structures called sidewalk sheds — overhanging wood and steel constructions that are supposed to be up only temporarily to catch debris from workers repairing building facades high above. There are about 6,000 sheds at any one time, in a city that constantly needs fixing.

headline: Colorado Rejects Same-Sex Civil Unions
text: DENVER — A bill that would have allowed civil unions for same-sex couples in Colorado was defeated on Monday night during a special legislative session called by Gov. John W. Hickenlooper to debate the issue.

headline: Chesapeake Energy’s Chief, Under Investor Pressure, Seeks to Win Over Skeptics
text: HOUSTON — Chesapeake Energy sought to calm investors on Monday by disclosing details of a new $3 billion unsecured bridge loan aimed at buying time for the financially beleaguered company to bargain for the best terms in selling valuable oil fields in West Texas and other assets.

headline: Mike McGrady, Known for a Literary Hoax, Dies at 78
text: Mike McGrady, a prizewinning reporter for Newsday who to his chagrin was best known as the mastermind of one of the juiciest literary hoaxes in America — the best-selling collaborative novel “Naked Came the Stranger,” whose publication in 1969 made “Peyton Place” look like a church picnic — died on Sunday in Shelton, Wash. He was 78 and lived in Lilliwaup, Wash.

headline: In City Where Dogs Outnumber Children, Finding a Way for Coyotes to Coexist
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Almost all creatures, great and small, are welcome in the city of St. Francis, patron saint of animals, whose spirit imbues this place with a love and regard for our nonhuman friends. Take just one example gleaned from census and city data: Dogs outnumber children here, making already assertive dog owners an even more formidable political force.

headline: Corrections: May 15
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: After the Best Race of His Life, a Horse’s Death
text: NASHVILLE — Even the winners can die. The steeplechase horse Arcadius — a thoroughbred like those in this weekend’s Preakness — won a race that rewards the hardy, the brave, the stout. Three miles. Eighteen hurdles. He galloped, he jumped, he stalked, he flew home.

headline: Can Dual Citizens Be Good Americans?
text: Should dual citizenship be allowed? The pros and cons of pledging allegiance to more than one country.

headline: One Swing Lifts Teixeira and Yankees
text: BALTIMORE — Mark Teixeira wore a worried expression Monday afternoon as he described the status of a cough he can neither shake nor understand. It has plagued him for more than a month and at times makes it difficult for him to breathe, especially after he has run the bases.

headline: The President’s Day in New York City
text: A behind-the-scenes look at President Obama’s day in New York City, where he spoke at a graduation, taped a television interview and attended two fund-raisers.

headline: Rangers Start Off With Strong Finish
text: The Rangers had several heroes Monday night in the latest renewal of the Battle of the Hudson.

headline: Word of the Day | dossier
text: dossier •\ˈdȯs-ˌya, ˈdäs-; ˈdȯ-se-ˌa, ˈdä-\• noun

headline: Rangers-Devils: Game 1
text: After two scoreless periods, a flurry of offense provided a victory for the Rangers.

headline: For Some, Same-Sex Marriage Is Not Politics, It’s Personal
text: WASHINGTON — Some of their best friends turned out to be gay.

headline: Rhode Island Order on Gay Unions
text: Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island on Monday ordered all state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere and to afford those couples many of the same rights and benefits that heterosexual couples get.

headline: Maldives President Rules Out Early Elections
text: The president of the Maldives ruled out early elections during an official visit to India on Monday, citing the constitution, and declared that the soonest that a vote could take place was July 2013.

headline: Judge Blocks Testimony for Edwards on Finance Law
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — In a setback for the defense, the judge in John Edwards’s corruption trial on Monday barred the testimony of a former federal elections official who was prepared to say Mr. Edwards did not violate campaign finance laws.

headline: Inflation Rate Outpaces Predictions
text: “Inflation in India accelerated faster than expected in April, as the cost of food, fuel and manufactured items all rose, complicating the central bank’s efforts to curb rising prices with economic growth slumping nearly to a three-year low,” Reuters reports.

headline: Romney Medicare Plan Draws a Stark Contrast
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on one thing about Medicare: the differences between them are huge. Each man says his opponent’s policies would end Medicare as it now exists, undermining the rock-solid guarantee of health care for older Americans.

headline: After Regaining Minutes, Kreider Capitalizes
text: As the final minutes of the game counted down, and Chris Kreider sat on the bench after his goal and assist had given the Rangers a 2-0 lead, the veteran wing Mike Rupp had some advice for the rookie. Or perhaps it was more like a command.

headline: Obama Ad Focuses on Workers Who Lost Jobs When a Mill Acquired by Bain Capital Closed
text: “Steel,” a two-minute advertisement for President Obama’s re-election campaign, will run on network television on Wednesday night in Colorado, Iowa, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia. The campaign is spending less than $100,000 to air the ad, at least initially.

headline: Too Many Sacred Cows
text: “On May 11, a furor erupted in India’s Parliament over a black-and-white cartoon from 1949,” Hartosh Singh Bal writes in the Latitude blog of The New York Times. “Reproduced in a textbook for high-school juniors, the drawing depicts B.R. Ambedkar — India’s foremost Dalit leader and the chairman of the committee that drafted India’s 1950 Constitution — whip in hand and astride a snail labeled ‘the Constitution.'” The first Prime Minister of India, Jawaharlal Nehru, “stands behind him, also wielding a whip.” Mr. Bal writes.

headline: Tackling a Hefty Reading List
text: In college, I took a course on Karl Marx that required reading everything that Marx and Hegel wrote. It was history as boot camp, and we were overwhelmed by the task.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 11 through May 13 with 615 adults across the United States.

headline: Illinois: 8 Arrested in NATO Protest
text: At least eight protesters were arrested on trespassing charges Monday after they refused to leave the building that houses President Obama’s re-election headquarters in downtown Chicago. The protest, organized by a national Roman Catholic group, was the first display of civil disobedience leading up to a NATO summit meeting being held in the city on Sunday and Monday.

headline: Ruling on Mine Will Be Appealed
text: The Obama administration said Monday that it would appeal a ruling by a federal judge that the Environmental Protection Agency illegally vetoed a major coal mining project in West Virginia. In a scathing decision in March, Judge Amy Berman Jackson of Federal District Court wrote that the agency overstepped its authority by retroactively revoking the waste disposal permit for the Spruce No. 1 mine in Logan County in January 2011. In taking the rare step of revoking the permit, which was granted in 2007 by the Bush administration, the E.P.A. said the coal mining would do permanent damage to rivers, wildlife and communities. The project, owned by Arch Coal of St. Louis, would have buried 6.6 miles of streams under tons of mining waste.

headline: Good News for Six Types of Fish
text: A record six populations of fish returned to healthy levels in 2011, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported to Congress on Monday. NOAA’s Fisheries Service said the count showed that its controversial and often unpopular catch limits have been working. Among the rebuilt populations are the Bering Sea snow crab, the summer flounder along the mid-Atlantic, the haddock in the Gulf of Maine, the Chinook salmon along the Northern California coast, the coho salmon off Washington State and the Pacific widow rockfish, the Fisheries Service said. Altogether, 27 fish stocks have been returned to health in the last 11 years, the agency said. Under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, NOAA must report annually on fish stocks in waters within 200 miles of the coast, and depleted stocks must be rebuilt to healthy levels. Scores of fish species have been in serious decline since the 1980s, largely because of overfishing.

headline: Inside the China-Philippines Fight in the South China Sea
text: Fish, oil and bananas all play a role in the latest round of the high-stakes sovereignty dispute in the South China Sea, a problem that may rival Europe’s own 19th-century “Schleswig-Holstein Question.” That long-simmering territorial dispute, between Denmark and Germany, led the British politician Lord Palmerston to quip that only three people had ever understood it: a dead prince, a German professor who went mad, “and I, who have forgotten all about it.”

headline: News Quiz | May 15, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: With Flexibility, Africa Surpasses India
text: Africa is a continent widely associated “in the Western imagination with poverty, corruption, conflict and disease,” Ian Bremmer writes in The New York Times. “Yet Africa has become the world’s most underrated growth story — in part because many of its governments have developed the resilience that comes with the ability to pivot.”

headline: May 15, 1911 | Supreme Court Orders Standard Oil to Be Broken Up
text: On May 15, 1911, the Supreme Court ordered the dissolution of Standard Oil Company, ruling it was in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 15, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Op-Ed “When a Parking Lot Is So Much More.”

headline: Top Murdoch Aide Is Charged in Hacking Case
text: LONDON — Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper empire and a close friend of Prime Minister David Cameron, was formally charged on Tuesday, along with her husband and four others, with perverting the course of justice in the phone hacking scandal that has burrowed deeply into British public life.

headline: Who Is Mark Zuckerberg?
text: WHO is Mark Elliot Zuckerberg?

headline: Making Choices in the Age of Information Overload
text: Recently my wife and I went on an epic hunt to uncover everything possible about baby formula. We scoured more Web sites than I’d like to admit to and learned about all the options: powder, liquid, milk-based, soy, D.H.A.- and A.R.A.-fortified. (I’m still not clear on what A.R.A. is, exactly.) Then we learned that none of it actually matters. Since the Infant Formula Act of 1980, the F.D.A. makes sure that all formula is pretty much the same, no matter which one you buy.

headline: Is TV Stronger Than Ever, or Becoming Obsolete?
text: Television, the entertainment stalwart, may have seen better days. Viewer demand for content is higher than ever, but consumers are increasingly watching it on DVR, computers, tablets or smartphones, which often allows them to skip advertising. Even with these changes, television advertising revenues were up in 2011. How do you watch TV shows? Is television as we know it in trouble?

headline: Shooting More Than a War
text: Nicole Tung, 25, spent much of 2011 in North Africa, photographing upheaval in Egypt and rebels in Libya. An American citizen, she was born in Hong Kong and attended New York University. She hopes to make a book of her images from the Libyan revolution.

headline: Iran Executes Man Accused as Israeli Spy and Assassin
text: LONDON — Iran said Tuesday that it had executed a man accused of being an Israeli intelligence agent responsible for the assassination of one of its nuclear scientists.

headline: Euro Zone Economy Skirts Recession
text: FRANKFURT — It’s way too early to call a turning point. But while Greeks were marching in the streets against austerity, their economy may actually have been growing for the first time since 2009. That surprise news resided deep within first-quarter economic data for Europe released Tuesday that also showed, to everyone’s mild relief, that the euro zone as a whole has still avoided slipping into a regional recession.

headline: The Shingles Vaccine Returns
text: You may have seen a rugged-looking retired firefighter named Dennis Grogan in a TV commercial recently. “I have never encountered such a burning sensation,” he declares. “Like someone had set a bag of hot charcoal on my neck.” An announcer warns, “As you get older, there’s a greater chance shingles can happen to you.”

headline: What Rule Should the Fed Follow?
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: A Dream College Acceptance, With the Money to Make It Come True
text: I stood on the sixth floor of my school, staring down the seemingly endless brown and black checkerboard patterned hallway, waiting for the (1) to pop up on the mail icon on my phone. Legs quivering, heart pounding, hands shaking. Finally, it appeared: “Syracuse University Admission Notification.” I couldn’t click the link attached to the e-mail fast enough.

headline: Hollande Meets Merkel to Start a Delicate Balancing Act
text: BERLIN — The new beginning for the most important relationship in Europe — between Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France — started Tuesday with a bolt from the blue, an apology, and a sense of harmony that seemed somehow more sincere for the adversity that came before it.

headline: The Early Word: Principles
text: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.

headline: Q&A: Turning Off a Social App
text: Q.

headline: Setback in Comeback for Giants’ Chad Jones
text: Chad Jones, a Giants third-round pick in 2010, has made impressive strides since a car accident halted his career soon after he was drafted from L.S.U. as a safety. But the decision by the Giants on Monday to release him suggests that his comeback may end one step short of the N.F.L.

headline: A Youth Entrepreneurship Program Goes International
text: In 1981, a gang of teenagers mugged the owner of an import-export business while he was walking on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. They ran off with the contents of his wallet, $10. But Steve Mariotti took away something more valuable: the germ of an idea.

headline: ESPN Doubles Up on ’30 for 30’ Documentary Series
text: ESPN’s faith in sports documentaries is so deep that on Tuesday it will announce a second go-round for its “30 for 30” series, which made its debut in the fall of 2009.

headline: Q. and A.: The Most Endangered Rivers
text: Five million Americans in four states and the District of Columbia drink water from the Potomac River. Yet according to the environmental group American Rivers, that water is at risk: in a report issued on Tuesday, it listed the Potomac as No. 1 on its annual list of the most endangered rivers.

headline: Toughening Its Stand, European Union Sends Forces to Strike Somali Pirate Base
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The European Union, which had vowed to take a tougher stand against the scourge of Somali piracy, took the fight to the pirates’ home base for the first time on Tuesday, destroying several of their signature fiberglass skiffs as they lay on the beach in a notorious pirate den.

headline: How to Enjoy the Derby in 10 Easy Steps
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. – More than a week removed from partaking in what Hunter S. Thompson called “the Derby’s special vibrations,” I’ve had time to reflect on the entire experience. The Kentucky Derby is the longest continuously held sporting event in the United States, and it truly is something to be checked off your bucket list. As John Steinbeck wrote in 1956: “What an experience. I am glad I have seen it and felt it at last.”

headline: German Growth Gives Rare Boost to Euro
text: LONDON — There is precious little good news coming out of the 17-nation euro zone these days. So the unexpected announcement on Tuesday that Germany’s economy grew by a robust 0.5 percent in the first quarter of the year was enough to give a mild boost to the battered single currency.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Campaigns Duel Over Romney’s Bain Record
text: Some of the most explosive moments in presidential campaigns are fueled by surprise. The political power of an unexpected allegation often comes from the frenzy surrounding its revelation.

headline: Dutch Masters Travel to Istanbul
text: Turkey and the Netherlands are celebrating 400 years of diplomatic relations this year, and for Istanbul, that means compelling additions to the cultural calendar, including a major exhibit of Dutch Masters at the Sakip Sabanci Museum.

headline: Word to Watch: ‘Advocate’
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Word to Watch: ‘Advocate’
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Opinion Report: Ending the Filibuster
text: From the editorial page

headline: Legal Rulings Favor Teachers' Union
text: The United Federation of Teachers came away with two legal victories on Monday. One orders the city to go to mediation to establish a teacher evaluation system at 33 struggling schools. The second ends a long-simmering dispute at the Sisulu-Walker Charter School of Harlem by certifying the union as the official bargaining agent for the school.

headline: A Woman Leader for the Isolated Jungle Village of Jharki Bisalpur
text: When Sheila Devi was growing up in the village of Jharki Bisalpur, wild animals would frequently wander through, searching for water and food. She saw deer and wild boar, foxes, even a python. There were rumored tiger sightings. But in the last few years “even the animals have had the sense to move elsewhere” Mrs. Devi, now a Panchayat leader in her late thirties, says dryly.

headline: Down on Austerity
text: Exhibiting “an allergy to austerity,” as The Guardian puts it, voters across Europe are turning against their leaders. In France, the recent election of the Socialist François Hollande as president ended 17 years of conservative rule. Greece has been roiled by political uncertainty since the mainstream parties were rebuked in parliamentary elections. And on Sunday Chancellor Angela Merkel suffered a big loss at the polls in Germany’s most populous state.

headline: More on Greek and Argentine Exports
text: Mark Weisbrot points out, in reference to my earlier post, that when comparing Argentina’s exit from the convertibility law with a possible Greek exit from the euro, the relevant comparison is with Argentine exports before the exit, not after. He’s right; here’s what it looks like (data from UN and Eurostat):

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s Growth Prospects
text: As Facebook turns to Wall Street in the biggest public offering ever by an Internet company, it faces a new, unenviable test: how to keep growing and enriching its hungry new shareholders, reports Somini Sengupta of The New York Times.

headline: Can Germany Change?
text: My co-author weighs in with faint hope that the austerity obsession may be easing, and dire warnings about what happens if it doesn’t.

headline: Carlyle’s Profit Falls in First Quarter
text: In its first earnings report as a public company, the Carlyle Group on Tuesday reported a 26 percent drop in profit.

headline: A 30,000-Foot View on the Presidential Race
text: We are beginning to see more national surveys now, including this week’s New York Times/CBS News poll, which show Mitt Romney with a slight lead over President Obama in the general election matchup. To be sure, there are also a number of polls that put Mr. Obama slightly ahead. But his lead does seem to have narrowed — from about three or four points in an average of national polls a month or two ago to more like a point or so in surveys today.

headline: Bret Michaels Settles Lawsuit After Injury at Tony Awards
text: The curtain has come down on a lawsuit filed against the organizers of the Tony Awards and CBS by Bret Michaels, who said he had been injured by a piece of scenery in the awards show but has reached a settlement in the case, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Visual Culture
text: Palermo’s contemporary art museum, Palazzo Rizo, was shuttered after a government official reportedly tried to install his wife as director weeks after the European Union awarded millions in funding to the museum. But the city’s art scene is irrepressible. After working for Gagosian in New York, the 40-year-old Francesco Pantaleone came home to open his namesake gallery (Via Garraffello, 25; 011-39-091-332482; fpac.it) to foster native talent like Benny Chirco (above, bennychirco.it), whose recent installations use disassembled landscape paintings industrially produced in China. The Ravenna-born Stefania Galegati Shines (galegati.net) moved to Palermo in 2007 to make work like her installation for the Palermo Galleria di Arte (galleriadartemodernapalermo.it) that featured tricked-out cars as a way of examining the city’s street culture. And the Palermo native Manfredi Beninati (manfredibeninati.com) has attracted international attention for the layering of imagery in his canvases depicting family members and domestic moments in fantastical landscapes.

headline: From 3 Commencement Speakers, a Familiar Script
text: If you’re delivering a commencement address, you must observe certain customs. No exceptions are allowed, not even for the biggest of shots, a reality reinforced in speeches made in the last few days by President Obama, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the would-be president Mitt Romney.

headline: More on Extreme Weather and the Greenhouse Effect
text: Martin P. Hoerling, a federal research meteorologist specializing in climate dynamics, faced a lot of pushback after he criticized some assertions made in an Op-Ed article on climate change by James E. Hansen of NASA.
