One critic is Dan Miller, an engineer and venture capitalist focused on non-polluting energy technologies who blogs on climate at ClimatePlace.org and helped Hansen craft his Times piece.

headline: A Question Inspired by the Skyline
text: Dear Diary, My youngest daughter recently visited me here. It was her first visit to New York, and living in one of the outer boroughs, she wasn’t keen on experiencing the subway. So each day during her stay, I drove us into the city.

headline: Hollande Is No Mitterrand. Can He Inspire, or Just Spook?
text: YARMOUTH, Isle of Wight — From here, 88 miles and several billion light years from France, the Socialists’ victory bash last week at the Bastille fell short of déjà vu. I was there in 1981 when François Mitterrand projected hope for real change to bellowing, rose-waving masses. This was not that.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Serious Eats: For all you would-be outdoor grillers who are daunted by fears of ruining that fine cut of meat, 11 tips, extensively explained, toward grilling the perfect steak. — Eric Asimov

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Charges in Phone Hacking, and When Reporters Wrote Smut
text: Rebekah Brooks, the former key aide to Rupert Murdoch and close friend with Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, was officially charged with perverting the course of justice in connection to the investigation of the phone-hacking scandal. She and her husband, Charlie Brooks, and four others were accused of concealing documents, computers and archive material from investigators, Alan Cowell and John F. Burns report. The couple went on the offensive, issuing a statement before the arrests were announced, deploring what they called a “weak and unjust decision.”

headline: Image of the Day: May 15
text: A young boy fishes for coins in river Yamuna, New Delhi.

headline: Dooming the Euro
text: At this point an argument that was once considered way out there — that euro area adjustment won’t be possible unless the inflation target is raised — now has widespread support, albeit not from the crucial players. Inflation significantly above 2 percent is almost surely a necessary (though not sufficient) condition for the euro to survive.

headline: Pondering That Green Label
text: When it comes to labels assuring consumers that they’re buying green products, buyer beware. In theory such labels are intended to help shoppers make responsible choices. But many of these labeling and certification programs are overseen by the industry they are supposedly policing.

headline: Chávez vs. Putin
text: MONTREAL — He came to power in the late 1990s, his energetic governing style ushering in an era of increasing prosperity that earned him plenty of goodwill. Luck also helped some: his rule coincided with an era of rising oil prices, and he used the petrodollars that flooded the state’s coffers to finance a dizzying consumption boom throughout the country. This helped him maintain his popularity even as urban elites became more and more disillusioned with his autocratic streak, deepening militarism, rampant corruption and his disdain for the traditional hallmarks of democracy.

headline: Bangkok Rising
text: One morning in January, I watched as young Thai men and women emerged from the Erawan Bangkok shopping mall, put down their Comme des Garçons and Burberry bags, and bowed with folded hands to the Hindu creation deity Brahma at the Erawan shrine conveniently located just outside. In Bangkok, it seemed, retail therapy was not a secular substitute for religious healing, but rather went together with it. This was merely one contradiction in a city famous for them. Walking past the massage parlors and transvestite clubs of the red-light district Nana and into the packed temples and spirit houses, I marveled at how the city combines the promise of guilt-free sex with a profound faith in the Buddhist cycle of karma.

headline: For the Lakers, It Gets Late Early
text: Monday night’s playoff games spurred one of sports’ eternal questions: When is Game 1 of a series just one game, and when is it the signal of everything ahead? (O.K., so it’s not a deep question, just a timeless one.) For the Lakers and Devils, have we watched the beginning of the end? Is panic in order? Or were Monday night’s losses just a stumble in what will be arduous journeys longer than a Kardashian marriage?

headline: Lady Gaga Denied Permit to Perform in Indonesia
text: Lady Gaga is too risqué for Indonesia. The national police denied her a permit on Tuesday for a concert that was to have been held in early June after Islamic hard-liners mounted protests, complaining that her sexy clothes and suggestive dance moves will corrupt the youth, The Associated Press and Reuters reported.

headline: Absorbing Blows in a Battle Just Begun
text: For the Rangers’ playoffs series this year, the overflow press box at Madison Square Garden is a narrow balcony tucked under the roof at the west end. It’s cold, dark and lonely up there, especially if you’re a Devils fan bound by the code of the press box not to show any feeling: no groans, cheers, fist-pounds or high-fives. You have less legroom than in the bulkhead seat on the Delta shuttle, and from this distance, the smoke plumes that shoot up from the rink ends when the Rangers score look like steam puffs escaping from a manhole.

headline: Tuesday Reading: My Son Looks Like a Girl. So What?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Dot-Music, Dot-Sport and (Security Experts Hope) Dot-Secure
text: Will the new Internet with hundreds of new top-level domain names be more secure or a wild free for all?

headline: Derby Victory Makes for Happy Days at Hastings
text: As I’ll Have Another ran down Bodemeister to win this year’s Kentucky Derby, across the continent the rafters were shaking throughout Vancouver, British Columbia. The local racetrack’s adopted son, Mario Gutierrez, had coolly piloted I’ll Have Another to victory, just like he brought home enough winners to perennially be among Hastings Racecourse’s leading riders.

headline: Live Blog: JPMorgan’s Annual Meeting
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Days after disclosing a $2 billion trading loss, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, faced shareholders at the bank’s annual meeting here on Tuesday.

headline: United States Ranks Last on Breast-Feeding Support
text: Does the United States — do we — really want women to breast-feed their  infants?

headline: Wheelies: The Fraternité Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Glimpse of the President’s Day in the City
text: President Obama came to New York on Monday to offer words of advice to college graduates, to make a guest appearance on a day-time television talk show and, given what is expected to be a challenging re-election campaign, to raise money. A New York Times photographer, Doug Mills, who often travels with Mr. Obama when he ventures away from Washington, captured the president’s day as his large entourage went around town — attracting spectators and snarling traffic.

headline: Tasting Notes
text: Many of the food world’s recent obsessions hail from Sicily. But don’t stop at arancini, those sauce-filled fried rice balls that are in every Sicilian cafe. Here’s how to sample regional specialties at the source.

headline: Ellen DeGeneres to Receive Mark Twain Prize for Humor
text: Slip on your dancing shoes, Ellen DeGeneres, because you have something to celebrate. On Tuesday it was announced that Ms. DeGeneres, the comedian and highly animated daytime talk-show host, would be the recipient of the 15th annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. The award, given by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington to “people who have had an impact on American society in ways similar to” Mark Twain, the arts organization said in a news release, will be presented to Ms. DeGeneres at a ceremony on Oct. 22 that will be recorded for a later broadcast.

headline: For Europe’s Banks, Pinch of Debt Crisis Intensifies
text: LONDON — The pain facing European banks shows no signs of ending any time soon.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Cho No Michiyuki’
text: Today’s winner of our Third Annual Found Poem Contest comes from Raena, who is 18 years old and lives in Kaneohe,Hawaii. Her poem was created from a review of a Kabuki dance performance, “Cherry Blossoms and a Fan Telling Tales.”

headline: Engineering Tricks That Helped Facebook Win
text: As Facebook’s monster initial public offering nears, it is useful to remember: none of this was inevitable. And not all the credit for its success belongs to Mark Zuckerberg, or even Facebook’s disarmingly plain, deviously clever user design.

headline: Seeking a Life Beyond the Ironman Triathlon
text: Chrissie Wellington of Britain so thoroughly dominates Ironman triathlons that fans measure her success by the number of pro men she beats. Wellington, 35, is undefeated at Ironman, which consists of a 2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bike and a 26.2-mile run. After setting a course record of 8 hours 54 minutes 2 seconds at the 2009 Ironman world championships in Hawaii, she waited almost 20 minutes for the second-place woman to finish.

headline: Leaving Manhattan for a Taste of the Tiki
text: When tiki and tiki-esque bars like PKNY, the Hurricane Club and Lani Kai opened in New York in the last couple years, they had no living Manhattan models to emulate. The Lexington Hotel’s Hawaiian Room was long gone. And Donald Trump shut down the Trader Vic’s in the Plaza Hotel in 1993.

headline: Business Day Live | May 15, 2012
text: Ignoring red flags at JPMorgan | Facebook's new challenge is turning data into gold | The role of private debt in Europe's crisis.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/15: Hawaii’s Beaches Fade, and Hertz Gets Zagat Stamp
text: Surf It While You Can The United States Geological Survey reports that over the last century, 9 percent of beaches on the islands of Hawaii, Oahu and Maui has vanished — or 14 miles of sandy coast. That erosion is likely to accelerate as sea levels rise. (The New York Times)

headline: On Our Radar: Coffee and Carbon Trading
text: Subsistence coffee growers in the foothills of the Peruvian Andes take part in carbon trading in the hope of arresting climate change, which has made their crop yields more unpredictable. [The Guardian]

headline: New Drug Trial Seeks to Stop Alzheimer’s Before It Starts
text: In a clinical trial that could lead to treatments that prevent Alzheimer’s, people who are genetically guaranteed to develop the disease — but who do not yet have any symptoms — will for the first time be given a drug intended to stop it, federal officials announced Tuesday.

headline: The Knicks’ Douglas Dilemma
text: With their Game 5 loss to the Miami Heat last Wednesday, the Knicks brought an end to one of the franchise’s strangest, most unpredictable seasons.

headline: Addressing Pay and Protesters at Morgan Stanley’s Annual Meeting
text: Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, never visited the Occupy Wall Street protesters at Zuccotti Park. But on Tuesday morning, the protesters visited him.

headline: Spring Staples | Under Cover
text: Seasons change and so much accessories.

headline: NetSuite Moves to ‘Commerce as a Service’
text: NetSuite manages corporate data and has been quite successful at its cloud-based system of sales, order and inventory management software.

headline: Boehner to Double Down on Debt Rule
text: Speaker John A. Boehner appears to be girding for another fight over raising the nation’s debt ceiling  – possibly just before the November elections.

headline: The Tyrant as Tourist
text: As you may already know — since most of the prerelease publicity has been done in character — Sacha Baron Cohen’s latest comic avatar is Admiral General Aladeen, despot of Wadiya, a fictitious North African country, and the subject of “The Dictator.” Aladeen, whose desert nation is a gilded monument to his own vanity, is a (perhaps only slightly) exaggerated cartoon of strongmen like Muammar el-Qaddafi and Saddam Hussein, but with certain identifying features strategically blurred.

headline: Enclave-Hunting in Switzerland
text: You could go to Switzerland for the mountaineering, the chocolate, the precision-watchmaking or, once every three years, the National Yodeling Festival [1]. You could also go enclave-hunting. The alpine confederacy is rife with bits and bobs of subnational territories stranded outside their “mainland” [2].

headline: There’s a New Town in Town
text: If your dog, the absence of beer and food trucks, or the indoor nature of conventional gallery viewing have been obstacles to your attendance at photography exhibitions, you will have to come up with new excuses this summer.

headline: Fivestory: A Boudoir With Stories to Tell
text: CAN fashion rise to the level of art? That’s the central question posed by the current “Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations” exhibition at the Costume Institute, in which the two designers, the first dead for almost 40 years, are felicitously if somewhat awkwardly juxtaposed with some cutting-edge video techniques (Skype-arelli!).

headline: Greek President Is Expected to Name Caretaker Government Ahead of Vote
text: ATHENS — As Greece’s president warned about the possibility of bank runs, Greek political leaders said Tuesday that they had again failed to form a government, ushering the rudderless country toward new elections that could lead to its leaving the euro.

headline: F.B.I. Begins Preliminary Inquiry Into JPMorgan
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining potential wrongdoing surrounding JPMorgan Chase‘s $2 billion trading loss, people briefed on the matter said Tuesday.

headline: TimesCast | Murdoch Aides Face Charges
text: Rebekah Brooks and six others will face charges of conspiring to pervert the course of justice in the case of the wrongdoing at Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid newspapers in Britain.

headline: After Suspension, Merritt Focuses on Another Gold
text: DALLAS – While many of the athletes at the Team U.S.A. media event here expressed their enthusiasm about being Olympic contenders, few have experienced as strange of a path to the Olympic trials as the defending 400-meter champion, LaShawn Merritt.

headline: Porsche Releases Test Photos of 918 Hybrid Hypercar
text: On Tuesday, Porsche announced that testing of its long-awaited 918 Spyder hybrid was under way.

headline: SNY’s ‘Yearbook’ Series Set to Revisit 1962 Mets
text: In the beginning, there was hope. How else to explain the genuine and overflowing enthusiasm for the 1962 Mets, a bunch of aging stars, castoffs and budding nobodies.

headline: What’s Your #gameritual?
text: We asked sports fans what they like to do to help make their team win. Here’s what some of you wrote.

headline: Prepaid Debit Cards: Here a Fee, There a Fee
text: Prepaid debit cards are all the rage, with more traditional banks joining the business to help bolster their fee income. The cards let consumers access their money at A.T.M.’s and stores and pay bills without having a traditional checking account.

headline: Smule, Early Apple App Star, Finally Tries Android
text: Smule, the software developer known for its musical apps for iPhones, has decided it will make Android software too. It would almost appear to be an act of betrayal, as Smule was among the first companies to highlight the appeal of making apps for Apple’s platform.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Unpaid Internships
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Get | Nancy Gonzalez Union Jack Clutches
text: Early fans of the London Olympic Games, which commence on July 27, can carry their own gold, silver and bronze from the designer Nancy Gonzalez without having to compete in Olympic Village. Available starting today exclusively at the designer’s shop-within-a-shop at Harrods, the crocodile-skin clutches combine Gonzalez’s penchant for exotic materials with a familiar staple of English culture, the Union Jack. Available in traditional red, white and blue (for purists), and two metallic styles — matte gray with black and white, and silver with gold and bronze trim — the clutches come in very limited quantities. Game on!

headline: ABC Has 10 New Series and Is Also Playing Up the Laughs
text: ABC, which has introduced more new shows in recent years than any other television network, is back with a slate of 10 new series for its 2012-13.

headline: Roots in New York, but Stretching to Europe: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet at Joyce Theater
text: When the Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet company was founded in 2003 by the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie, the news was greeted with a profound shrug by the dance world. The troupe’s first two years didn’t do much to dispel the idea that it was a rich woman’s whim: there was no headquarters and few performances, and reports arose of an oddly corporate environment with dissatisfied collaborators.

headline: Stern’s Arrival Bolsters ‘America’s Got Talent’ Ratings
text: Howard Stern helped NBC continue its strong ratings performance on Monday nights as his first night as a judge on “America’s Got Talent” kept the network in first place in the 8 p.m.-to-10 p.m. time period among the viewers most sought by advertisers.

headline: Thing Falls Apart
text: And the center not only did not hold, it couldn’t seem to get any attention whatsoever. Americans Elect, a lavishly funded “centrist” group that was supposed to provide an alternative to traditional political parties, has been a ridiculous flop. Basically, about seven people were actually excited about the venture — all of them political pundits. Actual voters couldn’t care less.

headline: Gay Prosecutor Is Denied Virginia Judgeship Despite Bipartisan Support
text: Virginia’s Republican-controlled House rejected the judicial nomination of a gay Richmond prosecutor early Tuesday morning, plunging the critical swing state into the middle of the national debate about the civil rights of gay Americans.

headline: In Iowa, Romney Tests Economic Message
text: Mitt Romney arrives in Iowa on Tuesday for a speech intended to dramatize the impact of the economic downturn, calling the nation’s debt a “prairie fire” sweeping across the Midwestern state and the rest of the country.

headline: One Cinderella Apparently Not Enough for Broadway
text: Another revisionist Cinderella is bound for Broadway.

headline: The Best Courts Money Can Buy
text: Republicans often rail against “unelected judges” who issue decisions they don’t like. That sneering phrase, often used in complement with “judicial activism,” is meant to conjure the image of elitist liberals eager to meddle with legislation.

headline: Preview: The Food of GoogaMooga
text: Duck hot dogs, foie gras doughnuts and other snacks that will be on hand at the festival in Prospect Park on May 19 and 20.

headline: Pork Belly, Lobster and, Yes, Music
text: FOR anyone who flocked to a rock festival back in the summer of 1967, the underlying message of the enterprise would come courtesy of the Beatles: “All You Need Is Love.”

headline: The Union Responds to Bari Jay’s Concerns
text: In a previous post Susan Parker, a member of our business group, mentioned that she wanted to investigate her domestic manufacturing options, which are complicated by the fact that her company, Bari Jay, is unionized. Toward that end, the labor lawyer that represents Bari Jay in its union dealings reached out to union factories that were supposed to contact Ms. Parker. But none had, and Ms. Parker said she was in a “holding pattern.”

headline: Chanel Resort 2013
text: The interseason collection had more frills and furbelows than Marie Antoinette might have jammed into her closets.

headline: Let Them Eat Cake: Lagerfeld Captures Versailles’s Heyday
text: PARIS

headline: An Outpost of Afghan Dining Inside an American Military Base
text: At Forward Operating Base Salerno recently, the April air at lunchtime smelled fragrantly of eucalyptus and roses.

headline: European Finance Ministers Reach Compromise
text: BRUSSELS — With a $2 billion loss by JPMorgan Chase in London serving as a reminder that risky trading has not gone away, European Union finance ministers broke an impasse Tuesday and agreed on a plan to force banks to hold more capital as a buffer against the unexpected.

headline: Ethics Panel Opens Inquiry Into No. 2 Leader in State Senate
text: ALBANY — The state ethics commission has begun a preliminary inquiry of the State Senate’s second highest-ranking member, Thomas W. Libous, people with knowledge of the matter said Tuesday.

headline: Now Reading | ‘Foodieodicals’
text: Earlier this month, the first Food Book Fair was held at the Wythe Hotel, Brooklyn’s new epicurean hostelry, in Williamsburg. The event was made up of many appetizing programs, from a panel discussion on “Food Porn” to a smashingly twee dinner party themed around passages from “The Sun Also Rises.” (That scrumptious meal, by George Weld and Evan Hanczor of Parish Hall, ended appropriately enough in a fog of Pernod.)

headline: Debate Swirls Around Race-Day Medication
text: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board received an overwhelming response to its call for public comment as it weighs whether to pursue a ban on race-day medication.

headline: U.S. and Pakistan Say Deal to Open NATO Supply Lines Is Imminent
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — American and Pakistani officials said Tuesday that a deal appeared imminent to reopen Afghan supply lines through Pakistan, after NATO extended an invitation for Pakistan to attend the summit meeting in Chicago this weekend.

headline: When College May Not Be Worth the Cost: Examining Student Loan Debt
text: Go to related article » | Go to related interactive »

headline: Photo Replay: May 15
text: The Italian Open tennis tournament continued in Rome, and the Olympia’s Tour, a cycling road race, began in Noordwijk, the Netherlands.

headline: Bet on Greek Bonds Paid Off for ‘Vulture Fund’
text: Vulture funds 1. Greece 0.

headline: The Challenges in ResCap’s Bankruptcy
text: The lingering mortgage crisis has finally reached the bankruptcy courts in a substantial way with the filing of Residential Capital’s Chapter 11 case on Monday.

headline: How to Uncover Underwater Artifacts
text: Lisa J. Lucero, a professor of anthropology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, is studying ancient Maya underwater offerings in central Belize under the auspices of the Belize Institute of Archaeology, National Institute of Culture and History.

headline: A Drug to Prevent Alzheimer’s
text: The Times reports today that a group of people genetically predisposed to Alzheimer’s disease — but who do not yet have any symptoms — will for the first time be given a drug intended to stop them from developing the condition.

headline: Panel: Parental Involvement Is Key to Success of Young Men of Color
text: A panel that ended a week of activities organized by the Eagle Academy Foundation discussed strategies for raising young men of color.  Alan Farrell, who works on the city’s Fatherhood Initiative, summed up the message: “One of the take-aways is advocacy. And advocacy means we have got to show up.”

headline: Police Officer Aided Drug Dealer, U.S. Says
text: A wiretap by the federal Drug Enforcement Administration to obtain evidence against a heroin trafficking ring uncovered a surprising suspect, officials said: a New York City police officer.

headline: Water Polo: Second Straight Title for Stanford Women
text: Before last weekend, Aztec Aquaplex had not been kind to John Tanner and the Stanford women’s water polo program. The Cardinal had lost in each of the two previous N.C.A.A .title games held on the campus of San Diego State, most recently in a 10-9 heartbreaker toSouthern California in 2010.

headline: Canada, U.S. Reach World Hockey Quarters
text: It’s not a surprise that hockey is captivating Canada right now. But it’s not the N.H.L. playoffs, which doesn’t have a Canadian team in the Conference finals, that’s drawing the interest. The I.I.H.F. World Championships are in full swing right now in Finland, with Canada looking to atone for early exits the past two years in the annual tournament.

headline: Mets to Host 2013 All-Star Game at Citi Field
text: Major League Baseball will announce on Wednesday that next year’s All-Star Game will be held at Citi Field, according to a person with knowledge of the decision.

headline: TimesCast | May 15, 2012
text: The race to define Mitt Romney's career at Bain Capital | President Obama courts female voters | Some surprising numbers in a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Facebook Must Spin Data Into Gold
text: May 15, 2012 — Facebook’s impending star turn on Wall Street will challenge the Internet giant to turn information into profits.

headline: Florida Woman Kills 4 Children and Then Herself, Police Say
text: A Florida woman killed her four children at the family's home in Port St. John, Fla., on Tuesday before killing herself, the authorities said.

headline: For Them, a Great Meal Tops Good Intentions
text: THEY are two of the world’s most acclaimed chefs, each with a raft of awards, a constellation of stars and schools of kitchen alumni spreading their gospel. So when the American chef Thomas Keller and Andoni Luis Aduriz of Spain sat down last week for a joint interview, they were in a position to back each other up while slicing through some of the profession’s favorite platitudes.

headline: Is There a Social Issues Strategy?
text: My column over the weekend made the case that the Obama campaign’s eagerness to change the subject from the economy to social issues has been winning them news cycles without helping their long-term cause. (Yesterday’s Times/CBS poll showing Romney with a slight lead would seem to provide some confirmation of that point.) The New Republic’s Alec MacGillis takes issue with my argument, suggesting that the Obama White House doesn’t have a social issues strategy at all:

headline: $100 a Day on a Southern Route
text: The quickest way to drive from the Washington, D.C., area to Savannah, Ga., is to steel your nerves, grit your teeth and high-tail it for nine and a half hours down the monotonous, multilane, McDonald’s-laden highway called I-95. Looking for Southern culture? Try a McRib sandwich.

headline: Sir Rocco’s Report
text: Even before building Verdura — his high-style resort that opened on the beach near Sciacca in 2010 (verduraresort.com) — Sir Rocco Forte had plenty of reasons to make frequent trips to Sicily, starting with these five.

headline: Former Murdoch Aide Is ‘Baffled’ at Charges She Obstructed Hacking Investigation
text: As my colleagues Alan Cowell and John Burns report, Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper empire and a close friend of Prime Minister David Cameron, faced charges on Tuesday that she, her husband and four others conspired “to pervert the course of justice” during a police investigation of illegal phone-hacking by tabloid journalists.

headline: Washington Square South, 2:30 P.M.
text: Any time is lunchtime in the Hawk Cam nest, now that the five-week-old hatchlings are big enough to feed themselves.

headline: Canning, Step by Step
text: How to pickle asparagus, from blanching the vegetables and preparing the jars to sealing them shut for storage.

headline: Knoedler Seeks to Have Lawsuit Over Disputed Painting Dismissed
text: Knoedler & Company and its former president, Ann Freedman, filed motions in federal court in Manhattan this week to dismiss a $17 million lawsuit from a customer who says the now-defunct Knoedler Gallery sold him a fake Jackson Pollock painting. The gallery and Ms. Freedman maintain that the work, dubbed “Silver Pollock” and now owned by Pierre Lagrange, a London collector, is authentic.

headline: Google Wins Patent for Project Glass
text: Google was awarded design patents on Tuesday for its Project Glass browser glasses. Project Glass is the company’s first venture into wearable computing.

headline: Bush Makes a Rare Return to Washington
text: Former President George W. Bush made a rare return to Washington on Tuesday to promote international dissidents, a memorial to Sept. 11 heroes and, as it happened, Mitt Romney.

headline: Brooklyn’s Art Deco Sears Store Is Now a Landmark
text: The Sears, Roebuck store in Flatbush, Brooklyn, an 80-year-old Art Deco structure with a distinctive 10-story corner tower, is now a city landmark.

headline: U.N. Team Sees Clash Between Syrian Protesters and Soldiers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A convoy of unarmed United Nations monitors got caught up in a violent confrontation between protesters and Syrian government forces on Tuesday, with activist organizations putting the casualty toll at around 20 killed and dozens wounded.

headline: Video: Facebook Needs to Turn Data Into Gold
text: Somini Sengupta and Catherine Rampell discuss how Facebook can to turn information into profits, and whether it can do so without alienating its users in the process.

headline: Sisters Joined by Tumult, Grown Apart in Time
text: Anouk Markovits was raised a Hasidic Jew in France, but at 19 she fled her community to avoid an arranged marriage. She went on to get a master’s degree in architecture and a Ph.D. in romance studies. “I Am Forbidden,” her first novel in English, centers on two Hasidic sisters: one who leaves, and one who stays, shunning modernity. Given the author’s background, you might assume that this is a story about how one of them is wrecked by her choice.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Sues Housekeeper, Saying She Hurt His Career
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn has filed a countersuit against a housekeeper at a Midtown Manhattan hotel who accused him last year of rape, saying her statements about him had damaged his political career.

headline: JPMorgan Loss Leads Lawmakers to Delay Debate on Dodd-Frank
text: Will Wall Street pay the price for JPMorgan Chase‘s trading debacle?

headline: With JPMorgan as Example, Warren Calls for More Wall Street Regulation
text: BOSTON — In the wake of a $2 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase, Elizabeth Warren is redoubling her focus on a familiar campaign theme, calling for more effective Wall Street regulation with a burst of national media appearances, campaign statements and a new radio advertisement.

headline: Military Curbs F-22 Flights Over Oxygen Concerns
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta on Tuesday ordered immediate restrictions on flights of the F-22 Raptor fighter jet after a “60 Minutes” program that profiled two pilots who refused to fly the planes because of fears of oxygen deprivation in the cockpit.

headline: Nokia Shores Up Bottom of Its Market
text: Nokia on Tuesday introduced two low-priced dual-SIM card cellphones designed for the fast-growing developing markets in Europe, Asia and Latin America.

headline: A Daughter Too Young — and Too Old — to Freeze Eggs
text: Robin: Oh, how well I understand the sentiment driving the middle-aged parents featured in yesterday’s New York Times story: “So Eager for Grandchildren, They’re Paying the Egg-Freezing Clinic.” I, too, am eager for grandchildren: 58 years old, with two grown daughters and with grandbaby lust so startling it can take my breath away.

headline: American Folk Art Museum to Offer Exhibition at Seaport With Museum of the City of New York
text: Having survived a near-death experience last fall, the American Folk Art Museum will present an exhibition starting June 20 at the South Street Seaport Museum with the Museum of the City of New York, which now operates the Seaport Museum.

headline: Making Strawberry Rhubarb Confiture, Step by Step
text: Spring will tempt you to try preservation, a fancy word for canning.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photos from France, Lebanon, the West Bank and England.

headline: Not So Scary: Easy Steps to Canning
text: THE fruits and vegetables that seduce us early in the season (asparagus, spring onions, rhubarb and now strawberries) make me greedy. I fall hard and completely, happy to lug home cumbersome bags from the farmers’ market and create a still life on my kitchen counter of big bunches of vegetables and piles of berries. I want to incorporate all of it into every meal. I want to capture the moment and bottle it.

headline: Devils Trying to Keep Rangers Fans from Playoff Seats
text: It is a nasty fact of life for both the Devils and Islanders: when they play home games against the Rangers, a huge swath of the seats are occupied by an occupying army of Rangers fans. And while it’s a financial boon to those teams to have more seats filled, it’s also sort of a slap in the face. And the Devils are trying to do something about that for Games 3 and 4 of the Eastern Conference finals, which will be played in the Prudential Center.

headline: Carlos Fuentes, Mexican Man of Letters, Dies at 83
text: Carlos Fuentes, Mexico’s elegant public intellectual and grand man of letters, whose panoramic novels captured the complicated essence of his country’s history for readers around the world, died on Tuesday in Mexico City. He was 83.

headline: Novel Graphics
text: The artwork of Bob Kessel demands a second look. His prints — squares or diamonds measuring 3 feet by 3 feet — can sometimes seem simply like colorful geometric shapes, but sharp-eyed comic book fans will recognize some of their favorite heroes within. More than 20 of these pieces will be on display in “Artworks Assemble! A Superhero Inspired Fine Art Exhibit,” which will be shown for one day only on Thursday at the Museum of Comic and Cartoon Art. The prints will be for sale and are priced from $1,500 to $5,000.

headline: Navigating Walls, Bridges and Border Crossings in Queens
text: “American Jornalero” is the feel-good racist vigilante story of the year.

headline: After Coty Bid Dies, Avon Faces Hard Slog
text: Was Avon Products  wise to pass up on Coty’s takeover bid?

headline: In Iowa, Romney Warns of a ‘Prairie Fire of Debt’
text: DES MOINES — Mitt Romney delivered a sweeping call for government austerity here on Monday, comparing the growth of federal spending and debt under President Obama to a fast-moving fire that threatens to engulf America’s families.

headline: Ignoring Red Flags at JPMorgan
text: May 15, 2012 - New information shows that some executives saw warning signs of large-scale losses at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Juice Mixes to Renew Your Palate
text: THE tall woman working the juice bar at Miss Lily’s Bake Shop & Melvin’s Juice Box was a lissome testimonial to what a cup of freshly juiced kale, apple, lemon, ginger and celery ($9.50) will do to a person. That complexion, that muscle tone, that easy smile: I’ll have what she’s having.

headline: J. C. Penney Posts Big Loss as 3 Retailers Gain
text: While retailers including Home Depot, Saks Fifth Avenue and TJX Companies reported solid profits on Tuesday, J. C. Penney, in the midst of an ambitious turnaround plan, posted a big loss and said its quarterly sales had dropped 20 percent.

headline: James Murdoch Is One of the Crowd at Fox’s Upfront Party
text: Spotted at the Fox upfront party Monday night: the recent television star (on British screens), James Murdoch.

headline: Twitter and the Games
text: DALLAS–Could the London 2012 Games be the Twitter Olympics?

headline: U.S. Has Its First Female Olympic Boxer
text: Marlen Esparza became the first American female boxer to qualify for the London Olympics, while the chances for the two United States fighters in the other weight classes, Quanitta Underwood and Claressa Shields, have been left hanging by a thread.

headline: New York Leads on E.V. Issues, but E.V.’s Have Yet to Follow
text: A new study places New York among the world’s most proactive cities trying to ease the way of electric vehicles, but leadership has its pitfalls.

headline: A Comfortable View to a Thrill
text: UNTIL I ate the vitello tonnato at Perla, I’d never thought of it as a dish to get a carnivore’s pulse racing. The veal is often too thin, too gray, too much a blank canvas for the mayonnaise and tuna.

headline: Former Commander of U.S. Nuclear Forces Calls for Large Cut in Warheads
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. James E. Cartwright, the retired vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and a former commander of the United States’ nuclear forces, is adding his voice to those who are calling for a drastic reduction in the number of nuclear warheads below the levels set by agreements with Russia.

headline: Perla
text: Like Minetta Tavern across the street, a new Italian restaurant deploys red banquettes and mirrors and lighting in a way that suggests it has been around for decades.

headline: U.S. Names Partial Roster
text: United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann on Tuesday announced a preliminary 16-man roster for a training camp at the ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex in Orlando, Fla.

headline: White House Releases Financial Disclosure Reports for Obama
text: President Obama remains a millionaire with assets that could reach around $8 million, thanks to proceeds from his two best-selling books and investments made possible by them, according to financial disclosure forms made public by the White House on Tuesday.

headline: Three Dishes at Perla
text: Before opening Perla in March, Michael Toscano spent years in Mario Batali’s kingdom, first as sous chef at Babbo and most recently as chef at Manzo. Like his old boss, Mr. Toscano has a red-blooded, generous approach to seasonal Italian cooking. I spoke with him on the phone about three dishes that illustrate what he and Perla do best.

headline: Hackers Breach Sites of Foreign Policy and Human Rights Groups
text: In recent weeks, hackers have breached Web sites belonging to several foreign policy and human rights groups, including Amnesty International and the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism, a nonprofit organization based in Israel that researches terrorism issues.

headline: Microscopic Neighbors, Evolving Together
text: It seems obvious that how different living things in a community or ecological system bump up against one another would affect how they evolve. That would include everything from the mix of fish in a lake to the bacteria, fungi and insects that coexist in rainwater that pools in the roots at the base of a beech tree.

headline: Goal: A Cheap, Reliable Used Car With No Monthly Payments
text: You’ve just graduated from college. If you’re lucky enough to find a job, you’ll probably need a reliable ride to get you to work.

headline: Soda Makers Scramble to Fill Void as Sales Drop
text: In much the same way their ancestors on the prairie had to check their guns at the door of the saloon, the 320 students in the Faulkton Area School District in tiny Faulkton, S.D., will be required to dispose of all carbonated soda containers before stepping into school buildings.

headline: Readers Ask: At Segregated Brooklyn School, Is It Race or Class?
text: Hundreds of readers responded to a New York Times article on Sunday about a charter school in Brooklyn that is representative of the many de facto segregated public schools in New York City. They raised issues of class, condemned a climate that is hostile to achievement and questioned whether more black teachers at the school would resolve the problems.

headline: Millesime Offers 1904 Prices for a Day
text: They are celebrating a doorway on Thursday at Millesime, the seafood brasserie of Laurent Manrique (above) in the Carlton Hotel, and hundreds of hungry bargain hunters will benefit. Until now, the entrance to the restaurant was on a corner, leading downstairs, through a cafe, then up a flight. Now, the original main entrance to the building, erected in 1904 as the Seville Hotel, has been reopened and leads directly to the restaurant. For the day, there will be a special three-course menu: an oyster (singular) Rockefeller, a choice of chicken Marengo or lamb stew with mint sauce, and an ice cream sundae, all at the 1904 price of $1.25, not including tax and tip. Soft drinks, coffee and tea will be 25 cents. No reservations will be taken; seating will be first come first served.

headline: Curious Berries to Tide You Over
text: The timing is not ideal: Just as the year’s first local strawberries are making their debut in the Greenmarket, some stores are selling weird but succulently flavorful new imported berries. But until the local fruit peak in taste over the next month or so, you might be tempted by these pricey curiosities.

headline: Whitworth’s Relational Takes Stake in Pepsi
text: Relational Investors, the activist hedge fund run by Ralph V. Whitworth, disclosed on Tuesday that it had taken a small stake in PepsiCo worth about $609 million.

headline: China Flexes Its Regulatory Muscle, Catching Google in Its Grip
text: In today’s globalized world, you can’t avoid China, or so goes the cliché. Google is discovering that it’s actually true.

headline: Reader of Clues in Oldest Bones
text: Maybe it’s unintentional, but “Bones of Turkana,” a look at the life and work of Richard Leakey, feels a bit defensive, as if Creationists had just made viewers a sales pitch. “Don’t listen to them,” it seems to say. “Evolution is still the way to go and is every bit as beautiful as the biblical story.”

headline: Rappers Do Not Delight in Morocco and Iran
text: As my colleague Thomas Erdbrink reported, an Iranian rapper living in Germany recently ran afoul of a leading cleric back home because of a song deemed heretical. The ayatollah’s fatwa in turn led an Islamist Web site to offer a $100,000 bounty for his killing.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Inside Anonymous and Inside Flickr
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. See more here.

headline: Real Designs for Fake Buildings Are Going to Venice
text: Last summer, the magazine published an article about the fund-raising site Kickstarter. It was by Rob Walker, a contributing writer, and started like this:

headline: Robertson Goes Down, So Soriano Steps Up
text: BALTIMORE — Attrition continues to chip away at the Yankees’ bullpen, as a second closer in less than two weeks has been sidelined by an injury.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: No longer known as generics, store lines are becoming increasingly sophisticated.

headline: For Sale: The Practice Piano That Made Van Cliburn Perfect
text: Van Cliburn was reminiscing about No. 157754.

headline: Judge Allows Class-Action Lawsuit on E-Book Pricing to Go Ahead
text: A federal judge on Tuesday denied Apple and several major book publishers’ motions to dismiss a class-action lawsuit that accuses the companies of conspiring to control the price of e-books.

headline: Clip: Mitt Romney in Des Moines
text: Mitt Romney spoke at a campaign event in Des Moines, Iowa.

headline: Democrats' Chairman Quits, and Cuomo Will Choose a Successor
text: ALBANY — The chairman of the New York Democratic Party said Tuesday that he would resign next week, clearing the way for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to install his own leader atop the state organization.

headline: Swimming in a Sea of Stories
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Seat belts should be installed, at least temporarily, in the Berlind Theater here, where the new John Guare play, “Are You There, McPhee?,” is clattering and careering across the stage in a premiere production directed by Sam Buntrock. Whiplash is inevitable after viewing this intermittently exhilarating, more often exasperating, comic fantasy about the terrors of childhood, the confusions of adulthood, the long reach of art into the lives of common folk, murder, screenwriting, the game-changing movie “Jaws” and ... wait, I’m getting dizzy.

headline: Visiting Artists | Geoffrey Hendricks
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Senate Approves Extension of Export-Import Bank
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved legislation on Tuesday to extend the life of the Export-Import Bank by three years, sending to President Obama a measure that had been waylaid for months by small-government conservatives seeking to kill off an agency they denounced as a boondoggle.

headline: How Older Workers Weather Layoffs
text: While the recession and its aftermath have been particularly rough on the youngest workers, the oldest workers may end up suffering the longest.

headline: A Band Battles Ticketmaster on Sales Fees
text: One Friday afternoon recently, about 50 fans and friends of the band String Cheese Incident took $20,000 in cash to the Greek Theater in Los Angeles to take a small stand against the system — in this case, Ticketmaster.

headline: To France and China, in Search of Adventure
text: For me and undoubtedly others who remember the work of the conductor Kenneth Schermerhorn, his spirit hovered over the last two concerts of the Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall on Friday and Saturday as an almost palpable presence.

headline: Drinking Less Soda
text: In recent years, Americans have been trading soda consumption for bottled water and other beverages.

headline: The Pleasure of Performing Composers
text: The closing program of the much-too-short Look & Listen Festival at the Pratt Manhattan Gallery on Monday evening focused mostly on composers who also perform and performers who compose. Until the early decades of the 20th century, it was the norm for musicians to do both, if not necessarily with equal success. The revival of this tradition is a salutary development, and a pleasant surprise in this age of specialization.

headline: Having It All: Daughter, Career, Mother’s Day Concert
text: At her Alice Tully Hall recital on Sunday afternoon — Mother’s Day — the soprano Christine Brewer naturally performed “For the Color of My Mother,” a song written for her in 2008 by Alan L. Smith. The text is a poem by Ms. Brewer’s daughter, Elisabeth.

headline: Dark, Darwinian Struggles in the Jungle That Is Moscow
text: Post-Soviet Russia in Andrei Zvyagintsev’s somber, gripping film “Elena” is a moral vacuum where money rules, the haves are contemptuous of the have-nots, and class resentment simmers. The movie, which shuttles between the center of Moscow and its outskirts, is grim enough to suggest that even if you were rich, you wouldn’t want to live there.

headline: A Broadway Stop for ‘Bring It On’
text: Broadway producers rarely open shows in summertime, when tourist-dominated audiences are biggest for long-running hits, but a new musical-comedy is moving into the St. James Theater in July: “Bring It On,” a spinoff on the battle-of-the-cheerleaders movie from 2000 starring Kirsten Dunst. The show will start previews on July 12, direct from a 13-city national tour — a rare example of a production that played in Los Angeles, Houston, Chicago and Toronto before coming to New York, where musicals usually begin before going on the road. The show was created by several Tony Award-winning artists: the music is by Tom Kitt (“Next to Normal”) and Lin-Manuel Miranda (“In the Heights”), with lyrics by Mr. Miranda and Amanda Green and a book by Jeff Whitty (“Avenue Q”). Andy Blankenbuehler, who won a Tony for choreography for “In the Heights,” is the director and choreographer. The production, which has a different plot and characters from the movie but still turns on a cheerleading competition, will include the tour’s entire cast, which includes real-life cheerleaders in some of the high-flying acrobatic sequences. The musical is scheduled for a limited engagement on Broadway, opening on Aug. 1 and closing on Oct. 7.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Benefits

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Up Where the Air Is Rare
text: LAST summer, outdoor beer gardens proliferated. This year, New Yorkers who love eating al fresco will find more intimate settings on rooftops and upstairs decks, some featuring high-end multicourse dinners — a gracious alternative to sidewalk seating, and with better views. Here’s a sampling:

headline: On Opening Night, Stepping Back to the Old Favorites
text: Does anyone at American Ballet Theater conceive of ballet as an art free of the manipulation of women by men, and of the clichéd pyrotechnics of repeated turns and jumps? It was hard to think so at its depressing opening gala on Monday.

headline: A Tempting Rationale for Leaving the Euro
text: Some two decades ago, when Europe’s leaders worked out the details of their grand vision to connect the European Union with a single currency, virtually every economist on this side of the Atlantic — and most of those on the other — figured out that the euro would be fatally flawed.

headline: Univision Takes a Few Shots at NBC in Seeking Advertisers’ Dollars
text: It’s not often that buttoned-up executives dance on stage in front of hundreds of their peers, but this is upfront week and networks are doing everything they can to make sure the ad dollars flow their way.

headline: New Delay in Opening African Art Museum
text: For the fifth time in three years, the Museum for African Art has been forced to delay opening its new home at 110th Street and Fifth Avenue, in East Harlem, as it continues to work to raise the money to finish the project.

headline: U.S. Men’s Basketball Requests More Time to Finalize Roster
text: USA Basketball announced Tuesday an extension to finalize its men’s national team roster by July 7 for the London Games, which begin later in July and conclude in August. The deadline extension, granted by the United States Olympic Committee, resulted from necessity, as the roster as of late seems to need an N.F.L.-style injury report.

headline: Western Support for Repression in Bahrain Stretches Back Decades
text: Activists and pundits accused the United States of hypocrisy last week for resuming arms sales to Bahrain, despite a continuing crackdown on dissent there, even as the State Department condemned Russia for selling arms to the Syrian government.

headline: Slave Graves, Somewhere, Complicate a Walmart’s Path
text: FLORENCE, Ala. — Dianne O’Neal still lives on the rustic cattle farm that her husband’s family has owned since his great-great-great-grandfather purchased the land in the 1830s. She still stays in a log cabin built from chestnut trees that his ancestors chopped by hand.

headline: Send an E-Mail to the World, and Other Student Projects
text: If you could send an e-mail to a million people, what would it say? One day you might have your chance thanks to The Listserve, one of many projects on display this week from the Interactive Telecommunications Program at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.

headline: ‘Bring It On’ Is Coming to Broadway This Summer
text: Broadway producers rarely open new shows in summertime, when tourist-dominated audiences in New York are biggest for long-running hits, but a new musical comedy is moving into the St. James Theater in July: “Bring It On,” a takeoff on the battle-of-the-cheerleaders movie from 2000 starring Kirsten Dunst. The show will start previews on July 12, direct from a 13-city national tour — a rare example of a production that played in Los Angeles, Houston, Chicago and Toronto before coming to New York, where musicals usually begin before going out on the road.

headline: Liberty Media Increases Its Stake in Live Nation
text: Liberty Media, the conglomerate controlled by John C. Malone, has increased its investment in Live Nation Entertainment, the concert and ticketing giant that includes Ticketmaster.

headline: The Day Carlos Fuentes Took to Twitter
text: For one day, March 19, 2011, Carlos Fuentes, it seems, tweeted. Mr. Fuentes, who died Tuesday at age 83, in total made 21 posts to Twitter that day, all but one in Spanish.

headline: Fatal Bomb Attack in Bogotá
text: AYACUCHO, Peru — At least two people were killed and dozens injured in a bomb attack on Tuesday in Bogotá, the Colombian capital, that officials said was an assassination attempt aimed at a former government minister.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,956 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Consumers Less Happy With BlackBerrys
text: OTTAWA — A survey of customer satisfaction released on Tuesday underscored the importance of a new line of BlackBerry phones for reversing the fortunes of the beleaguered Research In Motion.

headline: White House Appends Obama Policies to Online Presidential Biographies
text: Footnotes added to presidential biographies on the White House Web site that connect past presidents’ achievements to President Obama’s initiatives incited controversy Tuesday in conservative circles online over how far the Obama administration would go to promote its policies.

headline: Old Planes Attract New Interest From Investors
text: MARANA, Ariz. — On a sprawling piece of land here northwest of Tucson, 120 airliners bask in the Arizona sun like retirees — which many of them are, living out their days after decades of ferrying passengers around the world.

headline: Mall at an Ideal Crossroads Gets a Makeover
text: YONKERS — There is perhaps no better location for a business than the intersection of the New York State Thruway and the Cross County Parkway in Westchester County, where nearly a quarter of a million cars pass through each day.

headline: Adam Ginsburg
text: Mr. Ginsburg, 46, is a co-chairman of GDC Properties, which specializes in retail and residential development. The company was founded in 1994 by his father, Samuel Ginsburg. GDC Properties is based in Hawthorne, N.Y.

headline: A Murder Trial in Sweden, With Echoes of Norway
text: MALMO, Sweden — With echoes of the massacre reverberating from neighboring Norway, a trial has started here of a man charged with killing three people and the attempted murder of 12 others in a string of shootings that mostly targeted people with immigrant backgrounds.

headline: Jay Jacobs’s Resignation Letter to the Governor
text: In a letter to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, Jay S. Jacobs, the head of the New York State Democratic Party, resigned months before his term expired.

headline: Heard on a Drug Wiretap
text: The criminal complaint against Officer Devon Daniels by an agent of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration.

headline: Battery Maker Hires Adviser to Explore Its Alternatives
text: A123 Systems, a maker of lithium-ion batteries for electric cars, hired an adviser to evaluate strategic alternatives for the company, its chief executive said Tuesday, setting off a 5.4 percent gain in its share price.

headline: From Boilers to Dartmouth: ‘I Got Lucky’
text: Chris Navas needed a course that met at the right time in the evening and would not interfere with his day job, which was building boilers, or his daily obsession, which was building his body. That was a little over three years ago. He was making good money at a factory in Maspeth, Queens, forming new boilers from sheet steel as if it were clay, rolling it, shaping it, cutting it. He visited the gym fervently. His class work at Queens College was fitted into patches of time around boilers and barbells.

headline: USA Basketball Receives Extension
text: USA Basketball has been granted an extension to July 7 from June 18 to set its men’s roster for the London Games. The Americans’ 20-player pool has been reduced to 16 healthy bodies in recent weeks, with the potential starters Dwight Howard (herniated disc) and Derrick Rose (torn anterior cruciate ligament) joining the roster hopefuls LaMarcus Aldridge (labral tear) and Chauncey Billups (torn Achilles) on the injury report.

headline: Sued Over Death and Injury From Trees, City Fights Back
text: Lawsuits against New York over deaths and injuries caused by falling tree limbs open a window on the often combative way the city responds to injury claims. Investigators engaged in surveillance of a severely injured victim; the city claimed a grandmother had not suffered after her skull was cracked by a tree limb; and in one case, the parks department destroyed most of a decayed tree that might have been used as evidence.

headline: As One JPMorgan Trader Sold Risky Contracts, Another One Bought Them
text: For hedge funds that could smell blood in the water, it seemed to be an opportunity to take on JPMorgan Chase and win.

headline: Police Agree to Stress Rules on Searching Livery Riders
text: The New York Police Department has agreed to inform all officers of, and train new recruits in, the rules under which they may order livery passengers out of cabs, detain and search them.

headline: Iowa, Again, Serves as Proving Ground for Romney
text: DES MOINES — As he campaigned in Iowa on Tuesday, Mitt Romney used a “prairie fire” metaphor to describe the nation’s debt and its impact on the sagging economic fortunes of many Americans.

headline: More Pitches Accent the Spanish
text: ALTHOUGH the word “upfront” is English rather than Spanish, the broadcast networks and cable channels that aim programming at Hispanic viewers are again increasing their presence during the annual television upfront week.

headline: We Could Be Heroes
text: A few weeks ago, in “The Ethicist,” Ariel Kaminer asked readers of this paper’s Magazine to explain why it’s ethical to eat meat. The contest generated around 3,000 submissions, and as a judge I read about 30 of them. (Here are the responses from the winner and the finalists.)

headline: A Dam Clouds The Future of Peru’s Indigenous People
text: On the eastern slopes of the Andes in Peru, home mainly to indigenous peoples like the Ashaninka, the government wants to dam the Ene River and sell most of the hydroelectric power to Brazil.

headline: F.B.I. Inquiry Adds to JPMorgan’s Woes
text: Investors and federal investigators turned up the heat on JPMorgan Chase on Tuesday, as shareholders called for pay givebacks from executives responsible for a stunning $2 billion trading loss and the Federal Bureau of Investigation opened a preliminary review of the debacle.

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., G.M. to Quit Advertising on Facebook
text: Just days before Facebook is scheduled to hold its first public stock offering, which could value the company at more than $100 billion, one of the country’s largest marketers has decided to remove its advertising from the social network.

headline: Dam Project Threatens a Way of Life in Peru
text: BOCA SANIBENI, Peru — Along the murky waters of the Ene River, in a remote jungle valley on the verdant eastern slopes of the Andes, the rhythmic humming of an outboard motor draws the stares of curious Ashaninka children.

headline: Republicans Pledge New Standoff on Debt Limit
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner on Tuesday set the stage for a bruising election-year showdown on fiscal policy, vowing to hold up another increase in the federal debt ceiling unless it was offset by larger spending cuts.

headline: When Competitive Bidding Hurts Patients
text: LAST month, the Obama administration announced that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services would make much greater use of competitive bidding to buy medical equipment for Medicare patients. Because of Medicare’s size and position in the health care market, it is likely that this policy will be quickly adopted by Medicaid and private insurers.

headline: Aaron Sorkin Signs On as Screenwriter for Steve Jobs Biography
text: Mr. Sorkin said last year that he was inclined to adapt Walter Isaacson’s biography of Steve Jobs for Sony. But no deal had been set until now.

headline: Nuns on the Frontier
text: Fernandina Beach, Fla.

headline: A Routine Execution in Texas
text: Carlos DeLuna, who was executed in 1989 by the state of Texas, was almost certainly wrongly convicted of stabbing a young woman to death with a knife in a gas station robbery in Corpus Christi. Carlos Hernandez, who died in a Texas prison while serving time for stabbing someone else, almost certainly killed the young woman and repeatedly told others that he had committed the murder.

headline: Contractor Is Accused of Stealing $1.2 Million From Hedge Fund by Inflating Costs
text: Alex Getelman was still in his 20s when he turned his nascent company into what he called “New York City’s fastest-growing general contracting and construction management firm.” He had a list of blue-chip clients, a plush office on 57th Street and a luxurious home on Long Island’s North Shore.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Art of Scissors and Paper
text: A Chinese artist creates intricate portraits of subway riders.

headline: Making Faces in the Subway, Using Paper and Scissors
text: At the foot of a Union Square subway platform staircase, an artist focused on his delicate work, maneuvering a fold of black origami paper along half-open scissor blades.

headline: Numb to Carnage, Mexicans Find Diversions, and Life Goes On
text: CADEREYTA JIMÉNEZ, Mexico — Couples were walking hand in hand. Children were frolicking. Just down the road in this northern Mexican town, 49 bodies, headless with their hands and feet severed, had been found, then cleared away.

headline: Hamilton Tries to Quiet Talk of a Triple Crown
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Go ahead, crunch the numbers, project to season’s end the 18 home runs Josh Hamilton has and see where in baseball history they land. Throw in his 45 runs batted in and .402 batting average, and let talk of winning the triple crown begin.

headline: Come the Revolution
text: Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Needy States Use Housing Aid Cash to Plug Budgets
text: Hundreds of millions of dollars meant to provide a little relief to the nation’s struggling homeowners is being diverted to plug state budget gaps.

headline: Dancing With Derivatives
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Stranger Than Fiction
text: The purpose of this appreciative editorial about Mike McGrady is not to entice you to buy or read “Naked Came the Stranger,” the dirty 1969 best seller that was destined to be in the first line of Mr. McGrady’s obituary ever since he wrote it — with a couple of dozen other Newsday journalists — and got it published. It’s not a good book. For parodic thrills, you may be better off with “Naked Came the Manatee,” by Carl Hiaasen and Dave Barry, among others. Same idea, but a lot cheaper on Amazon.

headline: Alabama’s Disgrace
text: Alabamians should see on Wednesday, the last day of the legislative session, just how badly the Republicans who control the Statehouse want to continue down the path of anti-immigrant extremism.

headline: Mr. Boehner and the Debt
text: It clearly does not bother Speaker John Boehner that he pushed the United States to the brink of default last year. It does not matter that the deep spending cuts in the resolution he demanded to end that crisis will hurt economic growth. It does not even matter that the House he leads is determined now to break that agreement with even deeper cuts in vital programs.

headline: Lakers Suffer for Westbrook’s Newfound Maturity
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — He emerged from the locker room wearing gray slacks and a tightly fitted white Lacoste polo shirt plastered with multicolored fishing lures, a nerdy hipster-meets-business casual look that Russell Westbrook claimed as his own.

headline: Afghan Soldiers Increasingly Attack American Counterparts
text: The rise in “green on blue” killings — Afghan forces turning on their American trainers — has threatened the goal of leaving Afghanistan in the hands of a stable security force.

headline: I’ll Second That
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes it’s tough to solve all of the crossword puzzles day after day, week after week.

headline: As Trained Afghans Turn Enemy, a U.S.-Led Imperative Is in Peril
text: COMBAT OUTPOST SANGESAR, Afghanistan — A burst of gunfire snapped First Sgt. Joseph Hissong awake. Then came another, and another, all with the familiar three-round bursts of an American assault rifle — and the unfamiliar sound of its rounds being fired in his direction.

headline: The Mortgage Settlement and the States
text: Federal and state officials reached a $25 billion settlement with five big banks in February over abuses in their mortgage and foreclosure processes. A report from Enterprise Community Partners, a national affordable housing group, has found that many states are diverting the money to other purposes.

headline: Yemen Moves to Recapture Towns Controlled by Islamist Insurgents
text: WASHINGTON — The Yemeni government on Monday and Tuesday stepped up a campaign to recapture southern towns from Islamist insurgents, unleashing airstrikes and ground assaults that left dozens of people dead, including some civilians, according to officials and witnesses on the ground.

headline: Rediscovering a Shortcut to an Hourglass Figure
text: Blanca Murillo’s morning routine, for the most part, would seem unremarkable to any woman: she washes her face, brushes her teeth, runs a comb through her hair and daubs on makeup. Then, as she has for the past seven years, she tugs on her girdle.

headline: How Should Obama Appeal to the Disenchanted?
text: What can the president do to energize those groups who have supported him but are less enthusiastic, as well as those who were always skeptical of him?

headline: A Russian Magnate’s Facebook Bet Pays Off Big
text: MOSCOW — With his droopy eyeglasses and boxy suits, Alisher B. Usmanov is at no risk of being mistaken for a Silicon Valley venture capitalist. But the Russian steel tycoon is poised to make billions of dollars from the initial public stock offering of Facebook this week — in the same league as many of that social networking company’s early backers.

headline: Bush Dips a Toe Back Into Washington
text: WASHINGTON — In the three years since he left office, former President George W. Bush has largely stayed out of the political arena. He has spent his time mapping out his library, making speeches, hosting injured veterans for Texas bicycle rides and making clear how glad he is to be out of the nation’s capital.

headline: Edwards Defense Presents Witnesses Aimed at Discrediting His Accuser
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — A defense witness for John Edwards testified on Tuesday that the aide who helped Mr. Edwards hide an affair and the child it produced spent more of the cover-up money on his own family than on Mr. Edwards’s mistress, Rielle Hunter.

headline: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Brian Leetch
text: During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. In the second period of Game 7, Brian Leetch gave the Rangers a 1-0 lead that looked like it would hold up and get them to the Stanley Cup finals — but it didn’t. Leetch, who went on that year to become the first American to win the Conn Smythe Trophy, looks back on the biggest moments in that series.

headline: Hit Batter Provides the Highlight on a Dreary Night
text: The Mets’ bats looked soggy Tuesday night against the Brewers’ ace, Zack Greinke, who held the offense down inning after inning. Then tempers flared around one at-bat that never took place.

headline: Popular Priest Fathered Child and Says He’ll Step Aside
text: A telegenic American priest, widely known for his media commentary from Rome on popes, prayer and personal morality, has publicly acknowledged having an affair and fathering a child — the latest jolt to hit his scandal-torn religious order, the Legionaries of Christ.

headline: Yankees Go Quietly on Way Out of Town
text: BALTIMORE — The latest in a series of closers for the Yankees was eager and ready to take the ball in the ninth inning if asked Tuesday. Attrition has chipped away at the Yankees’ bullpen, and with Dave Robertson the latest to sustain an injury, Rafael Soriano moved up another rung to temporarily assume the title of closer.

headline: First Lady Without a Portfolio (or a Ring) Seeks Her Own Path
text: PARIS — Valérie Trierweiler faces an uncommon predicament.

headline: Mayor Told to Testify in Lottery Suit in the Capital
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge has ordered Mayor Vincent C. Gray to answer questions about the firing of the city’s top contracting officer, which is at the heart of a lawsuit alleging that elected officials meddled in a disputed lottery contracting process.

headline: South Korea: Myanmar Pledges To Stop Buying North’s Weapons
text: South Korea has received assurances from Myanmar that it will no longer buy weapons from North Korea, an aide to President Lee Myung-bak said Tuesday. President Thein Sein of Myanmar acknowledged that his country had bought conventional weapons from the North over the past 20 years but vowed in a meeting with Mr. Lee in the Burmese capital on Monday to end the practice, said the aide, Kim Tae-hyo. Mr. Thein Sein also indicated Tuesday that Myanmar had not pursued the development of nuclear arms and vowed to honor a United Nations Security Council resolution that bans countries from activities that could assist North Korea’s missile programs, Mr. Kim said.

headline: A Father’s Example Guides Tebow
text: LAMSUGOD, the Philippines — The last time Tim Tebow visited his father’s orphanage here in the remote hills of Mindanao island, he stood at the edge of a grassy yard and told the children to make a loop with their arms. Then, to their amazement, he threw a football right through them.

headline: The Horse That Ran Second Is in the Front of Everyone’s Mind
text: BALTIMORE — Horsemen have many ways of evaluating a thoroughbred’s energy levels after a demanding race. Feel their legs for heat. Check on the way they eat.

headline: As Clemens Trial Drags, Jury Keeps Dozing
text: WASHINGTON — In the five days it took lawyers to select the jury for Roger Clemens’s federal perjury trial, potential jurors were confronted with more than 100 questions.

headline: Devils Plot a Way to Make More Shots Count
text: NEWARK — There are probably better people to ask about the perils of shot-blocking than Martin Brodeur. He has done that for a living for 20 years, but rugged, take-one-for-the-team defenses have helped him win three Stanley Cups with the Devils.

headline: Harold A. Poling, 86, a Chairman of Ford, Dies
text: Harold A. Poling, the son of an auto mechanic who helped guide the Ford Motor Company through the recession of the early 1990s as its chairman and chief executive, died on Saturday in Pacific Grove, Calif. He was 86.

headline: The Third Party Fantasy
text: “Third parties are like bees,” the intellectual historian Richard Hofstadter wrote in 1955. “Once they have stung, they die.” It’s an aphorism that aptly describes the anti-slavery and anti-immigrant parties of the mid-nineteenth century, the Populists and Progressives who ushered out the Gilded Age, as well as more recent third-party standard bearers, from George Wallace to Ross Perot. All of these movements and figures influenced American politics dramatically, before fading away and leaving the basic two-party duopoly intact.

headline: Rangers Adopt Team-First Refrain Once Voiced in Tampa Bay
text: Perhaps no other N.H.L. team is as emphatic a personification of its coach’s philosophy as the Rangers.

headline: Saints’ Appeals in Bounty Case Focus on League Contract
text: The appeals for four Saints players who were suspended as part of the bounty scandal will begin Wednesday, not with an argument about whether the N.F.L. has enough evidence to prove a bounty system existed, but with a parsing of language in the collective bargaining agreement.

headline: Beckett Earns Reprieve With Seven Shutout Innings
text: BOSTON — There were no tee times Tuesday, and it was not one of Josh Beckett’s 18 days off. Beckett, the Boston Red Sox’s beleaguered pitcher, took the mound in Fenway Park for the first time since causing a firestorm in New England.

headline: Nebraska State Senator Upsets Rivals for G.O.P. Nomination
text: State Senator Deb Fischer of Nebraska surged past the state’s attorney general, Jon Bruning, on Tuesday to capture the Republican nomination for the closely watched contest for the Senate seat being vacated next year by Ben Nelson, a moderate Democrat.

headline: New York Racing Association Is Facing Loss of Payments
text: The administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo asked Tuesday that payments from the casino at Aqueduct racetrack to the New York Racing Association, which runs the track, be suspended immediately. It also said it was exploring revoking the association’s racing franchise.

headline: An Orphanage in the Philippines
text: At an orphanage founded by Bob Tebow, the children know of his son’s faith and his football.

headline: In Haiti, a New Stadium Will Rise
text: From the rubble, literally, of the earthquake that struck Haiti in January 2010, plans to build the first professional soccer stadium in the country are taking shape. The appropriately named Phoenix Stadium is set to rise in Cité Soleil, an area designated by the United Nations as a red zone — an impoverished town in desperate need of economic development.

headline: Cancer Survivors Who Stay Active Live Longer
text: Can going for a walk improve cancer survivors’ long-term prognosis? It may, according to new research showing that exercise can lower survivors’ risk of premature death, not only from cancer but from any cause. The findings are likely to resonate widely at a time when about 14 million Americans, and many more worldwide, have survived cancer.

headline: Word of the Day | philology
text: philology •\fə-ˈlä-lə-je also fi-\• noun

headline: Backer of Common Core School Curriculum Is Chosen to Lead College Board
text: David Coleman, an architect of the common core curriculum standards that are being adopted in nearly all 50 states, will become the president of the College Board, starting in October.

headline: K.K.R. Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy Stake in a Fund of Funds
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity giant, is in talks to buy a stake in a money manager that focuses on hedge funds, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: Germany and China: Too Close for Some
text: As global power shifts eastward, Germany and China are building a “special relationship” that risks undermining Europe’s overall position with the rising Asian giant and may have serious consequences for the balance of power between Europe and China, according to a hard-hitting new report from a European Union think tank.

headline: Indian Airlines Snub Europe’s Emissions Rule
text: Indian and Chinese airlines failed to submit carbon-dioxide emissions data for 2011, “disregarding European rules that seek to expand the region’s emissions trading system to include aviation,” Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Bangalore Start-up Promises Unbiased News, Cheaply
text: A long, winding staircase ends on the seventh floor of the Bangalore Metropolitan Transport Corp. building in Yashwantpur, Bangalore. At the entrance to Public TV, a new Kannada-language network, rows of green plants greet visitors. Like everything else at the TV station, the potted plants were purchased from an abandoned enterprise — in this case, a software firm.

headline: News Quiz | May 16, 2012

headline: Former Bosnian Serb General Hears Indictment, and Insults, as Trial Opens
text: THE HAGUE — Of all the men associated with the cruelties of the Bosnian war, none has been more roundly condemned by public opinion than Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb military commander who ran a deadly military campaign in the 1990s, of a kind not seen in Europe since World War II.

headline: May 16, 1977 | 5 Killed in Helicopter Accident on Top of Pan Am Building
text: On May 16, 1977, a rotor blade broke off a helicopter on the roof of Manhattan’s Pan Am Building after the copter’s landing gear failed, causing it to turn sideways. The blade killed five people.

text: In 1988, Eddie Adams gathered some of the best photographers in the business — along with 99 young, aspiring ones — at his upstate New York farm to “see what would happen.”

headline: In TV Race, Microsoft Has Lead, Forrester Says
text: When it comes to the underlying technology providers that matter for mobile app developers, there’s Google, Apple and everyone else. Microsoft is one of the companies trying to claw its way out of the everyone else category.

headline: When Is It O.K. to Replace Human Limbs With Technology?
text: Some amputees are taking advantage of prosthetic advances in a manner that would have previously been unimaginable: they are opting to have healthy parts of their bodies amputated to accommodate more sophisticated replacement limbs. Do you think this is ethical? If you had an injury like the ones described in the article, would you consider doing it? Where, in general, do you draw the line in terms of using science and technology to enhance human life? Why?

headline: What Remains of Treece
text: Remnants of a toxic town in Kansas.

headline: Last Ones Left in a Toxic Kansas Town
text: One problem with Treece, Kan., is that the ground keeps caving in. It has happened more than a hundred times over the last century. On most occasions, the subsidences — that’s what the scientists call them — are small, like when a sofa-size crater opened up on 10th Street last year. Other times, they are much worse. In 1966, a 300-foot-wide, 200-foot-deep abyss swallowed up the road out on the edge of town. Somehow no one died.

headline: An Online Guide to India’s Political Cartoons
text: If India’s parliamentarians, who were recently incensed by a 63-year-old cartoon, decide it is time to eradicate any political cartoons that might offend, where should they start? India Ink has put together a short compilation of potential targets, compiled for cartoon lovers and outraged politicians both.

headline: McGraw-Hill Announces E-Book Program With University of Minnesota
text: The textbook publisher McGraw-Hill Higher Education announced a pilot program with University of Minnesota bookstores last week that may eventually make early semester lines and sold-out core texts as obsolete as the diskette.
