headline: In Michigan, Aiming to Set the Fuel-Economy Bar at 3,300 M.P.G.
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — When a few engineering students here at the University of Michigan noticed that the 2012 SAE International Supermileage Challenge, scheduled for June 7 and 8, would be held an hour away from campus, they asked the obvious question: “Why aren’t we involved?”

headline: When a Spending Cut Can Be Like a Tax Increase
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Tip of the Week: Hotmail Keyboard Shortcuts
text: Microsoft Hotmail users who already have Yahoo Mail or Gmail accounts for collecting messages over the Web do not have to learn new keyboard shortcuts to speed up tasks like replying to or forwarding mail. Hotmail, it seems, is quite versatile.

headline: Bush and Clinton Team Up for 9/11 Memorial Fund-Raiser
text: The odd-bedfellows tandem of George W. Bush and Bill Clinton got together again Tuesday night to promote their latest shared post-presidential cause, a memorial to the heroes of United Flight 93.

headline: City and Unions Square Off Over Hiring at 24 Struggling Schools
text: City lawyers go to court on Wednesday to argue that attempts by the teachers' and principals' unions to slow down their hiring of new teachers for 24 schools that the Department of Education wants to revamp will have a significant impact on their ability to get the most-qualified candidates.

headline: Bronx Borough President Calls for Changes in Elite High School Admissions
text: In response to the low number of Bronx students who have been admitted to the city's elite public high schools in recent years, Borough President Rubin Diaz Jr. has recommended a change in the admissions process to place more weight on grade-point averages and essays, and less on a standardized exam. City officials said they had no plans to move away from a test-based admissions policy.

headline: The Power of Nursing
text: In 2010, 5.9 million children were reported as abused or neglected in the United States. If you were a policy maker and you knew of a program that could cut this figure in half, what would you do? What if you could reduce the number of babies or toddlers hospitalized for accidents or poisonings by more than half? Or provide a 5 to 7 point I.Q. boost to children born to the most vulnerable mothers?

headline: The High Cost of Bad Hiring
text: I was recently talking to a friend of mine who is struggling to find a production manager to run his small factory. The conversation brought back painful memories of my own struggles, many years ago, to find someone to oversee my factory.

headline: Obama Campaign Announces Raising $43.6 Million in April
text: President Obama and the Democrats raised $43.6 million in April, adding to the president’s edge over his rival, Mitt Romney, even as money continues to pour in to outside groups ahead of the fall campaign.

headline: Daily Report: A Russian Tycoon and His Soon-to-Be Facebook Fortune
text: In Wednesday’s New York Times, Andrew E. Kramer tells the story of Alisher B. Usmanov, a Russian steel tycoon who made an ambitious bet on Facebook in 2009, in the midst of the global recession. With a less than $900 million investment in Facebook through two Russian entities, Mr. Usmanov and his business associates stand to make more than $6 billion in Facebook’s initial public offering, based on the price range for the stock set by Facebook’s bankers.

headline: Lower Economic Growth Seen for Britain

headline: The Party Without the Lady
text: YANGON — If members of the National League for Democracy sit in Myanmar’s Parliament today, it’s thanks to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. Not only has she been the main opposition party’s leader, figurehead and inspiration since its creation in the aftermath of a bloody military crackdown in 1988. Last month, she was also instrumental in deciding that, after all, it wasn’t worth staying out of power for a relatively small matter of principle.

text: Good morning. It’s another rainy day, with highs in the low 80s. New York City spring is such a tease.

headline: Bosnia’s ‘Genocide Deniers’ Challenged

headline: Flight of Euros Accelerates, Adding to Greece’s Worries
text: ATHENS — As Greek political leaders assembled a caretaker government Wednesday to usher in new elections next month, bankers across Athens were monitoring a worrisome development: the continued flight of billions of euros from the country amid renewed concern over Greece’s fate within the euro currency union.

headline: Reviving the Barter System
text: Dear Diary: Last Friday, emerging from Trader Joe’s with two big shopping bags and an even bigger wish to be home, I file onto a M72 bus and then wait out a long exchange between the driver and a well-dressed woman whose senior MetroCard doesn’t seem to be working. Over the course of two light changes, the drama heats up.

text: HITTING the road this summer? Better get booking.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Rebekah Brooks Charged and Steve Jobs Reimagined
text: After multiple inquiries, innumerable investigations and dozens of arrests, police in England have finally made a formal charge in the hacking scandal that’s enveloped the country’s political and media elite. Rebekah Brooks, the former top editor at both News of the World and The Sun, was charged along with her husband and four other people of, in the charming English phrase, “conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.”

headline: CBS, Already Strong on Comedy, Will Add Three Dramas in Fall
text: 5:00 p.m. | Updated  CBS, the most-watched American television network, will add three dramas and one comedy to its schedule in the fall, it said Thursday morning in advance of its annual presentation to advertisers in New York.

headline: Russian Authorities Press Crackdown on Anti-Putin Protests

headline: Piramal Healthcare Continues Overseas Expansion With Decision Resources Deal
text: The Indian drug maker Piramal Healthcare said Tuesday that it will buy Decision Resources Group, a U.S. health care information provider, for $635 million. The acquisition is the latest in a string of overseas deals by the Indian company as it expands its research and development capabilities.

headline: A New Skirmish in the Ethanol Wars
text: The auto and oil industries plan to release a report on Wednesday indicating that some cars running on E15, the 15 percent ethanol blend that was recently authorized by the Environmental Protection Agency, experienced engine damage.

headline: Will You Be More Successful Than Your Parents?
text: If the American dream is doing better than your parents, only about half of recent college graduates think they will achieve it. They are even more pessimistic about the prospects for their peers, according to a new survey of recent graduates from the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University.

headline: New Walking Dead Event Calls for Brawn and Brains
text: It takes a very special kind of person to not only appreciate a narrative about apocalypse-by-zombie but also to actually want to take part in that apocalypse. And soon there will be an event for those fans that lets them play a role in the simulated downfall of civilization or, if they wish, contribute to it.

DiPaola Jr., a longtime photographer for The Baltimore Sun.

headline: Sweden — Sweden!!! — as Conservative Icon
text: I learn from Ezra Klein’s interview with Tom Coburn that Sweden, of all places, has become the new right-wing icon. I thought Europe’s woes were all about collapsing welfare states? But anyway, the story now is that Sweden has slashed spending and cut taxes, and is doing great; supply-side economics vindicated!

headline: 16 Retired Chinese Communist Party Officials Call for 2 Top Leaders to Step Down

headline: Collins’s Decision to Pull Wright: Wise or Weak?
text: It took something unusual to generate a conversation piece out of the Mets’ 8-0 drubbing by the Brewers Tuesday night, and Mets Manager Terry Collins provided it. After Mets pitcher D.J. Carrasco plunked Ryan Braun immediately following a Brewers home run, Collins figured David Wright would take one in the ribs during his next at-bat, which happened to be leading off the next inning, so he took him out of the lineup.

headline: The Heat Is Off
text: If we didn’t know any better, we would suspect Chris Bosh’s abdominal injury was somehow created by N.B.A. scriptwriters. Because until Bosh doubled over in pain, the Heat’s march to the N.B.A. finals was looking rather methodical. No one in the East seemed likely to snare more than a game or two from the Big Three. That meant fans had to stay up way past respectable bedtimes to catch the games with any drama, in the West. So you could imagine some league sorcerer — perhaps David Stern in a wizard cap — pulling out a Bosh voodoo doll and, voilà, instant turmoil.

headline: Could You Handle Being an Employee?

headline: In 2012, a Host Country With an Equestrian Tradition

headline: Obama Proposes New Tax Credit for Small Businesses That Hire
text: In a bid to retake the initiative on small-business policy, President Obama Wednesday is expected to propose a 10 percent tax credit tied to new hiring. But the policy appears designed as much to draw a political distinction as to generate new jobs. In describing the proposal, which Mr. Obama will flesh out in a visit to a Washington-area small business, the administration drew a sharp contrast with a Republican small-business tax cut that passed the House last month, which the White House contends is too tilted toward the wealthy.

headline: M.I.T. Chooses Its Provost for President

headline: Defense Rests in Edwards Trial Without Having Called Major Players to the Stand

headline: In Scrutiny of JPMorgan Loss, Bigger Questions Left Unanswered
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are looking into JPMorgan Chase’s trading debacle — and if you think anything is going to come of that, well, I’m pretty sure that JPMorgan has some derivatives it would love to sell you.

headline: Redefining ‘Crossover’ in Latin Pop
text: LOS ANGELES — The usual trappings of the arena rock concert were on full display at the Staples Center here on a recent evening. The lead singer professed his love for the capacity crowd. The adoring fans sang along with every lyric. The drummer tossed his drumsticks high above his head, jumping in and out of his chair to snatch them before returning to the beat and setting off even more declarations of devotion.

headline: Talbot-Lago and Concours-Winning Horch Are Standouts in RM’s Pebble Beach Catalog
text: Preparing for their annual sales around the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance in Monterey, Calif., it would seem auction houses have great expectations of the buying public.

headline: The Get | Zimmermann Rashguards for Shopbop.com
text: If you’re a girl, a cool rash guard is hard to find. Most are littered with logos or stamped with ubiquitous hibiscus flowers, or worse. Which might explain why the protective wet-suit-type tops haven’t had much success outside the surf scene — where they are a necessity — and on the sand, where they can be worn to effectively block the sun. “I’ve had friends who don’t surf asking to make them for ages,” explains Nicky Zimmermann of the Australian swimwear line Zimmermann. “The sun is so harsh in Sydney, so for summer we designed a one-off cropped mesh style and everyone really loved it.” Including Shopbop.com, which commissioned four “rashies” (Zimmermann’s word for them) for the site, on sale tomorrow. The swim shirts come in lively prints, ranging from leopard and chintz combos to allover birds of paradise, shown here. Made of Lycra and nylon, the guards look great and quite modern paired with bikini bottoms. Take that unsightly tan lines!

headline: College Board Selects Backer of Common Core School Curriculum as New President
text: The College Board has chosen David Coleman, an “often criticized” architect of the common core curriculum standards that are being adopted around the country, as its new president, our colleague Tamar Lewin reports.

headline: Ironclad Freedom
text: In an 1862 letter to his wife, Anna, William Keeler described the moment he saw a slave became a free man. It was late at night on May 16, and he was below decks on the Monitor, the Union ironclad then on duty off City Point in Virginia’s James River, 15 miles southeast of Richmond and 70 miles inside hostile territory.

headline: In Response to Complaints, Gehry Changes Design for Eisenhower Memorial
text: The architect Frank Gehry has refined his design for a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower on the Washington Mall in response to concerns from the Eisenhower family and historians that a youthful statue failed to represent the former president’s significant achievements.

headline: Plavix Set to Lose Patent Protection
text: For more than a decade, cardiologists treating patients who have had a heart attack have routinely scribbled one drug onto their prescription pads: clopidogrel bisulfate, better known as Plavix.

headline: No Gays Allowed (on the Virginia Courts)
text: In the dead of night on Monday, the Virginia House of Delegates scuttled the appointment of a highly qualified judicial nominee, Tracy Thorne-Begland, because he is gay. Even Gov. Robert F. McDonnell, a rock-ribbed conservative, found this display of intolerance a bit over the top.

headline: Brazil’s Leader Faces Defining Decision on Bill Relaxing Protection of Forests
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Dilma Rousseff is facing one of the defining moments of her presidency as pressure builds on her to veto a bill that would open vast protected areas of forests to ranching and farming, potentially reversing Brazil’s major gains in slowing Amazon deforestation.

headline: Presidential Ad Wars Kick Into Full Swing
text: The presidential advertising wars have begun in earnest, with the latest salvo —  a $25 million attack on President Obama by a Karl Rove-backed political group —  set to begin on Thursday.

headline: Playing Left, Right  — or Center
text: David Brooks: Gail, today I’m getting a big thrill. I get to be on the grass of center field at Yankee Stadium. This is hallowed ground because it’s where New York Mets center fielders play when they compete against the overblown team from the Bronx.

headline: With Three Postseason Goals, Rangers’ Kreider Ties Obscure Record
text: With his goal in Game 1 Monday, the Rangers rookie Chris Kreider tied an N.H.L. record for most playoff goals scored in a single postseason by a player who has not yet skated in a regular-season game.

headline: Paralyzed, Moving a Robot With Their Minds
text: Two people who are virtually paralyzed from the neck down have learned to manipulate a robotic arm with just their thoughts, using it to reach out and grab objects. One of them, a woman, was able to retrieve a bottle containing coffee and drink it from a straw — the first time she had served herself since her stroke 15 years earlier, scientists reported on Wednesday.

headline: When Good Things Happen to Bad Ideas
text: John Kay has a good piece about the damage done by the obsession with policy “credibility”. This is one of those ideas rooted in theoretical models that happened to mate perfectly with political prejudices, and hence became part of the orthodoxy almost immediately despite a lack of convincing evidence that it really does matter. (Moral hazard plays much the same role in health care discussion).

headline: ‘London Whale’ Said to Be Leaving JPMorgan
text: The $2 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase has claimed another victim.

headline: Lennon’s Killer Is Moved to Another Prison
text: After 30 years, John Lennon’s killer has a new home.

headline: He’s Just a ‘Custodian of the Moment’
text: THERE’S a scene early on in “Middle of Nowhere,” one of this year’s Sundance prize-winning films, when a young married couple bicker briefly in the visiting area of a prison: the room is pallid, even clammy, but the actors’ faces are vibrant and vulnerable, held full-frame. It’s a triumphant, even signature moment for the film’s cinematographer, Bradford Young.

headline: Study Says Sundance Is a Publicity Machine, to the Tune of $69 Million
text: The Sundance Film Festival attracted 46,000 people to the mountains outside Salt Lake City this January, a 2 percent increase over the prior year, according to an economic impact report released Wednesday.

headline: Little Drama Through 4 Draws in Chess Championship
text: After four games of the World Chess Championship match in Moscow, which began on Friday, Viswanathan Anand, the titleholder, and his challenger, Boris Gelfand, have been unable to make a dent in each other. All four games have been draws, and there has been little drama, as not one has lasted more than 40 moves. The game on Tuesday was 34 moves.

headline: TimesCast | May 16, 2012
text: Greece sets a date for new election amid euro exit fears. | Latino networks take center stage at television upfronts. | President Obama meets with Congressional leaders over the legislative agenda.

headline: DeBoer Shuffles Devils’ Lines to Try to Boost Offense
text: NEWARK — Devils Coach Peter DeBoer made sure to say after a morning skate Wednesday that he reserved the right to change his forward line combinations again, but it was likely that Zach Parise would rejoin Ilya Kovalchuk on the line centered by Travis Zajac for Game 2 of the Eastern Conference semifinals against the Rangers later in the day at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Dalglish Out at Liverpool
text: Liverpool fired Manager Kenny Dalglish on Wednesday, days after the club staggered to an eighth-place finish in the Premier League.

headline: A New Leica, Not in Living Color
text: If you like black-and-white photography and Leica cameras, and have around $8,000 to spare, you might be interested to know that the German optics maker has introduced the newest addition to its M line of cameras: the M Monochrom.

headline: For Tablets, an Accessory That Combines Two Functions
text: Tablets are easy to rest in your lap when you’re sitting, but they become awkward to grip if you’re standing or multitasking. I tend to hold my iPad by the flap of its cover, and I’ve noticed that the cover is starting to tear from the strain.

headline: What if the Mayor Had a Big Round Head With Red Stitches?
text: Top 10 reasons Mr. Met should be mayor — you can do better; let’s hear your reasons.

headline: Obama and House Republicans Offer Taste of Renewed Fight Over the Debt Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Congressional Republicans staged a preview of a looming end-of-year battle on Wednesday, as the president warned Republicans that he would not allow Congress to hold the economy “hostage” to another fight over whether to raise the country’s debt ceiling without accompanying cuts in spending.

headline: A Narrower Lead, but Big Changes Probably Aren’t the Cause
text: We are beginning to see more national surveys now, including this week’s New York Times/CBS News poll, that show Mitt Romney with a slight lead over President Obama in the general election matchup. There are also a number of polls that put Mr. Obama slightly ahead. But Mr. Obama’s lead does seem to have narrowed — from about three or four points in an average of national polls a month or two ago to more like a point or so in surveys today.

headline: Sony Puts a Phone Display on Your Wrist
text: You know how people who rudely check their phones every 42 seconds can drive you completely bonkers?

headline: Brain Ailments in Veterans Likened to Those in Athletes
text: Scientists who have studied a degenerative brain disease in athletes have found the same condition in combat veterans exposed to roadside bombs in Iraq and Afghanistan, concluding that such explosions injure the brain in ways strikingly similar to tackles and punches.

headline: Arms in the Air
text: For the travel issue’s T, the artist and photographer Adam Wallacavage turned his trademark — tentacled chandeliers — into the magazine’s. “It was a little bit harder than I thought it would be,” Wallacavage says. “My style can be dark and gloomy looking at times, but I wanted this to feel light and elegant and somewhat simple. The simple part was the hardest.” Here Wallacavage, whose work is on display at the Philadelphia Art Alliance in the installation “Shiny Monsters” through Aug. 19, talks to T about octopuses and why he’d never dream of eating one.

headline: N.H.L.’s Twitter Champ: The Kings
text: The Kings have a tough job getting attention in a Los Angeles market dominated by the N.B.A. Lakers and an up-and-coming Clippers Several years ago, the team began using its Web site more aggressively, hiring the longtime Kings beat writer Rich Hammond to write articles about the team and it has now added a vigorous social media effort.

headline: Defense Questions McNamee’s Honesty
text: WASHINGTON — Brian McNamee’s direct testimony early this week was four and a half years in the making and unfurled in pitch-perfect fashion with the familiar details of a hotel room in Toronto in 1998, drugs and a syringe laid out in a bathroom and the indomitable Roger Clemens ready for an unthinkable boost.

headline: Romney Campaign Tries to Block Reporters
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Romney campaign is renowned for its hyper-disciplined approach to the news media. Question-and-answer sessions with reporters are exceedingly rare. Aides avoid on-the-record briefings. And the candidate’s latest outreach to voters, a series of casual meetings with middle class Americans, is shielded from public view.

headline: Just Like Old Times
text: “HELLO and welcome to the 1920s,” two women dressed as flappers said to guests arriving at a neo-Georgian building on Park Avenue and 63rd Street on Monday night.

headline: Scene City: Literary Stars From the Past
text: Lapham’s Quarterly brings back the 1920s at a star-studded party.

headline: Hatched and Wild Salmon: A Bad Mix?
text: The pink and flaky salmon sitting on your dinner plate can be of three varieties: wild, farmed or hatched. As the name implies, wild salmon live and die by nature’s hand alone. Farmed salmon are bred, born and raised agriculturally. Hatched salmon, though, lie somewhere in between: they are hatched by humans and then freed as youngsters to spend the rest of their lives in the wild.

headline: Minutes Suggest the Fed Will Stay the Course on Policy
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is solidly entrenched in its current policies and there is little sign that a change is in the offing, according to an account the Fed published Wednesday of the most recent meeting of its policy-making committee.

headline: Thomas Keller and Andoni Aduriz Start a Food Fight
text: In an interview last week, two of the world’s top chefs, Thomas Keller and Andoni Aduriz, agreed that chefs should not have to carry the torch for local and sustainable agriculture. Or fight global warming. Here are a few posts from the firefight that has resulted on Twitter.

headline: Wimbledon White Will Be Out During Olympics
text: The dress code for the All England Club, the steeped-in-tradition home of the Wimbledon tennis tournament, is usually unwavering: wear white.

headline: Pulitzer Prize-Winning Play to Make New York Debut at Second Stage
text: Quiara Alegría Hudes’s play “Water by the Spoonful,” the winner of this year’s Pulitzer Prize for drama, has found a New York home. The play, about a Puerto Rican veteran of the Iraq war who faces personal demons when he returns to the United States, will be one of four mainstage productions in Second Stage’s 2012-13 season, the Off Broadway theater company announced on Wednesday. Davis McCallum will direct the play, which is to begin previews in mid-December and open in January.

headline: Military News Roundup: Green on Blue, a Call for a Nuclear Reduction and NATO’s Supply Line
text: There are a few interesting military-related pieces in the paper Wednesday. Here they are:

headline: A Twist in the Driving Debate
text: I picked up a lot of thought-provoking tidbits at the American Geriatrics Society’s annual scientific meeting in Seattle this month, and I plan to pass some of them along. Herewith, my first report, focusing on a perennial New Old Age conundrum: seniors and driving.

headline: Stone Links: Identity Check
text: If your brain were transplanted into an organ donor’s brainless body, would you be getting a new body, or would you be losing a brain? Eric Olson, a philosopher at the University of Sheffield interviewed at 3:AM Magazine, thinks you would be losing a brain (you would also be dead): what you are is not, ultimately, a psychologically continuous set of experiences — what might be sustained in the organ donor’s body — but an organism, a creature. You are just the animal you see in the mirror. Olson argues that if that isn’t how personal identity works, there would be 14 billion persons on the planet now, not 7:

headline: Art in Hong Kong? It Must Be May
text: If an art lover had to pick one month to visit Hong Kong, it would be May.

headline: Lessons from Afghanistan: Let’s Get Back to Real Foreign Reporting
text: Geneva, Switzerland–The Soviet occupation of Afghanistan during the late 1970s and 1980s was the last time western journalists had the luxury of reporting a conflict properly. I was a young foreign correspondent and this was my first war. Given the nature of Moscow’s involvement against a disparate force of guerrilla fighters, we had to trek clandestinely across high mountains and thrashing rivers, sometimes for weeks on end.

headline: Are the Spurs Invincible?
text: A combined 35 seasons and multiple championship rings among them, San Antonio’s “Big Three” has once again defied age and expectation in bringing their franchise – and their small-market city – into the basketball spotlight.

headline: Save the Date
text: Ready for the big event? I’d like to remind you tune into a live discussion of global events with me and Susan Rice, the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, and a selection of readers who raised their hands to participate. We’ll all be on camera, using Google+’s Hangouts on Air technology, on this blog, at nytimes.com and on Google+ at 2:30 p.m. EST on Thursday.

headline: Checking Your Social Security Benefits Online
text: The Social Security Administration is now making annual benefits statements available online.

headline: The Tricky Business of Taming the Beasts
text: An announcement about a paper coming out in the journal Nature mentions, in passing, that the silk moth is the only domesticated insect, but a little research raises somequestions: What about bees? Or pet tarantulas?

headline: Subway Musicians Audition
text: Musicians competed for a chance to play for commuters as part of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s “Music Under New York” program.

headline: When ‘Younger’ Skin Is Not a Blessing
text: GROWING up, Eileen Wolter, now 40 and a blogger about stay-at-home motherhood in Summit, N.J., was one of those rare teenagers without complexion concerns. “I had really good skin,” she said. “And I just used Ivory bar soap.”

headline: In a Slow Week Carrie Underwood Holds at No. 1
text: Carrie Underwood tops the Billboard album chart for a second time this week, but music sales were down all around.

headline: Greece Sets New Election Date
text: May 16, 2012 - Greek leaders schedule new elections in June, stoking fears that the country may abandon the euro.

headline: Grand Central Terminal, 12:55 P.M.
text: A blues singer, Michael Land, and his accompanist were among the 70 acts auditioning Wednesday for coveted spots in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s “Music Under New York” program. The winners get to perform in prime locations in the busiest subway stations.

headline: ‘Salesman’ Revival on Broadway to Turn a Profit
text: The Broadway revival of Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman,” starring Philip Seymour Hoffman, will recoup its $3.1 million capitalization this week, just 14 weeks into its run, the producers said on Wednesday.  That is a notably swift achievement for a show that has seven performances a week instead of the standard eight. Those missing performances translated into more than $1 million in unrealized revenue, based on an analysis of the ticket sale grosses for the show; it grossed $9.8 million in its first 13 weeks.

headline: Obama Meets Congressional Leaders
text: May 16, 2012 - President Obama discusses his legislative agenda for the rest of the year with congressional leaders.

headline: Face Time | Leelee Sobieski
text: I had the pleasure of doing Leelee Sobieski’s makeup recently (catch the last episodes of her police drama, “NYC 22,” on the next two Sundays on CBS.) The actress has excellent taste and knows what works for her style- and makeup-wise. (Of course, if ever in fashion doubt, she can consult with her husband, the men’s-wear designer Adam Kimmel.) The couple’s daughter, Louisanna, watched closely as her mom’s beauty regimen got under way, and even reached for her own tube of lipstick!

headline: Offering Is Possible Next Move For Coty
text: Coty has selected underwriters for an initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter, only two days after withdrawing a $10.7 billion takeover bid for Avon Products.

headline: Skechers Toning Shoe Customers to Get Refund
text: People who bought a pair of Skechers toning shoes may not get the great legs and abdominal muscles that the advertisements promised — but now at least they can get their money back.

headline: In District 75, Using the Arts in Everyday Academics
text: With help from a federal grant, special education teachers in New York City are learning how to better incorporate the arts into academics. They're getting new strategies through a program called Everyday Arts for Special Education, which runs on the basic principal that students need to have fun in order to be fully engaged with learning.

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Science: Investigating Genetically Engineered Organisms
text: Overview | What lessons can we learn about genetically engineered organisms from the example of the jabberjay, a fictional bird in the movie “The Hunger Games”? In this lesson, students discuss the definition of genetically modified organisms, learn about the risks and benefits of research on G.M.O.’s, explore the growing do-it-yourself biology movement, and develop proposals seeking to either restrict or permit research into genetically modifying the avian flu virus.

headline: A DVR Ad Eraser Causes Tremors at TV Upfronts
text: Broadcast television executives came to New York this week, as they do every year, to talk up their new TV shows in front of advertisers.

headline: Clear Channel Buys WFNX, Venerable Boston Rock Station
text: One of Boston’s most influential forces in radio, the long-independent rock station WFNX, has been sold to Clear Channel Communications, the largest radio company in the United States.

headline: After Awkward Debut, Volkswagen Passat Finds Its Stride
text: 5:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: Kerry’s 2004 Campaign Manager Joins Obama ‘Super PAC’
text: Mary Beth Cahill, who was the campaign manager for Senator John Kerry’s 2004 presidential bid, is joining the effort to help re-elect President Obama as an adviser to the leading “super PAC” supporting him.

headline: Krzyzewski’s Eye-Popping Salary
text: Yes, college sports as a big-money business does not exactly qualify as news. And college coaches commanding huge salaries is a trend we’ve all gotten used to.

headline: How I Answered Michele Bachmann’s Questionnaire
text: The leader of the Tea Party caucus, Rep. Michele Bachmann, sent out an email blast to her “fellow conservatives” this morning urgently seeking their donations to her re-election campaign … I mean soliciting their opinions on matters of great importance to the country in this election season.

headline: Amateur Hour: Jack Hitt Talks About an American Tradition
text: In “Bunch of Amateurs: A Search for the American Character,” Jack Hitt investigates the tradition of American amateurism in various fields, from politics to astronomy to bird watching. He writes, “American professionals have had to grow up right alongside their striving, awkward, amateur cousins in the same way that the first attempts at gentry in the Old South had to contend with their toothless cousins named Fishbait or Elrod, sleeping in the bushes outside the mansion.” In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Hitt discussed the reputation of the Tyrannosaurus rex, Benjamin Franklin’s role in the mythology of amateurism, the relationship between pros and amateurs, and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Artifacts From a Time of Many Droughts
text: Lisa J. Lucero, a professor of anthropology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, is studying ancient Maya underwater offerings in central Belize under the auspices of the Belize Institute of Archaeology, National Institute of Culture and History.

headline: A Pocket-Size Recording Studio
text: Once upon a time all a kid needed to make her way into a rock and roll career was an old six-string (bought at the five and dime) and a will to play it until her fingers bled. Luckily, now there is the Olympus LS-100 recorder to make all that hard work sound good.

headline: Taking Beats Anywhere, by Bluetooth
text: Even though thousands of consumer electronics products blanket the earth, from remote-controlled helicopters to MP3 toothbrushes, you probably have the same Must Have list as most people: computer, phone and TV.

headline: Michael D. Shear and Pete Sessions
text: Michael D. Shear interviews Pete Sessions.

headline: Viacom and Time Warner Cable Reach Deal on App for Streaming Programs
text: Time Warner Cable subscribers will soon have another way to stream “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and “Jersey Shore” on iPads.

headline: G.O.P. Congressional Committee Chairman Speaks Up for Fund-Raiser
text: Representative Pete Sessions of Texas, the chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, brushed aside ethics allegations against Representative Vern Buchanan of Florida, who serves as the chief fund-raiser for the committee that Mr. Sessions leads.

headline: Now on Pinterest: Scams
text: Wherever Internet users go, scammers are sure to follow.

headline: Germany Detains Activist ‘Whale Wars’ Captain
text: The founder of an aggressive conservation group known mainly for disrupting whale hunts has been detained in Germany at the request of Costa Rica, which wants him extradited over a 10-year-old maritime violation, the organization said Wednesday.

headline: F.B.I. Chief Says Leak on Qaeda Plot Is Being Investigated
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director told a Congressional committee on Wednesday that the authorities were investigating how information about a thwarted plot by Al Qaeda to detonate a bomb on an airliner bound for the United States was leaked to the news media.

headline: House Democrats Urge Senate Version of Violence Against Women Act
text: Several Democratic congresswomen said Wednesday that the House should adopt the Senate version of a bill to renew a 1994 domestic violence law.

headline: Martin Marietta Feels the Einhorn Effect
text: Turns out that executives at Herbalife can breathe easy. It appears that the company was not the target of David Einhorn, after all.

headline: Turner Broadcasting Invests in Funny or Die
text: Turner Broadcasting is taking a minority stake in Funny or Die, the producer of online comedy videos that was founded by Will Ferrell, Adam McKay and Chris Henchy.

headline: Republican Lawmaker Questions Uproar Over JPMorgan Loss
text: The $2 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase has led to worries about the bank’s risk management, the danger of high-stakes trading by Wall Street and the shape of future financial regulation.

headline: Big City Book Club: ‘Time and Again’
text: 10:07 p.m. | Updated  Thanks to all of you who participated in the Big City Book Club this evening. If anyone has further comments or questions, please post them below; I’ll follow up later in the week. And if anyone who participated is not yet a member of the Book Club mailing list and would like to join, send an e-mail to bigcity@nytimes.com with the word “Join” in the subject heading. We’ll be announcing the next book selection in a few days; members will receive e-mail notification. — Ginia Bellafante

headline: Democrats’ Odds of Retaining Senate Improve
text: When we last took an overview of Senate races in December, Republicans appeared to be slight favorites to take control from Democrats, with a net gain of four to five seats representing the most likely outcome.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Germany, Spain, Syria and England.

headline: Verizon Sees Cash Cow in Shared Data Plans
text: Verizon has outlined its strategy to make even more money from smartphones and tablets with two key weapons: shared data plans and its faster fourth-generation LTE network.

headline: A Facebook Co-Founder Reflects on the Path Forward
text: Eduardo Saverin can escape the United States, but he cannot slip Facebook.

headline: Quebec Plans to Suspend Classes Over Student Strike
text: OTTAWA — Quebec’s government said Wednesday night that it would introduce emergency legislation that would suspend the academic year at many of the province’s French-speaking universities and colleges in an attempt to end a 14-week student strike over a plan to increase tuition.

headline: Broadway Musical ‘Priscilla Queen of the Desert’ to Close
text: That’s a wrap – in this case, probably a neon-pink taffeta wrap – for the Broadway musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” press representatives for the production said on Wednesday. The musical, adapted from Stephan Elliott’s 1994 comedy “The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,” about a team of drag performers journeying through remote Australia in a camping (and camp) bus, will play its final show at the Palace Theater on June 24. The musical, which is directed by Simon Phillips and features a book by Mr. Elliott and Allan Scott as well as a score of disco-friendly pop hits, opened in March 2011 and won the Tony Award that year for its costume design by Tim Chappel and Lizzy Gardiner. Tony Sheldon, who played the role of the transsexual Bernadette – on Broadway as well as previous productions in Australia, Toronto and London’s West End – was also nominated for leading actor in a musical. “Priscilla” will have played 23 previews and 526 performances at its closing. A spokesman for the show said that it would not recoup its capitalization costs, which totaled $15 million for the Broadway run and a pre-Broadway tryout in Toronto.

headline: In Spain, Jobless Find a Refuge Off the Books
text: SEVILLE, SPAIN — More than six months ago, a 37-year-old worker here named Juan was laid off from his job delivering and assembling furniture for customers of Ikea, joining the legions of unemployed in Spain. Or so it would seem.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: May 17
text: A bandanna-print backpack; hand-stitched slippers; and elegant one-piece looks.

headline: The Gas Age, Circa 1986
text: The near-worldwide abundance of extractable natural gas has seemed like a surprise to many, but there’s a long line of analysis pointing in this direction, much of it originating with the work of the Italian physicist and systems analyst Cesare Marchetti.

headline: Asking a Skeptical Europe to Open Its Wallet for Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — There are few certainties for Afghanistan as the NATO troop withdrawal moves into high gear, but one of them is this: the Continental Europeans have a grimmer prognosis for what can be accomplished than do their American and British counterparts.

headline: Coffee Drinkers May Live Longer
text: Your morning cup of coffee may start to taste even better after a major government study found that frequent coffee drinkers have a lower risk of dying from a variety of diseases, compared with people who drink little or no coffee.

headline: Don’t Stop the Press! ‘Newsies’ Run Is Now Open-Ended
text: With strong ticket sales, eight Tony Award nominations and good reviews and word of mouth among theater-goers, the new Disney musical “Newsies” will plunge ahead with an open-ended run on Broadway rather than close Aug. 19, the producers of the show said on Wednesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Awful Phones and Learn-to-Code Overkill
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: The Riddle of Gay Marriage Polling
text: The same CBS/New York Times poll that shows Mitt Romney opening up a very slight lead on the president also contains a possible clue to solving the mystery I mentioned last week: The gap between public support for gay marriage in opinion polling and the actual support the cause tends to get at the ballot box. Unlike many of the recent surveys (Gallup, Pew, etc.) showing majority or near-majority support for same-sex marriage, the Times/CBS poll didn’t just ask respondents a yes/no question, but raised the possibility of civil unions as well:

headline: Einhorn and the PowerPoint Speed Read
text: The crowd began to buzz just before David Einhorn took the stage on Wednesday at the Ira Sohn Conference.

headline: Trayvon Martin Case Shadowed by Series of Police Missteps
text: SANFORD, Fla. — The killing of Trayvon Martin here two and a half months ago has been cast as the latest test of race relations and equal justice in America. But it was also a test of a small city police department that does not even have a homicide unit and typically deals with three or four murder cases a year.

headline: A Deadly Night in the Boxing Ring Is Grist for an Evening at the Opera
text: The grainy black and white footage is chilling.

headline: Killing Satire Isn’t Enough
text: Some people insist on waterboarding it first.

headline: Latino Networks Take Center Stage
text: May 16, 2012 - As television networks preview their new seasons to advertisers, Latino networks step further into the spotlight.

headline: Do 6-Month-Olds Really Need Music Class?
text: I’ve been holding onto this research study for a week. For some reason, it got right under my skin.

text: What book is on your night stand now?

text: A Video Flipbook

headline: F.C.C. Wants Clarity From Verizon on Proposed Spectrum Deals
text: The federal government is wondering why Verizon Wireless wants to sell some parts of the radio spectrum it already owns if it is allowed to acquire spectrum licenses from a group of cable companies.

headline: Original Review: ‘Man and Superman’
text: The original 1905 review of George Bernard Shaw’s play in The New York Times.

headline: James Abdnor, Former South Dakota Senator, Dies at 89
text: James Abdnor, a South Dakota Republican farmer who liked to say that he got off his tractor and went to Washington, where he served four terms in Congress and one in the Senate after defeating the Democratic incumbent, George S. McGovern, in 1980, died on Wednesday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 89.

headline: Syria Leader, in Rare TV Interview, Disparages Opponents
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said in an interview broadcast Wednesday that he faced no real domestic opposition in the 15-month-old uprising against him, the violence in his country is entirely the work of foreign-backed terrorists, and the boycott of parliamentary elections last week was a fiction.

headline: The Upfronts en Español
text: Tanzina Vega reports on the sharp increase in the number of broadcast networks and cable channels that aim their programming at Latino viewers at this year’s upfront presentations. The 50 million Latinos in the United States have advertisers’ attention.

headline: Shaw’s Battle of the Sexes, Waged Slyly if Vigorously
text: There is a touch of the unhinged in Jack Tanner, the hero of “Man and Superman,” as played by Max Gordon Moore in this sparkling revival of George Bernard Shaw’s comedy at the Irish Repertory Theater. Wide-eyed, exasperated by human folly, Tanner speaks for Shaw himself. But Mr. Moore’s agitation adds a vivid animus that this often talky play requires, and his performance illustrates what makes this staging, produced with Gingold Theatrical Group, so winning.

headline: An Anonymous Attack on Obama’s Record
text: There’s not much truth in the big new anti-Obama ad campaign from Crossroads GPS, but since the public doesn’t know who paid for it, no one can be held responsible for the misleading content.

headline: Google Broadens Its Search Vision
text: 9:49 p.m. | Updated Google announced a change to its search engine on Wednesday, introducing Knowledge Graph, which it said would help spotlight more relevant search results.

headline: In Minneapolis, Redesigning a Landmark
text: Peavey Plaza, considered an exceptional example of Modernist landscape architecture, is undergoing a controversial redesign.

headline: Minneapolis Tussles Over a Faded Plaza
text: In 1975 a two-acre outdoor public space called Peavey Plaza opened in downtown Minneapolis, offering city dwellers an “urban oasis” at a time when many Americans were re-embracing city life, its designer, M. Paul Friedberg, said in a recent interview. Using a 10-foot depression created during construction of the adjacent Orchestra Hall, Mr. Friedberg, a Modernist landscape architect based in New York, built a terraced amphitheaterlike space and a drainable reflecting pool that could be used as a stage in summer and a skating rink in winter. Waterfalls absorbed noise; garden rooms offered intimacy and softened concrete edges. In 1999 the American Society of Landscape Architects recognized the plaza as one of the nation’s most significant examples of landscape architecture, along with Central Park in Manhattan and the Biltmore estate in North Carolina.

headline: Homes for $500,000
text: Properties in Tucson, Michigan and Houston.

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: TUCSON, ARIZ.

headline: A Target Older Than the Jokes at Her Roast
text: Betty White’s age — she is 90 and still going strong — was the topic of much discussion Wednesday at the Sheraton New York in Midtown Manhattan, where Ms. White was the target of a Friars Club roast.

headline: Do Commencement Speeches Matter?
text: Ask people to tell you what was said at their college graduations and many of them will claim not to remember. That’s less likely to be the case (for a few years, at least) for the Class of 2012 at Barnard College and the U.S. Air Force Academy after President Obama has addressed them. Other high-profile commencement speakers this season include Condoleezza Rice at Southern Methodist University, Archbishop Desmond Tutu at Gonzaga University, Hank Aaron at Marquette University and Barbara Walters at Yale (Harvard gets Fareed Zakaria). But does anything said during a commencement speech really stay with us, or do we just remember the personality who delivered it? Below, some staff recollections.

headline: ‘Liz & Dick’ & Lindsay & Vitriol
text: LOS ANGELES — Nobody, Larry A. Thompson says, should have to endure the e-mails that he has gotten since deciding last month to cast Lindsay Lohan as Elizabeth Taylor in a television film for the Lifetime cable channel.

headline: Swimming Triumphantly to the Shore After the Shipwreck of Love
text: “After the Rain,” the title of the singer Sheera Ben-David’s stirring new show at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, is the name of a ballad about romantic afterglow by Michel Legrand and Alan and Marilyn Bergman that she performs late in the program. But that’s not all. Many of the songs use images of water to evoke states of emotional inundation. Boz Scaggs’s little-known “Hard Times” describes being sucked back into a bad relationship in a “sea of confusion” with “waves of no recovery.”

headline: If You Were So Inclined, You Could Stick It on a Bumper
text: “The Amateur” by Edward Klein is a book about an inept, arrogant ideologue who maintains an absurdly high opinion of his own talents even as he blatantly fails to achieve his goals. Oh, and President Obama is in this book too.

headline: Aesthetic Histories Interact, Movingly
text: BEACON, N.Y. — Museums, you may have heard, have been getting into the dance game again. MoMA PS1 acquired a performance dome; the Whitney made live work a cornerstone of its current Biennial.

headline: Senate Republicans Engineer Rebuke on Budget
text: A daylong Senate debate over a budget plan for the fiscal year that begins in October ended the way every senator knew it would — without a budget.

headline: Selling the Pared-Down Life
text: IT may be that the house of the future is an apartment — at 420 square feet, a very small apartment — in a century-old tenement building on Sullivan Street. Shiny and white, it has movable walls that allow it to morph from one room into six, as well as expandable furniture and filtered, or “country,” air, as the owner, Graham Hill, put it recently while showing off the apartment’s convertible tricks like a modern-day Bernadette Castro, dressed neatly in a black merino wool polo shirt, black pants and black Vans.

headline: Flexibility Is a Good Thing in a Complicated City
text: For musicians who frequent the orchestra pits of New York’s theaters, versatility is key: you have to read like a classical musician, swing like a jazzer, rock like a pop star and absorb new pieces on the fly. Those qualifications also apply increasingly to members of contemporary-classical ensembles, and that partly explains the success of the Pit Stop Players, a new-music group made up of performers who work in theater bands.

headline: In France, New Cabinet Is Announced by Hollande
text: PARIS — France’s new president, François Hollande, unveiled a center-left cabinet on Wednesday, leaving out the head of the Socialist Party, Martine Aubry, who is considered on the left wing of the party, and naming a onetime party rival, Laurent Fabius, as his foreign minister.

headline: Alber Elbaz, Life of the Party
text: The Lanvin designer in appearances at shows and events.

headline: In the Spotlight’s Glare
text: AT Via Quadronno, an Upper East Side cafe noted for its cappuccinos, Alber Elbaz was loosely discussing the difference between designing for women who are strong, as when he started his career, and for women who are powerful, as in today, when a powerful looking woman named Ester recognized him.

headline: A New Game Delights in Difficulty
text: Video games weren’t always so easy. Players who know only the current generation of consoles must think of their favorite games as gentle, kindhearted, almost mothering in their ministrations — adapting themselves to the needs of the gamer, serving up big shiny arrows or straightforward explanatory text when things get confusing, and just generally showering kisses and encouragement every time someone skins a knee.

headline: Showcasing a Jazz Legacy From Big Band to Hendrix
text: The first Gil Evans repertory concert — or at least, the first one expressly presented that way — took place at Carnegie Hall in 1974, when Evans was still around to steer his orchestra clear of sentimentality. Billed as “an evening devoted to the music and career of Gil Evans,” it was one of the earliest productions of the fledgling New York Jazz Repertory Company, for which Evans was one of several musical directors. He was in his early 60s then, an arranger and composer of pioneering achievement in jazz, and a bandleader not much in the habit of retracing his steps.

headline: Ask About Police Missteps in the Trayvon Martin Case
text: Last Updated | Thursday, 4:03 p.m. Our colleague Serge F. Kovaleski is answering questions from readers about his investigation into how the police department in Sanford, Fla., handled Trayvon Martin’s death.

headline: Early Baroque Songs With Deep Affection
text: The New York Continuo Collective performs every spring, but in a way it is less an ensemble than a club. Some of its members, including its directors — the lutenists Grant Herreid, Charles Weaver and Pat O’Brien and the multi-instrumentalist, singer and stage director Paul Shipper — are experienced early-music specialists who perform with the city’s best period-instrument groups. Others are amateur singers and players who love the vocal works of the early Baroque and want an opportunity to perform. To cultivate a sense of Baroque style, Mr. Shipper and Mr. Herreid coach the singers in stage movement and hand gestures in weekly rehearsals and classes.

headline: Judge May Permit Wiretaps as Evidence in Insider Case
text: It is perhaps the government’s most powerful piece of evidence in its case against Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director accused of leaking boardroom secrets.

headline: To Noise From Street, Humanity Rushes In
text: It’s impressive how the triple bill being shown this week at the Joyce Theater by Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet exhibits three quite distinct and thoroughly developed forms of dance theater. The pieces are well performed and well staged, with striking effects of lighting. Each gives you a clearly defined vision; nothing here is tentative or inefficient. The word “ballet” may mislead: there is no pointwork, and the sexes are given remarkably equal treatment.

headline: Doubt Cast on the ‘Good’ in ‘Good Cholesterol’
text: The name alone sounds so encouraging: HDL, the “good cholesterol.” The more of it in your blood, the lower your risk of heart disease. So bringing up HDL levels has got to be good for health.

headline: Real-Life Pregnancy: Hold the Showers
text: We used to be terrified of pregnancy — we being teenagers and other unmarried Americans, and pregnancy being the shameful, inevitable result of premarital sex.

headline: Columbia University Radio Station Is Fined $10,000

headline: Nuance Moves to a Grand Stage in a Familiar Ballet

headline: Popular Antibiotic May Raise Risk of Sudden Death

headline: Audit Finds Irregularities in Payments to Tutoring Agency

headline: Out of Mideast, a Comic Recipe for the Stage
text: WHEN “My Name Is Rachel Corrie” was postponed and then pulled from the New York Theater Workshop in March 2006, the ensuing furor raged chiefly between critics of the play’s unequivocal sympathy for the Palestinian cause and those, like Tony Kushner and Harold Pinter, who worried that the workshop had bowed to political censorship.

headline: Slammed Doors Are All Part of a Night’s Work

After a big greeting at the door and several rounds of complimentary drinks, the man, in a blue custom-made suit, continued down to West 16th Street.

headline: Cottages Spring Up in Manhattan
text: In the last few days, three little cottages have appeared at the base of the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan, like a rural-themed mirage. The installation is for Country Living’s semiregular House of the Year, which gives the magazine’s editors the opportunity to break out their tools and build a pop-up structure (or at least oversee its construction) to demonstrate what the editor in chief Sarah Gray Miller called an “idealized version of country living.”

headline: A User’s Guide to Finding Storage Space in the Cloud

You’ll tell them how it was called sneakernet because you had to physically move the data.

headline: House Vote Sets Up Battle on Domestic Violence Bill
text: WASHINGTON — After a fierce fight, full of gender politics, the House passed a Republican bill on Wednesday to combat violence against women, over objections from President Obama and other Democrats, who said it would reduce protections for many battered women, including lesbians, American Indians and illegal immigrants.

headline: Softening, Merkel Says She Is Open to Stimulus for Greece
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Wednesday that she was ready to discuss stimulus programs to get the Greek economy growing again and that she was committed to keeping Greece in the euro zone, signaling a softer approach toward the struggling country.

headline: Why Billy Bob Thornton Is Afraid of Antiques
text: If Billy Bob Thornton’s new memoir, “The Billy Bob Tapes: A Cave Full of Ghosts” (William Morrow), reads as if he’s sitting in a roomful of friends telling stories, that’s because it was written that way. The actor and musician ran a microphone up from his home recording studio (he lives in the guitarist Slash’s former house in Beverly Hills), pulled up some chairs and, with Kinky Friedman, his co-author, and others as an audience, talked out his life story.

headline: ICFF Events, on a Single Web Site

text: Rooms from the annual design event, which was held in a high-rise with views of the Hudson.

headline: Brooklyn Prosecutor Defends Record on Sex Abuse Cases
text: The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, on Wednesday defended his record in the face of criticism over his handling of accusations of child sexual abuse in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community.

headline: An Image Maker Who Gets the Picture
text: EDWARD ENNINFUL has a thing he likes to say on photo shoots: “I want her to look rich, rich, rich and chic, chic, chic.”

headline: Alabama: A Walmart Win
text: The city of Florence is moving ahead with a proposal to build a Walmart directly beside a historic cemetery, despite concerns that 80 slaves might have been buried on the site. The City Council voted 5 to 1 on Tuesday night to approve the construction plan, but to require more research. The retail giant says it will not disrupt any burial grounds.

headline: A Judge’s Plea for Pot
text: THREE and a half years ago, on my 62nd birthday, doctors discovered a mass on my pancreas. It turned out to be Stage 3 pancreatic cancer. I was told I would be dead in four to six months. Today I am in that rare coterie of people who have survived this long with the disease. But I did not foresee that after having dedicated myself for 40 years to a life of the law, including more than two decades as a New York State judge, my quest for ameliorative and palliative care would lead me to marijuana.

headline: California: Report Gives Details of Blogger’s Death
text: Andrew Breitbart, the conservative blogger and provocateur, died of heart failure brought on in part by hardening of the arteries, a report released Wednesday by the Los Angeles County coroner’s office said. Mr. Breitbart, who collapsed on the street and died in February, had a history of congestive heart failure. One of his major coronary vessels had narrowed by up to 60 percent, the medical examiner said.

headline: Some Rules Are Best Left Unwritten
text: More has been written about baseball’s unwritten rules than about most of the sports world’s written ones.

headline: SAT Scores Are Invalidated at a Brooklyn School
text: Nearly 200 students who took the SAT at a Brooklyn private school this month had their scores invalidated by the company that administers the test, apparently because some students were seated too closely together, school officials said Wednesday.

headline: Art’s Turn on the Catwalk
text: “LET me tell you something,” said the artist K8 Hardy, a star of the current Whitney Biennial, whose work typically subverts common conceptions of fashion and consumerism.

headline: ‘Two and a Half Men’ Aims to Lift Thursday
text: A YEAR ago, the television industry was abuzz about the CBS decision to keep the popular series “Two and a Half Men” on the air by replacing Charlie Sheen with Ashton Kutcher. A year later, all eyes are on “Men” again as CBS readies a move of the sitcom to Thursday from Monday, on which it has spent its entire run.

headline: U.S. Expected to Retry Ex-Senator on 4 Unresolved Charges
text: Federal prosecutors will try to recover nearly $500,000 that Pedro Espada Jr., a former Democratic state senator from the Bronx, was convicted this week of stealing from a nonprofit health care network, as they seek a retrial for Mr. Espada and his son, according to a person familiar with the case.

headline: App Smart Extra: Don’t Let Me Squint Too Long
text: “George Harrison: Living in the Material World,” the new e-book by Olivia Harrison ($15 on Apple’s iBookstore), has generated good reviews from iTunes users, and the content is excellent.

headline: Quinn Nears a Wedding, and a City Seeks Details
text: She interrupted a news conference on federal immigration policy so that her father could hand-deliver a decorative hair comb. She juggled questions about banking regulations with queries about her gift registry.

headline: D.E.A.’s Agents Join Counternarcotics Efforts in Honduras
text: WASHINGTON — A commando-style squad of Drug Enforcement Administration agents accompanied the Honduran counternarcotics police during two firefights with cocaine smugglers in the jungles of the Central American country this month, according to officials in both countries who were briefed on the matter. One of the fights, which occurred last week, left as many as four people dead and has set off a backlash against the American presence there.

headline: Estranged Wife of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Found Dead at Home in Westchester
text: Mary R. Kennedy, the estranged wife of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., was found dead on Wednesday at the family’s home in Bedford, N.Y. She was 52.

headline: Red Bulls Find Out Possible Opponents in Open Cup
text: The Red Bulls will either host Reading United or play at the Charleston Battery on May 29 in the third of the 99th Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

headline: Blitz of Campaign Ads Is Early and Aggressive
text: The presidential campaign is erupting into a full-scale advertising war, with both candidates and their allies pouring huge sums into early and aggressive efforts to define the fight on their terms.

headline: Fun Plans for Summer Vacation
text: John Boehner wants to restart the debt-limit debate. This is big news. Remember all the fun we had last time: threats, brinkmanship, wobbling financial markets, torpedoed Grand Bargain? You can certainly understand why he misses it.

headline: JPMorgan’s Trading Loss Is Said to Rise at Least 50%
text: The trading losses suffered by JPMorgan Chase have surged in recent days, surpassing the bank’s initial $2 billion estimate by at least $1 billion, according to people with knowledge of the losses.

headline: Big Gathering for NATO Puts Chicago on High Alert
text: CHICAGO — Foreign delegations are to arrive in this city over the weekend for a NATO summit meeting, the first such gathering to be held in the United States outside of Washington, and Chicago is bracing for all that will bring: thousands of international dignitaries, reporters and others; protesters from around the country; road closings and possible train delays — and what amounts to a significant trial for Mayor Rahm Emanuel, one year into his leadership of the nation’s third-largest city.

headline: Senate Passes Bill Creating Monitor for Disabled Care
text: ALBANY — The State Senate unanimously passed Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s legislation to protect developmentally disabled and mentally ill New Yorkers on Wednesday, but some high-profile advocates have been unnerved by what they perceive as flaws in the bill. Assembly Democrats have said that they intend to pass the bill, but will negotiate some changes before the legislative session ends on June 21.

headline: Jean Craighead George, Children’s Author, Dies at 92
text: Jean Craighead George, a Newbery Award-winning writer for young people whose books brought the natural world from the Catskill Mountains to the Alaskan tundra to wild, luminous life, died on Tuesday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 92.

headline: Derby Runner-Up Is Favorite at Pimlico
text: BALTIMORE — When a Kentucky Derby winner comes to the Preakness Stakes, hope remains alive. The potential of a Triple Crown victory has not been eliminated, and there is one horse who could win the second leg before ending the series drought with a victory at Belmont.

text: HIGHLAND PARK, N.J. — The Reformed Church in this prosperous suburb has for years packed a lot inside its walls, including addiction counseling, a housing program, dance groups, gatherings for developmentally disabled people, a restaurant, a thrift shop and space to worship for hundreds of people from half a dozen religious congregations.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 10
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Army to Review Its Handling of Psychiatric Evaluations
text: The Army said Wednesday that it had ordered a service-wide review of how its doctors diagnose psychiatric disorders, indicating that complaints about unfair diagnoses at a sprawling base in Washington State have been echoed on installations around the country.

headline: In Shift on Willets Pt., City Strikes New Development Deal
text: In a sudden departure from its long-held plans, the Bloomberg administration has struck a deal with a developer and the owners of the Mets to build a 1.4-million-square-foot mall and parking garage in Queens next to Citi Field, as well as a 200-room hotel and stores on the other side of the stadium.

headline: Believing in Obama

headline: Reform Stop-and-Frisk
text: Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court spoke up for the constitutional rights of blacks and Hispanics on Wednesday by granting class-action status to a lawsuit that accuses the New York Police Department of using race as the basis for stopping and frisking hundreds of thousands of citizens a year.

headline: The Doyennes of Pinup
text: Capturing the glamour, a cocktail of raciness and coy naïveté, of some of the most famous pinups in history.

headline: The Grand Old Party and the Sea
text: Add fish and oceans to the long list of environmental issues that House Republicans do not much care about. Last week, the House voted to deny further financing to a federal program that helps regulate commercial fisheries and has been increasingly important to the recovery of several at-risk species. For good measure, it also killed financing for a worthy effort by the Obama administration to improve the health of America’s coastal waters.

headline: Spellcheck, Please
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Yes, I know; if you’re doing this puzzle online, some of the squares have no numbers. Don’t panic.

headline: Ticks to the Slaughter
text: The mild winter is promising to bring a bad summer for disease-causing parasites like the deer tick, which causes Lyme disease, a danger throughout the Northeast. A three-year experiment in tick control in two areas of Long Island — Shelter Island and western portions of Fire Island — has shown encouraging results.

headline: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Adam Graves
text: Adam Graves took 31 shots againstMartin Brodeur in the 1994 Eastern Conference finals against the Devils, and only two got through for goals. That degree of difficulty helps to inform Graves’s frame of reference on the trans-Hudson rivalry, then and now.

headline: G.O.P. Upset Puts Focus on Would-Be Kingmaker
text: WASHINGTON — When an unheralded state senator, Deb Fischer, rose from nowhere on Tuesday to win Nebraska’s Republican Senate nomination, she beat more than just the state’s attorney general, Jon Bruning, and its treasurer, Don Stenberg.

headline: A Sly Wink to Pinups of the Past

headline: JPMorphing
text: When he disclosed a stunning $2 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase last week, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, insisted that the trades had not violated the Volcker Rule, a crucial part of the Dodd-Frank reform law that is supposed to bar banks from doing risky trading for their own account.

headline: Port Authority Shakes Up Police Force for Test Lapse
text: Responding to its Police Department’s failure to investigate a high-ranking officer for misconduct, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey stripped the department of control over its internal affairs division, officials said Wednesday.

headline: New York School Budgets Are Approved at High Rate
text: Voters around New York State overwhelmingly approved their school districts’ annual budgets on Tuesday, the first to be delivered under a new cap on property taxes for schools.

headline: Bank of America Hires 3 Power Specialists From Credit Suisse
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired a team of three investment bankers specializing in the power industry from Credit Suisse, the firm announced in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: Romney Camp Tries to Limit Reporters’ Access, and Rope Line Ruckus Erupts
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Romney campaign is known for its hyper-disciplined approach to the news media. Question-and-answer sessions with reporters are rare. Aides avoid on-the-record briefings. And the candidate’s latest outreach to voters, a series of casual meetings with middle-class Americans, is shielded from public view.

headline: How to Address Alcoholism on Indian Reservations
text: What steps can be taken, by tribes, states, the federal government and alcohol companies?

headline: Alabama: Changes Made to Immigration Law
text: With advocates for immigrant rights protesting outside, the Legislature voted Wednesday to make modest changes to the state’s immigration enforcement law, the nation’s most far-reaching. The bill, which awaits the governor’s signature, leaves much of the original law intact but adds a few provisions, like requiring the state to publish detailed information about every case in which an illegal immigrant appears in court for a violation of state law.

headline: Kuroda Yields 7 Runs in Worst Start as Yankee
text: TORONTO — Hiroki Kuroda excelled in his four years in the National League, where the parks are big and many of the hitters are not. In the American League, the stadiums are smaller and many of the hitters are bigger, making it a far more treacherous landscape for Kuroda to navigate.

headline: Canadian Police Violated Laws in G-20 Sweep, Inquiry Finds
text: OTTAWA — Police officers “ignored basic rights,” jailed people illegally, used excessive force and escalated violence at protests surrounding the Group of 20 meeting in Toronto two years ago, a long-awaited independent review concluded Wednesday.

headline: New Fight on a Speaker at a Catholic University
text: Among politically conservative Roman Catholics, Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, was already at the top of the list of Catholic public officials considered to be traitors to the faith.

headline: Santana Gets Job Done; Bullpen Doesn’t

headline: After 7 Years, No End in Sight to Phone Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — The phone hacking scandal that shook Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire and hit the heart of the British government began quietly on a Monday in 2005, when aides to the British royal family gathered in a palace office appointed with priceless antiques to air suspicions that their voice mail messages had been intercepted.

headline: The Stars Come Out in the Celtics’ Big Win
text: PHILADELPHIA — At the Boston Celtics’ shootaround Wednesday morning, Coach Doc Rivers noticed a particular seriousness from point guard Rajon Rondo. It was hours before the Celtics’ 107-91 victory against the Philadelphia 76ers in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference semifinals, and Rondo was already establishing the tone for his team.

headline: C.D.C. Lowers Recommended Lead-Level Limits in Children
text: For the first time in 20 years, federal health authorities have lowered the recommended limit for lead exposure in young children, which they say could add 200,000 children to those believed to have unsafe lead levels in their blood.

headline: Egypt’s Military Leader Promises a Fair Election
text: CAIRO — The leader of Egypt’s ruling military council promised on Wednesday to secure a fair vote in the presidential election beginning next week but also said the military would retain a “duty” to protect Egypt from domestic disturbances as well as to defend it against foreign threats.

headline: For Staples Center, 72 Hours of Overtime
text: There will be blood — and sweat and pucks and balls and spokes and triumph and anguish and a bit of Thunder — all on a single street corner, all in a frantic and fascinating 72 hours in downtown Los Angeles.

headline: Ahead of Facebook I.P.O., a Skeptical Madison Ave.
text: With Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg has created a seemingly perfect home on the Web, one where people feel comfortable chatting with friends, playing games, sharing photos and videos, listening to music and revealing the most intimate details of their lives.

headline: From the Start, Tortorella Senses That Something Is Amiss
text: Coach John Tortorella recognized his team’s lack of fire early. Soon after the opening face-off of the Devils’ 3-2 win in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals on Wednesday night, Tortorella paced up and down the Rangers’ bench, exhorting his players to get their legs moving and their heads in the game.

headline: Mural at I.S. 259 Teaches About 9/11 Attack
text: At I.S. 259 William McKinley in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, the events of Sept. 11 became the theme for the newest section of a continuing mural that students started in 2006.

headline: Pacquiao Is Put on Defensive Over Same-Sex Marriage View
text: The boxing champion Manny Pacquiao and his associates on Wednesday tried to quell an uproar incited by an article on a Web site that addressed his opposition to same-sex marriage.

headline: For Ultra-Orthodox, Clash Over Allegations
text: As thousands of supporters of a Brooklyn man accused of being a child molester attended a fund-raiser for his legal defense Wednesday night, a group of about 100 people supporting the young woman who alleged that he sexually assaulted her rallied outside.

headline: Graduation Will Let Wie Focus Efforts on Her Game
text: GLADSTONE, N.J. — Michelle Wie remembers what victory tastes like. When she tapped in for her first L.P.G.A. Tour title, in 2009, her fellow tour pros Paula Creamer and Morgan Pressel sprayed her with beer. A few days later friends at her Stanford University dorm surprised her with a beer bath.

headline: Jets’ Offense Hears Sparano Clear, and Loud
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The first time the Jets’ new offensive coordinator, Tony Sparano, addressed the team last month, he hushed his voice and said, deadpan, “I’m not a very loud talker.”

headline: Legal Fight Over, Wilpon and Mets Get 2013 All-Star Game
text: City Hall is just a few blocks from the federal courthouse where an acrimonious legal fight raised serious doubts about Fred Wilpon’s ability to hold on as principal owner of the Mets. That uncertainty ended two months ago when he settled the case that threatened his sports and real estate empire.

headline: Largest Generational Gaps in Minority Births
text: The Census Bureau confirmed that minority births in the United States outnumbered white births for the first time in the year that ended July 2011.

headline: Toni Kroos: Bayern Munich’s Best Hope
text: The UEFA Champions League final Saturday between Chelsea and Bayern Munich will be the ninth appearance for the German team as it hopes to pick up its fifth European title — in its own stadium, Allianz Arena. All that stands between the Bavarian team and European triumph is a peculiar opponent in Chelsea. Bayern must be wary.

headline: Rangers-Devils: Game 2
text: The Rangers often seemed a step slower than Ilya Kovalchuk, Zach Parise, Travis Zajac and the rest of the New Jersey Devils on Wednesday night.

headline: Whites Account for Under Half of Births in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — After years of speculation, estimates and projections, the Census Bureau has made it official: White births are no longer a majority in the United States.
