headline: Champions League Final: Heroes and, to Be Sure, Villains
text: Bayern Munich and Chelsea, the two teams that will contest the UEFA Champions League final on Saturday in Munich, harbor painful memories of recent finals lost.

headline: Study Finds Lack of Uniform Signage Poses Obstacle to Public Charging Networks
text: Motorists tend not to dwell on a traffic sign’s quality until they are forced to, such as after missing a poorly marked highway exit or getting a parking ticket in a spot where the violation is unclear. Drivers of electric vehicles face additional challenges as they hunt for charging stations or designated parking from city to city, a problem reported on recently in The Times.

headline: OPEC Sees Sanctions Taking Toll on Iran Oil Production
text: Iranian oil production, “the backbone of the Islamic republic’s economy,” fell by 12 percent in the first three months of the year and “is likely to fall even more, industry experts say, as sanctions make it increasingly hard for the country to find markets for its crude,” Thomas Erdrink writes in The New York Times.

headline: Lawrence Taylor Selling Super Bowl Ring; You Can Wear One
text: You don’t need to have played in a Super Bowl to wear a Super Bowl ring.

headline: Daily Report: The Reticent Rich in Silicon Valley
text: At Facebook, ground zero for the nouveau tech riche, peer pressure dictates that consumption be kept on the down low, reports Somini Sengupta of The New York Times.

headline: Robert Caro’s Tristram Shandy Moment
text: Robert Caro’s “The Passage of Power,” the fourth volume of his Lyndon Johnson biography, just made its debut this week at No. 1 on The New York Times best-seller list. The first three volumes, starting with “The Path to Power” 30 years ago, were best sellers too. Think people like power?

headline: Introducing Deirdre Lord, a New Business Group Member
text: Two new owners have joined the business group. Their companies operate in different industries and are at very different stages in their evolution. This post introduces one of them.

headline: Facebook vs. the Wireless Industry
text: Facebook hasn’t yet figured out how to make meaningful revenue from mobile, the fastest growing industry in the world, but it has done plenty to create both opportunities and headaches for the wireless carriers.

headline: The Great Gatsby Curve, for the States
text: 12:46 p.m. | Updated to correct description of Great Gatsby Curve.

headline: Closure in Disappearance of Computer Scientist
text: Just over five years ago, Jim Gray, a computer scientist then working for Microsoft, vanished with his sailboat somewhere in the waters beyond the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco. Because no trace of Dr. Gray or his boat, Tenacious, was found during the extensive searches that followed, he could not be declared legally dead.

headline: Britain Faces $3.2 Billion Loss from Northern Rock Sale
text: LONDON – Britain stands to lose £2 billion, or $3.2 billion, from the sale of nationalized lender Northern Rock to Richard Branson’s Virgin Money, a government report on the sale said Friday.

headline: In the Gulf’s Depths, a Rare Time Capsule
text: Four thousand feet beneath the surface of the Gulf of Mexico and 200 miles south of Louisiana’s marshy coastline, a machine called Little Hercules levitates in the darkness above the bow of a decaying wooden ship. Much of the wreckage has disintegrated over the many decades that the ship has soaked on the ocean floor, but Little Hercules’ lights illuminate a skeletal scrub forest of sea creatures thriving on what remains.

headline: Graff Diamonds Said to Move Closer to $1 Billion I.P.O. in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — While Wall Street is busy with Facebook’s debut on the Nasdaq, investors in Hong Kong, the world’s biggest market for new listings, are focused on whether diamonds really are forever — or at least long enough to shine above the current volatility in global markets.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Facebook to Begin Trading at $104 Billion Valuation  |  As investors raced to buy shares of Facebook, the sprawling social network raised $16 billion on Thursday, in an initial public offering that valued the company at $104 billion. While the I.P.O. shares, 421 million of them, are being sold at $38 each, the feverish anticipation of their debut could drive them higher on Friday when the stock starts trading about 11 a.m.

headline: Live Blog: Facebook’s Market Debut
text: 4:47 p.m. | Updated

headline: Uncomfortable Truths
text: LONDON — Last week, a court in Liverpool sentenced a gang of nine men, all but one of Pakistani origin, to between four and 19 years of imprisonment for committing a total of 25 sex offenses against children. The men had “groomed” up to 47 girls, some as young as 13, with alcohol and drugs before having sex with them. With prominent public figures such as the historian David Starkey accusing the so-called Rochdale gang of “acting within their cultural norms,” the case is exposing fault lines in race relations in Britain.

headline: A City Rises, Along With Its Hopes
text: Medellín, Colombia

headline: Friday Reading: Does Facebook Make You a Narcissist?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Opinion Report: Fingerprints for Food Stamps
text: From the editorial page

headline: New Pro-Union Group Jumps Into Mayoral Race
text: While they are duking it out with the city at the policy level, the public school unions are also hoping to kick it up on the political front, as part of a new coalition, New Yorkers for Great Public Schools, that plans to weigh in on the 2013 mayoral race. The group was formed to counter StudentsFirstNY, which has said it will inject $10 million a year, raised from hedge fund managers and venture capitalists, into the race to press for more policies like those adopted under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Win Some, Lose Some
text: Is it possible that I have misjudged Mitt Romney?

headline: Issues of Race and Religion Bubble Up in Campaign
text: 10:46 p.m. | Updated A revised version of this article can be found here.

headline: Going on Faith
text: The morning I arrived in Trivandrum, the capital of the south Indian state of Kerala, I met my friend Vinita, a Hindu, who promised to accompany me on a visit to the Sri Padmanabhaswamy temple, a place that is generally off limits to nonbelievers. Though my family is from Kerala, we are Christians, a community dating back to A.D. 52 with the arrival of St. Thomas on these shores. “Doubting” Thomas converted Brahmins to the faith, who are now the so-called Syrian or St. Thomas Christians. And that morning, one of their fold was proposing to enter a Hindu temple.

headline: Edible Selby | Fire Island
text: Just outside the town of Deià on the northwestern coast of Majorca, Spain, a rocky peninsula juts out into the Mediterranean. There, clinging to the edge of tall bluffs, sits the paella restaurant Sa Foradada — named for the peninsula — that Emilio Fernández, 72, opened more than four decades ago, and now runs with his daughter Lidia, 40. Their instruments are simple — grill, cast-iron pans — but their saffron-infused brews are anything but, incorporating squid, cuttlefish, mussels, prawns, clams, crab legs and sea bream, all plucked from the water below. True to Valencian tradition, tables are communal, dishes served family style. “It’s a place where the years haven’t passed,” Lidia says. More…

headline: Fill-In | Robotic Arms, Moved With the Mind
text: Go to related article »

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Facebook’s Billions, and Political Blowback for a Billionaire
text: Facebook raised $16 billion on Thursday in its initial public offering, with 421 million shares going for $38. That price values the company at $104 billion, Evelyn M. Rusli and Peter Eavis write, giving it a higher market value than McDonald’s, Citigroup, Amazon and all but a handful of other American companies.

headline: One Bench, Two Memories, in Central Park
text: Dear Diary: I was in Manhattan just for the day — I live in Massachusetts — with a brief respite from appointments in the midafternoon.

headline: Mysterious Arrogance
text: Kevin O’Rourke takes on Lorenzo Bini Smaghi, who argues that Greek voters are being “irrational” in rejecting austerity. As O’Rourke says, that’s an odd position to take given that the policy in question has been an abject failure.

headline: Chinese Tycoon Gets Life for Bribes and Smuggling
text: BEIJING — Lai Changxing, an illiterate peasant-turned-billionaire whose legacy of bribery, smuggling and monumental profligacy came to personify the excesses of the economic reform era, was given a life sentence on Friday for his role in what the government has described as modern China’s biggest corruption scandal, according to the state news media.

headline: Business Day Live | Facebook IPO
text: Facebook shares will begin trading on the Nasdaq today. Evelyn M. Rusli and Nicole Perlroth report.

headline: Stage Play of ‘The Exorcist’ Now Possesses Brooke Shields and Richard Chamberlain
text: Any version of “The Exorcist” should make heads spin, and a new stage presentation of this modern-day horror tale to be presented this summer at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles may accomplish that with a cast that includes Brooke Shields and Richard Chamberlain, press representatives for the Geffen have announced.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: theKitchn: No cream, no onions, no peas. This recipe for spaghetti alla carbonara is the real deal. — Eric Asimov

headline: Pentagon Report Says Chinese Military Continues to Press for Modernization
text: On May 18, 2012, the Defense Department released to Congress its annual report assessing the military strategy of China, noting that the Asian country continues to press for a long-range modernization of its military.

headline: Under ‘Crossroads of the World,’ Preserving a Latin Sound
text: Jesse Moskowitz was happy to just go for a walk in the sunshine on his days off. After all, he spent more than half a century underground in the Times Square subway station presiding over one of the city’s cultural landmarks, the Record Mart.

headline: Swapping Out Charcoal With Ethanol
text: Africa used to boast nearly three million square miles of forest, only about one-third of which remain today. The principal culprit is charcoal production for cookstove fuel, which emits soot that leads to endemic health problems.

headline: Radio Times, Philadelphia
text: Doing it NOW (or actually in a few minutes), from Princeton.

headline: Trying to Pull Heart Strings, Not Grenade Pins
text: Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Farm Fraiche
text: I lived in France for more than two decades and still return for long improvised intervals twice a year; a friend says she can set her clock by my trips (May and August). I travel to Paris and regions I have combed through many times mostly to see how they have got on in my absence and how far south the food has gone. Nostalgia aside, you get to a point where all you’re interested in is the peculiar luxury of cultivating a receptively blank mind in a familiar, inexhaustible place.

headline: Let’s Go Reading in the Car
text: How did we human beings become the hypersocial creatures we are today?

headline: Leading Off: James’s Reality Check Moment
text: It appears the Big Three may be down to the Big One. Which is not how LeBron James planned this at all.

headline: The Voice
text: My audiobook listening takes place during my morning exercise, which means I spend a good seven hours a week listening to books — far more of them, in fact, than I read in print these days. If you’d encountered me on the street recently, you might have seen me trotting along, laughing aloud to David Sedaris’s “Barrel Fever” or Tina Fey’s “Bossypants,” or crying — yes, real tears and grimaces, I have to admit — to the ending of “The Mill on the Floss.” My neighbors either don’t notice or are too kind to mention my seeming emotional instability.

headline: Books With 140 Characters
text: I run a book club. It’s a highly democratic operation, and the members choose what books they want to read. What with varying tastes and all, building a consensus can prove challenging. That may be true of any reading group, but my predicament is unusual: this book club has, at last count, 64,483 members.

headline: Ljubicic’s Tweet Gets a Heated American Response
text: The normally friendly (or at least restrained) Twittersphere of tennis players experienced a rare flare-up Saturday afternoon after a tweet from a recently retired player drew the ire of several of his former colleagues.

headline: Markets End Week With a Losing Streak Intact
text: Investors drove American stock indexes to their worst weekly performance of the year after excitement about Facebook’s stock offering failed to chase away the pessimism that has increasingly gripped investors in recent weeks.

headline: Pentagon Study Says China Military Getting Stronger
text: WASHINGTON — China is pressing a long-range modernization of its military, part of a strategy aimed at maximizing its leverage over Taiwan, extending its influence farther abroad, but avoiding conflict around its borders or with the United States, the Pentagon said on Friday in an annual report to Congress.

headline: How to Enjoy Going to the Movies Again
text: These are challenging times for cinephiles. The sanctity of our natural habitat — the movie theater — is disappearing amid the dynamite blasts of lighted phones while people text and tweet in the dark; the chain-saw buzz of disruptive conversation; and the slow erosion of common courtesy in communal spaces. As a committed moviegoer who once treasured the cathedral-like atmosphere of the movie house, I now find myself entering the auditorium anticipating a bad experience — sitting and nervously profiling every person who walks into the theater for their yet-to-be-committed misdemeanors. (Is he a talker? She definitely looks like a texter.) In fact, given the round-the-clock accessibility of movies, the advent of oversize HDTV screens and the quality of high-end home-theater sound systems, it’s more and more tempting just to hunker down and erect a cinematic temple in your own home.

headline: Who Made That Crash-Test Dummy?
text: Before the modern dummy was invented, crash-testing relied on cadavers, animals, sandbags and the occasional human volunteer. In 1949, Maj. J. P. Stapp, an Air Force flight surgeon studying the “physiology of rapid deceleration,” wanted to test his rocket sled on something resembling a human. He commissioned a dummy based on plaster casts of an actual pilot. A California firm called Sierra Engineering responded with Sierra Sam, a six-foot-tall steel-and-rubber dummy with instruments in his thorax and head. Soon, it became apparent that such a dummy could have a big impact on the auto industry. With the birth of the Interstate, in 1956, Americans began driving longer distances in bigger and more powerful cars, increasing concerns about safety. In 1965, Ralph Nader published “Unsafe at Any Speed,” and the following year Congress passed the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act. The same year, the engineer Samuel Alderson, who studied physics under J. Robert Oppenheimer, built the first dummy designed for the automotive industry. He called it V.I.P.

headline: All I Wanted Was for Alice Waters to Feed Me
text: Forty-two years ago, when Alice Waters taught preschool at Berkeley Montessori, I was among her pupils. Waters was fired, she told me later, for wearing see-through blouses. I wish I could remember the snacks. I’m sure they were good, because Waters opened Chez Panisse next, becoming the queen of our town’s most exclusive social court. My parents always reminded me of this the way other Berkeley parents reminded kids about how their entire family was once tear-gassed during an antiwar march.

headline: The 5.6.12 Issue
text: ARE THE RICH WORTH A DAMN?

headline: Richard Ford Is a Man Who Actually Listens
text: Your new novel, “Canada,” is set in 1960, the year a teenager’s life changes when his parents rob a bank. Your father died of a heart attack that same year. I can’t imagine that’s a coincidence.  It may be a subliminal thing. I would be foolish to say that that year wasn’t significant. And I have sometimes thought that because my father died when I was 16 that I write in a way that’s compensatory, that I write into a void that I never experienced. I’ve written two or three stories about boys and girls who have parents at age 16 and go on having parents at age 16 and what happens subsequent to that.

headline: Guardian Anger
text: My younger brother, who is now 40, began drinking heavily and using drugs in high school and was in a car accident that left him with brain damage. The last 25 years have been a cycle of rehab, jail, institutionalization and halfway houses, and he is now in such bad shape that he needs a guardian. My parents, who have health problems of their own, have asked me to take this on. I have no relationship with my brother. I am a single mother with a demanding job, and I live about a seven-hour drive away. I do not want my brother near my house or my daughter. Do I need to take on the responsibility of his guardianship? L.M., WISCONSIN

headline: First Look: ‘The Do-Deca-Pentathalon’
text: An exclusive preview of the new film by Mark and Jay Duplass.

headline: First Look: ‘Your Sister’s Sister’
text: A preview of the new film by Lynn Shelton, starring Mark Duplass and Emily Blunt.

headline: The Duplass Brothers Have Kidnapped Hollywood!
text: “Our time is worth a ton of money right now,” Mark Duplass said matter-of-factly, and indeed, he and his big brother, Jay, could have been spending this particular afternoon extracting large checks from Hollywood studios — setting up a feature film or toiling on a rewrite job. Instead they were in Jay’s garage-turned-office in Los Angeles, preparing for a sound-looping session for their microbudget movie, “The Do-Deca-Pentathlon,” and generally acting like stoned teenagers in faded black jeans. Jay rooted through cardboard boxes, searching for microphones. Mark watched, strumming an acoustic guitar. They called each other “Dupes” a lot, a variation on Duplass that they stole from a friend.

headline: Q. and A. With Gary Braness: How Do I Deal With Pests?
text: In this week’s Real Estate section, Samantha Storey writes about that most common of New York City problems: pests.

headline: Things Left Unsaid
text: “I would like you to write a simple story just once more,” a dying man says to his daughter in Grace Paley’s “Conversation With My Father.” He asks that she, like Maupassant or Chekhov, create “recognizable people and then write down what happened to them next.” The nine stories in Johanna Skibsrud’s first collection, “This Will Be Difficult to Explain,” could have been written with this mandate in mind. In them, young women stumble through summer jobs abroad, wives toy with leaving their husbands, and fathers labor to communicate with sullen teenage daughters. Her characters live in South Dakota and California, in unnamed suburbs, rural towns and far-flung capitals that, if unrecognizable in detail, are familiar in mood. What links these stories, aside from a handful of recurring characters, is their fascination with the mundane, with the instances in which the known becomes foreign or the everyday exposes a sinister architecture.

headline: Retracing His Steps
text: The central character in Paul Theroux’s latest novel, “The Lower River,” is an American named Ellis Hock who decides to return to Africa after an absence of almost 40 years. Life in his own country has become tiresome and frustrating, but there’s a village in Malawi where, during his Peace Corps days, Hock had once been happy and useful. He wants to be useful again. So he prepares to say goodbye to his failing men’s wear store in Medford, Mass., along with his embittered ex-wife and his grasping, heartless daughter.

headline: Loving Liberals
text: The trouble with liberals, Robert Kennedy complained in 1964, was that they were “in love with death” — they romanticized failure, finding greater nobility in losing the whole loaf than in winning half of it. In the years since then, liberals have not only lost a lot of loaves but have acquired a mess of other troubles, among them the difficulty of getting anyone to admit to being a liberal. To wear the label today seems an act of defiance, much as members of the gay rights community have appropriated, from their antagonists, the epithet “queer.” Liberalism — for decades (centuries, even) the prevailing philosophy in American political life — has become the creed that dare not speak its name, except late at night on MSNBC.

headline: Hating Liberals
text: Jonah Goldberg’s first book was called “Liberal Fascism.” It was a screed, of course, but a clever one. He argued that liberals who routinely denounce extreme conservatives as fascists should take a look in their own backyard, and he wasn’t fooling around: “It is my argument that American liberalism is a totalitarian political religion.” Goldberg has read around a bit, and he was able to lace his thesis with embarrassing quotations from progressives past who expressed admiration for Italian Fascism, eugenics and other assorted statist atrocities. But his essential point was a simple one: fascists believe in state control of almost every­thing, and so do liberals.

headline: Respect Your Elders
text: Richard Fortey has spent most of his life looking at fossils, the imprints of the skeletons of the very thoroughly dead. Here he sets out — like a more deeply thoughtful David Attenborough, without the cameras — to describe the distinguished groups of organisms that are still recognizable and thriving after millions and millions of years. The horseshoe crabs, velvet worms and other venerable creatures he encounters are Earth’s true conservatives. “We’ve devised a system that works very well for our niche,” they would tell us. “No big changes necessary. Maybe just a tweak at the molecular level.” As Fortey says, “to look at a living horseshoe crab is to see a portrait of a distant ancestor repainted by time, but with many of its features still unchanged.”

headline: In New Jersey, Memorial for ‘Comfort Women’ Deepens Old Animosity
text: Two delegations of Japanese officials visited Palisades Park, N.J., this month with a request that took local administrators by surprise: The Japanese wanted a small monument removed from a public park.

headline: Prairie Dust
text: Near the end of “Wichita,” Thad ­Ziolkowski’s first novel, the protagonist recalls a line from Rilke: “You are not surprised at the force of the storm — you have seen it growing.” It’s a passing reference; the character, Lewis, neither dwells on the line nor mentions the poem it comes from, “Onto a Vast Plain.” But Ziolkowski is an accomplished poet, and it’s not hard to see Rilke’s great poem about grief as the secret heart beating through this charming, smart and ­devastating book.

headline: Manageable Discontents
text: As we should all know by now, Jonathan Franzen is a serious writer who plays for the highest literary stakes, who is uncomfortable with American TV consumerism, and whose last two novels, “The Corrections” and “Freedom,” have legitimately catapulted him to the front ranks of American fiction. Less known is that he has also published three nonfiction books, “How to Be Alone” (essays), “The Discomfort Zone” (a short memoir) and, now, a second essay collection, “Farther Away.”

headline: America’s Team
text: Ben Fountain was the lead subject in a 2008 New Yorker article by Malcolm Gladwell about “late bloomers.” Whereas the precocious likes of Jonathan Safran Foer had books published practically the moment they got out of college, Fountain’s first collection of stories, “Brief Encounters With Che Guevara,” did not appear until he was 48, in 2006. Now, six years later, comes a novel that, appropriately enough, takes a while to bloom.

headline: Perilous Crossing
text: Next time you find yourself grousing when the passenger in front reclines his seat a smidge too far, consider the astronomers of the Enlightenment. In 1761 and 1769, dozens and dozens of stargazers traveled thousands of miserable miles to observe a rare and awesome celestial phenomenon. They went by sailing ship and open dinghy, by carriage, by sledge and on foot. They endured discomfort that in our own flabby century would generate years of litigation. And they did it all for science: the men in powdered wigs and knee britches were determined to measure the transit of Venus.

headline: Letter to My Father
text: “Oblivion” is a searing memoir written with love and blood: both family blood, the kind that’s thicker than water, and the spilled blood of barbarism and murder. From the first pages we feel the internal necessity driving this story. It is obvious that Héctor Abad had no choice but to tell it — as a personal catharsis, surely, but also as a reckoning with his country, Colombia, and its near-perpetual state of violent strife. “I draw out these memories from within,” Abad tells us, “as one gives birth, as one removes a tumor.”

headline: Silver Linings
text: On the cover of “Inseminating the Elephant,” Lucia Perillo’s 2009 book of poems, minimal brush strokes form what look like four legs and one red trunk with the overlapping color patterns of Cézanne and a few dribbled lines of a Pollock. The painter is in fact Jojo the elephant, “a sweet-tempered, tuskless bull” who had been painting for 11 years at the time of the book’s publication. He also plays harmonica in the Thai Elephant Orchestra.

headline: Up Front
text: When Poets & Writers Magazine interviewed Phillip Lopate a few years ago, it cited his well-deserved reputation as “one of the most important essayists of our time.” But Lopate himself originally wanted to be a novelist or poet, he told us via e-mail. “It took me a while to fall in love with essays,” he said. “Then I saw that I could combine story­telling and character from fiction, and associative leaps and consciousness tracking from poetry, and put them all together in one flexible form. In my early 30s I stumbled on the great 19th-century English essayist William Hazlitt, who turned me on to Charles Lamb and Michel de Montaigne, and from that point I was hooked.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE CONFLICT: How Modern Motherhood Undermines the Status of Women,  by Elisabeth Badinter. Translated by Adriana Hunter. (Metropolitan/Holt, $25.) A French feminist philosopher argues forcefully that women must avoid excessive child-centeredness.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SWIM BACK TO ME,  by Ann Packer. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) Packer’s novels, “Songs Without Words” and “The Dive From Clausen’s Pier,” confront loss head-on. In this piercing collection of stories, characters struggle against devastation: the broken promise of a second marriage, the resurfacing of old family wounds, the death of a nearly grown child.

headline: Inside the List
text: HORSE RACE: Toni Morrison’s novel “Home” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 9. The book takes place in the 1950s, which is around the time that Morrison (or Chloe Wofford, as she was still known) started thinking seriously about race relations in this country, according to a recent profile in the British newspaper The Guardian. In the late ’40s, as a freshman at Howard University in segregated Washington, D.C., Morrison saw news footage of white mothers in the South trying to overturn a school bus with black children inside. “I didn’t know if I could turn over a bus full of little white kids,” Morrison said. “I didn’t know if I could feel that . . . fury. And I tried very hard to. This is what I did: I said suppose . . . horses began to speak. And began to demand their rights. Now, I’ve ridden horses. They’re very good workers. They’re very good racehorses. Suppose they just . . . want more. Suppose they want to go to school! Suppose they want to sit next to me in the theater. I began to feel this sense of — ‘I like you, but . . . ’; ‘You’re good, but. . . . ’ Suppose they want to sleep with my children?!” Morrison laughed. “I had to go outside the species! But it worked, I could feel it. You know; don’t sit next to me.”

headline: A Close-Up for the Juvenile Hawks
text: The red-tailed hawks of Washington Square Park now resemble the regal hawks they will become.

headline: For Facebook, No Division of the Spoils
text: For a moment there a few months ago, it looked as if Facebook‘s initial public offering might be derailed or at least troubled by angry users demanding a cut of the loot. After all, they literally built the site with their photos and updates. Facebook would be nothing without them. Why shouldn’t they get some of the $100 billion the company was going to be worth? Google had much less claim to have been created by its users but it nevertheless sold its shares in a Dutch auction, allowing ordinary geeks to get in on the action. Facebook could at least do as much, it seemed.

headline: Since the Opening Curtain, a Question: Is Willy Loman Jewish?
text: A Yiddish play with the title “Toyt fun a Salesman” opened at the Parkway Theater in Brooklyn early in 1951. As most of the audience recognized from the name alone, the show was a translation of Arthur Miller’s drama “Death of a Salesman.” It seemed a mere footnote to the premiere production, which had completed its triumphal run on Broadway several months earlier, having won the Pulitzer Prize.

headline: Guatemala-U.S. World Cup Qualifier on PPV Only
text: There may be more live soccer games on television available in the United States than nearly any other place in the world, but the United States World Cup qualifying match at Guatemala on June 12 will not be one of them — unless you are willing to stick a crowbar in your pocket and pull out $29.95 for a pay-per-view only telecast.

headline: Business Day Live | May 18, 2012
text: An interview with David Kirkpatrick, author of "The Facebook Effect". | Why initial public offerings catch the public imagination. | James B. Stewart takes a critical eye to the hype.

headline: A New View for the Hawk Cam
text: As the baby hawks of Washington Square Park prepare to take flight, we’ve adjusted the Hawk Cam to maximize the view of the ledge on which they’re nesting. Boo and Scout, who hatched April 9 and 10, no longer resemble the helpless bobble-headed fuzzballs that first appeared on screen. Their white downy coats have been replaced with chocolate brown feathers, giving them more of the likeness of their regal parents.

headline: Business Day Live: The Facebook Hype
text: An interview with David Kirkpatrick, author of “The Facebook Effect.” | Why initial public offerings catch the public imagination. | James B. Stewart takes a critical eye to the hype.

headline: Mission Chinese Food Arrives Next Week
text: One of the year’s most anticipated openings in New York — a branch of Danny Bowien’s wildly popular San Francisco restaurant Mission Chinese Food — is now set for Tuesday. And like the West Coast original, the new outpost on the Lower East Side will break a number of rules.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/18: Medellín’s Revival and a Concert for Delayed Travelers
text: Flight Delay=Free Concert An Air Canada flight bound for Romania was delayed. Luckily, some of the passengers happened to be members of Lemon Bucket Orkestra, who describe themselves as a “Balkan–Klezmer–Gypsy-Punk-Super-Party-Band.” The 20-minute delay soon became an impromptu concert. (Consumerist)

headline: Times Square, 9:30 A.M.
text: The Facebook I.P.O. stops traffic in Times Square.

headline: Psychiatry Giant Sorry for Backing Gay ‘Cure’
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — The simple fact was that he had done something wrong, and at the end of a long and revolutionary career it didn’t matter how often he’d been right, how powerful he once was, or what it would mean for his legacy.

headline: Acura Recalls 53,000 TL Sedans for Leaking Power-Steering Hoses
text: In a news release sent earlier this week, Honda said its Acura luxury division would recall nearly 53,000 of its 2007-8 TL sports sedans because over time, the power-steering hose “may deteriorate,” causing it to leak.

headline: A Rolling Room With a View
text: Scenes from an RV trip, featuring hot springs, high-fives and a doggie swimsuit competition.

headline: Overnight in the Parking Lot
text: During a road trip in the West, a night at Hotel Walmart.

headline: Stop. Snap. Move. Repeat for, Oh, 10 or 20 Years.
text: FOR the last seven years, John Frame has been working on a film in his home in Wrightwood, Calif. Its cast includes a cockeyed skeleton, a bespectacled monkey and a horned man sporting a cloak adorned with eyeballs. Mr. Frame made all of the characters himself out of wood and found objects, built the sets, even composed the score. When he discovered that his characters were going “wherever they wanted to go,” he let them. For the first four years of the project, he worked completely alone, driven by what may have been a muse or “daemons,” he’s unsure which; not even his closest friends and colleagues knew what he was up to.

headline: Just Me and My RV
text: I HAVE spent the night in a Walmart parking lot. I have driven through a national park with a trail of cars in my rearview mirror. I have learned how to dispose of my waste through a plastic hose, and I have filled my gas tank more times in one week than I thought was possible.

headline: Big ‘Oil,’ in Big Pictures
text: The Photographer’s Gallery reopens this weekend in London, completing an 18-month renovation, and its main exhibit is Edward Burtynsky’s  13-years-and-counting project “Oil.” More than 30 large-scale prints will be on display.

headline: Now Online | T Travel Summer 2012
text: The summer travel issue of T kicks off in Oslo, Scandinavia’s next capital of cool, with the city’s model-movie star couple as our guide. Next stop is the French department of the Gers, where the joie de vivre includes plenty of Armagnac and foie gras. And then we make merry with the fife and drum players of Mississippi hill country as they celebrate one of America’s oldest forms of music. Between stops, we take the pulse in a remarkably resilient Bangkok, check into London’s latest hotels and have a romp through Sicily’s hot spots. And for a little reading along the way, Abraham Verghese heads to his ancestral homeland of Kerala, India, and Joyce Maynard says goodbye to Lake Atitlàn, Guatemala, reminding us of the importance of seeking out one’s happy place, even if you have to let it go. See more from the issue >>

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Free Flight Into the Wordless’
text: This poem, one of 11 winners of our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Vick, who is 25 years old and lives in Nottingham, England.

headline: The Cartoon That Taught Indians The Meaning of “Many”
text: For the generation that grew up in India in the 1980s, television was synonymous with Doordarshan, the national broadcaster. In the absence of cable television, which came to India a decade later, children grew up with limited television programs. This meant that their appetite for cartoons had to be satiated with the weekend staple of “Spider-Man,” “He-Man and the Masters of the Universe” and “The Mickey and Donald Show.”

headline: Kanye West and Marilyn Manson Take Films to Cannes
text: The Cannes Film Festival is typically regarded as a celebration of moviemaking in its purest form and a launching pad for films that might otherwise challenge or baffle mainstream tastes, like “V Tumane (In the Fog)” or “Madagascar 3: Europe’s Most Wanted.” But if you just want to gawk at celebrities and see rock and hip-hop stars out of their musical contexts, Cannes can provide that, too.

headline: A Bar Mitzvah, With Autism
text: It should be interesting.

headline: Romney Unveils First Ad of General Election
text: Mitt Romney unveiled a series of television ads in English and Spanish on Friday, kicking off his campaign’s general election advertising effort with a short and straightforward commercial that lays out what “President Romney” would accomplish on his first day in office.

headline: 10 Views From the Road
text: Take a trip from California to Vermont and explore some of America’s top drives.

headline: 10 Correspondents, 10 Drives
text: The bureau chiefs and national correspondents of The New York Times work from offices in 14 cities across the country, and report from all 50 states. The work requires a great deal of driving. The reporters have bureau cars with extra rations packed into the trunks in case they have to stay where they are going for a while. They carry water bottles and spare batteries and extra notebooks and underwear, energy bars and a suit in case there’s a chance to meet a governor. They drive and they observe and they eat and they buy and they report. Then they drive again. These are some of their favorite stretches of road.   — SAM SIFTON, National Editor

headline: Tunes for the Road
text: We asked a group of critics and reporters who cover music for The Times about their go-to tunes for road trips. Here is a selection of their picks.

headline: Where Garrison Keillor Gets ‘Carried Away’
text: GARRISON KEILLOR, 69, has been roaming the country with his traveling radio show “A Prairie Home Companion,” for nearly 40 years. Below he answers questions about the America he’s known.

headline: Evernote Will Go Slow on an I.P.O.
text: TOKYO – Amid the frenzy over Facebook’s long-awaited initial public offering, a question has emerged: Which Internet darling might go public next?

headline: My Car, My Sanctuary
text: ON Monday, the wind blew so hard that only a fool would have ventured near the rim of the canyon. On Tuesday, a sandstorm colored the sky the yellow of motel linoleum and left a film of grit in your mouth. By Wednesday, I was properly stir crazy, and so when I stepped out into a cold Arizona morning of cerulean skies and the medicinal smell of sage, I got into my car and, for no particular reason, decided to hit the road.

headline: When Your Guru Calls Shotgun
text: BY the time we reached the first rest stop, a Burger King in Cle Elum, in central Washington State, I was suffering two anxieties: That I would kill the guru, and that if I didn’t, he would ignore me for the next 3,000 miles.

headline: Letters to the Travel Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Easy China, Through Three Doors” (May 6): China is well worth the visit, but take it from a nearly six-year resident — personal habits evolve more slowly than living standards, and you should be ready for some boorish, self-centered behavior. Hawking and spitting, line-breaking, pushing, bewildering driving, cellphone screaming, unsanitary food preparation, shouting in stores, poor service, shameless staring, smoking in nonsmoking zones (including elevators), yelling and slamming doors in hotel hallways late into the night — these are day-to-day pitfalls on the mainland, including Shanghai and Beijing. Hong Kong feels more refined but not as authentic — call it China Lite. Best advice: maintain your sense of humor and awareness of the country’s dense population and difficult history and get ready for a fascinating trip.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: In 2008, this paper published a story about Joyce Maynard’s house on a lake in Guatemala. It was an “escape from all that” story, a celebration of the ability to start one’s life anew in midlife with limited means but abundant vigor. Friends of mine, trapped in their aging urban routines, still refer to the story, four years on, when fantasizing about the lives not led. It was that intoxicating.

headline: In the Undoing of a C.E.O., a Puzzle
text: When the activist shareholder Daniel Loeb confronted Yahoo’s directors on May 3 with the possibility that Yahoo’s recently hired chief executive, Scott Thompson, might have falsified his résumé by claiming to have a computer science degree, their initial reaction was disbelief. “Scott is a forthright, no-nonsense, straightforward personality and a likable guy,” one director said.

headline: At 71, an Olympian Again
text: The Japanese equestrian Hiroshi Hoketsu, who is 71, will likely be the oldest Olympian competing in the London Games this summer and is one of the oldest Olympians ever to compete. He was the oldest athlete in the 2008 Beijing Games and is currently training in Germany in dressage. He was interviewed by phone.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Joe Klein talks about Jonah Goldberg’s “The Tyranny of Clichés”; Jeff Shesol discusses Eric Alterman’s history of liberalism from the New Deal to the present; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: New Classroom Science Standards Up for Review
text: The first substantial update to national science teaching standards in roughly 15 years — and the first including the science of human-driven climate change — is open for public comment through this month. Here’s a short video description:

headline: U.N. Nuclear Chief Will Go to Iran, Elevating Talks
text: The United Nations nuclear monitoring agency said on Friday that its leader would travel to Iran on Sunday for a meeting with the country’s top nuclear negotiator. The unexpected development signaled that both sides had stepped up both the urgency of resolving their dispute and the seniority of the officials doing the negotiating.

headline: Facebook Engineers Hack the Nasdaq Button
text: David Garcia, a senior software engineer at Facebook, says a small group of Facebook engineers hacked into the Nasdaq button that Mark Zuckerberg pressed to begin trading in the stock so that it would automatically update Mr. Zuckerberg’s Facebook status when he pushed it. In a guest blog post on TechCrunch, Mr. Garcia explains how it happened.

headline: Stream of Thoughts
text: Facebook is getting the headlines, but don’t forget about that other wildly popular social network, Twitter. Follow what Twitter users are saying about Facebook’s initial public offering.

headline: A Half-Century-Old Road to Today
text: IF there is such a thing as a visionary time capsule, the newly released boxed set of “Route 66” is it. Watch these discs (from Shout! Factory) and you are transported back to a version of the United States that was still basking in postwar success, a country rich in blue-collar jobs and industrial production and somewhat oblivious to its problems. But while enjoying that return to America as it was, you may also be struck by how often this half-century-old black-and-white television series tackled issues that seem very 21st century.

headline: A Man Who Creates Coincidences
text: ON a recent Saturday afternoon in New York, Diplo, the Los Angeles D.J. and producer, was in a bar on the top floor of the Standard hotel, reminiscing about being arrested. He had been invited to New York last year to work with Beyoncé. The first day had gone well.

headline: Idealistic Lawmen Taking Crime Very Personally
text: The Big Heat

headline: Songs From the Border and the Clouds
text: The Royalty

headline: For Cal Softball, Another Chance at a Title
text: Last season, the stars aligned for the Arizona State softball team. The Sun Devils began the year ranked No. 10 in the nation, steadily climbed to the No. 1 spot, and defeated Florida to win the 2011 Women’s College World Series.

headline: Guest Post | Teenager Writes About ‘Crushing Weight of College Debt’
text: This week, The Times is publishing a series on student debt that includes articles, video and interactive graphics, as well as an invitation to write in to tell about how student debt has affected your life. On Tuesday, we published a lesson plan full of ideas for using the series in the classroom.

headline: Paying for Robo-Calls
text: Say you buy a new cell phone, and immediately start getting robo-calls from a debt collector. You’re not the intended recipient of the calls—they’re for the deadbeat who owned the number before you—but several times a day a pre-recorded message insists you pay off a credit card loan, or an electric bill.

headline: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, Lyrical and Powerful Baritone, Dies at 86
text: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, the German baritone whose beautiful voice and mastery of technique made him the 20th century’s pre-eminent interpreter of art songs, died on Friday at his home in Bavaria. He was 86.

headline: Facebook Closes at $38.23, Nearly Flat on Day
text: 4:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: On Our Radar: Tackling the Tsunami Debris
text: Senators from Western states grill a NOAA official about his agency’s plans to deal with debris from Japan’s 2011 tsunami that is washing up in the United States. He replies that the agency lacks the funds for a cleanup and that the work will probably fall to individual states. [ABC News]

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Friday is the last day of City Harvest’s “Skip Lunch Fight Hunger” campaign, which raises money to feed hungry children and their families. Participants can make donations online.

headline: Lady Gaga Shows Prompt Protest in Philippines
text: Scores of Christian youths protested against Lady Gaga in Manila on Friday, calling for her concerts there to be canceled because they object to her sexually charged lyrics and skimpy costumes, The Associated Press reported.

headline: In Prague, a Beer Festival Branches Out
text: Since its founding in 2008, the Czech Beer Festival has become an instant classic, the largest beer event in a country that drinks more beer per capita than anywhere else. But for this year’s celebration, taking place through June 2, visitors can expect several changes.

headline: Off the Charts: The Older the Worker, the Better
text: Employment for traditional working-age Americans remains well below where it was at the end of 2006, before the economy began to weaken. But the proportion of older Americans with jobs has risen, as baby boomers put off retirement or return to the work force.

headline: The Beast in the Big Easy
text: After Flag Officer David Farragut captured New Orleans in April 1862, Maj. Gen. Benjamin F. Butler occupied the city at the head of some 10,000 Union soldiers. That Butler should be in charge of the Union occupation of the South’s largest city is surprising: a former member of the Massachusetts State Senate, he had been chosen as a delegate to the 1860 Democratic National Convention, where he voted 57 times to nominate then-Senator Jefferson Davis for president, on the belief that only a Southern moderate could keep the party from splitting.

headline: Van Halen Postpones Dozens of Tour Dates
text: It appears that all is not right inside the classic rock band Van Halen.  The veteran rockers announced late Thursday that they were postponing more than 30 dates on their current tour to promote their new album, “A Different Kind of Truth,” The Associated Press and CNN reported.

headline: Spying Balloons as Artistic Muse
text: Some stories strike a chord with readers. And these days it is easy to share your thoughts on most of the things we publish here on The New York Times Web site. Most of that feedback comes in the form of comments — the letters to the editor of the modern era. But one story out of Afghanistan published last week inspired a different kind of tribute. It started with a story by Graham Bowley, who wrote about spy dirigibles, white surveillance balloons, called aerostats by the military, which have become constant features in the skies over Kabul and Kandahar, and anywhere else American troops are concentrated or interested in. Mr. Bowley writes:

headline: Image of the Day: May 18
text: A man pierced his tongue with a thin rod in protest in New Delhi.

headline: Video: This Week’s Movies, May 18
text: In today’s edition of “This Week’s Movies,” The Times critics look at a big-budget blockbuster, a low-budget indie and a star-driven comedy. Neil Genzlinger reviews “Battleship,” the action film loosely based on the board game. And A. O. Scott looks at both “The Color Wheel,” a black-and-white road movie, and “What to Expect When You’re Expecting,” an ensemble comedy based on Heidi Murkoff’s best-selling book. Our critics’ full reviews of the films can be found here.

headline: Should You Talk Puberty With a Stepdaughter?
text: How, D. asks, should I talk with my almost 10-year-old stepdaughter about puberty?

headline: Navigating New Trenches After a Breakup
text: SOME years ago, when I was living in Britain, I received an e-mail from a college friend who had recently announced her first pregnancy. “We have become good friends with a black/white couple,” she wrote. “They have a precious baby boy — you and Dan are going to have the cutest kids!”

headline: The Sweet Spot | Future of Television
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott wonder whether TV is still TV — and where it is going.

headline: What Will President Obama Say?
text: Mitt Romney is decidedly unpopular. Polling by the Times and CBS News shows his approval rating languishing at around 30 percent. Other polls show voters think President Obama is more likely to have good ideas about improving the economy than Mr. Romney.

headline: Soba With Green Garlic, Spinach, Edamame and Crispy Tofu
text: Green garlic and luscious spinach are both in abundance in the markets right now. If you can’t find soba (buckwheat noodles), you can serve the stir-fry with brown rice or other grains.

headline: Naming Her World, Part by Part
text: As a child growing up in a tiny, German-speaking village in Romania, on the edge of Transylvania, Herta Müller was assigned chores that included herding cows. Out in the pastures with little to do, she amused herself by giving names and personalities to the flowers she collected and the clouds that drifted by, or imagined a future as a seamstress, like her aunt, or perhaps as a hairdresser.

headline: Northwestern Takes Game Directly to Eastern Recruits
text: The Northwestern women’s lacrosse team traveled to Stony Brook, N.Y., last spring and won its sixth national title in seven years. Even though the Wildcats were more than 800 miles from their campus in Evanston, Ill., the stands were filled with young girls sporting their team’s colors.

headline: Trial Vaccine Made Some More Vulnerable to H.I.V., Study Confirms
text: A follow-up study on an AIDS vaccine trial that had to be stopped early has confirmed the worst fears of researchers: The vaccine made it more likely, not less, that some men would become infected with H.I.V.

headline: Friday Flashback: Sometimes Being First Doesn’t Mean Victory
text: The Swedish modern pentathlete Hans-Gunnar Liljenwall was once a fixture on the international scene. He competed in three Olympics–1964, 1968 and 1972–in the team and individual divisions. He was a middle-of-the-pack finisher in the individual event, but was a good contributor to the Swedish team effort.

text: Sansepolcro, Italy, received a distinguished visitor Friday.

text: Last Updated | Monday, 7:45 a.m. Two of China’s largest Internet companies are urging users to help crack down on “misbehaving foreigners,” the state-run People’s Daily reported on Friday, after a high-profile case of sexual assault by a British man in Beijing last week and amid a push by the authorities to rein in foreigners illegally in the country.

headline: Look of The Moment | Natalia Vodianova
text: The Look: Dolled up. A pleated mini takes a prim spin with the addition of a crocheted pilgrim collar.

headline: Some European Companies Try Bonds to Raise Cash
text: Among the midsize, family-owned companies that power the German economy, it has long been an article of faith: credit comes from the friendly local banker, not from cold and distant capital markets.

headline: Mexico Holds 4 High-Ranking Army Officers
text: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican government detained three high-ranking army generals this week, including a former second in command at the Defense Ministry, suggesting the depths to which drug cartels have gone in trying to infiltrate one of the primary forces President Felipe Calderón has counted on to combat them.

headline: Your Favorite Road Trips
text: For our annual U.S. issue, our theme is the open road. We asked a selection of national correspondents for their favorite routes, Guy Trebay discussed the joys of driving, and the Frugal Traveler shared his budget-friendly journey in the South. Now we want to hear about your favorite road trips. Share your favorite trips in the comments section below, or on Twitter, using the hashtag #faveroadtrip; we’ll collect our favorite tweets and post them on this blog.

headline: Presidential Job Records
text: Since former President Bush is going to favor us with a book on How to Succeed in Economic Policy Without Really Trying — and since Mitt Romney is essentially planning a return to Bushonomics — it might be worth looking at Bush’s job record compared with that of Obama so far. I focus on private-sector jobs because both Bush and Romney say that the government can’t create jobs, so only the private sector is real.

headline: Video: The Sweet Spot — The Future of Television
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott wonder whether TV is still TV — and where it is going.

headline: Jets Add Depth at Safety By Signing Bell
text: The Jets continued their off-season overhaul at safety Friday, signing the veteran Yeremiah Bell to a one-year deal worth $1.4 million. Bell, who spent the previous eight seasons with the Miami Dolphins, provides the Jets with a durable, in-the-box safety who is regarded more for his run defense than his pass coverage.

headline: The Plan for Greece
text: As we contemplate the Greek debacle, it’s worth looking at what was supposed to happen even if voters went along with the program. Here, from the IMF World Economic Outlook database, are projections for debt and unemployment under the program that’s now collapsing; and since unemployment has already spiked well above the forecast, we know that this was way overoptimistic. Anyway, this is what “responsible” policy is supposed to deliver:

headline: A Facebook Drop for Zynga, Other Social Stocks

headline: Delicate, Buttery Flounder With Green Garlic
text: UNTIL the culinary revolution began in the 1970s, there were two types of fine-dining restaurants in San Francisco. One served a kind of cuisine called Continental. Vaguely European and intentionally fancy, the food arrived from the kitchen beneath polished silver domes, accompanied by rich sauces in silver sauce boats, and occasionally by tableside theatrics performed by waiters in red dinner jackets.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $52.5 Million
text: A 30-room co-op spread over two floors at 740 Park Avenue sold for $52.5 million, the biggest sale of the week, according to city records, and the most ever paid for a co-op apartment.

headline: Green Garlic Says Spring
text: Let’s talk a little about green garlic. In this week’s City Kitchen column it shows up in a butter sauce for fish, but it is so wonderfully versatile, there are hundreds of other ways to use it. In fact, nearly anything you can do with regular garlic, you can do with green garlic; the result, however, will be milder, sweeter, fresher-tasting and more subtle.

headline: Barney Frank Says Secret Service Is Not on Wedding Guest List
text: Representative Barney Frank is getting married in July to his partner, Jim Ready, and he says that the president is not invited to the wedding. It is nothing personal; it is the Secret Service. Mr. Frank says that the hard-partying agents are actually party poopers.

headline: For Arab Lesbians, a Place to Dance Freely
text: AN unusually cold May evening left much of Greenwich Village looking abandoned, but inside Henrietta Hudson, Arabian desert rhythms were entrancing patrons. The lesbian bar was hosting the inaugural Banaat, the female offshoot of the gay Arab dance event Habibi.

headline: Dreve.me
text: Business Strategist Carol Roth evaluates an illustrative pitch for a technology start-up.

headline: The Heat Without Bosh? Not Good
text: Since LeBron James joined the Heat, the characterization of Miami as the league’s most imposing “Big Three” has morphed from a truism into a label of mere convenience. As such, the Heat is often seen as a flawed juggernaut featuring two indispensible pieces – LeBron and Dwyane Wade, a “Big Two” if ever there was one – and one formidable third wheel: Chris Bosh.

headline: Reaching Out to Avoid Someone, Like a Telemarketer or a Politician
text: WE were having dinner at a friend’s house the other week and her phone rang. She came back annoyed, reporting that it was a telemarketing call.

headline: Hollande Tells Obama Troop Pullout Will Proceed
text: WASHINGTON — François Hollande used his first visit with President Obama as France’s president on Friday to restate his pledge to withdraw combat forces from Afghanistan by the end of the year, two years earlier than originally planned.

headline: Diaw’s Playmaking Gives Spurs a New Dimension
text: When discussing the versatility of new-era big men, we often focus on the most immediate and obvious differences between today’s sweet-shooting bigs and the giants of yore: the space on the court that they occupy, and the range from which they can score. The new wave, led by Kevin Garnett and Dirk Nowitzki, shuffled any big men with a soft touch out to mid-range and beyond, and whether you choose to lament the lack of low-post threats in today’s N.B.A. or admire the innovation of the current generation, analytical conversations on the subject are tethered to scoring range and type. This often comes with a casual disregard for the ball skills and defensive flexibility that make the contemporary crop so interesting.

headline: Franchise Success Means Doing Things the Franchiser’s Way
text: FRANCHISES would be at the top of any list of investments people consider a sure bet. After all, the thinking goes, an entrepreneur is buying into an existing company and opening an outlet where none exists. Surely, the money will just pour in.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Loyola (Men) and Loyola (Women) Play for Final Four Spots
text: The Loyola Greyhounds lacrosse program exercised some postseason demons last weekend as both the men and women advanced to the quarterfinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

text: The Rail’s contributors welcome this year’s Preakness Stakes guest picker, the actress Bo Derek. Derek, a longtime horse racing fan, is a member of the California Horse Racing Board.

headline: Facebook Wins Oregon Tax Break
text: Facebook’s I.P.O. wasn’t the only thing to cheer about at Facebook. The company also got an important break in keeping its business profitable, by keeping its costs down.

headline: Remembering Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau
text: The German baritone, who died on Friday at 86, was the 20th century’s pre-eminent interpreter of art songs. Here are YouTube clips of some of his notable performances.

headline: Rebecca Creskoff and Michael Glassner
text: THEIR show, “Hung,” the HBO comedy series, had just wrapped for the season last spring, so when her co-star Anne Heche said they should go out for one last cocktail to celebrate before leaving Detroit, where they were filming, Rebecca Creskoff could hardly refuse.

headline: A ‘Fracked’ Photograph
text: On Thursday, I stumbled on the photograph at right on the blog of Mark Graf, a nature photographer from the Detroit area. Much of his work is conventional scenic imagery of wild places. But Graf also occasionally creates intriguing abstract photographs by zooming in tightly on polished surfaces of rocks and minerals. I find the results reminiscent of the work of Bill Atkinson, a programmer from the early days of Apple (MacPaint was his creation) who in recent years has produced extraordinary photography in this same way. (I wrote short prose pieces to accompany some of the images in his book, “Within the Stone.”)

headline: How Do We Think About a Mother’s Suicide?
text: Are you thinking about the four children Mary Kennedy left behind on Wednesday? I am — or, I should say, we are. It’s the kind of topic that it’s hard not to bring up, quietly, while dropping the children off at school or with other parents at work.

headline: Desormeaux Loses Preakness Mount After Failing Breathalyzer Test
text: BALTIMORE – The Hall of Fame jockey Kent Desormeaux was taken off his mounts at Belmont Park on Friday after he failed a breathalyzer test.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Starkly Different Views of American Liberals
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Joe Klein and Jeff Shesol review two very different books about American liberalism. Mr. Klein reviews Jonah Goldberg’s “The Tyranny of Clichés: How Liberals Cheat in the War of Ideas,” an argument about the misuses of political rhetoric by liberals. Mr. Klein writes that, “At his best, Goldberg’s erudition can entertain and enlighten,” but that the book focuses too much on irrelevant phrases and not enough on the substance of debates about policy. “[Mr. Goldberg is] more interested in style than substance,” Mr. Klein writes, “and there is a smarty-pants sloppiness that infects even his most astute moments.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 18
text: Subjects include the space shuttle Enterprise, falling tree limbs and a subway portrait artist.

headline: Memories of Donna’s Disco Nights
text: IN 1975, a 26-year-old singer who called herself Donna Summer floated onto the scene with “Love to Love You Baby.” Produced by the Italian disco pioneer Giorgio Moroder, it became a sensation, 17 minutes of a woman oohing and aahing as if in a state of ecstasy.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Hopkins Vs. Maryland (Chapter 109)
text: The most storied rivalry in college lacrosse continues. On the heels of their 19-9 first-round win over Stony Brook, second-seeded Johns Hopkins (12-3) will now meet Maryland (10-5) in the N.C.A.A. tournament quarterfinals on Saturday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from New York, Lebanon, Yemen and the West Bank.

headline: Facebook vs. Start-Ups
text: Facebook’s transformation from an idea born in a dorm room to a company valued at more than $100 billion is the fantasy of any wannabe entrepreneur. But the company’s successes will very likely influence its peers and generations of companies to come.

headline: Vows at 20: Mimi and Sheldon Toney

headline: Celebrity Couplings 20 Years Ago
text: In 1992, the year The New York Times started the Vows column in Sunday Styles, several notable couples wed.

headline: Planning Meets Serendipity
text: WHEN the Vows column first appeared two decades ago, it marked a sharp — even startling — break from the traditional coverage of marriages found everywhere, including in this newspaper.

headline: When Garlic Goes Green
text: Garlic is typically harvested in the middle of the summer, and the result is a familiar bulb of segmented cloves that we typically see in supermarkets. But shoppers at farmers’ markets may come across green garlic, which has been harvested early, before the cloves have matured. It looks more like a scallion and has a mild, juicy flavor, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: In the Postseason, Rangers Players Lead the Salary Parade
text: Of the 35 highest-salaried players in the N.H.L. this season, only 3 are still playing in the postseason, and they are all Rangers: Brad Richards, who made $12 million this season and is currently the highest-paid player in the league; Marian Gaborik ($7.5 million, tied for 18th); and Henrik Lundqvist ($6.875 million, 31st). The next highest-salaried player still skating this spring, according to figures provided by capgeek.com, is Mike Richards of Los Angeles ($6.6 million, tied for 36th).

headline: Virtual Reality Goes to School
text: THE blistering pace of advances in automotive technology may be confusing to consumers, but it seems to be creating a strong employment outlook for those who fix cars.

headline: Cramming for Degrees in Hybrids
text: LIKE many college students, Katherine Bovee, a master’s degree candidate at Ohio State University in Columbus, struggled to find a focus for her undergraduate studies. Wanting to sample a broad range of possibilities, she enrolled in a mechanical engineering program.

headline: House Vote Upholds Indefinite Detention of Terror Suspects
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday turned back an unusual coalition of liberals and conservatives and voted down legislation to reject explicitly the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects apprehended on United States soil.

headline: Facebook vs. Twitter

text: As a programming concept, a piano recital focusing on the theme-and-variations genre may not be that novel. But the distinguished pianist Emanuel Ax found a fascinating way to explore the idea in his exciting recital at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

text: BERLIN — A telephone conversation on Friday between Germany’s chancellor and Greece’s president became the latest flashpoint in the war of words between Berlin and Athens in the unfolding crisis over Greece’s membership in the euro.

text: Testing the 2012 Prius C, Toyota’s latest addition to its expanding family of hybrids, on a meandering cruise through and around San Francisco.

headline: W.P.S.: Gone, but Not Lost
text: When I read the official news today about W.P.S., I did not first think of the teams that folded, the issues that arose along the way, or the lawsuit with Dan Borislow. I thought of how fortunate I was to be a part of something successful — a league that was home to many of the best players in the world, where soccer was our full-time job. I feel sad that this opportunity is no longer available to me and other elite female players.

headline: The Biggest I.P.O. Disruption: Rank-and-File Riches
text: Big tech offerings like Facebook’s always generate a lot of publicity for the top executives, who walk away with personal scores worth hundreds of millions, even billions, of dollars.

headline: Putin Reaches Down to the Assembly Line for First Appointment

headline: The Chelsea Flower Show Opens in London
text: From Tuesday to Saturday the Royal Horticultural Society Chelsea Flower Show will feature some of the world’s most beautifully designed gardens and floral and horticultural displays. Held on the 11-acre grounds of the Royal Hospital Chelsea in London, the event draws up to 157,000 visitors annually.

headline: A Whisper of Nuclear War Spurs a Sell-Off in a Russian Stock Market
text: MOSCOW — An unusually candid reference to nuclear war by Russia’s prime minister prompted a sell-off in the nation’s stock market this week, underscoring how nervous traders here have become about worsening relations with the West, a street protest movement in Moscow and an overall slump in emerging markets.

headline: The Vows Column at 20
text: LOVE may be blind, but marriage can blindside you. That is one lesson that I have taken away from decades of writing the Vows column, which marked its 20th anniversary in this section this month.

headline: Lovers Circling Maypole, Sometimes in Clogs
text: As people were leaving the Big Cinemas Manhattan theater on East 59th Street on Wednesday, a man turned to me and said, “I hope you enjoyed that as much as I did.” The screening had been a live broadcast of the Royal Ballet’s production of Frederick Ashton’s “Fille Mal Gardée,” at the Royal Opera House in London, and his remark brought back the many different combinations of joy and wonder that this ballet has given me over the decades. Could that man have enjoyed it as much as I?

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 18
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Stay or Go?
text: Facebook ended its first day of trading on Nasdaq with a value of $105 billion while JPMorgan Chase’s trading loss surged to at least $3 billion. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Eduardo Saverin’s Billionaire Blues

headline: Caustic Comedian Alters Italy’s Political Map

headline: Mothers in Search of a Child
text: It is a time-honored tradition in New York for visual-art critics to engage in blood sport with the Whitney Biennial. This year, thanks to the curators Jay Sanders and Elisabeth Sussman, who have largely given over the fourth floor to the performing arts, the rest of us can get in on the game.

text: Every Wednesday morning at 11 Eastern time, two experts play for an hour at bridgebase.com with juniors from around the world. These sessions are arranged by Valerie Westheimer of New York City and Paula Mittleman of Boynton Beach, Fla.

headline: The Number of Those Working Past 65 Is at a Record High

headline: Turning Yoga Into Art
text: Robert Sturman, an artist from Santa Monica, Calif., has traveled around the world painting and photographing landscapes, cityscapes, musicians, athletes and even a surfing rabbi. But it is the study of yoga that has triggered one of the most creative periods of his career, resulting in a series of stunning portraits that capture the beauty and poetry of asana, the repertory of postures included in the practice of yoga.

text: The Fox medical series starring Hugh Laurie wraps up on Monday.

text: Tom Sachs’s “Space Program: Mars” has landed in the Park Avenue Armory, and it seems to coincide with the fashion world’s hunger to find a new look for a new space age.

text: Franchise restaurants may offer less risk than a restaurant started from scratch, since they follow a formula that’s already been tested. But, as Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column, franchise investors need a bit of luck to succeed.

headline: Don’t Feed Wild Dolphins (Even if They Beg)
text: Tara Thean, a biology major at Princeton University, writes from Sarasota Bay in Florida, where she is studying signature whistle development in wild bottlenose dolphins.

text: At-home mothers are more likely than employed mothers to report feeling sad or angry and to have been diagnosed with depression, according to a new report by Gallup.

headline: Chic in Review | Next Gen
Joy, Hacking and Nostalgia on I.P.O. Day
text: Reporters weren’t allowed near the Facebook campus in Menlo Park, Calif., on Friday as Facebook shares were sold to the public on Wall Street. We could glean something of the mood from what Facebookers chose to post on their Facebook pages.

headline: Reviewing the Toyota Prius C
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Nick Czap reviews the 2012 Toyota Prius C, a lightweight hybrid hatchback that, in its first three days of availability, surpassed the February sales of both the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf.

headline: Getting to Retirement With Minimal Financial Risk
text: JPMorgan Chase’s giant trading loss began as an effort to manage the bank’s risks — a move that turned into something that now looks more like a speculative bet. But don’t think this is solely a big-bank problem. Even small investors can run into trouble discerning the fine line between hedging and risk taking.

headline: The Drummer Vanishes
text: 10:50 a.m. | Updated Anyone who has flipped through David King’s classic study of Soviet propaganda, “The Commissar Vanishes,” knows the power of images to shape history. The book collected dozens of examples of official photographs from the Stalin-era Soviet Union that had been retouched, sometimes repeatedly, to erase insiders who had fallen out of political favor.

headline: A Museum Turns Wind Into Gold
text: GOLDENDALE, Wash. — The big winds that rake this nearly treeless channel of the Columbia River Gorge lightened somewhat last weekend.

headline: Putting New York City’s Tech Jobs on the Map
text: As a part of Internet Week here in New York, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday unveiled the Made in NY Digital Map, an interactive map that shows where the city’s tech companies, investors and incubator spaces are. It’s an encouraging sight.

headline: Week in Pictures for May 18
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the space shuttle Enterprise, falling tree limbs and a subway portrait artist.

headline: A Drop in Fund-Raising for the Obama Campaign
text: President Obama’s campaign took in $25.7 million in April, a significant drop from March, according to records filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday afternoon.

headline: Managing the Risk in Your Investment Portfolio
text: Not only does JPMorgan’s trading debacle remind us that the big banks are still capable of making mistakes that could potentially do damage to all of our portfolios, it also provides another takeaway for smaller investors: it’s not always easy to distinguish between where measured risk taking stops and some form of gambling begins.

headline: 'Jesse Stone: Benefit of the Doubt'
text: This is the eighth television movie in which Tom Selleck portrays Jesse Stone.

headline: Nursing Drinks and Solving Crime in Paradise
text: Jesse Stone has survived a lot, including the death in 2010 of the novelist who created him, Robert B. Parker. He is back on Sunday in “Jesse Stone: Benefit of the Doubt,” the eighth television movie in which Tom Selleck portrays him.

headline: Facebook Buys Karma, a Gift-Giving App
text: If Facebook’s offering wasn’t enough, on Friday the social network decided to buy another company during its first day as a public company.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Relationship of an Artist and an Original Beatle
text: New to our graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week, at No. 7, is “Baby’s In Black,” which chronicles the relationship between the artist Astrid Kirchherr and Stuart Sutcliffe, the original bass player of The Beatles, who met in Hamburg during the earliest days of the band. The graphic novel, by the cartoonist Arne Bellstorf, is already a success in Germany, and does a wonderful job of capturing the small moments of everyday life. It feels authentic, no doubt thanks to the extensive input from Ms. Kirchherr. The illustrations, in black and white with sketchy gray tones, are, for the most part, warm and inviting. “Baby’s In Black” has a couple of drawbacks: all of Mr. Bellstorf’s faces have small swirls of gray on their cheeks. It’s easy enough to get used to, I suppose, but this graphic tic often makes the characters look dirty (is that a smudge?) or surprised (are they blushing?). For those who know their Beatles history, the ending will be a foregone conclusion, but the story was new to me and I found the handling of Mr. Sutcliffe’s death quite abrupt.

headline: City and Unions Agree That Hiring Can Begin for 24 Schools
text: The city can start hiring new teachers and administrators to fill positions at 24 schools that will be closed and reopened by September, under a deal reached with the teachers' and principals' unions and announced late Friday. An arbitrator, meanwhile, will work quickly to decide whether the city's shuffling of staff violates the unions' contract. If the city loses the arbitration, its new hiring can be reversed.

headline: Shouldering the Burden of College Debt
text: To the Editor:

headline: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Howie Rose
text: “Matteau! Matteau! Matteau!” Howie Rose cried out those words after Stephane Matteau scored in the second overtime of Game 7 of the 1994 Rangers-Devils series at Madison Square Garden. Eighteen years later, Rose announces Mets and Islanders games, but that call remains his signature moment, and one of the most famous play-by-play calls in hockey history.

headline: New Chef, New Decor, New-American Menu
text: IF first impressions count for much, the Hudson House, in Nyack, made a fine one on a balmy night early this month. Set before me by our sweet-natured waiter, a flute of brisk prosecco arrived with a tiny orange nasturtium bobbing on top. “You can eat that,” he said, smiling. I did, at once, and a peppery snap of flower power turned an everyday aperitif into a charming opening act.

text: To the Editor:
