text: To the Editor:

headline: You Will Get Wet; You May Get Soaked. And Skip the Sushi.
text: Beyond nudity and yelling — common ingredients in performance art — the reputation of Ann Liv Young is that she is ruthless, shameless and takes no prisoners. She may wear disguises, yet she never masks her impatience with the person running the sound or a fellow cast member, who often turns out to be her real-life partner, Michael A. Guerrero.

headline: Real Celebrity Families of California, North and South
text: Keeping up with the Kardashians got easier last year. Stretched over 16 episodes, the sixth season of the family’s flagship reality series on E! averaged just over 3 million viewers, down from 3.5 million the season before.

headline: Why Bambi Must Go
text: Williamsburg, Va.

headline: Clemens’s Lawyer Takes Aim at McNamee’s Credibility
text: WASHINGTON — When Roger Clemens’s perjury trial adjourned Friday, Brian McNamee, the government’s star witness in the case, looked drained. His face was expressionless and pale. His body language suggested that he could use a nap. No wonder.

headline: Free the Post Office!
text: In the short run, it’s not all that difficult to figure out how to stanch the bleeding at the United States Postal Service.

headline: A Laid-Back Island in a Sea of Chic
text: THE dining scene on the Connecticut shoreline has changed significantly in the nearly 20 years I have lived there. Ethnic and chic contemporary kitchens have replaced fried seafood restaurants and neighborhood Italian-American joints. Restaurants have reworked their menus to reflect upscale styles like the ubiquitous farm-to-table trend, and prices have risen accordingly.

headline: ‘Stay Classy,’ Crossroads Admonishes Obama Camp
text: Capping off two weeks of debate on whether adolescent bullying and a former pastor are fair game is the latest affront to political discourse: abbreviated cussing.

headline: Empanadas, With Flair
text: At the year-old Island Empanada in Lake Ronkonkoma, the 24 varieties on the menu include not only traditional fillings like beef, chicken and cheese, but also creative combinations including shrimp and mango salsa, nacho (refried beans and cheddar cheese) and chorizo potato.

headline: Brooklyn Prosecutor to Target Intimidation in Ultra-Orthodox Abuse Cases
text: The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, is setting up a panel of prosecutors and investigators to crack down on witness intimidation in child sexual abuse cases in the borough’s ultra-Orthodox Jewish community.

headline: Exotic Offerings Among the Kebabs
text: THE many kebabs on the menu at Choopan Grill in Hicksville may at first distract you from some of the more exotic Afghan treats served at the restaurant. But don’t overlook offerings like aush, a traditional soup; badinjan burani, a sautéed eggplant dish; and the dumplings, called aushak. They were among the highlights of our visits.

headline: Edwards Jury Retires for the Weekend
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — After five hours, the jury in the federal corruption trial of John Edwards went home for the weekend Friday, leaving few clues about how their deliberations are proceeding.

headline: American Accents Being Heard on the Malecón
text: HAVANA — In the echoing cobbled walkway of an 18th-century fort that is home to part of the 11th Havana Biennial, an insistent clang emanates from an artwork in which a bronze bird continually hits a boat propeller with its beak. Behind that noise floats the melody of a Cuban son  played by a trio. And then, above it all, comes another kind of sound: American voices, crying out in English, “Look at that!” and “I want you to see this!”

headline: Up Close and Personal, if Distant
text: The official title for the ritualistic, immersive, often breathtaking solo piano concert at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse on Thursday was “An Intimate Evening With Cecil Taylor.” Hmm, intimate —  I’m not so sure about that. True, there was a striking proximity to the audience in the performance, which had Mr. Taylor, the stouthearted patriarch of free-improvisation, seated at a Bosendorfer piano within seven or eight feet of the nearest listener. And yes, the sound in the room was vivid and pristine, with only the subtlest hint of amplification.

headline: On an R.O.V., Learning to Safely Navigate the Wilds of Randall’s Island
text: Notwithstanding a ride in a wayward hansom cab in Central Park, there are few opportunities for off-roading in Manhattan. This might explain why, earlier this week, I stood under a bridge on Randall’s Island, wearing calf-length boots, rain gear and a helmet. There were a half-dozen of us, including my wife, Dale, and three women from lifestyle and travel magazines, all there to saddle up and receive driver safety training for recreational off-road vehicles, or R.O.V.’s.

headline: Diverse, Innovative, and Now Outdoors
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

headline: With Natural Gas Plentiful and Cheap, Carbon Capture Projects Stumble
text: WASHINGTON — A federal proposal to ban the construction of coal-fired power plants that release all of their carbon dioxide into the atmosphere would seem to smooth the way for carbon capture, a budding technology that traps the greenhouse gas for storage or other uses.

headline: Blessed With a Talent That Offends His World
text: If you are unfamiliar with the actors in the excellent new Long Wharf production of “My Name Is Asher Lev,” just imagine Kevin Kline and Mary Beth Hurt as the parents and a very young Richard Thomas as their son. The cast sometimes evokes those colleagues of theirs. But do remember Ari Brand, who plays the title role, a boy in 1950s Brooklyn who horrifies his Hasidic Jewish parents and community by becoming an artist. And the kind of artist he becomes.

headline: U.N. Observers Dodge Bullets and Mockery in Syria
text: At the end of a week in which the unarmed military observers sent to Syria by the United Nations were bombed and shot, and witnessed the security forces beating protesters, the mission’s leader was forced to defend his team from the ridicule of Syrian protesters.

headline: Appeals Panel Weighs Question on Press Rights
text: RICHMOND, Va. — At least two members of a three-judge federal appeals court panel appeared to express some skepticism on Friday about prosecutors’ request that they overturn a district judge’s order protecting a journalist from being forced to identify his confidential sources in the trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency officer.

headline: Celebrating the Birth and Impact of Pollock
text: East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: Restoring a Bridge, and a Link Between Neighbors
text: Throughout Highbridge are proud new reminders of the landmark bridge that the southwest Bronx neighborhood is named after, like vibrant murals at the public library and history lessons in the schools.

headline: Ed Ray, Bus Driver During Kidnapping, Dies at 91
text: Ed Ray, the California school bus driver who was hailed as a hero in 1976 for leading 26 children to safety after they were kidnapped and buried below ground in a truck trailer, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Chowchilla, Calif. He was 91.

headline: NATO and Afghanistan
text: In advance of the NATO summit meeting on Afghanistan, American officials are claiming real progress in the fight against the Taliban. “Every day we’re gaining traction,” Gen. John Allen, the top commander in Afghanistan, told reporters last week. There is improvement, but we are skeptical that the situation is that encouraging.

headline: Rangers Forwards Are Doing It All in the Playoffs, Except Scoring
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Rangers forwards may be executing most duties required to win Stanley Cup playoff games — forechecking, blocking shots, throwing body checks — but they are foundering in the most significant aspect of the game, scoring goals.

text: MUNICH — To the rest of the world’s soccer fans, Saturday’s hotly anticipated match between Chelsea and Bayern Munich is the final of the Champions League, the top prize in European professional club soccer. Here in the capital of Bavaria it is known in the local dialect as the finale dahoam — the home final.

headline: With Lackluster Debut, Facebook Must Prove Itself to Investors

headline: With Dementia, Stepping Outside for Fresh Air Can Mean Going Astray
text: Irwin Goffman, an 83-year-old retired sociology professor, sat in the waiting room of an Upper West Side doctor’s office on Wednesday afternoon while his wife went in for a checkup. The couple had taken a train from Massachusetts; they moved there from Greenwich Village a year and a half ago, partly for the change of scenery after he left New York University. And partly because of what was happening to Mr. Goffman.

headline: A New Attack on the Constitution
text: On Wednesday, a federal judge struck down a law allowing the indefinite detention of anyone suspected of terrorism on American soil as a violation of free speech and due process. Two days later, the House made it clear it considered those to be petty concerns, voting to keep the repellent practice of indefinite detention on the books.

headline: Subway Car Is a Writers’ Workshop on the Way to Queens and Back

text: The Virginia Legislature disgraced itself last week, rejecting the nomination of Tracy Thorne-Begland, a widely respected prosecutor, to be the first openly gay judge on the Commonwealth bench. Mr. Thorne-Begland was the only one of 37 nominees denied appointment to district courts in the final minutes of the session.

headline: Nature in All Its Lushness, From an Urbanite’s Mind
text: HAMILTON, N.J. — THE sculptor Ming Fay was directing two assistants atop a hydraulic lift as they positioned his three-foot-tall pine cone on a ledge far above his head.

headline: For Some Mets, the Series in Toronto Will Be a Time to Rest
text: TORONTO — Last weekend in Miami, as his team prepared to embark on a stretch of 20 games in 20 days, Terry Collins circled the Mets’ three-game series in Toronto as an opportune time to get some of his regulars off their feet.

headline: The Sport of Kings and Drugs
text: At the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, racing fans will be watching to see if I’ll Have Another can duplicate its Kentucky Derby victory and claim the second leg of the Triple Crown. Attention should be focused no less on the horse’s trainer, Doug O’Neill, who has a troubled record of sanctions and penalties for administering illegal performance-enhancing concoctions that endanger racehorses.

headline: Reds Circle N.Y. on the Calendar and Make Themselves at Home

headline: Rancor Flaring as Funeral for a Kennedy Approaches
text: The body of Mary Richardson Kennedy, the estranged wife of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., was finally released by the authorities to a funeral home late Friday afternoon after the rancor that occurred in the last years of her life spilled over after her death.

headline: American Eagle Looks to Sell Children’s Apparel Unit
text: American Eagle Outfitters, the teenage-apparel retailer with more than 1,000 stores in North America, said it would exit its children’s apparel business, which had a loss in the last fiscal year. The company said it was “exploring options,” including a full or partial sale of assets, for the 77kids by American Eagle brand, the company said in a statement. The brand had a net loss of $24 million on sales of $40 million in the year ended Jan. 28, according to the statement. American Eagle said in a separate statement that its chief financial officer, Joan Hilson, planned to step down after more than six years at the company.

headline: A 3rd U.S. Agency Said to Open Inquiry Into JPMorgan Loss
text: WASHINGTON — A federal investigation into JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar trading loss widened Friday as regulators pursued a new line of inquiry.

headline: It’s Their Party

headline: Now, @CardinalDolan

He has spoken before Pope Benedict XVI and the College of Cardinals in Rome. As archbishop of Milwaukee, he once put on a Green Bay Packers “cheesehead” during an outdoor Mass.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Austerity protests in Europe, the fallout from an embarrassing trading failure at JPMorgan Chase and Facebook’s long-anticipated initial public offering were among the week’s top business stories.

headline: Earmark Puts $17,000 Pans on Army Craft

headline: For Jockeys and Trainers, the Merry-Go-Round Is All Part of the Game

headline: A Last Trim in Chelsea
text: Set to close to make room for a new tenant, Manuel Castillo’s barbershop in Chelsea served as a hangout for the local old men, as well as a museum of sorts.

headline: From a Honduras Hospital, Conflicting Tales of a Riverside Shootout
text: AHUAS, Honduras — Lying in a sagging hospital bed with a gunshot wound in each leg, Hilda Lezama tearfully described what she considered the worst night of her life on the river she has known since she was a girl.

headline: Problems Mounting for Heat vs. Pacers
text: There is a decided limp in the Miami Heat’s usually sure-footed swagger, as the once short-listed N.B.A. title favorites stand two losses from playoff elimination.

headline: Refugee Farmers Find Solace in a Floodplain
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Unpredictability has been a life companion for Clothilde Ntahomvukiye and her fellow refugee farmers from Burundi, who were out clearing stubborn hillocks of weeds and dandelions with hand hoes the other day in a spring drizzle.

headline: Heard in a Temple
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — You know what’s fascinating? I never even noticed that this supposedly themeless puzzle by Patrick Berry had an Easter egg embedded in it.

headline: A Devils Rookie Emerges, and It Beats Farm Work
text: NEWARK — He always could use the help and also wanted to hammer home a point, so Joe Henrique had his four sons working summers on the family farm in Burford, Ontario. The cash crop was tobacco, and Adam Henrique’s job for one summer was priming leaves.

headline: SAT Service Cites ‘Lapses’ in Invalidating Scores
text: Proctors were “inattentive” and careless during an SAT exam given at a private school in Brooklyn on May 5, leaving exam booklets unattended, failing to check identification and allowing students to choose where they sat, according to an internal memorandum obtained on Friday by The New York Times.

headline: Chicago Protests Draw Thousands Before NATO Event
text: CHICAGO — Several thousand demonstrators, many of them nurses, filled a plaza in the heart of downtown Chicago on Friday for the first major rally in what is expected to be a weekend of protests as President Obama and foreign leaders gather in the president’s hometown for a NATO summit meeting.

headline: Students Get 2 Days Off, but Must Return for the Last (Half) Day
text: The mountains of snow and the icy roads never arrived last winter, depriving the city’s schoolchildren of the precious surprise of a snow day.

headline: Rising Greek Political Star, Foe of Austerity, Puts Europe on Edge
text: ATHENS — At 37, and looking not a bit his years, Alexis Tsipras is clearly enjoying his moment. He vaulted to prominence less than two weeks ago, when his previously obscure left-wing party placed second in national elections with the promise of repudiating the loan agreement Greece’s previous leaders signed in February.

headline: Vintage Pettitte Arrives Just in Time
text: Andy Pettitte said he does not regret his one-year respite from professional baseball. It gave him some perspective.

headline: Rejected New Yorker Covers
text: Few readers might wonder what the outtakes of a magazine cover look like, but The New Yorker rejects most of its candidates. As the magazine’s art editor, Françoise Mouly, writes in “Blown Covers: New Yorker Covers You Were Never Meant to See” (Abrams, $24.95), “a weekly only has one cover a week, after all.”

headline: ‘Metrosexual Black Abe Lincoln’
text: We knew this day would come.

headline: Blue Jays Put Their Power on Display in a Rout of the Mets
text: TORONTO — Terry Collins sat behind his desk inside Rogers Centre on Friday afternoon and tapped his fingers against a thick binder. Inside, he said, was a “big, nice, tremendously put together scouting report” on the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: Cardio, Cooking and Choir
text: Dennis M. Walcott recently completed his first year as chancellor of New York City’s Department of Education: He is responsible for 1.1 million students at some 1,700 schools, and says he often wears his “chancellor hat” at weekend events. Otherwise, Mr. Walcott, 60, devotes his Sundays to exercise (he ran in the New York City Marathon last year), singing in his church choir and cooking. He and his wife, Denise, 61, live in a 1930s brick Tudor in Cambria Heights, the Queens neighborhood where he grew up. They have four children, Dejeanne, Dana, Shatisha and Timmy, and two grandsons, Justin and Gavin.

headline: Romney Supporters Hopeful About New Hampshire
text: HILLSBOROUGH, N.H. — In the days and weeks after the 2008 election, it seemed as if President Obama had permanently yanked independent-minded New Hampshire out of the reach of Republicans.

headline: Up All Night, Scanning for Breaking News
text: James Crockman has a keen ear for breaking news information culled from a squawking sea of radio reports from New York City's emergency responders.

headline: Corrections: May 19
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Race and Religion Rear Their Heads
text: WASHINGTON — Perhaps the uglier side of politics is always close to the surface.

headline: Rings a Super Fit for Giants
text: The Giants received their Super Bowl rings at a ceremony at Tiffany and Co. on Wednesday in New York.

headline: A Neighborhood’s Star Turn, Courtesy of a Librarian
text: “THIS would be the perfect space to show movies on a summer night,” Sean Ferguson said, while standing on a rooftop that once served as the open-air reading room of the Seward Park Library, a majestic four-story Renaissance Revival building on East Broadway and Jefferson Street. He pointed toward streets of glowing brick face stretching to the Manhattan Bridge and East River. “I see this shot in the films I show all the time.”

headline: With Big 12-SEC Game, an Uncertain Ripple Effect
text: Less than a year ago, when conference realignment began to shift significantly, few could have imagined that Texas A&M’s decision to bolt the Big 12 for the Southeastern Conference would eventually lead to Virginia Commonwealth’s move to the Atlantic 10.

headline: Downward Dog at the Club
text: YOGA aficionados often describe the practice as having two possible benefits: strengthening the body and clearing the mind.

headline: Luxury Liner’s Removal to Begin Off Italian Coast
text: ROME — One of the most expensive and challenging salvage operations ever planned, the removal of the luxury liner Costa Concordia from granite rocks off the Tuscan coast, where it ran aground in January, will begin next week, the companies in charge announced Friday.

headline: As a Debt Battle Looms, Some See No Option but to Raise Taxes
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Republican leaders in Congress made history of sorts last year when they agreed to a 10-year plan to reduce annual deficits with spending cuts and no tax increases. Mr. Obama vows not to let it happen again.

headline: Table Tennis Beside a Bank, and Other Contests Intended to ‘Reclaim’ Midtown
text: At 12:45 p.m. Friday, under clear blue skies, dozens of table-tennis players gathered in the northwest corner of Bryant Park. It was an attempt at a covert operation. Some players wore neon spandex, others donned plastic shades, one man enveloped himself in a red boxing robe that concealed white short-shorts. Their goal: to hold a table-tennis tournament against the walls of the Bank of America building.

headline: Cubs’ Wood Ends Career With Strikeout and Hug
text: CHICAGO — Kerry Wood earned the nickname Kid K as a 20-year-old fastball pitcher after he struck out 20 Houston Astros in his fifth major league start. Fourteen years later, he ended his career on the same Wrigley Field mound with another strikeout.

headline: Alabama Gets Strict Immigration Law as Governor Relents
text: Only a day after calling a special session and urging the Alabama Legislature to make more changes to the state’s immigration enforcement law than the modest ones they had passed, Gov. Robert Bentley on Friday signed the bill into law anyway.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Crackdown on Students Stokes Fury Within Syria
text: Antigovernment anger in Syria escalated on Friday over the harsh repression of students in Aleppo, the country’s largest city, where activists reported what they called the most extensive protests there yet in the 15-month-old nationwide uprising against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Songs for a Champions League Final
text: For the Champions League final Saturday at the 66,000-seat Allianz Arena in Munich, Chelsea and Bayern Munich fans each have an allotted 17,500 seats. Both teams’ fans have a hard-core base that sings the most throughout the game. But Bayern and Chelsea fans have different chanting styles, said Michael Dennis, the creator of Fan Chants, a repository of soccer chants from around the world.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Film

headline: Sixers Come Alive After Halftime and Pull Out a Victory
text: PHILADELPHIA — Andre Iguodala recognized the reality: the Philadelphia 76ers entered Friday needing to even their Eastern Conference semifinal series by beating the Boston Celtics in Game 4.

headline: Looking to End a Drought in Scotland
text: The 44-year drought that Manchester City finally put to an end by winning the English Premier League last weekend is a trifle by comparison. Even the Chicago Cubs’ 103 years of failure and misery falls shy of the wait that Hibernian Football Club has had to endure in its quest to win the elusive Scottish Cup.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Comedy

headline: Amanda Burden Wants to Remake New York. She Has 19 Months Left.
text: AMANDA M. BURDEN, in a sheath dress, impossibly thin and with a blond bob reminiscent of the “Mad Men” ’60s, wore a serene smile as she oversaw a recent public hearing in a drab hearing room near City Hall.

headline: The Neighborhood Drinking Problem
text: Late last year, the New York City health department unveiled the latest installment in a subway advertising campaign meant to illuminate the perils of heavy drinking. Featuring young people who would seem to have aggressively exceeded the city’s recommended limits for alcohol consumption — no more than one drink a day for women, no more than two for men — the posters depict the ugly consequences of a kind of night life that draws many 22-year-olds to the city in the first place.

headline: Archie Peck, Competitive Croquet Star, Dies at 76
text: Archie Peck, one of the most celebrated players in a sport of cutthroat gentility — croquet — died on Wednesday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Trading His Uniform for a Suit
text: Despite his election to Congress in Brazil, Romário de Souza Faria insists that he is still the same man he was running up and down the soccer field for so many years.

headline: From Field to Congress, Soccer Star Leaves His Mark
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Barbara D’Arcy White, Interior Design Guru, Dies at 84
text: Barbara D’Arcy White, an interior decorator whose eclectic sense of style helped change Americans’ taste in home furnishings in the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s, when she was a design and merchandising guru at Bloomingdale’s, died on May 10 in Southhampton, N.Y. She was 84.

headline: The Voice That Made You Fall in Love With Lieder
text: I was a serious piano student of 16 or so when I decided the time had come to discover what German lieder were all about. The first recording I bought was Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau singing Schubert’s “Schöne Müllerin” with the pianist Gerald Moore. This was not Mr. Fischer-Dieskau’s first recording of the cycle, from 1951, but the one he made 10 years later, though I knew nothing of this at the time.

headline: The Fight Over Who Fights in Israel
text: JERUSALEM

headline: Algerians Belittle Elections, but Not Enough to Protest
text: ALGIERS — As Islamists rode the wave of the Arab Spring to power in Tunisia and Libya, it looked as if that same tide would lift religious parties in this much larger nation in North Africa, too.

headline: Rich Girl, Poor Guy and a Magical Makeover
text: Imagine “Pygmalion” written by the Marx Brothers. Starring Gordon Gekko from “Wall Street.” On speed.

headline: Bahrain: Unity Plan Denounced
text: Tens of thousands of protesters swarmed onto a major highway on Friday to criticize a proposal by Saudi Arabia for a closer union with Bahrain. Demonstrators chanted “The land is not for sale,” along with antigovernment slogans, in what activists said was the largest protest in months. The unity proposal has increased tensions in Bahrain, which is still in turmoil more than a year after the government violently suppressed a Shiite-led popular uprising, with military help from the Saudi government.

headline: Spain’s Yearnings Are Now Its Agony
text: Madrid

headline: Mongolia Wrestles With Dinosaurs, NATO and Politics
text: Squeezed between geopolitical giants Russia and China, Mongolia has long struggled for independence and visibility.

headline: Dissident From China Arrives in U.S., Ending an Ordeal
text: Chen Guangcheng, the blind legal advocate who recently sought refuge in the American Embassy in Beijing, arrived in the heart of Greenwich Village on Saturday, holding the kind of open-air news conference that he could have never imagined while under virtual house arrest in China.

headline: Going on Faith
text: “The morning I arrived in Trivandrum, the capital of the south Indian state of Kerala, I met my friend Vinita, a Hindu, who promised to accompany me on a visit to the Sri Padmanabhaswamy temple, a place that is generally off limits to nonbelievers,” Abraham Verghese writes for T Magazine of The New York Times.

headline: Launching of Rocket by SpaceX Is Aborted
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. — The launching of a privately owned cargo rocket heading to the International Space Station was aborted at the last second on Saturday morning.

headline: The Weekend Word: Pet Projects
text: Today’s Times

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The death of 363 children since this January in the only pediatrics hospital in Kashmir has raised an alarm in the Valley about medical facilities for children, Hindustan Times reported. The families of four infants who died overnight Friday staged protests outside the hospital and blocked the arterial Jammu-Srinagar national highway, the newspaper reported.

headline: Extreme Extreme Sports: Desert Run
text: HONG KONG — In a recent Global Athlete column, I wrote about adventurers who seek out the heat, focusing on the “Marathon des Sables” that took place in April.

headline: Jets and the 46 Defense
text: The Jets’ defensive line coach, Karl Dunbar, said earlier this week that he looked forward to using more of the 46 defense next season.

headline: Racing, and the Safety of Horses, Becomes Derek’s Focus
text: The iconic image of Bo Derek comes from the 1979 movie “10,” in which she runs on a beach in a nude-colored swimsuit, her beaded cornrows swaying. Derek, now 55,  is still acting, but she has taken a turn behind the camera. Her photograph of jockey Chantal Sutherland, nude and astride a retired racehorse in the Turf Club’s Chandelier Room at Santa Anita Park, appears in the June issue of Vanity Fair and has caused a stir. A longtime horse racing enthusiast, Derek is a member of the California Horse Racing Board. (Three of the top five finishers in the Kentucky Derby, including the winner, I’ll Have Another, are based in California.) She owns five Lusitano horses and has a line of pet care products called Bless the Beasts. Even the title of her autobiography reflects her love of animals: “Riding Lessons: Everything That Matters in Life I Learned From Horses.”

headline: Going To Extreme
text: The chart above is from the invaluable people at Voteview, who use data on Congressional voting to measure political positions and polarizations. What it shows is what should be obvious, but much of the Beltway chattering class still refuses to acknowledge: there has been a huge increase in polarization, and it’s because Republicans have moved right, not because Democrats have moved left. (You want to look at the Northern Democrat line; the southern Democrats disappeared or became Republicans).

headline: Cameron to Critics: Shut Up
text: Aha. I’m a “dangerous voice” for criticizing UK austerity policies, not to mention one of “those who”. Other dangerous voices include Martin Wolf, who is getting shriller than I’ve ever heard him (and rightly so), Jonathan Portes (who has been doing yeoman work), and Simon Wren-Lewis, who is getting remarkably cynical.

headline: ‘Community’ Creator Dan Harmon Is Replaced as Show Runner
text: For a brief moment, things seemed to be looking up at “Community,” the intensely loved if not widely watched NBC comedy about misfit students at a small college: it had been narrowly renewed for a fourth season (albeit for only 13 episodes) and its third-season finale on Thursday night concluded with an on-screen display of an optimistic Twitter hashtag: #sixseasonsandamovie.

headline: No Systemic Issues Here
text: No way, no how:

headline: Gay Hotel Tests Waters, Polar Bear and All
text: In a short-term takeover being billed as a pop-up hotel, the Hotel on Rivington in New York will become Lords New York, a spinoff of Lords South Beach in Miami, for a week.

headline: NBC’s ‘Community’ to Lose Its Temperamental Maestro
text: The rabid (if relatively few) fans of the NBC comedy “Community” got the word they were fearing late Friday night when the studio that owns the series, Sony Television, decided to replace Dan Harmon as the creative hand in charge of the series.

headline: Musical Meta (Self-Indulgent)
text: Some readers have asked why my Friday night music selections are mainly contemporary groups rather than classical selections, which some say are much more profound. So, since there are other things I’m supposed to be doing right now, let me procrastinate by answering that question.

headline: If the Crown Fits, but the Name Doesn’t
text: Secretariat. Affirmed. Whirlaway. Citation.

headline: Winning Jockey Came From a Struggling Track
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Jockey Mario Gutierrez was reunited with I’ll Have Another last week in Baltimore, preparing for the Preakness Stakes, the follow-up to their victory at the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Far From Land of Nip and Tuck, Kings Are Thriving Incognito
text: I was walking to Grand Central Terminal last Wednesday evening, feeling a little cocky. Two people in hockey jerseys were distributing Rangers signs, urging people to take one and join in a chorus of “Let’s go, Rangers.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.

headline: White Sox Coach Was a South Side Guy
text: The death last week of Kevin Hickey, a pregame coach and batting practice pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, highlighted one of the most unlikely paths to major league success.

headline: Survey Says: Stay-at-Home Mothers Are Not as Happy as Working Mothers
text: Blame Gallup.

headline: 1 Student Is Killed and 5 Are Injured in Bombing at Italian School
text: BRINDISI, Italy — A bomb exploded Saturday in front of a school in this southern city, killing a student and wounding at least five others, local officials said, raising fears of a return to the kind of violence that shook Italy decades ago.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Cannes Film Festival
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Variety: An Inventive Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — What fascinated me about this quote was learning, as Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon will tell us below, that the real Cyrano de Bergerac — not the fictionalized version in the Edmond Rostand play — was not just some “swordsman with a big nose,” but how ahead of his time he was in terms of his creativity and ideas. He was the very definition of a Renaissance man.

headline: In Afghanistan, New Group Begins Campaign of Terror
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A new, more radical insurgent group has begun a campaign aimed at terrorizing both Afghan officials and moderate insurgents, according to Afghan officials.

headline: Only One Chipper
text: ATLANTA — He is one of a kind. Of all the players in the recorded history of baseball, the major leagues and the minors, the only one named Chipper is Larry Wayne Jones Jr. of the Atlanta Braves.

headline: An N.B.A. Great’s Legacy Continues to Evolve
text: A curtain falls on one act and rises on another. Such has been the continuous narrative for Magic Johnson, who 20-plus years after receiving what was feared to be an immutable death sentence is not only alive but seemingly larger than life.

headline: Fallow Years Leave Demsey on Margins of Golf World
text: IRVING, Tex. — Todd Demsey walked onto the first tee at T.P.C. Four Seasons Resort at Las Colinas on Thursday dressed in an off-the-rack golf shirt and khaki pants held up by a white cotton belt with a nondescript buckle. His clubs sat in a vintage lightweight leather golf bag with one divider, two pockets and no logos. On the brand-conscious PGA Tour, Demsey looked out of place, like a muni golfer who had crashed the Byron Nelson Classic.

headline: Is Insider Trading Part of the Fabric?
text: EVEN before the news was official, it filtered out — unofficially — to Wall Street.

headline: Driver’s Seat Elusive for Black Racers
text: HUNTERSVILLE, N.C. — Darrell Wallace Jr. was playing Amateur Athletic Union basketball at 8 and perhaps on a path to college ball when his father bought him a go-kart after a trip to a local track.

headline: Seeing Bailouts Through Rose-Colored Glasses
text: THE multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan Chase has revived the idea of paring down banks that are too big to manage. That’s a good thing, if we ever hope to get off the boom-bust-bailout track.

headline: A 49-Year All-Star Gap for the Mets
text: The Kansas City Royals will host this year’s All-Star Game for the first time in 39 years. In 2009, the St. Louis Cardinals hosted he game for the first time in 43 years. But no franchise has ever waited as long as the Mets for an All-Star encore.

headline: Role Reversal for Fisher in Trying to End Lakers’ Run
text: LOS ANGELES — The curtain dropped, dramatic music thumped, and a blur of highlights played across the tapestry hanging over the Staples Center court. Then, three words: “Time marches on.”

headline: Discord at Key JPMorgan Unit Is Faulted in Loss
text: Ever since JPMorgan Chase disclosed a multibillion-dollar trading loss this month, the central mystery has been how a bank known for its skill at risk management could err so badly.

headline: Champions League Final: Bayern Munich (1) vs. Chelsea (1); Chelsea Wins Shootout, 4-3
text: Didier Drogba may never play another game for Chelsea. Then again, after his performance Saturday in the Champions League final against Bayern Munich, the 34-year-old striker from Ivory Coast has carved a place in club history that will not soon be forgotten.

headline: Los Angeles Lives by Car, but Learns to Embrace Bikes
text: LOS ANGELES — It was a warm April morning in downtown Los Angeles, and there was not a car on the road. For five hours, the streets were commandeered by nearly 100,000 people on bicycles — old and young, wearing spandex and silly hats, dogs and babies perched on handlebar baskets — in a celebration that produced a sight that once would have seemed inconceivable in this city of cars.

headline: A Champions League Home Match, Sort Of
text: MUNICH — I was about to head up to the Allianz Arena, the home field for Germany’s Bayern Munich soccer club, to get my accreditation for the Champions League final on Friday. Through an odd stroke of luck the team was hosting the finals out of all the stadiums in Europe — from Lisbon to Moscow — and managed to make the biggest game in professional soccer.

headline: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Mike Richter
text: During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. A sparkling performance by Mike Richter in Games 6 and 7 upheld Mark Messier’s guarantee and enabled Stephane Matteau’s series winning goal. Richter allowed one goal over the final 126 minutes 52 seconds, helping the Rangers overcome a three-games-to-two deficit — and a 2-0 deficit in Game 6 — to advance to the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: In One Adjective, Please Tell Me Who You Are
text: This interview with  Chris Barbin, chief executive of Appirio, an information technology company that focuses on cloud services, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: It’s Not Dick Tracy’s, but It Can Screen Your Messages
text: I’VE been looking at my wrist a lot lately — and not just to see what time it is.

headline: Trouble at the Tollbooth
text: SUMMER travel season is fast approaching, and for the Haggler that can mean only one thing: rage and envy about other people’s fabulous plans. That, as well as a modest uptick in the number of complaints about E-ZPass, the electronic toll collection system. But, truth be told, grousing about E-ZPass trickles in throughout the year. This grouse arrived a few weeks ago.

headline: How National Belt-Tightening Goes Awry
text: WHY is there such strong political support for fiscal austerity, for government cuts and layoffs, at a time of widespread unemployment?

headline: In Land’s Bounty, a Political Chip
text: BINGA, Zimbabwe — More than a decade after Zimbabwe’s government began seizing sprawling white-owned commercial farms, a new fight is brewing here over who will profit from the nation’s vast bounty of platinum, chromium, nickel and diamonds.

headline: Before Leaping, Listen to a Giant
text: WHAT are ordinary investors to make of the puzzling swings in Facebook’s first-day share price on Friday? Or of the fact that this company, all of eight years old, is now worth more than $104 billion on the stock market? For some perspective, I turned to Harry M. Markowitz, who may have had a greater influence on current theories of finance and investing than any other living person.

headline: Dark-Horse Candidates Add to Egypt’s Suspense
text: CAIRO — Signs of a late surge in popularity by two dark-horse candidates in Egypt’s first competitive presidential race are adding new suspense about the outcome of the initial round of voting just days before it is set to begin.

headline: Facebook Gold Rush: Fanfare vs. Realities
text: IT’S an old line on Wall Street: If you can get your hands on a hot new stock, you probably don’t want it.

headline: Teaching Is Their Other Marathon
text: I’VE been running for almost two years, ever since I lost almost 100 pounds. Another runner, Richard O’Brien, once said: “Running is not, as it so often seems, only about what you did in your last race or about how many miles you ran last week. It is, in a much more important way, about community, about appreciating all the miles run by other runners, too.”

headline: Wait Goes on for Hibs
text: After waiting 110 years for a Scottish Cup title, what’s one more year for Hibs?

headline: An Entrepreneur at Heart
text: I WAS born in Germany. My parents divorced when I was 5 and I moved to the United States with my white mother and the black American soldier who became my stepfather. From first through fourth grade I attended school in South Carolina and then Florida. I didn’t know anything about racism, but I could feel people looking at us.

headline: New Hints at Looser Rules on Travel Stir Hope in Cuba
text: HAVANA — From her small, tidy apartment here, Niurka dreams of visiting Miami one day to see her son’s home and the school where he is studying medicine. She also yearns to bid farewell to her late father at his graveside and to meet her brother’s children while they are still young.

headline: Letters: Adam Smith’s Way
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Logic and the Mandate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Teixeira, Battling a Cough, Is Given Another Day Off
text: Mark Teixeira, his voice raspy and his demeanor subdued, said he was reaching the final options in his battle to shake an infuriating cough, which is simply to rest.

headline: China Security Chief Seems to Keep His Hold on Power
text: BEIJING — The Chinese security chief, Zhou Yongkang, completed a prominent tour of the volatile region of Xinjiang last week, a sign that he still had a firm hold on his post and wielded power despite the fact that he had opposed the purging of Bo Xilai, an ambitious Politburo member.

headline: Insurance Firm Is Set Up for Land Trusts, Which See Legal Costs Soaring
text: NEW LONDON, Conn. — The $4 million estate on the Connecticut River in Lyme had everything: a six-bedroom home, a pool and a dock, all surrounded by 17 acres of native meadows, brush and woodlands. It also had a decades-old conservation restriction, held by the local land trust, requiring the property to remain largely in its “natural wilderness” state.

headline: In Whose Best Interests?
text: IN divorced families, whose needs count for more: those of parents or those of children?

headline: The Pain Hits Home in Madrid
text: Caught in a downward spiral of debt and economic decline, Spain’s banking crisis has been deepening and its unemployment rate has been rising. For all too many, it has been a season of despair.

headline: Winning 82 Pro Titles With Best Swing Ever
text: FAR HILLS, N.J. — The marks on her irons are the size of a quarter. Forged through repetition, they are a symbol of excellence and the pursuit of perfection. For 32 years, Mickey Wright made beautiful music with her set of 1963 Wilson Staff Dynapower golf clubs.

headline: Varying Rates of Growth in the G-20
text: Economies of the countries that make up the G-8 have seen much slower growth than the rest of the economies that make up the G-20.

headline: Crawford Greenewalt Jr., Who Shed Light on an Ancient City, Dies at 74
text: Crawford Greenewalt Jr., an archaeologist whose work over half a century helped illuminate the lives of king and commoner in the ancient city of Sardis, died on May 4 in Hockessin, Del. He was 74.

headline: At a Kennedy’s Funeral, Friends and Family Focus on the Lives She Touched
text: BEDFORD, N.Y. — In a service that mixed pain, tribute and wry humor, family and friends said farewell and paid tribute on Saturday morning to Mary Richardson Kennedy, the wife of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

headline: World Leaders Urge Growth, Not Austerity
text: CAMP DAVID, Md. — Leaders of the world’s richest countries banded together on Saturday to press Germany to back more pro-growth policies to halt the deepening debt crisis in Europe, as President Obama for the first time gained widespread support for his argument that Europe, and the United States by extension, cannot afford Chancellor Angela Merkel’s one-size-fits-all approach emphasizing austerity.

headline: 3 in Chicago Face Charges of Terrorism in Protests
text: CHICAGO — Tensions were increasing here on Saturday, the eve of a NATO summit meeting, after three men were accused of planning attacks on President Obama’s re-election campaign headquarters, the house of Mayor Rahm Emanuel, police stations and financial institutions in downtown Chicago, according to prosecutors.

headline: This Time, Two Runs Are Enough to Top Mets
text: TORONTO — There was regret in Mike Baxter’s voice as he described the instant Saturday afternoon when he seemed to lose his cool, throwing his arms into the air in frustration and stalking off the field at Rogers Centre with a tight scowl on his face.

headline: Marlins’ Johnson Working His Way Back to Dominance
text: It is not the kind of experience any pitcher wants, especially a two-time All-Star who can dominate hitters if his body will let him. But Josh Johnson, the No. 1 starter for the Miami Marlins, has intimate knowledge of the differences between elbow and shoulder problems.

headline: Peter D. Fuller Dies at 89; Had to Return Derby Purse
text: Peter D. Fuller’s brashness was in full flower the day before the 1968 Kentucky Derby. The owner of Dancer’s Image, Mr. Fuller practiced the walk from his box to the winner circle at Churchill Downs and composed a humble acceptance speech to deliver after his strapping gray colt had won the race.

headline: Patterns Hold as Rangers Wake Up in Third Period
text: NEWARK — It is definitely a pattern this spring, and it happened again Saturday afternoon. The Rangers were outplayed for most of the first two periods, but Henrik Lundqvist kept them in the game with fantastic goaltending, and in the third, they awoke and won.

headline: In Zimbabwe’s Bounty, a Political Chip
text: The party of the aging president, Robert G. Mugabe, is seeking to enforce a law that requires that black Zimbabweans own more than half the shares of companies working in the country.

headline: R. A. Dickey
text: R. A. Dickey is a starting pitcher for the New York Mets and the only remaining pitcher in Major League Baseball who primarily throws a knuckleball. He is the author of a recently published memoir, “Wherever I Wind Up: My Quest for Truth, Authenticity and the Perfect Knuckleball.”

headline: Finding the First Americans
text: WHEN and how did the first people arrive in the Americas?

headline: The Banker’s Job
text: I WAS traveling last week on my book tour and landed at the John Wayne Airport in Orange County, Calif. Because I am geographically challenged and probably need LoJack implanted under my skin, my publisher kindly provided a car to take me from the airport to the hotel. The car wasn’t there.

headline: Obama: Stop Condescending to Women
text: WHEN I listen to President Obama speak to and about women, he sometimes sounds too paternalistic for my taste. In numerous appearances over the years — most recently at the Barnard graduation — he has made reference to how women are smarter than men. It’s all so tired, the kind of fake praise showered upon those one views as easy to impress. As I listen, I am always bracing for the old go-to cliché: “Behind every great man is a great woman.”

headline: Credit Where Credit Is Due
text: THE NEW YORK TIMES’S two-part series on the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community two weeks ago was an eye-opener, exploring the plight of child sexual abuse victims and their advocates as they struggled for justice in the face of religious and cultural pressures to keep the problem under wraps.

headline: Punishment Outside Prison
text: Probation and parole for convicted offenders are complex and growing problems in criminal justice. Scholars and others with the American Law Institute, meeting in Washington this week, are to present draft proposals on ways to reform laws about offenders who serve these out-of-custody sentences.

headline: Adrift in Oratory
text: This week brings us to the heart of the commencement season, when dignitaries — notable and not so much — arise and breathe earnestness like annealing dragon fire over capped and tasseled heads. If you created a concordance of all the speeches delivered this year, the three most frequently used words would very likely be “you,” “dream” and “others.” Throw in “risk” and “reward” for good measure.

headline: The Most Powerful Special Interest in Washington: The Acronym
text: We are interuppting FiveThirtyEight’s regular data-driven analysis for an important public service announcement:

headline: Herbert Breslin, Pavarotti’s Hard-Driving Manager, Dies at 87
text: Herbert Breslin, the brash publicist and manager who helped fashion a supremely gifted tenor named Luciano Pavarotti into a superstar but who later wrote a biting memoir about their 36-year relationship, died on Thursday in Nice, France. He was 87.

headline: Making Schools Work
text: AMID the  ceaseless and cacophonous debates about how to close the achievement gap, we’ve turned away from one tool that has been shown to work: school desegregation. That strategy, ushered in by the landmark 1954 Supreme Court decision in Brown v. Board of Education, has been unceremoniously ushered out, an artifact in the museum of failed social experiments. The Supreme Court’s ruling that racially segregated schools were “inherently unequal” shook up the nation like no other decision of the 20th century. Civil rights advocates, who for years had been patiently laying the constitutional groundwork, cheered to the rafters, while segregationists mourned “Black Monday” and vowed “massive resistance.” But as the anniversary was observed this past week on May 17, it was hard not to notice that desegregation is effectively dead. In fact, we have been giving up on desegregation for a long time. In 1974, the Supreme Court rejected a metropolitan integration plan, leaving the increasingly black cities to fend for themselves.

headline: In Defense of Voting Rights
text: Racial discrimination in voting is “one of the gravest evils that Congress can seek to redress,” Judge David Tatel wrote in a crucial ruling on Friday upholding the constitutionality of the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Bring Back the Real Maverick
text: Senator John McCain has retreated from the campaign finance fight, once his signature issue. He may finally be ready to get back in. He told the newspaper The Hill that he had been talking with Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, Democrat of Rhode Island, the sponsor of a much-needed bill requiring timely public disclosure of donors writing checks of $10,000 and more for election ads, plus “stand-by-your-ad” identifications from the five biggest donors.

headline: Will Iran Take the Next Step?
text: The international community has not had much success trying to curb Iran’s nuclear ambitions. For years, it was split on how much pressure to apply, and Tehran deftly exploited that division. Since President Obama took office, the major powers have imposed increasingly strong sanctions aimed at Iran’s banks and oil trade. It is crucial to maintain that cohesion as a second round of negotiations opens this week in Baghdad.

headline: Like the Video? I Wrote the Book
text: THE first time I’d ever heard that there were video previews for books was when I was told I had to make one. A few months before my own book was to be released, my publisher advised me that official book trailers were now routinely posted on YouTube as a promotional device. I was skeptical, but remembering how instrumental video was in advancing the career of Men Without Hats, I acquiesced.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 20
text: The speaker of the House, John A. Boehner of Ohio, foreshadowed another battle over the debt ceiling this week, telling President Obama on Wednesday, “As long as I’m around here, I’m not going to allow a debt ceiling increase without doing something serious about the debt.”

headline: Valley of Shadows and Dreams
text: Photographs of California’s Great Central Valley by Ken and Melanie Light.

headline: The Vanishing Valley
text: For five years, we roamed the Great Central Valley, the agricultural center of California. It is a dream for a photographer and a writer — an amazing mix of startling light, and a kaleidoscope of faces and stories. Like so many of our fellow Californians, we hadn’t really thought about the communities and people that provide our food, or the labor that has made the state what it is.

headline: The Beginning of the End of the Census?
text: THE American Community Survey may be the most important government function you’ve never heard of, and it’s in trouble.

headline: Wild Ponies and Wild Weather
text: WITH the Atlantic hurricane season about to begin, the trusted weather forecasters at Colorado State University are predicting 10 storms severe enough to earn proper names and four wind-whipped into the demonic rampage we call hurricanes, with two of them major hell-raisers. That’s a relatively mild season, but if it’s your house that is demolished, it’s an active season for you.

headline: The Campaign Against Women
text: Despite the persistent gender gap in opinion polls and mounting criticism of their hostility to women’s rights, Republicans are not backing off their assault on women’s equality and well-being. New laws in some states could mean a death sentence for a pregnant woman who suffers a life-threatening condition. But the attack goes well beyond abortion, into birth control, access to health care, equal pay and domestic violence.

headline: Walter Wink, Theologian and Author, Dies at 76
text: Walter Wink, an influential liberal theologian whose views on homosexuality, nonviolence and the nature of Jesus challenged orthodox interpretations, died on May 10 at his home in Sandisfield, Mass. He was 76.

headline: Are You Safe on That Sofa?
text: IF you want a case study of everything that is wrong with money politics, this is it.

headline: Do You Want the Good News First?
text: Seattle

headline: A Little Bit Indian
text: “I still have a picture on my mantel and it is a picture my mother had before that — a picture of my grandfather. And my Aunt Bea has walked by that picture at least a thousand times [and] remarked that he — her father, my papaw — had high cheekbones like all of the Indians do. ... Being Native American has been part of my story, I guess, since the day I was born.”

headline: Week Ahead
text: The international community has not had much success trying to curb Iran’s nuclear ambitions. For years, it was split on how much pressure to apply, and Tehran deftly exploited that division. Since President Obama took office, the major powers have imposed increasingly strong sanctions aimed at Iran’s banks and oil trade. It is crucial to maintain that cohesion as a second round of negotiations opens this week in Baghdad.

headline: Gingrich Campaign at Least $4.8 Million in Debt
text: Newt Gingrich closed down his campaign early this month with at least $4.8 million in debt, according to campaign records filed with the Federal Election Commission on Saturday.

headline: Nova’s 12 Strikeouts Can’t Make Up for 5 Runs He Allows
text: There was not a cloud in the sky above Yankee Stadium on Saturday, yet after a 6-5 loss to the Cincinnati Reds, the Yankees spotted silver linings everywhere.

headline: Wisecracks
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes all it takes is a simple “Y’s” crack to make you laugh, am I right?

headline: Leppert Takes Mayoral Record Into Senate Race
text: Tom Leppert was a virtual unknown on the Dallas political scene before 2007, when he beat 10 other candidates to become the city’s mayor. At the time, he insisted he was focused on the city’s problems and not on higher office.

text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: The Wide-Ranging Legacy of Chipper Jones
text: ATLANTA – While reporting Sunday’s feature on Chipper Jones, his final season and his legacy in Atlanta, I thought of something that hadn’t occurred to me before: of all the players picked No. 1 over all, Jones worked out the best.

headline: Texas Gets Prehistoric With Two New Fossil Halls
text: Paleontologists have been lifting fossil bones out of Texas’ rock beds since the late 19th century. Now, after years of exporting these bones to some of the world’s best museums, the state is getting two huge new paleontology halls of its own, both of which offer a visual feast spanning millions of years.

headline: Live Analysis: Derby Winner I’ll Have Another Captures Preakness
text: For the second straight race, the Kentucky Derby winner I’ll Have Another ran down the pace-setter Bodemeister in deep stretch, winning the Preakness Stakes, the second leg of the Triple Crown, on Saturday at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.

headline: Illegal Immigrant’s Win Carves Path to Citizenship
text: The motto of the World Chess Federation is “Gens una sumus,” which is Latin for “We are one family.” The stories of two boys show how chess can live up to that lofty ideal, or fall short.

headline: United States to Unveil Plans to Bolster NATO Alliance
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Sunday will unveil a new package of NATO initiatives that includes the alliance purchasing a fleet of surveillance drones, sharing weapons and training facilities, and sustaining nuclear deterrence in Europe even as disarmament efforts continue with an often belligerent Russia, according to senior administration officials.

headline: Romney’s Faith, Silent but Deep
text: BELMONT, Mass. — When Mitt Romney embarked on his first political race in 1994, he also slipped into a humble new role in the Mormon congregation he once led. On Sunday mornings, he stood in the sunlit chapel here teaching Bible classes for adults.

headline: From Cubicles, Cry for Quiet Pierces Office Buzz
text: The walls have come tumbling down in offices everywhere, but the cubicle dwellers keep putting up new ones. They barricade themselves behind file cabinets. They fortify their partitions with towers of books and papers. Or they follow an “evolving law of technology etiquette,” as articulated by Raj Udeshi at the open office he shares with fellow software entrepreneurs in downtown Manhattan.

headline: Charting Obama’s Journey to a Shift on Afghanistan
text: It was just one brief exchange about Afghanistan with an aide late in 2009, but it suggests how President Obama’s thinking about what he once called “a war of necessity” began to radically change less than a year after he took up residency in the White House.

headline: Rangers Get Out of Way and Let Lundqvist Win Game
text: Under Coach John Tortorella, the Rangers will always be a shot-blocking team. But there are occasions, as there were in their 3-0 victory over the Devils on Saturday in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals, when the Rangers know the best move is to clear the way for goalie Henrik Lundqvist.

headline: Rangers-Devils: Game 3
text: The Rangers scored three third-period goals to beat the Devils and take a 2-1 lead in their Eastern Conference final series.

headline: What Chen Guangcheng’s Arrival in America Means
text: The world seemed to be watching United Flight 88 from Beijing to Newark, New Jersey, across the bay from New York City, as Chen Chenguang, made his way with his wife and two children out of China.

headline: Thousands March Against Austerity in Frankfurt
text: BERLIN — Thousands of people on Saturday marched through the heart of Frankfurt, Germany’s financial capital and the home of the European Central Bank, to protest against unchecked capitalism and Chancellor Angela Merkel’s insistence on austerity measures for much of Europe.

headline: Tseng, No. 1 Female Golfer in the World, Is Ousted in Match Play
text: GLADSTONE, N.J. — After Yani Tseng, the top-ranked female golfer in the world by a wide margin, became the biggest name to fall in a parade of upsets at the Sybase Match Play Championship, tears welled up and then fell from her eyes less than five minutes after she came off the course Saturday morning.

headline: Labor Showdown Looms Ominously for the N.H.L.

headline: Another Thriller, and More Believers
text: BALTIMORE — Love the horse. Love I’ll Have Another the way jockey Mario Gutierrez loves him. Sure, the colt has changed the young rider’s life, brought him out of the morning shadows of Santa Anita Park, where he worked horses for trainers who did not care to know his name, and into America’s living rooms for the first two legs of the Triple Crown.

headline: Down by 24, Spurs Rally to Win 17th in Row
text: LOS ANGELES — Blake Griffin soared for a time Saturday, lifting the Los Angeles Clippers just high enough to induce altitude sickness, and making the inevitable crash that much more spectacular.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Andrew Johnson’s Difficult Task
text: In a broadside posted prominently throughout Nashville in March 1862, the newly installed military governor of Tennessee, Andrew Johnson, issued an “Appeal to the People of Tennessee.” After describing the “lamentable crisis” through which the state’s government was “set at defiance, and the Constitution and the Laws contemned, by a rebellious, armed force,” Johnson solicited support from all those citizens “desirous or willing to see a restoration of her ancient government, without distinction of party affiliations or past political opinions.”

headline: Zuckerberg Ties the Knot
text: It has been a busy couple of days for Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook.

headline: The Annotated Playoff Leader Board
text: It has been an exciting postseason, with the East’s top seed already eliminated and the second round looking as if it could produce more upsets. Taking a look at the leaders in various categories gives a glimpse at which players are thriving in the playoffs. All statistics through Friday.

headline: Devils Forwards Silenced, During and After Game
text: NEWARK — By choosing to say nothing on two brisk trips through the Devils’ dressing room late Saturday afternoon, Zach Parise said quite a bit. Parise, the first-year captain, is usually gregarious and talkative, even when the Devils lose. This time, he was glum and mum.

headline: Homecoming Loses Its Luster in Final Minutes
text: An hour before the tip-off of the Liberty’s season opener, guard Kelly Miller exited the locker room and turned left, then right, before finally stopping to ask, “Which way is the court?”

headline: As High Seeds Fall, Pressel Rises at the Sybase
text: GLADSTONE, N.J. — Morgan Pressel qualified for the United States Women’s Open at 12 and became the youngest winner of a major title, the Kraft Nabisco Championship, less than two months shy of her 19th birthday.

headline: In Largely Symbolic Move, N.A.A.C.P. Votes to Endorse Same-Sex Marriage
text: The board of the N.A.A.C.P. voted to endorse same-sex marriage on Saturday, putting the weight of the country’s most prominent civil rights group behind a cause that has long divided some quarters of the black community.

headline: Rangers Get Air Support, and Fans Get Unusual Ride

headline: A Night of Farewells (or Were They?) at ‘Saturday Night Live’

headline: NATO Summit Opens With No Deal on Pakistan Supply Lines
text: CHICAGO — A NATO summit meeting here to discuss long-term security for Afghanistan opened on Sunday in the shadow of continuing tension between the United States and Pakistan over an unfinished deal to reopen supply routes for the war.

headline: Thousands Are Homeless in Deadly Quake in Italy
text: ROME — An earthquake struck the northern Italian region of Emilia Romagna on Sunday, killing at least five people, injuring dozens, leaving thousands homeless and damaging historic buildings as well as warehouses and factories, officials said.

headline: The Rail’s Scoreboard

headline: Megrahi, Convicted in 1988 Lockerbie Bombing, Dies at 60
text: Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, the only person convicted in the 1988 bombing of an American jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, has died in Libya, family members told news agencies on Sunday, nearly three years after Scotland released him on humanitarian grounds, citing evidence that he was near death with metastatic prostate cancer. He was 60.

headline: Keynes 1921 and the Euro Crisis
