headline: Nationalist Wins Serbian Presidency, Clouding Ties to the West
text: PARIS — Tomislav Nikolic, a nationalist and former cemetery supervisor, was elected president of Serbia on Sunday, in a surprise victory that cast doubt on whether the country would remain on its path toward the European Union or look increasingly eastward toward Russia.

headline: Bomber Strikes U.S. Soldiers in Southern Afghanistan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber on foot attacked a group of American soldiers with the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, apparently killing and wounding an unconfirmed number of them.

headline: Revisiting the War of 1812 On Its 200th Birthday
text: The Civil War isn’t the only United States military conflict hitting a milestone this decade. The War of 1812, whose end inspired our national anthem, marks its bicentennial this summer, an occasion that will be celebrated in military re-enactments, symphony concerts and historic tours in Ontario, Ohio, Maryland and other sites where battles were fought.

headline: Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, Libyan Convicted in Lockerbie Bombing
text: Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi was the only person convicted in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

headline: Pakistan Blocks Access to Twitter Over Cartoon Contest
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government blocked access to the social networking service Twitter for much of Sunday, after publicly holding Twitter responsible for promoting what it described as a blasphemous cartoon contest taking place on Facebook, officials said.

headline: Lockerbie Bomber Dead, Conspiracy Theories Survive
text: LONDON — Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, the only man ever convicted of the 1988 Lockerbie bombing, has died in Libya almost three years after he was released from jail in Scotland on the compassionate grounds that he had only three months to live.

headline: Disruptions: A Beacon to Silicon Valley, From a Start-Up for Children
text: I am flooded daily with pitches from Silicon Valley start-ups that boast they are the next big thing. The problem is, that next big thing is often an inconsequential variation on a previous big thing.

headline: Romney Says Obama Policies Undermine NATO Alliance
text: In Chicago Tribune op-ed on Sunday, Mitt Romney accused President Obama of undermining NATO. “At the same time that President Obama has been weakening our military, he has sent the message — intentionally or not — that the worth of NATO has diminished in America’s eyes,” Mr. Romney wrote. The op-ed was published as Mr. Obama and other world leaders are gathering in Chicago Sunday and Monday for a NATO summit meeting.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Taboos and Tourism
text: CANNES, France — The Austrian director Ulrich Seidl makes a habit of blurring boundaries: his work encompasses fiction (“Dog Days”) and nonfiction (“Animal Love”), and he typically works with nonprofessional actors using documentary-like settings and improvisatory techniques. But there is little middle ground when it comes to the reception of his films. Mr. Seidl tends to be condemned as a misanthrope who goes to unseemly lengths to prove the depths of human misery or hailed as a maestro of discomfort whose taste for confrontation masks a seriousness of purpose and a measure of compassion.

headline: ‘Battleship’ Pulls Up Lame at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES— Rotten buzz and superheroic competition sunk Universal’s “Battleship” over the weekend. Costing over $300 million to make and market, Peter Berg’s “Battleship” managed to sell about $25.4 million in tickets in its first weekend in North American theaters – a second-place finish behind “Marvel’s The Avengers” (Disney), which took in an estimated $55 million for a three-week domestic total of $457 million. Overseas, “Battleship,” inspired by the Hasbro board game, has taken in about $227 million since opening last month, a respectable total but not enough to make the expensive film profitable without better support from the United States, analysts say.

headline: In Rutgers Spying Case, Voices for Gay Rights Urge Leniency
text: In the two months since he was found guilty of using a webcam to spy on his roommate, Dharun Ravi has gone from being a symbol of antigay bias to being something of a folk hero, with rallies of his supporters urging the court to “free Dharun.”

headline: Foer Returns to New Republic as Editor
text: Two months after buying a majority stake in The New Republic, the technology entrepreneur Chris Hughes has lured one of its former stars, Franklin Foer, back to the magazine as its editor.

headline: An Obama Surrogate Criticizes Campaign
text: A revised version of this post can be found here.

headline: Greek Crisis Poses Unwanted Choices for Western Leaders
text: PARIS — The leaders of the Group of 8, emphasizing growth as well as fiscal discipline at their meeting on Saturday, made a strong plea for Greece to stay in the euro zone and the European Union.

headline: The Stripper in a Police Uniform? He’s for Real
text: It may never be recorded in any New York Police Department history books, but now it can be told: For eight years, the citizens of New York City were being served and protected by Officer Steve Stanulis, who by day went after drug dealers and by night stripped down to a G-string and thrilled women at Chippendales as the exotic dancer Steve Savage.

headline: Europe’s Worst Fear: Spain and Greece Spiral Down Together
text: LONDON — In a season of nightmare projections for Europe, this one could be the scariest: Greece leaves the euro currency union at the same time Spain’s banking system is collapsing.

headline: Left Coasting
text: What I know about the next few days:

headline: Rangers Don’t Rest, Lobbying for Calls From the Officials
text: The next time the Devils go on the power play in the Eastern Conference finals, eyes will be focused on the area around the star wing Ilya Kovalchuk. If one of Kovalchuk’s teammates frees him with a pick for an open shot, and one of the referees raises his right arm to call a penalty, John Tortorella will have had a very successful Sunday off in the series.

headline: Day After Game 3 Loss, the Devils Make Changes
text: NEWARK — Zach Parise, the Devils’ first-year captain, found a seat at his locker after a 45-minute practice Sunday and answered questions, still wearing his pads, until well after his teammates had cleared the dressing room. What a difference 21 hours had made.

headline: Conductor Says Goodbye With Hugs and Chopin
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra is going all out to acknowledge the contribution of Charles Dutoit as he concludes his fourth and final season as chief conductor. The orchestra owes him, big time. The musicians played splendidly for Mr. Dutoit on Friday night at Carnegie Hall, his last appearance in New York as their artistic leader.

headline: Nasdaq Concedes Facebook Missteps
text: 10:46 p.m. | Updated The chief executive of the Nasdaq stock market acknowledged on Sunday that technical issues had marred the debut of Facebook as a public company on Friday, but contended that the missteps had not affected the performance of the company’s shares.

headline: Three Celebrated Giselles, With Partners to Match, Define a Title Role
text: American Ballet Theater accomplished a feat on Thursday and Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House that rendered it exceptional among the world’s ballet companies: it presented the three most internationally admired interpreters of the title role of “Giselle,” each with a male partner who was an Albrecht of her caliber.

headline: Supply Lines Cast Shadow at NATO Meeting on Afghan War
text: CHICAGO — President Obama was struggling to balance the United States’ relationship with two crucial but difficult allies on Sunday, after a deal to reopen supply lines through Pakistan to Afghanistan fell apart just as Mr. Obama began talks on ending the NATO alliance’s combat role in the Afghan war.

headline: Philip K. Dick, Sci-Fi Philosopher, Part 1
text: This is the first in a three-part series.

headline: Sleep Apnea Tied to Increased Cancer Risk
text: Two new studies have found that people with sleep apnea, a common disorder that causes snoring, fatigue and dangerous pauses in breathing at night, have a higher risk of cancer. The new research marks the first time that sleep apnea has been linked to cancer in humans.

headline: Sabathia Falters in 7th, and the Yankees Stumble
text: All too often, meetings between aces end up being anticlimactic, with either or both pitchers failing to live up to the hype. That was not the case for five innings Sunday afternoon, as C. C. Sabathia and Johnny Cueto traded scoreless innings.

headline: In Flurry of Strikes, Closer Comes to His Own Rescue
text: TORONTO — The fans at Rogers Centre exhaled a thick stream of boos when Frank Francisco appeared on the mound Sunday to try to secure the Mets’ one-run lead.

headline: Selections by the French, From Tortured to Carefree
text: The French composer Ernest Chausson was puzzled by his bouts of depression, which occurred despite a seemingly charmed life that included a contented marriage, children, good health and an inherited wealth that allowed him to compose at leisure. But while he didn’t suffer the financial woes and chaos that often plague artistic careers, what he described as his “wretched, uneasy and violent brain” led him to write melancholy, tortured music.

headline: Digging Deeply Into Beethoven in Head and Heart
text: Recording the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas is an unusual way for a young artist to make a debut on a major record label, but EMI Classics is taking a chance with the distinctive 24-year-old Korean H J Lim. Ms. Lim, who performed the complete cycle in Paris over eight consecutive days in 2010, offered two sonatas — No. 29 in B flat (Op. 106, “Hammerklavier”) and No. 30 in E (Op. 109) — in her American debut on Thursday evening, for a small audience at Le Poisson Rouge.

headline: When Pain From the Past Is a Script for the Present
text: The “Two Alike” in the show of that title that opened at the Kitchen on Thursday are presumably the choreographer Jack Ferver and the visual artist Marc Swanson. Mr. Ferver has the stage to himself for all of this 40-minute production. Mr. Swanson designed the remarkable set, a construction of mirrors and thin wooden pillars that stands in for multiple places but most of all for a dance studio, a home for Mr. Ferver’s imaginings.

headline: Letting Jazz Have a Turn Interpreting the Poets
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center did something really self-assured last week. It presented two major large-ensemble pieces by members of its orchestra, neither very well known as composers, for a three-night run at the Rose Theater: “God’s Trombones,” by the trombonist Chris Crenshaw, and “Inferno,” by the saxophonist Sherman Irby.

headline: I’ll Have Another Arrives in New York
text: I’ll Have Another, who is set to compete in the Belmont Stakes on June 9 to try to become the first Triple Crown winner since Affirmed in 1978, arrived in Barn 9 at Belmont Park at 2:53 p.m. on Sunday after vanning in from Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.

headline: D’Oh!
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE— We haven’t seen Ian Livengood since February (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but I, for one, welcome him back. I like Mr. Livengood’s puzzles, and today’s offering is oh-so-smooth. Just the thing for a Monday.

headline: Would Departed Fido Want to Leash Up Again? Ask Him
text: Surprisingly, it’s possible to take “I Cloned My Pet 2” seriously for almost its entire length. Right up until the moment when one pet owner consults a medium to find out her dead dog’s opinion on whether she should clone him.

headline: At Network TV’s Gathering, Web Is Central
text: TWO media rituals took place in New York City last week: the television upfront presentations and the city-sponsored celebration of all things digital, Internet Week.

headline: Dance and Flower Power Abloom in New Jersey
text: Were there any artificial flowers left in New Jersey after the weekend? Thousands of people arrived garlanded and festooned with plastic blossoms to match the name of the new electronic dance music festival in town, Electric Daisy Carnival New York. Well, not quite in town; it took place Friday through Sunday at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: At Cannes, Love Beset by Age and by Faith
text: CANNES, France — By Sunday morning the 65th Cannes Film Festival had its first masterwork and an overwhelming critical favorite in Michael Haneke’s “Amour.” A tender, wrenching, impeccably directed story of love and death, the French-language film stars Emmanuelle Riva and Jean-Louis Trintignant as a Parisian couple in their 80s — named Georges and Anne, as are most of Mr. Haneke’s middle-class couples — struggling with an increasingly debilitating illness and the specter of what comes next. One day over breakfast she suffers a frightening episode that leaves her briefly locked in a mute, seemingly unaware blankness. She’s there, but not, and then just as suddenly she returns.

headline: Protesters and Police Clash at NATO Meeting; 2 Held on Terrorism Charges
text: CHICAGO — Protesters at the NATO summit meeting clashed with the Chicago police late Sunday as officers tried to disperse thousands of people who had gathered several blocks from the site of the meeting and refused demands to leave.

headline: The Mechanics of Loving and Grieving
text: Peter Carey has said that he worked backward to create his latest novel, “The Chemistry of Tears.” He assembled an inventory of seemingly unrelated elements that intrigued him, then found ways of stitching them together. On top of it all, he added an eerie sensuality: “I would rather scrub your bones and place them in the open air, scrub your sternum, labor at your spine, scrub and scrub, with love, each vertebra, as particular as a nose, and lay you in the grass amongst the bluebells.” That heady blend of sex and death is almost enough to keep the seams from showing.

headline: Trouble in Rhode Island for Boston Baseball Hero Trying Out a New Game
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Curt Schilling is a hero to Boston Red Sox fans who remember him pitching valiantly against the Yankees in the 2004 American League Championship Series with an injured ankle and a bloody sock. But a strange chain of events last week left some Rhode Islanders feeling differently.

headline: James Hits Help Button, and Wade Answers
text: INDIANAPOLIS — For six consecutive quarters, fate was not only fickle to LeBron James, it was downright infuriating. James, the self-proclaimed King, had joined Dwyane Wade in Miami during the summer of 2010 to have a co-star worthy of his royal presence, but Wade was missing in action when James needed him most — in the absence of the injured Chris Bosh.

headline: A Lead With a 24-Trick Difference
text: Last month we looked at two deals in which the opening lead made a large difference in the number of tricks won.

headline: Footnote
text: The New York City Ballet will announce its 2012-13 season at Lincoln Center on Monday. Highlights will include three music festivals conceived to celebrate the works of Stravinsky, Tchaikovsky and the 25th anniversary of the company’s 1988 American Music Festival. The season, to begin on Sept. 18, will also include world premiere collaborations between the company’s ballet master in chief, Peter Martins, and the French composer Marc-André Dalbavie; and the choreographer Justin Peck and the songwriter Sufjan Stevens.

headline: Palestinians Sign Deal to Set Up Elections
text: JERUSALEM — The rival Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed an agreement late Sunday in Cairo that paves the way for elections and a new unity government for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, officials said.

headline: Median Compensation for Public College Heads Grew 3% in 2010-11
text: Three chief executives of public colleges earned more than $1 million in total compensation during the 2010-11 academic year, according to a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

headline: Robin Gibb of the Bee Gees Dies of Cancer at 62
text: Robin Gibb, one of the three singing brothers of the Bee Gees, the long-running Anglo-Australian pop group whose chirping falsettos and hook-laden disco hits like “Jive Talkin” and “You Should Be Dancing” shot them to worldwide fame in the 1970s, died on Sunday. He was 62.

headline: Micah True’s Journey
text: The man who became known as Caballo Blanco took a long, fascinating path from a furniture mover and boxer in Colorado to an ultrarunner in the canyons of Mexico.

headline: Electric Daisy Carnival
text: Scenes from the dance musical festival.

headline: Three Giselles
text: American Ballet Theater presented the three most internationally admired interpreters of the title role of “Giselle.”

headline: Klinsmann Fills Out U.S. Roster With 11 Picks
text: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann on Sunday invited 11 more players to the United States national team camp as the team prepares for three friendlies and its first two World Cup qualifiers. By the end of the week, all 27 players invited — the 16 named last week and the 11 added on Sunday — will be in training in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Robin Gibb, a Bee Gee With a Taciturn Manner, Dies at 62
text: Robin Gibb, one of the three singing brothers of the Bee Gees, the long-running Anglo-Australian pop group whose chirping falsettos and hook-laden disco hits like “Jive Talkin’ ” and “You Should Be Dancing” shot them to worldwide fame in the 1970s, died on Sunday in London. He was 62 and lived in Thame, Oxfordshire, England.

headline: Caballo Blanco’s Last Run: The Micah True Story
text: GILA HOT SPRINGS, N.M. — Micah True went off alone on a Tuesday morning to run through the rugged trails of the Gila Wilderness, and now it was already Saturday and he had not been seen again.

headline: Fatal Bombing at Italian School Is Thought to Be the Work of One
text: BRINDISI, Italy — An official investigating a bomb blast in front of a vocational school here that killed a 16-year-old student and injured five others said on Sunday that investigators suspected the explosion was an “individual act.”

headline: Maturing as Publisher and Platform
text: It sounds like the setup for a very old, stale joke. Three guys walked into a bar in Brooklyn to complain about the state of journalism ... except by the time these guys were done chatting and plotting, they had come up with an actual business.

headline: Liberals Call for Cuomo to Champion Higher Wage
text: ALBANY — As legislation to raise New York State’s minimum wage faces strong opposition in the Republican-controlled Senate, several liberal advocates and lawmakers are calling on Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to work more assertively for its passage, urging him to do more to help the poor and address income inequality.

headline: More Earners at Extremes in New York Than in U.S.
text: The wealthiest 1 percent of New York City residents took in nearly one-third of the personal income in the city in 2009 — almost double the comparable proportion nationwide, a new study shows.

headline: Doctors Seek New Approach for Jailed Addicts
text: A group of prominent addiction doctors has mounted a quiet legal campaign on behalf of Cameron Douglas, the troubled son of the actor Michael Douglas, in hopes of finding a sympathetic ear for their view that drug addiction is best handled with more treatment, not more prison time.

headline: Surrogate for Obama Denounces Anti-Romney Ad
text: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, a prominent Democrat enlisted as a surrogate for President Obama’s campaign, sharply criticized it on Sunday for attacking Mitt Romney’s work at the private equity firm Bain Capital.

headline: Magazines Catching Eyes, and Clicks
text: Who knew there could be so much controversy left in the subject of breast-feeding?

headline: Fourth-Quarter Problems Leave Lakers Frustrated
text: LOS ANGELES — The hour was late, the arena had emptied and Kobe Bryant’s roar had been reduced to a low murmur.

headline: From a Facebook Founder Comes a Way to Streamline Work Flow
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook’s success has spawned a multimillion-dollar boom in social networking. There are networks for photo-sharers, for children and for workers inside companies. Yammer and Jive, for instance, promise to energize employees and increase their productivity by enabling fast information sharing.

headline: Ultra-Orthodox Jews Rally to Discuss Risks of Internet
text: It was an incongruous sight for a baseball stadium: tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jewish men, all dressed in black suits and white shirts, filing through the gates of Citi Field on Sunday, wearing not blue-and-orange Mets caps but tall, big-brim black hats.

headline: Agency Aims to Curb Rules by Lame-Duck Presidents
text: WASHINGTON — It is a political tradition that is almost as old as the White House: a president on the way out, unconstrained by electoral considerations, fast-tracks a flurry of contentious regulations in the waning hours of his term, sometimes even cutting short review from industry or the public.

headline: Coyotes Blank Kings on Road and Take First Step Out of an 0-3 Series Hole
text: LOS ANGELES — If the Phoenix Coyotes succeed in winning four consecutive games to reach their first Stanley Cup finals, they could look back to a rare power-play goal as the start of that seemingly improbable task.

headline: Crowdfunding Fertility Treatments
text: In vitro fertilization (I.V.F.) and adopting a child are expensive ventures. They’re also dreams that many people can sympathize with — when someone tells a friend, or even a stranger, “we’re trying to have a baby” or “we’re trying to adopt,” people often just want to help. Crowdfunding — putting your hopes on a Web site that allows others to donate money to their realization — is the latest way to make that possible.

headline: Waiting for Health Care
text: The filmmaker Peter Nicks goes behind the doors of an American public hospital struggling to care for a community of largely uninsured patients.

headline: Waiting for Health Care

headline: Clash of the Theme Parks
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Pull down your lap bars: Universal Studios, the theme park chain now controlled by Comcast, is rolling out new weapons in its battle against Walt Disney Parks and Resorts — and Disney is fortifying its defenses.

headline: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Stephane Matteau
text: The goal that Stephane Matteau scored against Martin Brodeur in the second overtime of Game 7 of the 1994 Eastern Conference finals is the most famous in Rangers history, and one of the most momentous in 120 years of Stanley Cup play. Today, Matteau, 42, is an assistant coach with the Blainville-Boisbriand Armada in the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League, but he still gets emotional recalling what happened at Madison Square Garden 18 years ago.

headline: A Fight About Beef: Why to Avoid ‘Pink Slime’

headline: Lottery Numbers
Taking Aim at Triple Crown, and Not Wasting Much Time
text: The Big Horse is already here. I’ll Have Another pulled into Belmont Park at 2:53 p.m. Eastern on Sunday and took up residence in Barn 9. The plan for him the next three weeks is to become acclimated to one of the most idiosyncratic racetracks in the world.

headline: Westward, Ho!
text: May 1862 found the Union fighting ferociously on two fronts, but it still had time for nonmilitary matters. Indeed, that month the Senate approved, and President Lincoln signed, a bill that would help define the course of American expansion after the war ended: the Homestead Act, which gave away vast tracts of western land for practically nothing, to anyone willing to settle and cultivate it.

headline: With Every Homer, Dunn’s Nightmarish 2011 Fades Into Past
text: CHICAGO — White Sox designated hitter Adam Dunn stepped to the plate last Monday against Drew Smyly of the Detroit Tigers and did what he does best: he turned on a fastball and sent a majestic fly ball over the fence and deep into the Midwestern night.

headline: Down to One Hospital, Rockaway Braces for Summer Crowds
text: Summer is coming to the Rockaway Peninsula, the thin strip of land lapped on either side by Jamaica Bay and the Atlantic Ocean. And with the warmth will come the usual hordes who play and bask on its beaches, and, inevitably, suffer heatstroke, volleyball sprains, beach glass lacerations and near-drownings — the sorts of seaside scrapes that send people to the emergency room every season.

headline: Munoz Wins Sybase Match Play After Controversies in Semifinal
text: GLADSTONE, N.J. — From a Q rating standpoint, Azahara Munoz’s 2-and-1 victory over Candie Kung to win the Sybase Match Play Championship on Sunday barely registered.

headline: Entitlement Reform For the Entitled
text: Philadelphia

headline: More Men Enter Fields Dominated by Women
text: HOUSTON — Wearing brick-red scrubs and chatting in Spanish, Miguel Alquicira settled a tiny girl into an adult-size dental chair and soothed her through a set of X-rays. Then he ushered the dentist, a woman, into the room and stayed on to serve as interpreter.

headline: Pink-Collar Opportunities
text: Men are moving into jobs traditionally dominated by women.

headline: Donning the 'Pink Collar'
text: A New York Times analysis finds that more and more men are starting to see the many benefits of jobs long-dominated by women.

headline: Such a Tradition of Humor, and This Is Only a Revue?
text: Every Jewish mother will die, a fact many are not exactly famous for playing down, but the Jewish-mother joke will live forever.

headline: A Stranger in Beckett Land
text: We are all embarked upon a strange, aimless journey from nowhere to nowhere — or to put it a bit more cheerily, from somewhere to somewhere else — according to the friendly sojourner in Will Eno’s “Title and Deed,” a haunting and often fiercely funny meditation on life as a state of permanent exile, performed by the marvelous Irish actor Conor Lovett.

headline: Deal Expands Chinese Influence on Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES — The Wanda Group, a Chinese conglomerate with extensive interests in the entertainment business, has agreed to acquire AMC Entertainment, North America’s second-largest movie theater owner, in a deal that is valued at $2.6 billion, including roughly $2 billion in assumed debt, the companies said Sunday.

headline: To an Artist, It Was a Tribute to New York; to the Police, It Was a Fake Bomb
text: The artist intended it to be a display of his love for the city: white plastic bags stamped with the “I ♥ NY” logo lighted from within and glowing moonlike from lampposts and trees in Brooklyn and beyond. Almost immediately, the installation attracted attention, though probably not the kind the artist, Takeshi Miyakawa, expected.

headline: Old Soul’s Hard Work Turns Into Big Opportunity
text: EASLEY, S.C. — Since he was in seventh grade, Louie Alexander has received mail inviting him to apply to costly summer study programs for the gifted, but he long ago stopped asking his parents if he could.

headline: Former Colombian Hostage Is Suspected of Helping Plan His Kidnapping
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The expression of overwhelming emotion on the face of Sigifredo López, freed after almost seven years as a hostage and about to clutch his two sons in a fierce embrace, is one of the most enduring images of Colombia’s nearly five-decade guerrilla war. That made the shock even greater for many Colombians last week when Mr. López was arrested on suspicion of helping to carry out the kidnapping in which he and 11 other provincial lawmakers were seized a decade ago.

headline: Buy Alcohol on Sunday? Connecticut Now Allows It
text: WOODBURY, Conn. — The end of one era and the beginning of a new one fell on Connecticut at precisely 10 a.m. on Sunday. And whether you bemoaned the one or celebrated the other was dictated by how you viewed the expiration of a longstanding law that had prohibited the sale of alcohol on Sundays.

headline: Yahoo Will Sell a Stake in Alibaba
text: Yahoo’s directors unanimously approved a deal on Sunday to sell about half of its 40 percent stake in the Alibaba Group back to the Chinese Internet company, concluding years of efforts by the two to reach an agreement.

headline: Small Business Owners Share Their New Plans
text: Entrepreneurs share their plans for new ventures with potential investors, employees and customers in the Make Your Pitch contest.

headline: Libyan’s Death Brings Up Debate Over His Release
text: LONDON — More than 23 years after an explosion plunged Pan Am Flight 103 to the earth over the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, the death on Sunday of the only man convicted in the bombing was marked as the attack always has been: with controversy over who was ultimately responsible, and whether Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi was among them.

headline: The Right to Record
text: The Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department took an important stand last week, declaring that citizens have a First Amendment right to videotape the actions of police officers in public places and that seizure or destruction of such recordings violates constitutional rights.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg’s 911 Call
text: New York’s blizzard of 2010 revealed serious weaknesses in the city’s 911 emergency dispatch system. With separate telephone facilities for police, fire and ambulances, many callers had to speak to two or three different operators. There were delays and mistakes and at one point 1,000 callers were urgently waiting for help.

headline: Will Disney’s Swampy Gator Be the Next Angry Birds?
text: LOS ANGELES — Will Swampy sink or swim in the Disney big leagues?

headline: What Price Glory? Glad You Asked
text: The 2012 London Games mark the 20th anniversary of my first Olympics.

headline: Esquire to Publish E-Books Devoted to Men’s Fiction
text: That creaky label “women’s fiction” tends to conjure up images of novels about family, career or relationships. But men’s fiction?

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Let Strategists Off the Leash
text: The intensifying flood of uncapped donations to outside political groups is transforming not just campaigns but the entire business of politics.

headline: International Agency Will Try to Resume Talks With Iran on Nuclear Program
text: On Monday, top officials from the International Atomic Energy Agency are to meet in Tehran with senior representatives of the Iranian government. The aim is to resume talks begun last week in Vienna on the proposed inspection of a building that the agency suspects Iran used in testing explosives that can trigger a nuclear blast. Iran denies the charge, and so far has given the inspectors no access.

headline: Candidate, Philanderer and Juggler, Too: Edwards Trial Shows Deception’s Strains
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — John Edwards ran for president in 2008 vowing to bridge the two Americas, the rich one and the poor one. There were two John Edwardses as well: a candidate and a lover so enthralled with his mistress that he could not stop the affair even when his top aides told him it would ruin his political career.

headline: Professor Makes the Case That Google Is a Publisher
text: IS Google search an intermediary like the phone company — simply connecting people with the information they seek? Or is Google search a publisher, like a newspaper, which provides only the information that it sees fit and is protected by the First Amendment?

headline: A New Attack on Alzheimer’s
text: The Obama administration has announced a bold research program to test whether a drug can prevent the onset of Alzheimer’s disease well before any symptoms appear. It is a long shot, but the payoff could be huge.

headline: Lawn Care Anonymous
text: I resent my lawn. It grows in the night. Right now, it’s deep enough to hide a rabbit. I’ve thought about cutting paths through it, letting the rest of it grow wild.

headline: Photo Replay: May 20
text: A look at the day in sports, from tennis in Rome to the Portuguese Cup soccer final.

headline: Dimon’s Déjà Vu Debacle
text: Sometimes it’s hard to explain why we need strong financial regulation — especially in an era saturated with pro-business, pro-market propaganda. So we should always be grateful when someone makes the case for regulation more compelling and easier to understand. And this week, that means offering a special shout-out to two men: Jamie Dimon and Mitt Romney.

headline: In China, Fear at the Top
text: IN the heyday of the Soviet era, Communist leaders were described by the dissident Yugoslav theorist Milovan Djilas as the “New Class,” whose power lay not in ownership of wealth but in control of it: all the property of the state was at their beck and call. There was the apocryphal but appropriate story of Brezhnev’s showing his humble mother around his historic office, his magnificent collection of foreign luxury cars and his palatial dacha with its superb meals, and asking for her impressions — to which she replied: “It’s wonderful, Leonid, but what happens if the Bolsheviks come back?”

headline: Rajat Gupta, Corporate Wise Man, Set for Trial in Insider Case
text: Movie stars, government leaders and professional athletes converged on Lincoln Center last month to celebrate Time magazine’s list of the world’s 100 most influential people. Seated at a table with the television host Matt Lauer and the actress Claire Danes was the prosecutor Preet Bharara, honored for his crusade against Wall Street corruption.

headline: Travel on the Trail With Distinct Purposes
text: In a presidential campaign, there are two kinds of travel: money and swing.

headline: PGA Tour Moves Slowly to Speed the Pace of Play
text: Kevin Na has heard the whispers and the jokes. It began before his waggles, whiffs and failure to pull the trigger earned him a bad time in the third round of the Players Championship.

headline: Outside Spending Turns From Presidential Race to Congressional Contests
text: Millions of dollars in outside money began pouring into Congressional contests around the country in April, while spending by presidential “super PACs” dropped off, according to records filed with the Federal Election Commission on Sunday and other data.

headline: For an Ethiopia in Transition, Guarded Hope for Freer Journalism
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — On a beautiful morning in late March, Alemtsehay Meketie rushed up the hill to the United Nations Conference Center in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia’s capital. Ms. Meketie, a 32-year-old reporter for the Ethiopian News Agency, was running late for the minister’s opening speech at the 21st annual meeting of the Ethiopian Statistical Association.

headline: Egypt’s Choice
text: Egypt’s once-opaque politics are a rich public spectacle, bubbling with talk of candidates, their missteps and their plans.

headline: In Streets and Online, Campaign Fever in Egypt
text: CAIRO — “Good morning! Who are you going to vote for?”

headline: A Female President Demands Equal Rights for Africa’s Gays
text: ACCRA, Ghana — The endorsement of marriage rights for same-sex couples by Barack Obama, the African-descended president of the United States, has struck some observers as a political calculation, others as courageous and some here in Africa as outrageous.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be reported this week will include: Existing home sales for April (Tuesday); new home sales for April (Wednesday); durable goods orders for April and weekly unemployment claims (Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for May (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

text: Accounts

headline: Leader’s Fall in China Put Allies in Peril
text: CHONGQING, China — Early this year, as a crisis unfolded in the chambers of power here, three men flew into this fog-wreathed riverside metropolis within a day or two of one another. They were members of the inner court of Bo Xilai, the Communist Party aristocrat who ran the city, and they had come to repair a rupture between the strong-willed Mr. Bo and his equally driven police chief.

headline: Obama on the High Wire
text: Is the Democratic party the tribune of the underdog or the slave of special interests?

headline: Is Segregation Back in U.S. Public Schools?
text: Jim Crow is dead, segregation lives on. Is it time to bring back busing?

headline: Diabetes on the Rise Among Teenagers
text: Nearly one in four American adolescents may be on the verge of developing Type 2 diabetes or could already be diabetic, representing a sharp increase in the disease’s prevalence among children ages 12 to 19 since a decade ago, when it was estimated that fewer than one in 10 were at risk for or had diabetes, according to a new study.

headline: Next Wave Festival Plans Announced
text: The American premiere of the final work by the choreographer Pina Bausch will be among the highlights of the 2012 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, organizers have announced. Titled “… como el musguito en la piedra, ay si, si, si…” (Like moss on a stone), the piece is based on the experience of Ms. Bausch and her company in Santiago, Chile. Ms. Bausch was 68 when she died in Germany in 2009.

headline: Stitching Lingerie Improves Women’s Lives in South India
text: S. Subhashini’s name means “she who speaks well.” However, the 25-year-old woman, who is from the Tiruvannamalai district of Tamil Nadu, has not been able to hear or speak from birth.

headline: Readers Offer Theories on Sitting vs. Standing

headline: What Would Your Fantasy Road Trip Be Like?

Where did you go and what made it so successful? If you were planning a fantasy road trip, in or out of the United States, where, when and with whom would you go, and what would you do along the way?

headline: North Korea Urged to Back Down on Nuclear Test
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Senior American, Japanese and South Korean diplomats warned on Monday that North Korea would face more sanctions if it conducted a nuclear test after its failed rocket launching last month. But, in their first meeting since the launching, they also urged the North to back down.

headline: For India and Brazil, a Rare Tie-up in Cinema
text: RIO DE JANEIRO – After challenging the Bollywood establishment by making provocative independent cinema, the Indian director Anurag Kashyap is now breaking another barrier — geography. In his support of emerging filmmakers, he has agreed to co-produce a film with Beatriz Seigner of Brazil, his first collaboration with a South American.

headline: Qaeda Link Seen in Deadly Blast in Yemen Capital
text: WASHINGTON — A huge suicide bombing in the heart of Yemen’s capital Monday morning left hundreds dead and wounded, stunning the country’s beleaguered government and delivering a stark setback to the American counterterrorism campaign against Al Qaeda’s regional franchise, which has repeatedly tried to plant bombs on United States-bound jetliners.

headline: SAT Scores Invalidated Because Proctors Were ‘Inattentive,’ Report Finds
text: On June 16, in a week when many high schools are holding graduations, nearly 200 students will have to return to a Brooklyn school to re-take the SAT because their scores were invalidated.

headline: Control
text: In the summer of 2011 the writer DW Gibson set out across the country to speak with Americans who had lost their jobs. The following account is adapted from Mr. Gibson’s July 12, 2011, interview with Dominick Brocato of Kansas City, who had been fired nearly two years before from his position with DST Systems, where he had worked successfully for 20 years. The full interview, and more than 70 others, are collected in the forthcoming book and documentary film “Not Working.”

headline: U.N. Nuclear Monitor Meets Leading Iranians

The timing of the meeting suggested that both sides could have news ahead of negotiations scheduled for Wednesday between Iran and the world powers over Iran’s disputed uranium enrichment.

headline: Europe Weighs Antitrust Case Against Google, Urging Search Changes
text: BRUSSELS — Google may have abused its dominance in Internet search by promoting its own businesses at the expense of competitors, the European Commission said Monday. It warned the company to propose changes in “a matter of weeks” to its method of answering user queries, or possibly face an antitrust lawsuit.

headline: Conflict Rooted in Syria Spreads to Lebanon’s Capital
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Gun battles between Lebanese factions supporting and opposing the Syrian government spread to Beirut on Monday in the most serious outbreak of violence in Lebanon since the Syrian uprising began, leaving several people dead and the country more tense than ever in its effort to avoid the conflict next door.

headline: Popping the Cap on Arctic Methane
text: Methane held underground by caps of Arctic ice is bubbling out as a warming climate causes those caps to melt, researchers report in the journal Nature Geoscience.

headline: A River Runs Through It
text: KOLKATA, India — India is embarking on an expensive last-ditch attempt to restore the heavily polluted Ganges River basin, home to 400 million people. The cleanup will take decades and cost tens of billions of dollars. The World Bank, which has already ponied up $1 billion in loans and grants, classifies it as “high” risk.

headline: Daily Report: A Facebook Founder’s Next Venture
text: In Monday’s New York Times, Quentin Hardy tells the story of Dustin Moskovitz, who helped found Facebook along with Mark Zuckerberg, Eduardo Saverin and Chris Hughes while at Harvard in 2004. His job was to make sure the computers straining to run Facebook’s expanding network never went down.

headline: Formula One Said to Seek $3 Billion in Singapore I.P.O.
text: The Formula One Group is aiming to raise up to $3 billion through a Singapore stock market listing, and the company will begin preliminary presentations of the deal on Tuesday to fund managers and other big institutional investors, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Greece’s Would-Be Savior Launches Charm Offensive

headline: Snow Days in June? Check Your Local Listings
text: Note to public school parents: Adjust your calendars. Though the rains keep coming this spring, the winter was a mild one, and in many schools, two snow days that were never used are being given back to students at the end of June. But there's a catch: after having those two days off, students must come back to school for a half-day of classes, for one final counting of attendance.

headline: Reforming Stop-and-Frisk by Adding More Stops
text: The unpleasant controversy over the police program commonly referred to as stop-and-frisk has disintegrated into a struggle among absolutists. (We’re not talking here about vodka drinkers.)

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Competing on Disney’s Turf, and to Catch a Straying Eye
text: There has been a recent spate of provocative magazine covers, Christine Haughney writes: a mother breast-feeding her 3-year-old son at Time; Newsweek crowning Barack Obama with a rainbow halo and the title “The First Gay President”; and, a little while back, Bloomberg Businessweek, showing two airplanes mating. The covers reflect a new goal for the magazines; with newsstand sales down, she writes, the purpose is as much to trigger attention online as off-line.

headline: ‘Skyfall': Word Association With James Bond
text: You know, folks, we’ve had some fun in recent months at the expense of the new James Bond movie, “Skyfall.” (Yes, “Skyfall.”) But with all credit to that film’s creators and its director, Sam Mendes, it appears that Agent 007 is just as dumbfounded by the title, if this free-association teaser trailer for the movie (which will be released Nov. 9) is any indication. (Also, Bond hearing the word “agent” and responding with “provocateur” is a nice touch.)

headline: Dear Belt Parkway: A Brooklyn Tale of Woe
text: Dear Belt Parkway (a Brooklyn tale of woe, with a soupçon of Staten Island thrown in for good measure), I despise you, Belt Parkway. You are just miles and miles of miserable tie-ups, never-ending construction, and gut-wrenching “signs” (both literal and figurative), that are, to put it mildly, less than truthful.

headline: Eaton Corp. to Buy Cooper Industries for $11.8 Billion
text: The power management provider Eaton Corporation said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Cooper Industries for $11.8 billion in a deal that would allow the companies to form a global electricity business.

headline: Monday Reading: Seven Tips for Saving on Rental Cars

headline: Lillian Jacobs, Mainstay of East 84th St., Dies at 102

headline: Putin Announces New Russian Cabinet
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin replaced all but a handful of Russia’s cabinet of ministers on Monday, in a long-awaited step that nonetheless held out little chance the new government would push through major political or economic change.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Surveillance Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a case concerning the government’s use of electronic surveillance to monitor the international communications of people suspected of having ties to terrorist groups. The court also issued three decisions, including one denying Social Security benefits to children who were conceived through artificial insemination after their father’s death.

headline: To Help Africa, First Understand It
text: PARIS — On my first trip to Uganda, in 1968 after a year of covering Congolese mayhem, a soldier guarding the Parliament smiled pleasantly as I passed. A gleaming sword rested on an epaulette of his sky blue tunic.

headline: White House Opposes Small-Business Contracting Provision in Defense Bill
text: Among the many objections that the Obama administration has raised to the National Defense Authorization Act, a Republican bill that passed the House Friday with a broadly bipartisan margin, 299 to 120, was one that might take small-business owners by surprise: The White House opposes a section of the bill that would direct more government contracts to small companies.

headline: Frederick J. Brown, Painter of Musicians, Dies at 67

headline: On Our Radar: Group of 8 Affirms Climate Change Efforts
text: Leaders of the Group of 8 nations call for the pursuit of sustainable energy policies and for reducing carbon dioxide emissions to deal with climate change. [The Wall Street Journal]

headline: Encores! Announces New Season
text: For its 20th season City Center’s Encores! will open just as it did when the long-running revival series began in 1994: with a production of “Fiorello!”, Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick’s musical about Fiorello H. La Guardia. Press representatives for Encores! said on Monday that its production of “Fiorello!” would open on Jan. 30 and run through Feb. 3. The musical, which features a book by Jerome Weidman and George Abbott, won the Tony Award for best musical (in a tie with “The Sound of Music”) as well as the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for its original 1959 Broadway run, which starred Tom Bosley. The first Encores! revival, presented in February 1994, starred Jerry Zaks, Philip Bosco and Faith Prince and was directed by Walter Bobbie.

headline: Whatever the Method, the Spurs Just Keep Winning
text: With a 102-99 sweep-completing win over the Clippers on Sunday, the Spurs extended their franchise record 18-game winning streak en route to a seventh conference finals berth in the last 14 years. The margin of victory was the narrowest yet for the Spurs in these playoffs, but it was yet another balanced effort as artful as it was cerebral and – in what is becoming the league’s new clockwork – another win for a team looking more and more invincible.

headline: Children Not Entitled to Dead Father’s Benefits, Justices Rule
text: WASHINGTON — Children conceived with a dead father’s frozen sperm are not entitled to Social Security benefits if they were not eligible to inherit property from him under state law, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Monday.

headline: A New Zealand Star Greets U.S. Fans in Person
text: On her 22nd birthday, Kimbra sashayed onto the stage at Webster Hall, in her first bona fide concert in New York, while her band vamped on a campy movie theme. She wore a short pink party dress with poofy sleeves and her hair in bangs and a flip, a retro 1960s do. She looked doll-like, a brunette version of Alice in Wonderland from a Disney film, but showing off more leg than Alice would. And when she began her first song, “Cameo Lover,” an upbeat plea to her man for intimacy, her voice was anything but innocent.

headline: Obama Defends Attacks on Romney’s Work at Bain
text: 5:11 p.m. | Updated CHICAGO — President Obama said that he considered attacks on Mitt Romney’s experience at Bain Capital to be fair game, declaring that the former chief executive’s claims to being a strong business leader made his background at the private equity firm worthy of a serious debate.

headline: Was Cory Booker Right About the Attacks on Private Equity?
text: Cory Booker, the young, dynamic and often unpredictable mayor of Newark, got himself into hot water over the weekend by likening Republican attacks on President Obama’s former relationship with Jeremiah Wright to Democratic attacks on private equity. “This kind of stuff is nauseating to me on both sides,” he said on “Meet the Press.” “It’s nauseating to the American public.”

headline: A Second Look at Dreve.me
text: Andre Swanston of Dreve.me answers questions about his start-up

headline: The Eight Best Songs by Regina Spektor
text: Wyatt Mason, a contributing writer for the magazine whose profile of Regina Spektor appears in this week’s issue, picks eight favorite songs from Spektor’s six albums.

headline: Rutgers Webcam-Spying Defendant Is Sentenced to 30-Day Jail Term
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — A judge here sentenced Dharun Ravi to 30 days in jail on Monday for using a webcam to spy on his roommate having sex with a man, a punishment that angered prosecutors and did little to quiet the debate over using laws against hate crimes to fight antigay bias.

headline: Chrysler Recalls 68,000 Jeep Wranglers for Potential Fire Hazard
text: Chrysler announced it would recall almost 68,000 Jeep Wranglers from the 2010 model year equipped with automatic transmissions because of a fire hazard, according to a report the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: With China’s Growth Easing, Premier Calls for Stimulus
text: HONG KONG — Premier Wen Jiabao is calling for Chinese economic policies to tilt a little more toward fostering growth, official media reported on Monday, in the latest sign of concern in China about a faltering in the country’s economic expansion.

headline: Rashid F. Davis: 'No Such Thing as Too Hard'
text: Rashid F. Davis is principal of Pathways in Technology Early College High School, a new school that opened in Brooklyn with a unique six-year plan that offers students a high school diploma, as well as an associate's degree, upon graduation. "Every single day it’s a new fight," he says. "Every single day that they walk out of this building they’re tempted, and unfortunately there are many bad temptations for students. And so we push as hard as we do to counter those negative temptations."

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: NATO Agrees on Afghan Security Transition in 2013
text: CHICAGO — President Obama and the leaders of America’s NATO allies on Monday agreed to end their guiding role in the decade-long war in Afghanistan next summer, saying it is time for the Afghan people to take responsibility for their own security and for the United States-led international troops to go home.

headline: Report Says Loretta Lynn Was All of 15, Not 13, When She Married
text: There is no doubt that Loretta Lynn, the country star from a poor mining family in Kentucky, married when she was a teenager and had four children in quick succession, a story told in her autobiography and the award-winning film “Coal Miner’s Daughter.”

headline: Sobriety Tools That Fit in a Pocket
text: Medicine isn’t the only science paving new paths to sobriety. Thanks to a new mobile app from the Hazelden Foundation, alcoholics are now leaving rehab with an interactive version of the 12 Steps in their pocket.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Victor Abramson joined the Portland, Ore., office of Advanced Broadcast Solutions in a new post, national sales manager for cable television solutions. He had most recently been a regional sales manager at the Satellite Engineering Group division of TVC Communications.

headline: Longing for the Return of Dueling Pistol
text: As the Olympics has grown and modernized over the years, many events have fallen by the wayside.  While many are unmourned — does anyone miss club swinging? — others could easily return to the program. Here are the top 10 events that would be exciting to resurrect. (Hat tip to “The Complete Book of the Olympics”  and Sports Reference’s Olympics section for much of the history below.)

headline: Boozer Leaves Legacy on and Off Court
text: As the years rolled by, the outward identity of Bob Boozer changed. For the younger generations, he was a mentor for African-American youth and an active volunteer at Boys Town in his native Nebraska.

text: When I was training for a marathon a few years ago, one of my great pleasures was listening to the audio book of “Born to Run,” by Christopher McDougall, to help me stay inspired on long runs.

headline: Still Earlier Drawing by a Teenage Sendak Is Discovered

headline: Greek Pro-Euro Zone Alliance Seeks Traction for New Elections

headline: A Rally to Discuss the Internet

headline: 11 and Counting: Can I’ll Have Another Overcome Recent History?
text: I’ll Have another wasted no time in arriving to his final destination on his Triple Crown tour, Belmont Park. He will now prepare for the final leg of the Crown, which will include a mix of gallops and a couple of breezes around the huge mile-and-a-half racetrack that is Belmont Park. The Belmont Stakes will probably be the only time these 3-year-olds will be asked to race that distance.

headline: Only Connect | Doug Aitken’s ‘Song1’
text: The artist Doug Aitken likes to bring people together. His 2006 book “Broken Screen” featured conversations with 26 artists, from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas. One of his favorite mediums is “the happening,” a sort of catchall for dynamic events he produces that can entail anything from live musical performances to panel discussions to line dancing. And yet in his video work, he tends toward lonely, restless souls like the insomniac city dwellers in the 2007 video “Sleepwalkers” (see trailer, here) or the any of the solitary animals that found themselves cooped up and climbing the walls in a remote desert motel in his 2008 piece “Migration (empire).” “Song1,” which finished a two-month run at the Hirshhorn Museum yesterday, is no exception. Only in this piece, the individual characters find a connection in the notes and lyrics of the doo-wop ballad “I Only Have Eyes for You,” which Aitken calls the perfect pop song. “The gritty romanticism of the piece suggests searching or loneliness, but the song binds the characters together,” says Kerry Brougher, the Hirshhorn’s deputy director and chief curator. The video, which was projected onto the windowless exterior of the Gordon Bunshaft-designed building from dusk until midnight, had a similar effect on the local community. Most nights the National Mall is a pretty desolate place after the sun goes down. “It turned the museum inside out,” Brougher says of “Song1,” noting that some nights there would be as many as 3,000 people camped out on the museum grounds, all watching together in quiet isolation.

headline: Whitney Houston’s Final Recording Makes Its Debut

Ms. Houston, who played the mother of one of the singers, drowned in a bathtub in Beverly Hills, Calif., in February just before the Grammy Awards, at the age of 48. The film was Ms. Houston’s last major project. It will open in August.

headline: Bringing a Bach Mass Home to a Holy Setting

Choral conductors, in any case, can argue that in terms of this Mass, theories about Bach’s choruses are academic, since Bach never performed the work.

headline: Expressions of Love That Bridge Real and Ethereal Worlds
text: According to Romantic ballet, there are two worlds: the real and the supernatural. Most of the famous 19th-century ballets that we know are about that dualism: The mortal hero belongs to this life, the ethereal heroine belongs to the other one. Ballet itself, with the unnatural extremes of its academic technique (pointwork, 180-degree turnout), is better suited to depicting the otherworldly and the language of the soul.

Starting with Skywalker Ranch, the various pieces of Lucasfilm came together over the decades behind the large trees on his 6,100-acre property, invisible from the single two-lane road that snakes through the area.

headline: France: Strauss-Kahn Faces a New Investigation
text: Responding to a request from investigating judges, the prosecutor’s office in the northern city of Lille said Monday that it had opened a preliminary investigation into allegations that Dominique Strauss-Kahn sexually assaulted a woman at a Washington hotel in 2010 when he was the managing director of the International Monetary Fund. Investigators had requested this month to widen the investigation, which has already resulted in charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn of “aggravated procurement in an organized gang,” the legal term for pimping, over a prostitution ring centered in Lille. His lawyers denied the accusations. After the police review the testimonies gathered by the investigators, the prosecutor will determine whether to open a formal investigation.

headline: China: North Koreans Free Detained Fishermen
text: At least 28 Chinese fishermen who had been detained by North Korean gunmen for 13 days returned home on Monday, according to reports in the Chinese state news media. The fishermen and their three vessels arrived in the Chinese port city of Dalian on Monday morning, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported. It said 29 fishermen had been detained, but a reporter from China National Radio said Zhang Dechang, the owner of one of the boats, said the number was 28. On Sunday, the North Korean Foreign Ministry announced that all the fishermen would be freed. Chinese news media reported last week that the gunmen had initially demanded a ransom of $189,000 and then lowered it to $142,000. It is unclear if any money was paid. China is North Korea’s closest political ally.

headline: Second Acts for First Ladies
text: Ames, Iowa

headline: ABC Requires Tether for Niagara Falls Walk
text: Nik Wallenda has always acknowledged that his planned walk over Niagara Falls on a two-inch-thick steel cable would be dangerous. But he did not anticipate that it would be deemed too dangerous for network television.

headline: What Do Spoilers Spoil?
text: Over 10 percent of the comments on my “Hunger Games” column brought up the question of spoiler alerts. “Haven’t you heard of a spoiler alert?”, one exasperated reader asked. Another reader, Jim, reported that he was “trying rapidly to withdraw my forward of the article to my wife who’s in the midst of the 2nd book.” He didn’t want his wife’s experience spoiled as it would be, he assumed, if she knew how things turned out.

headline: New York Delays Primary by 2 Days
text: ALBANY — Declaring that Sept. 11 is a day for reflection, and not for politics, New York has decided to delay this year’s state and local primary election for two days.

headline: Facing Criticism, Obama Defends Ads Attacking Romney’s Record at Bain Capital
text: CHICAGO — Responding to criticism from some Democratic supporters, President Obama said Monday that attacks on Mitt Romney’s experience at Bain Capital were fair game and that Mr. Romney’s years at the helm of a private equity firm were worthy of serious debate.

headline: Late for School After a Long Journey for a Drop to Drink
text: ZINDER, Niger — Wars keep children out of school. So does sickness. But in Niger, a sun-baked land where drought occurs with alarming frequency, a major impediment to education is thirst and the long trek required to quench it.

headline: Dueling Portrayals of Former Goldman Director at Insider Trading Trial
text: “He’s not an insider trader. He never defrauded anybody. He never cheated anybody,” said a lawyer for Rajat K. Gupta, once one of America’s most prominent businessmen. “He doesn’t belong in this courtroom.”

headline: How Fast Will States Recover Peak Employment?
text: A new analysis by the forecasting firm IHS Global Insight shows which states have returned to their peak prerecession employment levels (Alaska, Texas, Louisiana, North Dakota) and offers a forecast of how soon the rest will do so.

headline: As Facebook’s Stock Struggles, Fingers Start Pointing
text: Wall Street is playing the Facebook blame game.

headline: To Tan or Not?
text: We’ve all known for years that overexposure to the ultraviolet rays in sunlight can cause skin cancer. But now there is hard evidence of the damage that tanning beds can do, especially when people are exposed young.

headline: ‘Basketball’

headline: Fund-Raising for Romney Eats Into Obama’s Edge
text: President Obama’s once-commanding fund-raising advantage is declining as major Republican donors rally for Mitt Romney, conservative “super PACs” far outpace their liberal counterparts and tax-exempt issue-advocacy groups swarm the political landscape.

headline: Helping Special Education Students, and Paying With His Career
text: There was no particular moment when Harris Lirtzman decided to blow the whistle, and so close the door on his teaching career.

headline: The Most Comma Mistakes
text: As I noted in my earlier article, rules and conventions about when to use and not to use commas are legion. But certain errors keep popping up. Here are a few of them.

headline: Their Learnable Moment
text: On Tuesday, the Senate Banking Committee is holding a hearing on reforming derivatives — not a topic one would expect to draw a lot of energy or attention. But in the wake of JPMorgan Chase’s stunning trading loss, now reportedly at $3 billion and counting, committee members need to push the regulators testifying — and each other — to explain why, four years after the financial meltdown, speculative trading in these risky instruments has not been reined in.

headline: First Steps for Manning Are Easy Ones
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — The horseshoes on Peyton Manning’s helmet have been replaced by profiles of a horse’s head. The jersey is a different shade of blue, and the scars on his neck are a painful reminder of the last 18 months. Otherwise, nothing was different Monday about Manning, the only four-time most valuable player in N.F.L. history, as he went through his first practice as a Denver Bronco — and his first since missing last season because of multiple operations on his neck.

headline: Reinstating an Old Rule Is Not a Cure for Crisis
text: Call it the Glass-Steagall myth.

headline: France to Press Germany on Euro Bonds and Other Economic Measures
text: BERLIN — When European leaders meet on Wednesday to discuss the troubles of the euro zone, France’s president will press the issue of euro bonds, his finance minister said in Berlin on Monday. Yet, while the German government has been receptive to many proposals to revive growth on the Continent, officials here said euro bonds might well be a step too far.

headline: Day of Subdued Protests Follows Night of Clashes in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — On the final day of the NATO summit meeting here, Chicago was oddly quiet. Several hundred demonstrators, a far smaller group than had marched through downtown in the days before, staged a “die in” on Monday outside the headquarters of Boeing, whose workers, like many Chicagoans, had stayed home to avoid trouble.

headline: Zuckerberg’s Property Status, Post-Marriage
text: The new Mrs. Mark Zuckerberg might not have to worry much about money, but that doesn’t mean she is automatically a billionaire.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Kodak Loses Patent Case Against Apple and RIM
text: Eastman Kodak lost a ruling in a two-year legal fight against Apple and Research in Motion over a patent for digital image-preview technology. The decision may hurt the value of assets Kodak is selling.

headline: New York Investigates Insurer Payments to Banks
text: New York State regulators are investigating whether banks received improper payments from two insurance companies that write policies for financially troubled homeowners, as part of their examination of the unusual web of business relationships between the companies.

headline: Gates Puts the Focus on Teaching
text: A few months ago, Bill Gates wrote an Op-Ed article in this newspaper objecting to New York City’s plan to make public the performance rankings of its teachers. His central point was that this kind of public shaming was hardly going to bring about better teaching.

headline: Secret Clinics Tend to Bahrain’s Wounded
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Three young men were slumped on a living room mat, groaning with pain from nuggets of birdshot lodged in a cheek, a forehead and under the lid of an eye.

headline: A Jaw-Dropping Figure Even by Ruth’s Standards
text: Babe Ruth’s first season with the Yankees, 1920, is still reverberating. He batted .376, hit 54 home runs and drove in 137 runs. Attendance at the Polo Grounds more than doubled to 1.29 million. It was the season when the future Yankees dynasty began to take shape.

headline: ‘4000 Miles’ and Its Lead Actors Win Obie Awards
text: Amy Herzog’s critically acclaimed play “4000 Miles,” about a young man reconnecting with his grandmother as he is reeling from personal losses, won the Obie award for best new American play on Monday night at an awards ceremony honoring Off Broadway theater. The lead actors in “4000 Miles,” Gabriel Ebert and Tony Award winner Mary Louise Wilson (“Grey Gardens”), also received Obies, which have been presented by The Village Voice for the last 57 years.

headline: Wrapped in a Riddle
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Hey, a puzzle paying tribute to a musical puzzle! Now that’s cool. And impressive for a debut, especially on a Tuesday.

headline: On Top of It All
text: Some crane operators who help shape Manhattan’s skyline labor far above the pavement. There is an allure to their lofty position, but there also is a danger in getting too comfortable.

headline: Public Money Finds Back Door to Private Schools
text: When the Georgia legislature passed a private school scholarship program in 2008, lawmakers promoted it as a way to give poor children the same education choices as the wealthy.

headline: San Francisco Could Be in Warriors’ Future
text: The Golden State Warriors are no different from most other teams when it comes to their financial desires. Their owners covet a better arena to make more money and increase the value of their franchise. If it means moving to another city, even one quite close by, they would be following a longtime trend in sports.

headline: E.P.A. and the Spruce Mine
text: The Environmental Protection Agency last year revoked a permit for a planned, 2,278-acre West Virginia coal mine that encapsulated everything wrong with a particularly destructive form of strip mining known as mountaintop removal. Two months ago, however, in a wrongheaded decision, a Federal District Court judge ruled that the agency had not only exceeded its authority but resorted to “magical thinking” to justify its action.

headline: L.I.R.R. Plan for East Side Needs More Time and Money
text: Creating a Long Island Rail Road link to the East Side of Manhattan will take six years longer to accomplish than originally expected and will cost nearly $2 billion more than the initial estimate, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said Monday.

headline: Obama and the New Freedom
text: In evaluating President Barack Obama’s legislative record, historically inclined commentators frequently compare his first term to the early years of Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s New Deal. When it comes to winning re-election, however, the commentators — and Obama — might learn something from the only Democrat besides F.D.R. to win multiple elections in the 20th century on reform platforms: Woodrow Wilson.

headline: How Change Happens
text: Forty years ago, corporate America was bloated, sluggish and losing ground to competitors in Japan and beyond. But then something astonishing happened. Financiers, private equity firms and bare-knuckled corporate executives initiated a series of reforms and transformations.

headline: Year After Tornado, Obama Salutes Joplin’s Power to Heal and Grow
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — The clock at Joplin High School stopped a year ago at 5:40 p.m. The class of 2011 had just graduated, and students, parents and teachers were heading home when a powerful tornado ripped through town, destroying the school, much of the city and the lives of so many on a day that was supposed to be a celebration.

headline: Celtics Surge to Grab Hold of Second Half and Series
text: BOSTON — In a series characterized by striking ebbs and flows, one constant has remained: the team that wins the third quarter wins the game. That stood true in the first four games of the Eastern Conference semifinal series between the Boston Celtics and the Philadelphia 76ers, and it was driven home again, forcefully, Monday night.

headline: The Wal-Mart Corruption Case
text: The California State Teachers’ Retirement System, the largest teachers’ retirement fund in the country and known as CalSTRS, filed an important lawsuit this month against 27 current and past executives and directors of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world’s largest employer.

headline: Comparing Major Tax-Credit Programs
text: A comparison of tax-credit scholarship programs from Arizona, Florida, Georgia and Pennsylvania.

headline: Mets Have Control of the Game, Then Drop It

headline: Republican Officials End Relationship With Adviser Tied to Ad Proposal

Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., in an advertising campaign.

text: What kind of regulation would have prevented the latest Wall Street disaster, when JPMorgan Chase lost billions of dollars?

headline: Teixeira Demoted in Lineup; Offense Still Struggles
text: There was a new batting order pinned to the Yankees’ clubhouse door on Monday afternoon, with an unfamiliar placement, seventh, for Mark Teixeira, the slugger who is battling illness and ineffectiveness.

headline: Latest Met Aria: Bad Opera News Is No News
text: Opera News, 76 years old and one of the leading classical music magazines in the country, said on Monday that it would stop reviewing the Metropolitan Opera, a policy prompted by the Met’s dissatisfaction over negative critiques.

headline: Wife of Robert Kennedy Jr. Mourned at 3rd Gathering
text: For the third time in four days, friends and relatives of Mary Richardson Kennedy gathered to mourn her, this time on Monday night at a private memorial service organized by Ms. Kennedy’s friends and the Richardson family.

headline: Campaign Balance Sheet
text: Millions of dollars raised and spent since 2011.

headline: Flurry of Fists Ends Devils’ Way

The Rangers’ Mike Rupp was being escorted off the ice, having jabbed Martin Brodeur in the chest and jaw after a whistle, sparking a volatile scrum in which 38 minutes in penalties were called.

headline: Godwinization
text: So the Heartland Institute seems to have blown itself up with its billboard equating climate change researchers to the Unabomber. Of course, anyone who believed that the right-wing”think” tank was objective in the least was a fool; but now even the fools have been put on notice.

headline: Devils Get on Scoreboard and Under Rangers’ Skin
text: NEWARK — Ilya Kovalchuk, the Devils’ big-ticket forward, had a deep-red scab bridging his nose to accompany the thick black beard he has cultivated during the Stanley Cup playoffs. A game had bubbled over Monday with ill will, but Kovalchuk shrugged his shoulders.

headline: Rough Night for Rangers’ Mourning Defenseman
text: NEWARK — Michael Del Zotto was not celebrating just after the Rangers’ victory in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals on Saturday. He was down the hall from the locker room, in a long embrace with members of his family.

headline: Released Journalist Denounces Turkish Repression
text: ISTANBUL — Ahmet Sik, a Turkish journalist and author recently released from prison, says he is working with his lawyers to prepare for June 18, his next day in court, as he fights accusations that he was part of a plot known as Ergenekon, aimed at toppling the governing Justice and Development Party.

headline: A Hobby to Many, Card Collecting Was Life’s Work for One Man
text: Baseball fans argue endlessly about the best ever to play the game, tossing around names like peanuts at a ballpark. But no one disputes that the greatest card collector was Jefferson R. Burdick.

text: Federal agents and New York police officers raided a building in Chinatown on Monday, and an official said at least 11 people were detained in an investigation into a gambling operation.

headline: Bryant Raises Bar, but Thunder Clear It Easily

headline: Alabama: Sexual Assaults Reported in Women’s Prison
text: The Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women, Alabama’s only women’s prison, is the site of sexual assault and “pervasive sexual harassment,” says a report to be released Tuesday by The Equal Justice Initiative, a nonprofit group based in Montgomery. The report says guards have impregnated at least two inmates; it describes other instances of sexual assaults by guards, in one case by a chaplain. The report also says inmates are punished for reporting sexual misconduct.

headline: A River Runs Through It
text: “India is embarking on an expensive last-ditch attempt to restore the heavily polluted Ganges River basin, home to 400 million people,” Dan Morrison writes in The New York Times. “The cleanup will take decades and cost tens of billions of dollars.”

headline: News Quiz | May 22, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Preppy Street Style in Forest Hills
text: This week, we went to Austin Street and Continental Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens. Austin Street is a hub within this quiet, residential neighborhood filled with Tudor homes and apartment buildings. It’s also home to a strip of boutiques, restaurants and bars that attracts patrons from neighboring areas like Middle Village and Jamaica. In this pocket of Queens, khakis and plaid shirts are as common as Juicy Couture sweat pants and Dooney & Bourke bags.

headline: Disquieting Days for Foreigners in China
text: A foreigner pleads guilty to raping a local woman on a capital street at night. A judge remarks in court that the man’s crime is “uncharacteristic” of the minority ethnic community to which he belongs. A police officer agrees, saying: “Well I have never come across it before.”

headline: India’s Business Leaders Praise Insider Trading Defendant Gupta
text: Scores of India’s top businessmen have submitted testimonials to the Web site Friends of Rajat, dedicated to correcting what it calls “a greatly unfair and incorrect caricature of the real Rajat Gupta” presented by the press.

headline: District Grant Contest Unveiled
text: School districts will be able to submit proposals for innovative educational programs this year to compete for federal grants of up to $25 million under a new national contest, part of the three-year-old Race to the Top program. Rules for the competition were to be announced on Tuesday by the Department of Education.

headline: Qaeda Ally Says Yemen Bomb Was Payback for Attacks
text: WASHINGTON — A huge suicide bombing in the heart of Yemen’s capital Monday left more than 100 people dead and hundreds wounded, stunning the country’s beleaguered government and delivering a stark setback to the American counterterrorism campaign against Al Qaeda’s regional franchise, which has repeatedly tried to plant bombs on United States-bound jetliners.

headline: Iran Nears Deal on Inspecting Atomic Site, U.N. Chief Says

headline: The Syria Paradox
text: It took a month of protests to depose the president of Tunisia and 18 days to remove Hosni Mubarak from power in Egypt. Libya took longer. Rebels there spent more than eight bloody months fighting Muammar el-Qaddafi before defeating him. But Syria — where protests began at roughly the same time as in Libya — remains in a vicious civil war, and the fighting seems very far from over. One reason for this is simple: Syria’s economy was designed to all but prevent a broad coalition from forming against Bashar al-Assad’s regime. This is, of course, awful news for most Syrians. But it also calls into question some Things We Thought We Knew About Revolutions — the most important being that countries with diverse economies and a growing middle class are supposed to be better at overthrowing despotic rulers than petrocracies like Libya or Iraq.

headline: Would You Consider A Nontraditional Occupation?
text: An article this week reports a growing trend of men entering fields traditionally dominated by women to take positions like registered nurse, receptionist and bank teller.

headline: Some of Her Best Friends Are White
text: Myra Greene grew up in New York, where she was used to being around people of different races. But as she embarked on her photographic career, her work and travels took her to places where she was the only African-American.

headline: Familiar Confidants Chosen for Kremlin Posts
text: MOSCOW — With the unveiling of his Kremlin cabinet on Tuesday, President Vladimir V. Putin made it clear that power would be concentrated in his hands for the next six years, and gave no quarter to opposition demands to bring new voices into the highest levels of government.

This week, I review a pitch that focuses on using adaptive and dynamic analytics to manage your digital experience. In simpler terms, it intends to help you cut through the clutter and the noise online by curating content that is relevant to you.

headline: Daily Report: Europe Weighs Antitrust Case Against Google
text: Google may have abused its dominance in Internet search by promoting its own businesses at the expense of competitors, the European Commission said Monday. It warned the company to propose changes in “a matter of weeks” to its method of answering user queries, or possibly face an antitrust lawsuit.
