headline: Does the Andhra Train Accident Confirm Trivedi’s Fears?
text: “Everybody was telling me that if you don’t increase the fares you are going to turn the railway coaches into coffins,” Dinesh Trivedi, former railways minister, told India Ink  in March, shortly after he was fired for proposing higher passenger fares in an effort to modernize and increase the safety of Indian railways.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Facebook Finger Pointing, and Stocking Up on ‘Fifty Shades’
text: Questions are suddenly being asked after Facebook’s stock dropped 11 percent on Monday from the $38-a-share price set for its initial public offering, Michael J. de la Merced, Evelyn M. Rusli and Susanne Craig report. The price, set by the lead banker in the I.P.O, Morgan Stanley, was overly optimistic, critics say; the performance of Facebook stock is expected to put a damper on other technology stock offerings planned for the next few months.

headline: Death of a Terrorist
text: Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, the only person convicted in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, died Sunday. Megrahi had been released from prison almost three years ago on humanitarian grounds, for suffering from prostate cancer.

headline: The Get | Orlebar Brown’s Photorealistic Swimsuit
text: It was after a revelatory poolside moment while on vacation with friends that the photographer Adam Brown decided to take the plunge and start a line of tailored swimsuits called Orlebar Brown. The sleek suits, a riff on classic tennis shorts, have rapidly become the beach attire of choice among aesthetically minded men who prefer flattering, trimmer trunks over the usual baggy, calf-grazing surf jams. To commemorate the company’s fifth anniversary, Orlebar Brown is introducing a collection of swim shorts all printed with iconic, summer-centric pictures culled from the archives of the Getty Images Collection. Trunks like this pair, the popular Bulldog style printed with an image by Slim Aarons, will be released in monthly editions starting on May 24. Say surf!

headline: Twitchy About Twitter

Twitter, which has over six million account holders in Pakistan and started an Urdu-language version of its home page in March, is one of the country’s most popular social networking sites.

headline: A Misunderstanding at the Starbucks Counter
text: Dear Diary: My ears did a double-take a couple of months ago when a customer at the Starbucks on Lexington and 40th ordered something called “a black guy.” The cashier repeated “black guy” to the barista, so I knew I had heard correctly. When I noticed others order this drink a day or two later, I became curious, and asked Frank, the cashier, “What’s a ‘black guy’?”

headline: Malaysian Opposition Leader Denies Protest Charges
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges relating to his involvement last month in a protest that drew thousands of demonstrators into the streets calling for free and fair elections.

headline: Facebook Falls Again in Third Day of Trading
text: 5:01 p.m. | Updated to correct closing price.

headline: Clean Energy 101
text: Ben Jervey, an energy and environment writer formerly of Good Magazine, is helping create an online energy primer for Focus the Nation, a youth-oriented group seeking to build an energy menu that works for the long haul. He sent in a “Your Dot” contribution outlining the group’s plan, for which it’s raising seed funding via Kickstarter.

headline: On Our Radar: An Energy Challenge for Gamers
text: The Navy introduces a new version of its Mmowgli online gaming project, asking players around the world to figure out how the military can best meet its energy demands while reducing its dependency on fossil fuels. Meanwhile, Senator James Inhofe, an Oklahoma Republican, has been denouncing efforts by the Pentagon to improve the military’s energy efficiency and address climate change. [TPM, WND]

headline: VTB of Russia Sees Opportunities Amid Europe’s Woes
text: LONDON — The Russian investment bank VTB Capital says it expects to gain business as its larger European rivals are forced to scale back because of stricter capital rules and regulations.

headline: Business Day Live | May 22, 2012
text: Mark Zuckerberg and marriage, Matt Cohler, one of Facebook’s early employees, on entrepreneurship, and a collision at the intersection of Wall Street and Silicon Valley.

headline: Business Day Live: Love and Finance

headline: Google Closes $12.5 Billion Deal to Buy Motorola Mobility
text: 6:26 p.m. | Updated  Adding context and analyst comment.

headline: Reading and Thinking: Links Worth Talking About
text: This week, I interviewed mothers in India by phone about the challenges of getting their children vaccinated for an upcoming post — from a seat by the green at the local college, gazing at mowed lawns and relaxing students. Here’s more reason not to take our comforts for granted:

headline: Does Dharun Ravi Feel Remorse?
text: Sorry seems to be the hardest word.

headline: Weekly Communion, With the Occasional Elbow
text: Another wintry Sunday morning at 7. And in the bifurcated building of a century-old Catholic parish called St. Joseph’s, the faithful gather. On one side of the church wall, a few congregants beseech God as they join in the celebration of Mass. And on the other side, a few men beseech God as they join in games of basketball, their shouts of “Jesus Christ!” and “Goddammit!” rising above the wheezing of the close but unseen church organ.

headline: Study: Smooth Traffic May Indicate a Sour Economy
text: As much as motorists dislike traffic, a crowded road can mean deliveries are up, fuel prices are down and vacationers are spending money. Based on this conventional thinking, a decline in congestion may be indicative of an economy in shaky health.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/22: Summer Festivals and How to Leave Tips at Hotels
text: Summer Festivals The Times’s Arts & Leisure section did a roundup of notable festivals this summer, including pop, classical, dance and theater. (The New York Times)

headline: Doctoring Up the Store-Bought Stuff
text: This week’s column and video are all about making mayonnaise from scratch. But you can also doctor up store-bought mayo with pretty good results — not as good as making it from scratch, but not bad either. My favorite technique is to stir in pungent mustard, good olive oil and a minced clove of garlic, all of which help take down the sweetness of the commercial brands.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Melt’
text: This poem, one of 11 winners for our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Molly, who is 21 years old and lives in Andover, Mass.

headline: Image of the Day: May 22
text: Rising water level in Brahmaputra River and its tributaries is destroying the rabi or secondary crop in Assam.

headline: Man, 33, Is Killed in Brooklyn Hit and Run
text: A 33-year-old man was struck and killed in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Monday night by a hit-and-run driver, the police said. The man, Amjat Barakat, was crossing 72nd Street near Seventh Avenue around 9 p.m. when a beige four-door sedan heading south on Seventh Avenue hit him and fled in an unknown direction, the police said. Mr. Barakat was pronounced dead at the scene. The police are trying to track down the driver.

headline: Leading Off: Lakers Join Magic in Off-Season Chaos
text: The only surprise in the Magic firing Coach Stan Van Gundy and parting ways with Otis Smith, the general manager, on Monday was that it took them so long. And the only surprise in the Lakers joining the Magic in the realm of off-season chaos is that it took them so long. The Magic have been heading inexorably this way ever since Van Gundy laid bare Dwight Howard’s childish machinations to get rid of him. And the Lakers’ playoff lives were over roughly three minutes after their series with Oklahoma City tipped off.

headline: Le Bernardin
text: Inside Eric Ripert and Maguy LeCoze’s four-star restaurant in Midtown.

headline: Moving Ever Forward, Like a Fish
text: ERIC RIPERT has been the executive chef of Le Bernardin for 18 years, and people sometimes ask him if he gets tired of cooking fish. Clearly these people have never eaten at Le Bernardin. No other restaurant in the city makes the simple cooking of fish (and the fish at Le Bernardin is cooked simply, when it is cooked at all) seem so ripe with opportunities for excitement.

headline: Beware of Biting Dogs (and Liability Claims)
text: Inspector Clouseau got lots of laughs when he was bitten by a mutt in a classic scene from the movie “The Pink Panther Strikes Again.” But in real life, aggressive dogs can be a big problem. Dog bite claims account for more than a third of all homeowner’s insurance liability claims paid out, according to an insurance industry group.

headline: Ethan Hawke Will Star in and Direct New Play for New Group
text: Academy Award nominee Ethan Hawke (“Training Day”) will star in and direct a new Off Broadway play next winter about the self-destruction of a hedonistic musician in 1990s New York, the New Group theater company announced Tuesday. The play, “Clive,”was written by Jonathan Marc Sherman and inspired by Brecht’s early work “Baal.” Mr. Hawke also directed Mr. Sherman’s 2007 play “Things We Want” for the New Group.

headline: An English Photographer Goes to California for Milk and Ping-Pong Balls
text: Part of the job in the photo department is looking for new — new to us, anyway — photographic talents. When the photographer Martin Parr selected Robin Maddock’s “God Forgotten Face” as one of the best photography books of 2011 and called him “one of the freshest talents in the U.K.,” we knew we had to check out Maddock’s work. “God Forgotten Face” is the result of the two years Maddock spent taking pictures in the English coastal town of Plymouth, where he has family ties. He devoted the three years before that to documenting the police raids in Hackney, East London, where he used to live. That work culminated in Maddock’s first book, “Our Kids Are Going to Hell.”

headline: Resort Report | Oscar de la Renta
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Powell Holds Back on Endorsing Obama
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: A Winning Combination
text: Red Pollard and Seabiscuit. Mario Gutierrez and I’ll Have Another. Sometimes magic exists between rider and horse where reality surpasses the imagination.

headline: Sunday in the Park with Oscar
text: The resort season sure creeps up on you. One minute you’re shifting into a spring wardrobe and the next you’re looking at Oscar de la Renta in his new showroom on Bryant Park, facing a long row of editors ready to digest clothes that are destined for stores sometime around next January.

headline: U.S. Agency Approves New Gas Line to Run Under Hudson
text: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has approved the construction of a much-debated natural gas pipeline that would run beneath the Hudson River from New Jersey into the West Village in Manhattan, connecting with Consolidated Edison’s distribution system.

headline: Let’s All Devalue Against Each Other
text: Jeremy Siegel echoes a lot of what some of us have been saying for years about the infeasibility of internal devaluation, but then argues that the answer is devaluation of the euro as a whole. Um, against whom?

headline: Marvel’s Gay Superhero to Propose
text: Northstar, the mutant superhero, made a big splash in 1992 when he declared: “I am gay.” Twenty years later the Marvel Comics hero is making news again. In issue No. 50 of “Astonishing X-Men,” on sale Wednesday, Northstar will propose to Kyle, his longtime boyfriend, and in the next issue, on sale in June, they will get married.

headline: Britain’s Blunder
text: In the nature of things, the IMF can’t go to a country not in need of a financing program and say bluntly, “Ur doing it wrong”. Nor can it easily climb down from its original endorsement of the Cameron-Osborne austerity program. But the latest consultation comes about as close as the Fund can to saying that a huge error is underway, in particular mentioning “hysteresis”, the risk that the economy’s austerity-induced weakness will inflict long-run damage.

headline: Now Showing | Prada’s “A Therapy”
text: Directed by Roman Polanski and starring Ben Kingsley and Helena Bonham Carter, Prada’s latest short film, “A Therapy,” debuted last night at the Cannes Film Festival.

headline: An India Rarely Tasted
text: POONDU KOLAMBU is not a dish to be ordered lightly. Whole garlic cloves mob a turbid brown gravy, the spoils of at least two dismembered bulbs. There is nary a vegetable in sight. It is as if garlic, sick of truckling to other ingredients, staged a coup.

headline: U.S. Ambassador to Afghanistan Will Leave Post
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The leading American diplomat in Afghanistan, Ambassador Ryan C. Crocker, will leave his post this summer for health reasons after serving here less than a year, a State Department official said Tuesday.

headline: José Mourinho Recalibrates His Ambitions
text: Goals are the lifeblood of soccer and no person in the game -– not Didier Drogba, not Lionel Messi, not Cristiano Ronaldo -– is more goal oriented than José Mourinho.

headline: Transnistrian Time-Slip
text: Earlier this month, Catherine Ashton, the European Union high representative for foreign affairs [1], applauded the resumption of freight rail traffic through eastern Moldova as “a crucial step forward for restoring confidence between the sides to the Transnistrian issue.” For many this may have been the first time they became aware of something called the “Transnistrian issue,” let alone Transnistria itself [2].

headline: Pearl Jam, Skrillex and D’Angelo to Join Jay-Z at Philadelphia Festival
text: Pearl Jam, Skrillex and D’Angelo will be among the performers to take the stage at a music festival the rapper Jay-Z is organizing in Philadelphia over the Labor Day weekend. Jay-Z will also perform. The lineup, announced on Tuesday, is heavy on hip-hop and electronic dance music.

headline: For Yankees, Few Runs but Many Questions
text: Worried yet?

headline: In Aruba, a Cool Breeze and a Loose Game
text: NOORD, Aruba – The concierges at the major Aruban hotels generally do not hesitate when a guest asks for directions. Looking for Baby Beach? Out comes the map, a few quick slashes of a pen to mark the route and off you go. Best way to Little Switzerland? Slash, slash. Heading to Yemanja, the downtown gem of a restaurant with its smoky wood-fired grill? Slash, slash, a “pass the movie theater and you’ve gone too far” reminder and you’re on your way in seconds.

headline: Parasites Can Be Good for You (Seriously)
text: “When I open up a frog, it’s literally just bursting with parasites — thousands of them, and dozens of different species,” the evolutionary biologist Pieter Johnson says.

headline: On Night ‘House’ Ends, NBC Is From Mars, ABC Is From Venus
text: Amid a phalanx of competition shows, the finale of the long-time Fox drama “House” bounced to one of its best recent ratings on Monday night — though those ratings were still nowhere near what the show scored in its glory days.

headline: More to Learn About Dolphin Whistles
text: Tara Thean, a biology major at Princeton University, writes from Sarasota Bay, Fla., where she is studying signature whistle development in wild bottlenose dolphins.

headline: High Jump World Champion Vlasic Hopes to Heal for London Games
text: Blanka Vlasic of Croatia, one of the medal favorites in the women’s high jump heading into the Olympics, revealed Monday that she could be out of the Games because of a lingering bacterial infection in her left ankle. She recently underwent surgery to clean out the area, but Vlasic still feels her entire track season could be in jeopardy.

headline: 4 Senators Propose Easing Visa Limits for Highly Skilled
text: A bipartisan group of four senators proposed on Tuesday easing visa limits for highly skilled immigrants and foreign students, a move that challenges Congressional leaders on their fixed positions on the issue of immigration during an election year.

headline: Looking for Characters? Hit the Road
text: I can see how a solo camping trip or a week of beachfront isolation might appeal to some travelers – perhaps those who spend harried days on a trading floor or teaching middle school, then come home to wrangle three young children into bed before collapsing on the couch.

headline: The Doctor’s Remedy: Biofeedback for Stress
text: Patients aren’t the only ones interested in alternative and complementary medicine. In an occasional series, Well talks to doctors around the country to find out what nontraditional medicines or therapies they sometimes recommend or use themselves.

headline: On Eve of Egyptian Vote, Crime Wave Is the Main Topic
text: CAIRO — Parts of the ring road encircling this capital are dangerous no man’s lands, unsafe to drive on, by day or night. Kidnappings and bank robberies are common around the city. And women report sexual assaults by taxi drivers, even in broad daylight.

headline: Europe’s Approach to Antitrust Could Cause Friction
text: BRUSSELS — Europe delivered Google an ultimatum on Monday: Make concessions in four areas of your business, or face formal charges for breaking our antitrust laws.

headline: British Prosecutor Acknowledges Errors in Inquiry
text: LONDON – Britain’s Serious Fraud Office acknowledged Tuesday that there were flaws in its investigation into the role of a property developer in the collapse of the Icelandic bank Kaupthing.

headline: Using a Mobile Phone to Curb Domestic Violence
text: “In India, researchers are just beginning to study the effects that the explosive growth in the mobile phone market has had on women’s lives,” Nilanjana S. Roy writes in The International Herald Tribune’s Female Factor column.

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: CVC Capital Is Said to Have Cut Its Stake in Formula One
text: The private equity firm CVC Capital, which owns a controlling stake in the company Formula One, is not taking any chances before the racing company’s proposed $3 billion initial public offering.

headline: As Men Turn to ‘Pink Collar’ Jobs, Training Is a Hurdle
text: In researching our article about men’s entry into so-called pink collar jobs, we wanted to know how much the recession had accelerated an existing trend.

headline: In Pursuit of Pleasure and Trout
text: For a committed sensualist and prototypical hippie, a man who wore floppy hats, granny glasses, love beads and a droopy mustache that made him look like General Custer at an acid test, Richard Brautigan (1935-1984) had a potent work ethic.

headline: Big Risks for Uninsured Farmers
text: The farm bill, that cyclical flashpoint, is up for reauthorization in Congress this year, and reforms are needed to help small and organic farms obtain crop insurance, the Union of Concerned Scientists argues in a new report.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: From Chile, Pablo Larraín’s ‘No’
text: CANNES, France — When the young Chilean writer Alejandro Zambra (born 1975) was asked if he ever became frustrated with how his country remains associated with the long, brutal years of the Pinochet era (1973-1990), during which thousands were either executed or disappeared, he answered, “I grew up in a dictatorship, I said my first words in a dictatorship, I read my first books in a dictatorship.” A few days after the Chilean filmmaker Pablo Larraín (born 1976) stood in a large theater here, basking in the thunderous applause that greeted “No,” his latest movie, I asked if he related to Mr. Zambra’s remarks. It wasn’t a surprise when he shrugged and said, “of course.”

headline: Sports Replay: May 22
text: The day in sports, including the Paralympic World Cup in England, the N.C.A.A. women’s tennis championship and the Giro d’Italia.

headline: Painting Stirs a Debate in South Africa
text: South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, went to court on Tuesday to try to force an art gallery in Johannesburg to remove a painting that appears to depict South Africa’s president, Jacob Zuma, with his genitals exposed.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Attacks Boomerang
text: President Obama says attacks on Bain Capital are fair game | A political advertising expert on the softer message from Crossroad GPS | A group with divided loyalties: black Mormons.

headline: Video of Settler Shooting Raises Questions Over Israeli Army Response
text: The footage of Israeli settlers appearing to open fire on Palestinians drew international attention and raised questions over the effectiveness of Israeli military forces in calming such tense situations.

headline: Stanley Fish Defends Spoilers
text: After Stanley Fish posted a column about “The Hunger Games” on The Times’s Opinionator blog, many commenters blasted him for including plot spoilers. Now Mr. Fish has responded with a post making what he calls “the positive case for spoilers.”

headline: TimesCast | Awaiting the Edwards Verdict
text: Many expected a quick "not guilty" verdict in the John Edwards case, but the jury's deliberations have stretched on for days.

headline: At Hearing, Regulators Discuss JPMorgan Investigation
text: Federal regulators shed new light on their investigations into JPMorgan Chase’s multimillion-dollar loss, telling Congress that they were examining potential wrongdoing and weighing whether the bank’s trading debacle would reshape rules for Wall Street.

headline: Red Bulls Seek 6th Straight Win
text: Wednesday’s Major League Soccer game at Red Bull Arena will be a homecoming in many flavors and sorts.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Continues Attacks on Bain With New Video
text: Faced with a handful of Democrats who have gone off message recently, President Obama’s allies on Tuesday sought to shift attention back to Mitt Romney’s critics within his own party.

headline: Lakers, Clippers Face Coaching Questions
text: In the aftermath of the Lakers and Clippers being bounced from the playoffs rather unceremoniously by the Thunder and Spurs, both teams will face questions about their coaches’ futures.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Assistant Testifies in Gupta Trial
text: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: Black Mormons and the Politics of Identity
text: SALT LAKE CITY — When Marguerite Driessen, a professor here, entered Brigham Young University in the early 1980s, she was the first black person many Mormon students had ever met, and she spent a good bit of her college time debunking stereotypes about African-Americans. Then she converted to Mormonism herself, and went on to spend a good deal of her adult life correcting assumptions about Mormons.

headline: Case Against Chairman of Banco Santander Is Dropped
text: MADRID — Spain’s national court on Tuesday closed a tax fraud investigation focusing on Emilio Botín, the chairman of Banco Santander, and 11 of his relatives.

headline: 10 Million Shades of Green: Erotic Trilogy Dominates Book Sales
text: In case there was any doubt about the blockbuster success of the “Fifty Shades of Grey” trilogy by E. L. James, the numbers are in: More than 10 million copies of the books have been sold in the United States in six weeks, the publisher said on Tuesday, putting the books among some of the best-selling series in modern publishing.

headline: Plane Diverted After Implant Claim
text: WASHINGTON — A passenger flight to Charlotte, N.C., from Paris was diverted on Tuesday to Bangor, Me., because of security concerns set off when a passenger told the crew that she had a surgically implanted device.

headline: Now You Know Who Brandon Bass Is
text: On a night when half of the team’s vaunted Big Four struggled to get going, it was the undersize, quiet power forward who provided a series tipping point for the Boston Celtics.

headline: After New York Radio Deal, Early Signs of Ratings Gains
text: Last month, the New York radio market was rocked by a three-way deal that merged two venerable R&B stations, WRKS and WBLS, and brought ESPN to the FM band. It may be too early to get a solid reading on ratings, but preliminary data suggests that the newly changed stations are enjoying better numbers.

headline: Kidnapping in Syria Fuels Unrest in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Eleven Lebanese men were kidnapped near the northern Syrian city of Aleppo on Tuesday, officials and witnesses said, the latest spillover of the conflict next door to create waves in Lebanon.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Black Mormons
text: Susan Saulny and Megan Liberman discuss black Mormons, a group with divided loyalties in the 2012 election.

headline: Justice Stevens Talks Bush v. Gore
text: In the two years since he retired from the Supreme Court, John Paul Stevens has set a new standard, or at least created a new model, for life after the bench: The lone voice crying in the wilderness, publicly challenging the faulty decisions of the institution he left behind.

headline: Religious Space for Crowded Schools: Godsend or Trouble?
text: City lawyers have been arguing for years that letting religious groups rent space in public schools for Sunday worship violates the separation of church and state and could confuse students about the schools’ secular identity. At the same time, the city has increasingly been turning to the religious establishments to rent classroom space – to relieve school overcrowding – a policy that WNYC reports is troubling  people on both sides of the church-state divide.

headline: Forming a Caucus, Republican Women Send a Message
text: 5:47 p.m. | Updated The Republican women in the House released a video on Tuesday designed to present a unified message against what they consider to be a politically manufactured “war on women.” With the support of the House leadership, all 24 of the Republican women in the chamber formed the Women’s Policy Committee, hoping to add a “new perspective on issues facing the House.”

headline: Excerpt: 'February House'
text: Kacie Sheik as Gypsy Rose Lee in "February House" at the Public Theater.

headline: Follow the Money: Understanding ‘Super PAC’ Spending in Politics
text: Overview | To what extent does the money of wealthy individuals and organizations influence electoral politics? In this lesson, students learn about how “super PACs” are influencing the 2012 presidential campaign. They then use a technique called “structured academic controversy” to debate whether or not wealthy individuals and organizations should be allowed to engage in unlimited spending to influence elections.

headline: Largest Greek Banks to Receive Financing
text: ATHENS — The Greek government will pump 18 billion euros (about $23 billion) into the country’s four largest commercial banks this week to help them guard against losses from a worsening economy, bankers in Athens said on Tuesday, a step that will improve the banks’ ability to raise money but will still leave them unable to lend money normally.

headline: Merkel Defensive Amid Fresh Calls for Bonds
text: BERLIN — The pressure for Germany to reverse its defiant course on issuing euro bonds continued to grow on Tuesday, one day before a dinner meeting of European leaders. But German officials remained adamant that there was no way they would bend on collective debt, even if the new French president, as expected, makes it a dining-room topic.

headline: More L.I.R.R. Retirees Charged in Disability Fraud
text: Ten retirees from the Long Island Rail Road were charged on Tuesday with filing fraudulent disability claims to increase their pension payouts in what prosecutors called a “massive fraud scheme.”

headline: Satellite Images Show More Work at North Korean Nuclear Site
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea warned on Tuesday that it would have to take “countermeasures” if the United States insisted on sanctions, while the latest satellite imagery of the country’s nuclear test site suggested heightened preparations for a possible underground nuclear test.

headline: Sino-Forest and Executives Charged With Fraud in Canada
text: OTTAWA — The Ontario Securities Commission on Tuesday filed charges against the Sino-Forest Corporation, a Chinese company that once traded in Toronto, and five of its former executives, saying the company had overstated its timber resources and misled investigators.

headline: Gaining Entry to That Stomping Ground
text: OFTEN the shifts in the city are talked about in terms of place. This store used to be that store, which used to be that restaurant, which was once this sweatshop: oh, how time has passed, and oh, how meaning is wrung from the vagaries of real estate.

headline: SAP Agrees to Acquire Ariba for $4.5 Billion
text: SAP, the German business software giant, has agreed to buy Ariba, a provider of cloud computing services, for $4.5 billion.

headline: Rosés for Summer, and All Year Long
text: With the Memorial Day weekend approaching, along with a deep psychological exhalation that leaves us in a more casual state of mind, my column focuses on some easygoing drinking suggestions for the warmer weather.

headline: Freaky Friday, N.B.A. Style: When the Clippers Were the Celtics
text: Cheer up, Clippers fans! It’s no disgrace to lose to the Spurs. You have a promising future with Chris Paul and Blake Griffin anchoring the team.

headline: Cuomo Picks 2 to Lead New York Democratic Party
text: ALBANY — Solidifying his control over New York Democratic politics, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Tuesday that he would seek to install a mayor from upstate and an assemblyman from New York City as the state party’s new leaders.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Release Dueling Ads
text: A former Obama aide on Tuesday criticized a new ad by a Republican “super PAC” for featuring a fictional family suffering from President Obama’s economic policies.

headline: As U.S. Retailers Retreat, a Japanese Chain Sees an Opening
text: Many American retailers are cutting back at shopping malls. Chains like Gap Inc., Abercrombie & Fitch, Coldwater Creek and Talbot’s say they have too many stores at too many malls. Hundreds of stores are on the chopping block.

headline: Philippines Chief Justice Denies Corruption Charges
text: MANILA — At times weeping on the stand, the chief justice of the Philippines, Renato C. Corona, testified on Tuesday for the first time in his impeachment trial in the Philippine Senate. He denied the corruption charges against him, challenged his accusers to disclose their own finances and then tried to walk out of the proceedings.

headline: Venture Capital Partner Claims Sexual Harassment
text: 9:35 p.m. | Updated  A partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the blue-chip Silicon Valley venture capital firm that was an early investor in Google and Amazon, is suing the firm, claiming that she faced sexual harassment and discrimination there over a six-year period.

headline: The Growing Fed
text: One part of the economy that’s growing rapidly is the Federal Reserve.

headline: Follow a Hungry Chef and See Where It Takes You
text: DANIEL BOULUD is inevitably drawn to an intense but basic roast chicken in the West Village. Missy Robbins craves East Village ramen. And for Hugue Dufour, only those pristine oysters in Grand Central Terminal will do.

headline: Ron Darling Reflects on the End of His Playing Career
text: “I think it was denial,” the former Mets pitcher Ron Darling tells Rob Trucks at Deadspin about his surprise at being released by the Oakland A’s in the summer of 1995 (on his birthday, no less). “I thought that my position on the ballclub was secure enough, despite a bad year. Who would release someone in August? I mean, how’s that going to make a difference?” Not surprisingly–because it’s Darling–it’s a thoughtful recollection. You can read the full story–part of the site’s “Tell Me When It’s Over” series–here.

headline: Sweets With a Side of Savory
text: A food-focused book club lighted the oven for Erin Patinkin and Agatha Kulaga. Ms. Patinkin, who was working for a nonprofit, and Ms. Kulaga, a psychiatry researcher, met through the club and discovered they shared entrepreneurial ambitions. So they started Ovenly, a wholesale bakery in Greenpoint, Brooklyn; building on its success over the last two years, they have added a retail store. It opens Friday, and though they turn out red velvet cakes, chocolate chip cookies (bottom photo) and carrot spice cupcakes, most of their specialties offer uncommon flavors. Black olive shortbread, blue cheese-pecan scones, coconut date pistachio coffee cake (top), and a jelly doughnut muffin are all buttery and intriguingly savory-sweet, thanks to a good pinch of salt. Even the chocolate pudding frosting on the blackout cake is salted. The shop has a few seats for those wishing to indulge on the spot, with Stumptown coffee.

headline: Britain Charts Way to Wider Nuclear Investment
text: LONDON — Britain announced plans Tuesday to finance a new generation of nuclear power plants and renewable energy facilities in a move that illustrates divergent energy policies within the European Union as it grapples with the challenge of reconciling economic and environmental objectives.

headline: Medical Costs Contribute to Credit Card Debt
text: Medical bills are a leading contributor to credit card debt, a new survey finds.

headline: The Romney Campaign Joins the Birther Brigade
text: Whenever the “birther” movement rears its head, sensible people argue that the press should just ignore it, since it’s so far out on the lunacy spectrum.

headline: Memories of Beer and a Taste
text: Having trouble keeping track of all the craft breweries in and around the city? The current surge in suds is nothing if you glance back in time. The New-York Historical Society points out that by 1898, when the five boroughs were consolidated, there were more than 100 breweries in New York, with clusters on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in Bushwick and Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Prohibition finished off most of them. But some brands, like Schaefer, Ruppert and Rheingold, linger in memory. And on Friday, the museum will open an exhibition on beer in New York that includes hundreds of artifacts like old mugs, posters and trays. One end of the ground-floor gallery will feature a beer hall, with tables, stools and a bar where more than 50 visitors at a time can buy a draft or bottled beer and a pretzel from Sigmund’s. Talks and weekly tastings from various breweries will be offered throughout the summer.

headline: Recipes and Lists at Your Fingertips
text: MORE than a decade ago, I was confronted with a crisis: planning a week’s worth of menus and writing out the accompanying shopping list were gobbling up a humongous slice of my precious weekend. It stressed me out and caused a bit of marital strife. How, my new husband would ask, could it take me that long to make a list?

headline: A Brawny Line of Tools Adds Precision to Grilling
text: If you need proof that grilling is a guy thing, just wrap your fist around the wooden handles of the substantial new spatulas and turners in the Tim Love Collection at Sur La Table. Mr. Love, a chef in Fort Worth (and briefly in New York several years ago) has put his name on a hefty spatula with a 4-by-6-inch surface that will not be daunted by a whole flank steak, and a big, sturdy but gracefully curved slotted fish turner, able to lift a striped bass fillet. Both are stainless steel with walnut handles and a leather strap, and made in the United States by Lamson & Goodnow. Finely finished, they are beveled to a knife-sharp edge, the better to release your meat or fish cleanly from the grill, or even to make a test cut for doneness.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, Pakistan, India and Florida.

headline: Education Cuts Met With Strike in Spain
text: MADRID — It was no mistake that university campuses proliferated during Spain’s decade-long, construction-led boom years. Education and health care have long been two of the most prized — and seemingly sacred — parts of the European social model favored by Spain. Even as the economic crisis has spread through Europe, Spaniards had shielded social spending in those areas from the consequences.

headline: U.S. Men’s Eight Qualifies on Final Chance
text: The United States men’s eight pulled out a victory Tuesday just when it needed one  most — on the final day of Olympic qualifying for the eight, in the final race that would give one final boat a berth at the London Games.

headline: Greek Businesses Fear Possible Return to Drachma
text: ATHENS — For the last couple of weeks, the phone at Tasos Ioannidis’s five-star hotel on the breezy island of Mykonos has been ringing steadily, but not with the types of inquiries he wants to field.

headline: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston Gets Major Gift of Photographs and Other Works
text: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston has received a bonanza from one of its longtime trustees, according to a report in The Boston Globe.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Kickstarter Report and a Singing App
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. See more here.

headline: L.B.J. Was Wrong
text: More interesting stuff from the annual scientific meeting of the American Geriatrics Society, which I attended in Seattle this month:

headline: A Genetic Cure for Tomato Rot
text: Gardeners are all too familiar with the experience. You plant a handful of shriveled sand-colored tomato seeds, urge them out of the ground with diligent tending, and then smile with self-satisfaction as the first plump fruits ripen, flush on their furry stalks.

headline: At $25 Million, a Record Sale in Miami Beach
text: A MEMBER of the family that controls the German shoe company Birkenstock has sold a triplex penthouse in the South Beach section of Miami Beach for $25 million, a record price for a Miami-area apartment, eclipsing the previous record of $21.5 million reached five months before.

headline: ‘Big Willie’ Robinson, Who Sought to Bridge Social Divides at the Dragstrip, Dies at Age 70
text: Andrew Robinson, known as “Big Willie” Robinson to a vibrant automotive subculture that melded illegal street racing and organized drags, died Saturday at age 70. The National and International Brotherhood of Street Racers, an organization founded by Mr. Robinson and his late wife, Tomiko, said Mr. Robinson had been ill in recent months but did not disclose the nature of the illness.

headline: A Hard Drive for High Security
text: When it comes to video surveillance, it’s either feast or famine. Most professional solutions depend on hard drive recorders that cost in the thousands of dollars or dinky little cameras with barely enough storage to keep an eye on a bodega for an hour.

headline: Three Dishes at Le Bernardin
text: I was just talking to a colleague at The Times who ate at Le Bernardin a few weeks ago. We started describing dishes we’d both eaten, and each of us found that we could recall the smallest details of flavor and plating. Eric Ripert’s cuisine is like that: it’s so focused, and so devoid of extraneous elements, that to recall one aspect of a dish is to call up the whole thing. On Tuesday, before my review went up online, I spoke with Mr. Ripert on the phone, and asked him to tell me what was going on in three dishes that I thought were characteristic of the restaurant’s approach.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Facebook Offering
text: To the Editor:

headline: CNN’s Shrinking Prime-Time Audience
text: CNN has not reacted much to bad ratings before, so another week of distressed numbers may not faze its management.

headline: Met Reverses Itself on Reviews Ban by Opera News
text: The Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday backed away from its decision to bar reviews of its productions in Opera News, its affiliated magazine and the leading opera publication in the country.

headline: Fête Accompli | IWC Schaffhausen in Cannes
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Disclosure by Short-Sellers Would Improve Market Clarity
text: Just a few questions during a recent conference call cost the nutritional supplements company Herbalife more than $1 billion in stock market value.

headline: Social Causes, Served Cafeteria-Style
text: It’s not every day that students are encouraged to deface school property. But on Tuesday in Union Square, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott helped a few hundred middle-school students unveil brightly colored cafeteria tables that will soon be displayed in city parks.

headline: Capturing the Essence of Cage, if Not With Jackhammers
text: “Wherever we are, what we hear is mostly noise,” the composer John Cage said in a 1937 lecture later published as “The Future of Music: Credo.” Noise, Cage contended, constituted a disturbance only when you try to ignore it: “When we listen to it, we find it fascinating.”

headline: What’s Worse Than Being a Single Mother?
text: I never thought I would be a single mother. When I got pregnant at 19, my boyfriend and I asked each other: “How are we going to tell our parents? What about money? Where will we live?” We knew raising the baby would be hard, but I thought we wanted the same things: marriage, good jobs, a nice family.

headline: The Euro Zone Crisis: A Primer
text: FRANKFURT — With the daily drumbeat of alarming news from the euro zone, it’s often hard to hear above the din. Here’s a quick chance to catch up before the shouting starts again.

headline: Whisper and Repeat. Meditate a Little, Then Just Whisper and Repeat.
text: Some music can instantly seduce with eclectic elements, whether Bach’s counterpoint and Schubert’s melodies or Steve Reich’s hypnotic energy and Georg Friedrich Haas’s soundscapes. Then there are works, including pieces by Morton Feldman, that often require substantial effort from listeners. Indeed, those who have mastered the art of lengthy meditation may be best equipped to concentrate on his glacially slow, highly repetitive sounds.

headline: Moraya & Chris
text: Moraya and Chris tell the story of how they met in college and realized after graduation that a long distance relationship wasn't for them. They decided to get married instead.

headline: Peekaboo With a Curtain and Cascading Hair
text: The title of Luciana Achugar’s latest work, which just finished a two-week run at the Abrons Arts Center, strings many words into one: “FEELingpleasuresatisfactioncelebrationholyFORM.” A much shorter one-word title would have served, but it’s been used before: “Hair.”

headline: Dangerous and Funny: She’s Still a Flapper
text: The flapper — the tough-talking party girl with bobbed hair, a spangled headband and a shocking disdain for propriety — may be an archetype associated with the 1920s. But since her ascendance, she has never really disappeared. Wearing different outfits, the British bird of the 1960s and the breakdancing b-girl of the 1980s are among countless offshoots. Let’s not forget that defiant pop shape-shifter Madonna, a flapper to her bones, no matter what she wears.

headline: Revenge in a Bowl, Served Cold
text: The Shanghai Kunqu Opera made its biggest news in New York when it failed to show up. This is the company that was to have presented Chen Shi-Zheng’s 19-hour production of “The Peony Pavilion,” the Chinese opera written by Tang Xianzu in 1598, at the Lincoln Center Festival in 1998, but Shanghai municipal authorities blocked the troupe’s departure for political reasons. When the production did appear, in 1999, with performers gathered from around China, only the star, Qian Yi, and the flutist and orchestra leader, Zhou Ming, remained from the original troupe.

headline: Time Travel via Baton, With Nary a Pit Stop
text: The English conductor Jonathan Nott is becoming less of a stranger to New York audiences, but not quickly enough. He has visited most years since 2005, usually with the Bamberg Symphony, though he has also made a strong impression conducting the Ensemble Intercontemporain and as a guest of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Navigating Personal Space: Guarded, Infringed and Shared
text: The choreographer Helen Simoneau hails from Quebec, but judging by the animated crowd at the Joyce SoHo on Friday night, she’s no stranger in the United States. In 2010 she won first prize at “The A.W.A.R.D. Show!” in New York — a dance competition hosted by the Joyce Theater Foundation — and her company, Helen Simoneau Danse, is based both in New York and Winston-Salem, N.C. At first the setting seemed more suited to a cocktail party than a dance performance. One woman asked, “How do you know Helen?”

headline: Charter School Group Reports Steady Demand for Seats
text: An estimated 133,080 applications were submitted for 14,600 available seats in this spring’s random admissions lotteries, according to the New York City Charter School Center. The Charter Center's C.E.O. says that shows city parents still want more public school options.

headline: When Coaches Fight, NBC’s McGuire Has the Best View
text: When Rangers Coach John Tortorella and Devils Coach Peter DeBoer were jawing at each other in the third period of Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals on Monday, no one had a better listening post than NBC’s Pierre McGuire. His reporting perch is conveniently located between the teams’ benches.

headline: A Guinea Pig’s Night at the Theater
text: Even when it is not executed perfectly, theater can stir a range of feelings, from boundless elation to existential despair. On rare occasions, it can even impart blinding pain, as an overly tight mask presses your glasses into your face, setting off sensitive nerve endings you did not know you possessed.

headline: Spirits That May Be Stronger Than Their Fans
text: AT Cask, a San Francisco liquor store run by the people who own that city’s high-end cocktail bars Rickhouse and Bourbon & Branch, the spirit most coveted by customers is George T. Stagg, a limited-production bourbon that can exceed 70 percent alcohol. The store’s owner, Brian Sheehy, said the waiting list for Stagg is 190 names long.

headline: Will Microsoft Benefit From the Google-Motorola Deal?
text: The news on Tuesday that Google closed its $12.5 billion deal for Motorola is welcome for both companies, which have been waiting almost a year for the acquisition to get the final green light from regulators.

headline: An Expanding Plaza Food Hall
text: With more than 20 kiosks and stalls, the Plaza Food Hall will feature a diverse array of vendors and bakeries.

headline: Surprising Guests in a Bigger Plaza Food Hall
text: THE first surprise came about two years ago, with the opening of the shiny marble- and mosaic-covered Todd English Food Hall, in the lower-level concourse of the Plaza. The somewhat daring move brought a collection of counter-style dining options and food shops to an underused area that had been home to fashion boutiques.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Governors Island Picnic

headline: ‘Idol’ Grapples With Its Own Competition
text: As Fox’s “American Idol” wraps its 11th season this week with a sing-off between Phillip Phillips and Jessica Sanchez, those involved with the show are asking what went wrong, a rare dose of soul-searching for a show that has been the runaway hit of this century.

headline: Biden Presses Bain Attack as Prominent Democrat Urges Caution
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. continued the assault on Mitt Romney’s business background on Tuesday, saying it did not qualify him to be president, even as another prominent Democrat expressed misgivings about the White House strategy.

headline: Let’s Film These Poor People; Maybe We’ll Get Rich
text: The young filmmakers in the Filipino director Marlon Rivera’s satire “The Woman in the Septic Tank” are creatures of privilege. They drive around Manila in a nice car, drink fancy coffees and fiddle with their abundant Apple products (MacBook: check; iPad: check; iPhones: got ’em).

headline: RailAmerica May Put Itself Up for Sale
text: RailAmerica, one of the largest operators of short-line railroads in the United States, said on Tuesday that it was considering strategic alternatives, including the possible sale of the company.

headline: The Shared Fate of Treece, Kan., and Geamana, Romania
text: The magazine’s recent article about Treece, a Kansas town rendered virtually uninhabitable — only two residents remain — due to mining waste and environmental degradation, evokes the fate of another spot half a world away: Geamana, in Romania. The Hungarian photographer Tamas Dezso, who since 2009 has been documenting forgotten people and places in post-Communist Eastern Europe, took this picture of Geamana in 2011.

headline: An iPod Case With a Split Personality
text: Although iPod gamers seem to love their big, grippy game covers, the love affair ends when they have to jam the bulky case in a pocket.

headline: Facebook I.P.O. Raises Regulatory Concerns
text: 9:38 p.m. | Updated

headline: Rules for Truckers
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Raw Egg Conundrum
text: I celebrate homemade mayonnaise in all its wonderful incarnations in my column this week. But nowhere in the article do I mention using cooked or pasteurized eggs to make it. And that’s simply because I’ve never tried it. When I want homemade mayonnaise, I use a raw egg.

headline: Guiding  Hundreds of Trains, a Junction Named Harold
text: For decades, a standard response to delays and disruptions on passenger trains in New York City has been to blame it on Harold.

text: Opening
