text: To the Editor:

headline: Yankees Find Themselves in Unfamiliar Spot
text: The Yankees fell into a tie for last place in the American League East on Monday, with a chance to take sole occupancy of the cellar with a loss to the Kansas City Royals on Tuesday night combined with a victory by the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Sensible Nonsense
text: Link added.

headline: Democrats Push Bill to Close Wage Gap Between Sexes
text: Democrats have enjoyed trying to keep Republicans on the defensive about women’s issues, and on Tuesday, they tried to keep the debate going by reintroducing a wage gap measure that failed in the Senate in 2010.

headline: Struggling Torres Takes a Seat
text: PITTSBURGH — Andres Torres acknowledged Tuesday that he might need to change his hitting approach in order to get out of a slump and retain his place in the Mets’ lineup.

headline: Prized Logo Is Returned to Ford
text: DETROIT — The blue oval is back home.

headline: Female Sergeant Major Claims Gender Discrimination
text: A retired command sergeant major has come forward to say that she was the victim of gender discrimination by her superiors while she was commandant of the 3rd Infantry Division’s academy for noncommissioned officers at Fort Stewart, Ga., in 2006.

headline: A Community Springs From Acres Once Held by a Reclusive Magnate
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Over the last decade this city of 60,000 invested $76 million to erase memories of the malaise that had settled over its downtown. Not long ago, Main Street was a place to avoid, a skateboarder’s paradise with little but concrete sidewalks and ratty parking lots. The grand Poinsett Hotel, built in 1925, stood vacant and was occupied by squatters.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,964 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Traffic Plan for a Brooklyn Arena Cuts Parking Slots by Half
text: The conundrum that Samuel I. Schwartz, the traffic engineering expert, faced was this: How could the already jam-packed streets in the heart of Brooklyn accommodate thousands of extra cars filled with fans traveling to a basketball arena and desperately searching for parking?

headline: Advice for Chen Guangcheng, From a Fellow Passenger
text: ON Saturday night, I returned home from a business trip in China, on a flight made extraordinary by the presence of another traveler, who was leaving his country for mine: Chen Guangcheng.

headline: Recession Possible if Impasse Persists, Budget Office Says
text: WASHINGTON — The economy could relapse into a recession if President Obama and Congress remain at an impasse and allow several big tax increases and spending cuts to take effect at the start of 2013, the Congressional Budget Office reported on Tuesday.

headline: At CUNY, Stricter Admissions Bring Ethnic Shift
text: More than a decade after the City University of New York ended open admissions to its four-year colleges, a marked shift has occurred at its top institutions as freshman classes now enter with far better academic credentials and also a different demographic mix.

headline: Different Faces at CUNY
text: The end of open admissions in 2000 and the recent recession have led to significant shifts in competitiveness and demographics at the City University of New York’s top five four-year colleges.

headline: Leader of Catholic Order Admits Knowing Priest Fathered Child
text: The head of the Legionaries of Christ, a Roman Catholic religious order, sent a letter to his members on Tuesday admitting that he had known since 2005 that his most prominent American priest, the Rev. Thomas Williams, had fathered a child. The Associated Press reported that the Rev. Alvaro Corcuera, the order’s superior in Rome, said he regretted allowing Father Williams to continue giving public lectures and television interviews on living a moral life and teaching moral theology to seminarians. The Legion is trying to recover from revelations that its founder sexually abused seminarians and fathered several children. Father Williams, whose affair became public last week, sent an e-mail to Legion members on Tuesday, apologizing for failing to heed his superior’s advice to keep a lower profile.

headline: Christopher Schlank
text: Mr. Schlank, 45, is a managing partner and the founder of Savanna, a private equity and asset management firm that invests in commercial real estate. All of its properties are currently in the New York region, including 31 Penn Plaza and downtown buildings like 100 Wall Street. The company was founded in 1992.

headline: If Video Sites Could Act Like Cable Companies
text: BOSTON — Most consumers have no idea what an M.V.P.D. is, but they mail a check to one every month. What they call Comcast or Time Warner Cable or DirecTV, the government calls a “multichannel video programming distributor,” or M.V.P.D. for short.

headline: The Modest Worth of Big Banks
text: What can we afford to do about the financial industry?

headline: A Mutual Benefit from China’s Private Link to Treasury Auctions
text: WASHINGTON — The revelation that China is the sole country that can bid on and buy debt directly from the United States Treasury, rather than through a financial intermediary, has raised concerns that the Obama administration is giving a secret, sweetheart deal to its biggest creditor.

headline: Hamas-Run Schools Set Out to Teach ‘the Language of the Enemy’
text: GAZA — There are few electives in the Hamas-run high schools here. Students can study health and the environment, or they can learn French. And, starting this fall at some schools, they will be able to sign up for a new course called Know Your Enemy.

headline: Montana Football Team at Center of Inquiry Into Sexual Assaults
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — Montana advanced to the semifinals of last season’s Football Championship Subdivision playoffs — the 11th time the team made it that far, and yet another indication of why the Grizzlies have long been a source of pride in this bucolic, football-obsessed city of 67,000.

headline: The Crisis of European Democracy
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: U.S. Sees Other Countries Luring Expatriates to Return
text: The United States is facing intense competition from foreign countries, especially China, that are seeking to persuade highly skilled citizens who have settled in this country to return home to start businesses there, according to a report released Tuesday by an immigration group led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

headline: Binghamton Basketball Team to Hire Coach
text: Binghamton is on the verge of hiring Rider Coach Tommy Dempsey, according to a person with direct knowledge of the hiring. An announcement is expected Wednesday. Dempsey, 38, will take over a team that went 2-29 last season and whose talent and finances have been gutted in the wake of Kevin Broadus’s coaching tenure. More coverage at nytimes.com/thequad.

headline: Iran Recalls Its Ambassador From Azerbaijan
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — Iran has recalled its ambassador from neighboring Azerbaijan, citing a religious insult, in the latest sign of escalating tensions between the countries.

headline: U.S. Files Suit Against Jobs Agency Used by City
text: Federal prosecutors, claiming that they had found widespread fraud in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s much-vaunted job placement program, filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit on Tuesday against a nonprofit agency that was once among New York City’s favorite contractors.

headline: In Remote Alaska, Financing Puts a Rare Refuge at Risk
text: EMMONAK, Alaska — There are no roads that lead to this tiny fishing village 500 miles west of Anchorage, no doctor and a single state trooper, who is also responsible for patrolling a dozen other far-flung Yup’ik Eskimo hamlets along the coast of the Bering Sea. The nearest village, Alakanuk, is eight miles away.

headline: Eugene Polley, Conjuror of a Device That Changed TV Habits, Dies at 96
text: Eugene Polley, an inventor whose best-known creation has fostered blissful sloth, caused decades of domestic discord and forever altered the way consumers watch television, died on Sunday in Downers Grove, Ill. Mr. Polley, the inventor of the wireless television remote control, was 96.

headline: Even When His Latino Roots Might Help Politically, Rangel Keeps Them Buried
text: He utters basic Spanish phrases every now and then, waves a Dominican or Puerto Rican flag at annual parades and takes regular vacations on the white sand beaches of the Dominican Republic.

headline: Women’s Shelter in Remote Alaskan Village Faces Closing
text: The Emmonak Women’s Shelter, the only center for abused women located in an Alaska Native village, may close by the end of the summer.

headline: In the West, a Full Eclipse
text: OKLAHOMA CITY

headline: Deal Allows Development in Brooklyn Bridge Park
text: A long-simmering dispute over the relocation of a cutting-edge theater to Brooklyn Bridge Park has been resolved by a sweeping agreement among city officials, state lawmakers and several nonprofit groups, paving the way for the theater’s eventual move while expanding the park.

headline: Russia Demands Inquiry in Death of Child in U.S.
text: The United States government tried to head off a diplomatic row with Russia on Tuesday after Russian officials demanded an investigation into the death of a Russian child in an adoptive American family. American news media reported last week that Anton Fomin, a nine-year old Russian child adopted into a Nebraska family, died in a house fire while his parents were gone. On Monday, Russia’s children’s rights ombudsman, Pavel Astakhov, demanded an investigation, saying that American investigators had established that the child had been locked in the basement. “Either the boy was punished or he was neglected and got into the basement accidentally,” Mr. Astakhov said, according to RIA Novosti news service. “Why the boy was locked in the basement and why he could not get out, we will ask the U.S. attorneys about this.” The United States Embassy in Moscow expressed its condolences to the child’s family on Tuesday, and corrected what it called “unsubstantiated reports” that he was brought to the United States through an adoption program. “Anton immigrated to the United States with his biological parents, not through intercountry adoption,” the statement said. Russian authorities have repeatedly criticized lax checks on adoptive American parents after a spate of high profile deaths involving negligent and abusive families. Last December, Mr. Astakhov threatened to demand a moratorium on adoptions by Americans after a Pennsylvania court released a pair of adoptive parents with time served after they were convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of a child.

headline: For Native American Women, Scourge of Rape, Rare Justice
text: EMMONAK, Alaska — She was 19, a young Alaska Native woman in this icebound fishing village of 800 in the Yukon River delta, when an intruder broke into her home and raped her. The man left. Shaking, the woman called the tribal police, a force of three. It was late at night. No one answered. She left a message on the department’s voice mail system. Her call was never returned. She was left to recover on her own.

headline: Binghamton Expected to Hire Rider Basketball Coach
text: The Binghamton basketball program is on the verge of hiring Rider Coach Tommy Dempsey, according to a person with direct knowledge of the hiring. An announcement is expected Wednesday, once final details of the contract are worked out.

headline: Tall Tales About Private Equity
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA started his general election campaign by taking aim at Mitt Romney’s job creation record at Bain, setting off a lively debate over the fairness of the attacks.

headline: Band-Aids and Muppets Aim to Soothe Child’s Scrapes
text: SOME leading brands of wound treatments were themselves bloodied by the economic slump, as consumers switched to cheaper store brands.

headline: Warning of a World That’s Hotter and Wetter
text: Called from his seat to speak, Richard Leakey rose and seemed to keep going up, until he towered above a crowd gathered Monday evening for a swanky fund-raiser at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan. He stands about 6 feet 4 inches, atop metal legs that replaced the ones he lost two decades ago, when he made it his job to hound elephant poachers in Kenya and the plane he was flying crashed under murky circumstances. He is 67 now, and his face shows years under the African sun, as a boy who dug with his parents for the fossilized remnants of human ancestors, as a conservationist and as a political reformer and raconteur.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fastest Internet Connections
text: The United States ranks behind many countries in the speed of its Internet connections

headline: Partnership to Bring Ultrahigh-Speed Internet to Six Communities
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A start-up company plans to announce Wednesday that it has raised $200 million to deliver ultrahigh-speed Internet service in six communities surrounding research universities around the country.

headline: Dell Misses Estimates as Computer Sales Slump
text: Dell, the personal computer maker, forecast second-quarter revenue on Tuesday that fell short of analysts’ estimates as businesses held off on buying personal computers and smartphones and tablets ate into the company’s sales.

headline: Cowboys and Redskins Lose Appeal of Salary-Cap Penalties
text: ATLANTA — The Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys lost their appeal of a the N.F.L.’s decision to dock them millions of dollars in salary cap space over two years. Just before free agency began, the league announced that, with the agreement of the players’ union, the Redskins would be penalized $36 million and the Cowboys $10 million because the league said the teams had dumped salaries in 2010, when the N.F.L. operated without a salary cap after the collective bargaining agreement expired. Teams, the league said, had been warned not to do that, or to front-load contracts, because they would gain an unfair competitive advantage when the salary cap returned.

headline: Power With Purpose
text: Political power is always a double-edged sword. The more of it you amass, the more people expect you to use it to do big things, and, when you don’t, the more ineffectual you look. That’s the dilemma in which Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel finds himself. He avoided early elections by adding a new centrist coalition partner to his right-wing cabinet, giving him control of 96 of the 120 seats in Parliament. There are Arab dictators who didn’t have majorities that big after rigged elections. What is unclear is whether Bibi assembled these multitudes to be better able to do nothing or be better able to do something important to secure Israel’s future.

headline: Cheating Inquiry Under Way at 2 Top-Rated City Schools
text: Two of the highest-ranking public elementary schools in New York City are under investigation for possible irregularities on state examinations, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Philip K. Dick, Sci-Fi Philosopher, Part 3
text: This is the third in a three-part series.

headline: How Google Collected Data From Wi-Fi Networks
text: While taking pictures for its Street View project, Google also recorded Internet traffic from open Wi-Fi networks in homes and businesses.

headline: Google Privacy Inquiries Get Little Cooperation
text: Secrets spilled across the computer screen.

headline: To-Do List for Rangers in Game 5: Get the Offense Untracked
text: Two remarkable statistics: The Rangers are 0-7 during the Stanley Cup playoffs when they have a series lead; 9-1 when a series is tied.

headline: Learning to Adjust Has Kept Devils Alive
text: Zach Parise, the Devils’ forward and captain, is not exactly a model of composure on the ice. He chases after rolling pucks as if they just fell out of his wallet, and he raps at rebounds so hard that he looks as if he is trying to drive the puck clean through a goaltender’s pads.

headline: After Paul Falters, Backers Push Agenda in Party and Other Races
text: WASHINGTON — Armed with an inherited fortune and a devotion to Ron Paul, John Ramsey, a 21-year-old college student from Nacogdoches, Tex., plunged into a little-watched Republican House primary in Northern Kentucky this spring to promote his version of freedom.

headline: A Real Estate Firm’s History Is Told in Its New Home
text: PLAINVIEW, N.Y. — When William Rechler built a small industrial building hard by the Long Island Expressway here in 1961, it was a first step beyond Brooklyn for his family’s growing commercial real estate holdings. It is unlikely that Mr. Rechler foresaw that the facility would be remade 50 years later as the centerpiece of what has become a dominant real estate company in the region.

headline: Mississippi Prison on Lockdown After Guard Dies
text: A private prison for illegal immigrants in Mississippi remained on lockdown Tuesday after a violent outbreak on Sunday that ended with the death of a guard and 20 people injured.

headline: Fairer Ways to Choose Judges
text: More than two dozen states are holding elections for judges on their top courts this year, with millions of dollars expected to pour into those races. Among the states with the highest judicial campaign spending is Michigan, where three justices, nominated at political party conventions, will be elected to a seven-member court.

headline: The Sound of Fury, Between the Benches
text: When Rangers Coach John Tortorella and Devils Coach Peter DeBoer were jawing at each other in the third period of Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals on Monday night, no one had a better listening post than NBC’s Pierre McGuire. His reporting perch is conveniently located between the teams’ benches.

headline: Mr. Shays Rebels
text: Linda McMahon won an endorsement from Connecticut’s Republican Party convention last week for her campaign to replace Senator Joseph Lieberman, the retiring independent. Then she and party regulars promptly tried to push out her competition, former Representative Christopher Shays. He should stay in. It’s the best move for voters in Connecticut.

headline: The Webcam Spying Case
text: The 30-day jail sentence Dharun Ravi received in the Rutgers spying case will be debated for years, but it is far more just than the 10 years he could have received after being convicted of invasion of privacy, witness tampering and multiple counts of a hate crime called bias intimidation. The jury found that Mr. Ravi knew his conduct could make Tyler Clementi, his roommate, feel targeted because he was gay.

headline: Full Disclosure for Student Borrowers
text: For too many students, a college education that is supposed to create opportunities can also mean years of struggle to pay off tens of thousands of dollars in debt. Schools must be required to do more to educate students about the real cost of their education and about a complex borrowing process that even the most sophisticated people have trouble understanding.

headline: Difficult Decision for Judge in Rutgers Spying Case
text: In conversations over the past 50-odd years, Glenn Berman and his friend David Politziner have often talked about the importance of making a decision that balances the facts, regardless of outside pressure.

headline: Argentina: Bomb Was Set to Strike Former President of Colombia
text: A bomb discovered in a Buenos Aires theater on Tuesday was programmed to explode when the former president of Colombia, Álvaro Uribe, was scheduled to speak there on Wednesday, authorities said. A janitor found the bomb inside the power supply for the second-floor ceiling lights. “It was a simple apparatus, but enough to produce deaths,” said Norberto Oyarbide, the federal judge investigating the case. The bomb threat came a week after a failed assassination attempt in Bogotá against Mr. Uribe’s former interior minister, Fernando Londoño. Mr. Londoño was wounded in the attack, and two of his bodyguards were killed. No one has claimed responsibility for either bomb. Mr. Uribe’s address will take place as planned, Judge Oyarbide said.

headline: Go Home and Rethink Your Life
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t know if you’re a science and science fiction geek like me, but if you are, you already know that this month — May 25, to be precise — is the 35th anniversary of the release of the first (or the fourth, if you’re counting in base George Lucas) “Star Wars” film.

headline: Tuneful Rooms of Their Own in Brooklyn
text: When Carson McCullers explores her own mind these days on a stage at the Public Theater, the sound of a banjo goes with her. Now a banjo might seem too obvious a choice for the musical underlining of the thoughts of a Southern writer adrift in the North. But then you haven’t heard the banjo music composed by Gabriel Kahane for “February House,” the very literary new musical that opened on Tuesday night at the Public Theater.

headline: New York Taxi Drivers Unsure They Will See Benefits of a Fare Increase
text: As he ended his shift on Tuesday at a gas station in Midtown Manhattan, Alderete Faustino, a New York City cabby for 25 years, squinted warily at the receipt that laid out his earnings for the day.

headline: China: Tycoon Gets Reprieve
text: A self-made tycoon sentenced to death for financial fraud has been resentenced to death with a two-year reprieve, meaning her sentence will probably be changed to life after two years of good behavior. After the tycoon, Wu Ying, was sentenced to death in 2009, her case became a rallying point for opposition to the death penalty. In March, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said the Supreme People’s Court should handle Ms. Wu’s case carefully, and in April, the court ordered a lower court to revisit her sentence. The resentencing by a court in Zhejiang Province took place Monday and was reported by Chinese news media on Tuesday.

headline: New York Seizes Control of Horse-Racing Board
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York took control of horse racing in the state on Tuesday, announcing that he was creating a new board to replace the New York Racing Association in hopes of reforming a scandal-plagued industry that generates hundreds of millions of dollars for the state.

headline: In One Corner, a Champion of Government. In the Other, Its Foe.
text: WASHINGTON — The currency of political persuasion is emotion — and the way President Obama and Mitt Romney are spending it crystallizes their starkly contrasting appeals.

headline: Father Doesn’t Know Best
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Britain Says It Will Add Reactors for Energy
text: Britain announced plans Tuesday to finance a new generation of nuclear power plants and renewable energy facilities, in a move that illustrates the differences in energy policies among European Union countries as the bloc grapples with the challenge of reconciling economic and environmental objectives.

headline: Can Euro Bonds Save the Union?
text: Would the issuance of euro bonds help to solve the Continent’s debt crisis, or simply spread the pain to the stronger nations like Germany?

headline: Mr. Lucas’s Neighborhood
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Ex-Aide’s Plea Deal, Clouds for Washington Mayor
text: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, a federal inquiry of Mayor Vincent C. Gray’s 2010 election campaign has smoldered in the nation’s capital. After raids and subpoenas, intrigue flared and receded. Through it all, rumors swirled around the secret work of a grand jury.

headline: Distorting Their Bodies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dickey Strikes Out 11 and Rest of Mets Do Just Enough to Top Pirates
text: PITTBURGH — Mike Nickeas seemed a bit frazzled after the Mets’ 3-2 win over the Pittsburgh Pirates. But on nights when he catches for R. A. Dickey, that is generally a good sign for the team.

headline: Indians Feed the Monkeys, Which Bite the Hand
text: NEW DELHI — The first interloper stepped in front of her on the sidewalk and silently held up his hand. The second appeared behind her and beckoned for her bag. Maeve O’Connor was trapped.

headline: Monkey Patrol
text: As urbanization has steadily encroached on their habitat, monkeys have become the scourge of New Delhi. The solution for now: a bigger monkey.

headline: Goodell Says League Plans to Release Evidence in Saints Bounty Case
text: ATLANTA — N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Tuesday that he expected to eventually make public the evidence the league has gathered showing that New Orleans Saints players were paid bounties for injuring opponents. He had no comment on the defamation lawsuit against him filed last week by Saints linebacker Jonathan Vilma, who has been suspended for a year. Goodell said he did not expect that case to hold up the players’ appeals of their suspensions.

headline: Rodriguez and Teixeira Preserve Win With Their Defense
text: They are paid hundreds of millions of dollars to hit home runs and drive in runs by the dozens, but lately Alex Rodriguez and Mark Teixeira have been woefully insufficient in those areas. On Tuesday night, each was booed at different points during the game when he failed to produce hits that could have led the Yankees to an easy victory.

headline: Katie Beckett, Who Inspired Health Reform, Dies at 34
text: Katie Beckett, who was 3 years old and had been hospitalized almost since birth when President Ronald Reagan invoked her case as an example of irrational federal regulation in 1981 — a crucial moment in the movement toward government support for home health care — died on Friday in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, in the hospital where she was born. She was 34, more than three times the age her doctors had predicted she would reach.

headline: Leader of ’76 Insurgency Is Now a Target of One
text: SALT LAKE CITY — A conservative firebrand identifying himself as a nonpolitician denounces the economic and moral decay of a liberal agenda run amok in Washington, and urges voters to boot out a crusty incumbent who has fallen in love with his own reflection. Sounds like Tea Party 101, right?

headline: Front-Runners in the Egyptian Election
text: New top contenders in Egypt’s presidential race.

headline: Jean Pakter, Who Made New York a Model for Safe Abortions, Dies at 101
text: Dr. Jean Pakter, a former health official who made New York City a national model for providing safe, legal abortions and led an innovative effort to educate women about the benefits of birth control, prenatal nutrition and breast-feeding, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 101.

headline: Yankees Need Sluggers of Old, Not Old Sluggers
text: First he set the tee for a high pitch, and swung at the ball left-handed for a while. Then he lowered the tee and swung some more. Switching to the other batter’s box, Mark Teixeira raised the tee and took right-handed cuts. The thwack of the bat, coming from the Yankees’ indoor cage before practice on Tuesday, was a much better sound than a cough.

headline: Gains in Health System Seen as Lasting by Some
text: WASHINGTON — The new health care law is already transforming the way care is delivered, and the changes will continue regardless of how the Supreme Court rules on the mandate for most Americans to carry health insurance, a Democratic senator and an Obama administration official said Tuesday.

headline: Corrections: May 23
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Henry Denker, Author in Many Genres, Dies at 99
text: In a 1949 press release sent out after the publication of his first novel, “I’ll Be Right Home, Ma,” about a light-heavyweight fighter with “a sweet right-hand sock,” Henry Denker declared his belief that “a writer should be active in several forms of his trade.” He added: “Writing is a business and should be practiced as such. On days when you think you can’t possibly write a line you do it anyhow.”

headline: Public Library Head Faces Critics of Renovation Plan
text: The New York Public Library came under fire Tuesday night during a panel discussion held to debate its $300 million plan to remake its flagship Fifth Avenue branch.

headline: Golden State Warriors Return to San Francisco
text: The Golden State Warriors intend to leave Oakland in 2017 for a new arena on the San Francisco waterfront that the team’s owners say they would finance privately. The city is giving the team a long-term lease on the dilapidated 13-acre pier, and the team will pay the estimated $100 million cost of repairs.

headline: Obama vs. Catholics, Catholics vs. Obama
text: Exit polling tells us that in every presidential election since 1972, the candidate who has won Catholics has won the popular vote as well. To the unsophisticated, this statistic might suggest that the Catholic vote is tremendously important. But the self-consciously savvy often invoke it as evidence that “the Catholic vote” doesn’t really exist at all – that self-identified Catholics are as diverse and divided as the country as a whole, and thus any campaign that wins over swing voters in general will inevitably win over Catholic swing voters as well.

headline: Heat Regain Control Behind Their Big Two
text: MIAMI — The Miami Heat paired LeBron James with Dwyane Wade two summers ago with designs to dominate the N.B.A.

headline: Judge Rebukes City's Press to Reassign Williamsburg Charter Students
text: A hearing to determine whether the city can move ahead with plans to close Williamsburg Charter High School had nearly finished for the day when Andrew Rauchberg, the city’s lawyer, stood up and asked Judge Ellen M. Spodek if the city could start registering its students in other schools. Raising her voice, Judge Spodek told Mr. Rauchberg that the city might consider waiting until next year to revoke the school’s charter if it wanted to aid the students. “If you’re interested in what’s fair for the students, that would be fair for the students,” she said, drawing cheers from the school's supporters.

headline: Diouf Falls but Plays On as Video Villain (and Hero)
text: 1:17 p.m. | Updated  On Tuesday, May 29, the Museum of the Moving Image said it plans an encore for the exhibit, beginning on June 15.

headline: N.F.L. Owners Mandate Pads on Knees and Thighs, and Await Union Reaction
text: ATLANTA — N.F.L. owners made thigh and knee pads mandatory for the 2013 season, although the players union could raise an objection in another indication of the fractured relationship between the two sides.

headline: Is Marathon Running Bad for the Heart?
text: When word circulates that a runner has died of a heart attack, as the inexhaustible ultramarathoner Micah True did last month during a solo wilderness trail run, many people begin to wonder about the healthiness of prolonged strenuous activity. Could marathon training and racing perhaps have damaged the heart muscle of the 58-year-old Mr. True, a lead character in the book “Born to Run”? And, conversely, shouldn’t marathon training have made him — and, by extension, all runners — immune to heart disease?

headline: New Rules for Prepaid Debit Cards
text: The nation’s consumer financial watchdog is preparing restrictions on prepaid debit cards, a largely unregulated product that is flourishing even amid concerns about high fees and poor disclosures.

text: verbatim •\(ˌ)vər-ˈba-təm\• adverb and adjective

headline: CBGB Music Festival Line-Up Announced
text: Cloud Nothings, Pains of Being Pure at Heart and War on Drugs are among the bands that will participate in the first CBGB music festival being produced this summer, joining a line-up that is heavy on New York groups and spans rock from the mid-1970s to today, organizers said.

headline: Strike Shuts Down Canadian Pacific Railway
text: OTTAWA — Resource companies and manufacturers in Canada faced disruptions after a strike shut down the Canadian Pacific Railway early Wednesday morning.

headline: More Parents Are Saying No to Pearson's Field Tests
text: As city students have begun a new round of standardized tests -- this time so-called "field tests," which are experimental tests that the state-contracted test-maker, Pearson, is using to try out questions on city students for future use -- more parents are talking about opting out. And test resistance appears to becoming more widespread, with substantial numbers of parents at  several city schools deciding their children would not participate.

headline: News Quiz | May 23, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Lady Gaga’s Coming to Indonesia (Or Not)
text: Lady Gaga, the pop star who tearfully told a sold-out crowd in Manila on Tuesday, “I hope that you feel tonight as free as your hair,” still hopes to sing in Jakarta on June 3 – if the police, and various Indonesian religious authorities, allow her to.

headline: Donna Summer and the Grateful Dead Added to National Recording Registry
text: Recordings of Donna Summer’s “I Feel Love,” Leonard Bernstein’s first performance with the New York Philharmonic, “Rapper’s Delight” by the Sugarhill Gang and a 1977 concert by the Grateful Dead are among the diverse entries that will be added to the National Recording Registry, the Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday.

headline: Egyptians Vote in First Free Election for President
text: CAIRO — Egyptians went to the polls on Wednesday to choose their first freely elected president, hoping to recapture the promise of a popular uprising that defined the Arab Spring, end 15 chaotic months of military rule and perhaps shape the character of political Islam across the region.

headline: Iran Talks Are Extended as Signs of Common Ground Are Seen
text: BAGHDAD — Iran appeared to balk Wednesday at a detailed proposal presented by six world powers to address urgent concerns about its nuclear program, including a freeze on its enrichment of uranium that could be converted to bomb-grade fuel, because of what the Iranian side suggested was an insufficient easing of sanctions in exchange.

headline: May 23, 1934 | Bonnie and Clyde Are Killed in Police Ambush
text: On May 23, 1934, the bank robbers Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow were shot to death in a police ambush as they were driving a stolen Ford Deluxe along a road in Bienville Parish, La.

headline: Theft Stalls, but Does Not Stop, a Project
text: In recent years, Zanele Muholi threw her energy to documenting gay, lesbian and transgender people in South Africa and beyond. As a photographer and activist, she showed a different side of their lives and struggles as she compiled an unrivaled archive.

text: A Well blog post this week points out that people had a significantly lower death rate over 30 years if they maintained an optimistic attitude.

headline: Stone Links: Badiou on Love and Politics
text: Alain Badiou is France’s most famous living philosopher, an unrepentant communist and hardened veteran of the student protests of 1968. Yet a recent profile in the Guardian notes that this most anti-bourgeois of thinkers has released a book called “In Praise of Love,” which is apparently as much a personal memoir as it is a philosophical meditation on what many see as a particularly bourgeois virtue. According to Badiou, “solving the existential problems of love is life’s great joy,” and our society has confused that joy, directed towards “the very being of the other” with a mere sexual pleasure that fetishizes the body. Unfortunately for us, “when you liberate sexuality,” the problems of love remain unsolved. It would seem that the greatest love of Badiou’s life, however, has been politics, which still makes his “eyes gleam.” As the piece concludes: “Perhaps politics and love are not, if you’re a French Maoist, so very different.”

headline: Do Tax Credits Encourage Work?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Tip of the Week: Quick View Changes in Windows 7
text: If you find yourself frequently using the “Change your view” menu at the top of the Windows Explorer menu to switch between icon sizes and other styles of displaying the contents of a folder in Windows 7, you can save time and mouse travel with a shortcut. Just hold down the Control key while scrolling over the folder’s contents with the mouse’s scroll wheel to cycle through the different icon sizes and other options like List, Details, Tiles and Content. Let go of the Control key and stop scrolling the mouse wheel when you land on the view you want to use.

headline: A Conversation With: Delhi’s Wildlife Warden
text: India’s rapidly urbanizing, fast-spreading capital city, with a population of about 16 million people, hosts many more animals than monkeys – wild boar, mongoose, snakes, packs of stray dogs, feral cats, occasional cattle, rats, mice and all manner of insect life that also call Delhi their home.

headline: An Open Letter to India’s Graduating Classes
text: Dear Graduates and Post-Graduates,

headline: Mommy Wars: The Prequel
text: One Monday morning last spring, Ina May Gaskin got into her golf cart and drove it down the dirt road away from her home on the Farm, a community of 175 residents on a former commune in rural Tennessee that her husband started in the 1970s. She pulled up to the community center, where she would be teaching a class on delivering breech babies. The class was part of a weeklong seminar Gaskin and her fellow midwives were offering to an eclectic group: nurse-midwifery students attending for college credit; a Boston-area family-practice doctor; midwives from around the country; and one, from Australia, who went by the one-word moniker Macca. They had traveled to this corner of southern Tennessee to learn from the founding mother of the natural-birth movement.

headline: I Do Not Like to Fire People
text: Given how much you like to fire people, you should have fired yourself. — TB

headline: Green Roofs in Big Cities Bring Relief From Above
text: It’s spring — time to plant your roof. Roofs, like coffee, used to be black tar. Now both have gone gourmet:  for roofs, the choices are white, green, blue and solar-panel black.

headline: The Call of the Wild, Answered
text: So, black fly season is upon us. We had about a week of weather mild enough to let the fire go out in our stove, and then … they started to hatch! Black flies, for those not familiar with the little critters, are not much bigger than fruit flies, a different type of unpleasantness from the hard-biting green-headed flies encountered at beaches in the Northeast.

headline: If Romney Calls, I Would …
text: In the Washington parlor game known as “veepstakes,” there are three acceptable answers if you are asked whether you’re interested in being picked as the vice-presidential nominee.

headline: Comparing Checking Account and Prepaid Debit Card Fees
text: Prepaid debit cards are becoming increasingly common, and more traditional banks have begun offering them. But the cards, which offer convenience to customers who may not be able to qualify for a traditional checking account, also carry fees that can be significant.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: A Director Who Likes to Start in the Middle
text: CANNES, France — When the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami was last at the Cannes Film Festival two years ago, he brought with him one of his more crowd-pleasing efforts, “Certified Copy,” a two-hander set in Tuscany, and his first film with a movie star (Juliette Binoche, who won the festival’s best actress prize). Mr. Kiarostami is back this year with another film shot outside Iran, the Japanese-language “Like Someone in Love,” about the enigmatic, subtly shape-shifting relationship between a young woman and an old man in Tokyo, but the reception has been quite different.

headline: Thunder and Spurs Set to Battle on the Boards
text: The Western Conference finals bring together the two most outstanding teams of this year’s playoffs; the San Antonio Spurs and Oklahoma City Thunder will size each other up over a seven-game series, measuring for weakness and bending the matchup to their respective strengths. It promises to be one of the most compelling series of the postseason, with a dozen factors capable of determining its outcome.

headline: Two Brooklyn Schools Examined for Cheating
text: Allegations of cheating at two of the city's highest-performing public elementary schools have emerged, after teachers at the middle school that many of their students feed into noticed sharp discrepancies between student performance and their previous test scores.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Recipes and Lists at Your Fingertips
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Prison Term for Helping C.I.A. Find Bin Laden
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A Pakistani doctor who helped the Central Intelligence Agency pin down Osama bin Laden’s location under the cover of a vaccination drive was convicted on Wednesday of treason and sentenced to 33 years in prison, a senior official in Pakistan said.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Google Gets Defensive, and Remote Control Inventor Dies
text: “American Idol” on Wednesday night will crown a new winner — its 11th — marking the end of a season that has added a little tarnish to the jewel of network television. The program’s still-huge viewer totals are down nearly 25 percent — dipping below 20 million a night. The decline can be attributed to greater competition, Fox executives say, including a rival singing competition, “The Voice” on NBC, that they once dismissed. All of which is clearing the way for some “creative reinvigoration” at the show, said Kevin Reilly, the president of entertainment for Fox.

headline: Russia Tests New Missile to Counter U.S. Shield
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s military reported a successful test on Wednesday of a new type of intercontinental ballistic missile that generals said was designed to overpower the American missile defense system.

headline: WPP in Microsoft Deal for Digital Ads
text: WPP, one of the world’s largest advertising concerns, has entered into a partnership with Microsoft that will allow both companies to place and sell digital ads for the brands and publishers they work with, the companies said Wednesday. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Baku Bets on Eurovision Songfest
text: LONDON — The betting is heating up as Azerbaijan prepares to host Saturday night’s final of the Eurovision Song Contest, an annual festival of glitz and cheese that will be watched by more than 100 million people worldwide.

headline: A Modest Monkey Proposal
text: India has a problem with an abundance of aggressive rhesus monkeys in its cities; there is a push in the United States to severely limit the use of chimpanzees in federally-funded studies.

headline: It’s Turkey’s Time
text: ISTANBUL — If patience is a virtue, then Turkey’s place among the angels is secure. The country’s efforts to become a member of the European Union has been dragging on for some 50 years, and while Ankara has not always been free from blame, since 2005 — when negotiations began in earnest — it has been trying hard to climb over the wall of Europe’s prejudices.

headline: Summer in a Bottle | Americano Soda
text: During a recent visit to Portland, Ore., the uncooperative weather made it easy to camp out in the lobby of the Ace Hotel, where I was staying. On one side, there’s a Stumptown Coffee Roasters. On the other is the outstanding bar of Clyde Common. Basically, this means there’s no good reason to ever leave the building.

headline: Private Cargo Rocket Heads to Space Station
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. — A private cargo rocket bound for the International Space Station blasted off early Tuesday morning in what NASA hopes will mark an important step in handing routine space missions over to the private sector.

headline: Egyptians Vote for President
text: After weeks of debate, speculation and argument, Egyptians went to the polls on Wednesday to cast ballots.

headline: Daily Report: Google Privacy Inquiries Get Little Cooperation
text: In Wednesday’s New York Times, David Streitfeld and Kevin J. O’Brien take a deeper look at how Google escaped a full accounting for its Street View project, in which specially equipped cars scooped up data from wireless networks as they photographed the world’s streets.

headline: Don’t Blame Ellis: Four Actors Are Cut from ‘Smash’
text: An out-of-town production rarely makes it to Broadway without a few creative changes, as four soon-to-depart actors from the NBC series “Smash,” the comedy-drama about the making of a Broadway musical, can now tell you. The Inside TV blog of EW.com is reporting that when “Smash” returns for its second season next year it will be cutting four familiar characters from the show – and you can’t blame this one on Ellis, because he’s one of the characters being dropped.

headline: India’s Government Optimistic at Third Anniversary, But Voters Are Not
text: The United Progressive Alliance on Tuesday night, in New Delhi, hailed its achievements in reducing poverty and increasing security as it marked its third year of its second term as the governing coalition of India, even as recent polls show the Congress Party-led government is losing favor with the public.

text: Dear Diary: In a city where we don’t mince words, there was no chance of misunderstanding one New Yorker’s assessment of her friend’s fading romance.

headline: What We’re Reading

Order a brandy old-fashioned. … — Robert Simonson

headline: Hey, How Did You Find That Place?
text: EVERY March my most organized friends start reserving waterfront rooms, urban oases or country cabins for their perfect summer getaway, while I procrastinate, overwhelmed by the options. Recently, I logged onto VRBO.com (Vacation Rental by Owner), only to find my head spinning at the length of its roster — 180,000 properties worldwide. Scrolling through Hotels.com (145,000 hotels in more than 60 countries) and Airbnb.com (over 100,000 short-term rental places in 192 countries), I almost gave up.

headline: Obama Wins Contests in Arkansas and Kentucky
text: President Obama easily won two more Democratic primaries on Tuesday, earning victories in largely uncontested contests in Kentucky and Arkansas, where he nevertheless faced a challenge from a perennial candidate.

headline: How Judge Views Law Might Sway the Jurors at the Edwards Trial

headline: How Twitter Matters: Casting a Worldwide Net
text: As regular readers know, I came around to Twitter slowly but now find it an essential combination of sensory apparatus and global conduit for ideas and information. A demonstration of its power to plumb the collective mind occurred on Tuesday, while I was in Washington attending “The Science of Science Communication.”

headline: Baby and Child Care, the African Way
text: NAIROBI — Earlier this month, I met Richard Turere at a TED talk in Nairobi, Kenya. His story electrified the audience: using LED lights, an old battery and motorcycle parts, he’d created a lighting array to protect his family’s cattle from lions prowling on the outskirts of Nairobi. The invention so effectively mimicked a human with a flashlight that it was being used by several neighboring households.

headline: Unclear Future for Mainstay of Niagara Mist
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. — The Maid of the Mist tour boats have plied the roiling waters of the Niagara Gorge since the 1840s, taking tens of millions of visitors, including the future King Edward VII (1860), Marilyn Monroe (1952) and Mikhail Gorbachev (1983), past the American Falls to the base of the Horseshoe Falls, whose staggering height and swirling mist feel almost biblical.
