headline: I Found a T. Rex!
text: Being named after a circus impresario (P.T. Barnum, “the most famous circus owner in America”) is a dubious birthright at best. But Barnum Brown’s parents hoped their son, born in 1873, would go on to accomplish unusual and excellent things.

headline: Stalked by Shadows (and a Rabbit)
text: AFTER seeing the “The Normal Heart” on Broadway last June, three teenagers from Minnesota were in a frenzy explaining why they had chosen the play. “Sheldon!” they all shouted, naming the socially clueless lead character on the CBS hit comedy “The Big Bang Theory” played by Jim Parsons, who had a small role in the play.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Just Pure Innocent Fun’
text: This poem, one of 11 winners from our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Florence, who is 13 and lives in Germantown, Md.

headline: New Obama Ads Focus on Medicare and Veterans
text: President Obama’s campaign on Wednesday rolled out two new ads promoting his achievements, part of a $25 million advertising effort that his campaign unveiled this month.

headline: The Maim Event
text: You know something is officially askew when N.B.A games start to look like hockey games, N.H.L. games like scenes from “Braveheart,” and when the N.F.L. tries to make small move to try to reduce the number of unpadded knees ramming into players’ heads, the players squawk like kindergartners told there will be no milk and cookies at recess. Athletes seem to be conspiring to inflict as much bodily harm as possible between whistles. You can almost here the U.F.C. folks thinking, “And we’re still illegal anywhere?”

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/23: A Theme Park Rivalry and a Plane Diversion
text: Theme Parks, the Battle Universal Studios and Disney are heavily investing in their theme parks, which have been a safer bet than their big-budget films. Universal, home to the $265 million Harry Potter ride, has just opened a $100 million 3-D “Transformers” ride. Disney, for its part, is spending an estimated $500 million on an “Avatar” addition to its Magic Kingdom. (The New York Times)

headline: Was Greed Good?
text: As the debate moves – appropriately! – to a discussion of Romney’s career at Bain, one thing I’ve noticed is that everyone on the right, and a fair number of people who should know better, basically believes that Gordon Gekko was right. Before the Gekkos came along, they assert, American business was sluggish, unproductive, and uncompetitive. Then came the LBOs and all that, and our economic energy was unleashed.

headline: Finding Harlem Culture and Music at Ginny’s Supper Club
text: WHILE “supper club” conjures up images of bandleaders and showgirls, this bustling new joint below the Red Rooster in Harlem pays homage to no particular decade or movement in the arts, but to the entirety of Harlem’s cultural influence, from poetry to soul to hip-hop. Ginny’s Supper Club is a place to evoke the Harlem of not only Count Basie and the Cotton Club, but also Nina Simone and Kool Moe Dee.

headline: The Raw Food Diet for Pets
text: For years, raw food enthusiasts have touted the health benefits of uncooked food for humans. Now, some veterinarians and pet owners believe that a raw meat diet is best for pets.

headline: Secret Service Chief Sees No ‘Systemic’ Problems
text: WASHINGTON — Under skeptical questioning from senators, the director of the Secret Service insisted on Wednesday that the prostitution scandal that erupted in Colombia last month did not indicate a “systemic” problem with sex and alcohol in the service.

headline: In Meetings on the Web, Owners Turn to Owners for Advice and Support
text: On a recent Tuesday just after noon, D. Penn Moody, an Indianapolis optometrist and owner of Moody Eyes, was the first business owner to present a problem to his peer advisory group.

headline: Olympus Goes Back to the Future
text: You have to wonder if Marty McFly and Doc Brown are working for Olympus, whose new camera, the OM-D E-M5, is meant to evoke 1972’s groundbreaking Single Lens Reflex Olympus OM-1. Back to the Future indeed.

headline: The Beats Hit the Road Again on Screen
text: FOR filmmakers trying to capture the spirit of the Beats, there has always been the pressure — stated or not — of their work living up to the legends. Survivors of the movement, and the scholars who chronicled their every move, are certain to cast an unforgiving eye.

headline: In the Kipuka, Birds Take Shelter
text: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: An Early Look at ‘On the Road’
text: 6:49 p.m. | Updated  CANNES, France — At one point in “On the Road,” Walter Salles’s respectable, muted take on Jack Kerouac’s ecstatic American story, Sal Paradise (Sam Riley), who’s trailed after his friends Carlo and Dean, watching them cavort in a handsomely lighted gutter and atmospheric slum pads, delivers what should be a cri de coeur. “The only people that interest me,” Sal says in voiceover, with Mr. Riley scatting out the famous words, “are the mad ones, the ones who are mad to live, mad to talk, desirous of everything at the same time, the ones that never yawn or say a commonplace thing…but burn, burn, burn like Roman candles across the night.” Yet these boys scarcely simmer.

headline: What Would Your Ballpark Intro Sound Like?
text: What’s your favorite ballpark music?

headline: The Eggplant Parm Chronicles, Game 5 Edition
text: Jumping over the boards and returning to the ice for Game 5, Rangers-Devils, will be the eggplant and chicken parmigiana sandwiches from Manganaro’s Hero Boy on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: In Mexico, Santos Turns the Tables
text: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — Recent chases for silverware and titles have been a tale of two cities, and three teams from the north of the country, a region gripped by violence and cartels fighting for lucrative drug routes to the United States.

headline: When a Boy Found a Familiar Feel in a Pat of the Head of State
text: WASHINGTON — For decades at the White House, photographs of the president at work and at play have hung throughout the West Wing, and each print soon gives way to a more recent shot. But one picture of President Obama remains after three years.

headline: Sorry, Folks, Park’s Closed (Hours Early)
text: Just after 10 p.m. on Tuesday, James Drysdale was about to enter Tompkins Square Park when he was surprised to find his passage barred by a metal gate chained shut at East Seventh Street and Avenue B.

headline: Nicole & Steven
text: Nicole and Steven tell the story of how they met at a restaurant while Nicole waited for a date to arrive. Luckily for Steven, the date was mediocre.

headline: Imagine That: Peter Dinklage to Star in All-Male ‘Imaginary Invalid’
text: As they say on “Game of Thrones,” a Lannister always pays his debts. But does a Lannister always fill out a dress? Perhaps Peter Dinklage, the Golden Globe and Emmy Award-winning actor who plays the cynical aristocrat Tyrion Lannister on that HBO fantasy series, can answer the question: This summer he will be starring in a new production of Molière’s satire “The Imaginary Invalid,” as one of its lead female characters.

headline: Would You Be Comfortable Using an Online Peer Group?
text: On a recent Tuesday just after noon, D. Penn Moody, an Indianapolis optometrist and owner of Moody Eyes, was the first business owner to present a problem to his peer advisory group. He had recently expanded his vision practice and glasses store, and he said he was having difficulty balancing medical consultations and product sales. When a medical equipment manufacturer from Boston asked him for his value proposition, Dr. Moody replied, “I think the value proposition is that we’re the middle of the road.”

headline: The ‘Siren of the Shenandoah’
text: It was an oddly conspicuous act for a girl purporting to be a spy: On May 23, 1862, Belle Boyd, newly 18 and possessed of a “little rebel heart,” sprinted across the battlefield in Front Royal, Va., crinoline swinging, bullets plowing up the earth around her. She waved her white bonnet in grandiose loops, a signal for Confederate troops to advance, and caught the attention of staff officer Henry Kyd Douglas.

headline: A V.I.P. Room at a Middle School Dance
text: The blogger Marcy Magiera’s son is off to his Los Angeles area middle school’s spring dance this week, and to add to the usual angst — the girls on one side of the room, the boys on the other; the questionable lighting and décor; the too-loud music and hovering chaperones — the school has introduced a new element: a “V.I.P. lounge.”

headline: Postcard: Memphis
text: Members of the Fatback Collective, an all-star team of Southern chefs and pitmasters, competed in their second Memphis in May Barbecue World Championship last weekend. The eclectic team brought together a wealth of culinary knowledge and a healthy respect for American barbecue traditions, including the heritage-breed pigs raised by small-scale farms. The members gathered in Memphis to smoke three pigs for competition in the “whole hog” category.

headline: Spring Staples | Wrapped Up
text: Seasons change and so must accessories.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: May 24
text: Chic summer sandals; regal headpieces; and hand-braided bracelets.

headline: Carnegie Hall Announces Program Change
text: Carnegie Hall announced on Wednesday that Yefim Bronfman, the pianist scheduled to play Brahms’s Second Piano Concerto with the Cleveland Orchestra on Wednesday evening, had canceled the performance because of illness. He will be replaced by the violinist Gil Shaham, playing Brahms’s Violin Concerto. The rest of the program — Kaija Saariaho’s “Laterna Magica,” in its New York premiere, and Shostakovich’s Symphony No. 6 — remains intact.

headline: Image of the Day: May 23
text: Laborers work at a brick making facility near Jaipur, Rajasthan.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Powell Criticizes Romney on Foreign Policy
text: Colin L. Powell, the retired general and former secretary of state, indicated on Tuesday that he was not yet ready to endorse President Obama for re-election.

headline: An American Jihadist Now Has a Memoir Out
text: The mystery of Omar Hammami — a 28-year-old American jihadist wanted by the F.B.I. after joining an Al Qaeda affiliate in Somalia — has only deepened in recent months.

headline: Extra Mooga Festivalgoers Get a Refund
text: One of the recurring conversations around the picnic tables in the Extra Mooga section of the Great GoogaMooga festival last weekend was whether the $250-a-day tickets to that premium section (the festival itself was free) were worth the price.

headline: Turkey May Indict Senior Israeli Officers Over Deadly Gaza Flotilla Raid
text: A prosecutor in Turkey has prepared indictments and recommended life sentences for four senior Israeli officers over the killing of nine activists aboard a Gaza-bound aid flotilla forcibly intercepted by Israeli commandos two years ago, Turkish news services reported Wednesday.

headline: Obama More Conservative Than Hoover? Someone Thinks So
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — It’s not every day that a White House boasts of being more conservative than Herbert Hoover. But there was Jay Carney, the presidential press secretary, on Wednesday telling reporters aboard Air Force One that Mr. Hoover was a more profligate spender than President Obama.

headline: TimesCast | May 23, 2012
text: Egyptians go to the polls to select a president in an election cast as a watershed in their political history.

headline: Brooklyn Private School Reinstated as SAT Testing Site
text: The Packer Collegiate Institute and the College Board have reached a truce, allowing the school to continue to serve as an SAT testing site, including for two exams in June.

headline: A Secret Behind the Whale’s Mighty Gulp
text: Somewhere in the vastness of the northern oceans, a fin whale is feeding.

headline: Insecurity Touches the Tycoons of Greece
text: ATHENS — While money pours out of Greek banks and Europe debates whether or not Greece deserves its next handout, the people potentially in the best position to help shore up the nation’s finances are mainly keeping their heads down.

headline: Sequoia Capital Said to Be Expanding to Brazil
text: SAO PAULO, Brazil — Sequoia Capital is expanding to South America, becoming the latest Silicon Valley stalwart to tap into the region’s growing economy, according to two Brazilian investors with direct knowledge of the plans.

headline: Consumers Getting Savvier About Credit Scores
text: Consumers are getting savvier about credit scores, according to new findings from the nonprofit group Consumer Federation of America.

headline: Brooklyn Breeds a New Hotelier
text: ANDREW TARLOW doesn’t like to think of himself as a founding father of all things precious in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It sounds too stodgy, too grand and old-school to him.

headline: Indians Keep Winning, but Drawing Few Fans
text: The question is being whispered around Cleveland, and in the other corners of the American League: are the Indians for real?

headline: Going Negative
text: Gail Collins: David, why do you think there’s so much negative campaigning? The crazy billionaires who want their own nutty super PAC? The years-long presidential races where the candidates just run out of stuff to talk about? Our fraying national moral fiber? Or is it just because it works?

headline: How the Season Ended for Hopkins
text: BALTIMORE–Imitation may be the sincerest form of flattery, but forgive Johns Hopkins men’s lacrosse head coach Dave Pietramala if he was not entirely charmed by the strategy used by University of Maryland head coach John Tillman in the Blue Jays’ quarterfinal loss to the Terrapins on Saturday. With a slowed-down pace of offensive play and a tenacious defensive effort, Tillman utilized the same game plan Pietramala installed back in 2007 that led those Blue Jays to a national title. But this time around, it was Hopkins feeling the frustration of a game, and a season, slowly slipping away.

headline: Inventor of Wireless Remote Dies: Clunky Technology Lives On
text: When I read Margalit Fox’s gorgeous obituary of Eugene Polley, the creator of the wireless television remote, I was struck by the vision he displayed when he invented the so-called Flash-Matic back in 1955. I was also struck by the fact that more than half a century later, the technology he invented, which managed to be convenient and clunky at the same time, has yet to be really improved upon. The troubles in the system — which worked with TV sets built with a photo cell in each corner of the screen — were there right from the start.

headline: Site of SAT Mishap Is Reinstated as Testing Site
text: The Packer Collegiate Institute, a Brooklyn private school where the SAT scores of 199 students were invalidated because of serious violations with the test’s administration, will be allowed to continue serving as an SAT testing site starting in June.

headline: Falling Interest in ‘American Idol’ as It Prepares to Crown a Winner
text: There’s only one way to say it: “American Idol” lost a big chunk of its mojo this season.

headline: The Caucus Click: March of the Graduates
text: President Obama is the commencement speaker at the Air Force Academy.

headline: Pollution Tourism: Andrew Blackwell on Visiting the World’s Not-So-Hot Spots
text: In “Visit Sunny Chernobyl: And Other Adventures in the World’s Most Polluted Places,” Andrew Blackwell travels to the titular fallout site; Linfen, China; Port Arthur, Texas; and other deeply despoiled places, driven by concern for the planet but also by a desire to see what such unpopular places might have to offer. In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Blackwell discussed the wildlife around Chernobyl, the one place he wishes he had visited, possible futures for environmentalism, and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Growing Up With a Home Advantage
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — An Aston Martin, a Bentley and a Jaguar are among the cars parked at the Tennis Center at College Park. Through the door of the private club one will find luxury locker rooms; 30 courts; a health club; and an office, about 120 square feet with one window, that was once a makeshift apartment the janitor called home.

headline: International and U.S. Olympic Leaders Agree on Revenue-Sharing Plan
text: The United States put itself in position to once again win a bid to host an Olympic Games after Olympic leaders this week ended their longstanding, contentious debate about how to divvy some of the Games’ revenue, two people close to the discussions said Wednesday.

headline: Trying to Click Online
text: WITHIN 24 hours of Oscar de la Renta’s resort fashion show on Monday evening, more than 500 people had endorsed his look No. 42, a green and white sequined silk sweater that was based on a classic baseball T-shirt. By endorsed, we mean that they clicked on a photo of the sweater on Fancy (TheFancy.com), one of the new sites that allow users to communally create, browse and comment on portfolios of just about anything.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: A Return Visit for a Director Fond of Repetition
text: 3:07 p.m. | Updated  CANNES, France — Another Cannes, another Hong Sang-soo film. By now a new work by Mr. Hong, the prolific South Korean director, is as much a Cannes ritual as standing in line or drinking a midday glass of rosé. Eight of his 13 features have shown at the festival here, three of them — including “In Another Country” this year — in the main competition, and he won the top prize in the Un Certain Regard section in 2010 for “Ha Ha Ha.”

headline: New Study Outlines How the Military Could Create a Leaner, Less Expensive Force
text: WASHINGTON — The war in Iraq is over. The war in Afghanistan is winding down. Today, the challenge facing the Pentagon is identifying the best military plans in an era to be defined by economic austerity. The world will be just as dangerous, but in different, even more unexpected ways, than in the years after the Sept. 11 attacks, when the Defense Department had a virtual blank check to pay for its programs.

headline: Nude Paintings of Leaders Cause Stir in South Africa and Canada
text: The first protester applied a pair of strategically placed X’s in red paint to the face and genitals of a seminude portrait of the South African president, Jacob Zuma. The second went further, smearing the image with black oil paint, obscuring all but the silhouette of his form.

headline: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Claude Lemieux
text: During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. Perhaps no player in N.H.L. history was able to ramp up his intensity and effectiveness for the playoffs like Claude Lemieux, who won four Stanley Cups. In 1994 Lemieux tied Game 1 for the Devils with 43 seconds left, setting the stage for Stephane Richer’s double-overtime game-winner; received double unsportsmanlike-conduct and double 10-minute-misconduct penalties for going after Adam Graves in Game 2; and helped set up Valery Zelepukin’s tying goal with 7.7 seconds left in the unforgettable Game 7.

headline: Russell Westbrook Stays in Control
text: In the wake of last year’s 4-1 conference finals throttling at the hands of eventual champion Dallas, many doubted whether the Oklahoma City Thunder had the pedigree – and chemistry – to take the next step. At the center of the storm was whether Russell Westbrook’s shoot-first-ask-questions-later ethos too closely mimicked the talents and tactics of the team’s tenured superstar Kevin Durant.

headline: Collision Warning Systems Win Favor in Federal Test
text: An overwhelming majority of drivers who participated in government tests of wireless crash-avoidance technologies viewed the systems favorably, according to a report released Tuesday by the Transportation Department.

headline: Business Day Live | Women in Tech
text: May 23, 2012 - Silicon Valley lawsuit highlights scarcity of women in top tech jobs.

headline: Sweden 1912: A Tough Ticket
text: One hundred years ago the summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the games a century ago.

headline: Martha Stewart Returns as Chairwoman of Her Namesake Company
text: Martha Stewart is back at the helm in the boardroom.

headline: The Get | JewelMint’s Garden Party Rings
text: Designed by the actress Kate Bosworth and the stylist Cher Coulter, JewelMint is an online-only jewelry line that combines outstanding prices (everything is under $30) with ethical action. (Portions of the proceeds from celebrity-supported pieces go to charity; currently, a pair of Bermuda earrings picked by Krysten Ritter benefit Autism Speaks.) The brand changes designs and inventory monthly, and its latest fashion film (the sixth) features Bosworth paying homage to the 1920s screen legend Louise Brooks — replete with black bob and thick lip — while sporting delicate baubles. “The May collection has a ladylike vintage appeal that we felt would work well against a black-and-white ’20s backdrop,” says Bosworth of the film, screening exclusively here at T. Among this month’s Deco-like diamonds and door knockers are these quieter adornments, a set of three rings decorated with dainty flora and the teensiest stones. Stack them or scatter them about.

headline: U.S. Attorney in Chicago to Step Down
text: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney who oversaw the criminal prosecutions of successive Illinois governors on corruption charges as well as of the former Bush administration White House aide I. Lewis Libby Jr., will resign at the end of June, the Justice Department announced Wednesday.

headline: Lacma’s Rock Gets an Official Opening, Finally
text: LOS ANGELES — The journey is almost complete.

headline: The Economic Crisis in Greece
text: May 23, 2012 - Why Greek businesses fear a return to the drachma and Athenians talk about the economic crisis.

headline: Ask About the Egyptian Election
text: This week, I’ll be answering your questions about Egypt’s historic presidential elections here on Rendezvous. Leave your question by using the comments box below. Feel free to respond to others’ questions. I’ll post my answers as well.

headline: Former Employees Feel Silenced on Library Project
text: The New York Public Library’s plan to turn part of its flagship Fifth Avenue research center into a lending library has unleashed a torrent of commentary, with scholars, writers, artists and students signing a petition and writing articles, many of them critical. But one highly informed contingent has been notably silent: former curators, department heads and librarians.

headline: Google Cleared of Infringing on Oracle’s Java Patents
text: Google did not infringe on any Oracle patents when it used Java software in the Android operating system, a federal jury said on Wednesday.

headline: Pregame Chatter: Satisfied With Production, DeBoer Sticks With Same Lineup
text: NEWARK -– The Devils scored four goals in Game 4, the most allowed so far by the Rangers this postseason, so why mess with success? That seemed to be the thinking of Coach Peter DeBoer, who after the team’s morning skate said he would use the same lineup for Game 5 on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Photo Shoots and Fashion Parties at Cannes
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: F.A.Q. About Fledging Hawks
text: We are approaching fledge day, when the juvenile hawks of Washington Square Park take their first flight out of their 12th-floor nursery at New York University’s Bobst Library and begin the next phase of their development in the broader confines of the park. Wednesday is 43 and 44 days since Boo and Scout emerged from their shells. Typically, red-tailed hawks take flight between 42 and 46 days of life, though hawks in urban areas can take longer. Last year, the baby hawk named Pip by readers first used its wings after 49 days on the nest and sailed to a rooftop on a neighboring building.

headline: More Thoughts on the Ravi/Clementi Case
text: The Dharun Ravi case clearly evokes strong reactions, manifest in the number of comments my post yesterday received. I was glad to read through them and fascinated as I did. I admit I wasn’t able to give each a careful look, but I did get a sense of the variety of sentiments and of some recurring themes.

headline: Adam Lambert Tops the Billboard Chart
text: Adam Lambert has a mixed victory on the Billboard chart this week. With his latest release, “Trespassing” (RCA), he has scored his first No. 1 album, and he is the seventh “American Idol” finalist to reach the top spot on the chart. But with music sales slow, it had the least sales for a No. 1 album in almost a year.

headline: Romney, Dipping Into Education, Pushes School Choice
text: A revised version of this post is available here.

headline: The Secret Lives of Cater Waiters
text: From graffiti artists to interior designers to circus performers, eight cater waiters share their day jobs and career aspirations, as well as memories from the evening party shift.

headline: Does It Mean Anything That a Record Low Are ‘Pro-Choice’?
text: The percentage of Americans who call themselves pro-choice is at a new low, according to a Gallup poll. Asked to pick one of the two labels applied to the abortion debate, a full 50 percent said they were pro-life, whereas only 41 percent said they were pro-choice, down from the previous low of 42 percent recorded in May of 2009.

headline: Silver Trays and High Hopes
text: WITH the summer social season around the corner, photo-ready pretty young things aren’t the only ones popping up from Manhattan to Montauk. So, too, are the handsome cater waiters who flank the entrances of parties, hold trays of Champagne and pass around plates of truffled foie gras.

headline: One of 2 Suspects Arrested in Pickpocketing of Blind Woman
text: One of two suspects in the bump-and-grab pickpocketing of a 68-year-old blind woman at a Queens subway station was arrested on Wednesday, the police said. The suspect, Latisha Richardson, 39, was arrested on charges of larceny, possession of stolen property, drug possession and jostling, the police said.

headline: Managing Care Online
text: When Wendy Naumann’s father and three siblings received her mother’s diagnosis — a terminal brain tumor — they were overwhelmed. Just communicating within the family to keep everybody updated on her mother’s condition was exhausting, as they were spread out across the country.

headline: Hazing Ritual of a Band Is Described in Documents
text: MIAMI — Hoping to earn the respect of his band mates, Robert Champion agreed to enter Bus C in an Orlando parking lot one evening last fall and walk to the back in a common but brutal Florida A & M University hazing ritual — one that cost him his life, according to documents released Wednesday by prosecutors.

headline: Niese and No Need for Much Else
text: PITTSBURGH — The only bit of dissonance after Jon Niese’s glittery outing Wednesday involved how perturbed he was following his previous start.

headline: Education and Prevention: Creating Public Service Campaigns About Type 2 Diabetes
text: Overview | In this lesson, students read about a new study showing a rise in Type 2 diabetes among adolescents. They learn more about Type 2 diabetes and its causes, then develop a public awareness campaign to promote education and prevention.

headline: But Now, What to Wear?
text: THE bride wore Carolina Herrera, the other bride wore Ralph Lauren. That was the big reveal at the wedding of Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker, and her longtime partner, Kim M. Catullo, a products liability lawyer, in a ceremony held in the meatpacking district last Saturday evening.

headline: Unsteady Big East Pins Hopes on TV Deal
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — If television producers wanted to cast the Big East Conference as a 1980s sitcom, the plot would revolve around a series of hastily arranged marriages constructed to avoid deportation. As the conference braced to grow to 18 teams in basketball and 13 in football and stretch from Boise to Providence to Tampa, its many athletic directors, coaches and officials met here this week. Call them college athletics’ “Imperfect Strangers.”

headline: The New Masters of Parsons
text: EVEN from across the classroom, there was something that stood out about the jacket on Lucia Cuba’s dress form. A simple design on canvas, it was printed with repeating black-and-white photographs of a small boy standing at attention. You might have thought the jacket verged on adorable.

headline: Student Show
text: Looks created by the first graduates of a new M.F.A. program at Parsons the New School for Design.

headline: New Polls Underscore Close Presidential Race
text: Two new national polls show a close race between President Obama and Mitt Romney, while a new Florida poll shows Mr. Romney with a lead in a crucial swing state.

headline: Battle an Alien Horde at Sea
text: “Battleship” may be sinking at the box office, but you can still put on your captain’s hat and duel with alien warships at sea with a movie-inspired version of the Battleship iPhone app from Electronic Arts.

headline: Military Will Remain Strong With Cuts, Obama Tells Cadets
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — President Obama vowed on Wednesday to keep the military strong even as he winds down the wars of the last decade and takes the budget knife to Pentagon spending in an age of increasing government austerity.

headline: 14 Charged With Dealing Prescription Drugs in Washington Heights
text: The police and federal authorities announced the arrests of 12 people on Wednesday on charges of buying and selling prescription painkillers in open-air drug markets in Washington Heights.

headline: The 40th Annual FiFi Fragrance Awards
text: A look inside the Oscars of the fragrance industry.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: News of the Olympics from around the Web.

headline: The Triumphant Smells of Success
text: NEARLY everyone on the dating market has certain things that are deal breakers. Some people cancel the second date after finding out the person votes Republican (or Democratic). Others after finding out that their potential mate hasn’t had a steady job in two years. For Jane Lynch, a repeated theme when she was single was overly fragrant women. “I’d say, ‘You smell good, but I’m allergic,’ ” she said. “I don’t like perfume. I like scent.”

headline: The Facebook I.P.O.’s Potential Legal Exposure
text: Who, if anyone, will pay?

headline: School Choice, New York-Style? For Some More Than Others
text: A parent and professor of education writes: "Whatever the argument for school choice elsewhere, in New York City public schools it plays out very differently.  Instead of providing better education for all children, choice in New York City ensures a two-tiered system powered by demographics and ZIP codes more than anything else."

headline: French Data Regulator Chides Google
text: PARIS — Already facing scrutiny from antitrust authorities and privacy regulators on a variety of fronts, Google was criticized Wednesday by French data protection authorities, who accused the company of being insufficiently forthcoming in an investigation of its new privacy policy.

headline: The Next Treasury Secretary
text: 5:47 p.m. | Updated to include women mentioned for the job.

headline: Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup: Third Round
text: The 16 United States-based Major League Soccer teams, willing or otherwise, are about to be engaged as the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup enters the third round after the completion of games Tuesday night.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Pakistan, Israel and Colorado.

headline: As Computing Changes, Hewlett-Packard Struggles to Follow
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As the computer industry makes a radical shift to new modes of computing — in the cloud and on tablets and smartphones — Hewlett-Packard, a stalwart of the previous era, finds it hard to keep up.

headline: The Spending Binge That Wasn’t
text: Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, made a big show of reading reporters aboard Air Force One a MarketWatch report  saying that the rate of spending growth under President Obama is lower than under any president since Eisenhower. Mr. Carney said this proves the president has demonstrated far more restraint and responsibility than his critics would allow.

headline: Hot Nests Mean Baked Baby Leatherbacks
text: As if sea turtles didn’t already have enough troubles. On beaches, poachers snatch up their eggs and babies for stewing; at sea, adults get snagged by fishermen’s long lines and nets. Now, climate change joins the list, threatening the survival of critically endangered leatherback sea turtles in the Pacific.

headline: Poetry Slam of His Own, on Paper
text: “My heart is lovely, dark and deep,” Michael Robbins writes in a poem called “Plastic Robbins Band” in “Alien vs. Predator,” his first collection. He’s lying, shamelessly.

headline: After 36 Marathons, One Radio Goes Silent
text: For each of the 36 years that the New York City Marathon has existed as a five-borough race, Steve Mendelsohn could be found in the lead vehicle with the race director, cruising along with the lead male runner and relaying messages on his ham radio.

headline: A New Age of Drilling in the Arctic
text: Barring a successful last-minute challenge by environmental groups, Shell will begin drilling test wells off the coast of northern Alaska in July, opening a new frontier in domestic oil exploration and accelerating a global rush to exploit the untold resources beneath the frozen ocean.

headline: Government Report Says Medical Discharge Process Is Getting Slower
text: Since the deep embarrassment of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center scandal in 2007, the Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs have been trying to make the process of getting a medical discharge from the military less complicated, time-consuming and contentious. “Seamless transition” to civilian life was their oft-repeated goal.

headline: What You Get for ... $360,000
text: PITTSBURGH

headline: Homes for $360,000
text: Properties in Pittsburgh, Florida and New Mexico.

headline: Scene City: Garden Party at MoMA
text: Artists, collectors and pop stars dine and dance at the museum’s spring gala.

headline: First, Twitter; Then the Triple Crown
text: I’ll Have Another has accomplished quite a few remarkable feats on the Triple Crown trail so far. Typing with hooves is one of them.

headline: Chairs Reborn
text: A workshop called Crafting Design taught participants how to breathe life into castoff chairs.

headline: How Can We Bring Trust Back to Childbirth?
text: You could argue that women have never been able to easily access the “birthing experience” they desired. The old days of childbirth, fraught with risk to mother and baby, were followed by a variety of innovations, some more welcome than others. In her story on Ina May Gaskin and the home birth movement, “Mommy Wars: The Prequel,” in  this coming weekend’s New York Times Magazine, Samantha M. Shapiro writes that women once fought to move birth “out of the domain of midwives and the home and into the hospital:”

headline: A Garden Gala at MoMA
text: “I could kill a cactus,” said Santigold, the headlining performer at the Museum of Modern Art’s annual garden party on Tuesday night. She was eyeing the outdoor sculpture garden, which was landscaped with lush hedges, in addition to art works by Aristide Maillol. “I don’t water enough.”

headline: A Cooler, Lighter Summer Suit
text: This summer, men can look forward to light, less structured suits that keep cool and are fun to wear.

headline: Going Beyond Search, Into Fetch
text: You whippersnappers might not remember, but libraries used to have something called card catalogs. Each book’s index card told you which shelf housed the corresponding volume. You had to go fetch it on foot.

headline: A Uruguayan Derby With a Twist (or Tag)
text: Every spring, it seems, as if to counter the attention on the UEFA Champions League or England’s Premier League, the Uruguayan club Peñarol thinks of big ways to get people to look its way. Last year, Peñarol unfurled what it thought was the world’s largest flag, created in the team colors of black and gold and covering about half of the seats in its stadium. But flags are so … old fashioned.

headline: For Men, a New Look for the Summer Suit
text: THAT time of year is upon us: the sticky season, when the only suit a man can get excited about has one of two words in front of it: “swim” or “birthday.”

headline: James Lecesne Will Replace an Injured Michael McKean in ‘Best Man’
text: James Lecesne will play the campaign manager Dick Jensen in “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man,” replacing Michael McKean, whose leg was broken in an auto accident on Tuesday, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Seeing What’s on TV Without Touching the Remote
text: Smartphones and tablets have emerged as the best television companions since the Barcalounger. What better to do during two minutes of commercials than check e-mails, fire off a text or engage in some Words With Friends smack talk?

headline: Poetry and Other Texts, Fitted for a Song (or Two)
text: A primary focus of the Mirror Visions Ensemble is performing different settings of the same text, an interest shown by its name. So the group’s 20th-anniversary celebration at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening included two settings of the Heinrich Heine poem “Das Fischermädchen” (“The Fisher Maiden”), one in the original German by Meyerbeer and a Russian translation by Reinhold Glière. It also included “La Mer Est Plus Belle” (“The Sea Is More Beautiful”), a text by Verlaine, in settings by Debussy and Louis Durey.

headline: Single Again, and Embracing Playtime
text: Not many television shows these days can be said to have courage, but a new sitcom on TBS called “Men at Work” certainly does. It has the courage to announce: “Guy shows can be just as crass, penis-obsessed and vacuous as all those gal shows that started turning up last fall. More, even.”

headline: Parks Working Out as Smoke-Free Zones, City Says
text: When a ban on smoking in city parks took effect one year ago, some tobacco partisans vowed it would not stick, that it was unenforceable, that they would flout it to their dying breaths.

headline: House Hunting in ... Bali
text: AN EIGHT-BEDROOM ESTATE IN SEMINYAK, BALI

headline: New for the Season From Europe: A Sense of Humor
text: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet is known for bringing New York the news from Europe, importing choreographers whose work is well known over there but rarely seen here. Usually that work is dark and angst-laden, conforming to what Americans think of as Continental. But on Tuesday, during the second program of the company’s run at the Joyce Theater, the message from across the Atlantic seemed to be: hey, we can be fun, too.

headline: In Bali, a Beach Town Compound
text: An eight-bedroom estate in Seminyak, on the southwest shore, is for sale for $1.95 million.

headline: Exposing Multiple Personae, All Defiant
text: “This is my cougar song,” Shirley Manson told the audience at Webster Hall on Tuesday night, where her reactivated band, Garbage, was on tour behind its first new album in seven years, “Not Your Kind of People” (StunVolume). She looked more proud than rueful.

headline: What Good Is Sitting Alone at Your Keyboard?
text: With a schoolboy’s enthusiasm — indeed, looking a bit like Harry Potter all grown up — the writer Greg Pierce flipped through the three-ring binder on his lap, his forehead crinkling as he searched for the morning’s to-do list. He was sitting in the Upper West Side studio of John Kander, the Tony Award-winning composer of “Cabaret,” “Chicago” and more than 15 other musicals over the last 50 years. Show posters of all that fame hung on the room’s west wall, most of them featuring the legendary names Kander & Ebb — the latter, of course, being the lyricist Fred Ebb, who died in 2004.

headline: Now Booking | New Hotels in Chile
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Obama’s Anti-Bain Ad: Seldom Broadcast, but Much Seen
text: The Obama campaign’s two-minute commercial featuring steelworkers who lost their jobs after Bain Capital bought their company has many elements of the quintessential attack ad: somber music, old black-and-white photos, even references to blood and vampires.

headline: No Smiles. No Fusion. Just That Old-Time Flamenco Sadness.
text: “Everybody says I have the face of a dead man,” Manuel Agujetas sang in Spanish, in a dire, unaccompanied, ancient-sounding modal chant, its tonality blurred by his rasp. “It’s what happens to good Gitanos when life isn’t going well.” He sat on a chair, staring forward, hands on knees, his eyes like deep creases, an old scar running in a lateral slice on his right cheek.

headline: Stuntman Takes a Superhero Plunge
text: A man jumped out of a helicopter Wednesday and fell 2,400 feet to the earth without deploying a parachute. He was uninjured.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Goldman Trade a Focus at Gupta Trial
text: On the evening of Sept. 23, 2008, just before 6 p.m., Goldman Sachs announced that Warren E. Buffett had invested $5 billion in the bank. The vote of confidence from the billionaire investor was great news for Goldman and for the broader stock market, coming at a time of chaos and fear in the financial world.

headline: Technology Reaches Remote Tibetan Corners, Fanning Unrest
text: TONGREN, China — The young Buddhist monk, his voice hushed and nervous, was discussing the self-immolations and protests that have swept Tibetan regions of China when the insistent rap of knuckle on wood sounded behind him.

headline: Paul Fussell, Literary Scholar and Critic, Is Dead at 88
text: Paul Fussell, the wide-ranging, stingingly opinionated literary scholar and cultural critic whose admiration for Samuel Johnson, Kingsley Amis and the Boy Scout Handbook and his withering scorn for the romanticization of war, the predominance of television and much of American society were dispensed in more than 20 books, died on Wednesday in Medford, Ore. He was 88.

headline: In Brooklyn, the Writing’s on the Wall
text: Shantell Martin, a London-born artist, rents a room in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where her stream-of-consciousness drawings have taken over.

headline: A Very Fine Line
text: “I DIDN’T actually decide to do the whole room at first,” said Shantell Martin, contemplating the freestyle line drawings that cover all four walls and the ceiling of the room she rents in Brooklyn.

headline: Ad on Advertising's Lack of Diversity
text: The agency is competing on AMC's show "The Pitch." During the show it plans to make its own pitch about the advertising industry.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Is it worth replacing flimsy doorknobs with high-end hardware before listing my home for sale?

headline: A Little Tease to Bolster a Career
text: HOLLYWOOD is full of celebrities who got their start by taking their clothes off. But in a perverse twist, a growing number of male celebrities are finding that stripping may be a solid way to resuscitate a career as well.

headline: First Comes a Love Triangle, Followed by a Luminous Kingdom
text: Springtime at American Ballet Theater means a lot of stories about men who can’t make up their minds. Now in its second week at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company has dug deeper into its full-length repertory and replaced the two-timing nobleman Albrecht in “Giselle” with the two-timing warrior Solor in “La Bayadère.” Ballet, in other words, is as much about the wandering male eye as it is about the female form.

headline: Accounting Deals in China Cost a Firm Its Registration
text: What does it take to get into the growing business of auditing Chinese companies whose shares are registered in the United States?

headline: Oil Sanctions Take Economic Toll, Syria Says
text: Sanctions against Syria’s oil industry are taking a substantial toll, draining $4 billion from the country’s economy so far and causing widespread fuel shortages, a top official of the embattled government of President Bashar al-Assad said Wednesday.

headline: Individual Health Policies Fall Short, a Study Finds
text: More than half of all medical insurance policies sold to individuals now fail to meet the standards of coverage set by the federal health care law under review by the Supreme Court, a new study says.

headline: Unusual Results in a Rare Bridge Deal
text: In Monday’s column both Souths in a knockout match were in three no-trump. One declarer took 12 tricks and the other lost 12 tricks. This caused some e-mail traffic from readers mentioning other unusual results.

headline: Agency Competing on ‘The Pitch’ to Make a Pitch for Diversity in Advertising
text: An advertising agency that is to be featured on the AMC reality competition series “The Pitch” plans to run a commercial during the episode, but not on behalf of a client.

headline: For Oreo, Cadbury and Ritz, a New Parent Company
text: Shareholders of Kraft Foods on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved Mondelez International as the name of the $35 billion snack foods company that will be created when the company finally splits sometime later this year.

headline: A Second Chance for Idle Electronics
text: All the smart kids are selling their old gadgets, why aren’t you?

headline: Heat and Hamlet
text: A look at five decades of Shakespeare at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: Career Once in Doubt, a Devil Shines in the Playoffs
text: The Devils’ best player this spring may well be a 36-year-old defenseman who missed all of last season with a concussion so severe that it was unclear if he would ever play again.

headline: A Custody Case: Giving the 7-Year-Old a Voice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Older Faces on Screen Draw an Overlooked Crowd
text: LOS ANGELES — Anytime a film costs $10 million to make and ticket sales approach $100 million, Hollywood pays attention. But jaws really drop when a movie starring actors in their 70s and aimed at people over 50 pulls off that trick.

headline: Is the Church Becoming Less Catholic?
text: To the Editor:

headline: New and Frozen Frontier Awaits Offshore Oil Drilling
text: WASHINGTON — Shortly before Thanksgiving in 2010, the leaders of the commission President Obama had appointed to investigate the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico sat down in the Oval Office to brief him.

headline: Romney’s Faith
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Value of Opera Reviews
text: To the Editor:

headline: L.A. Law and the Fake Picasso
text: LOS ANGELES — Those searching for “all the tragedies and romance of life,” to steal a line from William Randolph Hearst, usually needn’t look farther than the Los Angeles County Superior Court.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cyberspy School and Internet Destruction
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: Toll Brothers, Orders Up, Beats Profit Expectations
text: Toll Brothers, the luxury-home builder, reported a second-quarter profit that beat estimates as orders rose in an improving housing market.

headline: Dangerous Trees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Witness Interviews in the Robert Champion Investigation
text: Police released transcripts of interviews with witnesses in the death of Robert Champion, a drum major with the Florida A&M University marching band.

headline: Euro Zone Crisis Boils as Leaders Fail to Signal New Steps
text: BERLIN — With Greece’s membership in the euro zone teetering, fears of bank insolvency rising and Europe’s leaders bickering about what to do, the euro crisis is once again intensifying and threatening to undermine fragile growth globally.

headline: Royals’ Hosmer Is Grappling With a Sophomore Slump
text: Eric Hosmer walked into the visitors’ clubhouse at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday afternoon with a new haircut and a smile. The little things go a long way these days.

headline: China: General’s Trip to Japan Is Canceled
text: One of the top generals in China, Guo Boxiong, has canceled a high-level trip to Japan scheduled for this week after a rise in political tensions between the two nations, a report in the official English-language newspaper China Daily said Wednesday.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Expanding Use of an Anticoagulant
text: A federal advisory panel narrowly recommended against expanding the use of the Johnson & Johnson drug Xarelto on Wednesday, saying concerns over dangerous bleeding outweighed evidence that the drug helped reduce the risk of blood clots in patients with serious heart problems.

headline: Google’s Comment on Street View Data
text: In Wednesday’s New York Times, David Streitfeld and Kevin J. O’Brien wrote about Google’s Street View project, an ambitious endeavor to map the world by sending specially equipped cars out to photograph every street. The cars also collected data sent over unencrypted wireless networks. That so-called payload data contained bits of personal e-mails and Internet postings and searches — whatever someone was doing on a computer as the car passed by. The collection of that data, as the article recounts, has been the subject of numerous investigations in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: A Closer Look at Watts and Joules, Power and Energy
text: Dale R. McIntyre, a metallurgical engineer from Bartlesville, Okla., who’s been an articulate and constructive voice on Dot Earth for a long time, took issue with aspects of “The WATT,” the planned primer on energy proposed by Focus the Nation. His main concern was with the name.

headline: Not All Israeli Citizens Are Equal
text: Washington

headline: Honduran Villages Caught in Drug War’s Cross-Fire
text: AHUAS, Honduras — The orange glow of a burning house brightened the morning sky. Then another and another. Four homes were set ablaze in this muddy river town just hours after the Honduran and American authorities swooped down in helicopters as part of a major drug raid that recovered a half ton of cocaine.

headline: Dam’s Flow Limit Loosened to Feed Grand Canyon
text: The Interior Department announced a plan on Wednesday to allow periodic increases in the flow of Colorado River water through the Grand Canyon, alleviating the environmental disruption caused by the construction of the Glen Canyon Dam in Arizona in the 1960s.

headline: Good Behavior May Reduce 30-Day Term in Rutgers Spying Case
text: Dharun Ravi could serve just two-thirds of the 30-day jail sentence he was given this week if he earns credit for good behavior and doing his chores behind bars, New Jersey corrections officials said Wednesday.

headline: A Way Out of the Same-Sex Marriage Mess
text: East Lansing, Mich.

headline: Pull Up a Chair, Then Fix It
text: IT’S hard not to get swept up in the excitement of Design Week in New York, when the newest home furnishings are introduced at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, and related events happen all over town.

headline: Turkmenistan: Gas Deal Signed With India and Pakistan
text: Three countries involved in a plan to build a natural gas pipeline across Afghanistan — Turkmenistan, Pakistan and India — signed an agreement on Wednesday in Avaza, Turkmenistan, covering commercial terms for gas sales.

headline: Eurovision Takes Baku
text: The glamour of Eurovision overshadows the human rights issues that mar Azerbaijan.

headline: Eat Your Hake and Have It, Too
text: Seattle

headline: A Well-Made Bed to Lie In
text: OUTSIDE of boarding schools, the military and mothers, few pay attention to proper bed making. Once you live on your own, your sheets can stay rumpled for days (and do, for many of us). Still, there’s an art to making a bed, or at least that was the message at Lorin Marsh last week, where three interior designers gathered in the furniture company’s East Side showroom to demonstrate to a small crowd the finer points of “styling” your bed.

headline: The Elle Décor Show House Opens
text: Eight up-and-coming designers were paired with more than a dozen home retailers, including Restoration Hardware, BoConcept and the Container Store, for the Elle Décor Modern Life Concept House, in a town house on West 53rd on the market for $4.2 million, part of a condo development that was 70 percent sold as of last week.

headline: Avenue Road Opens Manhattan Showroom
text: Avenue Road, the Toronto-based furniture company, recently opened a 5,000-square-foot showroom in Manhattan — an informal space designed to feel more “like entering someone’s beautiful apartment,” said Stephan Weishaupt, the president, than a stiff showroom.

headline: A Bunk Bed Inspired by the Sea
text: Roberto Gil insists that his foray into children’s furniture was an accident. Mr. Gil, a native of Argentina who studied architecture at Harvard, was between jobs and making furniture for himself when someone remarked that one of his benches looked “naïve and simple, like it’s for a kid.”

headline: YouTube’s Spaces Channel: A Hipper HGTV?
text: In addition to silly clips of family pets, cult-film trailers and practically every music video ever made, YouTube users can now watch a home design show called “Your Place Is a Deal Breaker.” In the first episode, a woman moves into her boyfriend’s apartment, which has a Barack Obama poster prominently displayed in the bedroom, and enlists the help of a designer to make the space reflect both their styles. “Obama has to go, baby,” she tells her partner.

headline: Hearing on Trainer Clouds His Bid for Triple Crown
text: I’ll Have Another jogged around Belmont Park’s massive mile-and-a-half oval Wednesday, his first loop around the track where he will try to become the 12th horse to sweep the Triple Crown and the first since Affirmed did so in 1978.

headline: Welcoming Eurovision, but Not the Scrutiny
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — More than 125 million people will turn their attention to Azerbaijan this week for the televised finale of the Eurovision Song Contest, the kitschy, over-the-top international crooning competition that can make “American Idol” seem as staid as a Sunday morning news show.

headline: Caught Violating Weekend Copter Ban, Bloomberg Will Alter Flight Plans
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is rich, and New Yorkers often forgive him for it. His life of weekend homes in Bermuda and private jet flights to Paris has not stopped him from earning the votes of constituents who give him credit for competence and leadership.

headline: Sales at Arhaus and Others
text: All painted and upholstered furniture is 15 percent off at Maine Cottage, May 25 to 28 (the Eloise armchair in a grade C fabric, originally $1,644, will be about $1,397; the Margate media console, originally $2,790, will be about $2,371); (866) 366-3505 or mainecottage.com.

headline: Romney Calls Education ‘Civil Rights Issue of Our Era’ and Urges Shift
text: Lamenting that millions of American children receive “a third world education,” Mitt Romney on Wednesday called for poor and disabled students to be able to use federal funds to attend any public, private or online school they choose.

headline: Our Not-So-Friendly Northern Neighbor
text: Montreal

headline: Heat Lose 2 Players After Flagrant Fouls
text: MIAMI — The Miami Heat, who are already without their injured All-Star forward Chris Bosh, will be forced to play Game 6 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series Thursday night at Indiana without the big men Udonis Haslem and Dexter Pittman.

headline: Handmade
text: The handmade artisan aesthetic is a trend this year at North America’s largest design show.

headline: A Fixture to Suit a Range of Moods
text: Alpha and Beta, two new lights by Paolo Franzin for Leucos USA, share a chameleon-like quality: their silk-screened glass diffusers are white when the lights are off, but display a range of shades, from white to sandy-beige, when the lights are on.

headline: Taking One for the Team. Or Not.
text: Baseball evokes the image of a father having that catch with his son. The grass is green, spring is in the air. Then you sign that professional contract.

headline: Buffett’s Goldman Deal Is Topic in an Insider Case
text: Byron D. Trott has spent a career carefully cultivating the image of the discreet investment banker, a behind-the-scenes consigliere to some of America’s wealthiest businessmen, including his star client, Warren E. Buffett. At Goldman Sachs, Mr. Trott was so vigilant about guarding clients’ confidences that he was known to fire underlings who discussed private matters in the bank’s elevators.

headline: The Danger Downwind
text: In 2006, then-Senator Barack Obama co-sponsored a tough law aimed at protecting the public from an accident or terrorist attack at one of the nation’s chemical plants. Opposed by industry and President George W. Bush’s White House, the bill never made it to the Senate floor. A weak substitute was passed instead, and the dangers remain. President Obama can fix the problem.

headline: Law of the Sea Treaty Is Found on Capitol Hill, Again
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican, joked that he was witnessing “sort of a Lazarus moment.” On that score, at least, Mr. Corker got no quarrel from his Democratic colleagues.

headline: Going With the Grain
text: ANDREW MAU had a man bun  — or rather, two of them. “A bun and a thing,” Mr. Mau said, referring to the stylish knot of hair perched high on his scalp and the smaller tuft gathered near his collar. If it’s not the coiffure you associate with the ancient vocation of woodworking, you clearly did not spend time at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, which on Tuesday ended its annual four-day run at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

headline: Designs From the 2012 International Contemporary Furniture Fair
text: Knotty furniture and woven tapestry have always appeared at the annual fair in New York, but this year the handmade threatened to upstage everything else.

headline: Unabomber Misses College Reunion, but Sends an Update
text: If you flip through the alumni registry of Harvard’s class of 1962, you will find doctors and venture capitalists, former members of Congress and a long-serving aid worker from the United Nations Development Program whose career included tours in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: When Marketing Links Web and TV Dramas
text: IN the season finale on May 31 of “Touch,” the Kiefer Sutherland drama on Fox, AT&T takes an unusual approach to paid product placement: showing characters using a mobile phone app that does not, in fact, exist.

headline: Welcome End of a Pseudotheory
text: Many opponents of giving equal rights and protections to gay Americans — at the workplace, in the military, in marrying and forming families — make the claim that homosexuality is a chosen way of life. They have long seized on the work of a towering figure in psychiatry to justify their position.

headline: China: Mysterious Inquiry About a Blood Sample
text: A prominent American forensic scientist, Henry C. Lee, said Wednesday in a telephone interview that he was contacted in February by a police detective from the Chinese city of Chongqing who wanted Dr. Lee’s laboratory to analyze a blood sample from someone who had died after drinking. Dr. Lee never received the sample and was not told whose blood it was. The inquiry to Dr. Lee, first reported in other newspapers, came in the same month that Wang Lijun, who had just been removed as Chongqing police chief, drove to a United States consulate and spoke of the death in Chongqing of Neil Heywood, a British businessman. Police officials said at the time that Mr. Heywood died of excessive drinking. Mr. Wang told American diplomats that Gu Kailai, the wife of Bo Xilai, then the Chongqing party chief, was involved in murdering Mr. Heywood.

headline: Questions of Fair Play Arise in Facebook’s I.P.O. Process
text: As Washington intensifies its scrutiny of the initial public offering of Facebook, the company’s bankers are facing questions about whether the process — even if perfectly legal — was fair.

headline: For Hospitals and Insurers, New Fervor to Cut Costs
text: Giselle Fernandez is only 17 but she has had more than 50 operations since she was born with a rare genetic condition. She regularly sees a host of pediatric specialists, including an ophthalmologist, an endocrinologist and a neurologist at UCLA Health System. Her care has cost hundreds of thousands of dollars so far, and she will need special treatment for the rest of her life.

headline: Lost in Translation
text: A persistent problem in American courts is the lack of translators to ensure that litigants who don’t speak or read English can take part in their cases. That’s the purpose of the Court Interpreters Act of 1978, which allows federal courts to order losing parties to pay prevailing parties the cost of interpreters.

headline: Union Accuses N.F.L. Owners of Collusion in Suit
text: In the latest and potentially most damaging salvo in an increasingly bitter family feud, the N.F.L. players’ union filed a complaint in federal court Wednesday charging the N.F.L. with collusion, saying team owners had a conspiracy to create a secret salary cap in the uncapped 2010 season.

headline: New Arrest in Death of U.S. Activist Reporting on Mexico Protests
text: MEXICO CITY — Authorities in the southern state of Oaxaca arrested a suspect on Wednesday in the killing of Bradley Roland Will, a New York activist and journalist shot during street protests in the state capital in 2006.

headline: Political Ads Don’t Tell Full Story on Private Equity
text: In an advertisement released this month by President Obama’s campaign, Mitt Romney and the private equity firm he co-founded, Bain Capital, are painted as vampires. They sucked the lifeblood out of GST Steel in the 1990s, which pushed it into bankruptcy, destroying jobs and eliminating pensions.

headline: Strategy on Rival’s Career Holds Pitfalls for President
text: Last week, a few dozen hedge fund and investment executives arrived at the Park Avenue home of Hamilton E. James, president of the private equity firm Blackstone. Each had paid $35,800 to spend two hours at a fund-raiser with President Obama, but the timing proved awkward: A few hours earlier, Mr. Obama’s campaign had begun a blistering attack on Mitt Romney’s career in private equity, the same business in which Mr. James has earned his many millions.

headline: Too Young for Pomp and Circumstance
text: How many “graduation” ceremonies will you attend this spring? At my two older children’s school, they call it “Step-Up Day.” I didn’t attend the first year I had a child there: he was in the second grade, going into third, a milestone that I did not expect to be marked with speeches.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Submits Reorganization Plan
text: More than a year after resorting to bankruptcy court, the Philadelphia Orchestra laid out its plan to erase debt and cut costs on Wednesday. But the Fabulous Philadelphians still face large deficits and are counting on optimistic fund-raising goals to recover its financial health.

headline: In Race for Congressional Seat, Israel Gets a Lot of Attention
text: Daniel J. Halloran III, a city councilman and Republican candidate for Congress in Queens, says that the corned beef his Irish family enjoys is actually a riff on pastrami.

headline: G.O.P. Nightmare Charts
text: Poll time!

headline: Cruisin’
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow, I had a tough time with this one, and no, it’s not because it required addition. At least on first glance.

headline: Prosecutor Seeks to Force Rabbis to Report on Abuse
text: The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said Wednesday that he would push for state legislation to add rabbis and other religious leaders to the list of professionals required to report allegations of sexual abuse to law enforcement authorities.

headline: FreshDirect Expands Delivery to Serve All of the Bronx
text: When FreshDirect received a $128 million package of cash and tax breaks in February to move to the Bronx, residents of the borough, the city’s poorest, protested loudly about a peculiar indignity: the online grocer did not deliver to most of their neighborhoods.

headline: Conduit to Arms Sting, a Star Witness Apologizes for His Crimes
text: By the time the authorities closed in on Andrew Smulian in Bangkok in 2008, he had lived a life full of intrigue. Born in Britain in 1941, he was raised in South Africa and served in its air force. And in 1966, he became a paid South African intelligence asset, using his air cargo company to spy on the military operations of nearby countries that opposed the apartheid regime.

headline: Lottery Numbers
She Has a Pimp’s Name Etched on Her
text: We think of branding as something ranchers do to their cattle. But it’s also what pimps do to women and girls they control across America.

headline: Church Official Testifies at His Philadelphia Trial
text: PHILADELPHIA — Msgr. William J. Lynn took the stand on Wednesday in a landmark trial to defend himself against allegations that he failed to prevent fellow Roman Catholic priests from abusing children during his tenure as secretary for clergy at the Archdiocese of Philadelphia.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 11
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Houston Tries to Find a Use for Its Fading Astrodome
text: HOUSTON — Dust is the only thing that rests on the roughly 65,000 red seats of the Astrodome these days. The bright green AstroTurf would trip up any wide receiver headed out for a pass: it lies not smooth and flat but bunched up in waves, as if the victim of a slow-motion earthquake.

headline: Mongolian Ex-President Denounces Timing of His Graft Trial
text: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia — As he prepared to go on trial on corruption charges, the former president of Mongolia lay in a wrinkled hospital bed, where he was recovering from a 10-day hunger strike he waged to protest being held in detention by his successor’s government.

headline: How to End Stop-and-Frisk Abuses
text: Commissioner Raymond Kelly of the New York Police Department issued a weak statement last week on efforts to “increase public confidence” in the city’s abusive stop-and-frisk program, which ensnares hundreds of thousands of mainly minority New Yorkers every year. Mr. Kelly seems to believe that tinkering at the margins will cure the program’s constitutional flaws. It will not.

headline: Rodriguez Rediscovering His Groove
text: When Alex Rodriguez flied out to deep left field in the eighth inning Sunday, it felt like a bad omen.

headline: Serving a Home Advantage
text: Francis Tiafoe, 14, who lived and learned tennis at the College Park, Md., tennis center where his father worked, is the top-ranked United States boys player in his age group.

headline: Putin Supports Sharp Rise in Fines for Protesting
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin lent his support on Wednesday to a sharp increase in fines for citizens who take part in unsanctioned demonstrations.

headline: Securing the Hispanic Vote
text: Hispanic voters make up a growing portion of the electorate in several battleground states.  What are Obama and Romney's strengths and weaknesses among Latino voters?

headline: Corrections: May 24
text: NEW YORK

headline: Phillips Takes ‘Idol,’ Echoing Winners Past
text: Phillip Phillips, a 21-year-old pawnshop employee from Georgia with a gutsy vocal style, won the Fox talent competition “American Idol” on Wednesday, beating out Jessica Sanchez, a teenage singing prodigy.

headline: Cloaked in History, 76ers Force a Game 7
text: PHILADELPHIA — As a motivating ploy for the Philadelphia 76ers leading to Wednesday’s Game 6 against the Boston Celtics, Coach Doug Collins showed his players a video from the 1982 N.B.A. playoffs. The video featured the Sixers going to Boston in the Eastern Conference semifinals to beat the Celtics in Game 7.

headline: Suffolk University Poll on the Massachusetts Senate Race
text: New polling numbers show Elizabeth Warren and Scott Brown about even in their election.

headline: Voters Shrug at Revelations of Ethnic Claim in Senate Race
text: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. — The controversy surrounding Elizabeth Warren’s ethnic heritage and whether she misrepresented herself as a minority in the past may have engulfed her Senate campaign and the news media, but in parts of western Massachusetts, voters seem either mystified by it or unconcerned.

headline: New Orleans Paper Said to Face Deep Cuts and May Cut Back Publication
text: The New Orleans Times-Picayune, which distinguished itself amid great adversity during Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath, is about to enact large staff cuts and may cut back its daily print publishing schedule, according to two employees with knowledge of the plans.

headline: Devils Start and Finish Strong
text: The match belonged with the epic encounters of 1994, a duel between two remarkably resilient teams that finally ended with a goal created by two fourth-liners.

headline: Rangers Can’t Overcome Shaky Start by Lundqvist
text: Rangers Coach John Tortorella took no small measure of grief for his pithy assertion Tuesday that perhaps the best thing he could do to get his top forwards to score more often in the Eastern Conference finals with the Devils was to “pray.”

headline: Woman Found Dead at Fire Scene
text: Firefighters responding to a blaze at a home in Queens on Wednesday discovered a gruesome scene: the stabbed body of a woman on a bed and a man in a closet hanging himself.

headline: With 2 Goals, Devils’ Fourth Line Makes Difference
text: Throughout his maiden trip to the N.H.L. playoffs, Stephen Gionta has communicated daily with big brother Brian, who hoisted the Stanley Cup for the Devils in 2003 and now serves as captain of the Montreal Canadiens. The postseason is a grind, Brian has told him, and it stokes emotions he did not even know he could feel. There was something else Brian mentioned.

headline: Word of the Day | opportunist

headline: Rangers-Devils: Game 5
text: The Devils earned a 5-3 victory and a 3-2 series lead at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Red Bulls and Chivas U.S.A. Tie
text: Kenny Cooper scored his 11th goal of the season and the Red Bulls tied visiting Chivas U.S.A., 1-1, in a Major League Soccer game in Harrison, N.J. The Red Bulls (8-3-2, 26 points) were seeking their club-record sixth straight victory, but had to settle for one point. Cooper’s goal canceled the first-half score by Juan Pablo Ángel, who played four seasons for the Red Bulls and is the club’s career-leading goal scorer.

headline: Obama Touts ‘Extraordinary’ Accomplishments at California Fund-Raisers
text: ATHERTON, Calif. – President Obama spent his evening Wednesday trolling for campaign funds amid the cultural and high-tech glitterati of Northern California, arguing that his accomplishments had been “extraordinary” but warning that it may take even beyond a second term to complete them.

headline: Who Cares if the Rupee Keeps Falling?
text: As the Indian rupee continues to fall in global markets, many respected analysts contend that the weakening currency signals the failure of the economic policies of the Indian government. In an op-ed column last weekend in The Business Standard, a leading business daily in India, Shankar Acharya said: “The real cause of the rupee’s weakness is the relentless deterioration in our economic policies in recent years. A falling rupee is simply a symptom of the underlying disease: unsound economic policies.” Mr. Acharya was part of the team that helped design the original economic reforms of 1991 and is a former chief economic adviser to the Indian government so his words should be taken seriously.

headline: A Two-Fly Plan for Beijing’s Toilets
text: Call it a “two-fly zone”: Many Beijing residents are sniggering at a new city rule that sets a limit of two flies per public toilet.

headline: News Quiz | May 24, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: ‘Idol’ Winner Cloaks His Talent in Modesty
text: If Phillip Phillips had been craving a victory on “American Idol” this season, he did an outstanding job of hiding it. Mr. Phillips is a secret sophisticate, often going to great lengths to mask his evident gift. Throughout the season he was shy and humble, even as his fingers, as applied to his guitar, displayed serious dexterity, and his voice, scratchy and earthy, showed real range and power.

headline: Drone Strikes Continue in Pakistan as Tension Increases and Senate Panel Cuts Aid
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — As tension between Pakistan and the United States deepened on multiple fronts on Thursday, a Senate panel voted to cut aid to Pakistan further, and C.I.A. drone strikes continued in northwestern Pakistan for a second consecutive day despite Pakistani condemnation.

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks End with No Deal
text: BAGHDAD — Talks between Iran and six world powers on its disputed nuclear program failed to produce a breakthrough on Thursday, in an apparent diplomatic setback for both sides.

headline: Muslim Brotherhood Candidate Has Early Lead in Egypt Presidential Election
text: CAIRO — The candidate of the Muslim Brotherhood, Mohamed Morsi, led the early returns of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election as the first ballots were counted on Thursday night and early Friday, almost certainly setting the stage for a runoff next month against either a more liberal Islamist or a former minister in the government of former President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: May 24, 1883 | Brooklyn Bridge Opens
text: On May 24, 1883, the Brooklyn Bridge, linking Brooklyn with Manhattan, was opened to traffic with a celebration attended by President Chester A. Arthur, Gov. Grover Cleveland of New York, and Emily Roebling, the wife of the bridge’s main engineer, Washington Roebling.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 24, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Rangers Storm Back Into Another World Series.”

headline: A Barrel of Hungry Monkeys Is Actually Not Much Fun
text: A man in India uses a large monkey to scare away its smaller relatives. Go to related article »

headline: Game On: A 19th-Century Approach to Photographing Modern Warfare
text: In an open field, a soldier lays limp, face down in the grass.

headline: How Did Wisconsin Become the Most Politically Divisive Place in America?
text: This past March, standing outside a Shell station in Mellen, Wis., in the state’s far north, Mike Wiggins Jr. told me about a series of dark and premonitory dreams he had two years earlier. “One of them was a very vivid trip around the North Woods and seeing forests bleeding and sludge from a creek emptying into the Bad River,” Wiggins said. “I ended up at a dilapidated northern log home with rotten snowshoes falling off the wall. I stepped out of the lodge, walked through some pine, and I was in a pipeline. There was a big pipe coming in and out of the ground as far as I could see.

headline: Dimon and the Fed’s Legitimacy
text: 2:47 p.m. | Updated  with comment by president of Kansas City Fed.

headline: What’s on Your Summer Reading List?
text: If you’re in school, no doubt you have some assigned reading this summer — but we hope you also have some books you want to read (and, of course, we hope you’ll participate in at least a few weeks of our summer reading contest).

headline: Behind Baku’s Bling
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — From my seat in the back of the sparkling purple-lit stadium at Eurovision Song Contest, it was hard sometimes this week to distinguish the pageantry of Europe’s largest international pop music competition from the pageantry of Azerbaijan’s self-promotion.

headline: A Conversation With: Maldives President Mohammed Waheed Hassan
text: Mohammed Waheed Hassan, president of the Maldives, concluded a five-day state visit to India last week, his first since taking over in February after Mohamed Nasheed, the country’s first democratically elected leader, stepped down. Mr. Nasheed said he was forced to leave in a coup that was orchestrated by loyalists to Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, the former dictator.

headline: Lawmaker Proposes Limiting Out-of-State Enrollment at University of California Schools
text: A California lawmaker is proposing to limit the number of out-of-state and international students who can enroll at University of California campuses.

headline: India’s Faltering Economy Could Get Worse
text: Few economic experts in recent months have been as critical of India’s fiscal policy and governance and as bearish about the country’s economic future if reform does not happen as Rajeev Malik, senior economist with CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets, an independent research and brokerage firm.

headline: Paris Loves Jazz, This Time With a Festival
text: Few cities celebrate jazz quite like Paris. Having given American jazz artists a home away from home since the 1920s, the city still knows how to welcome them and their fans from all over the world. And few districts are as associated with jazz as St.-Germain, where many performers made their mark in the local clubs and theaters after World War II. So it is only natural that a jazz festival was established there. Now in its 12th year, the St. Germain Jazz Festival runs through June 3, featuring a top-flight line-up that includes Kurt Elling, Ahmad Jamal, Yusef Lateef and Jacky Terrasson.

headline: E-Mail Shows Murdoch Bid Maneuvering
text: LONDON — The long-running judicial inquiry into the cloistered world of Britain’s media barons and powerful politicians on Thursday produced a new and potentially damaging insight into the internal maneuvering within Prime Minister David Cameron’s government as it considered Rupert Murdoch’s $12 billion bid last year to take control of the country’s most powerful and lucrative commercial television network.

headline: Silver Lake and Partners Group to Buy Global Blue for $1.25 Billion
text: LONDON — The private equity firm Silver Lake and the investment management company Partners Group agreed on Thursday to buy Global Blue, a tax-free shopping business, for 1 billion euros.
