headline: Queen Victoria’s Complete Diaries Released Online
text: As part of her Diamond Jubilee celebration, Queen Elizabeth II has established a Web site featuring the complete personal journals of Queen Victoria, the only other sovereign in British history to have celebrated 60 years on the throne.

headline: Brother of Chinese Dissident Escapes Guarded Village
text: BEIJING — A brother of the legal activist Chen Guangcheng, whose decision to seek refuge in the American Embassy here prompted a diplomatic standoff between China and the United States, has himself slipped through the security cordon around his village and made his way to the capital, according to a lawyer who met him on Thursday.

headline: Yes, There Are Comedians in Qatar
text: At 5 p.m. on a Sunday evening, the comedians started to arrive at the auditorium in Katara, the fake-old-looking development in Doha, Qatar. Eight of them were scheduled to perform that night, and Bilal Randeree, the 29-year-old leader of Stand Up Comedy Qatar, was worrying about the possibility that someone might joke about Islam or the emir or sex, which most of them say they have never had.

headline: Introducing Beth Shaw, a New Business Group Member
text: In my last post, we met one of two new members to join our business group. This post introduces a second.

headline: Tremors of Anxiety Over Arctic Drilling
text: As John Broder and I write in Thursday’s Times, the Obama administration is backing Shell’s audacious efforts to open Alaska’s Arctic waters to oil drilling. The plan offers the promise of greater national energy security, the thinking goes, and economic benefits for Alaskans.

headline: Confronting a False Meme: Libya’s Deadly ‘Stinger Equivalents’
text: Sometimes an article on the arms beat makes a claim that both demands attention and merits a deeper dive. The article excerpted below, posted earlier this year on Aviation Week’s Web site, was this kind of read. It began:

headline: Back in the Day, When Agents and Aliens Were Sweet
text: Can you think of a new movie with less reason for existing than “Men in Black 3”? What? “Battleship”? Yes, O.K. Good point. Hadn’t thought of that. “What to Expect When You’re Expecting”? Fair enough. But still. “The Avengers”? Let’s not go there. And stop interrupting me when I’m trying to make a serious point.

headline: Romney's Education Plan Calls for More School Choices

headline: A Jennifer Egan Original … Tweet by Tweet
text: When the novelist Jennifer Egan submitted her latest short story to The New Yorker, she hinted to Deborah Treisman, the fiction editor, that there was a catch. It soon became evident: Ms. Egan had written an entire work of fiction in 140 character bits, to be first posted on Twitter and then published in the magazine.

headline: Funeral Service Is Held for Donna Summer
text: Donna Summer, the pop singer and disco queen behind hits like “I Feel Love” and “Hot Stuff,” was remembered Wednesday at a funeral service for family members and close friends at Christ Presbyterian Church in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Summer, who won five Grammy Awards during a career that spanned some 30 years, died of cancer on May 17 at her home in Naples, Fla. She was 63.

headline: Woman Killed in Union Square by Hit-and-Run Truck Driver
text: A 21-year-old woman was fatally struck by a hit-and-run truck driver at Broadway and East 14th Street early Thursday morning, the police said. The woman, whose name was not immediately released, was crossing Broadway around 1:30 a.m. when a truck traveling east on 14th Street turned right on Broadway, hit her, and kept going, the police said.

headline: When a New Transit Project Is Announced, Expect Delays
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority let it be known the other day that its plan to have the Long Island Rail Road run into Grand Central Terminal was way over budget and behind schedule.

headline: Olympic Torch Turns Out to Be a Tough Sell
text: 2012 London Games torch relay commemorative pin: $11.

headline: New Romney Ad Focuses on the Economy
text: The Romney campaign is up with a new ad called “Day One” that describes what the first day of a Romney presidency would be like. It focuses on three areas: immediate deficit reduction, taking on China on trade issues, and repealing “job killing regulations.” The largely positive ad takes on President Obama by name only once, saying that Mr. Romney’s fiscal reforms are geared toward “ending the Obama era of big government.”

headline: A Pact on New York Watershed Discharges
text: New York City’s management of the reservoirs that supply drinking water to nine million people in the city and nearby counties has been praised for assuring quality and avoiding the need for filtration. Still, it has been criticized for contributing to flooding and pollution problems upstate.

headline: Thank You, Elegant Heroine
text: Dear Diary: I’m not from New York City, but when my family and I are there, I do my best to pretend. During our last visit, on the way to retrieve our car after a long day with kids in tow, we ended up at a subway station with no attendant and no ticket machines.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Details: Is “grazing” (in other words, eating a lot of small meals throughout the course of a day) really such a good idea? …

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Questions on BSkyB Bid, and Older Moviegoers Get Counted
text: The government inquiry into the ethics and behavior of the British press is hearing testimony on Thursday about the government’s response to News Corporation’s attempt to buy outright the satellite broadcaster BSkyB — a bid that was withdrawn as the phone-hacking scandal widened.

headline: The City’s Stage, in Rain, Heat and Ribald Lines
text: IN the 50 years since Joe Papp successfully lobbied the city to build an amphitheater in the middle of Central Park, the Delacorte Theater has played host to all 37 of Shakespeare’s plays plus a smattering of Chekhov, Brecht, Ibsen, Aeschylus and, as of this August, Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine (“Into the Woods”). During that time, more than four million patient theatergoers have waited in line to see a potent mix of raw talent, seasoned stage veterans and Hollywood imports do battle against the Central Park fauna, the occasional helicopter and the more than occasional thunderstorm to perform the classics free.

headline: Five Possible Detours for Drogba on His Way to China
text: Didier Drogba’s long exit from Chelsea, the team for which he secured its first European Cup last week, continues. He announced officially on Tuesday what we all knew: he’s leaving London.

headline: Life, Interrupted: The Beat Goes On
text: Music, as the saying commonly goes, can soothe even the savage beast. What about the frail beast? The sad one?

headline: Times-Picayune Confirms Staff Cuts and 3-Day-a-Week Print Schedule
text: 1:14 p.m. | Updated The Times-Picayune newspaper in New Orleans confirmed on Thursday that it would cut back its print publishing schedule to three days a week and lay off an unknown number of staff members.

headline: Yukking It Up in Qatar
text: In this Sunday’s magazine, I have an article about Stand Up Comedy Qatar, a group of amateur comedians that emerged in the wake of the Arab Spring. They tell jokes about traffic, KFC and suicide bombers. And sometimes despots, too.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘God Help Me’
text: This poem, one of 11 winners of our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Liam, 15, from South Portland, Me.

headline: Romney’s Unemployment Rate Dilemma
text: Mitt Romney is promising to turn the economy around if he is elected president. And there may be no more visceral measure of whether he ultimately keeps that promise than the nation’s unemployment rate.

headline: In Western Washington, Gas Prices Buck the Trend
text: TACOMA, Wash. — A lot has come down the pike since the summer of 2008, which for many Americans may already feel like the closed chapter of an old book. But here on the West Coast there is an unhappy echo: gasoline prices.

headline: Facebook’s Legal Issues
text: Peter J. Henning, The White Collar Watch columnist, examines the shareholder lawsuits against Facebook and the underwriters of its I.P.O.

headline: On Our Radar: BP to Tame Refinery Flares
text: BP agrees to spend more than $400 million to reduce noxious air pollution from a massive refinery in northwestern Indiana. The deal resolves a battle of nearly a decade over a $3.8 billion upgrade and expansion of BP’s Whiting refinery to process heavy crude oil pulled from tar sands in Canada. [The Chicago Tribune]

headline: Image of the Day: May 24
text: Telugu Desam Party activists in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, protest the 7.54 rupee petrol price hike by the central government.

headline: Daily Report: Questions of Fair Play Arise in Facebook’s I.P.O.
text: As Washington intensifies its scrutiny of the initial public offering of Facebook, the company’s bankers are facing questions about whether the process — even if perfectly legal — was fair, report Evelyn M. Rusli, Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced of The New York Times DealBook staff.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/24: Niagara Tours in Danger and Southwest Goes International
text: Niagara Falls’s Maid of the Mist in Peril The Maid of the Mist, the tour boats that take travelers from the American falls to the base of the Horseshoe Falls, has lost its contract to run tours on the Canadian side of the falls to a California company. With the loss of a contract, it no longer has anywhere to store its boats in winter. (The New York Times)

headline: Hollande on European Leaders: They Talk a Lot
text: BRUSSELS — François Hollande dove into the maelstrom of European Union politics on Wednesday, and what he discovered surprised even the president of a famously loquacious nation like France: Boy, can those Europeans talk.

headline: Tokyo Stores Serve a Feast of Plastic Food
text: TOKYO — On the chaotic streets of the world’s most sprawling restaurant-supply district, sales to home chefs have been declining of late. But one trending indicator is up, way up: fake food.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Officially a Billionaire
text: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, is now officially a billionaire. Until now, Mr. Zuckerberg has been staggeringly rich only on paper.

headline: After 33 Years, Police Make Arrest in Case of Etan Patz
text: A New Jersey man was arrested in the killing of Etan Patz, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced on Thursday, an extraordinary moment in a case that has gripped New York City’s psyche ever since the 6-year-old boy vanished in SoHo on his way to school in 1979.

text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Foreign Ministry on Thursday indirectly denied persistent rumors that President Bashar al-Assad’s brother-in-law, a member of the secretive inner circle governing the country, was fatally poisoned by the opposition.

headline: Was Facebook’s I.P.O. Fair?
text: May 24, 2012 - Why Facebook's I.P.O. has some investors crying foul.

headline: City Panel Approves Special Education Inclusion Plan
text: A plan to restructure the city’s special education program by funneling thousands of learning-disabled children into mainstream classrooms — an increasingly popular practice around the country — was given the go-ahead Wednesday night when the Panel for Education Policy voted to finance it. Following some criticisms to the plan, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott said after the vote, “We’re pure, at least with regards to the goals we are trying to achieve.”

headline: Sberbank of Russia in Talks to Buy DenizBank for $4 Billion
text: LONDON – Sberbank of Russia is in exclusive talks to buy DenizBank, a Turkish subsidiary of the struggling French-Belgian lender Dexia, for $4 billion, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Just One Look | DKNY
text: Though black suit looks (with trousers featuring either a tapered leg or boot cut) and pops of houndstooth (on skirts and coats) were omnipresent, the DKNY resort collection meant more than just business. Donna Karan presented a lineup stocked with party frocks and sequined separates too, all of them energized with shots of red, magenta and fuchsia, plus fur to boot. But it was the designer’s more urban, neutral offerings — blush tone tops, outerwear and bottoms, mixed with black leather accents — that met the DKNY working-girl-meets-fashion-girl customer right smack in the middle. The trench dress with leather sleeves, shown here, trumped all.

headline: Deposed Politician’s City Lists Names for Meeting on China’s Next Leaders
text: BEIJING — The Communist Party branch in Chongqing, the teeming western municipality once governed by the deposed politician Bo Xilai, has named candidates for its delegation to a critical party conference in the fall at which China’s next leadership lineup is expected to be announced. The list of 50 candidates includes some officials considered allies of Mr. Bo, but excludes Mr. Bo himself.

headline: Video: Was Facebook’s I.P.O. Fair?
text: Peter Lattman and Michael de la Merced discuss why some investors are crying foul on Facebook’s I.P.O. Some are wondering whether the process was really fair and who is to blame for the stock’s poor performance.

headline: The Boomer Quietus
text: The provocation of the week is the media impresario Michael Wolff’s New York magazine account of his mother’s long, agonizing dying process, a piece that moves inexorably from a compelling case against hyper-interventionist medicine (“what I feel most intensely when I sit by my mother’s bed is a crushing sense of guilt for keeping her alive”) to a case for assisted suicide (“give us the right to make provisions for when we want to go … “) to a case for straightforward euthanasia (“what I would not do for a fair-minded body to whom I might plead for my mother’s end”). It concludes with a promise that his generation will do these things differently when their time comes:

headline: What We’re Reading
text: News on the Olympics from around the Web.

headline: America Has ‘Idol’ Fatigue, as Finale Is Lowest Rated in Its History
text: The episode of “American Idol” on Wednesday, with the crowning of Phillip Phillips, represented the lowest-rated season finale for the singing competition in its 10-year run.

headline: The First Wired President
text: In an era when everything is online and the nation’s leader is tethered to what many call BlackBerry One, it’s important to remember that presidential telecommunications has a long history — going back to Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War.

headline: New York Philharmonic Concertmaster to Leave in 2014
text: Glenn Dicterow, the longest-serving concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic, has decided to step down, the orchestra said on Thursday. Mr. Dicterow, 63, plans to leave following the 2013-14 season, after 34 years, and will become a professor of strings and chamber music at the Thornton School of Music, which is part of the University of Southern California. Mr. Dicterow will continue to perform as a soloist and chamber musician, the orchestra said.

headline: Tight Race Seen in Swing-State Polls
text: Poll results in three swing states show President Obama and Mitt Romney in tight races in Florida and Virginia, and the president with a six-point advantage in Ohio.

headline: An Island Refuge
text: A few weeks ago, I visited Roosevelt Island for the first time in over six years. The aerial tram was crowded when I boarded and everyone had cameras ready as we began our ascent over the East River. Apparently I wasn’t the only one who thought the skinny little island east of Manhattan would be a good place to enjoy one of the first sunny weekends of the year.

headline: Right Wing Talking Point, Democratic Candidate
text: In 2008, Republican candidates in blue states and blue Congressional districts distanced themselves from George W. Bush’s policies. Now Democratic Party candidates in red states and red Congressional districts are distancing themselves from Barack Obama – on the theory that voters will surge to their side if they act like they’re not big fans of the president.

headline: Is This Kashmir’s Road Map for Peace?
text: In the summer of 2010, the Kashmir valley in Indian-controlled Kashmir erupted with protests after a school boy was killed under controversial circumstances. Locals alleged that the boy was shot dead by the police. The police in the region frequently fired upon protesting youths who threw stones, killing about 120 young boys that year alone.

headline: Most Underwater Homeowners Still Paying Mortgages
text: Nearly a third of homeowners with mortgages, or roughly 16 million borrowers, remained underwater on their home loans in the first three months of this year, an analysis from the real estate site Zillow finds. Underwater borrowers owe more on their mortgages than the home is worth.

headline: Facebook Releases a Photocentric App for Apple Devices
text: 1:11 p.m. | Updated  Adding Instagram context.

headline: On the Allure of Ostriches and New Paths in Climate Communication
text: Lynne Cherry, a prize-winning environmental writer and illustrator (remember “The Great Kapok Tree“?) who’s now also a youth-oriented filmmaker, recently alerted me to a paper exploring the limits of traditional environmental messages given a deeply ingrained human habit of avoiding inconvenient warnings.

headline: Taking Calcium May Pose Heart Risks
text: Calcium supplements, long recommended for stronger bones, may be bad for the heart, a large new study confirms. The study found that taking extra calcium may raise the risk of a heart attack.

headline: Gas Prices Modestly Lower as Driving Season Starts
text: HOUSTON — As the Memorial Day weekend and the summer driving season approach, gasoline prices are easing. But most drivers will find prices only modestly lower than a year ago.

headline: Republicans Apologetic After Raising Issue of Obama’s Birthplace
text: Representative Mike Coffman of Colorado apologized at length on Wednesday for reviving unsubstantiated claims that President Obama was not born in the United States.

headline: Justices Allow Retrial on Rejected Charges
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that a criminal defendant may be retried even though the jury in his first trial had unanimously rejected the most serious charges against him. The vote was 6 to 3, with the justices split over whether the constitutional protection against double jeopardy barred such reprosecutions.

headline: Bolt and Pistorius to Compete in Czech Meet
text: OSTRAVA, Czech Republic — Usain Bolt, the triple Olympic gold medalist and world record holder, will headline an impressive field at the 51st Golden Spike meet here Friday evening.

headline: Blacks and Marriage Equality: An Update
text: There has been a great deal of attention over recent years to black Americans’ attitudes about homosexuality and to their feelings about same-sex marriage in particular. This was a big part of the coverage of Proposition 8’s fate in California, and it has been an equally big part of the story of Maryland’s movement toward marriage equality.

headline: On Stage, the Repercussions of a Medical Mistake
text: Few plays or movies capture the complex emotional and professional aftermath of a medical error. So often, the characterizations and story lines are as facile as a cartoon, with careless and negligent doctors, irrational and vengeful patients and families, and soulless, ambulance-chasing lawyers.

headline: Romney and the Long Shadow of ‘Day 1’ Promises
text: For the second time in a week, Mitt Romney has offered a series of explicit promises about what he would do on his first day in the Oval Office.

headline: The Get | Mikimoto’s Avenir Necklace
text: Elevating the classic pearl strand is no easy task, but Mikimoto, the nearly 120-year-old purveyor of the ocean’s most valuable orbs, has done exactly that with its latest Avenir necklace. Made of a mix of Akoya and South Sea pearls, the Avenir gradates from white to black to gray, creating a smooth and soothing ombré effect — a first for this editor’s eyes. Feasting would be an understatement.

headline: For Voters, It’s the Job-Growth Trend That Counts
text: When Al Gore went before voters in November 2000, as a sitting vice president promising to continue President Bill Clinton’s economic policies, the economy was in excellent shape. The unemployment rate had fallen to only 3.9 percent, and middle-class incomes were growing at their fastest clip in a generation.

headline: At Fort Hood, a Welcome Home for Veterans of a War Long Past
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.— This welcome-home ceremony seemed like many held at the largest Army base in the country, although a little more elaborate. There were cheering families outfitted in red, white and blue, many carrying posters and flags. The multistory III Corps banner billowed in the wind as hundreds of soldiers stood in formation on the expansive parade ground waiting for the buses of troops.

headline: Theater Talkback: An Actress Makes a Choice and Two Others May Benefit
text: Fabulously funny as she is, strafing her nearest and dearest as a lovably hateful mother in “The Lyons,” Linda Lavin may not come home with a Tony Award this year. She has the fortunate misfortune of being nominated in the most competitive category in the awards, leading actress in a play.

headline: Iran Takes Credit for Thwarting Pirate Attack on U.S.-Flagged Vessel
text: Who scared the pirates away from a United States-flagged cargo ship in the Gulf of Oman on Wednesday — armed guards or an Iranian warship?

headline: The Advantages of Arbitration
text: Andrew Pincus, a partner at the law firm Mayer Brown in Washington, argued in the Supreme Court on behalf of AT&T Mobility in the Concepcion case. His practice focuses on Supreme Court and appellate litigation.

headline: Holdin’ On to That Rivera Feelin’
text: From television shows like “The Sopranos” and “Glee” to the Broadway musical “Rock of Ages,” Journey’s rock anthem “Don’t Stop Believin'” just keeps going on, and on and on and on. And the song is no stranger to the sports world.

headline: The Company He Keeps: I’ll Have Another and His Connections
text: It’s a shame that I’ll Have Another, our first Triple Crown contender since 2008, will head into the Belmont under the cloud of accusations about illegal drug use that hangs over the head of his trainer Doug O’Neill. In a CNN interview earlier this week, O’Neill’s brother Dennis claimed that they knew so little about what a “milkshake” — the illegal supplement that Doug O’Neill is accused of administering to his horses — was, that they had to Google it. Since everyone in the industry is familiar with milkshakes along with furosemide, steroids, phenylbutazone and other performance-enhancing drugs, the claim of having to Google the term does nothing to lift suspicion from the O’Neills.

headline: F.I.T. and ABC
text: This week, the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology opened the second part of its yearlong exhibition highlighting great works from its extensive holdings, alphabetically. Called “Fashion, A-Z,” the show is organized similarly to the first exhibition that closed on May 8. This time, the designers begin with Adrian and end with Zoran.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Show Gupta and Rajaratnam Were Close Friends
text: 9:23 a.m. | Updated

headline: In Wisconsin, Walker Is Likely to Survive Recall
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a Republican, is likely to survive a recall election on June 5, according to recent nonpartisan polls of the state.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Familiar Territory for Maryland
text: With Saturday’s second-round win over Loyola in the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Maryland Terrapins women’s lacrosse team’s senior players will have the rare opportunity to play in a Final Four every year of their college careers.

headline: Sweden 1912: Soldiers Welcome
text: One hundred years ago the summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

headline: Cuomo Says His Record Will Help Elect Democrats Across New York
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vowed on Thursday to “elect Democrats in every office all across this state,” arguing that his accomplishments as governor offered a strong platform for candidates running in local races this year.

headline: 4 Kidnapped While Aiding Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four aid workers for an international humanitarian organization were kidnapped Tuesday afternoon in northern Afghanistan, the organization, Medair, announced late Thursday.

headline: JPMorgan’s Deficient Disclosures
text: So many questions still dangle over JPMorgan Chase’s disastrous credit bet. Here is one more: Why is it so hard to find answers in the bank’s public financial filings?

headline: Digital Notes: Pandora Revenues Grow, and Streaming Music’s Global Drive
text: Pandora, which has been under scrutiny from investors since it went public almost a year ago, delivered some good financial news on Wednesday, and its stock price rose more than 13 percent by Thursday afternoon.

headline: A Visit, and What Really Happened
text: HIS e-mail read: “Here for one night. Giants game tomorrow. Buy you a drink?”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Moonrise Kingdom’
text: “Moonrise Kingdom,” the latest film from Wes Anderson, aims to capture the spirit and excitement of two kids in love. The film is set in 1965 on a remote New England island and follows Sam (Jared Gilman) and Suzy (Kara Hayward) as they try to run away together.

headline: Citigroup Wins Fed Auction for Maiden Lane Bonds
text: Wall Street continues to pick up the pieces from the American International Group blowup.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Moonrise Kingdom'
text: Wes Anderson, the director of "Moonrise Kingdom," discusses a scene from his film.

text: President Obama’s challenges with Wall Street donors | Mitt Romney’s biggest fan | Reader questions on the Massachusetts Senate race.

headline: In Klimt’s Kingdom, One Lady Reigns
text: The Neue Galerie is dedicated, with religious single-mindedness, to the cause of Austrian and German modernism. Like any church, it has its patron saints; Gustav Klimt is one. And it has its sacred objects, notably Klimt’s 1907 portrait of the Viennese socialite Adele Bloch-Bauer, a picture with the visual heft and cultish allure of a reliquary.

headline: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Bruce Driver
text: During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. On May 24, 1994, Bruce Driver was a Devils defenseman, happy after beating the Rangers at Madison Square Garden in Game 5 the previous day and looking forward to winning the series at home in Game 6 the next day — precisely the situation the Devils find themselves in today. But in 1994 it didn’t end up working out well for New Jersey. Today’s Devils can draw a lesson from what Driver experienced in Game 6, when he was on the ice for the three Rangers goals that turned a 2-0 Devils lead into a 3-2 deficit.

headline: Been Facebook-ed Lately?
text: Gotten whacked by the market today?

headline: At a Tech-Savvy School, Smart Questions About City's New Social Media Policy

headline: Cannes Film Festival: A Cool, Analytical Filmmaker Gets a Warm Reception
text: CANNES, France — The Austrian director Michael Haneke has made an art of exploiting audience discomfort. In a sense his new film “Amour” continues in that vein by staring down the least palatable of subjects: aging, sickness and death. But the universal specter of mortality has brought with it a tenderness seldom seen in Mr. Haneke’s cool, analytical cinema, and the film remains the closest thing to a consensus favorite among critics here.

headline: New Music Seminar Revives Its Festival
text: Back in the 1980s, the New Music Seminar was a major alternative-music convention in New York, an annual bash that drew more than 6,000 people and, in the days before the Internet, let talent scouts for record labels get a look at hundreds of emerging bands at dozens of nightclubs.

headline: Is Evan Turner in the Right Spot?
text: Few N.B.A. players could claim a postseason run more curious than that of Evan Turner. The 76ers guard is an off-the-dribble creator in exactly the mold that Philadelphia’s offense demands, and yet against the top-notch defenses of the Chicago Bulls and Boston Celtics, Turner has been shockingly inefficient. Beckley Mason of ESPN.com summed up Turner’s position rather well on TrueHoop:

headline: Photo Replay: May 24
text: Preparations continued for the Golden Spike track and field meeting in Ostrava, Czech Republic, and the Crowne Plaza Invitational at Colonial golf tournament began in Fort Worth.

headline: Ahead of Monaco Grand Prix, Jenson Button and Romain Grosjean Hone Knife Skills
text: The smell of burnt rubber may be the last thing a chef wants wafting into the kitchen. But beyond the door of the Pirelli Formula One hospitality motor home, the odor is simply a fact of life, according to “Miles and Meals,” a motorsports-themed cookbook from the Italian tire maker.

headline: Two Picassos, Twice Stolen, Find a New Home
text: It all started 44 years ago. “My aunt called and said, ‘Chuckie, you need to come to where my artwork is being shown,’” the nephew recalled. There was an urgency in her voice, with good cause: “‘Someone walked off with my Picasso.’”

headline: On ‘Mad Men,’ a Clawed Cure for Don Draper’s Waning Mojo?
text: Among the unlikely stars of this, the fifth season of the AMC television series “Mad Men,” is a bright red Jaguar E-Type.

headline: Handguns: The New Tote Bag
text: Tucker Carlson’s news site, The Daily Caller, has announced that it’s giving away a gun a week until Election Day. As The Atlantic Wire sagely observed, “there’s no way this could ever go wrong.” It’s such a great idea to hand out high-capacity 9mm pistols, which, according to the manufacturer, have a “snag free design ideal for concealed carry.” There’s really nothing worse than tearing your shirt when you’re trying to defend yourself.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: For Northwestern, Two Rivalries
text: For all the talk of Northwestern finally finding its match in the upstart Florida Gators, many seem to be forgetting that the Wildcats already have a fierce rivalry with another successful squad.

headline: Two Young Musicians Receive Avery Fisher Career Grants
text: Conrad Tao, 17, a pianist studying at Columbia University and the Juilliard School, and Benjamin Beilman, 22, a violinist who has racked up a number of competition prizes, were given Avery Fisher Career Grants this week. The awards, administered by the Avery Fisher Artist Program, are worth $25,000 and are designed to help young musicians help build careers.

text: The New York Times asked six artists to come up with their own version of a poster for the 1980 slasher film “Friday the 13th.”

headline: Pro Wrestling, Senegal Style
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Many called it the biggest match of all time. Others, just the biggest of the season. Either way, it was too big for the limited seating at Demba Diop Stadium here — a fact not lost on those who started lining up outside at 9 a.m., 10 hours before the main event.

headline: Talking to a Stepdaughter About Puberty Without Rocking the Boat
text: D.’s stepdaughter is almost 10 years old. She has a bra, she’s growing up, but D. said in last Friday’s parenting quandary, that it doesn’t seem like her mother has talked to her about the changes that lie ahead. D. loves her stepdaughter (who lives with D. and her husband half of the time) and wants to help, but without stepping on her mother’s toes.

headline: A Harlem Elementary School Offers Arabic Lessons
text: The principal and parents at the Hamilton Heights School on Amsterdam Avenue chose to offer Arabic to second through fifth graders partly to help the school earn an International Baccalaureate designation.

headline: Senate Backs Bipartisan Bill to Speed Drugs and Avert Shortages
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate passed a major bipartisan bill on Thursday to prevent drug shortages and to speed federal approval of lifesaving medicines, including lower-cost generic versions of biotechnology products.

headline: Alibaba Said to Seek Billions to Buy Back Yahoo Stake
text: The China Investment Corporation is in advanced talks to add as much as $2 billion to the Alibaba Group to help finance the Internet company’s efforts to buy back a stake from Yahoo, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Brazil’s New Leader Mulls Country’s Forest Protections
text: Lou Gold, an American expatriate living in Brazil’s portion of the Amazon River basin who is a frequent presence on Dot Earth, is keeping track of efforts to change the country’s Forest Code and has posted a helpful update on his blog, excerpted here with permission:

headline: No Dibs on Love
text: I went to a party with a friend and started flirting with a very hot girl. We ended up making out, and my friend was happy for me. The next weekend, we met her again, and she and I made out some more. Then I introduced her to my friend, at which point she dumped me and began an intense new relationship with him. I feel bad and can’t help treating my friend differently. He has asked me why. Should I tell him, or put my feelings aside and root for them?Edson, Brazil

headline: A Butterfly Takes Wing on Climate Change
text: A butterfly species in England is expanding its range, thanks to climate change.

headline: Russian Dancer Signs With American Ballet Theater
text: A Russian ballerina has decided to make America her artistic home. Polina Semionova, currently a guest artist with American Ballet Theater, will join the company as a principal dancer in September, Kevin McKenzie, Ballet Theater’s artistic director, announced. Ms. Semionova, who was born in Moscow and joined the Berlin State Ballet as a principal in 2002, first appeared with American Ballet Theater in 2011. She will perform with the company during its New York seasons, as well as on its national and international tours. Ms. Semionova, 27, is scheduled to perform with ABT at the Metropolitan Opera House in four more performances this season, including “La Bayadère ” on Saturday, “Apollo” on June 13 and “Swan Lake” on June 26 and 29.

headline: U.S. Human Rights Report Cites Bright Spots, but Also Points to Abuses
text: WASHINGTON — After an “especially tumultuous and momentous year” for human rights, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Thursday, the challenge in many Arab countries has shifted from breaking the back of entrenched dictatorships to protecting new freedom during the often chaotic and sometimes violent transitions that follow.

headline: First Phase of Governors Island Renovation Begins
text: In the past few years, Governors Island, the former military base in New York Harbor, has become the “it” summer destination for savvy New Yorkers. With free ferry service to the island on weekends, bicycle rentals, art exhibitions, food festivals, music and other cultural programs, Governors Island drew nearly a half-million visitors last year, up from 8,000 visitors in 2005.

headline: From the Miser, Art on Governors Island
text: For the last few years Memorial Day weekend has been the opening for Governors Island. Used by the military in one form or another for over 200 years, the island now feels like a floating park, combining natural lushness, historic architecture and cultural events.

headline: On the Go With Young Bluefin Tuna
text: Atlantic bluefin tuna aren’t much of a mystery when they’re dead. Sushi chefs roaming the Tokyo fish market can appraise a bluefin steak with a cursory glance. Multitudes of people are intimate with the distinct texture and flavor of bluefin meat.

text: Another day of voting in Egypt’s first free presidential election.

headline: Putin Ally Warns of Political Fallout if Economy Falters
text: MOSCOW — The economy in Russia is now as likely to sink into recession as it is to continue to grow, a prominent former finance minister said on Thursday.

headline: In the Persian Gulf, Struggling to Adapt as Deals Dry Up
text: DUBAI — As a new wave of austerity has left many financial firms around the world struggling, their counterparts in the Persian Gulf region have too been forced to hunker down.

headline: Senate Panel Holds Up Aid to Pakistan
text: A unanimous Senate Armed Services Committee took a bipartisan shot at Pakistan on Thursday for the sentencing of the physician who helped catch Osama bin Laden, approving a $631.4 billion defense policy bill that withholds aid to the wavering ally until supply lines are open, support for terrorist networks ceases and the doctor,  Shakil Afridi,  is released.

headline: Mississippi State Takes First-Round Win in EcoCAR 2 Challenge
text: Year No. 1 of the Energy Department’s EcoCAR 2 competition concluded this week in Los Angeles, with the team from Mississippi State University taking top honors, as well as $7,000 in prize money, among teams from 15 universities. Roughly $100,000 in total prize money was distributed to teams that distinguished themselves in 25 categories.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Obama and Wall St.
text: On TimesCast Politics, Catherine Rampell discusses President Obama’s challenges with Wall Street donors, Michael Barbaro looks at Mitt Romney’s biggest fan, and Katharine Q. Seelye answers reader questions on the Massachusetts Senate race.

headline: Hal Jackson, 96, New York Broadcaster Who Broke Racial Barriers in Radio, Dies
text: Hal Jackson, a veteran broadcaster who broke down racial barriers, becoming one of the first black disc jockeys to reach a large white audience and an omnipresent voice on New York City radio for more than 50 years, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 96.

headline: Noomi Rapace Can Hold Her Breath a Really Long Time
text: When the magazine asks actors to turn a photo shoot into a performance, they usually hit their marks with gusto. In the recent past, for example, we have gotten to see Jessica Chastain start a fire with her eyes, Gary Oldman channel a demented ventriloquist’s dummy and James Franco kiss himself in the mirror. Now the actor Noomi Rapace joins their ranks by turning in her own delicate performance for this week’s cover. All she had to do was hold her breath in 733 gallons of water.

headline: New Producers, New Opening for ‘Prince of Broadway’
text: “Prince of Broadway,” the musical retrospective of the career of the Tony Award-winning producer and director Harold Prince, will open on Broadway in the fall of 2013 instead of in November as originally planned, the show’s new producing team announced on Thursday.

headline: Giants’ Nicks Breaks His Right Foot
text: As the Giants’ running game floundered last season, the focus on their top three receivers — Hakeem Nicks, Victor Cruz and Mario Manningham — increased, with the three ultimately becoming the team’s most critical offensive weapons on the way to winning the Super Bowl.

headline: Dish Seeks Ruling on Feature That Skips All Commercials
text: 7:00 p.m. | Updated The Dish Network and three television networks filed opposing lawsuits on Thursday over Auto Hop, a feature that allows Dish subscribers to automatically skip all the advertising during most prime time shows.

headline: Facing a Teetering Greece, Europe Plans for the Worst

headline: Tracing the Path of Rehabilitation

headline: A Violin and Its Master Have Their Moment
text: In New York, where audiences are treated to regular performances by star musicians, there is excellent music-making in abundance. Yet for all the virtuoso playing — however enjoyable it may be — it is still rare to hear an artist communicate with the level of searing intensity that Sergey Khachatryan achieved in his sublime interpretation of Bach’s Partita for Solo Violin No. 2 at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening.

headline: A Pianist Shines His Light on Scriabin
text: The pianist Evgeny Kissin made a powerful impression when he played the Barber Sonata as the centerpiece of his Carnegie Hall recital three weeks ago. But he has not abandoned the big canvas of Romanticism, for which he has always been most admired, and on Wednesday evening he provided a gigantic sampling of it at a New York Philharmonic pension fund benefit concert. With Alan Gilbert on the podium, Mr. Kissin was the soloist in two big-boned works, Scriabin’s early Piano Concerto in F sharp minor, and Grieg’s Piano Concerto in A minor.

headline: It’s Not Rocket Science, but It’s Mars in Manhattan
text: By Friday morning the cargo capsule built by SpaceX, a private company, may (or may not) have docked with the International Space Station. After Tuesday’s launch of the Falcon 9, the rocket carrying the capsule, SpaceX’s chief executive, Elon Musk, said at a news conference, “We’re really at the dawn of a new era of space exploration and one where there’s a much bigger role for commercial companies.”

headline: Picasso’s Hong Kong Period
text: The largest Picasso exhibit in Hong Kong’s history, featuring 55 works from the Musée Picasso in Paris, is on view at the Hong Kong Heritage Museum through June 22. The retrospective covers the artist’s major periods — Blue, Rose, Cubist and Neo-Classical — and also includes photography and film.

headline: When Science Seems Like Magic
text: THE science-fiction author and technology prophet Arthur C. Clarke once said that a technology sufficiently advanced from our own would be indistinguishable from magic. So what will be onstage at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Tuesday night may look like magic in the boyish and capable hands of Brian Greene, the Columbia University physicist and author, who will perform the kind of tricks to make you think your eyes, or maybe your brain, have fallen out of your head.

headline: An Early Adopter in Photography Meets the Big Shots
text: Heinrich Kuehn (1866-1944), a Viennese photographer active at the turn of the 20th century, was one of the medium’s great control freaks. Consider the routine he went through when taking pictures of his family: He selected a site and sketched it in pencil, had his children and their nanny assume specific poses in clothing he had preselected for its photogenic qualities, and waited until every shadow was right where he wanted it to be.

headline: The Allure of Laamb
text: Although traditional wrestling exists in various forms throughout West Africa, the version in Senegal, known as laamb, has reached unparalleled heights.

headline: Dance Listings for May 25-31
text: Dance

headline: The Discreet Charm of a Trained Folk Artist
text: The portrait painter William Matthew Prior knew when to pretend to be untrained. In the 1820s, as a teenage apprentice, he learned meticulous academic realism. But he later opted for folk charm because it made good business sense.

headline: Canal Room to Open a Sister Club in Southampton
text: Southampton is about to become a little less sleepy.  The owners of the Canal Room, a fixture in New York City’s music scene, have announced plans to open a sister club, called Canal Room Southampton, on June 15. The new club will be on Elm Street in the quiet, seaside resort on Long Island and will be able to handle up to 800 people a night, twice the size of the club in Manhattan, the owners, Marcus Linial and Sam Lott, said on Thursday.

headline: A Tipple or Two? It Was Safer Than Water
text: Somewhere between the Captain Lawrence Freshchester Pale Ale and the Ithaca Apricot Wheat beer, as a relaxing haze was gradually descending, another was being lifted. Here, in the last gallery of the fresh and, yes, slightly intoxicating new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society, “Beer Here: Brewing New York’s History,” I was reminded just what all the fuss was about during the course of recorded history, or at least, in this case, the recorded history of New York State.

headline: TimesCast | Arrest in Etan Patz Case
text: After 33 years, the New York City police made an arrest in the case of Etan Patz, the 6-year-old who disappeared on his way to school in SoHo.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Offers Plan to Cut Debt
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra has laid out its plan to erase debts and cut costs in a major step toward exiting bankruptcy court. But the storied ensemble still faces large deficits and is counting on optimistic fund-raising and ticket-selling goals to recover its financial health.

headline: Off-the-Grid Living in Brooklyn
text: AS the standards for environmentally friendly construction rise, a Brooklyn developer has a new goal: renovate an apartment building so it generates as much energy as it uses.

headline: Market Values
text: Whatever their political party, American leaders have generally subscribed to one of two competing economic philosophies. One is a small-government Jeffersonian perspective that abhors bigness and holds that prosperity flows from competition among independent businessmen, farmers and other producers. The other is a Hamiltonian agenda that believes a large, powerful country needs large, powerful organizations. The most important of those organizations is the federal government, which serves as a crucial partner to private enterprise, building roads and schools, guaranteeing loans and financing scientific research in ways that individual businesses would not.

headline: Romney’s Massachusetts Woes: A Bad Omen?
text: A new poll in Massachusetts has confirmed what everyone knows — that Mitt Romney will very likely lose Massachusetts in November to President Obama. The Suffolk University/7 News poll conducted Sunday through Tuesday, shows Mr. Obama ahead by 25 percentage points among likely voters, with Mr. Romney winning only 34 percent of support in the state where he was once governor.

headline: The ‘Feather King’: A NoHo Prequel
text: IT’S a lively time they’re having on the six-square-block area south of New York University, as the university battles local interests to build new housing by filling in open spaces between its superscale housing complexes.

headline: Shore Town Says ‘No’ to B.Y.O.
text: WITH the summer season kicking off this weekend, residents of Ocean City can look forward to boat parades, crab beauty pageants, taffy sculpturing contests and other family-oriented events that have come to define this seaside resort. What they will not have to contend with is patrons sharing bottles of wine over dinner in any of the local restaurants. That is because they recently fought back a proposal that threatened to chip away at the “dry” status that many consider an equally defining element of this South Jersey community.

headline: A Nest and an Investment, Too
text: AFTER graduating from Queens College in 2005, Arash Vakil worked as a product manager for a software company. Living on the second floor of his parents’ house in Flushing, Queens, he had few expenses. Over time, his savings grew.

headline: 36 Hours in Dresden, Germany
text: DRESDEN, the German city whose name evokes a history of destruction, is looking more and more like its pre-World War II self. Roughly midway between Berlin and Prague, the capital of Saxony has largely restored the major architectural treasures damaged by Allied bombing raids: the Zwinger Palace, the Frauenkirche and the Semperoper. But while the Old Town, or Altstadt, was busy turning the clock back, the Neustadt across the Elbe River was looking forward. The Äussere Neustadt (Outer New Town) quarter is now filled with new bars and shops catering to a younger generation that doesn’t remember the days under Communism, much less the war. In the heart of this artsy district, you’ll find such delights as the Kunsthofpassage complex, home to an ingenious turquoise building that has rigged its drains, which are shaped like instruments, to play “water music” after it rains. Old and new come together in the Military History Museum reconceived by Daniel Libeskind in 2011, which, with its focus on the causes and corollaries of war and violence, represents a stark, contemporary rethinking of the past.

text: Drink beer along the Elbe, sample German tapas and visit the venue that premiered works by Wagner.

headline: Voting With Their Wallets
text: THE French aided the Americans in their revolution against their British oppressors. Now Benoît Pous-Bertran de Balanda, the descendant of a French general who fought for the Americans, is trying to help his wealthy countrymen escape what he calls the tyranny of a new Socialist government primed to severely tax the rich.

headline: A Brief Interplanetary Confluence
text: Meshuggah and Baroness, which appeared one after the other at Terminal 5 in Clinton on Wednesday night, both toil under the rubric of metal. They share some defining baseline attributes: exorbitant technique, driving propulsion, deft use of scale. Each band has forged a recognizable sonic identity. Both happen to have very good albums out this year. Beyond all that, they seem to reside on different planets.

headline: The Debate at Cannes Rages (as Always): What to Boo?
text: CANNES, France — The critics are angry. Wrung out perhaps by the arduous work of watching movies all day and night at the 65th Cannes Film Festival, they have begun to boo and jeer louder and more insistently, or so it seems. Are the selections really all that disastrous, deserving of the contemptuous dismissals or post- (and mid!) screening Twitter alerts? Certainly the antipathy aimed at the more formally experimental entries seems reflective of the same ungenerous, unadventurous mind-set (except when I boo, of course) that asserts itself here every year.

headline: How to Catch a Rich, Neatnik Renter
text: ONLINE listing services have proliferated in recent years. Following are four popular sites, along with a comparison to a traditional vacation rental agency. Full details are available on each service’s Web site or through their customer service departments.

headline: The Summer Rental Rat Race
text: RICHARD JOHNSTON used to rent out his two-bedroom farmhouse in southern France in a way that seems quaint two decades later: by buying advertising in publications like Harvard’s alumni magazine or The New York Review of Books and waiting for Francophiles to respond.

headline: Social Drawing, an Up-and-Coming Marketing Tool
text: There are social networks, social videos and, even, in the case of apps like Draw Something, social drawing. And just as those first two tools have been used in marketing, social drawing is being enlisted in the promotion of the new season of “Cake Boss” on TLC.

headline: New Under the Sun: Books for Basking
text: The heroine of this year’s best beach read was beheaded 476 years ago. The most chilling nonfiction spy story unfolds in cyberspace. The coolest biographical subject is a comic-book character. The hottest history is recent. The most amazing act of kindness is performed by an elephant. The most Harry Potter-ish action-adventure romance unfolds against the backdrop of the Arab Spring. And the Olympian Walter Cronkite shares space on the TV shelf with the guy behind Bravo’s “Real Housewives” shows.

headline: Slasher History by the Slice
text: A timeline of how slasher films have evolved as told through poster art.

headline: Scouting Out a Paradise: Books, Music and No Adults
text: Wes Anderson makes films about small worlds in which big things happen: love, heartbreak, calamities, death. In his latest, the wondrous storybook tale “Moonrise Kingdom,” a girl and a boy, both 12, run off to a remote inlet on an island where most of the adults seem disappointed and more than a little sad. The girl and the boy are very serious — about love, their plans, books, life itself — and often act older than their age. She wears bright blue eyeliner; he puffs on a corncob pipe. You wonder what their hurry is, given that here adulthood, with its quarrels, regrets and anguished pillow talk, can feel as dangerous as the storm that’s hurtling toward the island, ready to blow it all down.

headline: A Field Trip to End All Field Trips, Literally, for These Ninth Graders
text: In a dystopian future, the authorities have devised an ingeniously brutal way of keeping order and channeling the inherently violent impulses of the young. Every year a group of teenagers is sent into a carefully observed wilderness to hunt and kill one another, until only one survivor — the winner of the game — remains.

text: “Les Intouchables,” having broken box office records in France, arrives in the United States with a faithfully translated title — “The Intouchables” — that is not quite English. American audiences looking for a suitable French name for this ingratiating comedy of cross-racial friendship might settle on “Déjà Vu,” since it is a story we have seen many times before.

text: “Every family has its secrets — for us it was my father’s rage,” recalls Natalie Fine, the narrator of Debbie Goodstein-Rosenfeld’s semiautobiographical period drama, “Mighty Fine.” Heard but not seen, the grown-up Natalie (Janeane Garofalo) looks back to 1974, when the Fines abruptly moved from Brooklyn to New Orleans to be closer to her father’s apparel factory.

text: If he had his druthers, Rajat K. Gupta would have been in Cambridge, Mass., on Thursday, attending his daughter’s graduation from Harvard Business School. Instead, Mr. Gupta was seated at the defense table in Judge Jed S. Rakoff’s courtroom in Manhattan, on trial on insider trading charges.

headline: Temptation Dominates the Road to Recovery
text: Joachim Trier’s “Oslo, August 31st” is a perfectly linear story that bristles with suspense and ambiguity. The title and the structure make literal the recovery movement mantra “one day at a time,” and also show just how long and how full of danger a single 24-hour span can be. Stories of addiction frequently pass through a metaphorical crossroads — redemption down one path, catastrophe down the other — but Anders (Anders Danielsen Lie), Mr. Trier’s protagonist, faces such a choice at every waking moment. You are never sure what he will do next, and it is clear that he is not, either. Nor does he necessarily know why he makes the choices he does, or what they mean.

headline: In the Shadow of Ashe Stadium, Working Hard to Return
text: After practices, Melanie Oudin retrieves tennis balls and sweeps the clay courts at the United States Tennis Association’s training center in Queens. She performs these tasks in the shadow of Arthur Ashe Stadium, the site of her greatest accomplishment, close enough to hit with a long forehand, yet far enough for her star turn there to seem like it took place in another life.

headline: New Jersey Mayor Hacked Opponents’ Web Site, U.S. Charges
text: An insurgent political campaign in West New York, N.J., suddenly realized in February that its Web site had been disabled. The campaign was being run by opponents of the mayor, Dr. Felix Roque, and the Web site, recallroque.com, had been intended to rally support to recall him and collect information about what his critics described as his rampant mismanagement.

headline: At a Wildfire Base Camp, Logistics and Pop-Tarts
text: SPRING VALLEY, Ariz. — A long stretch in the burning wilderness is all it takes to redefine the meaning of life’s greatest pleasures. To Jon Crane, it was running an electric toothbrush around his teeth. To J. J. Rue, it was stepping on flat paved ground.

headline: Hofstra Makes National Splash
text: Since the first Women’s College World Series in 1982, every N.C.A.A. Division I softball champion has been a large public university, a team from a warm climate or both.

headline: How to Stop Wildlife Poachers
text: OVER the past 20 years, chimpanzees, gorillas and other great apes have declined the most in areas lacking a security force to protect them. Conversely, parks and protected areas with armed guards and anti-poaching patrols — places like Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park in the Republic of Congo, Kahuzi-Biega National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Volcanoes National Park in Rwanda — have not only retained their ape populations, but have seen population increases.

headline: Making Wright a Met for Life
text: Even with a half-century of history, the Mets have mostly been made up of transients. Some came from elsewhere, like Rusty Staub, Keith Hernandez and Mike Piazza. Others started here and left, like Tom Seaver, Darryl Strawberry and Jose Reyes. In five decades, only Seaver has done enough as a Mets player to have his number retired.

headline: Filmmaker Puts His Mental Illness on Screen
text: “This is not a film about hand washing,” says Bud Clayman at the start of “OC87,” adding, “It’s a film about the fear of acting on thoughts.” Mr. Clayman has obsessive-compulsive disorder — specifically “harm O.C.D.,” which involves intense anger and violent imaginings — and Asperger’s syndrome, which inhibits the grasp of social cues. This moving, penetrating documentary records his attempt to describe his conditions, confront them and learn to manage them.

headline: Total Eclipse
text: We interrupt reality to bring you Arizona, once known as the Grand Canyon state. So glorious, this home to sublime cacti and ugly javelina, an outdoor stage for the high histrionics of geologic time, but so very, very crazy. Even a spate of recent temperatures in the 105-degree range cannot explain the latest doings of government by crackpots.

headline: Three Young Men Reunited in Grief
text: In American movies male friendship is commonly explored within the familiar parameters of the buddy comedy — where yucks tend to trump insights — or through the heavily structured formula of the rookie-mentor relationship. In both iterations honest emotions are often obscured, whether by raucous humor or a passing-the-torch sentimentality that’s comfortingly clichéd.

headline: China Lawyer, in U.S., Voices Fears for His Family
text: Five days after his arrival in New York, the dissident lawyer Chen Guangcheng expressed concern over what he called intensifying retribution against his family back in China, especially a nephew who has been jailed and apparently faces charges of attempted murder.

text: Eddie Blazonczyk, a polka singer and bandleader who led bouncing, swaying, beer-hoisting dances for generations of Americans as one of that small genre’s biggest fish, died on Monday in Palos Heights, Ill. He was 70.

headline: Trainer Accused of Doping in 675 Harness Races
text: In what officials called one of the most sweeping and unusual enforcement actions in the history of horse racing, New York State accused a prominent horse trainer on Thursday of illegally drugging horses in 675 harness races over a 28-month period in the state.

headline: Egos and Immorality

headline: The Service Patch
text: Several years ago, the investment banks and consulting firms decided it was better to hire a supremely gifted 22-year-old than a moderately gifted 40-year-old who wanted to go home to his family. To attract these young superstars, the firms set up training programs that offered recent college graduates great salaries, practical skills and interesting life experiences.

headline: ‘What Is’ Meets ‘What if’: The Role of Speculation in Science
text: Woody Allen once said that when you do comedy, you sit at the children’s table. The same might be said of speculation in science.

headline: The Meaning of Same-Sex Marriage
text: It wasn’t long after President Obama’s statement earlier this month in support of same-sex marriage that the familiar debates on the issue began to flare again. And as usual, each side’s argument reflects a fundamentally different conception of marriage.

headline: Leaders of Moscow Protest Are Released, but Criminal Charges Remain Possible
text: MOSCOW — In the six months since antigovernment protests began in this city, the blogger and opposition leader Aleksei Navalny has exuded loose-limbed cheerfulness, as if trying to topple the Russian government was really not such a big deal.

headline: The Crisis This Time
text: They blew it, again. With Greece in meltdown, raising fears of cascading bank insolvencies and deepening recession, Europe’s leaders failed again this week to agree on the ambitious initiatives needed to quell the crisis.

headline: A Court Covers Up
text: The Obama administration has added to its string of victories in a tawdry pursuit — making overly expansive claims of secrecy and executive power to deny full disclosure of torture and other abuses of prisoners committed during the George W. Bush administration.

headline: Libya Agrees to Inquiry by Britain
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron said on Thursday that he had won the agreement of Libya’s visiting government leader for a Scotland Yard team to conduct an investigation in Libya into the killing by Libyan diplomats of a London police officer in 1984.

headline: New Orleans Newspaper Scales Back in Sign of Print Upheaval
text: The Times-Picayune, a 175-year-old fixture in New Orleans and a symbol of the city’s gritty resilience during Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath, has buckled under the pressures of the modern newspaper market.

headline: Since 1979, a Vigil for the Face on Milk Cartons and the Ages He Would Miss
text: It began — the uncertainty that darkened into anguish, the lurking sense of loss, the sudden expansion of people’s vocabularies to encompass phrases like “stranger danger” — on the day when a little boy talked his parents into saying yes to the kind of question every child asks, and when the answer is “no, not yet,” asks again and again: Can I walk to the bus stop by myself? Please?

headline: Illinois: Departing Prosecutor Has a Regret
text: A day after announcing he would resign as the United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who oversaw the prosecution of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, expressed regret for saying that the governor’s conduct would “make Lincoln roll over in his grave.” Mr. Fitzgerald was criticized for making the comment after the 2008 arrest of Mr. Blagojevich, who was eventually convicted of trying to sell Barack Obama’s vacated Senate seat. “I probably could have had a colder shower, a little more sleep and some decaf,” Mr. Fitzgerald said Thursday at a news conference. “Having said that, I did get grief over it, and what bothers me about that, frankly, is I don’t want it to overshadow what the agents did in that case.” Mr. Fitzgerald, whose other high-profile prosecutions include public corruption charges against former Gov. George Ryan and a C.I.A. leak case against I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff for Vice President Dick Cheney, said he would consider other government work, but ruled out running for office. “I’m not wired to campaign for anything or run for elected office,” he said. “Period.”

headline: Once More on the Law of the Sea
text: There are few things the environmental community and the oil and gas industry agree on. But here is one: the need for the United States to join the Law of the Sea Convention, a worthy global agreement that the Senate has stubbornly refused to ratify for nearly 30 years.

headline: Life in the Uncurated City
text: There is so much stuff on the Web — such an upwelling of texts and images — that a guide seems essential. But there’s a real pleasure in going unguided, too. In late April, the New York City Department of Records handed us all the digital equivalent of a box full of nearly 900,000 photographs gathered from the Municipal Archives. The only curation is your interest in this incredible city.

headline: Publicity First, Evidence Later in Patz Arrest
text: Back from London, the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, stepped in front of the cameras in prime time Thursday evening to announce that the police were accusing Pedro Hernandez of killing Etan Patz in 1979.

headline: Modern Chemistry Experiment
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — When you know that there is not going to be any theme in a puzzle — although we may see that begin to change, given last Friday’s puzzle-with-a-theme-that-I-apparently-missed (Across Lite, Solution, blog) — and you know that the clues have been toughened up so you can’t rely on many gimmes, where do you start? How do you get a toehold in a grid that has been smoothed to eliminate any toeholds?

headline: Savannah Auger and James Citron
text: IN Los Angeles, as in other cities overflowing with driven single people, “What do you do?” is often asked before “How do you do?” And though many pressing questions about a new acquaintance can be easily answered (or so it seems) with a few taps on a smartphone, Savannah Auger and James Citron remained blissfully unaware of entire sections of each other’s lives when they began dating. She thought he was an airline pilot, and she did not tell him that she had a flourishing second career as a singer — and would be on the road for weeks at a time.

headline: Caught in the Prison That Is Their Country
text: Hope has broken loose in Athol Fugard’s “My Children! My Africa!,” and those eager to embrace it had best beware. In the Signature Theater Company’s stirring revival of Mr. Fugard’s 1989 tale of friendship in the twilight of apartheid, a schoolmaster in a small South African township describes hope as “a dangerous animal,” one he usually keeps penned up, along with brutes like anger and despair.

headline: English Literati, Cracking Wise
text: The oenophile takes a sip of wine and pronounces judgment: “This is simultaneously bland and acid. Is it English?”

headline: In Spain, Bank Transfers Reflect Broader Fears

headline: What Romney Should Do About Immigration
text: Earlier this month, asked about Mitt Romney’s immigration policy, Bettina Inclan, the director of Hispanic outreach for the Republican National Committee, stumbled into the remark that “he’s still deciding what his position on immigration is.” While the campaign distanced itself from the gaffe immediately, the comment was actually good advice, even if unintentional.

headline: Neighbors Describe a Polite Family Man
text: There were recollections of family barbecues, a backyard teeming with children and a friendly stoop sale. In short, life at the two-story brown-and-tan house on East Linwood Avenue in Maple Shade, N.J., seemed typical of any residence in the modest suburb.

text: BEIJING — Hollywood studios, facing steep challenges in the North American movie market, are taking more interest in China.

headline: Primary Election Challenge to Rangel Turns Into a War of Dueling Endorsements
text: The endorsements have started to come in almost daily, as one side or another trumpets a new supporter. On Monday, it was a city councilman from the Bronx, declaring his support for the challenger. On Tuesday, a fellow representative stood next to the incumbent and sang his praises. On Wednesday came yet another endorsement for the incumbent, from a former challenger now embracing him and saying that they had “always been friends.”

headline: Both Campaigns Seize on Romney’s Years at Bain
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign sees the time he spent at Bain Capital, the private equity firm he co-founded and ran for more than a decade, as a positive experience that highlights his leadership skills and his ability to turn around companies and create jobs. President Obama’s campaign, meanwhile, views Mr. Romney’s Bain Capital years as a political liability that underscores his image as an out-of-touch multimillionaire, concerned only with turning profits for his wealthy investors.

headline: Predictions Are Offered, but Not Guarantees
text: The Rangers were not making Messier-like guarantees on the eve of Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals, with elimination staring them in the face at Prudential Center.

headline: Mining Returns to Michigan’s Upper Peninsula
text: The western portion of the Upper Peninsula hopes that recent interest from mining companies will help the region recover from a long slump.

headline: A Mining Rush in the Upper Peninsula
text: IRONWOOD, Mich. — On the far northern reaches of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, James Jacques drove on a rutted logging road to an old mining shaft surrounded by a chain-link fence.

text: Prices for many metals are higher than in the mid-2000s

text: Matthew Yglesias, Slate’s economics correspondent, makes a smart point in a post on his blog this week, arguing that “maybe rich people don’t like Obama because he wants to raise their taxes substantially.”

headline: Battle Over Dish’s Ad-Skipping Begins as Networks Go to Court

headline: Small Investors Seek Answers to the Confusion of Facebook Trading

headline: Counsel for NYRA Wants to Release 2011 Corruption Report

headline: The Netherlands: Mladic Trial Reset
text: The trial of a former Bosnian Serb general, Ratko Mladic, that opened in The Hague on May 16 will now resume on June 25 instead of next Tuesday as originally planned, the United Nations tribunal announced on Wednesday. Judges granted the extra month to the defense because the prosecution had been late in delivering a portion of the evidence — about 3 percent of the total, according to the prosecution — that must be shared with the defense team. But the judges turned down the request from the defense for six extra months of preparation time. The long-awaited trial is one of the most important to deal with the Bosnian war, from 1992 to 1995, in which Mr. Mladic was the overall commander on the Serbian side. He faces charges of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.

headline: Battle Brewing Over Labeling of Genetically Modified Food
text: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. — On a recent sunny morning at the Big Y grocery here, Cynthia LaPier parked her cart in the cereal aisle. With a glance over her shoulder and a quick check of the ingredients, she plastered several boxes with hand-designed stickers from a roll in her purse. “Warning,” they read. “May Contain GMO’s (Genetically Modified Organisms).”

headline: Wesley Brown, Pioneer as Black Naval Graduate, Dies at 85

headline: Cameron Defends Handling of Murdoch Bid to Take Over Sky Broadcasting

headline: Gayle King Gets Redonkulous
text: CBS’s morning shows have been in third place for nearly three decades now, and many people believe that a lack of chemistry among its anchors has been to blame. We had each already signed our deals before we even started rehearsals, and although we have mutual friends, I’m not going to lead you to believe that we were pals. I think they just thought, She brings this, he brings that and let’s give it a try. It’s not totally redonkulous.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE LAST WEREWOLF,  by Glen Duncan. (Vintage, $14.95.) Jake Marlowe — a wry, lustful, centuries-old werewolf — has slipped into an existential crisis in Duncan’s playfully brainy novel. Tortured by the spirits of his victims, he’s ready to surrender to the shadowy World Organization for the Control of Occult Phenomena, but the path to one of the group’s silver bullets takes a number of complicated turns.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: HOME,  by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $24.) A black Korean War veteran, discharged from an integrated Army into a segregated homeland, makes a reluctant journey back to Georgia in a novel engaged with themes that have long haunted Morrison.

headline: Inside the List
text: CARROT AND STICK: Buried deep in the 9/11 commission report, in the footnotes to a chapter tracing Al Qaeda’s determination to strike, there’s a reference to an active spy identified only as “Henry,” who before the attacks lobbied unsuccessfully for further C.I.A. involvement in Afghanistan. That spy, we now know, was Henry A. Crumpton — or Hank, as he’s been called since his childhood in rural Georgia — and his memoir, “The Art of Intelligence,” is new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 3. After 9/11, Crumpton was one of the C.I.A. operatives responsible for defeating the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan. In 2010 he told the “60 Minutes” correspondent Lara Logan how he went about it: “In a very crude way, it would be a carrot and a stick. The carrot would be, ‘If you come cooperate with us, we will reward you and your people.’ The stick was, ‘If you do not cooperate, the chances of your survival are greatly diminished.’ And we would prove this by attacking Taliban leaders who had rejected our overtures.”

headline: Up Front
text: David Leonhardt came to The Times from Business Week in 1999 and began a steady ascent, starting as a business reporter, becoming an economics columnist in 2006 and winning a Pulitzer Prize for commentary last year. Since September he has been The Times’s Washington bureau chief. In his writing as in his career, Leonhardt has positioned himself at the intersection of economics and politics, viewing issues with a skeptical but pragmatic eye. As he said in his final column last summer, “We do not spend enough time focusing on our actual economic problems. We are too often occupied with distractions, rather than trying to answer a simple question: What works? What economic policies have succeeded before and are most likely to lead to the best life for the largest number of people? Instead, we’ve effectively decided that because the United States is the richest, most successful country in the world, it is guaranteed to remain so.”

headline: Only Yesterday
text: What can you say about a 72-year-old man who died? More salient, what can you say about a 27-year-old novel that survives him?

headline: Minding the Gap
text: Writing in the middle of the 19th century, Karl Marx predicted that the gulf between the newly rich and the miserable urban poor, made much worse by the Industrial Revolution, would continue to widen indefinitely. This ever greater disparity, he thought, would ultimately undermine capitalism. Marx turned out to be wrong. Income inequality in Britain (and, from what we can tell, elsewhere in Europe too) began to narrow after the 1860s, and inequality in wealth peaked by the time of World War I. In America, inequality in both incomes and wealth began to lessen after the 1920s. The rich continued to live far better than the poor, but over the next 50 years the gap between them narrowed ­substantially.

headline: Paying for Labors of Love
text: There’s one mistake I worry readers will make about this book, so let me correct it right away: “The Outsourced Self” is not a work of journalism. Though it isn’t exactly not one, either. I guess you’d call it popular sociology, but I think of it more as an act of mourning. Arlie Russell Hochschild’s look at how we meet some of our most personal needs with the aid of paid strangers doesn’t try to be exhaustive; goes light on figures and statistics; and, when itemizing the most outrageous advances in the market for love and care, never lapses into that magazine journalist’s tone of wry amusement.

headline: The Sexagenarian Lothario
text: From the start, I made it clear to the man with whom I was involved that I cared deeply about being safe from sexually transmitted diseases. He assured me he would be loyal and agreed that if he strayed, he would not have unprotected sex. He lied. He had sex with three women without using condoms. He has agreed to get tested but not to tell the other women about one another. They all believe him to be in a monogamous relationship with me. Two of the women are our age (we’re in our 60s); the third is younger. I know all three women via Facebook. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell them about his activities? NAME WITHHELD

headline: My Father, His Father and President Kennedy
text: One of my earliest memories that doesn’t have to do with my tonsillectomy or the arrival of my baby brother — and I am not equating the two — is of seeing President Kennedy ride along East 161st Street in the Bronx in the back of an open limousine, moving up the hill that begins at Yankee Stadium and ends at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, next door to which my family lived. It was 1962. I was 6 and perched on my dad’s shoulders.

headline: Noomi Rapace Arrives in Hollywood, by Way of Outer Space
text: In 2007, Noomi Rapace read for the part of Lisbeth Salander in the Swedish film version of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo” as a long-shot contender. Though she was a smart and seasoned actress who had worked in film as well as onstage, she was known mainly to Stockholm theatergoers. Her name barely surfaced in the lively public debate in Sweden over who should play Lisbeth, one of the most sought after film roles for a Swedish actress in recent memory. Moreover, the film’s director, Niels Arden Oplev, feared that Rapace was too attractive to portray the androgynous Lisbeth. After working through a scene with her, though, he changed his mind. “When she’s Lisbeth and you put a camera on her, and she’s just sitting there looking at you, you think, Oh, my God, what is she going to do?” he says. “There’s an unpredictable, dark, dangerous energy that flows from her.”

headline: The 5.13.12 Issue
text: The likelihood that any of the children in the article will “end up just fine” without intervention is extremely low. That’s the approach our society has taken for too long: do nothing, wait until they grow up and commit crimes, then imprison them. The researchers in this article should be commended for their pioneering work in addressing an important, understudied societal problem.

headline: Predator and Prey
