headline: How Roland Barthes Gave Us the TV Recap
text: Among the brand-name French theorists of the mid-20th century, Roland Barthes was the fun one. (Foucault was the tough one, Derrida was the dreamy one, Lacan was the mysterious one — I like to imagine them sometimes as a black-turtlenecked, clove-smoking boy band called Hors de Texte, with the hit album “Discipline ’n’ Punish.”) Instead of constructing multivolume monuments of systematic thought, Barthes wrote short books built out of fragments. He was less interested in traditional coherence than in what he called jouissance: joy, surprise, adventure, pleasure — tantric orgasms of critical insight rolling from fragment to fragment. He proclaimed the death of the author and advocated a style of reading he referred to as “writerly,” in which readers work as active creators of a text. His critical metabolism ran unusually high: he would flit from subject to subject, defining new fields of interest (semiology, narratology) only to abandon them and leave others to do the busywork. He treated canonical French works with such unorthodox flair it drove conservative professors crazy. (Barthes first rose to prominence, or notoriety, thanks to the furor surrounding his early book about Racine.) In his inaugural lecture at the Collège de France — a sort of mission statement for the most prestigious academic post in the country — Barthes announced that he aspired above all to “forget” and to “unlearn” and proposed, as a kind of motto, “no power, a little knowledge, a little wisdom and as much flavor as possible.”

headline: Who Made That Fly Swatter?
text: The first modern fly-destruction device was invented in 1900 by Robert R. Montgomery, an entrepreneur based in Decatur, Ill. Montgomery was issued Patent No. 640,790 for the Fly-Killer, a “cheap device of unusual elasticity and durability” made of wire netting, “preferably oblong,” attached to a handle. The material of the handle remained unspecified, but the netting was crucial: it reduced wind drag, giving the swatter a “whiplike swing.” By 1901, Montgomery’s invention was advertised in Ladies’ Home Journal as a tool that “kills without crushing” and “soils nothing,” unlike, say, a rolled-up newspaper might.

headline: Swallows, Amazons and Bolsheviks
text: Arthur Ransome is a beloved if minor figure in 20th-century letters. Generations of British readers have grown up with his “Swallows and Amazons” series of young adult novels, the first of which was published in 1930. In these 12 books, children on holiday in the Lake District of England and elsewhere occupy themselves sailing, camping, fishing and playing at pirates. Contemporary readers raised on blood sport in Panem may find the series tame, but the novels are charming and well told. In the few weeks that I’ve contemplated the story of Ransome’s life, every mention of his name to a British acquaintance has elicited a fond smile; from every American it has drawn a blank.

headline: A Bloody Season
text: Hilary Mantel belongs to the same generation, roughly, as her compatriots Martin Amis, Julian Barnes and Ian McEwan, and is every bit their equal. Yet until “Wolf Hall,” her historical novel about the reign of Henry VIII, won the Man Booker Prize in 2009, she was much less well known in Britain, and in this country she barely registered at all. There may be nonliterary reasons for this: Mantel, who has been in ill health for much of her life, doesn’t live in London, doesn’t have a posh accent, doesn’t travel much, doesn’t regularly turn up on the chat shows. But another reason she isn’t better known may be that she’s a hard novelist to know, or at least to categorize: she’s always reinventing herself. Her new book, “Bring Up the Bodies,” a sequel to “Wolf Hall,” is one of very few Mantel novels that bear much resemblance to any of the others.

headline: Your Favorite Road Trips, Collected
text: As a companion to our recent road trip issue, we asked for your favorite U.S. routes, via Twitter, using the hashtag #faveroadtrip, and on Facebook. Here is a selection of your responses.

headline: Thank You for Your Service, Sort Of
text: The familiar narrative of the American military experience traces the long, occasionally glorious, always bloody march from Lexington and Concord to Iraq and Afghanistan. “Those Who Have Borne the Battle” amends that account by adding two subjects of acute contemporary relevance: how the United States has raised the forces with which it wages war; and how, in the aftermath of battle, it cares for and remembers those who fought.

headline: Set in Motion
text: In Peter Carey’s 12th novel, much depends on two voices. The first belongs to Catherine Gehrig, an horologist working at the (fictional) Swinburne Museum in London. We join her — she begins to speak to us — at the very moment she learns of the sudden death of her lover, Matthew Tindall, Head Curator of Metals at the same institution. For 13 years, Catherine has been Tindall’s mistress. He was older, married, a father, but the pair of them lived a blissful, secret life together. Now Tindall is gone — felled by a heart attack on the Underground — and gone with him, in Catherine’s mind, is all good, all possibility of happiness.

headline: State of Paradox
text: “India” and “change” were once virtual antonyms: old India hands returned again and again in large part because the subcontinent was so dependably different from the West. But since 1991, when a financial crisis forced India’s government to devalue the rupee, lower import barriers and relax controls on private investment, things have nearly reversed themselves. As the journalist Akash Kapur demonstrates in his lucid, balanced new book, “India Becoming,” his homeland now seems almost synonymous with change.

headline: The Counterculture’s Mark Twain
text: Richard Brautigan burned through his short career like a rock star. Born in Tacoma, Wash., in 1935, he handed out poems on the streets of pre-hippie San Francisco, then caught an updraft in the zeitgeist with his 1967 novel, “Trout Fishing in America,” that even he couldn’t have seen coming. Playfully elliptical, without plot or conventional characters, the book sold two million copies and transformed Brautigan into a libidinous Mark Twain for the new counterculture: a distinctly American voice that was so of its moment that it had nowhere to go but into a time capsule. By the time he ended his life in 1984, buffeted by drink and debt, he could not get an acceptable offer to publish his last novel. Thomas McGuane, a friend and sometime rival, summed up Brautigan’s arc succinctly: “When the 1960s ended, he was the baby thrown out with the bath water.” In life and death he was a moral fable for an era that invites easy moralizing.

headline: Philippine Chief Justice Defends Finances at Impeachment Trial
text: MANILA — The chief justice of the Philippine Supreme Court, Renato C. Corona, testified in his impeachment trial Friday that he had $2.4 million in undeclared foreign currency deposits, a figure far lower than prosecutors have alleged. And he insisted that, under his interpretation of the law, he was not required to disclose the money.

headline: Nature of the Beast
text: Admit it, Victorian mystery fans. We’ve been spoiled by the rigorous scholarship of writers like Peter Ackroyd, lulled by the formal elegance of stylists like Anne Perry. In short, we’ve lost touch with the lurid traditions of the 19th-century potboiler.

headline: Family Secrets
text: Tania James is a warmhearted writer. In “Aerogrammes,” her first story collection, she treats her eclectic band of characters — several children, a chimpanzee, an obsessive analyzer of handwriting, two Indian wrestlers in Edwardian London, a former grocer, an aging dance teacher, a widower, a writer and a ghost — gently, almost parentally, pitying them while recognizing the humor in their predicaments.

headline: First Private Craft Docks With Space Station
text: High above northwestern Australia, a robotic arm on the International Space Station grabbed onto a cargo capsule floating 10 meters away.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Michael Lind talks about his economic history of the United States, “Land of Promise”; John Leland discusses a biography of Richard Brautigan; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Business Day Live | May 25, 2012
text: Euro fears prompt some depositors to leave Spanish banks.| Mining booms once more in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula. | A weekend retreat for divorce.

headline: Business Day Live: New Interest in Old Mines
text: Euro fears prompt some depositors to leave Spanish banks. Mining booms once more in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula. A weekend retreat for divorce.

headline: Screening of Comedy ‘The Anti-Semite’ Is Canceled at Cannes
text: The business counterpart of the Cannes Film Festival said that it was canceling a screening of a new film by the controversial French comedian Dieudonné called “The Anti-Semite,” citing its policy of banning works that could offend religious beliefs or otherwise stir violence, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Jozy Altidore: Ready to Play
text: On Friday, Jozy Altidore was named to Coach Jurgen Klinsmann’s 23-man roster for coming friendly matches and the two World Cup qualifiers in June.

headline: A New Taste for Collard Greens
text: When most people hear of collard greens, they think of the soul-food version prepared by generations of Southern cooks — stewed greens flavored with ham hock or bacon.

headline: Daniel Kahneman on the Trap of ‘Thinking That We Know’
text: The National Academy of Sciences did a great service to science early this week by holding a conference on “The Science of Science Communication.” A centerpiece of the two-day meeting was a lecture titled “Thinking That We Know,” delivered by Daniel Kahneman, the extraordinary behavioral scientist who was awarded a Nobel Prize in economics despite never having taken an economics class.

headline: Gooding Lays Out Blue Chips, Including Maserati A6G and Bugatti 57C, Ahead of Pebble Beach
text: Gooding & Company of Santa Monica, Calif., released the first of what should be many teasers ahead of its auction event, scheduled for Aug. 18-19 during the collector-car festivities centered around Pebble Beach. And if these early glimpses are any indication, it should be an impressive catalog.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Seduction of Movement’
text: This poem, the 10th of 11 winners in our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Sonal, 17, of Latham, N.Y.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Illinois Is Trying, It Really Is’
text: This poem, the last of 11 winners from our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Aaron, 21, of Sioux Falls, S.D.

headline: This Week’s Movies, May 25
text: In today’s installment of “This Week’s Movies,” A. O. Scott looks at Will Smith’s return to the big screen in “Men in Black 3.” Manohla Dargis offers a positive take on Wes Anderson’s latest film, “Moonrise Kingdom,” which had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival. And Mr. Scott also looks at the French blockbuster that is making its way to the United States, “The Intouchables.” Full reviews and features about some of the other films opening this week can be found here.

headline: Inmate Is Awarded $16 Million After Injury Led to Quadriplegia
text: Updated, 2:44 p.m. | The New York Court of Claims has awarded nearly $16 million to a state prison inmate, saying the man did not receive proper medical care from prison doctors after suffering a head injury in an inmate basketball game that ultimately led to his quadriplegia.

headline: Look of The Moment | Liu Wen
text: The Look: Black Magic. The LBD is glamorously reinvented with an armor-like neckline, dramatic cut-outs and feathery fringe. Paired with accessories that echo these elements, it’s an absolute showstopper.

headline: King of Thailand Makes Rare Visit Outside the Bangkok Area
text: BANGKOK — Amid widespread anxiety in Thailand about his health, King Bhumibol Adulyadej made a rare visit outside his hospital suite on Friday in what senior Thai officials described as a demonstration of his improved fitness.

headline: The Dark Nooks in JPMorgan’s Fortress Balance Sheet
text: Banks get to play a fun game every quarter that could be called Guess the Value of Your Assets! JPMorgan Chase plays it more than its peers.

headline: Students Tap Tribute to Bojangles
text: Students at P.S. 51 tap their way through a physical education program, and will perform their new skills at a show honoring tap dance legend Bill "Bojangles" Robinson.

headline: A Campaign Pitch Rekindles the Question: Just What Is Liberation Theology?
text: The year 2012 looks a lot like 2008: high unemployment, a candidate named Obama promising to do something about high unemployment, and the Giants beating the Patriots in the Super Bowl. And one more thing: conservatives are still ridiculing liberation theology. With the complicity of clueless pundits and incurious journalists, they are reducing an important theological movement of the past 40 years to an abusive sound bite.

headline: On Our Radar: North Dakota’s Oil Boom
text: Western North Dakota’s oil boom has brought a surge in population, crime, air pollution, littering and health problems. Still, the toll is hard to measure. [OnEarth]

headline: Drawing Warriors
text: For over a year, a group of artists has been visiting Walter Reed National Military Medical Center to document the experiences of wounded service members.

headline: A Second Chance at Life and Hip-Hop
text: In Brooklyn, the non-profit, Art Start, offers young people with a blighted past a chance to become producers and performers of hip-hop.

headline: Peninsula Prep Continues to Plan for the Fall Semester
text: A Queens charter school that the city has been trying to close for months won an extension of its temporary restraining order on Thursday, allowing it remain open until the judge rules on the case, which could take months.

headline: Where a Hip-Hop Career Begins With a Court Sentence
text: Less than two years ago, Torey Baker was an 18-year-old high-school dropout facing prison time for robbery. When a judge in the Bronx sentenced him instead to six months in an alternative program, plus probation, he considered himself lucky. But he didn’t know the half of it.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Market Values
text: In the New York Times Book Review, David Leonhardt reviews Michael Lind’s “Land of Promise,” an economic history of the United States. Mr. Leonhardt writes:

headline: Summer Reading: ‘Between the Lines’ and ‘Chomp’
text: This summer, the Motherlode Book Club will be reading two books parents and older children alike can enjoy, from Jodi Piccoult and her daughter, Samantha Van Leer and Carl Hiaasen.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Paying Less for That Rental Car” (May 20): There are advantages to renting a car through an airline. I’ve linked several car rentals with recent reservations on British Airways, and not only was the rate cheaper than renting outright, but the combination flight and car puts you into a “holiday” category with much faster access to management, should something go wrong. This came in handy when an overseas flight was canceled and my car was automatically rebooked.DONNA ANTONHayle, England

headline: More Laffering
text: I gather that one of the things we may be talking about tonight on Bill Maher is Art Laffer’s claim that low state tax rates are the key to economic growth. What should you think about that claim? That’s easy: it’s junk economics (pdf). See the data in the linked piece.

headline: Winemaking Lures the Wealthy, but Not With Profits
text: IF there is one investment that has more to do with the heart than the head, it’s vineyards. It is also one that lends itself to jokes whose punch lines are always about losing money.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/25: Air France’s Plans and Tuscan Beer
text: Changes for Air France Air France is reducing reduce staff — for now, through attrition, not layoffs — and overhaul its flight operations. (Reuters, via The New York Times)

headline: A Company’s Stand for Gay Marriage, and Its Cost
text: In the months leading up to North Carolina’s vote this month to ban gay marriage, most of the state’s business leaders were conspicuously silent. While some executives spoke out against it as individuals, not one Fortune 500 company based in North Carolina, including Bank of America, Duke Energy, VF Corporation and Lowe’s, opposed it.

headline: Case Study | Armagnac in the Raw
text: Every distiller on the planet secretly wants to know the same thing: what’s the next vodka? That is to say, what’s going to be the next spirit to go from zero to 110 in the collective fancy of imbibers?

headline: Will the U.S. Ever Apologize for Torturing an Innocent Man?
text: Earlier this week, the White House received a petition bearing 60,000 signatures demanding an apology to Maher Arar, a Canadian citizen who was the victim of one of the more outrageous abuses of power under President Bush.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: From delicate macarons at FP Patisserie by Francois Payard (above) to Maine lobster-filled buns at Luke’s Lobster, it’s opening weekend for more than 20 kiosks and stalls that fill the new Plaza Food Hall, which joins the Todd English Food Hall on the concourse level of the Plaza, 1 West 59th Street, in Midtown.

headline: Voted Most Likely to Slaughter
text: READING “The Slasher Movie Book” is like paging through a 1980s yearbook from a high school for maniacs. Look how young Michael and Jason look! Oh, and there’s Freddy in that sweater he wore, like, every day. And whatever happened to Chucky, that little monster?

headline: Leading Off: Just the Two of Us
text: For a while, it looked like it could go seven, maybe even provide the N.B.A. playoffs with yet another upset of a top seed. The Indiana Pacers were feisty. Chris Bosh was out of the picture for the Heat, and Miami would be without the effective Udonis Haslem for Game 6. But then the series ended with a 12-point Miami victory on Thursday night — was the idea, or hope, of an epic series just an illusion?

headline: Ukrainian Lawmakers Debate With Their Fists
text: Tensions were high in Ukraine on Friday as opposition lawmakers blocked a session of Parliament and the speaker called for new elections after a violent bout on the floor of the legislature that some observers have dubbed the “rumble in the Rada.”

headline: The Challenge of Starting an Airline
text: Where are the start-up airlines?

headline: As Memorial Day Nears, a Single Image That Continues to Haunt
text: Memorial Day. The unofficial kickoff to summer. Barbecues sizzling. Lawn sprinklers hissing. Local marching bands tooting out Sousa. Red, white, and blue bunting hanging from the porch railings, and on TV, someone begins a recitation of Lt. Col. John McCrae’s classic poem: In Flanders field, the poppies blow/Between the crosses row on row …

headline: Hints of a Bottom in Home Prices
text: The median price of existing homes sold in the United States in April was $178,000, the National Association of Realtors reported this week. While the monthly figures are volatile, that was the highest figure in 20 months, and the average of the 12 most recent figures has also begun to rise. Only in the two major Texas markets, however, are median prices now at or above where they were in 2006.

headline: That Memorable Glass of Wine
text: The idea of owning a winery is enticing, especially for those with the wealth to indulge their passion. But, as Paul Sullivan notes in his Wealth Matters column this week, many wineries are not profitable. In fact, the definition of success in the business is breaking even, and most investors seem to accept the prospect of losing a manageable amount of money over many years.

headline: Marijuana Meets Moonshine
text: SPEAKEASY-STYLE bars with secret entrances and Prohibition themes may be popular, but their illegality is only an illusion.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Last Dances
text: A. O. Scott and David Carr (watch him bust a move) look back at the deaths of Donna Summer, Whitney Houston, Adam Yauch and others.

headline: TimesCast | Next Steps for the Patz Case
text: Pedro Hernandez, a 51-year-old man who confessed to killing 6-year-old Etan Patz, could be arraigned by video from Bellevue Hospital.

headline: Angels Reliever Piling Up Punchouts
text: 1:10 p.m. | Updated With Saturday’s GameFrieri entered Saturday night’s game against the Seattle Mariners with two outs in the eighth inning and struck out Miguel Olivo for his 20th strikeout in nine innings. He remained in the game for the ninth, striking out two more batters and earning his second save for the Angels.

headline: Schoen Steps Down From Thomas H. Lee Partners
text: The Boston-based private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners said on Friday that Scott A. Schoen had stepped down as vice chairman of the firm.

text: Donna Summer, Adam Yauch, Robin Gibb, Levon Helm, Whitney Houston.

headline: Kelly Slater
text: Kelly Slater, 11-time ASP World Champion, surfs around the globe.

headline: Answers About How to Deal With Pests, Part 1
text: Following last week’s Real Estate article about handling pest problems in New York City, readers submitted questions to our guest expert, Gary Braness, a pest management consultant and owner of Yosemite Environmental Services, about how to evict their unwanted roommates.

headline: Kelly Slater’s Wave-Finding Tips
text: AS a child, Kelly Slater surfed the modest swells near his home in Cocoa Beach, Fla.

headline: J.R. Smith Arrested in Miami Beach
text: J.R. Smith, the Knicks guard with a history of legal troubles, was arrested in Miami Beach on Thursday for failing to appear in court on a traffic matter.

headline: 4 Lisbon Restaurants Not to Miss
text: IF I say that I saw the future of Portuguese cooking in a martini glass, you might conclude that I was having drunken visions.

headline: How I Fell for Lisbon
text: WE meet the places we wind up loving much the way we meet the people we fall for: on purpose and accidentally; at precisely the right moment and exactly the wrong time; in the highest of spirits and the lowest of moods.

headline: Great Meals in Tokyo’s Tiny Outposts
text: ONE evening my French friend Pierre and I were browsing in a tiny embroidery store in the Shimo-Kitazawa neighborhood of Tokyo, a district of alleys and narrow streets not far from downtown, when a Japanese man in a chef’s white jacket emerged from a door at the back, offering — of all things — slices of French baguette with hunks of rillettes on top. He held out the plate and encouraged us to try it.

headline: Where Fish Outnumber Phones
text: IT was an hour before sunset on the remote Indonesian archipelago of Karimunjawa, a scattering of 27 tiny islands in the Java Sea, south of Borneo. My husband, Carsten, two children and I were on a turquoise outrigger canoe, paddling along the shoreline of the island of Menyawakan, which was lined with clusters of mangroves. Looking down into the clear, shallow water, we spotted a black sea cucumber that wound its sinuous way along the sand like a snake.

headline: Restaurant Report: Boucherie, New Orleans
text: Last May, three gunshots ripped through Nathanial Zimet’s body, and, in a sense, the whole New Orleans food community. The young chef, who had transformed food truck fame into a successful restaurant called Boucherie, was critically wounded in an attempted robbery and, though he survived, the road to recovery was complicated by financial difficulties.

headline: Beyond San Diego’s Surf and Sun: Suds
text: DURING a recent trip to San Diego, it took a while for me to fully appreciate the extent of the city’s beer obsession. There was the unexpectedly extensive tap list at the popular new ramen shop Underbelly, and the beer chitchat at the shoe store where I picked up some sandals. Then I tried to rent a surfboard in La Jolla and mentioned the reason for my trip, the sales guy handed me a slip of paper scrawled with the Web address for his beer review blog. Beer, it seems, has become as much a part of the San Diego identity as surf and sun.

headline: Walking the Streets of a Nuclear Ghost Town
text: THE tour guide smiled as he repeated a gesture he had made many times before. Surrounded by a busload of tourists, he pulled out a cellphone-sized radiation reader.

headline: Places and Faces of Lisbon
text: On a neighborhood crawl, discover a bookstore with catwalks and meet some of the city’s people.

headline: A Government Program That Could Improve the Economy
text: Considering how often the federal government is depicted as a huge, bloated, incomprehensible bureaucracy, it’s always refreshing when it does something forward-thinking and consumer-friendly. In the technology realm, it does that fairly often.

headline: Missing People and Faded Posters
text: If your computer permits you to view these photographs in full-screen mode, we recommend it.

headline: Shipyards Go Chic in Sweden
text: Where docks once went bust, video art is shown at a train station, and local herring is served up fresh.

headline: Charting the Rise of the King of Retail
text: One thing that CNBC’s profile of Millard (Mickey) Drexler, the chief executive of J. Crew, made clear on Thursday night is that his life is not the stuff of novels. True, he had what sounded like a lousy childhood, sleeping in the foyer of his family’s Bronx apartment. And later, as a very rich man, he bought classy real estate, including Andy Warhol’s former compound at Montauk. And true, he got the boot from Gap, in 2002, after a mostly innovative 19-year run that included the creation of Old Navy. (According to a Wall Street Journal profile, Mr. Drexler collected around $350 million when he cashed out his Gap stake.)

headline: Giant Lender in Spain Asks for Billions to Fend Off Collapse
text: MADRID — Spain’s banking crisis worsened Friday as the board of Bankia, the country’s biggest mortgage lender, warned that it would need an additional 19 billion euros ($23.88 billion), far beyond what the government estimated when it seized the bank and its portfolio of delinquent real estate loans earlier this month.

headline: For Would-Be Cougars, the Prom Is a Good Start
text: RECENTLY, as I heard my daughter, a junior in high school, and her friends discuss their plans for the prom, I had a vaguely troubling thought: can a 16-year-old be a cougar?

headline: Push Comes to Shove, and Punch, in Ukraine Parliament
text: MOSCOW — What began as a legislative debate over Ukraine’s official language policy escalated into a fist-swinging, clothes-ripping brawl between screaming, sweaty lawmakers that reverberated around the Internet on Friday, embellishing the country’s standing in the pantheon of parliamentary punchfests that are captured on camera.

headline: Brooklyn School Backs Off Condom Giveaway on Prom Night
text: 8:15 p.m. | Updated  The principal of Bedford-Stuyvesant Preparatory High School told ABC that condoms would not be available after the dance, saying he did not want to violate Education Department policy.

headline: Mainstreaming Sex Toys Through Better Design — and Conversation
text: Over at the Atlantic’s Web site, Andy Isaacson tells the story of the sex-toy company Jimmyjane (with entertaining diversions into the history of commercial products for genital stimulation). Steve Jobs helped us all recognize the benefits of good design in daily life, but it was nonetheless surprising to read about the entrepreneurial epiphany of Jimmyjane’s founder, Ethan Imboden. He was at a sex-products expo, surrounded by cheesy, blinking, tawdry junk, when he realized that he was “looking at the only category of consumer product that had yet to be touched by design. . . . The category had been isolated by the taboo that surrounded it. I figured, I can transcend that.”

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Teenager’s Obsessions
text: The first volume of “The Flowers of Evil,” by Shuzo Oshimi, enters our manga best-seller list this week at No. 3. It tells the story of Takao Kasuga, a teenage student with two obsessions: a female classmate and the poetry of Baudelaire. The book’s plot sounds creepy: Takao takes home the gym clothes of his crush, Nanako Saeki, but he doesn’t get away with his theft. Another girl in his class witnesses the event and blackmails Takao to do her bidding. On its Web site, Vertical, the publisher of the book, describes “The Flowers of Evil” as a romantic comedy, but reviews of the work suggest something more complex.

headline: Parent Un-Trapped | When Advice Goes Viral
text: Anyone who’s been at a dinner party where the conversation has stuck to the topic of strollers — Uppababy or Bugaboo? City Mini or Bob? — knows that moms love to talk kid gear. Sounds extremely dull, but it can be riveting if you’re about to have a child yourself and wondering if it’s crazy or necessary to buy a $300 organic crib mattress, and, if you do, is it a good idea to get the baby’s bed at Ikea for a hundred bucks?

headline: Will Someone Please Say ‘You’re Fired’?
text: The Romney campaign has a new offer out: Donate 3 bucks for a chance to dine with “the Donald” (and Mitt Romney, who gets second billing). It’s not clear whether the winner will really get a tête-à-tête-à-coiffure, or just an invitation to a fundraiser—like the recent Obama campaign raffle for a seat at a $15 million George Clooney event.

headline: In White Plains, Tesla Motors Sells the Sizzle and Maybe a Car or Two
text: WHITE PLAINS — “I hope we never sell a car here,” George Blankenship, vice president of worldwide sales and ownership experience at Tesla Motors, said as he gestured Thursday around the company’s newest storefront. The space officially opened here Friday at the Westchester, an upscale shopping mall. “Our goal instead is to interact with people when they’re looking at new things in the mall and not necessarily in the market for a car. The focus is on answering the many questions they have about electric vehicles and the Tesla Model S.”

headline: Living In | Glen Oaks, Queens
text: Apartments make up most of the housing stock in this Queens neighborhood built on property once owned by William K. Vanderbilt.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: For Florida, a Rematch With Meaning
text: The Florida lacrosse team made history on Saturday with its 15-2 win over Penn State as it advanced to its first Final Four and became just the second team to ever do so as a program in its third year of existence.

headline: Could You Spend Summer (More) Smartphone Free?
text: My older daughter had her school year’s last “performance assembly” this morning, and while the children were lining up, I scanned down the row: parent after parent, including me and my husband, with smartphones in hand, skimming e-mails with our younger children milling about our chairs. (Moments later, all phones shifted to camera mode, and all hands went up as the show began — synchronized parenting.)

headline: Sweden 1912: What a Trip
text: One hundred years ago the summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

headline: Put One Foot in the Past, Point One to Tomorrow
text: GROWING up in Colorado, Jodee Nimerichter was a serious bunhead: a driven young ballet dancer, whose dedication had landed her in a conservatory program. And then one day, in 1992, for reasons she still can’t fully explain, she quit. Full stop.

headline: Dimon Agrees to Testify, Without Committing to Specific Date
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has agreed to testify before a Congressional committee in June to discuss the bank’s recent multibillion-dollar trading loss.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Can the Orange Beat the Gators Again?
text: When Syracuse and Florida met for the first time on March 3 in Gainesville, Fla., the matchup didn’t exactly look like a Final Four preview.

headline: A Law Shielded Many Texans When the Housing Bubble Burst
text: ARE government-imposed limits on borrowing a good thing?

headline: Composing a More Useful Future
text: WHEN economic waters are rough — or perhaps just to shake things up in times of stagnation — musical institutions try to redefine themselves, sharpen their sense of mission and do some image tweaking. That can be hard when your mission is already unusual and clearly defined. But the American Composers Orchestra, which has been putting a spotlight on (mostly contemporary) American music since 1977, has lately been reinventing itself as a hybrid performing ensemble and service organization.

headline: Unplugged and Fully Recharged
text: MIAMI BEACH

headline: A Weekend Visit to History
text: AMERICAN fashion, like many Americans, is torn between the past and the future. While designers are swaddling and coddling customers in fondly retooled visions of yesteryear — just pick a decade — some designers are trying to take a blindfolded whack at the future. Some hit the piñata, and some hit the wall.

headline: From Punk Rock Snarl to Song Circle Leader
text: BEARDED, willowy and often dressed in white, Alexander Ebert, the frontman of the folk-rock act Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros, has a hippie leader vibe. It helps that his band’s music feels like a community singalong, with group harmonies and whistling, snaps and hand claps as percussion. Mr. Ebert started the band in California with the singer Jade Castrinos; their romance was captured on their 2009 debut album, “Up From Below,” in tracks like the hit single “Home.”

headline: French Open’s Defending Champion Remains Under the Radar
text: Leading Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 4-0, in the final of the Italian Open on Sunday, Li Na seemed poised to enter the French Open — where in 2011 she became China’s first major singles champion on a hot streak. But then things fell apart.

headline: Management Buyouts Can Be Too Cozy
text: Some corporate decisions leave you wondering what the board might have been thinking at the time. That seems to be the case with the board of Venoco, a California oil company that is the subject of a proposed $770 million management buyout.

headline: Brooklyn School Reverses Decision to Give Out Condoms at Prom
text: The principal at Bedford-Stuyvesant Preparatory High School had said his school passed out condoms in its sex-education program, so it would make them available at prom night too.

headline: Police in Azerbaijan Arrest Protesters at Eurovision Rally
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — About 50 antigovernment demonstrators were arrested Friday evening in Baku while trying to stage a flash rally in the city center, as opponents of President Ilham Aliyev sought to use the Eurovision Song Contest to draw international attention to human rights abuses.

headline: A Detective’s Early Search for Etan
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: May 27 — June 2
text: THE Accademia Carrara in Bergamo holds one of Italy’s most distinguished collections of Venetian painting. And while it is closed for restoration, some of its choicest items are on the road. The itinerary brings 15 pictures to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in  “BELLINI, TITIAN AND LOTTO: NORTH ITALIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE ACCADEMIA CARRARA, BERGAMO.”

headline: Students Complain About New Dress Code at Stuyvesant
text: Stuyvesant High School imposed a new dress code this year because school officials thought students were  making wardrobe choices that they did not think "were appropriate for school.'' In a report in the student newspaper, the Spectator, several students describe their brushes with the dress code enforcers.

headline: Forget the London Games, Try Kafkarate in Prague
text: The Olympic torch is on its way to London, but a Czech advertising campaign is set on getting Britons to flee their homeland this August and instead take part in “the Prague Games,” with events including “Kafkarate” and “Heavyweight Shopping.”

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Questions of Fair Play
text: In Washington, lawmakers and regulators are scrutinizing the fairness of Facebook’s I.P.O. process. In New York, a prosecutor continues his broad campaign to end insider trading. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: For Duke, Faceoffs Will Be a Factor
text: Meeting for the third time this season and the sixth time in the past two years, Duke and Maryland are hardly strangers to one another.

headline: Klinsmann Trims U.S. Roster to 23
text: United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann trimmed four players from his 27-man training camp roster Friday, streamlining the national team for its coming five-game, 18-day burst of exhibitions and World Cup qualifiers.

headline: A Veteran Stabilizes the Young Sixers
text: The 76ers will look to extend their remarkable postseason run on Saturday when they take on the Celtics in Game 7 in Boston.

headline: What Scares Oren Peli?
text: For Oren Peli, the filmmaker who helped usher in a new wave of found footage horror movies after the success of his first feature, “Paranormal Activity,” the scariest devil is the one you don’t know. His latest project, “Chernobyl Diaries,” follows young travelers who participate in what the film calls “extreme” tourism. A tour guide drives the group into the city of Pripyat, the former home to workers at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor, a place that was evacuated after the disaster. The travelers, of course, learn that the town isn’t completely deserted.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A City Hall area co-op, a Manhattan Valley condo and a Williamsburg condo.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A five-bedroom expanded Cape in Redding, Conn., and a five-bedroom 1920 colonial in Bayonne, N.J.

headline: Less-Fuss Paella Arrives in Time for Summer
text: PAELLA, the classic rice dish from Spain, is considered picnic food — a one-dish meal prepared over a fire at an outdoor party like our hamburger cookout. It is also cooked indoors, but always in a flat steel paellera or in an earthenware cazuela. The main rules are to cook the rice uncovered and, unlike risotto, not to stir once the simmering has begun.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $14,380,000
text: The last of three thoroughly modern new town houses on Downing Street in the West Village, changing hands for $14.38 million, was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Book Details Obama’s Pot-Smoking Youth
text: He inhaled.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Maryland on a Mission
text: John Tillman has used three words to consistently motivate his Maryland men’s lacrosse team this season: Why not us?

headline: A Paella Picnic, With Favas
text: In this week’s City Kitchen, I’m making paella, the indoor version. Though classically cooked outdoors over a fire, it’s not a hard and fast rule, and what with the current bout of rainy weather, at my house both the picnic and the cooking happened inside one recent Sunday.

headline: XOXO Aims to Be an Alternative to South by Southwest
text: Anyone who has ever trekked down to Austin for the Interactive portion of South by Southwest, a jumble of talks about technology, parties and music performances, knows that while it is an amazing confluence of the best and brightest in the start-up world, it can also be something of a nightmare to navigate.

headline: Warren Faces New Allegations on Ancestry
text: 6:10 p.m. | Updated Elizabeth Warren’s Senate campaign in Massachusetts had hoped the controversy over her ancestry would die down after a poll this week indicated that voters thought it was insignificant.

headline: Senate Panel Mildly Rebukes Coburn for Role in Ensign Scandal
text: 4:30 p.m. | Updated The Senate Ethics Committee has smacked the hand of Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, for his minor role in the sordid scandal that ended the career of John Ensign, the former Republican senator from Nevada.

headline: Where Etan Patz Walked, Many More Eyes
text: Could it happen now? Could someone sinister pluck a small child off that same street at that same hour on the same day, so that he vanished into the ether for 33 years?

headline: Now Coveted: A Walkable, Convenient Place
text: WALKING isn’t just good for you. It has become an indicator of your socioeconomic status.

headline: ‘Duck Dynasty’ Also a Power in the Ratings
text: The Robertsons, a down-home Louisiana family and the stars of the A&E reality series “Duck Dynasty,” may have earned millions of dollars from their duck calling business, Duck Commander, but now they can also claim to have drawn in a far more elusive prey: television viewers.

headline: When Doctors Grieve
text: MY mother died of breast cancer in 2005 after living with the disease for nearly 20 years. Her oncologist, whom I knew from the time I was 9 years old, was her doctor for most of that time. I practically grew up in the hospital, and my family felt quite close to the health care providers, especially the oncologist. After my mother died I wondered if the feeling was mutual.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: The Actor as Literal Shape-Shifter
text: 8:07 a.m. | Updated  CANNES, France — In its purest form, cinema is an art of motion, and no contemporary performer better expresses that truth than the French actor Denis Lavant. A former acrobat with a wiry frame and puckish features, Mr. Lavant is a one-of-a-kind screen presence who brings to his roles both a Chaplinesque pathos and eruptions of pure kinetic energy: think of his giddy moment of dance-floor release at the end of Clarie Denis’s “Beau Travail” (1999) or the lurching, pirouetting sprint he breaks into as David Bowie’s “Modern Love” comes on the radio in Leos Carax’s “Mauvais Sang” (1986).

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Loyola Is Still the 1
text: It has been a great year for Loyola (Md.) athletics. The men’s basketball team made the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1994. The women’s lacrosse team won the Big East for the second consecutive season.

headline: In Europe, Divorce and Separation Become a Burden for Struggling Fathers
text: MILAN — The pain of Europe’s economic crisis is being felt sharply by a new class of people: separated and divorced men who end up impoverished or on the streets as they struggle to maintain themselves while keeping up child support and alimony payments.

headline: Facebook’s Royal Wedding
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: At a Reunion, the Glamorous Faces of a New York Beer
text: Here is a question that no one asks of a Miss Subways: Does a Miss Rheingold miss Rheingold?

headline: The ‘Invisible Art’: A Woman’s Touch Behind the Scenes
text: THAT the Cannes Film Festival chose not to include any work by female directors in its competition this year created a mini-scandal. But it obscured a couple of other points about the state of women in film. For instance, only 2 of the 22 features in question were shot by female cinematographers. On the other hand, a full third of the movies were cut by female editors.

headline: Just Call It a Pre-Prenup
text: A BREAKTHROUGH occurred last November on the CBS comedy “The Big Bang Theory.” Sheldon Cooper, the commitment-wary physicist, ramped up his courtship of Amy Fowler, the skittish neurobiologist.

headline: With Andretti, Baltimore Hopes Third Time’s a Charm for Grand Prix
text: BALTIMORE — With three months before the green flag was scheduled to drop, it seemed the Baltimore Grand Prix was in an irreversible skid.

headline: A Camaro’s Legacy: Testing the Pack Alpha of Muscle Cars
text: THE 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 has a heavy load to bear. Its model designation, borrowing the General Motors option code for one of the most storied V-8 engines of the muscle car’s glory days, sets lofty expectations among those who lived through Detroit’s horsepower wars.

headline: Muscles on Its Muscles, but Nuance in Its Soul
text: ALTON, Va.

headline: Brawn, With a Touch of Ballet
text: Sure it’s heavy, and no, it doesn’t come cheap. But the Camaro ZL1 is light on its feet, delivering on-track performance that sets it apart from the average muscle car.

headline: Berlusconi, Hinting at Ambition, Urges Direct Vote for President
text: ROME — After months out of the spotlight, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy made a rare public appearance on Friday to call for an overhaul of the country’s Constitution that would allow Italians to directly elect the nation’s president, instead of letting Parliament make that choice, as is now the case.

headline: Diaper Duty, Divided and Decided: Sign Here.
text: If you could sit down with your new love interest, romantic partner or spouse, and create an operating manual for your relationship, what would the rules be? Would writing them down give them more gravitas than a conversation over a glass of wine? Would you consult a couples’ counselor? Even use lawyers?

headline: Devils Get High Praise From Elias on Eve of Game 6
text: NEWARK – The greatest Devils teams in franchise history dominated the N.H.L. about a decade ago, rising to prominence with a stifling neutral zone trap, an impenetrable goalie and opportunistic forwards that thrived on the counterattack. It was a group that, as Patrik Elias fondly remembered, knew “if we just played good enough that we’d beat anybody,” and the Devils often did, playing for the Stanley Cup three times in four seasons and winning it twice, in 2001 and 2003.

headline: ‘Idol’ Winner Had Surgery for Kidney Stones
text: Phillip Phillips, this year’s winner of “American Idol” on Fox, underwent eight surgical procedures to remove kidney stones during the competition, his father told People magazine.  Some references were made to Mr. Phillip’s health problems during the show, and he often appeared wan, but his father, who is also named Phillip Phillips, said his son, a 21-year-old pawnshop worker, was suffering more than he let on.  “They’ve just seen a glimpse of what Phillip can do,” the father said. “We can’t wait to get him well and 100 percent and really see how he can perform.”  The singer will undergo another surgery in the next few weeks to reconstruct his kidneys, then go on tour with the rest of the finalists on the show. “The recovery’s probably two to four weeks,” the elder Phillip Phillips said.   Mr. Phillips, an indie rocker from Leesburg, Ga., with a rootsy vocal style and solid guitar skills, won the competition on Wednesday night, besting Jessica Sanchez, a 16-year-old singing prodigy from Chula Vista, Calif.

headline: A Car Hoard, Pruned to a Collection, Gets a Fitting Home
text: TACOMA, Wash.

headline: A Beacon for Car Lovers, Shining in the Northwest
text: The $65 million LeMay museum in Tacoma, Wash., which opens on Saturday, hopes to become a new center of car culture in America.

headline: Noomi Rapace as Lisbeth Salander
text: A clip of the Swedish actress’s performance in the film adaptation of Stieg Larsson’s novel.

headline: Noomi Rapace in 'Babycall'
text: A scene from Norwegian film 'Babycall.'

headline: Behind Fat Radish, Two Britons With Catering Roots
text: In addition to creating a popular restaurant, Fat Radish’s youthful duo have kept catering and event design in the spotlight.

headline: A Diplomat in 2 Worlds of Jazz
text: Latin jazz at its best enacts a kind of diplomacy, a dialogue between two separate but related parties. The trumpeter and conguero Jerry Gonzalez has long been an emissary in the field, equally fluent in hard bop and the music of the Afro-Caribbean diasporas, and given to reconciling the two.

headline: As Apps Move Into Cars, So Do More Distractions
text: THERE have been the sexy horsepower wars and dull best-in-class fuel-efficiency battles. Now automakers are fighting an undeclared, escalating war over in-dash apps, worrying regulators about even more distracted driving.

headline: When Hindu Meets Catholic and the Children That Follow
text: “Only after I became a parent,” P. writes, “did my spiritual self matter to anyone but me.”

headline: Just a Minute: Why New Orleans?
text: David Carr on why a city like New Orleans is losing a daily newspaper.

headline: Admissions Letters for Gifted and Talented Programs Go Out
text: New York's youngest public school students began hearing on Friday whether they received admission to one of 89 gifted and talented programs throughout the city.

headline: ‘A Christmas Story’ Musical Inching Closer to Broadway
text: A musical adaptation of “A Christmas Story,” based on the Jean Shepherd stories of the 1960s and the popular 1983 film, is aiming to open on Broadway later this year for a limited run through Thanksgiving and Christmas, a spokesman for the production confirmed on Friday.

headline: Yes, Even Fashionistas Have to Eat
text: THE artist John Currin was mid-speech at the Art Production Fund gala last month when platters of roasted Norwich Meadows Farm heirloom carrots and barbecued Piedmontese beef brisket suddenly appeared from behind a white wall, carried by a brigade of artisanally handsome L-train-esque waiters.

headline: Audio: Veteran Times-Picayune Reporter on How Staff Heard the News
text: Bruce Nolan covers religion for The Times-Picayune, the New Orleans newspaper where he has spent most of his career. He has served as a reporter, a suburban bureau chief and assistant city editor. In that time, he has worked on hundreds of stories, including many about Hurricane Katrina and the Gulf oil spill.

headline: BMW Unveils Zagato Coupe at Villa d’Este
text: Befitting its role as the primary sponsor of the Concorso d’Eleganza, BMW unveiled a conceptual coupe on Friday at the vintage-car event, held at Villa d’Este, on Lake Como in northern Italy.

headline: Caramel Sauce
text: Melissa Clark shows how to make easy, delicious caramel sauce at home.

headline: A Famous Couple’s Tale Revives a Noted Pairing
text: ALMOST a quarter of a century has passed since the director Philip Kaufman last worked with the film editor Walter Murch. In 1988, when their “Unbearable Lightness of Being” was released, the Soviet Union was still in existence (the film memorably depicts the 1968 Soviet invasion of Prague) and Pauline Kael was still the film critic at The New Yorker, where she gave it a rave review.

headline: Inside a Rock Star’s Skin, or a 120-Pound Costume
text: For their shared program at Danspace Project, Andrew Dinwiddie and Michelle Ellsworth have scrutinized the act of transformation in two virtuosic solos. Mr. Dinwiddie is a rock star who turns into an object of worship in “Farewell Tour.” And Ms. Ellsworth, in a 120-pound, 5-foot-wide and 9-foot-high costume in “The Pythagodress,” becomes a wearable, portable set.

headline: Sassy Rap and Afro-Brazilian Beats
text: Rye Rye

headline: Like It’s 1999? The Sixers Bring Back Some Memories
text: BOSTON — Watching the Philadelphia 76ers push the Boston Celtics to the limit in their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series harks back to another team that defied the odds more than once: the 1999 Knicks.

headline: With a Job Like His, You’d Brood Too
text: FOURTEEN years before Lisbeth Salander tortured her legal guardian, and 16 years before Sarah Lund began badgering her superiors in the Copenhagen police department, Kurt Wallander ran over a rabbit.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Kickstarter’s Hidden Failures and Blaming Facebook
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: Rhubarb, It Turns Out, Can Be a Sweetie
text: SOME ice cream is perfectly smooth, with nary a nut or chocolate fleck to distract your tongue from its voluptuous texture. Then there is ice cream akin to a sundae in a pint container: so full of nutty brittles, veins of fudge and chunks of cookie or brownie that the ice cream itself becomes pretty much secondary.

headline: Just a Minute: Why New Orleans?
text: David Carr discusses why New Orleans and Michigan are on the leading edge of corporate experiments to end daily print newspaper publication in favor of Web-based news sites.

headline: New Victory Season Will Include Opera Adapted From Philip Pullman Novel
text: The 2012-13 season for the New Victory Theater, an Off Broadway presenter that specializes in productions for all ages, will include a new opera based on a novel by Philip Pullman (author of the trilogy “His Dark Materials”) as well as two new productions drawn from Shakespeare’s work.

headline: Bergman’s Bittersweet Ode to Youth’s Sunset
text: THE film “Summer With Monika,” released in 1953, isn’t among the best known or most representative works of Ingmar Bergman, but it may be his most influential. The story of two working-class teenagers from Stockholm — Monika (Harriet Andersson), who works in a grocery store and lives with her brawling, heavy-drinking parents in a crowded apartment, and Harry (Lars Ekborg), a shy stock clerk in a porcelain factory whose home life with his widowed father is tense and silent — it was Bergman’s 12th feature as a director.

headline: Easy-to-Swallow Ballet for the Masses, With a Broadway Perspective
text: In 2004, just before New York City Ballet first presented “Double Feature,” a two-part homage to silent films by the Broadway choreographer Susan Stroman, Peter Martins told The New York Times that he had hired Ms. Stroman because he wanted to sell tickets. Sometimes you get what you pay for. On Thursday the audience at the David H. Koch Theater greeted the return of “Double Feature” with great enthusiasm.

headline: A Sweet Primer
text: This week’s column features rhubarb ice cream shot through with pockets of homemade caramel sauce.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 25
text: Subjects include the wedding of the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn; crane operators at 1 World Trade Center; and an uncertain future for the Maid of the Mist at Niagara Falls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Egypt, Washington and New York.

headline: Reviewing the Chevrolet Camaro ZL1
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer reviews the 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1, a throwback piece of American muscle capable of romping through the quarter -mile in under 12 seconds.

headline: Jaunt Through Fallout Zone Goes (Shock!) Awry
text: Most good horror movies are rich with subtext. You could read “Psycho” as an Oedipal parable, say, or George Romero’s “Dawn of the Dead” as a sendup of voracious consumerism. “Chernobyl Diaries”? You could conceivably consider it a warning about nuclear power, but it’s really about the dangers of seeking adventure in a foreign country and trusting former Soviets. But please, don’t give it that much thought.

headline: Word Up! | ‘Graphic Design: Now in Production’ at the Cooper-Hewitt
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Cannes Chorus
text: Vampire makeup, pinched breasts and an onslaught of sequins sometimes define Cannes fashion, as it does this year. Group pictures of actresses are almost blinding, and tans under the hot lights look repellant. For this reason, minimally fussy gowns in sharp colors look best, like those on Kristen Stewart and Nicole Kidman (when does she ever look bad?), as do the short-and-skippy dresses worn by Lily Cole and Diane Kruger. Jeremy Irons looks like a musty boarder in his long jacket and vest, while Brad Pitt nicely surprises with a full Cleveland in his tan Gucci suit.

headline: Before China’s Transition, a Wave of Nationalism
text: BEIJING — As an English-speaking talk show host on China Central Television, Yang Rui likes to think of himself as a bridge between East and West.

headline: After Guantánamo, Starting Anew, in Quiet Anger
text: Nice, France

headline: Looking Back to the 1996 World Transnational
text: When Barry Rigal read last Monday’s column, he wrote to say it reminded him of this diagramed deal, which occurred during the World Transnational Mixed Teams Championship in Rhodes, Greece, in 1996.

headline: Icahn Discloses Stake in Chesapeake Energy
text: Carl C. Icahn has made his latest fight public.

headline: Looking Directly at Life’s Decline
text: CANNES, France — The Austrian director Michael Haneke has made an art of exploiting audience discomfort. In a sense his new film, “Amour,” continues in that vein by staring down the least palatable of subjects: aging, sickness and death. But the universal specter of mortality has brought with it a tenderness seldom seen in Mr. Haneke’s cool, analytical cinema, and the film remains the closest thing to a consensus favorite among critics at the Cannes Film Festival here.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Spending Addiction
text: If Congress cuts federal spending, does that help or hurt an economy in recession? The Republicans say it helps. What if Congress cuts federal defense spending? In that case, the Republicans say it hurts.

headline: Katie Finneran Will Be Miss Hannigan in ‘Annie’ Revival
text: Little girls of “Annie,” beware: Broadway’s new Miss Hannigan knows a thing or two about stealing scenes, no matter how cute the moppets are. Katie Finneran, the two-time Tony Award winner – most recently for playing a barfly in the 2010 revival of “Promises, Promises” – will play the alcoholic orphanage manager in the revival of the musical “Annie” that begins performances in October.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 25
text: More Photographs

headline: Hugging the Seine: Fashion, Design Restaurants and Club
text: Paris has many places to take in contemporary art, including the avant-garde Pompidou Center, the trendy Gaîté Lyrique and the newly renovated Palais de Tokyo. But the city was missing an all-encompassing hub for fashion and design until last month, when Les Docks, Cité de la Mode et du Design (34, quai d’Austerlitz, 13th Arrondissement) was officially inaugurated.

headline: Criminal Complaint Against Pedro Hernandez
text: Pedro Hernandez is charged with murder in the second degree in the death of Etan Patz.

headline: Why Cisco Stopped Making Tablets
text: Cisco announced on Thursday that it would be discontinuing its Cius tablet. Cisco cited the failure of the product on a “market transition,” which is a good way to describe the reality: people didn’t buy it.

headline: Apple Strikes Back at Government E-Book Lawsuit
text: A few days ago, Apple filed a formal response to the antitrust lawsuit filed by the Department of Justice in April against it and several book publishers.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Playtime
text: Madison Square Park held its children’s fair on May 19 with music, games, popcorn and cotton candy. The children, in their summery hats, resembled butterflies.

headline: Chinook Down
text: Freelance reporter revisits an Army helicopter crash in Afghanistan on May 30, 2007, that took the lives of seven soldiers.

headline: Chic in Review | Angelina Jolie Rocks (Literally)
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Hiring Woodson, the Knicks Make the Logical Move
text: The historically predictable company move would have been to try to lure Phil Jackson back to New York with a vault of Dolan dollars and the seat that belonged to his mentor, Red Holzman. But the lessons of nearly four tumultuous and championship-free decades tell us that Friday’s official hiring of Mike Woodson, the interim coach and another longtime Holzman admirer, made more sense.

headline: The Antichrist Cometh
text: Watch out, Britain! I’m on my way, and the Telegraph says that I’m a “false Messiah” with “Satanic intent”.

headline: After Digs at His Predecessor, Obama Will Host Bushes at White House
text: President Obama will host former President George W. Bush and his wife, Laura, at the White House next week for the unveiling of their official portraits, bringing the two presidents together at a time when Mr. Obama has been castigating Mr. Bush’s record on the campaign trail.

headline: Week in Pictures for May 25
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the wedding of the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn; crane operators at 1 World Trade Center; and an uncertain future for the Maid of the Mist at Niagara Falls.

text: The pair of government witnesses who testified on Friday at Rajat K. Gupta’s insider trading trial were from opposite ends of the business world.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Climbing Into the Future, or Just Into an Artist’s Whimsy
text: Participatory art is all the rage these days, an ever-expanding category and, increasingly, a means for museums to signal their hipness to the younger, broader audiences they so desperately want to attract. Nothing says accessible like something you interact with physically.

headline: Best of Cannes Beauty
text: The beauty highlights at the 65th Cannes Film Festival, from nude and unfussy makeup to carefully coifed updos.

text: To the Editor:
