text: To the Editor:

headline: Hope and Frustration in New U.S. Effort to Help Homeowners
text: As mortgage rates have hit one record low after another, millions of homeowners have been forced to watch, longingly, from the sidelines. They haven’t had the option of refinancing because sliding home values pushed their mortgages underwater, meaning they owe more than their homes are worth. The banks would just not work with them.

headline: Have You Tried to Refinance Your Underwater Mortgage?
text: This week’s Your Money column looks at the government’s latest attempt to extend a life jacket to homeowners who want to refinance but whose mortgages are underwater — in other words, they owe more than their homes are worth.

headline: Glamour in Cannes
text: Celebrities, including Diane Kruger and Heidi Klum, sparkled at the Cannes Film Festival.

headline: Prime Burger, Where the ’60s Were a Side Order, to Close
text: If you’re a fan of Prime Burger at 5 East 51st Street — and that would put you in the company of approximately half of New York, to judge from Friday’s lunchtime crowd — you should come Saturday for a burger and curly fries in your booth for one. You may never again have the chance.

headline: Albany’s Unkindest Cut of All
text: Albany

headline: New YouTube Channel Aims to Add Context to Activist Videos
text: A new YouTube channel devoted to human rights was introduced this week to help raise awareness and provide context for the growing number of videos created by citizen journalists and activists all over the world, YouTube announced in a blog post.

headline: One More Reason to Fear the Beach
text: As if we didn’t have enough probably fictitious but possibly real beings to worry about. All over basic cable, people are searching for Bigfoot, hunting down ghosts, looking for extraterrestrials. Now, it turns out, we need to add mermaids to the list.

headline: The Call of the Wild Salome, and Other Musical Temptations From Cleveland
text: All this season in New York, opera lovers and longtime admirers of the storied Cleveland Orchestra had been eagerly anticipating the concert performance of Strauss’s “Salome” at Carnegie Hall that finally took place on Thursday night. This was a chance to hear Strauss’s incandescent score played by that great orchestra from the stage of the acoustically glorious Carnegie Hall, with the stunning dramatic soprano Nina Stemme in the title role, and the powerhouse bass-baritone Eric Owens as Jochanaan.

headline: Have an Enjoyable Memorial Day Weekend
text: Wheels will be taking a short break in observance of Memorial Day, but we’ll return on Tuesday, May 29, with our regular coverage. Whatever mode of transport conveys you to your destination, the editors and contributors at Wheels wish you safe and happy travels this holiday weekend.

headline: Seeing HBO’s ‘Girls’ Without Buying a Television
text: Would the “Girls” character Hannah Horvath, a young Brooklynite without much cash, subscribe to HBO? Or would she rely on her friends?

headline: Leaving a Dark Day Behind
text: INDIANAPOLIS — As usual, thousands of race fans found seats, mostly in the shade, on a hazy Friday morning at Indianapolis Motor Speedway, parking their coolers to watch the final practice session before the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday. Dario Franchitti was the fastest.

headline: Inconveniences Aside, a Picnic Can Be a Delight
text: A GOOD picnic is a challenge. It can be done, but like tying a bow tie or driving a tractor, it doesn’t come naturally. A picnic sounds wonderful, but somehow, when the blanket is spread over rocky, wet earth, and the warmed potato salad is opened up like an invitation to the flies, when the sea gulls surround you, when you drop your sandwich in the grass, or lightning crackles overhead, the whole thing sours.

headline: Liukin Returns, a Veteran at 22
text: CHICAGO – It was just practice, just two hours of run-throughs for Saturday’s U.S. Classic gymnastics meet, but Nastia Liukin, the reigning Olympic champion in the all-around, was still anxious.

headline: In Vatican Whodunit, a Punch Line of a Suspect
text: ROME — A mysterious source named Maria. A room furnished with a single chair where sensitive Vatican documents are turned over to an investigative journalist at regular meetings. The arrest of the pope’s butler. Perhaps the greatest breach in centuries in the wall of secrecy that surrounds the Vatican.

headline: Intensity Cools After 2 More Draws in Chess Championship
text: After the fireworks and decisive results of Games 7 and 8, the world chess championship match between Viswanathan Anand, the titleholder, and Boris Gelfand, lapsed back into relative calm as Games 9 and 10 were drawn on Wednesday and Thursday.

headline: Yankees Sign Maine, the Former Mets Right-Hander
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Yankees signed the former Met right-handed pitcher John Maine to a minor league contract on Friday. He will join their extended spring training program in Tampa, Fla.

headline: After a Summer Hike, a Delicious Reward
text: SUMMER is the time to get outdoors and immerse yourself in nature, and hiking makes that as easy as lacing up your boots. The three parks below provide varied enough terrain to suit most levels of experience. The pleasure of walking through beautiful landscape is its own reward, but you will also have earned a delicious meal, on or off the trail, so recommendations for provisions and dining accompany each entry.

headline: A Challenging Bounty for the Clean-Plate Club
text: IF you plan to go to L’Acqua Ristorante, a homey little Italian place in downtown Freehold, I hope you have the experience I did on the second of my two visits. If you do, you will find good food, nicely presented by attentive servers. And you will manage to avoid the excesses that marred my first meal here.

headline: Hendrick Reclaims Spot Atop Nascar in Big Week
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Rick Hendrick jammed his leg into the No. 48 Chevrolet, straddled the driver’s side windowsill and held on for dear life on a precarious victory ride down the front stretch at Charlotte Motor Speedway last Saturday night.

headline: In Brooklyn, Taste of L.I. Wines
text: Geographically speaking, Long Island begins just across the Brooklyn Bridge from Manhattan. And Brooklyn was the setting for a showcase of East End wines this month, along with a few from the Finger Lakes and the Hudson Valley.

headline: Bloomberg Added Home No. 11 in 2011, His Tax Records Show
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may rule New York City, but he is also expanding his empire in Westchester County.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Romney Team Leader
text: Michael Barbaro reports on Mitt Romney’s biggest fan, Jim Wilson, who has become an unexpectedly valuable campaign asset.

headline: A Culinary Homage to an East End Industry
text: THE North Fork Oyster Company, a restaurant that opened about a year ago in Greenport, is an homage to the oyster industry on the East End; there are more than two dozen oyster farms in the area, according to the executive chef, Alex Algieri. Diners approaching the restaurant see a chef in the window opening oysters and otherwise tending the raw bar.

headline: Death on the Moor, Played for Laughs
text: The moors — by which we mean the open wastelands, not Othello and Emperor Macrinus — really need a P.R. person. Whenever they appear in literature, film or the theater, it seems, it is always nighttime, frighteningly dark and at least potentially stormy. And some wrongly accused man is running in terror for his life. Or the ghosts of young lovers are meeting to lament their failure to find happiness in life. Or a huge, mysterious, unseen, baronet-murdering dog that is said to glow like phosphorous is howling into the midnight air.

headline: Shipwrecked on a Magical Island, Windswept by Words
text: The gloomy caves, turbulent seas and wafting breezes of a faraway island cocoon the inhabitants, human and otherwise, of Shakespeare’s last great play, “The Tempest.” But in the vivid new Hartford Stage production, the director, Darko Tresnjak,  has banished this natural world and replaced it with an ocean of words, words, words.

headline: Plantations, Prisons and Profits
text: “Louisiana is the world’s prison capital. The state imprisons more of its people, per head, than any of its U.S. counterparts. First among Americans means first in the world. Louisiana’s incarceration rate is nearly triple Iran’s, seven times China’s and 10 times Germany’s.”

headline: If Tradition Holds, Hope and Wit Will Shower the Mets’ Stadium in Sheets
text: The long march of Mets history resumes Sunday after a 16-year break, as Banner Day materializes anew before the club’s 1:10 matinee game against the San Diego Padres. If precedent is a reliable indicator, paint will be spilled, linens will be ruined and at least a few people will have something clever to say.

headline: Germany Looks to Its Own Costly Reunification in Resisting Stimulus for Greece
text: MUNICH — When Germany wants to understand Greece and the crisis afflicting Europe it not only looks south to the Continent’s periphery but also turns inward, to the former East Germany, still struggling more than two decades after German reunification.

headline: A Frisky Musical With Many Lives
text: People have snickered for years about “Cats,” suggesting that the reason the show became the second-longest-running hit in Broadway history (after “The Phantom of the Opera”) was that the dance-driven extravaganza was an ideal attraction for tourists who did not speak English. But I suspect that some who dismiss this musical as mere spectacle have never actually seen or heard it. Maybe it is time they did.

headline: A Trio of Events With Music in Many Moods
text: THE rock-and-rap Bamboozle Festival in Asbury Park and the Electric Daisy Carnival of electronic dance music in East Rutherford may have grabbed the spotlight in New Jersey this month, but fans who favor other genres — and a more intimate scale — have plenty to look forward to in June.

headline: A Young Witness Propels a Farce
text: The gentleman of the house answers the doorbell in his bathrobe. He recognizes the cleaning woman (“the cleaner,” that is; we are in London), but has no idea what her name is. She is almost nine months pregnant and has brought along her daughter, who is almost 9, for the day. The lady of the house has disappeared. We are off and running.

headline: Brazil: President Vetoes Major Parts of Bill to Open Up Forests
text: President Dilma Rousseff on Friday vetoed portions of Brazil’s new Forest Code, a bill drafted to open big areas of protected forests to large-scale agriculture. The decision by Ms. Rousseff, which removes 12 articles from the bill, alters legislation sought by powerful agricultural groups. The bill had provoked outrage among environmentalists, some business leaders and cultural icons, especially over a provision that effectively granted amnesty to landowners who illegally deforested some areas. Responding to these concerns, Environment Minister Izabella Teixeira said the president’s line-item vetoes ruled out amnesty. Still, Ms. Rousseff’s action fell short of the expectations of environmental groups, which had wanted her to veto the entire bill. Details about the changes to the bill were sparse on Friday, with Brazil’s powerful Agriculture and Livestock Confederation withholding comment. The official text of Ms. Rousseff’s alterations, which include dozens of suggested changes to the bill in addition to the vetoed portions, is expected to be published on Monday.

headline: Media Executive’s Father Ordered to Pay $250,000 in Suit Over Fake Picasso
text: LOS ANGELES — Jack and Leslie Kavanaugh, the parents of the Relativity Media chief executive, Ryan Kavanaugh, got a double shot of bad news, as the elder Mr. Kavanaugh was ordered in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Friday to pay $250,000 in punitive damages for his role in the sale of a fraudulent Picasso drawing.

headline: Margaritas and Tacos Beneath the Bridge
text: Gran Eléctrica, in Brooklyn’s Dumbo neighborhood, is a brick-walled, votive-lighted, tin-ceilinged amalgam of the sustainably local and the whimsically loco. The mescal beverage options promise to knock your Birkenstocks off, as does the back garden, where the Brooklyn Bridge curves overhead like a distant awning. Set in a landmarked 1835 brick building that began as a purveyor of fire insurance to the shipping trade, the restaurant, at 5 Front Street, is owned by the group that brought Colonie to Brooklyn Heights last year. The chef, Sam Richman, honed his haute French technique at Jean Georges and Per Se but spent a month in Mexico on a culinary cram course before taking over the kitchen. Pacifico Clara beer ($6) makes its New York City debut on tap. About those skulls and skeletons on the walls: the Día de los Muertos motif of the Mexican artist José Guadalupe Posada has been customized in Dumbo-centric wallpaper. It works its intended macabre magic.

headline: Quietly Finding Haiti’s Audacious Beauty
text: To much of the outside world, the image of Haiti — when it pops up at all — is one of catastrophes, both natural and man-made. Violence, grinding poverty, flood, earthquakes all leave a lingering image of a benighted nation bereft of tender moments.

headline: Rules for the Road
text: “That man Haupt has built a bridge across Potomac Creek, about 400 feet long and nearly 100 feet high, over which loaded trains are running every hour,” declared President Abraham Lincoln on May 23, 1862, “and, upon my word, gentlemen, there is nothing in it but beanpoles and cornstalks!”

headline: On the Road for Romney, 40,000 Miles and Counting
text: CLEVELAND — In Florida, a state trooper pulled Jim Wilson off the highway, but instead of issuing a speeding ticket, asked a favor: Could he have a few Romney for President bumper stickers?

headline: Deciphering Mitt-Speak on Schools
text: Today, we’re going to talk about Mitt Romney’s education speech.

headline: Billionaire Finds New Role in Effort to Defeat Obama
text: When news broke last week that the billionaire investor Joe Ricketts had considered financing a $10 million advertising effort linking President Obama with the fiery race-based rhetoric of his former spiritual adviser, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., Mr. Ricketts quickly distanced himself from the proposal and Mitt Romney’s campaign denounced it.

headline: Balls, Strikes and Noodle Pudding
text: C. B. Bucknor, 50, was a physical therapist at what was then New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center when, on a whim, he used vacation time to attend umpire school in 1990. A career change ensued. Now, most of his Sundays involve ballgames and airline travel; he umpires 135 Major League games a season, not counting spring training and the playoffs. (He has worked the playoffs three times, but never a World Series, and his calls have sometimes been controversial.) In the off-season he spends time in his hometown, Savanna-la-Mar, Jamaica, where he helps run an annual “Treat 54” party (named for his uniform number) for local children. He lives in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, with his wife, who is a registered nurse, and their children, ages 9, 15 and 17; his mother lives upstairs.

headline: Some Comma Questions
text: Who knew people were so interested in commas? Commenters to my post “The Most Comma Mistakes” raised many points, questions and objections; collectively, they concentrated my mind wonderfully. Here are excerpts of a few representative comments, edited for clarity, followed by my responses.

headline: Control: An Update
text: Last week’s Anxiety post, “Control,” featured an interview with Dominick Brocato, conducted and transcribed by DW Gibson, the author of the forthcoming book and documentary film, “Not Working.” Many readers who commented wanted to know how Mr. Brocato was managing his various challenges — unemployment, illness and a lack of medical insurance among them — since the interview, which took place in July 2011. To provide that update to readers, Mr. Gibson contacted Mr. Brocato by e-mail and phone earlier this week.

headline: Friday Night Music: Ten Favorites
text: Too busy to hunt up new stuff, and going into makeup soon. So, for old times’ sake, ten of my favorite Arcade Fire performances, most featured at some time in the past, after the jump; consider it a sort of fantasy concert.

headline: Bank Regulators Under Scrutiny in JPMorgan Loss
text: Scores of federal regulators are stationed inside JPMorgan Chase’s Manhattan headquarters, but none of them were assigned to the powerful unit that recently disclosed a multibillion trading loss.

headline: Facebook’s Brilliant Disaster
text: So I guess you’ve heard about the recent initial public offering that didn’t turn out the way it was supposed to. The company’s Wall Street advisers misjudged the market, and, on its first day of trading, the stock went a little haywire. Then it slowly sank, dropping around 10 percent over the next month.

headline: For Cyclists, Revolution Must Catch Up
text: As someone who rides a bicycle in New York City, I am still waiting for the smartphone revolution.

headline: Unease in Lacrosse Amid Race for Earlier Commitments
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — When the junior varsity boys’ lacrosse team at Chaminade High School faced St. Anthony’s High School on Long Island in New York on Tuesday, a dozen Division I men’s lacrosse coaches were in the stands watching.

headline: Russia: Free Apartments for Injured Police Officers
text: The Moscow city government has promised to provide free apartments to four police officers who were injured during a brawl with protesters on May 6, in another demonstration of officials’ frustration with the antigovernment protest movement. A police spokesman confirmed to the Interfax news agency that the four officers would receive apartments, an extraordinary reward in a city with sky-high real estate prices. State-controlled television gave lavish coverage to the injured officers, who sustained bruises when they were hit by chunks of asphalt flung from people in the crowd. President Vladimir V. Putin’s spokesman, Dmitri S. Peskov, told an opposition lawmaker that “for an injured policeman, the liver of demonstrators should be smeared on the asphalt.”

headline: A Nightclub on Fire Island, Destroyed by Fire, Is on Track for a Rebirth
text: This Memorial Day weekend, visitors to the Fire Island Pines will find the prominent waterfront site long occupied by the Pavilion, the island’s legendary dance club and social hub, to be little more than a forlorn lot containing sand, ashen debris and memories of giddier times.

headline: Nuclear Power After Fukushima
text: The resignation of Gregory Jaczko, the embattled chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, means the country is losing a strong advocate for public safety who was always willing to challenge the nuclear industry and its political backers in Congress.

headline: Drug for Adults Is Popular as Children’s Remedy
text: Since it was first introduced 13 years ago, a drug called Miralax — an odorless, tasteless laxative that can be easily diluted in orange juice or water — has become a staple in many American households.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Suzanne Couture Millinery
text: Suzanne Newman, the owner of Suzanne Couture Millinery, wandered into a millinery shop on East 59th Street in the mid-1980s and found her vocation.

headline: The Lesson of Bain Capital
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign claims to be outraged that President Obama would dare criticize its candidate’s experience of running Bain Capital, a private-equity firm. Some Democratic politicians have also said the president went too far in tarring an important driver of economic growth. The financial price has been high: Mr. Romney’s campaign is reaping unusually generous Wall Street contributions, while Mr. Obama’s campaign is raising far less from the financial sector than it did four years ago.

headline: In Patz Investigation, a Confession Is Not the Final Word
text: The man breaks down and cries and says yes, I did it. I killed that 6-year-old boy 33 years ago. I did it.

headline: Corrections: May 26
text: NEW YORK

headline: Doctors’ Tips for Childhood Constipation
text: ¶ Too much dairy, too little fiber, and too few vegetables and fruits can contribute to constipation. In particular, P-letter fruits may help: prunes, pears, plums and peaches.

headline: Fabulous Hats That Tilt Just So
text: “I WANT the fabulous hat,” Caroline Traugott said with a laugh. “And whatever goes with it, who cares?”

headline: A Game to Help Doctors Ask Tough Questions
text: CHICAGO — As Dr. Danielle McCarthy listens to a man beg for a prescription for painkillers, she weighs her possible responses.

headline: Bodies Built by the Bar
text: Douglas Chapman has developed an acrobatic use of New York City's playground bars, and he runs a league for the sport, which he calls barmetrics.

headline: Edible Floppy Disk
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow, and other such celebratory words, this one was fresh and crunchy. I broke a mild sweat finishing it, but Peter Wentz’s grid is packed with some Scrabbly, sparkling goodness. Don’t miss this one.

headline: Taking the Bar to New Heights
text: DOUGLAS CHAPMAN, 39, beamed as his guys arrived — a dozen muscular men who entered a Bronx gym last weekend and walked right past the weights and exercise machines, and headed instead toward a set of jungle-gym bars.

headline: Knicks End the Waiting and Keep Woodson as Coach
text: Mike Woodson will be the Knicks’ coach next season, and he will almost certainly have Jeremy Lin running his offense.

headline: The Loss of a Friend
text: SPECIAL POST — It is with great sadness that Wordplay announces the loss of a very special person in the world of puzzling.

headline: Alkalinization, Lasix and Milkshaking: A Veterinarian’s View
text: The Kentucky Horse Racing Commission’s hearing on race-day medication last November revealed that Lasix alkalinizes horses, elevating their racing TCO2 values.

headline: Icahn Buys a Stake in Chesapeake Energy
text: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, bought a 7.56 percent stake in the Chesapeake Energy Corporation and demanded a new slate of directors amid growing shareholder concern about the company’s management.

headline: Sharing Outsider Status and a Style of Coping
text: The United States quietly passed a milestone this spring, mostly lost amid the clamor of the presidential race: for the first time, neither party’s candidate is a white Protestant. The contenders are both from outsider groups that were once persecuted, and despite Harvard degrees and notable successes, both men have felt the sting of being treated as somehow strange or different.

headline: The Appeal of Being First in Food
text: Much of the food-snob energy in the city this summer will percolate in street markets, festivals, food truck feedlots and underground events, and revolve around the inaccessible or artisanal, the locally sourced or handcrafted.

headline: Eat, Talk, Tweet
text: DANIEL DELANEY, 26, decided recently that he wanted to smoke and sell brisket, bringing small batches of what he called real Texas barbecue to New York.

headline: The Casino in Central Park
text: A selection of Times articles from the 1920s and ’30s about the Central Park Casino.

headline: Presidential Panel Urges More Flexible Use of Spectrum
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A just-completed report from a presidential advisory committee urges President Obama to adopt new computer technologies to make better use of a huge swath of the radio spectrum now controlled by federal agencies.

headline: Israel Is Anxiously Watching Egyptian Vote
text: CAIRO — Both candidates for Egypt’s presidency have pledged to respect the country’s peace treaty with Israel, but they differ greatly in their approach, especially regarding the Palestinians.

headline: Mets Find There Are Options Other Than Wright in Win
text: For one night, the Mets exorcised their demons. The cleanup hitter who preferred singles hit a home run, the stalwart in a 0-for-15 slump found his swing, the No. 4 pitcher who had mentally stumbled over himself looked unhittable at times and scored the go-ahead run — and Ike Davis hit a two-run single.

headline: The Night Spot That Roared
text: IF I could return to just one moment in New York’s story, I would go back to the Roaring Twenties, with their radiant gatherings in Harlem and the rise of the Chrysler Building, when the city threw its most jubilant parade for Charles Lindbergh, the shy young pilot who, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, had seemingly nothing to do with his generation except allowing us to dream once more of our greatest possibilities. I would watch Babe Ruth round the bases with odd little steps, and at night I would visit the one place to be: the Casino, the elegant night spot in Central Park.

headline: Hefner Remains Only Option for No. 5 Spot in Mets’ Rotation
text: Mets Manager Terry Collins may not know what he has in Jeremy Hefner, a 26-year-old right-hander, but he may have no choice but to keep trusting him. Hefner’s first career start Thursday was as confounding as the No. 5 spot in the rotation that he is trying to stabilize. When Collins was asked about Hefner on Friday, he started his answer by sounding confident, then ended it sounding desperate — mirroring the way Hefner’s first start went.

headline: They Are Taxis, Not Limos
text: Watching the meter climb in New York City’s yellow cabs could get a whole lot more stressful this summer after the Taxi and Limousine Commission raises basic fares for the first time since 2006. (The state added a fee of 50 cents per ride in 2009.)

headline: Lottery Numbers
Capital Punishment’s Latest Folly
text: The history of capital punishment in this country has had many horrifying turnings, few more macabre than a warning from states employing lethal injection that a federal court ruling has left them facing a shortage of the imported drug they rely on to kill death-row felons.

headline: Syracuse Reaches Final by Rallying Past Florida
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Trailing by seven goals in the second half on Friday, No. 4 Syracuse appeared headed toward an 0-3 record in N.C.A.A. women’s lacrosse tournament semifinals.

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York
text: On Sunday, because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect. Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations also will be suspended on Monday because of Shavuot and Memorial Day.

headline: Expression Will Be Free, but Only Partly
text: The resumption of Banner Day on Sunday comes with a proviso: the Mets reserve the right to deny access to the parade to anyone deemed to have an inappropriate banner.

headline: Beach Town of Eclectics
text: A few months ago, I received a letter from someone whose business card, included in his envelope and containing only a small fraction of his résumé, described him as a trained lawyer, educator, speaker, boxing journalist and, perhaps most significant, a historian of Sea Gate. Occupying the western tip of Coney Island, in Brooklyn, Sea Gate is a neighborhood of about 800 or so mostly single-family homes, with two gated entry points.

headline: Kings’ Investment in Doughty Is Paying Off in the Postseason
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. (AP) — Drew Doughty began this season holding out for an eight-year, $56 million contract from the Los Angeles Kings, demanding and getting an enormous sum for a young player with more potential than accomplishment.

headline: Edoardo Mangiarotti, Olympian Fencer, Dies at 93
text: Edoardo Mangiarotti, who won more Olympic medals and world championships than any fencer, starting with the Berlin Games in 1936, died on Friday at his home in Milan. He was 93.

headline: How Sweet It Is
text: In New York, beekeepers are scurrying to keep pace as colonies go into reproductive overdrive and proliferate, spurred by the city’s flowering plants and trees.

headline: H. H. Brookins, Influential A.M.E. Bishop, Dies at 86
text: The Rev. H. H. Brookins, a retired bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church whose role as a civil rights leader and a political kingmaker was clouded by accusations of financial chicanery, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: The Colonies Expand
text: IT’S a busy time of year for bees. As the city’s flowering plants and trees reveal their sweet nectar, colonies go into reproductive overdrive as they build armies large enough to take in the spring flow. And the urban beekeepers tending to these exploding colonies are scurrying to keep pace.

headline: Knicks’ Smith Arrested in Florida
text: J. R. Smith, a Knicks guard with a history of legal trouble, was arrested in Miami Beach, Fla., on Thursday for failing to appear in court on a traffic matter. Smith was cited in May 2011 for operating a scooter without a valid driver’s license and was ordered to stand trial on July 25. When he failed to show, a bench warrant was issued for his arrest.

headline: Shades of Guilt in One Soldier’s Purple Heart
text: The unofficial marker for summer’s beginning is upon us, and beyond the noise of summer barbecues, some will take time to honor the service members who fought and died in our nation’s wars. As a veteran of a recent war, I feel it is important to look past the general niceties spouted over heroic service, and to truly reflect upon the costs of war, and to honor the complexities of the situation that we soldiers are fighting in.

headline: Brain-Damaged Woman Wins Suit Against City Hospitals
text: A Bronx jury awarded about $120 million on Friday to a woman who has been incapacitated since she was treated at three local hospitals in 2004.

headline: Holiday on Monday Memorial Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Devils Advance to Finals After Ending Rangers’ Season
text: NEWARK — On May 25, 1994, the Devils stood on the verge of eliminating the Rangers in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals, but blew a 2-0 lead and lost the game and the series.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,967 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: With a Bipartisan Flurry, Becoming a Do-Something Senate
text: WASHINGTON — For the Congressional chamber where bills usually go to die, the Senate is on something of a roll, passing bipartisan legislation, confirming nominees — and potentially isolating House Republican leaders who have made Senate inaction a centerpiece of their political appeals.

headline: Police Officer in Alabama Is Arrested After Fires
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — A Birmingham police officer with almost three years on the force has been arrested after a series of arsons in abandoned houses in the city and a suburb this month.

headline: In Overtime, Henrique Has Answer
text: NEWARK — Balloting for the Calder Trophy, awarded to the N.H.L.’s best rookie, ended at the conclusion of the regular season, which is a shame for a 22-year-old member of the Devils who has scored not one but two series-clinching goals this postseason. The latest stroke of opportunism by that rookie, Adam Henrique, set off a celebration that echoed throughout Prudential Center on Friday night and a euphoric scrum to the left of the Rangers’ net, in which the puck that he nudged past Henrik Lundqvist at 1 minute 3 seconds of overtime had settled moments earlier, launching the Devils into the Stanley Cup finals with a 3-2 victory.

headline: As Hip-Hop Devotees Come in, Many Miami Beach Residents Prepare to Leave
text: MIAMI BEACH — This small city is accustomed to big events. But every Urban Beach Week, residents and businesses take in a collective deep breath and do not exhale until it’s over.

headline: Grab Your Suit! The McCarren Pool Is Almost Open
text: Once, the pool was an alternative to dips in the city’s filthy waterways. Then, things fell apart and it closed. Now, it is on the verge of a gleaming, new, expensive beginning.

headline: North Carolina: Edwards Jurors Take a Break
text: Jurors in the corruption trial of John Edwards ended their sixth day of deliberations without reaching a verdict and will not come back to court until Tuesday because of the holiday weekend. Before dismissing the jury, Judge Catherine C. Eagles briefly cleared the courtroom of spectators to discuss a “juror issue” with the prosecution and defense lawyers. Once she reopened court, she warned the jurors to discuss the case only when the full complement of 12 was present. “You shouldn’t talk about the case in small groups,” she said. She also planned to resume court at 9 a.m. in case the jury issue needed more attention. Jury behavior has drawn attention in recent days. On Thursday, the four alternate jurors came to court in yellow shirts. On Friday, they wore red. Two of the women alternates also giggled and glanced at Mr. Edwards, prompting speculation by courtroom observers that at least one of them was flirting.

headline: Fatigued or Not, the Rangers Can’t Climb Out of Another Early Hole
text: NEWARK — Inspired by their captain, Ryan Callahan, the Rangers managed to overcome another slow start in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals. But as in their loss two nights earlier, they could not finish the job and lost to the Devils, 3-2, on an overtime goal by Adam Henrique, bringing their season to an end on Friday night.

headline: Lazy, Hazy Summer Days: A Guide
text: New York can be a sweltering concrete jungle in the summer. But the city is also a huge, beautiful playground. And if ever there was a year to schedule a summer “staycation,” 2012 might be it. With food festivals, free concerts and a safe and sanctioned dip into the East River, there is more than enough happening to keep you happily occupied till Labor Day. Whether you are an athlete, aesthete, scholar, theatergoer, concertgoer, tourist or most anything else, here are some suggestions to get you started. STEVEN McELROY

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Rangers-Devils: Game 6
text: A goal 1 minute 3 seconds into overtime sent the Devils to the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: In Cambodia, Sentencing of Women Activists Sparks Outcry
text: Many around the world have died protecting it: land. The issue is highly charged in Cambodia where it flared again last week after 13 women, including a 72-year-old, were jailed for illegal occupation of land and “aggravated rebellion” after demonstrating on the site of their former homes in Phnom Penh, knocked down to make way for a commercial development, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Most Committed Romney Supporter
text: For the past year, Jim Wilson has devoted himself with the single-mindedness of a college-age groupie to following Mitt Romney around the country.

headline: Elephant Rights Movement Clashes With Tradition in Kerala
text: Elephants are revered across India for their majesty and loyalty, personified in the figure of Lord Ganesha, but no Indian state is prouder of its elephants than Kerala. And among Kerala’s elephant lovers, few are as famous for their devotion as the Malayalam movie star who goes by the single name of Jayaram. Mr. Jayaram’s own elephant, named Kannan, is a movie star in his own right, with over 30 South Indian films to his credit.

headline: Back in Oakland, and Back in the Groove
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Yankees have been searching for a consistent winning groove all season, but the only consistency they have shown is their inability to find any, even at home. But if there is one place that seems to generate victories for the Yankees, it is Oakland.

headline: Despite Boos, Chavez Relishes Return to Oakland
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  –  Eric Chavez made his return to Oakland for the first time since he left the Athletics following the 2010 season. But even after 13 successful seasons here, Chavez was booed when he came to the plate for the first time in the Yankees 6-3 victory over the A's on Friday.

headline: Mumbai in the Bad Old Days
text: “Ashim Ahluwalia’s film ‘Miss Lovely’ is set in in the seedy and violent back streets of Mumbai, where he grew up,” Joan Dupont writes in The New York Times.

headline: Dempsey Easing Away From Fulham, With a Nudge From Klinsmann
text: United States forward Clint Dempsey is coming off what might have been the strongest season in Europe  for an American player, and he has a year left on his contract with Fulham. But United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann strongly suggested on Friday that he find himself a new, bigger club.

headline: Beyoncé: Coming Back and Catching Up, Then Conquering
text: ATLANTIC CITY — Beyoncé gave birth to her daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, on Jan. 7, and is now between albums and tours. From a distance, her four-night run of shows through Monday at Revel, on the Boardwalk here, seemed to be functioning as an advertisement for the grand opening of a $2.4 billion casino, hotel, and luxury-shopping cosmos. It was a little unclear what she was going to do for her first post-maternal gig.

headline: The Weekend Word: Memorial Day
text: Today’s Times

headline: Dozens of Children Die in Brutal Attack on Syrian Town
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than 90 people, including at least 32 children under the age of 10, were killed in a central Syrian village, top United Nations officials said Saturday, accusing the government of perpetrating the “indiscriminate” shelling of civilian neighborhoods.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: In the state capital of Srinagar government employees called for a three-day strike on Thursday to demand that the retirement age of employees be increased from 58 years to 60 years, Kashmir Live reported. Additional demands included stabilizing the employment of daily wagers and “removal of pay anomalies,” the newspaper reported. Almost 450,000 state employees did not report to work.

headline: From the Retail World, a Lesson for Racetracks
text: The Doug O’Neill case has given me a flashback into my other life, long ago.

headline: M.L.S. Salaries: A Bigger Pot, but Still Half Full
text: Stumbling across a list of Major League Baseball salaries or a similar list featuring N.B.A. stars is a bit like driving through an exclusive section of Greenwich, Conn., or Beverly Hills, Calif. The amount of money involved is so staggering that it doesn’t seem real.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Robert Pattinson at Cannes
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Vermont Tourist Draw Expands After Storm
text: Nine months after Tropical Storm Irene struck Vermont, causing extensive property damage, the state’s third-largest tourist attraction has been rebuilt. The glassblowing workshop at the popular Simon Pearce Mill in Quechee, Vt., which draws 300,000 people a year, has reopened in a restored and enlarged space.

headline: Postal Service Offers Buyouts to 45,000 Mail Handlers
text: The United States Postal Service said late Friday that it was offering buyouts to about 45,000 mail handlers, part of the financially troubled agency’s efforts to cut its staff and reduce its operating costs.

headline: Belmont Sold Out? Not So Fast
text: When 3,000 reserved-seat tickets were made available online Monday after I’ll Have Another won the Preakness Stakes to keep his Triple Crown bid alive, they were snatched up in about three minutes, causing some to incorrectly assume that the Belmont Stakes was sold out.

headline: From Little League to the Major Leagues
text: As a major league pitcher for 15 seasons, including time with the Red Sox and the Mets, Bob Ojeda had an intense relationship with pain.

headline: The Glory and the Pain of Pitching
text: I’d lived with pain in my left arm since I was 12, when my dad would have me ice it after a Little League outing. My dad, who had pitched in the Army, was something of a pioneer in caring for young arms. Besides, he told me, Sandy Koufax iced his arm.

headline: Gleefully Devoted to Motherhood
text: Mary Lou Retton, the first American female gymnast to win a gold medal in the all-around, was the star of the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. She won five medals, including two silvers, for team and vault, and two bronzes, for uneven bars and floor exercise.

headline: Up for Bid, a Piece of Perfection

headline: The New Political Correctness
text: Remember the furor over liberal political correctness? Yes, some of it was over the top — but it was mainly silly, not something that actually warped our national discussion.

headline: Some Disdain Both Options in Egypt’s Narrowed Race
text: CAIRO — Faced with what seemed like an impossible choice — between a conservative Islamist with a rigid social agenda and a former minister with deep ties to the Mubarak government — Ahmed Abdel Fattah, 33, said he planned to sit out the remainder of the voting for Egypt’s president and hope for better choices in four years.

headline: Rangers Grind to Halt as Deeper Devils Play On
text: When the final blow to their psyche had been dealt and the Devils charged into one corner of the Prudential Center rink to celebrate madly Friday night, the Rangers fell to their knees in front of the net, staring off in a different direction. Their stunned expressions said they had no idea how Adam Henrique had poked home the winning goal, how the Devils had ended their season in overtime of Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: With Personal Data in Hand, Thieves File Early and Often
text: MIAMI — Besieged by identity theft, Florida now faces a fast-spreading form of fraud so simple and lucrative that some violent criminals have traded their guns for laptops. And the target is the United States Treasury.

headline: Spent Fuel Rods Drive Growing Fear Over Plant in Japan
text: TOKYO — What passes for normal at the Fukushima Daiichi plant today would have caused shudders among even the most sanguine of experts before an earthquake and tsunami set off the world’s second most serious nuclear crisis after Chernobyl.

headline: A Fan’s Lucky Day in Cincinnati
text: Caleb Lloyd did not take his baseball glove to Great American Ball Park in Cincinnati last Monday.

headline: Sketching the Wounds of War
text: War is one of art’s oldest muses. A work of art can both bear witness and rewrite history; it can also be a plea not to repeat the past. Our colleague Carol Kino writes that a new genre may be developing at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center via the Joe Bonham Project, a year-and-a-half-old group dedicated to documenting the experiences of wounded service members by drawing their portraits.

headline: Snow Pea Salad

headline: Cameron and the Confidence Fairy

headline: Club Members Learn to Swing More Than 5-Iron

headline: For Many Illegal Entrants Into U.S., a Particularly Inhospitable First Stop
text: EDINBURG, Tex. — For decades, the first stop for illegal immigrants making their way across the Texas border has often been a stash house or drop house, an apartment or rental home where they might spend hours or days in squalor waiting to be transported elsewhere. Often it is where they are held until their families pay the smugglers’ fees.

headline: In Massachusetts Senate Race, Top Democrat Has Rival
text: MIDDLETON, Mass. — As the lone Democrat seeking to challenge Elizabeth Warren in the Senate primary in Massachusetts, Marisa DeFranco has been ridiculed, admonished and, worst of all, ignored.

headline: Pope’s Butler Is Formally Charged With Leaks
text: VATICAN CITY (Reuters) — Vatican magistrates formally charged the butler of Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday with illegal possession of secret documents and said a wider investigation would take place to see if any accomplices had helped him leak them.

headline: Yemeni Army Fights to Retake Town
text: ADEN, Yemen (Reuters) — The Yemeni Army battled militants linked to Al Qaeda in the southern town of Zinjibar on Saturday, recapturing important positions in the rebel-held city and killing at least 62 Islamist fighters, a military official said.

headline: So, Your Idea Hit a Brick Wall. Congratulations!

headline: Standing Out and Blending In
text: Every profile starts with the beard, and why not? It is striking — dense and complex and lush with possibility. It has inspired a movement, a song and a cake. It is a shaggy portal into James Harden’s soul.

headline: Power Shortages Set Off Small Protests in Myanmar
text: BANGKOK (AP) — Numerous small protests have arisen in Myanmar over persistent power shortages as the past year’s democratic reforms have led to rising expectations from a long-suppressed population.

headline: In Peru, Wounds of Civil War
text: More than a decade after Peru vanquished a long-running insurgency, a bid by some former Shining Path guerrillas to form a political party reopened a bitter national debate on the war and how to move on.

headline: Peru Forced to Confront Deep Scars of Civil War
text: LIMA, Peru — During a scorched earth military campaign that threatened to topple the government here, the Maoist guerrilla group known as the Shining Path terrorized Peru with assassinations, bombings, beheadings and massacres. So Peruvians were rattled last year when a group of former guerrillas began collecting signatures to create a political party to participate in the democratic process they had once sought to destroy.

headline: A Family and a Series Seek a Fresh Start at Indy
text: INDIANAPOLIS — A 25-year-old racecar driver, wearing a sponsor’s cap with sunglasses perched on top, a wristwatch almost as big as a saucer and a supply of stubble, talked excitedly last week about his chances of winning the Indianapolis 500 for the first time.

headline: Patrick Takes to Nascar, and Feeling Is Mutual
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Four months into her new life as a full-time Nascar driver, Danica Patrick says she is far too busy to spend much time thinking about the Indianapolis 500. Yes, she watched some of the qualifying on television. No, she does not long to be there.

headline: Quick Getaways, at the Divorce Hotel

headline: As Bank Loans Dry Up in Spain, Small and Medium Businesses Fight for Life

headline: U.N. Observers View Bodies in Syrian Village
text: Last Updated, 9:37 p.m. As my colleagues Neil MacFarquhar and Hwaida Saad report, the United Nations mission in Syria said in a statement that its observers had visited a village near Homs on Saturday and “counted more than 32 children under the age of 10 and over 60 adults killed,” after what Syrian activists described as a government massacre.

headline: For Fastest Man, A Slower Step Toward London

headline: A Taste of Prohibition as Liquor Stores Go Private
text: CASHMERE, Wash. — What is a Memorial Day weekend start-of-summer party without a trip to the liquor store for that special gin Aunt Martha insists upon? Or an extra bottle of whatever-has-a-kick in case the get-together goes into extra innings?

headline: Along a Utah Range, a New Skirmish Over Development or Conservation
text: SALT LAKE CITY — The Wasatch Range, towering over an arid, urban sprawl of a million people, provides two important assets that are increasingly at odds — a vital supply of water for residents and pristine snow for a ski industry that rakes in $1.2 billion a year.

headline: With Santana in Control, Mets’ Bats Awaken
text: On a warm Saturday afternoon at Citi Field, the San Diego Padres became Johan Santana’s playthings.

headline: Watch Where You Turn Up the Volume
text: MEN shouting in trading pits practically define the securities industry, even as electronic trading makes their antics less necessary. There’s a reason that cameras love traders: their yelling conveys competitive urgency, excitement and drama.

headline: Can China Escape the Low-Wage Trap?
text: THE news out of China this year has been relentlessly bad. The political system was embarrassed in front of its own people by the Bo Xilai scandal and in front of the world by the Chen Guangcheng incident. The Chinese economy has slowed and its stock indexes have been rocked, while its neighbors have been strengthening their ties with the United States.

text: Readers discuss questions raised by the Facebook offering.

headline: Dev Patel
text: Dev Patel is a British actor of Indian descent who is best known for his leading role in the 2008 film “Slumdog Millionaire.” His latest film is “The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” which opened in theaters nationwide this week.

headline: Schumacher, Over 40, Still Making History and Confounding Critics
text: MONTE CARLO — Michael Schumacher scored pole position in Monaco on Saturday in his Mercedes at the age of 43 —18 years after his first pole position here in 1994. It was the 69th pole of his career and his fourth in Monaco.

headline: Running From the City
text: MAYBE because I grew up in New York with artist parents, I always saw the city as the obvious place to live a creative life. I went to college in Northern California partly to get away from the constant flow of creative energy — and pressure — in New York, but it didn’t occur to me until I returned home that I might need to be out of the city in order to sustain my creative spirit.

headline: The Betting Window Is Open for Greece’s Future
text: INTRADE is an online betting site with an enviable record for predicting Oscar winners and political events. It’s gotten the last two American presidential elections right. Now it’s wading into the perils of the euro zone.

headline: When Sailing Is Deadly
text: A HIGHLIGHT of the New England yachting calendar is an immensely popular sailboat race called the Figawi. Ted Kennedy used to love to participate. The race, which began in 1972, takes place over Memorial Day weekend and typically attracts more than 200 boats, which sail from Hyannis Port to Nantucket, roughly 30 miles across Nantucket Sound.

headline: This Is How We Ride
text: THIS summer the city’s Department of Transportation inaugurates a new bike-share program. People who live and work in New York will be able to travel quickly and cheaply between many neighborhoods. This is major. It will make New Yorkers rethink their city and rewrite the mental maps we use to decide what is convenient, what is possible. Parks, restaurants and friends who once seemed beyond plausible commuting distance on public transportation will seem a lot closer. The possibilities aren’t limitless, but the change will be pretty impressive.

headline: Albany, Ever Self-Absorbed
text: Pandering to the antitax crowd, Republicans controlling the New York State Senate will not give a number of county governments the authority to raise their local sales taxes — even a small percentage on the dollar. What makes that especially destructive is that many of these communities are struggling financially after an ill-conceived property tax cap imposed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo and legislators last year.

headline: A Disservice to Disabled Troops
text: The Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs have repeatedly promised to do a better job of handling the medical evaluations of wounded and disabled service members. Instead, they are doing worse.

headline: The Phony Regulation Debate
text: American business has always chafed at regulation, but rarely have the cries of outrage been as shrill as during the Obama administration. The United States Chamber of Commerce has moaned of a “regulatory tsunami of unprecedented force” issuing from Washington. Every Republican candidate this year has run on an antiregulatory platform, and one of the loudest has been Mitt Romney, who has promised to immediately tear down President Obama’s “vast edifice of regulations.”

headline: Obama Should Seize the High Ground
text: DURING a recent discussion in Seattle with a group of educators, one of them surprised me when she pointed out that even though their state did not win President Obama’s education “Race to the Top,” that program was critical in spurring education reform in Washington State. As I listened to her analysis, the thought occurred to me: I wonder how Barack Obama would do if he ran for president as himself. ... How he would do if he ran for re-election on all the things he’s accomplished but rarely speaks about.

headline: 2 Reservists Sue Over Army’s Ban on Women in Combat
text: RICHMOND, Va. (AP) — Two women in the Army Reserve have sued the Defense Department and the Army in a bid to reverse military policies barring women from combat roles.

headline: An All-Maryland Final in Massachusetts
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The Maryland men’s lacrosse team and more than a dozen staff members traveled here in two charter buses Wednesday, taking the scenic route.

headline: The Facebook Illusion
text: THERE were two grand illusions about the American economy in the first decade of the 21st century. One was the idea that housing prices were no longer tethered to normal economic trends, and instead would just keep going up and up. The second was the idea that in the age of Web 2.0, we were well on our way to figuring out how to make lots and lots of money on the Internet.

headline: Can State Laws Cohabit With Citizens United?
text: The Supreme Court is expected to respond in June to a Montana Supreme Court decision upholding the state’s Corrupt Practices Act, which bans corporations from making political expenditures from their general treasuries.

headline: Symbol of War, Now an American Teenager
text: A dozen years ago, a girl in Sierra Leone became an unlikely symbol of human depravity. The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof finds she’s now just a typical high school freshman in Washington.

headline: Learning to Chase Online Word of Mouth
text: BUMBLEBEE-STRIPED or polka-dotted, neon orange or neo-argyle, socks of all types are selling out fast on Fab.com, a popular design e-tailer. Gung-ho for hosiery, its fans are even posting sock images on Pinterest and tagging them on Tumblr blogs.

headline: From Tragedy to Triumph
text: To watch the video, press the play button in the bottom-left corner of the image.

headline: The Emotional Tug of Obama
text: FORGET your political affiliation. Never mind your assessment of his time in office so far. If you have any kind of heart, you’re struck by it: the photograph of Barack Obama bent down so that a young black boy can touch his head and see if the president’s hair is indeed like his own. It moves you. It also speaks to a way in which Obama and Mitt Romney, whose campaigns are picking up the pace just as polls show them neck and neck, are profoundly mismatched.

headline: Political Dividends
text: Four years after the 2008 collapse, the finance industry has regained its dominant position in American politics. Perhaps the development of deepest significance is an absence: the failure of a powerful anti-Wall Street faction to emerge in either the House or the Senate. This is in contrast to the response to previous financial crises, when Congress enacted tough legislation — after the Savings and Loan implosion of the 1980s, for example, and more recently after the bankruptcy of Enron and WorldCom in the early 2000s.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 12
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Goodbye to Windows Live (and Whatever It Meant)
text: IF you own a Windows-based PC, you may like the operating system well enough. Or you may merely tolerate it, if you give it much thought at all. But whatever your feeling, “love” probably isn’t the word that immediately comes to mind to describe it.

headline: Houston Community College Helps Expand Educational Options in Qatar
text: DOHA, Qatar — Ahmed Mohamed al-Hassan hit an educational glass ceiling. He needed a higher-education degree to move up the ladder at Aspire Logistics, the company that manages Doha’s massive sports complex. Although he had graduated from high school a decade before, his grade-point average was too low to enroll at Qatar University.

headline: Immersed in Global Business
text: I GREW up in Pumpkintown, S.C., northwest of Greenville, in a house surrounded by cow pastures. There I learned a lot of life lessons, like how to walk through the pastures in the dark.

headline: For Girardi, Cereal Revelations
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Among the topics of conversations before the Yankees played the Oakland Athletics on Saturday afternoon were such vital matters as Mark Teixeira’s reawakening offense, Bartolo Colon’s fastball and Joe Girardi’s year’s supply of Cap’n Crunch cereal, an apparent boyhood gift from the sweet-cereal gods.

headline: State Quarters
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Quiver in your boots, my friends. Byron Walden is back.

headline: Songs of Revenge, a Bartender and Lost Love
text: At the midway point, 2012 is looking like a better-than-average year for high-profile releases from Texas artists. We’ve already seen an array of nationally noted albums from both icons (Lyle Lovett, Willie Nelson) and upstarts (Sarah Jaffe, Kat Edmonson). With the summer touring season about to hit full swing, the coming weeks are also looking robust and promising, with a lineup of records highlighted by a national debut, anticipated new sets from veterans and a pair of subtle reinventions from restless bandleaders.

headline: On Tuesday, Answers Above and Beyond the Winners
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Top Four Slug It Out at U.S. Championship
text: The United States Championship affirmed that there is one big rivalry among the ranks of both the men and the women, and that those four players are head and shoulders above their peers.

headline: In Rarefied Sport, a View of the Romneys’ World
text: As Ann Romney immersed herself in the elite world of riding over the last dozen years, she relied on Jan Ebeling as a trusted tutor and horse scout. In her, he found a deep-pocketed patron.

headline: Tickets Available for Belmont Stakes
text: When 3,000 reserved-seat tickets to the Belmont Stakes were made available online Monday after I’ll Have Another won the Preakness to keep his Triple Crown bid alive, they were snatched up in about three minutes. That led some racing fans to assume that the Belmont Stakes, on June 9, was sold out. But about 400 reserved seats were available for purchase early Saturday at Belmont Park in Elmont, N.Y., and $10 grandstand general-admission tickets are being made available on Ticketmaster for the first time. On race day, grandstand general-admission tickets and clubhouse general-admission tickets for $20 will be available at the track. More coverage at nytimes.com/therail.

headline: Reader Comments on the Girl Who Symbolizes…Resilience!
text: The back story to my Sunday column is that I’ve always been interested in Memuna, because she’s a wonderful example of how an individual story and photos can galvanize the political will to end atrocities. (I’ve tried to use a similar approach to call attention and galvanize opposition to atrocities in other parts of the world, with mixed success.) That visit by Madeleine Albright, and the photos of her holding Memuna — as well as photos of other amputees — helped build the international resolve to defeat the rebellion and eventually prosecute Charles Taylor for crimes against humanity.

headline: That Sound Is a Healthier Teixeira, Delivering One Hit After Another
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — There is an evolving mathematical ratio, in inverse proportion, that is helping the Yankees win baseball games lately. The less Mark Teixeira coughs, the more he hits.

headline: Shannon Miller Is Still a Star
text: CHICAGO — The line to get an autograph from Shannon Miller, the most decorated gymnast in United States history, snaked down a long hallway on Saturday at the University of Illinois at Chicago Pavilion before the U.S. Classic.

headline: U.S. Hopes Assad Can Be Eased Out With Russia’s Aid
text: WASHINGTON — In a new effort to halt more than a year of bloodshed in Syria, President Obama will push for the departure of President Bashar al-Assad under a proposal modeled on the transition in another strife-torn Arab country, Yemen.

headline: U.S. 5, Scotland 1
text: The United States national team opened a five-games-in-18-days stretch on Saturday night with an exhibition against Scotland in Jacksonville, Fla. The biggest surprise in Jurgen Klinsmann’s lineup was the inclusion of Terrence Boyd, a 21-year-old German-American striker, who was given his first start for the senior national team.

headline: U.S. Efforts Fail to Curtail Trade in Afghan Opium
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For years, American officials have struggled to curb Afghanistan’s opium industry, rewriting strategy every few seasons and pouring in more than $6 billion over the past decade to combat the poppies that help finance the insurgency and fuel corruption.

headline: Kings’ Gagne Cleared to Return for Stanley Cup Finals
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — Sometime between Christmas and New Year’s Day, one of the N.H.L.’s leading wings contemplated premature retirement.

headline: Suspect’s Mental History Emerges in Etan Patz Case
text: Pedro Hernandez, the man the authorities say has confessed to killing Etan Patz in a Manhattan bodega 33 years ago, has been prescribed at least one antipsychotic medication for “a number of years,” a person with knowledge of his mental history said on Saturday.

headline: Tunisia Salafis Riot to Protest an Arrest
text: TUNIS (AP) — Hundreds of hard-line Islamists rampaged through a Tunisian town on Saturday, attacking a police station and stores selling alcohol.

headline: African Style Goes Global, Despite Little Tangible Support From African Leaders
text: ACCRA, Ghana — Every day on the downtown streets of Accra, debonair men and fashionable women can be seen proudly attired in Western-style skirts, shirts and slacks, all made from African prints by local tailors.

headline: Liukin Is Back in the Mix
text: CHICAGO — As her signature pink leotard sparkled under the lights and her tuft of blond hair bobbled atop her head, Nastia Liukin hopped onto the balance beam at the U.S. Classic on Saturday and walked right back into the mix for the U.S. Olympic team that will compete in London.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Uneven Showing on Uneven Bars for Bross
text: CHICAGO — Her showing on the uneven bars at the U.S. Classic on Saturday was far from a show-stopper, but it was a step in the right direction for Rebecca Bross, the 2010 national champion who last summer dislocated her kneecap and ruined her chances at an all-around Olympic gold medal.

headline: Carrie Smith, Singer in ‘Black and Blue’ on Broadway, Dies at 86
text: Carrie Smith, a jazz and blues singer who brought a warm stage presence and lustrous voice to Broadway in the musical revue “Black and Blue,” died on May 20 at the Lillian Booth Actors Home of the Actors Fund in Englewood, N.J. She was 86.

headline: Everett Ortner, Leader in Brooklyn Brownstones’ Revival, Dies at 92
text: Everett Ortner who, with his wife, Evelyn, was an early leader in the movement to restore the splendor of 19th-century Brooklyn brownstones after so many had been carved into rooming houses, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Brooklyn. He was 92 and lived in the four-story 1886 brownstone that he and his wife bought in 1963.

headline: Al Gordon, Skit Writer for Benny and Burnett, Dies at 89
text: Al Gordon, an Emmy Award-winning comedy writer whose fast-paced material helped Jack Benny make the transition from radio to television in the 1950s and was later a staple of the Smothers Brothers, Flip Wilson and Carol Burnett comedy shows in the 1960s and ’70s, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 89. His death was confirmed by a spokesman for Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.

headline: Celtics Gain Rematch Against James and Heat
text: BOSTON — The chant started in the final minute. Boston Celtics fans could sense the moment, and they know what awaits them this week. “Beat the Heat!” came from one pocket of the crowd before spreading throughout the arena. A sign on the video screen read, “Bring on LeBron.” The message was clear. Boston is ready for Goliath.

headline: Corrections: May 27
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: U.S. Begins Three Weeks Full of Games by Watching Donovan Collect a Net Full of Goals
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — A Landon Donovan hat trick was the highlight of a masterly performance by the United States national team as it cruised to a 5-1 win over Scotland on Saturday to extend its winning streak to four games with the start of World Cup qualifying fast approaching.

headline: Parents Share Advice for the Constipated Child
text: Miralax — an odorless, tasteless laxative — has become a go-to response for childhood constipation. For constipated children in excruciating pain, Dr. Tricia Jean Gold, a pediatrician in Brooklyn, has no problem recommending Miralax or a PEG generic laxative, which draws water into the colon to soften stool.

headline: Memmel Won’t Make the Team
text: CHICAGO — The cruel reality of just how difficult it will be to make the United States women’s gymnastics team for the London Games came crashing down on Chellsie Memmel — the 2005 world champion — on Saturday after the U.S. Classic.

headline: Hardest Shot in the Game? It’s Any One You Miss
text: What’s the hardest shot in golf?

headline: Liukin Progresses in Comeback Bid
text: Nastia Liukin hopped onto the balance beam at the U.S. Classic in Chicago on Saturday and walked right back into the mix for the American Olympic team that will compete in London. Liukin, the reigning Olympic champion in the all-around, gracefully flipped, twisted and split-jumped above the four-inch beam, receiving a score of 14.9, good enough to tie for third with Sarah Finnegan. Alexandra Raisman and Jordyn Wieber tied for first, with 15 points each. Liukin said she was thrilled with her performance after taking nearly three years off from the sport. More at nytimes.com.

headline: State of Paradox
text: “‘India’ and ‘change’ were once virtual antonyms: old India hands returned again and again in large part because the subcontinent was so dependably different from the West,” Geoffery C. Ward writes in The Sunday Book Review section of The New York Times. “But since 1991, when a financial crisis forced India’s government to devalue the rupee, lower import barriers and relax controls on private investment, things have nearly reversed themselves.”
