headline: Inquiry Ordered Into Deaths of Afghan Family
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Both President Hamid Karzai and NATO commanders ordered an investigation on Sunday into reports that a family of eight had been killed in a coalition airstrike in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: Douglas a Winner Without Winning
text: CHICAGO — Gabrielle Douglas did not win the U.S. Classic on Saturday, but she did seem to get more cheers from the fans than any other gymnast but the Olympic champion Nastia Liukin.

headline: Family Secrets
text: “Tania James is a warmhearted writer,” Emily Cooke writes in The Sunday Book Review section of the New York Times, about the author of “Aerogrammes.”

headline: Secrets of Taming the Wedge
text: While I was asking people to describe the hardest shot in golf, several top golf teachers instead wanted to talk about the shot that recreational golfers misplay most often, which is not the same thing, even if it is related.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Loud Boos Don’t Faze Carlos Reygadas
text: CANNES, France — At 40, Carlos Reygadas is firmly established as the leading enfant terrible of Mexican cinema and a favored son of the Cannes Film Festival. All four of his features, starting with his 2002 debut, “Japón,” have been shown here; on his previous trip, in 2007, he won the Jury Prize (the equivalent of third place) for the Dreyer-inspired “Silent Light.”

headline: Honoring the Exchange of Life for Life
text: The face never comes into view in my dreams, but I know it’s him. The twisted mouth is agape, molded in an eternal gasp of shock. The lower half of his body is gone, and there’s a black hole where his guts should have been. When Chevy was blown from the Stryker hatch, he took flight for an incalculable measure of time before landing on the slat armor of his vehicle. His uniform was blown off, which never happens in the movies. But he was whole, as complete and pure as the day he was born, I’m told. I never got the chance to see for myself before he disappeared into a body bag. The continuing ambush prevented that.

headline: U.N. Security Council Issues Condemnation of Syria Attack
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations Security Council on Sunday unanimously condemned the Syrian government for its role in the massacre of at least 108 villagers, with new details emerging from international observers that appeared to prompt rare Russian cooperation in criticizing its ally in Damascus.

headline: From Massacres to Shortages, Syria Is Under Pressure
text: LONDON — The Houla massacre is being widely described as a turning point in the Syrian uprising. But a turning point to what? Will it finally provide the impetus for unified international action to force a political transition in Damascus or will it mark a slide to full-scale civil war?

headline: The Leprechaun Factor
text: In understanding the Great British Blunder — the Cameron/Clegg/Osborne decision to engage in unforced austerity, which increasingly looks as if it may cripple the UK economy for many years to come — it is, I’m increasingly convinced, crucial to understand the leprechaun factor.

headline: A Poem for Penny
text: A poem written for Penny Chenery, breeder and owner of the 1973 Triple Crown winner Secretariat, and her daughter Kate, all about you know who.

headline: A Few Minutes With Alex Morgan
text: Alex Morgan made her debut for the United States women’s national team in 2010 and quickly established herself as a valuable substitute. Last summer, Morgan came off the bench in five of the six games at the World Cup — scoring in both the Americans’ semifinal win over France and their championship game loss to Japan — but this year she has made a case for a regular starting role with a string of stronger performances. Morgan, 22, is the national team’s leading scorer in 2012 with 12 goals, and her 7 assists on second to Lauren Cheney’s 10. Last week, two months before the Olympic soccer tournament kicks off, Morgan spoke with the Goal blog about her preparations for the Games, her goals for this summer and the one opponent she’s keeping an eye on.

headline: A Caddie in Your Pocket, or on Your Belt
text: Not many of us get to play with a caddie, which is too bad because it is a great, productive pleasure — the confluence of two trying to master a golf course together.

headline: F.A.A. Gives Tips on Seats for the Littlest Fliers
text: The Federal Aviation Administration has recommended using safety seats for small children on flights in recent years, but parents often have a hard time figuring out which ones are best.

headline: In Stunning Tennis Comeback, Scars Show a Career Arc
text: PARIS — The scars remind Brian Baker of the career that never really started. They number five, one for each operation in the six years Baker spent away from professional tennis.

headline: A Lost Bag and a Lost Night, but Not a Lost Cause
text: Those who have misplaced personal belongings on the streets of New York know this: The city does not care if you need your keys or wallet back.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: David Cronenberg on Adapting Unadaptable Books
text: CANNES, France — The Canadian director David Cronenberg has a long and eventful history at the Cannes Film Festival: he has competed for the Palme d’Or three times and was awarded a lifetime achievement prize in 2006. He has also stirred controversy both as a filmmaker (presenting the divisive “Crash” in 1996) and as the president of a jury (in 1999) that was both applauded and attacked for its surprising underdog choices.

headline: Romney Faults Obama After Syria Crackdown
text: 1:56 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney faulted the Obama administration on Sunday for its policy on Syria in the wake of a brutal crackdown in the city of Houla that killed scores of civilians, saying the president has failed to be assertive enough in confronting the Assad government.

headline: Romney Backers Explain Past Criticism of Him
text: Republicans have been assailing President Obama and his re-election team for days for pointedly – and they say unfairly — questioning the private equity experience of Mitt Romney. But on Sunday, three prominent Republicans were called to answer for their own past criticisms of the former Massachusetts governor.

headline: ‘Men in Black 3’ Leads Weekend Box Office
text: This is how high the summer movie stakes have become: “Men in Black 3,” representing the return of Will Smith after a four-year hiatus, took in about $55 million over its first three days in North American theaters — and Hollywood collectively winced.

headline: After Talks Falter, Iran Says It Won’t Halt Uranium Work
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s nuclear chief, reversing the country’s previous statements, said on state television on Sunday that the country would not halt its production of higher-grade uranium, suggesting that the Iranian government was veering back to a much harder line after talks in Baghdad with the West last week ended badly.

headline: Former Mountain Biker From Canada Wins Giro
text: Perhaps it was consolation for Canada’s absence from the Stanley Cup finals. On Sunday, Ryder Hesjedal became the first Canadian to win the Giro d’Italia, or any of cycling’s three major tours.

headline: Facebook Tries, Tries Again on a Smartphone
text: Can a software company build its own smartphone? We may find out soon.

headline: For Tech Start-Ups, New York Has Increasing Allure
text: When Doug Imbruce wanted to start an interactive video company in 2009, he had no luck finding investors in New York. So he moved to Silicon Valley — where venture capitalists were receptive to his pitch — and founded Qwiki.

headline: After the Boos: Reviewing the Cannes Film Festival
text: CANNES, France — On the last day of the Cannes Film Festival, festival attendees swap last-minute guesses about who will win the Palme d’Or and catch up on any of the selections in the main competition during the reprise screenings. By this point, the festival has largely cleared out, save for journalist laggers and, of course, those winners who have stayed in town hoping for a callback to the evening awards ceremony. The market, where thousands of titles are bought and sold by thousands of industry professionals closed Friday, and many journalists are already back home, where doubtless some will decide (as usual!) that this year really wasn’t as bad as it sometimes seemed.

headline: As Euro Bond Wins Supporters, Details Remain Vague
text: FRANKFURT — To euro zone countries in need, euro bonds would be a noble expression of European solidarity and a crucial instrument for preserving the common currency.

headline: Webber Wins Monaco Grand Prix
text: MONTE CARLO — In the end, it was a typical Monaco Grand Prix procession: The man on pole finished first, the man who started second finished second, and none of many potential surprises came to be.

headline: The Jersey Comeback
text: One real problem with living in New Jersey is that the state’s two major cities are, of course, New York and Philadelphia — which means that even if you live here, policy and politics reporting tends to be sparse. So it wasn’t until the latest budget fiasco surfaced that I even knew that Christie was running on the theme of the “Jersey Comeback”.

headline: Sundhage Names U.S. Olympic Roster
text: For the United States Olympic women’s team, it is all a numbers game.

headline: ‘Amour,’ a Wrenching Love Story, Wins at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — Heavy rain dampened the final day of the 65th Cannes Film Festival, but it mattered not at all when the Palme d’Or was awarded to “Amour.” Brilliantly directed with an atypically tender touch by the Austrian director Michael Haneke, this story about an octogenarian husband and wife facing their mortality — beautifully played by the French actors Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva — had left audiences stunned with its artistry and depth of feeling.

headline: Rival’s Gamble Ends in Crash, and Third Win for Franchitti
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The back seat of the convertible was just wide enough for a third passenger to join Dario Franchitti, the 39-year-old Scotsman who had just won his third Indianapolis 500 on Sunday, and Franchiti’s wife, the actress Ashley Judd.

headline: Something to Cluck About – A Bill Endorsed by Egg Producers and Animal Campaigners
text: I love moments when common interests create accord between factions in our society that are otherwise deeply divided. Here’s some news along these lines in a joint release from the United Egg Producers and the Humane Society of the United States about a Senate bill that would, among other things, double the space allotted for each hen in the country’s massive egg industry:

headline: Bacharach and the Beatles: The Sunny Side of the ’60s
text: Were my eyes deceiving me? Or was Jessica Paré of “Mad Men” a last-minute substitute for Jennifer Sheehan at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening? I had to blink twice. But no, it wasn’t Ms. Paré but Ms. Sheehan, the rising cabaret star transformed into Ms. Paré’s doppelgänger for her effervescent new show, “I Know a Place,” an anthology of 1960s songs that takes its title from the Petula Clark hit that led off the evening.

headline: ‘Mommy Wars’ Redux:  A False Conflict
text: The “mommy wars” have flared up once again, sparked most recently by the publication of the English translation of Elisabeth Badinter’s book, “The Conflict:  How Modern Motherhood Undermines the Status of Women.” In it, Badinter argues that a certain contemporary style of mothering — a style that requires total devotion of mother to child, starting with natural childbirth and extending through exclusive and on-demand breastfeeding, baby-wearing and co-sleeping — undermines women’s equality.  Badinter claims that it does this in several ways:  by squeezing fathers out of any meaningful role in parenting; by placing such high demands on mothers that it becomes nearly impossible to balance paid work with motherhood (especially once fathers have been sidelined); and by sending the message that day care, bottle feeding, sleep training and the other things that allow women to combine motherhood with paid work are harmful to children, and that the women who use them are selfish.

headline: A Delay for Duroville’s Replacement
text: A mobile home park that is home to farmworkers in Thermal, Calif., must be shut down, but new homes for the workers have been held up by funding issues.

headline: Budget Crisis Takes Toll on Community for California Farmworkers
text: THERMAL, Calif. — To understand the conditions at the Duroville mobile-home park here, a half-hour drive from Palm Springs, Calif., just look at the windows. Dotting the walls are stretches of plywood, cardboard, blankets and even tinfoil. Replacing the glass just costs too much for many of the residents to consider.

headline: In Bridge, UJA-Federation of New York’s Women’s Philanthropy
text: The world’s most successful single-session charity bridge tournament, the UJA-Federation of New York’s Women’s Philanthropy pro-am, was played on Tuesday at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. Organized by Marci Miron, Nancy Brown, Jennifer Hoine and Jacqui Weidman, the 49th such event raised over $115,000.

headline: Celebrating Marriage, Ancestors and Spirits, With Skips, Swivels and Twists
text: “Don’t be all stiff” was one of many instructions that Chuck Davis issued to the audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday. At DanceAfrica, the festival that Mr. Davis has been running for 35 years, audience behavior — down to the mandatory hugging of strangers — is as important as anything that happens onstage. But the instruction is theater. A DanceAfrica audience needs no reminder to loosen up.

headline: In Tech, East Chases West
text: As technology companies focus more on creating consumer products, New York is emerging as a viable alternative to Silicon Valley.

headline: Never Completely in Control, Dickey Sure Looks Like It Against Padres
text: That R. A. Dickey has become the lone remaining purveyor of the enigmatic knuckleball has not slowed his unending search for mastery over it.

headline: A Composer Who Turned Runway Lights Into Music
text: The International Contemporary Ensemble has contributed handsomely to the Miller Theater’s Composer Portraits series over the years, and when the theater turned its spotlight on Georges Aperghis on Thursday evening the group was on hand to do the honors. The performance had something of a guest star, as well. Ludovic Morlot, the recently appointed music director of the Seattle Symphony, conducted the ensemble in two chamber orchestra works.

headline: She Sells Seashells
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve said this before and I’ll say it again: I’m a fan of Mondays (the puzzle, not the day.) There are those who pooh-pooh these early week grids as being too easy, and they have a point. They’re meant to be an on-ramp to the rest of the week.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: In observance of Memorial Day, the stock and bond markets will be closed on Monday. The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday, and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Guns, Bad Blood and Something About a Dog: Inflaming a Family Feud
text: It’s possible to watch the six hours of “Hatfields & McCoys,” a three-night mini-series beginning on Monday on the History channel, and still be scratching your head over how, exactly, the whole thing got started.

headline: Earning Lasting Fame for Being Anonymous
text: Alcoholics Anonymous has tens of thousands of groups worldwide today, but it had an identifiable beginning with its co-founder Bill Wilson. In their documentary, “Bill W.,” Kevin Hanlon and Dan Carracino recount Wilson’s biography, which is inextricably linked to the developmental history of this lifesaving organization. But this film’s impact is hampered by a slavish adherence to chronology and vintage audio materials.

headline: From 2 Dissimilar Magazines, a Special Design Issue
text: Combining content from two different magazines can make for interesting, sometimes awkward matchups. Consider the risk in joining a magazine that offers readers design tips like how to avoid tripping over a lamp’s electric cord with a magazine that recently ran a 5,600-word cover article on the heart-wrenching decline of an aging parent.

headline: Corona Park, 10:29 A.M.
text: Marine infantrymen from the First Battalion Ninth Infantry interacted with the public after a brief show of their air assault demonstration on Memorial Day weekend in Corona Park, Queens.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Mozart’s ‘Don,’ in a Lunar Landscape, Haunts Gehry’s Hall in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — Maybe it’s because the movies provide this city with more than enough Wagnerian Gesamtkunstwerk. Whatever the reason, even though Puccini’s “Bohème” had its American premiere here in 1897, Los Angeles has never really been an opera town.

headline: Literary Lions Stalk Each Other Through Wars and Across the World
text: Philip Kaufman’s midcareer run of great films, released from the late 1970s through 1990, can be seen as an examination of the varieties of heroism: physical and psychological (“The Right Stuff”), moral and political (“The Unbearable Lightness of Being”), artistic (“Henry & June”), existential (“Invasion of the Body Snatchers”).

headline: Gregg Allman’s Memoir: Sex, Drugs and Southern Rock, in Success and Excess
text: Gregg Allman’s close friends have always called him Gregory. His brother, the guitarist Duane Allman, who died in a motorcycle accident in 1971, called him “baybrah,” a contraction of “baby brother.”

headline: 5 Boys Sing as Thousands Shriek
text: Inside the Beacon Theater on Saturday afternoon a security officer was girding for war: “When they come onstage you have to stay in your seats!” “You can’t go to the front of the stage!”

text: MONTE CARLO — Mark Webber took his second victory in three years in Formula One’s most prestigious race Sunday, and he drove his Red Bull car majestically, winning with style.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be reported this week will include: the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for March and consumer confidence for May (Tuesday); pending home sales for April (Wednesday); ADP employment for May, weekly jobless claims, first-quarter gross domestic product (revised) and the Chicago purchasing managers index for May (Thursday); and unemployment for May, personal income and spending for April, the Institute of Supply Management manufacturing index for May, and construction spending for April (Friday).

headline: Tropical Storm Interrupts Holiday Plans in Southeast

headline: Strong Outing by Kuroda Helps Yankees Extend Winning Streak to Five
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — A visit to Northern California was the perfect setting for the Yankees to extend their modest winning streak. Winning has become a habit for the Yankees at Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum in recent years, and the good fortune continued Sunday as they beat the Athletics, 2-0, for their ninth consecutive victory in this building, and their 13th in their last 14 games here.

headline: Alex Smith, Cam Newton and Judging Quarterbacks
text: 49ers quarterback Alex Smith recently caused a bit of a stir when, seemingly growing frustrated with reporters’ questions about his statistics, he decided to insert Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers into the conversation.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: May 20-May 26
text: Moments from the campaign trail this week, including President Obama’s commencement address at the United States Air Force Academy and Mitt Romney’s visit to Pennsylvania.

headline: Looking to Add to a Legacy Molded on Clay
text: PARIS — It was a private art exhibition on the Left Bank, but it looked more like a rugby scrum in the Stade de France as the pack surrounding Rafael Nadal pushed and pulled for prime position.

headline: In Medicine, Falling for Fake Innovation
text: THE sleek, four-armed “da Vinci” robot has been called a breakthrough technology for procedures like prostate surgery. “Imagine,” the manufacturer says, “having the benefits of a definitive treatment but with the potential for significantly less pain, a shorter hospital stay, faster return to normal daily activities.”

headline: Forecasting Hollywood Academy’s Succession
text: LOS ANGELES — No white smoke rises when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences elects its new president.

headline: Roddick Ousted in First Round; Venus Williams Wins
text: PARIS (AP) — Six major champions made their way through the first round of the French Open on Sunday’s opening day. One did not: Andy Roddick.

headline: Labor Board Member Resigns Over Leak to G.O.P. Allies
text: The National Labor Relations Board announced on Sunday that one of its five members, Terence F. Flynn, had resigned after the board’s inspector general found that Mr. Flynn, a Republican, leaked documents to G.O.P. allies.

headline: A Tiny Florida Outpost Divides Over Getting on the Power Grid
text: NO NAME KEY, Fla. — It is the promise of tranquillity that attracts the hardy few to this tiny wooded island that lies unspoiled off the road to Key West and off the grid altogether. What keeps them here is the pristine fishing, fantastic vistas, ambling Key deer and winter breezes blowing in sighs of contentment.

headline: Azerbaijan Delights in Taking the Stage as Eurovision Host
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — Intent on making a flawless debut on the world stage as the host of this year’s Eurovision Song Contest finals, the government of Azerbaijan left nothing to chance.

headline: Big Fiscal Phonies

headline: Ex-Goalie Relishing Goals as Loyola’s Lacrosse Coach
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — It had been nearly 22 years to the day since the Loyola of Maryland men’s lacrosse team last earned a trip to the N.C.A.A. championship game, and nobody knew this better than Coach Charley Toomey.

headline: Her Game Back Together, Oudin Turns to Off-Court Checklist
text: PARIS — Melanie Oudin has a problem. And for the first time in a long time, it’s not her tennis.

text: If it keeps on raining, levee’s going to break — “When the Levee Breaks,” Led Zeppelin

headline: The Future of Zoos
text: Zoos are increasingly concerning themselves with conservation and saving endangered species, but the effort has limitations.

headline: A Brief for Justice Kennedy
text: THRILLING as it was to hear a sitting president endorse marriage rights for gay and lesbian Americans, there is one man whose opinion on the subject matters more than President Obama’s. Justice Anthony Kennedy is the likely deciding vote when this issue reaches the Supreme Court. More than anyone, he has the power to transform what is now a license bestowed by the more enlightened states into an all-American civil right.

headline: Deciding Which Species to Keep
text: More than 200 American zoos and aquariums have joined an effort to prevent extinction. Zookeepers are now pressed to choose which animals to rescue.

headline: Spurs-Thunder Matchup Is Not Exactly Second Fiddle
text: SAN ANTONIO — For star power and panache, what happens in the Eastern Conference finals between the Miami Heat and the Boston Celtics may be at the center of the N.B.A. universe.

headline: West Point Is Divided on a War Doctrine’s Fate
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — For two centuries, the United States Military Academy has produced generals for America’s wars, among them Ulysses S. Grant, Robert E. Lee, George S. Patton and David H. Petraeus. It is where President George W. Bush delivered what became known as his pre-emption speech, which sought to justify the invasion of Iraq, and where President Obama told the nation he was sending an additional 30,000 American troops to Afghanistan.

headline: Cleaner Energy
text: Last week, President Obama visited a plant in Iowa that builds wind turbine blades to promote his campaign for green jobs and renewable energy — and to hammer the Republicans for not helping the cause. It was the right venue. Iowa is a leader in wind power, which provides about 20 percent of the state’s total electricity, as well as the thousands of jobs that go with it.

headline: Public Pensions Faulted for Bets on Rosy Returns
text: Few investors are more bullish these days than public pension funds.

headline: Mets’ Banner Day
text: Fans’ banners of all shapes and sizes were on display at Citi Field, as the Mets revived a tradition.

headline: The Politics of Religion
text: Thirteen Roman Catholic dioceses and some Catholic-related groups scattered lawsuits across a dozen federal courts last week claiming that President Obama was violating their religious freedom by including contraceptives in basic health care coverage for female employees. It was a dramatic stunt, full of indignation but built on air.

headline: Pensions and the New York City Budget
text: Since 2002, pension contributions have made up an increasingly large portion of total New York City budget expenditures.

headline: In Italy, Technology Is Leading to a TV Transformation
text: PARIS — When Italians said good riddance to Silvio Berlusconi, it turned out that they were ready for more than just a political change. Since Mr. Berlusconi stepped down from his post as prime minister last year, returning to life as a media mogul, the digital era finally seems to have dawned in Italy.

headline: To Save Some Species, Zoos Must Let Others Die
text: ST. LOUIS — With fluorescent yellow eyes and tufts of hair sticking straight up behind their ears, Bonner and Etienne look like slightly crazed old men.

headline: A Failure of Vigilance
text: In the trial of Alex Blueford, an Arkansas jury voted him not guilty on charges of capital and first-degree murder, but deadlocked on lesser charges. By a 6-to-3 vote  last week, the Supreme Court misguidedly ruled that the state can retry him on all charges, including those for murder.

headline: Devils’ Lamoriello Never Tires of Beating the Team He’s Tired of Hearing About
text: Lou Lamoriello, the longest-tenured general manager of a major league team in North America, was preparing for the Devils’ trip to the Stanley Cup finals against the Los Angeles Kings, so he was not inclined to look back, either on his 25 years running the team or on any of its four previous appearances in the finals.

headline: This Memorial Day
text: There was a time, not so long ago, when Memorial Day, and the knowledge that school would soon be ending, was the dock from which we looked out upon the sea of summer. From Memorial Day, to a child of the right age, September looked like some undiscoverable Indies, lying far beyond the visible horizon.

headline: At U.S.C., Media Training for Afghan Students
text: LOS ANGELES — Before he became famous in the media world as the chief executive of MTV, and then its parent, Viacom, Tom Freston had a less glorious career as the proprietor of a clothing company based in Afghanistan.

headline: Obama Finds Campaigning Rules Clock
text: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — By the time President Obama took the stage at the Fox Theater here, he was in the 18th hour of a 19-hour day. His tie was still knotted to the top as he launched into his stump speech, attacking his opponent’s record and defending his own. “I still believe in you,” he said, “and I hope you still believe in me.”

headline: Legislature in Nepal Disbands in Failure
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Nepal descended into a new crisis on Sunday after rival political parties in the Himalayan nation failed to reach an agreement on a new constitution before the national legislature’s term expired at midnight.

headline: Doug Dillard, Bluegrass Banjo Virtuoso, Dies at 75
text: Doug Dillard, a banjo virtuoso who began the 1960s by helping to introduce a generation of listeners to bluegrass and ended the decade as an early advocate of country-rock, died on May 16 in Nashville. He was 75.

headline: French Open Is the Next Stop on a Long Road Back
text: Three years ago, I wrote an article on the unimaginable string of injuries Brian Baker had sustained, as well as the five operations he had in an attempt to get healthy. We talked tennis that day, and I came away impressed not only with his deep knowledge of the game, but also with the stoical way he was handling the unfairness of losing the best years of his tennis career to one injury after another.

headline: Londoners Dread Traffic as City Plans Olympics
text: LONDON — London’s commuters have been warned to expect gridlock on the roads and paralysis on the subways. They have been advised to leave home well before rush hour; to travel by foot, bicycle or boat; and to forget about trying to drive anywhere even remotely connected with the Olympics.

headline: A Rare Haven for Gay Men and Lesbians in Harlem
text: In a church nestled among a row of residential brownstones, parishioners clapped and danced as a woman began to testify.

headline: Glatch Overcomes Tatishvili and Darkness
text: PARIS — In fading light at Roland Garros, Alexa Glatch of the United States found herself unable to solve a riddle: how could she put away Anna Tatishvili of Georgia in straight sets before darkness sent them into the locker room?

headline: Sticking Around, Showing the Way
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — Had circumstances been different, Dustin Brown could have spent the first round of the playoffs with the Vancouver Canucks.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Golden Gate Bridge Celebrates 75 Years
text: The Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco is celebrating its diamond jubilee this Sunday. For the past 75 years, the 1.7-mile suspension bridge has not only connected the northern tip of San Francisco to lush Marin County headlands, it has also become one of the most recognized American icons. The yearlong celebration is aptly titled “Bridging Us All.”

text: One property, in the Hudson Valley, includes a 16-car garage, a piggery and hundreds of yards of lake frontage.

headline: Frustrations Grow as U.S. and Pakistan Fail to Mend Ties
text: WASHINGTON — When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met Pakistan’s president at the NATO summit meeting in Chicago last week, the two spent most of the meeting talking politics, and Mrs. Clinton was nothing if not blunt.

headline: U.S. Women’s Team Nearing Olympics on Strong Note
text: CHESTER, Pa. — Pia Sundhage’s singing is not new. Sundhage, the coach of the United States women’s soccer team, has incorporated music into her team addresses in the past, and she took her (very) Off Broadway act global last summer, when she infused a news conference at the Women’s World Cup in Germany with a few bars from Simon & Garfunkel’s “The 59th Street Bridge Song (Feelin’ Groovy).”

headline: On an Inconspicuous Brooklyn Block, a Curious Nickname and Hobbit Doors
text: Outsiders call it the street with little doors. That is, if they know it at all, because Dennet Place, a tiny lane near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is something of a secret. It can evade GPS, and even some people who have lived nearby for years have never heard of it.

headline: Dennet Place
text: A small block in Brooklyn is something of a secret.

headline: 80,000 at Opposition Rally as Georgia Nears Crossroads
text: MOSCOW — Opponents of the president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, staged a sprawling political rally in the capital on Sunday in a stronger-than-expected opening to their campaign for a parliamentary election scheduled for this fall.

headline: Stuttgart Shows Confidence in a U.S. U-20 Prospect
text: As the season has now drawn to a close in Europe’s major leagues, many players will be looking for new clubs, but United States under-20 team forward Jerome Kiesewetter is already ahead of the curve: he just signed a four-year professional contract with Stuttgart.

headline: Kahne Takes Coca-Cola 600 for 3rd Time After Biffle Dominates Much of Race
text: CONCORD, N.C. — After Jimmie Johnson won the Southern 500 on May 12 to deliver victory No. 200 to Hendrick Motorsports, he presented the team owner Rick Hendrick with a helmet signed by almost all of the drivers who had won races for the team over nearly 30 years.

headline: Spurs Finish Strong for 19th Straight Win
text: SAN ANTONIO — The San Antonio Spurs looked closer to early retirement than in their ability to keep up with the Oklahoma City Thunder for three quarters Sunday night. Unable to cope with the flash of their younger opponent, the Spurs dipped deep into their reservoir of experience and guile.

headline: Dissident, in U.S., Concerned for Brother After Return to Chinese Village
text: BEIJING — The older brother of Chen Guangcheng, the persecuted rights advocate who left China for the United States this month, is back in the family’s home village after evading guards there to travel to Beijing to meet with a lawyer, an American legal scholar who is advising Mr. Chen said Sunday.

headline: Northwestern Women Extend Their Hold on N.C.A.A. Title
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Capping a week filled with milestones, Northwestern Coach Kelly Amonte Hiller won her seventh national lacrosse title in eight years Sunday night as the No. 2 Wildcats defeated No. 4 Syracuse, 8-6, in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament final.

text: The day in sports, including surfing in South Africa, racing in Monaco and Indianapolis, and rugby in London.

headline: In Battle of Neighbors, Falconi Prevails
text: PARIS — Irina Falconi of the United States roared back from a faltering first set to defeat Edina Gallovits-Hall of Romania, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1, in the first round of the French Open.

headline: A New Crisis for Nepal
text: “Nepal descended into a new crisis on Sunday after rival political parties in the Himalayan nation failed to reach an agreement on a new constitution before the national legislature’s term expired at midnight,” Kiran Chapagain and Jim Yardley write for The New York Times.

headline: Antiwar Protester Disrupts Inquiry as Blair Testifies
text: LONDON — It has been 15 years since Tony Blair entered office as the most popular British prime minister in modern memory, and five years since he left the job in a climate of opprobrium so dire that he opted to virtually disappear from his country’s public life, turning to a life as a richly rewarded world traveler, diplomat and consultant.

text: They have the power to steal your breath, provoke tears. They might overwhelm and inspire you, bring you to your knees, even.

headline: Three Years After Cyclone, Changed Lives in Sundarbans
text: CHUNAKHALI, West Bengal — May 25 was Ayantika Mandal’s third birthday. At her home on May 23 in Chunakhali, on the Indian side of the Sundarbans Delta, she changed into her dotted white dress for a picture, but refused to smile to the camera. “She is shy with strangers,” said her mother, Rina. “Otherwise, she is extremely talkative.”

headline: Valuing Domestic Product
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: International Pressure on Syria Grows After Killings
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — International efforts to pressure Syria intensified on Monday, as the United Nations special envoy Kofi Annan began negotiations in the capital, Damascus, and the chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff warned that continued atrocities could make military intervention more likely.

headline: Christie’s Case for Sports Betting in New Jersey
text: “If someone wants to stop us, then let them try to stop us. We want to work with the casinos and horse racing industry to get it implemented. Am I expecting there may be legal action taken against us to prevent it? Yes. But I have every confidence we’re going to be successful. We intend to go forward.” Chris Christie

headline: Responses to ‘An Open Letter to India’s Graduating Classes’
text: “Today, we regret to inform you that you are spoiled,” an Indian partner for a multinational corporation wrote in “An Open Letter to India’s Graduating Classes,” a bracing wake-up call for India’s new job market entrants. India’s graduates are neither as smart as they think they are, the author, Mohit Chandra, wrote, nor as ambitious or self-motivated as they should be. Their English skills are poor and they are unprofessional, he said.

headline: Zoos Raise Money for Faraway Animals
text: Zoo Boise, a small city zoo in Idaho, receives a lot of praise in the zoo community for its commitment to and success in raising money for conservation programs aimed only at animals in the wild — a goal many zoos aspire to but do not necessarily follow through on.

headline: Readers’ Memorial Day Rituals
text: Last week we asked you, our readers, to send us your Memorial Day rituals and traditions. You came through with great feeling, subtly and depth. Some of the rituals focused on remembrance, some on respect for our men and women of the armed services. All were heartfelt. Here are a selection of them. Happy Memorial Day.

headline: Greeks Unite Against Lagarde After ‘Tax-Dodgers’ Jibe
text: LONDON — Christine Lagarde, the International Monetary Fund chief, has succeeded in generating some rare unanimity in crisis-hit Greece with remarks in which she described the Greeks as tax-dodgers.

headline: Monday Reading: Identity Thieves File Taxes Early and Often
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: When Costly Medical Care Just Adds to the Pain
text: In talks about reducing the nation’s exploding health care costs, the “R” word — rationing — strikes fear into the hearts of both patients and doctors.

headline: A Memorial Day for War’s Fallen, Perhaps Someday for War Itself?
text: I wrote a song in the early 2000’s called “Arlington,” which partly retells the remarkable history of the nation’s last resting place for its fallen defenders but also notes that the cemetery has been running short of space. I’ve posted a new video version on YouTube to mark Memorial Day:

headline: Spain’s Borrowing Costs Rise as Bank Woes Deepen
text: MADRID — Spain’s borrowing costs approached record highs on Monday as investors fretted over how the government would find additional money to bail out Bankia, the country’s largest mortgage lender, and other troubled banks.

headline: Anglophone Potential (Wonkish)
text: As I get ready for my UK visit, one thing I’ve been puzzling over is the contrast in views between the US and the UK over the amount of economic slack. In the US, structuralist obsessives aside, there’s widespread agreement that we have a large gap between actual and potential GDP. In the UK, there’s much more pessimism.

headline: Reflections on the Revolution in Egypt
text: According to preliminary results for the first round of presidential elections in Egypt, the runoff in June will oppose Mohamed Morsi, of the Muslim Brotherhood, and Ahmed Shafik, the last prime minister of ousted President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Lady Gaga Apologizes for Canceled Show in Indonesia
text: Lady Gaga apologized over the weekend to her fans in Indonesia after a sold-out concert she planned to perform in Jakarta was canceled amid threats of protests and violence from Islamic hard-liners, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Russia’s Temps
text: MOSCOW — On Sunday I suggested to my 13-year-old son that he join me on a bike ride. I am an obsessive, possibly excessive, cyclist, and I wanted to take Vova on a respectable 18-mile trip to show him some of the beautiful paths around our country house.

headline: Tibetan Capital Sees First Self-Immolations
text: BEIJING — One man died and another was seriously injured when they set themselves on fire outside Tibetan Buddhism’s holiest temple in the center of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, according to Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency. It was the first time that such protests against Chinese rule have occurred in the city.

headline: Li Na Overpowers Cirstea
text: PARIS — A year ago, Li Na of China was the toast of Roland Garros, the winner of the 2011 French Open women’s singles title. But this day at Roland Garros, she was merely the defending champion, seeded seventh, expected to reach the quarterfinals at best.

headline: Who’s Minding the Store at Belmont?
text: Just in time for the most interesting Belmont Stakes in recent years, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has seized control of the New York Racing Association, the entity that operates the state’s three major-league racetracks, Belmont, Saratoga and Aqueduct.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: Girls, You Really Got Him Going
text: Season 5, Episode 10

headline: Taking His Doctor’s Advice Could Cost a Combat Veteran His Apartment
text: After Eugene Ovsishcher returned from a nine-month combat tour in Afghanistan, he experienced what his doctors called symptoms of post-traumatic stress: nightmares, flashbacks and a pervasive anxiety. A psychiatrist advised him to get a dog, and last August he did — a shaggy, mocha Shih Tzu puppy that Mr. Ovsishcher named Mickey because he crawled like a mouse.

headline: Sales From the Crypt: Presley Tomb to Be Auctioned
text: While there are many unique items being offered at a sale of pop-music memorabilia scheduled for next month by Julien’s Auctions in Beverly Hills – a robe worn by Amy Winehouse in her video for “Rehab”; a cigarette packet signed by the Beatles; Chinese ceramic dogs from the collection of Meat Loaf – one suspects the artifact that is going to generate the most interest is the crypt where Elvis Presley was first laid to rest before his body was buried at Graceland.

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Maryland’s Bernhardt Isn’t on the Field, but He’s Still a Presence
text: Drew Snider doesn’t like to reflect on games much. The Maryland Terrapins men’s lacrosse midfielder prefers to move on quickly, to focus on the next opponent as soon as the final whistle sounds.

headline: Japan’s Former Leader Condemns Nuclear Power
text: TOKYO — In an unusually stark warning, Japan’s prime minister during last year’s nuclear crisis told a parliamentary inquiry on Monday that the country should discard nuclear power as too dangerous, saying the Fukushima accident had pushed Japan to the brink of “national collapse.”

headline: N.C.A.A. Preview: Loyola Finds Its Defensive Power
text: The Loyola Greyhounds men’s lacrosse team earned a spot in Monday’s national championship game after an impressive 7-5 win over Notre Dame in the national semifinals on Saturday.

headline: A Tough Judge’s Proposal for Fairer Sentencing
text: WASHINGTON — Judge John Gleeson hears cases where he used to prosecute them, in the federal courthouse in Brooklyn. There, in 1992, he led the team of prosecutors that put the Mafia boss John J. Gotti in prison for life.

headline: Isner Makes Quick Work of Dutra Silva
text: PARIS — It wasn’t Goliath versus David, but it came close, and this time, David was definitely in over his head.

headline: Numberplay: Frog in Well
text: A frog finds itself at the bottom of a well 10 feet deep. Each day the frog climbs three feet up the side of the well. During the night the frog slips back two feet. How many days will it take the frog to get out of the well?

headline: Image of the Day: May 28
text: A Sufi festival in Rajasthan.

headline: It’s Not a Slam, but the Olympics Are Major
text: PARIS – Tennis returned to the Summer Olympics in 1988, in Seoul, South Korea, after a 64-year absence. In those days, the sport as an Olympic event was far less important on the calendar than it is now.

headline: Remembering the Crew of a Lost Chinook
text: On May 30, 2007 – two days after Memorial Day – an American CH-47 transport helicopter, known as a Chinook, was shot down by insurgents near the Helmand River in southern Afghanistan. The crash killed seven soldiers: five Americans, a Briton and a Canadian.

headline: Shots Fired, Pinpointed and Argued Over
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — At 7:22:07 p.m. on a recent Thursday, an electronic alarm went off in the soundproof control room of a suburban office building here.

headline: 7-Eleven Finds a Niche by Adapting to Indonesian Ways
text: JAKARTA — As night falls, groups of twenty-somethings gather at a trendy hangout, chatting at tables laden with beer, iced coffee and nachos. Some couples cuddle over chocolate pudding, while others groove to music on their iPhones.

headline: Analyzing Royalty’s Mystique
text: Next week, after the confetti from Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee celebration has been swept from the streets of London, more than 100 scholars will convene at Kensington Palace to ponder a phenomenon as puzzling as it is familiar: the robust survival of the British monarchy in a democratic age that long ago consigned similar institutions to the gilded dustbin of history.

headline: On a Fishing Trip, Casting for Striped Bass, and Reeling in a Tautog
text: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I. — One axiom of saltwater fishing in New England is that tautog, those thick and dark-toned fish of inshore reefs and submerged boulder fields, do not strike jigs. They are too busy, the thinking goes, nosing for the lobsters, crabs, mussels and clams that crowd their jagged habitat to bother with the passing imitation of a fish.

headline: It’s Not a Slam, but the Olympics Are Major
text: On the London 2012 blog, Greg Bishop writes that when tennis returned to the Summer Olympics in 1988, in Seoul, South Korea, after a 64-year absence, the sport as an Olympic event was far less important on the calendar than it is now. Players at the French Open have already altered their calendars and practice schedules to accommodate the Olympics this summer in London, held on the famous grass courts at Wimbledon, shortly after the Wimbledon tournament itself. There is an incentive to do well there, both for ranking points and national pride. Read the full story here.

headline: For Jankovic, a Lower Rating Is Motivation
text: Monday morning on a half-filled Court 2, No. 19 seed Jelena Jankovic recovered from a miserable first set to defeat 82nd-ranked Patricia Mayr-Achleitner 1-6, 6-1, 7-5, moving onto the second round of the French Open far less easily than she might have anticipated.

headline: Tending to Bodies Near the Breaking Point
text: COMBAT OUTPOST RAHMAN KHEL, Afghanistan — Each week, Capt. Rachel Odom takes off in a helicopter to fly to yet another distant military outpost of this mountainous region of eastern Afghanistan to patch the troops in her care back together.

headline: Medina Garrigues Overwhelms Robson
text: PARIS — Laura Robson is the darling of British tennis, a tall, talented teenager who drew an appreciative crowd at Roland Garros Monday. From the stands, a mature baritone sang: “We love you, Laura, we do.”

headline: In Cambodia, a Start-Up Combines Web Sales Skills and Hair Extensions
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — For an Internet start-up, Arjuni faces more challenges than usual.

headline: Candidate’s Offices Burn Amid Egypt Demonstrations
text: CAIRO — The presidential campaign headquarters of Hosni Mubarak’s last prime minister burst into flames Monday night as demonstrators marched in the streets protesting that former official’s confirmation as one of two candidates to advance to Egypt’s runoff election.

headline: When the Stars Roamed Shubert Alley
text: Blame it on John F. Kennedy.

headline: Veterans Stick With the Republican Nominee
text: President Obama never served, and neither did Mitt Romney. For the first time since World War II, neither presidential nominee is a military veteran. But polling suggests that veterans still have a strong preference for the Republican candidate.

headline: Looking For Risks In All The Wrong Places
text: Slides for my LSE talk tomorrow here (pdf).

headline: Chinese Man Kills Himself to Protest Son’s Death in Tiananmen Sq.
text: BEIJING — A Beijing man has hanged himself to protest the government’s refusal to account for his son’s death in a military assault on the 1989 Tiananmen Square demonstrations, a group that seeks justice for victims of the assault said Monday.

headline: Mundell and the Euro
text: Mark Thoma sends us to David Warsh on Robert Mundell, which is worth it just for the link to the MIT economists family tree.

headline: Top Seed Azarenka Struggles in Her Opener
text: PARIS — So Victoria, how is your French?

headline: U.S. Open Cup: Charleston vs. Red Bulls
text: The Red Bulls take their six-game unbeaten streak in Major League Soccer south to Charleston, S.C., to face the Battery on Tuesday night in a third-round match of the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup. The match will not be available on television but will be streamed live (7:30 p.m. Eastern) on the Internet at uslnation.com.

headline: Virus Infects Computers Across Middle East
text: 9:09 p.m. | Updated A complex computer virus has been pilfering confidential information from computers in the Middle East for at least two years, according to a security report released on Monday.

headline: Expert Links Dolphin Deaths to Sonar Testing
text: Did offshore oil exploration play a role in the recent deaths of nearly 900 dolphins off the northern Peruvian coast? Peru’s fisheries minister said last week that government scientists had ruled that out as a possibility and that the dolphins probably died of natural causes. But a marine veterinarian and conservationist who examined many of the corpses contends they were probably harmed by sound waves from seismic tests used to locate oil deposits.

headline: The Enigma 1,800 Miles Below Us
text: As if the inside story of our planet weren’t already the ultimate potboiler, a host of new findings has just turned the heat up past Stygian.

headline: Fire Spreading From Play Area of Mall in Qatari Capital Kills 19, Including 13 Children
text: Nineteen people, including 13 children, died Monday in a fire that raged through an upscale shopping mall in Doha, Qatar’s Interior Ministry said.

headline: The Science Times Podcast
text: Venus’s moment in the sun; a canine detective story; and a pilgrimage to the heart of medicine.

headline: The Structure and Movement of the Deep Earth
text: The dynamic motion of the Earth’s interior helps shape its surface — and ultimately makes life on the planet possible.

headline: Turkish Court Indicts 4 Israeli Military Leaders
text: JERUSALEM — An Istanbul court approved indictments on Monday against four senior Israeli military figures for involvement in a deadly raid on a Turkish passenger vessel trying to breach Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza in May 2010. In response, a senior Israeli official said the Turkish government had apparently decided to kill what was left of the diplomatic relationship between the two countries.

headline: Loyola Soaks Up Feeling of a Breakthrough Title
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — There was none of the glitzy offensive attack that had been its mark most of the season for Loyola of Maryland. Instead, its men’s lacrosse team led a defensive clinic in the N.C.A.A. championship game, shutting down Maryland, 9-3, for its first-ever title in front of 30,816 at Gillette Stadium on Monday.

headline: Hamas Takes Step Toward Palestinian Unity Government
text: Ismail Haniya, the Hamas prime minister in Gaza, made the first step on Monday toward ending his group’s disputes with the Palestinian Authority, which governs in the West Bank, and creating a unity government.

headline: Really? Flying Can Cause Mountain Sickness
text: THE FACTS

headline: Crackdown on Chinese Bloggers Who Fight the Censors With Puns
text: BEIJING — One of China’s largest hosts of Twitter-like microblogs decreed new punishments on Monday for users who post comments that its editors — and by extension, China’s government censors — deem inappropriate.

headline: The Mighty Tick
text: Q. If deer ticks were eradicated, would it hurt the ecosystem?

headline: Chess Championship Goes Into Overtime After Another Draw
text: The world chess championship match between Viswanathan Anand, the titleholder, and Boris Gelfand, is heading to overtime.

headline: European Union Poised to Release Report Cards on Member Budgets
text: BRUSSELS — As leaders in Germany and some other euro zone countries press for tighter coordination of the region’s borrowing and spending policies, European Union officials on Wednesday will take an important step in that direction by issuing report cards on national budget plans. Poor marks could eventually mean fines or other penalties for members that do not make adequate efforts to balance their books.

headline: Russian Chief of an Uneasy Joint Venture With BP Resigns
text: MOSCOW — Mikhail Fridman, a billionaire who has clashed with BP in a number of corporate governance disputes over the years, resigned Monday as chief executive of the British oil company’s joint venture in Russia.

headline: Stubborn Infection, Spread by Insects, Is Called ‘The New AIDS of the Americas’
text: Chagas disease, caused by parasites transmitted to humans by blood-sucking insects, has been named “the new AIDS of the Americas” in a lengthy editorial published in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases.

headline: A Mini Sub Made From Cheap Parts Could Change Underwater Exploration
text: This month, NASA engineer Eric Stackpole hiked to a spot in Trinity County, east of California’s rough Bigfoot country. Nestled at the base of a hill of loose rock, peppered by red and purple wildflowers, is Hall City Cave. For part of the winter the cave is infested with large spiders, but is mostly flooded year-round. Locals whisper the cave’s deep pools hold a cache of stolen gold, but Mr. Stackpole isn’t here to look for treasure.

headline: Waking Up to Major Colonoscopy Bills
text: Patients who undergo colonoscopy usually receive anesthesia of some sort in order to “sleep” through the procedure. But as one Long Island couple discovered recently, it can be a very expensive nap.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee
text: This week Britain is celebrating the 60th anniversary of the Queen’s coronation.

headline: Judging Tony Nominees by Their Dance Numbers
text: To see how hard it is to judge choreography in musicals, you need only watch all four of this year’s Tony nominees. What criteria are involved? In ballet and modern dance, choreography is the shaping factor, the ingredient that brings music, subject matter and performance together into a whole; in a musical, that’s seldom so. But the great choreographers are great directors too: inventors of their own genres of theater.

headline: A Swedish Love Triangle, With Some Slight Revisions
text: August Strindberg isn’t the first playwright who springs to mind when the phrase “comedy of manners” is uttered. Depending on how boisterous you find Georg Büchner and Neil LaBute, he may be the last.

headline: Employees Are Getting the Word About Safer Driving
text: The signs dotting the parking lot outside the Owens Corning headquarters in Toledo, Ohio, make the company’s new policy clear: “No cell phone while driving.”

headline: Baker Adds Another Victory to His Comeback Story
text: PARIS — Brian Baker’s improbable tennis comeback story continued Monday, with a straight-set victory in the first round of the French Open.

headline: In Wild Animals, Charting the Pathways of Disease
text: BOZEMAN, Mont. — High in the Wallowa Mountains of northeastern Oregon, Raina K. Plowright and other researchers blindfolded and hobbled a herd of bighorn sheep in a corral so blood samples could be taken and their noses and throats swabbed.

headline: Young Players Raise Horns to the Hunt
text: The programs that the impressive New York Youth Symphony presents at Carnegie Hall are typically ambitious and substantive. So it was on Sunday afternoon, when the orchestra played its final concert of the season, the last to be conducted by Ryan McAdams, who has ended his five-year tenure as music director. The main work was Mahler’s Symphony No. 5 in C sharp minor, a complex, craggy and demanding score lasting some 75 minutes. And Mr. McAdams drew an energetic and involving performance from the inspired players, who range in age from 12 to 22.

headline: New Releases From Travis Porter and Melody Gardot
text: TRAVIS PORTER

headline: Journalism, Old and New, Entangled on the Web
text: Take “Scoop,” Evelyn Waugh’s classic sendup of journalism, and replace its hero, a clueless nature columnist, with a perky Bridget Jones gal, move the time frame from the 1930s to 1997, and you’ve got a pretty good idea of what Annalena McAfee’s first novel, “The Spoiler,” aspires to be.

headline: Gothic Tale Scored in Twists and Turns
text: Among the operas of Benjamin Britten’s extraordinary canon, it is the larger ones that attract the most attention: “Peter Grimes,” “Billy Budd” and “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” turn up regularly in prominent houses worldwide. “The Turn of the Screw,” Britten’s 1954 adaptation of the Henry James novella concerning restless ghosts and corrupted innocents, is smaller, subtler and less widely exposed.

headline: On Memorial Day, Romney and McCain Appeal to Enthusiastic Veterans
text: SAN DIEGO — Mitt Romney warned veterans here to avoid putting America “on the pathway of Europe” by reducing the size of the military to pay for social programs.

headline: Inwood, 12:38 P.M.
text: David McCarrie and his son Matthew, 3, watching the wreath laying ceremony after the American Legion Memorial Day Parade in Inwood.

headline: Babies’ Hunger to Learn Has a ‘Goldilocks Effect’
text: Infants are constantly trying to make sense of the world around them, and they do this by seeking out situations that are neither too simple nor too complex.

headline: U.N. Report Says Rwandans Recruited to Fight in Congo
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — As the Democratic Republic of Congo teetered on the edge of civil war three and a half years ago, its tiny neighbor to the east, Rwanda, was accused of stirring the conflict by supporting a Congolese rebel leader.

headline: Vatican Allows That Butler Scandal Is Hurting Trust
text: The Vatican acknowledged Monday that the newest crisis in Pope Benedict XVI’s papacy was damaging trust in the church, even as it tried to contain a scandal that has sent the Italian news media into a frenzy since the pope’s butler was arrested days ago and accused of leaking the pontiff’s confidential correspondence.

headline: Learning to Heal, One Memorial Day at a Time
text: PFLUGERVILLE, Tex. — They had no plan, really, just memories. So after a few moments of awkward indecision, the young men ambled single file up to a simple gravestone to pay their respects. Each left behind a red or pale yellow rose, a mumbled word or a salty tear. Lance Cpl. Nickalous N. Aldrich, the stone read. Born Aug. 12, 1983, in Austin. Died Aug. 27, 2004, in Iraq.

headline: Organ Helps Coordinate Feeding in Some Whales
text: The group of whales called rorquals gulp vast amounts of water, then expel it through their comblike baleen plates to filter out millions of fish for consumption in seconds.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,971 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: A Silhouette of Venus
text: From sketches of the 1761 transit of Venus to satellite photographs of the 2004 event, a look at historical observations ahead of the June 5 transit.

headline: Look Now for Venus to Cross the Sun, or Wait Another Century
text: PHILADELPHIA — Observing the dark circle of Venus cross the face of the Sun on June 3, 1769, from his farm about 20 miles northwest of here, David Rittenhouse left a curious gap in his account of that day.

headline: Steep Fall in Death Rates Among Diabetics
text: Death rates among people with diabetes have declined substantially in recent years, according to a survey conducted by researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health.

headline: $8.5 Billion Deal for Calling Service Presents a Puzzle
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — By some measures, Tony Bates has accomplished a lot at Skype since Microsoft paid $8.5 billion for the Internet calling service.

headline: Folic Acid Tied to Lower Rate of Two Childhood Cancers
text: Folic acid enrichment of grain products has significantly reduced the rates of neural tube defects in infants. Now a new study suggests a further possible benefit: a reduction in rates of two types of childhood cancer.

headline: Method of Delivery May Affect Obesity Risk
text: Babies delivered by Caesarean section may have an increased risk of obesity by age 3, a new study has found.

headline: Howie Richmond, Music Publisher, Dies at 94
text: A hit song is not born but made. No matter how clever the lyrics, no matter how catchy the tune, no song climbs the charts on its own. To become a hit — or to have even a chance of becoming one — a fledgling pop song needs a behind-the-scenes campaign as tireless and well choreographed as any military offensive.

headline: Mets Are Short-Handed at Shortstop After Loss
text: For the Mets, the past week had been among their best of the season, featuring back-to-back shutout performances by Johan Santana and R. A. Dickey and a string of five victories in six games.

headline: Johnny Tapia, Champion Boxer Amid Chaos, Dies at 45
text: Johnny Tapia, a prizefighter who won world titles in three weight classes in a chaotic life that included jail, struggles with mental illness, suicide attempts and five times being declared clinically dead as a result of drug overdoses, was found dead at his home in Albuquerque on Sunday. He was 45.

headline: Spelling Out the End
text: Washington

headline: Greek Voters Tilt to Right, but Many Urge Caution
text: ATHENS — Four opinion polls conducted last week in Greece found that a right-leaning political party that has largely advocated staying the course under the harsh terms of the country’s financial rescue plan had surged ahead of its leftist competitor in popularity.

headline: Missing Couple’s Legacy: Shards of Hope
text: In 1979, Laurie Sylvia’s daughter, Camden, was graduating from high school, a summer — an entire future — ahead of her. Her mother looked at the smiling boy’s face on the milk carton and thanked the heavens that her daughter was not a vulnerable 6-year-old anymore. She was safe.

headline: For Movies, Some Immigrants Still Choose to Hit Rewind
text: South Korean immigrants flowed into Hwang Jae Video in Queens on a recent afternoon, dropping off their rentals and picking up new ones. Beloved South Korean soap operas, including “Dumb Mom” and “Delicious Life,” were especially popular.

headline: Ackerman Endorses Assemblywoman to Succeed Him
text: Representative Gary L. Ackerman, who unexpectedly announced in March that he would not seek re-election to Congress, is venturing into the primary contest to succeed him, backing the candidate he says best embodies his values: Assemblywoman Grace Meng.

headline: Getting a Hockey Education During the 1993 Finals
text: The route lined by the 4,000 fans who turned up at the airport in the dead of night last week to greet the Stanley Cup finals-bound Los Angeles Kings formed a kind of Nostalgia Lane for those of us old enough to remember when their high-scoring rookie left wing was Warren Rychel instead of Dwight King.

headline: After Facebook, More Fear of Stock Market
text: The excitement surrounding Facebook’s initial public offering was enough for Alex Tsesis, a law professor, to give the stock market one more try. But after the company’s stock encountered technical problems then sputtered for three days, he sold his few hundred shares for a $2,200 loss and vowed to end his equity gambles for good.

headline: Our Imbecilic Constitution
text: Advocating the adoption of the new Constitution drafted in Philadelphia, the authors of “The Federalist Papers” mocked the “imbecility” of the weak central government created by the Articles of Confederation.

headline: Investor Doubts Constrain a Russian Oil Powerhouse

headline: Obama Begins Commemoration of Vietnam Era
text: WASHINGTON — Barack Obama was still in the crib, just 5 months old, when American helicopters swooped out of Saigon into the jungle in January 1962 carrying South Vietnamese troops on a raid. It was the first time American forces participated in major combat in Vietnam, opening a chapter in history that reverberates to this day.

headline: VHS Loyalists
text: VHS tapes have long been declared dead. But in New York City’s immigrant communities, from South Asian to Senegalese, those chunky workhorses of the past still endure.

headline: Canadian Official Offers Bill to End Railway Strike
text: OTTAWA — Canada’s labor minister introduced legislation on Monday to end a strike by about 4,800 workers at the Canadian Pacific Railway. Lisa Raitt, the minister, said the move was necessary to prevent more economic damage from the six-day walkout.

headline: The Role of Uncle Sam
text: From the dawn of the republic, the federal government has played a vital role in American economic life. Government promoted industrial development in the 18th century, transportation in the 19th, communications in the 20th and biotechnology today.

headline: Shares Fall in Europe, Gain in Asia
text: PARIS — European stocks mostly fell on Monday, dragged down by worries about Spain and its banking bailout that caused Madrid’s benchmark index to slide more than 2 percent.

headline: U.S. Winds Down Longer Benefits for the Unemployed
text: Hundreds of thousands of out-of-work Americans are receiving their final unemployment checks sooner than they expected, even though Congress renewed extended benefits until the end of the year.

headline: Long-Term Joblessness Still a Problem
text: The number of people out of work more than six months has declined a little, but it remains far higher than it was before the recession.

headline: Arguments for Most Police Street Stops, and the Math, Don’t Hold Up
text: I grew up in the New York City so often invoked as the horror to which we might return if the police stopped illegally frisking hundreds of thousands of black and Latino men.

text: This is the sixth in a series of writing lessons by the author, starting with the basics and leading to more advanced techniques.

headline: Taking Up 4,486 Flags for Slain Soldiers, but Holding On to Their Memory
text: MILTON, N.Y. — For the past eight years, the emerald-green hillside by Caren Baker’s home was covered with a growing number of small yellow flags, each of them representing one of the 4,486 United States service members killed in Iraq.

headline: End of the Charade
text: The airwaves are already filled with blaring political attacks masquerading as “issue ads,” such as the one in Missouri in the United States Senate race that ends with: “Call Claire McCaskill. Tell her Missouri doesn’t need government-run health care.” This ad, and dozens like it, is sponsored by the United States Chamber of Commerce, which likes to claim that it is merely educating voters about the issues rather than telling them how to vote.

headline: The Simplicity Solution
text: Time to fess up: With the two-year anniversary of the passage of the Dodd-Frank financial reform law approaching, I’m still not sure what to think about the darn thing.

headline: In Far Northwest, a New Border Focus on Latinos
text: FORKS, Wash. — The Olympic Peninsula has always felt more like the edge of the world than a mere national boundary.

headline: Money From Colleagues Buoys Rangel Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — For years, Charles B. Rangel was among the Democratic Party’s most generous colleagues, crisscrossing the country to raise vast sums of money for other House candidates at election time. Now, as Mr. Rangel faces one of the toughest races of his career, he is among the party’s neediest.

headline: Logistics Hang Over a Ruling on 9/11 Cancer
text: About five years ago, Patricia Workman’s bones started breaking, and she was found to have multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow. At the same time, her skin cancer started to proliferate, leaving her face so scarred that she needed reconstructive surgery and still hides it with dark glasses.

headline: Unsafe Behind Bars
text: After a three-year delay, the Justice Department has finally issued mandatory rape prevention policies for federal prisons and state correctional institutions that receive federal dollars. The new rules, which were given the force of an executive order, are a clear improvement over a draft version. If monitored and enforced, they could help curb the assaults that are shamefully endemic to the corrections system.

headline: You Can Change the Channel, but Local News Is the Same
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex. — Call a reporter at the CBS television station here, and it might be an anchor for the NBC station who calls back. Or it might be the news director who runs both stations’ news operations.

headline: Lottery Numbers
New Breed of Products Is Said to Offer Sun Protection, but Doubts Linger
text: Can a laundry detergent laced with sunscreen turn your clothes into protection from harmful ultraviolet rays? How about a shampoo that claims to do the same?

headline: Traveling This Summer? Leave the Weaponry Behind
text: “SUMMER’S almost here!” the Transportation Security Administration’s chatty blog is currently informing us. That means more people at the checkpoints, of course.

headline: When Do Kids Become Adults?
text: Do the age requirements for certain rights — voting, drinking, legal consent — need to be lowered or raised? Shouldn’t they at least be consistent?

headline: Political Money Talks
text: As Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin faces a well deserved recall vote next month after stripping public unions of their bargaining rights, voters are discovering the generosity of Diane Hendricks. Ms. Hendricks, the billionaire chairwoman of the nation’s largest roofing and siding wholesaler, wrote a check for $500,000 last month to help defend Governor Walker, a Republican, against his Democratic challenger, Tom Barrett, the mayor of Milwaukee.

headline: Madoff Case Is Paying Off for Trustee ($850 an Hour)
text: Irving H. Picard, the court-appointed trustee seeking to recover funds for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, has been described as a modern-day Robin Hood. For nearly four years, he has been working to pay back those who were swindled by Mr. Madoff, some who lost their entire life savings.

headline: Where the United States Lags Far Behind Canada
text: NEW YORK — In yet another celebratory moment for gays and lesbians, last week came the news that the first gay Marvel comic-book superhero, a Canadian called Northstar, will marry his boyfriend in an upcoming issue of “Astonishing X-Men.”

headline: The Best and the Brashest
text: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — Connor Fields lounged on his BMX bike this month at the Olympic Training Center. While most of his fellow riders met with representatives from Oakley, Fields surveyed the track, a replica of the one riders will race on at the London Olympics, and noted his disdain for goggles.

headline: Location for Some Quick Calculations
