text: NATIONAL

headline: Pujols Is Starting to Look Like His Usual Fearsome Self
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Oakland Athletics pitcher Travis Blackley, an Australian left-hander who is always fighting for a job, was going into the set position on the mound last week, and as he brought his glove to his waist to throw the first pitch to Kendry Morales, he had a thought very few people in this world can share.

headline: A Fair Way to Handle Trash
text: In his first term, Mayor Michael Bloomberg mapped out an equitable plan to get rid of 11,000 tons of New York City garbage every day. The complex proposal was designed to make each borough take care of its own trash. It was also supposed to help limit noisy garbage trucks going long distances through the city to reach marine barges, railways or out-of-state trash facilities.

headline: Dewey & LeBoeuf Files for Bankruptcy
text: Dewey & LeBoeuf, the law firm crippled by financial miscues and partner defections, filed for bankruptcy on Monday night, punctuating the largest law firm collapse in United States history.

headline: Virtual Therapy Helps Residents of a Shellshocked City
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Every time Erica González put the video goggles on, the details of her four days in captivity came rushing back to her. She could smell the sweaty T-shirt used to cover her head, taste the ash in the beer bottles that she was made to drink water from and hear her abductors’ muffled conversations.

headline: For Rangers, Questions About More Firepower and the Future of a Top Assistant
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers, who fell two wins short of the Stanley Cup finals, need to add another top scorer, Coach John Tortorella hinted on Monday, which was breakup day at the team’s practice center.

headline: Former Beijing Mayor Denies Responsibility for Tiananmen Square Crackdown
text: Chen Xitong, who was the mayor of Beijing when the military cracked down on students and other protesters in and around Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989, has denied years of accusations that he turned Deng Xiaoping, China’s principal leader at the time, against the protesters and then played a key role in organizing the military assault, according to a new book. The book, “Conversations with Chen Xitong,” which goes on sale in Hong Kong on Friday, is by Yao Jianfu, a Chinese scholar, who writes that he spoke with Mr. Chen eight times since early last year.

headline: Russian Foreign Ministry Criticizes American Envoy
text: Russia’s Foreign Ministry released an unusual statement on Monday criticizing the American ambassador, Michael A. McFaul, saying that a talk Mr. McFaul gave to Russian students last week “went far beyond the boundaries of diplomatic etiquette.” The statement revived criticism leveled at Mr. McFaul when he arrived, accusations that he had come to Russia to foment revolution.

headline: Bahrain: Activist to End 110-Day Hunger Strike
text: A detained human rights activist, Abdulhadi al-Khawaja, announced Monday that he would end his 110-day hunger strike, saying in a statement that he had achieved his “goal of shedding light on the ongoing human rights situation in Bahrain.” Mr. Khawaja and at least 20 other dissidents remain in prison on charges related to their participation in an uprising against the ruling monarchy that began in February 2011. Another well-known Bahraini rights activist, Nabeel Rajab, was released on bail Monday, according to his lawyer. Mr. Rajab was arrested in early May on charges that included organizing protests and insulting the authorities on his Twitter account.

headline: Spurs Find Ways to Keep Streak and Mission Going
text: SAN ANTONIO — He’s a gawky, angular mass of elbows and knees, slicing toward the basket like a knife passing through brisket. Manu Ginobili is left-handed, too, which further befuddles defenders closing in on him.

headline: China: Communist Party Expels Former Railways Chief
text: The Communist Party expelled the government’s former railways minister, Liu Zhijun, who became ensnared in a 2011 corruption inquiry that raised questions about the nation’s huge investment in a high-speed rail network, state-run media reported. The Xinhua news service said Mr. Liu had “major leadership responsibility for the serious corruption problems seen on the railways system.” The corruption case against him has been turned over to prosecutors and the courts, the news service stated.

headline: Russia: 3 Are Charged Over Protest Violence
text: Russia’s Investigative Committee charged three people Sunday and Monday with inciting unrest and attacking riot police officers during clashes between the police and antigovernment protesters earlier this month. According to investigators, 18-year-old Aleksandra Dukhanina was arrested in Moscow on suspicion of instigating violent confrontations. Two men were arrested late Monday; the authorities said they broke through a police line, struck officers with their legs and arms and threw objects at them. Ms. Dukhanina is the first protester to face stiff penalties, including up to 10 years in prison, in connection with the violence during the demonstration.

headline: For Williams, Illness Lurks as Persistent Foe
text: PARIS — On her worst days, when Venus Williams struggled to climb out of bed, when her depleted energy reserves allowed for all of 10 minutes of tennis practice, she belted out songs from Whitney Houston and Mariah Carey.

headline: Heat’s James and Wade Continue Domination
text: MIAMI — Five summers ago, the Boston Celtics created a new model for title contention. Two summers ago, the Miami Heat duplicated it, with parts that were newer, shinier , springier, and guaranteed that the Eastern Conference playoffs would never lack for epic star power.

headline: Hunter Returns to Angels After Son’s Arrest
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Torii Hunter, a Los Angeles Angels outfielder, returned to the team Monday after spending two weeks with his family after the arrest of his son in connection with a sexual assault case.

headline: Euro Isn’t Loved, but Few Want to Drop It, Poll Says
text: BRUSSELS — More than two years into a euro crisis that has toppled governments and sown economic pain, citizens of five euro zone countries — including Greece — say the euro has not been a good thing for them, but nevertheless do not want to go back to their old currencies, according to a survey to be released Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | appurtenance
text: appurtenance •\ə-ˈpərt-nən(t)s, -ˈpər-tə-nən(t)s\• noun

headline: Michelle Obama Reveals How Her White House Garden Grows
text: Every so often, a flash of Michelle Obama’s humor comes through in her otherwise serious book about the White House garden and her campaign against childhood obesity, “American Grown: The Story of the White House Kitchen Garden and Gardens Across America,” which goes on sale Tuesday.

headline: The Baby Hawks Take Flight
text: Updated, 1:07 p.m. | The adolescent hawk stars of the live reality raptor series broadcast live from New York University’s Bobst Library, named Boo and Scout, fledged on Monday night after nearly 50 days of life.

headline: Egypt’s Election: David Kirkpatrick Answers Readers’ Questions
text: First of all, thanks so much for your questions on Egypt’s historic presidential elections. Here are my best answers to some of the best questions. There is a long road ahead — as the violent anger over the results of the first round of the election showed last night — and I look forward to continuing the conversation.

headline: Fresh From Kolkata, ‘Bengali Style’ Emerges
text: Since the 19th century, the Bengali capital, Kolkata, has been known for some of India’s greatest artists, like the filmmaker Satyajit Ray and the writers Rabindranath Tagore and Bankim Chandra Chattoapdhyay. During the British rule, the Bengal School of Art was famous for its nationalistic yet avant-garde style.

headline: Indian Premier League Saves Best Cricket for Title Game
text: “Manvinder Singh Bisla entered the Indian Premier League final as probably the least heralded of the 22 players who took part,” Huw Richards writes in The International Herald Tribune. “By the time it was over, he was a lot more famous — and potentially in line for a much bigger payday next season.”

headline: Angels’ Homer in Ninth Ends Wild Night Against Yankees
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The first sign that this would be a strange and compelling game came on the 12th pitch of the game when Angels ace pitcher Jered Weaver staggered in pain for no apparent reason in the top of the first inning.

headline: News Quiz | May 29, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Assessing Obama’s Counterterrorism Record
text: Officials in Obama administration and others outside, interviewed in recent months about President Obama’s counterterrorism record, said real progress had been made against Al Qaeda but also acknowledged lingering concerns about a fight that has shaped the United States’ approach to much of the world for the last decade. Excerpted below are remarks from some of nearly 40 current and former officials who had direct knowledge about the United States’ classified counterterrorism efforts.

headline: Striking Al Qaeda
text: President Obama inherited the drone program but drastically increased the number of strikes.

headline: Secret ‘Kill List’ Proves a Test of Obama’s Principles and Will
text: WASHINGTON — This was the enemy, served up in the latest chart from the intelligence agencies: 15 Qaeda suspects in Yemen with Western ties. The mug shots and brief biographies resembled a high school yearbook layout. Several were Americans. Two were teenagers, including a girl who looked even younger than her 17 years.

headline: A Pakistani Observes From the Indian Side of the Wagah Border
text: “I was not allowed to sit in the foreigner’s section, given that I didn’t look foreign, and I didn’t want to tell them that I was,” Saim Saeed writes in The New York Times. “This was ironic, given that — as a Pakistani sitting on the Indian side of the border — they would consider me to be even more foreign than most foreigners.”

headline: American Zoos Give Up on Indian Macaques
text: “With fluorescent yellow eyes and tufts of hair sticking straight up behind their ears, Bonner and Etienne look like slightly crazed old men,” Leslie Kaufman writes in The New York Times.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 29, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “100 Missing After Riverboat Full of Russian Families Sinks.”

headline: Western Nations, Protesting Killings, Expel Syrian Envoys
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United States joined with 10 other nations to expel top Syrian diplomats on Tuesday, increasing international pressure on President Bashar al-Assad. In Damascus, the United Nations envoy said the uprising had reached “a tipping point” after a massacre of more than 100 villagers, nearly half of them children.

headline: Tensions Rise as Tiananmen Anniversary and Tibetan Holiday Approach
text: As the summer heat builds in Beijing, so too, traditionally, does the tension leading up to June 4, the anniversary of the night in 1989 when democracy protests at Tiananmen Square were crushed by the military, killing hundreds of civilians.

headline: Your Veil Is a Battleground
text: Kiana Hayeri grew up in Tehran, where the country’s morality police restricted her public behavior. She left in 2005 when she was 17 and moved to Toronto, where she studied photography at Ryerson University.

headline: U.S. Says 2 Slain in Raid Were Qaeda
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — American military officials said on Tuesday that two militants killed in eastern Kunar Province on Sunday were members of Al Qaeda.

headline: Philippine Chief Justice Removed Over Omission in Report on Assets
text: MANILA — The chief justice of the Philippine Supreme Court, Renato C. Corona, was removed from office on Tuesday in a landmark conviction that could strengthen the president’s hand in cracking down on the endemic corruption that has long been a drag on the economy.

headline: More on 2012 College Admission Yields and Wait-List Offers
text: June 7 | Updated  This post now includes data from Dickinson College, the College of William & Mary, and the University of Pennsylvania.This month, we shared some preliminary data on admissions yield percentages, which represent the students who are taking the colleges up on their acceptance offers and intend to show up this fall.

headline: Republican Keynesians
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Massachusetts Debates ‘Death With Dignity’
text: The memorial service for Michael Southerland recently drew more than 200 people to the Unitarian Society in Northampton, Mass. Friends, neighbors and co-workers offered funny and moving stories.  They sang; they cried. They hugged his wife and daughters.

headline: What Cuts Should Cash-Strapped Schools Make?
text: Schools and municipalities across the country are dealing with budget cuts. Is your school affected? How about other schools in your community? Have programs or other initiatives been cut? If so, what has been the public’s reaction?

headline: India Reaches Out to Myanmar
text: India is moving quickly to cement new trade and diplomatic ties with Myanmar during Prime Minister Manmohan Singh’s visit this week.

headline: Marubeni of Japan to Buy Gavilon for $3.6 Billion
text: TOKYO — Marubeni, the Japanese trading house, said on Tuesday that it would buy the American grain merchant Gavilon Group for $3.6 billion, as it looks to ship American agricultural products to fast-growing Asian markets.

headline: Deadly Earthquake Hits Northern Italy
text: ROME — Less than 10 days after an earthquake struck the Emilia-Romagna region of northern Italy, a 5.8-magnitude tremor shook the area on Tuesday morning, killing at least 14 people, officials coordinating rescue efforts said. The latest earthquake destroyed more buildings and once again tested the fortitude of an already unsettled population.

headline: As Tamil Nadu Nuclear Plant Opening Nears, Protests Enter ‘Death Throes’
text: Ostensibly short stories have an unfortunate way of mutating into epic tragedies here in India – and, occasionally, farces.

headline: This Week, Talk of Bain, Jobs and Bipartisanship

headline: Coughlin Better Than Belichick?
text: The Sporting News recently listed “the coaches heading into next season from No. 1 to No. 32,” and ranked the Giants’ Tom Coughlin at No. 1.

headline: A Start-Up Shifts Gears to Try to Seize an Opportunity
text: A previous post introduced Deirdre Lord, an owner of The Megawatt Hour and a new member of the She Owns It business group. Her company offers an online subscription service that helps commercial and industrial clients manage, track and forecast their energy use and expenses. When we met in early May, Ms. Lord was scrambling to take advantage of a significant — and time-sensitive — marketing opportunity.

headline: London Hedge Fund Chief Fined $4.7 Million
text: LONDON — British financial regulators have issued a £3 million ($4.7 million) fine against Alberto Micalizzi, the chief executive of the defunct London hedge fund Dynamic Decisions Capital Management, the largest fine ever by British authorities in a case that did not involve market abuse.

headline: A Tighter Focus Yields Dividends for Penguins
text: While in St. Louis reporting out Monday’s article on how zoos are struggling to adapt to the worldwide extinction crisis, I met Fidget and Shadow, a pair of Humboldt penguins.

headline: On the Romney Plane, Where Even Small Talk Is Loaded
text: CRAIG, Colo. — Mitt Romney wants to talk about potato salad. And for a few minutes, anyway, so do the reporters who travel with him.

headline: Daily Report: $8.5 Billion Skype Deal Presents a Puzzle
text: Skype, the biggest acquisition in Microsoft’s history, will ultimately be judged by whether Microsoft can weave the product deeply into its vast product portfolio, providing a superior experience on products as various as Windows PCs and Xboxes. In that regard, Tony Bates, who was previously the chief executive of Skype and became president after the deal, and his Microsoft colleagues have not yet delivered, reports Nick Wingfield of The New York Times.

headline: Israel Gets the Blame for Flame Virus
text: LONDON — No prize for guessing who is getting the blame – or should that be the credit – for creating a new spyware super bug reported to have infected computers throughout the Middle East.

headline: It’s a Place, Not a Conflict
text: WASHINGTON — Sitting on the edge of my hotel bed here two Sundays ago, I watched a “60 Minutes” segment on Tel Aviv, the place I call home. It made me think two unkindly thoughts. One, they — that is, the people of “60 Minutes” — must have come up with this ultra positive story on the city that Lonely Planet ranks “the third hottest” in the world to compensate for the negative and very controversial story on Israel’s treatment of Palestinian Christians they broadcast in April. Two, even in a report supposedly about civilian life, about being chic and fashionable, Israel isn’t portrayed as a country; it’s portrayed as a conflict.

headline: Marina Keegan, Student Journalist Who Took On Wall St., Dies at 22
text: Marina Keegan, a student journalist and playwright who once wrote a guest column for DealBook, died on Saturday. She was 22.

headline: Give a Girl a ‘Hook,’ Get Her Into College
text: An article appeared in The Daily Beast a few weeks ago that should be sending a certain type of modern parent into apoplectic helicoptering overdrive. It seems that college acceptances at top institutions were especially rough this year on “unhooked white girls,” or as the writer Steve Cohen explained:

headline: Kenya’s Forever War
text: NAIROBI — A bomb exploded in downtown Nairobi on Monday — the eighth such attack in as many months. It was a far more sophisticated operation than the makeshift grenades that have been tossed from moving cars and into small churches and bars in the recent past. This bomb was big enough to send at least 30 Kenyans to the hospital.

headline: Young Scientists Embrace Crowdfunding
text: Crowdfunding, or appealing to the online community for funds for personal projects, seems to be thriving. One of the best-known platforms is Kickstarter, which generally features projects that are creative in nature – musicians seeking to record an album, for example, or inventors pursuing an idea.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Shared News on Local TV, and Saddam Hussein’s Memoirs
text: In dozens of cities, TV stations share a newsroom, broadcasting identical local news items, Brian Stelter writes, in a cost-saving effort that is similar to what has happened at some local newspapers. But the cooperation in local TV news has gone largely unnoticed. The Federal Communications Commission said it did not know how common the practice was, though its chairman, Julius Genachowski, indicated last week that the commission was beginning to study the issue.

headline: Tuesday Reading: When Costly Medical Care Adds to the Pain

text: Omar White is 12 years old, bright and horribly behind in his classes at Cornerstone Academy for Social Action Middle School in the Bronx. That is because he spends most of the time out of his class.

headline: Mapping the Glass Ceiling
text: We’ve written before about how the gender pay gap grows with age. Generally speaking, the older a woman is, the wider the gap between what she earns and what her male counterpart earns.

headline: Shackleford Shines in Thrilling Met Mile
text: Last year’s Preakness Stakes winner, Shackleford, took the Grade I Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park on Monday in what many observers will note as the horse race of the year. The Met Mile was deep in quality, with Caleb’s Posse, To Honor and Serve and Jackson’s Bend taking on Shackleford, who recently won only his first race since his Preakness victory last year.

headline: All-or-Nothing Draft Lottery for the Nets

headline: An Ancient Civilization, Upended by Climate Change
text: The Vedas, a collection of texts composed over 3,000 years ago in India, speak of a mythical sacred river called the Sarasvati from which the Hindu goddess of science and learning emerged. Hers was a river “surpassing in majesty and might all other waters.” But around 4,000 years ago, all was lost when climate change kicked in.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/29: A Gondola Battle Out West and the Algonquin’s Face-Lift
text: Ski Wars A bill that would allow developers to build a gondola linking the base of the Solitude ski area in Salt Lake City and the upper part of the Canyons ski area in Summit County and would result in the sale of 30 acres of public land faces a competing bill that would preserve the very land that is required for the gondola. (The New York Times)

headline: Motorsports: With Trio of Wins at Indy, Franchitti Joins Exclusive Club

headline: Ephemeral Islands
text: The date is April 15, 1986. Eighteen American F-111 jets are hurtling towards Libya from bases in England. Operation code name: El Dorado Canyon. Its purpose: to exact revenge on the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi — 10 days earlier, a bomb ripped through a Berlin discotheque popular with American servicemen, killing a civilian and a soldier and wounding hundreds more [1].

headline: Slouching Toward Corinth
text: In late April 1862, in the aftermath of the Battle of Shiloh, the largest military force ever assembled in North America — a 125,000-man, three-army Union leviathan under the command of Maj. Gen. Henry Halleck — set out slowly from Pittsburg Landing, Tenn., not far from the battle site. Its objective was Corinth, Miss., 22 miles to the south and defended by a 53,000-man Confederate force under Gen. Pierre G. T. Beauregard.

headline: TimesCast | Russians Stocks Struggle
text: Profitable Russian companies, including oil giant Surgutneftegaz, struggle with low valuation by foreign investors.

headline: Surveying a Lobster’s Reach
text: Maine lobsters are relatively inexpensive and plentiful these days, an especially welcome development for summer. And for an explanation, along with much more about them, there is “The Maine Lobster Book.”

headline: Frozen Treats, All Year Round
text: December is not the best time to sell a strawberry-rhubarb ice pop. So People’s Pops, a Brooklyn company that specializes in deeply fruity frozen confections on a stick that are made mostly with Greenmarket ingredients, closes its many market stalls and outdoor stands around New York during the colder months. The same goes for its bright new shop (in photo) in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which will be open only until late October, reopening next May. But now, with expanded production facilities gearing up, the company will soon produce enough pops to sell to grocery stores. So yes, we’ll have strawberry-rhubarb in the snow.

headline: Young and Global Need Not Apply in Japan
text: TOKYO — Ronan Sato, a graduate student in applied statistics at Oxford, has always been keen to work in his native Japan. But at a careers fair for overseas Japanese students, he found that corporate Japan did not return his enthusiasm.

headline: Brews and Bites Off the Usual Track
text: Suppose you are deep downtown, where Canal Street and the Lower East Side disappear into blocks of apartments past Seward Park, and you crave a beer. No, not just a Corona, but maybe something artisanal, like Ithaca Beer, from upstate. Kevin M. Heald’s smartly tailored little shop, Malt & Mold, is there to help. With his beard and hat, Mr. Heald (shown), 43, looks every bit the monger of cheese and beer he calls himself. He has assembled about 50 craft beers, mostly domestic, and a well-curated assortment of cheeses, also artisanal and American, along with some imports like taleggio. Pickles and chocolates from Brooklyn, yogurts, vinegars, crackers and cured meats line the shelves and display cases. For now, the beers are in bottles and cans; eight tap lines, and growlers in various sizes, await a state permit. The shop may be out of the way, but it is the only local retailer for the excellent sweet and savory knishes from Knishery NYC, a new company; for salami by Charlito’s Cocina, of Long Island City, Queens; and for ice cream from the Bent Spoon, of Princeton, N.J., which shares the freezer with Blue Marble, Adirondack and Van Leeuwen.

headline: Istomin Dominates Kunitsyn
text: PARIS — Denis Istomin, a Moscow resident who represents Uzbekistan, overwhelmed Igor Kunitsyn, a Russian from Vladivostok, in a first-round match at the French Open, 6-3, 6-1, 6-2.

headline: A Black Student Journalist Discovers in Turkey Her Color Is the Story
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — When my University of Illinois journalism class was preparing to depart for a three-week reporting trip to Turkey, I wondered how my “African-ness” would come across to Turkish people. My parents are Nigerian immigrants, which makes me Nigerian-American. For most of my childhood, I’ve been in the minority. Most of the people in my hometown are Caucasian and most of my college friends in Urbana-Champaign, where our university is located, are white or Asian.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry

He had been chief consumer engagement officer at Dentsu America, New York, part of Dentsu. MEC North America is part of the MEC division of GroupM, owned by WPP.

headline: Great Roasted Peppers: First, Get a Pile of Wood
text: IF learning how to cook is easy enough for a child to do (and it is), the continuing-education portion of it lasts a lifetime. I remember the first time I roasted a pepper, 44 years ago. It was a revelation. And I remember when I thought I had it down pat, 15 years ago, around the time I wrote my first Minimalist column.

headline: Ads Give Shout-Outs to Customers by Name
text: New media have enabled advertisers to more precisely tailor messages than they could during the era of mass marketing, to the point where pitches can be microtargeted in one-to-one fashion.

headline: Energy Agency Finds Safe Gas Drilling is Cheap
text: The International Energy Agency has issued a report that is essential reading for anyone interested in ensuring that the global boom in gas production facilitated by hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, is carried out with environmental integrity. The report, “Golden Rules for a Golden Age of Gas,” builds an economic case for adopting practices and technologies that limit chances of water or air pollution and produce adequate transparency to gain public confidence.

text: The rest of the footwear has finally fallen, and Dewey & LeBoeuf is now in Chapter 11. It joins Brobeck and Shea & Gould among the fallen white-shoe greats.

headline: New York’s Tech Boom: Here to Stay This Time?

headline: For City Teenagers, Stop-and-Frisk Is Black and White
text: One in five people stopped and frisked last year by the New York Police Department was a teenager between the ages of 14 and 18, according to a WNYC analysis of recently released police data. An overwhelming number of them were black or Latino boys.

headline: In Japan, Milledge Continues to Underwhelm
text: TOKYO – Meiji Jingu Stadium, the home of the Tokyo Yakult Swallows, is a long way from New York, Washington and the other cities where Lastings Milledge has played during his spotty career. But after a mediocre six-year stint with four major league teams, it is where he now hangs his hat.

headline: Sweden 1912: No Tickets? No Problem
text: One hundred years ago the summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

headline: Loyal and Loving Beyond Reason, and That’s Just the Owners
text: Dogs are having a television moment, with three very different programs about them turning up in the next few weeks on three very different outlets. Together they provide a dizzying display of reprehensible behavior, inordinate neediness and striking devotion. By humans.

headline: Plastic Waste = Cash Cow?

headline: President Obama’s Kill List
text: Whenever I raise questions about President Obama’s “targeted killing” policy, and the cavalier way his aides dismiss criticism of it, administration officials tell me that I wouldn’t worry so much if I understood the program’s inner workings. But the more that comes to light, the more worried I feel.

headline: Iran Confirms Attack by Virus That Collects Information
text: TEHRAN — The computers of high-ranking Iranian officials appear to have been penetrated by a data-mining virus called Flame, in what may be the most destructive cyberattack on Iran since the notorious Stuxnet virus, an Iranian cyberdefense organization confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Liking LinkedIn, While Wary of Facebook
text: Facebook doesn’t seem to be casting a long shadow over social networking stocks.

text: 8:40 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Broadway Move for ‘Hands on a Hardbody’

headline: For Years, Kings in Name Only
text: The history of the Los Angeles Kings (1967 to present) is a tragedy in five acts. Or, is it more like 10 installments of an obscure mini-series? The longer you’ve been a Kings fan, the more analogies you tend to reach for, with brief, weightless pauses for singular playoff success (read that literally) and, of course, the False God Whose Name Is Gretzky period.

headline: Plan a Frugal Trip in Sweden
text: Attention Swedes, fans of Sweden, or anyone who can find Sweden on a map and is willing to do some research: I’m asking for your help.

headline: BMW Zagato Coupe: A Different Breed of Z Car
text: The Concorso d’Eleganza at Villa d’Este, in Cernobbio, Italy, offers perhaps the most elegant backdrop of any motor show. The event also has become a reliable occasion for spotting new cars by Zagato.

headline: The Dream Life of Syrian Yuppies
text: This week in the magazine, Adam Davidson writes about the pockets of unexpected wealth in Syria’s two biggest cities, Damascus and Aleppo. A few years ago on a visit to the country, he was surprised to see that “many locals drove sports cars, wore fancy watches, ate at top-notch restaurants and generally made me feel like a broke hick.”

headline: Moving On, Adding a Sign Out Front
text: WHEN Sasha Petraske opened his bar Milk & Honey on a desolate Lower East Side block in 2000, the coming cocktail revival was barely a pie-eyed glimmer in the public’s eye. Almost instantaneously, the tiny watering hole near Delancey Street became the model for neo-speakeasy cool, attracting an enduring following. It is still regarded as near holy ground by cocktail mavens.

headline: Layers of Flavor: Lasagna With Roasted Vegetables
text: This week I dipped into the vegetable chapter of Molly Stevens’ terrific new cookbook, “All About Roasting.” Roasting brings a rich dimension to all sorts of vegetables. I’d never thought of roasting broccoli, for instance, but now I’ll be roasting that vegetable as often as I steam it, for sure.

headline: Summer 2012 on The Learning Network
text: Happy vacation! We searched The Times’s Web site to find a photo that fully captured that “school’s out for summer” feeling, and though we considered some more recent contenders, this 1997 image taken by the staff photographer Suzanne DeChillo said it best.

headline: A Maze of Complication in the Afghan Poppy Fields
text: The governor of the Zhare district in southern Afghanistan wanted to express a few helpful ideas for how to tackle Afghanistan’s opium poppy problem.

headline: New Google Chrome Aims at Windows 8
text: Google just released a new version of its Chrome operating system with fancy tweaks to online computing services like word processing and video — all designed to make it faster, more functional and easier to use.

headline: Hotels Upgrade Beauty Products
text: SINCE she’s been hopscotching hotels across the country for the last six years, touring as the violinist for the Brooklyn-based band Ra Ra Riot, Rebecca Zeller has had ample opportunity to inspect in-room skin care amenities. “It definitely matters what’s on the sink,” said Ms. Zeller, 28. “It’s always a little bit of a reward, especially after a long flight.”

headline: For Loyola Lacrosse, the Sprint Is Over
text: Loyola head coach Charley Toomey choked up during his on-field interview just seconds after the Greyhounds won their first national championship in school history with a 9-3 win over Maryland on Monday.

headline: A Dish Inspired by a Dive in Hanoi
text: UP a flight of rickety stairs in Hanoi is a 100-year-old restaurant that is often a must-not-miss in guidebooks. It serves one iconic, delicious dish, called cha ca la Vong, which also happens to be the name of the restaurant. In the bright, noisy dining room, packed with communal tables set with little charcoal burners, a skillet of fish and other components arrives, and you submit to a brusque ceremony of tabletop cooking and do-it-yourself assembly.

headline: Annan Says Syria Is at Tipping Point
text: Kofi Annan, the United Nations envoy, held a news conference in Damascus on Tuesday after meeting with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline: Dim Prospects for Financial Crisis Prosecutions
text: As has been noted many times, the lack of criminal prosecutions arising out of the financial crisis has been painfully obvious. And two items in the news last week underscores that the prospect for a signature case is growing even more distant.

headline: Embracing Finra, ‘the Devil We Know’
text: Financial firms hope to derail or delay new regulatory oversight, but they also have a Plan B: back a new regulator.

headline: Justices Reject Appeal Seeking Payments for Ex-Iran Hostages
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected the last legal appeal for former American hostages seeking compensation for their captivity in Iran three decades ago, leaving legislation newly introduced in Congress as the last chance to resolve their longstanding grievance.

headline: About Those Beards
text: The playoff beard is a fun tradition, and producers at Bleacher Report’s “Why We Watch” documentary series have made an engaging short film about it. Ryan O’Leary, who produced “N.H.L. Playoff Beards: A Growing Tradition” with Aimee Denaro, said, “We really wanted to discuss the evolution of the playoff beard from its early days on Long Island to its fundraising ability for team charities today. But, of course, it unites fans and players, which is very special for the sport.” You can see the film here:

headline: Serena Williams Loses in First Round
text: PARIS — Three hours three minutes into an upset that ranked among the most stunning and unexpected in the recent history of the French Open, Serena Williams turned into a backhand. It was immediately clear it would sail long.

headline: Younger Investors Jaded About the Stock Market, Survey Finds
text: The market downturn of 2008 may have had an especially chilling effect on younger Americans, a quarterly retirement survey suggests.

headline: Most Aid to Athens Circles Back to Europe
text: PARIS — Its membership in the euro currency union hanging in the balance, Greece continues to receive billions of euros in emergency assistance from a so-called troika of lenders overseeing its bailout.

headline: The Get | Prestat’s Diamond Jubilee Truffles
text: So, the De Beers Talisman Crown is way out of your price range. There’s another decadent (and delicious) way to partake in Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee this weekend — with a box of special-edition truffles from the queen’s official chocolatier, Prestat. Awarded the royal warrant by Her Majesty in 1975, Prestat was first established in 1902 and has accompanied the British monarch on everything from business trips to family holidays aboard the Royal Yacht Britannia. The Jubilee box, designed by the royal florist Kitty Arden, features a cheery illustration that incorporates the Union Jack, a gold coronation state carriage, a unicorn and the queen’s favorite corgis. (She’s owned more than 30 since being given her first, named Susan, on her 18th birthday.) Flavors include 1895 Gianduja, Marc de Champagne and Earl Grey. Sweet!

headline: Spanish Central Bank Chief to Leave Early as Crisis Gathers
text: MADRID — The governor of the Bank of Spain said Tuesday that he would quit his job early, just days after watching Spain’s banking sector sink deeper into crisis because of a huge bailout request from Bankia, the country’s biggest mortgage lender.

headline: Repsol to Sell Assets and Spend More on Exploration
text: MADRID — Repsol, the Spanish oil company, said Tuesday that it would cut its dividend, divest itself of as much as 4.5 billion euros ($5.66 billion) of noncore assets and spend more on exploration as it seeks to rebound from the loss of YPF, which was nationalized by Argentina last month.

headline: Cuisines Mastered as Acquired Tastes
text: A THAI-cooking superstar was getting ready to land in New York this spring, and in food-fanatic quarters, it felt more like the Beatles were about to touch down at Kennedy.

headline: The Camp Counselor vs. the Intern
text: In an act of quiet rebellion, my daughter will spend this summer as a counselor at a sleep-away camp in the Adirondacks. As rebellions go, this one is admittedly very tame. But she is resisting considerable pressure to join the throngs of anxious fellow collegians (she’s finishing her junior year) who will pad their résumés with summer internships in corporations, charities, law firms and other employers that, according to conventional wisdom, offer better preparation for the brutal economy than a summer camp.

headline: Lasagna With Roasted Beets and Herb Béchamel
text: I also call this “pink lasagna,” as the beets will bleed into the béchamel and onto the pasta when it bakes. Roast the beets ahead so that they will be cool enough to handle easily when you’re ready to assemble the lasagna.

headline: The Extinction of Hawaiian Birds
text: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: Travel-size beauty products have come a long way from the days when no-frills drugstore brands were the only options, and lovers of department store lines resorted to buying small plastic bottles and did messy transfers of their staples. But when T.S.A. regulations went into effect in 2006 limiting the size of carry-on toiletries, several high-end companies began to offer miniature versions of their most popular cleansers and creams. Some are making convenient kits filled with essentials.

headline: Colombian Rebels Release ‘Proof of Life’ Video of French Hostage
text: Last Updated, 6:00 p.m. A Colombian guerrilla group released video on Monday to prove that a French journalist captured during a gun battle with government troops last month was taken alive. The rebels said over the weekend that they intend to release the reporter on Wednesday.

headline: High Court Upholds Ability to ‘Credit Bid’
text: The Supreme Court has finally righted a bankruptcy muddle created by the appeals courts and their apparently limited understanding of the wonder that is Title 11. And they did it in an 11-page, unanimous (8-0; Justice Anthony M. Kennedy did not participate) decision. RadLAX Gateway Hotel, LLC v. Amalgmated Bank will make for an interesting comparison with the coming health care reform decision.

headline: How Spectrum Sharing Would Work
text: 5:32 p.m. | Updated  Adding additional comment.

headline: Back Forty and Back Forty West
text: A look inside two restaurant twins, where a similar philosophy of farm-to-table and sustainability is shared.

headline: Complaint Claims Illinois Senator Violated Campaign Finance Law
text: CHICAGO — A complaint sent to the Federal Election Commission by the former wife of Senator Mark Steven Kirk of Illinois claimed Mr. Kirk may have violated campaign finance law during a 2010 race to fill President Obama’s former Senate seat.

headline: Alcorn State Hires Conference’s First White Football Coach
text: If Jay Hopson was not white, his hiring as Alcorn State’s football coach on Monday would have brought up questions about the fall of a once-proud program and about what went so wrong at Hopson’s last job, as defensive coordinator at the University of Memphis. After all, Alcorn State is reeling from a chaotic, 2-8 season and a long slog in mediocrity. And Hopson was last seen resigning after the Tigers gave up 106 points in their first two games and he was about to be reassigned.

headline: Washington Square Park, 11 A.M.
text: On an eighth-floor window ledge at New York University’s Silver Center, one of the juvenile hawks that took flight Monday night for the first time.

headline: A Red-Knot Celebrity Is Back in Town
text: On Monday morning, Patricia M. Gonzalez, an Argentine biologist, was standing on the balcony of a house in Reeds Beach, N.J., peering through a telescope at shorebirds. She spotted a bird with an orange band around its leg, possibly suggesting that it had been tagged in South America.

headline: More Principals Receive Positive Evaluations
text: While the number of teachers rated unsatisfactory by the Education Department has risen in recent years, the number of principals rated poorly has continued to fall, according to information released by the city.

headline: Epic Ratings for ‘Hatfields & McCoys’ on History Channel
text: The most spectacular success of the summer season on television may have come before  summer has even started: the miniseries “Hatfields & McCoys” on the History Channel attracted a monster audience Monday night, 13.9 million viewers, the second largest for a cable program that did not involve sports.

headline: Bob Dylan Among Recipients of Presidential Medal of Freedom
text: It would be an overstatement to say that the whole wide world was watching when Bob Dylan’s ship came in, but surely his fans pinched themselves and squealed and knew that it was for real when he was awarded a Presidential Medal of Freedom on Tuesday afternoon. Mr. Dylan, 71, whose career of more than 50 years stretches from early folk songs like “The Times They Are A-Changin'” and “When the Ship Comes In” to the recondite rock of recent albums like “Modern Times” and “Together Through Life,” was presented with the medal at a ceremony in the White House, where President Obama said of him, “There is not a bigger giant in the history of American music.” Mr. Obama also praised Mr. Dylan’s voice for its “weight” and “unique gravelly power” that redefined “not just what music sounded like but the message it carried and how it made people feel.”

headline: The Lies That Buoy, Then Break a Marriage
text: Gillian Flynn’s ice-pick-sharp “Gone Girl” begins far too innocently by explaining how Nick and Amy Dunne celebrated their fifth wedding anniversary. Amy got up and started making crepes. Nick came into the kitchen, appreciating his wife’s effort but wondering why Amy was humming the theme song from “M*A*S*H.” You know, that “suicide is painless” thing.

headline: Research in Motion Projects a Quarterly Loss
text: 6:24 p.m. | Updated

headline: Windows Still Ready for Irene, 9 Months Later
text: When Amy Sedaris sees the X, she becomes sad.

headline: For These Twins, Nurture, Not Nature
text: AS SoHo began to feel less like a New York neighborhood and more like a suburban shopping mall with two lanes of taxis running down the middle, there was Savoy, a sane oasis on the quiet corner of Prince and Crosby Streets. Even when years passed between visits, I felt better knowing Savoy was there. Then one day last June, it wasn’t there anymore after 21 years, and the city felt a little smaller.

headline: European Official Calls for an Economic Road Map to Calm Fears
text: BERLIN — As the economic and financial troubles in Spain continue to deepen, so, too, does the sense that Europe’s crisis goes far beyond an isolated situation in Greece and that it could require a more comprehensive and systemic solution.

headline: London’s Next Big Restaurant? Shrimpy’s
text: London’s King’s Cross is, as it sounds, a crossroads — a neighborhood anchored by the King’s Cross railway station. And in that sense it’s the perfect place for David Waddington and Pablo Flack’s latest restaurant, Shrimpy’s. It’s not quite Palm Springs, which is where the duo first dreamed up the idea for an eatery based on their transatlantic journeys; and it’s not quite Mexico or Brazil, where they sampled the local cuisine and nurtured their culinary concept. But it’s a little piece of the Americas all the same, Waddington insists: bright, bold and flavorful.

headline: Patrick Denihan
text: Mr. Denihan, 60, is a co-chief executive with his sister, Brooke Barrett, of the Denihan Hospitality Group, an independent owner and operator of boutique hotels. The company’s portfolio includes properties, the bulk of which are in the New York area, operated under the James and Affinia hotel brands. Denihan Hospitality, which is based in Manhattan, has been operated by the same family for 50 years.

headline: Flute’s Revised Age Dates the Sound of Music Earlier
text: In hillside caves of southwestern Germany, archaeologists in recent years have uncovered the beginnings of music and art by early modern humans migrating into Europe from Africa. New dating evidence shows that these oldest known musical instruments in the world, flutes made of bird bone and mammoth ivory, are even older than first thought.

headline: In Crown Heights, Malfatti for the Trilbys
text: THIRTEEN years ago, no one in Manhattan went to Brooklyn for dinner by choice. You had to dangle Peter Luger as bait, and a car service back to “the city,” or at least an escort to the subway.

headline: Answers About How to Deal With Pests, Part 2
text: Following an article in the Real Estate section this month about handling pest problems in New York City, readers submitted questions to our guest expert, Gary Braness, a pest management consultant and owner of Yosemite Environmental Services, about how to evict their unwanted roommates.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Qatar and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Qatar, Italy, Egypt and Somalia.

headline: Israel to Aid Wider Range of Rabbis
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government announced on Tuesday that, for the first time, it planned to pay the salaries of a small number of Reform and Conservative rabbis, as it does with many Orthodox ones.

headline: High-Priced Tickets Help Make for a Record Year at the Broadway Box Office
text: Broadway musicals and plays had another record-setting season at the box office, grossing a total of $1.139 billion from 40 new productions and other long-running shows during the 2011-12 theater season, according to data released by the Broadway League on Tuesday. Audience attendance was 12.33 million, roughly the same as in the 2010-11 season, according to the League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

headline: Business Day Live — Microsoft and Skype
text: May 29, 2012 — Microsoft still working to integrate Skype.

headline: Few Buy Chromebooks, but Google Keeps Pushing
text: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg News“What I am sure of is the level of commitment inside the company,” said Sundar Pichai, the head of Chrome at Google.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Lone Star’
text: The blazing sun is at the heart of the artist Jason Glasser‘s mesmerizing new show, “Lone Star,” which is on view through June 10 at Parker’s Box in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Born in Connecticut, Glasser lives in Paris with his wife, who’s French. But his latest work sprouted out of the year they just spent in Texas — a “self-imposed exile,” Glasser called it, intended to help his young children learn English. That sojourn produced a trippy silent film, streaming above, which was made around Barton Springs, a popular place to swim in Austin. In the exhibition, this film is projected onto a concave piece of glass that was once a television screen. “My tourist-grade camera does some interesting things when the sun reflects off the water so intensely,” Glasser said. “The images in this film have not been manipulated other than what I got just using my camera.”

headline: A ‘Kill List,’ a Marine Ritual and a Therapist for 3,500 Patients
text: Welcome back from the Memorial Day holiday, readers. Here are a couple of articles you don’t want to miss.

headline: Ask About the Euro
text: European Union leaders are known for “muddling through.” Unfortunately, that means the euro zone sovereign debt crisis can be a muddle for readers trying to follow it. Here at the IHT we try to anticipate what questions readers may have, but no doubt we have missed plenty. So please ask me whatever you’d like to know about the European Central Bank, “Grexit,” euro zone banks or any other topic related to the debt crisis, and I’ll do my best to answer.

headline: Digital Notes: Samsung Music Hub Takes on Just About Everyone
text: are download stores, Internet radio players, streaming services, online lockers and services tied to mobile devices. The only way for a company to distinguish itself, it would seem, would be to combine as many of these features as possible into a single product.

headline: Cheap Natural Gas Prompts Energy Department to Soften Its Line on Fuel Cells
text: The Energy Department estimates that 95 percent of the United States’ hydrogen is produced from natural gas. The abundance of that contentious fossil fuel has revised the cost equation for fuel-cell vehicles. Even hydrogen skeptics like Energy Secretary Steven Chu are taking a second look.

headline: Will Nuclear Plants Withstand Quakes and Floods?
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission should consider requiring nuclear power plants to analyze their vulnerability to natural hazards like earthquakes by using the same advanced tools that the industry uses to understand the risks from mechanical accidents,  a new report from the Government Accountability Office argues.

text: Benefits (Appetites Welcome)

headline: Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company Announces New Season
text: The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company said on Tuesday that it would go on two major tours next season, a month-long swing in Germany, Italy, France and the Netherlands starting in late September and a two-week series of stops in the United States in November. The tours help mark the company’s 30th anniversary. The repertory will include “Story/Time,” which was inspired by music of John Cage; new and reconstructed works set to classical music and a group of early avant-guard works called “Body Against Body.”

headline: Noomi, Rooney; Rooney, Noomi
text: In this week’s issue of the magazine, Karen Olsson profiles the Swedish film star Noomi Rapace, whose next movie is ‘‘Prometheus,’’ a big-budget science-fiction opus from the director Ridley Scott. American audiences are likely to know her, though, as the original girl with the dragon tattoo — which is to say, she played Lisbeth Salander in the Swedish film adaptation of the best-selling thriller before Rooney Mara played Lisbeth Salander in the American adaptation of the same book.

headline: Video: Microsoft and Skype
text: Microsoft is still working to integrate the online calling service Skype, which at $8.5 billion was the biggest acquisition in Microsoft’s history.

headline: A Theatrical Patriarch, Onstage and Off
text: James Earl Jones smiled broadly as he recalled the moment, years back, when his young son couldn’t figure out why people were hovering nearby, asking for autographs.

headline: A Palestinian Whose Cameras Are Witnesses and Casualties of Conflict
text: “5 Broken Cameras” provides a grim reminder — just in case you needed one — of the bitter intractability of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. A chronicle of protest and endurance, punctuated by violence and tiny glimmers of hope, this documentary is unlikely to persuade anyone with a hardened view of the issue to think again. For anyone who retains an interest in the human contours of the situation, however, the movie is necessary, if difficult, viewing.

headline: At the French Open, Tennis Isn’t the Only Attraction
text: When it comes to lunch at Roland Garros, the complex has much more to offer than hot dogs and popcorn.

headline: A Profusion of Tiger Killers and Their Temple Maidens
text: To watch successive performances of the three-act ballet “La Bayadère,” no matter what the company or in whose production, involves its trials. The choreography, by Marius Petipa and a number of successors, ranges from the sublime to the ridiculous; the music, by Ludwig Minkus, is often trivial; the narrative is melodramatic and the storytelling repeatedly hammy.

headline: Give Me Your Tired, Your Over-Taxed
text: A couple of conservative news outlets reported today that New York State shed 1.3 million residents on net over the last ten years, with more than 600,000 leaving for Florida. During the same period, more than 200,000 Pennsylvanians also moved to Florida.

headline: Over 30 Is Far From Over the Hill in the Men’s Draw
text: PARIS — In 2002, there were 11 men playing singles in the French Open who were age 30 or older. A decade later, there were 37 of them, making up nearly a third of the initial singles draw. That is an Open-era record, and they are not just here to make up the numbers.

headline: Butler, Shine Keeps Mini Cooper Account
text: Anyone who has been watching “Mad Men” this season knows how fiercely advertising agencies fight to win automotive accounts. Now comes a real-life reminder of how fiercely they fight to keep them.

headline: For Private Equity, Fewer Deals in Leaner Times
text: It is not easy being a private equity firm like the Blackstone Group or Kohlberg Kravis Roberts these days. Not only do you have to worry about being dragged through the mud in a presidential election, but the business isn’t the money machine it used to be.

headline: More Room for Ideas in a Smaller Office
text: Ever since the economy started to slow down about five years ago, companies have been looking for ways to reduce their office space costs. One option that has become more popular is reconfiguring the office to fit the same number of workers in a smaller space, and either subleasing the leftover square footage or returning it to the landlord.

headline: A Rental Market Surge in Brooklyn
text: The market for multifamily buildings in Brooklyn has been heating up over the last year. But the recent sale of 111 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg was stunning even in a hot market.

headline: For Japanese Job Seekers, Overseas Study Can Be a Deal Killer
text: In this mind-boggling. eye-popping piece — given today’s global economy — our colleague Hiroko Tabuchi reports that for young Japanese professionals an overseas education can be a bad thing.

headline: With Recall Election Near, Walker Raises More Than $5 Million
text: Gov. Scott Walker, the Republican of Wisconsin who faces a recall election next week, raised more than $5 million in the last month alone, his campaign announced on Tuesday, a day when new fund-raising reports have to be filed to state officials.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,972 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Shuffling Through an Underground Artery to Gaza
text: RAFAH, Egypt — They stood just outside the gates of the Rafah crossing on the Egyptian side of the border with Gaza, a couple of inconspicuous Bedouin men waiting for people to be denied entry. As the disappointed travelers retreated, the Bedouins whispered from behind the gates: “You want to go to the tunnels? Fifty dollars.” Their gaze fixed on the Egyptian border police officers, who turn a blind eye to the Bedouins so long as they do not mention the tunnels within earshot.

headline: On Night of Trump Fund-Raiser, Romney Jokes About Presidential Requirements
text: LAS VEGAS — Mitt Romney, who is trying to distance himself from Donald J. Trump’s remarks about President Obama’s citizenship, joked about a new constitutional requirement for the presidency on Tuesday evening: business experience.

headline: The Slaughter in Syria
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Declining Source of Energy
text: While coal still remains the primary source of electricity in the United States, its share has fallen.

headline: Pep Boys Terminates Sale to Private Equity Firm
text: Pep Boys said late Tuesday that it had agreed to end its proposed $1 billion sale to the Gores Group, after the private equity firm raised concerns about the company’s deteriorating financial health.

headline: Presidents Cup Captains Named
text: Fred Couples and Nick Price were named captains for the 2013 Presidents Cup, which will be held at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses City’s Jails of Condoning Inmate Abuse
text: Eleven current and former inmates in New York City’s jails have filed a lawsuit charging that correction officials have tolerated and even condoned the unprovoked beatings of inmates by guards, resulting in serious injuries to prisoners and millions of dollars in legal settlements paid by the city.

headline: A Little-Used Fire Company, Rescued Annually
text: It has become a rite of spring on City Island in the Bronx, as reliable as the tourists who descend with warm weather or the traffic that backs up the main avenue. It is time, again, to save Ladder 53.

headline: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry
text: LOUISA, Ky. — For generations, coal has been king in this Appalachian town. It provided heat, light and jobs for the hundreds of people who worked in the nearby coal mines and the smoke-coughing Big Sandy power plant that burned their black bounty.

headline: Doc Watson, Blind Guitar Wizard Who Influenced Generations, Dies at 89
text: Doc Watson, the guitarist and folk singer whose flat-picking style elevated the acoustic guitar to solo status in bluegrass and country music, and whose interpretations of traditional American music profoundly influenced generations of folk and rock guitarists, died on Tuesday in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 89.

headline: As Rumors Swirl, Dustin Johnson Returns
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Dustin Johnson was gone from the PGA Tour for 11 weeks, but he was not forgotten. While Johnson rehabilitated a back injury that he said he incurred while pushing a Jet Ski into the water, his agent, David Winkle, was shooting down rumors in the blogosphere that Johnson had failed a tour-administered drug test and was in drug rehabilitation.

headline: A Prize-Winner’s Personal Insight
text: The National Press Photographers Association announced on Tuesday its final group of Best of Photojournalism 2012 winners. Ross Taylor of The Virginian-Pilot was chosen Photojournalist of the Year (Larger Markets), and David Weatherwax of The Herald, in Jasper, Ind., was named Photojournalist of the Year (Smaller Markets).

headline: City Pushes for More Authority in Sexual Misconduct Cases
text: The city is seeking to change state law to give the schools chancellor final authority to fire a teacher accused of sexual misconduct.

headline: ‘I Apologize,’ Ex-Rutgers Student Says Before Going to Jail
text: TRENTON (AP) — A former Rutgers University student who used a webcam to spy on his roommate’s intimate encounter with another man days before the roommate killed himself apologized on Tuesday and said he had accepted responsibility for what he had done.

headline: Tech Suits Endanger Innovation
text: Casual observers would find little in common between the smartphones in their pockets and the funky backbeat of the Beastie Boys’ Car Thief. But these two creations will go down together in the annals of creativity as reminders of the flaws in our intellectual property laws.

headline: Paul Simon Takes Us Back
text: Of all the raw and compelling voices in Joe Berlinger’s must-see documentary, “Under African Skies,” about the making of Paul Simon’s classic “Graceland” album in South Africa in 1985 — and his reunion with the same African artists 25 years later — my favorite is that of Graceland bass player Bakithi Kumalo. He tells about that day in 1985 when he met Simon in a Johannesburg recording studio:

headline: Still Rooting Against Brodeur
text: After Martin Brodeur and the Devils vanquished the Rangers in the Eastern Conference finals last week, one might have thought that talk of the Devils’ loss to the Rangers in 1994 was finally vanquished too. But apparently not.

headline: Our National Mammal
text: The United States has a national bird, of course — the bald eagle, which was adopted as such on June 20, 1782. Last week, Senator Mike Enzi, a Republican of Wyoming, and Senator Tim Johnson, a Democrat of South Dakota, introduced a bill to name the North American bison as the national mammal. It is hard to think of a better or more deserving creature for that distinction.

headline: Couples and Price Named Presidents Cup Captains
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Fred Couples and Nick Price on Tuesday were named captains for the 2013 Presidents Cup, which will be held at Muirfield Village Golf Club, site of this week’s Memorial Tournament.

headline: Dewey Hopes to Resolve Bankruptcy Quickly
text: As Dewey & LeBoeuf began its bankruptcy proceedings on Tuesday, its advisers said their aim was to speed the failed law firm through Chapter 11.

headline: After Scandal in Soccer, Italy’s Leader Urges Break
text: ROME — In his efforts to save Italy from the brink of economic disaster, Prime Minister Mario Monti has repeatedly incurred the wrath of taxpayers and pensioners upset by the severity of his measures.

headline: Rhode Island: Third City Loses Control of Finances
text: Gov. Lincoln Chafee appointed a commission on Tuesday to oversee the finances of Woonsocket. Officials in the struggling city, whose schools face a $10 million budget deficit, requested the commission this weekend, after a supplemental tax increase failed to pass. This is the third time Rhode Island has taken over the finances of a municipality; East Providence and Central Falls have fiscal overseers.

headline: North Carolina: Tease, Not a Verdict, in Edwards Case
text: Deliberations in the federal corruption trial of former Senator John Edwards stretched into a seventh day on Tuesday, with little indication that a decision was near. Noting that high school graduation season had arrived, Judge Catherine C. Eagles asked the jury to send her any potential coming conflicts. The stress inside the courtroom has built steadily as the jury seeks a verdict in the trial that began April 23. But on Tuesday, the judge inadvertently injected a little tension-relieving humor. “The jury sent me a note saying they have reached a,” she said, causing nearly every observer to jerk to attention. After a moment, she continued: “good stopping point.” The courtroom erupted in laughter and Abbe Lowell, Mr. Edwards’s lead lawyer, dropped his head to the defense table. “That was mean. I’m sorry,” the judge said.

headline: Heavy Debt, but No Degree
text: In the weak economy, people who graduate from name-brand colleges are struggling to repay the heavy debt they often rack up getting through school. But college debt is an even bigger problem for the growing numbers of borrowers who drop out without degrees.

headline: Clintons Make ‘Great Neighbors,’ but for How Long?
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — It might be assumed that Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has more pressing items on her to-do list than making it each year to the local Memorial Day Parade.

headline: With Records Gone, Odds of Finding Boy’s Remains Are Even Slimmer
text: On the morning after Memorial Day in 1979, the sidewalks in the Manhattan neighborhood where Etan Patz lived would have been overflowing with trash accumulated over the long weekend, clumps of refuse from the homes and studios of artists and the few stores and restaurants that catered to them.

headline: To Screen or Not?
text: A panel of experts that advises the government on screening tests stirred up controversy last fall when it proposed that healthy men should not routinely get a blood test to detect prostate cancer. It warned that the test may push them to undergo unnecessary invasive tests and treatments apt to harm more people than help. This month, the panel, after further review of the scientific evidence, issued the same recommendation in final form.

headline: A Stumble Is Surprising, but It’s No Longer Rare
text: PARIS

headline: The Massacre at Houla
text: The decision on Tuesday by the United States, Britain, France and at least five other major nations to expel senior Syrian diplomats was a powerful sign of international revulsion at the massacre of more than 100 Syrians in the village of Houla. But it was still short of the tougher diplomatic and economic sanctions needed to put real pressure on President Bashar al-Assad and his cronies. Russia, in particular, can finally help, or continue to be a roadblock to tougher action.

headline: Nomination His, Romney Steps Up Attack on Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney, having initially weathered the first sustained general election attack, is entering a critical 90-day stretch to the Republican convention on relatively equal footing with the White House and is unleashing a new offensive to win over independent voters and further undermine confidence in President Obama’s stewardship of the economy.

headline: Using ‘Dirty’ Products to Clean Up
text: FOR decades, fans have been able to buy merchandise, like T-shirts and coffee mugs, inspired by their favorite television shows. Now, a show has produced products meant to be practical.

headline: Euro 2012 Rosters Released Under Racism Cloud
text: The final rosters from the 16 teams competing in next month’s European Championship in Poland and Ukraine were released Tuesday. UEFA has the final lists here, or see below. There were few surprises, as most teams had narrowed their rosters earlier.

headline: Romney Calls for Action on Syria, but His Party Is Divided
text: WASHINGTON — The massacre of more than 100 civilians, many of them children, in Syria over the weekend has presented Mitt Romney with a new opportunity to sound a familiar theme: that President Obama’s foreign policy is feckless and lacking in courage.

headline: Challenges Mount for Chinese Maker of Electric Cars
text: HONG KONG — Four years ago, the BYD Company promoted the electric battery technology it was developing as a way to help China transform the automobile. No less an investor than Warren E. Buffett, one of the world’s richest men, boasted about the company’s prospects and bought a 10 percent stake.

headline: Seeking Easier Way to Fire Teachers in Sex Cases
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Tuesday that the city should have the final say on whether teachers accused of sexual misconduct should be fired, even if hearings determined that they should keep their jobs.

headline: Mets’ Shortstop Roulette Turns to No. 6
text: One turned ankle has led to the Mets’ trotting out their sixth shortstop this season, although at least the latest option has experience at the position.

headline: Plea Deal in Robbery Involving Nun’s Death
text: A 20-year-old Harlem man who was initially charged with murder pleaded guilty on Tuesday to an armed robbery that he and an accomplice committed two years ago and which ended when their getaway car killed a nun in Harlem.

headline: Supporters and Critics of Annan See Crisis in Syria as a Threat to His Legacy
text: Kofi Annan, the soft-spoken former United Nations diplomat and secretary general, has successfully navigated through multiple wars in the Middle East, the Balkans breakup, African genocides, a corruption scandal that touched his family and a raft of other crises over a career that spans more than five decades, winning a Nobel Peace Prize along the way. But friends and critics alike say Syria could be Mr. Annan’s undoing.

headline: Andromeda Is Coming!
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Allen Sees His Sweet Jumper Go Awry
text: MIAMI — The artistry of Ray Allen’s jump shot is as evident in the jump as in the shot, as much about feet as it is about hands. When Allen rises and lands in the same spot, all is right. Baskets swish, records fall, the Boston Celtics celebrate.

headline: Public-Place Laws Tighten Rein on Sex Offenders
text: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. — Convicted sex offenders are barred from surfing at the famous pier in this Orange County city.

headline: Being Smart Can Beat Being Big
text: The N.B.A. championship might be claimed by an East Coast city (Miami or Boston) that ranks high on the list of America’s most celebrated sports markets or by a Western Conference outpost (San Antonio or Oklahoma City) that many would have difficulty finding on a map.

headline: That’s Not Recyclable, Mom. That’s My Savings!
text: At age 12, Max Becker can admit that he and his twin sister, Drew, have the kinds of issues that simmer between siblings day after day, year after year. “My sister is, I don’t feel, the most trustworthy,” he explained on Tuesday. “She has stolen a lot of my stuff in the past.”

headline: Romney, on His Big Day, Finds Himself Upstaged
text: LAS VEGAS — It was supposed to be a day of triumph for Mitt Romney, when he would at last formally claim the Republican presidential nomination with a victory in the Texas primary. And Mr. Romney was to focus attention on an aggressive new attack on President Obama, highlighting the White House’s role in backing failed companies like Solyndra.

headline: Midtown Manhattan, 8:32 P.M.
text: Dark clouds gathering over the Chrysler Building.

headline: Yankees Claim Former Mets Reliever Igarashi
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Yankees added another bullpen option to the organization Tuesday when they claimed the former Mets right-hander Ryota Igarashi off waivers from the Toronto Blue Jays. Igarashi reported to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre in time for Tuesday’s game.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Drug Maker Seeks Protection Within Bill Favoring Generics
text: WASHINGTON — One of the few bills moving through Congress with bipartisan support this spring would speed government approval of lower-cost generic copies of brand-name drugs. But one company, with help from an influential former congressman, is lobbying to protect its most lucrative brand-name product against generic competition and appears to have had some success in the House, potentially altering the bill to make it more favorable for the company.

headline: Long-Running TV Show
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — We lost DICK CLARK in mid-April, but today we get to remember all of the pleasure he gave us as the World’s Oldest TEENAGER and host of television’s iconic music show “AMERICAN BANDSTAND.”

headline: Romney’s School Surprise
text: Last week’s speech by Mitt Romney, in which he presented his education reform plan to a group of Latino leaders in Washington, drew attention mainly because he criticized teachers’ unions and endorsed private school vouchers. But those points were perfectly predictable for a Republican candidate and not especially newsworthy.

headline: Adding to Unease of a Drug War Alliance
text: MEXICO CITY — The biggest military corruption case here in recent years has worsened an already frayed relationship between American law enforcement officials and the Mexican Army, the institution most trusted and empowered by officials here to fight the drug war.

headline: Two Exiled Flyers Land In Good Place
text: NEWARK — Eight months later, the shock had subsided for Mike Richards. Several questions remained unanswered — chief among them being just why, exactly, the Flyers had felt compelled to trade him, their captain, to Los Angeles last June as the pièce de résistance of Philadelphia’s biggest single-day shake-up since it mortgaged its future for Eric Lindros 20 years ago. But in the interim, Richards had vented plenty and reflected enough to have realized that there are worse things than wearing flip-flops to work in winter.

headline: Wasting Time Is New Divide in Digital Era
text: In the 1990s, the term “digital divide” emerged to describe technology’s haves and have-nots. It inspired many efforts to get the latest computing tools into the hands of all Americans, particularly low-income families.

headline: Home-Court Edge Includes Short Walk to Work
text: PARIS — This May, same as every May, tennis players descended on the French Open from all corners of the world. They came from Australia and Argentina, from Croatia and Kazakhstan, from Japan and Slovakia and points in between.

headline: Two Close Calls in the Outfield for Swisher and Granderson
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. —Nick Swisher had just finished describing to reporters late Monday night how he avoided a serious injury during his outfield collision with center fielder Curtis Granderson when he went around a corner to grab a bottle of water.

headline: Waivers for 8 More States From ‘No Child Left Behind’
text: The Obama administration freed eight states from core provisions of the No Child Left Behind education law on Tuesday, bringing to 19 the number of states granted waivers this year, and officials said that even more states would soon qualify for them.

headline: Known for Scoring, and Now for Leading
text: NEWARK — The main concourse at Prudential Center is just one long escalator ride up from the floor of the glass atrium where Ilya Kovalchuk, shaven and wearing a dark suit, was the focal point of a news conference 22 months ago to herald his gigantic contract with the Devils.

headline: Nudging Bahrain, Without Pushing It Away
text: How can the United States support democracy in Bahrain without damaging American political interests?

headline: India’s Economy Slows, With Global Implications
text: NEW DELHI — India’s coalition government just celebrated the third anniversary of its tenure with a self-congratulatory banquet that could not have been more poorly timed: India’s currency, the rupee, is falling; investment is down; inflation is rising; and deficits are eating away at government coffers.

headline: After Texas Vote, Romney Secures G.O.P. Nomination
text: After a long and wearying primary battle, Mitt Romney officially secured the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday with a victory in a Texas primary that delivered the final batch of delegates needed ahead of the party’s convention in August.

headline: Deportation Decision Awaits WikiLeaks Founder
text: LONDON — Britain’s highest court is to announce Wednesday whether the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, should be deported to Sweden to face allegations of sexual abuses there, the culmination of an 18-month legal battle.

headline: Corrections: May 30
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: U.S. Proposal Would Arm Italy’s Drones
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration plans to arm Italy’s small fleet of Reaper surveillance drones with Hellfire missiles and precision-guided bombs, a move that advocates say supports a staunch NATO ally in Afghanistan and that critics contend represents a potentially risky proliferation of advanced technology.

headline: From Baseball to Books, Dickey Shares Thoughts With Fans
text: R. A. Dickey can make a baseball waggle and turn in astonishing ways, subverting the expectations of those who face him.

headline: Unexpected Hitting From Pitcher and Shortstop Lifts Mets
text: If Jeremy Hefner was auditioning to keep his job as the Mets’ fifth starter, he did plenty Tuesday night to bolster his case. And this time, even a rain delay could not get into his way.

headline: Premier of Turkey Seeks Limits on Abortions
text: ISTANBUL — Calling abortion an act of murder and an insidious plan to reduce the Turkish population, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan called on Tuesday for legislation to restrict women’s access to the procedure.

headline: Finals Preview: Devils vs. Kings
text: For every player involved, being in the Stanley Cup finals is a dream come true. This year, it is especially true. The Devils finished ninth over all in the regular season and the Los Angeles Kings 13th, the first time both teams in the finals have come from outside the N.H.L.’s top eight since the playoffs expanded to 16 teams in 1980. But Los Angeles has gone 12-2 through the first three rounds, becoming the first playoff team to go 8-0 on the road. And the Devils, after needing a Game 7 overtime to beat Florida, knocked off Philadelphia and the Rangers in a surprisingly quick 11 games. Despite their seedings, this is a championship series between two very deserving clubs. JEFF Z. KLEIN

headline: A City Confronts Its Image
text: A recent magazine article dubbed Lawrence the “most godforsaken place in Massachusetts,” and for many of its residents, those were fighting words.

headline: Rangel Forcefully Defends His Record, as a Challenger Looks On
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, acknowledging on Tuesday that he faces a significant challenge to his re-election, offered a rambling but forceful defense of his service and his ethics while appearing beside his best-known challenger, State Senator Adriano Espaillat. Mr. Rangel said that he was the only candidate with the experience and qualifications to represent his Congressional district.

headline: Halladay’s Injury Is Latest to Test Phillies’ Resilience
text: On May 29, 2010, Roy Halladay tossed a perfect game for the Philadelphia Phillies. Ryan Howard made the final putout at first base, and catcher Carlos Ruiz wrapped Halladay in an embrace. On Tuesday, two years to the day later, Halladay joined Howard on the disabled list, and Ruiz sat out with a strained hamstring.

headline: Texas Runoff Set in G.O.P. Race for Senate
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In a heated race for the open United States Senate seat in Texas, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst failed to win enough votes in the Republican primary on Tuesday to avert a runoff with Ted Cruz, a Houston lawyer who cast the election as a battle between the moderate Republican establishment and Tea Party conservatives.

headline: After Seeing a Dismal Reflection of Itself, a City Moves to Change
text: LAWRENCE, Mass. — There is a litany of reasons one might avoid this city: double-digit unemployment, high crime rates, struggling public schools and, at the top, enduring suspicions of chronic mismanagement.

headline: How China Flouts Its Laws
text: SINCE I arrived in the United States on May 19, people have asked me, “What do you want to do here?” I have come here to study temporarily, not to seek political asylum. And while I pursue my studies, I hope that the Chinese government and the Communist Party will conduct a thorough investigation of the lawless punishment inflicted on me and my family over the past seven years.

headline: Marina Keegan, Journalist and Playwright, Dies at 22
