text: Marina Keegan, a journalist and playwright who won national attention for urging her fellow college students to resist the lure of Wall Street, died in a car crash Saturday afternoon in Dennis, Mass., just days after graduating from Yale. She was 22.

headline: Kathi Kamen Goldmark, Writers’ Catalyst, Dies at 63
text: Kathi Kamen Goldmark had made a lot of friends in the literary world by shepherding authors on book tours when one day inspiration struck: what the very best authors yearn to be, she realized, are rock stars.

headline: How Exercise Can Jog the Memory
text: From our archives.

headline: New Stephen King Thriller Coming Next June
text: You don’t have to be Stephen King to find small-town amusement parks inherently terrifying, but that author sees enough suspense in the environs of a 1970s-era carnival – and all the rusty arcade attractions and rickety roller coasters that suggests – to set a new novel there. On Wednesday the Hard Case Crime imprint of Titan Books plans to announce that it will publish “Joyland,” a new work of fiction by Mr. King, whose protagonist is a college student working at a North Carolina theme park in the summer of 1973. While employed there the character “confronts the legacy of a vicious murder, the fate of a dying child, and the ways both will change his life forever,” the publisher said in a news release. Charles Ardai, the Hard Case Crime editor, said in a statement that “Joyland” is “a whodunit, it’s a carny novel, it’s a story about growing up and growing old, and about those who don’t get to do either because death comes for them before their time.”

headline: Syracuse University Filmmaker Killed in Syria
text: Last Updated, 10:32 a.m. A Syrian filmmaker, who took a leave of absence from a fine arts degree program at Syracuse University to cover the carnage in his native country, was killed while filming in the war-ravaged city of Homs, the university’s chancellor said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | peregrination
text: peregrination •\ˌper-ə-grə-ˈna-shən\• noun

headline: Richard W. Lyman, Ex-President of Stanford University, Dies at 88
text: Richard W. Lyman, who as president of Stanford in the 1970s shepherded the university through an era of political turbulence, died on Sunday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Sports Replay: May 29
text: The day in sports, including a stunning upset at the French Open and volleyball in Central Park.

headline: Canada: Governing Party Headquarters Receives Package Containing a Foot
text: A parcel containing a severed human foot was delivered to the headquarters of the governing Conservative Party of Canada on Tuesday. Fred DeLorey, a spokesman for the party, said that “a suspicious package was sent to our office” but referred all other questions to the police. The Ottawa police said the package was bloodstained, but have provided few other details. The coroner’s office later confirmed that it contained a human foot. Since 2007, eight feet have washed up on British Columbia’s coastline, and three have been found along the coast of Washington State.

headline: Trumped
text: In the world of pious baloney that is modern presidential politics, Mitt Romney’s campaign has distinguished itself by being weirdly, even endearingly honest about its political calculations. Throughout the presidential selection process, the Romney camp has repeatedly pulled back the curtain of highmindedness to acknowledge more cynical realities.

headline: Apple’s Tim Cook on Steve Jobs, Leadership and Manufacturing
text: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, showed he had mastered his predecessor’s skill at promising big things for the future while revealing as little as possible about what it may bring.

headline: India’s Economy Slows, With Global Implications
text: “India’s coalition government just celebrated the third anniversary of its tenure with a self-congratulatory banquet that could not have been more poorly timed: India’s currency, the rupee, is falling; investment is down; inflation is rising; and deficits are eating away at government coffers,” Jim Yardley and Vikas Bajaj  write in The New York Times.

headline: Perfect in Playoffs, the Spurs Are Starting to Make Winning Look Easy
text: SAN ANTONIO — Tony Parker’s barrage of floating jump shots and finger rolls began early, staggering the Oklahoma City Thunder with such efficiency that it seemed to contradict his suggestion that experience was not necessarily an advantage for the San Antonio Spurs in these Western Conference finals.

headline: An Ancient Civilization, Upended by Climate Change
text: “The Vedas, a collection of texts composed over 3,000 years ago in India, speak of a mythical sacred river called the Sarasvati from which the Hindu goddess of science and learning emerged,” Rachel Nuwer writes for the Green blog of The New York Times.

headline: How Is India’s Economic Slowdown Affecting You?
text: “I think people are starting to question the long-term Indian story,” Glenn Levine, a senior economist at Moody’s Analytics in Sydney, Australia tells Jim Yardley and Vikas Bajaj in an article that says the air has been let out of the “once bubbly mood in the business and political classes.”

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi, Beyond Myanmar’s Borders
text: The last time Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmar’s democracy movement, traveled internationally, it was 1988 and the Berlin Wall was still standing. That year, she flew back to Myanmar from Britain to care for her ailing mother.

headline: Angels Beat Pettitte and Yankees
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Andy Pettitte feels he has already answered, at least for himself, the question of whether he can still pitch in the major leagues, even at age 39 after a one-year retirement.

headline: News Quiz | May 30, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Japan as “Role Model”
text: In my interview with Martin Wolf, I joked about apologizing to the emperor over Japanese policy — not because it was good, but because our policy in response to the liquidity trap has been even worse. I thought it might be useful to have some indicator of what I’m talking about.

headline: Planned Parenthood Ads to Target Romney
text: In the course of the Republican primary campaign, Mitt Romney took pains to convince socially conservative activists that he believes in them, understands their passions and would be an advocate for their causes in the Oval Office.

headline: The Kalnirnay ‘Calmanac’ Goes Digital
text: For four decades, traditionalists in Maharashtra on the cusp of buying a new home, switching jobs or scheduling surgeries have looked to one authority to establish the most auspicious moment at which to make these crucial decisions: Kalnirnay calendar-almanacs that list religious festivals, the phases of the moon, the timing of the sunrise and all the other information anyone seeking to divine the intentions of the cosmos could ever need.

headline: Israeli Official Weighs an Imposed Palestinian Border
text: TEL AVIV — Defense Minister Ehud Barak said Wednesday that Israel should consider imposing the borders of a future Palestinian state, becoming the most senior government official to suggest bypassing a stagnant peace process.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 30, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by David Prince at Math for America from the article “Hawaii’s Beaches Are in Retreat, and Its Way of Life May Follow.”

headline: A BMX Prodigy’s Ride to the Olympics
text: WHO is Connor Fields?WHO is James Herrera?

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Loses Another Bid to Halt His Extradition to Sweden
text: LONDON — Britain’s highest court ruled on Wednesday that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, should be deported to Sweden to face allegations of sexual abuse there, but Mr. Assange’s lawyers won an immediate stay of at least two weeks before British officials can initiate the final steps to hand him over to Stockholm.

headline: How the Art Market Thrives on Inequality
text: A few weeks ago, when Edvard Munch’s iconic painting “The Scream” went for about $120 million and became the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction, it seemed like we had reached the climax of a fine-art bubble. After all, from 2003 to 2007, the fine-art market grew even faster than subprime housing. And then it kept on growing, pausing only momentarily during the crisis before hurtling even further upward. Eleven of the 20 highest prices ever paid at auction have occurred since 2008, when the global economy all but collapsed. Less than a week after the Munch auction, Mark Rothko’s “Orange, Red, Yellow” sold for nearly $87 million.

headline: Craig Venter’s Bugs Might Save the World
text: In the menagerie of Craig Venter’s imagination, tiny bugs will save the world. They will be custom bugs, designer bugs — bugs that only Venter can create. He will mix them up in his private laboratory from bits and pieces of DNA, and then he will release them into the air and the water, into smokestacks and oil spills, hospitals and factories and your house.

headline: When Do You Become an Adult?
text: There is an array of opinions as to when a person fully matures. Should the legal age of adulthood be lowered or raised? At what age do you think you are grown? Is it fair that people can serve in the military and vote at 18, but not buy alcohol until they are 21?

headline: Planning a College Visit? Readers Suggest Questions to Ask
text: We recently listed questions that prospective college students should avoid on a campus visit if they’re trying to find a good fit. The “do not ask” list was based on questions that L. Randolph Lowry III, the president of Lipscomb University, said he hears all too often when students come to visit. Mr. Lowry also offered a list of questions that more students should ask when visiting college campuses.

headline: Thai Message Board Manager Is Given Suspended Prison Sentence
text: BANGKOK — A Thai court sentenced the manager of an Internet message board to a one-year suspended prison term on Wednesday for comments posted by users that insulted the Thai royal family. The sentence was immediately condemned by Google and human rights groups.

headline: The Early Word: New Attack
text: Today’s Times

headline: Economically, Obama Is No Jimmy Carter
text: President Obama faces re-election amid a mixed and mediocre set of economic indicators. While there has been some improvement in the economy, most major indicators still show below-average growth.

headline: The Asymmetric Recovery
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Time to Buy Lawrie?
text: Over the years, I have become increasingly methodical in my draft-day preparations. As with many owners who play in several leagues, there is a strong correlation between the rosters of my eight teams this season. As a result, there are much larger investments in some players than others, and, of course, an even greater portion of the player pool that I avoided entirely because I was concerned about playing time or injuries because the draft-day price tag simply became too high. If you are into investment terms, you would say that I shorted these players.

headline: Discovered: The Magic Word
text: The word “hospice” usually evokes a shift, a pivot from trying to cure to providing comfort and support at the end of life. Hospice workers help people through the final weeks and months of terminal illness, easing dying people’s pain and fear, bolstering their exhausted families.

headline: Q&A With 2012 Hall of Famer Tony Meola
text: U.S. Soccer will induct four new members into the National Soccer Hall of Fame on Wednesday before a friendly against Brazil (8 p.m., ESPN2) at FedEx Field in Landover, Md. One of them will be Tony Meola, a New Jersey native who played 100 times for the national team, appeared in two World Cups and was a reserve for a third. Meola was a transitional figure in soccer in the United States, bridging the gap between an era when few followed the national team to one it which it drew 100,000 people to the Rose Bowl for a World Cup match. He was an ambassador for the country’s first World Cup and then for its new league, M.L.S., where he played for the MetroStars and won a championship with Kansas City. He now runs his own company, GK1 Sports; coaches two youth teams; and works with U.S. Soccer sponsors like Allstate, for whom he conducts clinics and appearances as part of its Good Hands FC program.

headline: Rockefeller and Rothschild Dynasties Join Forces
text: LONDON — Two of the world’s best-known banking families are combining forces after RIT Capital Partners, the investment trust led by Jacob Rothschild, said on Wednesday that it was buying a minority stake in the investment and wealth management firm Rockefeller Financial Services.

headline: Tip of the Week: Multitasking Gestures on the iPad
text: Want an alternative way to jump back to the main screen of the iPad without fumbling around for the Home button? The “multitasking gestures” feature, new with last year’s iOS 5 update, lets you use movements from all four fingers on the screen to replicate certain functions normally performed by clicking the Home button once or twice.

headline: On Tebow and Other Topics, Jets’ Mangold Keeps It Light
text: Broncos receiver Eric Decker recently said in a radio interview that he appreciated and respected Tim Tebow as a teammate but added, “To be honest with you, it is nice just to kind of focus back on football.”

headline: Drop Is Seen in Casualties for Afghans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Civilian casualties in Afghanistan dropped significantly in the first four months of 2012, and a smaller proportion of the deaths was attributed to coalition and Afghan forces compared with a year earlier, the United Nations director in the country said Wednesday.

headline: Does a Cleaning-Equipment Company Belong on Pinterest?
text: Three months ago, Craig Schuster was at home when he noticed what appeared to be a visually interesting clothes-shopping site on his wife’s computer screen. She told him it was actually a relatively new social-networking site called Pinterest, something of a cross between Facebook and Twitter that focuses on sharing images rather than text snippets or personal photos.

headline: The Dawn of the Evidence-Based Budget
text: On May 18, the Office of Management and Budget issued a memorandum that couldn’t be more critical to restoring public trust in government.

headline: Cambodian Start-up Competes With India in Natural Hair Market
text: “For an Internet start-up, Arjuni faces more challenges than usual,” Ron Gluckman writes in the Deal Book blog of The New York Times. “The e-commerce site that sells hair extensions operates out of a five-story building here that lacks elevators and, sometimes, power.”

headline: Ex-Liberian Leader Gets 50 Years for War Crimes
text: LEIDSCHENDAM, the Netherlands — Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia and a once-powerful warlord, was sentenced on Wednesday to 50 years in prison for his role in atrocities committed in Sierra Leone during its civil war in the 1990s.

headline: KPN Rejects America Movil’s Official Bid
text: LONDON – The Dutch telecommunications company KPN rejected an official offer from América Móvil, the Mexican telephone operator owned by the billionaire Carlos Slim Helú, continuing to say the 2.6 billion euro ($3.2 billion) bid was too low.

headline: Malicious E-Mail Attachment on Olympics Making Rounds on the Internet
text: Olympics enthusiasts: You may want to think twice before opening that PDF e-mail attachment of the 2012 Olympics schedule.

headline: Romney Camp Misspells ‘America’ in New App
text: 2:39 p.m. | Updated  Apple has moved with light-speed to approve an update to Mitt Romney’s new iPhone app, which no longer includes the word “America” misspelled.

headline: Leaders Challenged to End Syrian Slaughter
text: LONDON — Bernard-Henri Lévy, the flamboyant French philosopher who gave himself the credit for spurring international military intervention in Libya last year, called on Wednesday for France to rally its allies behind similar action in Syria.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Opinion Report: The National Mammal
text: From the editorial page

headline: Have Patience, Stop Being Cynical, Senior Minister Tells India Critics
text: MUMBAI — As the Indian economy has slowed, corporate executives, investors, analysts and opposition lawmakers have increasingly criticized policy makers for taking too long to make decisions, reversing themselves when they do act or enacting policies that hurt the economy.

headline: Fiona Apple Faces Outward
text: FIONA APPLE was angry. Very angry. “Angry, angry, angry,” as she put it during a long, unguarded conversation on a Friday afternoon in SoHo. About a year and a half ago, after she had completed the album she’ll release on June 19 — a collection of stripped-down, percussive songs that’s as passionate, smart and cutting as anything she’s done — Ms. Apple got so angry that she started walking up and down a hill near her home in Venice, Calif.

headline: European Officials Caution France and Warn of Challenges in Spain
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission urged euro zone countries on Wednesday to move toward greater fiscal integration, even as it prodded national governments to live up to their existing budget promises.

headline: From Z(oos) to A(rks)
text: Beyond housing and breeding endangered species, zoos are doing a variety of things these days to respond to threats of extinction.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Questions to Ask on a College Visit
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: When Technology Works, It Seems Like Magic
text: On Saturday, I had a five-hour layover in the airport in Dusseldorf, Germany. (Don’t ask.) I thought it would be a perfect time to get some woodshedding done on a book I’m writing.

headline: A Power Play Over Power Cuts in Myanmar
text: YANGON — It’s been nearly two weeks since hundreds of residents throughout Myanmar have taken to the streets every night to protest repeated power cuts.

headline: On the Train, Taking a Moment to Look Up
text: Dear Diary:Scene 1: On the subway and surrounded by five people reading real books: “The Catcher in the Rye,” something by David Sedaris, something about the Medicis and two I couldn’t catch.

headline: Vain Glorious | La Prairie’s Luxe New Mani/Pedi
text: Who: La Prairie

headline: Google to Use Zagat to Refine Local Search
text: Last year, when Google paid $151 million to buy Zagat, the restaurant-ratings publisher, people wondered how it would integrate customer-generated restaurant guides and online reviews into its universe of search.

headline: Police Release Report on School Arrests
text: The city made 327 arrests at the city's schools this winter, and handed out 555 summons, according to new data released by the New York Police Department. It was a slight uptick from the 279 students arrested during the 55 school days between Oct. 1 and Dec. 31, 2011.

headline: Daily Report: Google to Make Zagat the ‘Cornerstone’ of Local Search
text: Google announced Wednesday that it is planning to make Zagat, the restaurant-ratings publisher that it bought last year for $151 million in cash, the centerpiece of a new free service, Google Plus Local, reports Glenn Collins of The New York Times. The new service is intended to enhance Google’s growing, potentially lucrative local information offerings.

headline: Le First Trailer for ‘Les Misérables’
text: Universal has released its first trailer for Tom Hooper’s film adaptation of “Les Misérables,” ahead of its Dec. 14 opening, and it offers many tantalizing glimpses of Hollywood A-listers playing sad Parisians: Hugh Jackman as Jean Valjean, Russell Crowe as Inspector Javert, Amanda Seyfried as Cosette, Gerard Butler as the Phantom of the Opera. (Wait, scratch that last one.) But the focus in this first trailer is firmly on Anne Hathaway, who as the ill-fated Fantine offers a rendition of “I Dreamed a Dream” that’s as unembellished as her closely cropped hair. If you’re an easy crier you might want to keep handy a box of les Kleenex.

headline: Pepsi and Twitter Announce Partnership on Ad Campaign
text: In a world where people are increasingly turning away from sweet sodas and calorie-packed beverages, Pepsi’s ad campaign “Live for Now” is attempting to refresh the brand and its image.

headline: New York Gets Waiver for No Child Left Behind
text: New York is one of 19 states to receive a federal waiver from complying with provisions of the No Child Left Behind law. State Education Commissioner John B. King says the waiver allows New York to disregard requirements that were "unproductive or unrealistic."

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Court Rules Against Assange and ‘Hatfields & McCoys’ Pulls in Viewers
text: Britain’s highest court has ruled that Julian Assange, the activist and founder of WikiLeaks, can be lawfully extradited to Sweden to face allegations over sexual abuse, John F. Burns and Ravi Somaiya write. The ruling, the culmination of an 18-month legal battle, has left Mr. Assange living in limbo in England while arguing that the Swedish charges were a prelude to a possible extradition to the United States to face charges over the release of hundreds of thousands of American diplomatic cables.

headline: Bain Capital Said to Plan Raising New Fund
text: Bain Capital will soon begin raising its 11th leveraged buyout fund, with an aim of drawing in about $8 billion from investors, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: A Politician’s Right to Choose
text: ISTANBUL — Is the prime minister of Turkey losing his grip? Normally he has one hand on the pulse of the people, the other on his opponents’ jugular. Yet in a mystifying outburst last week, he appeared to excuse the killing last year of 34 Kurdish villagers in a botched antiterrorism operation by saying that those deaths were no worse than the overuse of Cesarean sections to deliver children in Turkey and the overdependence on abortion as a form of contraception.

headline: On Our Radar: Ailment Strikes Endangered Bat
text: White nose syndrome has been confirmed in endangered gray bats in Tennessee, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service says. The disease, caused by a fungus, has decimated some bat populations in eastern North America after first being documented in a New York cave in 2006. [Live Science]

headline: Lee Rich Dies at 93; Helped Create Both J.R. and John-Boy
text: Lee Rich, the creative force behind Lorimar Productions, an independent studio that spawned two of television’s most enduring (and archetypally opposite) fictional American families — the poor but happy kinfolk of “The Waltons” and the rich but tortured Ewing clan of “Dallas” — died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Observer: Mario Batali’s partner, Joe Bastianich, on Joe Bastianich, writing about, er, Joe Bastianich. — Susan Edgerley

headline: Wi-Fi and Amtrak: Missed Connections
text: IT was a Thursday morning, and Robert Treat, the chief technology officer for an Internet company, was looking forward to some uninterrupted time to get work done on the train from Baltimore to New York. Leaning back, hot cocoa at the ready, he logged on, scrolled through a few e-mails and then ... no more Internet. He logged on again, managed to connect for a few minutes, and soon enough: nothing.

headline: New Details Emerge on Conviction of Pakistani Who Aided Bin Laden Search
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Tribal court documents show that the Pakistani doctor who was sentenced to 33 years in prison after helping the C.I.A. track down Osama bin Laden had not been charged with treason, as some Pakistani officials had initially reported.

headline: Ex-Aide to Cameron Charged in Scottish Perjury Case
text: LONDON — Andy Coulson, a former tabloid editor in Rupert Murdoch’s media empire and later director of communications for Prime Minister David Cameron, was arrested by the Scottish police on Wednesday and charged with lying under oath about whether he knew phone hacking was going on at the newspaper he edited, The News of the World.

headline: Slovakia’s Cibulkova Overwhelms King
text: PARIS — Vania King was in trouble, struggling in the second round of the French Open on Wednesday. King had not won any of the first five games, then double-faulted to start the sixth game against Dominika Cibulkova of Slovakia, who is seeded 15th.

headline: Europe’s Economic Troubles Push Investors Toward 10-Year Note
text: Unnerved once again by Europe’s economic problems, investors rushed to buy United States government securities on Wednesday, sending the yield on the Treasury’s 10-year note down to a record low.

headline: Leading Off: Spurs, the Throwback Team, Still Dominating
text: The proper way to watch the Spurs’ victory in Game 2 of the Western Conference finals was stock-still, jaw slightly agape, eyes following every pinpoint pass, focused on plays so intelligently run it seemed Coach Gregg Popovich had found a way to live-animate his play board. You could almost feel John Wooden beaming all the way from the basketball afterlife. The Thunder, for the most part, worked hard and tried hard and the young star players leaned hard on their natural talent, but they were no match. They ended up looking like the bumpers in a pinball game.

headline: Some G.O.P. Foreign Policy Experts Are Tepid on Romney
text: Henry A. Kissinger gave his endorsement to John McCain more than a year and a half before the last presidential election, explaining in April 2007 that Mr. McCain’s “record, character and belief that America’s best days lie ahead” made him the “the right leader for these times.”

headline: National September 11 Memorial Museum
text: An animated rendering of the exterior of the National September 11 Memorial Museum site.

headline: National September 11 Memorial Museum
text: An animated rendering of the planned interior of the National September 11 Memorial Museum site.

headline: Business Day Live | May 30, 2012
text: The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion projects more losses. | India faces sluggish growth and tough economic choices. | Most aid to Greece skips over Greek citizens.

headline: Spring Interactive and Pop-Up Book Roundup
text: A selection of the best interactive and pop-up books of the season.

headline: Case Closed: Historic Home of Conan Doyle Is Saved from Redevelopment
text: It may not provide any answers to the cliffhanger that ended Season 2 of “Sherlock” but it’s a victory for Sherlock Holmes aficionados nonetheless. A Victorian house where the detective’s creator, Arthur Conan Doyle, lived in the late 1800s and early 1900s and wrote 13 Holmes adventures, including “The Hound of the Baskervilles,” has been saved from redevelopment and will not be turned into multiple dwellings, The Guardian reported.

headline: Wheelies: The Crossed-Out Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Image of the Day: May 30
text: A holy man applies vermillion on a child’s forehead at Sangam in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Spring Interactive and Pop-Up Book Roundup
text: UP, TALL AND HIGH!Written and illustrated by Ethan Long.40 pp. G.P. Putnam’s Sons. $15.99.(Picture book; ages 1 to 6)Doubling as a baby book and an early reader, this book about the ups and downs of avian rivalry succeeds abundantly on both fronts. Three linked stories feature three birds trying to outdo the others in one way or another. Who is tallest? Who flies highest? Is it better to be up or down? With clever humor, the simple text conveys lessons about adjectives, opposites and early math concepts. Long’s brightly colored exotic birds look like a cross between Mo Willems’s pigeon and Nickelodeon cartoons — animated, expressive and entertaining. A judicious sprinkling of oversize flaps provides an interactive element that expands — literally — on the proceedings.ANIMAL 123By Britta Teckentrup.18 pp. Handprint Books/Chronicle Books. $12.99.(Picture book; ages 2 to 4)

headline: White House Says President Misspoke on ‘Polish Death Camp’
text: The White House said on Wednesday that President Obama misspoke when he referred to a “Polish death camp” during a Medal of Freedom ceremony, an explanation that appears not to satisfy outraged Polish officials.

headline: CNN Hires John Berman From ABC to Anchor Early Morning Show
text: Foreshadowing further changes to its weekday schedule this year, CNN said on Wednesday that it had hired John Berman, a longtime ABC News correspondent, to be an anchor and reporter.

headline: Berdych Turns Tables on Llodra
text: PARIS — Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic blasted his way into the third round of the French Open Wednesday with a 6-2, 6-3, 6-3 victory over Michael Llodra of France.

headline: American’s Open Is Over but His Career Is Renewed
text: PARIS — On Wednesday, Court Philippe Chatrier at the French Open featured the usual characters, some of the world’s best and best-known tennis players. It also showcased someone named Brian Baker, whom even Roger Federer said he first heard of last week.

headline: Digital Literacy Includes Learning to Unplug
text: The new digital divide isn’t between children who have access to computers and devices and those who do not. It’s between kids whose parents are saying “turn that thing off” and those whose parents don’t limit their access — because they don’t know how, or because they’re not available to do it.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 5/30: Hotel Cosmetics and Anthony Bourdain’s Jump
text: Beauty on the Go Hotels have been upgrading the toiletries they supply their guests, replacing in-house brands with upscale ones that can be found at department stores or apothecaries. And if you’d prefer to pack your own, several high-end cosmetics labels have been offering miniature versions of their most popular cleansers and creams. (The New York Times)

headline: In Thailand, Burmese Workers Call Out to ‘Mother Suu’
text: MAHACHAI, Thailand — When word got out that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the long-imprisoned democracy campaigner, would visit this gritty town on the Gulf of Thailand, the mood became electric in the massive fish and shrimp processing plants where some Burmese eke out a living and where she is a heroine to many.

headline: Curator of Comics Is Leaving Home
text: A TYPICAL episode of the “Comedy Bang! Bang!” podcast goes like this:

headline: China Begins New Round of Stimulus, With Caution
text: BEIJING — Spooked by a sharply slowing economy, China’s leaders have begun opening the financial spigots to build still more roads and airports and subsidize consumer purchases, reprising measures that enabled the nation to sail mostly unscathed through the last great global recession.

headline: In London, a Chic Way to Home-Stay
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Want Comfy and Cheap? Try Foot Locker, Not Nicholas Kirkwood
text: IF you are going to charge four figures for shoes, as a startling number of designers are doing these days, it behooves you to frame them as artwork. To create a “shoe-seum,” as Kenneth Cole might put it.

headline: For Giants’ Tuck, a Push for Reading Starts at Home
text: FORT LEE, N.J. — Jayce Tuck is a typical 2-year-old. He is precious to his parents, loves chasing a soccer ball in the backyard and has an abiding passion for “cooking,” which recently meant standing in the kitchen, mixing a concoction of salt, pepper and whipped cream in a bowl, then stirring continually.

headline: Judge Defends Penalty in Rutgers Spying Case, Saying It Fits Crime
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — A judge offered a spirited defense on Wednesday of the 30-day jail sentence he imposed on Dharun Ravi, the former Rutgers University student convicted of using a webcam to spy on his roommate having sex with another man.

headline: Sorting Through Familiar Names at the Finals
text: NEWARK – The most common surnames in N.H.L. history are Smith (59), Brown (27) and Wilson (26), according to the Elias Sports Bureau, so it stood to reason that at least one of them would be emblazoned on the back of a player participating in the Stanley Cup Finals. Look no further than Dustin Brown, the Kings’ pugnacious captain.

headline: Race-Day Medication: the View from Overseas
text: The debate on the use of Lasix and other medications on race day in the United States has an inevitable “us vs. them” tone because most other racing jurisdictions around the world prohibit such drug use. In the heat of the argument, one comment keeps popping up: The Europeans are hypocritical because they use all the same drugs, just not on race day.

headline: A YouTube Appeal to Egypt’s Diaspora From the Muslim Brother Who Would Be President
text: Readers who are curious about the Egyptian presidential candidate of the Muslim Brotherhood but are hampered by their lack of Arabic can get a sense of the man by watching a video message he recorded in English, appealing for the support of the Egyptian diaspora.

headline: U.S. Envoy Sees Grim Outcome for Syria
text: With world outrage still reverberating over a weekend massacre of villagers, the United States ambassador to the United Nations suggested Wednesday that with little hope left for a political settlement, the conflict in Syria appeared likely to develop into a regional sectarian war.

headline: Irish Voters Are Expected to Approve Fiscal Pact
text: DUBLIN — Ireland appears poised to ratify in a referendum on Thursday a European Union treaty intended to stabilize the euro by punishing member states that fail to adhere to strict budgetary constraints.

headline: Brazilian Names for the U.S. National Team
text: Years ago a friend sent me a link to an Internet widget that lets you enter your name and spits back your Brazilian soccer nickname. Every couple of years, often when Brazil was in a big game or touring the U.S., I’d remember it and waste a few minutes entering the names of my children, my colleagues, my friends.

headline: Tips on Preventing Tax-Refund Identity Theft
text: The New York Times recently wrote about increasing tax refund identity fraud. That’s when a thief uses your name, Social Security number and birth date to file a fake tax return with fabricated income and tax-withholding data to collect an improper refund — often, on an easy-to-use prepaid debit card, sent to a specially chosen address.

headline: Growing Education Divide in Cities
text: College graduates are more unevenly distributed in the top 100 metropolitan areas now, compared with four decades ago.

headline: Obama Calls to Congratulate His Official Opponent
text: President Obama telephoned Mitt Romney on Wednesday to congratulate him on securing the Republican presidential nomination, and told Mr. Romney that he looked forward “to an important and healthy debate about America’s future,” a spokesman for the Obama campaign, Ben LaBolt, said.

headline: Accused of Abuse, but Not Charged, Teacher’s Aide Remains in Limbo
text: Hany Abdalla was 35 years old, working as a teacher’s aide on the Upper West Side, when his world came to a stop. On April 25, police officers came to his apartment in Queens and arrested him on allegations that he had sexually abused an 8-year-old special education student at Public School 84 on West 92nd Street, where he had worked since 2007. The Education Department suspended him without pay.

headline: Kim France, Starting Over at 48
text: YOU might guess that working for a shopping magazine is pure fun and frivolity, but after a decade as editor in chief of Lucky Magazine, the Condé Nast title she founded, Kim France “was suffering from serious, pretty much daily migraine headaches that I had begun to suspect only a pretty profound lifestyle change could improve,” she said recently.

headline: TimesCast | May 30, 2012
text: Britain’s highest court rules against Julian Assange’s extradition appeal. | The Flame computer virus hits Iran as diplomats prepare for another round of talks. | The guitarist Doc Watson dies at 89.

headline: Vietnam War Images, Photosynthesized
text: Growing up in California, Binh Danh was fascinated by the weird discolorations left on the lawn by the sun. Shaped like a garden hose or a rake, the images were baked into the grass, the sun bleaching the bent blades. At the time, Mr. Danh could only marvel at the effects of photosynthesis — the process that sustains all plants — but by college he’d discovered that the sun’s power could also be used to replicate other images.

headline: Stephens Beats Mattek-Sands in Second Round
text: PARIS — Sloane Stephens rolled past Bethanie Mattek-Sands, 6-1, 6-1, to advance to the third round of the French Open.

headline: The Social Issues Strategy Revisited
text: Two weeks ago, I had a back-and-forth with The New Republic’s Alec MacGillis over whether it was fair to suggest (as I had) that the Obama White House would much rather talk about social issues like the contraception mandate, the DREAM Act, and even gay marriage than about the economy and jobs. As an exhibit for my side of the argument, I’d like to submit this passage from John Heilemann’s New York piece this week on the Obama campaign’s plans for going negative against Mitt Romney:

headline: The Presidential Cage Match
text: David Brooks: Gail, people are always asking me who is going to win the election. They must know I don’t have a clue. I think they just want to hear me say that their favorite candidate is going to win.

headline: Technical Trading Issues to Blame for Facebook’s Fall, Meeker Says
text: Mary Meeker, a partner of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, does not blame the bankers for Facebook’s bungled debut.

headline: More Genes Than Humans: The Tomato Decoded
text: The tomato, whose genome has just now been decoded, turns out to be one well-endowed vegetable, possessing 31,760 genes. This rich legacy, possibly a reflection of the disaster that killed off the dinosaurs, is some 7,000 more than that of a person, and presents a complex puzzle to scientists who hope to understand its secrets.

headline: Detached From His Label
text: ON March 16, just two days after Simon Spurr received a nomination for best men’s wear designer from the Council of Fashion Designers of America, he stunned the fashion industry by resigning from his own label, which is only six years old.

headline: A Gap in College Graduates Leaves Some Cities Behind
text: DAYTON, Ohio — As cities like this one try to reinvent themselves after losing large swaths of their manufacturing sectors, they are discovering that one of the most critical ingredients for a successful transformation — college graduates — is in perilously short supply.

headline: On Climate Change, It’s Money vs. Mouth
text: A number of major United States corporations publicly support climate change science but contribute heavily to politicians and research groups that deny or play down the threat of global warming, according to a new study from the Union of Concerned Scientists.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘The Bad and the Better’
text: When the playwright Derek Ahonen needed a poster for his latest work, the dark detective comedy “The Bad and the Better,” he asked Danica Novgorodoff, a graphic novelist and illustrator, for the kitchen sink.

headline: An Art Project Provides a Snapshot of a Closing School
text: An independent photographer volunteered to work at a school that is going to be closed, and in the process led to a series of portraits of students that will be displayed Wednesday night in the M.S. 571 gymnasium. Her goal was to create a project that would engage students, parents and community members in a dialogue about education and advocacy. “None of these kids chose to be in this situation,” she said about the closing school.

headline: Images of Vietnam War, Transferred to Plants
text: Over on the Lens blog, our colleagues have published a post on the work of Binh Danh, a photographer who has used photosynthesis to re-envision the Vietnam War.

headline: Books Under Glass: The Many Faces of E-Readers
text: IN some ways, the only reason to stick with dead tree books these days is nostalgia. E-readers are more fully featured and much more impressive than ever, and they have fallen far below the $100 price tag because of improved technologies. If you are still content to read the latest Stephen King novel in its full five-pounds-of-paper glory, get ready to rethink your habits.

headline: A Retreat for Haves, a Shelter for Have-Nots
text: With its curved lines and steel exterior, the House Arc may resemble an old Airstream trailer, but its design was inspired by a bike rack.

headline: ‘Hidden’ Water: Where Does It All Go?
text: Water, a plentiful banality to some Americans but a source of conflict for millions of others, is a more intriguing commodity than you may have thought. At least, that’s the conclusion one might draw from Surface Tension: The Future of Water, an exhibition that opened today in Manhattan as part of the 2012 World Science Festival.

headline: Academy Picks Piano and Pali to Design Film Museum
text: LOS ANGELES — The new movie museum planned by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has its architects. Renzo Piano, whose work includes the recent expansion of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, and Zoltan Pali, who has helped restore the Greek Theater and other buildings here, will join in building the film museum. The institution will be located in the old May Company department store next to Lacma.

headline: RIM Shares Drop, and Analysts Warn of Further Trouble
text: Research in Motion’s already depressed shares fell sharply on Wednesday after the company unexpectedly warned that it would probably post a loss for its first quarter, and several analysts predicted worse is yet to come.

headline: ‘Leap’ Producers Keep the Faith by Underwriting Tony Awards  Number
text: The producers and investors in the Broadway musical “Leap of Faith” lost more than $14 million when the show closed on May 13 after receiving terrible reviews from critics. Usually the only thing left would be the tax write-offs. But even as the biggest flop of the season, “Leap of Faith” had an unusual asterisk – its single Tony Award nomination, a major one, for best musical. And so the producers had a decision to make: Whether to leave “Leap of Faith” dead and buried, or capitalize on the nomination and pay to stage a musical number on the Tony Awards telecast on CBS on June 10?

headline: A Teacher's Aide, Accused of Sexual Abuse, Waits for Justice
text: Hany Abdalla, a teacher’s aide at Public School 84 on West 92nd Street, was arrested in April and accused of sexually abusing an 8-year-old special education student. The Education Department suspended him without pay, but he has not been charged with any crime.

headline: New Digs | The Hole Shop at the Hole Gallery
text: Back in 1999, before retail moved in and skinny jeans became the neighborhood’s de facto uniform, the hippest place on the Lower East Side was Alife, a sneaker shop-cum-gallery on Orchard Street that served as both clubhouse and launch pad for a generation of downtown artists, including Steve Powers, a k a ESPO; Ryan McGinley; and Dash Snow. Two of Alife’s founders, Rob Cristofaro and Arnaud Delecolle, have since gone on to found a design agency called New York Art Department, under the guise of which they’ve taken on a new retail project: the Hole Shop at the Hole Gallery. “The idea is to bring some of what we were doing at Alife, before the scene was appropriated and commercialized, and apply it to what’s going on today,” Delecolle explains. The merchandise includes books, T-shirts, Polaroid cameras from the Impossible Project, Krink markers and sustainable furniture made by the Brooklyn design firm Uhuru. Since taking over the Bowery space a couple of months ago, NYAD has also hosted book-release parties — the French graffiti artist FAFI dropped by last week to sign copies of her first comic book — as well as film screenings and a 24-hour-a-day curated video screen that’s currently under the auspices of Luck You, a collective of teenage artists who work out of a loft in Chinatown. Continuing Delecolle and Cristofaro’s tradition of introducing new artists to wider audiences, on June 1 they’re curating their first show at the Hole Gallery. It will feature the work of a graffiti artist known only as Jim Joe, whose combination of anonymity, ubiquity (Jim Joe’s cryptic tags are all over the East Village and the Lower East Side) and epigrammatic use of social media has spurred a cult following. “Jim Joe is one of those artists who have one foot in the graffiti world and one foot in something weirder and more conceptual,” says Kathy Grayson, the Hole’s founder. “I’m really excited to see what he comes up with for his first gallery exhibition. I’m sure that it will capture the odd humor and serendipitous, random mischievousness of what he does in public places, and I get the sense that he is sophisticated enough to make it work in a new way in a gallery space. I would definitely say that this is a very hotly anticipated show as no one knows who he is and everyone wants to see what he does next.”

headline: Vintage Murano Glass on the Block
text: Frank Toskan, a founder of MAC Cosmetics, spent about two decades amassing his collection of Murano art glass, and on June 9, Wright in Chicago will auction it off.

headline: DwellStudio’s New Dwelling
text: DwellStudio, a furniture and accessories company known for its boldly patterned textiles, is opening its first store on Friday.

headline: Meeting the Demand for Quirky Objects
text: Mario Marsicano and Chris Lenox founded Jellio in 2005. The company, which is based in New York, makes whimsical home furnishings.

headline: Divergent Path on Israel Helps Lobby Group Grow
text: WASHINGTON — There was a time not so long ago when political contributions from Americans supportive of Israel inevitably veered toward those Congressional candidates who were the most hawkish and outspoken in defending Israel and its security.

headline: Business Day Live: India’s Economy Slows
text: The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion projects more losses. India faces sluggish growth and tough economic choices. Most aid to Greece skips over Greek citizens.

headline: Paying Rent on Minimum Wage
text: As part of its 2012 report on rent affordability, the National Low Income Housing Coalition released a chart that’s been floating around the Internet. It shows that there isn’t a single state in the country where it’s possible to work 40 hours per week at minimum wage and afford a two-bedroom apartment at Fair Market Rent. In West Virginia and Arkansas, you’d need to work at least a 63-hour week, and that’s as good as it gets. In California, Maryland, D.C., New Jersey and New York you’d need to work 130 hours or more. Hawaii comes in last place: 175 hours.

headline: House Democrat Is Defeated in Texas Primary
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Representative Silvestre Reyes, a Democrat in his eighth-term who is a former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, was defeated Tuesday in the Democratic primary by a former El Paso city councilman, Beto O’Rourke.

headline: Facing Down the Bankers
text: WASHINGTON — Sitting in a corner office high above K Street here, Dennis M. Kelleher, one of the most powerful lobbyists on financial regulatory reform, looks every bit the corporate lawyer and high-ranking Senate aide he formerly was: tailored suit, quick smile, assertive tone.

headline: Name-Dropping at Gupta Trial
text: 8:54 p.m. | Updated

headline: After a Frustrating Election, Young Egyptians Look for a Way Ahead
text: In recent months, Mayy el Sheikh, a 24-year-old Egyptian reporter and researcher for the Cairo bureau of The New York Times, has written about Egypt’s political transition for The Lede. Here she describes her own family’s and friends’ experiences after the first round of the presidential election this month.

headline: The Products Sell, but Can Jellio Make Enough of Them?
text: We’ve just published a case study about Jellio, a maker of whimsical home furnishings that is based in New York. Mario Marsicano, a former advertising agency account director, had long collected old toys — Rock ’em Sock ’em Robots were among his favorites. He collected so many that he decided to experiment with embedding some in a table made of Lucite. When his friends started asking for their own Rock ’em Sock ’em tables, he figured he might be on to something. He and Chris Lenox, a co-founder, introduced Jellio with a Web site in 2005.

headline: An Interview With Alex Morgan
text: The Times’s Andrew Das spoke with the United States women’s soccer star about her team’s preparations for the Summer Games.

headline: Acme
text: TAKE a spot once occupied by a lowly Cajun restaurant, bring in a team from Indochine, install the Norwegian chef Mads Refslund and add a subterranean lounge with an oppressive doorman. That’s the calculus behind Acme, a restaurant and cocktail bar that, since opening in NoHo last February, immediately joined the gilded caste of places you’re obligated to visit.

headline: Detainees Are Handed Over to Afghans, but Not Out of Americans’ Reach
text: BAGRAM, Afghanistan — Gen. Ghulam Farouq is not exactly the master of his own house, the Parwan Detention Facility, at least not yet.

headline: In Italy, Electric Buses Wirelessly Pick Up Their Power
text: Battery-powered buses that do not require frequent stops at charging depots might seem a maybe-someday proposition. But Conductix-Wampfler, a wireless-charging engineering company based in Weil am Rhein, Germany, claims the bus of the future is fully operational on the streets of Turin and Genoa, Italy, and has been for 10 years.

headline: Keeping Score: Looking at History to Predict a Champion
text: Carlton Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method.” They have previously written on last year’s Stanley Cup finals, the World Series, the Super Bowl and N.C.A.A. men’s basketball final.

headline: Help in Buying Digital Savings Bonds
text: At this time of year, some people like to buy savings bonds for their grandchildren, nieces and nephews who are graduating from high school or college, or getting married.

headline: Video: Alex Morgan on Preparations for London
text: The Times’s Andrew Das spoke with the U.S. women’s soccer star about her team’s preparations for the Summer Games.Read the full Q. & A. with Morgan on the Goal blog.

headline: Chess Champion Keeps Title After Tense Set of Tiebreakers
text: Viswanathan Anand retained the world chess championship on Wednesday by defeating Boris Gelfand in a series of tiebreaker games in a title match in Moscow.

headline: Second Night of Feuding Brings Second Night of High Ratings
text: The History Channel’s spectacular success with the miniseries “Hatfields and McCoys” held relatively steady on Tuesday, its second night, drawing a total audience of 13.1 million viewers.

headline: Another Williams Is Ousted at Roland Garros, This Time Unsurprisingly
text: PARIS — It would have required much more accuracy and energy than Venus Williams possessed on Wednesday to successfully attack Agnieszka Radwanska, one of the sport’s great shock absorbers.

headline: Collector Sues Gallery Over Loss of Instructions for a  LeWitt Work
text: “Wall Drawing #448” by the Conceptual artist Sol LeWitt came in two pieces, a list of precise instructions on how to create a wall drawing and an example what such a drawing might look like.

headline: GoPro Makes a Case for Undersea Video
text: GoPro, makers of the wearable Hero cameras commonly used to film skiing, surfing and racing, has added a new underwater housing to its lineup.

headline: Oh, to Be Just Another Bearded Face
text: NOT since Walt Whitman edited The Brooklyn Daily Eagle has the borough’s beard-to-man ratio been this high.

headline: Eames Furniture and More for Less
text: All Herman Miller furniture is 15 percent off at the MoMA Design Store, through Tuesday (the Eames lounge chair and ottoman, below, regularly $5,000, is $4,250; the Eames Aluminum Management chair, regularly $2,045, is about $1,738); 81 Spring Street (Crosby Street), (646) 613-1367, momastore.org.

headline: How Michael Haneke Uses His Actors
text: “I’ve been accused of ‘raping’ the audience in my films, and I admit to that freely — all movies assault the viewer in one way or another,” Michael Haneke told the magazine in a 2008 profile by John Wray. “What’s different about my films is this: I’m trying to rape the viewer into independence.”

headline: TimesCast | Assange Faces Extradition
text: Britain's highest court rules against Julian Assange's extradition appeal.

headline: Deconstructing Harry (and Joan and Don):  Scholarly Blog Takes on ‘Mad Men’
text: Fans of “Mad Men” are used to flocking to venues like ArtsBeat’s “Mad Men Watch” or New York Magazine’s “Mad Men Recap” first thing on Monday mornings to obsessively parse the previous night’s twists and turns. But viewers who find those discussions a bit light on references to Marxist theory and other intellectual heavy artillery now have another place to go.

headline: Racism and Soccer Are in Play at a Big Event in East Europe
text: The most important sporting event in Eastern Europe since the fall of the Berlin Wall begins June 8 with the European soccer championships hosted by Poland and Ukraine.

headline: Extra-Strength Re-Enacting
text: As the dawn slowly brightened the sky above Pittsburg Landing, Tenn., a regiment of some 450 modern-day Yankee infantrymen blinked eagerly awake, if they had slept at all. The bluecoats had spent the wee hours resting on their arms beside a stone wall that runs along a path from the Shiloh battlefield visitor’s center down to the Tennessee River. On the other side of the wall ran the gravestones of their 19th-century counterparts covering a dewy hillside in tidy rows and half circles.

headline: Homes for $800,000
text: Properties in Idaho, San Francisco and Boston.

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000
text: SANDPOINT, IDAHO

headline: Digital Notes: Judge Presses U.S. in Megaupload Case
text: When the police in New Zealand raided the headquarters of the file-sharing site Megaupload in January on behalf of the United States authorities, the case, at first, seemed strong.

headline: John Mayer’s ‘Born and Raised’ Tops Billboard Chart
text: John Mayer has a throat condition, granuloma, that prevented him from doing some promotion for his new album, “Born and Raised” (Columbia). But that didn’t stop the album from reaching No. 1 on the Billboard chart with a healthy sales number, while most other titles looked anemic.

headline: Quinn, Presumptive Candidate, Will Publish Memoir Before Election for Mayor
text: Christine C. Quinn is taking a step more commonly associated with presidential campaigns than mayoral ones: She is writing a pre-election memoir.

headline: Why Camp Counselors Can Out-Parent Parents
text: Are you having trouble getting your 9-year-old daughter to make her bed every day? How about your 11-year-old son? Does he get up in the morning and run down to the dining room to set the breakfast table for the family? And after breakfast, does he clear the dishes and wipe down the table? He doesn’t? Sorry to hear that. (Neither did mine.)

headline: A Hillside Perch With Caribbean Views
text: A four-bedroom villa in the Dutch island enclave of St. Maarten is on the market for $1.95 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... St. Maarten
text: A CARIBBEAN VILLA WITH WATER VIEWS

headline: Europe Fears Bailout of Spain Would Strain Its Resources
text: LONDON — As Spain’s deepening financial problems make a European bailout a more distinct possibility, a looming question is where the money will come from.

headline: Research In Motion Prepares for Losses
text: May 30, 2012 - The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion projects more losses.

headline: Table Talk | Rosemary’s in Manhattan
text: When the restaurateur Carlos Suarez (owner of Bobo) was away at English boarding school, he missed the rustic meals cooked by his mother, Rosemary. “My father had his own business, so he worked a lot,” Suarez said. “Family dinner was our opportunity to sit together and enjoy her cooking: salads with tomatoes or avocados from the garden, shepherd’s pie and schnitzel (she’s English with an Austrian background).” Now living in a house with an olive grove in Lucca, Italy, Rosemary’s specialties have since changed, and it comes as no surprise that her son has named his new Italian restaurant in her honor. In the space that once housed Cushman’s, then Sutter’s Bakery, Suarez has Wade Moises, former chef de cuisine of Eataly, overseeing a kitchen that makes fresh pasta and focacce, as well as seasonal dishes prepared with ingredients grown on the restaurant’s organic rooftop garden. (The day’s harvest gets dropped down to the dining room in a basket on a block and tackle.) “It’s an opportunity to bring the source of the food literally a flight of stairs away from your dining table,” said Suarez, who plans to give students from the local Public School 41 tours and lessons on “how to turn those vegetables into lunch. We’re hoping to offer generosity, camaraderie and engagement — a sense of community,” he said. There’s another unusual aspect to the joint. Beyond the reclaimed wooden table tops, Suarez has gone green with a Dekar Design interior: “Instead of filling space with taxidermy and black and white photos, we used nature as our décor.” Inside are towers of artichokes and lemons, even “little Dr. Seuss” blueberry trees. Outside, the roof will also soon feature a beehive and chicken coop.

headline: Eisenhower Family Welcomes Some Proposed Memorial Changes, Rejects Others
text: The family of Dwight D. Eisenhower on Wednesday said it welcomed some aspects of a modified design for a memorial to honor the former president on the National Mall, but still has reservations about other components.

headline: ‘Nurse Jackie’ Star and Writer Team Up for Manhattan Theater Club Production
text: Edie Falco — the tart-tongued, pill-popping title character of the Showtime series “Nurse Jackie” — will star in the world premiere of “The Madrid,” a new play by Liz Flahive, who is also a staff writer on the series.

headline: A Prime Time Spotlight for Justin Bieber
text: NBC has decided to give Justin Bieber an hour-long special in prime time, planning to broadcast “Justin Bieber: All Around the World” on Thursday, June 21, at 8 p.m.

headline: A Return to the Finals Was on Ice For 15 Years
text: NEWARK — You can still hear the regret in Dainius Zubrus’s voice, all these years later.

headline: Q.&A.: Wireless Industry Likes Spectrum Sharing, but Still Wants More
text: As The Times reported last week, a presidential advisory committee is urging President Obama to adopt computer technologies so that better use is made of radio spectrum for wireless communications. The report says that newer radio technologies could help share spectrum among, say, government agencies and companies, and thereby increase capacity a thousandfold. In other words, the technologies would help carriers serve the exploding number of data-guzzling smartphones and tablets on the market.

headline: U.S. Imposes Duties on Chinese Wind Tower Makers
text: WASHINGTON — Chinese manufacturers of towers for wind turbines received unfair subsidies and must now pay duties of 13.7 to 26 percent, the Commerce Department said on Wednesday in a preliminary decision in a case brought by four American manufacturers of the towers.

headline: French Scholar Died of Heart Disease, Officials Conclude
text: A leading French academic whose naked body was found in a Midtown hotel room last month died of heart disease, the medical examiner’s office said on Wednesday.

headline: Photo Replay: May 30
text: The French Open continued in Paris and the former Yankee Hideki Matsui hit a home run in his debut with the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Quakes’ Fallout in Italy Is Also Economic
text: MEDOLLA, Italy — Until 11 days ago, this district in northern Italy was renowned as the home of some of the world’s leading manufacturers of disposable medical devices used for dialysis, transfusion and surgery.

headline: Scene City: Miracle House Kicks Off Summer
text: In certain circles, the Miracle House benefit signals the start of the summer social season.

headline: How to Sound Like an Expert While Watching the Finals
text: The Stanley Cup finals begin tonight in Newark. You can impress your friends during Game 1 by dropping some of these nuggets of knowledge, courtesy of the N.H.L.

headline: When a Countess Holds Court
text: BEFORE she played herself on TV as a real housewife of New York, and before she became a countess through marriage and remained one after the divorce, LuAnn de Lesseps was a licensed practical nurse from Connecticut.

headline: Wildlife Refuges Raise Property Values, Study Shows
text: Beyond the scenic views or flora and fauna, metropolitan area homeowners who live near a national wildlife refuge now have a different reason to appreciate the proximity. Research shows that such homes have higher property values than those that are farther from a reserve.

headline: College Grads Flock to Some Cities, Forgoing Others
text: There is a growing disparity among cities that have a surfeit of college graduates, like Washington, and those, like Dayton, Ohio, that are trying to attract more grads, an analysis by the Brookings Institution indicated. College graduates are increasingly important economic drivers, particularly in cities that have largely lost their manufacturing sectors and the accessible jobs they provide.

headline: Sweden 1912: For Marathoners, a Breath of Fresh Air
text: One hundred years ago the Summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

headline: Mary Meeker’s Views on Mobile
text: Mary Meeker, the Internet analyst now with the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, presented the latest version of her influential Internet Trends report at the All Things D conference on Wednesday. The report showed that Internet growth is being driven largely by developing countries, with China adding 215 million Internet users between 2008 and 2011. It also shows the explosion of mobile, which has been rapid, but still has a lot of room to grow. There are 953 million smartphone subscriptions, but 6.1 billion mobile phone subscriptions. There are still some concerns about how to monetize mobile Internet use. Ms. Meeker argues that the prospects are good, but that it will take time. The slides from Ms. Meeker’s presentation are embedded below.

headline: Samsung Takes On iPod Touch, With Flair
text: In the swimming pool’s worth of ink that has been spilled on Apple over the years, not enough fuss has been made about the iPod Touch.

headline: Debating the Merits of Patent Warfare
text: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif. — Nathan Myhrvold, the founder and chief executive of Intellectual Ventures, says he doesn’t care much whether people in the technology industry like him. Many people in the tech industry seem happy to oblige him.

headline: Obama Video on Fox News Criticized as Attack Ad
text: 6:53 p.m. | Updated The Fox News Channel came under withering criticism on Wednesday for a four-minute video broadcast on its morning show “Fox & Friends” that portrayed President Obama’s tenure as a series of failed promises.

headline: A.E.P. Backs Down on Coal Plant Retrofit
text: American Electric Power conceded defeat on Wednesday, at least temporarily, in its push to save Big Sandy, its 49-year-old coal-burning plant in eastern Kentucky, surprising state officials there by withdrawing its $1 billion plan to retrofit the power plant so that it can meet tough new federal environmental regulations.

headline: To Hear Doc Watson, You Really Had to See Him
text: Doc Watson, who died on Tuesday at age 89, was the first truly great guitar player I ever saw up close. For me, growing up in Santa Monica, Calif., in the 1950s meant that great musicians were only manifested on records and radio, making it hard to catch a glimpse of the person behind the layers of sound and presentation. You knew people like Hank Snow and Merle Travis were great, but you couldn’t be sure how much the Nudie suits and custom boots had contributed to the sound you heard on KXLA radio.

headline: History, 4 Wheels at a Time
text: The Great Tail Fin Wars of the late 1950s, between Chrysler and Cadillac; the Prius-Hummer face-offs of the early 2000s; the Cinderella transformation of the drab little Ford Falcon into the snazzy Mustang; and the even more startling metamorphosis of Hitler’s Volkswagen into the American counterculture’s car of choice in the ’60s and ’70s — these are just some of the wonderfully entertaining real-life stories in Paul Ingrassia’s book “Engines of Change: A History of the American Dream in Fifteen Cars.”

headline: Efforts to Save Endangered Hawaiian Birds
text: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

headline: In San Francisco, Reviving Irish-American Whiskey
text: Irish-American whiskey has returned.

headline: For Some, Exercise May Increase Heart Risk
text: Could exercise actually be bad for some healthy people? A well-known group of researchers, including one who helped write the scientific paper justifying national guidelines that promote exercise for all, say the answer may be a qualified yes.

headline: The Get | Chance’s Elliott Stripe Tees
text: Founded by Julia Leach, a former executive vice president and creative director for Kate Spade, Chance is a T-shirt company turned total-lifestyle brand. Take Leach’s latest “California” collection (her second), for example. It includes not only a group of simple and thoughtfully designed striped tees in fresh West Coast colors, but also all of the things that support a summer well spent wearing them: sheared cotton towels that read “Seashore” and “Poolside,” espadrilles, Turkish “foutas” (multi-use textiles) and straw fedoras, to start. This month the designer adds yet another must-have to the mix — a limited edition long-sleeve style featuring a wiggly stripe hand-drawn by the artist Elliott Puckette, a friend of Leach’s. “I wanted the shirt to appear to be a canvas,” Leach says. “I didn’t want trims or excessive stitching to interfere with the grace of the lines.” Available in four colors — soft black, pink, sky blue and pool blue — the Pima cotton tees echo Puckette’s preferred palette. For her, the design process began as ink on paper. “Ordinarily I etch the lines in my paintings, which is fairly laborious and slow,” she says. “I found the process of drawing these lines instead very meditative and fluid.” Here, the artist Leanne Shapton surrounds herself with all four. Wouldn’t you?

headline: Obama Extends the Export-Import Bank
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama signed a bill on Wednesday that extends the life of the Export-Import Bank through 2014, ending an unexpectedly fierce political fight over an institution dedicated to financing American exports abroad.

headline: Three Varied Tools for Blogging With a Hand-Held
text: Being a dedicated blogger once meant accepting life as a laptop nomad or being shackled to a desktop workstation.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Two dads, one real and one fictional, navigate their new realities, while novelists embrace the drama in a railroad accident and an assassination. Meanwhile the woman-behind-the-great-man genre welcomes George Balanchine and a ballerina wife into the fold.

headline: Revisiting the Romantics at a Breathless Sprint
text: There are only a few artists so popular that Carnegie Hall will place chairs onstage to accommodate the large audiences they invariably attract, as the pianist Lang Lang did on Tuesday evening for his solo recital there.

headline: TimesCast | Flame Fallout in Iran
text: Iran confirmed that Flame, a data-mining virus, had spread into the computer systems of high-ranking Iranian officials.

headline: Father and Son, and Other Pairings
text: John Pizzarelli has the gift of gab in more ways than one. A great storyteller, he can spin the tiniest anecdote about the musician’s life into a sidesplitting absurdist yarn. As a guitarist who leads his own quartet, he instigates high-speed musical conversations within the group that have the fast, frisky playfulness of a pro basketball team tossing off a victory. Propelling the ensemble’s signature bounce are Mr. Pizzarelli’s younger brother, Martin, on bass, the drummer Tony Tedesco and Larry Fuller on piano.

headline: Baker’s Run Ends, One Rally Short
text: Watching Brian Baker’s straight-sets win over Xavier Malisse on Monday, I sensed a moment, late in the third set, when Baker began to lose his legs. Playing eight matches in eight days has a way of wearing a person down, and Baker, despite a two-sets-to-love lead, needed to put Malisse away in the third set tiebreaker. He stepped up his aggressive play and pressured Malisse into some forced errors, and won the match to continue his magical ascendance up the rankings.

headline: Playing Up the Humor When Fools Fall in Love
text: When two ballerinas share a full-length narrative ballet, they are usually rivals, fighting over the same man, often to the death. In “La Bayadère,” which American Ballet Theater performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last week, one woman poisons another. In Alexei Ratmansky’s “Bright Stream,” Ballet Theater’s latest offering, a husband strays, but the two toe-shoed objects of his affection stick together in solidarity.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Zuckerberg’s Tipping and Google Tablet
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: Romney’s Favorable Ratings Are Up in New Poll
text: Mitt Romney’s positive ratings have improved and Michelle Obama remains as popular as ever, according to two new national telephone surveys.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Lebanon, West Bank, Spain and Argentina.

headline: Taking Her Leave
text: IT was a little more than a year ago that the New York City socialite Amanda Brooks was appointed fashion director of Barneys New York, to some cluck-clucking in the industry. After all, Ms. Brooks, 38, had little experience in retail, other than acting as a muse and later creative director to the fashion label Tuleh, and was more often photographed in preppy classics than the avant-garde brands for which Barneys had been known under the stewardship of her well-regarded predecessor, Julie Gilhart. As the blog Fashionista put it, “We’ve always thought of Brooks as more of a Bergdorf girl.”

headline: Back to I ♥ NY, With More About What’s to Love
text: ALBANY — The Cuomo administration wants to put the New York back in “I ♥ NY.”

headline: Fluent in the Hard-Core Joy of Monk
text: Thelonious Monk’s music stands for many things — intuitive rigor, rugged refinement, a system of intervallic order — but what often goes underused by his interpreters is its baseline condition of pleasure. That particular lapse is not a problem for the pianist Eric Reed. During his sold-out first set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night, he played six Monk compositions with thoughtful attunement to their essence. He also made them seem about as cheery and buoyant as a bunch of balloons held by the string.

headline: Adding Some Guesswork to Memorabilia Sales, Just for Televised Fun
text: Ah, the stresses of the memorabilia sellers on “Final Offer,” Discovery’s new entry in what might be called How Much Can I Get for My Stuff Television. Four buyers, but no clue as to which one is willing to pay the most. “If only I could drill into their heads and see what they’re thinking,” these hopefuls must be musing.

headline: We’re Fox News and We Approved This Message
text: It’s hardly controversial to say that Fox News serves the Republican agenda. Certainly there’s a rightward slant to their commentary programs, which I actually think is fine. (The Times opinion section generally has a leftward slant.) What’s problematic is that their opinion and news offerings are often indistinguishable, leading to accusations of bias.

headline: Turning Your Phone Into a Photo Studio
text: SO your smartphone has a camera; now what? It is probably time to get some apps.

headline: Small Cameras That Can Switch Focus or Ride a Bike
text: POINT-AND-SHOOT cameras are being assaulted on all fronts. Smartphones are threatening to make pocket-size cameras unnecessary by offering passable results on a device many people are already carrying around. Meanwhile, photographers who want better performance are likely to be tempted by mirrorless interchangeable lens cameras, which are shrinking to nearly pocket size while offering features like those found on professional-level, single-lens reflex cameras.

headline: Duets, Ensembles, Dance Music and Arias, All in the Lobby
text: Only a musician with theatrical imagination and pluck would have walked into the artsy lobby of the Gershwin Hotel in the Flatiron district of Manhattan and seen its potential as a space for quirky opera productions. That is what happened in 2009, when the harpsichordist, pianist and conductor Jennifer Peterson founded the performance company Operamission.

headline: Sociopathic Thoughts With a Twist
text: The triple bill at Rumsey Playfield on Tuesday night was a snapshot of current pop: calculated, crisp, insistently catchy, selectively nostalgic and diligently seeking twists.

headline: Toys That Will Bring Out the Boy in Any Dad
text: FEW things can peel away the layers of maturity from a man like a well-made remote-controlled toy helicopter. In the spirit of helping Dad remember his boyhood, here is a roundup of recent toys that the children might enjoy too. We have tried to include something for all ages, abilities and budgets.

headline: Cake Shop’s Struggles
text: A Lower East Side club that served as an incubator for celebrated indie bands hopes an Internet fund-raising campaign will allow it to stay open.

headline: For Gamers, a Kind of Christmas Comes Early
text: With the annual Electronic Entertainment Expo (known as E3) next week in Los Angeles, most of the video game industry is focused on the future. But that doesn’t mean there aren’t great games on the market right now.

headline: Recreating Lost Instants in a Reconstructed Ballet
text: WASHINGTON — Dance, the art of the uncapturable present tense, continually loses its past. As a result, the world of ballet is forever characterized by nostalgia for stagings that exist only in memory but that exert extraordinary force there.

headline: Joël Robuchon to Close at the Four Seasons
text: The Four Seasons Hotel and L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon have issued a joint announcement that they will not renew their operating agreement and that the restaurant will close June 30. The agreement is amicable, both parties said.

headline: Crumbs From the Crowd to Pay the Bills
text: Cake Shop, a Lower East Side club that served as an incubator for celebrated indie bands like Vampire Weekend and the Dirty Projectors, is facing a financial crisis and has started a novel Internet fund-raising campaign to keep its doors from closing.

headline: Madeline Miller Wins Orange Prize
text: Madeline Miller, an American debut novelist, won the Orange Prize on Wednesday for her book, “The Song of Achilles,” a lyrical retelling of “The Iliad” that was published by Bloomsbury in Britain and Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, in the United States.

headline: The Secrets of a High-Quality Vinyl Record
text: TURNTABLES, those once-arcane machines for playing records, have staged a big comeback as a hipster essential, like cocktails with artisan bitters and skinny jeans with rolled cuffs over oxfords without socks.

headline: Red, Blue and Purple: Hollywood Tries Bipartisan Bashing
text: LOS ANGELES — Will Ferrell plays Cam Brady, apparently a Blue Dog Democrat.

headline: In New Digital Comics, Each Tap Holds a Surprise
text: “AVENGERS VS. X-MEN” is giving fans what they have long come to expect from Marvel Comics: epic slugfests and earth-shattering perils rendered vividly on the page by prominent writers and artists. But this time around, the publisher has added something new: its first Infinite Comic, a digital-only prelude to “Avengers vs. X-Men” that was released with issue No. 1 of the print series last month. It represents another step by the comic book industry toward embracing the digital format, and one that holds the potential to push traditional comic book storytelling to a new level.

headline: No One Needs to Know You’re Absent-Minded
text: YOU may have seen the advertisements for a cellphone with a really big number pad.

headline: Goldman Pairs at Eastern States Regional
text: The Goldman Pairs is the oldest bridge pair event still being held. The first was played in 1929. The winners of the 84th edition, last Sunday at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan, were Franco Baseggio and Andrew Stark of New York City. They finished one and a half boards ahead of George Krizel of Feasterville-Trevose, Pa., and Albert Shekhter of New York City. Third were Murray Melton of Las Vegas and Marty Seligman of Philadelphia.

headline: Daddy, What Were Compact Discs?
text: ONE day, when my children are a little older, I will gather them close and I will tell them about how I lived through the Great Format Wars.

headline: The Buzz
text: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

headline: In Praise of Typing, the Clattering Kind
text: AMID the civil hush of the New Main San Francisco Public Library, I recently experienced an aspect to writing I’d all but forgotten: noise. It happened in a workspace called the Typewriter Room. Operating the machine that gives the room its name, I struck the “T” key, then the “H” key, and for the first time in at least two decades, I was rewarded with the bracing clackety-clack of analog-era content production.

headline: Up-to-Date Tricks for Aging Wheels
text: CARS on American highways are getting older. The average vehicle is now nearly 11 years old, up from about nine years in 2001, according to the R. L. Polk automotive research company. That means many drivers in the “dads and grads” cohort are probably candidates for a technology upgrade.
