Fortunately, there are plenty of options for gift givers, as varied as high-tech collision warning systems and phone-related devices intended to prevent driver distraction.

headline: New Police Photo of Suspect in Patz Case
text: Here is the police photograph of Pedro Hernandez, 51, who was arrested last week and charged in the death of Etan Patz, the 6-year-old boy who disappeared from a SoHo street in 1979. Mr. Hernandez has been charged with second-degree murder. He is being held at Bellevue Hospital Center.

headline: A Guide to Deciphering the Language of Smartphones
text: BUYING a smartphone, whether for yourself or as a gift, is a harrowing process made all the more mystifying by the language the marketers use. Every year they add new lingo and ever trickier claims — all networks can’t be the fastest, can they?

headline: M.L.S. Fans Get Chance to Argue For Stadium on Hudson River
text: A joint public meeting of the Hudson River Park Trust and the Park Advisory Council is being held on Thursday that will have an enormous impact on a potential future for Major League Soccer at Manhattan’s Pier 40, on the Hudson River.

headline: Going Beyond the Wand to the Brain
text: ZENITH’S Flash-Matic, the original wireless TV remote invented by Eugene Polley, looked like an intergalactic weapon, and no wonder. It was born at the same time as the “Flash Gordon” TV series, which ran from 1954 to 1955.

headline: First, Some Rules
text: As the source of numerous marital skirmishes and intrafamily feuds, the battle for control of the remote is an undeniable irritant in many homes. But for all that, little has been written about the etiquette of using the clicker, said Peter Post, the great-grandson of Emily Post and author of “Essential Manners for Men.”

headline: Mike Daisey Returns to the Apple Story, With Journalists as Targets
text: Mike Daisey was last seen apologizing for exaggerations and falsehoods in his influential one-man show “The Agony and Ecstasy of Steve Jobs” about the working conditions at the Chinese factories that make many Apple devices.

headline: Mubarak’s Sons Charged With Insider Trading
text: CAIRO — Prosecutors charged Gamal and Alaa Mubarak, the imprisoned sons of former President Hosni Mubarak, with insider stock trading on Wednesday, just three days before both men are expected to hear the verdict in a criminal trial charging them with corruption during their father’s three decades of rule.

headline: Pushing All Our Buttons
text: IT started out in the 1950s as an effort-saving gadget, like the electric can opener or electronic car keys. It evolved into a necessity, a cultural magic wand that has transformed the relationship of viewers to their televisions, and the style and content of the programs on view.

headline: CFDA Fashion Awards 2012 Nominees
text: Some on the list are very familiar faces, others are newer nominees.

headline: Prosecutor’s New Assistant on Staten Island: Therapy Dog
text: Crime victims on Staten Island have a new assistant to the district attorney to help get them through the often re-traumatizing judicial process.

headline: Summer Without Splinters
text: I USUALLY don’t like to tackle a home improvement project until bloodshed or bankruptcy is imminent, but sometimes you just can’t tell.

headline: A Palazzo’s Rebirth

headline: Just When You Got Digital Technology, Film Is Back
text: When is the last time you took a photo with an old-school camera — the kind that doesn’t have a wireless connection, needs to be loaded with finicky rolls of film and is too bulky to slide into a back pocket?

headline: At 86, Kit Currie Is Still Reinventing the Box
text: Kit Currie recently showed a visitor around the West Village apartment she has lived in since the late 1970s. There are lots of books, probably because Ms. Currie, who is 86 and was born in England, spent more than 40 years working for rare book dealers like Bertram Rota in London, Dawson’s in Los Angeles and H. P. Kraus in New York. She also has dozens of origami boxes on display — some of the pieces she has made over the years.

headline: Bistro Chairs
text: CLAIRE PIJOULAT and Odile Hainaut have lived in New York for a combined 21 years, yet neither is quite used to the sight of people hustling down the street carrying coffee.

headline: Cable News Ratings Fall Across the Board, From Fox to MSNBC
text: Is a presidential election a turnoff to news viewers, even those who generally like to hear political opinions reflected in cable news shows?

headline: Like Mona Lisa, Ever So Veiled
text: TO appreciate the designs of Rei Kawakubo, the woman behind the label Comme des Garçons, it helps to be a specialist in fashion, or something of a kook.

headline: A Hybrid That Runs on Foot Power and Beer
text: AMSTERDAM — Eight British bankers in orange jumpsuits, their ID patches embroidered with the names of Tolkien characters, were in town for a bachelor weekend (Frodo was getting married). They had just finished a two-hour city tour on a beer bike. “Arwen fell off!” said a very cheerful Pippin. “He almost killed himself!”

headline: Kleiner Perkins Fires Back in Sex Discrimination Case
text: The venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, sued this month by a junior partner who said she had been sexually harassed and then punished for complaining, fired back on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Lidstrom Set to Announce Whether He’s Playing or Retiring
text: Detroit General Manager Ken Holland declined to say Wednesday whether Red Wings defenseman Nicklas Lidstrom will announce his retirement at a news conference scheduled for Thursday morning in Detroit.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,974 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Polish Premier Denounces Obama for Referring to a ‘Polish Death Camp’
text: WASHINGTON — On May 28 of last year, President Obama stood next to Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland in Warsaw and declared he would support new rules to help more Poles get tourist visas to the United States. “If you’ve lived in Chicago and you haven’t become a little bit Polish,” Mr. Obama joked, “there’s something wrong with you.”

headline: Former Justice Stevens Portrays Court as Inconsistent After Citizens United
text: Justice John Paul Stevens, who retired from the Supreme Court two years ago, accused his former colleagues in a speech Wednesday night of inconsistency, if not incoherence, in their rulings in the aftermath of Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the blockbuster 2010 campaign finance decision.

headline: N.H.L. Labor Talks to Begin Soon, Bettman Says
text: NEWARK — Negotiations on a new contract between the N.H.L. and the Players’ Association will begin “within the next few weeks,” Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday. Earlier this month the league sent the union notification that it was terminating the current agreement on Sept. 15.

headline: You Can Go Home Again
text: THEY’RE back.

headline: Mets in No Rush to Negotiate With Wright
text: Jeff Wilpon, the chief operating officer of the Mets, said Wednesday that the organization was in no hurry to initiate contract negotiations with David Wright, the team’s star third baseman.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 13
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Students Press for Action on Immigration
text: Young illegal immigrants, saying President Obama has done little to diminish the threat of deportations they face despite repeated promises, have started a campaign to press him to use executive powers to allow them to remain legally in the country.

headline: Graff Diamonds Pulls $1 Billion I.P.O. in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — Graff Diamonds said it pulled an initial public offering here that had planned to raise $1 billion, the third such deal in the city to be withdrawn this week due to falling global markets.

headline: Michael J. O’Neill, Ex-Editor of The Daily News, Dies at 89
text: Michael J. O’Neill, a former editor of The Daily News in New York who directed its breathless coverage of the “Son of Sam” serial killer, then became a strong national voice for responsible media behavior, died on Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: Shopping Calendar Gets a School Day
text: A MAGAZINE for teenage girls will try, joined by marketers and retailers, to add another “special” day to the American marketing calendar already crowded with celebrations both real (Christmas, Halloween) and fanciful (Black Friday, Cyber Monday).

headline: The Tale of Ticks and Other Excess
text: I cannot tell you what a relief it was when I discovered that the multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan was because of deer.

headline: Tougher Drug Rules Ordered at Belmont, With Extra Scrutiny on O’Neill
text: The 144th running of the Belmont Stakes may or may not produce horse racing’s 12th Triple Crown champion, but New York racing officials are taking measures to ensure that I’ll Have Another’s bid to sweep the series is contested on a level playing field and without illegal drugs.

headline: In Milwaukee Post, Cardinal Authorized Paying Abusers
text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York authorized payments of as much as $20,000 to sexually abusive priests as an incentive for them to agree to dismissal from the priesthood when he was the archbishop of Milwaukee.

headline: Markets and Morals
text: Does it bother you that an online casino paid a Utah woman, Kari Smith, who needed money for her son’s education, $10,000 to tattoo its Web site on her forehead?

headline: The Fire Next Term
text: Nerves are jangling across the ideological spectrum as the end of the Supreme Court term approaches. So confident just weeks ago, conservatives now appear oddly rattled, beset with sudden worries over the prospect that Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may fail to do their bidding and could actually vote to uphold the health care law. Leading conservative columnists have devoted their energy during the past week to bucking up the chief justice.

headline: That Unused Hour on Your Parking Receipt? You Might Think About Selling It
text: For its most single-minded users, the city’s transportation system has long offered the occasional opportunity for profit.

headline: Education Budget Basics for Next Year
text: SchoolBook attended the CIty Council hearing on next year's school budget so you didn't have to. We have the highlights and details.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Weakness in Facebook Stock Adds to Pause in I.P.O.’s
text: In the days since the highly anticipated opening of Facebook turned into a flop last week, the impact has become worse as would-be issuers have taken a second look at what they’re getting into.

headline: Too Much Power for a President
text: It has been clear for years that the Obama administration believes the shadow war on terrorism gives it the power to choose targets for assassination, including Americans, without any oversight. On Tuesday, The New York Times revealed who was actually making the final decision on the biggest killings and drone strikes: President Obama himself. And that is very troubling.

headline: For the White House, a Wary Wait as Syria Boils
text: WASHINGTON — After ordering American forces to Libya last year, President Obama declared that he had tackled a humanitarian crisis more decisively than his predecessors.

headline: Hornets Land Top Pick in N.B.A. Draft
text: Anthony Davis ended his lone season of college basketball by cutting down the nets in the Louisiana Superdome after helping Kentucky win the national championship. Now, it looks as if he will make New Orleans his permanent home as the Hornets won the No.1 pick in the N.B.A. draft lottery on Wednesday night in New York.

headline: The Credit History Underclass
text: Millions of Americans with damaged credit records are at risk of being unfairly denied job opportunities by companies that use credit histories to screen applicants. Faced with growing public complaints, seven states have rightly limited the use of credit histories by potential employers. Federal, state and local lawmakers who are considering similar legislation are on the right track.

headline: Leo Dillon
text: Mr. Dillon and his wife, Diane, produced artwork that praised for its vibrancy, ecumenicalism and beauty.

headline: Charles Taylor and the Next 50 Years
text: In his fancy suit, yellow tie and wire-rimmed glasses, Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, looked deceptively respectable as he sat waiting for his sentencing on Wednesday. No one was fooled, least of all the judge at an international criminal court near The Hague who gave the former warlord 50 years in prison for his role in instigating murder, mutilation, rape, sexual slavery and the use of child soldiers in Sierra Leone’s horrifying civil war during the 1990s.

headline: Down by 2-0, Thunder Grab for Lifeline
text: SAN ANTONIO — Intentionally fouling a 6-foot-11 backup center five times in a 54-second span of the third quarter might sound like the final desperate act of a team on the brink of elimination.

headline: Sexual Harassment Settlement by School District Is in Dispute
text: LOS ANGELES — Last week, officials with the Los Angeles Unified School District announced that they had settled with a senior employee who accused former Superintendent Ramon C. Cortines of sexual harassment. But that settlement appears to be coming undone, and the matter could be on the way to a long legal battle.

headline: Leo Dillon, Celebrated Illustrator of Children’s Books, Is Dead at 79
text: Leo Dillon, who with his wife and longtime collaborator, Diane, was one of the world’s pre-eminent illustrators for young people, producing artwork — praised for its vibrancy, ecumenicalism and sheer sumptuous beauty — that was a seamless amalgam of both their hands, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. He was 79.

headline: Bases Loaded, and the Yankees Are Coming Up Empty
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — A year ago the Yankees were the most productive team in baseball with the bases loaded, hitting 10 grand slams and scoring 146 runs.

headline: Escaped Bees Bring a Visit From the Police
text: Animals will get restless if left unattended in a sweltering parked car.

headline: Doc Watson
text: In the 1960s, nearly every aspiring guitarist spent a lot of time sitting beside a record player, setting the needle on the vinyl, listening to a few bars and then trying to pick out the notes on the guitar. (Now, of course, there are apps to make this easier.) You would do this over and over and over again. With a little patience, a song would give up its secrets. And the more songs that gave up their secrets, the easier the learning became. For a lot of us young guitarists, that process came to a halt when we first heard Doc Watson, who died on Tuesday at 89.

headline: A Peace Plan in Name Only
text: Cairo

headline: Training to Spot Tree Decay Is Urged for Parks Workers
text: Arborists and tree-care experts say that New York City could significantly improve public safety by ensuring that the workers who evaluate trees understand the warning signs of decay and failure.

headline: Lightning Strikes Feed Volatile Fire Season
text: DENVER — Driven by high winds, brittle conditions and lightning strikes, wildfires raged across swaths of the Southwest and the Midwest on Wednesday, the latest rash of blazes in what has already been an especially volatile fire season.

headline: Berlin Exhibition Highlights Soviet Architecture
text: Eager to distance themselves from their imperialist past and embody the new ideals of the Soviet state, the architects of Communist Russia created avant-garde structures with a social purpose.  Through July 9, the exhibition “Building the Revolution:  Soviet Art and Architecture 1915-1935” at the Martin-Gropius-Bau (Niederkirchnerstrasse 7; 49-30-254-86-0) in Berlin combines vintage photographs, period artwork and current images to explore the Constructivist movement that rose out of the Russian Revolution.

headline: Comptroller Says Contractor on 911 System Billed Millions in Inappropriate Charges
text: A major contractor on New York City’s troubled 911 emergency-dispatch system inappropriately billed at least $2.5 million, and possibly up to $50 million, for tasks as varied as opening an office door and killing water bugs in a bathroom, according to an audit released on Wednesday by John C. Liu, the city comptroller.

headline: U.S. Still Learning, With Brazil as Teacher
text: LANDOVER, Md. — When the United States crashed out of the men’s Olympic qualifying tournament earlier this spring, it was seen as an incredible disappointment, an opportunity missed for the top young American players who lost out on a chance to play on some of the sport’s grandest stages at the London Games.

headline: New York Plans to Ban Sale of Big Sizes of Sugary Drinks
text: New York City plans to enact a far-reaching ban on the sale of large sodas and other sugary drinks at restaurants, movie theaters and street carts, in the most ambitious effort yet by the Bloomberg administration to combat rising obesity.

headline: Don’t Bring Me Down
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — The word BANDBOXES was a new one on me; I always thought they were called hatboxes, but you can put any old thing in a bandbox I guess, not just a hat.

headline: Should Latin America End the War on Drugs?
text: Instead of an ever-escalating war, governments could approach drugs as a public health issue. Would that reduce the body count?

headline: M.T.A. Agrees to Allow Its Workers to Wear Religious Headgear
text: Muslim and Sikh transit workers will be allowed to wear religious head coverings while on the job under a settlement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced on Wednesday. The agreement ended a winding legal case propelled by the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: On Campus, New Deals With Banks
text: College campuses have long been attractive hunting grounds for financial institutions looking for new customers.

headline: Amid Uproar, Graphic Painting of South African President Is Removed From Gallery
text: JOHANNESBURG — To the artist and a gallery director, it was a scathing piece of satire — a riff on Soviet-style propaganda aimed at a powerful president with a controversial sexual history who presides over a liberation movement-turned-political party that many here feel has lost its revolutionary appeal.

headline: Researchers Find Clues in Malware
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Security experts have only begun examining the thousands of lines of code that make up Flame, an extensive, data-mining computer virus that has been designed to steal information from computers across the Middle East, but already digital clues point to its creators and capabilities.

headline: 2 Publishers Deny Claim of E-Book Price Fixing
text: The government’s complaint “piles innuendo on top of innuendo.” It is based “entirely on the little circumstantial evidence it was able to locate.” And it “sides with a monopolist.”

headline: ‘American Idol’ and Its Owner to Undergo a Retooling
text: The company that owns the rights to the hit television series “American Idol” is reorganizing and changing its name in an effort to diversify as a broader-based media company, in recognition that its biggest moneymaker, “Idol,” has finally begun to lose momentum.

headline: Brazil’s Political Class Jolted by Claim That Ex-Leader Pressed a High Court Judge
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s political establishment is being shaken by a claim that Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the country’s most influential contemporary political leader, put pressure on a high court judge to delay a trial over a vote-buying scandal involving high-ranking members of the governing Workers Party.

headline: Governor Throws Weight Behind Senate Candidate
text: SOMERVILLE, Mass. — In a last-minute change of heart, Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, who said last year that he would stay neutral in the race against Senator Scott P. Brown until Democrats had settled on a candidate, endorsed the embattled Elizabeth Warren on Wednesday.

headline: Syria Sees No Need for Journalists to Investigate Massacre
text: Updated | Thursday, 8:43 a.m. Just hours after a correspondent for Britain’s Channel 4 News filed a video report from the Syrian village of Houla, where dozens of children were killed in a massacre last week, Syria’s ambassador to the United Nations made it clear that his government would not be swayed by witness accounts of the killings gathered by journalists.

headline: Geek Chic: ‘Be N Er Dy’ Tote Bag
text: A fashion statement with a science angle, as seen at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute commencement weekend on the shoulder of a talented chemistry major.

headline: Colombia: Rebels Release Journalist
text: The country’s largest rebel group on Wednesday released a French freelance journalist whom it had held captive for more than a month. The group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, had claimed that the journalist, Romeo Langlois, was a prisoner of war. He was taken captive on April 28 when he accompanied Colombian Army soldiers on an antidrug mission. The soldiers got into a firefight with the FARC, which gets most of its income from drug trafficking. Four soldiers and a policeman were killed. Mr. Langlois said that he was tired but in good health.

headline: Tibetan Woman Dies in Self-Immolation
text: A Tibetan mother of three died after setting fire to herself on Wednesday in the county of Ngaba, known in Chinese as Aba. The woman, in her mid-30s, was identified by Free Tibet, an advocacy group, as Rechok. She set fire to herself outside the Jonang Dzamthang monastery in the town of Barma, Free Tibet reported. The group added that Rechok had tended to the family’s animals in the last few days and then traveled to town to kill herself. Radio Free Asia identified the woman as Rikyo, 33.

headline: After 8 Days and No Edwards Verdict, Alternate Jurors Are Sent Home
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — After more than 45 hours of jury deliberations over eight days, there is still no verdict on whether former Senator John Edwards is guilty of violating federal campaign laws.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (1) vs. Brazil (4)
text: The United States national team’s match against Brazil on Wednesday night was Game No. 2 in an 18-day stretch culminating in the Concacaf World Cup qualifier at Guatemala on June 12.

headline: Bolivian Politician Takes Refuge at Brazilian Embassy
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — A prominent Bolivian opposition politician has taken refuge in the Brazilian Embassy in La Paz, claiming that he is being persecuted by the administration of President Evo Morales for accusing government officials of human rights abuses, drug trafficking and corruption.

headline: Gay Marriage Ban Challenged in Illinois
text: CHICAGO — Less than a month after President Obama endorsed gay marriage, two dozen same-sex couples filed two separate lawsuits in the president’s home state on Wednesday, arguing that it is unconstitutional for Illinois to deny them the right to wed.

headline: Kenya: Suspect Is Sought in Blast
text: Kenyan authorities were looking for several people who they believe planted a homemade bomb at a crowded market in Nairobi on Monday. Originally, the police said that the explosion, which injured more than 30 people but killed no one, was caused by an electrical malfunction. But on Wednesday, Kenya’s largest newspaper, The Daily Nation, published a mug shot of a foreign terrorism suspect who the police say has extensive bomb-making experience and recently entered the country from Somalia. Kenya has suffered several relatively small bomb attacks since it sent forces into Somalia in October to fight the Shabab, a militant Islamist group.

headline: Down With Religion?
text: Everyone knows that America is far more religious than most other developed countries.

headline: Mets Rough Up Lee, but Bullpen Breaks Down
text: Minutes after Lucas Duda broke out at the plate Wednesday night, the Mets’ bullpen broke down in a big way on the mound.

headline: Rhode Island: Deal May Avert Bankruptcy
text: A tentative deal between the city of Providence and its workers and retirees will prevent the city from going into bankruptcy, Mayor Angel Taveras said Wednesday. Mr. Taveras announced that retirees, current safety officials and current municipal workers agreed to a 10-year suspension of cost-of-living increases for most pensions — and limitations thereafter — and the migration of their health care plans onto Medicare. He had said the city would run out of money in June if it did not lower its pension obligations and increase voluntary contributions from the city’s tax-exempt institutions; the city has since secured deals on increased payments with universities and hospitals.

headline: For a High Price, SAT Available in Summer
text: For the first time, the SAT exam will be offered outside the school year — but only to students enrolled in a $4,500 summer program for gifted students on the Amherst College campus. Elizabeth Stone, an independent college counselor in California, calls the Aug. 3 exam unfair and elitist, since other students, including hers, cannot take the SAT until October. Robert Schaeffer, public education director of FairTest, said students want the opportunity to take the SAT over the summer, free from the pressures of daily school work. The College Board said that exam is a pilot “to evaluate the feasibility” of summer tests.

headline: An American Diplomat in Moscow Takes Flak on Twitter
text: Diplomacy is usually a nuanced game that can turn on a word and a handshake preferably delivered in private.

headline: Corrections: May 31
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Body Parts Found in Canada Came From One Man, Police Say
text: OTTAWA — Three human body parts — a foot, torso and hand — that were discovered separately on Tuesday all came from the same victim, a man who apparently had been killed and dismembered in a Montreal apartment, the police there said Wednesday.

headline: Rhode Island: State Surrenders Suspect in Killing
text: A suspect in a killing at the center of a lengthy custody battle between federal prosecutors and Rhode Island was handed over to federal authorities on Wednesday, when he was arraigned in a Federal District Court before a magistrate judge. Jason W. Pleau, 34, is accused of killing a gas station attendant in 2010. Gov. Lincoln Chafee refused to surrender Mr. Pleau in 2011, arguing that doing so could expose him to the death penalty, which Rhode Island does not have. The state was ordered to hand over Mr. Pleau this month; Mr. Chafee has said he will appeal that decision to the Supreme Court.

headline: Washington: Ruling Against Border Patrol Backup
text: The practice of Forest Service officers’ requesting language interpretation and security backup from Border Patrol agents during stops of Spanish-speaking people is discriminatory, according to a federal administrative ruling made public this week. The ruling, by Joe Leonard Jr., the assistant secretary for civil rights of the Department of Agriculture, said requesting interpretation assistance was “merely an excuse to target Latino individuals for immigration enforcement.” The ruling came in response to a claim by the companion of a Mexican man who drowned in a river on the Olympic Peninsula of Washington last year after a Border Patrol officer, summoned by a Forest Service officer, chased the man into the woods. The couple had been stopped on national forestland while picking salal, an evergreen shrub used in floral arrangements. The ruling included disciplinary actions against some employees, and it ordered the Forest Service to create new guidelines for dealing with people who speak limited English.

headline: Fluke Bounce Aside, Quick Proves Too Tough to Solve
text: NEWARK — It happens every nine years, or close to it. A team from Southern California opposes the Devils in the Stanley Cup finals, and it heads east with a goalie that lets in pucks with the approximate frequency of a lunar eclipse.

headline: Kings Break Away to Take the Opener
text: NEWARK — The Los Angeles Kings’ juggernaut kept rolling at Prudential Center on Wednesday night.

headline: Devils Have a Plan, but Fail to Execute It
text: NEWARK — As if the Devils had not been suffocated enough by Los Angeles’s stout defense through almost two full periods Wednesday, Kings goaltender Jonathan Quick fell on top of Zach Parise and stayed there, using his elbow to knock off Parise’s helmet.

headline: Usher to Recruit Digital Dance Crew for Concert Webcast
text: Judging from his recent “Saturday Night Live” appearance, Usher already looks plenty busy when he’s onstage. But for a concert he will play on June 11 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London, and which will be broadcast live on the Internet, his collaborators say they have devised a way for Usher to be joined in performance by digital dancers created by online viewers.

headline: Afraid to Speak Up at the Doctor’s Office
text: A friend of mine, a brilliant and accomplished academic in her 70s who once specialized in history and literature, recently phoned to ask for medical advice after being discharged from the hospital for what sounded like a mini-stroke. Ever eager to learn something new, she pressed me on “the latest research” and asked what doctors around the country were doing for her condition.

headline: Graduated Licensing Is Credited for Declining Death Rate Among Teenage Drivers
text: In news that ought to relieve parents, the death rate of teenage drivers has fallen steadily and dramatically in the United States since 1996, when states began enacting graduated driver licensing laws. Analysis of the death rate was recently performed by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and its affiliate organization, the Highway Loss Data Institute, which are financed by the insurance industry.

headline: Word of the Day | lancet
text: lancet •\ˈlan(t)-sət\• noun

headline: The Heat Withstand a Big Night by Rondo
text: MIAMI — They watched Rajon Rondo whirl through them like a blender, witnessed a Ray Allen renaissance and felt the full force of the Boston Celtics’ survival reflex. For three stressful, strenuous hours Wednesday, the Miami Heat lived the mantra coined by their slogan-happy coach: “Embrace the difficult.”

headline: Delhi’s Modernist Architecture in Photographs
text: Veteran photographer Madan Mahatta took shots of some of the prominent buildings that defined the landscape of Delhi from the 1950s to the 1980s, as the city was embracing Modernist architecture. An exhibition of his work is on at the Photoink gallery in New Delhi till July 2, 2012.

headline: News Quiz | May 31, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: India’s Chess World Champion Retains Title
text: Viswanathan Anand retained the world chess championship on Wednesday by defeating Boris Gelfand “in a series of tiebreaker games in a title match in Moscow,” Dylan Loeb McClain writes in The New York Times.

headline: On ‘Greece-Proofing’ China
text: China urgently needs to “Greece-proof” itself to avoid powerful shocks that will undoubtedly come if Greece leaves the euro, a leading Chinese economist says, amid the sound of screeching brakes from an economy that has been looked to for world growth.

headline: Yankees Survive and Avoid Sweep
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — After repeated attempts and failures, the Yankees finally got Mark Trumbo out in the final at-bat Wednesday, and barely avoided a sweep by the Los Angeles Angels. They also avoided the ignominy of falling into a tie with the Boston Red Sox for last place in the American League East.

headline: India’s Super Rich Help Fuel Art Market
text: “A few weeks ago, when Edvard Munch’s iconic painting ‘The Scream’ went for about $120 million and became the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction, it seemed like we had reached the climax of a fine-art bubble,” Adam Davidson writes in The New York Times.

headline: Yankees’ Martin and Umpire Are at Odds
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Yankees catcher Russell Martin had an unusual night Wednesday in the Yankees’ 6-5 victory over the Angels.

headline: Japan Moves Closer to Restart of Nuclear Plant
text: TOKYO — Japan moved closer to restarting the first of the nation’s idled nuclear plants as the prime minister signaled that he might order a start-up as early as next week and as a new round of scrambling to persuade local leaders to drop their opposition appeared to be working.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 31, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Former Mountain Biker From Canada Wins Giro.”

headline: Charles Taylor Is Sentenced for War Crimes at International Court
text: WHO is Charles Taylor?

headline: A Big Dig Close to Nature and Home
text: Jonathan Blaustein has a lot of rocks. He has probably more rocks than any single man could ever need.

headline: British Minister Concedes Sympathy to Murdoch TV Bid
text: LONDON — With his career in the balance, Culture Minister Jeremy Hunt said at a judicial inquiry into the British media on Thursday that he had been personally sympathetic to a bid by Rupert Murdoch to take over Britain’s most lucrative pay-television network, but that he did not act with improper bias.

headline: Jamie Dimon and the Fall of Nations
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Who Would Be the Ideal Celebrity Neighbor?
text: There’s a fact you may not know about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton: they try to take time out of her daunting schedule every year to attend their neighborhood Memorial Day parade in Chappaqua, N.Y. The neighborly behavior is characteristic of the Clintons, who are surprisingly involved in the community. Do you live near any celebrities? If you could pick a famous person as a neighbor, whom would you pick?

headline: A Terse Warning for Euro States: Do Something Now
text: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president who pulled the Continent back from the financial brink late last year, is facing an even more daunting challenge as the debt crisis in Spain deepens. But this time, he may have a harder time fashioning a rescue plan that will work.

headline: The Early Word: Diplomacy
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: CGI of Canada to Buy Logica for $2.6 Billion
text: LONDON — The Canadian computer services company CGI Group on Thursday agreed to buy the British information technology company Logica for £1.7 billion, or $2.6 billion, as CGI looked to continue its expansion into overseas markets.

headline: Steve Jobs Still Looms Large
text: Steven P. Jobs died nearly eight months ago, but the technology industry is not ready to let him go.

headline: Harbaugh, ‘Hard Knocks’ and the Hard to Believe
text: In homage to David Letterman’s old Museum of the Hard to Believe, we offer two exhibits:

headline: Q&A: Safely Dumping Old Data Discs
text: Q.

headline: Twelve Cold Soup Recipes
text: Adaptable recipes that can be made with the vegetables and fruits of summer, or whatever is in your fridge.

headline: Soup, Hold the Heat
text: Vichyssoise once seemed the height of sophistication, something served only in French restaurants, and serious ones at that. It turns out, however, that cold leek-and-potato soup — which is an American invention, by the way — is just cooking-from-the-garden stuff, as simple as it gets.

headline: Freaks, Geeks and Microsoft
text: When the Kinect was introduced in November 2010 as a $150 motion-control add-on to Microsoft’s Xbox consoles, it drew attention from more than just video-gamers. A slim, black, oblong 11½-inch wedge perched on a base, it allowed a gamer to use his or her body to throw virtual footballs or kick virtual opponents without a controller, but it was also seen as an important step forward in controlling technology with natural gestures.

headline: Stone Links: Philosophy, American Style
text: In this essay, adapted from his book “America the Philosophical,” Carlin Romano rebuts the common charge — shared by Tocqueville — that American culture is essentially anti-philosophical. That’s only true, he says, if we think of philosophical engagement as the academy would have us, namely, as tantamount to knowledge of the Western philosophical canon. While it’s true that Americans are less familiar with that canon than some of their European counterparts, it needn’t be true that they are philosophically averse, so long as we take philosophy not to inhere in any body of knowledge, or in the application of any particular method — conceptual analysis, phenomenology and so forth — but rather in an imaginatively critical cast of mind. Taken this way, America turns out to be the most philosophical culture on the planet.

headline: Cheers and Jeers For Queen’s Jubilee
text: LONDON — Britain is gearing up for a monstrous excess of pomp and overindulgence this weekend to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: Q.&A.: Martin Cooper, Father of the Cellphone, on Spectrum Sharing
text: Martin Cooper, the former vice president of Motorola who helped create the first working cellphone, has been saying for some time that technology is the solution to dealing with the ever-rising demand for wireless data capacity. Now a presidential advisory committee agrees with him, urging President Obama to adopt technologies that would use radio spectrum more efficiently. Wireless carriers argue that they need more spectrum, not just better-managed spectrum.

headline: Obama Campaign’s New Attack on Romney’s Record as Governor
text: How can President Obama defeat Mitt Romney?

headline: After the Houla Massacre
text: Last week’s massacre of 108 people, including 49 children, in the Syrian area of Houla was unanimously condemned by the Security Council. Are the tables about to turn against President Bashar al-Assad?

headline: Venezuela’s Top Party Prison
text: MONTREAL — On their way into Discoteca Tokio, women were greeted with a single rose. It was Mother’s Day after all, and this was a Mother’s Day celebration. Ads for the concert had been running all week on local radio. Singers were brought in from Puerto Rico and Colombia. Ladies, ready for the raffle? Win a washing machine, or a 42” plasma HDTV!

headline: Strains on India’s Government Grow After Sharp Economic Slowdown
text: MUMBAI, India — India’s growth fell to its slowest pace in almost a decade last year, according to government estimates published Thursday, putting further pressure on a fractured coalition government in New Delhi that has been widely criticized for its management of the economy.

headline: Visiting the Suburbs Without the Drive
text: AS a native of suburbia, I have a soft spot for its ethos: the arena rock and shopping malls, the chain stores and competitive lawn care. But when I moved to New York City, I did so because I wanted to do all the things that New Yorkers do. Lately, though, I noticed something odd happening around Manhattan: The suburbs are seeping in.

headline: India’s Growth Slows to 5.3 Percent
text: India’s gross domestic product growth for the year ending March 31, 2012 was 6.5 percent, down from earlier estimates of 6.9 percent, thanks to lower-than-expected performance in “manufacturing, trade, hotels, transport and communication,” the Ministry of Statistics reported Thursday. Growth for the three months ending March 31 was 5.3 percent over a year ago, thanks in part to steep drops in cargo transport and slowing manufacturing, among other factors.

headline: A Legal Battle Over Newly Returned Bison
text: The legal battle continues over the fate of a herd of wild bison that are roaming the plains of northern Montana for the first time in more than a century.

headline: Seven Scientists Win Kavli Prizes
text: Seven scientists whose work spanned the outer reaches of the solar system and penetrated the inner workings of brain circuits and nanotubes were named winners of the 2012 Kavli Prizes on Thursday. The $1 million awards, sponsored by the physicist, businessman and philanthropist Fred Kavli, are given every two years by the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters for work in the fields of astrophysics, nanoscience and neuroscience, “the biggest, the smallest and the most complex,” in the words of Mr. Kavli.

headline: A Youthful Visit at Stonestreet Farm
text: There is a certain kind of glee one experiences when the heavy cast-iron gates of Stonestreet Farm in Lexington swing open. It reminds me of “Tthe Wizard of Oz.” when Dorothy and friends enter the Emerald City. Before you is an oak tree lined drive with manicured grounds. Almost on cue, two groundskeepers roll silently by in a modified golf cart picking up small twigs and limbs. They give a jaunty wave and move on. In the silence, I listen to the birds and the rustle of the leaves. A small group of mares graze in contentment next to the fence. There are gold and purple iris in bloom and blooming clematis is being trained to climb a tree near the entrance. The gate blends in with the iconic Kentucky stone fences. It is serene.

headline: Daily Report: Researchers Find Clues in Flame Virus
text: Security experts have only begun to examine the thousands of lines of code that make up Flame, a data-mining computer virus that has been designed to steal information from computers across the Middle East, Nicole Perlroth reports in Thursday’s New York Times. But already digital clues point to its creators and capabilities.

headline: Relations Tested in Case of South Korean Activist Detained in China

text: Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott wants to open 20 health and mental health centers in middle and high schools throughout the city, he told the City Council at a budget hearing. This comes after more than 70 school-based mental health centers were closed over the last two years.

text: MOST actors create one or two memorable characters in a career, if they’re lucky. The portraits etched by the mercurial Giancarlo Esposito, on the other hand, are so distinct that you can imagine them playing scenes off each other.

headline: Parents Dig Deeper to Relieve Tight Public School Budgets
text: After five years of cuts to public school budgets, parents say they are being pressed for more supplies, support and dollars than ever, and many are spending hundreds of dollars, and in some cases, thousands, a year on school-related items. This is the first in a series of posts planned by SchoolBook on the rising cost of public school, originating with our readers' responses.

headline: Mordekai Jewelry Line Now in Stores
text: Ken Borochov, the brain behind Mordekai, a line of imaginative jewelry and headpieces, gets his ideas from the hardware he uses. “I search online for the most random materials, and that’s where I start,” Mr. Borochov said. He has constructed earrings that resemble blonde hair extensions from a horsetail, and believes his line stands out because of his fantastical design approach. His work has recently caught the eyes of buyers for Patricia Field in New York City and Ikram in Chicago, the first brick-and-mortar locations to sell Mordekai pieces. Now, shoppers looking to makeover their wardrobes can choose from his eye-catching necklaces, rings and headdresses.

headline: Trying to Solve the Great Trump Mystery
text: Life, as we know, is filled with mysteries. Some are cosmic, like who was the first to catch a lobster and think anyone would want to eat something that looked like that? Or where do the children of circus performers run off to when they rebel against their parents?

headline: Morgan Stanley to Raise Stake in Brokerage Venture to 65%
text: Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, has made it clear he wants to get his hands on the brokerage business it owns with Citigroup. Now, he will spend the next few months figuring just how much the business, Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, is worth to his bank.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Publishers Blame Amazon, and a ‘Mental Mincemeat’ Maker
text: Penguin Group USA and Macmillan, the two publishers who did not settle with the government over its lawsuit on e-book prices, responded to the charges on Wednesday by denying that they had fixed prices with Apple and other major publishing houses, Julie Bosman reports. But they also said that the government was siding with a monopolist by advancing the cause of Amazon. Penguin’s response, she writes, called Amazon “predatory” and a “monopolist” that treats books as “widgets.”

headline: The End of Brain, Child Magazine
text: “Good time? Bad time?” My friend Stephanie Wilkinson is on the phone. We’ve been trying to connect for days, but our lives keep getting in the way. I glance around my kitchen — two teenagers in need of food and transportation, an under-walked dog, and, oh yeah, the day job I am supposed to be doing from my home office upstairs.

headline: Cha-Cha at the Supermarket

headline: Is It Too Late to Send Myself to Camp?
text: Summer camp was a foreign concept where I grew up, in the middle Midwest — Kansas, not Chicago or the Detroit suburbs. I never went, and neither did any child or teenager I knew. Our summer experience was public pools and malls, mowing lawns and summer jobs. Camping, maybe, but summer camp? That was for people in books and Disney movies, not people like us.

headline: 36 Hours in Oxford, England
text: OXFORD is not a college town — it is the college town. Its namesake university’s 38 colleges are so steeped in scholarly history they make Harvard and Yale seem like baby-faced freshmen. To wit: Oxford’s New College was last considered “new” in the 14th century. (Even the obsolete term “New World” is newer.) Students here get into the act, many dressing in tweed coats, sometimes even with elbow patches, and ordering pints of cask ale at pubs that have been in business for nearly four-fifths of a millennium. But Oxford has a modern side, too: night spots blare house and electronic music; restaurants serve modern takes on local food and exotic ethnic cuisine; and comfortable boutique hotels and bed-and- breakfasts beat medieval lodging houses for comfort any day. (Just don’t ask for a place to hitch your horse.)

headline: Earmarks and the Stimulus
text: The Romney campaign’s strategy-of-the-week is to question the president’s motives for passing the stimulus. “Were these investments the best return on tax dollars, or given for ideological reasons, to donors, for political reasons?” an aide asked Politico before dubbing the stimulus “the mother of all earmarks.”

headline: Face Time | Julianna Margulies
text: I scored some face time with Julianna Margulies at a recent L’Oréal Paris event, held in honor of her new role as ambassador for the brand’s Women of Worth program. Inspired by the famous 1971 slogan “Because you’re worth it,” the program aims to support strength, confidence and positivity in women. L’Oréal made a good choice in Margulies. Within moments of meeting her, she demonstrated all those attributes and more. Aside from her many accomplishments, including playing the role of Alicia in CBS’s “The Good Wife,” she also maintains a flawless, porcelain complexion. I wanted some tips!

headline: The Best of Overtimes, the Worst of Overtimes
text: There is nothing quite like playoff overtime, for its riveting suspense and hero-making qualities, for its ability to destroy your plans for a full night’s sleep because playoff games start ludicrously late to begin with. But as both hockey and basketball sent its showcase games into extra time Wednesday night, the similarities ended there. The N.B.A.’s version featured a rather discomfiting ending to an often mesmerizing game, when the Heat’s victory over the Celtics dissolved into squabbles over officiating, while the N.H.L. capped a grinding slog with one of the prettiest goals you’ll ever see in playoff overtime.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Keeping Cancer at Bay
text: “How are you doing?” is a complicated question for a cancer patient.

headline: A New Front Line in the U.S. Drug War
text: WASHINGTON — After several villagers were killed on a Honduran river last month during a raid on drug smugglers by Honduran and American agents, a local backlash raised concerns that the United States’ expanding counternarcotics efforts in Central America might be going too far. But United States officials in charge of that policy see it differently.

headline: British Comedian Simon Amstell Bringing Solo Show to New York

headline: The Micro-Multinational: Incubators Aren’t Just for Start-Ups
text: The idea of a business incubator is to host a bunch of start-ups together in one space. The goal is to build a vibe of inspiration and to sprinkle in some shared services — legal, accounting, human resources — in the hope that efficiency and energy and creativity will blossom. Some incubators even offer financing.

headline: Scarlett Johansson and Chris Pine in Talks to Star in Broadway Revival of ‘Cat on a Hot Tin Roof’
text: A new Broadway revival of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” is in the works for the spring of 2013, with Scarlett Johansson starring as Maggie the Cat and Chris Pine (“Star Trek”) and the Academy Award nominee Jeremy Renner (“The Hurt Locker,” “The Town”) among the actors under consideration to play her alcoholic husband, Brick, according to theater executives with knowledge of the project.

headline: Nadal Overpowers Istomin

headline: One Afghan’s Three-Generation Quest for Peace
text: Two years ago, I began working with Afghan writers in workshops, introducing them to short narratives from around the world, frequently from postwar writers. Most of my students weren’t raised reading stories in English, and very few had ever sat down to write their own in a second or third language. Unlike an American workshop, it was rare to find an Afghan who felt their story warranted such attention, theirs or mine, or who wanted their work to ever appear in print.

headline: Watching Devils’ Brodeur Never Gets Old

The fans now text between periods, and for Game 1 against the Los Angeles Kings, many were wearing battery-powered devil’s horns of a sort I don’t remember seeing before.

headline: Two-Step
text: Let’s talk about Fred. And his partners: Rita, Cyd, Paulette, Vera-Ellen, Nanette, the two Powells — Eleanor and Jane — Judy, Leslie, Audrey, numerous couches and chairs, several tables (dining and coffee), a British ceiling and one supremely fortunate coat rack. But mainly, of course, there was the divine Ginger, always magnificently dressed, occasionally, as in “Top Hat,” by three or four well-endowed ostriches.

headline: Fortunate Son
text: After seeing “Memphis” on Broadway, I hopped on the uptown 6 train to visit my mother in the Bronx. I had just gotten off at the Parkchester stop and started walking down the dark street toward her house when I felt a blow to the back of my head. A guy in a red hooded sweatshirt punched me in the face. Another pinned me down and searched my pockets. On the ground, next to the highway, kicking and shouting, I heard the intro to “Law & Order” in my head: “Dun, Dun …”

headline: China Lets Currency Weaken, Risking New Trade Tensions
text: HONG KONG — China’s currency dropped further in May against the dollar than in any other month since the Chinese government began allowing the renminbi to appreciate gradually in the summer of 2005. The shift could help Chinese exports but worsen trade friction with Europe and particularly the United States.

headline: The South’s Gunboat War
text: When Matthew Fontaine Maury, one of America’s most famous scientists but a naval officer of middling rank, accepted the position as head of the Confederacy’s coastal defense in 1861, he did so knowing that storms were ahead — of the political variety. His new post meant he would be reporting to two men with whom he had butted heads in pre-secession days: Stephen Mallory, secretary of the Confederate Navy, and Jefferson Davis, the Confederacy’s new president.

headline: Murray Fights Through the Pain to Advance

headline: Lidstrom Retiring? Hard to Imagine, but It’s True
text: Perhaps the most amazing thing about Nicklas Lidstrom’s career is that his extraordinarily consistent excellence redefined amazing. Who could possibly play 20 seasons in the N.H.L. and do almost nothing wrong? Who could make a grueling game look effortless night after night, leading a Red Wings team that made Stanley Cup contention its default position, without any down seasons or even, as his teammates claim, any bad games?

headline: On Our Radar: A Greenhouse Gas Milestone
text: For the first time in hundreds of thousands of years, carbon dioxide levels in the Arctic atmosphere have exceeded the level of 400 parts per million, monitoring shows. Although the milestone for this heat-trapping gas had been anticipated, the global monitoring director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Earth System Research Lab says it’s a reminder that “we’re still in trouble.” (Globally, the level is around 395 parts per million.) [The Christian Science Monitor]

headline: Lights, Camera … It’s the Brooklyn Knights
text: Sebastian Podesta’s family is from Argentina and he is a fan of River Plate, the Buenos Aires club known as Los Millonarios. So it might seem a bit irreconcilable that Podesta, 26, who grew up in Colorado and is a graduate of New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts, is currently on an odyssey to produce a film about a team of soccer players who are about as far from soccer millionaires as they possibly could be.

headline: Doc Watson Dies
text: May 30, 2012 - Guitarist and folk singer Doc Watson died Tuesday at the age of 89.

headline: Dudley Clendinen, Reporter and Editor, Dies at 67
text: Dudley Clendinen, a courtly Southern journalist and author who wrote lyrically about civil rights, aging in America, the poignancy of ordinary lives and his own approaching death as a gay alcoholic victim of Lou Gehrig’s disease, died on Wednesday in a hospice in Baltimore. He was 67.

headline: Business Day Live: Euro Bonds
text: Hunting for new bank customers on college campuses. After Facebook, enthusiasm ebbs in the I.P.O. market. Could the euro bond ever be more than an idea?

headline: Romney Campaigns at Failed Solyndra Factory
text: 1:26 a.m. | Updated  Read a full report of Thursday’s presidential campaign news here.

headline: Back by Popular Demand | Portia & Manny
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: By Court Order, $3.8 Million Mercedes-Benz Roadster Might Be Returned to Heirs
text: A 1935 Mercedes-Benz 500 K Roadster sold by RM Auctions last year could find its way back to the family of its initial owner.

headline: Abacus Bank Charged With Mortgage Fraud
text: Abacus Federal Savings Bank, a small bank with a major presence in New York City’s Chinese community, and 19 of its former employees have been charged with inflating the qualifications of mortgage applicants to meet federal loan standards, a scheme that prosecutors say brought the bank tens of millions of dollars in ill-gotten fees and sent hundreds of millions of dollars in risky mortgages to the investment market.

headline: An Exposé Before a Vote on Sex-Selective Abortions
text: Last Updated, 2:20 p.m. As my colleague Jennifer Steinhauer reports, the House rejected a bill on Thursday that would have banned abortions based on gender.

headline: No New Name for High-Fructose Corn Syrup
text: The United States Food and Drug Administration has rejected a request from the Corn Refiners Association to change the name of high-fructose corn syrup.

headline: 2012 Edinburgh Fringe Festival Announces Lineup
text: Rather than shrink from the competition presented by the London Olympics and the London 2012 Festival, the 66th annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe is going bigger than ever. The full program for the 2012 festival, running Aug. 3-27, is to include 2,695 events in 279 locations, organizers announced on Thursday, saying it was an increase in size of about 6 percent over last year.

headline: The Darker Side of the Story
text: I’m not sure this counts as a spoiler of anything other than Universal’s sleek and seductive marketing campaign — which has properly emphasized crows, swords and Charlize Theron’s hair — but there are actually some dwarfs in the new movie “Snow White and the Huntsman.” The small fellows who befriend the exiled princess here are nothing like the grumpy, sneezy, dopey guys you remember from the Disney version. The actors who play them (including Ian McShane, Eddie Marsan, Ray Winstone and the great Bob Hoskins, all digitally shrunken) might otherwise have been assembled for a nasty little Cockney gangster film. These dwarfs are industrious, but they don’t whistle while they work. Their most memorable song is a haunting dirge performed at the funeral pyre of a fallen comrade. So take note: There is nothing cute about this movie.

headline: Romney and Trump
text: I used my Campaign Stops column this week to bemoan Mitt Romney’s entanglement with Donald Trump. Here’s Byron York explaining the Romney campaign’s thinking:

headline: Appeals Court Turns Back Marriage Act as Unfair to Gays
text: A federal appeals court ruled unanimously Thursday that the federal law declaring marriage to be a union solely between a man and a woman discriminates against married same-sex couples by denying them the same benefits afforded to heterosexual couples — a ruling that could set the stage for the Supreme Court to review the issue as early as next year.

headline: Turn Waste Into Energy, Group Urges New York
text: New York City should embrace waste-to-energy plants to reduce the $300 million it spends annually disposing of its garbage, a government watchdog group suggested in a report released on Thursday.

headline: Clinton Says Russian Inaction May Lead to Syrian Civil War
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton signaled the Obama administration’s mounting frustration with Russia over the unending violence in Syria on Thursday, saying that Russia’s refusal to take decisive action against President Bashar al-Assad threatened to precipitate the very civil war that Russian diplomats have said they wanted to avoid.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Massachusetts Focus
text: The Obama campaign brings up Mitt Romney’s record as governor | A preview of the Wisconsin recall election | Republicans hit the president hard on the Solyndra loans.

headline: New Charges for Queens Teacher Accused of Sex Abuse
text: A grade-school computer teacher arrested in February on charges of sexually abusing two boys in his Queens classroom has been charged with molesting three other boys, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Former Lehman C.F.O. Joins Broker
text: Ian Lowitt, the last chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, has joined the London financial firm Marex Spectron.

headline: On Cusp of History, Remembering One of the Greats
text: Who is the greatest racehorse of all time? It is a fruitless but enjoyable debate. In America, you might argue for the pre-eminence of Lexington in the 19th century, and Secretariat in the 20th. Many of us in Europe would nominate St Simon (1881-1908) and Sea Bird II (1962-1973) from those centuries; we might also suggest that our current champion, Frankel, has the potential to join these ranks. But if superiority over contemporaries, enduring fame and influence on the breed are measures, no horse has surpassed Eclipse (1764-1789).

headline: TimesCast Politics: Massachusetts Focus
text: On today’s TimesCast Politics, Michael D. Shear looks at the Obama campaign’s criticisms on Mitt Romney’s record as governor, Monica Davey previews the Wisconsin recall election, and Michael Barbaro discusses the Republican attacks on the president over the Solyndra loans.

headline: Young’s Progress Cheers Mets
text: The Mets, while enjoying a day off after 20 consecutive games, received a few bits of encouraging news out of upstate New York on Thursday afternoon.

headline: For Kings, an Old Look Proves a Winning One
text: Soon after Anze Kopitar’s overtime goal gave the Kings a win in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals, General Manager Dean Lombardi and the assistant G.M. Ron Hextall decided to take the stairs from the upper reaches of the Prudential Center down to the Kings’ dressing room. On their way down, Lombardi and Hextall found themselves getting swept into a sea of dejected, red-clad Devils fans filing out of the arena. The fans, descending the stairwell quietly, paid no notice to the top two figures in the Kings’ front office. That was apt; the Kings had just stolen off with the opener of the finals.

headline: The Get | Alvar Aalto’s Stool 60 by Way of Comme des Garçons
text: The Internet abounds with not-so-subtle knockoffs of Alvar Aalto’s Stool 60 — not to mention various D.I.Y. notions about how to jazz up its charmingly simple design. (Decoupage seems to be very popular.) But if you step into a Comme des Garçons boutique this summer and see the Finnish classic dressed up in black polka dots, don’t accuse Rei Kawakubo of Ikea-hacking a Frosta: this is the real deal.

headline: Haley Ethics Inquiry Reopened
text: South Carolina legislators voted Wednesday to reopen an ethics investigation into whether Gov.Nikki Haley illegally lobbied fellow politicians while she was a state representative.

headline: Facebook Shares Stage Recovery
text: 5:01 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Barn-Find Chrysler Tidies Up, Just a Touch, for Greenwich Concours
text: This weekend, the 17th edition of the Greenwich Concours d’Élégance will do much to stoke the allure of the barn find. To some attendees, an unlooted 1937 Chrysler Imperial limousine, complete with cigarette butts in the ashtray and peeling paint, will represent a gilded sarcophagus with the mummy inside. The car was exhumed recently, wearing a thick patina of dust, from the former estate of William K. Vanderbilt II in Centerport, N.Y., on Long Island, and is scheduled to be featured at the concours, its first public viewing since 1986.

headline: Going Her Own Way
text: The jewelry designer Irene Neuwirth, 36, a former horseback-riding teacher, is a nominee for her first Council of Fashion Designers of America award. Ms. Neuwirth lives in Los Angeles and is dating the director and producer Phil Lord. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: In Rat Experiment, New Hope for Spine Injuries
text: Rats with a spinal cord injury that left their hind legs completely paralyzed learned to walk again on their own after an intensive training course that included electrical stimulation of the brain and the spine, scientists reported on Thursday.

headline: Can Liberia Be Liberated From Its Past?
text: The recent news that The Hague has handed down a 50-year prison sentence to Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, brought to mind a couple of articles the magazine has published about that ravaged country. One was a moving excerpt from Helene Cooper’s memoir, “The House on Sugar Beach,” about growing up there in the 1970s and early ’80s, when the Liberian president, William Tolbert, was viciously murdered by a young rebel named Samuel Doe. Doe had the support of Taylor, who later became president himself.

headline: Digital Notes: Liberty Media Keeps Sirius XM in Its Sights
text: A boardroom drama has been unfolding over the last couple of months between Sirius XM Radio and its biggest shareholder, Liberty Media.

headline: Ackermann Hands Over Reins of Deutsche Bank
text: FRANKFURT — Josef Ackermann bowed out Thursday as the chief executive of Deutsche Bank after more than a decade in which he transformed the institution into a global contender but also became a symbol to many Germans of the excesses of capitalism.

headline: No Room to Play
text: At P.S. 24 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, 54 percent of students are overweight or obese and P.E. classes are a weekly activity.  Limited space means that only half of the students at the school can participate in P.E. classes each year.  What does the school do to meet its students' health and exercise needs? A Columbia journalism school student examines the issues in an article and multimedia report.

headline: Dissident From China Expresses Optimism
text: Despite suffering from years of illegal detention, Chen Guangcheng, the Chinese activist whose daring escape began an odyssey that brought him to New York University on a fellowship, expressed optimism on Thursday about the future of legal rights in China.

headline: The Mosquito Invasion
text: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week’s image.

headline: ‘Spider-Man': Turn On the Lawyers
text: The first courtroom arguments will take place in Manhattan on Friday in the legal battle between the Broadway producers of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” and their former director, Julie Taymor, with three procedural motions before the judge in the case, according to people on both sides. Private settlement talks broke off in late winter, and both camps are now focused on assembling evidence and arguments for a full-blown trial next year when boldface reputations and millions of dollars would be at stake.

headline: Paris Boulangerie Awarded Coveted Top Prize for Best Baguette
text: Buying a baguette at the corner boulangerie is one of the greatest pleasures Paris offers. But not all bread is created equal. This month, a panel of bread experts and enthusiasts awarded the prize of “best baguette in Paris” to Sébastian Mauvieux of the Boulangerie Mauvieux (159 rue Ordener, 18th Arrondissement; 33-1-42-62-76-70).

headline: Q. & A. With Hugo Lindgren on Reddit
text: Friday afternoon, from about 3:30 until 5:00 p.m. Eastern time, Hugo Lindgren will respond to questions in a Reddit “IamA” interview. You can ask him anything, “Rampart”-related or otherwise — what it’s like to edit the magazine, how to write a better Lives essay, why he is covered in bunny rabbits.

headline: An Identity Inspired and in Flux
text: An appropriate air of disorderly fabulousness pervades “Jukebox Jackie,” a scrapbook of a show at La MaMa that pays spirited tribute to Jackie Curtis, one of the pioneering gender adventurers who orbited Andy Warhol in the late 1960s and early 1970s.

headline: Political Truce for a Portrait Unveiling
text: WASHINGTON — When former President George W. Bush returned to the White House on Thursday to unveil his official portrait, he brought along his wife, Laura; his parents, George and Barbara; daughters, Jenna and Barbara; and a couple of hundred cheering and whooping former staff members.

headline: London Underground | Digging the Serpentine Pavilion
text: The Serpentine Gallery Pavilion has, over the last 13 years, established itself as a must-see architectural event of the London summer season, not only for its experimental structures — which have allowed A-list architects like Zaha Hadid, Frank Gehry and Jean Nouvel to realize their first built projects in this city — but also for the glitzy parties and intellectually rigorous event marathons that accompany the structures.

headline: Alan Horn Is Named Chairman of Disney Studios
text: 7:36 a.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company has turned to one of Hollywood’s senior statesmen to calm its turbulent film studio.

headline: Study Ties Albany’s Distance From Voters to Its Corruption
text: It took no less than the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard to demonstrate that out of sight is, indeed, out of mind. Or, if you prefer a different cliché, that when the cat’s away, the mice will play.

headline: Lepchenko’s Victory Has Olympic Implications
text: PARIS — When the American Varvara Lepchenko topped the former world No. 1 Jelena Jankovic, 7-6, 4-6, 6-4, Thursday, she advanced to the third round of the French Open. That was significant. So, too, was the fact that this victory put her ahead of Vania King in the WTA rankings, which was also significant because the top four American women could qualify for the London Games in July.

headline: A Ruling Gives Gay Couples Hope for Financial Equality
text: 5:54 p.m. | Updated  To add more details about the effects of a Supreme Court reversal.

headline: Pressure Continues on Regulators to Approve Volcker Rule
text: In the wake of JPMorgan’s multibillion-dollar trading loss, regulators are under pressure to beef up the proposed Volcker Rule.

headline: Photo Replay: May 31
text: The Diamond League’s Golden Gala track meet was held in Rome, and the French Open tennis tournament continued in Paris.

headline: Edwards Not Guilty on One Count; Mistrial on Five Others
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — When former Senator John Edwards, a man who reached for the presidency while scrambling to hide a pregnant mistress, heard on Thursday that a federal jury would not convict him on the six corruption charges he faced, he fell back in his chair and closed his eyes.

headline: So Far, Being Lucky Beats Being Good, by Half a Game
text: The Yankees and the Mets have spent the last 51 baseball seasons being as different as two teams can be. Whereas the Yankees have tradition and more titles than anyone wants them to count, the Mets have often been an exercise in frustration with occasional bouts of miraculous behavior.

headline: Obama Hosts George W. Bush for Portrait’s Unveiling
text: President Obama put partisanship aside for a few hours to pay tribute to his predecessor at the official unveiling of George W. Bush’s official White House portrait. Read the full story here.

headline: A Cattelan Billboard for the High Line
text: After his blockbuster retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum in New York last fall, Maurizio Cattelan, who is just 51, said he was officially retiring from making art. What did that mean, exactly, coming from a jokester like Mr. Cattelan?

headline: Panel Approves Bill Tailored to a Wealthy Donor’s Bank
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress on both sides of the aisle have railed against earmarks, those mysterious clauses tucked into bills that often benefit a single project or constituent. But what about an entire bill, consisting of just a few words, that is intended to help one business — whose owner is a big donor to both parties?

headline: Producer of Obama Video on Fox News Loses CNN Job Offer
text: The Fox News producer behind a provocative four-minute anti-Obama video that aired Wednesday and caused the network considerable embarrassment has found his career on ice.

headline: An Idea Charged Up in Zuccotti Park
text: Pacing around his Brooklyn apartment, Tommy Mitchell paused to eye his machine with frustration. On top was an 85-watt solar panel that he realized he had just installed upside down.

headline: Oh, for the Sweet Music of Belly Laughs
text: COMEDIANS have long worked song-and-dance gags into their acts. Certainly “Saturday Night Live” has produced its share, whether a spaghetti-limbed Steve Martin performing “King Tut” in pharaoh garb or Adam Sandler mewling “The Hanukkah Song.” But strapping on a guitar or plugging in a vintage synthesizer is now becoming standard practice. Contemporary jokesters like Zach Galifianakis, Reggie Watts and Demetri Martin have made musical instruments essential comedic accouterments, as common as ill-fitting trousers and a brick wall.

headline: After Close Call With I’ll Have Another, Belmont Contenders Will Have Track to Themselves
text: A filly got loose and almost slammed into I’ll Have Another before his gallop at Belmont Park on Thursday morning, nearly putting his Triple Crown bid in jeopardy.

headline: When Is Sex-Selective Abortion a ‘Problem’?
text: Here’s an interesting paragraph from Dana Milbank’s Washington Post column assessing the political consequences of the House Republican push to pass a ban on sex-selective abortions:

headline: Final Installment of ‘Hatfields & McCoys’ Draws Biggest Audience
text: The History Channel wrapped up a string of ratings successes Wednesday night as the third part of the miniseries “Hatfields & McCoys” reached a new audience high of 14.3 million viewers, vaulting the series into three of the top positions for entertainment programs on cable television.

headline: A Superhero That Doesn’t Exist
text: The storyline of the N.B.A. playoffs may be LeBron James’s quest for a title, but the story of this postseason involves someone who is not even present, Dwight Howard, the N.B.A.’s would be Superman.

headline: Its First Mission Done, SpaceX Looks to More Private Flights
text: After a nearly flawless nine-day routine, the Dragon stuck the landing, too.

headline: Defending Marriage From DOMA
text: There is much to celebrate in today’s federal appeals court ruling against the Defense of Marriage Act. But it was far from a full and final rejection of a law that is so clearly driven by bigotry and so clearly unconstitutional.

headline: Video: A Superhero That Doesn’t Exist
text: The story line of the N.B.A. playoffs may be LeBron James’s quest for a title, but the story of this postseason involves someone who is not even present, Dwight Howard, the N.B.A.’s would be Superman, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: NBC Hires Ward, With Numerous Roles in Mind
text: Hines Ward evidently made a strong impression as a guest analyst on NBC’s Super Bowl pregame show. On Thursday, the NBC Sports Group hired Ward, the former Pittsburgh Steelers receiver, for a three-job portfolio. The Steelers released him in late February after a 14-year career that included 1,000 receptions.

headline: Theater Listings for June 1-7
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

text: N.Y. See: On the water in the wilds of Queens.

headline: Israel, in Gesture, Repatriates Bodies of 91 Palestinians
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israel returned the remains of 91 Palestinians on Thursday, most of them killed while carrying out attacks against Israelis, to the West Bank and Gaza in a move described by Israeli officials as a gesture intended to help bring the Palestinians back to peace negotiations.

headline: Fight Reignited Over Student Loan Rates
text: With the Senate in recess and the House just back in action after its week off, the fight over how to deal with an impending increase in some student loan rates was reignited Thursday when Congressional Republicans sent a letter to the White House offering some suggestions on how to pay for an extended lower loan rate.

headline: Black Women’s Transitions to Natural Hair
text: To watch the video, press the play button in the bottom-left corner of the image.

headline: Transition
text: The filmmaker Zina Saro-Wiwa presents an Op-Doc on black women’s decision to embrace their naturally kinky hair, rather than use chemical straighteners.

headline: Banks Choose to Be Less Than Transparent on Europe
text: United States banks received a regulatory memo this year asking them to make clearer their public disclosures about their exposure to Europe’s troubled countries. Not all the banks bothered to comply fully, however. And this could backfire on them if financial conditions in Europe deteriorate further.

headline: Summer Series That Come and Go
text: The list of new television shows arriving this summer is a long one — that’s true of every part of the calendar nowadays — but the season feels quieter than it has in recent years. Cable networks like USA, TNT and Syfy that have aggressively introduced high-profile series seem to be in a consolidation mode, with the season’s biggest news — outside of “The Newsroom” on HBO — involving award-winning shows embarking on their final go-rounds: “The Closer,” “Damages,” “Breaking Bad.”

headline: Curlicues and Cleopatra in Kenyan Poet’s House
text: LONDON — The Kenyan poet Khadambi Asalache disguised stained and damp walls at his London town house with wooden filigree scenes of desert oases. He lived in an 1810s brick shoe box in the Lambeth section of south London, wedged between modernist housing blocks and a church graveyard. He bequeathed the place to the National Trust when he died in 2006, at 71.
