headline: Ingenious New Earbuds From Arriva
text: Four years ago, I reviewed an ingenious little product called the Arriva earbuds. The writeup went like this:

headline: An Artist Unearthing Himself
text: “I was assured when I came to live in this space on Broadway between Prince and Spring that SoHo would never come this far,” David Gordon said, looking out the wall-to-wall windows in his second-floor loft. “Instead I now live in the Mall of America.”

headline: Following the Curves of a Republic’s Golden Age
text: If you have ever been to Venice, you know that getting lost in that maze of canals and piazzas is as serendipitous as it is inevitable. So it is with “Renaissance Venice: Drawings From the Morgan,” the Morgan Library & Museum’s first attempt to showcase the Venetian works from its large collection of Italian drawings.

headline: Ignoring Laws of Physics as They Run Across Roofs
text: “A Cat in Paris” is a nifty little caper in which blustery gangsters, intrepid detectives, cat burglars (one of them literally feline) and a little girl named Zoé scamper across nighttime rooftops unraveling a pleasantly tangled plot. The film, just about an hour long and directed by the French animation team of Jean-Loup Felicioli and Alain Gagnol, is also a refreshing reminder, at a time of large-scale, highly polished cinematic spectacle, of the essential, elemental sources of movie-watching pleasure.

headline: Teaching Paralyzed Rats to Walk
text: A video from the Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne explaining how scientists helped rats with a spinal cord injury learn to walk again.

headline: Another Marathon for Isner, but This Time He Loses
text: PARIS — This time, it turned out differently after all that effort. This time, John Isner lost to an unseeded Frenchman at a Grand Slam tournament with the fifth-set score deep, though not nearly as deep, into double digits.

headline: What’s Wrong with Soda?
text: Whatever your opinion on Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s proposal to ban the sale of large sugary drinks in restaurants and movie theaters in New York City — overdue public health effort? or the worst kind of nanny state-ism? — it’s worth revisiting “Is Sugar Toxic?” in which Gary Taubes puts forward a scientific case against sugar. Taubes argues that sugar (and by that he means both high-fructose corn syrup and the granulated stuff) does not amount to just empty calories; it is also chemically and singularly harmful “at least if consumed in sufficient quantities.” Sugary drinks come in for especially harsh rebuke:

headline: 20 More Cookbooks
text: ALAIN DUCASSE NATURE: Simple, Healthy, and Good. By Alain Ducasse with Paula Neyrat and Christophe Saintagne. (Rizzoli, $45.) The great French chef surprises with a lighter take on his favorite flavors.

headline: Territorial Claims in South China Sea
text: Six countries claim conflicting territorial rights in the South China Sea, a region rich in oil, gas, fishing and mineral resources.

headline: Free Kayaking on the Hudson River
text: As the weather turns warmer, city dwellers inevitably seek out the water, and many now happily get their fix without leaving town. Whether it’s on City Island or in Tubby Hook, in the Rockaways or in Red Hook, you don’t have to look hard to find opportunities for boating, swimming and surfing.

headline: Officer Charged With Lying About Man’s Arrest
text: The homeowner was accused of trying to run over a police officer in the driveway outside his house. He was charged with felony reckless endangerment and spent three nights in jail.

headline: Design in the Service of Subversion
text: A person working in almost any field could have written a book like “How to Be a Graphic Designer Without Losing Your Soul”: designers don’t have a monopoly on worker alienation, after all. But that title of Adrian Shaughnessy’s 2005 book reflects the special circumstances of graphic designers, who generally practice their art in the service of clients and commerce.

headline: High School Teacher, Accused of Having Sex With Student, Surrenders to Police
text: The latest episode of a teacher being accused of having sex with a  student comes days after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called on the state to pass legislation that would give the city greater power to fire teachers accused of sexual misconduct.

headline: Legislative Panel Rejects 2nd Christie Pick for State Supreme Court
text: TRENTON — A New Jersey Senate panel rejected on Thursday the second of two men nominated by Gov. Chris Christie to the state’s highest court, dealing another blow to the governor’s attempt to reshape what he has criticized as an overly liberal and activist institution.

headline: Making Quite a Show of Dying
text: To Christians in the Middle Ages, dying was the equivalent of a giddy elevator ride. You either shot straight up to an air-conditioned luxury penthouse, dropped down to the basement boiler room or got stuck on a stuffy mezzanine, from which, with luck and lots of prayers said by family and friends, you might eventually rise.

headline: Of Saints and Sinners, in a Fevered Mexico
text: “For Greater Glory,” an old-fashioned, Hollywood-style epic that overlays thundering hoof beats with a humid layer of piety, remembers the Cristero War, a bitter 20th-century conflict in which persecuted Roman Catholics rose up against the anticlerical Mexican government.

headline: The Secret Lives of Dangerous Hackers
text: In December 2010 the heat-seeking Internet pranksters known as Anonymous attacked PayPal, the online bill-paying business. PayPal had been a conduit for donations to WikiLeaks, the rogue whistle-blower site, until WikiLeaks released a huge cache of State Department internal messages. PayPal cut off donations to the WikiLeaks Web site. Then PayPal’s own site was shut down, as Anonymous did what it did best: exaggerate the weight of its own influence.

headline: Classics in the Palms of His Hands
text: Pier Jacopo Alari Bonacolsi (about 1455-1528) — or, as he was known, Antico, “the antique one” — was one of the most skilled and innovative sculptors of the early Italian Renaissance, celebrated during his lifetime for impeccably neo-Classical bronze statuettes of pagan heroes and gods. But his achievements were swamped and obscured by wave upon wave of generic desktop-size bronzes in the ensuing centuries, and his name was forgotten until early-20th-century art historians rediscovered him.

headline: Beating the System With Tainted Brownies and Tainted Minds
text: One accomplishment of the stoner comedy “High School,” although I’m not sure “accomplishment” is the right term, is to evoke a state of drugged stupefaction in which the connections between words are lost, and nothing makes sense.

headline: Women on the Verge of Everything
text: THE decision to devote the main galleries of the New Museum in Lower Manhattan to female artists this spring “didn’t happen by all of us sitting down and saying, ‘Let’s do a round of shows by women,’ ” Massimiliano Gioni, the museum’s associate director and director of exhibitions, said. Rather, as often happens when a number of curators are involved in planning a season, there was a cacophony of suggestions involving all kinds of artists.

headline: Speeding Toward Englishtown, and Hauling an Uncommon Pedigree
text: For Alexis DeJoria, drag racing is the consummate concentrated thrill.

headline: Turning a Charity Symbol Into a Corporate Logo
text: In “Pink Ribbons, Inc.” the director Léa Pool takes aim at the breast cancer movement and the corporations that benefit from its ubiquitous rosy symbol of awareness and action. Yet for all the stellar intentions; revelatory evidence; and thoughtful, wall-to-wall interviewees, this frustratingly overstuffed documentary indulges more in spraying buckshot than stalking a target.

headline: Amid Uncertainty on Euro, Europeans Hedge Their Bets
text: There is an unfortunate logic to bank runs. The rational thing for any depositor to do is to join in the run if there is even the smallest possibility that the bank really is in danger of failing. If you pull your money out and the bank survives, the costs of your mistake are tiny compared to the costs if the bank fails with your money in it.

headline: Pina Bausch’s ‘World Cities’ in London
text: A selection of images from the dances to be performed.

headline: An Olympian Twirl Around the Globe
text: LONDON

headline: At Annual Meeting, Wal-Mart to Confront Shareholder Unrest
text: ROGERS, Ark. — As Wal-Mart celebrates its 50th anniversary at its annual shareholders’ meeting on Friday, the company is expected to face some of the staunchest opposition in years to the continued tenure of several board members and its chief executive, as well as some corporate policies.

headline: A Broadway Hangout, Old Chum
text: IN a room deep below the streets of the Theater District last week, it looked as if a Broadway show was a few frantic days from opening night. Carpenters drilled as other workers huddled over a glowing iPad. The set designer John Lee Beatty stood atop a banquette staining a picture frame. The lighting designer Ken Billington watched while spotlights brightened and dimmed onstage. The producer Richard Frankel monitored the commotion.

headline: The Cost of Regulations
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Dying Village Gets a Curious Visitor
text: A neorealist ghost story, a documentary fable, a postcard from a vanishing world, Julia Murat’s “Found Memories” takes place in Jotuomba, a tiny, fictitious rural village in northern Brazil. To call Jotuomba a place that time forgot would be less a cliché than an accurate description, since the aging, dwindling population — a quarrelsome pair of shopkeepers, a haggard priest, an assortment of idle agricultural workers and dedicated drinkers — seems to exist beyond the reach of modernity.

headline: Coveted Lobsters From Nova Scotia Return to New York
text: Fourchu lobsters are back, and this year, there are more.

headline: Judge Allows Class-Action Suit Over Google’s Book Scanning
text: A federal judge in Manhattan granted class-action status on Thursday to authors suing Google over the company’s ambitious book-scanning project, allowing the long-stalled case to move forward.

headline: Roger Revelle’s 1980 Discussion of CO2 and Climate Risks
text: Roger Revelle, one of the pioneering researchers in the study of the human influence on the atmosphere, carbon cycle and climate, gave a prescient lecture on carbon dioxide, climate and the oceans in 1980 that was recorded by the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and now surfaces via the Web site Climate Science TV.

headline: A Hangout for Locals
text: The Black Whale, a restaurant on City Island in the Bronx, has no water view, but plenty of history to appeal to local residents.

headline: A New Class of Cancer Drugs May Be Less Toxic
text: Fern Saitowitz’s advanced breast cancer was controlled for about a year by the drug Herceptin and a toxic chemotherapy agent. But her hair fell out, her fingernails turned black and she was constantly fatigued.

headline: Judges Should Write Their Own Opinions

headline: Trial Lawyers’ Support of Republican Candidates Yields Less Than Stellar Results
text: Trial-lawyer-backed is a label ready-made for Republicans’ attack ads in tort-reform-happy Texas. But if the 2012 primaries are any guide, the plaintiffs’ bar is becoming less shy about investing in the Republican side of the ballot — and Republican candidates are not being bashful about accepting the money.

headline: Status Quo Between 2 Sudans Is Not Quite War, Not Quite Peace
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — For the first time in months, after killing scores if not hundreds of each other’s men, Sudan and South Sudan are back at the negotiating table, wrangled into peace talks by an increasingly worried international coalition, including the United States and China, that was terrified that the two countries were on the brink of a cataclysmic war.
